column2: The voters of New York State will be called upon today to approve or reject one proposition for a $40,000,000 construction-bond issue and six proposed amendments to the State Constitution.
Word has been received from Port Elizabeth, South Africa, of the death of Reginald W. Poe, a sales manager for the General Motors Corporation. His age was 44.

In furtherance of safety and economy the railroads are about to start "the most complete and exhaustive research ever undertaken" to obtain improvements in the axles of locomotives and freight and passenger cars, according to an announcement by J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

THE TURNING WHEEL, by Stuart Cloete. (Houghton Mifflin, $2.50.) A novel of South Africa and the great Boer trek of 1836. ENGELS ON "CAPITAL." (International Publishers, $2.) Marx's work as seen by his collaborator.

Trading in apartment buildings in the southern part of the Bronx featured the realty deals reported yesterday. The four-story house at 1,410 Rowland Street, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, has been sold to an investing client of A. Michelson Co. by the Shafecraus Realty Corporation, represented by Morris A. Crausman, attorney.

The Rev. Dr. Melanchthon W. Jacobus 2d, dean emeritus and acting president of the Hartford (Conn.) Theological Seminary, who died last night at the age of 81 in his home at Hartford, was senior member of Princeton University's board of trustees, and high tribute was paid him here tonight by President Harold Willis Dodds.

A new constitution and by-laws, designed, among other aims to prevent the "chaotic condition of the market" which has developed in the last week, is in preparation and will be presented next week to the New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Thomas Barclay of Argenti Co., president, told members at their meeting yesterday at the association's office at 300 Fourth Avenue.

Charles E. Bedaux, the American engineer at whose chateau in France the Duke and Duchess of Windsor were married last June, arrived last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to help complete arrangements for the arrival next week of the Duke and Duchess on a five-week tour of this country.

About 100 football coaches, officials-and reporters gathered yesterday at the Commodore Hotel for the weekly luncheon of the Football Writers Association and heard reports of teams from as far away as the Pacific Coast.
Stocks drifted listlessly at-lower levels, and closed steady and dull; turnover, 1,029,210 shares. United States Government and other bonds firm and mixed in quiet trading; transaction, $5,439,100.

Pickets of the International Longshoremen's Association marched in front of Pier 27, North River, and later before Pier 15, East River, yesterday afternoon in protest against alleged discrimination on the part of the New York Puerto Rico Line against A. F. of L. seamen.

A drop in the value of collateral behind the Alleghany Corporation's bond issues has prevented the former Van Sweringen holding company from dealing in the stock market and acted to impede moves in furtherance of its reorganization, the Guaranty Trust Company disclosed yesterday. The recent declines in the stock market caused this situation.

The historical Old South Forum and the Community Church were termed "propaganda factories" today by Royal K. Hayes of Middleboro, testifying before the legislative commission investigating Nazi, Fascist, Communist and Klan activities. Mr. Hayes said he represented the Yankee Division Veterans Association.

This is a day of local elections, and therefore the current annum is known to politics as an "off-year." Yet local elections have often foretold the trend of national polling. And single communities have often, among-the candidates before them for parochial office, made a choice which events proved to have been more notable than any others in that year.
Metropolitan Museum of Art. Italian Renaissance painting (general tour), 11 A. M.; motion picture, 2:30 P. M.

Vladimir Petrovich Vorobieff, who supervised the embalming of Lenin's body for the red and black mausoleum on Red Square, where it has lain for thirteen years, died yesterday at Kharkov. His age was not announced.
It was plainly apparent at the National Automobile Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday that women are increasingly interested in the selection of the family automobile.

Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin was removed from the United Fruit steamer Quirigua to the Panama Canal Hospital today, suffering from influenza. The hospital authorities state his condition is not serious.

The Dairy Farmers Union massed its forces today in a concerted drive against up-State New York's three larger dealers and reported that the nineteen-county strike against dealers supplying fluid milk to the metropolitan market was "progressing satisfactorily."

" Calcium Night," the quaint climax to the rushing period of junior fraternities at Yale University, was abolished tonight by action of the interfraternity council because of the "increasing riotous conduct" to which it was conducive.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oot. 27: Decreases of $57,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loan and $163,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities;

Biennial election campaigns closed tonight in Connecticut's three largest cities where oncedominant Republicans sought to regain power. Bridgeport, New Haven and Hartford will elect entire municipal tickets tomorrow.
Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that the parade of the GermanAmerican Bund in Yorkville last Saturday was sponsored by his political opponents and that it had the effect of creating racial hatred.
The 102,291 seats in the Municipal Stadium, Philadelphia, were sold out today when the deadline for tickets for the Army-Navy football game on Nov. 27, expired at the Naval Academy.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 48.6 per cent of capacity, the lowest rate scheduled since the week of Dec. 30, 1935, when it was 46.7 per cent, and with that one exception since the week of Sept. 2, 1935, when it was 45.8 per cent.

The upward trend in Canada's export trade was continued in September, but the increase was moderate. A large advance in shipments to the United States was partly offset by a decline in exports to the United Kingdom, while trade with the rest of the world showed a small gain.

The Hannah Penn House Group presented a "Spectacular All-American Pageant of New Creations From Famous American Designers" today in the ballroom of the Ritz Carlton. Luncheon was served during the pageant. Mrs. George G. S. Cavendish was chairman and Mrs. Carrol T. Mitchell, director.

Wilfred Walter, British actor and playwright, entertained members of the Greenwich Woman's Club at its meeting this afternoon in the Masonic Temple auditorium. He presented life studies from an English actor's sketchbook. He gave a portrayal of an Englishman's first visit to New York and the difficulties encountered in finding Times Square.

Trading was fair to slow. Top choice and prime heavy and medium weights steer hinds and ribs were steady; others were sharply lower. Steer cuts were weak to sharply lower. The lamb market was higher. Fresh pork cuts sold unevenly -and other classes were about the same as last Friday.

The Very Rev. Canon H. R. L. Sheppard of St. Paul's Cathedral, who died in his home here yesterday, will be buried in Canterbury Cathedral. His body will lie in his former church of St. Martin's-inthe-Fields until Thursday morning. The funeral. service will be held on Thursday in St. Paul's Cathedral.

Motorists launching gayly into the lovely new parkway recently opened between Seventy-second Street and the George Washington Bridge have been appalled to find that not all traffic problems have been solved.

The United Engineering Trustees joint agency for the four societies of civil, mining and metallurgical, mechanical and electrical engineers announced yesterday the election of D. Robert Yarnall as president of the agency. Mr. Yarnall is chief engineer of the Yarnall-Waring Company of Philadelphia.

The Nassau County campaign closed tonight with leaders of the Republican and Democratic organizations predicting victory. A record offyear registration of 191,406 indicated an exceptionally large total vote in the county's three townships and two cities.

Rear Admiral Harris Lanning today succeeded Rear Admiral Thomas Washington as governor the United States Naval Home here. Admiral Washington retired to private life. Admiral Laning formerly was commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard and of the Third Naval District.

Realizing that time is all too short before the Manhattan football team meets the powerful University of Detroit eleven at Ebbets Field Saturday. Coach Chick Meehan sent the Jaspers through a brisk practice yesterday morning at Innisfail Park.

This year's divisional leaders of the National Football League are the teams with the best defensive records, weekly statistics released yesterday reveal. The New York Giants, on top In the Eastern standings, have held their six opponents to a total of 893 yards and 30 points.
The international stock market indices for Oct. 30, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

A $1,200,000 building program recently undertaken by the White Plains Hospital was endorsed tonight by Dr. Haven Emerson of New York, speaking at the Scarsdale Golf Club at a meeting of the hospital's building fund committee.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday that the dismissal of thirty-eight WPA dentists and dental hygienists for lack of relief status would necessitate the closing of twelve of the ninetytwo clinics through which the WPA and the Department of Health have given dental aid to more than 500,000 children in the last two years.

The ban imposed by the city authorities on Communist meetings in Montreal has been extended to gatherings of the unemployed. An unemployed meeting last night, which was to have been addressed by R. L. Calder, K. C., who said he believed in capitalism, but also in free speech, was prohibited. As a result Mr.

W. Jett Lauck, chairman of the Pennsylvania Anthracite Commission, proposed today a plan for consolidation of all private anthracite properties in Pennsylvania into a single private corporation for unified production and marketing.

The draft of a convention for the suppression of terrorism was opposed as interfering with freedom of speech by the British delegate, Sir John Fisher Williams, when a conference to consider it opened in the League of Nations today.

Prizefighters and church deacons, longshoremen and school teachers will be paired off tomorrow in the most elaborately organized army to safeguard the elections in the history of Hudson County. The county is a major battleground in the gubernatorial election in which United States Senator A. Harry Moore and State Senator Lester H. Clee, a Newark minister, are the chief contestants.

On events in the important Shansi fighting areas the official versions differ widely. The Japanese claim a detachment advancing westward upon Taiyuan, capital of Shansi Province, has captured the important towns of Yangkwan and Hsinhsing, twenty-six miles west of Niangtze Pass, taking seven locomotives, seventythree freight cars and much booty.

The estate of Alvah K. Lawrie, former president of the Aluminum Company of America, who died on Dec. 21 last, was worth $13,999,861 at the time of his death, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday..
The 9,000ton steamer Florida Maru of the Japanese Kawasaki, Kisen Kaisha Line, scheduled to leave for Mollendo the middle of September, is still lying off Callao.

Contrary to general belief, members of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System do not want stock market values to spurt upward too closely after the change in margin requirements which became effective today.
The Voelkischer Beobachter sneers at both candidates on the New York Mayoralty race and brings in President Roosevelt for good measure.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, advised railroad managements tonight to eliminate what he viewed as expensive and unnecessary duplications of service, and not to rely too heavily on rate increases to meet their problems.

Campaign firing ended tonight on the eve of the State election to choose an Assembly of 150 members, 168 delegates to the 1938 Constitutional Convention, and change' or reinstate administrations in virtually every municipality. Eligible voters number 5,921,625.
The Postoffice Department disclosed today that it had exercised its censorship powers on Rockwell Kent's mural "Dellvery of the Mail in the Tropics."

Varsity stars of future years will be on display at Ohio Field this afternoon when New York University and Fordham freshmen clash in their annual battle. Potential All-America material may be hidden away.

Warned not to go near a football field today but to take conditioning walks, the Yale football regulars and reserves who battled Dartmouth to a 9-9 tie Saturday omitted practice. They will report tomorrow prepared to defend against the Brown attack, which was studied by the scrubs, the only Eli squad to drill today.

James Roosevelt, son and secretary to the President, today began actively his new duties as a "clearing house" for his father to dealing with the independent agencies in the administrative arm of the government.

The declining trend in prices for cotton was continued on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday under further Southern offerings. As all deliveries but October eased below the 8-cent basis, liquidation developed and, with buying restricted principally to trade fixations on a scale-down, the market displayed little rallying power.

The New York Stock Exchange and all other security and commodity markets in New York will be closed today because of municipal elections. Banks, likewise, will not open for business. Major commodity and security markets in certain key cities in the United States, however, will be open as usual.

Greene St, 208, 25x100; Irving Trust Co to 208 Grene Street Corp. 123 William St, care of S. Sharpiro; consid, $10,000. 77th St 323 E. 25x102.2; Central Savings Bank to Stralia Realty Corp, 545 5th Ave, care of S. V. Hirsch ($17). La Salle St, 20. 25x101; same to Emma L. Zinkand, 259 W 12th St (23). 24th St, 121-23 E. 50x98.9; J. Kenneth O'Grady to Central Hanover Bank; consid, $125,000, foreclosure.

Bobby Pacho, 148 1/4, California, gained an eight-round decision over Phil Furr, 149, Washington. D. C., veteran, in the feature bout before 2,500 at the St. Nicholas Palace last night. Pacho piled up a lead on points in the early rounds, which offset Furr's closing spurt.

A complete synchronization of public and private social work is essential for the development of efficient welfare service, Mrs. Peter L. Harvie of Troy, N. Y., president of the Assoclation of the Junior Leagues of America, declared in an address at the opening dinner of the League's Welfare Conference here this evening.

Henry H. Rogers Jr., who received only the income of a $500,000 trust fund in his father's will, was sued yesterday in the Supreme Court by executors of the will to collect three promissory notes of $5,000 each that he gave his father, Colonel H. H. Rogers, in 1934.

Printer's ink has been responsible for changing the opinion of the people of the United States toward railroads, officials Of lines operate. ing in six Southwestern States were told today at a conference here. The session was the last of eleven such meetings, held from.Boston to San Francisco, which were called by officials of the American Railroad Association.

Mayor La Guardia, according to his custom for nearly twenty years, closed his campaign for re-election last night with a speech at his "lucky corner," 116th Street and Lexington Avenue, in the heart of the Eighteenth Congressional District, which he formerly represented.

President Roosevelt devoted most of today to a conversation with his fiscal advisers, but out of these conferences there emerged nothing but speculation, heightened by an acknowledgment that the economic situation and the question of revision of the capital gains and the corporate surplus taxes haad been discussed.

Continued preference for blues over other colors, a wider use of fabrics, especially gabardines, and a tendency to hold prices down deIpite improvements in quality marked the Spring showing of the Shoe Fashion Guild of America, Inc., which opened yesterday at the Biltmore -Hotel, and concurrent showings by manufacturers of medium and popular-priced shoes at the New Yorker Hotel and the Hotel McAlpin.

By midnight tonight all New York will be celebrating the triumph of Americanism over communism, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, declared in a series of addresses last night in Queens, where he wound up his campaign.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Oct. 30, unless specified: At San Pedro: Astoria, Chester, Chicago, Louisville, Minneapolis, Quincy, San Fran. cisco, Saratoga, Teal, Tuscaloosa. At Gibraltar: Kane, Oct. 31; Raleigh, Nov. 1: Fickerel, Hatfield, Nov. 1, and Claxton.

Sister M. Gertrude Balda died suddenly last night at the Sacred Heart Convent here following a heart attack. Her age was 74. She was born in Ecuador and entered the Benedictine Order there in 1890, an expert at fine needle work.

Treasures of Armageddon are on private display at the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago. They are relics which the institute's Megiddon expedition, headed by Dr. Gordon Loud, unearthed in a subterranean treasury last March.

The speech of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons today, created the most painful impression here where it is considered a perfect example of the complete lack of understanding with Italy's and Germany's problems as viewed in London.
A decline in duty collections at the focal port last month is linked by importers with the general uncertainty regarding Christmas business now prevalent among import houses.

Professor Waldemar Jochelson, anthropologist, ethnologist and a scientific writer associated with the Carnegie Institute, died last night after a week's illness in Sydenham Hospital. He was 82 years old.
Buoyed by the victory over Navy, the Pennsylvania varsity squad started work today for the annual game here on Saturday with Penn State, a traditional rivalry that goes back to 1890.

Three candidates are sure of election today as justices of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, comprising the counties of New York and the Bronx. These are Edward J. Glennon, Salvatore A. Cotillo and Charles Poletti. Two others, Nathan D. Perlman and Thomas F. Noonan, should be elected and probably will be.

Two thrill-seekers died in the crash of a stunting airplane here today. A third, a woman, was seriously injured. The flight, outcome of a chance beer garden meeting between the two men victims and the woman, ended in a plunge from about 1,000 feet.

Clarence (Chief) Boston, Harvard's star blocking back and signalcaller, who took plenty of hard bumps in the Princeton game, and all the other Princeton game starters, with the exception of Cliff Wilson, center rush, were excused from practice today.

Highly pleased with his team's showing against Providence, Coach Benny Friedman started preparing yesterday for City College's final home game of the season, the contest with St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia, at Lewisohn Stadium next Saturday.

George White reported at Columbia today to initiate the musical that will replace Oscar Hammerstein 2d's "Paris on Broadway" which has been abandoned because of casting troubles and other difficulties.
Benny Frey, pitcher for the Cincinnati Reds, from whom he had sought voluntary retirement after being ordered into the minor leagues, was found dead today.
Richard W. Barrett, San Francisco attorney, Republican leader and a friend of former President Herbert Hoover, died here today of influenza.

A card party and tea in aid of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be held the afternoon of Nov. 23 at the home of Mrs. John D. Ryan, 3 East Seventy-eighth Street. Mrs. Ryan heads the sewing committee which provides all the clothing worn by the children while at the shelter.
Ken Smith of Oceanside and Al Brosch, Bethpage professional, turned in a brilliant 30, 34--64, seven under par, to win the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro best-ball golf tournament today.

Health Department inspectors have impounded 15,000 pounds of corned beef and tongue in a dozen wholesale provision establishments in Manhattan and the Bronx, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The Coca-Cola Company reports a balance available for the common stock of $8,041,700 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30. This is after charges, Federal Income taxes and dividend requirements on the Class A stock, and is equivalent to $2.01 a share on 3,991,900 no-par shares of common stock. No provision.

Deaths from automobile accidents showed a decrease over the weekend, according to the report of the safety bureau of the Police Department, issued yesterday, but there was one more death in the week ended Oct. 31 than in the corresponding week last year.

High Fleet, only filly in the race, was first by half a length in the $3,400 Baltimore Autumn Handicap, the most important of eight races which attracted 10,000 persons to the opening of the Fall meeting at Pimlico today.

Since the beginning of 'the depression the theory has been put forward in some quarters--and, in effect, acted upon in our own budget--that it is not merely allowable but even desirable that budgetary deficits should exist in poor years. Echoes of this doctrine have recently been heard again.

Plans were virtually completed tonight for transferring Frederick B. Snite Jr., infantile paralysis victim, into a lighter respirator. If all goes well at a test, possibly tomorrow, young Snite will be placed in the new device for periods lengthening daily, to accustom him to the change.

Harry Braithwaite, goal tender for the Toronto Rangers last Winter, will play this season for the New York Rovers in the Eastern Amateur League, Lester Patrick, manager of the New York Rangers, announced today.

Action for debt adjustment whereby creditors would share with debtors losses from crop failures and abnormally low prices is proposed in a new Saskatchewan Conservative platform announced tonight by J. G. Diefenbaker, Provincial party leader.
The garment company of Nell Donnelly Reed, who attracted wide notice as the victim of a kidnapping in 1931, opened a Federal court battle today against the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

Opening of the cooperative stores in Greenbelt, Md., the Federal Resettlement Administration project, will take place about Nov. 15, according to announcement yesterday by Herbert E. Evans, vice president of the Consumer Distribution Corporation, which will operate the stores.

Four of New York City's undefeated and untied schoolboy football teams will risk their records in today's program of eight contests on local gridirons. The day will be a busy one, as twenty-six games are scheduled on four fronts in the metropolitan area.

Turpentine firm, 26 3/4@@27c: sales 63 barrels: receipts 263 barrels; shipments 656 barrels; stock' 39,510 barrels. Resin firm; sales 465; receipts 984; shipments 6,051; stock 82,426. Quote: 3, D. E, $6.50: F, G, $6.80; H, I, K, $6.80-$6.82-; M. $6.82,-S6.85; N, $7.00; WG, $7.25-$7.30; WW, X $7.50.

If every one of the more than 2,000,000 New Yorkers who are expected to vote today were to spend three days in a hospital the total of more than 6,000,000 days of hospital care would approximate the amount of hospital service provided by New York's voluntary hospitals in a year, John W. Davis, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign, said last night.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was called "merely a stool pigeon" for John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department of the A. F. of L., in an editorial appearing in the current issue of The United Mine Workers Journal, official organ of the union of which John L. Lewis is the head.
Don Schumacher of Dallas, Texas, and Johnny Goodman, defending champion from Omaha, Neb., won their way into the final of the Mexican National Amateur Golf champion'ship today.

The list of the Holland-America liner Volendam, due today from the Channel ports, includes Captain Baron I. L. D. Sirtema van Grovestins of the Blue Hussars, coming from Holland for the National Horse Show;
A Maritime Commission spokesman said today that President Roosevelt was "greatly interested" in proposed changes in the merchant-marine routes designed to improve service to Latin America.

Stirred by reports in New York newspapers on Saturday, including THE NEW YORK TIMES, Lord Rothermere ordered a notice posted in his hotel today to the effect that he wishes other guests to know that there is no word of truth in the statement that the dance orchestra was moved indoors at his request.
Cornell today announced the appointment of Associate Dean S. C. Hollister to be dean of the College of Engineering, succeeding Dean Herman Diederichs who died last Summer.

Plans for a luncheon and fashion show to be given on Nov. 30 at the St. Regis for the benefit of the Give and Take Shop, 1,272 Third Avenue, will be drawn up today at a meeting of the beneficiary's entertainment committee at the home of Mrs. Charles E. Adams, 4 East Seventy-second Street.

Contending that tax officials of the town of Harrison have overassessed many parcels of real estate by more than 30 per cent and have not followed State tax-exemption laws, twenty-four property owners filed certiorari suits in Supreme Court here today.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Perry Beadleston entertained with a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria for Colonel and Mrs. Latham Gallup Reed, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Hoving, Mr. and Mrs. Russell Gilbert, Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ladd, Mrs. Cooper Wicks Stewart and Leverison Gower of London.

A continuing decline in the birth rate in New York City was reported yesterday by the Department of Health. For the week ended Saturday the birth rate was 12.2 per 1,000 inhabitants, according to Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Arnold Valentine, 15 years old, of Howard Street, here, was held by Nassau County police tonight on a charge of fatally stabbing Russell Hawkins, 14, of First Street, following an argument at Broadway and Nicholai Street.

Lieut. Col. Bowyer B. Browne, Corps of Engineers, will proceed on or about Nov. 16 from Governors Island, N. Y., to Wilmington, Del., and Trenton. N. J., in turn, for temporary duty in connection with Organized Reserves activities, and upon completion of this temporary duty he will return to his proper station.

While the Dartmouth varsity football team merely ran through signals today, the players who did not see much service in the Yale game defeated the freshmen, 27-0, in a scrimmage as practice for the Princeton game began.
Unless the process is postponed for 'considerations of public order, the leader of the Algerian Nationalist party, a certain Messali, will be brought to trial tomorrow in Algiers.

The Dun-Bradstreet index number of wholesale commodity prices as of Nov. 1 shows average decline of 5N, per cent during October. The Nov. 1 index number is the lowest reached by the Dun average since Oct. 1, 1936.

Miss Claire Hasbrouck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. F. Hasbrouck of Jersey City, has completed plans for her marriage to Harrison Waterbury Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Waterbury of Cos Cob. The wedding will take place Nov. 13 in St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church at Riverside, this town. The Rev. Joseph J. Ganley, the rector, will officiate.

The State Civil Service Commission refused today to approve the payroll of the Ocean County Board of Freeholders for the latter half of October and notified County Treasurer Theodore B. Cranmer that he must not pay the workers.

Harold W. Hastings, Tammany candidate for District Attorney, made his closing speech of the campaign early last night over the radio. He charged that in none of his speeches during the campaign did his opponent, Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor in the rackets investigation, give "a real argument as to why he would make a better prosecutor than I."

For citizens of this metropolis who desire a continuation, development and perpetuation of good government there are four principal objectives to be attained by today's voting: 1. The re-election of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.

In a ceremony marking the completion of the first contract unit for the new $18,000,000 Bronx-Whitestone suspension bridge, Mayor La Guardia laid yesterday the cornerstone of the foundation of the Bronx anchorage of the bridge.

The Right Rev. Patrick M. O'Brien, former pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Maplewood, was installed here today as abbot of St. Mary's Benedictine Abbey at a ceremony attended by Bishop Thomas J. Walsh of the Newark diocese.

Patrolman Joseph R. Charlton of the Newton police bagged probably the best deer taken in this city since Colonial times today and thereby broke the law, but saved the Brae Burn Country Club a bit of money.

Our congratulations go to Professor Arthur Lehman Goodhart who has been elected to the chairmanship of the Law Faculty of Oxford University. This is said to be the first time that an American or any foreigner has been given this distinction.

Mrs. Louis Guerineau Myers gave a luncheon yesterday in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for members of the Penland Board of the Church of the Ascension. Afterward a meeting was held at which final plans were made for the bridge and tea to be given next Tuesday in the Viennese Roof of the hotel for the benefit of the board's Appalachian School at Penland, N. C.

Plans for picketing Fisher Body plant No. 1, employing 7,300 persons, tomorrow were announced by local leaders of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O. affiliate, today, as an effort to determine that all workers wear union buttons.

An exhibition setting forth "twenty years in the evolution of Picasso" opened yesterday at the Seligmann, 3 East Fifty-first Street, to be current until Nov. 20. Two Picasso exhibitions were to have opened simultaneously, the other one at the Valentine:

New York University's freshman football team will meet the Fordham University cubs this afternoon at Ohio Field. The game is scheduled to begin at 2 o'clock. The Violet outfit has been defeated twice in two starts this season, losing to the Lafayette yearlings, 6--0, and to the Army plebes, 7--0.

Dr. Harry Adler, for ten years president of Sinai Hospital here and later clinical Professor of Medicine and Therapeutics at the University of Maryland Medical School, died at his home here today. His age was 65.

The plea for cooperation between the United States and Great Britain in the Far Eastern crisis made by Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, in the House of Commons today was welcomed here as apparently furnishing a promising background .'or the Brussels nine-power conference, which is to convene on Wednesday.

The Federal Theatre Project will give in four of the five boroughs tonight full-length entertainments. "No More Peace" will be offered at the Hunt's Point Palace, the Bronx; "The Singing and the Gold," at the Community Gardens, Queens; "Patience,"

Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here made a poor response today to the strength in Liverpool and while there was an advance of around i cent a bushel in the early trading there was no snap to the buying and it took but little selling to start a decline.

A generation ago the late Dr. William T. Hornaday warned sportsmen that within a few years they would do more hunting and less "shooting" unless they recognized and acted upon the conservation of wild life.
Renewed heavy rains in Syria last night added to the already heavy toll of lives and property. The Jebel Druze and Latakia districts are particularly affected.

A brighter picture of the mortgage situation with respect to repayment of advances made by the Rome Owners Loan Corporation to formerly distressed owners of dwellings may now be painted from the national and local records of this $3,000,000,000 emergency enterprise.
The InterAmerican Radio Conference opened here this morning in the salon of the House of Representatives with delegates in attendance from fifteen countries.
A large and fashionable crowd will Father at Belmont Park today to see the curtain come down on the metropolitan turf season at the annual Autumn meeting of the United Hunt Racing Association.

New Jersey's American-born golf professionals scored their third straight victory in the annual matches for the Edward J. Gaffney bucket today when they defeated a picked group of British-born pros, 10 to 3, at the Crestmont Golf Club.

Extraordinary police precautions against fraudulent voting in Boston, Everett and Cambridge and the possibility that Westfield will have this State's first woman Mayor featured the eve of elections in sixteen Massachusetts cities.
The report of the American Light and Traction Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges, of $5,846,684.

A pamphlet implying that Mayor La Guardia was a Communist and urging the election of his opponent, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, as a "Godfearing man," was repudiated yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, secretary for charities to Cardinal Hayes.

Robert Craig Sutherland, a statistician, died in a private sanatorium here yesterday at the age of 30. Born in Lima, Ohio, he was graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1930. During his cadet days he was a member of the fencing team and also played football and polo.

With Ford volume operations delayed, automobile production eased last week, when the seasonal rise should have continued. The adjusted index slumped to 115.9 from 139.6 in the previous week. For the week ended Oct. 31, 1936, the index was 78.5.
Chauncey H. Young, president of the Long Island Produce and Fertilizer Company, Inc., of Riverhead, died today of a heart attack at his home here at the age of 60.

With speculative interest reduced to a minimum because of the election day holiday in security Exchanges today, trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange dwindled to the smallest full day's session in about two months.

Robert Calthrop Brown, electrical engineer, died in his home here Saturday night at the age of 72. Born in Medford, Mass., Mr. Brown was president of the Canadian Shipping Agency and vice president of the Canadian and General Finance Company, the Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, the Rio de Janeiro Tramway, Light and Power Company, the Sao Paulo Tramway, Light and Power Company, Ltd.;

Ralph Franklin Cummings of Saundersville, this town, who is 38 and calls himself "Reckless Ralph," has a collection of old "dime novels" totaling more than 8,000 and is constantly adding to this library, which is believed to be the largest in the country.
King George II of Greece today visited Premier Benito Mussolini at the Palazzo Venezia after receiving Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Foreign Minister, at his hotel.
Officials of the city of Akron, Ohio, have invited bankers to submit bids on Nov. 22 for a new issue of $898,000 of bonds. Other details of the financing are to be announced at a later date.

Frank L. Devine, director of the convention and tourist bureau of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce, who was instrumental in bringing 950 conventions to the city in the last five years, died in Misericordia Hospital today following a stomach operation. His age was 52.

The marriage of Miss Trina Calhoun Marshall, daughter of Mrs. Levin Rothrock Marshall of 49 East Eighty-second Street and Glen Head, L. I., to Nathaniel Read Norton Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Read Norton of 111 East Seventy-eighth Street, took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy-first Street.

Walter Lippmann, newspaper columnist and author, entered a legal appearance today through his attorney in the divorce suit filed by his wife, Mrs. Fay Lippmann. The Lippmanns have a Winter home at Anna Maria, a gulf coast resort near here. Neither is at the Winter home now.

Ninety of the prized pieces of printing done during the year by forty-one New York printing concerns yesterday were selected by a committee of judges as the best examples of the art in the exhibition of the New York Employing Printers Association at the Hotel Astor.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today Raymond J. McElhannon of New York was admitted to practice and the following proceedings were had:

Mrs. John D. Beals, president of the Junior League Glee Club, gave a luncheon yesterday at the league clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, for Miss Eva La Pierre of th, City Hospitals Visiting Committee, at which plans were discussed for the club's Christmas entertainment in the city hospitals.

Japanese planes dropped eight bombs near the Chinese section of the CantonKowloon Railway in a brief raid this afternoon, but the line was not damaged, although a through train was held up when the raiders appeared.

The Majestic Apartments on Central Park West are 91 per cent rented and the net profit for the year ended Sept. 30, before interest and depreciation, was $177,538, according to an operating report by Amott, Baker Co. Profit was at the rate of 1.78 per cent on $9,998,333 of outstanding 4 per cent income bonds, against 1.61 per cent for the previous year.

BABCOCK-Suddenly, Maud, beloved wife of John R. Babcock, at 25 East 86th St., New York City, Sunday, Oct. 31, 1937. Services private, Runyon Funeral Home, Plainfield, N. J., Tuesday, Nov. 2, 1937, 2:30 P. M. Interment Plainfield, N. J. Please omit flowers.

Funeral services for Dr. William Metcalfe Stone, who died Friday night, were held yesterday afternoon at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in Flushing. Dr. Stone had been a practicing physician in Flushing since 1900 and since 1916 had been chief of the medical staff of Flushing Hospital.

The number of business failures in the United States in the week ended Oct. 28 was 178, compared with 149 in the corresponding week last year, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The greatest of our military leaders have long insisted that war is not an exact science, but a deadly art--a canvas of chaos, in which the lightning brush strokes of a master may shape some awful sanity out of confusion.

A seven-month deadlock, at times marked by strike threats, over a wage scale for mine-workers in the Indiana field was at an end today. Committees representing Indiana miners and operators accepted yesterday a $5.65 basic daily wage scale.

A compilation yesterday of the results obtained in the four auction sales of properties owned by several closed Queens and Nassau County national banks, the last of which was held on Saturday, revealed that sixty-nine properties were sold.

The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today some new statistics on the cost of underwriting security issues based on registration statements filed under the Securities Act of 1933 for the five quarterly periods from July 1, 19S6, to Sept. 30, 1937.
Commissioner Valentine announced last night that applications for 2,075 warrants had been made as the result of the police investigation of illegal registration in the city.

Prison authorities permitted 200 "old-time" Sing Sing convicts to leave the prison today and file past the bier of Mrs. Kathryn Lawes, wife of Warden Lewis E. Lawes, who died after a fall last Saturday.

Denying any Japanese territorial or material claims as a result of the present SinoJapanese conflict, Shingoro Takaishi, editor of the Osaka Mainichi and the Tokyo Nichi-Nichi, blames China for her aggressiveness and anti-Japanese attitude.

More than 200,000 votes will be cast in tomorrow's election in Westchester County, it was predicted today by William Cronin, chairman of the county Democratic committee, and Charles H. Griffiths, head of the county Republican organization. Registrations have reached 238,000, an off-year record.
They are inaugurating George M. Cohan President of the United States (well, Fifty-second Street) tonight, the ceremonies taking place under the title "I'd Rather Be Right" at the Alvin Theatre.

Any one picking up the threads of the football season only yesterday and watching Columbia's practice on Baker Field would have been led to believe that the Lions were taking the coming game with Navy in lighthearted fashion, for none of the regulars was on the field.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. McEnery of 333 East Sixty-eighth Street and Amagansett, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Gillies McEnery, to Hugh Frederick Gage, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry L. Gage of Upper Montclair, N. J., and Amagansett.

Four years of offers from movieland have broken down the resistance of Jose Itufbi, nationally known orchestra conductor and pianist, who declared here today he had agreed to do a movie short when an acceptable script was found.

It is expected that members of the uniformed force will have voted before reporting for duty on Tuesday, Nov. 2. Where it is shown that they were unable to do so by reasons beyond their control a reasonable time will be granted to them upon request to their superior officers, who will rerange to excuse one man at a time, in order that they may have an opportunity to vote.

The New York State Parole Board declared yesterday that an incorrect statement of fact was made by Lawrence Marks last Friday in Kings County Court during his trial for the first-degree murder of Paula Magagna, when he said that he had been released from Great Meadows Prison on parole on June 16.
Majorca today is run strictly on a war schedule because the island is being used as a base for all Insurgent air raids against Catalonia and the rest of government-held territory in Spain.
The gunmetal watch with which Pierre Curie timed the first radium experiment will be one of the exhibits at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, opening on Friday.

Four persons are reported dead and fifteen seriously wounded as a result of a clash between Croat peasants and gendarmes in the village of Novi Gradic on the occasion of a Peasant party meeting today at which a Croat Deputy named Meserov spoke.

Loans to farmers to enable them to hold their corn, which Treasury experts have been trying to finance "within the budget," will be provided by the Commodity Credit Corporation with funds to be supplied by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, President Roosevelt announced in a telegram to Jesse H. Jones, Chairman of the RFC.

The 3,884 Parkway Garage Corp, Samuel Cooper, president, gave a purchase money mortgage to St. Luke's Hospital for $32,000, due 5 years hence at 4 per cent, when It bought 157-159 W 18th St for $40,000.

Raymond Moley, one-time leading member of the Roosevelt brain trust, announced yesterday that he would vote for Bruce Barton, Republican nominee for Representstive in the Seventeenth Congressional District, breaking a Moley family rule of voting Democratic since 1852.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its .monthly review, issued yesterday, calls attention to the fact that the monetary gold stocks of the United States increased last month by less than the amount of the month's gold imports and releases of earmarked gold.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey wound up his campaign for the office of District Attorney last night with a radio speech, and awaited the outcome of today's election with the assurance of his supporters that he would oust Tammany Hall from control of New York County's prosecuting office by a large majority.

Miss Yvonne Georgette MacDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gordon MacDonald of Riverdaleon-Hudson, was married to the Rev. William Frederick Doscher, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Doscher of Glendale, Queens, yesterday afternoon in St. James Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler of this city.

Controller Frank J. Taylor predicted yesterday that city tax collections this year would reach the highest total attained in many years, as he disclosed that payments for the second half of 1937 were now $3,185,559.50 above those for the comparable period last year.
Groucho Marx and Chico. Marx, the comedians, were fined $1,000 each in Federal court today on their conviction of infringing a copyright. Their attorney gave oral notice of appeal.

The Christmas campaign for -the social service work of the New York City Cancer Institute will begin with a dinner dance on Nov. 10 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, which that night will be formally opened for the Winter season.
The United States golf pros' invasion of this country reached its high point today when Henry Picard won the Argentine open championship with a record-equaling seventy-two-hole score of 288.

Coach Jack Blott gave the Wesleyan regulars a rest today after the hard contest with Trinity Saturday. Holzer, fullback, injured his shoulder in the game, and Mues. who took his place, received an arm injury.

Ewald Peterson did not lose his temper when a telephone operator gave him the wrong number once or twice, but when he got twentytwo wrong numbers in succession at a cost of 5 cents each things began to happen.

Parental disapproval tonight threatened to break up the marriage plans of Bob Gregory, who claims the European middleweight title in catchas-catch-can wrestling, and "Princess Baba," 21-year-old daughter of Sir Charles Vyner de Windt Brooke, famous "white rajah" of Sarawak.

In the United States Court of Claims the following proceedings were had today: K-539--United States Ordnance Co. Petition dismissed; judgment in favor of the United States. Opinion by Judge Green. M-110-Moses Scheuer and Nathan Scheuer, surviving partners. Petition dismissed. Judgment in favor of the United States. Opinion by Judge Williams, Judge Littleton dissenting.

Vast hotels like those in the United States "wouldn't do" in Scotland, Captain Alastair D. Cameron, head of a group of ten Scottish hotel men visiting this city, said yesterday in an interview at the Hotel McAlpin.

The National Labor Relations Board today directed Leo L. Lowy, individually, doing business as the Tapered Roller Bearing Corporation, Brooklyn, to offer to reinstate within ten days twenty-eight employes found by the board to have been locked out on April 23 for union activities.

A "National Brands Promotion" in which super-markets all over the country will participate is being planned for the period from Feb. 24 to March 5, M. M. Zimmerman, secretary of the SuperMarket Institute, announced yesterday.
The reorganization managers of the Lawyers Mortgage Company announced yesterday that there have been sent out requests for assents to the proposed plan

CERTAIN types of people won't like "The Turning Wheels," Stuart Cloete's novel of South Africa and the Boers.* Deadly-in-earnest readers who never bother with anything romantic won't like it, nor will the delicate ones who shrink from plain-speaking in any form. As for the rest, they ought to run it through a long series of printings before the Winter is over, and I hope they do. It is a big story, ably told.
Robert F. Bigley, a graduate of New York University, was named boxing coach at Dartmouth College today, and will also have duties as coach of freshman and recreational soccer.

Miss Katherine Logan Brown, daughter of Mrs. Hay Brown of Springfield, Ill., and the late Mr. Brown, was married to Harvey Rowland Clapp Jr. of Baltimore, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Rowland Clapp, this afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church at Springfield.

The Federal Trade Commission ordered a large part of the window-glass industry today to abandon a price system alleged to be monopolistic. Aimed at both manufacturers and wholesalers of window glass the order prohibits them from combining to fix prices, classify buyers for illegal purposes, or exchange information for the purpose of evading the order.
Indictions are that the current recession in business and industrial activity "will run well into 1938," the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.

Gertrude L. Frank, Nat Cohen, in Essex House, 160 Central Park South, and renewale in same building with Louis Katz, William B. Randolph and John Kaplan. William Norms, in 375 Park Ave, through Albert M. Greenfield Co.

John M. Bradshaw, Dallas, Texas, commission buyer of gasoline, identified the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Sinclair Refining Company in Federal court here today as two of the concerns that bought gasoline from small East Texas refiners in 1935 and 1936.
The Friends of the Near East will hold their annual meeting tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Ray P. Stevens, 834 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. John H. Finley, the president, will preside.

PATROLMEN--Michael Knoblauch, 109th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Floyd A. Porter, Traffic Precinct C. at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 28, 1912. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-Daniel D. Scannell, 74th Precinct, assigned to tours 8 A. M. to 4 P. M. and 4 P. M. to 12 midnight, for 30 days.

Despite their conflicting predictions of large majorities in the voting tomorrow, United States Senator A. Harry Moore and State Senator Lester H. Clee, chief candidates for Governor, continued their quests for votes today by addressing meetings in various parts of Northern New Jersey and speaking over the radio.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday ordered a "thorough investigation" to determine why no report was made- of the accidental shooting of Robert H. Brennen, Republican-Fusion candidate for the Assembly, while he was being questioned by detectives early Sunday morning in the Kingsbridge police station, the Bronx.
Opponents of the plan for a Republican party conference next year are reperted prepared to urge the national committee, at its meeting in Chicago Friday, to defer action until January.

Gari Shelton, who is a recurrent entrant in New York's annual recital lists, played a program of music for the piano at the Town Hall last night. The results were, as they say in financial circles, mixed.

The so-called "battle of the blends" will be launched here tomorrow when 1,000-line copy for Schenley's new Red and Black label starts in newspapers. On Tuesday or Wednesday of next week, National Distillers will break forth with double-page spreads in newspapers for its new Eagle blend, to be followed by full Daaes.
New York University's football squad held a strenuous three-hour workout at Ohio Field yesterday in preparation for the game with Lehigh on Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

Dr. A. J. Cronin, author of "The Citadel," has cabled his publishers, Little, Brown, that he will sail from England on Nov. 10 for a visit to this country. Dr. Cronin is scheduled to speak at THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Fair.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 29: CAPTAINS Bowdey, G. H., the Pensacola, to the staff of the Naval War College, Newport, R. I. Grady, R. C., to additional duty as Commander of Submarine Division 14. Speicher, P. E., when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., to headquarters, Third Naval District.

Chin Jack Lem, 61 years old, one of the wealthiest citizens of Chicago's Chinatown and described as its most feared of the powerful men behind the scenes, was shot and killed tonight as he was walking in the rain in the heart of Chinatown.

Rankings for the 1937-38 season were released by the Amateur Fencers League of America yesterday, with Joseph L. Levis the leader in the foils division, Lieutenant Thomas J. Sands of the United States Army first in the ipee group and John R. Huffman topping the saber list.

Dr. Sigmund Pollitzer, former president of the American Dermatological Association and for many years a leading practitioner, died at his home, 1 West 85th Street, early yesterday after a long illness. His age was 78.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has sold the well-known Paul Laurence Dunbar Apartments, occupying the Harlem block bounded by Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Macombs Place, 149th and 150th Streets, to the 320 East Seventy-third Street Corporation, which is headed by E. Cranford Stuckless. The indicated consideration was $1,000,000.

Ave A, 216; to 4-story tenement and stores; East River Savings Bank, 26 Cortlandt st, owner; H. B. Mullken, architect; cost, $3,500. Brookiyn Marine Ave, 100-10 s w cor Ridge Blvd; 41-family brick apartment house, 6-story, 85x84.4 and 90; Marven building Corp. 4.915 17th Ave, owner; kavy Kavovitt, architect; cost, $146.000.
For the third successive week, land without anything approaching serious debate, California's all-conquering Golden Bears occupy the national football peak.

By adding 28 points to his previous total over the week-end, Bill Tranavitch, sophomore halfback of Rutgers's football machine, gained the lead in the nation's individual scoring parade, according to The Associated Press.
Anna Marie Hahn entered blanket denials today of State charges that she fatally poisoned four old men for their meager fortunes, and said of one of them: "He was more like a father to me."

More than 300 guests attended the annual benefit "Hobgoblin in Fancy Dress Ball" tonight at Kate's Mountain Lodge. Proceeds are for the Boy Scout room addition to the local community house. Prizes were awarded for the most outstanding costumes.

The elimination of the wall between the so-called ivy colleges and the non-ivy group was foreseen yesterday by Asa S. Bushnell of Princeton, who will take office on Jan. 1 as executive director of a vast Eastern intercollegiate athletic group that will embrace more than fifty colleges in some half dozen sports.

William Smith, 16-year-old Jamesburg Reformatory parolee, is being held by the police here on a charge of atrocious assault and battery with intent to kill as a result of a shooting affray today in the home of Mrs. Catherine Bammann of 9 Cedarbrook Road, where he boarded.
Shortening of the period of labor in childbirth through use of a drug, pentothal sodium, is reported by three Montreal doctors in a paper published in The Canadian Medical Association Journal.

The seventh annual exhibition of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild opened here tonight, at the County Center with a reception attended by 300 members and friends. On display were 232 art objects, including oil paintings, drawings, etchings, lithographs and sculpture.

The loss of a bet that he could cycle to Princeton, N. J., for Saturday's Harvard-Princeton football game was registered today against Eugene S. Buder, '38, of St. Louis, one of the editors of The Harvard Crimson.

Bullets killed one man and wounded about thirty others today as an army of hunters estimated at more than 300,000 opened Pennsylvania's small-game season. George Arferdy, 43 years old, of Curwensville, was killed by an accidental discharge of his gun.
As one of the immortals Alfred Lunt is mercifully mortal. As a fabulously faithful wife of the classical age Lynn Fontatine is deceptively modern.

Movement of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follows: HOGS Receipts 16,000 including 4,000 direct. The market was fully 10e higher than Friday's average; top, $9.60; bulk good and choice, 150-180 pounds, $9.15-$9.50;

Richard W. Uhlig, holder of more than 500 patents, chiefly for typewriter inventions, died yesterday at his residence, 10 Renner Avenue, at the age of 77. In 1925 he retired as vice president of the Allen Typewriter Company of Allentown, Pa.
Oberlin M. Carter, former captain of Army Engineers, appealed to the Supreme Court today to void a court martial verdict under which he was dismissed from the army in 1898.

Twenty-four years ago physicians attending Miss Jean Annett for injuries she received in a train collision did not expect her to live another year. Her spine had been crushed and she was paralyzed from the waist down.

Adele Carpless Ulman, one-time secretary to Helen Hayes, actress, received a divorce today from William A. Ulman, magazine writer. She came here from New York to contest a suit brought by her husband.

WPA supervisors may be released from duty long enough to permit them to vote, but for no other purpose, in tomorrow's elections. They are specifically forbidden, on pain of discharge, to attempt to influence the votes of other WPA workers.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: General O'Ryan's letter. in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. ll with its advocacy of the need for establishing a world.police force is very welcome.

Joseph Curran, general organizer for the National Maritime Union of America, has denied that he recently stated that the union was going to "get the scalp" of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission.
The first half of the 1937 football season took a toll of fourteen lives, about 25 per cent less than in the same period last year. Dr. Floyd R. Eastwood reported to The Associated Press today.

Optimism over the outcome of arbitration of the boundary dispute between Nicaragua and Honduras was expressed today by Dr. Frank B. Corrigan, United States representative at the arbitration conference at San Jose, Costa Rica, before he boarded a plane here today for the Costa Rican capital, where he expects to arrive tomorrow noon.

Four hundred dollars and a prize collie pup were the trophies carried off yesterday from Lord Taylor's by Ruth Vernam of Hackensack, N. J., a 16-year-old high school junior. first-prize winner in the contest to determine the most tasteful and sensible wardrobe that can be purchased for a maximum of $250.

George Bersch has been appointed merchandise administrator for L. Bamberger Co., succeeding Harry W. Newburger, executive vice president and director, who has resigned. Mr. Newburger has not announced his future plans. Mr. Bersch was formerly merchandise counsellor.

Tomorrow's election, which is expected to bring out a record total of voters for a municipal contest here, probably will give the C. I. O.'s powerful United Automobile Workers representation on the Common Council, but not even the most optimistic union partisan nor the most frightened conservative expects to see labor win control of the: city government.

Mrs. Alice Hinckley of 54 Lafayette Place, Greenwich, was serlously injured in an automobile accident at Newton, Mass., this afternoon, when a car struck the machine in which Mrs. Hinckley was riding.
Marketing quotas proposed for cotton, wheat and rice failed today to win a place in the House Agriculture Committee's rough draft of new general farm legislation.

The forward movement of the Hungarian Nazis and the Henleinists' [camouflaged Czechoslovak Nazis] recent demonstration at Teplitz-Schoenau in the form of a scuffle between Deputies and police that was designed to influence communal elections, coincide with a revival of aggressiveness on the part of the Austrian Nazis.

JUNIOR MEDICAL OFFICER (ROTATING INTERNESHIP), $2,000 a Year. JUNIOR MEDICAL OFFICER (PSYCHIATRIC RESIDENT), $2,000. St. Elizabeths Hospital, Department of the Interior, Washington, D. C. Applications must be on file not later than Nov. 29 if received from States other than those named below: Dec. 2, 1937, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.

Referring to an action filed in the Federal court on Saturday requesting reorganization of the Third Avenue Railway Company under the National Bankruptcy Act, Alfred T. Davidson, counsel for the company, said yesterday that after examining the petition he believed there was no basis for maintaining the suit.

Frederick Gore King, member of an old American family distinguished in the history of New York for more than a century, died yesterday at his residence, 61 East Eighty-sixth Street, at the age of 85. He was a great-grandson of Rufus King, one of the first two United States Senators from New York and twice Minister to England.

The three-story business building at 26 East First Street, Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has been purchased by the Eastchester Savings Bank of Mount Vernon. Purchase of the property, which is assessed at $37,500, was for cash.

France's new great flying boat, the Lieutenant de Vaisseau Paris, landed today at Dakar, Senegal, French West African colony, after a flight across the South Atlantic from Natal, Brazil. The return voyage, the crew reported, was without incident.

Evidence that many concerns still are enjoying expanding trade despite the recent reports of recession in general business was found in the realty brokerage notices yesterday showing rentals of larger quarters by a number of firms.

Bids on the sixth contract in connection with the $5,000,000 grade crossing- elimination project here, have been received by the Central Railroad of New Jersey. The work involves the construction of a highway underpass and two railroad bridges at Humboldt Avenue, also known as New Fourth Street.
The Bureau of Internal Revenue described the Franate Investing Company, Inc., of New York City, today as a corporation formed to prevent imposition of a surtax on its stockholders.

A competition for the writing of the words and music for a new Smith College song has been announced by the Smith College Alumnae Association. The class of 1907 is offering two prizes of $50 each for the best words and tune written by a Smith student, alumna or faculty member.

Andrew Joyce Miller, a partner in the investment banking firm of Hallgarten Co., 44 Pine Street, died of a heart ailment on Sunday aboard the Italian liner Conte de Savoia while on his way to Italy. Mr. Miller had sailed on Saturday with his daughter, Donna Frances del Balzo of Rome. He resided at 53 East Seventieth Street.

Lady Wright of Durley, one of the outstanding women riders in England, arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to participate in the open jumping and hunter events at the National Horse Show which opens in Madison Square Garden tomorrow.

The United States imported about 7,400,000 more pounds of tea this fiscal year than in the previous year, according to the Food and Drug Administration of the United States Department of Agriculture, which supervises tea imports. Total imports were about 91,500,000 pounds, the largest amount since 1929, excepting 1933.
Varicolored uniforms in which a visiting independent football team from McKeesport played the prison team at Rockview Penitentiary had Deputy Warden Rhoads and State Police wondering today.

Fordham's football squad had a day off yesterday. Bruised from the hard game with North Carolina and weary from the overnight train ride Saturday night, the unbeaten Rams were excused from both the regular Monday workout and the blackboard lecture that Coach Jim Crowley had planned for Scout Earl Walsh's report on the 13-0 defeat of Iowa by Purdue.

The monthly payrolls of the steel industry increased at a faster rate than steel output this year, following a four-year period when the payrolls and output were closely elated, according to a survey made by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
Emperor Hirohito today approved the promotion of about 1,200 army officers, which military men said would definitely strengthen the army command for the fighting in China.

Newton D. Baker of Cleveland, Secretary of War under President Wilson, was elected a director of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company today to fill a vacancy caused by the death of Colonel Grayson M. P. Murphy of New York. Mr.

Judge W. L. Stumbo of Floyd County, Ky.; Arthur C. Carter, Mayor of Prestonburg, Ky., and fourteen other persons appealed to the Supreme Court today in an effort to escape serving two-year terms in the penitentiary.

The Japanese flag advanced farther today in the Pacific marine service when the new seventeen-knot freight motor ship Yamazoto Maru left for North Atlantic ports. She crossed from Yokohama in thirteen days to begin Yamashita Lines' new seven-ship run to New York, South America and back.

Speaking at a reception in Brooks Hall yesterday afternoon, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve said that as "liberal arts colleges are threatened by the multiplicity of advice they are asked to give on all subjects, we ought to resist this tendency to make us into finishing schools for young ladies."

The current confusion in the men's clothing market over prices for Spring will be ended tomorrow, when those mills, which have not named lower cloth quotations, will do so, reports here yesterday indicated. The American Woolen Company will have a new list ready and other companies are expected to follow suit.

A "dictatorship" is imminent if such legislation as the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill is enacted at the coming session of Congress, N. P. Hull of Lansing, Mich., president of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation, asserted at the opening session of the organization's annual convention today.

The Federal Grand Jury returned indictments today against thirty-nine persons in its investigation of white slave traffic. Twenty-two of those named today had been indicted previously, the seventeen additional bringing to sixty-five the number thus far accused of violation of the Mann act in the Federal drive against commercialized vice.
Caution continued to mark the purchasing of' out-of-town stores yesterday, with the result that mail orders coming into the local merchandise market were numerous but -for small quantities.

Since 1937 was a post-Olympic year with none of the Olympic incentive that had made the two preceding seasons banner campaigns, the record output for American athletes dropped to 136, contrasted with 188 in 1936 and 292, the alltime high of 1935.

Two performances in the near future of "I'd Rather Be Right," at the Alvin Theatre, have been taken over to raise funds for charitable organizations. The performance Thursday night will aid the work of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York.

Princeton University's Clee for Governor Club, undergraduate organization formed to muster the campus vote in support of Lester H. Clee, Republican nominee for Governor, will play an active role in Republican election activities here tomorrow. Headed by Daniel P.

VOTE early. Study the ballot carefully and if the following propositions and amendments can be found 'anywhere in the polling booth, kindly follow 'the' voting. directions printed here by advice of counsel, Messrs. Rowley, Powley, Gammon Spinach.

Ralph C. Smith, at Fulton House, Flax Hill Road, South Norwalk; A. V. Harris, at house on Covewood, South Norwalk, for Samuel Hoyt Jr.: C. E. Collier, at Jennlings House, Birch Street, Norwalk, Conn.; rentals by G. LeRoy Kemp Co, Inc, brokers.
City Manager H. F. McElroy sent the Ford Motor Company written pledges today intended to bring about the reopening of its assembly plant here to the more than 2,500 employee.
Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina asserted today that President Roosevelt, if he would, could balance the budget. -In an interview with The Worcester Evening Gazette, the Senator said:

Sylvia Smith, native New York pianist, will make her first Town Hall appearance in a recital tonight. Because of Ernest Schelling's injury to his eye be has cabled the Philharmonic - Symphony Society from Switzerland that he will be unable to conduct the opening concert of the young people's series on Nov. 20 at Carnegie Hall.
Mrs. Oscar Adams, Democratic National Committeewoman for Minnesota, died today at St. Mary's Hospital. Her age was 52. Mrs. Adams was born in Minneapolis and lived here all her life.

A man identified by Police Chief Alden C. Sisson as Leslie Pearce, 37, escaped Medfield State Hospital patient, gave himself up tonight at police headquarters. Chief Sisson said he would be held for Medfield police.

Colonel Maurice E. Gilmore took office yesterday as regional director of the Public Works Administration in eleven Northeastern States. The central offices for the region will be at 2 Lafayette Street in this city, with an associate office at Harrisburg, Pa.

The Nicaraguan Government will collect a consumption tax of 5 cents on each gallon of gasoline for road-building purposes. With the three bridges donated by the United States for the International Highway and $100,000 in road-building equipment, Nicaragua has begun her extensive highway program.

H. Lyman Stebbins, New York stock broker, married Marsinah Neison of London on Oct. 15 in the British capital, it became known here yesterday after the couple arrived on the liner Queen Mary. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowland Stebbins of 133 East Sixty-fourth Street. His father is well known as the producer of "The Green Pastures."
The Insurgents in Southern Spain have just finished harvesting an almost bumper crop of the famous Seville green olives, of which the largest consumer is the United States.

In the greatest demonstration Rio de Janeiro ever witnessed, several thousand green-shirted Integralistas (Fascists) paraded today in honor of the 100th anniversary of Brigadier-Couto Magalhaes, Brazilian ??atriot.

There was a flurry of excitement here today when reports from London credited Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, with having placed responsibility for calling the Nine-Power Conference on the United States.

Anthony (Sappy) Sapienza, wanted in Chicago on a murder charge, started tonight the northward journey by train. Handcuffed and his ankles fastened with chains, he was guarded by two Chicago policemen.
Secretary Ickes warned the nation tonight that its cupboard would be as bare as "Old Mother Hubbard's" soon if national resources of oil, lumber and minerals continued to be exploited.

The State Board of Agriculture appointed tonight as secretary of that de. apartment Williard H. Allen, extension professor at the State College of Agriculture at New Brunswick and executive officer in New Jersey for the A. A. A.

For the fifth time since the beginning of the series for the chess championship of the world, a draw was recorded tonight in the twelfth game between Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris.

In a three-page presentment the October grand jury yesterday described Mayor La Guardia's allegations that District Attorney Samuel J. Foley of the Bronx had made a "deal" with James J. Hines, Tammany leader, as "false and baseless charges which tend to undermine the successful prosecution of crime and law enforcement."
The Labor party further strengthened its control over the London municipal government and held its own in the provinces in elections in England and Wales yesterday.

As Philadelphia prepared to go to the polls tomorrow to elect county officers and vote on city-county consolidation and four other proposed constitutional amendments,. Jay Cooke, Republican city chairman, accused the Democrats today

Production of crude oil in Venezuela in September amounted to 17,376,584 barrels, a daily average of 579,219, compared with 13,914,313, a daily average of 463,810, in September, 1936, according to O'Shaughnessy's Oil Bulletin.

Funeral services for Francis Joseph Heney, "two-fisted"' prosecutor of San Francisco's celebrated graft cases of 1908, will be held Wednesday. Mr. Heney, who died yesterday of influenza complications at the age of 78, had been a Superior Judge in Los Angeles County since 1931.

Miss Helen E. Iangdon Brown, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ellis Brown of 1,125 Park Avenue, will be married to John H. Claiborne, son of Mrs. J. Herbert Claiborne of 145 East Fifty-second Street and the late Dr. Claiborne, on Saturday afternoon at the Brown Summer home in Tuxedo Park, N. Y.
Tammany Hall regards Jeremiah T. Mahoney as a "long shot," but one who will come home in front, it was indicated yesterday.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue said today that Frank C. Paine of Boston "wanted to have his cake and eat it" when he deducted $99,990 from his 1930 taxable income as a loss on the America's Cup defender "Yankee."

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday a reduction of 10 cents a barrel in the price of bunke- fuel oil, grade C, delivered at North Atlantic ports. This makes the price $1.25 a barrel, f.o.b. terminals at New York, Boston, Baltimore and Norfolk, and $1.20 at Charleston; S. C.

Failure of the Government Printing Office to publish and distribute the new Civil Air Regulations has automatically postponed their effective date, it was learned yesterday from Leonard Jurden, supervising inspector of the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce in New York and thirteen near-by States.

A group of local New York banks made available yesterday funds to the St. Joseph Railway, Light, Heat and Power Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, to enable the company to meet the payment of principal and interest on $5,000,000 of first-mortgage 5 per cent bonds, due yesterday, it was learned here.

A family reunion today at the home of Mrs. William Mattil of 168 Monmouth Road here culminated a fifteen-month search for her father, Oswald Rudolph, 79 years old, who disappeared in July, 1936, on a visit to Manhattan.
Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn tonight defeated Andrew Ponzi, of Philadelphia, 125 to 59, in five innings, the shortest match played thus far in the world championship pocket billiard tournament.

" Religious instincts are expressed in two forms, one collective and the other individual, and the building we are beginning to use formally tonight is dedicated to both forms," said President William Allan Neilson at the dedication of the new chapel in the Smith College-library tonight.

The culmination of an election campaign brings up a profound inconsistency in human nature. Let us suppose that we wish Candidate A to win. We follow A's arguments with interest. To us they seem irresistibly convincing.

General Chang Fah-kwei, the "Iron General" who now commands the Chinese on the Shanghai front, is to the Western World one of the colorful figures of China. In that country he has been a leader since the time of Sun Yatsen, the first president of the new republic, whom he served, from all early reports, faithfully and well.

A brief In answer to the appeal of thirty-nine former employes of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation of North Chicago who were sentenced for contempt of court for a sit-down strike in February was filed today in the Appellate Court at Ottawa, Ill.
Army personnel on duty in the 1,604 Civilian Conservation Corps Camps throughout the country will begin tomorrow the task of fingerprinting the more than 300,000 enrollees.

Vernon Spencer, 40, former baseball player, was in jail tonight as a material witness pending investigation of the shooting of his hunting companion, Helen Grier. An inquest was tentatively scheduled for tomorrow night.

Dr. Frank D. Facienthal, secretary of Columbia University for twenty-seven years, was appointed provost of the university yesterday at the - monthly - meeting of the board of trustees. He will be succeeded as- secretary by Philip M. Hayden, his-assistant since 1919.

The Internal Revenue Bureau asked the board of tax appeals today to decide whether Charles Edison, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, is entitled to deduct from the 1931 income tax return of his father, Thomas A. Edison, the amounts the late inventor spent with Henry Ford and Harvey Firestone on rubber experiments.
Kenneth Ives Co. and the Fred F. French Management Company acted as brokers in the sale of the estate of the late Fred F. French in Pawling and Dover, Dutchess County; to Lowell Thomas.

Another attack was made by Arabs on the Daharieh police post near Hebron late last night. The same post had been raided a fortnight ago by Arabs, who robbed the policemen of their arms and drove them from the post.
The present Sino-Japanese hostilities were declared to be "entirely due to Japan's ceaseless aggressions against China" in a long statement issued yesterday by the Foreign Office spokesman.
Apple dumplings are plumper -and pies are chock-full of fruit this Fall with such a bumper crop being harvested from South Jersey orchards that storage houses are being crammed to their roofs.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec' 13 to stock of record of Nov. 12, and the regular quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share on the $5 preferred stock, 'payable on Feb. 1 to stock of record of Jan. 10.

The Brooklyn College football team enjoyed a day of rest yesterday, after the victory over Hofstra College Saturday. Coach Lou Oshins will start pointing today for the Kingsmen's game with Trenton Teachers at Trenton Saturday.
The Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine reported today that the number of trees affected by Dutch elm disease had decreased 25 per cent since last year.

The omission of the usual reference to Turco-Soviet friendship from the address of President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, opening the third session of the fifth National Assembly today, caused some speculation in Turkish-diplomatic circles.

Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, on the eve of his departure for Brussels to attend the nine-power conference, today told the House of Commons that any action taken in Far Eastern affairs depends essentially on the cooperation of the United States.

CAINES, JANE A. (Nov. 20, 1934). Gross assets, $36,731: net, $15,661. To Edward E. Caines, husband. Chief assets, real estate, $35,731. Samuel Weisstein, attorney, 220 Broadway. COHEN, MINA SEEMAN (June 29, 1937). Gross assets, $72,334; net, $67,666.

George Reed Wadsworth, who retired in June after nine years as First Assistant State Commissioner of Correction, in charge of prison industries throughout the State, died of a heart attack yesterday at his residence, 29 Washington Square. He was born in Keene, N. H., sixty-two years ago.

Opposing counsel battled over nearly every point of testimony today before a National Labor Board examiner in a renewal of the inquiry into relations between the Bethlehem Steel Company and its employes.

Adopting a report submitted by its Committee on Education, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors refused this afternoon to undertake a vocational education program or to appropriate funds for a survey of current methods of establishing and operating trade schools.

Had SirArthur Grenfell Wauchope left Jerusalem in December, 1935, at the expiration of his first term as High Commissioner and Commander in Chief for Palestine and High Commissioner for Trans-Jordan, he would have been hailed by both Zionists and Arabs as a just and creative administrator.
