After serving continuously for thirty-five years as director of the Aquarium, which about a century ago was the most popular music hall and now is the most popular educational institution in the city, Dr. Charles H. Townsend will officially retire today.

One-sided victories were registered by the Columbia University, Princeton, New York Athletic and City Athletic Clubs as competition in the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis team championship opened yesterday.
The establishment of an Imperial general headquarters under the direct supervision of the Emperor for coordinating naval and military action is projected and will probably be realized soon.

Japan's war against China will go on for another year, Nathaniel Peffer, writer and authority on the Far East, predicted yesterday. Despite a "lot of romantic illusions about how heavily nations can be crushed economically," he said, Japan can carry on "for fourteen, sixteen or eighteen months."

Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec' 13 to stock of record of Nov. 12, and the regular quarterly dividend of $1.25 a share on the $5 preferred stock, 'payable on Feb. 1 to stock of record of Jan. 10.

The Brooklyn College football team enjoyed a day of rest yesterday, after the victory over Hofstra College Saturday. Coach Lou Oshins will start pointing today for the Kingsmen's game with Trenton Teachers at Trenton Saturday.
The Bureau of Entomology and Plant Quarantine reported today that the number of trees affected by Dutch elm disease had decreased 25 per cent since last year.

The omission of the usual reference to Turco-Soviet friendship from the address of President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, opening the third session of the fifth National Assembly today, caused some speculation in Turkish-diplomatic circles.

Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, on the eve of his departure for Brussels to attend the nine-power conference, today told the House of Commons that any action taken in Far Eastern affairs depends essentially on the cooperation of the United States.

CAINES, JANE A. (Nov. 20, 1934). Gross assets, $36,731: net, $15,661. To Edward E. Caines, husband. Chief assets, real estate, $35,731. Samuel Weisstein, attorney, 220 Broadway. COHEN, MINA SEEMAN (June 29, 1937). Gross assets, $72,334; net, $67,666.

George Reed Wadsworth, who retired in June after nine years as First Assistant State Commissioner of Correction, in charge of prison industries throughout the State, died of a heart attack yesterday at his residence, 29 Washington Square. He was born in Keene, N. H., sixty-two years ago.

Opposing counsel battled over nearly every point of testimony today before a National Labor Board examiner in a renewal of the inquiry into relations between the Bethlehem Steel Company and its employes.

Adopting a report submitted by its Committee on Education, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors refused this afternoon to undertake a vocational education program or to appropriate funds for a survey of current methods of establishing and operating trade schools.

With speechmaking continuing until after midnight, the largest number of voters ever to register their choice in a New York municipal election will go to the polls today to determine whether Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia will continue in office for the next four years or whether Jeremiah T. Mahoney Democratic candidate for Mayor, is to be elected.

A bronze plaque showing the figure of the late Joe Humphreys, famed announcer at sports shows, was unveiled yesterday in the main lobby of Madison Square Garden. Approximately 100 persons were present at the ceremonies.

The Actors Equity Association, taking an unprecedented step in the theatre, has adopted a resolution to compel producers to cooperate in "any activity or plan of action" which may improve the interests of the legitimate theatre and those to whom it gives a living, it was learned yesterday.
Mayoralty elections shared interest with the contests for Governor and other offices in many New Jersey municipalities yesterday.

The campus discipline committee of Monticello A. M. College weighed today the case of a ducked instructor. Campus gossip had it that the ducking was in retaliation for numerous class "flunks" given by the professor.

The Democratic party triumphed in Philadelphia yesterday and achieved at least a partial victory in State-wide balloting on five proposed constitutional amendments. The figures in both instances looked silm, however, in comparison with the plurality of 660,000 rolled up by President Roosevelt in Pennsylvania a year ago and with his 209,000 plurality in Philadelphia.

Hank Soar, leading ground gainer for the New York Football Giants, returned to action yesterday for the first time in two weeks and took part in the drill at the Polo Grounds, where the local team meets the Pittsburgh Pirates on Sunday.
Many of the patronesses will entertain guests at the card party for the benefit of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery this afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the WaldorfAstoria.

While sales in New York department stores yesterday were better than those of election day in 1936, the gains varied sharply as between stores, some reporting very slight improvement while others noted increases of as high as 10 per cent. The unofficial estimate for the city as a whole was 2 to 3 per cent.
A $49,250,000 subway bond proposal and a proposed anti-picketing ordinance, major issues in today's municipal election, trailed tonight as first returns were tabulated.

The engagement is being announced simultaneously here and in London today of Miss Elizabeth Ayres Tweedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Leslie Tweedy of London, to Wilbert Thornton Mendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marlin Mendell of Redwood City, Calif.
The MacGregor Arctic expedition has offered to place all its equipment and personnel at the disposal of the Russian Government to aid in the search for the lost Russian fliers.

Results from fourteen out of fifteen districts in Putnam County showed that Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme, Democrat, had only 3,586 votes, while his Republican opponent, Gerald Nolan, received 5,064.

Playing smart football, Baldwin High School's Blue and Gold eleven today turned back Freeport, 13-0, before 6,500 fans to register its fifth straight victory of the season and remain undefeated and untied.

Sir Murchison Fletcher, Governor of this British West Indian island, .announced at a special legislative session today that a company of infantry would be stationed in Trinidad oil fields this month to guard against disorders (presumably after publication of the report of a Royal Commission that inquired into labor riots last June and July during which fifteen persons were killed.)

The speech in the House of Commons yesterday by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, today drew from Informazione Diplomatica, Foreign Office news agency, a reply so strong, both in substance and in form, that it is almost universally recog nized as having been written by Premier Mussolini himself.

A new fight by private interests against the government program for electric power development was brought before the Supreme Court today when the West Virginia Power Company requested a review of the Fourth Circuit Court decision permitting condemnation of lands and a dam site for the $13,000,000 Bluestone Reservoir project on New River.

Mr. and Mrs. Maxfield Parrish have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Parrish, to Augustus T. Seymour of Columbus, Ohio. The wedding will take place the latter part of December. The couple will make their home in Albuquerque, N. M.
With the Republicans apparently capturing every office in the county by substantial pluralities today, the party claimed its first victory in Bergen since President Roosevelt's victory in 1932.
A list of flood-control projects calling for expenditure of many millions has been returned to army engineers by the White House for selection of those which could be completed quickly.

Oliver Stanley, President of the Board of Trade, told the House of Commons today that "there is nothing in public life which I take so seriously or for which I strive so hard" as a trade treaty between Britain and the United States.

Final returns tonight showed that Herbert Morrison led the Labor party to success in the London Borough Council elections. The sweep was almost as striking as that of last March, which strengthened the party's hold on the London County Council.

The death list of Pennsylvania's hunting season jumped to six today, the second of the season. Leo Bansock, aged 19, of Oley Valley, Luzerne County, and Frank P. Schroeder of Reading were the new victims.

Italian difficulties in Ethiopia are again emphasized in a dispatch from Jibuti, French Somaliland, displayed in The Times of London telling particularly of economic hardships in the newly conquered territory.

A general wage increase for the lower-paid categories of workers in all commissariats and departments of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics was ordered in a decree issued today by the Council of People's Commissars.
The Rev. Henry C. Schlueter, retired Presbyterian minister who had filled pastorates in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Iowa, Missouri and Baltimore, died here yesterday at the age of 81.
Omaha business and professional men approved today a plan to "buy up" pay scrip for twenty-two county hospital nurses and thereby keep the hospital open.

Emil Ludwig, author of "The Nile" (Viking), is scheduled for two talks at Columbia University in the next two days. He will address Professor John H. H. Lyon's class in Literature of Today--Authors of Today at 3 P. M., today, in the School of Business, and at 8:15 P. M. tomorrow he will speak in the McMillin Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street, on "Living Makers of History."

A group of 61 building and loan executives and members of their families arrived last night on the Grace liner Santa Elena after an intercoastal voyage from San FrancIsco where they attended the annual convention of the United States Building and Loan League at Los Angeles. Leading the group were Morton Bodfish, executive president of the league, and T. W. Atkins, secretary.

Thomas E. Dewey, who was elected District Attorney of New York County yesterday, is nationally the best known of all those seeking office in this city, with the exception of Mr. La Guardia, who won his first election when the famous "racket buster" was only 14 years old.
The Congregation of the University of Oxford today conferred the degree of Master of Arts on Lord Nuffield, motor car manufacturer who gave large sums to the university.

Frank Parker Stockbridge, writer and president of the Silurians, paid tribute last night to George Horace Lorimer, late editor of The Saturday Evening Post, as "a great editor, an honest man and the greatest benefactor of all time to the profession of writing," in a speech at a memorial meeting at the Writers Club in the Hotel Woodstock.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Oct. 30: Mumma, Major H. L., Q.M.C., five days leave, Nov. 17. Hoge, Capt. K. G. (Cav.). Adjutant General's Dept., two days' leave, Nov. 4. Dougherty, Capt. J. R., Inf., two months' leave, Dec. 21.

Topping the Yankees' famous Joe DiMaggio by four points and scoring a total of 78 out of a possible 80, Charlie Gehringer, veteran second-base star of the Detroit Tigers was voted the most valuable player in the American League for 1937 by the Baseball Writers Association of America, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

Since one of Japan's professed aims in the undeclared war on China is the suppression of Communist tendencies, the Japanese Army will soon face the serious problem of coping with the communist force reorganized under the Chinese Government as the Eighth Route Army and with other former Red forces, which are being reorganized and equipped as the Fourth Army.
In the most overwhelming defeat ever suffered by Tammany, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, the first "reform" Mayor to succeed himself, was re-elected yesterday by a plurality of 454,425.
Sight has been restored to Jeannette Pepin, 20-year-old office worker, blinded by a lightning flash during a storm more than three weeks ago, Dr. J. Victor Lavoie said today.

Rabbi Nathan Wolf of the Times Square Synagogue, 240 West Thirty-eighth Street, for years the lone voter of his election district-at a cost to the city of $500-this year was supposed to have had company in the Forty-second Election District of the Tenth Assembly District in the person of Jack Chason, who registered as watchman and resident of a loft building at 256 West Thirty-eighth Street.
Liquidation developed today in the wheat market on the Board of Trade here as a result of weakness in Liverpool and a slow demand for domestic hard Winter.
George Palmer Putnam was appointed trustee today of the estate of-his wife, Amelia Earhart, who vanished during a flight over the Pacific Ocean last Summer.

Bruno Chiorsi, 11, of 144-25 222d Street, Rosedale, Queens, was instantly killed at 8 A. M. yesterday when his bicycle was caught beneath the front and rear wheels of a trailer on a truck driven by Andrew J. Gorman . of. 130 East St. Mark's Place, Valley Stream.
The United States topped all nations supplying Canada with goods in the six months ended on Sept. 30, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics said today, while the United Kingdom came second.

Governor Lehman sent last night to Mayor La Guardia a telegram offering congratulations and "best wishes for a successful administration." The message was sent from the Hotel Biltmore, where the Governor was visiting Postmaster GeneralFarley. The Governor refused further comment.

A ruling that native-born Americans cannot be deprived of citizenship by action of parents during minority of the children was handed down today by Justice Jennings Bailey of the District of Columbia District Court. The State Department will appeal the matter to the Supreme Court it necessary.
Debtless Nebraska's general fund balance sank to a record low of $4.27 today, the most acute shortage since a 1921 constitutional provision prohibited bonded indebtedness.

A Mexican Federal judge refused today to hear the first case challenging the constitutionality of President Lazaro Cardenas's nation-wide land division program. This means that neither Mexican nor United States landowners whose land is seized will have any legal recourse in Mexico.

Morris Rolnick, 62 years old, of 1,738 Sixty-second Street, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday afternoon in an automobile accident at Dahill Road and Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, while he was returning home from a polling place after casting his ballot.
A lone mule, housed in a stable 100 feet below the surface of the Bygrade Mine, near here, escaped death in a fire which took a toll of thirty-five pit ponies today.
Colonel Leonidas Coyle, State Fire Warden, was found dead in his apartment here this afternoon by his physician, Dr. John Zielinski. Death was attributed to cerebral apoplexy. His age was 60.

Harry Morrissey, ranked by many as the greatest starter of all time on the American turf, died of a heart attack at his Woodside ranch last night at the age of 62. Active until the last, Mr. Morrissey sent the fields away at Bay Meadows race track Saturday.

An exposition to prove that "whatever of permanent value exists in Eastern Europe in the way of cultural civilization is of German origin" was opened, here today. The purpose of the exposition was revealed in an address by Hans Hagemeyer, chief of the Bureau for the Support of German Literature. He said:

George Bernard Shaw declared yesterday that war was the result of maldistribution of work and wealth and that the nations were slowly drifting into another worldwide conflict through their failure to "put their houses in order."
The Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of New Durham has sold the two-family dwelling at 115 Seventh Street, West New York, N. J., to Olga Huber for occupancy.
Mrs. Meredith Howard Erskine, 27, onetime Follies star, won an uncontested divorce on grounds of desertion today from Albert R. Erskine Jr., adopted son of the late automobile builder.

After maintaining its downtown store at Fulton and William Streets for seventy-three years, the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., manufacturers of paints and varnishes, announced yesterday the leasing of new quarters at 110 Fulton Street, corner of Dutch Street, thus returning to the location it occupied eighty-six years ago.

The board of army engineers stated today that it was not convinced of the advisability of a forty-foot channel for the Delaware River from Philadelphia to the sea at the present time, and invited those interested in the proposed improvement to submit 'further arguments within thirty days.
Shootings and disturbances in two eastern Kentucky counties marked an otherwise quiet off-year general election in Kentucky today. Unfavorable weather caused a light vote.

The John Adams H. S. football team maintained its undefeated record yesterday when it turned back the Jamaica eleven, 20 to 12, at Dexter Park before a crowd of 10,000 persons for its fifth straight triumph, but Jamaica earned the distinction of being the first team to score on the winners this season.
Johnny Rohrig, 134, Clifton, N. J., gained a draw in his eight-round encounter with Felix Garcia, 139 1/2, of Puerto Rico, in the Coliseum last night before 5,000 persons.

Released from workaday chores and routine by the election day holiday, thousands of visitors made their way yesterday to the. Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue, between Forty-sixth and Fortyseventh Streets, to view the various 1938 models of the twenty American and two foreign makes of automobiles.

Taking another step to bring the utility companies in this district more completely under the control of the Commonwealth Edison Company, Commonwealth Edison and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois filed today with the Illinois Commerce Commission a joint petition asking authority to redeem at $120 a share the preferred stock of the Public Service.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 1 unless specified: Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, to sea: Acushnet, Decatur, Herbert. Puget Sound Yard to Mare Island Yard: Lark, Quail, Whippoorwill. At Port Townsend: Oglala, Preble, Prultt, Sicard, Tracy, Antares, at Coco Solo. Bushnell, at San Pedro.
The church which declared him an heretic, unfit for its episcopacy, gave refuge to William Montgomery Brown in death today.

A crowd of 107,000 at the Caulfield race course today saw The Trump, 5-year-old bay gelding, come from behind in the last 100 yards to win the classic Melbourne Cup. Willie Win, a comparative outsider in the betting, was second, half a length behind, and less than a head away in third place was Sarcherie.
The Republicans took complete command of the Assembly in yesterday's election with the Democratic strongholds both in New York City and up-State suffering staggering losses.

Mrs. Charles Gibson Bennett of Oldtrees, Middletown, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Susanna Pelletreau Bennett, to Henry Boas Maguire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Maguire of Flourtown, Pa.

The Daily Maroon, University of Chicago student newspaper, reported today its poll of undergraduates showed a majority favored the university's remaining in intercollegiate athletics and the Big Ten Conference.
I MET A MAN, by Michael Blankfort. (Bobbs-Merrill, $2.) A novel laid in Germany in 1915. TO SEE OURSELVES, by Rachel Field and Arthur Pederson. (Macmillan, $2.50.) Anovelwith a Hollywood setting.

Democrats sprung a surprise in the Suffolk County elections today when they made Frederick J. Under, Republican, nose into the office of District Attorney with a scant 600 votes, upsetting predictions of a 3,500 plurality over John R. Vunk, who was appointed to that office last month by Governor Lehman.

Mayor La Guardia, playing the role of a motorized Haroun Al Raschid, started a whirlwind tour of the city in the 5 o'clock darkness of yesterday morning and spent the entire day observing how the election was being conducted -in various parts of the city.
After hearing the returns from 1,850 election districts at 10 o'clock last night, which gave him about 599,000 votes to 436,000 for Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Mayor La Guardia said:

Holders of State of Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil) forty-year 7 per cent bonds of the external loan of 1926 will be notified today by Ladenburg, Thalmann Co., special agents, that funds have been deposited sufficient to pay 35 per cent of the amounts of coupons due on Monday.
Northern Westchester's oldest residents, Mrs. Angeline Ga??ner and Mrs. Sarah Lossee, 103 years old and 101 respectively, were early voters in the same election district here today.

The voters of the State approved yesterday two amendments affecting vitally the operation of the government of the State. These were Amendment No. 1, extending the term of the Governor to four years, and Amendment No. 2, prolonging the tenure of Assemblymen to two years.
A new party, the American Labor party, holds the balance of power in New York City and State elections, it was clearly indicated by the results of the voting here yesterday.

A full day of tramping the ridges and standing on wind-swept slopes, and all we have to show for it is a dull ache behind our knees. There are deer in these hills, and perhaps, as Clayton Meyers says, there are bear, but the only deer we saw were does, with the exception of two very dead bucks.

The Treasury ended the first four months of the current fiscal year on Oct. 31 with a deficit of $562,403,216 and a public debt of $36,956,368,228, compared with a deficit of $937,496,214 for the corresponding period in the last fiscal year, and a public debt on Oct. 31, 1936, of $33,832,528,147.

The number of ships under construction in American yards on Nov. 1 was fewer by eight than the total reported a year ago, but their tonnage exceeds the 1936 total by 117,407 tons, according to a report published yesterday by the American Bureau of Shipping.
If the former Edward VIII were still King of England and arrived here on a visit, there would be perhaps as

Thirty-three young men and two women students in the upper classes of the four-year course in hotel administration at Cornell University, Ithaca, N. Y., will take over the entire management of the $26,000,000 Hotel Astor here for one day on Nov. 15.

A total of 4,561 Americans had been evacuated from China up to Oct. 29 while 5,802 remained, according to a report receive. by the State Department today from Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, commander in chief of the Asiatic Fleet.

Railroad service between Rivas and San Juan del Sur, Pacific seaport, has been discontinued because of torrential rains. Eight inches of rain fell in twelves hours and all rivers of Nicaragua overflowed, some having risen fifty feet in twenty-four hours. Cattle, hogs, horses and even wild animals unable to escape were drowned.

The tenth annual graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine was told last night by Dr. Arthur M. Fishberg, associate in medicine at the Mount Sinai Hospital, that recent experimental findings indicated the need for a radical revision of the universally accepted diet regimen for patients suffering from malfunction of the kidneys.
Nassau County remained Republican in the election today when a record-breaking vote was cast for county-wide and local candidates in the three towns and two cities that comprise the county.

Mrs. Jane S. W. Fuller charged cruelty today in obtaining a divorce from Charles E. Fuller, prominent socially in New York City. They were married Sept. 9, 1922, and have three children-Jane Sage, 12: Blair Fairchild, 10, and Isabel Whitney, 6.

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States announced today that it is conducting a referendum on the desirability of the Norris-Mansfield Bill to create seven regional planning agencies. A special committee of the chamber has reported adversely on the measure.
Viscountess d'Osmoy of Nice, France, arrived on the Europa and is at the Savoy-Plaza. Brigadier General Guy V. Henry and Mrs. Henry have come from Fort Riley, Kan., to the Waldorf-Astoria.
The cotton market here showed a fair degree of activity in the early trading today, due to overnight trade buying orders and rather better Liverpool cables, and prices advanced 1 to 3 points.
Dr. George M. Whicher, professor emeritus and for twenty-five years head of the Department of Greek and Latin at Hunter College, New York, and a well-known poet, died here today. He was 77 years old.

The Federal Communications Commission took under advisement today the question of whether non-commercial or commercial interests shall control important government short-wave frequencies for broadcasts to Latin America.

THERE will be more elections later but only certain interested parties will be allowed to go to the polls. In the meanwhile, the campaign is progressing nicely. The reference is to the various football bowls to be filled with successful candidates, two to a bowl.

After a nightlong search of the Saguenay River which divides this little Lake St. John County town, a diver today had found a bumper and license plates as the only trace of an automobile believed to have plunged from a bridge here yesterday, carrying Alexandre Gagnon, 34, and his wife and two children to their deaths.
Albert Foerster, Nazi leader in Danzig, today forecast in a programmatic address that the Third Reich's swastika soon will fly over Danzig as the Free City's flag.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. C. A. Brady of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Genevieve Brady, to Robert M. Woolfe Jr., son of Dr. Robert M. Woolfe of South Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mrs. Woolfe.
On the eve of the Brussels conference seeking a peace formula for China and Japan, five leading university presidents telegraphed the conferees.

A comprehensive order against practically all domestic window glass manufacturers and a large group of distributors was issued today by the Federal Trade Commission, on the ground that certain trade practices prevalent in the industry violate the Federal Trade Commission Act and the Robinson-Patman act.
Several private residential parcels were included in the properties which changed hands in deals announced by brokers yesterday. Activity was in scattered sections of Manhattan and the Bronx.

An exhibition of models of the engineering projects of the Port of New York Authority will be presented tonight at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, as a feature of the annual observance of Visitors Night at the institute's evening school of science and technology.
The New York University varsity cross-country team defeated the C. C. N. Y. harriers, 17 to 38, yesterday, over the five-mile course in Van Cortlandt Park.

Members of society from the North and South Shore colonies of Long Island and from New York, New Jersey, New England, Maryland and Virginia attended this afternoon the Fall meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park.

Frank L. McWade, former leader in the Townsend old-age revolving pension movement, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 61. Mr. McWade was a strong supporter of Dr. Francis E. Townsend, founder of the movement, and later a coworker with the Rev. Clinton Wunder, former Rochester minister, in promoting the plan.
Cotton receipts today were 18,000 bales including 4,500 American. A limited demand developed for spots, with prices 4 points lower.

Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for the Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria. The other guests were Mrs. Howard B. Sherman, Lady Hubert Wilkins, Mrs. Arthur Wooley-Hart of London, John Jacob Astor and Luis Rossini.
The Republicans of Essex County elected their twelve candidates for the Assembly and their three candidates for the Board of Freeholders in yesterday's election.

Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, will speak tomorrow evening at a dinner rally for the 350 workers in the 1937 Community Services campaign of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, Charles Pratt, general chairman, announced yesterday.

When she admitted yesterday before Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio, in Yorkville Court, that she had "lost her head" when she was asked Monday night to give up her room in the Hotel Shelton, 525 Lexington Avenue, and had struck Harrison D. Reed, assistant manager of the hotel, Joyce Lang, 24year-old photographer's model, was found guilty of disorderly conduct.

A threat to the world record holder, Menow, appeared today in Nedayr, who surprised 10,000 observers when he captured the $11,150 Walden Handicap by a nose at the Pimlico track. Menow was the winner of the $76,000 Futurity at Belmont when he set the new six and a half furlong mark.

So far as is known Newbold Morris is the only championship figure-skater ever to have a seat in the Board of Aldermen. As a result of yesterday's election he becomes the first president of the City Council under the new charter, which will replace the old Aldermanic board after Jan. 1, 1938. He is a Republican.

Three crews of British seamen, numbering eighty-five, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Scythia to take over three United States Shipping Board freighters that have been sold for scrapping.

Nine railroad companies, which together haul about 36,000,000 tons of lake cargo coal from Lake Erie and Lake Ontario ports, were charged today by E. A. Burslem examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission, with violations of the Elkins act, in that they failed to collect demurrage charges.

As the three special automobile shows, now running concurrently with the national exhibition, completed their next to last day last night, both attendance figures and sales volume gave cause for satisfaction to their sponsors.

James Monroe preserved its unblemished record by defeating Theodore Roosevelt, 7 to 6, while De Witt Clinton won the twenty-ninth renewal of a long rivalry with Stuyvesant, 6 to 0, in a scholastic football double-header at Randalls Island yesterday.
King Carol and Prince Michael have gone hunting in the Carpathian Mountains with their guests, President Eduard Benes and Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia.

Tearing the line of its time-honored foe to shreds with a powerful running attack, Boys High routed Alexander Hamilton, 20 to 6, at Boys High Field in Brooklyn yesterday. It marked the thirty-first meeting between the Brooklyn schools in the oldest scholastic football series in New York City that began in 1906.

Is Mr. Joseph P. Kennedy, whose sound judgment is accompanied and relieved by plenty of wit and humor, ironically suggesting- the appointment of a Culinary Commission? After luncheon yesterday at the White House with Mr. James Roosevelt, coordinator and liaison officer and interpreter of the bigwig bureaucrats to the President, Mr. Kennedy was asked by a mischievous reporter: "How was the lunch?" "All right,"

The Treasury minted $4,282,401.55 worth of new coins in October. This includes $1,568,577 in ordinary half-dollars, $2,503 in Daniel Boone commemorative halfdollars, $951,125.75 in quarters, $85,050.30 in dimes, $270,855 in nickels and$604,290:50 in pennies.
Special Justice Charles F. Archambault of the Third District Court died today at St. Luke's Hospital at the age of 48. Death was caused by a ruptured appendix.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the Mountain States Power Company has been called for Deo. 1, in Wilmington, Del., to authorize an issue of 69,160 shares of no-par prior preferred $6 cumulative shares.

Mayor Harold F. Mason and his five running mates, all Republican incumbents, were retained in office for a third term today by the largest pluralities ever given to Winning candidates since this city was founded in 1918.

Miss Judith Ann Wilcox, daughter of Mrs. Harold G. Wilcox and the late Dr. Wilcox, will be married here to Hugh Wheeler Sanford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Sanford of Knoxville, Tenn., on Nov. 24, in the Second Congregational Church.

An investing client of Irving Honigsberg, attorney, purchased the five-story apartment house at 85 Hicks Street, Brooklyn. The building is on a plot 25 by 100 feet and is situated near the St. George Hotel.

Lou Salica, 118, Bensonhurst, knocked out Joe Wach, 125 3/4, East Side, in one minute of the fourth round of their feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena last night before 4,000 persons. Referee Johnny McAvoy halted the contest to save the loser from further punishment.
Play in the annual invitation squash racquets tournament started at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn yesterday with eight matches being played to fill the quarterfinal bracket.

League for Political Education, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Essentials of Democracy," Dorothy Thompson. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "The American School of Portraiture," Alfred Busselle Jr., 11 A. M.; the print galleries (general tour), 2 P. M. "Mediaeval Castle Buildings," Margaret B. Freeman, 4 P. M.

The market holiday in New York City put a curb today on trading on the Stock Exchange here and prices were irregularly lower most of the session, but they firmed before the close, giving the industrial and gold shares minor net-gains, while the miscellaneous-mines index closed a half point off.

Fsune-chi Yu, Chinese Consul General in New York, took issue yesterday with parts of the sketch of General Chang Fah-kwei, commander of the Chinese forces at Shanghai, printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES esterday.

There is little chance that Nicaragua and Honduras will resort to arms to settle their dispute over boundary lines, according to Dr. Leon de Bayle, according to Dr. Minister to the United States, who arrived last night on the Grace liner Santa Elena to take up his duties in Washington. He was accompanied by his wife.
Senator Glass recommended today that the undistributed profits tax be repealed and the capital gains levy be modified to stimulate employment and business.

A crowd of 8,000 saw Lincoln High School's eleven hand St. Peter's Prep its first defeat of the season at Roosevelt Stadium today, 7 to 0. The setback dropped St. Peter's out of first place in the Hudson County football race, Dickinson moving into the lead.
John S. Barber Daingerfield, member of an old Virginia family, has filed suit charging E. Pendleton Turner of Washington with alienation of Mrs. Daingerfield's affections. He asked $108,000 damages.

Sir Lenthal Cheatle, noted British surgeon; Sir Richard and Lady Pease, Prince von Hohenlohe, Mrs. Robert W. Bingham, wife of the United States Ambassador to Great Britain; Oscar Strauss, Viennese composer, and Hannen Swaffer, British columnist, are among the passengers booked to sail today for France and England on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.

Bob Pastor, Washington Heights heavyweight, and Nathan Mann of New Haven, Conn., have been matched for a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 26, Al Weill, Twentieth Century S. C. matchmaker, announced yesterday.

Fordham's freshman football forces, a very likely looking group of yearlings who would warm the heart of many a varsity coach, displayed plenty of talent yesterday at Ohio Field in taking the measure of the New York University firstyear men by a 19-6 count.

A thousand persons attended yesterday a luncheon given by the National Distillers Products Corporation in the Hotel Commodore to introduce its latest product, National's Eagle, to wholesale distributors and salesmen from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Rhode Island.
Charles Eustace Hands, one of the most famous reporters Fleet Street ever produced, died today in Ventnor, Isle of Wight, where he had lived in retirement for many years.
Violence, assaults and constant bickering at polling places throughout the county today and tonight marked one of the most disorderly elections in the recent history of Hudson County.

Rockland County witnessed today one of the closest election contests here in many years. Lawrence J. Murray Jr. of Haverstraw, Democrat, was elected Assemblyman over Walter G. Hamilton of Stony Point, Republican county chairman, by a margin of about 2,000.

lady Bountiful 2d, 18 months old, white leghorn hen. lived up to her name yesterday by laying an egg as she was adjudged the "Hen of the Year" at the opening of the Third Annual Poultry Industries Exposition in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

James H. Price, present Lieutenant Governor and Richmond Democrat, exceeding the expressed hopes of his supporters, tonight had a lead of almost 5 to 1 over J. Powell Royall, his Republican opponent for Governor of Virginia.

Advertisers' expenditures on the National Broadcasting Company's networks in October totalled $3,339,739, a gain of 17.2 per cent over the September figure, it was announced yesterday. This is the twelfth month in which billings have exceeded $3,000,000 in the eleven years of the company's existence.

New York City had the cleanest, most orderly city election in its history yesterday. Despite the bitter campaign and widespread belief that thuggery would keep policemen busy at the polls, the whole procedure ran off with unprecedented smoothness; no violence, no uproar, no noticeable intimidation of voters.
The Raleigh Ministerial Association refused by unanimous vote today to conduct devotional services on Armistice Day in grammar schools of the city at exercises sponsored by the American Legion.
Maurice Goldblatt, president of Goldblatt Brothers, and Nathan Goldblatt, secretary and treasurer of the company, have waived all salary for the next year, the former announced today.

Two timely pass interceptions which produced touchdowns and some brilliant offensive play by burly Jack Martin carried Manual Training High School's football squad to an 18-to-7 surprise victory over its old rival, Erasmus Hall, at Ebbets Field yesterday.
Scoring once in each of the first and fourth periods, the Brooklyn Friends School football team downed Friends Academy of Locust Valley, L. I., 14 to 0, at Friends Field in Brooklyn yesterday.
United Air Line officials announced tonight that hereafter their planes would fly at a minimum altitude of 13,000 feet over the mountainous section of the Cheyenne-Salt Lake City route.

The thirty-second annual chrysanthemum exhibition of the North Country Community Association today attracted many flower lovers and members of society, who were in their country homes to vote, and both the afternoon and evening hours were crowded with visitors. The show was held in main building of the Pratt Oval on the Pratt estate.

Clarence E. Selvage, vice president of the George T. Stagg Company, Inc., distillers, and Kentucky sales manager for the Schenley Products Company, was found dead in bed this morning at his home here.

George Cockill Sr., former football coach at Bucknell University and once an umpire in the National League, died today at the home of his son at Steelton, near here, after an illness of nearly two years. He was 56 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fuller of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of Mr. Fuller's daughter, Miss Fairfax Fuller, to Henry Lorin Binsse of Glen Cove, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bancel Binsse of Washington, D. C.

Maurice J. Tobin, 36-year-old school, committeeman, was elected Mayor of Boston today by a margin of 24,673 votes. His nearest rival in the field of six candidates was former Mayor and former Governor James M. Curley, making an attempted political comeback following his defeat by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., in the last national elections.

A statement declaring that the results of the vote in New York State indicated a "repudiation of the-New Deal leadership of Jim Farley" was issued last night by William S. Murray, chairman of the Republican State Committee.

Fred H. Hoehler of Chicago, director of the American Public Welfare Association, told members of the National Association of Junior Leagues today that social legislation, to be useful, must meet a specific need.

With no more ceremony than the notes from a hunting horn summoning the contenders in the first class, the fifty-second National Horse Show will open in Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock this morning to continue through next Wednesday.

The Duke of Windsor is scheduled to extend greetings to the American people over the radio in a broadcast from Washington on Friday, Nov. 12, the day after his scheduled arrival at New York, it was announced here yesterday. His fifteen-minute address will be carried over- the facilities of the major broadcasting networks at 7 P. M., Eastern standard time.

Maude Valerie White, composer of "Until," "The Devout Lover" and many of the most popular songs of the last generation, died in London today at the age of 82. She had been a recipient of a State pension for her "services to music."

The twenty-second annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers will open with a preview reception and tea this afternoon from 3:30 to 6 o'clock in the galleries on the seventh floor of Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center. With the American work will be shown a large group of contemporary prints from Sweden. The joint exhibition opens to the public tomorrow.

The Republican Central Committee of Cook County today opposed a move to call a mid-term convention of the party. A resolution to that effect was adopted while members of the national committee converged on the city to vote on the proposal at a meeting on Friday.

Food and tobacco are more. expensive items in the family budget of Eastern farmers than they are in the budgets of prairie farmers, who spend more for automobiles and education, according to a report by the Agriculture Department.

Sales of two small estates and several other residences were reported on Long Island yesterday. The former H. H. Seaman property at Bayport, L. I., one of the show places of that section, has been purchased for occupancy by C. William Wohlers, president of the Hamburg Savings Bank of Brooklyn.
The Rev. Albert Lang, former pastor of St. Benedict's Catholic Church here, died today in St. Michael's Hospital of a heart ailment following a long illness. He was 66 years old.

George H. Swift, general manager of Swift Co., Chicago meat packers, tonight reported to police that he was beaten and robbed of a $2,000 pearl scarf. pin and between $300 and $500 in cash in a shooting affray with 'three robbers.

With three New York Curb Exchange A. A. stars and one representative from the New York Athletic Club winning the four individual events, the Lawrence-Cedarhurst Chamber of Commerce staged its first annual invitation track meet at the Municipal Stadium today.
Marguerite Yvonne, Inc, millinery, store and mezzanine at 509 Madison Ave; Rogers-Weil, Inc. ladies' apparel, store at 745 Madison Ave; Butler Baldwin, Inc, brokers.

Jasper McLevy, Bridgeport's Socialist Mayor, was elected for his third consecutive term today with a record-breaking plurality of 19,555 votes over George M. Coughlin, Democratic candidate. The Republicans ran third.

By two years of hard work as Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey has earned himself four more years of hard work as District Attorney of New York County. He cannot regard yesterday's vote as anything short of a tribute-to his character and personality, to the energy, intelligence and persistence he has shown in exposing and rooting out racketeering in New York City.

Tammany Hall, symbol of the political machine since the days of Tweed, suffered its most serious defeat at the polls yesterday. It was a blow from which the organization may never recover, so far as operations in its old-time manner are concerned.

New Yorkers did their first proportional representation balloting smoothly and rapidly, on the whole, belying predictions by political observers that the need to pore over a long list to make numbered preferences would entail long delays or cause many to avoid voting for Councilmen.

Formal notice was given by the State Department today that the United States contemplates negotiating a reciprocal trade agreement with Turkey, and interested persons were invited to submit suggestions as to the products that should be considered.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Winslow White were hosts this morning at their home in the Commack colony at a breakfast after the drag of the Smithtown Hunt which started from the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Beh in Green Lawn, Huntington.
Government officials estimated the increased cost of a five-day, thirty-five-hour week for Federal employes today at, roughly, $50,000,000 to $100,000,000.
The citizens of Detroit rose up today and smote the C. I. O. which had tried to win control of the city government with a liberal Democrat as standard bearer.

The endowment assets of Amherst College increased from $10,089,357 to $11,608,182 during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1937, according to the annual report of the treasurer, Charles A. Andrews. Plant assets increased from $4,268,874 to $4,452,234, largely due to new buildings.
Carlon de Cespedes, Cuban political leader, looked forward today to a general amnesty law to be presented at the session of Congress opening in Havana tomorrow as a means of unifying the republic.
The Grover Cleveland High School eleven of Queens downed the High School of Commerce, 14 to 0, in an inter-borough clash at the George Washington High School Stadium yesterday.

Wage increases of $500,000 annually were in effect--today for more than 3,000 Seattle department store and specialty shop workers under an agreement between the Retail Clerks International Protective Association and the Seattle Department Stores Association, Inc. It runs to June 1, 1939.

Joseph D. McGoldrick is that rarity, the professor in politics. The new City Controller has been a teacher since 1922, but his interest in city government antedates that, and his practical experience with politics goes back to 1934.

The marriage of Mrs. Marguerite Gillison Howser, daughter of Mrs. Sawyer Hill of this city and Cannes, France, to Kent Crane, son of Mrs. Frank Crane of New York and the late Mr. Crane, will take place here on Nov. 10.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

Mrs. Annis Chittenden Flanders of 818 Madison Avenue has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Virginia Lee Flanders, to Walter S. Gurnee, son of Mrs. Burgess Gurnee of 322 East Fifty-seventh Street and Rock Hill, Oyster Bay, and the late Walter S. Gurnee.

The mysterious characters whose voices are known to the customers through the "Mickey Mouse" and "Silly Symphony" series of Walt Disney will have identity in "Radio City Revels," if negotiations between RKO and Disney are successful.

Pacific Western Oil Corporation--Nine months ended on Sept. 30: Net income, $1,232,249, equal to $1.23 a share on 1,000,000 outstanding capital shares, compared with $913,279, or 91 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year.

An edition de luxe valued at $5,000 and an exhibit of books written by relief workers in the Federal Writers Project of the WPA will be in neighboring booths at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, to open Friday.
The non-intervention subcommittee of nine nations finally agreed today to ask both sides in Spain to approve the British plan for the gredual withdrawal of the foreign "volunteers."

It is the reviewer's grateful function to write in pleasant vein of the piano playing of Sylvia Smith, a native of New York, who gave her first local concert last night at the Town Hall. For Miss Smith is one to whom music is more than the conscientious observance of printed instructions.
Mrs. Anne Baron, wife of Benjamin Baron of 1106 Neilson Avenue, Far Rockaway, died Monday night in the Rockaway Beach Hospital at the age of 41 after a long illness.

Though the Trustees of Columbia College more than a century ago established the office of provost, even praying that the provost might by amendment of the charter be made eligible for a trusteeship in the college, Dr. Fackenthal is but the third to be granted the title. The office so named is a survival from the ecclesiastical establishments in which it originated.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator here, announced yesterday that six ??PA supervisors had been dismissed Monday night for political activity in behalf of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor.

Flying around the world by regular airways, Sir Keith Smith, who with his late brother, Sir Ross Smith, was co-pilot on the first flight from, England to Australia in 1919, and Wing Commander A. H. Cobby, member of the Civil Aviation Board, will leave Sydney in February as envoys of, Australia's 150th anniversary celebration.
Harry Sewell Dorrothy, retired life insurance investigator, died last night at his Summer home at Indian Lake of a heart attack.

Fish are cold-blooded creatures who invariably obey their worst impulses and have no regard for the rights of others. Big fish eat little fish, little fish eat smaller fish, and so on down to the minute form of life known as plankton, which only wishes to be let alone but isn't.
Walter Blumenthal, president of the United Dressed Beef Company, died on Monday after a short illness in his home at 440 Park Avenue. He was 64 years old.

An emergency loud-speaker system whereby the master of the vessel may communicate readily with pert sons in all parts of the ship has been installed on the Dixie of the Morgan Line and contracts have been drawn for installation on twelve more ships, it was announced yesterday.

An early lead held by Senator A. Harry Moore, Democratic candidate for Governor in New Jersey, was being slowly whittled down as late returns came in this morning, with the result that a close race was indicated with his Republican rival, the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee, Presbyterian clergyman in Newark and State Senator from Essex County.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,602,950 barrels, compared with 3,613,300 in the previous week, a decline of 10,350, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

Charles Leo Wardell of East Orange, vice president of the Wardell Laundry Company of Newark, which he and his brother, the late George Wardell, organized in 1897, died here yesterday in the Presbyterian Hospital, after a long illness, at the age of 58.

A new rule barring State hospital employes from any labor organization unless its constitution contained a "no strike" clause brought from Robert J. Watt, executive secretary of the State. Federation of Labor, today a statement that the ruling "apparently violates" the National Labor Relations Act.

With the exchanges in both New York and Paris closed, the stock market here today was extremely quiet although generally steady. Gilt-edge issues were well supported, but foreign loans were easier for the most part. Transatlantic stocks showed activity and International Nickel went ahead.

A plan to construct a wide and attractive approach to the East River Drive development is being considered by the district plan committee of the East Side Chamber of Commerce, it was learned last night.

Continuing his "get acquainted" conferences as his father's clearing house for the independent agencies of government, James Roosevelt talked to six other bureau heads today relative to their administrative problems.
Coach Jim Crowley put the Fordham football squad through a twohour workout on Fordham Field yesterday morning as practice started for the game with Purdue at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

" Society week" at Woman's College was marked by invitations to more than 700 new students from Adelphian, Aletheian, Cornelian and Dikean. An invitation is issued to every girl on the campus and the names are drawn impartially.

Possibilities of aerial bombardment of New York in the event of war are no more remote than such catastrophic visitations as earthquakes and hurricanes, consequently architects in designing new buildings for this metropolis should consider providing protection for that event, it is suggested in the current edition of News and Opinion, official organ of the Building Trades Employers Association of New York.

A dozen followers of Father Divine in Jamaica, who were challenged when they appeared to vote in the polling place of the 174th E. D., of the 4th A. D., Queens, because they had given only their "heavenly names" when they registered, finally were permitted to vote after an appeal to S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections.

Of the eight Wellesley seniors elected to the Phi Beta Kappa honorary fraternity this week by the Eta chapter of the college, six live within a sixty-mile radius of New York City and the seventh lived in Manhattan before her marriage in June.

The Ministry of Finance will publish the following notice tomorrow: "As a preliminary toward seri-. ous measures the Government contemplates for the regulation of the coffee markets that the exchanges in Rio Santos and Victoria will be closed tomorrow.

Thomas F. Holling, Independent Democrat, was elected Mayor of Buffalo today over Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican County Chairman, by the narrow margin of 1,427 votes. The vote-was Holling, 94,037; Jaeckle, 92,610. Two other candidates for Mayor obtained a total of about 18,000 votes.
A State of war was enforced in Asuncion, capital of Paraguay, tonight after an attempted uprising by members of the army, who sought to create a dictatorship.
Three men were burned slightly on their faces, necks and hands yesterday when a gas stove exploded in the smoked-fish plant at 474 Rodney Street, Brooklyn, where they were employed.

An entirely new method of supervising building plans and buildings in New York will go into effect on Jan. 1 under the new City Charter. Under the revised set-up, the Tenement House Department will be consolidated with the Departments of Buildings of the five boroughs into a city-wide Department of Housing and Buildings.

The Soviet Union probably will take economic reprisals against Japan if Italy joins the reputedly anti-Communist Japanese-German agreement as, according to reports both here and abroad, Italy is preparing to do.

" National Weather Week" will begin Saturday, the first annual in a series sponsored by Taylor Instrument Company, which has planned promotions for stores, national advertising, promotion pieces and displays.

Senator Joseph Paganon, a member of seven Cabinets, died of heart disease at his Paris home during the night. He was 58 years old. M. Paganon, one of the leaders of the Radical Socialist party, had represented the Isere Department in the Senate since 1935.

The Holland-America liner Volendam arrived from Rotterdam yesterday bringing back twentyfour. cases of the works of the famous Dutch painter, Frans Hals, containing thirty-four pictures owned in the United States which are valued at $6,000,000.

The 1937 all-America basketball team was announced yesterday by C. L. Parsons, chairman of the A. A. U. basketball committee, with the publication of the A. A. U. Guide containing the new official rules for the coming season.

The newly organized ninety-twopiece orchestra, which Arturo Toscanini will direct in a series of Saturday night broadcasts beginning Christmas night, was heard in a "dress rehearsal" yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock over the WJZ network. Artur Rodzinski, drill master, conducted.
The West Chester State Teachers defeated St. Joseph's College in the closing minutes of their football contest at Wayne Field tonight, 14-7, before 10,000 spectators.

John H. Neun, former major league first baseman, was named yesterday as manager of the Newark Bears to succeed Oscar Vitt, recently moved up to the field generalship of the Cleveland Indians. According to the announcement, which came jointly from the office of Ed Barrow, business manager of the Yankees, and Ray Kennedy, secretary of the Bears, Neun has been signed to a one-year contract.
The Institute of American Meat Packers said today a survey showed wholesale prices of most grades and classes of beef, veal and fresh pork dropped from 7 to 30 per cent in October.

The Board of Trade for GermanAmerican Commerce, Inc., will give a luncheon and reception today at the Waldorf-Astoria for Karl Lindemann, chairman of the board of directors of the North German Lloyd Line;

By electing Bruce Barton to the House of Representatives, the voters of the Seventeenth District have filled a vacant place in Congress with an able, energetic and public-spirited citizen. Mr. Barton made an excellent campaign, holding out no promises of large favors to come from the National Treasury, but choosing instead to emphasize the importance of putting the fiscal affairs of the Government in order and bringing its budget into balance.

Steel ingot production declined again last week in a contra-seasonal movement, bringing the adjusted index down to 74.6, compared with 81.3 for the previous week. It was the lowest figure since the week ended March 7, 1936. For the corresponding week last year the index was 106.8.

Ralph Greenleaf of New York tonight retained first place in the world's pocket billiard championship tourney by beating Charles Seaback, of Boston, 125 to 37, in twenty-two innings. It was Greenleaf's fourth straight triumph.

While the election returns show tonight that the City Manager proposal was beaten in Yonkers in a referendum today by 1,625 votes, Horace Gray, chairman of the City Manager League, charged that serious errors were found in two districts by the improper marking of the backs of voting machines where the total vote was recorded.

The statement that relations between Senator Hance J. Logan and Captain Freeman Hatfield were not those of solicitor and client, since Mr. Logan had a half interest in Captain Hatfield's claim for $71,000 reparations for the wartime sinking of his schooner, the Gypsum Queen, was made by R. S. Robertson, counsel for the Crown, before the Supreme Court of Canada today.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Democratic candidate for Mayor, declared last night that he believed his defeat could be attributed to two causesa desire of voters for a radical political philosophy and a wide belief that Mayor La Guardia should be rewarded for having given the city an administration free of corruption.

Despite the Sino-Japanese situation, which tended to lessen shipments of dyes, medicinals, toiletries, etc., United States exports of chemicals and related products continued active in September, the Commerce Department reported today.
Federal prosecutors in the government's gasoline price-fixing case turned their attention today to three market publications charged with playing a part in the alleged price conspiracy.

Weather signs meant all things to all men yesterday as notables on both sides went to the polls. Kenneth F. Simpson, Republican County chairman, looked on the rising sun at 5 o'clock in front of a tearoom polling place at 1,374 Lexington Avenue, and found it good for the Republicans.

George B. Wells, president of the American Optical Company, has been elected a director of the First National Bank of Boston. The Guaranty Trust Company, as agent, will exchange stamped and unstamped certificates for Class A and B preferred stock of the Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation for the new securities as provided in the plan of recapitalization.

Fusion in this city has won a smashing victory. By a very large majority the people of New York have chosen to return to office an Administration which has given them four years of clean, progressive government. The result is more than a personal triumph for a Mayor whose dash and energy and courage have won for him the admiration of large numbers of his fellow-citizens.

" Hooray for What!" which is the Ed Wynn show, won't be arriving at the Winter Garden .until after Thanksgiving-probably during the week of Nov. 29. Now in Boston, it will visit Philadelphia for a fortnight starting Nov. 15, instead of opening on Broadway on the evening of Nov. 16, as it first thought.

This evening's major recital events will be Jascha Heifetz's first appearance of the season, at Carnegie Hall, and the appearance of Leonard Shure, pianist, at Town Hall. The WPA Composers Forum Laboratory will present tonight the works of Quinto Maganini at the Theatre of Music.

Two seniors at Columbia College, arguing in French, will oppose two students representing Canadian universities in a debate tonight on the advantages of the League of Nations as against a league of American nations. Argument will begin at 8:30 P. M. in' Columbia's Philosophy Hall.

Mrs. Carrie Schlaegel Jones of 464 Riverside Drive, wife of Dr. Thomas Jesse Jones, educational director of the Phelps Stokes Fund, died yesterday afternoon in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after an illness of ten days.
The Continental Oil Company is changing the set-up of, and expanding its refining and other facilities at several points in its territory, according to an announcement yesterday.

Alberta's bank taxation, credit control and newspaper regulations bills, passed at the last special session of the Legislature, will be subject to reference to the Supreme Court to determine if they become law, Prime Minister Mackenzie King said tonight.

Three mortgages aggregating $525,000 have been placed on the three six-story apartment houses recently completed at the northeast corner of Broadway and Dongan PL The Prudential Insurance Co. is the mortgagor. A corporation headed by David Rose is the owner.
An early end of the nineteen-county milk strike, called by the Dairy Farmers Union in a demand for recognition and higher prices to producers, was predicted today by Archie Wright, union organizer.

Sailing his Class X craft Wench, Sam Wetherill made the highest score today in the dinghy races at the Larchmont Yacht Club. He won four out of six contests and was second once after being third the first time out. His total of points was 117 to 115 for Harry Hall in the Wow.

Dr. Thomas W. Hopkins, Assistant Superintendent of Jersey City Schools, said today that cities could not afford to neglect intelligent use of existing public agencies for prevention of juvenile delinquency.
Baptist dignitaries will not forget Felix de Pancis, a brickmason, when they dedicate Fork Union Military Academy's new chapel on Saturday.
Franklin D. Roosevelt, giving his occupation as "farmer," cast the 299th vote recorded today in the Third Election District of Hyde Park.

Mrs. Susanna Bednar, 54 years old, died today in the Elizabeth General Hospital here of injuries suffered yesterday when she was struck by an automobile while crossing State Highway Route 25 to visit Mount Calvary Cemetary. Charles K. Horndostel Jr. of Monmouth Beach, who police say was the driver of the car, will be arraigned in police court tomorrow on a charge of manslaughter.

Mr. and Mrs. John Douglas Laurie of this city have announced the coming marriage of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Marie Laurie, to William M. Nelson of Washington, D. C. The ceremony will take place on Nov. 13.

Senator Borah, upon his return to the capital today,expressed the belief that enactment of legislation to curb monopolies would do more than subsidies to farmers to improve agricultural conditions. He said he expected to cooperate with the Administration on new anti-trust legislation.

William Mather Lewis, president of Lafayette College, will be the principal speaker at the ninth mid-year conference and dinner of the New Jersey Bankers Association on Thursday in the Berkeley-Carteret Hotel here.

Bruce Barton, Republican and Fusion candidate for Representative from the Seventeenth Congressional District, won an easy victory over his two rivals for the office. His vote represented a plurality of 12,773 and a majority of 3,076.
The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the following awards of cotton textile contracts, totaling 674,000 yards:
Receipts from the alcoholic beverage tax in September were $2,241,849.22, an increase of $135,287 over September, 1936, it was said today by Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission.

For the first time since the Supreme Court invalidated the Bankhead act with its penalty taxes on cotton marketed in excess of prescribed quotas, a representative of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration recommended before the House Agriculture Committee today similar legislation for the corn crop.

Tom Sawyer, Huck Finn and Becky Thatcher once more will climb Hannibal's hills, roam through the cave and eat in the low-ceilinged home where their creator, Samuel L. Clemens (Mark Twain), spent his boyhood.

A Spanish Government communique tonight reported that 120 persons, including fifty children, were killed during an Insurgent air raid on Lerida, seventy-five miles west of Barcelona Several hundreds were reported injured.

Despite strong opposition from northern townships, the proposed new charter for Westchester County was carried by a majority of about 10,000 votes, according to estimates tonight by Democratic and Republican leaders.

ONCE again to the problem of food, since feed we must and do. How long, for example, has homo sapiens been eating the things he eats today? How is it that any one managed to survive and flourish in the days before science hit upon sewers, iceboxes and the fact that certain substances were good for us and others were not?

Jungle King, carrying the popular colors of Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree Stable, captured the fourteenth running of the Temple Gwathmey Memorial Steeplechase Handicap that featured the Autumn meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association at Belmont Park yesterday. The program brought to a close the metropolitan racing season.
Not a vote was cast today in the Second District, Tenth Ward, until nearly two hours after the polls opened.

The National Doll and Toy Collectors Club, composed of women who collect dolls as a hobby, announced plans yesterday for the establishment of a national museum, exclusively for dolls of all ages and nationalities.

The purpose of the United States in participating in the Nine-power treaty conference on the Far East in Brussels is to share in the common task of finding, within the provisions of the treaty that guarantees the territorial integrity of China and the policy of the Open Door and in accordance with the principles of peace that have been repeatedly stated here, some pacific solution of the Sino-Japanese conflict.

A prediction that Hawaii will be forced to wait a decade for Statehood "because of racial prejudice in the United States" was made here today by Dr. D. L. Crawford, President of the University of Hawaii.

Louis F. Edwards, Democratic candidate, was elected Mayor of this city today. He defeated Lorenzo C. Carlino, the Republican nominee, polling 2,801 votes to Carlino's 2,338. With the exception of the office of Supervisor, for which Jacob W. Osmann, Republican, defeated Peter J. Deyine by 2,608 to 2,069 votes, Long Beach's Democrats made a clean sweep of the election.

Fourteen seamen of the freighter Algic, charged with mutiny, were remanded to jail by James K. Cullen, Federal commissioner, today pending further study of the case. The commissioner, ending hearing on the charges, said:
The Chinese defenders of Shanghai are believed by foreign military observers to be preparing for an early retirement from contact with the International Settlement and French Concession.
Representative Fish, Republican, was elected today as delegate to the Constitutional Convention from the Dutchess County districts. Commenting on returns this evening, he said:
Nine persons were killed and seventy were injured early this morning in the wreck of a Central Railway train bound for Sao Paulo from Rio de Janeiro.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Oct. 30: Denney, Capt. A. D., Naal Recruiting Station, Los Angeles, Calif., to command the Pensacola.

New Yorkers who voted Mayor La Guardia and District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey into office yesterday did not make the customary nocturnal pilgrimage to Times Square to celebrate their decision with horn blasts and cheering. It was one of the thinnest election crowds that veteran policemen could recall.
China has asked the League of Nations to resume consideration of her appeal before Nov. 21 "in any case," which is to say, regardless of what the Nine-power conference does.

Horace Greeley Knowles, attorney and former United States Minister to Rumania and to the Dominican Republic, died last night at 145 East Forty-sixth Street, where he had lived for the last five years.

Dr. Lyell M. Rader, a Salvation Army chaplain who was formerly an industrial chemist, died in a New York hospital on Monday after suffering a stroke the previous day at his home, the Salvation Army Men's Industrial Institution, 535 West Forty-eighth Street.

Palma,- once a gay Mediterranean rendezvous for Americans as well as an all-European playground, now has become a city of suspicionsand war hysteria. The spy fever is rife and the town is completely blacked out at each sunset.
Gerald F. Dunne, chairman of the Council of. Metropolitan Liquor Package Store Associations, appealed yesterday for increased use of domestic liquors.
Clarence (Ace) Parker, Duke's allAmerica halfback last year, said today he had agreed to play the remainder of the football season with the Brooklyn Dodgers of the Rational League.

The proposal of the Cuban Government to all the American governments for mediation of the Spanish civil war has been rejected by the United States. A note delivered to the Foreign Office in Havana by J. Butler Wright, the United States Ambassador, was made public today by the State Department here.

Denying reports of Japanese atrocities in the war with China, Shingoro Takaishl, editor of The Osaka Mainichi and The Tokyo Nichi-Nichi, declared last night in a radio address that Japan retains intact "her long-established code of ethics" and engaged in the conflict only "to defend ourselves."

Frank (Lefty) O'Doul has a contract to manage San Francisco's Pacific Coast League baseball club "from now on." President Charley Graham said today O'Doul was given what amounts to a "life" contract plus a considerable salary increase for bringing the Seals through 1937 in second place.

The Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that, where it had considered the merits in a case and entered a decision and no petition for review had been filed with the courts within the statutory limit of three months, it was without authority to grant a motion for reopening and reconsideration.
The Government of Panama will remain democratic, it was stated by President J. D. Arosemena today. "There is no place, in the life of Panama for either communism or fascism" he said.

Two fireboats, in addition to the regular fire apparatus, were: called out yesterday morning to fight a smoky, stubborn fire on the pier of the Hudson River Day Line, 129th Street and the Hudson River. Two alarms were turned in as a precautionary measure.

The threatened picketing of dedication ceremonies yesterday at the new parish house of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church in Whitestone, Queen, was averted by action of the Building Trades Council of the American Federation of Labor.

Retail package store liquor dealers were warned by Commissioner Henry E. Bruckman yesterday to devote their efforts to keeping their books in order, so that the work of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board might be simplified.
The romance of Prince David Kalakaua Kawananakoa with a pretty half-caste girl he is accused of murdering led to a prison sentence today for violation of his probatiorr on an old manslaughter charge.

Albert Kuelling, long active in civic affairs of Brooklyn and one of the charter members and secretary of the Vanderveer Park Taxpayers Association, died at his home, 1,266 New York Avenue, on Sunday at the age of 64.
Brig. Gen. Edward Anderson, who retired from the army in 1923 after thirty-five years of active service, died today in the Lake City Veterans Hospital at the age of 73.

Placing five of its ten first-team men in the third, fifth, sixth, tenth and twelfth positions, Bishop Loughlin Memorial yesterday won the tenth annual running of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country championship over the Van Cortlandt Park course.
Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota contended today that the "same forces which were at work destroying our spirit of neutrality and peace twenty years ago are once again engaged at that task."

Fiorello H. La Guardia, re-elected Mayor of New York, has been a man of action throughout most of the fifty-five years of his life. Except for a few brief periods he has spent most of his time in politics, and even before he entered the hustings he earned his living on the government payroll.
The Reichsbank's statement for Nov. 1 showed the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Breaking 98 out of 100 targets, T. H. Lewis won the first HighOver-All Cup as the regular shooting season of the New York Athletic Club opened at the Travers Island traps yesterday. The Class A trophy went to G. E. Churchill. There was a tie for the Class B prize between W. Black and W. B. Miller, and Black triumphed in the shoot-off.

I'D RATHER BE RIGHT, a musical show in two acts, by George S. Kaufman and Moss Hart; music by Richard Rodgers; lyrics by Lorenz Hart; choreography by Charles Weidman; modern dances arranged by Ned McGurn; book staged by Mr. Kaufman; produced by Sam H. Harris. At the Alvin Theatre.

Chairman Jesse H. Jones of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation probably allowed himself the luxury of a very private chuckle when he got the President's telegram instructing him to underwrite 85 millions for a Federal corn crop loan.

Johnny Goodman of Omaha played sub-par golf to beat young Don Schumacher, of Dallas, today and repeat his 1936 victory in the Mexican national amateur championship. Goodman's winning margin was 6 and 5.
Walter Dorwin Teague, in 400 E 52d St; Talman Bigelow, Inc, broker. Morris Douw Ferris, 12-room suite in 800 Park Ave, through Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc; Douglas L. Elliman Co, agents.
A silver plate appropriately inscribed was presented to Lord Baden-Powell, Chief Scout, and Lady Baden-Powell, head of the Girl Guides, at a private dinner here tonight.
The voters of Newark yesterday rejected a proposal to issue $2,000,000 in school bonds for improvements and additions to the school buildings. The vote was 15,039 to 12,249.

The Republicans won eight of the fifteen contests for delegates at large and probably a clear majority of the 153 district delegates from the fifty-one Senatorial districts of the State in yesterday's election for next April's convention to revise the State Constitution.

The weather in this city yesterday was what impatient proprietors of outdoor ice-skating rinks are accustomed, with polite restraint, to call "unseasonably warm." The sun smiled down, and although there were brisk breezes playing through the golden Autumn leaves, theywere southwest breezes.

Rockwell Kent's message to the independence movement in Puerto Rico, painted into a mural decorating the halls of the Postoffice Department Building here, will be obliterated by another artist, Treasury officials decided today.

A dinner dance under the patronage of well-known members of society will be held Nov. 17 in the La Maisonette Russe at the St. Regis for the benefit of the Russian Refugee Children's Welfare Society and a fund in memory of Prince George Matchabelli for destitute Georgians in this country.
The undefeated Barnard School football team topped Fieldston, 19 to 13, yesterday on the loser's field in a close struggle.

What is now happening to the proceeds of the social security taxes substantiates the predictions of the harshest critics of the reserve fund provisions of the Social Security Act. It was pointed out when that act was passed that the gigantic reserve fund of $47,000,000,000 contemplated by 1980 would constitute simply a gigantic delusion.
Colonel James Goold Warren, a retired member of the United States Army Engineers Corps, died at his home here today after an illness of a week. He was 79 years old.
Lewis K. Rockefeller, Republican, of Hudson, defeated Mrs. Nancy Schoonmaker, Democrat, of Woodstock for election as Representative in Congress from the Twentyseventh district today.

Conversations on the eve of the assembly of the Nine-Power treaty conference here have not yet brought into focus any plan of action toward restoring peace in the Far East. The prospect is that the conference will meet tomorrow without any plan, hoping to evolve one as the deliberations proceed.

War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha exploded rumors that the famous Royal Scots Greys would be mechanized in the House of Commons today as Scottish Conservative members and many others were prepared to launch a spirited attack if the Minister's answer upheld the report.

Tammany Hall was swept out of the office of the New York County district attorney yesterday for the first time in twenty years. In a smahing victory that he took to be a mandate for "decent government," 35-year-old Thomas E. Dewey was elected bya majority of 108,823 votes.

President Roosevelt has approved the application of Brig. Gen. George B. Pillsbury, Assistant Chief of Engineers, for retirement, effective Dec. 31, 1937, it was announced today by the War Department. He has received leave of absence pending retirement.

While Chief Boston, Harvard's quarterback, was in togs for the Crimson's secret practice session today and worked in the offensive drill, Cliff Wilson was the blocking back when Dick Harlownatned the team that seems most likely to start against the Army here Saturday.
Sir Geoffrey Latham Corbett, adviser to the Egyptian Ministry of Commerce and Industry, died today. He was 56 years old.
Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin was reported improving at the United States Government Hospital here today from a severe attack of influenza.

Two men, accused by police of having defrauded small property owners of more than a half million dollars in real estate deals during the last six years, were held for nearing on Nov. 10 on a charge of grand larceny when they were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Charles Solomon in Felony Court, brooklyn.
The National Hockey League's All-Stars defeated a combined team of Montreal Canadiens and Maroons tonight, 6--5, in the Howie Morenz benefit game.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Samuel Laufbahn, if he would criticize the Administration's economic policy, should state that policy fairly. The problem the Administration is trying to solve might be stated thus: Times are not as good as we should like them to be.
The Consolidated Royal Chemical Corporation, Chicago, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 300,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.

A large assemblage of friends of the late Mrs. Lewis E. Lawes, wife of the warden of Sing Sing, who died Saturday night from injuries suffered in an accidental fall, paid tribute to her today at her funeral.
