Only five nativeborn Americans failed to respond to their government's call to evacuate Majorca when the Spanish civil war broke out. They are still here. There are six in Iviza, as well as approximately seventy Puerto Ricans with United States passports. All of these are safe and sound.

Hemp's Skippy Girl, an open-marked, heavy-type beagle, captured the 15inch all-age bitch event as the annual Fall field trials of the Long Island Beagle Club ended today. Skippy Girl, owned by Art Jungblot of Hempstead, was directed by Mrs. Jungblot.

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto, sitting in Brooklyn Traffic Court, ruled yesterday that there was sufficient cause of action in the complaint of Thomas F. Mulhern, circulation manager of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, against Isidore Kaufman and John Deegan, striking employes, charging them with conspiracy.

Based on present indications, the United Parcel Service plans for no particular increase in the number of packages, handled for local Christmas retail trade, an official of the service reported yesterday. He said that, while the current plans are subject to change, the delivery organization expects a volume of Christmas trade about on a par with last year.

After several weeks of manoeuyring by both sides, Warners have at last approached James Cagney, reeking a settlement of their tworear fight. It has been learned that studio representatives met the actor a few days ago and a peace agreement was broached by which Cagney would return to the lot for two films a year, with the privilege of making one for another lot each season.

Loans on securities to member firms decreased $313,497,644 in October, it was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The loan total at the end of October was $725,622,872, compared to $1,039,120,516 at the close of September.

William C. Dodge, the District Attorney who escaped the FusionAmerican Labor party avalanche election day because Tammany refused to renominate him, announced yesterday that, on the expiration of his four-year term on Dec. 31, he will return to private practice.

The first graduating class of Far Rockaway High School returned to the institution at Oceancrest Avenue and Beach Twenty-fifth Street, Queens, yesterday-morning for exercises marking the fortieth anniversary.

Maids, housemen and service elevator operators employed in the Hotel Taft, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first Street, were called out on strike yesterday by Local 32-A of the Building Service Employee International Union, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

The marriage of Mrs. Hope Bush Dillon, daughter of Mrs. Howard Bush of Ardsley-on-Hudson and of the late Francis D. Beard, to John Courtney Haddock of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., took place yesterday afternoon in the bride's home at 21 East Ninetieth Street. The Right Rev.
The Fatherland Front, Austria's only legal political organization, announced tonight that thousands of Socialists had joined the party before memberships closed Nov. 1.
George S. Forbes died today after suffering a heart attack on the wheat pit floor of the Chicago Board of Trade. He was 57 years old.

Drastic legislation for the regulation, if the elimination, of railroad holding companies was hinted today at the hearing before the Interstate Commerce Committee of the Senate now investigating the financial structures of the rail systems.

In the twelve years since its establishment in 1925 the International Labor Defense has defended more than 64,000 men and women and has won the liberation without jail sentence of 91 per cent of that number, according to a summary made public yesterday at the organization's national office, 80 East Eleventh Street.

It is conceivable that "we might have a Supreme Court of stooges who would sustain anything the Executive did," Dorothy Thompson, writer, told the League for Political Education yesterday in the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street.

Bronko Nagurski, the Chicago Bears' powerhouse, used football tactics to score a victory over Chief Little Wolf in the feature finish wrestling match at the Hippodrome last night before a crowd of 3,000. Bronko, weighing 230, dropped the 210-pound Chief with a flying tackle and pinned him with a body slam in 23:20.

The American Newspaper Guild charged, in a complaint filed at the regional offices of the National Labor Relations Board yesterday, that The Associated Press had refused to engage in collective bargaining "within the meaning of the National Labor Relations Act," despite an NLRB decision certifying the guild as the bargaining agent for the 350 editorial employes in the New York office of the newsgathering organization.
A bigger election than the one we have just been through is scheduled for next month in Soviet Russia.

The Insurgent authorities in Algeciras recently jailed more than fifty Insurgent coast guards, carabineers, and Civil Guards for allegedly having been involved in the escape from that city of hundreds of government supporters.

F. Trubee Davison, president of the American Museum of Natural History, gave a dinner last night at the museum, 15 West Seventyseventh Street, for Dr. Leonard C. Sanford, who has assisted for many years in expanding the bird collections there.

Freddie Steele yesterday received the permission of the New York State Athletic Commission to withdraw from his bout with Fred Apostoli; whom he had been scheduled to meet at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 12.
This Beaver County community and home of a Jones Laughlin steel plant, which had only eight registered Democrats until four years ago, elected a Democratic slate "all down the line" yesterday.

Despite the fact that the Federal Housing Administration in New York has approved mortgage insurance on thousands of homes during the past three years, it has yet to pay its first claim on this insurance, a study of the State records shows.
The Society for Advancement of Young Musicians, Raphael Bronstein, director, has been formed for the purpose of providing organized aid for debutantes.

Mrs. Helen Meher Herbert sued today to divorce Clifford V. Herbert, son of Victor Herbert. She charged he associated with other women; that he was surly and abusive and told her that he no longer loved her.

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, and several other members arrived in Chicago today for the committee's session Friday, at which the proposal for a conference of the party in 1938 to discuss and take a position on national issues will be acted upon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We now know officially that-a billion dollars has been collected by the social security tax during 1937 and that it has already been spent. Bonds for that sum have been put away, which will draw interest.

The Wesleyan squad was given a long workout today in preparation for the Williams game here Saturday, finishing under arc lights. Coach Blott gave the first-string men a thorough drill in blocking, which was one of the weak points against Trinity.

The Harvard varsity team lined up for its signal drill today with three players in the backfield who did not start at Princeton. The absentees were Chief Boston, whose chances of playing against the cadets are slight; Fullback Vernon Struck and Right Half Torbert Macdonald.

ADAMS--Julia Elder, on Tuesday, Nov. 2, daughter of the late Charles W. Adams and Lily Taylor Adams Bachman, and granddaughter of the late Douglas Taylor. Funeral service on Friday, Nov. 5, at 2 P. M., at the residence of her aunt, Miss Clara Taylor, Hotel Bolivar, 230 Central Park West. It is earnestly requested that no flowers be sent.

The entire fourth floor of 9 Rockefeller Plaza, in Rockefeller Center, has been leased by the National Association of Manufacturers of the United States, Inc., for use as its national headquarters and executive offices.

The State Department made pubic 'today the following text of the speech of Norman H. Davis, American delegate, at the opening of the NinePower Conference at Brussels: We have come to this conference to collaborate in efforts toward an objective for which all peoples and all governments should strive. That objective is peace.

New York University's football forces continued their live tackling work at Ohio Field yesterday, going through a strenuous three-hour practice in preparation for the game with Lehigh at the Yankee Stadium on Saturday. Coach Mal Stevens made no secret of his dissatisfaction with the Violet's tackling in the last two games, and most of his attention was devoted to that phase.

The government issued a decree today by which it takes over the operation of the British-owned Central Cordoba Railroad for one year, within which period it is expected that Congress will pass the government's bill for the purchase of the line.

Rockwell Kent, who declares that he has received only $600 of the $3,000 for which he agreed to paint two murals that now decorate the halls of the Postoffice Department Building in Washington, threatened yesterday to sue the Treasury Department if it allowed another artist to delete his independence inscription from one of the murals without first paying him the $2,400 balance.
Chrysler Corporation completed its one-millionth car today for the year 1937, thereby bettering its 1936 record by six weeks.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company plans to open a branch office in the City of London about March 1, next, under the authorization granted to it recently by the State Banking Department, it was learned yesterday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered a hearing today on the complaint of Representative Arthur W. Mitchell of Chicago that he was compelled, as a Negro, to ride in a second-class car, although he held a first-class ticket..
The Social Security Board granted $4,335,914 today to New York for public assistance from Oct. 1 to Dec. 1.

Two armed thugs, who held up and robbed Henry L. Ward, treasurer of James Gray, Inc., multigraphers, of a $5,500 payroll at 11 A. M. yesterday, made certain of their escape by forcing their victim to climb to the roof of a four-story tenement house at 210 East Fortyfifth Street. a few doors from his office at 216.

Shoe retailers were advised to anticipate "firm holiday business" and a good year in 1938, and to see that they have a voice in- government, by Herbert Marcus, president of Neiman-Marcus Company, Dallas, at a luncheon sponsored by the Shoe Fashion Guild of America, Inc., at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday on the closing day of the Spring showing of quality shoes.

John Steiger, market checker in Tulsa, Okla., for Platt's Oilgram, a trade publication, testified today in Federal Court here that he did not consider buying of independent gasoline by major companies in 1935 and 1936 as "pool" or "program" buying.
The faculty of American University voted down today the proposal of Football Coach Gus Welch to have a co-ed kick for points after touchdowns by his team.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 1: COMMANDER Sauer, E. P., to duty as officer in charge, Naval Recruiting Station, Los Angeles, Calif.
John Charles Thomas, the singer, claims as a business expense allowance $16,776 he said it cost him to operate his yacht in 1934.
It cannot be said that Leonard Shure, who gave a piano recital at Town Hall last night, lived up to the expectations aroused by him at his previous appearance in this city.
Anglo-American trade treaty preliminaries are being "actively pursued on both sides of the Atlantic" and "to the satisfaction of both sides so far," informed sources asserted tonight.

The American Labor party through Alex Rose, its State executive secretary, sent a telegram yesterday to President Roosevelt, reaffirming its loyalty to him and asserting that New York was the greatest New Deal stronghold in the nation and the American Labor party was still the stanchest adherent of the President's policies.

A Harlem investment deal was announced yesterday when Arthur L. Dryfoos, as broker, bought for a client the five-story double flat on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 221 West 120th Street from the estate of Carrie Sanders. The building has two five-room apartments on a floor and was renovated recently to comply with the Multiple Dwelling Law.
Captain George Eyston halted a distance run at 6:59 P. M. (Pacific standard time) tonight after capturing three major world speed records-3,000 kilometers, 12 hours and 2,000 miles.

An American Arbitration Association board has unanimously disallowed a claim by Wallace Waite, who charged that his dramatization of "Journeyman," Erskine Caldwell's novel, was plagiarized by Alfred R. Hayes and Leon Alexander.

Mrs. Paul D. Cravath gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 903 Park Avenue, later taking her guests to Mrs. Benjamin P. Watson's exhibition of paintings at the Arden Gallery. In her party were Mrs. Thomas T. Gaunt, Mrs. William Henry Harrison, Mrs. Ethelbert Nevin, Mrs. Thomas Bloodgood Peck, Mrs. Eldon Bisbee, Mrs. Frederic Van Lennep and Mrs. Herbert Noble.
Sanctity, owned by Mrs. C. C. Winters, today gained a three-length victory in the Center Harbor Handicap at Rockingham Park, returning $9.10, $4.70 and $3.30 for $2 across the board.

A vital link in the trans-Pacific airline, the China air services of the National Aviation Corporation, is being restored two weeks hence with the ineuguration of a new airline from Chungking by way of Kweiyang and Kweilin to Hong Kong.
Mr. and Mrs. Francis Rogers entertained yesterday with a luncheon at the Soldiers and Sailors Club, 283 Lexington Avenue; for Brig. Gen. Perry L. Miles, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Miles.

With the season approaching the climactic weeks, the usual free-forall selections of all-America teams are being put into form and the usual complaints are being heard. There are, for instance, a large number of backs and only a few guards. That has long been a complaint of guards-that the spotlight fell on the back after the guard had rubbed his nose in the earth preparing the way for him.
Despite the natural preoccupation on international affairs in the British press, more space has been given to the New York City election than ever before.

Plans for a tall apartment house in the Chelsea section to accommodate 207 families were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Twentieth Street. The site includes 160 to 164 Seventh Avenue and 200 to 206 West Twentieth Street, a plot of about 12,000 square feet, and was bought by H. A. Hyman, Inc., from the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had closed its case against the Shefford Cheese Company, Inc., Syracuse, which had been charged with price discrimination.

A published appeal in two Willes-Barre newspapers called upon Governor Earle and county and city officials tonight "to preserve law and order" while the presses of The Wilkes-Barre ReCord, a morning paper, remained silent because of an American Newspaper Guild strike.

Germany is at work in laborastories and factories fabricating products to take the place of substances which the rest of the world hesitates to sell to her, according to Karl Lindemann, chairman of the board of the North German Lloyd Line.

Owen J. C. Norem, recently appointed United States Minister to Lithuania, sailed for Europe yesterday on the Manhattan. He was accompanied by Mrs. Norem and their three children, Donna, 9; Evelyn, 4, and Owen Andrew, 7. Mr. Norem, who is 35, is a native of Sioux City, Iowa.

Dr. Carolyn Silbermann, daughter of Parole Commissioner and Mrs. Milton Silbermann of the Bronx, was married here last night at Essex House to Dr. Joseph Szilagyi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Szilagyi of this city, by the Rev. Dr. William F. Rosenblum.

The forces of retributive Justice were at work on University "Field and for the first time within recent memory Princeton's scrub elevens, bolstered by the third-string backfield, soundly trounced the two varsity units in a scrimmage approximating game conditions today.

Mrs. Loring Robertson Gale of this place and Riverdale-on-Hudson in New York and her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Reynolds Knapp of Mount Kisco, N. Y., entertained with a dinner at The Inn here tonight for Mrs. William J. Parry and Loring Robertson Gale, who will be married here tomorrow at noon.

Ardie Bernfield is now in charge of leasing, sales and management in the midtown area for Midtown Realty Company. The sixteen-family apartment at 410 East Seventy-eighth Street is fully rented, according to Proops Management, Inc., agents.
The Consolidated Royal Chemical Corporation, Chicago, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 300,000 shares of $1 par value common stock.

The twenty-second annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers, held this year in conjunction with a representative group of contemporary Swedish prints, opened with a preview yesterday afternoon in the top-floor galleries of Maison Francaise, Rockefeller Center.

After having been actively engaged in theatre management for nearly thirty years, Winthrop Ames retired in 1932. His failing health made it impossible for him to continue at work. Although five years' absence had given Broadway a chance to grow accustomed to his absence, his death is no more tolerable on that account.
Mr. and Mrs. William Ewing will give a dinner dance on Thanksgiving night in the main ballroom of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Jessie V. Ewing.

Deposits of many Jewish merchants here, amounting to about $500,000, were confiscated today from various banks by the Free City's police. They explained that it was being done to prevent the flight of Jewish capital.

Miss Elizabeth Blanche Wilmot, last surviving member of a Loyalist family which played a major role in the political life of New Brunswick before and after confederation, died last night at the home of her nephew, R. D. W. Huhbbard. in Burton. near here.
Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation announced today that it had bought 542 carloads of grapes in Michigan, New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

The shipment of another $6,600,000 of gold from Japan was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. One of a new series of engagements which began about ten days ago, this latest gold transfer from Japan makes the total sent here from that country since the middle of last March $210.600.000.

Fifty years put into city service by Arthur S. Tuttle, former chief engineer of the Board of Estimate, were recognized' by Mayor La Guardia yesterday when he gave the veteran a Distinguished Service Certificate at City Hall.

The Board of Tax Appeals agreed today to hear arguments in New York City on collection of more than $700,000 additional income taxes from Ed Wynn and the late Arthur Brisbane. No date for the hearing was set.

Yale's hardest contact practice of the week was ordered by Coach Raymond (Ducky) Pond today. However, long runs and scoring were eliminated as the Elis endeavored to perfect their timing and position play.
Stocks weakened and closed heavy, with losses of l to 6 points; turnover, 1,734,140 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other groups lower, with rails weakest; transactions, $8,967,450.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st Grade James W. Munson, Engine 1, died Nov. 1. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 471 Central Park West, Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M., Thursday, Nov. 4. Interment at St. John's Cemetery.

The State of Kentucky will receive bids on Nov. 23 for a new issue of $915,000 Bridge Project No. 13 bonds. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per -cent. The bonds will be dated Dec. 1, 1937, and due Jan. 1, 1953, but at the option of the State may be called for redemption in 1940, 41, 42, 43 and 44.

MORNING EVENTS Class 21, Hackney Stallions and Fillies, 2Year-Olds-First, Miss E. Gwen Martin's b. s. Killearn Presto. Class 46, Hackney Pony Stallions, Mares and Geldings, 3-Year-Olds-First, Miss Judy King's b. g. Highland Cardinal; second, Dicksfield Farm's br. m. Stonehedge Temptation.
Advances in trans-Atlantic freight rates within the jurisdiction of the Canadian Freight Conferences will go into effect on Jan. 1, W. C. Sproule, secretary of the conferences, announced today.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced today that $75,000,000 had been made available to the Commodity Credit Corporation for loans on corn at the rate of 50 cents a bushel for corn with a moisture content not in excess of 14% per cent.

More detailed returns yesterday showed that the Republicans won a strong majority of delegates to next April's constitutional convention in Tuesday's election. They elected 92 or 95 of the 168 delegates, including eight of the fifteen delegates at large.

KEYSTONE REFRIGERATOR EXCHANGE, INC., 735 Broadway-By Equity Advertising Agency, Inc., for $718; Mantell Hardware Corp., $17; Herman Holding Corp., $300. Wilson Lee Cannon was appointed receiver under $1,000 bond by Judge Goddard.

The Chicago Stock Exchange has worked out a tentative plan for supplementing its regular memberships with associate memberships, Virgil C. Webster chairman of the committee on public relations, disclosed tonight.

A resolution condemning the impending visit of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor to this country with the announced purpose of studying labor conditions was adopted unanimously here tonight by the Baltimore Federation of Labor, a unit of the American Federation of Labor.

Henry M. Robinson, banker, economist and confidant of Presidents, died today at the age of 69 as the result of a spinal injury suffered last July. Mr. Robinson died in the Huntington Memorial Hospital, a new philanthropic institution, of which he was board president.

Navy's soccer team made it three straight today by winning from Gettysburg, 2 to 1. All the goals were shot in the first half. Kilpatrick of Navy scored the only point of the first quarter, and Mizell tallied for Gettysburg and Kelly for Navy in the second.

Parents kept twenty-three pupils of the Willard School from their classes today in a move to bring about "adequate" police protection at a street intersection where Eugene Morris, 6, was killed Oct. 21.

Further reductions were made In the price of gasoline yesterday. In the Middle West, the Standard Oil Company of Indiana made a cut of three-tenths of a cent a gallon on all grades of gasoline in tankwagon delivery throughout most of its territory.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order revoking the registration as broker or dealer in the over-the-counter market of William A. Bachrach,
DIVIDED WE STAND, by Walter Prescott Webb. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) An interpretation of American society. I FIND AUSTRALIA, by William Hatfield. (Oxford, $3.) Experiences in the Antipodes.

War Admiral, 3-year-old champion, scored his eighth straight victory of the year today by capturing the $7,500 added Pimlico Special. His earnings now total $166,500, the largest credited to any American thoroughbred in 1937.

George and Willis Duvalier, brothers, were sentenced today to be hanged after a jury that deliberated twenty minutes had found them guilty of murder in connection with disorders on Great Inagua Island in August.
The 1938 session of the Legislature will be one of special significance in the light of current political trends, a final count upon Tuesday's election indicated yesterday.

Notre Dame tested its offense against Pittsburgh's defense in a twenty-five-minute scrimmage on Cartier Field today. Every member of the squad was on hand for practice and all saw action as Coach Layden primed the varsity for the eleventh game in Notre Dame's football series with Pittsburgh.

Chancellor Hitler has issued orders protesting against distortion of his speeches in books and pamphlets published here and providing that in the future such publications must be submitted in advance to his secretariat.

If you have ever tramped the mountains in snow and rain for ten hours, toting a rifle that gains in weight at the rate of about two pounds an hour, and maintaining a constant lookout for a deer, only to see nothing but does, you know how the writer feels tonight.
Mrs. Jane Fiske Schermerhorn, widow of Richard Schermerhorn, died yesterday in the home at 183 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, where she had lived for more than fifty years. Her age was 86.
THE opening of the Dizzy Dean filling station in Bradenton, Fla., indicates that Dizzy is getting smarter. He's selling gas now. He was giving it away for years.

The thirteenth game of the match for the chess championship of the world between Dr. Max Euwe of Amasterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris was opened tonight at the Krasnapolsky Restaurant, with the former in charge of the white pieces. Once again Dr. Alekhine resorted to the Slav defense.
The eligibility of Associate Justice Black to act as a member of the Supreme Court in a case affecting the seizure of telegrams was challenged tonight by three Florida oil companies.
Apparently assured of control of the coming General Assembly, Kentucky Democrats stretched their lead over Republican opponents today as counting of ballots in yesterday's election continued.
Dr. Charles Demarest Kline, physician, died today at his home here of a heart ailment in his seventy-first year.

Coach Wilder Tasker sent Rutgers's second and third-string elevens against one another in a two-hour session today. Stressing passing, which probably will figure greatly in the Scarlet attack against Lafayette at Easton, Pa., Saturday, the coach had Bill Tranavitch and Herman Greif, halfbacks, doing most of the tossing. Scrimmage against the freshmen will wind up preparations for the Leopards tomorrow.
Two salaries of almost $100,000 topped a list of compensations reported today by corporations to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Directors of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., declared yesterday a special dividend of 30 cents a share on its capital stock. The dividend will bring total distribution this year to 80 cents a share, compared with 70 cents in 1936.

Bonds were unable to make any headway yesterday and in sympathy with the share list moved generally lower, although trading on the New York Stock Exchange was in larger volume than on Monday. Total sales were $8,967,450, compared to $5,439,100 on Monday.

Woman's Rposevelt Memorial Association, Town Hall, 11 A. M. "What May Be Expected of a 5-Year-Old Child," Mrs. Rustin McIntosh. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Mohammedan Pottery," Mable Harrison Duncan, 11 A. M.; "English Furniture: Elizabeth to James II," Ethelwyn Bradish, noon; the medieval collection (general tour), 2 P. M.

Amsterdam Ave, n e cor of 138th St, 199.4x 143; to 4-story school; College of the City of New York. Convent Ave and 139th St, owner; Dr. Howard G. Bohlin, engineer; cost $94,000. Broadway, 32-4; to 18-story offices and stores; Seamen's Bank for Savings, 74 Wall St, owner; Scott Prescott, architects; cost $25,000.

Travelers arriving from Honduras reported today that that country had reinforced its frontier garrisons at Dani, El Paraiso and Las Mercedes with 1,000 well-armed soldiers. This is in the region where United States Marines pursued the late General Agusto' Sandino, rebel chieftain, for five years.
ANGEL. and adaptation of the play by Melchior Lengyel: screen play by Samson Raphaelson; directed and produced by Ernst Lubitsch for Paramount. At the Paramount.
In one of the most active opening sessions in years, coffee futures broke yesterday the 1-cent limit permissible in a day's trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange here.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe yesterday approved settlement of suits filed in 1934 in Supreme Court against former officers and directors of the Paramount-Publix Corporation, now known as Paramount Pictures Corporation.

In sympathy with weakness in the outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange broke more than $1 a bale yesterday to end with losses of 9 to 22 points. Pressure on the December, which developed on Monday, ran that month 15 points under the July with final quotations the lowest closing figures of the season.

The word politician, once respectable, long ago fell into disrepute. If the adjective "professional" is placed before it the phrase becomes positively damning. Nevertheless, in the fine old original sense of the word, we elected a number of professional politicians on Tuesday.

The New York State Federal Theatre Project will present "Coriolanus" at the Theatre of the Four Seasons, Roslyn, L. I., tonight and tomorrow and Saturday evenings. "Pygmalion" will be offered on Thursday and Friday of next week, and "Coriolanus" again on Nov. 12 and 13.

The executive committee of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company called yesterday for redemption on Jan. 3, 1938, at par and accrued interest, $12,923,000 of the company's ten-year 41/2 per cent convertible debentures due July 1, 1939.

Christopher St, s w cor of Bleecker St, 97.11x4Oxirreg; Samuel A. Sherman et al to Shergill Holding Corp, 1,440 Broadway, c/o J. A. Gilman ($2). 31st St, 215 E, 18.9x98.9: 215 E 31st St Corp to Craigsmoor Realty Corp, 441 Lexington Ave; mtg $28,583 ($2.50).

Brokers find no fault with the Securities and Exchange Commission's determination to collect statistics on odd-lot purchases and sales, adopting the tolerant position that a man who likes to collect figures deserves the same consideration as the collector of postage stamps.

Winthrop Ames, for more than a quarter of a century an internationally known figure in the theatrical world, died here early today at the Deaconess Hospital. He had been ill for many months and a relapse resulting in pneumonia was the immediate cause of death He was 66 years old.

Dissatisfaction of a C. I. O. government workers' union with the Secretary of Labor's dealings with the union has led to a conference between Miss Perkins and union leaders which is expected to formulate policies as to the relationship between Federal administrators and employe organizations throughout the country.

Twelve per cent of the undergraduates at Wellesley College are daughters of Wellesley alumnae and these "Wellesley granddaughters" will be guests at a tea and reception sponsored by the Alumnae Association tomorrow afternoon in Green Hall. President Mildred H. McAfee will be in the receiving line.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 2, unless specified: At Guantanamo Bay: Nokomis, Owl. Port Townsend to Mare Island Yard: Oglala, Preble, Pruitt, Sicard, Tracy. Antares, Coco Solo to Pensacola, Nov. 3. Bushnell. San Pedro to San Diego.

For a stated consideration of $30,000 the East River Savings Bank sold to the Froeb Corp, William J. Byrne. president, the tenement at 783 Amsterdam Ave, taking back a purchase money mortgage for $28,000, due in seven years at 3 to 4 per cent.
Effective tomorrow, members of the Toronto Stock Exchange are authorized by the Exchange to reduce margin requirements.

Theodore A. Kruse, formerly in the automobile insurance field, died in the Lenox Hill Hospital on Tuesday after a short illness. Mr. Kruse, who formerly resided at 30 Chelsea Place, East Orange, N. J., had been vice president of Appleton Cox., Inc., until his retirement in 1932. He had been connected with this firm for thirty years.

Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Oct. 23 amounted to 306,556,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the figures of the previous week, this total represents a net decline of 1,341,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,313,000 and 28,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

Secret Service operatives seized a counterfeiting plant, nearly $30,000 in spurious Federal Reserve Bank notes and arrested two men in a raid today on an isolated house near Monaca, in the Western Pennsylvania hills.

Count of the more than 2,000,000 ballots cast by the voters of the city for the members of the new City Council was begun yesterday in an armory in each of the five boroughs by a special corps of canvassers.

A British polo team to invade Jamaica in February was named today by the Hurlingham Club. Lord Louis Mountbatten, a cousin of King George, will captain the team, the first ever to visit the West Indian Island.

Another big treason case in which forty-seven persons accused of varying counterrevolutionary crimes, including two vain attempts to assassinate Joseph Stalin, is under way in Sukhum, in Stalin's own native Georgia.

There was an unusual number of transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders in September, when security values were failing sharply, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
The French are greatly upset by the British Government's decision to station a commercial attache at General Francisco Franco's seat of government.

Theodore G. Montague, a vice president and director of the Borden Company, was elected yesterday president of the company and chairman of the executive and advisory committees to succeed Arthur W. Milburn, who died in Germany on Oct 11.

141st St. 457 to 461 E (9-2286); De Metrovich Realty Corp to Samuel P. Watson, 420 E 140th St; Installments, 41/2 to 5 per cent: $12,000. Bainbridge Ave, 3.510 (12-3344): 3,510 Bainbridge Avenue Realty Corp to Sarah L. Barg. 485 Central Park W; installments, 6 per cent: S17,000.
Vigorously defending business against the charge of being reactionary, Percy C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade, as vigorously assailed New Deal measures yesterday.

The annual book-of-the-year exhibit of the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park, opened last night with the first of four authors' nights. The exhibit includes 2,000 books printed this year by ninety publishers.

A new plan for non-occupational disability benefits for hourly wage le workers in all plants of the General Foods Corporation, effective Nov. was announced here today by Harry W. Brown, manager of General Foods-Post Products Division (Postum). Without cost to.the employes, Mr. Brown said, they will so be allowed two weeks off work M with pay each year.

Neville Miller, Mayor of Louisville, Ky., who attained national prominence last Winter in flood relief work in the Ohio Valley, has been appointed assistant to the president of Princeton University, it was announced today by Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, the president.

Funeral services for Mrs. Michael H. Larkin, mother of Dr. John F. Larkin, Kingston physician, and the Rev. Michael J. Larkin of New Rochelle, who died Sunday, were held here today in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.
The scene is a stadium located in the borough of Manhattan, in the City of New York. Entering, you notice a few scantily attired youngsters fooling around with lacrosse sticks.

The Brooklyn College football team devoted a strenuous practice yesterday to offensive tactics for the game with the Trenton Teachers at the latter's home field Saturday. Coach Lou Oshins sent his forces through a three-hour session to perfect new formations which start from the Kingsmen's usual single-wing attack.
Trevor Randulph Owen, father of the Most Rev. D. T. Owen, Anglican Primate of Canada, died of pneumonia at his home here today. His age was 90.

The Duchesse de Richelieu, Countess Pecorini, Mrs. Hamilton Paine, Mrs. H. Monnet, Judge and Mrs. Thomas Coulter, Alfred Partridge Klots, Mrs. Watts Stevens, Henri Lanson, Abbe C. Ernest Dimnet, Mr. and Mrs. Jose Luccioni are due today from Havre via Southampton in the French line motorship Lafayette.

As a sequel to "The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas," Random House will publish early in December Gertrude Stein's "Everybody's Autobiography." Part of this personal narrative concerns Miss Stein's visit to the United States in 1934.

Tobacco dealers having for sale mixtures of tobacco in unstamped containers were warned today by the Internal Revenue Bureau that this is a violation of the law even though the mixtures are prepared from packages stamped tax paid.

The possibility of a recount in the Gubernatorial election in New Jersey loomed this afternoon as backers of the Rev. Lester H. Clee, Republican nominee, who was apparently defeated by Senator Moore by 44,630, conferred for several hours.

A marked reduction in prices received for the current crop of cotton and an indicated record world supply of 50,800,000 bales may result in some reduction in foreign acreage and production of cotton in the 1938-39 season regardless of any effect that the soil-conservation program may have on production in this country, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today.

The Manhattan football team closed its heavy preparations for Saturday's game with Detroit at Ebbets Field by holding a brief scrimmage in which all phases of the Jasper offensive were tested at Innisfail Park yesterday. Receiving principal attention were the passing plays built around Vic Fusia, left halfback, which consistently pierced the defense set up by the freshmen.

Walton Ave, (11-2853), w s 167 s of E Tremont Ave, 98x135; Hillcrest Realty Corp to I. A. T. Realty Corp, 2, 306 Walton Ave. Kingsbridge Terrace, 2,738, (12-3253); Joseph I. Boylan, referee, to Carrie Haas, 1.167 Clay Ave. Bainbridge Ave, (12-3344(. n e cor of E Gun Hill Rd. 125x105; Sarah L. Barg to 3,510 Bainbridge Ave Realty Corp, 116 Mosholu Pkway S; mtg. $213,000.

The name of Judge Samuel Seabury was not flashed in lights or shouted in top headlines this week. He was not running for any office. Yet without the cornerstone which he so well and truly laid, the edifice of good governmeant which we now see rearing its sturdy walls might not have been built.

The Montclair A. C. annexed its second triumph in the Metropolitan League interclub Class A squash tennis matches last night by conquering the Crescent A. C. team at the Brooklyn clubhouse courts, 4 to 1.

The marriage of Miss Gwendolyn Marie Jacobsen of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert Jacobsen of Lincoln, Neb., to Reginald Sims, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Sims of New Port Richey, Fla., took place yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration.
The interior of a two-story brick apartment house at 405 Magnolia Boulevard was destroyed by fire about 9 o'clock tonight, leaving fifteen families homeless. The cause of the fire is undetermined.

James Cox -Brady, son of the late James Cox Brady Sr., who was largely responsible for interesting Walter P. Chrysler in the reorganization of the Maxwell Motor Corporation about twelve years ago, out of which the Chrysler Corporation was born, has been elected a director of the Chrysler Corporation.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

September receipts of $6,584,268.95 in gasoline taxes for August sales were reported today by Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, who noted an unusually heavy use of motor vehicles in August as well as July.

Wesleyan's undefeated cross-country team will meet the Coast Guard Academy here Friday and then will move on to Williamstown Nov. 13 to compete against Amherst and Williams in the Little Three triangular meet.

De luxe editions of the three principal speeches President Roosevelt made on his good-will tour of South America last year have been presented to the heads of the American Republics by the Chief Executive.
The State won one suit against the Standard Oil Company of Louisiana for back taxes of $142,915 today and pressed another one for $750,000.
WALTER PRESCOTT WEBB'S new book has a curious, arresting and, to my mind, misleading thesis-that one section of the United States is devitalizing the other two.

The French Canadian Province of Quebec has banned "The Life of Emile Zola," the American film which stars Paul Muni as the great French author and leader of the fight for the reinstatement of Captain Dreyfus.

Professor Roswell P. Angier, chairman of the Department of Psychology, has been appointed associate dean of the Graduate School of Yale University. Professor Angier, for many years secretary of the Graduate School faculty, was recently appointed by President Seymour as a member of the Committee on Educational Planning.

Charles A. Schneider, Tammany leader of the Eighth Assembly District, who was attacked in the last week of the campaign by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey and Commissioner of Accounts Paul Blanshard, resigned late yesterday as an assistant attorney general.

Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 2: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Brown, S. E., Med. Corps, Denver, Colo., to Hawaiian Dept., to sail from San Francisco about March 5.

Official launching by the Hearn Department Stores, Inc., of its new bureau of standards was hailed by more than thirty representatives of leading women's clubs and consumer organizations at a meeting held yesterday afternoon in the store restaurant. Mrs. William Dick Sporborg, chairman of the Women's National Exposition, congratulated the store for its "progressive step" as an aid "to hundreds of thousands of consumers."

" Orchids on Your Budget" will be the theme of the third annual Consumers' Mart sponsored by the American Woman's Association, to "The be held Nov. 18 and 19 at the country American Woman's Club, 353 West balance Fifty-seventh Street. From 5,000to out of 7,000 New York business women credit and suburban club women are ex- gets to pected to attend.
Eighty foreigners, mostly Spaniards, Italians and Germans, involved in Paris bomb explosions, the Brest attack on a submarine and other acts of terrorism, were ordered e pelled from France today..
Mrs. Frederick A. Ogg, active for years in city and State affairs, died of pneumonia here this afternoon. Her husband is a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin.

Construction of a new boathouse for crews competing in the annual intercollegiate rowing regatta on the Hudson River was assured today with announcement that the Common Council had included a $7,000 appropriation for the project in the 1928 city budget.

Reversing a previous decision, Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, has ruled that employes of the general organizations of New York City high schools are exempt from provisions of the Social Security Act, James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education and chairman of its law committee, announced yesterday.
John Bimson, who retired as chief of the Paterson Police Department in 1917, died last night at' his home, 140 Jersey Street, at the age of 92. He had been ill for some time. Mr.

Major Albert Bond Lambert, one of Charles. A. Lindbergh's backers preparatory to his flight to Paris ten years ago, said tonight that he had received a letter from Colonel Lindbergh in which "he expressed a desire to come back to- St. Louis-and very soon."

Republican drive aimed at preventing the Earle administration, for the second time in two years, from "tinkering ,with the Constitution" apparently was successful at the polls in Pennsylvania yesterday.
Twentynine University of Detroit football players will entrain tomorrow morning for New York, but Halfback Andy Farkas will not be among them.
Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland took undisputed hold of second place in the world pocket billiard championship tonight by defeating George Kelly of Philadelphia, 125 to 64, in eleven innings.
Albert J. Hartley, for forty years superintendent of Elsinore, the former Edward R. Ladew estate on Hempstead Harbor, died last night at his home after a short illness. His age was 77.

The defense in the murder trial of Anna Marie Hahn rested today, relying on three witnesses to save from a State's demand of death in the electric chair the woman who is charged with the murder-by-poison of 78-year-old Jacob Wagner.

D. Hayes Murphy, president and treasurer of the Wiremold Company, Hartford, Conn., is the new presldent of the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association. He was elected last week in Chicago by the board of governors.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. William Paton of this city for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth F. Paton to Walter F. Lindsley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Lindsley of Hillside.

Mrs. Mary Kirk Raffray, a close friend of the present Duchess of Windsor, is in Nevada, supposedly to establish residence for a divorce. Mrs. Raffray came to the State five weeks ago and has been making her home at a ranch south of here.

The Group Theatre swings back into action this evening at the Belasco, where it will give the first performance of "Golden Boy," by its favorite playwright, Clifford Odets work to be sponsored by the a bow toward the career of Lou Ambers, the play will be the fifth Odets work to be sponsored by the group.

Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, fiscal agents for Kingdom of Bulgaria 71/2 per cent Stabilization Loan of 1928, announced yesterday that coupons of dollar bonds of this loan would be paid on or after Nov. 15 at the rate of $12.19 for the $37.50 coupon and $6.09 for the $18.75 coupon in full settlement for and against surrender of the coupons.
Edward J. Maguire, vice president of the First National Bank of Mount Vernon, died here today at the home of his brother, Frank Maguire, 210 Fifth Avenue, after a year's illness. His age was 47.

The majority of important world currencies could be stabilized at fixed parities tomorrow, Dr. O. M. W. Sprague of Harvard University, formerly advisor to the Bank of England and to the United States Treasury Department, told the bankers' session of the National Foreign Trade Convention at the Hotel Cleveland here today.

Across meal tables and in hotel rooms delegates to the Ninepower Far Eastern conference, which opened in Brussels yesterday, are holding a parallel conference to array the democracies in an effort to draw a line against dictatorial aggressions.

Announcement was made here today by Dr. Otto Struve, director of the McDonald Observatory of the University of Texas and the Yerkes Observatory of the University of Chicago, of the recent solving of an astronomical problem.
Government spokesmen in both houses of Parliament went out of their way today to repeat their desire for a restoration of Great Britain's oldtime friendship with Italy.

Up-State members of the Milk Producers Bargaining Agency said tonight that no agreement had been reached after an all-day discussion of recommendations for a price increase in milk shipped to the New York City market.

Rare books from the library of the late Frederick Spiegelberg of this city brought $9,394.50 last night at the first of three auction sessions at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc. Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach paid $900 for one of the two earliest editions of Saint Augustine's "De Arte Praedicandi" and $220 for a set of first issues of Samuel Butler's "Hudibras."

Announcement has been made by Richard Lacey of 422 East Fiftyeighth Street of the marriage of his daughter, Miss Elva Louise Lacey, to Kenneth MacPherson of Helena, Mont., formerly of Wenatchee, Wash., which took place in Butte, Mont., on Monday.

Data on which Congress may be expected to revise substantially the undistrib- uted corporate profits tax and write numerous other changes and simplifications into the labyrinthine revenue laws will be laid before a special Ways and Means subcommittee on taxation tomorrow by Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury.

A judgment delivered today at Osgoode Hall by Justice Kingstone, in an action by the Montreal Trust Company against the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, found that the bond mortgage for $50,000,000 given by the defendant company to the plaintiff was a valid and first charge upon the assets of the defendant company.

Encountering the strongest resistance offered in any sector of North China since the warfare started, Japanese troops have captured the Chinese defenses of Sinhsien, forty miles north of Talyuan, the capital of Shansi Province.

A unique laboratory building erected here by the American Rolling Mill Company to prove the practicability of sheet iron and steel and stainless steel in industrial construction, and to house the company's research division, will be demonstrated at a gathering of more than 200 research scientists, business executives and editors on Friday.

The Dartmouth Indians held a long scrimmage today, the workout lasting until dusk. The temperature took a big drop after a snowstorm this morning, and the drill was held in weather below freezing. Early in the session the coaches were not satisfied as scrubs stalled the varsity attack.
The stock market here was quietly firm today and slight gains were registered in most sections. Gilt-edge issues were in good demand but foreign bonds behaved irregularly.

The price of lead was reduced yesterday a quarter cent a pound to 5.25 cents here and to 5.10 cents in St. Louis. The reduction was attributed to lack of interest among buyers and generally declining metal markets both here and abroad.

The annual dinner of the incoming class of the New York University School of Retailing, tendered by New York merchants and alumni and faculty of the school, will take place tomorrow evening at the University Restaurant at Washington Square East,

The social season in New York City was opened officially with a brilliant first night of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. In former years it was the opening of the grand opera season that marked the beginning of the Winter's social activities.
The rise of labor as a national political factor, and new possibilities of Mayor LaGuardia as a Presidential candidate in 1940 were main topics of political conversation in Washington today.

In view of the large vote which was cast on Tuesday in this city under the banner of the American Labor party it is interesting to compare this experiment in labor politics with another experiment in the same field, undertaken in Detroit.

Frank E. Mead of 100 Milbank Avenue, Greenwich, died of a heart attack late this afternoon in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Mead, who had been with the Yale Towne Manufacturing Co. in Stamford, for forty years, was leaving the plant when he was stricken.

A campaign to supply customers with information regarding rayon content of merchandise at every point of contact with the public, and to bring exhaustive pressure to bear upon producers to label all merchandise containing rayon as such, was urged upon retailers at a meeting of merchandisers, buyers and executives of member stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

A vitally important turning point is approaching in Japan's policy. On one hand is the possibility of an early peace; on the other hand is the serious likelihood of an aggravated, extended war with an increased risk of foreign entanglements.

New electric razors, which have been held back as the result of uncertainty created by litigation in the field, may make their appearance in increasing volume, as the result of a decision handed down this week by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

The Tammany tiger looked yesterday into the cupboard it had hoped to replenish at the polls on Tuesday and found it bare, save for a Sheriff and a Register. How it can subsist for the next four years was a question that no one in the organization wanted to try to answer.
Pennsylvania's junior varsity, using Penn State plays, made little progress against the Red and Blue varsity in a long scrimmage today in preparation for the game here Saturday.
Henry Ford paid $100,000 for option rights to sponsor the broadcast of the last world series, but declined to exercise his option, it was announced today.

The State Labor Relations Board will hold two conferences today with representatives of the Transport Workers Union, who will present claims for extension of their jurisdiction on the B. M. T. system for collective bargaining purposes.

Mrs. John H. Finley, president of the Friends of the Near East, an organization under the auspices of the Near East Foundation, reported yesterday that the group, now three years old, had 370 active members.

Miss Elizabeth M. Bouldin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bouldin 3d of Mount Pleasant Avenue, this place, has chosen Thanksgiving afternoon, Nov. 25, as the date for her marriage to Frederic Martin Blaicher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Blaicher of Orange.

Electric power output declined last week contrary to the normal seasonal and long-term trends and the adjusted index has receded to 102.1 from 103.6. This is the lowest point it has touched since the week ended June 27, 1936. The figure for the week ended Oct. 31, 1936, was 103 8.

Ten thousand persons paid their last tribute to the Very Rev. Canon Hugh R. L. Sheppard of St. Paul's Cathedral, familiarly known as Dick Sheppard, as they filed past his bier in St. Martin's-in-theFields Church last night.
Final returns yesterday in the New Jersey Mayoralty elections showed close margins of victory in some cases, and a few changes from the results indicated by early returns.
The Rev. Donald Boyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Boyle of Jersey City, died here today after a long illness. He was 39 years old.
Mrs. Sylvia Ringler of. 242 East Nineteenth Street was selected yesterday as the first woman to serve on a Federal grand jury in this city under the new law making women eligible for jury duty.

The report of the American Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued today, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges of $11,382,853, as compared with a net of $10,161,200 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1936.

Charles F. Hosford, chairman of the Bituminous Coal Commission, said today that he had asked President Roosevelt to relieve him of his official duties so that he may retire to private business life as soon as the Commission has completed its task of establishing first minimum prices for the industry.
Standees lined the walls when the chairs gave out at the first consumer forum of the season last night under auspices of the Advertising Women of New York at the Advertising Club.
MANHATTAN DOWN. FRED J. A. (Oct. 23). Estate $12,500. To Grace E. Down, 186 Pinehurst Ave., $2,500 and life estate in residue;

President Roosevelt will leave here tomorrow and make a brief visit to his town house in New York City before returning to Washington. While in New York he will receive Mayor La Guardia, probably at luncheon. This became known tonight following an official announcement at the temporary White House of the President's plans to leave here.

City A. C. 4, Harvard Club 1 Lester Strasser, City, defeated Willard K. Rice, 1-15, 15-12, 15-9; Julian Cowen, City, defeated R. C. Flack, 15-4, 18-14; C. Fitch Jr., City, defeated E. V. Otis, 15-10, 15-10; Fillmore Van S. Hyde, Harvard Club, defeated S. A. Tanburn, 17-15, 17-16: Otto Barth, City, defeated F. S. Milev. 18-17. 15-5.

Pope Pius left the Vatican again this morning and went to the Church of St. John Lateran, where he inaugurated the pontifical Roman Atheneum, built out of his private purse at a cost of about $500,000.
Secretary of Commerce Roper said today he considers it premature to guess at business trends for the first part of next year.

Complete returns today showed increased pluralities for the Republican ticket which carried to victory every nominee for Suffolk County office, legislative post and delegate to the State constitutional convention.
The Juilliard School of Music announces its annual competition for the publication of orchestral works by composers who are native or naturalized American citizens.

Final tabulations today of the vote in Nassau County yesterday increased the extent of the Republican victory. While it was expected the Republicans would win the election and retain control of the county government, the most optimistic leaders of the party were surprised by the landslide proportions of the Democratic defeat.

Isaac Mendoza of 225 West 106th Street, one of the city's well-known dealers in second-hand books, who established his shop at 15 Ann Street in 1894, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a fortnight's illness at the age of 72.

Just how long it will take to count those P. R. ballots nobody knows. President S. Howard Cohen of the Board of Elections is on what might be called the long side and those who had most to do with getting the system introduced are on the short side.
The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the State of New York to intervene in proceedings broplght by nine Southern States for lower freight rates to and from points in the South.

After playing the four regular quarters and two overtime periods, Army and Penn State's soccer teams finished in a scoreless tie today. The game, played on a fast, half-frozen field, was hard fought, with Adams, Army goalie, standing out for the Cadets.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 14,000 including 2,500 directs. The market was 10c-20c higher than Tuesday's average; top $9.80; bulk good and choice 190-230 pounds, $9.60-$9.75 150-180 pounds, $9.45-$9.75: 240-300 pounds.

A card index compiled by WPA workers at Ellis Island from yellowing volumes of ship manifests has speeded the process of turning aliens into citizens, it was announced yesterday at the offices of Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator.

The Rockaway Hunting Club made a clean sweep of its match with the Junior League, 5-0, yesterday on the former's courts in Cedarhurst as the annual women's interclub Class A squash racquets tournament got under way.

After a heated controversy among some of its members over the compulsory marketing quota on corn proposed by the AAA, the House Agriculture Committee appeared today to be as far from agreement on general farm legislation as it was on the first day of its meeting a week ago.
In jubilant mood, Mayor La Guardia pledged yesterday that the policies in city administration upon which he based his campaign would not be changed for the next four years.
The opening concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony's Young People's fifteenth anniversary season has been postponed from Nov. 20 to Dec. 18. It will be conducted by John Barbirolli at Carnegie Hall.

A system of twenty-four-hour coverage of felonious crimes in New York County by the office of the District Attorney will be begun Jan. 1, Thomas E. Dewey, newly elected public prosecutor, said yesterday.

Hopes for an early settlement of the industrial union controversy between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization were no higher tonight, on the eve of the resumption of parleys, than they were last week when the conferences started.
Robert, Philip and Allan S. Lehman, of Lehman Brothers, New York, asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine deficiencies aggregating $111,883 in 1933 income taxes.
Panama celebrated today the thirty-fourth anniversary of her independence from Colombia with an elaborate program including salutes to the flag by 10,000 school children.
Car fever, contracted aboard a west-bound train by Heelfly, famous race horse, led to hurried plans for treating the valuable animal today.

The Duchess of Gloucester, 35-year-old Scottish wife of the brother of King George, was ordered tonight by four royal physicians to take a month's rest following a minor operation this morning. She will be confined to York House, where the operation was performed.

Consumer "co-ops" in the democratic countries of Europe are preventing overexpansion of credit purchasing, which "eventually results in a crash," and, through agreements reached between their wholesale organizations, are breaking down the barriers of international trade, thus tending to avoid a European war, E. R. Bowen, executive secretary of the Cdoperative League of the United States of America, said in an interview here yester- world day.

A decrease of 1.1 per cent in the average retail cost of food between Sept. 14 and Oct. 12, reported today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, resulted from a drop in meat prices and a continued decline for prices of fruits and vegetables, it was said.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Donaldson of this place have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Clara Donaldson, to Robert Hogg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Hogg of Scarsdale.

Trading was fairly active to slow. The lamb market was stronger; pork loins and calf hindsaddles higher, veal strong to higher; other classes and cuts mostly unchanged. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be steady, lamb strong to slightly higher, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A message from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, expressing admiration for the fight Irvington House, a sanitarium for child heart sufferers, is waging against rheumatic heart diseases was made public yesterday by the organization.

The United Air Lines Transport Corporation had a net income of $411,664 for the third quarter of this year but operated during. the nine months ended on Sept. 30 with a net loss of $50,921, according to its report, issued today.
For the second successive day Coach Glen Harmeson sent his Lehigh football players through a long scrimmage today in preparation for New York University.

The Insurgents' bombing of Lerida yesterday, which shocked Loyalist Spain as nothing else had since their raids on Guernica, was followed today by another Rebel air attack-this time on Barbastro, only about - thirty miles from Lerida in Northeastern Spain.

Exports of iron and steel products from the United States in the third quarter of this year aggregated 1,155,993 gross tons with a value of $69,880,468, the highest level for a quarter since 1920, when the quarterly export average was 1,177,138 tons, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestie Commerce reported today.

The State will bring to trial soon twenty-four Protestant pastors, and laymen charged with collecting funds for confessional synods. The basis of the charges is a decree issued last Spring by Hanns Kerrl, Church Minister, prohibiting church collections of which he has not officially approved.

Revision downward of rentals in PWA housing projects wherever possible and simplification of plans for new low cost housing developments so that they will be within the low income groups' ability to pay will be the major objectives of the new United States Housing Authority, Nathan Straus of New York, administrator, said in taking up his new duties today.

Turpentine firm, 27c; sales, 169 barrels; receipts, 296 barrels; no shipments; stock, 40,123 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 511 barrels; receipts, 1.616 barrels; shipments, 1,057 barrels; stock, 84,646 barrels.

Two games tonight will mark the opening of the 1937-1938 National Hockey League season. On the ice at the Chicago Stadium, the Black Hawks will line up against the New York Americans, while in Toronto the Maple Leafs will play hosts to the world champion Detroit Red Wing sextet.
One nundred and one of the Japanese shells fired today did double duty. Japanese batteries aimed a 101gun salute, honoring the birthday, Nov. 3, 1852, of the late Emperor Meiji, into Chinese lines.

The 13th annual competition of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America opened at the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club today with the open-for-all-age English Springer Spaniel Stake as the feature event.

Steel ingot production this week has declined to 48 per cent of the country's- capacity in a further adjustment to the small volume of new business, The Iron Age says this week. Of the major producing districts, only at Pittsburgh has the rate been maintained at last week's level of 42 per cent.
A suit to recover $28,439 which it paid to the city under protest in sales taxes was started yesterday in the Supreme Court by the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique (the French Line).

Many reservations have been made for a benefit bridge party to be given for Willoughby House Settlement this afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Stanley K. Greene and Mrs. Walter P. Holcombe head the benefit committee.

The Westchester County charter proposal was carried in yesterday's election by more than 19,000, according to unofficial returns today from the county's entire 381 election districts. In Yonkers the vote was 14,790 in favor and 6,387 against, and in the rest of the county 32,612 in favor and 21,162 against.
Farm bills before Congress will benefit the poultry industry generally, delegates to the National Legislative Forum at the third annual Poultry Industries Exposition were told yesterday.

It was back to the wars for Fordham yesterday after a most enjoyable excursion into Dixie. Figuring that seventy-two hours was a reasonable period of grace to permit his men to get over their nostalgia for honeysuckle and pine and reorient themselves on the subway circuit, Jimmy Crowley ordered full steam ahead for the Purdue game.

In preparation for the public opening of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock in Rockefeller Center, it will be previewed privately tonight by representatives and guests of the 110 book publishers who are sponsoring it jointly with THE TIMEs.
The move for a Republican midterm convention was endorsed last night by the national affairs committee of the National Republican Club at a meeting in the clubhouse, 54 West Fortieth Street.

The capacity house which last night attended Jascha Heifetz's first Carnegie Hall recital of the season heard a program that dealt with something less than eternal verities. The response of that house must have been heartening to the soloist.
Pensioned ON HIS OWN APPLICATION PATROLMAN--John J. Healey, Traffic Precinct N, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Jan. 3, 1910.

Individual scoring and pass receiving records in the National Football league may be destined for shattering by the time the professional season, moving into its final month, has ended, it was revealed yesterday.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 168 East Seventy-fourth Street, on a plot 90 by 100 feet, has been sold to an investing syndicate represented by Choate, Laroque, Mitchell Ely by Bernard L. Touroff, acting as trustee, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.
Because his father-in-law submitted to the Italians, the Ethiopian Crown Prince, Asfaou Wassen, is now suing his wife for divorce.

It is imprudent, as well as unsound, to read too much into a series of local elections such as were held in this country Tuesday. Neighborhood trends necessarily differ because of community personalities and issues. The outcome is to a national election what a crazy-quilt is to tapestry.

Les Hart, backfield coach for Colgate's Red Raiders, put on his yearly exhibition of passing today as the varsity worked on defense in anticipation of an aerial attack Saturday when the Maroon faces undefeated Holy Cross at Worcester, Mass.
KiNGS CONIGLIO, JOSEPH (Oct. 1. 1932). Gross assets, $1,750; net, $1,750. To wife, Amelia Coniglio; son, Salvatore Coniglio, and daughter, Anna C. DeMotte, onethird of residuary estate each.

Asuncion, the capital of Paraguay, was put under martial law today and a warning was published that any one attempting to create disorder of any kind would be shot without trial. Military patrols were ordered to shoot to kill if their first command to halt was not obeyed.

The discovery of the existence of hitherto unobserved large numbers of exceedingly fine blood vessels in the inner lining, cavities and covering of the arteries was presented last night before the tenth graduate fortnightly of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Endowed with all its erstwhile glories, but imbued with a new spirit in the tempo of today, the National Horse Show opened yesterday in Madison Square Garden. The fifty-second annual exhibition will continue through next Wednesday with afternoon and evening sessions each day except Sunday, when there will be only an evening performance.
Increased production of wheat and other grains during 1937 was reported today by the Ministry of Agriculture.
Cooperating with the National Education AssoCiation, which has asked the States to observe the period from Nov. 7 to 13 as "American education week," Governor Lehman today issued this proclamation:

The earlier automobile show here was responsible for local newspapers during October carrying linage approximately equal to that of the like month of last year, despite elimination of more than 600,000 lines of advertising carried in The New York American for October, 1936, according to a report yesterday based on Media Records figures. The total for last month was 11,581,576, as against 11,598,637 for October, 1936.

The National Supply Company of Delaware, including Spang, Chalfant Co., Inc., reported yesterday an unaudited consolidated net profit of $6,614,289 for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, after all charges, minority interest and taxes, but before surtax on undistributed income.

Business failures increased in four business groups in the week ended Oct. 28, compared with the corresponding period last year, and declined in one group, construction, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report is as follows:
Five navy fliers were killed and two others rode to safety in parachutes today when a bomber and a pursuit plane collided during gunnery manoeuvres high above Boeing Field.

E. G. Benson and F. B. ?? were among the pairs to gain the semi-final round of the annual invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Heights Casino yesterday. They won from L. H. Fitch and W. A. Stanger Jr. after losing the initial game, 12-15, 15-6, 15-8, 15-10. The semi-finals are slated for today, with Benson and Frantz opposing L. W. Francis and B. C. Durfee.

The four-story brick apartment building at 16 Lexington Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by Wendel and Barbara Bohlinger to the Whitehall Realty Corporation for investment. The house contains eight apartments of four and five rooms and it is reported to be fully rented. Joseph Schoenberg was attorney for the buyer and Philip Sauer for the seller. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

The indications are for fair weather with slowly rising temperatures today and for increasing cloudiness and warmer tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock last night.

More than 3,000 photographs from this country and abroad have been received to compete for admission in the International Salon of Photography under the auspices of the Oval Table Society, which will open on Nov. 16 at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Forty students were arrested here today after an anti-government demonstration in connection with the recent clash.in Croatia in which four peasants were killed and 15 wounded when gendarmes fired .into the crowd.
With interest well maintained until the end, the thirty-eighth annual National Automobile Show closed last night at the Grand Central Palace after a run of eight days.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's status in the government is still not clear today, one week after his own statement that he had resigned as Minister of Economics. There can be no doubt now, however, that Chancellor Hitler is loath to part with him.

Joachim von Ribbentrop is expected to arrive here by air Friday ostensibly to join his daughter whom he left at Capri on his last visit, but actually, it is believed, in order to be present for the signature of the Italo-Japanese Pact reported designed to combat communism.

The governing board of the Pan American Union, at a special session today, unanimously re-elected Secretary of State Hull as chairman. It named as vice chairman the Ambassador from Chile, Manuel Trucco, who in 1931 was Acting President of Chile.

Notwithstanding an unusually large number and variety of noteworthy events in different parts of the world, the foreign news yesterday, except for a scant column, was jostled off the front page by the New York and other local and State election returns.
H. A. Ballou, retired Commissioner of Agriculture of the British West Indies, died here today. He was born in Swanzey, N. H., in 1872.

Congress today passed a law decreeing that 50 per cent of the revenues on merchandise entering Managua will be used for the maintenance of the fire department of the Federal District established last year.

Columbia's eleven, battered by Army, Penn, Brown and Cornell the past four weeks, confined its activities to a very light workout at Baker Field yesterday as Coach Lou Little attempted to freshen the players for the encounter with Navy at Annapolis Saturday.

Loans made on home mortgages by New York State savings and loan associations in September of this year were 4 per cent higher than in the same period of 1936, according to the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

The freighter Brazos of the Clyde Mallory Line sailed yesterday for Jacksonville, completing the schedule of sailings published by the line. The company has decided to withhold other tonnage from service until difficulties with longshoremen over wage contracts are adjusted,
A 532-pound, bear killed by Gene Mose of Saranac Lake was described today by Conservation Department officials as being one of the largest ever taken in the Adirondacks.

A surplus of $567 in intercollegiate sports operations was reported by James Lynah for the Department of Physical Education and Athletics at Cornell today for the period from July 1, 1936, to June 30, 1937.

Routed in yesterday's municipal election, in which its candidates failed to finish in the money, the C. I. O.'s offspring, the United Automobile Workers of America, was still on a the political warpath today.

Professor Joseph D. McGoldrick, alert and happy despite only five hours of sleep on election night, delivered his regular 10 o'clock lecture on American parties and politics yesterday morning before a Columbia government class which greeted him with a salvo of applause.
The national death toll, attributed by the American Medical Association to the use of an elixir of sulfanilamide including diethylene glycol, reached sixty-seven today.

Liquidation was under way in wheat futures today, with all deliveries on the Board of Trade selling at a new low price since June, 1936, and while there was a recovery of around 1 cent a bushel from the inside figure, net losses were 17/8 to 21/8 cents.

The executive committee of the Citizens Committee for Continuance of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway approved tonight a proposal that the Legislature create a State transit authority to acquire and operate the railroad's thirtymile system.

The search for backs to fill vacancies created by injuries was culminated today when Blackler, a junior varsity ball carrier, was assigned to the starting fullback position as Lehigh concluded practice for New York University.

Observing Italy's nineteenth anniversary of the World War armistice, Premier Mussolini declared today the Italian people "will defend both the victory and the peace." II Duce spoke only briefly from the balcony of Palazzo Venezia.

President Roosevelt arrived here at 8:45 tonight from Hyde Park and New York City, ready to return to his desk and to plunge into the problems presented by his calling of Congress into special session Nov. 15.

Turkey led all countries in the amount, of licenses issued by the State Department for the export of arms, ammunition and implements of war last month, taking a total of $2,670,000, all for military airplanes, according to the monthly report issued today.

" Spring of Joy and Armour Wherein He Trusted" will be the fourth volume in Dutton's illustrated series of the works of Mary Webb. The three preceding were "The Golden Arrow," "Gone to Earth" and "Precious Bane."

Captain F. Takata will get a bonus of $5,000 if he reaches Japan with the twenty-year-old freighter Eastern King Maru, which sailed today loaded with scrap iron from the Panama Canal consigned to Yawate.

Discussions of price and taxation trends, legislative developments, labor relations, wholesale distribution, wholesale service to customers,. truth-in-fabrics legislation and fair trade laws will feature the annual convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute to be held Jan. 18 and 21 at the Hotel New Yorker, it was announced yesterday.

If "Conquest" cost the $3,800,000 Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has said it did, the company was overcharged. For the new film at the Capitol, with all the munificence of its production, with all the starring strength of a Greta Garbo and a Charles Boyer, is merely a surface show. It goes no deeper than the images its screen reflects and we can watch it, and study it, as academically

To Vernon H. Struck, Harvard football player, was awarded today the Francis H. Burr scholarship, one of the leading undergraduate honors. Struck, who is from Centralia, Ill., has been on the Dean's list

Freda Edell extended for five years at 5 per cent, with quarterly amortization of S250, a mortgage for $19,000 she holds from Rose Heisler on 424 Grand St and 29 Attorney St. The 954 Fifth Avenue Corp, Anthony Campagna, president, gave a purchase money mortgage for $50,000, due Oct. 28,

RUNNING along the alphabetical line, AlaR bama'comes first. And apparently deserves the rating on other grounds, too. Undefeated and untied. Chubby Frank Thomas has another crack team, which causes practically no surprise at all.

Steps to revise the "pound price" basis for the sale of chinaware to department stores in favor of the "scale price" system in use by the chain stores were approved at a meeting of china and glassware buyers of metropolitan stores held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The first farmer-owned and controlled wholesale market in the State will be opened here next Spring, according to Leroy M. Chapman, county agent of the Fairfield County Farm Bureau and advisory director of the Bridgeport Fruit and Vegetable Growers' Association.

Germany has offered her services for mediation of the Sino-Japanese conflict and the offer has been accepted by both powers. Beyond brief confirmation that Chancellor Hitler's mediation had been accepted by Tokyo and Nanking no details concerning the offer or the circumstances that had initiated it were obtainable tonight.

The Brooklyn Dodgers participated in another extensive practice at Ebbets Field yesterday with Clarence (Ace) Parker, Duke backfield star of last year, in the line-up: Parker, who was signed by the Dodgers on Wednesday, took an active part in the preparations for the National Football League game with the Philadelphia Eagles, to be played at Ebbets Field on Sunday.
