Despite irregular demand, a belief persists in the wool trade that values have reached bottom and trading will broaden as soon as clothing stocks are cleared, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday, adding that buyers must soon realize that the time is drawing near when they must purchase requirements or run the risk of being without goods when they need them.
The NinePower Conference on the Far East, according to indications late tonight, will institute tomorrow a committee probably of six powers to open communication with Japan.

Mrs. Edward Livingston Coster of White Hall, Katonah, N. Y., entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for Miss Dorothy D. Butler, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Butler. The other guests included Mrs. Butler,...

The United States Treasury notified yesterday depositary banks in this Federal Reserve District that it had called for the repayment of $10,852,700 of its deposits on next Monday and a like amount on Tuesday.

An appeal for special contributions to the $325,000 fund needed for the yearly requirements of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, was issued yesterday by Frank L. Polk, special gifts chairman of the 1937 Roll Call of the chapter.

Herman J. Jansen has been appointed branch manager of the Detroit sales territory for BigelowSanford Carpet Company, Inc., succeeding Ray Horan, who resigned to become sales manager of the rug division of Artloom Company.

A questionnaire provided the highilight of the luncheon of the Touchdown Club held at the Advertising Club yesterday, when a large gathering of former football players and coaches had some difficulty with the historical queries set forth on a list of fifteen.

James A. Parley will resign formally as Postmaster General in another week, according to a Democratic leader here who said today that the Democratic chairman had told him that he would do so on Nov. 12.

Accumulation of shares of The Fair (Chicago department store) by the Kresge Department Stores, Inc., is disclosed by twin reports submitted to the Securities and Exchange (Commission and made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

A group of Spanish priests in the dioceses of New York, Brooklyn, Newark and Philadelphia have organized the Spiritual Union of Spanish Priests in the United States, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Francis X. Talbot, editor of America and advisor to the new group.

Undefeated Ralph Greenleaf of New York tonight won his fifth straight match to retain first place in the world pocket billiard championship, beating Benny Allen of Kansas City, 125 to 46, in eight innings. Greenleaf scored in easy fashion, taking a commanding lead with a string of 56 in the second session

Two of the larger salaries paid by the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railway, which is in bankruptcy, were reduced last year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday.

Stock market business here continued small today and the general tendency was to irregularity. Gilt-edge issues were in demand but foreign bonds were easier. International shares, reflecting yesterday's Wall Street weakness, fell off, and, despite some strength in the afternoon, United States Steel and International Nickel were down.

Robert A. Pinkerton has transferred his New York Stock Exchange seat to Allen B. Whitney of Pinkerton Whitney. Dealings in the first mortgage 4 per ecnt gold bonds of the New York, Chicago St. Louis Railroad Company, which were due on Oct. 1, will be suspended from dealings on the Exchange on Nov. 15.
The following Reserve officers recently released to the First Military Area, N. N. Y., are assigned as follows: 391st Infantry-2d Lt. Fred S. Stanton Inf.-Res., 17 Birch Crescent, Rochester, N. Y.

The prosecution in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing conspiracy case today produced its first witness from a big oil company to testify that his company had bought gasoline from independent refiners in 1935 and 1936 to contribute to stabilization of the market.

Of the making of books there is, fortunately, no end. In this country there is hardly a beginning; not counting textbooks, about half a book a year per capital is all we buy. The inference is that there are many millions of Americans who haven't yet discovered what a good thing a good book is:

Mrs. Harris Fahnestock was in charge of the Thursday tea at the Lenox Club this afternoon. Arriving tomorrow to be with Giraud Foster at Bellefontine, Lenox, will be his son, Giraud van Nest Foster, from Swingalong Plantation, Wilson, La., and Mrs. Foster, who has been in London.

Mayor La Guardia and President Roosevelt conferred for half an hour yesterday at the President's town house on East Sixty-fifth Street, in a move that seemed designed principally to emphasize the similarity of objectives of the two men.

Mrs. Winifred Crane Parry, daughter of Thomas Crane of Stamford, Conn., and widow of William J. Parry of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., was married here at noon today in the East Room of The Inn to Loring Robertson Gale, son of Mrs.

The workings of our nervous system in the transmission of impulses in the form of electrical messages to all parts of the body, culminating in the brain, where these messages are translated into consciousness, depend on the presence inside the nerve cells of a higher concentration of electrified potassium molecules than on the outside, Dr. Herbert Spencer Gasser, director of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, reported here today.
The Wichita, eighteenth and last of the cruisers to be built by the United States under the limitations of the London treaty, will be launched Nov. 16 at the Philadelphia Navy Yard.
Rear Admiral Andrew T. Long, United States Navy, retired, was injured painfully today when struck on the head by a descending elevator.

Robert B. Scull, pioneer brick contractor and prominent in Masonic circles, died early today in the Atlantic City Hospital, six days after falling from a scaffold. He was 69 years old. Mr. Scull was helping his men build a boiler house at the Breakers Hotel here when he fell fifteen feet.

Miss Janet Morrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Morrison of 315 East Seventy-seventh Street, was married to Charles William Salter, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Francis Salter of 720 Park Avenue, last night in the manse of the Astoria Presbyterian Church, Long Island City.

Speaking today before the Nebraska Bankers Association, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, held that the problems of bankless communities could not be solved by branch banking.

A comprehensive program of business ethics, which is in effect a "check-list" of ideal industrial and trade practices for the guidance of those companies not measuring up to the highest standards, was announced yesterday by the committee on industrial practices of the National Association of Manufacturers.

Pensioned ON POLICE SURGEON'S CERTIFICATU PATROLMAN Joseph J. Buckley, Shield 206, Traffic Precinct N, at $1,488 per annum. Appointed Feb. 26. 1918. Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-James F. Reynolds from 103d Precinct to 18th Division, for 12 days. William C. Pfizenmeier, from 104th Precinct to office of the Police Commissioner, assigned to duty as chauffeur, for 14 days.

District Attorney J. J. McGuigan requested today that charges against Hugh T. O'Neill, American seaman, for the alleged killing of Anastacio Papadoupolos be dismissed because of the lack of sufficient evidence to warrant bringing the case to trial.

The first impressions here of the proceedings of the Nine-Power Conference in Brussels yesterday have not brought any indication of a change in the Japanese attitude. This could hardly be expected as only press summaries of the principal speeches were available and the Foreign Office, up till tonight, had received only brief reports from the Japanese Embassy at Brussels.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Romeyn Benjamin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yolanda Ricasoli Benjamin, to Crawford E. L. Donohugh, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Thomas S. Donohugh of this city and White Plains.

The Republicans will have a comfortable majority in the constitutional convention which meets next April. If they treat this situation as a political opportunity they will be able to make a partisan revision of the State Constitution.

Further changes are in prospect for the old Chelsea district on the West Side Manhattan. The number of drab private dwellings there dating back to the brownstone era, or even earlier than that colorful period in the city's growth, is dwindling rapidly.

Refusing to go on record as supporting controversial resolutions submitted by its committee on social action because of insufficient time allotted for debate, the New York City Congregational Church Association, which held its sixtieth annual convention in Brooklyn yesterday, diluted one resolution attacking Fascist and Nazi support of General Franco and the Rebel forces in Spain and tabled another denouncing Japan for "acts of aggression" in China.

Decision was reserved yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board on a petition of the Transport Workers Union asking for certification as collective bargaining agency for 800 motormen employed on B.-M. T. Subway and elevated lines.

Kentucky Democrats continued to pile up a commanding lead today as counting of Tuesday's general election ballots neared completion. In the only State-wide race, Attorney General Hubert Meredith, incumbent by appointment, led his Republican rival, G. Tom Hawkins.

The world is now witnessing the bankruptcy of one more scheme of government agricultural planning. Brazil has announced that it will abandon its pricecontrol program for coffee, reduce the present export tax on coffee by 75 per cent and adopt a program of open competition.

President Lazaro Cardenas today decreed the nationalization of 350,000 acres of oil lands under lease to the Standard Oil Company of California as part of the nationalization of 2,000,000 acres of oil territory in the three Southern States of Tabasco, Campeche and Chiapas.

The aggregate net income of eleven oil companies which have reported for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 was $90,934,977, compared with $67,659,260 in the same period in 1936, an increase of 34 per cent, according to Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.
Real estate tax collections for the second half of this year will exceed by about $14,000,000 the amount collected in the second half of 1936, Controller Frank J. Taylor said yesterday.

H. Christian Huber, retired treasurer of the Hudson Motor Car Company of New York and former member of the Mountain Lakes Borough Council, died today at his home. 170 Boulevard, after a short illness. He was 63 years old.

Payson McL. Merrill Company, Inc., and Frances Tilghman were co-brokers in the recent sale of 133 East Sixty-second Street. Mrs. Theodora H. Townsend, formerly with Mrs. Ida Catlin, and Mrs. Frances Wallace Have joined the residential department of Payson MeL. Merrill Company, Inc.

Miss Barbara Frances Cary, daughter of Commander Robert M. Cary, U. S. N., of the Naval War College, and Mrs. Cary, was married to Lewis Pembroke Brown, son of Lewis F. Brown of Arlington Heights, Mass., this afternoon in Berkeley Memorial Church, Middletown.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

Byron Price, executive news editor of The Associated Press, issued a statement yesterday challenging the validity of the complaint filed against the news agency by the American Newspaper Guild with the National Labor Relations Board charging refusal to bargain collectively with editorial employes.
A C. I. O. union threatened today to strike rather than sign a contract under which the employer would have the right to discharge workers suffering from diabetes or venereal disease.

Harry Weinberg, trading as Nu-Art Tailoring Company, 818 Broadway, New York, is charged in a complaint filed today by the Federal Trade Commission with making misrepresentations "having a tendency to deceive purchasers" through acts of some twenty salesmen he employs at various points in the United States.

Carpenter Ave (17-4822), s w cor of 229th St. 114x105; Lester H. Brown to Jacob Solomon, 675 E 223d St: mtge $152.OQO. Davidson Ave (11-2862), w s, 346 ft's of Tremont Ave. 98x103; also Davidson Ave, w s,. 246 ft s of Tremont Ave, 100x100; Kolb Realty Corp to Schatten Holding Corp, 2.024 Hughes Ave: mtge $202.275.

A hearing into allegations that the Chesapeake Ohio Rallroad and other carriers charge "unjust and unreasonable" rates on bituminous coal shipped from mines in Southern West Virginia, Virginia and Eastern Kentucky to Newport News,

Princeton's gridiron forces worked behind locked gates today, concluding preparations for Saturday's traditional Dartmouth encounter here with a light session that indicated the Tigers will rely upon an intricate aerial attack to hurl back the Green warriors.

The City College football squad engaged in a two-hour workoLt under the supervision of CoachBenny Friedman at Lewisohn Stadium'yesterday in preparation for the game with St. Joseph's of Philadelphia on the New Yorkers' gridiron tomorrow.
Martinez Fraga, Cuban Ambassador, presented to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt the Grand Cross of the Cuban Red Cross Society at the White House today.
One of the most popular legends of latter-day mythology has just been retold for the benefit of the American people.
Stocks fluctuated erratically and closed irregularly lower; turnover, 1,470,940 shares. United States Government issues higher, other bonds lower; transactions, $8,066,000.

Sam Baron, a member of the Socialist party in New York and one of the editors of The Socialist Call, today informed friends here that he was under arrest in Valencia, Spain, accused by Communist agents of Trotskyist activity.

The Board of Tax Appeals said today that on Nov. 17 it would hear pleas of Fisher Fisher, Inc., and Cartoonist Court, Inc., both of New York City, for redetermination of an assessed deficiency of $53,149 in 1932 income taxes.

During the week ended Nov. 3 member bank reserve balances decreased $62,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $46,000,000 in money in circulation and $17,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and a decrease of $11,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, offset in part by decreases of $6,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold and $4,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
William F. Decker, member of the firm of Decker Brothers, piano manufacturers, who died Oct. 28 at Bethlehem, Pa., left real estate of upward of $10,000 and personal property of upward of $10,000.

After returning from Washington last night Charles E. Bedaux, friend of the Duke of Windsor, issued a statement at the Hotel Plaza in which he declared that the Duke had declined his offer to withdraw from his role in connection with the Duke's American tour.

Ambassador Alexander A. Troyanovsky of Russia will discuss his nation's position on world peace at a public reception for him at Carnegie Hall tonight, on the occasion of the twentieth anniversary of the Soviet Republic, it was announced yesterday.

Sales of the F. W. Woolworth Company for the ten months ended with October increased 5.2 per cent to $232,450,263 from $220,981,276 in the first ten months of 1936, according to a report issued yesterday. Sales in October amounted to $26,788,140, against $26,733,270 in October last year, a gain of 0.2 per cent.

Little doubt was left today that substantial revisions of the corporate undistributed profits tax would be undertaken at the regular session of Congress after Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, had concluded a preliminary discussion with the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Taxation.

Miss Grace McLaughlin of 2,170 University Avenue, the Bronx, was married to Samuel J. Foley, who on Tuesday was re-elected District Attorney of that county, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Holy Cross in West Forty-second Street. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, who also celebrated the nuptial mass that followed.

October awards for engineering construction in the United States reached the highest weekly average for any October since 1930 with a total of $189,801,000, or $47,450,000 for each of the four weeks, according to The Engineering News-Record.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustees for St. Luke's Hospital, sold to the 3,884 Parkway Garage Corporation, represented by Louis A. Jackson, the six-story garage on a plot 40 by 89.6 feet at 157-9 West Eighteenth Street. The property was sold subject to a lease with Ralph and Benjamin Kantor, the tenants.
Dr. W. L. McEwan, president of the board of trustees of Princeton Theological Seminary, died today at his Summer home near this Northwestern Pennsylvania community at the age of 78.

Voters in 100 municipalities in thirty States approved bond issues aggregating $5,937,060 in October, compared to $7,576,089 of bonds approved in September, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. The total for October, 1936, was $7,749,325, against $43,767,739 in October, 1935, and $4,369,800 in 1934.

An international plan for the relief of unemployment, through coordination of education and occupational planning, as an alternative to dictatorship is proposed in "Unemployment in the Learned Professions," published today by the Oxford University Press.

In tatterdemalion garb, the New York Giants continued their practice sessions at the Polo Grounds yesterday in preparation for Sunday's battle there with the Pittsburgh Pirates. Sartorially the Giants were a sight; they wore old uniforms, ragged pullovers and faded jackets of bright college years.

At a preview of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center last night Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, defined "the powerful books," still unwritten, for which he said "the stage is now being set."

MANHATTAN BAADE, MARGARET (Oct. 26). Estate, less than $8,000. To Edward McGowan, 25 Martin St., Bloomfield, N. J.; Catherine Wolken, 306 E. 142d St.; Arthur McGowan, 1,575 -Tomlinson Ave., and Peter Me(owan, 89 Wadsworth Ave., grandnephews and grandniece, onetwentieth residue each; William J. Baade, nephew, 544 Linden Ave., Brooklyn;

The AngloGerman and Anglo-Soviet naval agreements, under which Berlin and Moscow accepted the provisions for qualitative naval limitation and exchange of information on new construction, laid down in the London naval treaty of 1936, became effective today.
Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union called a strike yesterday against H. Milgrim Bros., Inc., women's clothing store at 6 West Fifty-seventh Street, to which six elevator

A contest for an orchestral composition has been announced by the Musicians Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy. Aaron Copland, Roy Harris, Roger Sessions, Bernard Wagenaar and Alfred Wallenstein will serve as judges. The prize will be the performance of the work in concert at Carnegie Hall in March.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

London paid a last and demonstrative farewell to popular Canon Hugh R. L. (Dick) Sheppard today. After a brief service in the Church of St. Martin's-in-the-Field, of which he had been vicar, the coffin was carried in procession along the Thames Embankment to St. Paul's Cathedral.

Administration hopes for a draft of general farm legislation by the time Congress meets on Nov. 15 were obscured today by conflict between House and Senate Agriculture Committee leaders over the merits of voluntary and compulsory crop control programs.

The United Brewers Industrial Foundation will embark on an institutional advertising campaign to be carried on simultaneously with the continuation and expansion of its other activities, according to a statement from the foundation yesterday.

The "mate" of the prehistoric Peking Man, Sinanthropus Pekinensis, was exhibited for the first time today by Dr. Franz Weidenreich, director of the Coenozoic laboratory of the Rockefeller-endowed Peiping Union Medical College.

The recent "roving" convention of the International World Police in Montreal, Washington and New York did more than provide a forum on criminology for the assembled police officials from several nations. It was a meeting of the minds of men dedicated to the preservation of law and order, and, as such, a factor in the unending campaign for peace.
Wheat futures in the world's leading markets with the exception of the December delivery at Winnipeg dropped today to new low levels for the season as a result of fairly general liquidation.

The Dartmouth football team did a complete turn-about today from yesterday's disappointing showing and, upon the completion of the last Hanover workout before the Princeton game, drew praise from Head Coach Earl Blaik.
The Right Rev. William T. Manning, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, pledged $1,000 last night toward the building fund of the Church of the Epiphany.

Approximately 60,000 employes of the General Electric Company will be saved between $90,000 and $100,000 in December through suspension of their contribution to the company's additional group life insurance plan, W. W. Trench, secretary of the company, stated yesterday.

With a message from President Roosevelt declaring that "we cannot have too many forums for the free and untrammeled expression of public opinion," the third season of "America's Town Meeting on the Air" opened last night at the Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street.

Harry Balsamo of Harlem and Walter Woods, popular middleweight battler from the East Side, will meet in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome tonight. With each boxer having a large personal following, Promoter Mike Jacobs is confident that a capacity crowd will turn out for the event.

Lumber output declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index slumped to 70.9 from 78.3. This is the lowest point it has touched since the week ended Feb. 13. The index for the week ended Oct. 31, 1936, was 82.6.

The Museum of Modern Art announces for next week the first major exhibition in its 1937-38 season. This will be composed of canvases by about forty American artists, all of whom have likewise been invited to contribute work to the contemporary section

The Herbert Schiff Memorial Trophy, awarded annually to the naval aviation unit with the best record for safety in flying, will go this year to Patrol Squadron 7, commanded by Lieut. Comdr. Robert L. Fuller.

There was regular scrimmaging for third-stringers and a few second string men and intensive dummy scrimmage for all hands on both offense and defense as Fordham's football forces went through another hard day of practice under the direction of Coach Jim Crowley at Fordham Field yesterday. Continuing preparations for the game with Purdue at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, the Rams worked at a fast pace all the way.
The two-family dwelling at 21 Speedway Avenue, Newark, N. J., has been sold by the Dime Savings Bank of Newark to Lorenzo Simeone. George Samuelson and Antonio Orlando were the brokers.

Teachers should be permitted to retire at 60 or after thirty years of service with full pay, Dr. Emil Altman, chief medical examiner of the New York City school system, asserted yesterday. He declared that because of the "harrowing" and "nerve-racking" life teachers lead, few of them can reach 60 and still be useful to the schools.

Substantial speeding up of the count of proportional representation ballots cast for the new City Council was noted yesterday in each of the five boroughs. The canvassers were more familiar with their jobs and supervisors took drastic action to curb the "soldiering" that had featured the first day of the count.

Adolf Rembte, 35 years old, and Robert Stamm, 37, Communist Labor leaders, were executed here today. They were sentenced on June 4 on charges of attempting to recreate an illegal political organization.

Believing that the Russian trang polar fliers lost in the Arctic wastes last August may have been thrown off their course by disturbances in the magnetic circle-but that they did cross the Pole-Commander Clifford J. MacGregor of the MacGregor polar expedition announced last night his plans to undertake an immediate airplane search.

Current accomplishments and ultimate objectives of the Administration's reciprocal trade treaty program predominated in discussions at the second day's session of the National Foreign Trade Convention at the Hotel Cleveland here today.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Gaylord Burwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Burwell, to Sackett Brooks Miles, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Miles of Sackett Homestead, Warren, and 1,158 Fifth Avenue, New York, will -take place here tomorrow noon at the home of the bride-elect's parents.

Baldwin Locomotive Works new refunding 6 per cent convertible mortgage bonds, due in 1950, and 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $30 par value, will be admitted today to listing by the New York Curb Exchange.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York has filed with the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, now investigating railroad financing, charges that the printed records of the committee teem with errors bearing on transactions between the Guaranty Trust and the Van Sweringen railroad interests.

The Bank of Mexico's metallic reserves fell to under 50 per cent, continuing the month-old downward movement, according to an official weekly statement published today, despite efforts by the government to hold them above 50 per cent by transferring the weekly mining company taxes in metal to the bank instead of spending them.

Favorites finally hit their stride at Pimlico today and five won to lift the average of the meeting to something near normal. Four of them scored in a row, including W. L. Brann's Challephen, victor in the $2,920 Heiser Handicap, a memorial to C. L. A. Heiser, first president of the Maryland Horse Breeders Association.

Hendrik Willem van Loon was elected yesterday president of the Authors Guild of the Authors League of America. Also named at a meeting of the Guild in the Hotel Woodward were Henry F. Pringle, vice president, and Margaret Widdemer, secretary.

Eradication of bovine tuberculosis from the herds of the State to less than one-half of 1 per cent was observed in an "Achievement Day" here today by farmers, agricultural leaders and veterinarians. The task has been accomplished in nineteen years by State officials, with the cooperation of dairy farmers and veterinarians.
All city commissioners except those serving for fixed terms will be asked to turn in their resignations to Mayor La Guardia as of Dec. 31, 1937, it was learned yesterday at City Hall.

AFTERNOON EVENTS Class 6, single harness horse, over 15.2--First, Mrs. Loula, Long Combs's b. g. Invasion; second, Miss Judy King's br. g Killearn Magi; third, Killearn Farm's b. m. Killearn Beauty; fourth, Greyholme Stables' ch. g. Broompark Chancellor.

An unexpected windfall brought happiness yesterday to Thrift House, 7 East Fifty-seventh Street, an organization that sells for charity a wide assortment of donations, ranging from old clothing to furniture.

Sound credit will be restored to railroads undergoing reorganization when it is realized that the "disease" of the carriers is inadequate earnings and not the burden of debt, in the opinion of Fairman R. Dick who discussed "The Delay in Reorganizations" yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

Effective Federal legislation for the formation of a poultry bureau in the Department of Agriculture, consumer education and cooperation in raising the standards of quality, were suggested yesterday, as aids to the poultry industry, by James E. Rice, past president of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council, who spoke at the seventh annual luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

Coach Jock Sutherland and his powerful Panthers, drilled in a defense that Pitt followers hope will stop any sort of an aerial attack, headed tonight for South Bend to meet Notre Dame in a battle Saturday that will be the swan song of their colorful football series.

The United States Lines announced yesterday that bids for the purchase of the liner Leviathan must be submitted by Monday to be considered. The Federal Government recently authorized the company to sell the vessel to shipbreakers and agents of several potential buyers since have been aboard at her Hoboken Dier.

VINCENT SHEEAN'S "Personal History" was the story of an adventurous search for values in a gun-haunted world. It was a good book, a disturbing book, one that had its share in shaping the ideas of a generation. His last novel, "Sanfelice," carried on the search in a rococo frame of revolutionary Naples.

All hospitals, both private and municipal, need a medical research department, Dr. Haven Emerson, professor public health practice at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, told the United Hospital Fund's medical social service meeting in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

The dollar continued yesterday to fall in foreign exchange and the price of gold in London rose to 18 3/4 cents an ounce premium over its New York parity as Europe gave further attention to rumors that the value of the dollar would be reduced again in an effort to cheek the current slump in business and prices.

Frisby Ave, 2,512-2,524 (15-3982); Frisby Realty Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, Madison Ave, extends mtg to May 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $184,000. Frisby Ave, 2,500 to 2,510 (15-3982); Frisby Realty Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, Madison Ave, extends mtg to May 1, 1942, at 5 per cent; $184,000.

Trucking companies throughout the United States plan to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission and State regulatory bodies for an increase of 15 per cent in freight rates in conformity with a petition for a freight-rate increase of like amount to be filed with the commission by the railroads next week, it was disclosed here yesterday.

The direction of claim work formerly carried on by the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters has been assumed by the Association of Casualty and Surety Executives, Claude W. Fairchild, general manager, announced yesterday.

Swift Co. today announced its weekly supply of hides would be sold "at the going market" and so ease the present situation in the hide market. No sales have been reported since early August and the present range is 12 3/4 to 16 1/2 cents, which brokers reported was merely a nominal quotation.

The nations of Europe will continue to settle their conflict of interests through negotiation rather than through "an appeal of war," Maurice Duperrey of Paris, president of the Rotary International, declared yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by the Rotary clubs of the metropolitan area.

Considerably revised since its championship campaign was concluded last March, the Eastern Amateur Hockey League will launch its 1937-38 season at Madison Square Garden a week from next Sunday with the New York Rovers opposing the Baltimore Orioles.
The New York Americans announced tonight the purchase from the Boston Bruins of Hooley Smith, for years one of major-league hockey's star centers.

The American Federation of Labor-Committee for Industrial Organization parleys were resumed today in an atmosphere of pessimism, but when an adjournment was agreed upon until tomorrow hopes for peace in the interunion war appeared brighter than they have at any time since the C. I. O. was organized two years ago.

Expressing increased confidence in the future of private power companies, Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, declared today at the second session of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America here that, in his opinion, Federal control had strengthened materially the financial position of the companies and restored confidence of the public in utility securities.

Hardy Fall blooms from suburban estates throughout the metropolitan area filled the stately halls of the ground floor of the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park WVest, yesterday at the opening of the thirtieth annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York.

Republican leaders had under consideration today a plan to go to court in an effort to upset some of the results of Tuesday's election here. Meanwhile, Mayor Wilson again took the center of the political stage as an election aftermath by claiming the support of a majority of the Republican members of the City Council, just as he was being termed "politically dead" by State PartY leaders.

Pope Pius gave himself over to complete rest today. He had spoken briefly yesterday at the inauguration of a new atheneum at the ancient basilica of St. John Lateran, and Vatican sources said his doctor had advised rest after this activity, which followed so closely his return from Castel Gandolfo, his Summer residence.

High meat prices will soon be a thing of the past in the opinion of Agriculture Department officials, who contended today that consumer prices for the better grades of beef and pork already had reached their peak and were now entering a gradually declining cycle.

Building projects submitted yesterday included Brooklyn plans for a laboratory to be erected in Park Place by the city and a fifty-fourfamily apartment house to be built in East Sixteenth Street. Architects also filed for several small dwellings in Queens.
The Southern Pacific Company announced yesterday that it was about to order 75,000 tons of rail, the largest commitment of its kind to be placed in many months.
Fourteen seamen of the Algic, ordered held for a Federal grand jury on mutiny charges, swore out warrants today charging two officers of the government-owned freighter with involuntary manslaughter.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized John Dickinson today to be general solicitor of the Pennsylvania and the Long Island Railroads and also to be an officer or director of a long list of railroads, including the Pennsylvania and the Long Island.

The program of the Pension Fund concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, taking place Monday evening, Nov. 22, at Carnegie Hall, will be conducted by John Barbirolli and will present two soloists. They are Bidu Sayao, Metropolitan Opera soprano, and Julius Katchen, 11-year-old pianist.
The Bedaux system, which labor representatives are condemning in connection with the scheduled visit of the Duke of Windsor, arbitrarily divides up production into units.

Tammany's 105 job holders in District Attorney William C. Dodge's office began preparing yesterday for their exodus from the city payroll on New Year's Day, when Thomas E. Dewey, victorious Fusion-American Labor party candidate, moves in as prosecutor.

The report of the Standard Oil Company of California and its domestic subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 shows a net profit of $31,135,818, after depreciation, depletion, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges.
Pageantry of a kind rarely seen even in India marked the state entry of the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithgow, into Bikaner today when the Maharajah's golden jubilee celebration reached its climax.

Pump Operators The following members of the department [having satisfactorily completed the course in the care and operation of motors and pumps used in the department are design nated as motor and pump operators, and they are, therefore, qualified to be assigned to that duty in their companies or in anI company to which they may be transferred in preference to all other members who have not previously qualified:

The four-story apartment house at 31-03 Twenty-third Street, Astoria, on a plot 100 by 50 feet, has been purchased by a client of the Arthur I. Harrison Company for cash above a first mortgage of $49.500.

Ida M. Tarbell, biographer of Abraham Lincoln and historian of the Standard Oil Company, sat yesterday in the old-fashioned apartment at 120 East Nineteenth Street which she has occupied since before the war and, in an interview on the eve of her eightieth birthday today, spiked the fallacy that the present is America's most exciting time.

Ray Hanson, a six-foot, two-inch farmer from Bingham Lake, Minn., won the national corn husking championship today over a field of nineteen other picked shuckers from ten. States who battled for eighty minutes through a cold, driving rain and slippery mud.

Making the most of a slight positional advantage and continuing to play in his best form, Dr. Max Euwe of this city, world chess champion, tonight succeeded in winning the thirteenth game of his title match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, after sixty-eight moves.

Coach Wilder Lasker sent his first and second Rutgers elevens against each other in a long dummy scrimmage today, with the reserves employing Lafayette plays to test the Scarlet defense. The guards were alternated, Art Rolph and Don Saxton at right guard and Paul Bednarczyk and Walt Bruyere at left guard interchanging in the two lines.

Further curtailment in industrial production and in originating freight shipments accounted for a drop of 3.5 points in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

Miss Mary Dobbin, daughter of Mrs. John J. Dobbin of St. John's, Nfld., and the late Mr. Dobbins, was married to E. Noel R. Trentham, financial counselor at the British 'Embassy, Washington, yesterday afternoon in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building.

An increase of more than 300 per cent in net income in the first eight months of the year was reported yesterday by 141 Class I railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The figures are after deductions for interest, whether paid or not paid.

Jack McAuliffe, who retired in 1896 as the undefeated professional lightweight-boxing champion of the world after holding the title for twelve years, died yesterday at his home, 73-20 Austin Street, Forest Hills.

Further heavy selling in coffee futures at the opening of the market yesterday forced prices down 29 to 87 points under the previous close in the Santos contract, while the lower-priced Rio delivery fell 10 to 69 points at the opening call.

Nov. 15 has been selected tentatively by officials of Los Angeles, Calif., for the sale of $10,200,000 of electric plant revenue bonds. It is expected that this date will be confirmed when the Water and Power Commission of the city meets next week.
The special measures Queen Wilhelmina announced in her speech from the throne for strengthening the defense forces are now down in a financial memorandum to Parliament.
The Bell System reported yesterday an increase of 74,600 telephones in service during October, compared to 107,000 stations added in the same month last year.

The estate of Harris Hammond at Bordentown, 242-acre remnant of the 1,000-acre tract once owned by Joseph Bonaparte, brother of Napoleon, was sold for $200 at an auction at the Mount Holly Court House today.

Dr. and Mrs. Leslie Vickers of Cloverly, East Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Elizabeth Vickers, to Martin Ives Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Phillip Goodman of Rockville Center, L. I.
It was a boy from the banks of the Mississippi who in age wrote an imagined letter to the Younger Pliny in praise of Virgil, dating it in the Autumn of A. D. 99:

Hans Gorrissen, Buenos Aires business man, died Tuesday at the German Hospital in the Argentine city at the age of 33, it was announced here yesterday by relatives. Mr. Gorrissen was born in London and studied in England and Germany.

Directors of the Radio Corporation of America have been called for a special meeting. for this afternoon, it became known yesterday. Although the purpose of the session was not divulged by tne company yesterday, it was noted that the date is a full three weeks in advance of the regular directors' meeting.

Although actual reserve balances of member banks of the Federal Reserve System decreased $62,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the excess reserves of the banks fell only $20,000,000, to a total of $1,050,000,000.

The bond market had yesterday another sinking spell under liquidation of the speculative rails, although obligations of the highergrade carriers held firm. Trading in all bonds on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to $8,066,000, compared with $8,967,450 on Wednesday.

A giant electric light bulb, fourteen feet high, which will glow as a land beacon on the $100,000 Edison Memorial Tower at Menlo Park, N. J., has been completed by the Corning Glass Works and will be shipped late this week.
Yorkshire and continental European buyers were spirited bidders for average to good selections in today's wool auctions. Offerings amounted to 12,670 bales, of which 10,582 were sold.

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise in September, as announced by the Department of Commerce, are compared herewith with those of the preceding month and with September, 1936.

There is still no sign of a lessening of Palestine's terrorism. A Jewish-owned bus was again fired on early this evening on the Jerusalem-Jaffa road, two Jews being seriously wounded and taken to the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem.

Shanghai has endured another day of constant shaking from a duel of heavy artillery beyond the International Settlement's western borders, and again both Chinese and Japanese official statements concerning the outcome of the bitter fighting are utterly contradictory.

Two remakes of above average importance became a part of Metro's program for the season when "Madame Pompadour" and "Journey's End" were added to the studio's tentative schedule. It was learned that Ilona Massey, one of the studio's recent European

A new milk price scale giving producers an increase of 28 cents a hundred pounds for milk and 25 cents a hundred pounds for milk used for cream, has been agreed upon by directors of milk-producing and distributor agencies, it was announced here yesterday.

A generation ago many people were annoyed with Ida Tarbell because she was destroying images before which they had been taught to bow down. She had told the truth about a great industry and a great fortune, and the truth was bitter.

For the second successive day, the price of lead in the domestic market was lowered yesterday a quarter -cent a pound. The new prices are 5 cents a pound here and 4.85 cents in St. Louis. These quotations are the lowest since late in 1936.

Twenty-seven colleges have been invited to compete on the Charles River at Cambridge, Mass., on Sunday in the intercollegiate dinghy races, and announcement was made yesterday by the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that seven prominent yachtsmen would offer, through M. I. T.,

Mrs. Louise Dorothy Lehmann charged yesterday in Supreme Court that her husband, Franz Lehmann, was being coerced by agents of the German Government into attempting to deprive her of her dower rights in his property. She said, in an affidavit filed in court, that she believed her husband was a prisoner in Germany, although he is classed by the Reich as an "Aryan." She is Jewish.

Robert Gair, president of the Gair Realty Company of 155 East Forty-fourth Street, Manhattan, and formerly vice president of the Robert Gair Company of Brooklyn, manufacturers of paper boxes, died suddenly today at his home on the Jerich?? Turnpike in this community. His age was 56.

KINGS DONOVAN.-JOHN (Oot. 14, 1933). Gross assets, $58,243; net, $53,825. To wife, Ellen Donovan, life income from specific realty, household furnishings and effects and life income from residuary estate. Chief assets, real estate, $9,000: mortwages, notes. eash and insurance. $41.450;

Baron Wilhelm Wymetal, 74 years old, former director of the Vienna State Opera and for many years of New York's Metropolitan Opera, attempted to take his own life today by poison. His condition is reported grave. Is is believed ill health motivated his act.

Two dozen students and teachers gr from the Harvard University Bureau for Street Traffic Research pitted their driving skill against that of a New York taxi driver yesterday in an attempt to find out how much time the West Side express highway system will save for New Yorkers who are in a hurry to get out of town or back again.

Unless one believes that the Jersey City machine of Mayor Frank Hague developed enough careless inefficiency on Tuesday to furnish proof of the widespread vote frauds often charged, but never established, in Hudson County, then A. Harry Moore can be accepted as Governor-elect of New Jersey and his election viewed in national terms.
Another French ship has been attacked off the Spanish coast by "pirate" airplanes, it is stated in a note published here tonight by the Ministry

General Water, Gas and Electric Company and Subsidiaries Twelve months to Sept. 30: Net income, after expenses and charges, $424,144, comparing with a net of $377,806 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1936.

Funeral services for Dr. George Meason Whicher, professor emeritus of Hunter College, New York, were held today in Grace Episcopal Church. Dr. Whicher, who had made his home in Amherst since his retirement in 1924, died here Tuesday. He was 77 years old.

The trade of The Netherlands and the Netherlands Indies with the United States showed a considerable increase during the first eight months of this year compared with the same period last year, according to official figures today.

A decision awarding the bulk of the $40,000,000 to $60,000,000 estate of the late Colonel Edward H. R. Green, son of Hetty Green, eccentric financier, to his sister, Mrs. Matthew Astor Wilks, was announced last night by Surrogate Harry E. Owen of Essex County, following a final hearing in the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street.

The report of the Gatineau Power Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after all expenses and charges, of $1,445,379, comparing with a net of $1,051,700 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1936.

After being criticized for his failure to support Mayor La Guardia in the recent election campaign, Joseph P. Ryan, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council for fifteen years, announced at a meeting of the council last night in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, that "for a very obvious reason I am not a candidate for re-election."
With increases in dollar volume reported increasingly harder to obtain, retailers are adopting. a twofold course of action, more or less at variance, it was reported here yesterday.

Mrs. Patricia Ryan, 20 years old, who is alleged to have shot and killed her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan, in a quarrel Sunday at their home, 1,350 Purdy Avenue, the Bronx, was held without bail yesterday by Magistrate Earl A. Smith for a hearing Saturday. Mrs. Ryan was charged with homicide.

A generation of children "properly born, trained, educated and healthy, would wipe away a thousand problems of government," Mrs. Walter L. Bowen of Riverton, N. J., president of the New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers, said here today.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City declined $1,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $7,913,000,000, according to the condition statement of the banks, issued yesterday.

One year ago, in the first days following the national election of 1936, American business faced the future with apparent confidence. In that very week THE TIMES index of business activity reached a new peak for the whole recovery movement.

The Chandler centennial dinner, ending a month of celebration by Columbia University of the 100th birthday anniversary of the late Dr. Charles Frederick Chandler, industrial chemist and founder of the Columbia School of Mines, was held last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

For the third time, the Harvard football team worked out today with the line Coach Dick Harlow organized immediately after the Princeton game and with a backfield of Cliff Wilson at quarter, Austie Harding at left half, Frank Foley at right half and Ralph Pope at fullback.

The opening of the Brussels conference was not auspicious. From what was said--as well as from what was left unsaid-by the representatives of the principal Powers, it is clear that no country wishes to assume responsibility for leadership. Only Litvinoff, the Russian Foreign Minister, spoke with unguarded frankness, condemning Japanese aggression.

While the struggle around Shanghai prolongs itself far beyond what the overconfident Japanese had expected, some curious and arresting facts are being learned from high Japanese commanders, which indicate the correctness of the assumption that the Shanghai hostilities are in Japanese eyes in the nature of an unpremeditated sideshow.

The marriage of Miss Margaret La Farge, daughter of the late Oliver H. P. La Farge and his first wife, the former Miss Mary B. Lewis of Seattle, Wash., to Samfel McClintock Hamill of New York and Cherry Grove, Princeton, N. J., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's stepmother, Mrs. Oliver H. P. La Farge of 161 East Seventyninth street.

Lionel Robsarte, operatic tenor and a vocal instructor for the last thirty years, died last Wednesday at his apartment and studio iii the Hotel Woodward Annex at the age of 60. Mr. Robsarte, who attended the University of Rochester, was a member of Theta Delta Chi.
Whether the Duke and Duchess of Windsor will sail for the United States Saturday morning is in doubt tonight.

Paul Hammond Company has placed a first mortgage loan of $155,000 on the new six-story apartment house at 87-84 165th St, Jamaica, Queens. Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., has arranged for Rackllnn Fagin a $115,000 first mortgage on the recently completed six-story apartment on the south side of Clark Place, 110 feet west of Walton Ave. the Bronx.

The Hamburg - American liner Hamburg, arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports, has among her passengers Mr. and Mrs. Heinrich Nostiz, Mr. and Mrs. Hans Cram, Mr. and Mrs. D. R. O'Connor, Maximillian Foster, Dr. Rudolf Kuechner, Mr. and Mrs. Ray Coulter, Mr. and Mrs. James Colquhoun, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Perry and Professor and Mrs. Henry R. Bartner.

New York Military Academy remained undefeated, untied and unscored upon by turning back a heavy eleven from Liberty (N. Y.) High School, 27-0, today. Finding their ground plays repulsed near the goal line, the cadets thrice took to the air to score, and added a safety and a recovered fumble in the end zone for their margin of victory.

Undergraduates of Columbia and N. Y. U. are urging a post-season football game between the two institutions, which severed gridiron relations in 1925. The lead in the movement has been taken by two undergraduate publications, The Columbia Spectator and The N.Y. U. Commerce Violet. Both have published columns favoring the contest and each printed a copy of a letter written by Bert Coffey, sports editor of The Commerce Violet.
Henry M. Robinson's achievements in the service of the United States occasioned today a flood of tributes to the work of the financier-economist-attorney, who died yesterday at the age of 69.

Yale's old blues certainly stick together. So much so that whenever you go up-to watch N. Y. U. practice you find them in clusters, like the Dionnes in Canada. They're five strong up there on the football campus and you momentarily expect them to break out into a "boola-boola."

Bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities of the United States for the five-day week ended on Nov. 3 amounted to $5,311,305,000, compared with $5,296,277,000 in the similar week last year, an increase of 0.3 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody said today: "I have not signed a contract, I do not intend to and I have no plans for turning professional." She declined further comment. Reports were current that she was about to join the pro tennis ranks.

Installed cost of equipment sold by members of the Air-Conditioning Manufacturers Association this year will approximate $85,000,000, compared with $53,000,000 last year, it was announced yesterday following the annual Fall meeting of the association, just completed in Chicago.

Seven teams competed in the tourney conducted by the Long Island Women's Field Hockey Association for Long Island and Brooklyn private schools on the Adelphi College field today. The outstanding players received emblems and certificates or both.

Believed to be the first dog ever to use a mechanical aid to hearing, Duke, a Boston terrier owned by Dr. George Cohen, veterinarian at the Park Veterinary Hospital, 229 East Sixtieth Street, was back on the job yesterday.

Carleton Upham of New York, who says he agreed with Mrs. Marcella Upham of Boston to be her "companion and shape his life according to her needs" if she left hiM the bulk of her estate, brought suit today for $2,000,000 against the executor of the estate.
A decline in the wholesale commodity price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for the last week in October was announced today by Commissioner Lubin.

Four favorites in a row today entered the winner's circle at Rockingham Park in the first five races. J. H. Logan's Miss Mars, the last of the quartet to score, annexed the feature race by one length over W. G. Townsend's Diarissa, who, incidentally, was the second choice.

The marriage of Mrs. Annette Scheuhing Davies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Scheuhing of Philadelphia, to Charles Dudley Walker, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel 0. Walker of Depver, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Marble COllegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentyninth Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale.

Prime Minsister Neville Chamberlain admitted today that his government was negotiating with Generalissimo Francisco Franco for the admission of agents who would watch over British live and British trade interests in Spanish Insurgent territory.

The election of United States Senator A. Harry Moore as Governor of New Jersey will be contested in a series of recounts and investigations, it was learned definitely tonight from leaders in the Republican patty.

We went out before breakfast yesterday morning to find out whether the surf anglers were still angling, and managed to locate a few members of the long-rod brotherhood, but not many. The Jones Beach Surf Fishing Club members seem to have deserted the rod and taken to the duck gun, although a few diehards still pull in an occasional weakfish at Parking Field 9.

The movement for a mid-term convention of the Republican party next year along the lines of suggestions attributed to former President Hoover by opponents of the idea was at least temporarily shelved here tonight on the eve of the national committee meeting at which advocates of the convention idea had expected that it would be approved.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest Wendell L. Willkie's article in the magazine section of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 31, under the caption "New Deal Power Plan Challenged."

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the preferred, common class A and common class B stocks of the Railroad Employes Corporation. The Manufacturers Trust Company is paying agent for $329,000 of Jefferson Plaquemines Drainage District bonds of Louisiana, series of 1937.

Increase of almost $20,000,000 in deposits of chartered banks was noted today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 51.80 per cent this week, 54.18 last.

Mrs. Virginia Kobbe Hollins of New York, daughter of Mrs. Gustav Kobbe of East Islip, L. I., was married to Henry Morgan of East Islip here this afternoon at the home of George B. Thatcher by the Rev. William Moll Case.

The appointment of Judge Francis D. McCurn of Syracuse as a justice of the Supreme Court, Fifth District, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Edward L. Robertson of Syracuse, was announced today by Governor Lehman.

A Netherland ship landed today at the port of Manzanilla with 1,000 tons of United States munitions intended for Loyalist Spain. The war material is to be transmitted to Veracruz, where a Loyalist cargo ship is prepared to take it aboard and run the Rebel blockade.
A decline in the wholesale commodity price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for the last week in October was announced today by Commissioner Lubin.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest Wendell L. Willkie's article in the magazine section of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 31, under the caption "New Deal Power Plan Challenged."

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the preferred, common class A and common class B stocks of the Railroad Employes Corporation. The Manufacturers Trust Company is paying agent for $329,000 of Jefferson Plaquemines Drainage District bonds of Louisiana, series of 1937.

Increase of almost $20,000,000 in deposits of chartered banks was noted today in the statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 51.80 per cent this week, 54.18 last.

Mrs. Virginia Kobbe Hollins of New York, daughter of Mrs. Gustav Kobbe of East Islip, L. I., was married to Henry Morgan of East Islip here this afternoon at the home of George B. Thatcher by the Rev. William Moll Case.

The appointment of Judge Francis D. McCurn of Syracuse as a justice of the Supreme Court, Fifth District, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Edward L. Robertson of Syracuse, was announced today by Governor Lehman.

A Netherland ship landed today at the port of Manzanilla with 1,000 tons of United States munitions intended for Loyalist Spain. The war material is to be transmitted to Veracruz, where a Loyalist cargo ship is prepared to take it aboard and run the Rebel blockade.

Morris Goldis, 27 years old, was indicted yesterday for the firstdegree murder of William Snyder, one-time president of Teamsters Local Union 138. He was first charged with the killing in 1934 and freed in Homicide Court, where his attorney was Charles A. Schneider, Tammany leader of the Eighth Assembly District, who resigned as assistant State attorney general on Wednesday.

Joseph Loye, chairman of the executive committee of the advisory committee on accessories and apparel for the New York World's Fair 1939, and Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair, signed a contract yesterday afternoon for rental of 53,433 square feet of exhibit space on which the allied apparel and accessories industries will erect a $500,000 building. The ceremony.

Predicting a "Class A transit crisis for the city" if the Interborough Rapid Transit Company should be permitted to disaffirm its 999-year leases of its elevated lines, William G. Mulligan Jr., assistant corporation counsel, suggested to Federal Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday the appointment of a committee to settle the pending controversy between the Interborough and 'the Manhattan companies through reorganization and consolidation of both corporations.

Unusual activity in odd-lot transactions on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Oct. 23 was reported today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. With market values falling, there were purchases aggregating 4,841,451 shares valued at $116,680,113 and sales of 3,319,616 shares valued at $81,961,761. Shares bought on balance numberecd 1,521,835.

The National Maritime Union reached an agreement yesterday with the Black Diamond Steamship Company calling for an increase in wages of about 12 per cent and improvements in working conditions. The union, an affiliate of the C. I. O., acted for the company's unlicensed sea-going personnel.

More than 350 officials of banks in New England have registered for the eighth New England bank management conference to be held tomorrow in the Hotel Statler here, under the auspices of the bankers' committee of the New England Council.
Herbert H. Howard, Albany real estate agent and a leading Mason in this section of the State, died today. He was stricken Tuesday with apoplexy.
As a result of a decline of more than a half cent a pound in the price of cotton within a week, less cotton was offered yesterday in producing sections and the market steadied somewhat.
Rally, New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, Women's Division, Plaza Theatre, Madison Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, 10:30 A. M. Address by Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman.

After two weeks of light skirmishing, Army is on the march again with heavy packs and facing a major objective beset with mouse traps that all but took the hide off the Princeton Tiger. The invasion of Soldiers Field by the West Point cadets turns the spotlight on them for the first time since their disastrous experience in the Yale Bowl.

The feature event of the thirteenth annual meeting of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of America held at the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club today was the open all-age cocker stake. Sixteen outstanding dogs competed.

Columbia's football team received the polishing touches on offensive play in its final practice of the week at Baker Field yesterday in preparation for the battle with Navy at Annapolis tomorrow. The Lions were restricted to light work the second successive day.

The Gibraltar frontier police made an important discovery this afternoon when a mule cart en route to La Linea from Gibraltar carrying several big boxes was examined and found to contain firearms, ammunition and shells destined for General Francisco Franco's army.

High blood pressure, one of the most frequent causes of death, particularly among older persons, is rarely caused by food or by alcohol taken in moderation, Dr. Herman 0. Mosenthal, Professor of Clinical Medicine at the New York Post Graduate Medical School of Columbia University, declared last night in a paper at the tenth annual graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

Deploring sheltered nursery life that deprives young children- of their independence, Mrs. Rustin McIntosh, head mistress of the Brearley School, declared yesterday that parents should give their children more physical freedom and allow them to participate in tasks about the house.

Visitors to the Mayor's office In City Hall yesterday tramped over the spreadeagled skin of a large tiger which was given to Mayor La Guardia as a present from Colonel Harold Fowler, first deputy police commissioner.

Back from Hollywood and his movie appearances, Leopold Stokowski began his six-week term as co-conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra with an all-Russian program tonight at the Academy of Music. The largest audience yet in attendance at the Thursday night "experimental" concerts, which are replacing the Saturday night programs for a few weeks, greeted him.

A military service for Colonel Leonidas Coyle, State Fire Warden, who was found dead in his apartment here on Tuesday, was held here today. Chaplain Walter Angelo of the 114th Infantry, New Jersey National Guard, officiated. Burial was in the Princeton Cemetery, Princeton.

The Nev York Americans, showing vast im provement over the club which fin ished in the International Groul cellar last season, shut out the Chi cago Black Hawks, 3-0, in a fasNational Hockey League battle to night. A crowd of 13,000 saw the opening engagement of the cam paign.

Consumer price resistance, and the fact that the public has apparently satisfied its replacement needs, are blamed for a decline of 3.5 per cent in retail sales of furniture and house furnishings for the third quarter, compared with the corresponding period in 1936, in the quarterly digest issued yesterday by Arthur Fertig Co., accountants.

The auction sale of the library of the late Frederick Spiegelberg of this city, which was completed last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., brought a total of $27,137 at three auction sessions.

Mrs. John S. Walker Jr., daughter of former Senator Sutherland, was found dead today, overcome in her bathroom by carbon monoxide gas. Mrs. Walker was president of the State Federation of Republican Women's Clubs.

Two doughty representatives of the Irish Free State captured the honors in the second phase of the international military jumping competition in Madison Square Garden last night. This part of the low-score event was the most popular number of the second evening program of the Fifty-second National Horse Show.
Mrs. Henry. E. Warwick gave a luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for several of the members of the St. Hilda's Guild after their sewing meeting at Grace House, 802-Broadway.

F. D. Shaw and Rolfe Kaltenborn gained the final of the Heights Casino invitation squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday, winning a semi-final match by 15--4, 15-11, 15-6, from A. B. Sheridan and Earl Holmes.

A demonstration of the printing etching will be given by David Strang of London this afternoon at 3 o'clock at Rockefeller Center, on the seventh floor of Maison FranCaise, where the annual exhibition of the Society of American Etchers is in progress.

The Hearn Department Stores announced yesterday plans for expanding their sales of home furnishings and the centering of warehousing facilities at 675 Sixth Avenue, corner of Twenty-first Street, a six-story building containing 285,000 square feet of space.

Mrs. Lillian Stokes Bostwick McKim, daughter of Mrs. Fitch Gilbert of this city and the late Albert C. Bostwick, was married to Ogden Phipps yesterday morning in the apartment which the bride has taken for the Winter at 117 East Seventy-second Street.

The second night of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden was marked with a large and fashionable attendance, and a scintillating display of fashion. The boxholders showed great enthusiasm over the chief features of the evening.
The body of a smartly dressed won man found in an automobile parked at the side of a lonely country lane near here was identified by authori? ties tonight as Lucy Dubank Ward, 35. of Pittsburgh. Pa.

The postal authorities will issue special anti-Semitic postcards in connection with the new anti-Semitic exposition, "The Eternal Jew." The cards bear stamps that promise to become a collectors' rarity.

Complaints that he used more than $60,000 of his customers' securities for his personal trading activities in the stock market resulted yesterday in the arrest of a dealer in securities who described himself as Malcolm E. Kennedy, 40 years old, of 29 Broadway, on a charge of grand larceny.

The Rev. James M. Cahill, Professor of Philosophy and Religion at Fordham College, has been appointed regent of the Fordham University School of Law, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university.

Clarita Sanchez, soprano, will give a recital this evening at Town Hall. The Federal Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Louis Kroll, will be heard tonight at the WPA Theatre of Music. Samuel Antek, violinist, will be soloist. Carmela Ippolito, violinist, will play a free concert this evening at the Midtown Community Center, 93 Park Avenue.

A cow and her calf strayed from a pasture early today and wrecked the Illinois Central "Panama Limited." James T. White, 40, of Memphis, the fireman, was crushed to death beneath the overturned locomotive, and Charles J. Barnett, of Memphis, the engineer, was injured critically.

The auction sale of the library of the late Frederick Spiegelberg of this city, which was completed last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., brought a total of $27,137 at three auction sessions.

Mrs. John S. Walker Jr., daughter of former Senator Sutherland, was found dead today, overcome in her bathroom by carbon monoxide gas. Mrs. Walker was president of the State Federation of Republican Women's Clubs.

In its monthly supplementary report of foreign trade, the Department of Commerce published today figures showing how exports and imports gained by countries in September over the corresponding month of last year.

Ernest J. Hanford, former first vice president of Frederick Loeser Co., Brooklyn department store, died of coronary thrombosis today at his home, 2 Barclay Road, here. Mr. Hanford, who was 65 years old, retired from business in 1917 after passing virtually all his adult life with Loeser's.

The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals sued yesterday in Supreme Court to be declared exempt from the New York City sales tax on the ground that it was a semi-public institution within the meaning of the- sales tax law.

Only $4,621,865 of new financing by one State and forty-one municipalities is scheduled for the coming week. This compares with the revised total of $6,638,942 for the past week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $24,048.986.

Forty heavy government bombers made a raid on Saragossa today, according to a Loyalist air communique, and blew up a large munitions dump. The explosion not only was witnessed by pilots but was also seen and heard from the ground, it is stated.

The United States Embassy today investigated and reported to the State Department upon the nationalization yesterday of 350,000 acres of Mexican oil lands under lease to the Standard Oil Company of California in the Southern States of Tabasco and Chiapas, Ambassador Josephus Daniels said.

A jinx that has almost reached the proportions of the one-time Yale Bowl specter will face Dartmouth's football team in Palmer Stadium tomorrow before an anticipated crowd of 30,000 when the Hanover Indians seek their first victory over Princeton since 1913.

Communism is not an issue, either in Spain or China, but clamor concerning an international fight against bolshevism by aggressor countries "may be a smoke screen for attacks against other parts of the globe," AlexanderTroyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, said last night in an address at Carnegie Hall.
Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 769,000 bales, against 771,000 a week ago, 773,000 two weeks ago, 726,000 three weeks ago and 758,000 a year ago;

The Bureau of Navigation released the followings orders today, dated Nov. 3: Mason Lt. Comdr. R. E., Hartford, Conn., to the Savannah and on board as First Lieutenant and Damage Control Officer when commissioned.

A few months ago the Mediterranean waters boiled. Now they simmer and steam. In the meantime dozens of ships have been torpedoed in this sea. Today slow-moving patrol boats along the traffic lanes are sinister reminders that another undeclared war still is in progress.

A contest for a one-act opera by an American composer on an American theme has been announced by Paul Csonka, director of the Salzburg Opera Guild, which makes its debut here tonight at the Fortyfourth Street Theatre.

The Social Security Advisory Council, attended by twenty-two representatives of labor, industry and the public, started today discussion of proposals to extend the Social Security Act coverage to 13,000,000 more persons than the 35,000,000 already included.
Bowing once more to public opinion even though it may be minority public opinion, the Duke of Windsor this evening announced that he had decided to postpone his visit to the United States.

Children's Peace Sunday will be commemorated tomorrow by 38,000,000 pupils and teachers in the Protestant Sunday Schools of the world. This is because Armistice Day is next Thursday. The. observance will be under the auspices of the Peace Education Committee of the World's Sunday School Association.
Class 2, Limit Harness Horse (over 14.2 First, Mrs. Loula Long Combs's br. m.

Miss Jane Carrott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orville Browning Carrott of Belle Haven, this place, has completed plans for her marriage to William Hall Boardman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Boardman of Quarry Top, Riverdale-on-Hudson, which will take place on the afternoon of Nov. 25 in St. Mary's Church here.
By this time a great many newspaper readers have no doubt discovered the secret. If the world as reflected on the front page in the

Defending its anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America, the government today informed the Supreme Court that the corporation's assets had increased by nearly $148,000,000 in the twenty-two years up to 1934.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The analysis of the election vote by Arthur Krock was most enlightening and of particular interest, since written by one who, like the physician, knows his pulse and takes the count before arriving at conclusions.

Raw silk estimated at $2,800 was stolen yesterday morning by burglars who utilized a truck, also stolen, to carry away the loot, according to a report made to police of the Ericsson Place station yesterday by the Virginia Motor Lines, a trucking firm at 115 Watts Street. Detectives of the safe and loft squad also investigated.

Babe Didrikson, playing exhibition golf here, said today she had received a telegram signed by Grantland Rice inviting her to play in a match at the Fresh Meadow Club on Long Island Sunday, Nov. 14, with John Montague, Babe Ruth and Miss Helen Hicks and that the receipts were to go to the Boys Club of New York. She wired her acceptance.

National conservation groups, representing agriculture, forestry and wildlife, began a nation-wide attack today on the conservation provisions of the government Reorganization Bill, scheduled to be taken up by the coming special session of Congress.

For the first time in its corporate history the Radio Corporation of America, through action taken yesterday by the board of directors at a special meeting, declared a dividend on its outstanding common stock.

A glance at today's football schedule makes it seem almost as if games in many sections had been arranged carefully with a view toward setting the stage for the familiar specter of Autumn Saturdays, the upset.
In command all the way, Phil Bieber's Founder today won the mile and a sixteenth feature at Rockingham Park.

Legislation to authorize widespread reorganization of the government machinery will be the first business of the Senate when the special session of Congress convenes, Senator Byrnes told President Roosevelt today.

Mr. and Mrs. Giraud Van Nest Foster have left the Pierre to join Mr. Foster's father, Giraud Foster, at Bellefontainc, Lenox, Mass. Mr. and Mrs. George W. van Siclen, Miss Elise Irving van Siclen and Mrs. Arthur van Siclen are at the Blackstone for the Winter.

The former site of Camp Gregory, consisting of sixty-four acres of farm land in Woodbury, Orange County, has been sold by Hiram C. Todd to Renanah Park, Inc., a membership corporation, which plans to use the property as a Summer colony for its members.

The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee charged today that the Guaranty Trust Company of New York had staged a "cheap publicity stunt" when yesterday it "accused the subcommittee of distributing a printed volume containing a false financial exhibit."

With the varsity and reserves in their best physical condition of the season, City College is hopeful of bringing its home football schedule to a successful close today when it, opposes the St. Joseph's College eleven of Philadelphia at Lewisohn Stadium. The kick-off is set for 2 P. M.

A mortgage for $600,000 on the group of five four-story buildings on the s e cor of Madison Ave and 35th St and on the twostory structure at 43 E 34th St, contiguous, was assigned by B. Altman Co., John S. Burke. president, to the Altman Foundation, George R. Read Co., attorney, 30 Nassau St.
The Washington University Bears capitalized on breaks tonight to score two touchdowns and defeat the Oklahoma Aggies, 12 to 0, in a Missouri Valley Conference game.

General Evangeline Booth of the Salvation Army will speak on "The March of Christianity" at a meeting in the Metropolitan Opera House tomorrow at 3 P. M., to be held as a tribute to her under the sponsorship of a New York Citizens Committee of 250, of which Henry W. Taft is chairman.

Dr. Halvdan Koht, Foreign Minister of Norway, who has been in the United States for several days discussing a reciprocal trade treaty with Secretary of State Cordell Hull, said last night at a farewell dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria that the Norwegian Government was in hearty accord with Mr. Hull's premise that trade agreements were an effective means to promote international friendship.

Hearings on the application of Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, for authority to disaffirm its lease of the elevated lines continued before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack yesterday, with a mass of accounting and statistical data being put in evidence.
A total of $84,302 has been given in scholarships to 186 members of the class of 1941, according to the freshman scholarship committee. These new awards were announced today:
With the government's monthly estimate of the cotton crop due on Monday, there was less selling pressure on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices improved 9 to 10 points, ending at the top.
The two-story dwelling at 2,068 West Sixth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold for cash by the Gotham Equities Corporation (Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner) to a client of Sabatore Mannone.
The formation of a committee of Scarsdale commuters to oppose discontinuance of service on the New York, Westchester Boston Railway was announced today.

The Pullman Company's revenues from the operation of its passenger cars increased in September, but larger expenses decreased the net return, according to a statement issued yesterday. For the nine months ended on Sept. 30, however, both gross and net increased. The results are shown in the following table:

Sales of household refrigerators in the United States in September totaled 79,905 units valued at $6,445,727, compared with 72,846 units valued at $5,431,226 in September, 1936, a gain of 18.7 per cent in dollar sales, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

George Washington made the errors and Mississippi turned them into touchdowns tonight as the Southerners converted two intercepted passes and a pair of recovered fumbles into a 27-to-6 intersectional football triumph before 11,800 fans.
The Department of Commerce reported today that gold worth $28,328,130 was imported into the United States in the week ended on Oct. 29.

It is now clear that the stretch-out system is not being applied to the wage slaves who are counting P. R. ballots at the rate of $10 a day. But human nature is doing about as well as could be expected under the circumstances. P. R. is new, a job is a job,
