Mrs. Patricia Ryan, 20 years old, who is alleged to have shot and killed her husband, Patrolman Michael Ryan, in a quarrel Sunday at their home at 1,350 Purdy Street, the Bronx, was indicted yesterday by the Bronx grand jury for murder in the first degree.

Retail milk prices will be increased 1 cent a quart and the price of heavy cream will go up 2 cents a half pint, with proportionate rises for other cream items, beginning tomorrow, according, to announcements by the Sheffield Farms Company and the Borden Company last night.

The Commonwealth statistician estimates that the wheat harvest for the 193738 season is 163,000,000 bushels, or 13,000,000 more than the 1936-37 yield, and will be the highest since the 177,000,000-bushel crop in 1934.
Secretary Wallace appointed an advisory committee today for New York State to help administer loans to tenants for buying farms under the new Tenant Aid Law.

Manhattan Alterations 114th St, 606 W; to 4-story tenement; Berho Realty Co; 209 Prospect Ave. Mamaroneck. N. Y., owner; Moore Landsiedel, architects; cost $4,500. 20th St, 320 E; to 5-story school; Board of Education, City of N. Y., owner; Walter C. Martin. architect; cost $3,500.

Governor Lehman today called upon Edward F. Jaeckie, Erie County Republican chairman, to submit to him by letter all the facts and allegations in his possession on which the demand was made that the Governor name a special District Attorney to prosecute charges of municipal payroll padding in Buffalo.
Fears that a corner may exist in Pure Oil Company 5 per cent preferred stock led yesterday to action by the New York Stock Exchange.
AMHERST vs. Trinity--What this world needs is more harmony and less discord. The Book of Musical Knowledge, by Arthur Elfson, may provide the key. Striking a musical note, A minor vote for Amherst.

Directors of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation have repealed authorization of an issue of 16,964 additional preferred shares and ordered withdrawal of the application made last August for registration of the issue with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Pittsburgh's potent contender for national gridiron honors and awakened Notre Dame will collide tomorrow in the final game of their series, probably before a capacity crowd of 56,000.

The third year of the Chinese Art Club has been inaugurated by the election this month of M. Tiam as president. The showing of Chinese art, plays, exhibitions, classes and other cultural gatherings are among the club's many activities.

Beyond admitting that the announcement of the impending mediation by Germany in the Sino-Japanese conflict is "premature" none of the official or diplomatic quarters concerned was prepared today to deny that negotiations to that end are progressing.

The Treasury Department capitulated sufficiently to Rockwell Kent today to make final payment for the two murals he executed in the Postoffice Department building. It mailed to him a check for $1,050. He had previously received $1,950.
The Navy football team made its final preparations today for the game with Columbia tomorrow with a short workout in Thompson Stadium. The pass defense,

Marked by the complete absence of any corporate financing and restricted entirely to issues for new tax-exempt securities, the new bond financing this week fell to a total of $3,130,000, the smallest since the week ended Oct. 15, when new loans of $2,850,000 were marketed.

Wesleyan and Williams will meet here tomorrow in a Little Three football contest that may have an important bearing on the series. Wesleyan has been defeated by Amherst, which will oppose Williams next week.
Today's most important incident in Palestine's unceasing reign of terror was the killing of two British, soldiers of the Black Watch regiment.
Jean de Brunhoff, French artist and the originator of the Babar stories for children, died in Switzerland on Oct. 16 at the age of 37, according to word received here yesterday.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels's speech in the Berlin Sportspalast tonight, which was expected to be a high point in the colonial and minorities campaign, turned out to be significant only for its threats against the church. Neither the colonies nor minorities were mentioned.

Cooperative business management of the thirteen fraternity chapters in Amherst College, a plan adopted a year ago, has resulted in marked savings, according to a report presented today to the alumni council.

Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia tonight set a new high run of 98 in the world pocket billiard championship. He defeated Charles Seaback of Boston, 125 to 87, in six innings. The previous high run, 96, was made by Ralph Greenleaf of New York, the defending champion, Oct. 28.

The marriage of Miss Lillian Kathleen Feicht, daughter of Mrs. Caroline Feicht of New York, to Harry Mattes Galbraith, son of Harry Hager Galbraith of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mrs. Galbraith, took place yesterday afternoon in the Fort George Presbyterian Church.

The power to bring about an alleviation of certain conditions which have affected the business and economic life of the nation to such a degree that the country now is on the threshold of another depression unless those conditions are corrected, lies principally in the hands of the Federal government, investment bankers, assembled here at the twenty-sixth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America, were told today.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 30 totaled 771,655 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,698 cars, or 0.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 42,859 cars, or 5.3 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 89,657 cars, or 13.1 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
Stocks eased and closed irregular after moderate gains; turnover, 1,250,550 shares. United States Government bonds higher, rail issues weak, Japanese obligations strong; transactions, $744,900.

Stell Andersen, American concert pianist, who played Chopin and Mozart for the Duke and Duchess of Windsor and the other guests at a dinner given last night by William C. Bullitt, United States Ambassador, told today how the Duke had inquired after the concert where she had studied in Europe.
Metro laid plans today for the future with one story purchased, a "Thin Man" sequel added to the schedule and a writer sent to prepare a history of the Canadian Royal Mounted Police.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Princeton's varsity cross country team defeated Harvard and Yale in their sixth annual triangular meet over a four and a half mile course today for Big Three laurels.

Kenneth Collins, vice president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., will head the department and specialty store groups in the United Hospital Fund drive to raise $3,171,000 needed by ninety-two hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

John J. O'Brien, secretary to Senator and Governor-elect A. Harry Moore, died yesterday at the Medical Center here from complication of ailments. His age was 50. He was scheduled to become the secretary to Governor-elect Moore when the latter assumed his office in the State House next January.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 4: MAJOR GENERAL Brown, A. W., Judge Advocate General, Washington, D. C., to retirement.

Walter O'Keefe, in Hotel Ambassador, Park Ave and 51st St. Julius C. Holmes, in 830 Park Ave; George W. Ullman. through Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc. in 375 Park Ave; Herman F. Feinstein, in 151 E 80th St; Renee O. Ross, in 75 Central Park W; Byrne Bowman, Inc, broker.

Production of hosiery in September was 7,816,330 dozen pairs, a moderate gain over the 7,702,758 dozen pairs produced in August but a drop of 9 per cent from the 8,589,015 dozen pairs turned out in September, 1936, according to figures made public by the Bureua of the Census yesterday, based on reports from 381 manufacturers, representing 445 mills.

Richard Edgcumbe, who had been sergeant at Arms to Queen Victoria, Edward VII and George V, died yesterday at his Berkshire home. He was 94 years old and had spent more than forty years in the royal household.

Heinz Rutha, right-hand man of Konrad Henlein, leader of the Sudeten German [Nazi] party, hanged himself last night in his cell at Boehmisch-Leipa jail, where he was detained on charges of immorality.

Major Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Brooklyn department store 'which bears his name, told the annual dinner gathering of the New York University School of Retailing at the University Restaurant last night that if the retailers of the country did not soon join to regulate themselves government regulation would make them "an aggregation of glorified slot machines."

Steps designed to bring about a more progressive and aggressive stand, especially in matters of legislation, on the part of the Investment Bankers Association of America were taken here today in two unexpected moves embodied in a report of the special advisory committee of the association.

President Roosevelt announced today that Charles H. Robb, Associate Justice of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, would retire Nov. 15, the day after he becomes 70 years old.
Ever since the Federal Theatre Project put on its famous version of T. S. Eliot's "Murder in the Cathedral," various commercial producers have flirted with the idea of offering it again to Broadway.

Edward Atkinson St. John, vice president of the National Surety Corporation of New York, died here today of pneumonia at his home, 117 Brixton Road. Mr. St. John was born Aug. 26, 1869, at Buffalo, where he was educated in the public schools.

Orders for better blouses for cruise and resort wear are being placed both by local buyers and on the West Coast several weeks earlier than usual, and initial requests are running larger than for several years, manufacturers said yesterday.

What amounted to a European flight from the dollar yesterday lift'ed all important foreign exchanges to higher prices than they have seen in more than a year and caused the price of gold in London to rise almost to the equal of our Treasury's buying price here, nearly 23 cents above the gold-shipping parity.

The Works Progress Administration notified Senator William H. Smathers today that President Roosevelt had approved allotment of $185,000 for eleven New Jersey projects. All subject to review by the ControllerGeneral, they are:
Acceding to the requests of various corporations, the New York Stock Exchange cut yesterday from ten to seven days the required notice of the record date of a dividend.

Retail distribution made further gains last week, although depending largely on price reductions to build volume, but, despite an increase over the previous week amounting to 2 to 6 per cent, the gain over a year ago ranged only from 4 to 15 per cent, which was less than the preceding week's gain over a year before, according to the weekly trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.
Arthur K. Winget of Albemarle, N. C., was elected president of the North Carolina Cotton Manufacturers Association today to succeed Herman Cone of Greensoro; Herman Cone of Greensoro;
A strong St. John's Prep eleven defeated a stubborn Provdence College freshman squad, 6-0, in Alumni Stadium today.
Liquidation of the late Ivar Kreuger's affairs has progressed so far that the administrators of the bankruptcy estate propose to pay dividends.

Columbus and Southern Ohio Electric Company and SubsidiariesTwelve months to Sept. 30: Net income, after all expenses and taxes, $2,804,826, comparing with a net of $2,589,406 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1936; gross revenues for the period were $11,618,321, against $10,671,389 previously.

Miss Ellen Lehman entertained with a dinner last night at the Stork Club for Miss Loriel Martens Johnson and William Livingston Desloge of St. Louis, whose marriage will take place next Friday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. Halsey Johnson of Aubyn Manor, Mount Vernon, N. Y. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Lewis, Miss Eleanor French, Miss Marjorie Hothorne and James Lewis.

A challenge for the Seawanhaka Cup, blue ribbon trophy of small yacht racing internationally, has been received by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L. I., it was announced yesday. It came from the Royal Northern Yacht Club of Scotland, and is for a match next year.

Foreign Minister Guido Schmidt flew to Berlin on a surprise visit tonight. The official explanation of the trip is his desire to visit the International Hunting Exposition, but there is little doubt that the real reason for his precipitate departure is the crisis in Austro-German trade relations.

Harry Roth, identified as a former aide ot Charles (Lucky) Luciano, and ten other persons pleaded guilty today to indictments arising from a Federal grand jury's investigation of the white slave traffic in New Jersey.

5th Ave, 379, 24.5x100; Column Holding Corp to Cabin Holding Corp, 565 5th Ave. 1st Ave, 1,641, 25x75; excx will of Ernestine Breitenbach to Elsie Whitten, 117 Seaman Ave; consideration $11,000 over mtg for $9,000.

The one-family residence at 47-51 Parsons Boulevard, on a plot which runs through to 156th Street, in the Kissena Park section of Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, represented by Harry G. Gebhard, Inc., to Katherine Page Kennedy.
A doe deer and her fawn sought escape today from Deep Fall Creek Gorge, bordering Cornell University's campus, after spending the night on a ledge opposite the university's power plant.

J. C. Pierce, an agricultural student at North Carolina State College, became the 1937 intercollegiate poultry judging champion yesterday afternoon at the Twentieth Eastern Intercollegiate Poultry Judging contest, which was held at the Poultry Industries Exposition in the Port Authority Building, Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street.
An exchange transaction involving a West Side apartment house and a building site in Westchester County featured realty activity in the metropolitan area yesterday.

New York's theatre buildings of the future undoubtedly will differ vastly from the typical amusement structures of today in architectural design and layout. The change will come about not from a gradual evolution of construction or planning methods, but from sweeping revision of the regulations governing this type of edifice under the new Building Code which goes into effect on Jan. 1, 1938.

A parade of several hundred modern and ancient vehicles of transportation was held tonight on Broad Street as a prelude to the National Motor Truck show and the Newark Automobile Show opening tomorrow. More than 7,000 persons lined the route of the procession.

The marriage of Miss Rita Catherine Mulroy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Joseph Mulroy, to Melville Perrine Chamberlain Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs.'Melville P. Chamberlain of Hightstown, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents.
At 10:15 tonight the following bulletin was flashed over, news tickers: "The Duke of Windsor has decided to postpone his visit to America."
Mayor Andrew J. "Bossy" Gillis tonight brought forward his wife as the "darkhorse" candidate he had been promising. Two minutes before the deadline, Mrs. Louise B. Gillis filed nomination papers.
In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals Charles C. Willson of New York was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:
The Amherst swimming team defeated an all-star alumni team, 37-31, today to dedicate Amherst's new $165,000 pool.

Dr. William Allan Neilson, president of Smith College, advised 800 women students and alumnae of Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn yesterday to put more faith in the mental capacity of their own sex and to assert their will "in the process of education" to combat the tendency of women to allow themselves to be intellectually browbeaten by men.
General Manager Jack Ogden of the Baltimore Orioles of the International League announced today the purchase of Nolen Richardson, veteran Newark shortstop,

Scholastic football activity comes to a close today for a few prep school elevens, notably Lawrenceville and Mercersburg, which will terminate their campaigns against Choate and Kiskiminetas, respectively.

Miss Hilda Ann Taylor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Fillmore Taylor of this city, became the bride of Richard Redwood Deupree Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Redwood Deupree of Cincinnati, today in St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

After seven hours' deliberation a jury in Federal Court returned a verdict of guilty last night against Clifford H. Parliman, former head of the House of Parliman, and Peter M. Steenland of Palisades Park, N. J., who were charged with mail fraud and conspiracy.

The Union Oil Company announced today that it had brought in the second deepest producing oil well in the world, which, by extending the San Joaquin Valley producing area, may result in the largest oil field in America, with the possible exception of the East Texas region.

Beginning Jan. 1, milk sold by the glass in restaurants, at soda fountains and all other food-dispensing places in this city must be sold in original containers or drawn from sealed dispensing devices satisfactory to' the Department of Health, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.
President Roosevelt, at his press conference today, characterized stock market speculation as "dangerous" and conveyed the impression that he thought it should continue to be "dangerous."
A newly formed chamber ensemble, the Trio of New York, made its local debut last night at the David Mannes School of Music, playing the first of a series of six Friday evening concerts.

Diplomatic inquiries from the Brussels conference into last night's Berlin report foreshadowing Chancellor Hitler's mediation in the SinoJapanese conflict indicated plainly today that while the American comment that it was "premature" was in some respects correct, the report itself had a substantial basis.
Fordham and Purdue will meet this afternoon at the Polo Grounds for the fourth time in the Maroon's third intersectional engagement of the season. Play will begin at 2 o'clock.
The continual assault on the lower-grade railroad bonds failed to letup yesterday and as a result the remainder of the issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange were unable to make any headway.
Death sentences today were reported imposed upon twenty persons for crimes against the Soviet Government, ranging from assassination plots to responsibility for the death of livestock.

October continued to reflect the down-trend in advertising, which had begun to get under way the previous month, according to compilation of available figures yesterday. The gain in magazine linage was narrowed to about 7 per cent, radio dropped an equal amount under a year ago, while newspapers might have run slightly ahead.
The twenty-ninth annual Brooklyn Automobile Show will open today at 2 P. M. at the 106th Infantry Armory, Bedford and Atlantic Avenues, for a week's showing of the 1938 models.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 4, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk: Sirius, Nov. 5; Acushnet. At Mare Island: Preble, Pruitt, Sicard, Tracy.
Guerlain, Inc., New York manufacturer of perfumes, asked $100,000 damages today in each of two suits filed against Washington firms, charging infringements of trademarks.
A temporary injunction restraining the Holly Sugar Corporation from paying a 25-cent dividend on its common stock was vacated yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.

The American Smelting and Refining Company yesterday lowered its price for copper in the domestic market 1/2 cent a pound to 11 cents. It is understood that the volume of business done at the new price was not any more encouraging than that following other price reductions.
Reports that Chancellor Adolf Hitler was prepared to mediate in the Sino-Japanese dispute were received with incredulity in official circles here.

The A. L. Improvement Company sold to Alvin Blau for investment the twenty-family apartment house at 336 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, N. J. The sale was arranged by B. F. Kislak, Inc., broker, for cash over a mortgage of $48,000. The same broker sold the sevenfamily flat at 320 Twelfth Street, West New York, for Leo Schreiber to Peter Valla for investment.
Thomas Peppler, 90-year-old head of Thomas Peppler Sons Co., farm implement concern, died at his home on York Road here last night of a heart attack.

William J. Coles of Taylortown Road, this community, retired secretary of the Waldrich Bleachery of Delawanna, died today at the Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, following an operation. He was 73 years old.

Harold Russell Ryder, former stock broker who served three years in Sing Sing Prison following conviction for grand larceny resulting from his activities in the stock market, was permanently enjoined yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer from dealing in securities in this State.

There are many more Democratic votes in Hudson County, N. J., than the Republicans can bear with composure, especially when their defeat is recent. So the cry of "fraud" is raised. The suspected ballot boxes are sealed. A recount is demanded.

A drop in cotton-mill activity last week, when the seasonal trend called for a slight increase, brought the adjusted index down to 114.8 from 121.2, the revised figure for the previous week. The index for the week ended Oct. 31, 1936, was 131.5.

Establishing himself as one of the greatest handicap champions in recent years, Seabiscuit today not only beat off challenge after challenge while carrying top weight of 130 pounds, but smashed a Pimlico track record in doing it. While Mr. and Mrs.

James Lodge, 29 years old, a steel worker of Poughkeepsie, N. Y., was drowned today when he fell seventy-five feet into Kensico Reservoir from a concrete ledge on which he was working directly beneath the Rye bridge on Route 22 here.

The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the Tennessee, Alabama Georgia Railway Company, a Delaware corporation, to issue up to $590,525 of capital stock, rights to subscribe to 15,405 of such shares of stock, and not more than $1,027,000 of first collateral lien twenty-year, 4 per cent, sinking fund bonds.

Bowing to opposition to the plan for a midterm conference to adopt a party platform for the 1938 Congressional campaign, the Republican National Committee today rejected former President Hoover's proposal for such a gathering, but moved to create a program committee to define the party's stand on national issues and report to the national committee.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Will some one please tell me what sense there is to the selection of an All-America football team each year ? Frankly, I think it's a farce and ought to be abolished.

The real estate brokerage business formerly known as S Jckwell Marling will in future be carried on under the firm name of Bertha Stockwell. Blumstein Management Company has moved its offices to 1,620 Amsterdam Avenue.
71st St, 115 W, 9-story brick apartment, 49.11x102.2; Leonard Mortgage Co against 115 W 71st St Corp; due, $50,742; taxes, etc, $2,622; subject to mortgage of $188,000; to plaintiff for $193,000.

Two bandits held up Herman Greenberg, proprietor of a gasoline station and restaurant at 709 West Edgar Road, this afternoon and escaped with $1,100 which one of the pair forced Mr. Greenberg to turn over to him after threatening him with a revolver. The bandits escaped in an automobile.

The stock markets here were quiet today, but prices were firm. Gilt-edge issues were in strong demand, while foreign loans were dull. International shares were firm in light trading; United States Steel and International Nickel showed gains.

Protesting that the company had refused to bargain collectively with them, more than 2,000 agents, members of the Independent Insurance Agents Union, Local 30, held a demonstration from noon to 1 o'clock yesterday around the building of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, Madison Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

Bowdoin's junior varsity won a close game from Exeter Academy, 7 to 0, today, scoring a touchdown in the third period. A forward pass, Tucker to Dale, gave the collegians the ball on Exeter's 5-yard mark. from where Tucker went over on the next play.

While on a recent hunting trip we came to realize just how much the CCC boys have done to insure the angler and hunter of today and tomorrow that he will have streams to fish and woods in which he may hunt.
The State Banking Department today announced approval of a reduction in the value of the capital stock, and an increase in the member shares of the Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York.

Trading in beef and veal was slow; other classes fair to good. Lamb and pork loins sold strong to higher. Other classes were mostly unchanged from Thursday. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be barely steady to lower, other classes strong to higher as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Sales of several large corner apartment houses in various sections of the Bronx marked the realty trading reported in that borough yesterday. One of the largest deals involved the six-story house at 3.510 Bainbridge Avenue, at the corner of East Gun Hill Road, on a plot 125 by 105 feet.

Miss Theodora Updike, daughter of Mr and Mrs. David Montgomery Updike of 160 East Forty-eighth Street, was married yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to Harrison Pease of Germantown, Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison H. Pease of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William D. F. Hughes.

The Canton-Kowloon Railway had its first respite today from daily airplane bombings which had been resumed on a small scale recently, The service is normal, because the slight damage was quickly repaired.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., at a hearing yesterday before the Public Service Commission, requested a postponement of the hearing on an application to issue $30,000,000 of new debentures for capital expenditures.

J. Richard (Dixie) Davis, attorney for the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and reputed heir to the latter's policy rackets, was disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in an unanimous decision.

Dr. Halvdan Koht, Norwegian Minister of Foreign Affairs, who has conferred here with Secretary of State Hull and President Roosevelt, will sail for home today on the Norwegian America liner Stavangerfjord.

In an official policy statement handed to members of a House Agriculturaz subcommittee, Secretary Wallace said today that cotton farmers would have to reduce annual plantings by 8,000,000 to 12,000,000 acres "to maintain a balanced supply" and that such a course would mean a sacrifice by producers of between $200,000,000 and $300,000,000 a year.

Deaths Announced Fireman First Grade William S. Hade of Hook and Ladder 37. died Nov. 4. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 2,314 Valentine Ave., Bronx, at 9:30 A. M., Monday, Nov. 8. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.
Transfers and Assignment PATROLMEN--From precinots indicated to office of the Second Deputy Police Commissioner, Division of Licenses, assignment to duty as inspectors of licensed hacks continued:
Thirty Lafayette football players are spending the night in Monroe County resting for the important game with Rutgers here tomorrow. A crowd of more than 15,000 is expected.

Judge Phillip Forman in United States District Court here said today he would call a three-judge court to hear the application for an injunction to restrain the Asbury Park Beach Front Commission from functioning.
Sixteen Boy Scouts will receive awards for saving lives given by the National Court of Honor of the Boy Scouts of America, National Scout Commissioner Daniel Carter Beard announced yesterday.

Retail trade here was featured by wide disparities between the showings of individual stores, but on the average was estimated as showing an increase of about 3 or 4 per centover the same week last year.
In more commodious quarters than last year, THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair of 1937 was opened to the public yesterday in Rockefeller Center, for its first day.
The Italian liner Roma passed through the harbor to her pier yesterday under the tow of tugs that had taken her in charge at the entrance to Ambrose Channel early yesterday morning.

According to a Brussels dispatch to The Evening Standard, it is understood that within the next few weeks Premier Benito Mussolini will withdraw the Italian Ambassador from Brussels as he recently recalled his Ambassador from Paris.

Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson has entered decrees approving the settlement of suits brought on behalf of note and debenture holders of the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago and Insull Utility Investments, Inc., against Chicago and New York bank creditors of those companies.
Private funeral services were held today for Winthrop Ames, a prominent figure in Boston and New York theatrical circles.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Howell of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their laughter, Miss Frances Cross Howell, to James Ferguson Locke, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Allen Locke of Boston and Williamstown.

Five more persons were eliminated as heirs to the $877,500 estate of Ida E. Wood yesterday when Surrogate James A. Foley ruled that there was insufficient evidence to substantiate their claims of relationship.

Paul Moss, License Commissioner, told 500 members of the Actors Equity Association yesterday afternoon that he planned to draft an ordinance providing a curb on speculation in theatre tickets by licensing all ticket brokers. The Equity members met in the Hotel Astor.

The Governor of the Panama Canal reported to the War Department today that 461 ocean vessels passed through the waterway during October, paying tolls amounting to $1,981,087.87, and eighty-two small vessels paid tolls of $4,170.56.

Ray Steele, 215, Glendale, Calif., threw Cliff Olson, 215, Minneapolis, in 20:13 of the main wrestling match at the Twenty-second Engineers Armory last night. A crowd of 2,000 saw the victor end the bout with a body spread.

Forty-one building and permanent loans totaling $185,000 have been arranged by Monroe Miller with the Dime Savings Bank for Warranty Homes, Inc., on dwellings under construction at 188th St near Liberty Ave. Hollis, Queens.
Scoring in each of the first three periods, Dartmouth's junior varsity football team defeated the Harvard jayvees, 20 to 0, at Soldiers Field today in their annual game.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ellis Brown gave a dinner at their home here tonight for their daughter, Miss Helen Langdon Brown, and John Herbert Claiborne, whose marriage will take place here tomorrow afternoon.

A touchdown in the last minute of the game by Jack Bolger, reserve back, enabled St. John's Prep of Brooklyn to take a thrilling 14-12 decision from Horace Mann in the sixth annual meeting between the schools at Horace Mann Field yesterday.

The holidays celebrating the twentieth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution were opened unofficially but gaily tonight. Tomorrow is a normal free day, so when the people quit work this evening it was for a holiday. that will last through Nov. 8, except for people working on essential services, such as transportation, electricity and the like.

John Palmieri, well known as a lawyer and Republican politician among Italian-Americans in this city for thirty years, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital of complications following an operation several weeks ago. Mr. Palmieri was 64 years old and lived at 150 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn. He had his law offices in the Pulitzer Building, 63 Park Row, for many years.

The remarks on Wednesday to the Foreign Trade Convention at Cleveland by Dr. O. M. W. Sprague, now of Harvard University but formerly special adviser to the Bank of England and later to our own Treasury Department, give food for thought.

Floral decorations for luncheon tables arranged by professional gardeners from suburban estates in the metropolitan area and similar arrangements by amateur gardeners in those communities were featured yesterday at the thirtieth annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York in the Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

The closed shop provision in the contract signed on Oct. 11 between the Independent Traction Workers Union and the B. M. T. will be suspended pending an investigation of the status of that union by the State Labor Relations Board.

A hearing has been called by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Nov. 19 on a declaration by the Worcester County Electric Company, Worcester, Mass., a subsidiary of the New England Power Association, covering the issuance of $250,000 of 2 per cent notes payable in six months.

Pointing out that when the present period of emergency expenditures, including armament building, has exhausted itself, the world will face the possibility of a depression and unemployment, the National Foreign Trade Convention in its final declaration today urged immediate steps to offset such a development through the widest possible expansion of foreign trade.
Richard W. Hill has been appointed secretary of the American Bankers Association, it was announced yesterday to Dr. Harold Stonier, executive manager of the association.

While waiting to plead for his clients in Tombs Magistrate's Court at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, James J. Mayer, an attorney, collapsed with an attack of heart disease. An attendant caught Mr. Mayer as he fell on to a bench inside the magistrate's enclosure. The lawyer was carried into Magistrate Ford's chambers, where he was attended by an ambulance surgeon from Beekman Street Hospital.

The Chemical Industry Medal for 1937 was presented to E. J. Crane, editor of Chemical Abstracts, at a joint meeting of the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry and the American Chemical Society at the Chemists Club, 52 East Forty-first Street, last night.

Walter Woods, East Side favorite, matched his boxing skill against a deadly right-hand punch and annexed a decision over tarry Balsamo, the "Belting Brakeman" from Harlem, in their ten-round bout at the Hippodrome last night.

Addressing the executive committee of the American Labor party at its campaign headquarters in the Hotel Claridge, Mayor La Guardia charged yesterday that John J. Knewitz, Bronx Republican leader, had sold out to the Democrats to re-elect Borough President James J. Lyons and denounced Mr. Knewitz as a "political pimp."

The movement for revision of the undistributed surplus tax gained a prominent supporter today in Senator Byrnes. "I am in favor of modifying, or repealing, the undistributed profits tax," he said after talking taxes with President Roosevelt.

An attorney should not expect much compensation for assisting a school board to negotiate a bond issue, Supreme Court Justice Raymond E. Aldrich indicated here today when a motion was argued in a suit brought by Irving B. Lydecker of White Plains for $2,500 legal fees from the Somers Board of Education.

Mrs. Mary M. Burnham, clubwoman, died yesterday afternoon after a long illness at the home of her daughter, Mrs. James S. Thompson, at 2 Oxford Road here. She was in her eighty-fourth year and had lived here since 1922.

Representatives of the International Longshoremen's Association in South Atlantic ports signed an agreement yesterday with operators of coastwise ships calling for wage increases of 8 cents an hour for regular time and 12 cents an hour for overtime.

Miss Dorothy Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Richard Coleman of Maplewood, was married this evening to Howard Gilbert Engler, son of Mrs. Charles H. Engler of South Orange, in St. George's Episcopal Church here. The rector, the Rev. Francis H. Richey, performed the ceremony.
Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Ambassador to Britain, arrived here this morning to sign on behalf of Germany the Italo-German-Japanese anti-Communist pact to be concluded tomorrow.
Five hundred couples danced in the Alumni Memorial Gymnasium tonight in the annual interfraternity ball which opened the social season at Lafayette College.

An authentic but not very illuminating account of the conference yesterday between President Roosevelt, Mayor La Guardia and Postmaster General Farley was made available here today. Its source was the President himself.
MANHATTAN FRIEDMAN, MAX (Aug. 7, 1938). Gross assets, $3,550; net, $2,894. To Ethel Friedman, widow. Chief assets, miscellaneous property. $3,500. Matt Goldstein, attorney, 225 W. 34th St.
Dr. William McKimmie Higgins, who maintained two pathological laboratories in New York for many years, died in New Haven Hospital yesterday after a month's illness.

The annual Armistice ball of the Seventy-seventh Division, A. E. F., will be held tonight at Hotel Roosevelt. A feature of the affair will be the massing of colors, with the various regiments of the division passing in review.

Liquidation was resumed today in the wheat market following an early advance of around 1 cent a bushel, and all deliveries in North American markets with the exception of December at Winnipeg dropped to new low levels for the season.

Elizabeth Drew, lecturer in English Language and Literature at Cambridge University and author of "Discovering Drama" (Norton), will be guest of honor at a tea at 4:45 P. M. tomorrow at the headquarters of the New York Branch of the English-Speaking Union, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Japanese extraterritorial privileges in Manchukuo were extinguished by a treaty signed in Hsinking, the Manchukuoan capital, today. The treaty will become effective Dec. 1. Since July, 1936, a system of partial abolition has been in force and Manchukuo with the help of Japanese advisers codified her laws and established reliable courts.
A new land fighting front in the Shanghai area has been established on the north shore of Hangchow Bay, according to an official Japanese announcement at 11 o'clock this morning, saying:
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration reported today that offshore producing areas had supplied all but 563,365 short tons of their 1937 raw sugar quotas.
The Haverford College soccer team went down to defeat before a strong Princeton team, 2-0, in an Intercollegiate League game today.

Mr. and Mrs. Elton Scovill Wayland gave a dinner and dance tonight at the Waterbury Country Club to introduce to society their eldest daughter, Miss Lucy Elton Wayland, for whom another dinner will be given on Dec. 3 in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton, New York, before the first Junior Assembly.

IT was Woodrow Wilson who taught us to distinguish between the nature of a people and the ambitions of their rulers. The trouble is that meantime the rulers go marching on. In his cautious appraisal of "Japan Over Asia,"* William Henry Chamberlin finds many good things to say about the people of Japan. All very true.
The will of Lizzie Birdseye, widow of Isaac W. Birdseye, Bridgeport manufacturer, and daughter of Aaron B. Sherwood, was filed for probate today. It disposes of a $500,000 estate.
Witb Menow, world sprint record holder, retired for the season due to an injury, the field for the $35,000 Pimlico Futurity, to be run tomorrow, consists of eight colts and one filly.

That Great Britain has taken a step toward de facto recognition of the Rebel regime in Spain is the obvious conclusion to be drawn from the guarded statement of Neville Chamberlain in the House of Commons on Thursday.

Senator Truman, Democrat, of Missouri, criticized Balthasar H. Meyer, Interstate Commerce Commissioner, after receiving evidence today that Mr. Meyer had told a railroad man about a commission decision before it was made public. Such disclosures are "very bad practice," said Senator Truman, who is acting chairman of the Senate's Rail Financing Committee.

Two libel suits totaling $800,000 were filed in Supreme Court today against Rayford W. Alley, defeated Democratic candidate for Nassau County Executive, in reference to statements issued by Mr. Alley during the campaign.

The Association of American Railroads, through J. J. Pelley, president, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition for authority to make a horizontal increase of 15 per cent in freight rates, except for five commodities for which maximum rates are requested and also for permission to change rates for passenger coach travel from 2 to 2 1/2 cents a mile in the Eastern territory.
Counsel for seven railroads operating in New Jersey petitioned the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today for a readjustment of State tax assessments on their properties.

189 St (11-3091), n s. 50 ft e of Belmont Ave. 50x90; John Lyons to Tillie Feldman, 24 Bay 32d St, Brooklyn; mtg $35,000. Hill Ave (17-5123), a e cor of Cranford Ave, 100x27; Benjamin Zevlin to Eastchester Savings Bank. Eagle Ave, 894 (10-2627); Dorothy Sklar to David Sklar, 67 W Tremont Ave.

Exclusive of Russia, the world's gold production in September amounted to 2,535,000 ounces, compared with 2,641,000 in August and 2,431,000 in September, last year, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics.

September installations by members of the Air Conditioning Manufacturers' Association decreased by 11.99 per cent, from the figure for September, 1936, William B. Henderson, executive vice president, announced yesterday.

Spencer D. Bettelheim, president of the Lyco Realty Corporation, a member of the executive staff of the Sam H. Harris theatrical interests for many years and a veteran of the World War, was found dead last night of two bullets in the head in his office on the second floor of the Lyceum Theatre on West Forty-sixth Street, between Broadway and Sixth Avenue.

Leases of store, office and showroom space in the midtown section of Manhattan were announced yesterday by brokers. Anne Nichols, author of "Abie's Irish Rose," has taken space for executive offices in 9 Rockefeller Plaza, Rockefeller Center.

Today's major events in concert and opera: "Cosi fan tutte," Salzburg Opera Guild, Forty-fourth Street Theatre, 8:40 P. M. (company's New York debut); Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; Eugene List, pianist, Town Hall, 3'P. M.; Philip Fine, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.;

Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont led a field of 48 players for low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association over the Shackamaxon Country Club course today. She carded 39, 45--84 in this extra test on the association's 1937 golf calendar.

Miss Frances Honnet Stern, only daughter of Mrs. Julius W. Cone of this place and the late David Stern, was married here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Cone to Ferris Sands Hetherington Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferris S. Hetherington of Plainfield, N. J.

Returning to the familiar surroundings of Ebbets Field after two road trips, the Manhattan football, team will engage a highly rated Detroit eleven this afternoon Showing that they were out of the doldrums by an impressive victory over Georgetown, the Jaspers are seeking to hand the Titans thei second defeat of the season.

The Sud Express, a crack train connecting Paris with Spain and Portugal, which ceased to run with the outbreak of the Spanish civil war, resumed operation today, taking passengers straight through to Lisbon.

The Electromotive Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, has delivered to the Union Pacific Railroada 5,400-horsepower oil-electric locomotive ordered last December for use between Chicago and Los Angeles on a schedule of thirty-nine and threequarters' hours.

Franklin D. Roosevelt has become the nation's most traveled President. His arrival from Hyde Park last night ended the eighth 600mile round trip to his mother's estate this year and raised his aggregate travel mileage since he became Chief Executive to 114,008.

A score of farmers from the Northeastern seaboard gave their approval generally of government crop control on a voluntary basis in testimony yesterday before a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Agriculture at a hearing in the State Office Building.
Dowagers and debutantes and many noted personalities in the world of sports were among the glittering assembly of society in the boxes at the Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

The biggest money transaction ever undertaken in the Swedish market was concluded today with the conversion of old loans amounting to 135,000,000 Swedish kronor and the issue of a 15,000,000 krona 3 per cent loan at 99 1/4 for conversions and 99 1/2 for new subscriptions.

Materials enough to make a few Frankenstein monsters were shown last night at a preview of new Fall exhibits of the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center. At the same time, with three generations of Townes on hand, a portrait of the late Henry R. Towne, a founder, was unveiled in the main hall.

It was reliably reported today that President.Getulio Vargas in a message to Congress early next week would ask immediate legislation to reduce the coffee export tax. Only sales as from Nov. 4 are to enjoy the new tax, which, it is believed now, has been settled at about 15 milreis a bag.

The Illinois Commerce Commission today granted the joint application of the Commonwealth Edison Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois for authority to redeem the $100-par preferred shares of Public Service at $120 a share, a price fixed in the charter.

The Japanese vanguard arrived at the north gate of Taiyuan, the capital of Shansi Province, last night, but decided to await reinforcements before entering the city. The walled city appeared defenseless, the Chinese forces having retreated across the country in a direction still unreported by Japanese scouts.
Harvard ruled a slight favorite tonight to gain its first victory over Army since 1931 when the two meet on Soldiers Field tomorrow before an estimated crowd of 45,000.

Canada's clever team of riders last night captured the international military competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. Thirteen thousand thrilled spectators cheered the splendid jumping of the visitors from across the border, who gained a leg on the perpetual trophy offered by His Excellency Arturo Alessandri, President of Chile.

Contributions totaling $317,000 were announced yesterday at the first report rally at the Plaza Theatre, Fifty-eighth Street near Madison Avenue, of the $1,000,000 campaign quota of the combined women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities.

Resuming a gridiron rivalry that lapsed twenty-eight years ago, New York University's football team will meet the fast, rangy Lehigh University eleven at the Yankee Stadium today. The game is scheduled to start at 2 P. M.
The city of London paid tribute to Earl Baldwin today as embodying "all that is best In the national character."

Dr. Louis J. Pritzker, physician and surgeon, who went into semi-retirement two years ago after practicing in Chicago for forty-five years, died today in the hospital at Kenosha, Wis., where he had a Summer home. He was 71 years old.

Applications of the Public Service Interstate Transportation Company of New Jersey to merge with the Public Service Interstate Transport to lease and purchase the Public Service Coordinated Transport, to issue securities to control Jersey Bus Lines, Inc.,

The General Motors Traffic Association has been formed to establish more uniform policies and practices with respect to the movement of freight and the readier exchange of helpful information between divisions of the corporation, it was announced yesterday by William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation.
Actual count of the paper ballots cast for the election of the members of the new City Council was under way yesterday in every borough except Richmond. There the count will start this morning.
All members of the labor movement in Canada would be delighted if the Duke and Duchess of Windsor visited the Dominion, P. M. Draper, president of the Trades and Labor Congress of Canada, said today.

A dinner marking the first reunion of alumni members of The Daily Princetonian and the formation of The Daily Princetonian Alumni Association was held tonight in Madison Hall of Princeton University attended by 300 former and present members of the staff, faculty members and guests.
The government won forty-five seats and the Labor Opposition twenty-nine in the recent parliamentary elections. The Labor party thus will gain only one seat.

Mrs. Pauline Nicolaison, wife of the Rev. Henry Nicolaison, pastor of Gospel Pentecostal Church, Poughkeepsie, died on Wednesday night at her home here at the age of 27. She was graduated from Gorham Normal School at Gorham, Me., and Zion Bible Institute at East Providence, R. I.
The Berlin Appeals Court ruled today that church collections by Confessional Synods were illegal and that only collections approved by the State-appointed Church Finance Board could be permitted.

Republicans, already assured of control of the 1938 State constitutional convention by one vote, were well on the way tonight to acquiring a 92 to 76 working majority by virtue of belated returns from Tuesday's election.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in NewYork State, now offered by dealers:

Meguerdich Karayan was condemned to death today for the assassination of James Theodore Marriner, United States Consul General. The sentence was imposed after the Armenian-American had a sanity hearing before an extraordinary tribunal in Criminal Court.
A Common Pleas Court jury received tonight the case against Mrs. Anna Marie Hahn, charged with the poison-murder of Jacob Wagner, 78, and accused by the State of a series of slayings for gain."

Sir Philip Colville Smith, for twenty years Grand Secretary of the United Grand Lodge of Freemasons in England, died today at the age of 75. His name was known everywhere that Freemasons foregather, for England is the mother Grand Lodge of the world.

Sharp curtailment of imports except from Germany is expected to follow the new exchange control regulations, which permit the unrestricted purchase of aski [devalued] marks for the payment of German goods.

Mr. and Mrs. George I. McKelvey of Glen Ridge, N. J., entertained at luncheon in the Empire Room today. Their guests were Mrs. James D. Topping of West Orange, N. J.; Miss Ann Breeden of San Francisco, Harold B. Cutler of Los Angeles, and Horace Cousmer of Evanston, III.

Yale and Brown will meet in the Bowl tomorrow in the forty-second game of a series dating back to 1880. The weather promises to be clear and cold, and a crowd of 40,000, the largest ever to see the two teams in action, is expected to look on.

Morris Goldis, a thin, bespectacled young man charged with the first degree murder of William Snyder, one-time president of Teamsters Local Union 138, entered a plea of not guilty in Supreme Court yesterday.
A fourday peace conference, with delegates from this country and abroad, will begin here Monday under the auspices of the World Alliance for International Friendship through the Churches.

The average price of 200 realty bond issues on properties in New York, Buffalo, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and other Eastern cities is back to the level of April and May, 1935, according to a survey by Amott-Baker Co.

The honorary degree of Doctor of Science was conferred by Mount Holyoke College this morning on Dr. Annie Jump Cannon, curator of the Harvard College Observatory and guest speaker at the Founder's Day exercises celebrating the one hundredth anniversary of Mount Holyoke's opening by Mary Lyon.

The first step in the national census of the unemployed will be taken by postoffices here on Tuesday, Nov. 16, when they start delivering unemployment report cards to each dwelling throughout the postal district, it was announced yesterday by Postmasters Albert Goldman in Manhattan and Francis J. Sinnott in Brooklyn.

In a decision upholding the right of the Board of Examiners to deny a teaching license to candidates because of personality and temperamental defects, Commissioner of Education Frank P. Graves dismissed the appeal of Miss Gertrude Epstein, Barnard honor graduate of 1934, for a New York City teacherin-training license, the Board of Education disclosed yesterday.

Plans for a world campaign to improve physical fitness was adopted by the League of Nations' Health Committee at its twenty-sixth session, just concluded here. The plans call for the formation of national committees on the subject patterned after the League's work on business and on housing and nutrition and for an international commission composed of representatives of these national committees to meet early in 1938.

MANHATTAN BASES, ABRAHAM (Sept. 9). Estate, more than $10,000. To Krakauer Charity Aid Society, $2,000; nineteen varying bequests; Annabel Bases, widow, executrix, 898 West End Ave., residue. Jacob Goldman, 139 Beach 72d St., Arvene, L. I., executor.

The entire crest of Mount Holly, in the township of Lewisboro, one of the highest points in Northern Westchester, consisting of 150 acres, has been sold by Martin T. Silkman to a New York client of Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc.

Purchase of stocks in odd lots, less than 100 shares, continued to exceed sales on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended Oct. 30 when the market was staging a rally, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Francis X. Azzara, 39 years old, of 276 St. Nicholas Avenue, Brooklyn, who was the head of a brokerage firm at 120 Wall Street in 1933, pleaded not guilty yesterday in General Sessions to a second-degree grand larceny indictment based on a complaint of a customer of the concern.

After taking. a revolver from a payroll guard, three hold-up men. two of whom, were armed, escaped yesterday morning with $3,780, but overlooked $8,020 in addition, which their two victims had concealed in their clothing.
The 1938 Walker Cup golf matches between Great Britain and the United States amateurs have been set for June 3 and 4.

Fate made Henry A. Wallace a Secretary of Agriculture and ordained that he should wrestle with the most gigantic economic problem of our time. He brought to this problem the vision of a Hebrew prophet and the practicality of an Iowa farmer.
The sanitary police have created a cordon through the Upper Rhine valley to prevent the spread of hoof and mouth disease from Alsace. About 10,000 farms are affected.

A considerable amount of "hot money" is plainly going out from this country at the present time. The persistent pressure on the dollar in the foreign exchange market bears witness to the movement, and a comparison of the changes in the Treasury's statement of monetary gold stock with the known gold imports from Japan and elsewhere shows that a hidden loss of gold, presumably to Europe, is in progress.
The Crescent Athletic Club team moved into the lead in Class C play of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League as it defeated the invading Yale Club, 4-1, last night,

Sir Thomas Inskip, Minister for Coordination of Defense, told a political gathering at Darwen, Lancashire, last night that since he took office nineteen months ago orders had been placed for ??288,000,000 worth of armaments.
The twentieth annual Hispanic rally and bazaar under the auspices of the Spanish clubs of Adelphi College was held in the college auditorium here today.

Almost 300 synagogues and churches in Manhattan and the Bronx will hear Red Cross appeals today and tomorrow at all their services of worship. This announcement was made yesterday by the Churches and Synagogues Division of the New York Chapter's annual Red Cross roll-call. Cardinal Hayes has asked all his pastors to give "full cooperation."

The point after touchdown won for the Coast Guard Academy over Massachusetts State tonight. The score was 7-6. The cadets won in the third period when Louis O'Neill booted the extra point following a touchdown by Ben Engel.
Citizens of the State were urged today by Governor Lehman to make the annual Red Cross campaign a success. A proclamation issued at the Executive Chamber read:

The isolation for the first time of two viruses causing serious diseases in animals and their identification as protein molecules of enormous dimensions rather than small bacteria, was announced here today before the American Institute of Physics at the University of Pennsylvania by Dr. Wendell M. Stanley of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

Mrs. Nicholas Brown has selected next Wednesday for a reception at her home, Harbour Court, in honor of her sister, Vicountess D'Osmoy, who recently arrived from abroad and who is to be her guest at that time.

After an interval of several years, Clarita Sanchez, Mexican soprano, returned to the local concert platform in a song recital at Town Hall last night. A large audience, which included numerous prominent musicians of the city and a host of her compatriots, accorded the singer a hearty welcome.
Wearing white overalls and with his face begrimed, King Boris of Bulgaria today set a royal speed record of 88 miles an hour as engineer of the streamlined train the Coronation Scot.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. applied today to. the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to build and operate experimentally the first tank cars for carrying nitric acid ever constructed with fusion-welding anchorage.

The Rev. Dr. Remsen Du Bois Bird, president of Occidental College, Los Angeles, stressed the influence of incidents in college careers on the future lives of students when he gave the Lafayette College Founders' Day address here today.

Officers at the Police Traffic Bureau are still talking about this one. Parking her car yesterday, a woman driver pushed another parked car back into a no parking zone. When she returned, she saw the car had been tagged by traffic officer.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Angler Biddle Duke of Tuxedo Park, Park, N. Y., yesterday at the Doctors Hospital, this city. Mrs. Duke is the former Miss Priscilla A. St. George, daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
The Greyhound Corporation applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to issue up to $1,368,300 of 5 1/2 per cent preference stock for payment of a dividend.

Municipal AIRBRAKE REPAIRMAN--Salary: 80 to 85 cents an hour; pension; vacation (80 cents an hour for first year). Vacancies: Occur from time to time; all persons on last eligible list (15) were appointed. Ages: Through 45, on Nov, 19. Applications:

Miss Marion Stanley Blake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Hamlin Blake of this place, was married this afternoon to William George Cullimore, also of Englewood, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Croome Cullimore of Stanford, Ontario, Canada.

Germany and Poland drew nearer together today with the exchange of mutual guarantees in the troublous minorities question and the Reich now has hopes of drawing Poland into the so-called anti-Soviet pact. Negotiations to this end, it is reported, will be Joachim von Ribbentrop's first duty when he returns from Italy.

In labor circles here tonight it was said that Charles E. Bedaux, designer of the plant production system that bears his name, "ran to cover" when it appeared that an attack would be made on his organization from coast to coast and that such an explosion would inevitably embroil the Duke of Windsor, who had placed all arrangements for his American visit into Mr. Bedaux's hands.

A foreign office spokesman said today that Soviet Russia had been urged to renew her fishing treaty with Japan "not only from the standpoint of justice, but in consideration of future Russo-Japanese relations."

Henry Gersten has joined the trading department of Alexander Kremer Co., Inc. Patrick O'Driscoll has become associated with L. P. Frazee Co. Paul E. Wieland has become affiliated with Wieland Co. in the trading department.

University Ave. 2,400 to 2,412 (11-3213); Uniford Construction Co to East River Savings Bank. extends mtgs to Sept. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent: $222,500. Davidson Ave (11-3196), n e cor of 182d St, 100xl5; Franwick Realty Corp to Dollar Savings Bank, installments, 4 7/2 per cent; $168,000.

The six refusals of 13-year-old Grace Sandstrom to salute and pledge allegiance to the American flag resulted today in the conviction of her parents, Charles and Hilda Sandstrom, on a technical charge of keeping the child away from school.
The series of auction sales liquidating realty assets of closed Za tional banks will be continued at 2:30 P. M. today in Odd Fellows Hall, 880 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, N. J.

A shift reinstating Buster Poole, big rookie end from Mississippi, on the New York Giants starting eleven for tomorrow's game with the formidable Pittsburgh Pirates at the Polo Grounds was announced by Coach Steve Owen yesterday.
The Republican decision to seek a recount and investigation of Gubernatorial balloting in Hudson Conuty and Jersey City provoked a bristling challenge from Mayor Frank Hague today.

Spurred on by President Roosevelt's strong hopes for a reunion of organized labor, supplemented by other important factors, the American Federation of Labor-Committee for Industrial Organization peace conference made progress today.
One of the game's youthful stars, Frank Iannicelli of the New York A. C., moved through the opening round yesterday of the Princeton Club's eighteenth annual invitation squash tennis tournament.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks took under advisement late today a challenge to the constitutionality of the so-called Federal "Anti-Strikebreaking" Law under which a grand jury indicted James H. Rand Jr., industrialist, and Pearl L. Bergoff, head of a New York strikebreaking agency.
Mackerel, mystery fish of the North Atlantic which normally disappear at this time of year, were reported running today off Marthas Vineyard and nearly a dozen fishing trawlers hurried to the scene.

James Talcott, Inc., has been appointed factor for Denis-Greenberg, Inc., distributors of dress rayons. David Maitland Harvey has been appointed superintendent of the oil department at the Philadelphia plant of E. F. Houghton Co., makers of metal cleaners, processing oils, heat-treating salts, lubricants and leathers.

Charles E. Bedaux, industrial engineer and former sandhog whom labor attacks as a proponent of the "speed-up system," last night awaited word from the Duke and Duchess of Windsor that their proposed American tour had been canceled.
The United States Shipping Board freighter Independence Hall collided today with the French fishing schooner St. Louis in a Channel fog off Cape Cris Nez.

Premarital examinations and the recording of any family diseases of couples contemplating marriage were urged in an address by Dr. William G. Herrmann, president of the Medical Society of New Jersey, at the thirty-seventh annual convention of the New Jersey Congress of Parents and Teachers here today.
Leopold Stokowski's twenty-fifth anniversary as conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra was celebrated at today's concert in the Academy of Music.

With Victor F. Ridder, publisher of the New York Staats-Zeitung, as guest of honor, the Ladies Society of the German Press Club of New York celebrated its twentyfifth anniversary yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Astor. Other guests who addressed the 150 women present included Joachim H. Meyer, editor-in-chief of the StaatsZeitung, and Heinrich Heide, president of the Press Club.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Reductions in prices on goods by the American Woolen Company this week to the levels of their competitors have not stimulated buying noticeably, although the- trade expects some buying of cloth soon if the clothing trade is to be able to gqt its Spring clothing through the works in time for the Spring trade.
So precocious that she has even begun to anticipate the seasons, Mistress Temple brought out her Christmas show yesterday, a cute and attractive little package addressed to the Roxy's youngsters.

The report of the Borg-Warner Corporation and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $5,561,156 after depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges. No provision was made for surtax on undistributed profits.

Governor Lewis O. Barrows today proclaimed Nov. 7 as Lovejoy Sunday "to. revere the memory" of Elijah Parish Lovejoy, a native of Albion and a graduate of Colby College, who gave his life in martyrdom 100 years ago at Alton, Ill., defending the freedom of the press.

The text of the report of the special advisory committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America, in session here, follows: This committee was appointed by President Hall on authority granted him at the 1937 May meeting of the board of governors at Hot Springs, Va.

Apparently in motor boating as in other pleasures "it never rains but it pours." Just when skippers thought they could settle back for a shore rest between their hauling out in October and the boat exposition in January, along comes not one but then two and now three out-of-season cruiser shows which must be visited and applauded.

Armistice celebrations in New York, as for many years past, will include several evening parties that have been features of mid-November entertaining since that first Armistice night of enthusiastic ceremonial nineteen years ago.

That photography is an absorbing hobby to women as well as men, both in this country and abroad, is indicated in the more than 600 photographs that have been selected for the International Salon of Photography, sponsored by the Oval Table Society, Inc., which will open on Nov. 16 at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

TWENTY-EIGHT years ago in Arizona the letters CCC had a widely known meaning, very different from what they denote today. The "three C's," as the initials were called, stood for the Chiricahua Cattle Company that ran the outfit on the San Carlos Indian Reservation.
Hitler, Mussolini and Stalin might be interested in a condensed list of epoch-making books put forward last Thursday by Secretary of

President Roosevelt heard recommendations today that the Administration steer clear of a "legalistic conception" of the anti-trust laws in its coming drive, announced by the Department of Justice, to tighten enforcement of the statutes dealing with restraint of trade.

Miss Helen Catherine Dailey, daughter of Mrs. Frank B. Dailey of this place, was married to W. George Onions, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Onions of Irvington, yesterday by the Rev. James A. Hughes of Jersey City, a cousin of the bride, at the home of her mother.

VACATIONISTS who travel long distances to reach their objectives are discovering the advantage of taking along in their baggage a few simple pieces of play equipment. Hours which ordinarily would lag on ship, train or bus, in trailers and automobiles and even in airplanes are made to pass quickly.
THE eighth season of the Town Hall Endowment Series of concerts will open Wednesday night. Lotte Lehmann, Metropolitan Opera soprano, will be heard on this occasion.

Miss Elenore Montague, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Everett Montague of Riverside, was married here this afternoon in the Second Congregational Church to Robert Vincent Harry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Guy Harry of Brooklyn. The Rev. Daniel Bliss performed the ceremony.
TWO exhibitions of Christmas cards that include reproductions of paintings and prints by well-known American artists present the first holiday note in the New York art season.

ONE of the most famous operatic compositions of history, and one which raises a number of the most fascinating and difficult problems known to musicians, will be presented here next -Tuesday night when the Salzburg Opera Guild performs Ernst Krenek's version of Monteverdi's

Ohio State's BigTen championship hopes were trampled into the turf of BuckeyeStadium today as Indiana's Hoosiers won, 10 to 0. A crowd of 47,000 watched the inspired Hoosiers turn back two Buckeye threats in the opening minutes and then go on to gain a pressive.

WITH completion of the planting of 20,000 native hard wood trees by the National Park Service, Theodore Roosevelt Island has assumed the appearance of a forest primeval such as the Indians knew when they roamed over what is now the national capital.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helene D. Rosenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Micheal Rosenberg of 239 Central Park West, to Leslie R. Schwartz. son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Schwartz of Cedarhurst, L. I.

THE Negro as a serious dance artist, instead of a specialist exclusively in jazz and hotcha, figures increasingly in the news. Two events exhibiting diametrically opposite approaches to the subject are, as a matter of fact, on the schedule of local activities within the next fortnight.

Sir Evelyn Wrench of London, founder of the English-Speaking Union, and Lady Wrench will be the principal speakers and guests of honor at a dinner on Nov. 18 at the Hotel Plaza, which will end the annual meeting of the EnglishSpeaking, Union of the United States. Sir Evelyn, who is head of

Considerable concern over the growing tension between Haiti and the Dominican Republic was manifested at the State Department today. Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles announced that R. Henry Norweb, American Minister to the Dominican Republic, had been instructed to rejoin his post at once and would arrive at Ciudad Trujillo tomorrow morning.

In the office building at 26 West Forty-fourth Street is a door which bears on a glass pane the legend "Vitality Records." Here Professor Irving Fisher of Yale is taking what he regards as the next important step in the prolongation of human life.

IN photography the time has come for outdoor character studies. Fresh Fall winds have swept the first of the leaves from the trees and soon nature will be revealed in stark simplicity. Many photographers have already gone afield, and more will soon roam the countryside in an attempt to capture the beauty that is being revealed and so interpret the mood of the season.

A new social approach to the study of homemaking is being introduced this Fall by Pratt Institute in its School of Household Science and Arts, under the direction of Dr. Frederic Howe. Each student in the Institute's home economics classes is now making a survey of actual conditions in her own home, and is bringing in reports for class discussion on various phases of family adjustments and relationships.
Carnegie Tech, conqueror of Notre Dame, upset the favored Duquesne Dukes, 6 to 0, today. The Tartans counted the game's only score on a forward pass in the second period before a crowd of 28,000.

The Duke of Windsor, saysSamuel Untermyer, is Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "latest roaming ambassador." Before learning that the Duke's projected. American tour had been canceled, the New York attorney declared yesterday:

Senator Carter Glass of Virginia will be guest of honor at the 121st dinner of the Economic Club of New York, to be held in the Hotel Astor on Dec. 7, it was announced yesterday by Robert Erskine Ely, executive director of the club. Senator Glass is expected to speak on "Balancing the Budget," the discussion subject for the evening.

THIS very useful but limited and somewhat fortuitous collection of recollections is meant only for readers of A. E. Housman's poems. There is no remarkable life to write about, and the writing in itself is not distinguished, and the papers themselves have merely been bound together here after having been printed elsewhere in the proper magazine for their special occasion.
Turpentine firm, 26 3/4c; sales. 56 barrels; receipts, 283 barrels; shipments, 1,210 barrels: stock, 39,542 barrels., Resin firm; sales, 596; receipts. 966; shipments, 3,385; stock, 76,635.

Premier Benito Mussolini, in one of his speeches, once protested strongly against the prevailing practice of drawing contrasts between democracies and dictatorships. He made the claim that Italy was the world's most democratic State.

Because commercial potato growers raised a larger crop this year "than the domestic markets are likely to absorb in normal trade channels," the Agricultural Adjustment Administration will spend up to $1,500,000 to pay them for feeding the tuber to livestock, the agency stated today.
So "equal" are the sexes in Turkey now that henceforth all pupils in intermediate and high schools for girls, as well as all girl students at the university, will receive lessons in military science.

A bridge party will be given on the afternoon of Nov. 17 by the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street, to raise funds for its educational program.

Miss Helen Langdon Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ellis Brown of this place and 1,125 Park Avenue, New York, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents, to John Herbert Claiborne, son of Mrs. J. Herbert Claiborne of 145 East Fifty-second Street, New York, and the late Dr. Claiborne.
Its new laboratory building of streamline design, described as "The House That Research Built," was dedicated last week by the American Rolling Mill Company at Middletown, Ohio.

With Joe. LaManna, shifty fullback, running wild, the N. Y. U. freshmen defeated the Rutgers freshmen, 13 to 0, today. La Manna's dashes of 65 yards and 33 yards plus ' is placement kick for an extra point, accounted for all the points for the Violet cubs.

When fashion decreed plaids for the American continent this Fall it issued at the same time a bolder edict for the homeland of tartan. To be a la mode in Scotland this season women as well as men must wear the kilt.
How a whole battery of machine guns may be fired by remote control either separately or singly is revealed in a patent Just granted here to Lucient A. Boussel of Courbevoie, France.

New Yorkers who have long been interested in the new career of housing management will soon have an opportunity to compete for positions on the management staffs of housing developments under the supervision of the New York City Housing Authority.

The GermanJapanese agreement was described by Toshio Shiratori, former Foreign Office spokesman, as a frame into which any picture might be fitted. Ideological warfare has brought ideological diplomacy.

The industry committee of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York recommended to members yesterday a clause for use on ontracts for future delivseries to cover the "strong probability that a new processing tax bill will be introduced in the coming session of Congress."
A series of teas has been given in the last few weeks by Mrs. Dwight Whitney Morrow at the Colony Club for patrons and patronesses of the Welsh Concert to be given on Nov. 19 at Carneige Hall.

The senior class at Rutgers University faces a more difficult task in obtaining jobs after graduation than did last year's graduating class, according to Ralph N. Campbell, director of the university's Bureau of Personnel and Placement.

Colorful events have been planned for Ye Olde English Faire, the annual three-day bazaar for the benefit of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women in Ossining, N. Y., which will be held Nov. 17, 18 and 19 at the Biltmore under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire in New York State.

The volume of home building during the Winter months in the various residential communities in Queens and adjacent sections of Long Island will depend chiefly according to many of the larger builders, upon the actual demand for homes. There is, however,

Despite the recent weakness in gasoline prices. the consensus in important quarters of the industry is that crude oil quotations will be tax. maintained provided that the regulatory bodies of the oil-producing States keep production within consumptive demand through March of next year.

Plans for the expansion of the vocational education department of the New York City school systems calling for the erection of thirtyeight buildings at an estimated cost of $50,000,000 were disclosed yesterday by Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools. Existing services would be nearly tripled by the increased facilities.

Acting at the request of the New York Stock Exchange, the Twentieth Century Fund will undertake an investigation of the activities of the "bears" of Wall Street to determine if short selling has been responsible for the current market slump, Evans Clark, director of the fund, announced yesterday.

Twenty-five men and women who have been pensioned by Best Co., Fifth Avenue department store, were guests last night at a dinner given by Philip Le Boutillier, president of the company, while on anbther floor of the Hotel Biltmore 2,000 of the organization's present employes danced at the twenty-first annual event held by the company's Mutual Benefit Association.
THE arresting title is in no way fanciful It is. on the contrary, geographically precise. Melanesia is one of the three great divisions of Oceania; it includes the Fiji

The engagement of Miss Priscilla Danvers Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Thompson of this place, formerly of Brooklyn, N. Y., to Bradford Wells Ketchum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Ketchum of Norridgewock, Me., has been announced by her parents.

The port of San Francisco showed a slight gain in traffic volume in October over that of a year ago, according to official figures. Statistics reveal a rise of 20,694 tons coming in and some 4,806 tons departing.
Italy's signature on the German-Japanese socalled anti-Communist agreement, making it a tripartite treaty, has double significance for Germany.

THE bicentenary of the death of Antonio Stradivari falls on Dec. 18, 1937, and it will be elaborately celebrated in this city by way of a special concert to take place the day after, on a Sunday evening, at Carnegie Hall. Emil Herrmann, violin dealer of this city and of Berlin, under whose auspices the event is being planned, hopes to assemble enough Strads actually to equip an entire orchestra.
Joseph Dickson Eddy, partner in the firm of Dickson Eddy, anthracite mine operators and anthracite merchants, of 17 Battery Place, died here on Friday. His age was 42.

The following Foreign Service changes since Oct. 30 were announced today by the State Department: Raymond E. Cox of New York, Consul General at Praha, Czechoslovakia, has been designated as First Secretary of Legation there; he will serve in a dual capacity.

Striking suddenly in the third period, Adelphi's football team went almost the length of the field for the touchdown that brought a 6-to-0 triumph over the Hopkins Grammar School of New Haven on the victors' field in Brooklyn yesterday.
