Miss Marian Florence Brother, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Doran Palmer Brother of Detroit, was married here yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration to Barrett Farley Welch of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Welch of Peoria, Ill. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

The Department of Parks will conduct indoor social dances this Winter, with music by three orchestras provided by the WPA Federal Music Project, at the following locations: Mondays, Prospect Park Picnic House, Fifth Street and Prospect Park West, Brooklyn; Wednesday, Crotona Recreation Center, 178d Street and Fulton Avenue, the Bronx, and Highbridge Recreation Center,

A blocked punt brought an end today to Georgia's six-year football supremacy over Florida. Converted into a touchdown, it gave Florida a 6-to-0 victory. More than 20,000 persons watched the Gators beat off a desperate fourth-period attack that once carried to their four.

The short session in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange again was disrupting to prices yesterday, railroad issues being especially liquidated, and the uninterrupted selling in the carriers continued as a drag on the rest of the list.

The Bellazmine Debating Society of St. Peter's College will present a debate on the subject "Resolved: That the National Labor Relations Board should be empowered to enforce compulsory arbitration of all industrial disputes" on Monday evening at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Union City.

In an atmosphere charged with contention, the Republican National Committee declined this week to pass immediately on former President Hoover's proposal that a national convention be held next year to adopt a set of principles on which to fight the 1938 Congressional campaign.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 5 unless specified. At San Pedro: Arctic, Brooks, Utah. At Mare Island Yard: Lark, Oglala, Pompano. Quail, Whippoorwill. Brazos, San Diego to San Pedro. Bushnell, at San Diego.

As was the case last week, this week will comprise but five business -days. In observance of Armistice Day on Thursday, all the principals security and commodity markets and banks in the United States and Canada will be closed.

King George VI is an interesting person to photograph and has a delightful sense of humor, according to Miss Dorothy Wilding, British court photographer, who will open a New York studio on Tuesday at 15 East Fifty-sixth Street.
A course in real estate appraising, sponsored jointly by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers and the General Education Division of New York University,

EYES turn toward Moscow today as the Soviet Union celebrates the twentieth anniversary of the revo lution. Never since those "days which shook the world" in November, 1917, has the anniversary of the revolution been an occasion of such tense drama.
Effects of the protests against the high price of meat are now visible in New York retail markets, where prices have been lowered a few cents on all cute of pork and some cuts of veal and beef.

A FEW months ago the Winthrop Ames Association held its annual get-together, a regular event in the lives of the men and women who, when Mr. Ames pulled down the flag and turned the Little Theatre over to commerce, occupied the tiny offices

THE town has just been through another premiere. The other evening Samuel Goldwyn contributed to that amazing indigenous phenomenon with his "The Hurricane" and untold thousands stood in the streets to watch the spectacle of celebrities arriving and departing.

WASHINGTON. IT is two years and a little more than two months since the Congress passed the Motor Carrier Act which, by its terms, became Part II of the Interstate Commerce Act. Through this legisnation, to government was delegated a control over transportation in this country that would have been thought impossible a few years ago. However, the law was not the result of New Deal "regimentation."

Star students from universities of fourteen different countries will be shown in action, discussing problems of international relations in Geneva, in a motion picture sequence to be given at the Girls Service League, 138 East Nineteenth Street, on Wednesday evening.

Carl K. Withers, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, will resign in January to become president of the Lincoln National Bankof Newark, according to announcements made today by the bank here and by his department in Trenton.

Elsie Thorenz Petri won an uncontested divorce today from Bruno Petri, Long Island City. She charged cruelty. The court restored her maiden name of Thorenz. The Petri's were married in Brooklyn, Jan. 30, 1932.

Europe has all but forgotten the story of those fearless horsemen with the new creed who swept from the deserts of Arabia thirteen centuries ago when most of the "civilized" Western World was in the grip of the Dark Ages.

L. A. G. STRONG is an accomplished young Irish man of letters who lives in England. His interest in Tom Moore dates back to the days of his childhood, when his Irish grandmother sang him the Melodies";

ONCE more J. B. Neumann has demonstrated his peculiar adeptness at arranging a "theme" show that leaves us with vision broadened and deepened. In this instance what is announced as a retrospective exhibition becomes a "theme" by virtue of its selecting one special facet of an artist's

A FOUR-HOUR drive from New York over the Lincoln Highway, or longer over less traveled roads if one prefers rural scenery to speed, brings the motorist to the heart of the country inhabited by those sturdy, humble folk known as the "plain people."

In the presence of the French vice consul from Boston, A. J. Morand, the formal dedication of Le Foyer, new language house at Mount Holyoke College, was held here today. The brief ceremonies, conducted in French, were brought to a close with the raising of the American and French flags in front of the house.

The vanguard of a Japanese flying column driving north from Hangchow Bay was reported today to be within twenty-five miles of Shanghai. Refugees streaming from Sungkiang, twenty-two miles southwest of Shanghai, informed Red Cross ambulance drivers that the column had split into several units, with an advance body reaching a rice ferry on the Whangpoo River, three miles from Sungkiang, at dawn.

Proposals for five amendments to the undistributed profits tax legislation, if the basic principles of that tax "are to be retained for the present," are contained in a resolution approved by the directors of the New York Credit Men's Association and sent up to the National Association of Credit Men.

Japan today faces the most critical situation since the empire's foundation, according to a comprehensive article on the economic aspects of the Sino-Japanese war in The Oriental Economist, Englishlanguage monthly published in Tokyo.

PLACES, PLEASE!-Tomorrow evening at the Golden Theatre. A new play by Aurania Rouverol, one which tells of a young actress who marries a (conservative) New Englander. Lillian Emerson, Robert T. Haines, Richard Sterling, Donald Dillaway, Ruth Abbot, Matthew Smith, Henry Hull Jr. and others are in it.

Miss Margaret Fitzpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Fitzpatrick of this city, was married to Thomas P. O'Malley, son of Mrs. Patrick O'Malley, also of New York, and the late Mr. O'Malley, yesterday in the. Church of St. Catherine of Genoa by Mgr. Edmund J. Britt of Buffalo.

A resolution asking a Federal investigation of the Nazi movement in the United States was adopted yesterday by the general board of assistants of the General Society of Mayflower Descendants at their annual meeting in the Hotel Biltmore. The resolution will be sent to President Roosevelt.

While Republican supporters of Senator Lester H. Clee were proceeding with plans for recounts and investigations on the Governorship election in which Senator A. Harry Moore, the Democratic candidate,

Miss Clara J. Glaser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Glaser of West Newton, Pa., was married to Kenneth F. Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarke Lewis of South Orange, this evening in Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church, East Orange. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Platt, the assistant pastor.

Coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange underwent, last week in excited trading, one of the severest losses in the history of that commodity. News that Brazil had virtually abandoned its thirty-one-year-old policy of supporting coffee prices, received here on Wednesday morning, brought is losses on the local Exchange that day of 100 points in both the Santos and Rio contracts-the limit permissile in a day's trading.

Renewed weakness in outside markets caused a slight decline in prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and the list ended with losses of 4 to 7 points. Considering the size of the crop and the season of the year, Saturday hedging operations were conspicuously limited and fluctuations held within a narrow range under quiet trading.

Probably no type of garden holds a wider diversity of uncommon odds and ends than the rock garden. We are surely indebted to it for the frequent discovery of plants of undeniable value for other gardening purposes. Many of these plants are in the nature of ground covers and carpetings, suitable for numerous uses.

The first of a series of semiannual conferences to develop cooperation between education and leaders in American vocational groups will be held Thursday at Teachers College, Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort,

The first performance for this season of the Yale Puppeteers will be given the night of Nov. 16 at the Women's Repubican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, for the benefit of the Home Thrift Association. The association,

Average prices on the New York Stock Exchange on Nov. 1 were roughly one-third of those on Sept. 1, 1929, the peak of the boom, and two and a half times the level of July 1, 1932, the pit of the depression. They were about 30 per cent below the high levels for 1937, reached about March 1.

Michigan's Wolverines rallied dramatically in the final four minutes of play today to score two touchdowns and defeat an inspired University of Chicago football team, 13 to 12. It was Michigan's third successive Western Conference victory, all by 1-point margins.

The City Council this afternoon again stepped into the city payroll scandal by appointing a board of five and appropriating $10,000 to conduct an investigation into "city affairs." After a stormy session the Council President, George W. Wanamaker, appointed himself and Councilmen George K. Hambleton, Anthony Dropik, John E. Selkirk and George J. Young to conduct the investigation.

Enactment of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Act ultimately wil benefit real estate as a whole, and the United States, in providing low-rent housing under the act, is not departing from traditional practices but is merely following the example set by a number of conservative European nations, states Joseph Milner, real estate adviser to the New York City Housing Authority.

The Jacob A. Riis NeighborhoodSettlement will benefit from a performance of Guthrie McClintic's production, "Barchestey Towers," on Dec. 7. The play, with Ina Claire in the leading role, will be opened late this month at the Martin Beck Theatre.

The campaign in a political off-year is traditionally fought in various communities over differing local issues, evolving personalities as much as parties. Yet through that complex patchwork often runs a common thread suggesting the design of future national developments.

A story of the work its members have undertaken in aid of more than 1,000 persons confined to their homes through age or illness will be told in reports to be presented at the annual meeting of the State branch of the Shut-In Society on Friday at 11 A. M. at the Hotel McAlpin. Mrs. Emil Goldmark,

Nelson A. Rockefeller and Wallace K. Harrison will be the chief speakers at a luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress on Wednesday. Mr. Rockefeller will discuss renting and various other activities in Rockefeller Center and Mr. Harrison will present the "architectural conception and execution" of the project.

Miss Barbara Elizabeth Sims, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Sims, was married to William Wheeler Bainbridge, son of Dr..and Mrs. William Seaman Bainbridge of this city, yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents at 103 East Seventy-fifth Street.

In the death of Frank Damroach, many of the younger musicians of America have lost a sincere friend. How well do I remember my first view of him, when, at the age of 9, I was taken by my father to play the C minor prelude and fugue from Book 1 of the "Well-Tempered Clavichord" for the late dean of the Institute of Musical Art!
The attendance at the second day of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center was greater than last year, but the doubled space accommodated the throngs comfortably.
Before 12,000 persons, the Stamford High School eleven today defeated Ansonia High, 12 to 6, practically deciding the C nnecticut title and a trip to Florida.

The Yale freshmen today defeated the Princeton Cubs, 12-0, in their annual class game. Jim Reily scored the first touchdown on an end sweep of nearly 60 yards and Captain Ray Anderson the second on a 20-yard tackle plunge, both in the third period.
Auburn's line demolished a favored Tennessee football team today as the Tigers came through with a 20-to-7 victory before 20,000 fans.
The newspaper Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung disclosed today what it considered the real reason behind the Duke of Windsor's postponement of his study of labor conditions in the United States.
Locked in filing cabinets in the War Department's munitions building are the production secrets of 20,000 American industrial firms.

LISTENING in on the radio is tne only means by which the old grad and football fan can get to the sidelines and still stay at home. In his easy chair. with no worries over being drenched or bitten by a cold autumnal wind. he "watches" every play through the eyes of a quick-witted. ready-tongued radio announcer, whose No. 1 rule is "Keep-your eye on the ball!"

WITH all the nervous anticipation of a man trying to get a gag over to his radio audience before Milton Berle hears about it, George Jessel is pacing up-and down these days anxiously awaiting the start of his first flight as a producer of motion pictures.

After the Union College Glee Club sang some of Dr. Day's favorite songs, Theodore V. W. Anthony, '96, in behalf of fellow alumni and friends of the former president of Union College, presented a portrait of Frank Parker Day to the college.
The marriage of Miss Nina Swenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver A. Swenson of Orange, to Edson Rexford Garrabrant of East Orange, took place today at the home of the bride's parents.

Mrs. Frederic Cromwell, who is chairman of the New York City Committee of the Mothers' Health Centers, is a member of the committee in charge of the benefit performance of "I'd Rather Be Right" on Tuesday evening at the Alvin Theatre.

An ingenious telephone alarm which automatically "phones" a message to police headquarters whenever a burglary is being perpetrated forms the subject matter of a patent just granted here posthumously to Ralph W. Carnahan, Shaker Heights, Ohio.

Women in Caldwell, Verona and Montclair, N. J., are serving on the committee for the annual exhibit and sale of handicraft made by refugee women in the Near East, which will be held throughout tomorrow at the home of Mrs. James M. Speers in Montclair. Mrs. Edward Everett Hughes will be the honored guest.

The second in a series of concerts planned by the Hudson River Member Society of the Chamber Music Society of America and sponsored by the Hudson River Junior Service League will be held Friday evening at the Scarborough School.

Fordham Law School undergraduates included on the honor list for maintaining an average of at least "B" during the 1936-37 scholastic year number 235, it was announced yesterday by Ignatius M. Wilkinson, dean of the school. The 1937 seniors received their honors and awards at the June commencement.
Miss Mary Perpall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs Harold Perpall of Boxwood, Rydal, was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea dance which her parents gave.

Informed officials said today that the War Department would ask Congress to approve an increase of 2,185 in the number of army officers. The Budget Bureau, they said, has given its approval to the increase, which would be spread over several years as appropriations are provided.

SOME fifty board members and campaign workers of the Turtle Bay Music School met last Wednesday afternoon for a rally to open their 1937-1938 budget appeal for $19,473. Mrs. L. Martin Richmond, campaign chairman, will preside. According to Mrs. Richmond, the purpose of the campaign which will continue through November, is to raise the difference between the nominal sum paid by students and the running expenses of the school.

IN how few present-day novels is the skill of an illustrator called in to assist the art of the author! This departure from earlier practice is deplored by a correspondent of John o' London's Weekly, who laments the lack of illustrations generally and thinks them especially desirable in period novels, where they help the reader to visualize the descriptions of scenes and costumes.

THIS volume continues the story begun in "The Defrauded Yeggman" It tells of the trial by military court-mrtial of the three wanderers who were arrested on the charge of espionage during the war between Mexico and Harleysburg, Texas.

Colin Campbell Cooper, wellknown artist and dean of the Santa Barbara art colony, died here this morning after a three-weeks illness. On Oct. 19, at festivities of the Strollers Club, of which he was a founder, the artist was stricken and taken home. His age was 81.

Dr. and Mrs. T. C. F. Shirley of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Wibberley Shirley, to Howard James Gillespie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard S. Gillespie of Westfield.

A jury of eleven women and a man decreed today that Mrs. Anna Marie Hahn, 31-year-old mother, should die in the electric chair for the poison-murder of Jacob Wagner, 78, one of four men she is alleged to have killed for their money.

IT is highly gratifying that at this juncture in the world's affairs the City of New York and one of America's great newspapers should be willing to give time and energy for more than two weeks to so outwardly tame and peaceful an event as a book fair.

AS Britain prepares to play a more positive role in European affairs during the difficult and dangerous readjustments that lie ahead, she relies upon a new leader-and perhaps a new type of leadership-to see her through Neville Chamberlain has been at the head of the government only about six months, hardly more than time to settle down to his task and to reveal in his quiet way

Three rare Mortlake tapestries were sold yesterday afternoon for $4,500 at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries. They were all purchased by the same man, Frank Schnitjer, and came from the estate of Emanuel Boasberg.
The annual Thanksgiving benefit party of the Presbyterian Hospital in Newark will be given Wednesday at the Woman's Club of Orange.

Tracing the present recession in business to the statement by President Roosevelt last Spring that flat prices had advanced too fast and too far. Howard Veit, vice president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., cotton goods converters, declared yesterday that "the President can stop us today from sliding down hill just as effectively as he stopped us when we were rolling in the Spring."

Based on the records of production for the first six months of this year, the estimate is made that minerals output in Canada in 1937 will be more than $60,000,000 larger than it was In 1936. At the half year ended on June 30, production was valued at $215,382,814, which is almost $50,000,000 greater than in the corresponding period of 1936.

Interest in the Autumn field trial meetings continues unabated. While the pointers and setters have completed their season in this section, a number of important events for both retrievers and spaniels remain on the calendar. It is regrettable that there is one serious conflict dates.

THE opening of the season at An American Place may be best described as an event rather than an exhibition. To be sure, it is a show: one of the most "modern" and exciting shows of recent seasons, But this "Beginnings and

Recent declines in shoe and textile activity and prices have led some manufacturers to seek wage scale reductions from their employee groups or from unions, but in few instances have such proposals been accepted, reports in the New York market last week indicated.

NOT merely because of his eminence as a journalist and litteratour, but because he brazenly admits responsibility for the script of a motion picture called "White Fang," which was subsequently picked by this department as among the twelve or possibly thirteen worst of 1936, we have long had a hankering to meet Gene Fowler, mainly, we suppose, to see if his cheek had a permanent lump from writing so often with his tongue in it.
A strong New Hampshire football eleven scored a 3-0 victory over Tufts today.

Fordham's football forces built a rock foundation to their claim to football greatness at the Polo Grounds yesterday. By a score of 21 to 3 they turned back Purdue and continued their undefeated march through one more Autumn Saturday, and they left no single doubt among the 40,000 who watched as to which was the better team of the day.
In 1887, less than two years after Alexander Graham Bell patented his novel "talking" device, the first telephone exchange was opened in New Haven, Conn., with twentyone connected instruments.

NANKING. E famed Shanghai-Peiping Express, glorified in story and on the screen, is miser ably failing these days to live up to its reputation for speed and crack service, but is balancing the scales by furnishing passengers gratis thrills that rival those that movie scenarists weave Into plots about the train.

Unless the two large distributors and the independent companies limit their proposed rise in retail milk prices to half a cent a quart instead of the 1 cent announced as effective today, the city will have "to look around and see what it can do to protect itself," Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

With the usual admonition to "Address Plainly," "Wrap Securely" and "Mail Early," the postoffice announces the latest sailing dates for mail intended for delivery in foreign countries before Christmas. The postal authorities

ONE group exhibition and seven one-man shows of water-colors attested the undiminished popularity of this medium in the roster of attractions last week. Hudson Walker is introducing the work of Mervin Jules (until Nov. 20), an artist whose subjects range from architectural mining scenes to the macabre, grotesque humor and a cartoon-like social comment.

Lord and Lady Digby, their daughter, the Hon.Pamela Digby; Roger W. Babson, economist: Mrs. Babson, Johannes Jensen, Danish author; Professor Einer Lundsgaard, and Miss Edna Rubinstein, violinist, are among the passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic.
The first of the Pall Mall dances of the season, held at the Warwick, was attended tonight by more than 300 persons. The event was for the benefit of the Cooperative Soup Kitchen.

ALTHOUGH the sites of many of the world's vanished cities--Babylon, Tyre, Thebes and India's Fatehpur Sikri, to name only a few-are visited by modern travelers, Anuradhapura, ancient capital of fabled Lanka (Ceylon) is seldom heard of. Yet it was once as large as the London of today and filled with imposing temples and dwelling-places.

The Court of International Justice announced its preliminary decision today in the suit brought by the Belgian Government against the Madrid Government in connection with the killing of Baron Jacques de Borchgrave, attache of the Belgian Embassy at Madrid.

State and municipal financing in October aggregated $36,199,804, compared with $82,311,050 in October, 1936, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. The total for the first ten months of 1937 was $835,439,434, against $987,921,607 for the similar period last year. The figure for October of this year was the smallest for any comparable month since 1931.

What does Japan want in Shanghai? This important question, vitally affecting hundreds of millions of dollars in American and other foreign investments I ere, which only high and uncommunicative Japanese military officers can answer fully, is being raised daily wherever foreign business executives meet.

Delayed by printers in England, Bermuda's coronation currency issue in [Pound]1, 10s and 5s appeared today. The local bank issued [Pound]40,000 worth of the new notes in return for equal values of the old notes which are being withdrawn from circulation as they come in.

The Foreign Office statement introducing the Italo-Japan pact significantly omitted any reference to the effects the agreement is likely to have on Japan's relations with England. Explaining why Italy has suddenly become Japan's partner, the spokesman finds a relation between the Spanish civil war and the Chinese struggle.

Earnings of the Ohio Oil Company and subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year were reported yesterday as $2,433,540 larger than those for the entire year of 1936. The net profit was $10,315,011 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes, minority interest and other charges, but before provision for surtax on undistributed income.

The conference in Brussels on the Far Eastern situation is so cautious, so pusillanimous, so helpless that, in the note forwarded to Tokyo to refute the arguments Japan used in order to justify her decision not to send delegates, it did not even dare mention or suggest that China has claims of her own that cannot entirely be overlooked.
In his annual report presented to the trustees of Lafayette College today President William M. Lewis urged a strict limitation of the student body. In an address to them he said:

Emergence of the American Labor party as a major political force in New York City and State and the collapse of Tammany were the major political results of last Tuesday's municipal election which are likely to have far-reaching consequences in the State and nation.

Hugo Arthur Kuranda, Reuters Vienna correspondent, was acquitted today by a Vienna court on a charge of hav- s ing disturbed public order-and security by sending a dispatch to his London bureau concerning Foreign s Minister Constantin von Neurath's alleged, proposal to Austria to conclude a defensive pact with Germany, Hungary and Italy.

In a speech in the House of Commons this week Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden denied that victory for the Franco forces would mean the creation in Spain of a regime which would be hostile to Great Britain.

The first of the season's student concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor, took place last night at Carnegie Hall. The first half of the program was a repetition of Thursday's and Friday's performances: Elgar's "Introduction and Allegro for Strings" and Schumann's Fourth symphony in D minor. In the second half,

A gift of $25,000 from the United States Steel Corporation to the United Hospital Campaign was reported last night by Clarence Francis, chairman of the campaign's commerce and industry committee. Myron C. Taylor, chairman of the board of the steel corporation, in a letter accompanying the gift said:

Frequent spills and hairline finishes thrilled 5,000 racing devotees at the twenty-fourth meeting of the Pickering Hunt on the estate of William Clothier today. John Strawbridge lost his chance to retire the Pickering Challenge Cup, won by his jumpers in the past two years, when Rockicy, favored chestnut mare, lost a duel with Seafarin Dan, a chestnut gelding from the stables of Captain Ewart Johnston.
