THE Bulgarian stamp set recently issued in honor of the birth of an heir to the throne adds another figure to philately's royal kindergarten. While the royal children of many lands are pictured on stamps, the largest representation comes from the reigning family of Great Britain.

West Virginia's Mountaineers were held to a 6-to-6 football tie today by Georgetown's battered team. West Virgiina's star passer, Kelly Moan, tossed the forward that tied the score in the last period, but Georgetown blocked his placement kick for the extra point that would have won the game.
Wilmeth Sidat-Singh, passing star of Syracuse University's aerialminded football team, led his mates to a 27-6 triumph over Western-Reserve before 15,000 fans in Archbold Stadium today.

Driving 67 yards for a touchdown midway in the third quarter, the undefeated Dickinson College football team won its sixth game of the season with a brilliant 7-0 triumph over a favored Gettysburg College eleven on Biddle Field today before an overflow homecoming crowd of 7,500.

Scoring three times in the first half and once in the second, Haverford College defeated Hamilton 26-7 today on the victors' field. The visitors' lone score came as the result of an interception by Carmer, their captain. For Haverford, Derr and Beller were outstanding.

The marriage of Miss Clare Honore Nolan, daughter of Mrs. Thomas J. Nolan of this city and the late Justice Nolan of the Court of Special Sessions, to Edward Francis Keller, son of Mrs. Joseph W. Keller of Elmhurst, Queens, and the late Mr. Keller, took place yesterday morning in St. James's Roman Catholic Church, James Street.
The Walter Hines Page Chapter of the D. A. R. met at the Hampstead, home of Mrs. Byron Clark, this week. Mrs. Amos Dean, vice regent, was the chairman.

" Avoiding Taxes" J. E. B. wants to locate an opinion which, to the best of my recollection, was handed down by the Supreme Court of the United States about ten to fifteen years ago. Substantially it was as follows: It is not only the duty but the obligation of a corporate official to avoid taxes whenever and wherever possible, and if he fails to do so he is guilty of neglect to his stockholders.

Miss Henrietta Szold, founder of Hadassah, the organization which maintains a complete medical service in Palestine, has come to this country from Palestine for a brief visit and will be the guest of honor at a tea to be given by the New York Chapter of Hadassah tomorrow afternoon in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THROUGHOUT the semi-arid lands of the Southwest there has lately developed a passion for water sports. Every little town wants a lake and nearly every family a swimming pool. The result has been the construction of more dams within the region than the most optimistic conservator of water-for irrigation, power,

At the New York Academy of Medicine last week there was exhibited, among other instruments, two which determine night blindness and deficiency in vitamin A and which are the result of research conducted for years by Drs. J. B. Feldman and W. J. Ezickson of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON. -- Substantial increases in imports and exports were reported for the first nine months of this year by the French Government, the Commerce Department says. Imports amounted to 30,126,071,000 francs, as compared with 17,433,190,000 during the same period last year, while exports were recorded at 16,843,007,000 francs,as against 10,667,364.000.
A spectacular 73-yard sprint by Dick Todd ahd an aerial interception by Joe Turner gave Texas A. and M. a 14-to-0 triumph over Southern Methodist University today before 8,000 fans.

Public health officials and community leaders will meet tomorrow at the Hotel Roosevelt to outline the work, aims and objectives of district health committees which have been organized by the Committee on Neighborhood Health Development of the Department of Health, and to enlist public interest and community support for the city's district health program.

The first concert in this season's series of Albert Morris Bagby's Musical Mornings will take place on Nov. 22 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The concerts annually receive a large patronage from persons prominent in society.

WASHINGTON OLONELJ. MONROE JOHNSON, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, and other government authorities are planning legislation to govern the extension of foreign airlines with the expectation that Pan American Airways will begin regular mail and express service between the United States and England next Spring.

MODERNIZATION of the transmitters and installation of improved beam aerials on KDKA's reservation at Saxonburg, Pa., is aimed to greatly increase the station's signal strength and range over Europe and South America.
Nearly half a century of work with girls in State institutions will end for Dr. Fannie French Morse when she retires next week as superintendent of the State Training School for Girls at Hudson.

The swimming team of James Monroe High School, holder of the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the P. S. A. L., virtually lost all chance of successfully defending its title when it was defeated yesterday by Evander Childs, 48 to 23, at the weekly series of dual meets for the triborough title in the 25-yard De Witt Clinton pool. It was Monroe's second reverse of the season.

The undefeated Albright eleven triumphed over La Salle of Philadelphia, 13--0 today, registering the fifth straight conquest for Coach Dietz's warriors, who have not had their goal line crossed this season.

Miss Annis Burnham Stearns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stearns of this place, has completed the plans for her marriage to Frederick Spofford Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilber of Englewood.
A determined, fighting Illinois team pushed Northwestern all over Dyche Stadium today to score a smashing upset, 6 to 0, victory. A near capacity crowd of 42,000 saw the struggle.

Four persons were killed today when the Southland, Central of Georgia Railroad limited, hit a truck and was derailed. Those killed were the engineer, D. C. Wall of Atlanta, and the occupants of the truck, James Allen, 29, of Rex, his wife and their 2year-old son.

At Regina House, Fifteenth Street, opposite Stuyvesant Park, residence for dependent girls preparing to enter business or college, the Dominican Sisters are striving to inculcate self-reliance in the girls for meeting the problems of life when they are "on their own," Sister M. Germaine, the director, said yesterday.

With the arrival of the Cunard White Star flagship Queen Mary in port last-week, her passenger total for the year to date reached 50,515 persons. fficials of the line said the total exceeded that of any other transatlantic liner for the same period by at least 10,000.

ALONG with the trend toward modern interpretations of colonial rooms a vogue for more authenticity has started. Dusty colors suggesting time-faded fabrics, soft patinas and antique finishes on furniture woods, and more emphasis on accuracy in copies of traditional types of furniture, are characteristic of this new return to the old.

In our Magazine Section today we publish a defense by Secretary Ickes of the Administration's proposal to create six more regional Authorities similar to the TVA. In our Magazine Section of last Sunday that proposal was challenged by Wendell L. Willkie, president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

In the Wakefield Park area of the southerly Westchester County section of Yonkers and near the New York City line, Oscar Stevenson, who began the Wakefield Park development several years ago, is completing two dwellings on plots of 75 by 100 feet.

IT must be almost four years since we were promised early release for the Philadelphia Orchestra's summary of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff" as arranged and directed by Leopold Stokowski in the manner of his Wagnerian "syntheses." Recording companies have contributed their fair share of paving stones for the road to the nether regions, and long since we concluded that another excellent intention had found its resting place.

Miss Helen Dorothy Rausch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Rausch of the Knewood, was married this afternoon to Walter Persson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Persson of Roslyn, at St. Paul's Church. The rector, the Rev. William Grime, officiated.

MOVING up from Gramercy Park, where for so many years its exhibitions were held, the Society of American Etchers, of which John Taylor Arms is president, opened last week in Rockefeller Center the 1937 annual, to which is added an almost equally large group of contemporary prints from Sweden.

The Department of Social Philosophy of Coop?? Union is maintaining undimmed a fine tradition. This season's program of free lectures, to be given in the Great Hall beginning tomorrow night, is worthy of a university. The purpose of the discussions,

The Spelman Fund of New York, with an income of $497,682.14 in 1936, appropriated $1,911,550 in furtherance of its program for the improvement of the administrative machinery and methods through which government policies are put into execution,

The struggle between the Hoover and the antiHoover forces in the Republican party began in earnest today when the executive, committee of the Republican National Committee, delegated to select the chairman and members of the Program Committee of One Hundred, began the consideration of names for it.

Ripe cheese will prevent foodstuffs containing oils from turning rancid, it is revealed in a patent just granted here to Mayne R. Coe of Washington, D. C., a Department of Agriculture research worker.

Members of the board of directors of the People's Institute, United Neighborhood Guild, Brooklyn, will meet at a luncheon to be held on Tuesday at the Bossert Hotel. Mrs. Dudley D. Campbell will preside.

The marriage of Miss Mollie McKible, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. O. McKible of 300 Central Park West, to Walter Jacobs, son of Samuel Jacobs of this city, Miami Beach, Fla., and-Lake Tarleton, N. H., and the late Mrs. Jacobs, will take place this morning in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldont-Astoria.
HORSEMANSHIP, daring and picturesqueness are the order of the day at the jaripeo, or Mexican rodeo, gaining ground today as a substitute for bullfighting in Mexico's capital.

With current indications pointing to a sagging tendency in retail trade during the first half of next year, important readjustments of inventory valuation, profit margins and mark-up, and expense control will be required, according to retail executives here.

Although many of them are not pleased with the failure of fabric mills to reduce Spring prices furtheir, manufacturers of clothing will be forced to bring out their new quotations this week or, in instances where new ranges have been introduced, to revise lists, reports here yesterday indicated.

In sermons yesterday morning, three rabbis discussed Tuesday's election. Two hailed it as evidencing the healthy persistence of demooratic institutions despite pressure from extremists on either side. The third referred particularly to the significance of the labor vote.

COHN--Mr. and Mrs. Milton M., 467 Central Park West, announce the arrival of their second son, Frederic Richard. Nov. 3, the Knickerbocker Hospital., COMDEN-Mr. and Mrs. George Comden of Westport, Conn. (nee Charlotte Katz), of Brooklyn, N. Y., announce birth of son on Nov. 2 at the Norwalk General Hospital, Norwalk, Conn.
Miles L. Colean, deputy administrator of the FHA, declares that the administration's rental housing projects indicate a definite trend toward sounder financing in the moderate rental field.

Mayor S. Davis Wilson, "read out of the Republican party" and unacceptable at present to Democratic leaders as a candidate for Governor next year, issued today a new declaration of war against the Republican organization heads, specifically Jay Cooke, city chairman.

The Curtis High football team of Staten Island, N. Y., scored a 7 to 6 victory over Manchester Central High in a hard-fought game before 3,000 spectators today in the seeond intersectional game between these teams.

The New York Aggies bowed to the Montclair Teachers by 25 to 12 today. It was the home team's first setback of the campaign. John Hughes and Ed Walck scored for the visitors in the first half. Montclair also tallied in the third and fourth periods, Hughes and Waldorf accounting for the touchdowns. Kaplan went across twice for the losers.

A brochure containing detailed data on plant facilities, labor supply, proximity to leading markets and other general advantages to industry in Massachusetts has been prepared by the Massachusetts Development and Industrial Commission in cooperation with the Associted Industries of Massachusetts, 950 Park Square Building, Boston.

Mr. and Mrs. Elias Weinstock, 1 Waverly Place, Lawrence, L. I., announce the engagement of their daughter, Judith, to Mr. Samuel Barasch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Barasch of Rockville Center, L. I.

MOST people think an au thor's work should be judged independently of his life and personality, yet to do this in the case of Pirandello would be to cast aside the crutches that are most helpful in arriving at an understanding of the strange psychological complexities of the characters he created.

HE is no longer the aggressive, fist-shaking young militarist who for years criticized the Chineserace from platforms throughout the land. His youth is gone, and illness has reduced him to amere shadow of the dashing young general who swept northward with his ragged armies eleven years ago to place China on the road to a new destiny under his personal direction. He is too thin for his handsome

The Ocean Steamship Company of Savannah will succeed the New England Steamship Company as the water link for freight moving from Canadian points to New York via Boston, if the Interstate-Commerce Commission grants an application filed today.

When a "coup de politics" severed the Division of Consumer Service from the 1938 city budget the Board of Estimate immediately felt the impact of hostility and protest from a staggeringly large number of women who value the informatory program evolved by Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, and demand its continuance.

Miss Hildegarde Helene Erler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Erler of Clifton, was married to Clarence Paul E. Schneider, also of Clifton, today by the Rev. Paul E. T. Lemke in St. John's Lutheran Church.

A tenant from the new Williamsburg houses and one from a slum district still to be cleared williams with leaders in the housing movement in paying tribute to Senator Robert F. Wagner at a dinner to be given Friday evening at the Hotel Astor.

Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson, acclaimed as Britain's greatest classical actor and one of the last of the fast disappearing race of actor-managers who ran their theatres for art's sake, died today in his home at St. Margaret's Bay, near Dover, at the age of 84.

SINCE Mr. Rice's historic bout with New York's dramatic critics and his wild flaying of the general theatrical set-up, people have been wondering as to what form his next composition would take. No one, probably, was prepared for an oversized, leisurely, undramatic novel from the author of such tightly made plays as "Counsellor-at-Law" and "Street Scene."

The ringing cry of General Booth when she spoke at the great meeting in Madison Square Garden is still heard: "Try Religion!" -not this or that form of religion but religion as one has defined it in its highest sense, that has "a deep appreciation of the permanent values of life."

Making his first appearance at the National Horse Show, Lieutenant G. M. Heffernan of the Irish Free State Army last night gave a superb exhibition of horsemanship in Madison Square Garden to win the Bowman Challenge Cup.
Frank P. Walsh, New York lawyer, and former Senator James A. Reed of Missouri, who split over the New Deal, broke their five-year silence yesterday but only momentaily.

The marriage of Miss Mildred Lillian Berry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Berry of Maplewood, to Arthur George Smith, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert Smith of Nowark, took place today at the Home of the bride's parents.

The Yale eleven, which now heads for Princeton and Harvard, remained in the unbeaten ranks tonight after stopping Brown, 19 to 0. Checked in the initial period and scoring the first touchdown shortly after a disastrous penalty for Brown, the Blue packed power into a second-half drive that earned a touchdown in each of the closing quarters by long runs.

Lobar pneumonia contracted after the removal of a gold tooth from his lung by means of a bronchoscope caused the death of Dr. Felipe Contreras, cousin of the President of Venezuela, at Temple University Hospital on Oct. 29, it was learned today.

Stalin and other Soviet leaders officially launched the twentieth anniversary celebration of the Bolshevist seizure of power tonight in the annual revolutionary eve mass meeting preparatory to tomorrow's Nov. 7 parade through Red Square.

AN impressive new postoffice is rising in the center of this most northern of capitalsanother evidence of the "American" pace at which the almost 300-year-old city has been modernized since the Finnish Republic, formerly an autonomous Grand Duchy of the Russian Empire, was established in 1919.

Ralph Greenleaf of New York suffered his first defeat in the 1937 world pocket billiard tournament tonight, losing to Jimmy Caras of Wilmington, 125 to 55, in twelve innings. Caras, 1935 champion, -went out with an unfinished run of 75. Greenleaf, badly off form, was constantly out of position. He mustered a run of 27 in the eleventh frame, his last turn at the table.
The Harry Coulby, flagship of the Interlake fleet, today flew the pennant for the largest cargo ever transported on the Great Lakes.
AT the annual meeting of The Automobile Association held in London recently, Charles McWhirter, the chairman, said that the increase in membership of 46,- t 663 had been the greatest ever achieved.
The problem of housing for slum families is receiving wider attention today probably than at any previous time in the nation's history.
Boston College outrushed, outpassed and outgeneraled Western Maryland today for a 27-0 victory. A crowd of about 2,000 saw the Marylanders go down to their third consecutive defeat.

Staging the biggest Maine State series upset in years, the University of Maine came from behind in the fourth quarter to tie powerful Bowdoin, 6 to 6, today. Bowdoin, however, retained the State championship. A capacity crowd of 11,000 witnessed the game.
Mrs. Otto A. Rosalsky, widow of the General Sessions judge, caused the arrest yesterday of Mrs. Dorothea Kulkin, 40 years old, of 400 West End Avenue, on a charge of grand larceny.

Except for the certain sections of the South and Southwest, reports, on retail trade for the week indicated that volume was barely holding even with a year ago. On the Coast there was a fairly substantial drop.

Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, said today the United States Government had requested information concerning the nationalization by the Mexican Government of 250,000 acres of oil lands of the Richmond Petroleum Company of Mexico, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 4: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Duffey, G. E., to the Quincy, instead the Chester.

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions were on view this week: P. S 208. Avenue D and Forty-eighth Street. Brooklyn-Seven posters, history of Civil Service. Hebrew Orphan Asylum, 1,560 Amsterdam Avenue-Thirteen easel paintings.
The St. Lawrence University eleven ran wild in the final period to defeat the University of Vermont today, 31 to 0. Goodrich romped through

THIS is an exciting book. It is exciting because it tells the life story of the Polish immigrant who became head of the Thompson-Starrett Company and built so many of the great skyscrapers of New York. It is exciting for what it reveals of the history of some of those skyscrapers-the Woolworth Building. the Equitable Building and
Boston University marched to a 28-to-0 victory over the American International College eleven at Nickerson Field today.

The Fort Jay football team of New York City will meet the strong Fort Hoyle eleven of Maryland for the 1937 championship of the First Division at Ebbets Field on Nov. 14 in the second annual All-Army service game. Last year Fort Jay played against Fort Dupont in the service encounter before 15,000 spectators.

The police tonight broke up a committee meeting of the Democratic Republican party, headed by former President Mario G. Menocal, in the city of Camaguey and detained a group including Representative Juan Cabrera Hernandez. They were later released.

Miss Ursula Meinhold, daughter of Mrs. Irma Meinhold of Westfield, was married to William H. Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roi C. Collins, also of this place, today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Loesch.

APPLICATIONS keep pouring in for the "Fifty-Year Club" being organized in connection with Josef Hofmann's golden jubilee concert to be given Nov. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Only those are eligible who attended the Hofmann concerts of fifty years ago. Walter Damrosch is chairman.

Havana University students today declared a twenty-four-hour suspension of classes in protest against the castor oil dosing of Doctor Rodolfo Mendez Penate, assistant to the Rector, by four unknown persons last night.

The Musicians' Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy is sponsoring a prize contest for a new symphonic composition which will be given its first performance at Carnegie Hall In March. Four American composers-namely, Aaron Copeland, Roy Harris, Roger Sessions and Bernard Wagenaar, and Alfred Wallenstein, cellist-conductor-will be the judges.

The Spartans of Michigan State, viciously rebuffed for three quarters, arose in the final period today to smite Temple University's hitherto undefeated forces for two touchdowns and a 13-to-6 triumph that toppled the Owls off their unbeaten perch.

A meeting of the Home and Community Builders National Association will be held in Washington, D. C., Jan. 11, 12 and 13, to discuss a plan under which a $2,000,000,000 home-building program might be effected during 1938.

Officials of the Museum of Natural History at Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West reported an increased attendance yesterday at the thirtieth annual Autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, which closes this evening at 5 o'clock;

A MATCH between two teams of four players each is said to be the fairest test of skill at contract bridge. Attendance at team-of-four tournaments suffers, however, from the fact that it is difficult to assemble four players who are able to give up enough time from their regular business
The 232 graduate students at Radeliffe College this year have taken their bachelors' and masters' deagrees at 103 colleges and universities, instead of last year's eightyeight.
THE use of large, built-in aquaria as an element in interior decoration is a new phase of the exotic fish hobby. It is true that this art or device was practiced in the days of the Roman Empire.

Louisiana State walloped Mississippi State, 41 to 0, today before a homecoming crowd of 20,000. L. S. U.'s versatile halfback, Pinky Rohm, led the scoring parade with a dazzling 58-yard return of a punt near the end of the first period.

A powerful second-half attack carried the George Washington High football team to a 13-to-O victory over Seward Park before 4,500 at the Washington Stadium yesterday. The triumph, its fourth in five starts, kept Washington in the running for the mythical Manhattan title.

Young women of society headed by Miss Peggy Brokaw are aiding Mrs. Nelson B. Burr and Mrs. Richard C. Goheen in the plans for the dinner dance for the benefit of the New York City Cancer Institute which will be held Wednesday at the formal Winter opening of the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

News leaked out tonight that the Admiralty had been in trouble with the crews of three fleet auxiliary steamers at Singapore, key fortification in the Far East. Seventy-two of the men, it is said, are traveling homeward aboard the liner Naldera to place their "grievances" before the Admiralty and the National Union of Seamen.

A new regional organization now comes before the country as the official representative of the unity of New England. The six Governors have formally constituted themselves a New England Governors' Conference. The chairman is Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut. The secretary is Governor Francis P. Murphy of New Hampshire.

Four canvassers engaged in counting the. proportional representation ballots for Councilmen in the Bronx were summarily discharged late yesterday afternoon as a result of apparent tampering with the ballots cast in one Bronx election district. In the district, the forty-fourth of the Seventh Assembly District, the canvass showed 22 ballots marked for Joseph E. Kinsley, Democrat; 81 for James Graham, Republican, and the 56 remaining ballots of the district invalid.

Six hours of conference on two successive days between committees representing the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization have sent labor peace stocks up and the twoyear labor conflict shows signs of yielding to negotiation.
Income tax laws impose a penalty upon corporations for accumulating earnings beyond the reasonable needs of the business. This applies to operating companies as well as personal holding companies.
The complete list of the signers the "medical declaration of inependence" up to Oct. 30, advoating the principle of socialized rtedicine, is as follows:

Debutantes of this season and former years are assisting members of the Seventh Regiment in preparations for the annual Fall military ball to be given by the regiment on Dec. 4 in its armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
A tea and sale will be held on Dec. 2 at the Pierre for the benefit of the Art Workers Club for Women It will be augmented by a fashion show to be known as, "Debutantes After Dark."
Scoring in every period, a greatly improved Taft School eleven smashed out a 2T-7 victory over Kent before a Fathers' Day crowd of 1,500. The entire student bodies of both schools attended.

Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, denied today published reports that he was sponsoring a proposal for banking legislation that would make the board the supreme authority over all phases of banking in this country.

SINCE it is not really so far away as it seems, Christmas Night is now being eyed by the gentlemen who still see in it one of the choicer opportunities for bringing a show to Broadway's attention. Arthur Hammerstein has

The Advisory Council on Social Security adjourned today with the appointment of an ad interim committee to function until the council meets Dec. 11 and 12 to take up again the troublesome 'question of the eventual huge "reserve" from the tax on employes and employers.

Only a small volume of bonds was called last week for redemption before maturity. The announcements were even fewer than in the preceding week, when activity also was extremely light. Except for two large issues, one for a public utility corporation and the other for a foreign government loan, the calls were principally for small amounts of municipal and real estate bonds to satisfy sinking fund requirements.

Such devices as the "wagon stage" and rotating cast are being employed by the Little Theatre Workshop group at New Jersey College for Women to enlarge its scope and prevent physical difficulties from limiting its type of production.
Union defeated the Rochester eleven, 13 to 0, today, an alumni homecoming crowd of 4,000 witnessing an exciting contest.

Between Britain and pain strong bonds of trade have long existed. In 1935 more than $55,000,000 worth of Spanish wines, oranges, iron ore, potatoes, almonds, onions, grapes, pyrites, raisins, lemons, copper ore, mercury and other products were bought by Britain: more than $25,000,000 worth

IN 1917, one-lunged "contraptions" chugged about the streets of our larger cities trying to compete with horses and wagons in offering local transportation service. Today, in 1937, six and eight cylinder streamlined tractors and trailers haul tons of freight on regular scheduled over-the-road runs, some

LONDON.-Future methods of warfare are unlikely to be more devastating than those we know about, Professor J. B. S. Haldane of London University told military officers at a United Service Institution meeting in London recently. Among the illusions,

Twelve days after he had climbed into the driver's cab of a produceladen truck in Ketchikan, Alaska, Al Radero cut the ignition at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in front of the Bronx Terminal Market to deliver two tons of Matanuska Valley potatoes to the City of New York.

BRUSSELS where the Ninepower Conference on the Far East is meeting, is an unfamiliar name in the ranks of conference cities. For that matter, conference cities as a distinct species of the urban genus are not nearly so familiar as they might be. Even conferences themselves, old though they seem to be, are in their present dispensation only as old as democratic diplomacy.

Commissioner Balthasar H. Meyer of the Interstate Commerce Commission issued to day a statement explaining his action in giving to a railroad man in 1932 certain information which was criticized yesterday by Senator Truman of Missouri, acting chairman of the Senate's Rail Financing Committee.

The Poly Prep eleven of Brooklyn today emerged victor over Irving School, 12 to 6. Ferris and Newrohr scored touchdowns for the visitors after sustainted drives of 70 and 40 yards. Bruckel made a 20-yard pass to Burrows, who sprinted 60 yards to tally for Irvin.

IF your day, we'll rid our punclogged system of the one about the screen's having seen the era of its ways last week-two eras, in fact, the Napoleonic and the Victorian. "Victoria the Great" was the reverent chronicle of the life of England's "most respectable of queens." "Conquest" was Metro's expensive account of the romance between Napoleon and the Polish Countess Walewska.

Placing four men in the first five, Sayville High School's well-balanced squad romped away with the Suffolk County cross-country championship today. Forty runners from seven schools participated in the two-mile run over the fairways of the Island Hills Golf Club.
The Duke of Windsor's decision not to go to the United States to study social and industrial conditions caused little surprise in London.
Though civil war continues its disruptive course in Spain, and the battle area in China grows wider, mail from the United States is still reaching its destinations in both countries.

The widespread European fears of a further devaluation of the dollar and the accompanying scramble for gold in London which appeared last week in the foreign-exchange market testified to an abrupt-and confusing change which' has taken place recently in world monetary affairs.

Two large shows opened here today at the Pennsylvania Museum this morning a superb loan exhibition of oils, drawings, composite wash drawings and lithographs by Daumier; at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, the combined 1937 display of the Philadelphia Water Color Club and the Pennsylvania Societfy of Miniature Painters (private view this evening), open to the public beginning Sunday.
Yale's undefeated 150-pound team continued its winning ways today by defeating the lightweights of Villanova, 20 to 13. The Elis started with a rush by scoring twice in the opening period.
A good demand for Brooklyn real estate was indicated by sales of properties reported yesterday in that borough.

Federal Judge Dickinson ruled today that the Federal Government cannot acquire lands within State lines by condemnation without the consent of the State. He rejected a request by the Department of the Interior to condemn 459 acres for a Public Works Administration park and recreation project.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Louise Edwards, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Hughes Edwards of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Dr. Edwards; to John Hanna Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Morris of Boston.

PLAYRIRIGHT MOSS HART, cornered in a Pullman en route last Sunday with the "I'd Rather Be Right" company, was asked for some salient facts concerning the origin of this harlequinade which spoofs President Roosevelt and most of the New Deal policies.

Mrs. Eugene Rhodes of this town is a firm believer in the principle that every crippled child has the right to not only care, treatment and education, but also to such training as will fit him or her for self-support, wholly or in part.

The Far Eastern conflict, now in its fourth month, echoed through the world's chancelleries last week. It was the subject of an international conference (which promises to achieve little of importance), and it was a contributing factor in a tri-national pact (which promises to achieve considerable importance in the world politics of at least the immediate future).

Bloomfield, High School's eleven moved nearer the Group Four State football championship today by scoring a 34-to-0 victory over the hitherto undefeated Irvington High School eleven. The game was played before more than 15,000 spectators, the largest crowd ever to attend a school game here.

Connecticut State scored its fourteenth victory in the thirty-four-game series with Rhode Island State, 13-7, today by rallying in the fourth period to tally twice before a homecoming day crowd of 4.000.

In resplendent settings softened by the warm glow of candlelight the annual Horse Show Ball took place last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. It was the first important event of its kind of the new social season which was formally inaugurated at opening night of the National Horse Show last Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.

Directors of Safeway Stores, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 1-100th share of 5 per cent preferred stock on each share of common. Previously, this year, the company paid cash dividends of 50 cents each on April 18, July 1 and Oct. 1.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The cause of liberalism is not endangered by running slow or running fast, provided it remains upon its track. It is lagging down today and has come to a standstill in many countries because it jumped the track.

Pershing Mondorff, a soccer player who changed to football a year ago, place-kicked an 18-yard field goal with one minute to play to give the University of Maryland a 9-to-7 victory over Virginia Military Institute today before 5,000 fans.

The report of the controller of Cornell University for the fiscal year ended June 30 shows an average rate of return on investments of 4.7468 per cent, an increase of nearly three fourths of 1 per cent over that of the previous year.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Sargent and Robert Hude Neilsop will give jointly a dinner dance on Dec. 30 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis to introduce to society their respective daughters, Miss Mary A. Sargent and Miss Sarah R. Neilson.

The Cosmopolitan Club, by virtue of its 3-1 victory over the strong Carroll Club, remained the only undefeated team in the interclub rivalry of the New York Women's Field Hockey Association following yesterday's matches in. Prospect Park.

One quick aerial thrust for a touchdown in the second period today carried a scrappy Penn State football team to a 7-0 victory over the University of Pennsylvania in the thirty-sixth meeting of the two.
Hugh Wolfe, University of Texas back, kicked Baylor off the unbeaten list today with a 26-yard field goal that submerged the last Southwestern team with a perfect record. The score was 9 -6.

THIS scholarly study by Dr. Eleanor Tupper and Dr. George E. McReynolds of American public opinion on Japan since 1905, appearing on the eve of the Brussels Ninepower conference at which our government must make important decisions concerning American policy on the Far East, is most timely.

George A. Farrell, director of government farm programs in Western wheat areas, said today that a majority of wheat growers appeared to favor "some compulsory control over wheat production or marketing." He based his opinion on testimony before a Senate agricultural subcommittee's hearings in the wheat areas.

Such developments as the signature of the protocol binding Italy, Germany and Japan together in a war against communism tend to in crease the difficulties now plaguing the world, in the general opinion of responsible officials here, none of whom would make any public comment today on the Rome ceremony.
The Italian liner Roma sailed on time yesterday after a crew of workmen had toiled through Friday and Friday night repairing a disabled steam turbine.

WITH seventy-two motor truck and accessory manufacturers occupying 78,000 square feet of floor space in the Center Market Building, Newark's fourth annual Motor Truck Show opened yesterday, to run through Nov. 12. Big trucks and little trucks, ranging all the

Modifications of the Federal Housing Act at the forthcoming Congressional session are essential, declares Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, to stimulate home building on a broad national scale.

A. B. Wolosoff, Kew Gardens, L. I., builder, in commenting on the recent report of the F. W. Dodge Corporation which predicted that 215,000 family units would be constructed during 1938, says that he believes this estimate is conservative.
A series of fourteen lectures on building management will be given at Columbia University Extension on Wednesday evenings from Feb. 2 to May 11, 1938, announces Dr. James C. Egbert, director.

Dr. Charles Du Bos, French critic, writer and Catholic scholar is expected to arrive, on the French liner Normandie due to dock in New York tomorrow. Dr. Du Bos .will become a member of the permanent faculty of the University of Notre Dame, it was announced.
The fiftieth anniversary of the Seligman Solomon Society of the Alumni of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum of the City of New York was celebrated last night at a dinner and dance at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Dictatorship was described as a system of government under which the growth of the creative arts was retarded by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University in his opening address to alumni and faculty of the university's School of Education at the opening of the school's alumni day ceremonies yesterday at Washington Square East.

BERGER-ROTER-Mr. and Mrs. louis Roter announce, the marriage of their daughter, Ethel, to Milton Berger, Oct. 30. Rabbi J. M. Lawn officiated. GODDESS-KINZLER-Mr. and Mrs. Kalman Kinazler of New York City announce the marriage of their daughter, Hazel Cecile, to Mr. Eugene D. Goddess, son of Mr. Joseph Goddess of Chicago.
Bucknell defeated a hard-fighting Furman football team, 20 to 7, before a crowd of 5,000 today. The Bisons scored in the first, second and third periods. Furman's touchdown came in the final quarter.
The $6,250,000 New York-Brooklyn Federation Campaign for Jewish Charities will open next Sunday the joint annual dinner of the, two federations at the Hotel Commodore,

THIRTEEN years ago a graduate of Yale was assured of leisure and the means to make the most of it. He devoted his time and his resources to a task of his own choice. He would learn all that there is to be learned and tell all that there is to be told about Horace Walpole.

William J. O'Donnell, head of the 3. O'Donnell-Murray Tours, 500 Fifth Avenue, and founder and president' of the World Fellowsnip of the U1timate Religion, died Friday night in the Presbyterian Hospital after five weeks' illness. He was born in Broklyn sixty-eight years ago.

INSTEAD of strumming a guitar and humming nostalgic nonsense in the bunkhouse, as is the traditional wont in old Wyoming, Curly Twyford spent a sort, of Franciscan boyhood there, exchanging airy badinage with the bird life and guying the gophers.
Reports that Chancellor Hitler is about to offer to mediate between Japan and China are unconfirmed in official quarters in London and are expected to remain unconfirmed.

Down East business men engaged in capitalizing on fish scales reflect today that it was a Russian artist working on a portrait of a Governor of Rhode Island who made the discovery, back in Civil War days, which resulted in the development of the artificial "pearl lacquer."

New members will be elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 633 West 155th Street, at the annual meeting on Friday, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the academy.

The Alumnae of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel in White Plains will hold their annual Autumn dance next Tuesday night in the Perroquet Suite of the WaldorfAstoria. The dance committee in-cludes Miss Mary Drury, chairman, whose aides are the Misses Marie Ryan, Margaret McGuiness, Clementine Garriazo, Doris Dowd, Regina Spellman, Eleanor Besler, Kathryn Cahill and Rosemae McCabe.

The decline in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business has become sharper. For the week ended on Oct. 30 the index-dropped to 95.4 from 97.8 (revised) in the previous week. It compared with 101.3 for the corresponding week last year.

IF Chancellor Hitler's current demands for restoration of Germany's pre-war colonies were to be granted, stamp collecting would be profoundly affected. The return of Germany's former possessions in Africa and Oceania through abandonment of the mandate

With six minutes left to play in a game clearly dominated by Harvard, Army recovered a fumble and went 33 yards for a touchdown to defeat the Crimson today for the sixth successive year before 47,000 spectators at Soldiers Field. score was 7-6.

The wedding of Miss Dorothy Matilda Holdridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Holdridge of this place, to Joseph Smith, son of Mrs. Elizabeth Smith of Upper Montclair, took place here this morning at the Sacred Heart Church. Mgr. T. M. Donovan,

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sibley Putnam of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Chaslotte Putnam, to Charles M. Reppert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Reppert of Pittsburgh.

The marriage of Miss Emily MacLachlin, daughter of Mrs. Mary Roe MacLachlin of this city and the late Harry Marshall MacLachlin, to Croxton Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Thomas Morris of White Plains, N. Y., took place here tonight in the First Baptist Church.
Members of the Washington Headquarters Association will give their annual benefit bridge party and tea on Thursday in the Florentine Room at Schrafft's, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The announcement that is expected to accompany the Soviet Ambassador's return from Moscow by plane is awaited with suppressed excitement. It is conjectured that possibly the envoy, Dimitri V. Bogomoloff, will announce that Russia will return to China unqualified and unrestricted sovereignty over outer Mongolia.

The work of the American Merchant Marine Library Association in supplying books to seamen is being graphically illustrated at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair now in progress at the International Building in Rockefeller Center.
A last-period rally gave New York University's women's field hockey team a 2-to-O triumph over the Hofstra College eleven of Hempstead, L. I., at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday.

The recent mock battle between planes and power boats in Long Island Sound was won by the aircraft, it was announced yesterday by George W. Rappleyea, whose best previous idea resulted--according to John Thomas Scopes himself--in the Tennessee evolution trial twelve years ago.

PROFESSIONALLY speaking, what looks in prospect like the best football game of the day will be played at Wrigley Field in Chicago, where the undefeated Bears will take on the up-and-coming Green Bay Packers. Curly Lambeau's Green Bay brigade started the season by running some reverse plays to the wrong side, but they haven't missed since they turned to the right and they have scored 144 points in the last four games.

Although the government persists in denying all reports of uprisings in Trans-Jordan, it is true that dis orders have broken out and that rumblings of rebellion are in /the air. Today bombs were thrown by Arabs on government offices in Irbid and Madaba. Telephone wire Eng were cut between Amman and Sulach and also between Irbin and Roman and at Es Salt.

The American college girl of today's freshman class is physically taller and more slender than her sister of earlier years, and she is younger. Temperamentally, she seems. more serious, more objective in her outlook on life. Socially, she is as funloving as ever.

BECAUSE books can and do exert an important influence upon youth, the Boy Scouts have long been encouraged to cultivate good reading habits. The reading program of the movement is outlined in its constitution and by-laws, and many local Scout councils have reading program committees which cooperate with libraries and other neighborhood agencies to promote the use of good books.
The annual card party in aid of the Chapin Home for the Aged and Infirm in Jamaica, Queens, will be held Nov. 16 in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria.

At an installation dinner of the Forty and Eight Society of the American Legion at the Hotel Commodore last night, John J. Cronin was installed as chef de gare, Isidore Jablons as chef de train, Gustave J. Fricke as commissaire intendant, and Elmer Hirschorn as correspondent.

An Italian war vessel will carry Angelo Maria Cardinal Dolci, Papal Legate, to the Eucharistic Congress at Tripoli next week, the Vatican announced tonight. The Italian Government has placed the 8,000-ton cruiser Da Barbiano at the disposal of the pontifical mission for the trip, it was stated.

Colonel Snowden A. Fahnestock of this city, Gibson Fahnestock Jr. of New York and Mrs. Markgaret Drummond-Wolff of London share equally in the estate of their mother, Mrs. Carolyn Andrews Fahnestock, who died at her Washington home last month.

Just a year ago from the day this will be printed a great military upset occurred. Foreign Legionarles, Moors, Requetes, Carlists, German artillery and German and Italian planes smashed with apparently irresistible force against Madrid.

Minnesota's Golden Gophers, prides pricked by Iowa's unexpected early 10-point lead, roared back with characteristic power and deception to crush the Hawkeyes, 35 to 10, today before 40,000 homecoming football fans.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, will give the first pair of concerts of its forthcoming season in Carnegie Hall,Thursday night, Nov. 18 and Saturday afternoon, Nov. 20. For the initial program Beethoven's "Eroica" symphony and the Second symphony of Sibelius have been chosen.

An order for 47,000 tons of steel, estimated to cost $2,350,000, for extension and improvement of the Ford Motor Company's plant at River Rouge, Mich., has been announced by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.
Middle Western farmers generally will be pleased with the corn loan announcement, although there is likely to be considerable complaint against some of the terms.

Health officials from throughout the country, international dignitaries and State government officials will be among the principal speakers at the ceremonies here on Nov. 24, marking the thirtieth anniversary of the first Christmas Seal sale.

Many angles of the toll of traffic congestion, causing deaths and injuries on the highways and interfering with the movement of motor cars, will be discussed this week at a seminar of safety under the auspices of the C. I. T. Safety Foundation, established in 1936 by the Commercial Investment Trust, with' Henry Ittleson, Arthur 0. Dietz and John W. Darr as trustees.

At 2 o'clock this morning three persons were fatally injured when an automobile skidded on the wet pavement on Route 25 (State highway) here and crashed into a tree and a telephone pole. The pole was severed at its base.

Charles A. Lent, head of Brown, Lent Pett, 70 Washington Street, Brooklyn, stationery manufacturers, died yesterday at his residence, the Hotel Granada, Brooklyn, after a long illness, in his eighty-first year.

FOR the persistent reviewer of frothy fiction the pleasure of reporting one of Mrs. Miller's deft trifles is just a little unbalancing. She knows how to give the illusion of depth and sagacity without being in the least profound. Her story can be wildly improbable and violent without violating taste or sensibilities. One is willing to give her credit for magic while knowing that it is all done with mirrors.
John B. Ehrhart, president of the Rochester Vulcanite Pavement Company, died early today at the BrookLea Country Club as he was talking with friends. His age was 59.

Student scientists at the Bowdoin scientific station on Kent's Island, working under the direction of Professor Albert R. Brand of Cornell University, successfully broadcast by short wave during the Summer the calls and songs of birds. It is hoped that next year these calls may be broadcast over national radio networks.
A four-year fight was won by William Strain against residents of the Round Hill section, when the Board of Appeals of the Greenwich Zoning Commission. granted Mr.

A contribution of $1,000 has been pledged by the New York State Socity of the Daughters of 1812 for a bronze bust of Daniel D. Tompkins, Governor of New York in 1807, which is to be placed in the portico of St. Marks-in-the Bouwerie, Protestant Episcopal Church at 234 East Eleventh Street, it was announced yesterday.

An inspired Manhattan eleven, pounding its rival's line with a furious, relentless ground attack that eventually took its toll of the gallant Titans from Detroit University, recorded a notable upset victory yesterday before 10,000 persons at Ebbes Field.

Three days of discussion of "Pan Americanism, Its Justification and Future," will be held at George Washington University on Dec. 6, 7 and 8. Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State; Don Manuel de Freyre Santander, the Ambassador of Peru; Dr. Leo S. Rowe, Director General of the Pan American Union, and others will address the opening meeting.

The Salzburg Opera Guild opened its first season in America last night at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre with a delicious performance of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte." It has been long since such a spirit and such an ensemble has been witnessed in musico-dramatic representations in this city.

Miss Elizabeth Telfair Mines, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Telfair Mines of Lynbrook, N. Y., was married to William R. J. Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Anderson of York, Pa., here today at the new home of the couple at 333 East Seventh Street.

The Appalachian School at Penland, N. C., which is supported by the Penland Board of the Church of the Ascension, will be the beneficiary of a bridge party and tea to be held on Tuesday on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. Mrs. Louis Guerineau Myers heads the arrangements committee, assisted by Mrs. Stewart M. Seymour, vice chairman; Mrs. W. Rice Brewster,
Members of an expetition into British Guiana's jungles to study native drugs and diseases prevalent among aboriginal Indians has reported that it soon will stage the first jungle radio broadcast.

Unbeaten Scarborough School of Westchester County added another victory to its two-year string by deeating La Salle Military Academy, 7-0, today. It was the twelfth straight triumph in two seasons for the Maroon and the first defeat of the year for La Salle.

Lafayette outscored a slightly favored Rutgers eleven on Fisser Field today to continue among the nation's undefeated and untied teams. Fifteen thousand fans watched the Leopards score their sixth straight triumph by a 13-to-6 score.

Henry Hirschberg, District Attorney of Orange County, disclosed today that three Negroes had been arrested and charged with the murder of Woo Lung, 70 years old, a laundryman, who was found dead in his shop at 157 Water Street more two years ago.

Max D. Steuer, who has defended i some of the most publicized criminal cases in recent years, will be one of the speakers at a meeting on jury service for women to be held at the American Woman's Association tomorrow at 8:30 P. M. in the clubhouse auditorium. Mr.

A large reception will be given on the afternoon of Nov. 16 in the clubhouse of the Junior League at 221 East Seventy-first Street to mark the termination of four years' successful operation of the Housekeeper Service by the Junior League and the transference of the service to the Children's Aid Society.

As a special feature of the activities which will mark "High Education Week" at City College, the Educational Clinic at the college, the first of its kind in the city, will celebrate the completion of twentyfive years of service to schools and social agencies.

Large long-term commitments which furnish the backbone of foreign trade must wait on currency stabilization of a more permanent nature than now exists, according to views expressed by bankers who attended the twenty-fourth annual national foreign trade convention of the National Foreign Trade Council, here.

The annual theatre party for the benefit of the Little Italy Neighborhood Association at 146 Union Street, Brooklyn, will be the performace of "French Without Tears," the night of Nov. 22 at the Henry Miller Theatre. Miss Louise Goetze heads the committee for the benefit.

At Philadelphia last week Dr. W. M. Stanley of the Rockefeller Institute's Princeton station reviewed the present state of our knowledge of the mysterious viruses which cause some plant diseases as well as infantile paralysis, yellow fever, rabies and encephalitis.

Walter Johnson was acclaimed tonight by hundreds of capital sports enthusiasts on his fiftieth birthday. The lobby of the Mayflower Hotel echoed with the applause of 450 admirers as the former baseball hero bashfully walked into the banquet hall.

" SWING high-swing low!" shouts the master of the revels, as a group of dancing couples, responding to the urge of a hot band, "truck" into a semiformal circle and start a slow, rotating shuffle around the floor... "Get your girl and take a twirl!"

Spanish Insurgents reported tonight a government attack on the Madrid front had been thrown back with be heavy losses on the eve of the first Anniversary of the capital's siege. The border dispatches said the Madrid forces had attempted to drive a wedge into the Aravaca sector, northwest of the capital, in one of Defense Commander Jose Maija's which will be one year old tomorrow.

One long and accurate pitch from Bernie Bloom to Harry Shorten early in the first period and a stabbing 29-yard run by Ed Williams late in the third quarter yesterday gave N. Y. U.'s Violets two touchdowns and a 13-0 triumph over Lehigh at the Yankee Stadium.

Convicted Friday night of mail fraud in connection with real estate operations of the House of Parliman, Clifford H. Parliman of Jersey City, N. J., head of the company, was sentenced yesterday to serve two years in the penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa. Peter M. Steenland of Palisades Park, N. J., must serve a year and a day.

MULTIPLYING signs mark the return of prosperity to Boston stages. Not the least among the portents are two new productions opening during the past week. Nor is it without significance that one of them, Sidney Howard's and the Theatre Guild's
Things are very nearly ready, R. H. Macy Co. announced yesterday, for the Thanksgiving Day parade that will escort Santa Claus to the toy department of the store at Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway.

New Rochelle High School's Purple Wave was subjected to its worst beating at the hands of a White Plains High football team in twenty-one years today when the undefeated Tigers scored a 29-0 victory in the thirty-third meeting between the old rivals at Parker Memorial Stadium. A crowd of 10,000 saw the W. I. A. A. battle.

Today Pen and Brush Club--Tea in honor of Rachel Crothers, 4 P. M. Monday A. A. U. W. (Monmouth County, N. J., Branch)-Meeting. Judge Joseph Seigler and Calvin Derrick, speakers on delinquency, home of Mrs. Abram Elkus, Red Bank.

Secretary Swanson, in his report for the fiscal year, urged President Roosevelt to call upon Congress for increasesd appropriations for the navy to carry the naval construction program to completion, provide for larger enlisted and commissioned personnel, with "adequate" pay, and strengthen the naval reserve.

The Lighthouse Eye Clinic of the New York Association for the Blind will be the beneficiary of a dinner dance to be held on Nov. 30 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. The dance, a Bal de Tete, will be featured by a showing by six young women of the latest evening coiffures and head dresses.
Miss Frances Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Vincent Wise, was married to John Carrington Yates of New York yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, 89 Woodbine Avenue, Newark,
IN a week when more than a half hundred exhibitions opened it must be obvious that many of the shows cannot receive the extended comment and careful at- tention they intrinsically merit.

(1) Representatives of the States which met in Brussels Nov. 3 have taken cognizance of the reply which the Japanese Government sent to the invitation of the Belgian Government and the statement which accompanied this reply.
Abe Coleman, 206, Brooklyn, defeated Chief Thunder Bird, 215, Victoria, B. C., in the main wrestling exhibition at the Broadway Arena last night. The latter missed

In Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's City Hall office-an office he now retains for four years more-was spread out last week the huge striped skin of a tiger, an election day present from Harold Fowler, first Deputy Police Commissioner and big-game hunter. A tag offered this identification:

Vice President Automobile Manuturers Association EACH year as the National Automobile Show completes its eight days showing, the show committee and members of the Automobile Manufacturers Associtation invariably look upon it as "the best ever." As a result of these shows, for the past few years the industry has looked forward to
Miss Agnes Warren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Northam Warren of this place, will be married to Karl W. Illigan of Harrisburg, Pa., on Nov. 27 in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, New York.

An Italian program to increase reserves of wheat through savings to be accomplished by mixing increasingly large proportions of corn flour with wheat flour was disclosed today in a report from Rome made public by the Department of Commerce.

City College's football team produced only one sustained scoring drive in a hard-fought game with St. Joseph's yesterday, but that one, coming through the air midway in the final period, was enough to give the Beavers a 7-to-O victory over the visitors from Philadelphia at-Lewisohn Stadium.

A spirited Blair football team marched to victory over the Rutgers jayvee eleven, 13 to 0, today. Both touchdowns were tallied in the final period. A 60-yard run by Conrad, Blair left half, put the ball on the jayvee 5 and Reumann plunged through center for the touchdown.
A card party and tea under the auspices of the Women's Auxiliary of Holy Innocent Church in Brooklyn will take place on Nov. 16 in the school auditorium opposite the church.

Elsewhere in this issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES appear letters from Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association, Professor Milton C. Winternitz of Yale's University School of Medicine,

TWICE every year the Shenan doah Valley shows a marked preference for monarchs. In the Spring, when apple orchards are cascades of pink and white blooms, the citizens of the valley choose a Queen of the Apple Blossom Festival. And in the Fall, when trees are heavy with ripe Fruit, they provide a consort for the Queen by crowning a King of the Apple Harvest Festival.

The American-owned Rubicon Inn, south of Soochow Creek, was struck today by Japanese shells and aerial bombs. The once-famous night club now is encircled by barbedwire fences and is used by Chinese troops for machine-gun nests.

Seventh annual Regional Conference of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, Community House of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street, 9:30 A. M.; luncheon 12:45 P. M.; afternoon session 2:30 P. M.

More than 3,000,000 Jews in Poland are "standing their ground" despite pogroms and economic warfare against them by anti-Semiti minorities, according to a report to the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee based on a three-month survey in. Poland by Alexander Kahn. a vice chairman.

ALBERT HALPER, along with the entire school of realists who have grouped themselves around the proletarian banner, is committed to the assumption that a man is a passive thing, acted upon rather than acting.

An American passenger listed as Stephen Balogh, New York City jeweler, was missing when the Polish liner Batory docked here today from New York. The Batory's Captain told harbor authorities Balogh, en route to Rumania with his wife, disappeared from the liner shortly before the vessel reached Copenhagen.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Berry of Rome, Ga., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabelle Chaney Berry, to Paul Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. Forney Johnston of Birmingham, Ala.
The Supreme Court in its session today considered litigation involving the constitutionality of sit-down strikes.

STIFF breezes have blown the sidewalk cafes out of existence for a while, but the New Yorker who knows his town has watched their seasonal eclipse without concern. November's nippy days mean a return, for him, to one of the joys of metropolitan existence-the good food and good companionship of the neighborhood restaurant.

BUTLERS, the supreme gift of the British Empire to Hollywood and mystery fiction, are the specialty of Ernest Cossart. You have seen him buttling with frozen gravity and punctilio of bedtick vest in "Two for Tonight" and "Accent on Youth," and you will now see him as the correct gentleman's gentleman in "Angel," which Ernst Lubitsch has made with Marlene Dietrich and Herbert Marshall.

The Bisons of Howard University tagged the Seasiders of Hampton Institute with a 13-6 defeat today. Starting their offensive at the beginning of the second quarter, the Bisons tallied twice, Prime and Elliott going over. Griffin made the Hampton touchdown at the close.

Official circles have confirmed that the government has granted $1,000,000 toward improvement of air fields and general equipment and overhauling of planes and materials belonging to the National Airlines, carrying passengers, mails and cargo between the port of Arica and Puerto Montt.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Nov. 3, aggregated $8,722,000,000, or 4 per cent below the total reported for the precedin week and 1 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

For the current mid-season showings, Maggy Rouff has divided her collection into models for present and Spring wear. The first half shows richly furtrimmed slim coats, form-fitting gowns that are still draped through the waist and evening gowns with corselet bodices and full net skirts.

Miss Lillian Francesca Sinclair daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Sinclair of this city, was married to Robert Roland Dehart, son of Albert Dehart of Pueblo, Col., today in Hallam Chapel of St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Frank St. Morehouse, the rector, performed the ceremony.

The Japanese forces are still outside the gates of Taiyuan, the capital of Shansi Province. The Chinese authorities refused yesterday to surrender the city. The Japanese will again demand today a peaceful surrender by noon. If this is refused they will

Plans for the annual luncheon and card party in behalf of the Almoners to be held Thursday at Sherry's will be completed at the monthly meeting of the organization tomorrow afternoon at the same restaurant.

Postponement of-the Duke of Windsor's American tour-produced almost as much relief in London today as it appears to have caused across th- Atlantic. Officially, the Duke ceased to be a problem the day he left English shores, but neither the British Government nor the people has enjoyed watching him make one mistake after another in the last few weeks of his exile.
PINEHURST, N. C.-Featured on the Fall sports calendar here is the seventeenth annual Midsouth professional golf tournament, which is scheduled to be held a week from Tuesday. Special arrangements are
Before a crowd of returning alumni the Peddie School varsity football team reopened its rivalry with the Bordentown Military Institute today and was defeated, 21-0.
Alabama's Crimson Tide, thanks to a thrilling field goal in the waning minutes, rolled on undefeated and untied today with a 9-to-6 conquest over Tulane's Green Wave.

Interest payments to investors in certificated mortgages held by the State Mortgage Commission have increased substantially during the time that body has had charge of the guaranteed mortgage certificate problem, the commission announced yesterday.

The Brotherhood Council of the Confessional Church will issue tomorrow a public warning against the teachings of Dr. Alfred Rosenberg. The declaration says that in his latest work, "Protestant Pilgrims to Rome," the National Socialist party's educational chief demands the divorce of the German nation from Christianity.

The outbreak of a mysterious malady among sailors is causing concern in maritime circles in France. Last night the French ship Jean L. D. reached Dunkirk from Lndon with seventeen members of the crew stricken with a mysterious fever.

The fine velvets that make glamorous gowns also will produce clearer and brighter television pictures, according to the claim in a patent just granted here to Philo T. Farnsworth of San Francisco, noted for his inventions in television.

ON the day after Lawrence Tibbett's three-hour-long recital in the Musikverein Saal Dr. Paul Stefan wrote in the Stunde: "His concert was an outright triumph and he could be a darling of the Viennese tomorrow if the day after tomorrow he did not have to sing in Paris, then in America, then in Australia."
The Silver Cross Day Nursery will be aided by a card party and bazaar to be held Nov. 17 in the ballroom of the Plaza under the auspices of the executive committee or the organization.
Eldred Griffith, for years well known in the cotton brokerage business, died today at a charlotte hospital after a long illness. His age was 83.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional Director of the National Labor Relations Board, informed the Financial Workers Organizing Committee yesterday that "there seems to be nothing in the National Labor Relations Act which denies to bank employes the same rights accorded to other employes."

A half century of burlesque and satire by undergraduates of the University of Pennsylvania will be marked by the Mask and Wig Club's golden jubilee production, "Fifty-Fifty," whose gypsies, G-men and honeymooners are in the midst of rehearsals for the opening performance on Nov. 19.

Mrs. Mary B. Hoy, a missionary in Japan and China for the Evangelical and Reformed Church for more than a half century, died at Hankow, China, yesterday, in her seventy-fifth year. Word of her death was received here today by the church's Board of Foreign Missions.

Commitments for mortgage insurance finally or tentatively approved by the New York, Brooklyn, Jamaica and White Plains offices of the Federal Housing Administration during October totaled $5,955,300, according to Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director.
Some belief is entertained here that an announcement may be coming soon from London concerning the attitude of the British Government toward the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement.

The report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, showed a net income of $10,038,413, after all expenses and charges. This was equal after preferred dividend requirements to 88 cents a share on the outstanding common stock.

The life ambition of the late Mrs. Samuel J. Kitson, wife of the famous British sculptor and long a resident of New York, finally was realized on lonely King Island, in the Bering Sea, last Sunday, the feast of Christ the King, seven months after her death.

The annual Christmas sale and tea in behalf of Hope Farm, rural community and school near Millbrook, N. Y., will be held this year on Nov. 17 and 18 at the Pierre. In addition to the bric-a-brac gathered during the Summer in this country and Europe by members of the various committees, a collection of early American glass will be a feature of the sale.

The sight of trainloads of army ovens moving into Buenos Aires to enable the National Government to make cheap bread for sale to the public has finally caused the bakers to reduce the price of the staff of life.

That the ultimate determination of the Robinson-Patman Act complaint against the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company will hinge upon - three points was indicated last week in an analysis prepared by the American Institute of Food Distribution of the brief submitted by the Federal Trade Commission's attorneys in that case.

A highly favored Dickinson High School eleven, defending champion in Hudson County, was beaten by Union Hill of Union City today before 6,000 spectators, 6 to 0, in the major scholastic upset of the season.

LONDON.-Whatever the final outcome of the movement toward stricter governmental control of Britain's coal-mining industry, the living conditions of the miners continue to improve through the efforts of a private body, the Miners Welfare Committee, representing the miners and their employers.

Another brilliant victory was added to Choate School's enviable string of gridiron conquests today as Captain Charlie Spreyer and his mates swept to a 33-to-0 triumph over Lawrenceville in the sixth annual football meeting between the schools.

THE opening of the National Horse Show last Wednesday was the signal for the launching of the fashion season. Society turned out in glamorous array. From the moment that the brilliant throng began to cross the lobby of Madison Square Garden it was evident that women intend to follow the opulent trend of style this Winter.

Through homemaking courses offered in the New York City vocational high schools, nearly 4,000 girls between 13 and 17 are learning to become expert cooks, waitresses, nursery maids, mother's helpers, cafeteria workers, restaurant hostesses and tea room managers, Miss Isabel A. Ennis, assistant director of continuation schools, declared yesterday.
A knight of the open road with $27,000 in his pocket dug in for the Winter today at the home of a Philadelphia relative.

THIS slender volume with its ironic title, is a tract in parable form. With extreme, almost biblical simplicity, it tells the story of four related tragedies which were incidental to the Mexican Revolution of 1910-20.

Miss Elizabeth Bartlett Elmore, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Elmore of Chile, South America, and a niece of the Rev. Carl Hopkins Elmore of Englewood, was married here today to Harry Edwards of Santiago.

The Maurice and Laura Falk Foundation announced today a grant of $100,000 to the Brookings Institution of Washington, D. C., for a two-year study to determine the effeets of governmental measures and agencies on industry.

Kearny High retained the New Jersey high school cross-country championship today when it captured the annual run of the New Jersey State interscholastic Athletic Association over the modified Warinanco Park course.
Pennsylvania's undefeated freshman football team, led by its elusive quarterback, Frank Reagan, subdued the Columbia freshmen, 26-6, at Baker Field yesterday.

The fourth night of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden was outstanding in point of attendance and the brilliant array of fashion in the boxes. The majority of the boxholders and their guests attended the horse show ball and supper given after the night session in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

A group of debutantes, headed by Miss Sarah Benjamin, is working toward the success of the two-day chrysanthemum luncheon and fashion show to be held Nov. 17 and 18 at the Versailles Restaurant for the benefit of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry.

The annual Armistice Day celebration of the Seventy-seventh Division was held last night at the Hotel Roosevelt. The twentieth anniversary of the establishment of the division at Camp Upton, Yaphank, L. I., was celebrated at the same time.

Catholic University defeated West Virginia Wesleyan's eleven today, 21--0. Nick Sarelas and Joe Guyon carried the ball over for touchdowns in the third period, and in the last few minutes of the game Guyon took the ball thirty-eight yards through tackle for another score, being injured on the play.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Frances Murray, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Murray of Brooklyn, to Francis G. McKee, son of Mrs. James McKee and the late Mr. McKee, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis of Assissi in Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas A. Gately.

More than half a million proud and curious parents are expected to invade New York's classrooms this week in the largest schoolvisiting project in the city's history. It is the seventeenth anniversary of Open School Week and parents are being urged by the United Parents Associations not only to concentrate their gaze upon their own children but to study the organization's three-point program, smaller classes, improved health among children and better recreational centers.

JUST as I sat down at my desk this morning I heard a lovely but ominous sound. Across the fields came the jolt of a cart wheel. It sounded with the sharp clarity of Autumn, every jolt like a muffled shot.

The Boerse was firm today throughout the list, with a relatively good turnover. Heavy industrials, chemicals, electricals and other leaders showed improvement. Shipping shares were comparatively quite; textiles were mixed.

A tremendously powerful Pittsburgh football team kept its 1937 record clean and terminated its series with Notre Dame in glorious fashion today by grinding out a 21-to-6 verdict before a record throng of 56,000 spectators.

The Committee on Immigration has decided to arrange for the early establishment of thousands of families from Norway, Sweden, Denmark, Belgium, Switzerland and other countries in unexplored regions of Southern Chile, principally in Aysen and Magallanes provinces, it was announced.

THE soup and fish stands are functioning smoothly now and a leisurely trip over the circuit is apt to restore the faith of the master of his own collar button in the .theory that quality does not yet have to toss in the towel to quantity, the Broadway on-onon-on-on bargains to the contrary.

THIS excellent and comprehensive survey brings together a vast amount of information on a topic which daily becomes more important. It is a commonplace to say that modern communications make the world smaller; they also make the exchange of news between nations more significant to peoples and governments.

The Author's program at the Book Fair at 2:30 this afternoon will be "An Afternoon of Light Verse", under the chairmanship of William Rose Benet, author of "Rip Tide". The guest speakers will be Arthur Guiterman, author of "Gaily the Troubadour";

THE facts about Arthur Brisbane seem to be that he was an extraordinarily able journalist who worked for money, an editorial writer who was more interested in what he was paid than in the truth of what he wrote.
