THESE are halcyon days for the miniature camera fan. An active fellow in any season, he is indefatigable in the Fall. Football games, theatre openings, night clubs, political rallies, large gatherings of any kind are his happiest hunting grounds.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 7,000 head, including 6,500 direct. Around 400 hogs, averaging 190 to 250 pounds, sold at $9.40-$9.60 a hundredweight; prices steady to 10c lower than Friday's average. Shippers took none; estimated holdover, 500. Compared week ago,
Members of the Ladies Auxiliary of St. Joseph's Church will hold a card party on Friday night at the Garden City Hotel.

Police Lieutenant James Gaffney said that Mayor Thomas P. McCoy and two other Pawtucket, R. I., city officials were taken from a New Haven Railroad train tonight and arrested on charges of breach of the peace.

An aura of mystery overhangs the production of Shakespeare's "Cymbeline," opening at the Embassy Theatre Nov. 16. Although it has been reported that George Bernard Shaw has "rewritten the latter part of the play,"

A contract providing for wage rises averaging 12 per cent and machinery for arbitration was signed yesterday by the Black Diamond Steamship Company and negotiators for the National Maritime Union. Frederick Myers,

Three armed men got away with $1,500 at 6 P. M. yesterday after cowing thirteen employes in th?? Milwood Laundry Service Corn pany, 2,214 Fifty-ninth Street Brooklyn. The thieves missed $500 which several drivers had collected and had not yet turned in.

Miss Courtenay Marshall Cochran, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Cochran of Alexandria, was married to Park Edmund Ticer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund F. Ticer, also of this place, this afternoon in Leeds Church, Fauquier County.

With the award of fourteen university fellowships among the thirtyfive students enrolled, the Division of General Studies, started three years ago in the Yale Graduate School, has progressed from the experimental stage and made a permanent place for itself.

LANDING airplanes with their wheels retracted, as occurred twice recently at Newark Airport, has occasioned some exciting moments for airmen, aground and aloft. A singular case occurred some time ago when L. J. Holoubek, Los Angeles inspector for the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce, was testing a new passenger transport near Burbank, Calif.

George H. Davis, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared today that new taxes to finance continued Federal spending at the rate of $7,500,000,000 to $8,000,000,000 a year would inevitably result in putting new brakes on business progress.

Inventories in the hands of their customers provide the chief basis for granting of credit by manufacturers in the various merchandise fields, as a result of the slower retail trade in recent months, credit executives said here yesterday.

Stubborn defensive play and an alert offense carried the light Hobart College football team to a 12-7 victory today over the University of Buffalo. Hobart scored twice through the air after trailing by 7 points. Led by Dalfonso, Buffalo ripped through the Orange line to the vicinity of the goal line repeatedly, only to be thrust back to midfield.

Commemorating Horace Mann Day, next Tuesday, a pageant written and enacted by students of Horace Mann School, Columbia University, has just been published. Originally intended to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the school's founding, it is dedicated to those leaders of human thought "who fought for freedom and liberty, a society without class distinction, equal opportunities for all in education."
Searching for a Moses for the 1940 campaign, many of the leaders of the Republican party, meeting here to consider rejuvenation plans, are inclined to look upon Thomas E. Dewey as a likely hope.

THE practice of opening radio studios to the lucky few who can command tickets for "seeing" a broadcast is fast becoming as popular in London as in New York. As a result the British Broadcasting Corporation, long the target for criticism from general fault-finders, now finds the entertainment industry itself registering the complaint.

UPON consulting the classical dictionary it appears that "Amphitryon 38," which the Guild and the Lunts brought to town on Monday, is not strictly in accordance with the facts. The scandalous affair between Jupiter and Alkmena preceded her union with Amphitryon.

SILENT until recently in the world of short-wave broadcasting, the city of San Salvador now sends a loud signal northward into the United States. Located in El Salvador, a republic no larger than the State of New Jersey, this new station, with call YSD, is heard clearly on 7.89 megacycles along the Eastern seaboard weekdays, between 8 and 10 P. M.

What, if anything, has been proved by all the efforts of the past eighteen months to maintain at least the fiction of non-intervention in Spain is that no country in Europe just now is prepared to risk a major war on a minor pretext.
WORK by women bulked large in the exhibitions of the last week. Oils, water-colors, pastels, drawings and silhouettes were shown by nine artists, and two group shows opened.
With the dismissal of three patrolmen yesterday, including one for ambulance-chasing, the number of men dropped from the force since Lewis J. Valentine became Commissioner rose to 185.

Unable to halt the sweeping end runs of Sid White and the line bucks of Irv Roth, the Trenton State Teachers College football eleven went down to an 18-to- defeat brought about by Brooklyn College on the windswept hill Wood Lakes gridiron today.
Williams won the Little Three soccer game from Wesleyan today, 4 to 2. Close scored twice for the Purple and Fox and Fraser added goals. Dowds and Hammerstrom tallied for Weslevan.

A program of training and research in industrial relations is in process of formation at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology through the establishment of a special section of the Economics Department devoted to that subject.
The accelerated momentum acquired by the German colonial drive in the past fortnight presages, in the opinion of neutral diplomatic circles here, an early foreign political undertaking by the Reich.

THE recent remark accredited to Mayor La Guardia that the microphone makes sissies of speakers caused one observer to say, "Yes, and think how much famous oratory would have been lost to America if Lincoln had delivered his Gettysburg speech with one eye on the studio clock. And can you picture Patrick Henry

Louisiana State University. is hastening completion of a $3,000,000 building program with an enrollment for the year expected to reach 8,000. The addition this term of eight new buildings, including a "Coliseum" and an imposing law building, will not only relieve congestion of both classroom and dormitory space but provide for recent innovations in the curriculum.

Registration of securities under the Securities Act. of 1933 since Oct. 1 by investment trusts and investment companies reached today a total of $71,048,240 with the filing of a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the National Investors Ccrporation, New York, covering 5,000,000 shares of $1-par-value capital stock for estimated proceeds of $28,750,000.

Nothing so quickly helps to take the curse of "newness" from a new home place as a good-sized tree or two. Yet often the equivalent of the cost for a very nice specimen is expended for other plant material which will make less of a showmaterial that might well be left for later consideration.

The Reading Company has ordered eight oil-electric switching locomotives at an approximate cost of $600,000. The American Locomotive Company will build two of the engines, which will be of 900 horsepower each, and the Electromotive Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, will build the others, of 600 horsepower each.
Hempstead High School's eleven scored its sixth straight victory of the year today by defeating Westbury, 48-7, in a Nassau Conference battle.
After five months of searching in the stony dinosaur bowl of the West, Dr.Barnum Brown has returned to the Museum of Natural History with an eight-ton footprint clue to a "mystery dinosaur,"

New Yorkers will take time out from their regular routine this week to pay tribute to the soldiers of the World War, living and dead, in a series of ceremonies commemorating the nineteenth anniversary of the signing of the armistice.

A series of Saturday afternoon entertainments for children is being sponsored by the Junior Service League of Summit. Robert Sharpe, magiaian, is to appear in the first performance, which will take place Saturday in Summit High School auditorium.

The Radical Socialist party, in the saddle as Parliament is about to open, had a chance to hear what other parties think of the present situation. Last week the Radical Socialists adopted a program so inclusive and yet so indefinite as to mean the continuation of the status quo and of the Popular Front on its present conservative basis.

ALTHOUGH London is the scene of this profoundly moving novel by the author of "We the Accused," the title is symbolic. When the first London settlers built their stout block house above the Thames, for endless miles below them stretched bog and fen. And they on the slight hill were the masters when other settlers began to filter into the land lower down.

Thirtynine colleges, and universities, thirteen more than last year, have granted scholarships to enrollees of the Civilian Conservation' Corps for the current academic year, Herbert W. Oxley, director of CCC camp education, today reported to Robert Fechner, director of the corps.
The Old Guard of the City of New York, oldest veterans' organization in the country, will give its anniversary ball on the night of Jan. 28 in the grand ballroom of the Commodore.
One of the features of this resort's Winter entertainment program, the ice hockey games in the Municipal Convention Hall, will get under way on Nov. 17.
MARYA ZATURENSKA is an extremely skillful poet. Every lyric in "Cold Morning Sky" has a beautiful surface, and this book shows great technical advance over the poet's first book.

Group chairmen representing business, industry, professions and local government units in the 1937 roll-call of the New YorK Chapter of the American Red Cross were announced yesterday by Leon Fraser, general chairman of the drive. The campaign to raise $325,000 for the chapter's yearly activities will open on Thursday and continue to Nov. 25.

The advice of veteran engineers and engineering teachers that the average engineer has been too neglectful of his ability to make himself heard in the world around him is bearing fruit at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

The marriage of Miss Martha Greenleaf Sykes, daughter of James Greenleaf Sykes of this city and the late Mrs. Sykes, who was Miss Anna Wells to David Clendon Hale, also of New York, son of Mrs. David Campbell Hale of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr. Hale, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's father, 580 Park Avenue.

A committee of Internationally known physicians, including one Nobel Prize winner and several professors from the Harvard and Yale Medical Schools, made public yesterday a "medical declaration of independence," subscribed to by 430 outstanding medical men from all parts of the country, advocating a set of principles and proposals which had been overwhelmingly rejected last June by the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, ruling body of organized medicine in America.

Many Nicaraguans doubt the mediation conference to settle the boundary dispute with Honduras will be a success because Honduras contends there is nothing to arbitrate. Honduras contends her boundary was fixed in 1906 by arbitradition in which the King of Spain's decision was accepted by both countries.
Last week (Nov. 2, to be precise), the Museum of Natural History of Springfield, Mass., ceremoniously dedicated its new planetarium-the fifth thus far installed in the United States.
The administration urged the Supreme Court today to reverse previous deciadons and hold that utilities should be valued for rate-making purposes on a "prudent investment" basis.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Winifred Biles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Biles of Hot Springs, Va., and Sommerville, N. J., to Hudson Peck Mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Conklin Mann of Chicago, took place here yesterday in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Harold F. Lemoine performed the ceremony.

The extra-classroom activities committee at Brothers College of Drew University unanimously voted this week to refuse recognition of the newly organized Drew Chapter of the American Student Union, a national organization, now functioning on some 200 school campuses.

Miss Helen Myrtle Kent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Duane Elson Kent of this city, was married to Sanford Stowell Withereli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Leslie Witherell of Shoreham, this afternoon at the Kent home.
The Army-Notre Dame football game next Saturday at the Yankee Stadium will provide a colorful background for one of the largest dances of the Autumn that night in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor

THE first performance of. Robert Schumann's "Lost Concerto" for' violin and orchestra, recently discovered in the. archives of the Berlin State Library, will be heard in a broadcast on Nov. 28 by the Berlin Philharmronic Orchestra, with Wilhelm Kulenkampff as soloist. Centenary's Gents joined the ranks of the gridiron giant killers of 1937 today by upsetting Texas Christian, 10 to 9. A pass from Bynum to Huddleston enabled the latter to sprint 40 yards to a touchdown behind perfect interference in the second quarter.

N. C. State's Wolfpack, out-rushed and out-passed, took advantage of the breaks today to defeat The Citadel, 26 to 14, before 7,000 fans. Intercepted passes paved the way for two State scores and another came after a rolling punt, which Reed bounced against a Citadel back, was downed by the Wolfpack on the Bulldog's 8.
The Swarthmore College eleven was beaten for the fifth time this season when it lost, 20-7, to Johns Hopkins on the Garnet field today.

LAST week B. P. Schulberg made known plans for "Permit to Kill," which will advocate a tightening of the Federal Food and Drug Act. Not to be caught napping, the Warners now announce acquisition of "The Clarion," a Samuel Hopkins Adams novel about newspaper life in a small American city.
The creation of the Richard F. Hoyt Memorial Seaplane Fellowship at the Guggenheim School of Aeronautics of the New York University College of Engineering was announced yesterday.

The world is again tottering on the edge of a great conflict, though not yet healed from the last one, James W. Gerard, wartime Ambassador of the United States to Germany, told the Canadian Club today.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Donaldson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. M. Donaldson of this village, and Harry Hunter Jamieson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry D. Jamieson, also of Sea Cliff, took place this afternoon in St. Luke's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Wilburn C. Campbell, the rector, officiated.

FOR the third time in a royal career without precedent in history, England's eighth Edward is on his way to the United States and once more the world is guessing. Edward has abandoned his brief reign over one-quarter of the human race. But he is still an autocrat over those uncertainties that fascinate the public.

THE "capitulations" stamps from Egypt have been received. As announced in these columns on Oct. 17, they commemorate the signing, some months ago, of -the "Conference de Montreaux" (Conference of Montreaux, Switzerland) treaty

I AM asked to "confess" and sign my name to it. It was this way: Even in the friendly, peaceful hills of Connecticut the far-off rumblings of the wicked world are sometimes faintly heard. A Summer ago private fights were raging in various places on the earth, inviting all who would to come in and do as much killing as they pleased, although no war had been declared.

With three judicial posts recaptured from Democratic Gubernatorial appointees and with almost complete control of county-wide and local government outside of Yonkers retained, Westchester Republicans turned this week to a renewed study of the county charter

Captain George E. T. Eyston today traveled the fastest man has ever gone in an automobile-310.685 miles an hour-but, because of mechanical trouble, again failed to break the world's official land speed record.
Alfred University defeated Clarkson, 12-6, today to finish the season undefeated and untied. The Saxons were paced by Bo Johnson, who was the outstanding player.
The Rutgers 150-pound football team defeated the Lafayette lightweights, 13 to 6, today. Rutgers scored early in the first period and again in the last.

Large East Side apartments having an assessed valuation of more than $100,000,000 are now under the management of Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents, states Leslie H. Moore, vice president of that firm.

Biographies and biographical novels are the most popular recreational reading among Connecticut College students, according to the dormitory library lists recorded in the Palmer Library. Fiction other than biographical is second and poetry third in popular demand.

Duke University's undefeated football team ran roughshod over Wake Forest today, rolling up a 67-0 count. It was the biggest score Duke has made since Wallace Wade began coaching here in 1931.
Before an Old Timers' Day crowd of 2,500 the Ursinus Bears went down to defeat today at the hands of Coach Alan Holman's Franklin and Marshall Diplomats, 7--0.

Season-long bloom in the shaded garden begins with the snowdrop in February and completes the cycle with the Christmas Rose which comes into flower before the holidays and often continues until the snowdrop appears. Gardeners with shaded plots need not waste energy in trying-to raise roses and other sun lovers. By planting suitable species now lovely effects next season can be assured.
Miss Sophia Han of the Univerity of Peiping will speak on Chitese art at the first in a series of ectures to be given by the Decorators Club at the Cosmopolitan Club tomorrow evening.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Maybelle Anderson, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Svening L. Anderson of New Britain, Conn, to Francis Wright Clinton, son of Mrs. Francis W. Clinton of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Clinton, took place yesterday morning in the First Presbyterian Church of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Phillips Elliott.

Mrs. Ogden Hammond Jr. heads the dance committee and Miss Mary Weeks the debutante committee for the annual naval ball of the Association of Former Russian Imperial Naval Officers, which will take place on Nov. 18 on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

When the prices of beef and other meats skyrocketed to a point in excess of prices since the World War, when bread prices reached a level they had not attained in two years, adding $50,000,000 a year to the consumer's food bill, and when dairy products rose 14.5 per cent in a two-year period, the great American housewife began to make heard her protests against the rising cost of living.

The annual meeting of the Child Study Association of America will be held on Nov. 15, at 8:15 P. M. at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street. Dr. Robert S. Lynd and Helen M. Lynd, authors of "Middletown," and "Middletown In Transition," will be the guests of honor.

Students on campuses in all parts of the country this week are planning to give their annual Armistice Day mass meetings a practical turn by discussion of, and in some cases by resolution on, the part America should play in the situation created by the wars in Spain and China.

Robert P. Goldman of Cincinnati, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, was guest of honor last night at a dinner reception at the Hotel Pierre at which clergymen and laymen discussed problems confronting the Jews and the possible contributions of organied Reform Judaism to their solution.
Miss Geraldine Elizabeth Bennett, daughter of Walter H. Bennett of Montclair, was married this evening to Richard Edward Boschen, son of Otto Boschen, also of Montclair. The ceremony, which took

The availability of Federal Social Security funds has made it possible to couple an increase of 90 per cent in the number of persons receiving old-age relief in this city with an actual saving in cost to local taxpayers, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, reported yesterday.

Noses bled and eyes were blackened in a 30-minute general melee among spectators today, after Colorado University defeated the University of Utah eleven, 17 to 7. About half the 20,000 spectators surged onto the gridiron when Colorado students attempted to tear down the Utah goal posts. The other half stayed in the grandstand and cheered.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Seward Bader Jackson of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gwen Bader Jackson, to Benjamin Ackley Rowe, son of Mrs. Benjamin Ackley Rowe of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mr. Rowe.

A POLITICAL miracle happened in New York last week. For forty years Fusion groups have been trying to beat Tammany in two successive elections. They have always failed, but last Tuesday they succeeded, with Fiorello La Guardia as the spearhead of the attack. The result is that the Mayor has four more years in which to carry on his battle for efficient government.

Ben Ames, former European correspondent, will speak on his reent tour of Europe in a talk before the Jamaica Women's Club on Wednesday at 2:15 P. M. in the Y. M. C. A. His subject will be The People Under the Dictators."
Oregon State College defeated Willamette University, 20 to 0, today in a non-conference football game. Oregon State scored once in the first period and twice in the closing quarter.

The new Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, for which a campaign is in progress to raise $230,000 to erect the edifice at York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, in the heart of a growing medical and residential center, will be open twenty-four hours a day to allow doctors, nurses and scientists to worship.

Karl E. Prickett has been elected vice president and treasurer of the Vick Chemical Company. He first jointed the company in 1925 as assistant treaurer, became secretary and treasurer in the following year, and was vice president in charge of finance in 1928.

Princeton University, in keeping with its policy of attracting to the campus an enrollment representative of all sections of the country, admitted twenty-nine members of the freshman class this Fall without entrance examinations, it was announced today by Professor Radcliffe Heermance.
Worcester Tech today defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute on the gridiron, 14-0.

An inspired University of Washington team exploded the myth of the University of California's football invincibility today by holding the Golden Bears to a scoreless tie, an upset unequaled in the Far West this year.

Two nervous novices who escaped with more than $14.000 in jewels and $385 in cash last night were being sought today by local police and forces in near-by territory. The police had good descriptions of the two men.

Except in instances where special promotions were staged, retail trade lost ground last week, and slight declines in volume from the corresponding 1936 period developed in several districts. The South found sales slower but still well ahead of a year ago.

SYDNEY, Australia.-Australia's new industrial boom, spurred by the Empire's rearmament, finds the Commonwealth facing a shortage of skilled labor in spite of the large number of unemployed.

The Ironbound Manufacturers Association of Newark points out that the total of industrial construction in Newark in 1936, according to the Newark Building Department, numbered 216 buildings, valued at $4,506,765. During the same period residential construction consisted of sixty-three units, aggregating a cost of $710,050.

In a standardized English aptitude test 246 freshman students in Queens College composition classes averaged 103.6 points out of a possible 160 points, compared with an average of 88 made by students who took the test in nineteen States, it was disclosed yesterday.
Some sixty persons quietly filed out of the New Yorker Theatre, 523 Eigth Avenue, near Thirty-sixth Street, at 8 o'clock last night when fire started in a room adjoining the projection booth.

Navy's football team, encountering much firmer opposition than it expected, defeated a hard-fighting Columbia eleven today. Battering their way through the line for a touchdown in the first period, and profiting by an-intercepted forward pass in the fourth, the Middies sucneeded in downing their game New York rivals by the score of 13 to 6.

Members of the board of managers of the Bethany Day Nursery will give a reception tomorrow afternoon at the headquarters of the nursery, 402 East Sixty-seventh Street, to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the organization.

Miss Lydie Hopkins Kuykendall, daughter of Mrs. Mary Waller Kuykendall, was married to Emanuel G. Farley of Atlanta at noon today in the home of her mother in Martinsville by the Rev. P. Manning Hank of Richmond.

Leading all the way of the mile and a sixteenth, Nedayr today won the $33,140 Pimlico Futurity and assured Willis Sharpe Kilmer, owner-breeder, of a fine prospect for 3-year-old honors, as this event annually is regarded as an index to staying qualities in a thoroughbred.

Leaders in society and artistic circles, as well as others prominent in diplomatic and civic affairs, have formed a distinguished list of patrons and patronesses for the golden-jubilee concert of Josef Hofmann on Nov. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House. This event, celebrating
Washington and Lee's Generals, defeated in their last four games, came back before a Homecoming Day crowd of about 8,000 today and downed the University of Virginia eleven by 13-6.

John Bossi, 25 years old, of 21 Park Row admitted stealing the uniform coat of a policeman when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Michael Ford in the Felony Court. "A very, very foolish bit of thievery," commented Magistrate Ford as he held Bossi in $500 bail for Special Sessions.

FOR several weeks the Carnegie International has been open to the public. Thousands of people have milled through the Pittsburgh galleries, intent upon one thing. They have wanted to see the "monstrous" prize winner, Georges Braque's "The Yellow Cloth," and to heap upon it added ridicule and insult.

Potatoes, milk and dairy products should be included among the basic agricultural products in any Federal system of production control, farmers of the Northeastern States told a subcommittee of the Senate Agriculture Committee at a hearing yesterday in the State Office Building.

Nathan Straus, recently appointed by President Roosevelt as administrator of the United States Housing Authority created by Congress in the passing of the Wagner-Steagall bill, will be a speaker at the homebuilding conference to be held in Washington, D. C., Nov. 17 and 18 under the auspices of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Alderman Sir Harry Edward Augustus Twyford, framework-knitter, becomes London's 615th Lord Mayor on Tuesday when the traditional show which forms part of his procession from the Guildhall to the Law Courts to be sworn in by the Lord Chief Justice again will block London's narrow streets and stop the business of the city for a whole morning.
Led by Gus Rook and Jimmy Donnolly, Northeastern University defeated Springfield College, 12 to 6, before 3,000 persons today.

THE Armistice site memorial in the forest of Compiegne in France is at last complete. Wellesley students are engaged this year in building up in each dormitory a library for reference and recrational reading as a convenience to themselves and a heritage for future generations.

Miss Marjorie Elizabeth Campbell, daughter of Mrs. Alexander Carlyle Campbell of 363 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Campbell, has chosen Nov. 19 as the date for her marriage to Robert Lethbridge Foshay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Addison Youngs Foshay, also of Brooklyn.

Teachers should have the courage to tell their students the truth behind the economic causes of depressions and not hide the fact that "mass poverty" still exists in this country, Aubrey Williams, director of the National Youth Administration. declared yesterday.

WHEN the Eudora first began running from New York to Fall River, they harnessed oxen to the ship to back her around the dock. But that was a couple of years before the old Fall River Line really came into existence.

The grand jury recommended "prompt disciplinary punishment" today for officers responsible for "inhuman conduct" in holding W. Vance Harrell incommunicado while he sought to deliver medicine to his dying son, but Police Chief H. Leslie Quigg said that no such action was planned.
The number of government employes and the amount of the payroll as well declined slightly in September from the August levels, the Civil Service Commission reported today.

The fourteenth game of the match for the chess championship of the world between Dr. Max Euwe and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris was started tonight with the latter conducting the white pieces.

WEEKS such as the one just experienced do not occur with great frequency. "It's a fine thing for the art world, all this stir and excitement," observed a prominent picture impresario. And that, of course, cannot be denied. But it is also true that such a week among the galleries of New York can make reviewers long with a swift and terrible longing for next Summer.
The Amherst eleven routed Trinity Colege, 20-0, on Pratt Field today for ts fifth straight victory. The Sabina eleven made 23 first downs to for the visitors.

The Wesleyan football team dropped to the cellar in the Little Three today when Williams administered a stinging 19-to-0 defeat in the presence of twenty-eight former Cardinal captains here as special guests of the university.

COMPARATIVELY few actions be were taken against commercial sponsors on the air during the .fiscal-year ended June 30 last, the Federal Trade Commission disclosed during the past week in its annual report.

THE far-off hills of Hollywood may have a green and substantial look to many an aspiring actor, but with Fredric March it has been different. With sixty-nine lectures dealing with contemporary problems in international relations, literature, society, culture and personality constituting the program for 1937-38, Cooper Union's free public forum will open tonight its forty-first year.

A new system of honors study is on trial for a year in several departments at Wells College in the expectation that the benefits of ths type of studying may be offered to a larger number of students than are now attracted.

TODAY the Soviet Union celebrates its twentieth anniversary with particular emphasis on its aviation records as symbolic of the country's attainments in numerous industrial fields. While much credit is given Russian airmen, news from the Soviet indicates that credit is shared by steel and other basic industries which contributed to the country's aerial leadership.

When adolescents stop shooting up like beanpoles their parents and teachers hope that their mental growth not only will continue but will be accelerated.

After a twohour debate the Nine-Power Treaty Conference adopted today the text of a message to Japan, inviting her to exchange views regarding her conflict with China with "a small number of powers to be chosen for that purpose." Then it adjourned until Tuesday to await a reply.

Eugene List, 18-year-old Americaa pianist, whose gifts won recognition from public and press in two previous Town Hall recitals, was heard there again yesterday afternoon. The sum impression of his performances was that of regular and healthy development of a talent that is in process of transition from youth to manhood.

MANHATTAN ANDERSON. ALBERT J. (Oct. 20). Estate, more than S10,000. To Sidney W. Anderson, son, executor, Hotel McAlpin, Broadway and 34th Street, residue. FALTIN, MARIE (Oct 10). Estate, $11.919. To Aloisie Benesh, daughter, executrix. 411 E. 81st St.. residue; Charles Faltin, son. 314 E. 73d St.: Julia Faltin, same address; Charles Michalek, 402 E. 73d St.. 1,000.

A reviving interest in public affairs, shown last week in committee meetings at the Y. W. C. A., has resulted in plans for three rallies in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, at which State leaders and delegates will discuss methods of forming study groups and plotting procedure for action on a variety of topics, ranging from birth control to a Japanese boycott.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Caroline Candee, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Nehemiah Candee of this city, to Frederick Fuller Mack, son of Mrs. Frank E. Mack of Washington, D. C., took place here this afternoon in the First Congregational Church on the Green. The Rev.
The Flying Dutchmen of Lebanon Valley College today scored another 3-to-0 victory, achieved over Upsala College, and due to the place-kicking prowess of Tony Rozman, rangy halfback.

Miss Eleanor Reba Wilkisson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wilkisson of Maplewood, N. J., was married here yesterday at noon in the chantry of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church to John Page Stiger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Hilliard Stiger of South Orange. The ceremony was performed by the assistant rector, the Rev. E. Felix Kloman.

A plan to put the Labor Department in control of the wages and hours of workers whose product goes into interstate commerce appeared today to be gaining favor in the House Labor Committee. That was the view of Chairman Norton, who made a brief visit to the capital. She said that both committee members and

A program designed to attract new industries to Middlesex County, N. J., drawn up by the Freeholders of that county, has resulted in the creation of an industrial commission at New Brunswick under the direction of T. A. Haish.

THE interior of an automobile should be in keeping with the modern living room, where the user can relax, and operating a car should prove just as comfortable and enjoyable as sitting in an easy chair at home, stated John Oswald, chief body engineer of the Olds Motor Works,

A card party to assist the Hudson Avenue Boys Club of Brooklyn will he held the afternoon of Nov. 19 at the Towers in Brooklyn. Mrs. Leigh J. Sessions and Mrs. Andrew L. Adams head the benefit committee. Serving with them are Mrs. Burt Foss Nichols, Mrs. George P. Kennedy, Mrs. Walter E. Divine, Mrs. William P. Radkay and Mrs. Henry H. Hamilton.

Federal spending for welfare purposes is in direct conflict with the principles of our Constitution, T. Jefferson Coolidge, vice president of the First National Bank of Boston and formerly Under-Secretary of the Treasury, said here today to the Investment Bankers Association of America.
A strong, fast Kiskiminetas Springs school eleven today defeated Mercersburg Academy, 6-0. Left Halfback Rogan raced 53 yards in the third period for the only score of the game.

Ar event of many years' standing is the annual Armistice Ball of the British Great War Veterans of America, which will take place Armistice night, Thursday, in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

John Tierney of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn led home a field of ninety-nine harriers yesterday morning to win the annual Athletic Association of Private Schools championship at Van Cortlandt Park.

THERE is a clause in Gregory Ratoff's contract which may soon lead to his becoming a producer. And that will round things out rather nicely, for at present he is connected with the movies only as an actor, a writer (he wrote "Cafe Metropole," "You Cah't Have Everything" and "Shanghai Deadline") and a director (he just completed his first picture in that capacity, "Lancer Spy").
Mr. and Mrs. James E. Gray of 110 Cambridge Place, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Happy Gray, to Robert Landy Burger, son of Mrs. Maurice Loer of Cincinnati, Ohio.

An anthology of the poetry written during the past eighteen years by Holy Cross students will be published early in December by The Purple, the literary monthly of Holy Cross College. The anthology will contain 150 verses selected from the pages of The Purple.

The collection of European arms and armor formed by the late Theodore Offerman will be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Thursday and Friday afternoons, On Saturday afternoon the same galleries will sell Gothic and Renaissance art from the collection of Mrs. Theodore Offerman.
De Paul University, behind a potent running attack and an alert defense against forward passes, today routed Wichita University's favored eleven, 31 to 7.

A minimum wage for single women to provide not only the bare necessities of life but to cover "a fair and decent" standard of living, which will insure "emotional peace," will be. estimated on the basis of answers to a questionnaire which is being circulated by the Consumers' League of New York.

It has been one of the more modest claims of a favorite clairvoyant that she can reveal what goes on within any four walls while it is happening. Accordingly in shameless disregard of several sets of ethics, on the pretext that it was an obligation he owed to the reporting of contemporary history, this correspondent repaired at 2:30 o'clock Thursday afternoon of last week to the mystic Harlem headquarters of Madam Tussaud.

The Chrysanthemum Society of America will hold a chrysanthemum show at the Netherland Plaza Hotel in Cincinnati, Ohio, in connection with the annual meeting Friday through Sunday. ... On Monday at 3 P. M. the Flushing (L. I.) Garden Club will hold election of directors and a flower tournament at the House of the Weeping Beech.

Kansas, the expected soft spot for Nebraska, turned out today to be just soft enough to mire the Cornhuskers in a 13-13 tie and put a sharp crimp in their plans for a third consecutive Big Six football championship. A crowd of 34,000 saw the game.

JUST when wage and salary earners are obtaining shorter working sessions, bankers, who long have had a limited workday. are asked to give it up and keep their doors open all day. Independent lending concerns, it was said at the recent convention of Kentucky bankers, are getting a lot of business after the sacred closing time of 3 P. M.
The French colony in this city will celebrate the anniversary of the Armistice with a Fete de l'Armistice Wednesday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Raymond R. Beatty has been reelected chairman of the property management of the division of the Westchester County Realty Board, with John Marbach as vice chairman; Edward H. Hufnagel, treasurer, and Harry D. Cole, secretary.

Prominent bankers, economists and educators will join with Columbia University officials this year in conducting a banking seminar organized in the Columbia School of Business by Dr. Benjamin H. Beckhart, Associate Professor of Banking and co-author of "The New York Money Market," it was announced yesterday.

Publishers of Wilkes-Barre's four newspapers charged today that the strike of the American Newspaper Guild at the plant of The WilkesBarre Record was the start of a campaign by the C. I. O. to control the press of the-United States.

The Swiss Federal Council issued a statement today denying that there had been "the slightest conversation between the Swiss and French general staffs" since 1917. The statement was in reply to an interpellation caused by suspicions recently expressed by a German military review.

Miss Nancy J. McGee, daughter of Mrs. Mildred Case McGee of Santa Monica, Calif., was married to Ensign M. Ramon Peppard, U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus R. Peppard of this city, here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament by the Rev. James P. Kelly, the rector.

A narrative of events from the death of George V to the accession of George VI. HER MAJESTY THE QUEEN. By Lady Cynthia Asquith 8vo. New York: E. P. Dutton Co. $3. A biography.

The conevening here late this week the Social Security advisory Council, to study suggestions for amending the Social Security Act at the next regular session of Congress,- threw into sharp focus a growing controversy over the financing of this ambitious program of the Roosevelt Administration.
Backed by a $20,000 investment of public funds, a group medical service and health protection plan became available this week to 2,000 employes in Washington of the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

Expressing satisfaction with the results-of his eleven-day visit here, Dr. Halvdan Koht, Norway's Minister of Foreign Affairs, indicated yesterday that the way had been paved for a new trade agreement between his country and the United States.

The College of William and Mary defeated Hampden-Sydney on the gridiron today, 21-12. The winners pushed across touchdowns in the first, second and fourth periods.

A CONNOISSEUR and collector of old masters. Mr. Tarkington has a fund of personal experience in the art world which must have made the writing of this novel. treating so largely of dealer wiles and collector vagaries, an undertaking of special relish.

Faced by a possibility of a drop into second place of the Eastern Division of the National Football League if they lose, the New York Giants will fire away at the Pirates with both barrels at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, starting at 2:15, a quarter of an hour earlier than in the past.
New York Hippodrome Opera Company yesterday presented "Madama Butterfly" in the evening and "La Traviata" in the afternoon. Good-sized houses attended both.

Washington Irvlng High topped Bronxville, 12-7, today as Pat Cancro scored twice. He tallied by lugging the opening kick-off back70 yards, then took a 30-yard aerial from Taxter. Charles Brickley made Bronxville's tally after a 55-yard march.

The General Dealers Corporation and Presser Lubin, both of 120 Broadway, New York City, have withdrawn their registrations as brokers or dealers in the over-thecounter markets, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

THIS informative addition to philately's expanding book shelf is based on the wisdom and experience of thirty-two recognized authorities on major and sideline phases of the hobby of which President Roosevelt is America's No. 1 exponent.

Morris Moscovitz of 577 East Ninety-first Street, Brooklyn, assistant manager of the Stuyvesant Heights division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in Brooklyn; died yesterday noon at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center at the age of 55.

Austrian social and hunting circles are indignant because two of the leading hunting organizations-the fashionable Austrian Hunting Club and the Green Cross Association-were not invited to participate in the Berlin International Hunting Exposition.

American labor will extend "a most sincere and hearty" welcome to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor at any time they may visit the United States, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, announced today.

Undefeated but tied Holy Cross conquered a fast Colgate football team, 12 to.7, before 22,000 spectators at Fitton Field today. It was the Red Raiders' fifth straight setback against major opposition.

Dr. Alexander Hamilton Rice has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the French Institute in the United States. Dr. W. Francklyn Paris, founder of the institute. was elected first vice chairman; Ormond V. Gould, second vice chairman; Albert L. Hoffman, third vice chairman; Lawrence L. Gillespie, secretary general, and William R. Britton, treasurer.

In a symposium on biophysics arranged by the American Institute of Physics and held last week at Philadelphia Pa., Dr. W. M. Stanley of the Rockefeller Institute's Princeton (N. J.) station delivered a notable address which brought our knowledge of the disease-producing viruses up to date.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 25 appears an editorial "Subsidized Medicine," purporting to discuss an editorial in a recent issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association which discussed the report of the American

Evidence that living plants contain a mysterious and as yet unisolated substance which plays the major role in harnessing the energy of sunlight for the creation of living plant substances out of carbon dioxide and water was presented at the closing session of the symposium on biophysics at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine today.

Election from a country district is the best assurance for a long Congressional career, the National Resources Committee reveals in a recent report. In both the House and Senate, rural Congressmen, on the average, have longer tenure than their city colleagues.

Captain Frederick R. Naile, retired navy officer, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 57. Born at Norristown, he was appointed to the Naval Academy in 1896 and upon his graduation was sent to Asiatic waters, where he remained on duty until 1905.

" Grand Vizier of the Loose Ends" is James Roosevelt's new nickname in Washington's select tag-bestowing circles. Like a good many other Washington wisecracks, it celebrates an executive arrangement. The "loose ends" are the eighteen independent government agencies which the President's 29-year-old son began to deal with this week as a liaison officer for the Chief Executive.
A savings club plan to finance out of weekly savings the trips of prospective visitors to the New York World's Fair in 1939, has been devised, and banks in twenty-one States have made inquiries,

Orders received in the New York wholesale market diminished last week as retailers continued to consolidate their stocks, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.
Mr. and Mrs. William J. Clothier gave a tea this afternoon for the officers of the Pickering hunt race meet.

These words, minutely inscribed on a letter which an American postman on horseback is delivering to a group of Puerto Ricans, appear on a mural painting in the Postoffice Building in Washington, embellishing a corridor near the office of Postmaster General James A. Farley.

Connecticut, which prides itself on being conservative and is rather proud of the designation as "the land of steady habits," is coming to accept as a lasting institution a Socialist Mayor of Bridgeport, its third largest city.

New housing was provided for more individuals last year in New York City than in any other of the fifty principal American cities, according to a nation-wide survey covering 310 large communities made by Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis.

BRUSSELS.-On the battlefield at Ypres stands an English school whose 100 British pupils have never seen Great Britain. The Ecole Britannique de Ypres was erected in 1929 by Eton College, as a memorial to 1,020 Etonians who died in the World War.

IN the "Book of General Laws," published at Cambridge, Mass., in 1673, the first book to contain Connecticut laws, one finds records of some interesting colonial customs. Among other things, each of the twenty-four towns had a letter of the alphabet for branding all its horses.
Legitimate world production and consumption of narcotics is increasing, according to the final figures for 1936, the Permanent Control Opium Board made public here.

Frank P. Graves, education commissioner, today sustained the New York City Board of Education in refusing to reinstate Ella K. Bricker, who resigned as a high school clerical assistant.

Undefeated Villanova's goal line was crossed for the first time this season as it swamped Marquette, 25 to 7, in an intersectional game today- before 10,000 at Shibe Park. Villanova marched 68 yards to a touchdown as soon as it gained possession of the ball on its own 32, a short. forward, Howlett to Earle, bringing the score.
It rained goals tonight, a little harder for Toronto than for the Americans and the Maple Leafs defeated the New Yorkers, 6-3, in a wide-open National Hockey League game before 10,000.

AS the calendar reckons, Maude Adams will be 65 years old next Thursday. But here in the fitful Missouri sunshine it is quite clear that, like her ageless alter ego. Peter Pan, whom a generation ago she first impersonated on the American stage. she has outwitted the years.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marcille Littlefield, daughter of Mrs. Mildred F. Littlefield of 155 Riverside Drive, and of George Homer Littlefield, also of this city, to Richard Servis Petty, son of Mrs. Robert Davison Petty of New York and the late Professor Petty, former dean of the New York Law School.

General liquidation was under way in the grain markets today and, with numerous stop-loss orders uncovered, all deliveries of wheat and rye and December corn dropped to new low levels for the season, with wheat and rye reaching the lowest levels touched by any future since the middle of June, 1936.

Delegates from hundreds of women's clubs will gather in Albany tomorrow to hear outstanding speakers discourse on youth and crime, the problems of industry, and the social significance of the motion picture, at the forty-third annual convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs.

Scoring in every period but the first, Arnold College of New Haven, Conn., defeated Wagner College yesterday, 26 to 7, in Wagner's last appearance on the gridiron this season at Grymes Hill, Staten Island. It was "home-coming day" for Wagner and a celebration appeared in order as the local eleven hopped off to a 7-0 lead in the first period.

The Hafdin-Simmons cowboys of Abilene scored more than a minutes point a minute today to keep unblemished their undefeated and untied record as they swamped the Emporia State Teachers of Kansas, 66 to 6.

Stopping the vaunted Port Chester aerial attack and at the same time showing a surprising running attack, the A. B. Davis High School chalked up its fourth consecutive Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association triumph before 3,000 fans today to continue the unbeaten league leader. The score was 20 to 7.

The Fine Arts department of the College of William and Mary will present the second of the series of ten foreign films tomorrow afternoon at the Williamsburg Theatre. This program will be "The Moving Camera" consisting of two films, "Hamlet" and "The Last Laugh".

The Supreme Court here has overruled a lower court verdict convicting Theodor Fischer and Silvio Schnell for distributing the antiSemitic book "Protocols of the Elders of Zion" on the ground that it violated a law against immoral publications.

Miss Fannie E. Fellows, daughter of George Leslie Fellows of East Orange and the late Mrs. Fellows, was married this afternoon to Arthur Philip Henricks Jr., also of East Orange, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Henricks.
Though it is necessary to guard against exaggerating the immediate danger from native unrest in French Morocco, it would be easy to underestimate the significance of the manifestations of discontent.

Loehr of Yonkers head the list of patrons and patronesses for the dinner and dance to be given on Thanksgiving Eve at the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind.

LAST week President Roosevelt pressed the gold telegraph key that formally opened the Mount Whitney-Death Valley Highway in California-- highway that is still another link in the long line of motorways through the country's Western parks and public resarves.

In a report dealing almost exclusively with a discussion of the Federal Government's activities in the power business, the public service securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America declared today that government-subsidized competition to private power companies was virtually "killing" the private utility business.

The cast was given distinction by the appearance of Yvette Gilbert, the great French disease, as one of the trulls. Meyrowitz conducted and Francesco von Mendelssohn was the stage director. In the cast were Renee Saint-Cyr, Suzy Solidor, Raymond Rouleau, Rene Bergeron, Raymond Cordy and others.

Title to the 150-year-old Dunbar estate in Framingham passed today to James Roosevelt, son and secretary of the President. The homestead, comprising 100 acres of property, contains fourteen rooms, a stable, a dairy and a fourcar garage. A caretaker's house is also located on the land.
In a double wedding ceremony, Miss Mary Andrews and Miss Dorothy Fox were married this evening in the First Presbyterian Church, Penn Yan.

Proving beyond the shadow of a doubt that he has outclassed the schoolboy harriers just as he had established his supremacy on the cinder and board tracks, Leslie MacMitchell of George Washington High School won the twenty-eighth annual city P. S. A. L. cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.
Balls for bearings vary in diameter from a quarter of an inch to five feet. Scientists have to run some very fast machines in jewel bearings because they can't get balls small enough.

Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, said today that the United States could no more escape the consequences of another great war "than a carefully barricaded householder in the path of a cyclone" could escape the storm.

The verbal orders of the Commanding General, directing the travel of Capt. Terence J. Smith, Engr. Res., on temporary duty from Governors Island, N. Y., to CCC Camp SP-52, Peekskill, N. Y., on or about Oct. 26, 1937, and return to his proper station, Governors Island, N. Y., upon completion of such temporary duty, are confirmed and made of record.
Thomas E. Dewey, newly elected District Attorney, sailed yesterday on the Monarch of Bermuda for a two-week vacation in Bermuda. He plans to return Nov. 19.

Mounting ties by industrial wages are luring cityward the workers who "went back to the opened. farm" during the depression, F. A. Harper, a member of the Cornell University Department of Agricultural Economics declared today.

Maine and Illinois will join tomorrow in honoring Elijah Parish Lovejoy, martyr for the freedom of the press, on the centenary of his death. Simultaneously in the towns of his birth and death, commemorative exercises will take place.

Three Roosevelt measures urged for passage in the coming special session of Congress were condemned today by Representative James W. Wadsworth of Livingston County. Speaking before the Rochester City Club, Mr. Wadsworth assailed the President's proposed Wages Hours Law, Executive Department reorganization and crop control "steps toward dictatorship."

A new course in religious education, open to upper classmen at Pennsylvania College for Women, has been elected by more than 20 per cent of the student body. This seems significant, since the required course in religion which had been given for many years had come to be resented by the students,

There seem to be almost as many schools of thought concerning the New York black bear as there are bears, and we have known brothers to take opposite sides on the argument. In the first place, there are hardly enough black bears in this State to go around, although every deer hunter who takes out a license cherishes a hope that he will sight one within range.

Invitations have been sent out for the marriage of Miss Natalie Clemens, daughter of Mrs. James C. Clemens of West Hartford, Conn., to George M. Burbach Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Burbach of St. Louis, which will take place here on the afternoon of Nov. 25 in the Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

The Trade Research Institute perceives signs of a reversal in the trend of the Reich's foreign commerce. Whereas the first three years of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's four-year plan witnessed a shrinkage of export surpluses with Europe and import surpluses with overseas, the new tendency is toward a renewed increase of both.

A "China Emergency Relief Fund," designed to care for homeless and impoverished church members and refugees, provide hospital care for sick and injured and to facilitate removal of missionary mothers and children to places of safety, will be raised on a nationwide basis by the Methodist Episcopal churches and their members, according to an announcement yesterday.
During most of the past week stocks went lower; the decline in the averages reached 8 points on Thursday; recovery of about 4 points occurred next day, all of it lost on Saturday.

IMPERIAL CITY, by Elmer Rice (Coward-McCann, $3). A novel laid in. New York City, You HAVE SEEN THEIR FACES, by Erskine Caldwell and Margaret Bourke - White (Viking, $5). Word and picture account of share-cropping in the South.

William C. Hope, who retired in 1928 as passenger traffic manager of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, died today of a heart attack on board a Southbound train nearing Jacksonville, Fla., according to word received at his home here. He was 78 years old.

The Original Celtics staged a strong rally in the closing minutes to vanquish the Kingston Colonials, 31-29, last night at the Hippodrome for their second victory in as many American Basketball League games. Trailing, 28-27, with two minutes remaining, the Celtics clinched victory as Pete Berenson tossed in a field goal and converted a foul.

Drastic curtailment in rayon fabric production continues, with the reduction in operations ranging from 55 to 93 per cent under the peak this year, according to the results of a survey of loom activity for the week ended Oct.

The special Fall exhibition of the Greenwich Society of Artists opened with a preview and tea at the art gallery of the Greenwich library this afternoon. It will be continued daily and Sundays through Nov. 21.

At the end of a trip of more than 6,000 miles by boat, train and ambulance, much of the time on a stretcher, Miss Katherine M. Talmage, a missionary in China for sixty-three years, arrived at the North Country Community Hospital here this morning, still rebellious at having had to leave the place she called home.

Holiday goods in accessories and house furnishings held the center of interest in the New York wholesale market last week. Initial orders were placed on dresses for under-coat and cruise wear. Sport coats moved well. Weakening in prices was noted in coats, furs,

ALTERMAN-Louis L., beloved husband of Rebecca, father of Montague T., Miriam Zerner, Janet and Daniel, brother of Samuel, Herman, Lewis B. and J. Jay, on Nov. 7, 1937. Funeral Tuesday, Nov. 9, at 2 P. M. from Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St., Manhattan. Interment Mount Neboh Cemetery.

The New York women's field hockey team gave its best performance of the season in winning a hard-fought game from Manhattanville College, 4-0, at Prospect Park yesterday. Both teams displayed a strong attack. Although Manhattanville had many opportunities to score, its forward line never seemed able to overcome the winners' defense.

Unquestionably a battle over primary economic principles is raging behind the scenes in Germany. The crisis over Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics, was the result, rather than the cause, of this battle.
Six firemen were injured early today in subduing a blaze of undetermined origin which damaged the Third Presbyterian Church and several near-by business buildings.
The authors' program at the Book Fair at 2:30 this afternoon will be under the chairmanship of Clarence Budington Kelland, author of "Spotlight."

One of the first wooden crosses planted today in the Armistice Day Field of Remembrance adjoining Westminster Abbey was that inscribed "On behalf of H.R.H. Duke of Windsor in Memory of Fallen Comrades."

A 790-foot pedestrian bridge to connect Manhattan at 103d Street with Wards Island, which is to be developed as a city park, is the latest innovation, submitted to the Board of Estimate and Mayor La Guardia by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Discrimination on account of age "has become a menace and terror to thousands of family breadwinners" when they reach the age of 45 or 50, Secretary Perkins said to night in a speech before the Bridgeport Sunday Evening Community Forum.

Mr. and Mrs. Aymar Johnson will give a dinner dance Nov. 25 in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for their niece, Miss Marie Hamilton Russell, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hamilton Russell.

Now that (for most of them) the angling season is over, the New York Athletic Club Anglers have decided that the time has come for reminiscence on the good or bad luck they have had. So, in order to do it en masse, they have set the date for their annual dinner-the 17th.

Players and singers who once graced the American stage, the memory of whom has faded like the printed programs bearing their names, received a memorial yesterday, a marble monument erected on the plot of the Catholic Actors Guild in Calvary Cemetery, Queens, where they lie buried.
George W. Alger, chairman of the board of directors of the Henry Street Settlement, announced yesterday the election of John M. Schiff as president of the organization. He succeeds Miss Lillian D.

The socalled "youth problem" springs from the enforced idleness of many young people and the chief method of solving the situation lies in educational, recreational and vocational training, according to the introductory sections of a 138-page book entitled, "Youth, a World Problem," published today by the National Youth Administration.

Five Japanese and one British ship passed through the Panama Canal last week bound for Japan with 40,000 tons of scrap iron, pig iron, steel, copper, aluminum, tin plate, cotton and automobile machinery.
Isadore B. Geller, operator, sold the four-story apartment house for forty-two families on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 1,250-60 Leland Avenue, adjoining the corner of Westchester Avenue. the Bronx.

Sailing before a fifteen-mile breeze, Frank Campbell's Felix tallied 119 points to outscore eight others and gain top honors at another of the series of dingby races held by the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Ordeal, owned and skippered by Howard Michael, was second with 109 markers.

Splendid exhibitions by a majority of the unbeaten teams marked scholastic football contests of the past week-end. With few exceptions the Eastern prep school powers will wind up their schedules this week. For four successive days, starting on Wednesday, there will be traditional games of front-rank importance.

With the signing of Herbert Marshall for the role of the despondent musician who is rejuvenated by Deanna Durbin, Universal began casting "Mad About Music" this week-end with an aim toward making it one of the more formidable offerings of the season.
An official roster disclosed today that Germans who have died in Spain will be honored for the first time in the annual list of Nazi party members who "have died for the cause."

Resolutions condemning the Administration's foreign policy as a "catspaw of Britain's selfish purposes" and charging that a "virtual alliance" has been made with England were adopted at the final session of the eighteenth national convention of the American Association for the Recognition of the Irish Republic yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Three hundred delegates from fifteen States were present.

Dr. John R. Kirk, president emeritus of the Northeast Missouri State Teachers College here and a former State Superintendent of Education, died of a heart ailment at his home here late today, at the age of 86. He was president of the college for twenty-six years, retiring in 1925.

Changes in the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera Association will bring eleven new players into the ensemble for the season, which will begin Monday evening, Nov. 29, it was announced yesterday. Four first-desk men have been engaged for the flute, oboe, trumpet and harp sections.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek today issued a formal statement opposing direct peace negotiations with Japan. The Premier of China and chief of her defense forces reaffirmed China's determination to continue the struggle until "justice is re-established in this part of the world."

Here all other events are overshadowed by the anti-Communist manifesto. Yesterday afternoon, when extras appeared containing the text of the protocol signed by Italy, Germany and Japan, the papers were snatched up and read in the streets as avidly as war bulletins.

Wheat prices on the Board of Trade here continued last week to decline, and quotations were at the lowest level in more than sixteen months as a result of general liquidation induced by an almost total lack of foreign demand for the domestic exportable surplus.

Warring labor union factions and determined shipping interests may stage their long-awaited "showdown" at Los Angeles harbor tomorrow as a direct result of the signing on of fifteen Filipino deckhands by the Danish motor ship Marchen Maersk in New York, it was indicated today.

The junior auxiliary of the North Hudson Hospital of Weehawken A will inaugurate a campaign this month to raise $125,000 needed to build a new home for nurses. It will be assisted in the drive by the senior auxiliary.

Francis P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, Inc., and former United States Alien Property Custodian, died early yesterday at his home, 740 Park Avenue, where he was stricken with pneumonia Thursday. His age was 62.

Today's events: Rossini's "Matrimonial Market" and Ibert's "Angelique," Salzburg Opera Guild, Forty-fourth Street Theatre, 8:40 P. M.; Andrew C. Haigh, piano, and Gilbert Ross, violin, joint recital, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Simon Barer, piano recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M., and Rosalyn Tureck, piano, Bach recital, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.
Laurence Russell Wilder, electrical engineer and considered one of the nation's foremost shipbuilders, died of apoplexy at his home here last night. His age was,49.
The gaudy eighty-room mansion which Father Divine took over as a "super-super heaven" near here last Spring, burned to the ground at noon today.

The New York Yankees tallied four field goals, a safety and one touchdown to defeat the Cincinnati Bengals, 21 to 13, in an American League football game here today. The victory put the Yanks in third position in the league race. The Bengals, held scoreless until the final period, went over the goal twice in the last few minutes.

The Financial News's index of British bond prices, based on the average of 1928 as 100, yesterday stood at 128.3, compared with 127.4 a week before, 127 a month ago, 138.4 a year ago, and with the high record of 141 at the end of January, 1935, and the low record of 90.6 at the end of September, 1931.

The engagement of Miss Mary Howard, daughter of Mrs. Abner Updegraff Howard of this place and the late Mr. Howard, to Dr. William Muir Fitzgerald, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Jesse Comfort Fitzgerald, also of Yonkers, has been announced by her mother.

Setting precedent for future taxing of corporation assets, the Supreme Court affirmed today the State Tax Board's stand that a corporation's intangibles were taxable elsewhere than in the municipality in which the corporation's office was registered.

Charles Clifford Randolph, sales manager for the Barrett Company of New York, in charge of the Tarvia department, died today at his home here at the age of 65. From 1905 to 1915 he served the city as a Councilman.

Miss Hazel Thrall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver J. Thrall of this place, was married to Joseph Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Sullivan of Waterbury, this afternoon at St. Gabriel's rectory here by the Rev. Harold Mulqueen, S. J., of Fordham University.
Attempts to win public support for the "Committee of Five- Million" drive for resumption of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin's recently halted crusades began here today.

An experiment to determine whether stenotyping offers a new practical career for the blind reached its final stages yesterday with the insertion in New York newspapers of a "situation wanted" advertisement seeking a position for Carl Weiss, 26 years old, it was announced by the Guild for Jewish Blind, 200 West Seventy-second Street.

Leading practically all the way, Victor Dyrgall of the Millrose A. A. won the national junior cross-country championship today at the Empire City race track. Dyrgall also holds the metropolitan senior 15,000-meter title.
The British plan for partition of Palestine into an Arab State and a Jewish State is "fraught with gravest danger," a report made public today by the Foreign Policy Association declared.
President Roosevelt's fifty-fifth birthday on Jan. 30 again will be made the occasion for public participation in the fight against infantile paralysis, it was announced today.

President J. Spencer Weed of the National Horse Show Association and Mrs. Weed gave a reception and tea yesterday afternoon in the Jansen suite at the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of the members of the international military jumping teams participating in the exhibition at Madison Square Garden. More than 200 guests attended.

Expansion in commercial loans at reporting member banks from the beginning of August to the middle of October was as rapid as at any time since the resumption of the increase in these loans early in 1936, according to the Federal Reserve Bulletin for November, made public today. The gain amounted to about $450.000.000.

Miss Viola Hewitt Buell, daughter of William H. Buell of this city and the late Mrs. Gertrude H. V. Buell, was married in Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale yesterday afternoon to Roswell Parker Angier Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. R. P. Angier.
Although the Schacht affair has not been officially elucidated, it influenced the markets downward for the greater part of this week.
Either the number of booklovers in the metropolitan district has increased since last year or word has got about that this year's NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair is not only bigger but better.

It is plainly more than a coincidence that Italy has chosen to ally herself with Japan and Germany, in their "anti-Communist" entente, precisely at a time when an attempt is being made at Brussels to persuade Japan to recognize her responsibilities under the Nine-Power treaty.

The Union Building and Loan Association of Passaic has sold four buildings in New Jersey communities to four different investors. The properties have a total value of about $500,000 and were sold through J. B. Wolfe, Inc., as broker.

Because of his continued illness, Paul Dullzell has postponed a final decision on whether he will reconsider his resignation as executive secretary and treasurer of the Actors Equity Association, it was said yesterday by Frank Gillmore, Equity president.
Pennsylvania's relief rolls were reduced on Oct. 30, for the fifth consecutive week, a report of Karl De Schweinitz, Secretary of Public Assistance, revealed today.
Members of the Southeastern Underwriters Association assembled here today for their semi-annual meeting, which is to lust through Wednesday.
Central American exiles here are expressing a growing fear that the war talk emanating from Nicaragua might seriously prejudice, if not destroy, peace efforts in the NicaraguaHonduras border dispute.

The Helen Haire Levinson Prize for 1937 has been awarded to Louise Bogan for her group of poems published in "Poetry" and later included in her volume, "The Sleeping Fury," recently issued by Scribner.

For 1,400 slum dwellers Uncle Sam will play the role of Cinderella's godmother within the next two months. Two new Federal housing projects, the Hill Creek in Philadelphia and the Highland Homes in suburban Wayne, costing a total of $2,300,000, are rapidly nearing completion for occupancy by 308 families now living in tenements.

A series of field exercises unique in American military history will come to a climax this week when 10,000 men in 1,100 motor vehicles will make a "motorized march" from San Antonio to Mineral Wells, Texas, and return.
Miss Ruth Ehn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ehn of this place, was married here to Carl Bergstedt of Brockton, Mass., yesterday afternoon in the Swedish Congregational Church. The Rev.

New York's Rangers, making their 1937-8 debut, defeated the champion Detroit Red Wings, 3-0, tonight in the Wings' first home game of the National Hockey League season. A crowd of 13,000 watched the game.

Only two of twelve walkers who left Newark at 4:45 this morning on the Newark-to-Blairstown hike of the Essex County chapter of the Walk-for-Health Association of America were able to finish the jaunt of sixty-three uphill miles.

Green Bay's champion Packers struck a lusty blow in defense of their National Football League laurels today by a spectacular triumph over the Chicago Bears, 24 to 14, before a record throng of 44,977 at Wrigley Field.
Citizens of Julius Streicher's Nuremberg were warned today that President Roosevelt and the United States may be driving an unwilling Europe toward war.

To map out new policies for the State Federation of Women's Clubs, which holds its annual convention here beginning tomorrow and continuing for four days, the officers met tonight with the policies committee. The committee's report is to be submitted to the board of directors tomorrow.

Four hundred officers and men of the Fourteenth Infantry Regiment of the National Guard participated yesterday in an Armistice Day and Memorial service conducted by the Rev. Dr. George Steininger, the chaplain, at the South Reformed Church.

Reported by the American News Company, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbels, Maoy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's: FICTION The Citadel, by A. J. Cronin (Little, Brown). Northwest Passage, by Kenneth Roberts (Doubledav. Dorap).

FOR a time on Saturday afternoon it would have been no great surprise to learn that Communist brigades had overturned various city halls and were marching on Washington, chanting merrily: "Comes the Revolution!" Princeton was leading Dartmouth, Purdue was leading Fordham, Colgate was ahead of Holy Cross, Iowa was out in front of mighty Minnesota, and Chicago seemed to be winning its first game of the season.

A National Economic Council composed of six members was created by President Alberto Enriquez by executive decree today for the purpose of harmonizing, unifying and orienting the work necessary for economic rehabilitation.
John H. Clarke, for half a century active in New Haven business affairs and a former president of the Standard Supply Company, died last night at his home here at the age of 83.

A memorial address on Father Francis Patrick Duffy was broadcast last night in an Armistice Day program and conducted over Station WMCA from 6:30 to 7 P. M. by the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement at Garrison, N. Y.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Scott Sloan of 2 Montague Terrace, Brooklyn, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lidie Lane Sloan, to Andrew M. McBurney Jr., son of Mrs. Andrew M. McBurney of Philadelphia and the late Mr. McBurney.
The stock market opened this week with foreign and domestic selling and continued to decline for four days, with bulls interested only in potashes and some electrical issues.
A truce was arranged tonight to end the strike of the American Newspaper Guild at the plant of The Wilkes-Barre Record, the city's only morning daily, which suspended publication Tuesday night.
A. L. Burns and L. F. Sanman tied for the high scratch cup over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Each finished with 96 out of a possible 100 targets. In the shoot-off,

In the first summary of income and expenses given by the treasurer of the Yale University Athletic Association in at least three. years, it was announced today that the receipts from football increased from $360,053 in 1934 to $405,464 in 1935, but decreased in 1936 to $409,130.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 87.9, which compares with 88.1 a week ago, 89.3 two weeks ago, 89.5 three weeks ago and 89.8 four weeks ago.

The Scholarship Fund of the Smith College Club of New York will be aided by a special performance of "The Barber of Seville," with Lily Pons,, Ezio Pinza and John Charles Thomas in the leading roles, the afternoon of Feb. 11 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club came through with two victories to win the annual invitation handicap squash racquets tournament of the Nassau Country Club today. Playing with a 3-point allowance. Rice beat Herbert Lancaster of University Club, the defending cup holder, 15-11, 15-9, 15-1, and Samuel Cochran Jr. of the University Club, 13-16, 15-9, 16-18, 16--14, 18-17.

Thomas. Haire's Delirium tallied twenty points today to lead the Class B boats at the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association weekly series. Aided by a strong breeze, Haire gained three more points than Ted Clark's Eskimo.

The J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation has announced that it has sold to the Fiscal Management Company, Ltd., of Toronto, its common stock holdings in the Continental Securities Corporation which were acquired in the market a few years ago, and that the buyers also have acquired from other parties sufficient additional shares in Continental Securities to give them voting control.

The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in its November bulletin publishes the following list of types of organizations, which, in addition to churches, charity hospital associations, fraternal orders and endowed educational institutions, may be considered as operated primarily for religious, philanthropic, charitable, educational, fraternal or other similar purposes, and the deposits of which may be classified by member banks as savings deposits if the organizations are not operated for profit:
Spieker-Truax Homes bought from the Vandeventer Realty Corporation a plot of seven lots on the north side of Twenty-eighth Avenue, between Forty-eighth and Forty-ninth Streets. Astoria, L. I.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Hecht of Brooklyn of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bernice J. Hecht, to Milton L. Fleiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Fleiss, also of Brooklyn.
A survey of income taxes in eleven representative States has disclosed wide variations. in the rate of the taxes, an announcement by the Twentieth Century Fund said yesterday.
Fifteen government agencies made 107 supply awards valued at about $7,001,385 in the week ended on Nov. 4 under the terms of thePublic Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has reported.

A debate on "Is a Japanese Boycott Justifiable" will feature the initial luncheon of the Executive Club, sponsored by the International Association of Sales Executives, to be held at the Hotel Astor on Wednesday.

The German and Italian Navies, according to a Rome dispatch to the Agence radio tonight, will hold combined manoeuvres in the Mediterranean. This is the first instance of two countries collaborating-this way since the war.
