Scoring after two minutes of the "sudden death" period on a 50-yard shot, Warren Sackman gave the First Division a 10-9 victory over Fort Hamilton in a thrilling polo game yesterday at the Army

The New York Civic Orchestra, directed by Eugene Plotnikoff, presented a program devoted to Schumann, MacDowell and Sibelius at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. A large audience received the performances warmly.

The first report of television from land to a ship at sea was brought here yesterday by Captain A. T. Brown, master of the Cunard White Star motorship Britannic, who said the experiments had been successful. The tests began after the ship left London on Friday, Oct. 29, and were continued at intervals while the Britannic was going down Channel from Southampton on her way to Queenstown, Ireland.

Charles McKenna, 46 years old, of 123 Third Avenue, logger and truck driver, died in Queens General Hospital of a self-inflicted bullet wound yesterday four hours after he had wounded Mrs. Esther McMullan, 40 years old, a widow employed as a registered nurse, in her home at 116-40 196th Street, in St. Albans, Queens.

Dismayed by State Senator Lester H. Clee's defeat by the comparatively small margin of 44,630 votes in the Gubernatorial election last Tuesday, Essex County Republican leaders weighed sweeping changes in the county organization today, but it was generally expected that these changes would not be decided upon until the question of a recount in Hudson County had been settled.

At the close of the last session the Rules Committee of the House was roundly denounced for preventing the Federal Wage and Hour Bill from coming to a vote. But regardless of the motives of the committee, or the justification of its action from a purely

There is no sense of permanency, no complete satisfaction, for men and women on this earth, the Rev. Frederic'S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The fundamental necessity for a belief in the after life was stressed yesterday morning by Bishop William T. Manning in his All Saints' sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

Dr. Hu Shih, Professor of Philosophy at Peiping University and a representative of the Chinese Minister of Education, told 1,500 Chinese in the China Theatre yesterday that the Chinese people must be prepared for a long war and should not be discouraged by current news from China.

The second season of the New Friends of Music began yesterday afternoon in Town Hall with a packed house, and the whole series of sixteen concerts of chamber music by Mozart, Schubert and Schumann were fully subscribed in advance of the opening.

The Seamen's Bank for Savings sold to Viola Khoury 56-60 W 119th St for $40,000, taking back a mortgage for that amount, due in five years at 3 per cent. Viola Khourt then conveyed these parcels to the Maloof Realty Co, Inc, of 1,042 St. Nicholas Ave.

Erica Morini's recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon provided an exhibition of violin playing which probably could not be paralleled by. any other woman player of the instrument now before the public.
The British Government has proof that the exclusive statement made in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Monday about the Rome-Berlin axis represents the exact truth.

More than 250 stands of colors escorted by 3,000 marchers were paraded down Fifth Avenue to St. Thomas Church at Fifty-third Street yesterday in the annual massing of the colors ceremonies held by military and patriotic organizations.

To reduce the surtax on undistributed earnings, the directors of the Walworth Company have approved a plan calling for an initial dividend on the common stock amounting to either 25 cents in cash or 30 cents in the par value of new preferred stock.

The feeling regarding the French domestic position has been more favorable this week. The statement of Finance Minister Georges Bonnet before the Financial Committee of the Chamber of Deputies was considered encouraging.
The first service in the new edifice of the Central Presbyterian Church, Jefferson and Marcy Avenues, Brooklyn, was conducted yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Paul F. Barackman, pastor.

Miss Barbara Jane Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Blaine S. Smith of this place, has completed plans for her wedding to Anson Krickl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Krickl of Scarsdale, on Nov. 27 in Christ Church here.

Clergymen in Flushing gave special sermons yesterday in observance of the 100th anniversary of the incorporation of Flushing as a village. This was in response to a message sent to them by Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens.

Dowager Queen Marie of Rumania suffered tonight a severe recurrence of the intestinal hemorrhage that doctors said she had experienced last March. Eight noted specialists were summoned to fly to her bedside in Zotrozeni Castle for a consultation tomorrow noon.

While the number of exhibitions on the local art calendar dropped from fifty-six last week to a mere thirty new ones for the current week, the hardened gallery-goer may find consolation in the fact that this week's shows include a number of large and important events with a ponderable percentage of attractions that might well cause any seven-day period in an ordinary season to be remembered.
Lieutenant Scott M. Sanford of the United States Army last night won the first and second prizes in the international military jumping competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.
Colonel John W. Lowe, for many years a druggist of this city, died in Brooks Hospital, Boston, day following an operation. He was born in Wallingford, Conn., seventy-eight years ago.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Hughes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Hughes of this city, was married here to Daniel H. Geary, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Geary of Springfield, Mass., yesterday in St. Joseph's Church.

Defining the current mood of the world as "catastrophic," the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said in his sermon yesterday morning that while the world may revolve age after age in swirling economic and spiritual cycles, faith in Christ will provide a steadiness to humanity to offset the predictions, true or false, of impending disaster.
A Cabinet member declared today that France soon would be equipped for a radio counter-offensive against Italian propaganda in France's own colonies.

Thirty-eight Princeton University undergraduates have been named as members of the cast for the Tri-angle Club's forty-ninth annual production, it has been announced by William J. Watson of Trenton, N. J., president of the organization.

In the largest intercollegiate dinghy regatta ever held in this country and the first to draw international competition, two crews from the home club, the M. I. T. Nautical Association, regained possession of the Boston Dinghy Club intercollegiate challenge cup on which it had won the original leg in April, 1936.

Charles McLaughlin, whose hand pulled the throttle of the New York Central System's famous "999" speed engine during the gay nineties, died on Friday night at the age of 88. Mr. McLaughlin, oldest engineer on the Mohawk Division of the road, retired in 1922.

On the reopening here on Wednesday after the two religious holidays, the stock market displayed a more favorable trend than had been expected in view of the weak tone shown in the foreign markets while the Stock Exchange and banks here were closed.

Destruction of property is always an economic waste, declared the Rev. Dr. J. Stanley Durkee in a sermon yesterday morning at the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims, Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.
Mrs. R. C. Kelly, 66, described by Deputy Sheriff J. G. Reese as the mother of Governor E. D. Rivers of Georgia, was charged today with shooting a 68-year-old Nashville Alderman.

The armistice which ended the World War nineteen years ago was made the subject of sermons by several New York City pastors yesterday, all of whom looked with foreboding on the present state of the world and urged a return of Christian principles lest another great conflict begin.

Miss Virginia Walbridge Hill, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. George W. C. Hill of Sunset Farm, West Hartford, has chosen Nov. 26 as the date for her marriage to Richard Lyons Hughes, son of Mrs. Clarence Hall Wilson of Albany Avenue, West Hartford.
" Red Cross Sunday" was observed yesterday in churches throughout the city. Appeals were made from pulpits for support of the annual roll-call of the New York chapter, American Red Cross.

Miss Marion Tompkins Wilsdon of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Wilson of Waterbury, was married to Gerald Hazen Loomis, son of Frank W. Loomis of this city, yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Immanuel Congregational Church.
The frano this week has pursued a steady course and the equalization fund has intervened in the market only to buy foreign currencies, which have been largely offered.
The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has expanded its medical department to provide for an exhaustive annual check-up of its executive personnel in the New York area.
Miss Susanna Larter, daughter of Mrs. e Harry C. Larter of this city, will be married to Clarence Dickinson Long I Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Dickinson Long of Fairfield, N. J., on Dec. 20.

John C. Rice, former Chief Justice of the Idaho Supreme Court, died here today at the age of 73. Judge Rice was born in Cass County, Ill. He received his A. B. from Illinois College in 1885, his law degree from Cornell in 1890. Two years ago Illinois College made him a doctor of laws.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,761,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

Members of a rescue party reported tonight two men were killed in the crash of a navy amphibian plane in the marshlands west of here. The naval air station at OpaLocka sent two officers to investigate.

Dave Smukler, former Temple University star billed as "Dynamite" on the program, took personal charge of the blasting operations at Ebbets Field yesterday and guided the Philadelphia Eagles to a 14-to-10 decision over the Brooklyn Dodgers before 12.000 fans.

" The Union in Your Synagogue" was the general theme of addresses and discussions at the seventh annual convention of the Northeast Region of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, held here all day yesterday.

With public exercises in which the "mother of radium" was hailed as "the greatest woman scientist of all times" and trees were planted in her memory, the seventieth anniversary of the birth of Marie Sklodowska Curie, the discoverer of radium, was commemorated yesterday under the auspices of the New York State Conference of Polish Clubs.
At alert guard took advantage of a blocked punt today and scored the winning points for St. Vincent's Bearcats in a hard-fought game with St. Anselm College. The final score was 19 to 13.

The Soviet Union was twenty years old yesterday. Exchanges of greetings by radio from one and of the country to another, from Russian ships at sea and even from the Russian base at the North Pole marked the anniversary. A great military display was staged and 1,500,000 persons paraded through Red Square. [Page 1.]

The security markets here last week furnished some striking contrasts in the divergence of tendencies. Gilt-edge issues, particularly the government securities, developed remarkable buoyancy, while industrial and commodity equities continued depressed.

The Fort Totten football team turned back the Colony Club eleven, 12 to 0, at Fort Totten in Bayside yesterday. Fort Totten scored in the first and fourth periods, with James Gallagher and Joe Kirsten going across on short plunges.

As had been foreshadowed by the position at the time of adjournment last night, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris succeeded today in defeating Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, in the fourteenth game of their title match.

British industrialists endorse the view generally held in United States financial circles that conditions in this country are greatly improved, but they hesitate to apply the same generalization to Continental Europe.

Union employes of the Ford Motor Company's assembly plant here today empowered officers of their Local No. 25 of the United Automobile Workers of America, a C. I. O. affiliate, to call a strike "if the company continues to refuse to consider complaints of the union's grievance committee."

Spencer D. Bettelheim, operator of the Lyceum Theatre and a member of Sam H. Harris's executive staff, who died Friday night, will receive a military funeral. Services will be held 11 A. M. tomorrow at John J. Barrett's Chapel, Boyertown Building, 41 West Sixtieth Street. Burial will take place in Woodlawn Cemetery.

Czechoslovakia, known until recently as the most stable, most progressive and most democratic of the States born of the World War, has been suddenly pushed to the, forefront of world attention as one of Europe's potentially most explosive trouble zones.

Crown Drug Company-Year ended on Sept. 30: Net profits before taxes, $266,359, against $312,007 in preceding year; gross sales, $8,562,946, against $8,240,734. General Outdoor Advertising Company, Inc.-Quarter ended Sept. 30: Profit $433,290.

The general index of wholesale prices in France on Oct. 30 stood at 611, against 614 on Oct. 23 and 620 on Oct. 16. The gold index of raw material prices was 48.2 on Oct. 30, against 48.5 on Oct. 23 and 49.2 on Oct. 16.

11:15-Class 81, horses suitable to become hunters. AFTERNOON 2:00-Class 102, finals, Brooks-Bright Foundation Challenge Cup. 2:25--Class 29. single harness ponies over 13.2. 2:40-Class 59, three-gaited park saddle horses, the Biltmore Challenge Cup.
Motorists on United States Highway 12, west of Galesburg, Mich., today witnessed the death of a young man who fell from a Michigan Central Railroad express as it sped toward Chicago.
Jay Darling, former chief of the United States Biological Survey, called upon American sportsmen today to join forces to conserve wild life resources.

Mrs; Anne H. Rush Baker Lewis, widow of John Frederick Lewis, admiralty lawyer and art patron, died at her home here today. She was a member of a prominent Philadelphia which family, the daughter of the late Alfred G. and Henrietta Fales Baker.

IF it is altogether what it pretends to be--an ex-insider's candid account of Hitlerism from the diaper days of 1922 to the splendid manhood of June 30, 1934--Kurt G. W. Ludecke's volume of reminiscences* is a significant piece of history.
The most eventful year in Madrid's long history ended today with celebrations from one end of Loyalist Spain to the other commemorating the beginning of the siege.
The Times this morning called upon the British Government to speed up the Anglo-American trade treaty negotiations.

With prayer, song, oratory and pageantry, Passaic dedicated today a huge boulder in Pulaski Park to mark the purchase of Menehenicke Island, later to become part of Passaic, by Hartman Machielson, a Holland adventurer, from the Indians in 1678.
Miss Erna Rothschild, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Rothschild of New York and Patterson, N. Y., was married here today to Allan R. Rosenberg, son of Dr. and Mrs. I. G. Rosenberg of Brookline, Mass.

The National Biscuit Company, which refused to supply certain data sought by the Federal Trade Commission pursuant to a Congressional resolution until the commission took the matter to court, paid its officers an average salary of $35,525, the highest of any related group covered by the study, the commission announced today.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Anne Elizabeth Muhlenberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hiester Henry Muhlenberg of Wyomissing, Reading, to Jackson Kemper 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Poyntell Kemper of Clingan, Birdsboro.

A chemical process that, contrary to all ordinary expectations, is retarded by increasing heat, was described yesterday in a statement by the American Chemical Society. Such a thing, the society declared, is as remarkable as "a fire which quenches itself as it grows hotter."

The unanimous decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, disbarring J. Richard Davis, sets an important precedent. Davis, attorney for the late Arthur Flegenheimer, better known as Dutch Schultz, is now a fugitive from an indictment on a charge of racketeering.

The engagement of Miss Geraldyne Margaret Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Joseph Murphy of Fieldston, to Eugene A. Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas F. Walsh, also of Fieldston, has been announced by her parents.

George H. Hart of Hartford, Conn., sailing his dinghy Protest, took the first race today toward the Roosevelt Trophy, scoring 18 points in one race to 17 for Harry Hall of Larchmont, who was second in his craft Wow. Dr. Kenneth S. Scott in the Vodka, Hart's old boat, was third, and Mrs. Helen Hill, in her Dunker from Larchmont, was fourth.

Corn, while resisting pressure in the early part of last week, finally was affected by the drastic decline in wheat, with the December delivery at the Board of Trade here selling at a new low level for the season and since June, 1936.

The Ninepower Treaty conference, recessing over the week-end while awaiting a reply to its attempt to open communications with Japan, enters a second phase, if there is to be a second phase, Tuesday, by which time it is hoped, but not too optimistically, that Japan's reply to its note of yesterday will be received.

In order to be able to continue its purchases of foreign currencies, the French equalization fund should find it necessary soon to sell gold to the Bank of France, which is the only means at its disposal to obtain francs.

When a drama critic is hospitably invited to the theatre he may be sure that it is not for the charm of his company. He is invited in the hope of a few lines of praise in the newspaper and another dollar or two in the till.

Walter Percival, president of Local 829 of the United Scenic Artists Union, who for the last seventeen years had been a leader in the labor organization activities of his fellowcraftsmen, died suddenly at his home here this afternoon of a heart attack. He was born in Wilmington, Del., fifty-seven years ago.

Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "Conservatives and Liberals," Merwin K. Hart. Child Study Association of America, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, 11 A. M. "Creative Work for Women." Genevieve Taggard..

Railroad freight traffic in the Reich in September was almost 14 per cent above the level of the same month in 1936. Bankruptcies in October numbered 175, against 163 in September. According to the Steel Syndicate's monthly report, the home market for semi-finished products was quieter, as far as structural steel was concerned. Foundries were less active but the demand for wire was unabated.

Half-back Walter Carew tallied three touchdowns in one period today as the St. Bonaventure football team repulsed Mount St. Mary's from Emmittsburg, Md., 22 to 0. Carew amassed his 18 points in the second period on short runs preceded by marches in which he was the princinal ball carrier.

By a strange coincidence, the twentieth anniversary of the Russian revolution was celebrated here almost exactly twenty-four hours after the signing of the Italo-German-Japanese antiCommunist pact, and the Russian Embassy, where a magnificent reception was held, was crowded for the occasion with diplomats.

Mrs. Morris Exra Alling of Northford, Conn., announced at a family dinner party yesterday the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Cooke Alling, to William Daniel Carter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Carter of Wakefield, Mass.

The police raided Jews' homes at 5 o'clock this morning and took 503 Jewish men and women to headquarters for Inspection of their identification papers. By this evening all but twenty-nine were released.
Fewer cattle and calves will be killed for the market in 1938 than in 1937, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics predicted today, but the total beef supply will be nearly as large as this year.

More than 500 members of American Legion posts of Nassau County and their auxiliaries attended annual Armistice Day services this afternoon in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church here after parading from the Dugout to the church to the music of three military bands.

Niagara University scored its sixth triumph in seven football games this season when it defeated Providence College, 17 to 6, today. It was the fourth victory for the Purple Eagles in six battles with the Friars.
Alexander Scott-Gatty, veteran actor and close friend of Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson, died last night a few hours after the death of Sir Johnston, it was announced today.

Six Harvard students named Murphy have received an aggregate of $2,250 in this year's awards of the annual scholarships donated by William Stanislaus Murphy, '85, for the "collegiate education of men of the name of Murphy."

The world must rid itself of indifference toward Christ if we are to solve the national, religious and personal problems of today, declared the Rev. Irwin C. Wise in a sermon yesterday morning at the Second Presbyterian Church, Ninety-sixth Street near Central Park West. Mr.

Cotton prices continued their downward movement last week on the New York Cotton Exchange with the December and January deliveries losing 34 and 33 points, respectively. July and October declined 15 and 16 points, respectively. During the week, the December position established a new low for the season, but closed somewhat higher.
Hearings scheduled for this week in New York by the Federal Trade Commission involve the following respondents on the days indicated:

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that unless there was a drastic change today in the manner of counting the proportional representation ballots for the City Council he would invoke his police powers to assure an honest count.

Life with father, as the lamented Clarence Day made clear, was an ordeal requiring the utmost fortitude and delicacy on the part of the Victorian wife and mother. There were some things that father knew a woman couldn't understand, some things she ought not to know about, some problems that had to be left to the head of the house because no one else had any sense about them. Clarence Day's father,

A marked improvement in the Eastern shipping demand for cash lard, due to the accumulation of supplies before a seasonal increase in freight rates becomes effective on Nov. 15 and a big reduction in local stocks in October, resulted last week in a sharply higher range of prices on the Board of Trade here on the near-by deliveries.

Ray L. Hudson, an insurance company executive and prominent Baptist layman, died at Tioga Baptist Church today while preparing food baskets for the Baptist Home for the Aged. Death was attributed to a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 65.

The Hoffman Beverage Company of Newark, N. J., has been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to stop disparaging competitors' beer products by asserting that "heat treating beer during bottling operations spoils the fresh taste" and that heat treating is necessary "in all other American breweries-except Hoffman."
In the United States we have a political Left Wing but in Loyalist Spain these elements constitute the conservatives.

The Youth Peace Conference, held over the week-end at Vassar College and ended today with about 200 representatives of colleges, universities and peace organizations in attendance, adopted a working platform.

The role that cities shall play in relief of the unemployed appears likely to become an issue at the coming session of Congress. Advocates and opponents of proposals to make municipalities bear a larger share of the burden are marshaling arguments for a possible clash.

In spite of a mass of conflicting rumors, it is authoritatively stated here that the Duke and Duchess of Windsor have not yet made new plans to substitute for their canceled tour of the United States.

A report urging the repeal of the undistributed profits tax has been adopted by the board of directors of the New York Board of Trade and will be submitted to the membership for ratification at a meeting tomorrow, according to an announcement yesterday by Percy C. Magnus, president of the organization.

Attacking the provisions of the Lea bill as it applies to State and municipal debt reorganizations, Charles M. Johnson, State Treasurer and chairman of the Local Government Commission of North Carolina, told investment bankers here today that this legislation not only was absolutely unnecessary but appeared to be the entering wedge for ultimate control of State and municipal financing by a bureau of the Federal Government.
Chancellor Hitler issued a decree today forbidding parents to leave property to children who have incurred the displeasure of the National Socialist regime and have lost their citizenship.

The Federal Power Commission has filed a brief with the Supreme Court as "friend of the court," and has asked permission for its general counsel, Oswald Ryan, to appear in oral argument Nov. 11 in an effort to nullify the thirty-nineyear-old doctrine of determining utility company valuations on the basis of reproduction costs, the commission announced tonight.

The air mass analysis taken in the weather observatory in Central Park has shown a decrease in pollution of New York City air every month of 1937, as compared with the corresponding months of last year, it was announced yesterday by the observer, David R. Morris.
Bids will be taken next month on the local $1,000,000 unit of the $5,000,000 coastto-coast building program of Sears, Roebuck Co.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 79.7 on Nov. 3, compared with 80.7 a fortnight before, 81.6 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Ten minutes after returning to his home at 59 East Park Street, here at 4 o'clock this morning with his wife after attending a party at the home of friends, Walter A. Snow, 24-year-old graduate student of sociology at New York University, went to - a storeroom on the third floor and put a pistol bullet through his head.

At 37, an age when most athletes are content to look back on a career, Pat Dengis, airplane mechanic from Baltimore, today added to his reputation as one of the country's greatest long-distance runners as he registered a brilliant victory in the Yonkers marathon.

A continuing committee of parents and educators, designed to make the children's theatre unit of the WPA Federal Theatre Project partly self-sustaining, was set up yesterday at the closing session of the WPA Autumn festival for children at the Maxine Elliott Theatre.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Haines Plum 2d of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stephanie Wilder Plum, to Edward Austin Guthrie Jr., son of Mrs. Edward A. Guthrie, also of Madison, and the late Mr. Guthrie.

Indecent books and plays were denounced yesterday by the Rev. James M. Gillis, editor of The Catholic World, at the annual communion breakfast of the Ladies Auxiliary of La Salle Academy, 44 East Second Street.
Many of our "best minds" believe that the capital gains tax and the undistributed surplus profits tax retard industrial and commercial activity, Morris S.

Delay of naval ship construction by strikes was recorded today in the annual report of Admiral William D. Leahy, chief of naval operations. The report also declared that "late delivery of materials, insufficient drafting force and necessary changes during construction" had slowed work and that the various causes had delayed the building of twenty-three destroyers in the fiscal year ended June 30.

Reviewing member-bank earnings and expenses in the first six months of 1937, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System announced today that profits on the sales of securities, recoveries on loans and investments, and all other recoveries of member banks, amounting to $158,456,000, had fallen short of meeting losses and depreciation which amounted to $166,023,000.

The Marquess of Milford Haven, the Marquess of Queensberry, Lord Beaverbrook, Count and Countess G. de Castellane, General de Chambrun, Colonel Jacques Balsan and Mrs. William R. Hearst are due today from Europe on the French liner Normandie.
Stocks sharply lower with widest weekly decline since week ended on July 22, 1933; turnover, 6,251,230 shares.

Although Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson had long since gone down in the records as a great actor, he was never certain that he had adopted the right career. The son of an art critic, he was trained as an artist, but turned to-the stage, which had always interested him.

President Roosevelt was asked today by Albert Levitt, a former special assistant to the Attorney General, to instruct Attorney General Cummings to start legal proceedings to remove Justice Black from the Supreme Court.
The Metropolitan Opera House was filled as for a gala performance yesterday afternoon by persons eager to pay tribute to General Evangeline Booth, head of the Salvation Army.

More than 600 delegates at a conference on Palestine land redemption at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon resolved to undertake the immediate sale of $50,000 of bonds to buy land In Upper Galilee.

Bishop Francis J. McConnell, resident Bishop of the New York area, officiated last night at a liturgical service celebrating the merger of St. Andrew's Methodist Episcopal Church with St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. St.

Sixteen municipalities of New Jersey, those having acceptable landing facilities, will have their outgoing air mail picked up by planes and brought to Newark Airport for rerouting on Nov. 16 as a feature of New Jersey Air Mail Week, to be observed Nov. 15 to 20 by proclamation of Governor Hoffman.

For the moment, the German Government does not need money badly. In the current financial year the gross tax revenue will reach 14,000,000,000 marks and the Ministry of Finance believes that as much as 17,000,000,000 marks will be received in the fiscal year 1938.

Following their determined resistance to the Japanese advance along the Tatung-Taiyuan highway in Shansi Province, the Chinese forces, who have been pushed back to Taiyuan, are making an unexpectedly strong stand, according to dispatches from the Northern Shansi front.

More than 15,000 laundry workers in this city won a 10 per cent wage increase, a reduction in hours and other gains in an arbitration award handed down by Dr. George W. Taylor of the University of Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday.

The ninth mid-year Trust and Banking Conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association will be held on Thursday and Friday in Asbury Park, N. J., when officials from almost every bank in New Jersey will meet to discuss contemporary problems affecting the banking and trust field, including recent national legislation.

The assistance of the Emergency Relief Bureau and the police will be enlisted in focusing public attention on the national unemployment census that the Federal Government Will begin on Tuesday, Nov. 16, Robert K. Straus, chairman of Mayor La Guardia's cooperating committee, announced yesterday.
More than 1,100 sewers have been built by the Public Works Administration at a cost of about $400,000,000, the PWA projects division reported today.

Whether civilization, now facing the greatest crisis in history, will adjust itself to democratic progress or be plunged to destruction by threatening war, was declared to be the question now facing the world by Dr. Harry F. Ward, Professor of Social Ethics at Union Theological Seminary;

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 48 per cent of capacity, down 3 points in a week and 36 points in nine weeks, from the week before Labor Day, when the rate fully equaled the average earlier in the year.

Carla Bradley, a young dancer who has appeared abroad as well as in this country, gave her first formal New York recital last night at the Guild Theatre. Her program consisted of eleven dances and ten incidental 'cello solos by Young Bilstin, which gives the evening to the dance by only the slightest of margins.

Deputy Fire Chief Gerhardt E. Weber, a veteran of forty-three years of fife fighting in New York, died suddenly at 6 o'clock last night of a heart attack at his home, 236 East 176th Street, Bronx. He was 66 years old.

" We cannot rely on words, oral or written, for our religion," the Rev. Haywood Lewis Winter declared yesterday before the congregation in the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue.

If traditions run true in 1938, the Republicans, as the present minority party, will gather 10 per cent net of the ballots that went to the Democratic party in the 1936 Congressional elections, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., chairman of the Republican National Congressional Committee, declared today.

Yale University, as a teaching institution, spent $6,840,134.80 during the year ended June 30, according to the report of the treasurer. Gifts received totaled $6,787,507.90, bringing the net total of Yale's funds to $104,083,076.94.

Detective Arthur J. De Marrias of the Thirteenth Detective District, Brooklyn, who had been cited several times because of his adeptness at solving crimes, died last night in Brooklyn Hospital five hours after he had been hit on the head with a length of pipe and bitten on the cheek by a Negro prisoner.

Louis L. Alterman, pioneer motion picture theatre operator in Long Island, died yesterday at his home, 144-58 Eighty-seventh Road, Jamaica, Queens, of a complication of diseases. He was in his fiftyninth year.
A lifesize marble statue of St. Christopher, patron of travelers, was dedicated here today on the grounds of St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church in the presence of 1,500 persons.
Staving off a rally in the final minutes to protect its lead, St. Thomas of Scranton turned back Canisius, 12 to 7, in a bitterly contested football game today before a crowd of 7,000.

A simple memorial service for Winthrop Ames, theatrical producer, who died Tuesday in Boston, was held yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street. More than 250 persons, many of them close friends of Mr. Ames, attended.

The number of Protestant pastors and lay leaders now imprisoned has increased from eighty-five to ninety-five. Thirtyseven pastors have been expelled from their pulpits, 31 are forbidden to preach under police orders and 36 have been exiled from their communities by police decree.
A deal of activity is in store for Broadway next week, which now shapes up as follows: MONDAY, Nov. 15.-"Too Many Heroes," at the Hudson. TUESDAY, Nov. 16.-"Madame Bovary," at the Guild.

Word was received here last night of the death yesterday of pneumonia at his home in Monaghan, Ireland, of Edward R. Rice, a de Valera supporter in the Dail Eireann since 1932, who twice had been imprisoned for alleged seditious activities. He was 63 years old.

Bear, Stearns Co. and E. A. Pierce Co. announce that they have been authorized to pay for Commerz und Privat Bank American certificates for 5 1/2 per cent notes due on Nov. 1, 1937, with this year's May 1 and Nov. 1 coupons attached, $66.925 flat for each $100 bond, or, without such coupons, $65 flat for each $100 bond. The offer will expire on Nov. 15.
The Amish "wedding season" has arrived and the "plain people" are abandoning their dawn-to-dusk toil on 'the farms to enjoy their only form of festivity.

Party meetings which closed tonight presage the opening of Parliament the middle of November with the Popular Front coalition of Socialists and Radical-Socialists, with Communist support weakened but still intact.

The anti-Jewish campaign in Mexico attained serious dimensions this evening when the important National Revolutionary party bloc of the Senate asked the Department of the Interior to send Congress a list of the Jews in Mexico, a report on their status under Mexican law and an estimate of the amount of capital they have in this country.

Cardinal Hayes voiced his appreciation and happiness for the "true Catholic faith," of the Mount Carmel parish, in an address there yesterday morning, at the dedication services of the rebuilt Italian Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Belmont Avenue and East 187th Street, the Bronx.
Germany's wholesale price index on Oct. 27 was 105.8, against 105.9 on Oct. 20. The index of the cost of living for October was 124.8, against 105.1 in September.

It is likely that the United States had a net loss of gold last week because the volume of withdrawals of "hot money" to Europe probably exceeded the inflow from Pacific countries, it was learned today from a high official of the Treasury Department.

With the season heading into the home stretch, Eastern leaders of the football parade stood up notably under the increasing pressure of the race for national recognition on Saturday as idols crashed or lost stature in other sections.

The task of making the German people "Danzig minded" received a fresh impulse last week through the visit of Albert Foerster, Nazi leader for Danzig, who has been traversing West Germany on a speaking campaign.

Without any frills but in exceedingly workmanlike fashion, the New York Giants ground out a 17-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates before a crowd of 21,447 at the Polo Grounds yesterday and thereby strengthened their hold on the Eastern division lead in the National Football League.

A card party and tea for the benefit of the West Sixty-third Street Community House, known as The Friendly House, which was formerly the Riverside Day Nursery, will take place Wednesday afternoon at its headquarters, 149 West Sixty-third Street.

Fifty thousand spectators watched the greatest parade in the history of this city today as Daniel J. Doherty came home for the first time since his election as National Commander of the American Legion in New York.

When the United Front movement to promote newspapers as an advertising medium gets under way, it will be buttressed by sectional efforts on the part of various newspaper groups, which will provide separate budgets for the work, recent developments have revealed.

St. Mary's Gaels defeated the University of San Francisco's Dons, 3 to .0. in their annual football clash today. Lou Ferry, veteran quarterback, was sent in after the Gaels had smashed down to San Francisco's 28-yard line in the first quarter.

Our dog is a Scotty named Ellen Mac-Gregor. For many years she has, in her own mind, been the dominant and ruling figure in this neck of the woods. Ellen is pretty well on now. She is fat and built so close to the ground that her bowed legs are hardly worth mentioning.

An "enthusiastic reception" by industry to the recommendations of the industrial practices committee of the National Association of Manufacturers for the "adherence of business to high principles" was shown in comments of business leaders en the report, according to a statement issued yesterday by the association.

A fugitive for thirty-three years, Harry Burns celebrated his forty-ninth birthday in rare fashion last night. He walked into the Desplaines Street police station, tipped his hat to Desk Sergeant John Scherping and announced that he wanted to surrender.

Bishop Thomas E. Molloy of the Brooklyn Diocese yesterday dedicated and blessed the grounds 'and the $85,000 edifice of St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church at 242-12 the Eighty-eighth Road, Bellerose, Queens.

A quiet observance marked the seventy-fourth wedding anniversary here today of Captain and Mrs. Gilbert M. Smith, 94 and 91 years old, respectively, in the two-story frame dwelling at 67 Amity Street that has been their home for the last fiftyfive years.

Negro ministers were urged to demand from their pulpits next Sunday, on the eve of the opening of the special session of Congress, that President Roosevelt openly declare himself in favor of a Federal antilynching law.
Dr. Samuel Fomon, in 1,215 5th Ave; Joseph Paterno Jr. in 21 E 90th St; Dorothy Tunley, in 400 E 59th St ; John McKane, in 136 E 36th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers.

Miss Eleanore Hayden Darling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Coburn Darling, was married to Frederick Wilder Bellamy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. W. Bellamy of New York and Katonah, N. Y. yesterday afternoon in a candlelight ceremony at the Central Congregational Church here.

To meet a triple-pronged Japanese threat from Hangchow Bay aimed at their right flank the Chinese defenders of Shanghai were withdrawing yesterday from Pootung and from areas west of Shanghai. One of the three columns in the Hangchow Bay area was advancing west into Chekiang Province.

Distribution of funds raised in the United Hospital campaign will be directed by a committee of seven civic leaders, John W. Davis, chairman of the drive, announces in a pamphlet, "Looking Ahead at Health," which will be mailed today and tomorrow to representative New Yorkers.
Paul S. Van Baarn. Ltd. art gallery, two floors in 32 E 57th St; Brown, Wheelock. Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.

Jonathan Dorr Pierce president of Bermingham, Castleman Pierce, Inc., advertising firm of 136 East Thirty-eighth / Street, died Saturday afternoon at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 35 years old. His residence was at 170 East Seventyeighth Street.

Capitalizing on their opponents' errors, the Detroit Lions swamped the Cleveland Rams, 27 to 7, in a National Football League game played before a crowd of 15,000 today. Following a scoreless first period, Cleveland tallied two minutes after the start of the second quarter when Bob Snyder went over from the 2 to end a 74-yard march.

Speaking in Italian to the foreign language division of his supporters for re-election, Mayor La Guardia thanked the voters of the city for returning him to office in a radio address from station WOV at noon yesterday.
An advisory committee on the prevention of pneumonia mortality has been called into conference Friday morning by the Public Health Service, Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general, announced today.

11th St, 711-13 E. 50x103.3; Dora Fuchs to Sentry Storage Warehouse, Inc, mtg, $15,000, 711 E 11th St. 128th St. 36 W, 25x100; Arthur Smith and Arthur Smith Jr, to Turlan Realty Corp, 2,089 Anthony Ave, Bronx.

Agustin Legorreta, internationally known financier of Mexico City, Mexico, died yesterday afternoon after a brief illness at the Medical Arts Center Hospital, 57 West Fiftyseventh Street, at the age of 55.

AFTERNOON EVENTS Class 102, Finals for Brooks-Bright Foundation Challenge Cup among twelve selected from elimination-First, Cleland Stables' blk. m. Margot, ridden by Lieut. Marshall Cleland; second, Canadian Army Team's b. g. Flying Poet, ridden by Lieut. Douglas Cleland; third, Canadian Army Team's gr. g. Squire, ridden by Lieut. Marshall Cleland; fourth, U. S. Army Team's b. g. Renzo, ridden by Lieut. W. H. S. Wright.

"Midnight," a society drama by Franz Shulz and Edwin Justus Mayer, was assigned today to Carole Lombard as her next starring vehicle at Paramount. Originally intended for Marlene Dietrich, in the writing it became a story tailored for Miss Lombard.

A brokerage office designed principally to serve the large number of United States residents and transients here will be opened on Dec. 1 by George A. Thatcher Jr. of Boston, for whom Paine, Webber Co. of New York City will act as correspondents.

Although reports to the Department of Agriculture indicated the largest cotton crop on record, prices on the Cotton Exchange resisted pressure yesterday and made a sharp recovery of more than $1 a bale.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Irvin entertained with a dinner in the Bowman Room of the Biltmore for Colonel and Mrs. Henry Stouse of Louisville, Ky. Also in the party, which later attended the theatre, were Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Rhodes and Mrs. Clarence A. Chandler.

Representatives of Eastern trucking companies conferred in the Traffic Club yesterday on proposals to raise their rates in conformity with the petition for the railroads for an increase of 15 per cent in freight charges. It was decided to appoint a committee to act with truckers in other regions.
The War Department today announced purchase of ninety-five basic combat airplanes from North American Aviation, Inc., Inglewood, Calif., at a price of $1,490.972.96.

Steel production in the United States is scheduled at 41 per cent of capacity this week, compared to 48.6 per cent last week, a decline of 7.6 points, or 15.6 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

On an evening of too much music one commentator had to leave Carnegie Hall just as Simon Barer, a pianist of very exceptional equipment, appeared to be warming to his task Such, at least, was the indication of the performance of the Chopin F minor Ballade, which by all odds was the climax of the first part of the recital.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I add the voice of a layman to your discussion of the socialized medicine problem? After all the polemics have become echoes, it is I and millions like me who will either benefit or suffer from the outcome.
Properties at the northerly end of Manhattan, and on the upper West Side, figured in several of the realty transactions reported by brokers yesterday.

A major battle in the North China campaign is being waged for the possession of Taiyuan, Shansi Province capital, where Japanese and Chinese forces are locked in a death struggle around and inside the ancient city's walls.
The six-story apartment house at 312 Manhattan Avenue, recently remodeled at a cost of approximately $100,000, has been sold by the Green-Wood Cemetery to William Perry Doing, operator.

State Auditor Walter R. Darby reported today in a quarterly statement that municipal tax collections in New Jersey at the end of September showed a gain of about 2 per cent compared with receipts up to Sept. 30 last year.
Mr. Hoover has by his cogent and spirited address lifted the celebration of the centenary of the death of Elijah Lovejoy at Colby College in Maine into a national event.

In the grip of another "black Monday," commodities and stocks vied with each other today in a race downward on British markets. Copper, tin, lead, zinc, rubber and wheat all touched new low levels for the year to date and the entire industrial list on the Stock Exchange moved downward.

Edward Augustus McGeehan, retired editor, publisher and author, who was long associated with The Montclair Times, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday while attending mass at the Immaculate Conception Church.

Deputy Chief Gerhardt E. Weber, 7th Division, died Nov. 7. Funeral will take place from his late resi. dence, 238 East 176th St., Bronx, at 10 A M., Wednesday, Nov. 10. Interment at Woodlawn Cemetery.

Miss Elizabeth J. Aylward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Aylward of the Chateau Lafayette, here, has completed arrangements for her marriage to Alfred Reed Pennell, also of Greenwich, son of John Frederick Pennell of New York.

Far from satisfied with the showing of the Penn varsity against Penn State, Coach Harvey Harman ordered a scrimmage for a number of the regulars today as work started for the Michigan game. A rearranged varsity defeated the junior varsity. 13-0.

Popham Ave. (11-2877), n w side 179 n e of 175th St, 50x100 1,647-49 Popham Ave Corp to Sabreit Realty Corp, 280 E 137th St; mtg $47,500. Bryant Ave. (10-2761C), n e cor of Seneca Ave, 150x125; Joseph E. McKenna, ref. to Marion Rothstein. 3,154 Grand Concourse; mtg $205,000.
Dr. Walter Hullihen Fundenberg, former president of the State Board of Dental Examiners and first dean of the University of Pittsburgh Dental School, died today.

The Board of Elections completed yesterday its first official canvass of last Tuesday's vote and announced that Bruce Barton, Republican-Fusion candidate for Representative from the Seventeenth Congressional District in Manhattan, had defeated Stanley Osserman, his Democratic opponent, by 13,715 votes.

Carl Weiss, 26-year-old blind college graduate, was optimistic yesterday afternoon that he would eventually get a job as a stenotypist and compete on an equal footing with the sighted. Undiscouraged by a lack of replies to his advertisements in the classified sections of New York newspapers, he was sure that his fifteen months of arduous learning and practice would not go unrewarded.

Giraud Foster had a dinner party for a company of thirty-five tonight at Bellefontaine, in observance of his eighty-seventh birthday. Chrysanthemums were used for house decorations, the bronze shade prevailing on the tables.

The C. I. O.'s Steel Workers Organizing Committee will open a central national office next week in Toronto, headquarters of that anti-C. I. O. leader, Premier Hepburn, to coordinate its organization drive in Canada, it was announced here today by Selby Barrett, Dominion regional director for the S. W. O. C.

Gifts totaling $41,047 were made to Columbia University last month, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, announced yesterday. The money will be applied chiefly to scholarships and ressearch in science and medicine.
President Roosevelt is credited with a four-point program for ending the Sino-Japanese conflict in a report from the .Domei News Agency's New York correspondent.

Amid the bickering and confusion caused by arrests in the Bronx, discharges in Brooklyn and name-calling in Manhattan, canvassers of the P. R. vote for Councilmen increased the tempo of the count yesterday to the speed of a slow-motion movie, and S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, estimated that it would be easy to get them out of the armories by Thanksgiving Day.

Samuel Chocano, 42 years old, a Peruvian, of 300 West 112th Street, was convicted in Special Sessions yesterday of conspiracy in the sale of altered passports of Central and South American countries to volunteers here seeking to join the Loyalists in Spain.

A not guilty plea to an indictment charging $19,000 in thefts from investors in his alleged "group stock-trading" scheme was entered in General Sessions yesterday by H. Russell Ryder, 41 years old, the ex-convict former "playboy of Broadway."
The talk that has sprung up, on Wall Street and in Washington, that the United States is beginning to export gold after its long series of importation, need not greatly disturb the financial mind.

The value of exports of automotive products from the United States in September of this year amounted to $24,260,418, an increase of 81 per cent over the total of $13,295,700 in September of 1936, the Commerce Department reported today.

52d St, s s, 600 e of 6th Ave. 20x100.5; Column Holding Corp to Morton Kulick, 1,491 Vyse Ave, Bronx. 84th St, 328 E, 25x102.2; Sadie E. Suber to Natalia Kath: same prop, Natalia Kath to Minnie Ohmer, 216 E 85th St; 1st mtg: $21.000. 2d $2.700 ($1).

A market for $5,000,000 worth of American dresses annually in South Africa has been retained through denial of a petition by South African manufacturers for a flat duty of $2.50 each on American dresses, regardless of value, M. J. Glassberg, president of Dominion Buyers, Inc., 225 West Thirty-fourth Street, declared yesterday on his return from South Africa on the Normandie.
James E. Friel has been elected a director of Distillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd. He continues as vice president and treasurer of the subsidiary companies operating in the United States.
The six-story apartment house at 700 Ocean Avenue, between Beverly Road and Regent Place, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Long Beach Equities, Inc. The Maffer Realty Corporation was the seller.

Leave of absence for two days, effective on or about Nov. 7, is granted CoL. E. E ; McCammon, infantry. 1st Lt. Kenneth T. Fairfax, Med.-Res., 423 Main St., Geneva, N. Y., is relieved from assignment to the 17th Station Hospital and is assigned to the 69th General Hospital.

Tomorrow will mark the opening of the small game season in New Jersey, and thousands of hunters will take to the field in search of the rabbits, quail and pheasants which the State seems to have in plenty.

At the request of Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, Governor Hoffman will present to Amory H. Waite Jr. of Trenton a Congressional medal awarded for his part in rescuing the explorer from his isolated outpost in the Antarctic.

A tawny 150-pound deer which apparently had strayed into the Bronx from Westchester was fatally injured yesterday morning when, in attempting to hurdle an iron picket fence surrounding the Jerome Park Reservoir, it was impaled.

A critical situation of traffic stagnation on the more important travel arteries of all American cities will develop within the next year or so at the present rate of increase in automobile use, Dr. Miller McClintock, director of the Harvard University Bureau for Traffic Research, warned yesterday at the opening of a seminar on safety in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Notices of income-tax liens against the estates of two of the Ringling brothers aggregating more than $2,000,000 were filed in Federal court here today by J. Edwin Larson, Florida Collector of Internal Revenue.

The caissons rolled today at a far faster clip than oldtime artillery men ever believed possible. About 10,000 men, with complete equipment, truck-transported, and twenty-eight field guns, trucktowed, traveled at an average speed of about twenty-seven and a half miles an hour this morning over a network of three roads stemming northwards from San Antonio.

Expressing "absolute confidence" that Walter Foley, 42 years old, of 374 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, would never set another fire, Judge George W. Martin in County Court, Brooklyn, suspended a 40-year prison sentence he imposed yesterday after Foley had pleaded guilty to a charge of first-degree arson.

The first increase in the death rate for September in five years occurred this year when the rate rose from 9.4 per 1,000 population to 9.7, Dr. J. V. De Porte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics, reported today.

Walter Millies of Cicero, Ill., 27-year-old catcher for the Senators, was named manager of the Chattanooga Lookouts of the Southern Association today by President Joe Engel. Willies has been with the Senators two years. He played with the Lookouts in 1935 when he belonged to Brooklyn.

Settlement of a strike of 400 workers at the Columbia studio, which tied up production for a day, was announced late tonight by Harland Holmden, vice president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

South Australia defeated the touring New Zealand cricket team today by ten wickets. Led by E. L. Badcock, who made 114 runs, the Aussies compiled 331 and 7 for no wickets, against the New Zealanders' 151 and 186.

Charges that Harley L. Clarke was a dictator in his rule of the $400,000,000 Utilities Power and Light Corporation from which he was ousted, that Floyd B. Odlum had offered about $17,000,000 for the British properties of the company whereas it was estimated by others they were actually worth $25,000,000 and other charges were submitted in a report today to. Federal Judge William H. Holly.

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth S. Freeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Southgate B. Freeman of Cody, Wyo., formerly of Morristown, N. J., to W. Theodore Nussbaumer, son of Mrs. D. L. Nussbaumer of Basle, Switzerland, and the late Mr. Nussbaumer.

The participation of voluntary and private agencies in the work of the city's newly established district health centers is needed today more than ever before as a service supplementary to government if the decentralized system is to continue to operate efficiently, community leaders were told yesterday.

The West Texas Gas Company of Lubbock, Texas, a subsidiary of the Southwest Development Corporation,.a registered holding company, has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval of the payment
Sales of Montgomery Ward Co. for the nine months ended with October amounted to $319,788,818, compared with $265,598,051 in the same period of 1936, a gain of 20.4 per cent. October sales of $48,825,
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 3:

Manhattan College's unbeaten freshman cross-country team triumphed over the Gorton High School harriers, 21-34, in a dual meet at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. Individual honors went to Andy Neidnig of Manhattan, who covered the two-and-one-half mile course in 13:04. James Beckmann of Gorton was second in 13:15.

Because of the disqualification of Little Marty, Jungle King was declared the winner of the $6,500 Manly Memorial Steeplechase, revived before 15,000 spectators at Pimlico today following a lapse since 1931.
Leading stocks improved and closed steadier at irregularly lower levels after opening declines; turnover, 1,377,456 shares.
Mr. and Mrs. Gordon M. Trautschold of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite deHees Trautschold, to Tilson Sherman Denham of New York.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petition JACOBSON GARMENT CO., INC., 270 W. 38th St,-Involuntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law by Kaufman, First Rosenkrantz. Inc., for $600; Dickoff, Gordon Jacobson, $375; Samuel Fine, $130.
Bank clearings in 194 cities throughout the country in October totaled $27,533,079,277, a gain of 2.1 per cent over the preceding month, but a loss of 3.9 per cent as compared with October last year.
Fred Michel defeated Bill Williams, 150 to 148, in fifty-four innings, in one of four games in the amateur straight-rail handicap billiard tournament at the Strand Academy last night.

A conscience-stricken thief, who ransacked an apartment here on Saturday and fled with jewelry and clothing valued at $240, returned the loot today by parcel post with all charges prepaid, the police reported tonight.

American school children were warned today that they must be prepared to take the offensive in the battle being waged by certain organizations and individuals to adulterate the minds of the nation's youth with subversive propaganda.

About 75 per cent of the class of thirty-seven cadets graduated by the New York State Merchant Marine Academy on Sept. 30 have been placed on merchant vessels under American registry, Captain James H. Tomb, superintendent, said today.

For the third successive, day progress marked the deliberations of the American Federation of Labor-Committee for Industrial Organization conference which is seeking a formula for peace that would end the two-year internecine labor war.

Wme. Madeleine La Ferriere, French actress and journalist, better known as Magda de Fontanges, who shot and wounded Count Charles Pineton de Chambrun, former French Ambassador to Italy, arrived yesterday on the Normandie of the French line in the tourist class under the name of Mlle. Magdeleine Coraboeuf.

Premier Camille Chautemps's Cabinet today decided to continue the Paris International Exposition through 1938. Permission of the International Exposition Committee for the continuance was voted Oct. 28.

After one year's selling of Physical Culture shoes in selected areas at a sharply reduced price, $6.50 as against former quotations of $10 to $12.50, the company will expand to a national basis for the Spring season, L. A. Leopold, general manager of the Physical Culture Shoe Company, announced yesterday.

Miss Emlen Davies, daughter of Ambassador Joseph E. Davies of the United States, will begin studies in law tomorrow in the Moscow Juridical Institute, a department of Moscow University. Her purpose is to increase her knowledge of subjects in which she always has been interested and to improve her Russian, in which she has already made considerable progress.

Unless the Pennsylvania Democratic leaders accept Thomas Kennedy, present Lieutenant Governor and secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers, as their candidate for Governor next year, indications are that there will be a third party in the field.
Mrs. Julian Burdick of Pittsburgh has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Martha Anne Burdick, to Thomas Fisher Jr., son of Thomas Fisher of Merlon and the late Mrs. Fisher.
Air-conditioning, an infant industry in point of years but now a giant-in the volume of business it represents, is steadily expanding its sphere of operations.

The Williams football eleven went through a light drill today, working hard only on Doug Stearns's punting, which for the first time this Fall this week when the Purple beat Wesleyan, 190 on Saturday. In preparation for the final game of the season with Amherst, Coach Caldwell put his squad through signal practice, developing several new plays which will be utilized in the fifty-second encounter in which Williams has faced the Jeffs.

Traffic accidents, deaths and injuries continued to decline last week compared with the corresponding period of last year, the report of the Safety Bureau of the Police Department showed yesterday. Similar declines were reported in the figures covering the week-ends.

Including posing for press photographers with American Ambassador Jefferson Caffery at the American Embassy at noon today, the American women composing the People's Mandate "Flying Caravan" had a busy day making the official rounds. They visited President Getulio Vargas, visited the Foreign Office, addressed a women's club and attended a night reception given by Mr. Caffery.

Ross McMahon, 47-year-old World War veteran of 346 East Sixty-fifth Street, who a few hours before spent his last 6 cents for food for his wife and child, plunged to death yesterday morning from the roof of the apartment building where he lived. Unknown to McMahon, a Department of Welfare check was in the mail.

The international goodwill congress of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches opened here today with the cooperation of the Massachusetts Council of Churches and the Greater Boston Federation of Churches, representing more than 1,000 clergymen.

The report of the Department of Agriculture issued yesterday putting this year's cotton crop at the record figure of 18,243,000 bales was 250,000 to 400,000 bales larger than the trade had been expecting. Soon after the issuance of the report, the market declined about $1 a bale, but subsequently recovered and final prices were 55 to 60 cents a bale net higher.

Returning yesterday aboard the Normandie after a two-week visit in Loyalist Spain, Representatives Jerry J. O'Connell of Montana and John T. Bernard of Minnesota declared that they would urge upon President Roosevelt the end of the present Neutrality Act provisions as applied to Spain.
Haile Selassie of Ethiopia has decided to sell his large house in Bath because it costs too much to keep up, according to The Daily Telegraph.

Among those who will give luncheons today at Sherry's, before the bridge and bazaar under the auspices of the Convent of Marie Reparatrix for the fund from which Christmas baskets are supplied to the poor, are Mrs. Henry W. Taft, Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont,
A diversified list of businesses was represented by the list of firms comprising yesterday's report of business leasing. The bulk of the leases were for space in the midtown district.

The sixth night at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden attracted a large and brilliant assembly. Titled visitors were among the guests in the boxes. international. military jumpers and thoroughbred hunters added to the spectacular side of the exhibition.

Smiling Ralph Schmidt, 9 years old and blue-eyed and tow-headed, arrived in New York yesterday from San Francisco, en route to Hamburg, Germany, on a 10,000mile journey to Berlin he is making unaccompanied.
Officials of the Union Free School District No. 1 of Islip, N. Y., have invited bankers to submit bids on Nov. 19 for a new issue of $990,000 of school bonds.

The first phase of the epic struggle between Chinese and Japanese forces in the Shanghai area was concluded this morning, when the Chinese armies withdrew from contact with the western area of the International Settlement and abandoned the whole trackage of the Shanghai-Hangchow Railway beyond the borders of the French Concession. The struggle was begun Aug. 13.

The Rev. Dr. Robert George Boville, president and world director of World Association of Daily Vacation Bible Schools at 156 Fifth Avenue, New York, died yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital here at the age of 83. He lived at 2,734 Arlington Avenue in the Spuyten Duyvil section of New York.

Walter Scheiber, Milburn professional, and Dr. E. J. Kempf of St. George's turned in a 69, two strokes better than par, to take first honors in the Long Island P. G. A. amateur-pro competition at the Bethpage State Park golf course today.
The international stock market indices for Nov. 6, with comparisons, are as follows, the basic figure of 100 representing conditions on the last Saturday in 1927:

The wheat Br market showed more buying resistance today, although an accumulation of selling orders over the weekend caused an early drop to another set of low marks for the season. From the low point there was a brisk recovery, and early losses were more than recovered.

Add another feather or two to the cap of the Salzburg Opera Guild. Following up the esprit of its initial performance of "Cosi fan tutte," this visiting company put on last night at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre Rossini's first opera and a farce by the contemporary French composer Jacques Ibert.

Efforts to counteract the policies of druggists who have avoided becoming subject to the Fair Trade Laws by pushing unknown brands were discussed at a meeting yesterday of the Brooklyn Retail Pharmacists Association at the Bossert Hotel, at which George Gottesman, president, presided.

The New York paint companies have stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to discontinue certain misleading representations concerning the germicidal qualities of their products, the commissioner announced today.

Approximately 67,000 hides were sold in the Chicago cash hide market today at prices unchanged from last week, when about 105,000 hides changed hands at 4 to 5 1/2 cents a pound below the levels of the last previous sales three months ago.

The mighty have fallen on tne gridiron-definitely. After the first Saturday in November, the honor roll of major teams which remain undefeated and untied reads: Alabama, Colorado, Montana, Santa Clara, Lafayette.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today in a precedent-setting decision that the Northern States Power Company of Minnesota could not reclassify 275,000 shares of outstanding cumulative preferred stock, $5 series, into a like number of shares of convertible preferred stock, $5 cumulative series.

Women were called for jury duty in Queens County yesterday for the first time. Of two women called in County Court, Long Island City, one was accepted and the other challenged because she had objections to the death penalty.
Paul Spaak announced tonight that he had formed a new Cabinet for Belgium. It is as follows: Premier-Paul Spaak. Foreign Affairs-Senator Hubert Pierlot.
Farm tenancy was described as a "blot on the land, a threat to national stability and a boon to radicalism" at the opening session of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference here today.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden tonight reaffirmed Great Britain's partnership with France in such strong terms that one might have thought he was answering the signing of the anti-Communist pact in Rome Saturday.

Retail demand for foods will be good for the balance of the year and show an upward swing in the Spring, the American institute of Food Distribution, Inc., predicted yesterday in its weekly report on the outlook in the food industry.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's racing stable, consisting of fifteen head, was sold in the paddock at Pimlico this morning for $119,600, the vendue being the most important dispersal of its kind in Maryland turf history.

Harvard spirits reached a high point today when injured players began to come back into line. Quarterback Chief Boston, battered participant in the Princeton contest, was in the backfield again. As a result Coaqh Harlow put Cliff Wilson back at center, where he played in every game except that against the Army. Bobby Stuart, hurt a few weeks ago, was thrust unexpectedly into backfield service.

Admittedly disappointed in the showing of the Rutgers team which lost, 13 to 6, to Lafayette Saturday, Coach Tasker today announced his intention of starting the entire reserve line against Ohio University next Saturday.
Thomas F. Murray, former Democratic leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District, died yesterday afternoon at his home, 619 West 140th Street, after a month's illness, at the age of 72.

Dr. Jesaiah Rosenberg of 910 Riverside Drive, who had written a column on economics and current Jewish affairs for the Jewish newspaper The Day under the name of Karl Vornberg for several years, died last evening in the Beth Israel Hospital of complications following a minor operation. He was born in Kovno, Lithuania, sixty-five years ago.

Albert Sarraut, Director of French North African Affairs, met with the Governors of Tunis, Algeria and Morocco and the Ministers of Colonies, War, Navy and Air today in a secret session which officials said was "chiefly concerned with questions of national defense."

Chaplains of Germany's armed forces are reliably reported to have sent to Hitler petitions asserting that the Reich military strength is being endangered by the government's treatment of the church problem.
Visitors at the annual Brooklyn Auto Show in the 106th Infantry Armory, 1,332 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, saw a film on traffic safety shown yesterday under police auspices.
The administrative committee of the InterAmerican Radio Conference unanimously adopted this afternoon a resolution recognizing the sovereign right of every nation to use every broadcasting channel.

Major Gen. James Douglas McLachlan, British military attache at Washington, 1911-12 and 1917-19, died yesterday at the age of 68. On his second tour of duty in the United States he received the Distinguished Service Medal, which came after he had been severely wounded.

Gertrude Kingston, well-known actress, who was prominently associated with Henry Irving and Beerbohm Tree at the height of their popularity, died in a London nursing home today. Besides making a success on the stage, she was a painter and writer.

Harry Strauss, known in the underworld as "Pittsburgh Phil," was booked on a charge of homicide last night at the Empire Boulevard police station in Brooklyn after a 75-year-old woman had been killed by an automobile he was driving.

Contact work was omitted today by the Yale players who faced Brown last Saturday, but they held a signal drill which stressed the aerial strategy for the Princeton contest this week. Head Coach Pond told them to be ready for heavy scrimmaging tomorrow.

Frederick Donaghey, former dramatic critic of The Chicago Tribune, and widely known in the theatrical world, died suddenly late today in a dentist's chair. Mr. Donaghey, who was 68 years old, had been suffering from a heart ailment.

Thomas E. Dewey's "first real vacation in five years" began as a busman's holiday this morning when he and Bermuda's Commissioner of Police, Ivor Stourton, exchanged notes on the police forces of New York City and Bermuda.
Seven firemen were overcome by smoke last night while fighting a stubborn cellar blaze in the basement of the four-story building at 143 Columbus Avenue, at the corner of Sixty-sixth Street.

Associate Justice Black aligned himself with the three other liberals of the Supreme Court today in opposing a majority of five who voted against Federal taxation of bonuses given to employes of the Universal Oil Products Company.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will not pay its customary visits to the Brooklyn Academy of Music this season, it was announced yesterday. The Metropolitan had given occasional Tuesday night performances in Brooklyn since 1908.

Mrs. Caroline Wyville Robertson of Washington, D. C., was married to Colonel Frank Van Vleck, United States Army, retired, also of Washington, this afternoon at the Highland Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Dr. Peter H. Pleune performed the ceremony.
New York State will not have a candidate for first vice president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs when the triennial convention meets in Kansas City in July.

The National Maritime Union, an affiliate of the C. I. O., has been designated as the spokesman of the crews of the Baltimore Mail Steamship Company and the Richfield Oil Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board.

Plans for altering the former Elks clubhouse at 102-14 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, at a cost of about $800,000, were filed yesterday. The twelve-story structure, which will be used as the main administrative office of the Board of Education, was acquired by the city in November, 1936.

A strong opposition party is "absolutely necessary" under our system of government, Postmaster General Farley declared last night in a radio address made here on the National Radio Forum program over a coast-to-coast network of the National Broadcasting Company.

A dummy scrimmage featuring forward passes opened the Brown preparation for the Holy Cross game today. Brown failed to complete a pass against Yale and the coaches are trying to correct the weakness in the air attack.
Mr. and Mrs. Horace G. Reed will give a dinner dance on Christmas night in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Anne B. Reed.

Miss Marjorie Lee Judd, daughter of Mrs. Mortimer N. Judd of this city, was married to Paul Allan Luchini, son of Joseph S. G. Luchini of Boston, in St. Mary's Church here this morning by the Rev. Raymond J. Clabby of Groton, Conn.

Forward-passing in the National Football League is 1 per cent better than last season, when all clubs totaled 36 per cent for a new record in effectiveness in that department, statistics released yesterday show. Three teams have completed 42 per cent of their aerials. The League record is 41 per cent.

The George Putnam Fund. of Boston, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement covering an issue of 250,000 shares of beneficial interest to be sold at market for $3,877,500, the proceeds to be used for investment, according to an announcement today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.

The New York Curb Exchange issued yesterday a revised list of companies in bankruptcy, receivership or under Bankruptcy Act reorganization which have securities listed in its market. The list showed no fully listed bonds.
The Loyalist Government is fighting with its back to the wall against Spanish fascism, and no doubt it feels a deep and a natural gratitude for the

Two judges of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals indicated during an appeal argument today that they would not interfere with a lower court order enjoining the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission from holding -public hearings on Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company valuations for the purpose of fixing the fare.

There's something about a soldier! There must be something about a soldier, judging from the way people are clamoring for tickets for the Army-Notre Dame game at the Yankee Stadium in New York Saturday and the age-old Army-Navy battle in the Municipal Stadium at Philadelphia three weeks hence.

The board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History paid tribute at its Fall meeting last night to the late Ogden L. Mills, for many years a board member. Junius S. Morgan was elected chairman of the auditing committee, a post held by Mr. Mills. John D. Rockefeller 3d was chosen for the vacancy on the executive committee left by the death of Mr. Mills.

The 1,376 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,264,366,806 par value as of Nov. 1, had a total market value of $42,591,139,774, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday.

Continuing its domination of the Class B squash field, the Princeton Club, undefeated 1936-37 champion of the metropolitan team league, registered its second straight triumph of the season yesterday by vanquishing the Yale Club, 4 to 1, on the latter's courts.
James Middleton, Yale '79, publisher and author of educational works died last night at his home in West Haven at the age of 87.

Three engineers identified with the designing of New York City's new $272,000,000 Delaware Aqueduct urged Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief here today not to interfere with construction work at the shaft beside Palmer Avenue in Lawrence Park West, Yonkers.

The Treasury's 127-day bills offered on Friday were sold today at an average interest rate of 0.201, compared with an average of 0.226 for the last issue, sold on Oct. 29, and 0.261 for the preceding issue, Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight.
The three-power anti-Communist pact signed in Rome on Saturday is of a much more far-reaching and practical nature than was generally expected.
Dr. Percy Willard Roberts, wellknown New York orthopedic surgeon, died suddenly yesterday at the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled. His age was 70. Dr.
Turpentine firm; 26 3/4c; sales 99 barrels; receipts 200 barrels; shipments 360 barrels; stock 39,382 barrels. Resin steady; sales 380; receipts 912; shipments 415; stock 77,132.

Francis de Croisset, noted playwright, died this afternoon in the American Hospital at Neuilly. His age was 60. Born and educated in Brussels, Belgium, he passed the greater part of his life in France, where he wrote most of his stage successes either singly or in collaboration with Robert de Flers.

The fiftieth wedding anniversary of Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Doyle of 2,700 Creston Avenue, the Bronx, will be observed this morning at a solemn high mass of thanksgiving in the Church of Our Lady of Mercy, the Bronx, at which their son, the Rev. Francis X. Doyle, rector of St. Patrick's Church, Verplanck, N. Y., will be the celebrant.

Mounted policemen and other policemen at Wallkill prison and the Woodbourne Institution for Defective Delinquents come under Section 178 of the Labor Law, which provides an eight-hour day for certain State employes, according to a ruling issued today by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.

Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia Club, the only seeded player in action yesterday in the Princetbn Club's eighteenth annual invitation squash tennis tournament, successfully negotiated the second round by defeating Joseph Larocque Jr., of the Harvard Club.

Julius Streicher, Nazi anti-Semitic leader, opened the exposition on "The Eternal Jew" here today with the statement that Jews are "children of the devil" and with a threat to "bring to an end the reputation of eternal life possessed by this race of world criminals."
