Laxity in having fire extinguishers recharged in the New York County Jail is the chief fault found with that nonfireproof building by John L. Schoenfeld, Commissioner of Correction, in his report of conditions discovered on a recent inspection.

Beginning an investigation of the plan for reorganizing the Missouri Pacific Railroad, now pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce disclosed for the record today that the late O. P. Van Sweringen had submitted no less than nine plans for the reorganization of that system.

Acquisition of the capital stock of the Waterbury Tool Company, Waterbury, Conn., and Vickers, Inc., Detroit, Mich., sole source-of supply of certain equipment of the United States Navy, by the Sperry Corporation, New York City, has a tendency to create a monopoly by lessening competition, the Federal Trade Commission charged in a complaint filed today.

Political observers here considered it unlikely today that Republican leaders would demand a recount in the election of United States Senator A. Harry Moore to the governorship of New Jersey over State Senator Lester H. Clee by a plurality of 44,630 votes.

Several Latin-American countries have expressed a hope that the United States would lease to them over-age destroyers since tentative arrangements of that character were made in the case of Brazil last Summer.

The buying power of farm families in 1938 will be less than it was in 1937 because of lower income from the sale of farm products and increased production expenses, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics and the Bureau of Home Economics predicted in a joint report issued today.

The Gothic towers of the Hradschin, ancient royal castle, which for many centuries were symbols of the Bohemian Crown of St. Wenceslaus, today are symbols of the last remaining democracy in Central Europe.

Duquesne Light Company-Twelve months to Sept. 30: Net income, after expenses, $10,616,771, comparing with $10,627,170 in the preceding period; gross revenues were $30,878,590, against $26,868,569 in the year to Sept. 30, 1938.

Budget increases aggregating $2,875,778 for 1938 were requested today by Westchester County department heads in filing their annual operating estimates with the Board of Supervisors here. The appropriations for this year were $15,221,017.

The death of Detective Arthur J. De Marrais, 41 years old, on Sunday night soon after he had been operated on for bite wounds inflicted in a struggle with a prisoner who unsuccessfully attempted to escape, was due to "strangulation brought about by foreign substances in the throat," according to an autopsy report made public yesterday by Kings County Medical Examiner Manuel E. Marten.
Mrs. Anna Pierson McDougall of 5 Duryea Road, author and former missionary in Papua, died here last night in Mountainside Hospital, where she had undergone an operation on Oct. 20. Her age was 68.

An exhibition called "Paintings for Paris" opened with a reception and preview last evening at the Museum of Modern Art, 14 West Forty-ninth Street, where, beginning today, it may be viewed by the public. The paintings will remain through Dec. 13.
The 171st anniversary of the granting of the original charter of Rutgers University will be observed tomorrow and Wednesday by undergraduates and alumni groups.

Importers of silk table covers were advised yesterday that country of origin -markings on such goods hereafter must be made either by stamping the fabric itself or by means of labels sewn to the covers.
Listed bonds of virtually all descriptions were forced sharply lower yesterday in relatively light trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

In a brief filed with the War Department today, the Newark Chamber of Commerce declared potential tonnage had not been proved to the extent of justifying the expense of reconstructing the Delaware and Raritan Canal as a Federal project.

William (Wolfie) Goldis and Sam Schorr, officials of Local 138 of the Teamsters Union, who had been drawing salaries from the union while in jail since their conviction in one of Thomas E. Dewey's racket prosecutions, 'have been expelled from the union and dropped from its payroll, it became known yesterday.

To the strains of "God Save the King," some 12,000 spectators stood in Madison Square Garden last night to honor Lieutenant Marshall Cleland of the Canadian Army team as he received the trophy for winning the international jumping competition, leading event of the sixth evening session of the National Horse Show.

The Commerce Department has been advised that the Mexican Government will strictly enforce after Jan. 1, 1938, provisions of the 1928 Weights and Measures Regulations, which prohibit the use of any other than the metric system.

United States SENIOR VETERINARIAN (ANIMAL DISEASE RESEARCH), $4,600 a year, bureau of animal industry, Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file not later than Dec. 6, if received from States other than those named below. Dec. 9, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada. New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.

Italo-Russian relations entered a delicate phase today when the Russian Ambassador called on Foreign Minister Galeazzo Ciano and officially served notice on him that the Soviet Government looked on the anti-Communist pact signed by Italy, Germany and Japan on Saturday as an unfriendly action.

The battered first team and a few of the top-ranking replacements were excused from practice yesterday as coach Lou Little drilled the Columbia reserves in a contact scrimmage at Baker Field. The Lions will meet Syracuse Saturday in their first home apperance in three weeks.

Martin Mager, a former Democratic leader in Queens, died in Mary Immaculate Hospital, Jamaica, yesterday, morning after an illness of a month. His age was 79. Mr. Mager's home was at 130-01 Hillside Avenue, Richmond Hill.

Senator William H. King, Utah Democrat, said on his return to the capital today that he opposed much of President Roosevelt's program of special session legislation. He said he "supposed" he would be one of the "no" men of the session, which convenes next Monday. Of the President's program, the Utah veteran had this to say:
Gross assets, $3,600; net, $3,511. To husband, Domenico Coniglio. Chief assets, real estate. $3,600. Anthony R. D'Andrea, attorney, 16 Court St.

Under the chairmanship of Miss Dorothy Butler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Butler, the debutante committee aiding plans for the Children's Aid Society's benefit opera performance next month will hold its first meeting on Thursday at the home of Mrs. E. Halsey Malone. 1 East End Avenue.
The Spanish Loyalist press, apparently under suggestion, today warns all its readers that hard days are ahead for Madrid.

Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia moved into a tie tonight with the defending champion, Ralph Greenleaf, for first place in the world championship pocket billiard tournament by defeating Marcel Camp of Detroit, 125 to 14, in eleven innings.

The locust plague that has afflicted Nicaragua for several months, destroying half the cotton, corn, rice and bean crops, received a setback today when millions of sea gulls flew in from the Pacific Ocean and began eating the locusts.

Mrs. S. Stanwood Menken will give a tea this afternoon at the Ambassador at which plans will be formulated for the dinner dance to be held on Dec. 17 at the WaldorfAstoria in memory of Miss Lila Agnew Stewart, for many years organizer of pageants and balls in behalf of various charity organizations.

Assurance that information furnished by the unemployed in next week's national census of those in need of work could not be used by the Federal Government to check on illegal entry, citizenship or tax matters was given yesterday by Robert K. Straus, chairman of Mayor La Guardia's cooperating committee.

Theakston de Coppet, philanthropist, former member and chairman of the New York Stock Exchange and clubman, died suddenly today at his home on Kingstowne Road here. He was 61 years old. Funeral services will be held at the home Wednesday afternoon with burial in New York.
Coach Carl Snavely started putting the finishing touches on his Cornell offensive for Saturday's encounter with the Dartmouth Indians at Hanover in a long workout today.
Peace negotiations between A. F. L. and C. I. O. are making headway. It is stated that President Roosevelt's influence is being strongly exerted to bring about a settlement.

The address of Herbet Hoover at the Colby College centennial memorial to Elijah Parish Lovejoy was as follows: On this day 100 years ago Elijah Parish Lovejoy, a graduate of this college, was killed while defending free speech and free press in the United States.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania due today from England and France includes Margaret Countess of Suffolk and Berkshire, Sir Karl and Lady Knudsen, Lady Ward, George Arliss, the actor, and Mrs. Arliss; Mackenzie Ward, English actor; John C. Newman, D. A. Campbell, Mr. and Mrs. Harden Church, Mrs. John Hubbard and Mrs. Francis Bliss and Miss Enid Bliss.

While the Federal Government in Washington posted rewards for information leading to the arrest of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, who jumped bail and disappeared after they had each been sentenced to serve two years in jail, fifty of their co-defendants in a Sherman anti-trust case pleaded guilty here yesterday in Federal court.

Seven members of the staff of Thomas E. Dewey, special Supreme Court prosecutor and District Attorney-elect, made a surprise visit late yesterday afternoon to the quarters of District Attorney William C. Dodge at Center and White Streets.

Consumers will understand the difficulties to be overcome in labeling rayon fabrics, and these difficulties will have to be worked out in a spirit of fair play and cooperation, so that no undue hardship will be suffered by manufacturer, retailer or consumer, Miss Alice L. Edwards, chairman of the committee on standards for consumer goods of the American Home Economics Association, declared in a statement issued yesterday.

Finance Minister Souza Costa said tonight that President Getulio Vargas would send to Congress tomorrow a message setting forth Brazil's new-coffee policy and naming the new export tax, asking immediate passage.

In a decision which is expected to be appealed to the Supreme Court three judges of the Federal Circuit Court of-Appeals unanimously upheld yesterday Federal Judge Julian W. Mack in the letter's ruling against the Electric Bond and Share Company's attempt to test the validity of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Pierre Monteux, French conductor, arrived yesterday on the French liner Normandie to conduct the newly organized National Broadcasting Symphony orchestra. He said American taste was rapidly turning to symnphonic music, and that the new radio series of fulllength concerts would give even greater impetus to the turn.

Seven Manhattan harriers, coming over the finish line in a prearranged dead heat, encountered no difficulty in capturing the metropolitan intercollegiate cross-country championship for their team as the Jaspers won for the fifth successive year at Van Cortlandt Park.

The partnership of Miller Goldhammer, architects, has been dissolved and George G. Miller has opened his own office in 67 West Forty-fourth Street. Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc., report that the remodeled house at 4 East Ninety-fourth Street is fully rented.

Use of this city's foreign trade zone as a place for the storage and cvtransshipment of automobiles imported from Europe for sale in Central America, the United States and Canada, is contemplated by the Fiat-Advance Corporation of Atlanta, Ga., according to reports here yesterday.

Though it was the World War that broke the hold of the German coal-tar chemical cartel on a dozen American industries, ranging from textiles to books, leather to banknotes, drugs to photographic developers, chemists in particular have reason to cherish the memory of Francis P. Garvan.

Rhode Island State College successfully defended its varsity team title in the twenty-fifth annual New England intercollegiate cross-country run at Franklin Park today, scoring 50 points to 68 for Tufts, the runnerup. While the team honors went to Rhode Island in both the varsity and freshman races, the individual honors were captured by runners from Maine arid New Hampshire.
More than 2,000 members of the New York Chapter of Hadassah attended a reception yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that marked the opening of the chapter's new membership drive.
Secretary Perkins spoke the other night at Bridgeport about discrimination against middle-aged wageearners,

James E. Friel has been elected to the board of directors of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams Limited. Mr. Friel continues as vice president and treasurer of the subsidiary companies of Distillers CorporationSeagrams Limited in the United States, which position he has held since 1934.

Justice Black voted against the government in one of the cases decided today by the Supreme Court. He joined with his eight colleagues in holding that jig-saw puzzles are not a game and that the government therefore cannot levy a game tax on them.

Interpretation by Oswald Tower, editor of Spalding's basketball guide, of changes in the rules featured the annual meeting of basketball coaches and officials at the Hotel McAlpin last night. About 400 persons attended.

A "Prevue of 1938 Fashions" will be shown today at a special luncheon and pageant to be given in the Caprice Room of the Weylin as a benefit for the Visiting Nurses Service of the Henry Street Settlement.

The thirty-five-story office building comprising the entire block front on the north side of Pearl Street between Platt and John Streets and known as 225-35 Pearl Street was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.

Mrs. George E. Stringfellow of Montclair gave a luncheon at the Montclair Golf Club today for members of the Southern Society of the Oranges. Mrs. Harold G. Hoffman, wife of the Governor of New Jersey; Mrs. Richard C. McMullen, wife of the Governor of Delaware; Mrs. Edward E. Hughes of West Orange and Baroness Winspeare of Montclair and Italy were guests of honor.

The Duke of Windsor today swung into a routine of sports which he planned to occupy the time left empty by the postponement of his tour of the United States. He donned a heavy gray suit and in a thick fog, reminiscent of the British Isles he once ruled, went out for a round of golf on the Saint Cloud course, one of the toughest in France. The Duchess remained at their hotel.

Cost of program development, cost of transmission and, most important of all, the expense of the receiver to the man who has to buy one to 'see and hear programs, are the things that keep television from developing with tremendous strides, but it is here, even if it is not ready for widespread use, H. H. Beverage, president, today told the Institute of Radio Engineers and Manufacturers Association.

The Syracuse varsity football squad had a virtual holiday today as preparations were begun by Coach Ossio Solem for the contest with Columbia in New York Saturday. Limbering up exercises and a game of touch football was the only physical work done.

Major Gen. Septimus J. A. Denison, aide de camp to the Earl of Aberdeen during his term as Governor General of Canada and during the South African War A. D. C. to Field Marshal Earl Roberts, died here today at the age of 78. He was A. D. C.

October sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States and Canada and shipments overseas totaled 166,939, compared with 90,764 a year ago, a gain of 84 per cent. This is the highest for the month on record, and compares to a previous high of 128,459 in October, 1927. In September sales were 32,317.
The American Federation of Labor reported today that employment among its members dropped last month, the first October drop since 1931.

Various ways of inducing private capital into a quick campaign of industrial construction as a major stroke toward ending the business recession were discussed by President Roosevelt with administration economists this afternoon in a four-hour conference at the White House.

Unofficial sources reported today that at least 2,700 Haitians, mostly women and children, had been killed in a series of attacks attributed to soldiers and civilians of the Dominican Republic since Oct. 5.

Jacques Stern, formerly French Minister of Colonies, who will sail for France on the Normandie tomorrow upon the conclusion of several weeks' study of American financial and economic conditions, said yesterday that "it seems unquestionable that business is slowing down in the United States, but one has no right to speak of a crisis yet."

The Department of Agriculture reported today that this year's cotton crop, based on conditions as of Nov. 1, would amount to 18,243,000 bales of 500 pounds each. This would be the largest crop in the history of the nation.

Among those reported yesterday as having signed contracts for residential space was Vinton Freedley, theatrical producer, who leased an apartment of twelve rooms at 39 East Seventy-ninth Street. Culver, Hollyday Co., brokers, negotiated the lease. Details of other rentals follow:
Gilbert Ross, violinist, and Andrew C. Haigh, pianist, appeared in a joint recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. They have given programs on the same stage individually in past seasons.
A contribution of $56,000 from Mrs. Kate Macy Ladd to the United Hospital Campaign was announced yesterday by-John W. Davis, chairman of the drive.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Nov. 6 unless specified: At Norfolk Yard, Sequoia, Nov. 8, Kewaydin.
John F. Sinnott Jr., Newark ,Postmaster, traveled 351 miles in an airplane today to promote interest in New Jersey Air Mail ,Week, which will be observed Nov. 15 to 20.

The Lincoln Building and Loan Association of Jersey City sold to Abraham Goldberg the sixteen-family flat at 58-60 Avenue B, Bayonne, for $46,500. The building is on a plot 37 1/2 by 100 feet. The new owner gave back in part payment a purchase money mortgage for $38,000 at 6 per cent.

Funeral services for Francis Patrick Garvan, who died at his home, 740 Park Avenue, Sunday at the age of 62, will be held on Wednesday. A solemn high requiem mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10 A. M. will be followed by a private funeral. The Rev. Patrick F. Seely,

Mrs. John Henry Hammond, president of the Home Thrift Association, reported yesterday afternoon at the association's annual meeting that both its day and evening schedules had been expanded in the last year and that its scope in the coming year would be greatly increased by the recent opening of its new building at 350 East Eighty-eighth Street.

Lord Beaverbrook, British publisher, owner of The London Daily Express and other newspapers and periodicals, arrived yesterday on the French Liner Normandie on his way to spend the Winter in Jamaica. He will remain in New York for a few days and then go by plane to Kingston.
GENERAL VON STEUBEN, by John McAuley Palmer (Yale, $4). A biography. THESE AMAZING ELECTRONS, by Raymond F. Yates (Macmillan, $3.75). A popular exposition.

Captain Thomas Frank Gates, well known to thousands of transatlantic travelers as the "laughing skipper" who commanded the Minnetonka until his retirement in 1933, died today at his home after a brief illness at the age of 74.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that hearings on the petition filed last week by several railroads for a horizontal 15 per cent rail-freight increase and a half-cent-a-mile rise for coach passengers in the East would be opened here on Nov. 29.

Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, denounced the strike at The Brooklyn Daily Eagle yesterday as an attempt by the American Newspaper Guild to obtain "absolute dictation" over the newspaper through vilification of its publisher and intimidation of employes, advertisers t and readers.

Henry T. Berry, controller of the Interborough Rapid Transit Corporation, testifying yesterday in the hearings before Federal Judge Julian W. Mack on the application by the I. R. T. receiver for disaffirmance of the lease on the elevated lines, said that operating revenues of the elevated lines for June, 1937, had dropped to a total gross of $849,000, or $94,000 less than in June, 1936.

Colonel Francois de la Rocque, leader of the French Social party and one-time hope of Nationalist and Fascist elements in France, was sentenced today by a correctional court in Lyons to pay a 200-franc fine and 3,000 francs damages with costs to his former lieutenant, Joseph Pozzo di Borgo, who had brought suit for defamation.

The Foreign Office disclosed today that Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos had completed plans to visit Poland and the Little Entente nations to discuss the effects of the anti-Communist pact signed at Rome Saturday.

Movements of July livestock in the Chicago markets today. as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 23,000, including 6,000 directs. Hogs, from 200 pounds down and packing sows were 10-15 cents lower; heavier hogs 15-25 cents lower, but mostly 15-20 cents lower than Friday's average. Top, $9.55;

Many phases of Federal and State taxation were covered by rulings handed down today by the Supreme Court, which upheld in one of these the right of Virginia to tax an outof-the-State corporation for the privilege of -doing business within the State.

Problems created for city housing authorities by the new national public housing program are among the topics listed for discussion and possible action by the housing administrators and experts who are expected to attend the conference of the National Association of Housing Officials in Cleveland next week.

The Danzig Diet, which is now more than two-thirds Nazi, this afternoon celebrated the disappearance of all opposition parties by voting amnesty for all prisoners sentenced to less than a year. Of nearly eighty leaders sentenced for anti-Nazi activities, however, only one-third are in that category.

Henry J. Vander Eb of Fernbel Lane has announced plans for the marriage of his daughter, Miss MarJorie Vander Eb, to T. Norman Willcox of Schenectady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Byron C. Willcox of Hasbrouck Heights, N. J.

THE name of von Steuben is among the most honored in our annals, and nearly every schoolboy knows who he was. Or thinks he knows. There is at least one Steubenville on the American map, and a Steuben State Memorial Park. Not only a chain of restaurants commemorates his fame but also a Society and a series of busts, monuments and portraits.

THE new head man or "top kick" in Eastern, intercollegiate athletics is a fellow who is being jovially addressed by companions as "Judge Landis," the reference being to the lordly power he will wield and not to his taste in hats, the way he wears his hair or the magnitude of his salary.

Dr. Edgar Calvin Seibert of this city, former president of the local Board of Education and descendant of a historic family, died yesterday of a heart ailment in St. Mary's Hospital here after a brief illness. His age was 65.

At the afternoon session of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center yesterday, four well-known authors told how they happened to write their books. In the evening, three more told how they happened to wander about the world in the process.

Arriving yesterday on the Narmandie was Jed Harris, back from a business trip to London and with a sheaf of plans that he will announce in detail today. It can be said now, however, that there is a prospect of two Harris shows opening on Broadway during Christmas week. One is "A Doll's House,"

A manikin committee composed of several debutantes of the season will participate in a fur and hat fashion show to be given tonight at Mon Paris for the benefit of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

At the White House yesterday President Roosevelt discussed the present business situation with several of his advisers. One school of official opinion is said to believe that the recession has now' gone so far, particularly in the case of steel and some of the other heavy industries, that it has become essential for the Government to reverse its financial policy.

The interest of the late Raymond E. Streit in H. T. Carey Co. ceased on Nov. 5. The New York Stock Exchange has been notified that George Putnam plans to retire from Townsend, Anthony Tyson on Nov. 20.

The new firm of Carrick Evans has four titles on its first list, which will be ready in January; "Two Wars and More to Come," by Herbert L. Matthews, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Spain; "The Lady and the Panda," by Ruth Harkness; "Lloyd's: The Gentlemen at the Coffee House," by Ralph Straus, and "The Jester's Reign," a novel, by Boyne Grainger.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 5: CAPTAIN Giffen, R. C., the Boise, to the Savannah and in command when commissioned.

Walter Hammond, England's greatest all-round cricketer of modern times, is leaving professional ranks and next season will play as an amateur for Gloucestershire. It is thought likely that Hammond will be seriously considered as England's captain against Australia next year.

Among the realty holdings of closed national banks in New Jersey sold at auction Saturday at the Lawyers Building, Union City, N. J., in the sale conducted by Joseph P. Day, was the six-story bank and office building at 147 Summit Avenue, Union City.

Orchardton Duce of Wingan, a black Labrador, owned by Jay F. Carlisle and handled by David D. Elliott, won the derby stake over the Shinnecock Hills today in the seventh annual field trial of the Labrador Retriever Club. The 14month-old dog was sired by Orchardton Donald and his dam was Mona of Ammurrness. Weather conditions were ideal and the covert for the trials was perfect.
Leading football scorers found the going rough last week-end, but Byron (Whizzer) White of Colorado provided the big exception, according to The Associated Press.

L. J. Van Laeys, general manager of The Wilkes-Barre Record, announced today that publication was being resumed, through a tentative agreement signed today with striking news room employes. The strike wags called last Tuesday night by the American Newspaper Guild unit here.

Several homes on Long Island were reported yesterday as having been sold. At Mineola, the one-family dwelling at 8 Droesch Place was sold by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston to Paul E. Bauer. Coleman Perlstein, attorneys, represented the sellers.

How to stimulate purchasing power once again, but this time without affecting the current.budget adversely, has become the object of a determined search in the capital. Industrial slumps and layoffs have followed the recent collapse of stock prices, and once more the pumpprimers have come to the fore with various suggestions in their particular economic field.
The European flight from the dollar, which had been set in motion last week by strong rumors abroad of an impending further devaluation of the dollar, gained momentum yesterday.
Arthur David Condon, a native of New York, who was appointed to the Bureau of Internal Revenue by President Roosevelt in 1934, was admitted to practice before the Supreme Court today.
A new top price of $5.50 for Rose Bowl football tickets, fixed by the Pacific Coast Conference, was announced today, and the New Year's game is expected to set a new gatereceipt record as a result.

Plans for the benefit performance of "Tristan and Isolde" on Dec. 10 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the Neighborhood Music School were discussed at a meeting and tea held yesterday at the school, 238 East 105th Street, at which Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford, chairman of the executive committee for the benefit, and Mrs. Otto H. Kahn, president of the school's board of trustees, presided.

Steve (Crusher) Casey, 225, Ireland, threw Hans Schnabel, 220, Berlin, in 36:45 of the feature wrestling match before 2,500 at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night. The winner employed a body slam in pinning his rival to the mat.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Oscar B. Frazer, Harold L. Warner, George D. Yeomans and William H. Hotchkiss of New York were admitted to practice today and the follow ing proceedings were had:

Mrs. Mary A. Donoghue, widow of Joseph Donoghue and sister of Public Works Commissioner John J. Halleran of Queens, died last night at her home, 36-35 Bowne Street, Flushing, after an illness of eleven months of heart disease.

J. R. Page, 68, victim of a shooting that brought a charge of assault with intent to kill against Mrs. J. C. Kelly, 66, mother of Governor Rivers of Georgia, suggested today that the chrage might be dropped.
Hernry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, outlined to farmers of the Middle West today his program for an ever-normal corn granary to prevent disturbance of economic stabilization by droughts.

Swiss measures to meet the "hot money" problem were explained by Dr. Gottlieb Bachmann, Governor of the Swiss National Bank, to his colleagues on the board of the Bank for International Settlements, who were here yesterday and today for its monthly meeting.

The Federal Government will conclude its gasoline price-fixing case against twenty-three oil companies, three market publications and forty-six individuals, prosecuting attorneys said today, with presentation on Wednesday of price tabulations by government accountants.

Institutions of higher learning fail to give their students a proper start in life because their "cynical precepts" teach their undergraduates to distrust the "perfect lessons they learned at their mother's knee," the Most Rev. James E. Kearney, Bishop-elect of Rochester, N. Y., declared here today at the fifteenth annual investiture of the College of Our Lady of Good Counsel.

The Manhattan College football team, bruised and battered in their victory over Detroit, was given a day of rest yesterday by Coach Chick Meehan. Today intensive preparations will be begun for Saturday's game with North Carolina State at Ebbets Field.

Estate, about $10,000. To Virginia Keeling, granddaughter, 1,241 Lexington Ave., temporary estate in $6,600, principal at 21; Dorothy F. Murphy, granddaughter, 423 W. 23d St., about $1,600; Edward M. Blackburn, grandson, P. O. Box 81, Ardsley-on-Hudson, N. Y.. about $1,600; Theresa A. Becker, daughter, executrix, 1.241 Lexington Ave. about $3,200.

Northern railroads have agreed to slash their freight rates on soft coal from Pennsylvania to New England, guaranteeing an increase of 1,000,000 tons annually to the State's Vast bituminous fields, it was officially disclosed today.

A drastically cut version of "Spanish Earth," in which Ernest Hemingway supplies a commentary on a film showing the suffering in Loyalist Spain, was finally permitted to be shown at a West End motion picture theatre tonight.
The Navy team started special preparations for the Army game when it scrimmaged today against a combination drilled in the formations of the,West Point eleven.

Arriving on the Normandie yesterday were fifty-one paintings and drawings by the French artist Toulouse-Lautrec that will be seen for the first time in this country. One of the paintings comes from the Louvre in Paris and another from the Petit Palais, also in Paris, but the bulk of the work comes from the museum at Albi, France.

While fully in accord with the steps being taken by retailers to reduce unwieldy inventories, some merchandisers here are convinced that the more store stocks are cut the sharper will be the rebound when the current unsettlement wears itself out.

Following a further sharp break on the London Metal Exchange, the price of copper in the export market yesterday declined to 9.65 cents a pound c.i.f. the European base. ports, the lowest level in more than a year.

Plans for the transfer of existing branch offices to new and larger quarters were announced yesterday by two large local banks, the Manufacturers Trust Company and the Public National Bank and Trust Company.

Testimony that Dana Wallace, former District Attorney of Queens County, had directed that payments on a percentage basis be made to Chauncey Holcombe for investigative services in connection with negligence actions was offered yesterday at the hearing into charges of unprofessional conduct filed by the Queens County Bar Association against Mr. Wallace and two former law associates, Abraham M. and H. Irwin Brownstein, brothers.

"New Historical Novels of Distinction," Eleanor Markell, Hotel Plaza, 11 A. M. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Design in Textiles," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; the Collection of Armor (General Tour), noon; Motion Pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Color in Chinese Porcelain," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Egypt: Individuals of the Middle Kingdom," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 4 P. M.

The Fort Jay eleven and the New York Football Giants will hold a joint practice workout at Governors Island this afternoon in preparation for important battles Sunday, when the soldiers will clash with the Fort Hoyle combination of Maryland for the army's First Division championship at Ebbets Field and the Giants will engage the Detroit Lions at the Polo Grounds.

Sentences to Sing Sing were imposed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Wallace on two men who had pleaded guilty to the holdup of an organizer for the A. F. of L. in the Plymouth Hotel, in West Forty-ninth Street, last Aug. 9, to obtain papers, they asserted, for a rival C. I. O. union.

America's only living ex-President paid tribute to a pioneer champion of free speech today when Herbert Hoover addressed a special convocation of Colby College on "Free Speech and Free Press" on the 100th anniversary of the martyrdom of Elijah Parish Lovejoy.

The General Sessions trial of Robert- Edward Edmondson, elderly pamphleteer, accused of criminal libels on Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor; Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College and the Jewish religion was set yesterday for next Monday before Judge James G. Wallace and a jury.

Former Mayor Leo D. Santangelo testified today that James H. Rand Jr. said that he "feared trouble" at his Middletown typewriter factory on the day the government asserts the industrialist and Pearl L. Bergoff violated the Byrnes Act by importing strikebreakers to the Connecticut city.

Oscar Kay, 47, who was tied to a free and whipped by a girl because of a slanderous remark attributed to him, was convicted of criminal libel today before Judge J. Arthur Charbonnet and will be sentenced Friday. Alfred Willis,

Two boys, one 5 years old, the other 10, confessed today to starting the three-alarm fire at the freight station of the Erie Railroad in Newark on Oct.' 19 that caused $25,000 in damage, Police Commissioner George Kaas announced.

A sealed copy of "The Mint," a book written by the late T. E. Lawrence (Lawrence of Arabia), was taken from a vault in the Nassau County Trust Company here this morning and carried by airplane to Boston by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, vice president of the DoubledayDoran Publishing Company of Garden City.

Indication that the Supreme Court will not pass upon the legality of the sit-down strike was given today when the justices directed the members of the Full Fashioned Hosiery Workers to show cause why their appeal against the Apex Hosiery Company of Philadelphia should not be dismissed as a moot question.
New York has seen the building of so many and such stupendous vehicular bridges and tunnels in recent years that we have grown a little apathetic to these marvels.

The Jeptha Abbott Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution will give its fourth annual dinner dance in aid of Philadelphia charities and underprivileged mountain children of the Tamassee and Kate Duncan Smith Schools on Nov. 19 in the ballroom of the Bellevue-Stratford.

Secretary Swanson today sent to Major Gen. Thomas Holcomb, commandant of the Marine Corps, a statement to be read Wednesday, the 162d anniversary of the establishment of the corps. The statement said:
They nailed the S. R. O. sign today outside the office at Pitt Stadium where tickets have been on sale for the Pitt-Nebraska football game Saturday.

The game with Williams Saturday took heavy toll of the Wesleyan football squad. Daddario, star quarterback, sustained a dislocated shoulder which will keep him out for the rest of the season. The only first string backs who will be available Saturday for the Rochester game are Holzer, Sonstroem, Cotter, Murphy and Mues.

Mayor La Guardia expressed regret yesterday when he accepted the resignation of Corporation Counsel Paul Windels and announced that William C. Chanler, first assistant Corporation Counsel, would be promoted to head the Law Department.
A consolidated net profit of $375,443 for the first nine months of 1937 was reported yesterday by C. L. Egtvedt. president of the Boeing Airplane Company.

Today's major events include the season's first appearance here this season of Leopold Stokowski, directing the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall tonight; the performance of Monteverdi's "Coronation of Poppea" at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre tonight by the Salzburg Opera Guild; and recitals at the Town Hall by Viola Wasterlain, violinist, in- the afternoon, and Phil Duey, baritone, in the evening.

J. Warren Weller, 35 years old, former employee in the manufacturing division of the Standard Oil Company of New York, was found dead at 8 A. M. today in the garage under his home at 22 Edgewood Lane here. Dr. Amos O. Squire,

Ending their final meetings on the future of American-Philippine trade relations the Joint Preparatory Committee disclosed today that the six Filipino members of the twelve-man group are not returning to the United States with the Americans.
George Daley, Irish lightweight boxer, scored a surprise triumph over Paul Junior of Lewiston, Me., in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

During the past forty-eight hours high winds have increased at the Macgregor Arctic base camp. These winds have broken up the ice in Smith Sound, leaving the sound open as far as one can see. Ice continues to break off near the harbor here and open water extends to about 300 yards from our supply ship.

Regret at the death of Francis P. Garvan was expressed today by his long-time friend, the Rev. John F. O'Hara, C.S.C., President of the University of Notre Dame. He said: "Notre Dame has lost another devoted friend and generous benefactor.

The Nassau County Board of Supervisors was informed today of the first specific assessment that will be removed from the tax rolls through acceptance by the county of land now a part of the Long Island Motor Parkway.

What proved to be the most interesting of the weekly luncheons of the Football Writers Association drew a big crowd of coaches, officials and advance men for out-oftown teams to the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
A nominal decline in automobile production last week, at a time when the seasonal trend pointed to a sharp increase, brought the adjusted index down to 102.4.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 3859-Ex parte Arthur J. Ericksen. Dismissed for failure of appellant -to prosecute under the rules.
After being missing from her Los Angeles home for three years, Jean Becker, 19 years old, was found by Sheriff Abram Molyneaux of Ulster County today in one of Father Divine's "heavens" near here.

Application for 67,000 square feet of space in the main exhibit area of the New York World's Fair in 1939 for erection of an exhibit building to cost about $500,000 by the Men's Apparel Quality Guild, Inc., a new organization of manufactures in allied clothing and men's wear fields was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.

Unofficial returns from eleven upState counties, where the voting is done by paper ballots, show a close race among thirteen Republicans for the six places still to be decided on the slate of delegates at large to the coming State Constitutional Convention. Chief Judge Frederick -E. Crane of the Court of Appeals heads the list, with a margin of only seventy-four votes over the candidate in last place.

Six B. M. T. employes started suit in Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin the B. M. T. organization and the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, from enforcing against them the closed shop agreement under which certain classifications of the system's employes face discharge if they are not members of the union by Nov. 10.
The Nine-Power conference delegates, who are scattered through Brussels hotels while the conference is recessing, are feeling more encouraged.

The petroleum industry, which says that it is the nation's largest taxpayer, took up the question of easing the tax burden on the average automobile owner today at the opening of the eighteenth annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute.

President Getulio Vargas accepted today the resignation of Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, Minister of Justice and Interior. Francisco Campos, Commissioner of Education in Rio de Janeiro and Minister of Education in the first Vargas Cabinet, was appointed to the vacancy.
More emphasis was placed on special promotional items in orders coming into the local merchandise market yesterday, manufacturers and resident buyers reported.
At the annual meeting of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association, held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, one new officer and three new members of the board were elected.

Drastic measures were employed today to fight the hoof and mouth disease, which authorities said threatened to spread throughout the nation. Officials ordered wholesale destruction of cattle in Eastern England to check the disease and closed many livestock shows.
Sir Samuel Instone, an industrialist who built up. large interests in the fields of coal shipping and aviation, died today after an operation, at the age of 59.

" I intend to marry Ernest Aldrich Simpson," said Mrs. Mary Kirk Raffray this afternoon as she emerged from the court room of Judge B. F. Curler, after ,having obtained a divorce from Jacques Achille Louis Raffray, New York broker.

Postponed twice during the last fortnight because of bad weather, the annual inspection of the uniformed personnel and operating equipment of the Manhattan and Bronx Park Departments finally took place yesterday.

The Dramatists Guild took unprecedented steps yesterday to cripple permanently the Bureau of New Plays, financed by the leading motion picture companies, with which it has quarreled for more than a year on the matter of film rights to Broadway plays.

Bellini's "Norma" was chosen today as the opening production of the Metropolitan Opera Association's Philadelphia series, beginning on Nov. 30. The selection was made by the Metropolitan Opera committee here at a meeting with Edward Johnson, the company's general manager.

The law committee of the Board of Education has voted to appeal the decision of Dr. Frank P. Graves, Commissioner of Education, ordering the reinstatement of Mrs. Angela D'Auria, a teacher in Public School 43 dismissed on charges last Fall, it was disclosed yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the board.
Andrew Matthew Kenlon, president of the contracting firm of Dooling Kenlon of Mount Vernon, died here last night at his home. His age was 81.

Volunteer workers of the women's division of the United Hospital Campaign Committee reported yesterday a total of $374,792.37 toward the $1,000,000 quota assigned to them in the campaign for an annual maintenance fund for: ninetytwo institutions throughout the city and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn.

The Rev. Alfred W. Price, rector of St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church, Eightieth Street and Eleventh Avenue, Dyker Heights, Brooklyn, will receive the Purple Heart medal for bravery under fire with the United States Marines, the presentation to be made at the morning service next Sunday.

Paul A. Wright, aviation executive, shot dead his wife and one of his close friends, John Bryant Kimmel, early today when, he told Police Chief V. B. Browne he found them in each other's arms in his home.

CHRISTOPHER MARLOWE, by John Bakeless. (Morrow, $3.75.) A biography of the Elizabethan dramatist. THE MAKIKG OF SOCIETY, edited by V. F. Calverton. (Modern Library, 95 cents.) An outline of sociology.

In late dealings yesterday sales of copper were made in the export market at 10.20 to 10.225 cents a pound c.i.f. European base ports. Early sales were made at' 9.65 cents, or at Monday's final quotations. Asprices advanced, the volume of business declined noticeably.

It-seems to be a general concept, especially among punsters, that all's well in the medical profession when epidemics are raging. That's not true, of course, and it's especially untrue when the medico happens to be a head football coach, like Dr. Marvin (Mal) Stevens at N. Y. U., and when the epidemic is chiefly broken bones of his star players.

Final fees and expense allowances for more than $900,000 were asked yesterday by attorneys and others who took part in the reorganizetion of the United Cigar Stores Company of America and its subsidiaries at a hearing before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe. The company emerged from reorganization proceedings last July.

Twice defeated in attempts to force Associate Justice Black out of their lawsuit, on the ground of prejudice, Florida Oil Share brokers today laid the groundwork for another drive against the eligibility of President Roosevelt's appointee to the Supreme Court.
Big-hearted, big-minded Julius Streicher has just opened a big anti-Jewish fair in Munich.

The first direct step toward the establishment and enforcement of minimum wage standards for workingwomen in this State will be taken "within the next few weeks," when a laundry wage board will be appointed, Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews announced yesterday.

Army held a secret practice for the Notre Dame game today. The varsity players were all in their accustomed berths except Hank Sullivan, end, who was hurt in the Harvard contest. Rogner and Samuel alternated in that position on the left flank, with Kobes at the other end.

Many persons of social distinction viewed the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night, All the boxes were filled, glamorous fashions adding to the color 'and sparkle of the erformance.

The Countess of Suffolk, who arrived yesterday on the Aquitania, is at the Pierre before leaving for Tucson, Ariz., where she plans to pass the Winter. Mr. and Mrs. Alexander J. M. Tuck of Tuxedo Park are at the Weylin.
Following are the conclusions in a special report to Congress of the United States Maritime Commission on its economic survey of American shipping, issued by Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman:

Fordham University will resume basketball relations with St. John's University of Brooklyn after a lapse of five years, it was disclosed yesterday when the St. John's court schedule of nineteen games for the 1937-38 season was released.

Sedate and picturesque Governors Island yesterday presented a scene of activity rather uncommon at the ancient fortress. Some fifty young men, wearing jerseys, shoulder pads and helmets, were busily engaged in tossing and kicking pigskins, forming huddles and going through the general routine of football practice.

What is meant as a demonstration of France's colonial air might began at 8 o'clock this morning when seventy-six military planes took off from Istres, near here, on an "empire flight" to France's dominions beyond the seas.
Robert S. Winsmore, author, journalist, secretary of The Players and former stock broker, died yesterday at his home, 55 Park Avenue, of cardiac asthma. His age was 61.
An eight-State police alarm was sent out yesterday for four robbers, three of whom invaded the sevenroom flat on the East Side of two crippled sisters, one 80 years old and bedridden;

Trading was mostly slow. Steer sold weak to sharply lower; the lamb market was sharply lower; fresh pork cuts were steady to lower; and veal and calf mostly unchanged. Early trading In kosher meats indicated beef and veal to be weak; lamb sharply lower, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The kite that was sent up last week at Berlin is still flying. Neutral press reports that Germany is prepared to play a role in bringing Japan and China together seem altogether too substantial to be disregarded, although the Foreign Office here still denies that the Japanese Government knows anything of the matter.
Harold Arnold, referee in bankruptcy and vice president of the Dutchess County Bar Association, died at his home here today after a succession of heart attacks. He was 60 years old.

The Veterans Temple of Peace at the 1939 World's Fair will symbolize the peaceful aspirations of a nation made up of peoples of diverse races and creeds, living and prospering in harmony, according to tentative plans made public yesterday.

In the Supreme Court of the United States Harris Jay Griston of New York was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 229--Jesse C. Duke, petr., v. United States. Motions to recall order denying petition for writ of certiorari and to reconsider petition for rehearing submitted by Jesse C..Duke prose.

The student strike at Kearny High School, which was threatened last night because the students wanted, among other things, permission to do the "big apple" and "trucking" at school dances, has been called off, for the present at least, it was announced today by George G. Mankey, principal.

The Retailers National Council, a federation of ten national retail trade associations, urged today repeal of the undistributed profits tax. If Congress should not see fit to repeal the tax, the council urged that modifications be made to protect small business firms and encourage expansion.

The Chinese claim they repulsed a Japanese attempt yesterday to land near Peishou Fort, slightly northward of Amoy. Five Japanese gunboats opened a barrage while sailors embarked for the shore in sampans, it is said, but firing from the fort killed or wounded more than twenty Japanese, including a boatload sunk by shells, and the others withdrew.
The dollar was a big question mark for European central bank governors in private talks during their meeting here in the past few days as directors of the Bank for International Settlements.

I believe that an article appearing in THE TIMES of Oct. 25 may give a false impression of conditions in Puerto Rico. The article is headed "Puerto Rico Police Assailed in Report" and represents a review through secondary sources of a biased report.

Mrs. Helen Curtiss Cowles of Eastham, Va., daughter of Dean and Mrs. Charles E. Curtiss of Ames, Iowa, was married to Frederick John Allistair Cameron, son of Mrs. Allistair Cameron of London and the late Mr. Cameron, yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. A. Stewart Walker of 823 Lexington Avenue.

The importance of establishing personal contact between manufacturers here and their customers in Latin America was stressed by C. E. Thomas, sales representative in Argentina for a number of American companies, in an address yesterday before the Export Managers, Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Following is the text of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's address on foreign affairs at the Lord Mayor's banquet at Guildhall tonight; It is customary at this dinner for the Prime Minister to give a general review of the situation abroad.

Sales of General Motors cars to dealers in the United States, Canada and abroad in October increased by 76,175 units over dctober a year ago, the company's New York office reported yesterday. The mark for October was 166,939, cormDared with 90.764.

After each had registered four victories in preliminary competition, Jose R. de Capriles outpointed his brother, Miguel A. de Capriles, and Warren Dow in a fence-off to ,capture the senior epee competition for Amateur Fencing League of America medals at the Salle Santelli last night. All three of the leaders represented the host organization.
Complete Japanese investment of Taiyuan, capital of Shansi Province, followed an intensive bombardment of the city's walls, a Japanese spokesman here declared today.

Earle R. Lewis, who has been connected with the Metropolitan Opera since 1908, has been appointed an assistant general manager of the company, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson. Mr. Lewis's present posts are box office treasurer and assistant secretary.

There may be some quarters where it is more or less taken for granted that Yale is going to defeat Princeton when the old friends come together in the Bowl on Saturday, but this is certainly not one of those places.
Three mortgages aggregating $200,000 on 975-79 8th Ave, held by the Bank for Savings from the Horn Hardart Co, Edwin K. Daly, president,

The number of visiting. buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was above the preceding week but considerably lower than in the corresponding week of last year, according to the listings in THE TIMES.

The real nature of James Ramsay MacDonald, in the opinion of some of his contemnporaries, was too deep for easy explanation. Less friendly critics said it was merely hidden by changing political masks. Those who professed to know him best explained apparent contradictions on the ground that he was too consistent for inconsistent people to understand.

Diplomatic and military officials are in substantial agreement that the chief importance of the fall of Shanghai is psychological rather than military. This has been the view since the fight for the seaport began.
In preparation for the clash with Columbia at Baker Field in New York Saturday, Coach Ossie Solem sent his Syracuse varsity football team through a long drill on Hendricks Field today.
Admiral Claude C. Bloch, commander of the Battle Force, was designated by President Roosevelt today as commander in chief of the United States Fleet, effective Feb. 1.
The War Department today was notified of the death in Boston yesterday of Colonel Henry S. Greenleaf, retired medical officer, at the age of 67.
A price cut of $15 on its de lure models for 1938 has been announced by the Plymouth division of Chrysler Corporation. Prices for 1938 were first announced on Oct. 18.

The 625-acre dairy farm of the late Dr. David McAlpin, known as Brooklawn Farms, at Littleton, Troy Hills and Whippany, N. J., has been sold to the Alderney Dairy Company of Newark, through Leo Flaster and Country Properties, Inc., co-brokers.

Exports of New Zealand beef to New York amounted to 920 frozen beef quarters and 1,640 bags of boneless beef during September, the Commerce Department reported today. During the eleven-month period from October, 1936, to September, 1937,
Carl M. Snyder has been appointed manager of appliance sales for the General Electric Company, effective immediately, it was announced yesterday.
The body of Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson, famous actor, who died Saturday, was cremated at Golders Green Crematorium today.

Production of rayon yarn made from viscose and cuprammonium processes was 62,600,000 pounds in the three months ended Sept. 20, a new record for the period, compared with 55,100,000 pounds in the third quarter of 1936, the Rayon Organon, published by Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reported yesterday.
Broadway paused yesterday for a brief interval to honor the memory of the late Spencer D. Bettelhelm, World War veteran, operator of the Lyceum Theatre and an executive on the staff of Sam H. Harris.
State Senator Charles E. Loizeaux of Union...

Visitors to THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center browsed yesterday among books, old, new, rare, fine, fictional, factual, adult and juvenile. They also saw a printing plant in operation, a publishing office in action and many other exhibits.

The persistent downward trend that had characterized the bond market so far this month was arrested yesterday and, although the gains were far from impressive, the forward movement clearly was evident.

President Roosevelt, to permit greater attention to problems arising from the convening of Congress next week, as well as the normal inflow of business to the executive offices, instructed his secretary, Marvin H. McIntyre, today to restrict his engagements to see callers and curtail outside appointments.

When the joint legislative committee investigating the guaranteed mortgage situation holds a further hearing here, probably next week, it will receive various suggestions from realty interests on the questions of the mortgage moratorium and deficiency judgments.
Development in Berlin of-two types of concrete mortar which can be used at temperatures up to 2,912 degrees Fahrenheit without undergoing any change has been reported to the Commerce Department.

Mrs. Tomasa Toruellas of Ponce will never again use lottery tickets to pay bills. The woman sent her two children to get a haircut. When the barber called for his money, the mother, without change gave him two-twentieths of a Puerto Rican public lottery ticket.

John Kenton, freshman at Brown University, saved 32 cents on a telegram and started a spy hunt. Kenton, whose home is at 76-09 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Jackson Heights, N. Y., was to attend the Brown-Yale game at New Haven last week with Andrew Bato of Orange, N. J., a student at Yale.

The youthful composer starving in a garret was termed a "thing of the past" yesterday by Miss Grace Moore of the Metropolitan Opera Company, who spoke as a guest of honor at the first campaign luncheon of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, Inc., at the Hotel Pierre.

President Roosevelt, in a Thanksgiving proclamation today, said that the United States had "no selfish designs against other nations" and that while other parts of the world were experiencing strife and threats of war, "our people are enjoying the blessing of peace."

Miss Kate Hunter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy O. Hunter of Rye, was married here to Albert Plaut of this city on Monday, it was disclosed early yesterday when the couple went to the Merry-GoRound, a restaurant in East Fiftyfourth Street, for a post-midnight "wedding breakfast" and announced to friends that they had been married.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday and at one time all three late months sold above 8 cents a pound. A gain of $2 a bale from the low records made immediately following Monday's large crop estimate brought out December contracts and the list ended with gains of 3 to 5 points.
Assemblyman Harold B. Ehrlich of Buffalo, chairman of a joint legislative committee investigating the petroleum industry, proposed today new standards for grading gasoline in New York State.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patents Appeals the following proceedings were had today: PATENTS 3864--Jan Van Hulst v. Francis D. Sullivan. Cause on merits and motion of appellant to strike portions of appellee's brief argued for both.
Nineteen men, including high officials, have been shot and eight others imprisoned following two simultaneous trials in Sukhum and Shemakhe, near Baku, in Trans-Caucasia.

Another full session of five hours was consumed tonight by Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in the fifteenth game of their match for the chess championship of the world. After forty moves had been recorded an adjournment was taken and play will be resumed tomorrow night.
A wide area of Manhattan was represented in the realty deals announced by brokers yesterday. Residential properties formed the bulk of the day's trading.

Business failures were higher In three trade groups in the five-day week ended Nov. 4, compared with a year ago, while there was a decrease in the retail division and the number of failures among manufacturers was unchanged, according to the weekly analysis issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The detailed report follows:

Harry (Pittsburgh) Strauss, 30 years old, of 558 Sackman Street, Brooklyn, who has been arrested twenty-six times in the last ten years on charges ranging from possession of a pistol to homicide, but who has never been convicted, was held yesterday in $2,500 bail on a charge of manslaughter by Magistrate Malbin in Brooklyn Homicide Court.

Turpentine firm,. 26 3/4c; sales 71 barrels; receipts 242 barrels; no shipments; stock 39,824 barrels. Resin firm; sales 1,050; receipts 1,330; no shipments; stock 78,462. Quote: B, D. $6.15: E, $6.15-.25: F to M. $6.30-.40; N, $6.621/2.75; WG, $6.92 1/2-s7; WW, X, $7.50.
George F. Rolfe, Past Grand Patriarch of the Grand Encampment, I. O. O. F., State of New York, died Sunday at his home in Guilderland. He was 57 years old.

Steel ingot production eased further last week, and the adjusted index, continuing its downward movement, receded to 71.0 from 74.6. This is its lowest point in twenty-one months. The figure for the week ended Nov. 7, 1936, was 108.6.

John T. McNeill, Professor of the History of European Christianity in the University of Chicago Divinity School, is the author of the Religious Book Club selection for November: "The Christian Hope for World Society" (Willett, Clark).
Word was received here today of the sudden death of Ross Garrison Bennett, works manager of the Bryant Electric Company, at Asheville, N. C. His age was 41. Mr.

Fearing that the installation of Thomas E. Dewey as District Attorney of New York County will lead to an influx of petty criminals to this and other cities near New York, Philip S. Tilden, Director of Public Safety of New Rochelle, asked the City Council today to add twelve patrolmen to the present force of 137 men.
General Victor Constant Michel, who preceded Joffre as generalissimo of the French Army, died this morning in Meulan, a Paris suburb, at the age of 87.

Freshmen at Columbia College took a cue from the recent election of city councilmen and gathered in the McMillin Academic Theatre yesterday to elect four class officers by proportional representation. Tabulation of the 398 ballots was completed in two hours and a half.

A survey of the American merchant marine which discloses, in the words of Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, that it is a "very sick industry," was made public today by the chairman.

Canadian interests have agreed to buy approximately $4,500 000 face value of the four-year se cured notes of the South American Utilities Corporation, it was announced today by Lampard, Marston Co., Ltd., of Toronto. Subject to completion of the purchase, a plan of reorganization may be submitted to shareholders of the corporation.

Exceptional class was shown today as the open all-age stake of the seventh annual field trial meeting of the Labrador Retriever Club was concluded in the Shinnecock Hills. The judges had high praise for the class and consistency of the twenty-two entries in the three-day meet, which will end tomorrow.

Joe Medwick, clouting left fielder of the St. Louis Cardinals, has been voted the most valuable player in the National League for 1937 by the Baseball Writers Association of America, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

Charles Dana Gibson and Thomas F. Conroy were named yesterday as honorary pallbearers in addition to others already announced for the funeral service of Francis P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, Inc., lawyer, philanthropist and former United States Alien Property Custodian.

Now in its 229th year, Trinity School received "The Technology Award" from Massachusetts Institute of Technology at a chapel service for the student bodyyesterday morning in the school building at 139 West Ninety-first Street.

In the first case of its kind three fur concerns accused of violating a boycott of Nazi Germany have been fined $75,000 by an arbitration board that acted on charges mode by the Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewits Congress and Jewish Labor Committee.

The National Bank of Greece is charged with illegally obtaining about $25,000,000 in deposits from Americans, chiefly persons of Greek extraction, in a suit pending in Supreme Court. The depositors, it is alleged, have for some time 'been unable to obtain the return of any of their funds.
Mayor La Guardia ridiculed the Transit Commission yesterday for "pulling a transit unification plan out of the hat" and said he would ask the Legislature in January to abolish the commission.

Hunts Point Ave (10-2763B), w s, 343 a of Coster St, 75x100; Lillian Cotkin to 737 Realty Co, Inc, 18 E 41st St; mtg, $98,000. Mt Hope P1 (11-2844), n s, 100 e of Monroe Ave, 160x125; 1,815 Monroe Ave Corp to Mutual Equities, Inc, 156 2d Ave; mtg, $285,000.

Arture Godoy, Chilean heavyweight, knocked out Eddie Mader. of the West Side in 0.40 of the fifth session of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. The loser, at 186 pounds, conceded his opponent ten and a half pounds.

Walter Shear Sullivan, yachtsman and one of the foremost authorities on Long Island Sound racing, died yesterday of pneumonia in Morrisania Hospital, the Bronx. He was 58 years old and lived at 4,143 Park Avenue.
J. Ramsay MacDonald, thrice Prime Minister of Great Britain, died peacefully aboard this ship tonight as a result of a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

Tallulah Bankhead will reappear in the local arena this evening when the firm of Laurence Rivers, Inc., gives at the Mansfield a rerevival of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra." The title roles will be taken by Conway Tearle and Miss Bankhead.

Two silver medals commemorating the tenth anniversary of the opening of Holland Tunnel will be given to the two motorists who are paying their toll at each end of the tunnel at precisely 3 o'clock Friday afternoon, officials of the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.
The Great Lakes freighter Calgadoc, eleven days out of Sydney, N. S., for Wabana, Bell Island, was still unreported tonight on the voyage which ordinarily would have been completed in sixty hours.

Although inquiry for leathers has improved sharply in the last few days, it has represented largely the desire of buyers to get posted on values, rather than preparation for the placing of orders, a canvass of the market disclosed yesterday.
The Autumn is delayed this year-I found A wild rose blooming by the first slow flame Of sumac where the spring brook bends around The hill; a thrush was singing when I came

Irregularity in some degree now is noticeable in industrial operations in Canada, according to A. E. Arscott, general manager of the Canadian Bank of Commerce. Declines in production have not been confined to forestry, newsprint and lumber, but include other and sundry manufacturing units, he said.

Joe Louis, heavyweight champion of the world, will see action in two Winter bouts before he meets Max Schmeling. next Summer, it. was announced yesterday by Mike Jacobs, Twentieth Century S. C. promoter.

Employment of the social security reserve fund to foster a nation-wide industrial construction and housing drive, reopening of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for industrial loans and other moves were being seriously considered today by President Roosevelt and his advisers as they continued the search for ways to halt the down trend of business without resumption of deficit spending.

Marcel Olivier, former, Governor General of Madagascar and now chairman of the French Line in Paris; Karl Lindemann, chairman of the North German Lloyd Line; Captain A. L. P. Mark-Wardlaw, assistant naval attache at the British Embassy in Washington, with his wife and daughter;
The following reserve officers, having established permanent residences beyond the territorial limits of Third Military Area, are relieved from assignments as indicated after their respective names:

Miss Charlotte Gertruide Sommer, daughter of Mrs Robert Phillips of 333 West End Avenue, was married last night to Christopher Thomas Coll Jr., son of Mr . and Mrs. Christopher T. Coll of Allenhurst, N. J.,- and-. Miami, Fla., in the Lutheran Church of the Advent, :Broadway and Ninety-third Street. The Rev. Edmund Steimle, son of the former pastor, the late Rev. Dr. Augustus Steimle, performed the ceremony.
When Harvard lined up for signal drill to close today's workout, the line included the regular tackles, Kevorkian and Booth; Joe Nee at left guard, Cliff Wilson at center and Daughters at right end.

The gross value of the estate of Frank Melville Jr. of 1,060 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan, and Oldfield, Suffolk County, head of the Melville Shoe Corporation, has been appraised at $5,218,999, as of the date of his death, Feb.- 25, 1935.

The first round of the fight within the Professional Golfers Association over the policies of President George R. Jacobus turned out to be a shadowboxing match today during the opening session of the organization's twenty-first annual meeting.

138th, 428-46 E (9-2282), also 137th, 425-43 E; 430 E 138th St Corp to Mastan Co, 350 5th Ave; due as per bond; $18,000. Valentine Ave ( 1-3154), w s. 200 ft n of Fordham Rd, 126x100; Deval Realty Corp to Dollar Savings Bank; extends mtg to Nov. 8, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $104,000.

Indications multiply that the President and his advisers are earnestly canvassing various plans to stimulate business. From Washington now come, on usually good authority, reports that, in addition to certain tax reforms, these things are in view:

President Getulio Vargas sent to Congress this afternoon a proposed law that would fix the new tax on coffee at 12 milreis a bag and provide other pertinent measures tending to regulate Brazil's export coffee business.

Indifference tinged with hostility was the reaction of the rugged individualists who shine shoes outside the Public Library to an announcement yesterday that the Barbers and. Beauty Culturists Union of America would seek- to enlist the city's bootblacks under the C.I.O. banner.

Russell Lee Bradford of 7 Gracie Square, a member of the law firm of Mitchell, Taylor, Capron Marsh, 20 Exchange Place, died yesterday morning in the Doctors Hospital after an operation for appendicitis performed two weeks ago. He was 53 years old.
Ernest Lee Wichert, candy manufacturer here, died at his home today after a long illness in his sixty-second year. He had been in the candy business for more than forty years.

A more cheerful sentiment pervaded the grain pits on the Board of Trade here today, the result of a fair recovery in stocks, strong cables, and intimations of a better export inquiry, althoug'h actual sales were not large.
Today's sales saw a fair selection of 12,145 bales of wool offered, of which 9,620 were - sold, with the prices of best merinos unchanged and average faulty wools 5 per cent lower.

A $130,000 mortgage has been placed on the 6-story apartment house recently completed on the west side of Morris Ave, north of 167th St, the Bronx. The Henwin Realty Corp, Harold Litwin, president, is the owner. The Metropolitan Life Insurance Co is the mortgagor.

Sixty eight drivers employed by the Garden State Bus Company went on strike here this morning for a 20 per cent increase in wages and forced 8,000 Bergen County commuters to seek other means of transportation over the George Washington Bridge to New York City.

Mass terror and wholesale brutality were the distinguishing features of scenes at all bridges leading from Siccawei and Nantao into the French Concession today, where tens of thousands of panicky Chinese clamored for admission to the safety of the foreign-controlled area.

37th St, 112 E. 20x98.9; executors of will of Samuel Riker and eight others, to Louis N. Ellrodt. 204 S 3d Ave, Mt. Vernon (quit claims). Stanton St, 24, 20.3x69.6; Philip Podvesoker to Regina Mandel. 128 Diamond St, Brooklyn: mtg. $6,000.

After a few weeks' comparative quiet, antiJewish student rioting was renewed at Warsaw Law School, where six Jewish students were injured today when Nationalists broke into a lecture hall and attempted to unseat Jews occupying benches outside the "ghetto" section.

Renewal early in December of the agreement pertraining to Germany's short-term debt has been virtually assured as the result of private conversations which have been going on for several weeks in London between representatives of the foreign bank creditors and members of a German committee.

Preparing for both Princeton and Army, the Navy football squad put in a long afternoon's work today, the offensive, both passing and running, occupying most of the attention of Head Coach Hank Hardwick and his helpers.
Newbold Morris, president-elect of the New York City Council and Mrs. Morris, and Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx, arrived here this evening for a two-week holiday.

Plans to form a New Jersey Labor party because of "callous disregard of the rights of labor" by Democratic and Republican leaders in this State were announced today by Carl Holderman, chairman of Labor's Nonpartisan League of New Jersey and New Jersey director of the C. I. O. Textile Workers Organization Committee.

In recognition of his work for Catholic charities in the Archdiocese of New York, John A. Coleman, stock broker, has been appointed a Knight of St. Gregory the Great by Pope Plus XI, it was announced yesterday by the Catholic Charities offices at 477 Madison Avenue.

Apprehensions created by Russia's declaration that she considers the Italo-GermanJapanese anti-Communist pact an unfriendly act showed signs of dying' down today when yesterday's demarche was not followed by any new diplomatic step and hope began to be entertained that both Italy and Russia will allow matters to rest as they are without complicating the situation with further protests or recriminations.

Fourteen insurance companies holding more than $55,000,000 in securities of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company introduced today a new plan in that carrier's reorganization proceedings before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Henry W. Breyer, investment broker and former head of the Breyer Ice Cream Company, divided $9,745,000 among relatives, friends and veteran employes during fourteen years before his death, it was disclosed today.

The Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad has announced that it has started daily through merchandise car service from New York and near-by points to Minneapolis, Des Moines and Kansas City by virtue of connections with the Western Steamship Company by way of Norfolk. Va.

Discovery of a method to detect measles before the characteristic rash breaks out, a potent weapon in combating periodic nation-wide epidemics of one of the most common communicable diseases, was reported yesterday by Dr. Jean Broadhurst, Professor of Bacteriology in Teachers College, Columbia University.
Neville Chamberlain again promised tonight that Great Britain would keep fully in step with the United States in trying to settle the Far Eastern war.

The eighty-fifth annual Harvest Home Festival exhibition, tea and sale of the handiwork of the Mariners' Family Asylum for aged women-wives, widows, mothers, sisters and daughters of former seamen of the Port of New York-will be held this afternoon at the headquarters of the institution, 119 Tompkins Avenue, Stapleton, S. I.

Recent developments in South American countries affecting adverrising have begun to worry exporters here, who feel that the cost of promoting goods in those nations will become unduly high, according to executives of export ad agencies here yesterday.

Company commanders shall forward reports to this office on Monday, Nov. 15, giving the names, groups and platoon numbers, of members of their commands who feel qualified to give short educational talks on fire protection.

Miss Eva Frances Cumnock, daughter of the late Alexander G. Cumnock, founder and first president of the Lowell Textile Institute, died at her home here yesterday at the age of 81. Her family has been prominent In the industrial, philanthropic and social life of Lowell for a century.
The report of the American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for twelve months to Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a 'net income, after all expenses and charges, of $13,389,922.
A large squad reported to a secret practice today as Amherst began preparations for the Williams game Saturday at Williamstown, Mass.

SERGEANTS-John T. Gleason, from 20th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, N. Y. County, for 5 days. William A. Newburg, from 111th Precinct to 16th Division, assigned to duty as Supervisor of Plain Clothes Patrolmen, for 15 days.

The Federal Water Servce Corporation, following its announcement of registration on Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act made public yesterday its plan of recapitalization, which also was filed with the SEC upon registration.
In the four business days ince last week's statement was published by the Bank of Mexico, its reserves fell nearly 1 per cent, from 49.80 per cent to 48.84.
Running Tom, entered by Sam Stephenson of Cincinnati, compiled 180 points in four scoring Chase to lead the field today in the Chase Futurity of the National Foxhunters' Association field trials.

Premier Maurice Duplessis, foe of communism, invoked today for the first time the law designed to "protect this Province against Communist propaganda" by ordering a police raid on the offices of the Montreal weekly newspaper La Clarte (The Light).

Gross assets, $639,471; net, $590,392. To Leon N. Adler, husband, one-third residue and contingent remainder in two-thirds residue; Stanley L. Adler, son, life estate in two-thirds residue with privilege of receiving $10,000 a year from income and principal:

Class 110 Officers' Chargers for Charies L. Scott Challenge Cup--First, Lt. Col. Herbert H. Frost's gr. g. Jeb Stuart; second Captain R. A. Drake's gr. g. King-Hithird, Captain and Mrs. Frank deK. Huyler's ch. m. Modesta: fourth, Captain G. M. van Alicante-Kauffman's ch. g. Martin.

Annual meeting, Academy of Political Science, Hotel Astor, 10 A. M. Afternoon session 2 P. M. Dinner session 7 P. M., at which speakers will be S. Parker Gilbert, Governor Harry F. Byrd, Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr.

Raymond F. Meyer, blinded as a result of his World War service in the United States Air Corps and one of the first American aviators to go overseas; died at his home here after a heart attack. He was 46 years old.
Scott P. Squyres, new commander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, told President Roosevelt today that ultimately there must be jobs or pensions for all World War veterans.

The seventy-one-family apartment building at 200 Dyckman Street which recently was purchased by Harry Franklin has been resold to the Dyckrap Realty Corporation, M. Rappaport, president, through Volz Maas, Inc., broker.

For the first time in manly years a sympathy and a real feeling of friendliness exists between the Republican organizations up-State and the party leaders in this city, it was said yesterday by Republican party leaders.
