Five Jewish young men, their ages ranging from 23 to 27, were killed instantly this morning by dum-dum bullets fired by members of an Arab gang near Kiryathanavim, a Jewish colony about eight miles south of Jerusalem.

The production of silver in Canada has been marked by a striking advance during recent months. The increase for the first eight months of the year amounts to 27 per cent, the Canadian Pacific reports.

George de Ghika, Hungarian consul general, made an address of welcome yesterday morning at the opening session of the biennial conference of Hungarian Presbyterian pastors, meeting under the auspices of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the
The Danzig Senate's decree prohibiting all political parties and establishing a totalitarian State failed to impress official circles here, because the move was expected.
An offensive scrimmage that saw the Brown varsity eleven break away for five touchdowns against the reserve eleven featured today's preparation for the Holy Cross game at Providence Saturday.

London's fashionable Mayfair district was startled tonight by two robberies that netted jewels valued at $94,000. The Berkley Square apartment of Mrs. Leander J. McCormick was robbed of gems valued at $4,000.

King Carol's audience with Premier George Tatarescu this afternoon marked the outbreak of a Cabinet crisis. The King also received several othee-political leaders, and tomorrow will receive former Premier Alexander Vaida-Voevod, a possible candidate' for the Premiership.

The, Union Colleges varsity football team went through a vigorous scrimmage today in preparation for its forty-fifth game with Hamilton at-Clinton Saturday. It will be the last contest of the season for Union.
Facing the task of getting Finance Minister Georges Bonnet's balanced budget passed by the end of this year, the French Cabinet decided today to convoke Parliament for next Tuesday.

Miss Florence Skinner was married yesterday to Sibley A. Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamont A. Hall of New York, formerly of Waterbury, at the home of her father, Roberts K. Skinner. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. William T. Hopper, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, was followed by a reception for the two families and a few friends.
Because Haile Selassie has given up his house in Bath for a smaller one in the same town, there is no need to condole with him on the rise in the price of living.

Charging violations of the Public Service Law by the Consolidated Edison Company in the acquisition of private electric plants, the Public Service Commission directed its counsel yesterday to bring suit against the company. The action is expected to be a penalty suit in the Supreme Court.

Senator Capper was accused by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, today of "discrepancies and false conclusions" in an article critical of the reciprocal trade agreements program in The Saturday Evening Post.

Because children are "assets to this complex world" and because divorce is a necessary evil today, Mme. Karin Michaelis, Danish author and lecturer, declared yesterday that children of luckless marriages should be protected against the results of such marriages by a special government tax, levied against both single and married men.
Robert Harold Ickes, 24-yearold foster son of Secretary Ickes, is working here as a construction gang laborer for a steel company. He has been here four months, drawing laborer's wages.

Faultless is the word for Elswyth Thane's "Young Mr. Disraeli," which had a discreet reptition generale at the Fulton last evening. And perhaps a dress rehearsal. guest ought quietly to add that it is also tepidly interesting in the theatre.
The Reichsbank's statement as of Nov. 8 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands marks:

Miss Lila Sheldon Putnam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Calvin Putnam of 496 Stratford Road, Brooklyn, will be introduced to society this season. She will be among the debutantes receiving at the debutante ball in the Brooklyn Heights Casino on Nov. 24.

The financial report of the Dartmouth College Athletic Council, issued today, shows a surplus of $24,883.03 for the academic year 1936-37, which is a more favorable report than the previous year, when a surplus of slightly more than $10,000 was posted.
Herbert W. Marache of Granberry, Marache Lord has been elected a director of the Lionel Corportation, toy train manufacturer.
William Howard Boyce, believed to be the last surviving Civil War lieutenant in this vicinity, died at his home here today at the age of 92. Mr.

Dr. Livingstone Lovell Lewis of Hoboken, N. J., died of coronary thrombosis there last night. He was 60 years old. Born in Hoboken on May 17, 1877, he was graduated from Bellevue Hospital Medical College and served his interneship at St. Mary's Hospital, Hoboken.
President Roosevelt offered the public utilities industry the cooperation of his administration today, on one condition.

Leopold Stokowski made his first appearance of the season at Carnegie Hall last night when he directed the Philadelphia Orchestra in its second concert of the New York series. It might almost be said that Mr. Stokowski appeared "in person," for a few paces down the street he was being advertised as a screen luminary.

Madison Square Garden again will present a Winter sports show and international ski meet. A carnival modeled after that of last year, when 80,000 persons attended seven. performances, will be held from Dec. 7 to 11.
For the first time since his injury Yale game, Bob Schuenemann, veteran right end, will start for Penn when Michigan comes to Franklin Field on Saturday.

With the British and French fleets in active partnership in the Meditteranean the present cordial relations between London and Paris were emphasized again today with the arrival of French Vice-Admiral Jean Charles Abrial aboard his flagship the cruiser Algiere.

Charles Du Bosch, 21 years old, of 368 Thirteenth Street, Brooklyn, a tall youth wearing a fawn-colored camel's hair coat and a dark Homburg hat, was placed under arrest in Brooklyn last night on a charge of attempting to extort $7,200 from his former school teacher and her husband under threat of revealing what he pretended was a clandestine romance between himself and the teacher.

Movemeints of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 25,000 including 6.500 directs. The market was fully 25c lower on barrows and gilts; packing sows 10-15c lower than Monday's average; top 59.25;

Governor Martin L. Davey of Ohio declared last night at a meeting of the Ohio Society of New York at the Pennsylvania Hotel that he had called out the National Guard in the steel strike last June to preserve law and order and to prevent bloodshed.

An announcement from- Canisius College said that the. Rev. James P. Sweeney,. president of the college, would confer today in New York City with the Very Rev. Joseph A. Murphy, provincial of the Maryland-New York Province. of the Society of Jesus.

Viewing the undistributed profits tax as unworkable and proposed farm legislation as foredoomed to failure, the New York Board of Trade called yesterday for repeal of the former and opposition to the latter in the forthcoming special session of Congress.
Mr. and Mrs. William V. Negus of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Negus, to Rudolph Moller Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Moller of Clifton.

Chicago spoiled the Canadiens' opening in the new National Hockey League season tonight by sinking two third-period goals to gain a 2-all tie. The Canadiens came from behind in the final minute to even the score on George Mantha's goal.
Mr. David B. Costuma may or may not be correct in his assumption that his three colleagues on the Board of Elections have been trying to give Proportional Representation a black eye.

Bolstered by the return of Caspar (Cappy) Townsend, who has been out for several weeks witha leg injury, the St. Mark's School football squad is ready to give the favored unbeatedn untied and unscored-upon Groton School forces a keen battle in the forty-ninth contest of their traditional series here tomorrow.

Tremendous casualties are believed to have been caused yesterday by intense airplane attacks on Nantao, east and south of the French Concession, where 12,000 Chinese troops are facing. overwhelming Japanese Army and naval forces.
Stocks advanced moderately and closed steady and slightly higher; turnover, 1,048,770 shares. All groups of bonds generally higher in quiet trading; transactions. $7.599.050.

Long standing friction between the Haitian and Dominican people is regarded as one of the most important underlying causes of their present strife, which has caused the death of an undetermined number and threatens to disrupt their diplomatic relations.
Mrs. George Schiff Backer of 944 Fifth Avenue was sworn in at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia yesterday for a nine-year term without salary as a member of the Board of Child Welfare.

Setting an example in a movement to bring "the warfare against syphilis into the open," twenty-five socially prominent Montclair women, members of the executive boards of the League of Women and the Montclair Chapter, American Red Cross, took Wassermann tests today at the Department of Health offices.

Mrs. James J. Edwards, the former Miss Margaret Rouse, who had been active in the parish work of St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church of Brooklyn, died on Monday at her home. 46 Berkeley Place, Brooklyn, after a short Iilness. Surviving are her husband;

One million school children in this city will "tutor" their parents and neighbors in the method of filling out report cards in next week's national unemployment census, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.
Pittsburgh's football power house, triumphant in the Rose Bowl last New Year's Day and seemingly ambitious to try it again, has dis placed the University of California as the nation's No. 1 team.

Lafayette's 1938 football schedule, listing eight games, was announced today by Henry W. Clark, director of athletics. Brown returns to the schedule for the first time in thirty years. Penn will be taken on as an opener after a lapse of- one year.

The Louisiana State University School of Geology announced today the discovery of hilgardite, a heretofore unknown mineral. The university said that clear, colorless borate was found last Spring in a salt dome in Iberville Parish by Ralph E. Taylor, a graduate student from Ann Arbor, Mich.

In a message last night to 400 Young Democratic Clubs throughout the nation, President Roosevelt declared that the major task of the present day was to find "a new approach to the solution of age-old problems" affecting the happiness and security of the people of the nation.
The stock market here was extremely quiet today and renewed weakness developed in most sections. Gilt-edge issues lost ground and foreign bonds were dull.
The report to Congress of the United States Maritime Commission headed by Joseph P. Kennedy is a model of what such a report should be.

Queen Mary tonight entertained twenty royal guests at a brilliant dinner in Marlborough House. Three kings ??re present at the affair, which ?? one of the most impressive ??rings of royalty here in more ?? a decade.

Sale of a New York Stock Exchange membership for $75,000, down $5,000 from the previous sale on Nov. 4, was reported yesterday. The Walworth Company has notified the Stock Exchange of a proposed increase in its common stock from 1,400,000 to 1,550,000 shares and of the creation of 150,000 shares of convertible 6 per cent preferred stock, $10 par value.

Still reporting progress but with a definite slowing of tempo, the American Federation of Labor-Committee for Industrial Organization peace committees held two sessions today and adjourned for another conference on Nov. 18.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, announced yesterday that he wanted to retire at the end of the year, but at Mayor La Guardia's request he agreed to think the matter over for a few days more before reaching a definite decision.

Daily average sales of variety stores for October were about 1 per cent over October, 1936, while the increase from September to October of this year was considerably less than the usual seasonal trend, the Commerce Department reported today.

Viola Wasterlain at once established herself as a violinist of distinction at her debut recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. From the fine quality of her performances it was evident that this copiously gifted young newcomer had waited until her art had reached ripe .maturity before venturing an appearance here.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has rejected the application of New Jersey interests for reopening of the port lighterage case by which a rate differential was sought for New Jersey shippers and consignees below the rates which New York competitors would pay on rail freight, it was announced yesterday.

An order temporarily restraining J. S. Judge Co. of 44 Exchange Place from dealing in securities has been issued by Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel, it was disclosed yesterday at the office of the Attorney General here.
Spanish Insurgent officers reported tonight sharp counter-thrusts

The Massachusetts Development and Industrial Commission announced today three new industries for this State have been negotiated in less than three weeks. Since the State began its unprecedented -advertising campaign in the middle of October employment for 3,000 has been arranged.

In the ballroom of the Hotel Ten Eyck today some 600 delegates and visitors to the annual convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs got a series of news bulletins at the opening sessions. Most of it was bad news.
Four resolutions of the recent Lima aviation conference for increasing the safety of passenger traffic were ratified today by the administrative committee of the radio conference in session here.

John T. Dooling, chairman of the Tammany law committee and Democratio director of the P. R. count of ballots for the new City Council, wrote to Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday protesting against the presence of detectives among the canvassers in the 165th Regiment Armory, at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, where the Manhattan vote is being tabulated.

With most of the few intrepid anglers left resigned to catching cod, a dozen or so of the Shark River and Brielle die-hards were rewarded for their efforts last Sunday by unexpected catches of big bluefish off the New Jersey coast.

The marriage of Miss Julia Reynolds Vaughan Pitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Reynolds Pitt of 259 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, to James Alfred Wadsworth, son of Arthur H. Wadsworth of Hollis, Queens, and the late Mrs. Wadsworth, took place last night in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Gordon Decatur Pierce.

Two or Maryland's best known racing figures, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Ral Parr, saw their color bearers run a dead heat today in the $3,600 Sagamore Handicap, a new stake at Pimlico. The race was named for the Sagamore Farm of Mr. Vanderbilt in the near-by Worthington Valley, where his Pit Bull was conditioned.

Financial aid from the National Youth Administration, a government emergency bureau for student aid, was given to 850 needy students at City College this semester, it was announced yesterday by Dr. A. J. Malkin, director of the college N. Y. A. office.
Governor Lehman today informed Edwin F.

Mrs. Otto A. Rosalsky, widow of the General Sessions judge, yesterday in the Felony Court withdrew a charge of suspicion of grand larceny against Mrs. Dorothea Kulkin, 40 years old, of 400 West End Avenue, owner of a jewelry establishment at 1 West Forty-seventh Street.

The reduction in Plymouth automobile prices by $15 is equivalent to about one-third of the recent price increases and is practically certain to be followed by Chevrolet and Ford owing to the competitive nature of the low-priced car business. The action is viewed in Wall Street as the wisest sort of move at this time.

One of the briefest hearings in the history of the Securities and Exchange Commission came to an end last night when Smith W. Brookhart Jr. of counsel for the commission closed his attack on the registration statement of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., with a request that its effectiveness be suspended.
Since 1920 the number of motor vehicles registered in the United States has increased three times, since 1916 eight times. The early years of the depression forced the figure drastically down.

For the second time within six months the Interstate Commerce Commission today declined to ratify the appointment of Vincent Dailey as a trustee of the New York, Ontario Western Railroad. The commission, in a split decision, held that the expenses of a second trustee of the property would be an unnecessary expense.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Oct. 30 totaled 307,140,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines.

The Department of Docks will be asked to remove an abandoned pier at the foot of East Twentysixth Street as "a menace to the safety of Bellevue Hospital," authorities there said yesterday as they watched flames lick at the rotted wooden piles for the thirtieth time. this year.

Two more defendants, one an alleged lieutenant of Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, fugitive racketeers, pleaded guilty yesterday to violation of the Sherman anti-trust law in the city's $75,000,000-a-year fur-dressing industry.

In the United States District Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday 340 aliens were admitted to citizenship in this country; 247 were women and ninety-three men. Judge Grover M. Moscowitz who presided at the proceedings commented on the fact that women far outnumbered men.

The improved position of properties being handled by the State of New Jersey in the course of liquidating or reorganizing many banks, building and loan associations and title and insurance companies in that State is emphasized in a report submitted to Carl K. Withers, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, by J. K. Powell, chief of the real estate section of the Division of Conservation.

Declaring as fallacious the belief of manufacturers that they can pass along to consumers all of their increased labor costs, Dr. Lionel D. Edie, economist and head of the advisory services bearing his name, yesterday asserted that merchandise prices must be adjusted down- G. E. ward in line with the reduction in consumer' purchasing power.
A seven-judge Supreme Court will decide whether the Department Of Justice can proceed with its suit in a New York Federal court in an effort to dissolve the Aluminum Company of America.

In its survey of the Merchant Marine Industry sent to the Capitol for consideration,of the special session of Congress, the Maritime Commission recommended a number'of amendments which would liberalize the law and define the commission's powers more clearly.

Among today's major events will be the appearance tonight of Lotte Lehmann in a lieder recital at the opening of the Town Hall's annual endowment fund series; a triple bill, comprising "Le Pauvre Matelot," "The Matrimonial Market" and "Angelique," at the Fortyfourth Street Theatre by the Salzburg Opera Guild this evening, and a program by Miss Stiles-Allen, dramatic soprano, at the Town Hall in the afternoon.

Greater strides toward uniformity in State traffic laws have been made in 1937 than in any prior year, A. W. Koehler, executive secretary of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators, declared yesterday at the. second session of a seminar on safety in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Class officers fdr the current semester at Hunter College were announced yesterday as follows: Lower Freshman Class-President, Laura Whitehorn; vice president. Anna Marie Visaggio; secretary-treasurer, Margaret Berman; council representatives. Patricia Williams and Geraldine Schmidt; judicial board representative. Jeanne Bernstein.

The Belgian Cabinet crisis continues. After completing his Cabinet yesterday, Paul Spaak, before submitting the list to King Leopold today, learned that three of his proposed Ministers had withdrawn. He must go through the entire process of consultations again tomorrow after consultation with the King.

The dollar recovered strongly in the foreign exchange market yesterday as news of the Treasury's action in releasing $10,250,000 in gold for shipment to France was accepted abroad as tending to discredit rumors of a further advance in the price of that metal.
Katherine Bregy, poet and lecturer, has been elected president for 1937-38 of the Catholic Poetry Society of America, to succeed Daniel Sargent, it was announced yesterday.
An investigation of rumors that freshman athletes at the University of Michigan have been subsidized in violation of Western Conference rules was aunched tonight.

All monthly sales records for the export of Studebaker cars and trucks were broken in October, Arvid L. Frank, president of the Studebaker Export Corporation, announced yesterday. The previous record was set in March, 1928.

Lieut. Col. G. M. de Kruyff of The Netherlands Army team last night won the International Individual Military Championship Challenge Trophy at the seventh evening session of the fifty-second National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 8: COLONELS Kelley, R. H., Inf., Philippines, to Columbia, S. C., as instructor of Infantry, South Carolina National Guard.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte" by the Salzburg Opera Guild -on Friday night at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre for the benefit of the philanthropic and educational fund of the New York Society for Ethical Culture.

The declining birth rate in New York City dropped still further for the week ended last Saturday, according to a report yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. Only- 1,714 births for the week were reported, the fewest of any week since that ending May 29.
Radio distortion and fading have succumbed in large part at least, to efforts of research workers, according to a report made to the Institute of Radio Engineers at its Fall meeting here today.
Ralph Greenleaf of New York, the defending champion in the world championship pocket billiard tournament, defeated Marcel Camp of Detroit, 125 to 92, in 17 innings tonight.

Lewis N. C. Medbury, actor, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 56 years old. Born at Atlas, Mich., Mr. Medbury had been on the stage from the time he was graduated from Racine College in Wisconsin, until his retirement in 1931.

Leon Fraser, chairman of the roll call of New York Chapter, American Red Cross, expressed confidence in the success of the campaign at a conference of leaders and division chairmen yesterday at the chapter house, 315 Lexington Avenue.

The Czechoslovak Republic celebrated a few days ago the nineteenth anniversary of its foundation on that storm-swept Oct. 28, 1918, when the Austrian general command in Prague woke up late after a late night and found the city in control of the Czechs.

Mayor La Guardia will be the principal speaker at the observance of the nineteenth anniversary of Armistice Day tomorrow at 10:45 A. M. at the Eternal Light in Madison Square Park, it was announced yesterday by Major Gen.

The Frans Hals exhibition, which opened to the public yesterday, at the Schaeffer Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, promises to pile up a large attendance record during its brief stay of a fortnight.

Miss Alethia Brandford Sheldon, daughter of Mrs. Oakley Sheldon of 170 East Seventy-eighth Street and of Dr. William Hills Sheldon of Rome, Italy, will be married to R. Alastair Macleod of this city on Thursday afternoon, Nov. 18, at the home of her mother.

Magdeleine Jeanne de Fontanges, 32-year-old French actress, who arrived Monday on the Normandie under her maiden name of Madeleine Coraboeuf and who was detained on the ship for the night by the Immigration officials, went to Ellis Island yesterday morning and appeared before a board of special inquiry composed of three inspectors.

The International Paper Com pany, subsidiary of the Internation al Paper and Power Company, has purchased the entire 40,000 tons of newsprint output of the Brompton Pulp and Paper Company, Ltd., at Bromptonville, Que., for five years.

Jack Dunn, Olympic ice-skating champion who was under contract at Universal for a year without appearing before the camera, was signed today by Paramount for a leading role in "Everybody's Girl," which will be Howard Estabrook's first production.

The funeral of John Palmieri, former City Court Justice, was held yesterday in Brooklyn. A solemn mass of requiem was celebrated in the Roman Catholio Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, Fort Hamilton Parkway and East Fourth Street, by the pastor, the Rev. Daniel Dwyer.

Estate, $1,500. To Josephine Jalma Alexander widow, executrix, 28 Washington Sq. BLUMENTHAL, ALTER (Nov. 1). Estate, more than. $20,000. To Sara Pam Blumenthal. widow, executrix, residue. A. Pam Blumenthal, son, 1,120 Park Ave., and Irving Blumenthal, brother, New Canaan, Conn., executors.
The army's experimental infantry division made another great mechanical bound toward the north today over roads mired and matted in Texas mud.

In one of the finest matches played thus far this season Frank Hanson of the Columbia University Club, second in the tournament seeding, eliminated 19-year-old Frank Iannicelli of the New York A. C. in the second round yesterday of the Princeton Club's annual squash tennis tourney.

The historic march of the Hitler Putschists on Nov. 9, 1923, from the Buergerbraeu Keller to the Feldherrenhalle was re-enacted today as on previous anniversaries since Adolf Hitler's accession to power.

Frank A. Randall, 521 Fifth Avenue, trading as Sulpho-Sol Company, the Lander Company, Inc., 200 Fifth Avenue, and Warner's Safe Remedies Comnpany, Rochester, N. Y., have agreed to stop certain allegedly misleading advertising representations, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.
Passing and kicking were emphasized by the Princeton football squad as it went through a spirited two-and-a-half-hour practice on University Field today.

Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Day Mallory entertained a company of seventyfive at their home here this evening in honor of their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Miller of Elkhorn Ranch, Bozeman, Mont. Colored motion pictures of life on his Montana ranch were shown by Mr. Miller.

Richard Frankensteen, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, announced here today that 11,000 employes of the Hudson Motor Car Company at Detroit would return to work tomorrow to end a strike that started this morning as a result of the- lay-off of certain union members in alleged violation of an agreement. Mr.

Of the seven major teams in the East that remain unbeaten, Pittsburgh has the most formidable opposition to reckon with down the homestretch and Lafayette appears to have the best chance of finishing the season without a setback.

The Ranee of Sarawak, who rules with her husband over the sultanate in Northern Borneo often described as "the last Eden," arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania for a two-month visit.

The War Department granted a further extension today to the Department of Plant and Structures of New York City to Nov. 2, 1938, and Nov. 2, 1940, respectively, for beginning and completing the construction of a bridge across Sheepshead Bay at Ocean Avenue,- Brooklyn.
Edwin Stearne, a real estate conveyancer, father of Judge Allen M. Stearne of the Orphans' Court, died at his home here today. He was 80 years old.

Dr. Earle Bryant Perkins, Assistant Professor of Zoology at Rutgers University and zoologist with the second Byrd expedition to the Antarctic, received the Congressional Medal of Honor here tonight at the Charter Day dinner of the Rutgers Club of New Brunswick..

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,533,150 barrels, compared to 3,602,950 in the previous week, a decline of 69,800, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

The United Federal -Workers of America, an organization of government employs affiliated with the C. I. O., declared today that Secretary Perkins's proposed method-for the handling of grievances in the. Labor Department, "if used by employers in private industry, would be declared a company union device."

Another of the indictments returned by the August, 1934, New York County grand jury in its investigation of charges of irregularities among several mortgage companis which had got into financial difficultiese was quashed yesterday in General Sessions.

British steel producers announced today a decision to maintain prices of steel at their present level until the end of 1938 in conformity with a recommendation of the British Iron and Steel Federation.

Mrs. Reba E. Minford, for many years in her own business here and in Florida, has been appointed manager of the new residential deapartment formed at Riker Co., Inc. She will handle furnished and unfurnished apartments and houses on the East Side for sale and lease.

Two city officials testified yesterday that contracts for electrical work under the jurisdiction of their departments had been canceled after strikes against the low bidders had been called by Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate.

Gustavo Vidal, Philip B. Niles, in 1,143 Fifth Ave; Leonard T. Holton, in 141 E 88th St; Mrs. Charlotte Satterlee, Mrs. Bertha K. Bixby, in 21 W 58th St; Mrs. Rose Austerlitz, in 140 E 81st St: Mrs. May Furman, in 24 W 59th St;

Plans have been completed by Miss Beatrice Gertrude Boye, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Louis Boye of Summit, N. J., for her marriage to Robert William Talbot, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Maxwell Talbot, also of Summit, which will take place in the First Baptist Church in Summit the afternoon of Nov. 27. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. David K. Barnwell.

William J. Wallin, Yonkers attorney and former Mayor-of that city, was elected president of the Westchester County Park Commission at an executive meeting of the commission here yesterday, it was announced today.

The audience, large and happy, that gathered last night in the Forty-fourth Street Theatre to hear the Salzburg Opera Guild's production of Monteverdi's "Coronation of Poppea" saw a kind of spectacle and heard a kind of music which they probably had not, in a majority. anticipated.

The restaurant building formerly known as Pelham Heath Inn at 1,500 Pelham Parkway, southeast corner of Eastchester Road, the Bronx, has been purchased by a client of Greiner, Peecook Buck, attorneys.

A net profit of $38,944,380, equivalent to $2.57 each on 14,584,025 nopar common shares after allowing 300,00 for preferred dividends, was reported yesterday for the first nine months of 1937 by the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

Columbia's regulars returned to practice at Baker Field yesterday for the first time this week. Though many of the players were severely battered by the big Navy team last Saturday, the first team lined up intact for a light dummy scrimmage in preparation for the game against Syracuse here on Saturday.

An involved explanation of the postponement of Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch's projected visit to Berlin, issued in semi-official circles tonight, was considered an indication that for the present at least France's influence here is still strong.

President Roosevelt said today that the government would continue to build up social security reserves, but emphasized that the law undoubtedly would be changed by Congress in the light of experience.

Most of the canvassers hired at $10 a day to tally the proportional representation ballots for Councilmen in the five boroughs "just about passed" the non-competitive examination for the post conducted by the Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was revealed yesterday.
G. G. Palma has been appointed district passenger agent of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway in New York. He was formerly passenger representative here.

Mrs. Kate Livingston Seymour Seymour, wife of Frank Seymour, died at her home in Cos Cob today, after a long illness. She was born in Cochecton, N. Y., seventy-five years ago. The daughter of the Rev.

Charges that James H. -Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., and Pearl A. Bergoff, former head of the Bergoff Industrial Service, Inc., had tried to suppress evidence were made in Federal District Court today by Charles H. Carr, special government prosecutor, in their trial for alleged violation of the Byrnes act prohibiting the transportation of persons across State lines for strike-breaking purposes.

With the testimony of thirty-four witnesses written into the record, Government attorneys today neared the close of their presentation of evidence in the gasoline price-fixing conspiracy case, now in its brace sixth week.
Mrs.L. H. Nimkoff's gallant 7-year-old campaigner, Beefsteak, showed a trace of old-time form today in winning the feature race at Rockingham Park before 10,000 spectators.

IT would be almost impossible, I suppose, to say who first thought of using the camera to mold public opinion, but artists are using it for that purpose today, and with tremendous effect. Perhaps the pioneer. was old Mathew B. Brady, who carted around his clumsy picture-box in the train of- the Union armies and took those incredible scenes of bloated and several-days-dead soldiers lying on the fields of Antietam and Spottsylvania Court House.

Tom D. Cochrane, general manager in the Orient for Paramount Pictures, Inc., and long prominent in the moving-picture field, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of a paralytic stroke suffered on Sunday night.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman D. Aery of 140-20 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Flushing, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anita E. Aery, to Brantlin J. Mecklenburg, son of Mrs. John J. Mecklenburg, also of Flushing.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 6: REAR ADMIRAL Pickens, A. C., when discharged from treatment at the Naval Hospital, Washington, D. C., to duty as member of the General Board, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C.
Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Nov. 8 unless specified: San Pedro to sea: Arizona, Brooks, California, Colorado, Idaho, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, West Virginia.
Faced with the possibility of losing Harry Harrison and Co-captain Sammy Donato for the Maryland game Saturday, Coach Bob Higgins experimented with a new Penn State backfield today.

A supplemental contract was awarded by the War Department today to the Douglas Aircraft Company of Santa Monica, Calif., for twenty-nine additional Model A-17-A attack airplanes at a cost of $654,155.90.
The Dartmouth football squad, which devoted yesterday's practice to horseplay, turned to the serious business of stopping the Cornell offense today in preparation for next Saturday's game here.

Medical and chemical research has made considerable progress in clearing up the mystery of the mechanism underlying the formation of stones calculii) in the bladder and associated organs, the tenth annual graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine was told last night by Dr. Linwood D. Keyser, surgeon at the Roanoke General Hospital, Roanoke, Va.

Officials of Boston announced yesterday that sealed proposals would be received on next Monday for an issue of $2,307,000 of bonds for relief and airport purposes. The bonds, to be dated Dec. 1, 1937, will mature serially on Dec. 1, 1938 to 1947. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest.

Competition in women's squash racquet tournaments started yesterday, with the Rockaway Hunting Club giving a sterling performance as it downed the Staten Island Cricket Club representatives, 5 to 0, on the victor's courts in Cedarhurst in a Class B Metropolitan Association engagement.

Lieut. Col. Ralph Sasse, one of football's most colorful figures, resigned today as head coach of Mississippi State College. G. D. Humphrey, university president, said Sasse resigned on orders of his physician, Dr. J. W. Eckford, who asked that the colonel relinquish his duties immediately.

The part played by the protective committee for the holders of Missouri Pacific Railroad first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds in the plans for the reorganization of that railroad was the subject of inquiry today by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce.

The government's decision on the petroleum wage controversy affecting sixteen American and British firms is now ready. The Department of Commerce in Washington announced yesterday that a decision unfavorable to the companies might have an extremely unfavorable effect on Mexican economic conditions.

As the President and his advisers survey the present business situation, and consider what can be done to check the recession which is now in progress, the public utilities industry invites attention.

Since the number of cases of rabies among dogs. in the Bronx has not abated to the extent expected in the last six months, the Board of Health yesterday extended for another three months the quarantine against dogs in the borough.
Senator James J. Davis, Republican, has. resumed active direction of the Royal Order of Moose, which he gave up seven years ago, William gave up seven years ago.
Lawrence Marks, 49-year-old exconvict, was sentenced yesterday in Kings County Court to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison during the week of Dec. 20 for the sex-slaying of 8-year-old

The Department of Agriculture now estimates that this year's cotton crop will reach 18,243,000 bales, the largest in the history of the country. This crop is being reached in the face of an acreage control program. The previous record crop, that of 1926, was produced on 45,000,000 acres.

War Admiral pounded down the stretch, Helen Wills Moody swung a tennis racquet and.. other- performers appeared on a small screen in the Bourse Building here this afternoon as the Bell Telephone laboratories demonstrated, for the first time, the use of the company's coaxial cable between this city and New York as a transmitter of a- current similar to a television current.

A forty-eight-family apartment house, costing about $195,000, is planned for 197-211 East Second Street, Brooklyn, and a six-story house which is expected to cost $175,000 will be built on the northwest corner of Twenty-ninth Street and Thirty-fifth Avenue, Long Island City, according to specifications submitted by architects yesterday.
A number of contracts for commercial space in the upper Fifties featured the business leasing activity announced yesterday by brokers and agents.
The old home on Middle Road, near Oakwood Avenue, Bayport, L. I., which for thirty years housed the family of Dr. Frederick B. Keppy, has been purchased by Frank Cahill of Brooklyn.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Rogers of New York and Mountain View, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Rogers, to J. Warren Jones also of this city and Huntington, W. Va.
Seven-year-old Helen Logan of Seattle returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania with her faith in the protective powers of the American flag undiminished.

CAUGHT at rest on his New Rochelle homestead, Onkel Franz Frisch, the FarmerLabor leader of the St. Louis Cardinals, eased himself into a chair and yawned. Probably that came from thinking of Dizzy Dean. "Good old Gunga Dean!" said Onkel Franz with a grunt, "I see where he's opened a filling station in Florida.

Sentiment in the, stock market here today was bolstered by yesterday's recovery in Wall Street, so most sections went ahead. Gilt-edge issues weakened slightly but foreign bonds did well. Transatlantic stocks were in demand; United States Steel and International Nickel advanced.

With the opening today of the gunning season for upland game in New Jersey, forty-two woods and brush fires were reported to Captain Leroy S. Fales, acting State fire wardens Most of them were small and quickly extinguished, but only Hudson, Essex and Mercer Counties were not affected.

THOSE who admired Paul B. Sears's "Deserts on the March" should welcome its successor, "This Is Our World,"* in which genuine literary skill is once more blended with an amiable, wise and skeptical scientific spirit. Although Professor. Sears is by training a biologist, his interests extend into the larger spheres of life and living in general.

In a move designed to bring about the adoption of a common standard of athletic eligibility among the group of colleges with which it desires to have relations, Cornell University has subscribed to a verbatim copy of the triple agreement among'Harvard, Yale and Princeton.
After three attempts to form a Ministry that have dragged out for more than two weeks, Belgium is without a Cabinet tonight.

With the entrance of manufacturers of home wares and furnishings into the Christmas picture on a large scale for the first time, the scramble for holiday business this year will be particularly pronounced and advertising media may be expected to benefit, agency executives pointed out here yesterday.

Plans are well advanced for the last three units of Rockefeller Center and "within the next year or so" these buildings will rise to complete the vast midtown amusement and commercial development, Nelson A. Rockefeller, executive vice president of Rockefeller Center, Inc., told the New York Building Congress yesterday.

Joseph Stalin, leader of the Soviet Union, who had been nominated in 580 different districts for a seat in, the new Supreme Soviet [Parliament], announced today he would accept the nomination of the so-called Stalin district of Moscow.

With interest of buyers at this time almost entirely confined to silver fox skins, the quantities of newcatch furs coming into the market here continue comparatively small, Meanwhile, there has been some delay in the issuance of additional price lists by dealers receiving trappers' consignments here.
Negotiations for purchase of the Marmon Motor Car Company plant No. 2 at Indianapolis by the Stewart-Warner Corporation are in an advanced stage, it was announced today.

The charity ball held tonight on the roof of the Bellevue-Stratford to assist four hospitals was attended by more than 500 persons and depicted the pageantry of five great wars in the history of the United States. The first charity ball of this city was held in the American Academy of Music in 1881.

Senator Byrd of Virginia emphasized the Federal Government's "double budget" last night's in his economy speech before the Academy of Political Science. He pointed out that even after all recovery and relief expenditures of the "emergency"

Eliro Dokanaki, 35-year-old woman emplayed as a typist in the code deapartment of the Greek Foreign Office for ten years, has been arrested and charged with betraying official secrets and spying, it was disclosed today.
The twenty-first annual membership roll-call of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross will begin today in Manhattan and the Bronx and will continue until Thanksgiving.

The reserves raised havoc with the Dartmouth varsity's defense for nearly a half hour today, but near the end of the defensive drill, the regulars, led by Gus Zitrides and-Roy Duckworth, guards, and Left Tackle Larry Dilkes, began to solve the Cornell formations.

Lou Little, Columbia coach, and Columbia itself must have remarkable recuperative powers. Looking at the squad the morning after the Cornell game, less than two weeks ago, bruised and battered and scarcely able to navigate on their own power,

The Department of Agriculture forecast today that Massachusetts would have its second largest crop of - cranberries in history475,000 barrels-to supply the "fixin's" for Thanksgiving and Christmas dinners.

Our Tallulah is taking a valiant fling at Cleopatra in Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra," which was put on at the Mansfield last evening. But in all conscience it is' difficult to find anything except her courage to praise in her performance.

Legality of the application of land holders of the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., for reorganization of the company, was questioned by Arthur Slaght, K. C., counsel) for Wood, Gundy Co., before Justice McTague in Supreme Court at Osgoode Hall todays.

The constitutionality of the 1934 laws permitting bookmaking at State horse racing tracks was challenged from a new angle today in five suits filed in the Supreme Court here against five racing associations and John G. Cavanagh, supervisor of betting operations at the tracks.

Scott Freeman Ennis, Past Potentate of Islam Temple of the Mystic Shrine here and wealthy business executive, died today from injuries suffered in an automobile accident last week. He was 68 years old.

After two days of rest, the Fordham football, squad began work yesterday at Fordham Field for the game with St. Mary's at the Polo Grounds a week from Saturday. The Maroon was worked hard by Coach Jim Crowley, who ordered forward passing for the
Bronx real estate deals announced yesterday principally involved multi-family dwellings in the central and southern sections of the borough.

With considerable grumbling and occasional threats of a sit-down strike, the canvassers of the proportional representation ballots for the new City Council learned yesterday that, beginning tomorrow, they must work a full eight hours for their daily stipend of $10 for as long as it takes them to complete the count.

The marriage of Miss Isabelle Vera King of Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Holbrook King, to Henry Valentine Birgel, son of Mrs. Henry F. Birgel, also of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Birgel, took place yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Refuge in Brooklyn.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Horton of this city for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Horton, to Francis H. Orr, son of Mrs. Mary Orr of Rahway. The wedding will take place Thanksgiving Eve in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception here.
The will of Winthrop Ames was offered for probate at the registry today by Hobart Ames and Lucy Ames of Easton, brother and wife of the testator, who are named executors.

Charging that Communist and other anti-democratic elementse have captured the present Spanish Loyalist Government, the Notre Dame Club of New York, composed of 600 alumni of the University of Notre Dame, commended the. Spanish Insurgents' cause in resolutions adopted last night at a meeting at the Center Club; 120 Central Park South.

In its first move in twenty years, the Merriam Paper Company of 150 Lafayette Street will occupy the seven-story building at 135 Hudson Street, which it has leased from the Ernst Bischoff Company. John Avlon was the broker.

Manati Sugar Company common stock, $100-par value, and 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100-par value, have been suspended from New York Stock Exchange dealings. The company now is going through a recapitalization under which holders of old preferred will receive three shares of new common and a ten-year warrant to buy another share at $12.50;

General Hugh S. Johnson, who was scheduled to speak over WJZ from 10 to 10:15 last night, learned when he arrived at the studio that he would not be permitted to read a prepared speech, which he had submitted in advance, because it was a discussion of the ravages of social disease.

The address of Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau before the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor last night follows: I welcome the opportunity to discuss before the members and guests of the Academy of Political Science the subject of Federal spending and its relation to the balancing of the Federal budget.

Dreams of airplanes flying at a speed of 1,000 miles an hour at an altitude of 100,000 feet are absurd, Major Albert W. Stevens, United States Army stratosphere explorer, told the Kiwanis Club here today.

At an informal discussion of the rules and regulations authorized by the Federal Trade Commission for the rayon industry, at the commission's headquarters here today, the National Retail Dry Goods Association

Telegraph Company, Inc., for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses and charges of $2,825,457. This was equal to $2.70 a share on the outstanding capital stock,

Continuing their enforcement of the new "padlock law" on orders of Premier Duplessis, Quebec Provincial police today shut down a printing plant, raided a book shop and padlocked the living quarters of Jean Peron, editorial writer and candidate of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation for the St. James Division in the 1935 Federal elections.

Frederick C. Havemeyer 2d. in 1,001 Park Ave: Mrs. J. Prentice Kellogg. through Brown, Wheelock, Harries, Stevens, Inc, in 860 Park Ave: Joshua J. Cosden, in 19 E 72d St: Edward L. Kilroe, through Culver, Holiday Co, Inc. in 9 E 96th St: Beatrice L. Renwick. Inc, broker.

A one-hour sitdown strike took place today in the metal industries throughout the Paris region. Although in some instances the employers threatened the workers with reprisals, there were no disorders and work was resumed when the time limit set by the unions had elapsed.
A mine fire swept on unchecked today beneath part of the city where live 10,000 inhabitants.
Syracuse scored a double victory over Army in cross-country running today, capturing a varsity match, 17 to 38, and a freshman contest, 21 to 34.
The Public Utility Commission refused today the request of railoads in Pennsylvania for increases in freight rates. Commissioner Richard J. BeamIsh said this was the first time that
Appeal from a death sentence imposed upon Anna Marie Hahn will be taken to the United States Supreme Court, if necessary, Joseph H. Hoodin, defense counsel, said today.
Charles F. Hosford Jr., chairman of the Bituminous Coal Commission, told friends today that he intended to stay on the job until the commission approved a soft coal price structure.

Fatal accidents to babies less than 1 year old in the United States exceed 2,000 annually and take a toll of infant life greater than the combined mortality from measles, scarlet fever and diphtheria in any average year, statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company reported yesterday.

News from Rio de Janeiro yesterday that Brazil would suspend payment on her debts abroad recalled that her external bond issues have frequently remained in default for varying periods of years because of an inability to acquire sufficient foreign exchange.

The Federal Council has approved the text of a bill that it will propose to-Parliament authorizing the Council to make provisions so that the army and the country will be sure of indispensable supplies in wartime.

Shipments of finished steel products by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation during October totaled 792,310 tons, a low for the year and a decline of 255,652 tons from September. It was the highest October since 1929 with the exception of last year, when shipments for the month were 1,007,417 tons.

General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator, attacked the New Deal's spending program as threatening eventual collapse or complete change of the politicoeconomic system in an address yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting of the Academy of Political Science at the Hotel Astor.

Frank J. Morris, who was a police inspector from 1914 to 1919 and retired from the department with the rank of captain in 1924, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 220 Boscobel Place, the Bronx, after a fortnight's illness. He was born in Ireland seventythree years ago.
Baron Wilhelm von Wymetal, former stage director of the Vienna Opera and the Metropolitan Opera Company of New York, will be buried on Friday. Baron von Wymetal, 75, died Monday.

On the eve of RKO's reorganization of its stock structure, approval of which on Monday in Federal court in New York is anticipated realignment of studio personnel to compensate for the resignation of S. J. Briskin as head of production has been completed by Leo Spitz, president of RKO-Radio. Pandro S.

You have invited me to speak on the expenditures of the Federal Government, a subject that has interested me more than ever before because of my investigation as chairman of the Senate select committee to investigate Federal agencies for purposes of government reorganization.

The Franklin Building and Loan Association of Jersey City has sold the two-family house at 68 Charles Street, Jersey City, to Anna Goggin. J. I. Kislak, Inc., and the Rollfs Realty Company were the brokers.

Federal experts increased their estimate of this year's corn crop by 89,000,000 bushels today in a report which is expected to be used by Administration officials as an argument for new legislation to control production.

The prosecution in the RandBergoff case scored a point today when, over repeated objections from the defense, Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the Federal District Court admitted evidence designed to show that the methods used by Remington Rand, Inc., in the strike of its 1,200 employes at Middletown, were part of a system employed by the company at other plants in New York during the strike.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Oct. 31 showed the ratio of gold reserve to notes in circulation to be 130.58 per cent, against 132.34 per cent on Oct. 15. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities was 88.76 per cent against 90.40 per cent.
Science is scoring resounding victories these days. Only a few weeks ago it was established by actual laboratory test that
Williamsbridge Rd (12-3359), s w cor of Bronx Blvd. 50x115; Charlotte Svigals to Haffen Realty Co., 2,791 3d Ave; mtge, $17,500.

Scotland and Ireland practically frittered away their chances of gaining international soccer honors this season by drawing, 1-1, today. In previous encounters both countries were defeated, the Scots bowing to Wales, 2-1, while England trounced Ire. land, 5-1.

William F. Fitzgerald, Boston banker and broker, died today at his home in Brookline. He was 69 years old. Called the "copper king" of Boston, he was head of the brokerage firm of Fitzgerald, Hubbard Co.,

J. Gould Remick's Sarona Jacob of Marvadel was awarded first place today in the amateur stakes of the annual field meet of the Labrador Retriever Club, held in Shinnecock Hills. Thirteen dogs competed in the final series. The winner, handled by his owner, is a son of Penwortham Protector and Sarona Gipsy.

Following the Senate's action at the last session, the House is scheduled to rush through a Federal Wage and Hour Bill without making any serious effort to acquaint itself with the actual conditions with which that bill is to deal. No comprehensive figures exist, for example, which show precisely what the differences in wage rates are between the different sections of the country.

The protective committee of stockholders of the Old Colony Railroad Company advocated two alternatives before the Interstate Commerce Commission today concerning reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company.
A vicar of the Church of England tonight disputed the Duke of Windsor's privilege of attending Armistice Day memorial services at St. George's Church.

With a special session of Congress convening Monday to consider permanent farm legislation, Louis J. Taber of Columbus, Ohio, master of the National Grange, suggested today ten basic principles which he told delegates to the annual convention should be contained in any workable agricultural program.

Nathan L. Amster, president of the Manhattan Railway Company, told stockholders yesterday at thb annual meeting that unification of the city's transit properties was closer now than ever before and "at a price at which the city can congratulate itself." It is possible,

Francisco Campos, Minister of Justice and Interior, said that the Constitution, promulgated today and to be submitted eventually to a plebiscite, strengthens democracy by molding it to the real requirements of the Brazilian nation.

Colonel-General Hermann Goering is aiming to speed up the German Four-Year Plan to the point of finishing it in two years if possible, and this is what has brought to a climax the general conflict between him and Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, according to a source in a position to know the inside of this affair.

Dr. Henry Clay Ferris, an orthodontist and one of the early residents of this place, died this morning of a heart attack at his home here. Dr. Ferris, who was 66 years old, maintained an office in New York at 104 East Fortieth Street.

James Sanders, identified by the police as James Sweeney, was arrested here tonight, and Detective Lieutenant Jack Malina said the prisoner was wanted on a Federal indictment for alleged participation in the kidnapping four years ago of John J. O'Connell Jr. in Albany, N. Y.
THE KAISER ON TRIAL, by George Sylvester Viereck (Greystone, $3.50). A statement of the case for Wilhelm II.

Legislation to carry out the recommendations of the Maritime Commission for changes in the Ship Subsidy Act will be considered by the House Merchant Marine Committee, Representative Bland of Virginia, its chairman, said today.

Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a twostory exhibition building on the World's Fair grounds to be erected at a cost of. $1,500,000. Sloan Robertson, architects, filed the plans.

" I am the law!" Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City declared tonight in a talk on "City Government" before nearly 1,000 members and guests of the Emory Methodist Episcopal Church, Bergen and Belmont Avenues, here.

Muriel Lester, pacifist, social worker and founder of Kingsley Hall in the East End of London, said yesterday afternoon that it would be "rather soppy" of her not to go to Japan and China "because of a war." Consequently,
The Italy America Society and the American Society of the Royal Italian Orders opened their new headquarters yesterday at 122 East Forty-eighth Street.

The Chase National Bank, acting as trustee under the indenture securing $35,974,000 of 5 per cent debentures of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation due on Feb. 1, 1959, has notified the company of an acceleration of the issue, which calls for immediate maturity, it became known yesterday.
President Roosevelt issued a call today to citizens to enroll in the American Red Cross membership drive, which begins tomorrow.
The Duke of Gloucester today unveiled an equestrian statue of Earl Haig, ending an eight-year quarrel over the fitness of the four-ton memorial.

President Getulio Vargas's Cabinet today approved and put into immediate effect a new Constitution. The instrument dissolves the Federal Congress, State Assemblies and Municipal Councils and concentrates in the hands of the President greater authority than any head of the Brazilian State has enjoyed since the days of the Braganza Emperors.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of James French in THE TIMES of Nov. 1 indicates some confusion as to the economic considerations involved in railway service and railway rate-making. He contends that the value of railway property is determined by the "inexorable law of supply and demand," and appears to believe that present stock market prices reflect the true value of railway property.
Two Japanese operations south of Shanghai today indicated imminent offensives to wipe out the last Chinese resistance here and to launch a major drive toward Nanking, China's capital.

Circuit Judge James E. Chenot granted a temporary injunction today restraining two unions affiliated with the United Automobile Workers of America from picketing the Detroit automobile show. A hearing was set for Saturday.

A new crush-proof process for rayon pile fabrics was announced yesterday by the rayon department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. The process, designed particularly for transparent velvets, which are made with a rayon pile and silk back, has been adopted by a number of leading velvet manufacturers, and involves treating the fabric with a solution of formaldehyde in water, in the presence of a suitable catalyst, such as amonium chloride.
Canada last night captured the International Military Perpetual Challenge Trophy, chief event of the final session of the fifty-second National Horse Show in MadisonSquare Garden.
Arguments in the case of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company involving rate-making procedure for public utilities, will be heard by the Supreme Court tomorrow.

Governors of the thirteen original States or their personal representatives are expected to take part here tomorrow night in a dual observance of Armistice Day and New Jersey's ratification of the United States Constitution.

The Mercury Theatre will ring up its first curtain this evening at its rechristened house, formerly the Comedy. The production is Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar," done in modern dress, these people being among the players: Orson Welles,

Paul Spaak, Belgian chairman of the Nine-Power treaty conference, announced to a brief session of the conference today that his government had learned from Baron Albert de Bassompiere, its Ambassador to Tokyo, that the Japanese Cabinet would consider its reply to the conference's overture at a meeting Friday.

Plans for stimulating a nation-wide private housing program, involving large and small construction, began to take shape today in a conference held by President Roosevelt with five business leaders and economic advisers within the administration.

Baron Kishichiri Okura, a leading Japanese industrialist, sailed on the French liner Normandie yesterday after passing through a hostile picket line demonstrating against war and fascism and the Japanese campaign in China.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Nov. 26 on an application by the Potomac Electric Power Company, Washington, D. C., a subsidiary of North American Company, for exemption from the requirement of filing a declaration with respect to the issue of $5,000,000 of its first mortgage bonds, 31/4 per cent series, due in 19666.

Fair-trade contracts are being issued to retailers in forty more States that now have fair-trade contracts by the toilet article department of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, it was announced yesterday by Manning O'Connor, manager of the toilet article department.

Pudge Heffelfinger, one of Yale's football immortals, heard himself acclaimed yesterday as the greatest football player the game has ever known. The occasion was the all-America luncheon of the Touchdown Club at the Hotel Martinique.

Promulgation of the new Brazilian Constitution is seen here as a successful coup by President Getulio Vargas to establish an authoritarian regime making Brazil the first corporate State in South America.

A large-scale exhibit of Brazilian industries and products at the 1939 World's Fair was assured yesterday when Raphael Correa de Oliveira, official Brazilian representative, signed a contract for 48,000 square feet of space at the fair.
President Roosevelt has become the first honorary member of the American Press Society, it was disclosed today at the White House.
Playing on their own courts, the Junior League team scored a decisive 5-0 triumph over the Heights Casino in the Women's Metropolitan Interclub Class A squash racquets tournament yesterday.
Proceedings brought in a Swedish court today by two Swedish officers revealed that the German Veltjens arms firm had supplied a large order of cartridges to the Spanish Government.

Herbert O. Bergdahl, merchandise manager of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, presented data showing the relative volume of business done by members of the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., and various groups of manufacturers in the dress industry at a hearing yesterday before the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway.
General Vojeslav Tomic, Belgrade military commander, attempted to commit suicide today by firing two shots into his body. His condition is extremely grave.

Mrs. Eleanor Widener Dixon of Ronaele Manor, Elkins Park, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eleanor Widener Dixon, to James C. Gentle, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Gentle of Brookline, Mass.
Soviet newspapers warned "bourgeois democratic" countries today that they, as well as' the Soviet Union, were threatened with war by the Italo - German - Japanese alliance against communism.

Thomas Hitchcock Jr., Sands Point. Stewart Iglehart, Meadow Brook. Cecil Smith, Austin Polo Club. NINE GOALS M. G. Phipps, Meadow Brook. Captain C. T. I. Roark, Great Britain. EIGHT GOALS William Post, Meadow Brook. Erie Pedley, Midwick Country Club. Gerald Balding.

Visitors poured into THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair at Rockefeller Center yesterday to examine the latest and best books of 110 outstanding American publishers, to hear favorite authors in auditorium talks in the afternoon and evening and to examine the general exhibits on which all the publishers had cooperated to show what lies behind books.

10:45-11:02A. M.-Armistice Day Services at Tomb of Unknown Soldier, Arlington Cemetery-WABC. 10:45 A. M.-12:00 M.-Armistice Day Ceremonies at Eternal Light, Madison. Square; Mayor La Guardia and"Others-WNTC.

Victor B. Bendix, ship broker, of 39 Cortlandt Street, said yesterday that reports from Balboa, C. Z., that the captain of the freighter Eastern King Maru would get a bonus of $5,000 if he took his cargo of scrap iron to Japan safely and that the ship would then be scrapped were not correct.

Even in a screen season which has been rich in comedies, the Strand's "It's Love I'm After" must be reckoned among the gayest. It is a rippling farce, brightly written and deftly directed, and it has been played to the limit by an ingratiating cast.
A painting by the nineteenth-century French artist Paul Cezanne has been acquired for Philadelphia, Joseph E. Widener announced yesterday on behalf of the Commissioners of Fairmount Park.

Trustees of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to lease the Chicago, Rock Island Gulf Railway while the Rock Island Pacific is in bankruptcy.

A suit seeking to hold the Bank of the Manhattan Company responsible to the extent of $10,000,000 for losses sustained by investors in the $27,000,000 Series F certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was instituted yesterday in the Supreme Court.

Miss Jean Elizabeth Forsch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Forsch of this city, was married yesterday afternoon in St. James Church to Hugh Russell Jackson, son of Mrs. Dellem 0. Jackson of Lexington, Ky., and the late Mr. Jackson. The Rev. James A. Paul performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Rosalie Crockett Rand, widow of Colonel William Rand, New York lawyer, died yesterday morning at her residence, 145 East Fifty-fourth Street, after a brief illness. She was born in Medford, Mass., sixty-eight years ago.
Dr. Edward Leamington Nichols, internationally known physicist and author, died tonight at the home of his son. He was 84 years old. He was ill only a short time.

One of the few voters who wanted to cast a split ticket for delegateat-large to the Constitutional Convention charged yesterday in a letter to the Board of Elections that "ignorant and stupid" election inspectors had prevented him from exercising his franchise.

Few artists before the public today equal Lotte Lehmann in warmth and feeling, and capacity to communicate emotion to an audience. This was shown again at her first New York recital of the season last night in Town Hall.

Estate, more than, $10,000. To Frances Berman, daughter, 720 West End Ave., one-half residue in trust; six specific bequests; Bernard Berman, son, executor, 2 South Pinehurst Ave., one-half residue. Samuel Berman, brother, executor, 720 West End Ave.

With Steve Owen continuing to experiment with new backfield combinations, the New York Football Giants yesterday went through a drill at the Polo Grounds in preparation for Sunday's important struggle with the Detroit Lions at the Polo Grounds.
Three jobs and a prospect of several more materialized yesterday for Carl Weiss, 26-year-old blind college graduate who advertised for a position as a stenotypist.

The Newspaper Guild of New York made the following announcement last night: "The Newspaper Guild of New York filed today with the National Labor Relations Board a complaint against the New York Times, Inc.,

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 9, unless specified: At San Francisco: Arizona, California, Idaho, Nevada, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, West Virginia. Tsingtao to Shanghai, Nov. 10: Blackhawk, Stewart.

With each returning Armistice Day we must search our souls again as to the wisdom of the role this nation played in 1917 and 1918, and as to the direction it must now take. But however we might wish to reconstruct history, we can be sure of this:

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May of Brooklyn denied yesterday the application of six employes of the B. M. T. for a temporary restraining order to prevent the company from discharging them because of their failure to join the Transport Workers Union of America, the C. I. O. affiliate with which the company has a closed shop agreement.
Maguarditch Karayan, Armenian murderer of James Theodore Marriner, United States Consul. General at Beirut, was hanged at dawn today. While on the scaffold he shouted:
A declaration of the progress made in building up Yale as a center of learning was made by Dr. James Rowland Angell today in his-final report as president of the university.

Having added to his lead last Sunday, Clark Hinkle of the Green Bay Packers continues to. set the pace in the race for individual scoring honors in the National Football League, according to the statistics released yesterday.

Production of men's wear wool fabrics increased slightly in the four weeks ended Sept. 25 over the corresponding period last year, despite a decline in weekly average sales of 59.4 per cent from the weekly average of a year ago, data published in the monthly statistical
Andover defeated Exeter, 1-0, in soccer today to keep its undefeated record intact in the ten-year series with Exeter. Hagedorn, German exchange student, scored for Andover in the first quarter.
Mrs. Mary D. Hickman Price, leader in State social, patriotic and philanthropic circles, died in Virginia Mason Hospital last night.

More than 700 members and guests of the Holland Society of New York gathered in the Hotel Plaza last night for the fifty-third annual dinner of the order. The members trace their ancestry to the Dutch settlers of Manhattan Island before 1675.
Now that the excitement of the terrific conflict is ebbing away from Shanghai this city today began despairingly to clean up the dirt and debris of war and to count the cost.

The decline in electric power production last week was more than seasonal and ran counter to the normal long-term trend, lowering the adjusted index to 100.8 from 102.1. The figure for the week ended Nov. 7, 1936, was 105.6.
The largest wage dividend in the history of the Eastman Kodak Company, amounting to approximately $3,555,000 and payable on March 1, 1938, was voted today by Kodak's directors.

Stockholders of the E. W. Bliss Company have been called to a special meeting on Dec. 9 to approve amendments to the recapitalization plan of Aug. 17, under which it will be provided that no additional securities will be sold to the public at this time;
Higher prices were the rule oh the local commodity futures markets yesterday, reflecting strength in spot markets and higher security prices attributed to signs of a recovery in business confidence.
A three-year tapering-off period for the New York State mortgage moratorium was proposed yesterday before the Nunan legislative committee investigating moratorium and deficiency judgments.

Retail package deliveries rose 1 per cent for the week ended Nov. 6 over the same week last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. For the previous week the delivery organization noted an increase of 2 per cent.
W. C. Flanders has been appointed sales manager of the Worthington-Gamon Motor Company of Harrison, N. J., succeeding G. H. Gleason, who recently resigned as vice president in charge of sales.

The Chase National Bank applied yesterday in Supreme Court for a warrant of attachment against all the property in New York of the Commerz and Privat Bank Aktien Gesellschaft of Berlin, which is alleged to have defaulted on a $4,000,000 gold note on which $3,220,560 is now due.

As a resuIt of the incessant campaign of murder and terrorism throughout the country the Palestine government has decided to take the most stringent measures. A law, effective Nov. 18, makes the carrying or discharging of firearms an offense punishable by death.

Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. asserted last night that the Roosevelt Administration would make a "determined" movement toward balancing the Federal budget through reducing relief, farm and public works expenditures, and would try to encourage expansion of private business through revising taxes found to be inequitable.

Queen Elizabeth wound up a typical royal day when she drove with King George to London University tonight to receive from its Chancellor, the Earl of Athlone, the honorary degree of Doctor of Literature, and thus become the first reigning Queen to have conferred upon her an honorary degree from the 100-year-old university.
William G. Hall, a director of the Boys Club here and a building superintendent for the Mount Vernon Board of Education for forty years, died last night at his home at the age of 64.

Further changes in the amendments to the administrative provisions of the Tariff Act of 1930 are sought by the Merchants Association of New York, which announced yesterday that it had asked Senator Pat Harrison, chairman of the Senate committee on finance, to arrange a public hearing on the amending bill which was passed at the last session by the House.

A new form of labor protest was introduced yesterday by strikers of the Horn Hardart Automats, who staged a "lie-down strike" by sprawling on their backs in front of the Automat at 557 Seventh Avenue, near Thirty-fourth Street. A noonday crowd of 1,000 persons gathered, tying up pedestrian traffic and impeding vehicular traffic.

The text of uncompromisingly anti-Christian orders issued to higher Storm Troop officers by Viktor Lutze, their Chief of Staff, has become available here. Throughout the orders Christianity is referred to as "foreign ideology" and brown-shirt troops are advised to have nothing to do with it.

Engineering construction awards in the short week which, owing to the Armistice Day holiday, ended yesterday totaled $35,920,000, or 6 per cent less than the $38,372,000 reported in the corresponding week of last year, according to The Engineering News-Record.

Lafayette will seek to avenge a 31-6 defeat suffered at the hands of Washington and Jefferson last year when the Maroon eleven meets the Presidents here Saturday. A victory will give Lafayette its seventh in as many starts.

The Transit Commission invited Mayor La Guardia's cooperation yesterday in negotiations, already in progress, which the commission believes will result in rapid transit unification on terms far. more favorable to the city, including a saving of $70,000,000 in purchase price, than those fixed in the ill-fated plan for which Samuel Seabury and City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr., were sponsors.

The tremendous amount of water required for operation of the big air-conditioning plants installed in theatres and other large buildings has created a problem which municipal engineers and manufacturers of equipment are seeking to solve as quickly as possible to permit unretarded development of this industry.
An example of the value of sane and sensible conservation has been given by the West Virginia Conservation Commission, through its action on the squirrel situation in that State.

Harvey Dow Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, and Joseph C. Rovensky, vice president of the Chase National Bank, will represent American banks again at the annual meeting of short-term foreign creditors of Germany, it was learned yesterday,

An aged rancher emerged victorious tonight from a fantastic duel to death with a hooded, knifewielding marauder who could not match his sword-and-pistol defense. The intruder entered the home of Thomas Elliott, 79, on the pretext of delivering a telegram last night.

Miss Zita Yvonne Smail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward James Smail Jr. of Akron, Ohio, was married here last evening in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to John Elizardi Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Godfrey Miller of Havana.

Boycotts were variously classed as instruments of war and as the only effective means for maintaining world peace, in a debate of the advisability of banning Japanese merchandise, conducted yesterday at the initial meeting of the Executives Club, newly organized luncheon group at the Hotel Astor.
The Federal Trade Commission today issued an order requiring the Elite Glove Company, Inc., Gloversville, N. Y., to stop allegedly misleading representations in the sale of its products.

Stocks closed strong with gains of 2 to 6 points, dealings heaviest in utility shares; turnover, 1,923,650 shares. United States Government bonds steady, other groups higher; transactions, $10,775,025.
Corinne Rcche gave a mortgage to Delicia Gattegno for $6,000, payable $750 semiannually beginning next May 10, 5 per cent, on 410 W 50th St.

Although metal markets mostly were unchanged yesterday, sentiment both here and abroad was better. A heavy volume of business was reported as having been done in the export copper market at 10.20 cents a pound, c. i. f.

The General Farm Bill, which Congress pledged to make "the first order of business" at the next regular session, will not be ready for its consideration on Nov. 15 and leaders were unwilling today to predict when it would be.

Plans for modernizing two buildwings on the lower East Side were announced yesterday when the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to the 149-151 Norfolk Street Corportion the property at that address.

A luncheon meeting to spur the interest of producers in the activities of the American Theare Council, organized to improve theatre attendance, will be held tomorrow at the Hotel Astor. Frank Gillmore,

Japan will not be satisfied until she is able to subject. China wholly to her will, Dr. C. T. Wang,-Chinese Ambassador to the United States, said tonight in an address at the Armistice Eve banquet of the International Good-Will Congress.
