Steel production is holding above the national average in only a few districts, according to Iron Age, which reports that the Pittsburgh district is down to 34 per cent of capacity, the Chicago district down to 36 per cent, the Youngstown area to 40 per cent, the Cleveland-Lorain district to 37 per cent, and Buffalo to 32 per cent, with the national rate at 41 per cent, the low est since July, 1935.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

Judge George T. Cann, prominent attorney and former Chatham County Superior Court judge, died here today in his home of a heart attack. Judge Cann had been a member of the bar for more than fifty years.
Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-From 44th Precinct to 7th Division, assigned to duty in plain clothes; Charles B. Roman, Peter F. Ward.

Deciding that major changes were needed in Army's line-up if the cadets are to present a formidable front to Notre Dame in the Yankee Stadium Saturday, Coach Gar Davidson today made a number of shifts which are calculated to throw more weight where Harvard went through so easily last week-end, and also increase the strength of the backfield.

Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc. have placed a first mortgage of $340.000 with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on the recently completed apartment at 750 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, for a corporation headed by Joseph Seeger and Morris Cohen. The loan will carry interest of 4~1 per cent and runs for five years.

Holding its first scrimmage in three weeks, the Brooklyn College football team engaged in a threehour contact drill yesterday in an effort to polish the defensive tactics of the line and increase the power of the running and passing attacks.

More than 400 foreign films were presented for review to the motion-picture division of the State Education Department during the year ended June 30, Irwin Esmond, the director, said today in his annual report.
Bob Downes, 188-pound third-string guard, was used on the first team today. Otherwise Harvard's first team line-up was unchanged.
President Gabriel Terra today issued a decree prohibiting indefinitely the importation of automobiles, buses, trucks, chassis, motors and bodies. He acted at the request of the Miniter of Finance.

In a telephone conversation early this morning from Rio de Janeiro with THE NEW YORK TIMES, Frank M. Garcia, this newspaper's correspondent in the Brazilian capital, said yesterday's coup by President Getulio Vargas was accomplished without any untoward incidents on the part of the populace.

The growing belief in trading circles that the government is now fully aware that steps must be taken without undue delay if the decline in business is to be arrested, brought about yesterday a brisk advance in prices of securities and of most commodities.

The entire personnel of the Herbert Street police station, Brooklyn, made arrangements yesterday for the funeral of 13-year-old William Troeller who ended his life by hanging himself from the transom of his bedroom in his home at 275 Driggs Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, last Tuesday night.

With an operating loss of $7,822,000 over a seven-year period, there is nothing left for Panama Pacific and Grace Steamship Lines except to put their "luxury liners" in a more profitable service, according to A. Crawford Greene, counsel for the lines. He presented figures to West Coast business men, who are trying to prevent the transfer, to show that his company had made 158 voyages since opening the service.

Pointing to the oil industry as a prime example of individualism and free enterprise under the American system, Axtell J. Byles, president of the American Petroleum Institute, spoke here today on the theme "Gasoline Is Cheap; Only the Tax Is High."
The following Reserve officers recently released to the 1st Military Area are assigned as follows: 367th Field Artillery-2d Lt. Edward A. Rich, P.A.-Res., 931 University Pl., Schenectady, N. Y.

The dollar continued to make a better showing in foreign exchange yesterday, although it showed a small net loss in terms of sterling and the franc and arrangements for the export of $5,000,000 gold to England were announced by the Treasury in Washington.
If they are doomed and all that can be done Should fail-if they must die and disappear And we must see them dying one by one, Summer and Fall and Winter, year by year,
Japan's ultimate enemy in the present warfare in China is Great Britain, according to Yasuzumi Yamasaki, special writer for the newspaper Yomiuri.
Walter' Lamont Tower, former postmaster here and historian of the town, died last night of leukemia after an illness of two years. He was in his sixty-eighth year.

Many prominent military figures and consular representatives of foreign nations were among the large and brilliant assembly of society in the boxes at the final performance of the Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

The Works Progress Administration informed Senator Smathers today that President Roosevelt had designated five New Jersey projects eligible for allotment of $21,517. These are the projects, subject to review by the Controller General.

Curry, J. F., Air Corps, General Staff Corps, two days leave, Nov. 10. Brasted, A. J., Chief of Chaplains, one month and 13 days leave, Dec. 23. Hamilton, C. S., Inf., Philippines, detailed with the organized reserves, Manchester, N. H.
The beat and throb of New York City will slacken to a murmur at 11 o'clock this morning while the city pays its respect to the memory of those who gave their lives in the World War.

A lively fifty-minute dummy scrimmage featured the New York University football squad's workout yesterday at Ohio Field. Coach Mal Stevens is leaving nothing undone to prepare for Saturday's game with Georgetown at the Polo Grounds, and accordingly put his charges through a fast, hard practice session.

Friends of the budget in particular and followers of -Davy Crockett's famous maxim in general will find in the report of the United States Maritime Commission reading which is as remarkable as it is pleasing. This one passage in the chapter of conclusions is enough to establish the report as a breaker of records among government documents:

United States and British oil companies with an investment of $400,000,000 in Mexico will refuse to accept the government's decision on the oil wage controversy if this exceeds the pay increases offered by the companies.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. F. McCann have left their country place, Sunken Orchard, Oyster Bay, and are at their home here, 4 East Eightieth Street, for the season.
Cornell announced tonight, in making public its football schedules for 1938 and 1939, that it is seeking a major rival for a game in Ithaca Nov. 5, 1938. The date is open.
George R. Jacobus of Ridgewood, N. J., won his battle for a fifth term as president of the Professional Golfers Association of America today over loud but futile opposition by the Illinois section.
The city's policemen and firemen will be tinkering with toys in their spare time for the next few weeks in the campaign to give Christmas toys to underprivileged children.
Six peace organizations issued a "People's Armistice Day Declaration" here today in protest "against this country's twice following the disastrous road to foreign war."
The United Scenic Artists of America have established four new classifications designed to strengthen them in their relations with employers.

Carl K. Withers, State Banking Commissioner, said today that he planned to submit soon a plan of "orderly liquidation" for the Gloucester County Title and Mortgage Guaranty Company of Woodbury, of which he is trustee.

Reports by 141 Class I railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed a combined net operating income of $59,304,948 in September, against $70,096,166 in September, 1936. Gross revenues were $363,070,852, against $357,058,213.

Leaders in various fields were among the more than 1,800 persons who attended yesterday morning a funeral service at St. Patrick's Cathedral for Francis Patrick Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, Inc.,

The President of the District Court of Jerusalem, Judge W. Clive Curry, this morning faced a dilemma when he had to decide who was right, Copernicus or Benjamin Cohen, 70-year-old American Jew of Tel Aviv.
Augustus Eugenio Ingram, former American consular officer and former editor of The American Foreign Service Journal, died at his home at the Hotel Roosevelt here last night at the age of 70.
Governor Lehman, who was not on the program, stepped to the rostrum before the convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs today and completely took the spotlight away from every one who was.

A novel 75mm. howitzer which can be uncoupled from its towing truck and made ready for action within fifty seconds is one of many new types of weapons which have been alloted to the "army on wheels" which has been bivouacked here.

With the heavy rains in the Mississippi Valley, where considerable cotton remains in the fields, and strong outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday to end with gains of 1 to 7 points, or 5 to 35 cents, bale.

The first decoration of the recently created Order of Vasco Nunez Balboa to be conferred on an American by the Government of Panama has been awarded to Dr. A. B. Herrick, who is now seriously ill in the Panama Hospital, of which he is the head and founder.

Hockey will make its seasonal bow in this city tonight when the New York Rangers play host to the Chicago Black Hawks at Madison Square Garden. With their interest whetted by activities on several other fronts during the past week, local fans to the number of 15,000 and more are expected to turn out to see Lester Patrick's group of young hopefuls ring up the local curtain on the National League campaign.

The Joint Committee of Teachers' Organizations, representing New York City's 40,000 educational employes, has filed an injunction suit in the State Supreme Court to prevent the Municipal Residence Law from being applied to teachers, Robert Comin, chairman, announced yesterday.

The fact that New York has a larger hospital population than the total population of Los Angeles was the basis of a plea made yesterday noon by David H. McAlpin Pyle, president of the United Hospital Fund, for contributions in the current campaign -to support ninetytwo local hospitals.

The Santa Paula polo four established itself as the favorite in the Argentine open championship by defeating the United States Aurora quartet, 17 to 8, in a practice match at the Hurlingham Club today.

Word has been received here from Toronto of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Creswlcke, youngest daughter of the late Alfred Edmund Horace Creswicke, former King's Counsel of Barrie, Ont., to Falconbridge Cassels, only son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Cassels of Bronxville, N. Y.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

North Farm Challenge Trophy-Killearn Farm's b. m. Killearn Beauty. Frederick D. Mackay Memorial Challenge Cup-Mrs. Loula Long Combs's ch. m. Captivation. Erduin yon der Horst Koch Perpetual Memorial Trophy-Glenholme Farm's b. g. Coronet.

The Hamilton Club of Chicago, for fortyseven years a stronghold of the Republican party lost its home and virtually became defunct today with the appointment by Federal Judge William H. Holly of a trustee ordered to liquidate the property.

Prime Minister John Metaxas said in a speech two days ago, which was released for publication today: "Greece will remain aloof from the political troubles that are threatening to split Europe into two hostile camps. She will remain faithful to the principle of peace and maintain friendly relations with all foreign countries."

Miss Katherine Munger Adams, daughter of Professor John Chester Adams of Yale University and Mrs. Adams, was married here this afternoon at the home of her parents to John Gedney Cushman, son of Mrs. Charles F. Cushman of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mr.

Declaring that hosiery executives, like many in other industries, are influenced greatly by sentiment in Wall Street, Earl Constantine, managing director of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, calls for greater consideration of the facts in the hosiery industry itself, in a signed article appearing in the current issue of the association's Special News Letter.

Three Cuban planes took off at noon today from Military City en route to the Dominican Republic, where they will be joined by a Dominican Army plane and will commence a 21,000mile Pan-American good-will trip tomorrow.

The Pennsylvania Railroad declared yesterday a dividend on its capital stock of 75 cents, bringing total disbursements for the year to $1.25. Like other declarations in recent years, the latest was an irregular one.
4th St, n e cor Perry St, 17.11x50: excr will of Alice T. O'Connor to Blanche W. Ainsworth, 49 Perry St; consideration $15,000.

Mrs. Marguerite Gillison Howser of this city, daughter of Mrs. Sawyer Hill of New York and Cannes, France, was married to Kent Crane, also of this city, yesterday afternoon in the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twentynineth Street.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, now investigating plans for the reorganization 'of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, introduced into the record this afternoon a list of insurance company officials and bankers who, it was asserted, are supporting or have acquiesced in the so-called debtor or Alleghany Corporation ?? reorganization plan now pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The closing weeks of a football season always produce one or two points on which is built a clamor for a rule change. In recent years the clamor has not brought as much in the way of results as was the case in the more distant, past, but there have been results.

The crews of the British-flag passenger ships Queen of Bermuda and Nerissa, operated by Furness, Withy Co., to Bermuda and the West Indies, respectively, went out on strike yesterday morning, forcing the company to cancel a holiday trip of the Queen to Boston and postpone the sailing of the Nerissa from yesterday afternoon to this morning.

Alfred M. Heston, former Atlantic City Controller, treasurer and historian, died in the Atlantic City Hospital late today. He was 84 years old. Since the death of his wife shortly after his retirement as city historian in 1927,

The Army Plebes defeated Allentown Prep School, 21 to 6, today in the final game of the plebes' football campaign. With the score 6-6, Polk caught a forward pass in the end zone. to give the plebes a 12-to-6 lead at the half.

Miss Jean Harder, daughter of George Achilles Harder of 510 Park Avenue, will be married to Clendenin J. Ryan Jr. of 834 Fifth Avenue, grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, and a secretary to Mayor La Guardia; on Nov. 18. No formal announcement of the engagement has been made.

To demonstrate their faith that the way to peace lies in international cooperation, the various cooperative organizations of the New York area have called a mass meeting to be held tonight at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, at which Anders Hedberg, secretry of the Swedish Cooperative Union and a member of the central bureau for the International Coopertive Alliance, will be the principal speaker.

Residents of Stonington Borough played hosts to railroad officials today at the dedication of a tablet commemorating the 100th anniversary of the first railroad in Stonington, which was later to become the New Haven system.

Cuban imports of iron and steel products through the port of Havana, which receives about 70 per cent of the Cuban imports, totaled 46,462 metric tons during the first nine months of the current year, as compared with 30,870 metric tons in the same period of 1936, the Commerce Department reported today.

American business must resign itself to greater government control unless it is prepared to cooperate in strict compliance with the anti-trust laws, Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the Senate, told the American Finance Conference at the Palmer House today.

Viscount and Viscountess Hardinge, Mrs. Henry W. Peabody, Viscount St. Vincent, Mrs. John R. Drexel, Sir John and Lady Pritchard Jones, Lady Janet MacGregor Maule, Dr. Oscar Straus, Viennee composer, and W. Hude Neilson are among the passengers due to sail today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania.

The fifteen-story Alden Apartments on the northwest corner of Central Park West-and Eighty-sec-, ond Street and the adjoining fourstory stone dwelling at 7 West Eighty-second Street were bid in at auction yesterday by the Manhattan Company, plaintiff, for $2,500,000.

The possibility of an increase In the fine for parking violations from $1 to $2 was indicated yesterday by Jacob Gould Schurman Jr., chief city magistrate, in an address at the Commercial Investment Trust's seminar of safety in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The primary duty at a university is great and inspiring teaching, Clarence A. Dykstra, recently appointed president of the University of Wisconsin, said last night in the Hotel Roosevelt at a dinner attendIed by 175 men and women of the New York Alumni Association. Mr.

A banking group composed of Phelps, Fenn Co.; Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc.; E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc.; Eldredge Co., Inc.; R. H. Moulton Co., and Harold E. Wood Co. has obtained the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 of rural credit refunding bonds of the State of South Dakota.

Mrs. Elizabeth M. Bartram filed suit today to divorce Rensselaer W. Bartram Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn. An agreement is said to have been reached on custody of their child, Rensselaer 3d. The charge is cruelty.

Held to a 6-all tie in the initial half, while being scored upon for the first time this season, Groton School slipped its offensive into high gear after the intermission and conquered St. Mark's, 26-6, today in the forty-ninth edition of their traditional series.

The Economy Baler Company, Ann Arbor, Mich., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a statement covering 80,000 shares of $1 par common stock. Fifteen thousand shares are to be offered by the company and 10,000 by a trustee for two stockholders at $3.75 a share.
The Army Quartermaster Corps announced today award of contracts for more than $500,000 worth of supplies for the Civilian Conservation Corps. Successful bidders included:

THE icemen are in town. Not only the hockey players to open the rough-and-tumble season on the Garden rink-and on Armistice Day, of all dates!-but the fancy skaters with musical accessories. Up in the hills the skiers are practicing for the Winter sports carnival to be held indoors later on.

The marriage of Miss Jean Elizabeth Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roger R. Thompson of 1,317 East Thirty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, to Iver Arnold Iversen, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Iversen, also of Brooklyn, took place last night in the Strong Place Baptist Church, Brooklyn.
The 1937 exhibition of contemporary American painting opened to the public yesterday at the Whitney Museum, where it will remain until Dec. 12. This is the sixth show in a series begun in 1932.

It is expected that trade diversion measures against the United States will soon be reviewed as an aid to the conclusion of the Anglo-American trade agreement. The government would probably abandon them if reciprocal concessions could be assured,

MANHATTAN AXT, CAROLINE (Nov. 7, 1936). Gross assets, $53,054; net, $49,359. To Mary C. McComb, daughter, $48,359; United Brethrens' Church on Staten Island, $500. Chief assets, real estate, $51,250. Lewis M. Johnson, attorney, 76 William St.

A tract of twenty-seven acres in the town of Ardsley, fronting 222.19 feet on the west side of Broadway, running through to the Hudson River, and including riparian rights, has been sold by the Ardsley Land Corporation to J. Russell Carney for investment.

The proposed understanding between Britain and the Rome-Berlin axis suddenly sprang to the forefront of the European political stage today when the Corrispondenza Diplomatica, the Foreign Ministry's official organ replying to Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech yesterday at the Lord Mayor's dinner calls on him to set the machinery of negotiation in motion without further delay.
Miss Fonrose Wainwright, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. J. Mayhew Wainwright, was married to Philip King Condict of Orange, N. J., this afternoon at the home of her parents at Milton Point here.

The definite statistical prophecy is made by the United Hospital Campaign Committee that there will be more than ten million people in New York by 1960, and it is estimated that by that time there should be 48,600 beds in the hospitals, 10,600 nurses and 4,300 visiting nurses in the five boroughs.

Colonel Robert S. Knox, commander of the Camp Dix Reservation for the past year and an officer in the United States Army for more than thirty-eight years, will be retired for age on Nov. 30, according to War Department orders received here.

Bronko Nagurski, 230, Minnesota, claimant of the world heavyweight wrestling championship, was declared the winner on a foul over Ray Steele, 214, California, in the feature match before 1,800 persons at the Hippodrome last night. Referee George Bothner disqualified Steele for illegal use of the knee after 30:04.

The eastern end. of the Nome waterfront, extending over a mile, was wrecked today by pounding seas. Hardly a building there remained intact after a terrific storm. Business men estimated the loss at more than $125,000.

Today's major events: Moriz Rosenthal, pianist, at the Town Hall in the afternoon; the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in the evening, and the Salzburg Guild, presenting "Angelique" and "The Matrimonial Market," at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre tonight.
The St. John's University soccer team recorded its first victory in three starts and avenged a previous setback by conquering Panzer College, 2-1, yesterday at Victory Field in Woodhaven.

While the liner Reina del Pacifico plowed slowly toward Bermuda with the body of J. Ramsay MacDonald, Britain's first Labor Prime Minister, who died last night, his friends and enemies at home united today in tributes such as he never heard during his lifetime.
Spanish Government advices tonight reported militiamen blasted a railroad bridge deep within Insurgent territory in Northeastern Spain to cut their enemy's supply line.

Declaring that dress returns during the second half of this year are approximating $15,000,000, Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, said yesterday he had received assurances in a conference with officials of the Federal Trade Commission that unjustified dress returns by retailers come within the purview of the "price discrimination" clause of the Robinson-Patman act.

Reports of possible damage by frost to Argentina's crop of wheat provided the incentive today for late buying of wheat on the Board of Trade and thus bolstered the local market. Earlier the market was strong on higher cables, improvement in the stock market and, to some extent, on continued drought conditions over the hard Winter wheat belt in the West and Southwest.
The Rutgers regulars who played in the Lafayette game Saturday were back in action today after two days of rest and engaged the reserves in a dummy scrimmage. Spirit was high,

In a two-hour interview at the Harvard Club yesterday morning, Dr. William Moulton Marston, former director of the psychological laboratory at Harvard, inventor of the lie-detector and at present a consulting psychologist, advanced a theory and a prediction.

A perpetual check brought about a draw in sixty-two moves in the fifteenth game of the match between Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris for the chess championship of the world, which was adjourned last night and played to a finish this evening.
In the Supreme Court of the United States Frank Weinstein of Brooklyn, N. Y., was admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

Securities of two companies which have resulted from mergers were approved yesterday for listing by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange. The American News Company is listing 432,000 shares of common stock, no par value, and Rayonier, Inc.,

With the reserve members of the Manhattan football team still taking the brunt of the "heavy duty" workouts, Coach Chick Meehan sent the Jaspers through a stiff workout at Innisfail Park yesterday in preparation for Saturday's intersectional clash with North Carolina State at Ebbets Field.

" No. Shaw" was Bernard Shaw's telegraphic reply to students of St. Andrew's University who wished to have the dramatist as a candidate in this week's rectorial election. Polling takes place on Saturday and the two candidates already nominated are Lord MacGregor Mitchell K. C. and Sir Hugh Walpole.

Gifts of $18,343 in the $200,000 budget campaign for 1938 of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York were reported yesterday at a luncheon at the Central Branch Y. W. C. A., 610 Lexidngton Avenue. The total amount raised to, date is $95,899.

Although today's closing scrimmage in preparation for the Princeton game on Saturday lacked pressure, it lasted so long that darkness had fallen and the floodlights were turned on before the work ended on Anthony Thompson Field.
The Gay Blades arrived in town yesterday to open the Winter indoor sport season at Madison Square Garden Monday with an exhibition of speed, grace and comedy on ice.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Danneman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Danneman of 25 Irvington Place, Brooklyn, and Westport, Conn., to Millard Fillmore Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sheffield Smith of Brooklyn and Lake George, took place last night in All Souls Universalist Church, Brooklyn. The Rev. Cornelius Greenway performed the ceremony.
After fifteen months of controversy, the Spanish-American War memorial statue was put in place today on a granite platform in Summerfield Park here. There was no ceremony.

Department stores throughout the country in October showed a decline of 1 per cent under the sales totals for the same month last year, according to the monthly report issued today by the Federal Reserve Board.

Miss Norah Eaton, 23-year-old equestrienne, was thrown from her nount, the chestnut gelding Goldair, last night in the $1,000 open lumper stake at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, ?ufferingg painful injuries.

Pelham Bridge Rd, e a, whole front to Long Island Sound between Pelham Bay Park and Westchester County line, 209.6x 150xirreg; including l-family dwelling and frame float; Lawyers Trust Co, trustee, against Forhan Realty Corp; due, $22.584: taxes, etc, $1,585; to plaintiff for $15,000.
Rose Zell Rowland, 20-year-old former American dancer of Columbus, Ohio, was married to Baron Jean Empain, 36, a Belgian millionaire,

Alfred P. Sloan, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, and Dr. Alexis Carrel are among the leaders in various fields who are scheduled to speak at the thirtyfirst annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to be held in the WaldorfAstoria on Dec. 2 and 3.
Secretary Morgenthau's address last night at the Academy of Political Science is a highly reassuring statement, and it ought to be read as such by the business community. To be sure,

S. Howard Voshell, a former "first ten" man in the national tennis ranking, who held the national indoor championship in 1917 and 1918, died yesterday at his home, 32 Abingdon Road, Kew Gardens, Queens, after an illness of six months. He was born in Boston forty-nine years ago.

John J. Rooney Jr., assistant clerk of the Westchester County Court here since 1931, fell dead at 11:15 this morning in a corridor of the county courthouse, an hour after having had an infected tooth extracted bY a dentist in Tuckahoe.
Pembroke Stephens, special correspondent of The Daily Telegraph of London, was killed today while watching the fighting in the Nantao quarter of Shanghai.

Irving Crane of Livonia, N. Y., tonight moved Ralph Greenleaf of New York out of a first-place tie in the world pocket billiard championship, defeating the defending champion, 125 to 72, in thirty innings.

Bonds moved upward impressively yesterday in the heaviest trading so far this month on the New York Stock Exchange. All major groups participated in the upswing, the incentive for which was advices from Washington which indicated that the Administration was ready to take definite fiscal steps to check the present slump in business.

C. C. N. Y., preparing for Saturday's game against Moravian at Bethlehem, Pa., went through one of its longest practice sessions of the campaign yesterday. Coach Benny Friedman directed his charges in a three-hour drill, which was concluded under arc lights at Lewisohn Stadium.

At the annual meeting of shareholders of the Third Avenue Railway System yesterday, S. W. Huff, president, said that he was confident the company would be able to continue payment of interest on its refunding 4 per cent mortgage bonds.

Lucrezia Bori was soloist at the first of the season's midweek concerts of the National Symphony Orchestra tonight in Constitution Hall. The Italian Ambassador and Mrs. Fulvio Suvich were guests of honor in the box party of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Townsend.

Army defeated Cornell at soccer, 4 to 0, here today for its fifth victory in six games. The Cadets tallied twice in the second quarter and added two more in the final. Raleigh scored two of the Army goals and Odom and Lough had one each.

Most of the 325 pupils of the Keyport High School who went on strike yesterday because the Board of Education had announced a curtailment of interscholastic athletics were back at class today victorious, but not 100 per cent satisfied with the outcome.

Plans for extensive collaboration by public and private agencies in the Federal unemployment census which begins Tuesday were completed yesterday at a meeting of Mayor La Guardia's coordinating committee at City Hall.

Both the Montclair Athletic Club and the Columbia University Class A squash tennis teams maintained their victorious pace in Metropolitan League play last night, continuing in a first-place' deadlock with three victories and no defeats each.
Mrs. Philip Lehman, wife of the senior partner of Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, died yesterday at her home, 7 West Fifty-fourth Street. She was 72 years old.
COMMERCIAL FOOD CORP., 48 W. 22d St., by B. Mandel Co. on a claim for $576.

The New York City Cancer Institute was the beneficiary of the dinner dance last night which opened the Trianon Room at the Ambassador for the Winter. Proceeds will go toward the work of the social service auxiliary.

Building operations in this country during 1938 probably will show a decline of about 81/2 per cent. a compared with construction activity this year, according to a survey of prospects for the industry made public at a conference held yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel under the sponsorship of the International Statistical Bureau.

Basil (Pat) Ryan remained secluded today in a hospital which he entered last Friday morning a few hours after he married Miss Martha Barkley of Morgantown at the home of a Morgantown justice of the peace.

High Fleet ran her last race today at Pimlico, driving home to capture by a head the newly inaugurated Ritchie Handicap, a memorial to Albert C. Ritchie, for many years Governor of Maryland. Carrying the silks of Andrew Jackson Joyner, High Fleet came from behind and was in a full drive to get up and defeat Wise Prince, who in turn was a length and a half before Deliberator.

Lilian Stiles-Allen, British dramatic soprano, made her debut here in a. recital at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. She has a voice of natural beauty, which shines forth impressively when the singer is not forcing it.

Captain John F. Milliken, president of the United Licensed Officers Association and for many years a prominent figure in the maritime labor field, was suspended from office yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the union's executive committee.
Pittsburgh and Nebraska will meet Saturday in the Panther stadium before 71,330 persons.

Unemployment Census The Fire Department has been requested to cooperate in the National Unemployment Census. Posters, pamphlets and report cards will be distributed on Friday. Posters will be placed where they can best be seen by the general public.

The constitutional and dictatorial moves of President Getulio Vargas of Brazil appeared here today, upon the basis of incomplete reports, to have posed the problem of a Fascist government in this hemisphere.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Borough President-elect of Manhattan, urged yesterday the immediate establishment of impartial boards for mediating rent and other disputes between landlords and tenants rather than waiting for the passage of adequate rent laws designed to curtail such disagreements.

Miss Marie Joan Rice, daughter of Mrs. Elsa Rice of Great Neck, L. I., was married here yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration to Alexander R. Whittaker, son of Mrs. Alexander R. Whittaker of Brooklyn Heights and the late Mr. Whittaker, by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.
Kingsbridge Rd, 2,3399 (12-3293); 239 E. K. R. Corp to Anny Alkoff, 1,825 Harrison Ave; installments, 6 per cent; $15,000.

The American Guild of Musical Artists, of which Lawrence Tibbett is president, announced yesterday the establishment of minimum pay scales for singers and ballet dancers in grand opera companies having a "$2 top."
President Roosevelt issued a statement today in tribute to the late J. Ramsay MacDonald, former British Prime Minister. The statement follows:

It became a habit to speak of the tragedy of Ramsay MacDonald. The principal founder of the British Labor party and twice Labor Prime Minister, he broke with his party toward the end of his career to become the head of a Nationalist coalition. Carrying with him only a handful of Labor followers, he spoke of himself, perhaps jestingly, as the prisoner of his Conservative allies.

Magistrate Nicholas H. Pinto, presiding in Bay Ridge Court in Brooklyn yesterday, dismissed a disorderly conduct charge brought against one striking employee of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle and reserved decision in two other cases growing out of the same incident.

Operations of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and subsidiaries in the first nine months of this year resulted in a net profit of $6,185,066 after interest, depreciation, depletion, Federal income and State income taxes, according to a report issued yesterday.
Secretary Perkins indicated today that she favored some modifications in the wage-hour bill to be considered by the special session of Congress and said she was ready to offer her suggestions.
William Johnson Graham, presiding judge of the United States Court of Customs and Patents Appeal, died after a heart attack at his home early today. He was 65 years old.

Despite Mayor La Guardia's request that he reconsider the announcement of his resignation, Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, said yesterday that he had definitely determined to leave the city service on Jan. 1.
President Roosevelt was represented today as favoring legislation permitting the Navy Department to cut up obsolete ships, retain the "strategic" materials and sell the hulks.
Mrs. Lucy P. Scott, widow of Supreme Court Justice Francis M. Scott and a leader in the anti-suffrage movement in New York City, died here today after a long illness.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow; HOGS Receipts. 18,000 head, including 8,000 direct. Market closing active, mostly 10c a 100 pounds higher than yesterday's average; top, late, $9.20: bulk, good and choice,

William Struthers Ellis of Fox Fields, Bryn Mawr, a civic leader and sportsman, died tonight after an illness of several years. His age was 70. Born in this city, he was the son nf the late Rudulph Ellis,

Spanish Insurgent communiques reported tonight that Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops had thrown back attacks by Government forces on the northern Aragon front, "crushing whole regiments" in furious action.

Miss Edythe Corinne Bax, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Bax, was married here this evening at the home of her parents to Harold von Lehe Seifert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Seifert of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Holthusen of Forest Hills, the same minister who married the bridegroom's parents.

The great emphasis now being placed by retailers upon price promotions and clearances of merchandise is essential to stimulate volume and cut unwieldy inventories, but may raise a problem on clearances in January, the normal month for such sales, it was reported here yesterday.

President Roosevelt led the nation today in observance of the nineteenth anniversary of the ending of the World War, placing a wreath of white chrysanthemums upon the tomb of the Unknown Soldier during a brief and simple ceremony.

Miss Mary Reynolds Bird, daughter of Mrs. Francis W. Bird and the late Mr. Bird, was married today in Union Congregational Church, East Walpole, to Walter Massey Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Phillips of Torresdale, Pa.

At an Armistice Day assembly filling every seat in the Vassar College chapel, Dean Mildred Thompson advocated government control and ownership of the munitions industries; recognition that trade means buying and selling, not just selling and making it impossible for other nations to buy;

Mrs. Christian R. Holmes will give a dinner next Wednesday for General and Countess Adelbert de Chambrun. Mrs. John R. Drexel, who had been at the Pierre, sailed on the Aquitania to pass the Winter at her Paris home. 34 rue Francois Ier.

Climaxing a protracted period of friction between himself and other factors on the lot, Mervyn Leroy today notified Warner Brothers of his withdrawal as producer for that company and of his assignment with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a member of the executive staff.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated Nov. 10: COLONELS Murray, A., Med. Corps, 3 months' leave, Dec. 9, with permission to visit foreign countries.

J. Ramsay MacDonald's family today declined an offer that he be buried in historic Westminster Abbey. The sub-dean of the Abbey said the family, while appreciative of the offer, felt they must refuse because they wished burial to take place in Mr. MacDonald's native Lossiemouth, Scotland.
Rutgers University's lightweight football team defeated the University of Penn squad of 150-pounders today in the annual Armistice Day game at Hinchliffe Stadium, 9--6.

The hope so often expressed by President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull, that the democratic form of government will be preserved in the Americas, has become more fervent than ever in consequence of the establishment of a corporate State by President Getulio Vargas of Brazil, but that attitude will not operate to prevent the United States from keeping hands completely off the situation.

A funeral service for Tom D. Cochrane, general manager in the Orient for Paramount Pictures, Inc., who died in St. Luke's Hospital here Tuesday, was held yesterday afternoon at the Columbus Circle Chapel, 43 West Sixtieth Street. Mr. Cochrane, who was 68 years old and who lived in Tokyo,

The condition of Basil A. (Pat) Ryan, who was admitted to a hospital here six days ago a few hours after his surprise marriage to Miss Martha Barkley of Morganton, was described tonight as "not critical."

A collection of Thomas Jefferson autograph letters and manuscripts, in one of which the author of the Declaration of Independence condemned the concentration of political power, were bought by Gabriel Wells for $3,500 yesterday afternoon at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the autograph collection of J. Macy Willets of this city.
Mayor La Guardia took a train to Washington at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon for a meeting of the executive committee of the United States Conference of Mayors, of which he is president.

Aided by the three and a half hours of extra shopping time which the Thursday night opening afforded, Armistice Day sales in department stores here ranged from 5 to 10 per cent larger than on the same day last year, retail executives here estimated yesterday.

The fifty newspaper representatives attending the Commercial Investment Trust's seminar of safety in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria took Ia respite from their discussions yesterday to tour the metropolitan area's system of bridges, parkways and tunnels and view the latest facilities for handling heavy traffic.

Prospects for substantial changes in the tax laws relating to corporations as a way to spur business recovery brightened materially here today as the search for effective measures continued throughout the governmental establishment.

Three women suffered leg fractures yesterday afternoon in Times Square when a taxicab got out of the control of its driver and plunged into a crowd of pedestrians who were crossing Forty-third Street at Broadway.

The National Association of Manufacturers announced yesterday that the "business yardstick" plan recently submitted by its industrial practices committee has continued to receive favorable comment from all parts of the country and from many branches of business.

The entire nation was reported tranquil today. President Getulio Vargas's assumption of dictatorial power apparently has been quietly accepted by the masses, judging by the behavior of crowds in the streets. Business is going on as usual.

The 1937 Nobel prizes for physics, chemistry and literature were awarded today. The physics prize was divided between Dr. Clinton Joseph Davisson of New York and Professor George Paget Thomson of London for the experimental discovery of interference phenomena when crystals are irradiated with electrons.

The University Club squash racquets team moved into the lead last night in the Metropolitan League Class A competition by triumphing over the Downtown A. C., 4 to 1. The victory, scored on their home court, was the third in as many starts for the University players.

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine and District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn were among 2,500 persons who attended an inspector's funeral yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel, 915 Putnam Avenue, Brooklyn, for Detective Arthur J. De Marrais.

Miss Lorraine Posey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George MacArthur Posey of Henderson, Ky., was married to Dr. Edward Spencer Cowles of New York this afternoon at the home here of her uncle, William Thornton Posey of 170 Irving Avenue. The Rev. Dr. John A. MacSporran performed the ceremony.

Mr. and Mrs. Waldron Kintzing Post of 290 Park Avenue and Strandhome, Bayport, L. I., received a cablegram yesterday from their daughter, Mary, Viscountess Lymington, of London, announcing her engagement to John How, also of London.

The executive committee of the Washington Newspaper Guild adopted resolutions tonight urging President Roosevelt and Chief Justice Hughes to reconsider their action in accepting honorary membership in the American Press Society.

Republican leaders, in discussing informally their plans for the coming State Constitutional Convention, have talked of the possibility of selecting former Governor Alfred E. Smith for vice chairman of the convention.

AHEARN--Suddenly, on Nov. 11, at her late residence, 296 East Broadway, Elizabeth Atwell, beloved wife of the late John F. Allearn and loving mother of Mrs. William J. Murray, William J. Akearn, Mrs. Elizabeth Hood, Mrs. Howard P. Keady, and the late Thomas J. and Edward J. Ahern. Notice of funeral later. Please omit flowers.

A movement to enlist support for the Veterans Temple of Peace planned for the 1939 World's Fair was officially launched last night at an Armistice Day dinner given at the Hotel Commodore by the Veterans Temple of Peace, Inc., of which Deputy Controller Milton Solomon is chairman.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 9: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Overand, J. W., St. Julien's Creek, V., to the Kanawha. Ross, W. T., the Kanawha, to home, relieved from all active duty.

Fear that Germany will re-establish her Aski mark trade with Brazil on a large scale troubled exporters here yesterday in their consideration of the new Constitution put into effect on Wednesday by President Vargas.

A plea for a greater number of married women as teachers was made yesterday by. Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, Professor of Education, New York University, at an all-day conference on teacher education, held under the auspices of the Cooperative School for Teachers, 69 Bank Street.

In the Supreme Court of the united States Patrick J. Roche and Edmund J. Fanning, New York City, were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 804--October Term 1936. Railroad Commission of the State of California et al., aplts., v. Pacific Gas and Electric Company. Leave granted the Public Utility

They are finally getting around to the premiere of "Places,- Please!" at the Golden Theatre tonight, this being Aurania Rouverol's farcecomedy about an actress wedded to an untheatrical New Englander.
The mystery of the noiseless salute at the grave of a former service man was cleared up here today at the State Armory. The firing squad was set at the grave and a sergeant gave the order to fire.

With Governors or other official representatives of five of the thirteen original States participating, New Jersey's signing of the ratification of the United States Constitution was celebrated here tonight in a gala manner.

Peace under the rule of totalitarian States is "a glorified form of slavery," and war, although it has "no place in a civilized life, community or nation," may eventually be resorted to in order to gain real peace, the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks declared in an Armistice Day sermon yesterday.

The four principles laid down by the committee of physicians are not new. The nine proposals enunciated are likewise not original and offer nothing new. Taking them in order: 1. Prevention of illness. This has ever been the endeavor of physicians, as seen by (a) diphtheria, scarlet fever and smallpox immunization, to mention the more prominent, and (b) public health measures relating to water purification, food inspection, etc.
Chairman McNinch of the Federal Communications Commission put into effect today two new orders which he said would prove that "we want to live in a glass house."
The influx of foreign skiers for the coming season began yesterday when Benno Rybizka, famous Austrian instructor, arrived aboard the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Line.

Miss Sara Heller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Heller of this city and Rumson, was married this afternoon in Old First Presbyterian Church here to Joseph Fewsmith Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howell Gurney Lord, also of Newark.

As its sixteenth annual exhibition, the American Academy of Arts and Letters offers a memorial showing of work by Elihu Vedder, who was born in 1836 and who died in 1923. It will be opened with a private view this afternoon and to the public tomorrow, remaining current in the galleries on Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets until next April.
Admiral Baron Sotokichi Uriu, last surviving Japanese graduate of the United States Naval Academy at Annapolis, died today at his home at Odawara, southwest of Tokyo. He was 80 years old.
In an effort to train dog owners to observe the sanitation laws, the Department of Sanitation has posted some twenty-five signs bearing the legend "Please Curb Your Dog" at points about the city.

Managua's population has grown from 25,000 to 11O,000 since- the destruction of the city by an earthquake in 1931. More than 10 per cent of Nicaragua's population now lives in Managua, and the population of the other cities and villages with few exceptions is decreasing.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed, as of Oct. 22, 1937. on the eligible list of teachers of classes for children with retarded mental development in day elementary schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license.
Two brief air raids, topped by a bit of magic at the goal line, carried Texas Tech to a 13-0 triumph today over a Duquesne football team that failed to get past the Red Raiders' 40-yard stripe.

Mr. and Mrs. Ray Wilcox of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Wilcox, to James L. Dawes, son of Mrs. Lewis C. Dawes of Englewood and Marlboro, N. H., and the late Mr. Dawes.

The following Reserve officers, having established permanent residences beyond the territorial limits of Third Military Area, are relieved from assignments therein as indicated: 1st Lt. Alfred N. McCausland, Med.-Rer., 3,780 Milakind Blvd., Los Angeles, Calif., unassigned. 1st Lt. William Furst, Med.-Re.., Philadelphia General Hospital, Philadelphia, Pa., Engineers Bn. (Sep).
The Commerce Department was advised today that the Chilean Government reduced on Nov. 6 the so-called gold rate on certain "luxury" products imported into that country.

Bank clearings in twenty-two leading cities of the United States for the six business days ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,422,722,000, compared with $5,144,728,000 in the corresponding five-day week last year, of a rise of 5.4 per cent, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The most ambitious basketball schedule in City College history was announced yesterday for the 19371938 season by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. Seventeen games, five to be played at the Garden, are listed.

Generally slow trading in wool goods, consideration by clothing manufacturers of readjustments of Spring apparel prices in line with lower fabric values, bargain offers by jobbers and others seeking to reduce fabric stocks, and further curtailment of mill operations

"Gay Blades," the new musical skating extravaganza, co-starring Miss Maribel Y. Vinson of Boston and Karl. Schafer of Vienna, internationally famous figure-skating champions, had its world premiere tonight in the New Haven Arena before an enthusiastic audience of 3,000.
"Tristan und Isolde" will be the opening night presentation at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday evening, Nov. 29, it was announced yesterday by Edward Johnson, general manager.

Many thousands of people thronged Parliament Hill today to hear and see in the presence of the Governer General, Lord Tweedsmuir, and Prime Minister Mackenzie King, the Canadian Legion's national service of remembrance.

Olin Downes, music critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was made a Commander of the Order of the White Rose of Finland on Monday at a luncheon at the Hotel Ritz-Carlton given by Eero Jarnefelt, Minister of Finland, it was announced yesterday.
Miss Isabella Margaret Lynch, who served in the navy during the World War as a first class yeoman F, and who was a charter member and past vice commander of the Barbara Fritchie Post 43

The headlights of 1,070 vehicles danced across the dust-covered mesquite and thorn bushes of the Texas hills last night and early today as the "Army on Wheels" rumbled northward 130 miles in the first of two night marches.

The marriage of Miss Eileen Patricia O'Connell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel O'Connell of Shore Front Park, South Norwalk, Conn., to William Parker Rousseau, son of Mrs. Henry Harwood Rousseau of this city and Blue Hill, Me., and the late Rear Admiral Rousseau, U. S. N., took place yesterday in the Church of St. Ignatuis Loyola. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frances Donovan.

Six hundred Catholic boy scouts of the Bronx Council observed Armistice Day yesterday morning by attending a special mass, communion and breakfast at Fordham University. In their first turnout of the kind they heard the Rev. Thomas V. McMahon, Manhattan moderator of the Catholic Youth Organization, declare that world peace, to be enduring, must be founded on obedience to God's law.

The two minutes of silence which the British Empire every year consecrates to its war dead, was broken today by an escaped lunatic who burst through the guard of honor surrounding King George at the World War Cenotaph ceremony with the wild cry:

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone, on motion of counsel for the government, dismissed today charges of conspiracy against seven corporations and one individual in the Federal Government's gasoline pricefixing case.
The principal speaker at the meeting of the Savings Banks Real Estate Managers, which will be held Tuesday evening at the Cornell Club, will be George Allin of Allin, Tucker Allen.

With 329 girls as guests at the fifteen fraternities and the Garfield Club, Williams College will begin the celebration of Amherst weekend tomorrow. Six Williams athletic teams will face Amherst for Little Three titles on Saturdav.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederic West Thatcher of this place, formerly of Boston, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Dee Thatcher, to Richard Schoonmaker Greene, son of Mrs. Marshall Winslow Greene of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. Greene.

The Japanese Foreign Office said today Japan had declined a second invitation to send a representative to the Brussels conference on the Far Eastern war. [The Brussels conference asked Japan to send a representative to exchange views with a small group of powers chosen by the conference, the talks to be within the framework of the Nine-Power Treaty.]

Extension of banking services was forecast here today by Ferd I. Collins, president of the New Jersey Bankers Association, who said to the 400 members attending the ninth annual mid-year conference of the group:

President Roosevelt received today from Charles Baron, member of the French Chamber of Deputies, a portrait of the Marquis de Lafayette and the only existing copy of a famous painting of Chevalier Bayard.

The National Labor Relations Board today ordered the Consolidated-Edison Company of New York, Inc., and six affiliated companies to break their contracts with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, on the ground that the companies had imposed the A. F. of L. union on the 30,000 employes and had discriminated against the United Radio and Electrical Workers of America, affiliate of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

A group of Wellesley alumnae who have made names for themselves in law and politics will join the faculty and students of the college in a three-day sesquicentennial celebration of the framing of the Constitution of the United States next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.

A warning that "business must be scrupulously correct in its advertising" is voiced in The National Grocers Bulletin, organ of the National Association of Retail Grocers. Under the title, "Let the Seller Beware," the publication says:
Lanz of Salzburg, women's sports and skiing apparel, through Huberth Huberth, corner store in 571 Madison Ave; Harold C. Samuels Co, brokers.

Nearly 500 wartime fliers, members of Aviators' Post No. 743, American Legion, observed Armistice Day yesterday with a dinner at the Hotel New Yorker. Representatives of the Army, Navy and Marine Air Services and the National Guard Air Services of nearby States also attended.

With the impressive and colorful ceremonies of the High Church of England, the Right Rev. Wallace John Gardner was enthroned at Trinity Cathedral here today as Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey. He succeeds Bishop Paul Matthews of Princeton.

Lieut. Col. W. E. Peel's Inversible won the Grand Sefton steeplechase today with Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's American-owned Flying Minutes second. V. Thompson's Underbid was third in the field of sixteen. The race, at two miles and seven and one-half furlongs, carried a purse of $7.500.

Mail service between Shanghai and Nanking, disrupted since Sunday, is being restored by postal trucks operating on the north bank of the Yangtze from Pukow down the river to a point below the boom at Nantungchow, connecting with Shanghai by British river steamers.

Miss Alice Baker, 18-year-old Dairy Queen of Wisconsin, arrived in New York yesterday morning to celebrate the climax of Cheese Week, which began last Sunday and was so ordained by some twenty-eight proclamations by Governors.
New York has written its remembrance of World War service in a record of more than $51,000,000 paid outright to veterans and fifty-five laws enacted for their benefit, a survey disclosed today.

Mrs. Corina La Borde, leader of the Republican Club of the Twelfth Assembly District, died on Wednesday at the home of her daughter, Miss Corina La Borde, 46 West Fifty-second Street. She was 57 years old. Mrs. La Borde had been active in Brooklyn politics for fifteen years.

Legislative plans for the special session of Congress, which will convene Monday, began to take shape today as Speaker Bankhead and Senator Barkley majority leader, returned to the capital. Mr. Bankhead lunched with President Roosevelt and Mr. Barkley has an appointment to see the President tomorrow.

"The Front Page" was given tonight at the University Theatre, and will be repeated Saturday night as the Fall production of the Yale Dramatic Association. The audience included many alumni and visitors here for the Yale-Princeton football game Saturday.

Tony Wons, in 100 W 57th St. Charles W. Frankle, in 240 W 75th St; Walter Samuels, Inc, broker. Clarence Bamberger. in 400 E 57th St; Edwin C. Sauter, in 140 W 57th St; Payson McL. Merrill Co, Inc, broker.

Rear Admiral Ernest J. King, who is to be promoted about Jan. 1 to Vice Admiral, will have higher rank and more gold braid. but less pay. Naval authorities studied complicated pay schedules today and reached the conclusion that his net income would be reduced by about $300 to $10,200 when he becomes commander of the fleet's battle force aircraft.

Taking the first three places, Seton Hall Prep School easily captured the national Catholic high and preparatory school cross-country championship race held under the auspices of Seton Hall College today.

Stud poker is a game in which, in its simplest form, four cards are dealt face upward and one-the hole card-down. If all the cards are exposed by the dealer the game is no longer stud, but cold hands, a considerably less sporting proposition.

The Hamburg - American liner Hansa will arrive today from Hamburg and Channel ports, bringing among her passengers Mr. and Mrs. Hans F. Kinderlen, Kurt G. Sell, Clemens Mark, Dr. Hans Schuette, Dr. C. C. Tucker, Mr. and Mrs. W. C. McCoy, Dr. Paul von Haggenmacher, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest W. Reinhardt-Picchioni, F. W. Oakes, Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. O'Neill and Miss Adele Phelps.
Dr. and Mrs. Shepard Krech gave a dinner last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mr. and Mrs. Harrie Lindeberg and Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Shepard.
South Side High School gained a tie for the lead with West Side High in the Newark High School Football League by scoring a 9 to 0 victory over Wee??uahio today.
The Rev. Charles Calvin Proffitt, for twenty-eight years rector of Trinity Church, Garnerville, N. Y., died here tonight at his home at the age of 81. He had been in ill health for some time.

Orval W. Adams of Salt Lake City, president of the American Bankers Association, said today that "Secretary Morgenthau's pledge to balance the budget through cutting expenditures will receive the unqualified endorsement and grateful appreciation of every good American citizen."

Alberto Lovell, the Argentine boxer who won-the heavyweight championship at the Los Angeles Olympic Games in 1932, will make his first ring appearance in New York tonight. He will oppose Eddie Blunt, Corona (L. I.) battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome.

The Board or Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church announced tonight at the semi-annual meeting here the acceptance of the proposed plan for unification with the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, and the Methodist Protestant Church.
Showing terrific power in its drives, the Lehigh junior varsity eleven pushed to four touchdowns to defeat Rutgers jayvees today, 25 to 6. The line-up:

For the eighth successive week The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices declined in the period ended on Tuesday and reached 88.9, the lowest point since the beginning of December, 1936. On Nov. 2 the index stood at 89.5, while on Nov. 10, 1936, it was 86.0.

Announcement was made today of the engagement of Miss Kathryn Schuyler Dougherty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Dougherty of this place, to John Osborne Howard, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Howard, also of Montclair.

General Henri Gouraud, one-armed hero of the Dardanelles campaign and commander of the French Fourth Army, whose magnificent defense and counterattack near Rheims in 1918 made Marshal Foch's victory possible, was the central figure of today's armistice celebration in Paris.
Mrs. Mary A. Young, widow of Asa W. Young, who was a Mount Kisco and White Plains coal dealer, died today at her home at the age of 77. She was a member of the Contemporary Club,
Columbia's football forces went through their final light manoeuvres yesterday in preparation for the game with Syracuse tomorrow at Baker Field.
Fur coats came out of closets and pedestrians stepped more briskly yesterday as the temperature fell to the freezing point for the first time this Fall.
Taxes under the New Deal, especially the undistributed profits tax, were denounced at today's sessions of the American Petroleum Institute as "killing the goose that lays the golden tax eggs."

The Maroons' three-goal splurge in the third period tonight beat their neighborhood rivals, the Canadiens, 3 to 0, and the winners climbed into a second-place tie in the international section of the National Hockey League.
Contracts for textile supglies for the army and the Civilian Conservation Corps were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot here today, as follows:

Pembroke Stephens, special correspondent of The London Daily Telegraph in Shanghai, went out yesterday to cover the fighting in the Nantao quarter But he did not file his story. A bullet or a bit of shell wrote "thirty" at the foot of the page-the newspaper man's obituary.

Lle Wol Lah Son, 11-month-old red chow, owned by Mrs. A. V. Hallowell of Delphi, Pa., reached a new high mark in the course of several months of sensational showing when he captured the chief prize at the annual Chow Chow Club exhibition in the roof garden of the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
Persistent organized international cooperation" was declared today by Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State, to be the only channel through which "stable peace" could be attained.

Three third-round matches in the Princeton invitation squash tennis tournament at the Princeton Club were played yesterday, the winners moving into the quarter-finals. Five contests are scheduled for today and the final set for Nov. 23.

The Glee Clubs of Princeton and Yale Universities will sing for the first time in public two new songs as part of their program in their joint concert here tomorrow night in Sprague Hall on the eve of the annual football game between the teams of the universities.
Many luncheon parties were given yesterday in conjunction with the luncheon and card party held at Sherry's under the auspices of the Almoners.

The Chicago Black Hawks completely spoiled the opening of the local hockey season for the New York Rangers last night. Bill Stewart's sextet, profiting a great deal by a goal made in the first two minutes of play by Harold (Mush) March, turned back the blue-jerseyed aggregation, 3 to 1, at Madison Square Garden.

"Today we see about us everywhere a world from which democracy seems in retreat, where military force is a chief pursuit of States, and where not one but several nations display a philosophy of conquest and dominion which contradicts what used to seem the settled direction of world movement," said Professor James Grafton Rogers in an Armistice Day address at Yale today.

Operators were active yesterday in the purchase of houses in Manhattan. The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 322 Central Park West, northwest corner of Ninety-second Street, was sold by the builders to the Norman Lila Estates, Inc., operators.

Charles Ackerson, cavalryman, who fought in twenty-four battles in the Civil War, died at his home here yesterday in his ninety-ninth year. Mr. Ackerson, who always called himself "a New Jersey dirt farmer," was born and raised in Northern Morris County and at the age of 24
The State Department has taken official notice of Uruguay's embargo on imports of automobiles by expressing the hope to Montevideo that American interests will not be discriminated against.

Delegates to the convention of the Associated Coffee Industries of America here adopted a resolution pledging cooperation to a joint program of the Associated Coffee Industries and the Pan-American Coffee Bureau to promote consumption of coffee in the United States.

With the jayvee squad again affording the opposition, the Brooklyn College football team continued contaot drills yesterday. Coach Lou Oshins sent the varsity through a two-hour scrimmage in preparation for the game with the Fort Hamilton soldiers at Erasmus Field Saturday.

Z. G. Simmons and A. Mullhaupt tied for the high scratch cup in the Armistice Day event over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. Each finished with 96 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off Simmons took the trophy by breaking 23. Mullhaupt had 22.

The National Bituminous Coal Commission determined today the weighted average costs of bituminous coal to be $2.15 and $1.79 a net ton, respectively, in minimum price areas Nos. 1 and 2, comprising all the coal-producing States east of the Mississippi River except Alabama. Theareas produce more than 80 per cent of the country's bituminous coal.

Clarence S. Stein, New York architect, has bought from Chester McCord the old Lambert farm on Journey's End Road, Ossining, N. Y., consisting of a Colonial farmhouse and thirty-five acres of land. The 150-year-old dwelling, once the home of Ransome Lambert, will be restored and remodeled by the purchaser.

Yale staged a short defensive and offensive drill today on Anthony Thompson Field. The Princeton attack was sent against the regulars by the scrubs. To allow the varsity linemen to brush up on blocking assignments, they were given a short offensive drill.

Radiation therapy of the-kidney, bladder and prostate "have taken on formidable proportions during the past ten years," the graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine was told last night by Dr. Benjamin S. Barringer of Memorial Hospital.

The annual Armistice Day luncheon sponsored by the Canadian Club of New York in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel was taken by Gordon D. Conant, Attorney General of Ontario, as an opportunity to deliver a blow at the Committee for Industrial Organization, whose excursions into Canada have been bitterly opposed by the provincial authorities.

Westchester County was described as the "fastest growing portion of the entire Anglican communion throughout the world" in a report on missions and population changes submitted and accepted tonight at a meeting of the Archdeaconry of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the county.

John Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, while paying lip service in his Pittsburgh speech to the principle of parole, referred to the "blatant outcry from these crime-coddlers," to "these selfappointed ambassadors of the open cell-block," to the "ignorant blatherings of either ill-informed or selfishly motivated persons," and so on.

The followings Marine Corps changes dated Nov. 8 were announced today: COLONEL Shearer, M. E., promoted to colonel. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Thomason, J. W., Jr., promoted to lieutenant colonel. Croka, W. B., to duty at Marine Corps Base, San Diego, Calif.

Application of new knowledge about the atomic behavior of iron on treatment with heat is putting this country on the threshold of a new era in steel making, members of the Franklin Institute were told tonight by Dr. John Johnston, director of research of the United States Steel Corporation.

Oswald W. Knauth, general chairman of the 1937 City-Wide Christmas Seal Sale Appeal, announced yesterday the appointment of Frank L. Jones, vice president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, as chairman of the business groups division. The quota of the division has been set at $40,000.

Thomas M. Love, former general manager of the Nixon-Nirdlinger theatre circuit, died today at his home in Cynwyd in his sixty-eighth year. He had been well known among theatre men of this city and New York for more than thirty years.

The robbery of a small safe containing jewels valued at $15,000 was reported early this morning from the home of Mrs. Frances C. Kitchen on the seventh floor of an apartment house at 157 West Fifty-seventh Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

Wholesale prices, which declined steadily in October, continued downward in the first week of November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today in its weekly summary. At Nov. 6 the bureau's index, based on the 1926 average, was 83.8, compared with 84 in the preceding week and 81.3 on Nov. 7, 1936.

Pelham Memorial High School staged a strong aerial attack in the fourth quarter at Memorial Stadium today and dashed Pleasantville High School's aspirations for the Westchester County Class B football championship, winning by 20 to 19 to break the Panthers' undefeated and untied record.

Our forefathers used to maintain that you cannot eat your cake and have it too. Starry-eyed advisers are trying to persuade the Administration that this is an exploded superstition. As a result of profound reasoning they have emerged with the conclusion that you can eat your cake twice-and still have it.

Announcement has been made by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, and Mrs. Morgan of 1,120 Fifth Avenue and Mount Kisco, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wendy Morgan, to Thomas Rodd 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Rodd of Pittsburgh and Washington. Conn.
Extremists invariably stage a violent demonstration on Armistice Day as a counter-blast to what they term Imperialist displays by British exservicemen.

Proposed extension of democratic principles to labor relations, the means of operating industry for the general welfare and the role of public education in those issues were the chief points of controversy among more than 200 leaders in business, industry and education who gathered yesterday at Teachers College, Columbia University, in the Third Conference on Educational Policies sponsored by the college's Advanced School of Education.

Sir George Frederick Clucas, Speaker of the House of Keys, as the Manx Parliament is known, died here today following an emergency operation for appendicitis. His age was 67. Overcome by emotion, Lady Clucas suffered a stroke and died a few hours later.

More than 1,000 persons, including officers of many veterans and patriotic organizations, participated yesterday in Armistice Day memorial services of the New York Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars at the Veterans Memorial Flag Pole in Central Park.

Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, challenger for the chess championship of the world, who holds a 3-point lead over Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the titleholder, failed to take full advantage of the play tonight in the sixteenth game of the series, in which, at one stage, he had the upper hand.

The marriage of Mrs. Helen Copp Windle of Millbury and Pinehurst, N. C., to John E. Dixon of East Orange, N. J., will take place here next Thursday afternoon in Trinity Church. The ceremony will be performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving.

Rear Admiral Clark H. Woodward, commandant of the Third Naval District, gave the keynote yesterday for Armistice Day exercises in Kings and Queens Counties, when he advised a Brooklyn gathering of 5,000 persons in Borough Hall Square to prepare for war but to study all causes of conflict with a view to avoiding it.

Edgar C. Proctor, at one time private secretary of Mark Hanna and later to William McKinley as President, died yesterday at his home at 9 Kew Gardens Road, Kew Gardens, Queens, after a short illness. He was 63 years old.

Before a gathering of 40,000, the largest crowd that has ever witnessed a prep or high school game in this city and with -a Governor and a Mayor among the attending notables, Admiral Farragut Academy's football team of Toms River, N. J., defeated the New York Military Academy of Cornwall, 31 to 0, today at the Municipal Stadium.

Mrs. Elizabeth Atwell Ahearn, widow of John F. Ahearn, former Borough President of Manhattan and Democratic leader of, the Fourth Assembly District, Manhattan, died yesterday at her home, 296 East Broadway, after a long illness. She was 81 years old.
Paul Windels and Paul Blanshard have served this community faithfully and brilliantly, the one as Corporation
THE Red Menace is reaching its tentacles out over the gridiron, and not even Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. has issued a clarion cry to stamp out the dastardly thing.
The Exchange Control Board today suspended licenses for dealing in foreign exchange. Brokers decreed a strike against the order, which banned all operations in credits.

Dean William Payson Richardson of the Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University announced yesterday that five college clubs at the school had awarded scholarships to seven first-year students. The names of the winners and clubs awarding the scholarships are:

After a parade along Park and Fifth Avenues, more than 1,000 members of the Catholic War Veterans, Inc., marched into St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning to 'attend the third annual national memorial mass of the organization. About 1,500 other persons crowded into the edifice for the solemn high mass, under the auspices of the New York chapter.

The People's Tribunal in Berlin has condemned to death W. H. Cammans, 43, a former resident of the village of Venlo near the German frontier. He was reported to have been lured last January into Germany, where he was arrested and charged with high treason.

The desirability of trading in an expiring grain future in the last ten days of the delivery month will be considered at a public hearing to be held in Chicago on Nov. 30, Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture announced today.

Rallying in the third quarter after the Scarlet and Gray had scored a touchdown in the second period, the Manual Training High School football team gained a 6--all tie with Alexander Hamilton High at Commercial Field in Brooklyn yesterday A crowd of 3,000 saw the game.

About one out of five of the City Council ballots cast in one Bronx election district was tampered with, authorities announced yesterday at the completion of an investigation of the district vote. Less degrees of tampering were found in other districts. Ballots from twenty eleotion districts in the borough have so far been impounded.

After sharp showers right sweet is the sun. Too long Republicans upState and Republicans down-State have sniffed and scoffed at one another. The causes of this unbrotherly feeling there is no need to catalogue. It is enough to say that misfortune isn't apt to improve the temper. The up-State brethren simply couldn't understand why the New York City Republicans insisted upon renominating Mayor La Guardia.

The Federal Trade Commission has ordered Al Hartman, Inc., 1,400 Broadway, New York, to discontinue representing the fibre content of certain dresses as "crepe" when they contain material other than silk, the commission announced today.

Although rescuers have been toiling all night they have still not determined how many persons perished in a landslide last night that blotted out the sulphur mining village of Tsumakoi, near Kusatsu, Japan. About 1,300 miners dwelt in the village and 350 were definitely known to be safe when the disaster occurred.

Miss Pamela Brinton entertained with a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Miss Henrietta Colgate, chairman of the committee for the fashion show to be given on Dec. 2 at the Pierre in conjunction with the Christmas Bazaar and Tea for the benefit of the Art Workers Club for Women.

William P. Lee, Bayonne City Clerk for twenty-four years and recognized as an authority on New Jersey municipal law although he wasn't a member of the bar, died suddenly of a heart attack at his home here today. He was 71 years old.

The Hapag Lloyd Line announced yesterday that the world cruise of the liner Bremen, which was scheduled to start on Feb. 2, had been cancelled because of heavy losses of passenger bookings resulting from the change of the ship's itinerary.

The longest and most successful National Horse Show in the fiftyfour years of its history which came to an end Wednesday night successfully refuted the prediction that the exhibition could not maintain interest over a period of eight days.
St. John's Prep and the St. Anselm freshmen battled to a 2-2 deadlock at Alumni Stadium today as both teams shone brilliantly on the defense in a football game.

The painstaking arrangements made for the voyage of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, all of which came to naught when the trip was canceled, were revealed yesterday when the Bremen docked with 1,049 passengers, most of whom were keenly disappointed.

Oddlot trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Nov. 6 was marked by a continuance of the buying trend regardless of a sharp decline in the security values, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

The Rev. John Wharton Stokes, former attorney and the pastor of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, died at his home here last night. He was 53 years of age and had served the local church for eight months.
A children's safety program will be instituted tomorrow by a parade and meeting in New Rochelle. More than 1,500 children and city officials are expected to take part.

Loyola's Lions today subdued the strong Centenary College eleven from Louisiana, 14 to 7. Pursued by misfortune in their past five games and rated the under dogs today, the Los Angeles team broke a 7-7 deadlock in the final quarter on a 57-yard march climaxed by a 26-yard touchdown pass.
Mayor La Guardia was reported yesterday to be seeking an opening on the bench for Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts.

The New Jersey upland game season opened yesterday with the dawning of sufficient light for hunters to outline their sights on game, and as the light strengthened salvos literally rolled from the low hills surrounding this area.
