The German Government is immensely pleased with the turn of events taken in Brazil. All reports from government circles are unanimous on this point and the press supports these conclusions. Coming so soon after the Italian signature to the antiComintern pact, the Brazilian experiment opens up possibilities for anti-Communist and authoritarian cooperation which are fully, though at the moment hesitantly, appreciated.

The Duke of Windsor failed to attend the Armistice Day services in St. George's Church here today despite the fact that the Anglican rector apologized for remarks he made concerning the Duke which were printed in the papers this morning.

Ten of the thirteen vacancies caused by death in the membership of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, 633 West 155th Street, will be filled at an election this morning which will feature the annual meeting of the organization.

Remarking that he was feeling "the same as ever," General John J. Pershing, commander of American troops in the World War, returned last night from a six-months stay in Europe and expressed the hope that there would "never be another war."

A curfew order again was declared in Jerusalem beginning at 6 o'clock tonight as the result of various incidents here today. Early today the body of Hussein Mohammed Hamad of Lifta, an Arab village just outside of Jerusalem, was found on the road leading from Sanhedria, a Jewish quarter in Jerusalem, to Lifta.

Getulio Dornelles Vargas, who has seized virtually dictatorial powers under the Constitution proclaimed Wednesday, has ruled Brazil for seven years, three years longer than any other man has governed South America's largest country since the fall of the empire in 1889.
A gift of $42,000 from Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson to the United Hospital Fund drive for $3,171,000 was announced yesterday by Miss Louise Iselin, chairman of the women's campaign committee.

Correspondents of The Dally Telegraph in Moscow and Warsaw report the arrest in the latest purge of three Soviet diplomats, namely Konstantin K. Yureneff, Ambassador to Germany; Y. H. Davtian, Ambassador to Poland, and Mikhail Karski, Minister to Turkey.

War veterans of four nations tonight voiced a plea for international harmony and peace over a national network of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. Prime Minister Mackenzie King and Brig. Gen. Alex Ross, Dominion president of the Canadian Legion, expressed the sentiments of the Canadian people.

The New York Central Railroad Company, including all leased lines, reported yesterday for September a net income of $224,495 after all fixed charges. This was equal to 3 cents a shire on the outstanding stock. It is compared to $1,133,374, or 23 cents a share in September, 1936. Operating revenues in September were $30,603,439, against $30,568,132 in the same month last year
Edith Maxwell, Wise County school teacher twice convicted of killing her father, lost, her appeal for a third trial in the Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals today.

To the strains of martial music the battle flags of the World War Allies were carried together again last night at the annual Armistice ball of the British Great War Veterans of America at the WaldorfAstoria.

Miss Marjorie Jane Kendig, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Roescoe B. Kendig of Grosse Point, Mich., was married this evening to Frederick Emerson Creamer, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Warren Emerson Creamer of Williamsport, Pa., in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer, brother of the bridegroom, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Stanley Kilbourne. the rector.

An impassioned defense of the members of the newly formed triple alliance against communism-Italy, Germany and Japan-by Dr. Bruno Roselli, former Professor of Italian at Vassar College, enlivened last night a discussion at the Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, of America's place and part in maintaining world peace.
The annual Friends Fair, under the auspices of the Friends Seminary Alumni Scholarship Committee, will take place today and tomorrow at the school, Sixteenth Street and Rutherford Place.

Strollers along Broadway and vicinity from about Seventy-sixth to Ninetieth Streets were subject to coughing and sneezing spells shortly before 6 o'clock last night when a mysterious pall of odorous smoke which resembled a heavy fog descended on the area, especially around Eighty-fifth and Eightysixth Streets, from Riverside Drive east to Columbus Avenue.

Henry Platte, a Civil War veteran and Mason, died Tuesday at his home, 1,228 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, in his ninety-fifth year. Mr. Platte enlisted for the war in the Twenty-eighth Regiment, National Guard, and after his discharge re-enlisted in the 133d Regiment of New York and served for the duration of the war under General Sheridan.

Minus one of its ace ends, Alonzo (Al) Hearne, Andover's football squad participated in a brisk drill on Brothers Field today in preparation for its classic appointment with Exeter that is scheduled for 1:30 o'clock on Saturday at Exeter, N. H.

ONE November evening twenty-one years ago, when the man in the White House was--with the rest of the country--entertaining a certain amount of honest doubt as to whether he'd won the election or whether Charles Evans Hughes had beaten him, Dr. Grayson was trying to be appropriately sympathetic.

Acting under orders of the Chinese high command, most of the Chinese troops in the Nantao section of Shanghai laid down their arms last night and withdrew for internment in the French Concession, but occasional outbreaks of machine-gun fire this morning indicated stragglers and snipers were still in Nantao in large numbers.

The James Monroe High School eleven remained unbeaten and untied as it downed De Witt Clinton High, 7--0, and the Theodore Roosevelt outfit overpowered Evander Childs, 30--6, in a schoolboy doubleheader at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday.

Stamps sought by philatelists appeared today on the envelopes containing Army-Navy football tickets. Postmaster William A. Strohm arranged to have the stamps canceled at the Naval Academy postoffice on Armistice Day, an action making the stamps and envelopes more sought after.

Audrey Lewisohn, daughter of Frederick Lewisohn of New York and Cannes, France, and of Mrs. Gabriel Prudhomme of Paris and Kenya, was married to Matthew Baird 3d of Philadelphia at Kensington Registry Office Tuesday, it was learned today.

The United Shoe Workers of America adopted a resolution today opposing Secretary of State Hull's negotiations for reciprocal trade treaties, particularly with Czechoslovakia, which include consideration of a lower tariff on shoes.
Pingry School of Elizabeth defeated the Wardlaw School eleven today, 18 to 0, in one of the oldest private school gridiron rivalries in the country. The teams met for the first time in 1883.
Dr. Glenn Frank vigorously assailed governmental policies of an "economy of scarcity" in an address before the convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs here this afternoon.

Annual meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the election of new members, 632 West 156th Street, 11 A. M. Literary exercises at 3 P. M. Speakers: Owen Wister, William Lyon Phelps and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

The proportion of the bank's reserve to public and private deposits was 26.9 per cent. Last week the ratio was 26.9 per cent, against 28.6 two weeks ago. The highest ratio this year to date was 42 per cent, on Jan. 21, and the ratio on Aug. 5, at 16.6, was the lowest.

John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that four of his party's predictions of 1936 have come true. "First," he said, "there has been a sharp increase in the cost of living.

Andrew Ponzi of Philadelphia tonight scored a surprise victory over Ralph Greenleaf of New York in the world pocket billiard championship, beating the defending title-holder, 125 to 56, in eight innings.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust, Boston, of which Merrill Griswold is chairman, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 2,000,000 shares of beneficial interest to be offered at the market price.

Villanova's undefeated Wildcats encountered unexpected opposition today from Boston University's ambitious football Terriers while grinding out a 12-0 victory, thanks to left end Johnny (Socko) Wysocki, before a crowd of 15,000 fans at Fenway Park.

George Sheringham, decorative painter, theatrical designer and book illustrator, died in Hampstead today. He was 53 years old. Mr. Sheringham had worked in close collaboration with the actormanager Sir Nigel Playfair,

The current difficulties of man in interfering with' his universe were examined last night by three outstanding authorities who have recently written on the subject, in addresses before, an auditorium audience in Rockefeller Center at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair.

Senator J. Hamilton Lewis of Illinois returned from Europe on the United States liner Washington last night after a visit to Germany, during which he discussed plans for payments to bondholders in this country on $100,000,000 invested in Germany. He said that arrange-, ments were started which he hoped would be satisfactory.

Ward Cuff of Marquette and the New York Giants is the apple of Coach Steve Owen's eye-the Big Apple, if you please. Probably the best blocking back in the National Football League, the freshman ace is being groomed for more important duties, tasks that will bring him an even larger share of the headlines than he has had.

In the hilly borderlands of Bohemia, from the song-famed Boehmer Wald to the southern tip of Silesia, the Sudetio Germans. who gather nightly at their Stammtische drink silent toasts these days to "Der Tag"--the day when Chancellor Hitler will march into "Sudeten Germany" to free them from the rule of the Czechs.

Thus far an ocean of blue water has separated the people of this country from the nearest Fascist State. That has been our good fortune. But there have been prophets who predicted that this good fortune would not last. They saw in the Fascist countries a great and gnawing hunger for raw materials. They saw in the countries of South America cheap and abundant sources of many kinds of raw materials:

Shielding their movements with secrecy, government officials met the freighter West Selene at Quarantine late yesterday afternoon with subpoenas for three able seamen alleged to have quit their berths on the government merchantman Algic after a strike on that vessel in Montevideo, Uruguay, several months ago.

Six two-story buildings in the Batson Block on Main Street wore destroyed by fire early this morning. The blaze, discovered about 1:30, kept 100 volunteer firemen of Sayville and West Sayville busy five hours. Three were felled by smoke.

The marriage of Miss Ethel Winthrop Kopper, daughter of Mrs. Robert Porter Barbour of this place, to Alfred Eoff Smith, son of Mrs. Walter Smith of Upper Montclair, took place tonight at the home of the bride. A reception there followed the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Dr. Luke M. White, rector of St. Luke's Church here.
The vacant plot known as 68-70 Sands Street, Brooklyn, 37 by 100 feet, has been sold by John Humphrey to William Low, a client of Bulkley Horton Company, broker.
The annual Northeast sectional tournament to be conducted under auspices of the Boston Field Hockey Association will open on the Smith College field tomorrow at 2 P. M.

Cotton 4,000 bales, including 400 American. Limited demand for spot; prices 6 points higher. Quotations in pence: American, strict good middling, 5.54; good middling, 5.24; strict middling, 4.99; middling, 4.69, against 4.63 yesterday;

Continued opposition to legislation that might encourage a banking monopoly of any kind was forecast yesterday when William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks and president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks, appointed an executive committee of the association.

Coercion of automobile dealers by manufactures with respect to dealers' choice of finance companies in their retail trade was assailed today by David B. Cassat, president of the Interstate Finance Corporation, Dubuque, Iowa,

President Roosevelt's theory that rates charged by public utilities should be based on the amount reasonably and honestly invested in the properties, instead of on the sum required to reproduce them new, was laid before the Supreme Court today by the Federal Power Commission, intervening in the appeal of the California Railroad Commission against an injunction obtained by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.
Authors will talk at the Book Fair at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon on gardens out of books, and this evening, at 8 o'clock, on books out of universities.

Talk of the restoration of a Bourbon to the Spanish throne in the event of a Rebel victory is heard in Spanish monarchical circles here as a consequence of the two-hour conference yesterday between former King Alfonso and Antonio Goecochea; special envoy of General Francisco Franco.

The Manati Sugar Company has advised its creditors and stockholders that the new bonds, shares and option warrants issuable under the plan of reorganization that became effective on Nov. 5 are available for distribution at the Bankers Trust Company.
Mrs. Clifford D. Gregory, widow of a former Albany County judge, died last night after a year's illness. She was a native of Albany and was graduated at the Albany Acadamy for Girls.
Domingo E. Delgado, export sales manager of Eastman Kodak Company, died tonight at his Sagamore Hotel home. He was 56 years old.

With 2,000 volunteers at work, 515 Red Cross flags flying from prominent buildings, and 1,560 displays on view in store windows, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross opened yesterday its twenty-first annual membership roll-call.
A typhoon swept across five Philippine provinces and through Manila tonight, leaving an undetermined number of dead, injured and homeless. Property damage was extensive.

Two boyhood friends, one the Vice President of the United- States and the other a Paraguayan rancher visiting here after a quartercentury absence, met again today. Vice President Garner, on his way to Washington, stood on the steps of his private car and saw the slight figure of William X. Lewis approaching.

With the corps of cadets lined up along the highway cheering them on, Army's football players left tonight after practice for the Knollwood Country Club at White Plains, N. Y., where they will remain until they move into the Yankee Stadium Saturday for the contest with Notre Dame.

Conversations are being held here this week with the idea of bringing industrial workers' organizations, farm workers and members of the official National Revolutionary party into a united popular front for the first time in Mexican history.

Yesterday's note in the Correspondenza Diplomatica, official organ of the Foreign Ministry, calling on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain to open negotiations immediately for an agreement between Great Brittain and the Rome-Berlin axis, has been followed at an interval of only twenty-four hours by prompt action on the Italian side and the first contact preliminary to official conversations was established today.

There used to be, probably still are, those who, looking over Army's roster and noting how many of the men have played football in other colleges prior to entering West Point, regard the cadets as having a decided advantage over their opponents.

Max Schmeling, who entertains hopes of being the first heavyweight ex-champion to regain his crown, returned to New York yesterday from his native Germany. The swarthy fighter, accompanied by his trainer, Max Machon, was met by his American manager, Joe Jacobs, as he debarked from the Bremen of the North German Lloyd line. They proceeded to the Essex House, where they will remain until tomorrow.

Busy Times Square traffic. was halted yesterday when eleven Boy Scout buglers played taps at 11 o'clock to commemorate the nineteenth anniversary of the signing of the armistice. Men and women stood with bowed, uncovered heads as the roll-call was sounded.

Miss A. Doris's Lady Higloss, a heavy favorite with New England racing fans, today annexed the major portion of the $1,500 purse in the Armistice Day handicap, a sprint of five and one-half furlongs, before 30,000 persons at Rockingham Park.

Another example of State intervention in industry, or so-called "Tory socialism," was given tonight when the issuance of the government's longawaited Coal Bill revealed that all the coal in Britain, known and unknown, will pass into the ownership of the State on July 1, 1942.

The address of Secretary Morgenthau, calling for reduced expenditures and budget balancing as a means of stimulating private capital, has met wide press approval, with some editors, however, urging a direct statement of views from President Roosevelt. --Excerpts from the editorial comment are as follows:
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index has advanced to 72.4 from 70.9 during the previous week. The index for the week ended Nov. 7, 1936, was 72.5.

Four persons were ordered to appear for questioning in the Fire Marshal's office this morning in an investigation to determine the cause of a fire that swept the upper floors of the old Cosmopolitan Hotel, a landmark at Chambers Street and West Broadway, early yesterday.
Parades of war veterans and public officials, ceremonies at soldiers' graves and a brief cessation of business at 11 A. M. marked the Armistice Day activities today throughout Westchester County.

Children's voices of two nations blended today in their respective national anthems to a common tune, and speakers pledged their fellow-country men to continued friendship beside the sixty-foot Peace Arch, built atop the unfortified international divide.

The possibility of stricter enforcement of the Multiple Dwelling Law requirements for improvement of old buildings used as rooming houses faces owners of these structures when the new city charter goes into effect on Jan. 1.

Coach Elmer Layden and a squad of forty-four Notre Dame football men left this afternoon by special train for Harmon, N. Y., where they will detrain tomorrow morning, and then proceed to their headquarters at the Westchester Country Club, Rye.

The Most Rev. James Edward Kearney, former Bishop of Salt Lake City and one time pastor of a Bronx parish. was installed today as fifth Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rochester in ceremonies at the Pro-Cathedral of the Sacred Heart.

Sergeant Alvin C. York, the Tennessee squirrel hunter who became the "greatest civilian soldier" of the World War, surveyed the world situation today and declared himself ready to fight again in the interest of universal peace.
Plans for a 350-foot steel bridge carrying the West Side Express Highway over Canal Street at the West Street intersection will soon be submitted to the Board

Listing of the following stock issues has been approved by the New York Curb Exchange: R and H Corporation namee to be changed to Allied Products Corporation, Michigan, as successor by reincorporation to Allied Products Corporation, Illinois)--64,200 shares of Class

With the impending reopening of the consulate at Bilbao the United State Government will virtually be following the example of Great Britain in appointing consular agents in the-Franco Government's territory to protect the business and personal interests of its nationals.
Nathan Straus announces a housing policy which is almost revolutionary in its return to common sense.

Al though naval construction has in creased by leaps and bounds since the expiration last Dec. 31 of the London Naval Limitation Treaty ol 1930, Japan has been able to keep secret her building activities to such a degree that, if known information is to be believed, she has on the ways or authorized 10,000 toni less tonnage than she- had under construction when the treaty expired.

Five hundred Boy Scouts will begin a highway safety campaign here Dec. 18 by visiting gasoline stations and giving "pep talks" to motorists, it was announced today by George A. Ecclesine, vice chairman of District 2 of the Fenimore Cooper Boy Scout Council.
Dr. Arthur Sauter, dermatologist, died tonight of a heart attack at the age of 68. He was well known in the State and was frequently called upon as a consultant.

For the first time in twenty-one years the St. George's school eleven from Newport, R. I., defeated its ancient rival, Middlesex School, 7 to 0, today in their annual game before a large holiday crowd.

The Hippodrome OperaCompany presented a holiday double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" last night before a moderate-sized audience. Fidela Campigna made her first appearance at the Hippodrome in the role of Santuzza in "Cavalleria."

Lincoln Ellsworth, the explorer, returned from England yesterday with Mrs. Ellsworth, after receiving the Patron Medal of the Royal Geographic Society on Oct. 18. They also spent some time hunting in Austria, where Mrs. Ellsworth bagged two chamois.

The marriage of Mrs. Josephine Keith Colyer, daughter of Mrs. Charles Augustus Bush of Dallas, Texas, and of the late Walker A. Keith, to James Matthews Faust of 310 East Fifty-fifth Street, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Armstrong Faust of New York, took place here yesterday at noon in the Central Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore C. Speers.
Thomas L. Burton was named today in a report of the nominating committee for commodore 'of the 57-year-old Larchmont Yacht Club.

With two more days to run, Chicago's thirtyeighth annual automobile show tonight had attracted 260,000 persons to the International Amphitheatre during six days of the exhibition. The management announced this figure and said last year's record total attendance of 318,000 may be exceeded before this year's event is ended at 11 o'clock Saturday night.
Mary Garden, retired operatic soprano, returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen after a search abroad as a talent scout for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

Directors of Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., will announce today the declaration of a dividend of 50 cents a share on the outstanding common stock of the corporation for the quarter ended on Oct. 31.

Bowman-Biltmore Hotels Corporation (Hotel Commodore) - October: Net profit before amortization and provision for income taxes $43,700, compared with $63,971 in October, 1936. Ten months ended Oct. 1: Net profit, on same basis, $168,464, against $79,536 in same period last year.
INTERNATIONAL ASPECTS OF GERMAN RACIAL POLICY, by Oscar I. Janowsky and Melvin M. Fagen. (Oxford, $2.) EIGHT DECADES, by Agnes Repplier. (Houghton Mifflin, $3.) Personal essays.

The engagement of Miss Virginia Alice Fincke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Fincke of Five Oaks, Willow Grove, to the Rev. Louis E. Fifer 3d, son of Mrs. Louis E. Fifer of Glenside, has been announced by her parents.

Publication of two books on government ownership of railroads was announced yesterday by the Transportation Conference, an organization formed by the Railway Business Association. The latter is composed of companies which manufacture equipment and supplies for the railroads.

In as magnificent an effort as he has ever made, the handicap champion, Seabiscuit, met defeat today by a nose at the end of the mile and five-eights of the $12,225 Bowie Handicap, which was captured by Esposa.

George Herman (Babe) Ruth, once the monarch of baseball, was the mighty Nimrod of Nova Scotia when he rolled his automobile off the S. S. New York at Pier 19, North River, shortly after 8 A. M. yesterday.

With a two-minute pause in its manifold activities at 11 A. M., with speeches, parades, dinners, military and civic exercises and church services, the world paid tribute yesterday to the dead and wounded of the World War on the nineteenth anniversary of Armistice Day.

Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill in Coney Island Court, Brooklyn, yesterday complimented Bobby Salomon, 12-year-old Boy Scout, for attempting to aid his family's Negro maid, who was arrested for turning in a false fire alarm.
The Manhasset High School team defeated Roslyn High, 13 to 6, in an experimental football engagement today. Six players lined up for each side, three playing in the line and three in the backfield.

Sinclair Lewis, whose latest best, seller was "It Can't Happen Here," asserted yesterday that "it has happened here." His book, published in 1935, dealt with the possibility of a Fascist State in this country.

Vardis Fisher's first major work since the publication of the Vridar Hunter tetralogy is a novel entitled "Forgive Us Our Virtues." It will be published by Caxton. Mr. Fisher is at present editing "The Idaho Encyclopedia," written by members of the Idaho Federal Writers Project.

The St. Anselm College eleven scored an impressive 20-0 victory over Ithaca College today, although minus the services of four regulars. Ray McLean tallied two touchdowns and Frank Murphy raced 30 yards with the final score after intercepting Legare's pass.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today heard oral argument on a report by Edward C. Johnson, trial examiner, who held that Charles C. Wright of New York, Wright Sexton, Herbert King, Norman Stern and Arnold Co. violated the anti-manipulative provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 in trading in stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Company, Ltd., on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange from July 1, 1935, to April 9, 1936.

An effective quarantine against Japanese aggression in the Far East,-in accordance with the policy announced by President Roosevelt in his Chicago speech, was urged yesterday in a statement issued by the recently organized American Committee for Peace and Security in the Pacific.

Often the presence of a soloist on a symphonic program is an intrusion and a distraction from matters of greater significance. For the modern orchestra, under a distinguished conductor, is the greatest of all soloists, and there is little in the literature of the concerto for soloist and orchestra that equals in value the masterpieces of the purely symphonic repertory.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Dean Dimmitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Dimmitt of Clearwater, Fla., to George Waterhouse Sanders, son of Mrs. Lawrence Witsell Sanders of Montclair, N. J., and Chisholm Island, S. C., and the late Mr. Sanders.

Move over and-make room for the Mercury Theatre. After a glimpse of the modern version of "Julius Caesar," which opened at the. old playhouse in Forty-first Street last evening, it is plain that a place must be found for so much original acting talent.

The popularity of six-man football has tripled annually since the sport was introduced in this country in 1934, according to Stephen E. Epler, inventor of the game, who is now doing graduate work at Columbia University's Teachers College.

In even the best accounts of the controversy over the President's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court little attention has been paid to the part played by the court's decision in the Pacific Gas Electric case last June. Yet that ruling was much responsible for the continuance of the fight for enlargement, after the liberal Wagner and Social Security Act opinions.

The Rev. Charles H. Collett of Germantown, Pa., on vacation at the home of a brother here, died of a heart atLack today after a brief illness. He was 49 years old. Mr. Collett was rector of Christ Church and St. Michael's in Germantown.

Extension of the present recession in general business during a large part of the first half of next year and a substantial upturn in the last half of 1938 were predicted by A. W. Zelomek, economist of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc. in an address before the Philadelphia Purchasing Agentp here tonight.

Funeral services for Walter Shear Sullivan, a yachtsman and authority on yachting, were held yesterday morning at St. Joseph's Cathollo Church, Bathgate Avenue and 178th Street, the Bronx. A solemn requiem high mass was celebrated by the Rev James S. Darron.

Colby and Bates fought through four periods of torrid football today to end their annual Armistice Day battle in a 6-6 tie. Colby scored in the second on a pass to Hersey and Bates in the third on a 52-yard march, Briggs making the touchdown.

Stormy weather continues at the MacGregor Arctic Expedition base here. Snow has fallen for the past week, with no let-up in sight. The temperature remained around 10 above zero. All vegetation is Well covered up, forcing all game out into the open to seek food.
Some 200 Princeton University freshmen heard talks by three newspaper men and an advertising executive at a smoker tonight in the sophomore lounge at the university dining hall.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Waring of this place and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beverly Waring, to E. Newton Cutler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle N. Cutler of Morristown.
A Japanese Army spokesman, expressing regret for the killing today of Pembroke Stephens, London Daily Telegraph correspondent, freely admitted Japanese responsibility.

Funeral services for Walter Shear Sullivan, a yachtsman and authority on yachting, were held yesterday morning at St. Joseph's Cathollo Church, Bathgate Avenue and 178th Street, the Bronx. A solemn requiem high mass was celebrated by the Rev. James S. Darron.
Dartmouth's varsity football team spent a long session today in preparing for Cornell's visit Saturday. Bill Hutchinson returned to his fullback post. shaping his position with Colby Howe.

A squad of six patrolmen and a sergeant, all in plainclothes, began a 9 P. M. to 5 A. M. patrol of the Brooklyn Heights residential section last night in an effort by the police to curb noise making by early morning revelers who have been disturbing the sleep of residents for many months.
Determined opposition to the Black-Connery Wage-and-Hour Bill, as passed by the Senate, was voiced here today by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

A repeat performance cost Charles F. Steinbach, freshman at Utah State Agricultural College, his life. He told four persons he would demonstrate how Carroll S. Anderson, 15, of Hollywood, killed himself "like a Czarist guardsman."

The Rev. Dr. Paul W. Koller, for nine years executive secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions of the United Lutheran Church, died here today at the age of 65. He was president of the Lutheran Synod of Ohio for seven years before coming to the Mission Board in Baltimore.

The 150-pound football teams of Yale and Princeton preserved their undefeated status today in Palmer Stadium by battling to a 6-6 tie in a contest that leaves the Big Three rivals deadlocked at the top of the Eastern Intercollegiate Lightweight League.

Business in the stock markets here was small today, but a more confident tone prevailed in most sections. Giltedge issues improved, while among the foreign bonds further buying took place in Far Eastern issues. International shares were actively traded and United States Steel and International Nickel went ahead.

American industry is working on programs of stabilization of production and employment, and labor is willing to cooperate, Secretary Perkins told 300 manufacturers tonight at a dinner of the Associated Industries of New York.
Flares turned the leaves of the campus to brilliant orange tonight as the students marched behind their band to University Field to let the football players know Princeton was behind them.

Apartment house deals reported yesterday in the Bronx included the sale of the five-story building for twenty-five families at 2,341 Webster Avenue for the Danielson Realtors, Inc., to a client of the A. Michaelson Company, broker in the transaction. The buyer paid cash over a first mortgage, which has been extended for five years.

A committee of eighteen steamship owners, operating on foreigntrade routes, has submitted a report to the Federal Maritime Commission analyzing the 435-foot cargo ship designed by the commission as a model for future construction in the merchant marine.

After spotting its old rival, Brooklyn Prep, one touchdown in the first period, the Adelphi Academy eleven rallied to score in the second and third quarters and win, 14-7, on Boys High field yesterday. Nick Cavagnaro, Brooklyn Prep quarterback, sent his team off to the early lead with a 28-yard run around right end to a touchdown.

Germany today captured the land plane speed record from the United States. Chief Pilot' Wurster of the Bavarian Airplane Works flew a Messersmith racer 610.2 kilometers [about 379.16 miles] an hour, bettering the record of 352.388 miles made by Howard Hughes Sept. 12, 1935.

A warrant for the removal to New York of James Sweeney, 36, to face charges that he was implicated in the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. of Albany, was sworn out today by United States Commissioner David B. Head.

As had been predicted, the recent decision in the General ShaverPackard Lektro-Shave case, favoring the former, has begun to encourage the introduction of other dry shavers, which had been held back because of the litigation.
A minor contra-seasonal recession in cotton mill activity last week lowered the adjusted index to 112.8 from 114.8. The figure was 131.5 for the week ended Nov. 7, 1936.

President Lazaro Cardenas signed today a contract with the Royal Dutch Shell-controlled Eagle Oil Company, agreeing to give that company concessions in the remainder of the Pozarica oil field, regarded next to the Iraq field as the richest in the world.

A gift of $350,000 to build a new wing on Houston Hall, first student union building in the world, was announced today at a luncheon of campaign workers seeking a $12,500,000 bicentennial fund for the University of Pennsylvania.
Meeting of the Association of Civics Teachers at The New York Times Clubroom, Twelfth Floor, 229 West Forty-third Street, 10:30 A.-M. Speakers: Winfield L. Rice, Grace M. Anderson.

1st Lt. Stanley A. Liszcz, Inf-Res., 29 Slater St., Amsterdam, N. Y., 41st Infantry (RAI), is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective Nov. 12. He will proceed to Headquarters Schenectady District, CCC, Schenectady, N. Y., for assignment in connection with CCC activities.
Two of Europe's outstanding ski aces, Sverre Kolterud and Tomm Murstad of Norway, arrived in New York yesterday on the S.' S. Bergensfjord of the Norwegian-American Line.

The body of former Premier Ramsay MacDonald will be taken from Bermuda, probably Monday or Tuesday, aboard the 6,980-ton .. cruiser Apollo to Plymouth, England, and is expected to arrive the morning of Nov. 25.

The current business recession permits of "no indecision or inaction" in carrying out a large housing program to marshal the recuperative forces in industry, finance and labor, Senator Robert F. Wagner declared last night at a dinner given in his honor at the Hotel Astor by the National Public Housing Conference.

Major Gen. Albert J. Bowley, commander of the Third Corps Area of the army, with headquarters at Baltimore, was ordered today to the command of the Ninth Corps Area with headquarters in San Francisco, succeeding Major Gen. George S. Simonds, who will retire from active service on March 31, 1938. General Bowley will sail from New York on Feb. 10.

The Board of Transportation has refused to attend hearings, or even informal conferences, before the State Labor Relations Board on the application of the TransportWorkers Union of America, C. I. O. affiliate, for an order certifying it as sole bargaining agency for the 5,400 employes on the city's Independent Subway System.

The "lie-down strike" show produced before a huge noonday crowd last Wednesday by twenty-one men and three girls who stretched out on the sidewalk in front of the Horn Hardart Automat at 455 Seventh Avenue, near Thirty-fourth Street, was criticized yesterday by Magistrate Brodsky as "a bad performance."
The Riverdale Country School football team brought its season to a close yesterday by bowing to Scarsdale High, 26 to 6, on Riverdale's field.

Dr. Leslie Washington Weedon, nationally recognized as an authority on yellow fever, died today at a hospital here after being stricken with a heart attack last night. He was 77 years old. Dr. Weedon, who lived through two yellow fever epidemics, gained national recognition because of his research work, and was sent to New Orleans by the United States Government in 1894 to aid in an anti-fever fight there.

The recovery of the dollar was carried forward strongly yesterday in the foreign exchange market, with the pound sterling falling 1 15-16 cents to $4.98 3-16, and the france 2 1/8 points down to 3.38 1/4 cents. Other important exchanges,

Franklin Ave (10-2607), e s, 455 ft s of 166th St, 54x201; George M. Penfield to Keller Realty co, Inc, 369 E 149th St; mtg $53,000. Pugsley Ave (14-380-4), e s, at n e s of 177th St, 92x142; Keystone Estate, Inc, to Greengate Holding Corp, 300 Madison Ave; mtg $314,900. Crotona Park E (11-2938), s s 176 ft e of Prospect Ave, 50x64; Morris H. Bosenbaum to Meyer Goodman, 1,420 Crotona Park E.
The purchase of $10,400,000 of government securities by the Reserve Banks, disclosed in this week's report, redeems the promise that was made by the Federal Open Market Committee on Sept. 12.

Now that the early confusion attending Wednesday's coup d'etat in Brazil has subsided and there has been an opportunity to study the new Constitution, it is possible to form a clearer idea of what President Getulio Vargas's new State is intended to be.

A roller-skating party with many carnival divertissements was given carnival divertissements was given last night in the Mecca Temple Casino, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the Vocational Service for Juniors, an organization long active in the promotion of vocational guidance in the schools of New York.

Japan's rejection of the Far Eastern conference's attempts to initiate a discussion of her conflict with China reached Brussels this afternoon. While the rejection was not unexpected, the refusal is so positive and so comprehensive that further advances to Tokyo are recognized as impossible.
Reports by 141 Class I railroads to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed an increase a more than 6 per cent from-a year before in their combined passenger

E. Kent Hubbard of Middletown, president of the Connecticut Manufacturers Association, declared in a speech here today that the Wagner Labor Relations Act "ought to be scrapped just as the NRA was scrapped."

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine issued an equivocal denial yesterday of reports that he would resign on Jan. 1, after strong statements to that effect, emanating from Police Headquarters, had appeared in the newspapers.

The board of directors of the Twenty-third Street Association will hold its monthly luncheon meeting in the Cornish Arms Hotel on Wednesday. G. Satriale was co-broker in the recently reported sale of the apartrent house at 3,315 Cruger Avenue, the Bronx.

For the sixty-first time since the day in November, 1873, when they met in this city for the first time on the gridiron, Yale and Princeton come together for a football game tomorrow. Today the teams went through their final rehearsals and tonight
Closing the season in triumph, Hill's eleven remained unbeaten today by turning back Hotchkiss, 16 to 7, in the thirty-second meeting between the schools.

Precedent and general sentiment here favor Exeter, but the season's records point to an Andover victory tomorrow in the annual renewal of their traditional football rivalry scheduled for 1:30 P. M. on Plimpton Playing Field.

The League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers and managers, decided yesterday to ask the Actors Equity Association to revise its unprecedented rule compelling managers to cooperate in any Equity plan for the improvement of theatre attendance.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce, which for three weeks has been investigating the plan for reorganization of the bankrupt Missouri Pacific Railroad, now pending before the Interstate Commerce Commission, adjourned this afternoon for an indefinite period.

Sir Barton, one of the highest priced sires on the continent andoutmatched at his peak only by the great Man o' War, is dead on a farm at Douglas, Wyo., where he had lived in retirement for more than seventeen years.
The Child Education Foundation will dedicate its new building on Monday night as a memorial to William Sloane Coffin, for many years president of the foundation, it was announced yesterday.
The Brooklyn College football team went through its final workout yesterday in preparation for today's game with the Fort Hamilton eleven at Erasmus Field, Brooklyn, at 2 P. M.

Dr. Sidney F. Blanchet, a prominent physician specializing in the treatment of tubercular patients at Saranac Lake for the last twenty years, died yesterday morning in his room at the Psychiatric Hospital of the Medical Center. Death was caused by a self-inflicted wound of the throat.

Frederick M. Eliot, president of the American Unitarian Association, described his church last night as "to too great an extent a class church," and declared that it must take steps to break down class barriers if it is to be "a force which stands behind the democratic process."

President Roosevelt, informed today that the American Newspaper Guild had protested his acceptance of an honorary membership in the American Press Society, said that he had accepted the membership after reading and approving the constitution of the organization.

Miss Katherine Russell, -for more than twenty-five years a teacher at Public School 5, 124 Edgecqmbe Avenue, Manhattan, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness at the age of 52. Miss Russell lived at the- Congress Hotel, 19 West Sixty-ninth Street.

Al Schacht, famous baseball comedian and former corporal in the United States Army, has accepted the position, of coach of the Fort Jay football team in the annual charity game with Fort Hoyle, from Maryland, for the championship of the First Division at Ebbets Field tomorrow.

Three seamen, who are alleged to have quit their berths on the steamship Algic of the American Republic Line when that vessel was in Montevideo, Uruguay, last Sept. 10, were arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn on a charge of conspiracy to deprive the captain of the Algic of authority and cormmand on board the vessel.

A copy of the first edition of the first version of Fitz-Gerald's "Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam" brought $2,750 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of property of J. Macy Willets of this city and others.
Now and then one would like to see the Nobel Science Prize given for something really big. We are speaking in a literal
Geoffrey Mander, Liberal Member of Parliament, would like to know whether any foreign countries want to join the British Empire.

Former President Hoover charged tonight that President's Roosevelt's reorganization bill was directed toward abandonment of the merit system in government and substitution of "personal political control."
Ten persons aboard a BerlinMiim airliner were killed to night when the craft crashed twelve miles from Mannheim Airdrome. Seven passengers were among the dead. Two passengers were injured.

Justice George A. Larkin this afternoon subpoenaed Mayor George J. Zimmermann to testify before the Common Council payroll investigation committee. Justice Larkin issued the subpoena at the request of Attorney Frank G. Raichle Jr., counsel for the committee.

A funeral service for Andrew J. Miller, a partner in the banking firm of Hallgarten Co., 44 Pine Street, will take place today at 10 A. M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle will officiate at the mass.
No more licenses for imports will be issued until new regulations for the control of imports and foreign exchange have been adopted, according to a notice issued today by the Exchange Control Board.

The Spanish civil war dwindled today to a series of skirmishes along the upper Aragon front. Insurgent dispatches said this was the calm before an imminent Insurgent offensive. Generalissimo Francisco Franco's troops were expected to be ready for the drive in Northeastern Spain by Monday, weather permitting, although the points chosen for the jump-off remained a military secret.

Rhode Island State conquered Providence College, 13 to 0, in their annual intrastate game tonight. The Rams marched 69 yards for their first touchdown early in the final chapter. A 13-yard aerial, Rene Duranleau to Chet Jaworski, paved the way for the touchdown.

This being Nov. 13, Mrs. Bourke Cockran will celebrate at her home, 1,136 Fifth-Avenue, the birthday that Robert Louis Stevenson transferred to her by deed of gift forty-six years ago, when she was a little girl in a gingham pinafore on the island of - Upolu in Samoa and he, with . only three years more to live, "had no further

Candid camera photographers who strip public notables of their Olympian superiority by snapping them in the act of transferring a wellloaded fork to a gaping mouth or in any of the other intimate processes of eating or drinking have drawn a rebuke from Winston Churchill.

Arthur W. Kilpatrick, 54 years old, crossing watchman on the Belvidere branch of the Pennsylvania railroad was committed to jail today without bail on a charge of and wrecking a Pennsylvania passenger Hofn train near his home at Pinchers Point south of here on Oct. 16.

Possessing the best attacking record in the circuit, the Detroit Lions will arrive this morning and engage in their final workout at the Polo Grounds preparatory to meeting the New York Giants in a National Football League test there tomorrow.

The Italian liner Rex will sail today for Mediterranean ports. Her passengers include Dr. Ugo Bordoni, vice director of tourism in Italy, who has been making a survey of American hotels; accompanied by Ettore Rossi, architects and Mrs. Rossi; Dr. and Mrs. Giorgio Cerio, Mr. and Mrs. William G. Elmslie, Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Millar, Mrs. A. B. Waddell, Mr. and Mrs. E. Welker and Francesco Saroli.

First in an interesting novice stake, the opening competition of the three-day annual field-trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club was the young dog Tarzan, owned by Anthony A. Bliss of Westbury and handled by Lionel Bond.

The break in Brazilian dollar obligations as a result of the Vargas political coup and suspension of external debt service announced over the holiday, was the principal feature of the bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Declines of 2 to 20 points ruled among loans of Brazilian origin,

Staging a strong comeback after the home eleven had taken the lead early in the game, St. Paul's School downed its old rival, Poly Prep, 20 to 6, on the latter's field in Brooklyn yesterday. It marked the twenty-eighth meeting between the schools in a series which began in 1892, and it was the final game of the season for both teams.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Lois Gould, daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Everett W. Gould of New M. York, to Henry Pratt Foster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Crosby Christi Foster of Plainfield, took place here tonight at the home of her uncle Mrs. and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Van Vleck. The Rev. Dr. Dwight W.

The Federal grand jury today returned indictments, charging violation of the Corrupt Practices Act, against Walter E. O'Hara, president of the Narragansett Racing Association and publisher of The Providence Star-Tribune, on four counts;

The Japanese Government has refused for a second time to send representatives to the Nine-Power conference which is now in session at Brussels. The reason for its refusal is implicit in the position which Japan has taken all along, and this reason is restated in the note which was sent to Brussels yesterday.

The Domei News Agency reported today in a dispatch from Seoul, Korea, that a Japanese patrol boat had been chased by a Soviet patrol boat and later threatened by a Soviet plane off the East Siberian coast.
The Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today that authorizations and commitments in October amounted to $77,875,390, while authorizations aggregating $7,085,147 were canceled or withdrawn.

As the first move in a drive to reduce sex crimes, District Attorney Walter A. Ferris of Westchester County issued a warning today that all salacious magazines" must be removed from newsstands in the county by Dec. 1.

Postmaster Francis J. Sinnott, In Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon turned in an alarm of fire for a blaze in 500 tons of coal in the subcellar of the Federal Building, at Washington and Johnson Streets, Brooklyn. Deputy Chief Edward G Conway, who responded to the call, said he believed spontaneous combustion caused the blaze.

Fire destroyed a 2.000-room bathing pavilion and eight one-story frame concession stands between Beach 100th and Beach 101st Streets, Rockaway Beach, Queens, and damaged four other stands shortly after 6:05. o'clock last night, causing damage estimated by the police between $50,000 and $75,000.

A shipment of 4,000 tons of Canadian grain which left New York ten days ago en route to London was accepted yesterday at London without payment of import tax, according to information received by New York grain interests.

Physicians redoubled precautions today to guard Pope Pius's health as the first Winter cold touched the Vatican. Outwardly the 80-year-old Pontiff appeared as strong as during the Summer, but a swelling' of his legs, with which he suffered last Winter, has caused him to give up using stairways.

The fortyninth annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union will open its three-day session here tomorrow with the delegates, nearly 400 of them, in exceptional accord, though threatened with ructions from without.

Former President Herbert Hoover said today that "this country is in a great crisis" and declared that "the solution has got to come through the adoption of some constructive program vastly transcending any personal politics."

Edward Lamb, Ohio counsel for the C. I. O., in a speech tonight over a radio network, called Governor Martin L. Davey a "Judas Iscariot" and accused him of uttering "a deliberate falsehood" concerning the C. I. O. strike against "Little Steel."

Scoring at least once in each period, Choate School's football powerhouse climaxed an undefeated campaign in emphatic style today by rolling to a 33-0 triumph over a courageous but outclassed Kent School eleven in the twenty-eighth annual renewal of their traditional gridiron rivalry.

Liberals rightly claim Justice Brandeis as one of their tribe. Yet it is not so much the mode of his thinking as it is the quality, not so much the conclusions at which he arrives as the means by which he arrives at them, that constitute his distinction. Neither in his fighting days in Boston and New York, nor now, in his judicial withdrawal, could he be considered a man of slogans and shibboleths.

Paul A. Wright, 38-year-old airport executive, listened unmoved today to a police version of the killing of his wife and his "best friend," John B. Kimmel-a crime which the officers said he admitted "because she was cheating on me."

The Pennsylvania Railroad offered today to pledge with trustees its entire holdings of New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad stock in order that the latter carrier's reorganization proceedings might be facilitated.

A list of fifty bills affecting advertising and selling now in Congress and to be acted upon at the session opening on Monday has been prepared by George McMillan, secretary of the Association of National Advertisers, and sent to members of the organization.

FERRIS, CATHIARINE A. (July 12, 1937). Gross assets, $51,189; net, $49,350. To brother, Frank J. Ferris. Chief assets, real estate, $4,500; stocks and bonds, $2,415; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $7,585; Jointly owned property, $29,814; transfers, $6,874. G. W. and W. M. Winans, attorneys, 124 Montague St.

Several large Manhattan buildings were among the eight parcels of realty sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street rooms. The fourteen-story office and store property at 16-24 West Fortyseventh Street, on a plot 100 by 100.5 feet, Was bid in by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff against the Stephen Realty Company, for $500,000.

The Cabinet crisis is not yet solved although Premier George Tatarescu's resignation and the Peasant leader, Ion Mihalache's undertaking to form a new Cabinet are expected tomorrow. A surprise solution, however. is still possible.

If the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad is to be operated independently with any degree of success, about $13,000,000 of new capital will be required for rehabilitation and improvements, according to a report by engineering experts of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which became available today.

Four planes representing two of the earliest discoveries of Christopher Columbus in the New World, the Dominican Republic and Cuba, climbed into the clouds today on a delayed PanAmerican good-will flight on behalf of the great Columbus lighthouse to be built here as a tribute of all the Americas to their discoverer.

The Long Island State Park Commission has begun to work out a policy of keeping trailer camps away from the parks and parkways it controls except in two specially designated. areas in Suffolk Coutnty, it was disclosed yesterday at the offices of the commission in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

The Little Three football championship will be decided by the fiftyfourth Williams-Amherst classic tomorrow. A record crowd of more than 9,000 is expected. Amherst invades Williamstown as the highest scoring football team in the country this Fall and has been defeated only by Dartmouth.

A plan to extend the New York State mortgage moratorium a year and thereafter allow foreclosures only when the mortgagee could prove that a refinancing loan of at least 75 per cent of the existing principal had been offered was advocated yesterday at a hearing before the legislative committee investigating moratorium and deficiency judgments. Realtors,

St. Andrew's Hospital and Church, the Episcopalian American Church mission properties in the town of Wusih, 95 miles southeast of here, were both bombed by Japanese planes this morning with extensive damage, according to news telephoned from Wusih to the United States Embassy here.

The usefulness of the gold-buying policy of the United States in the financing of Japan's warfare was noted by observers here today with the publication of reports of the Deapartment of Commerce showing the heavy movement of gold to this country from Japan and the determination of Tokyo to speed the nation's gold-mining program.

Mayor Denton Pearsall signed today an ordinance levying a 1 per cent tax on the earnings of public utilities in this city. The ordinance, adopted two weeks ago by the Common Council, is retroactive to July 1 and, according to officials, will net the city about $30,000 a year.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. John Brownlee Voorhees of this place of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Evelyn Treat Voorhees, to Arthur Brewster Emmons 3d of Dover, Mass. Miss Voorhees is a daughter of the late Rev. Dr. Voorhees, pastor of the Asylum Hill Congregational Church

Shattered communication lines hampered officials tonight as they surveyed the toll of yesterday's typhoon, which killed at least fifteen persons and left thousands homeless when it lashed across seven Philippine Provinces.

The establishment of a corporate State in Brazil by President Getulio Vargas late Wednesday and with it a declaration of the immediate suspension of all debt service on the country's external obligations caused a virtual collapse yesterday in the market for outstanding Brazilian bonds.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 11:

Alberto Lovell of the Argentine, who weighed 190.and fought like a lightweight, easily gained the decision over Eddie Blunt of Corona, L. I., in the feature ten-round bout at the Hippdrome last night.

The administration of the French Cameroons gave a report to the Mandates Commission yesterday likely to whet the appetite of its former German owners. It said that the price of, palm kernels had trebled during 1936 and that exports of them had risen 20 per cent.
The members of the department band shall be directed to report to Captain Julius A. Unrath at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, Columbus Ave. and 62d St. Manhattan, at 9 A. M., Saturday, Nov. 13, 1937.

In a speech to bankers yesterday Finance Minister Toyotaro Yuki declared that the economic measures adopted after the conflict in China had broken out were operating effectively and smoothly and that Japan's international trade, monetary condition, foreign exchange situation and commodity prices were generally favorable.

Davidson Ave, 2,016-2,018 (11-2863): Rutlyn Realties, Inc, to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave, extends mtgs to April 1, 1946, at 5 1/2% to April 1, 1941, and 5% thereafter; $25,000. Webster Ave (11-3143), w s, 163 ft $25,000. 180th St, 33x100; Sarah Goldberg to Dollar Savings Bank, installments, 4 1/2 per cent: $13.500.

Continued deflation of bank credit was disclosed in the weekly condition statement of the reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City, which was issued yesterday. The statement showed a net decline for the week ended on Wednesday of $25,000,000 in the total of the banks' loans and investments, reducing them to $7,888,000,000, compared with $8,642,000,000 a year ago.

J. Lindsay McKenna, a former newspaper man, died on Thursday at the French Hospital at the age of 57. Born in Philadelphia, he was the son of the late John J. McKenna, former city editor of The Public Ledger there and former managing editor and publisher of The Newark Advertiser.

Prices of wheat soared today on the Board of Trade here and on all other world markets on reports of serious frost damage to the crop in Argentina. Liverpool, which was open yesterday, was the first to reflect the bullish turn of conditions in Argentina with a sharp advance on Thursday and further advances today, to close 3 to 5 1/2 cents a bushel higher than on Wednesday.

Five officers and stockholders of R. Cummins Co. of Battle Creek, Mich., distillers, were sentenced today by Federal Judge Arthur F. Lederle to terms ranging from two to five years in the Federal penitentiary at Leavenworth, and fined $10,000 each.

A new method for preparing an effective vaccine against rabies in animals, which may open the way For making similar vaccines against infantile paralysis and other virus diseases, is reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Public Works Administration offcials said Mayor La Guardia of New York City was expected to confer late today with Harold L. Ickes, administrator, concerning an $11,268,229 grant for the $29,000,000 crosstown vehicular tunnel in Manhattan. Mr. La Guardia arrived here last night.
Two great football teams were sequestered far from the scene of battle tonight as Dartmouth and Cornell awaited the opening whistle of a game .which should be one of the Eastern classics tomorrow.

The San Francisco Chamber of Commerce said in a statement today that withdrawal of luxury liiiers from the San Francisco-East Coast run would "constitute an economic crisis on the entire Pacifie slope."
A "concentration camp" for idle Spanish Government vessels now congesting French Bay of Biscay ports is suggested to alleviate the situation.

Bruised and exhausted, Dr. James I. Seder, 79-year-old former missionary and one-time head of the State Anti-Saloon League, was recovering here tonight, while three men were held charged with extortion.

The Federal Alcohol Administration will continue as a unit of the Treasury Department, it was learned today, despite the amendment passed by Congress last year providing for taking the organization from the Treasury and placing. a board of three men in charge.

Viscount Halifax, formerly Viceroy of India and now one of the most influential figures in the British Cabinet, will meet Chancellor Hitler next week for the first personal talk that any British Minister has had with the Fuehrer in two and a half years.
American World War veterans honored their brothers-in-arms from England, France, Italy, Belgium, and Poland last night at the American Legion's annual Victory Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria.
M. Bardoul, Director of the Mint, in a report before the Chamber of -Deputies Finance Commission today stated that it actually cost more to mint five and ten centime pieces than their face value.

Jimmy Coughlin, 9-month-old son of Mr. and Mrs. William Coughlin of 1,164 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, has won a first prize of $500 in the sixth annual children's national photograph contest, it was announced yesterday. The child's father is employed as an indexer by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and the couple have two other children, William Jr., 3, and Robert, 2.

Stocks, eased from best levels but closed irregularly higher on day after moderate gains; turnover, 1,881,730 shares. Brazilian loans dropped 2 to 20 points, other South American bonds weakened, UTnited States Government and corporate bonds steady and mixed; transactions,

Albert B. Hines looked back yesterday on his twenty-five years as director of - the Madison Square Boys Club and said: "I'd like to do it over again. I've had fun." In his littered office in the three remodeled tenements at 312 East Thirtieth Street, which were made into one structure for the club, Mr. Hines compared boys of 1912 with boys of today.

Sales of copper in the export market were made yesterday at 10.58 to 10.67 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports. This compared with 10.20 cents on Wednesday. The recovery was owing to an advance in prices on the London Metal Exchange.

The marriage of Mrs. Alice Fuller Davenport of 410 Park Avenue and Providence, R. I., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fuller, to Henry T. Dumbell of New Canaan, Conn., son of the late Rev. Dr. George William Dumbell, former rector of the Goshen Episcopal

Charles F. Hosford Jr. said after a conference with Secretary James Roosevelt at the White House today that he would withdraw his resignation .and remain indefinitely as chairman of the Federal Bituminous Coal Commission.
Comments and suggestions for improvement of realty and housing conditions have been received from various sources, bearing largely on topics recently discussed in this column.

A verdict of guilty was returned by a jury in Federal Court last night at 10:30 o'clock against Alexander Dumbrowski, sculptor, no address; Steve Jannick and John Muller, both of 228 East Twenty-seventh Street, on trial for possession and

The streets or New York City are the safest thoroughfares in the- entire State, according to a report of motor accidents in the State for the nine-month period from January to September. The report was released by Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles.

Manhattan, in opposing powerful North Carolina State this afternoon at Ebbets Field, will meet its seventh consecutive major opponent of the season. The intersectional contest is expected to attract more than 12,000 spectators, and the kickoff will be at 2 P. M.

The Hudson Motor Company closed its plant today for the second time this week as a result of a dispute between union workers and the management.. More than 10,000 employes stopped work at noon after men employed on the final assembly lines protested against what they said was a violation of seniority rights.

Proposals to dissolve three partnerships have been received by the New York Stock Exchange. The firm of J. W. Bowen Co. would dissolve on Dec. 1, H. T. Carey Co. on Nov. 30 and Joost, Patrick Co. on Nov. 30.

The, first shipment of medical supplies to the Chinese Government by the newly organized American Bureau for Medical Aid for China was announced yesterday. A consignment of 5,000 vials of antitetanus serum was placed on a transcontinental plane to connect with the China Clipper to be used for the treatment of injured civilians.

The principal speakers at the dinner of the Economic Club of New York, which is to be held at the Hotel Astor on Dec. 7, will be Lewis W. Douglas, former Director of the Budget, and Wayne C. Taylor, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, it was announced yesterday by Paul D. Cravath, president of the club. The topic under discussion will be "Balancing the Budget."
Rabbi-Joshua.Chosak of the Voloshiner- Yeshiva of Brooklyn died yesterday in his home at 496 New Jersey Avenue, Brooklyn, after an illness of several weeks. He was 72 years old.

A cablegram received at the Presidio today reported the death of Colonel Laurence Redington, retired army officer, in the military hospital at Manila Wednesday of pneumonia and heart ailment at the age of 56. His widow is visiting Mrs. Philip Carroll in New York.

Moravian College concluded a week of intensive football practice for the City College game tomorrow with a light signal drill today. Realizing that the Beavers will present a fast and deceptive offense, Coach Ed Snavely and his aides perfected the Greyhounds' defense.
On his own application: PATROLMAN-William A. Higgins. 76th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Sept. 1, 1904.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is a distinctly better tone in the wool market this week, owing chiefly to the reversal in form in the top futures market. but more especially to the better political news from Washington.

A plan of reorganization for the Phoenix Silk Manufacturing Company, Inc., under which $200,000 in new working capital is to be raised, was approved yesterday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson. Under the plan, a loan of $150,000 is to be obtained from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation; the remainder is to come from mortgage loans covering physical assets of the corporation.

A little red card from the file of known pyromaniacs maintained by Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy resulted yesterday in-a solution of the mysterious fire Thursday morning in the Cosmopolitan Hotel fat Chambers Street and West Broad way, and the arrest of a 28-year old former employee as the man responsible for the blaze.

Justice C. P. McTague said today he felt that no matter what ruling he might give in the reorganization of the $85,000,000 Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., the court order would be appealed. He urged counsel for opposing sides to "work out a compromise."

In the first round of the Northeast Field Hockey Association sectional tournament on the field of Smith College today Long Island sprang a surprise by defeating the strong Stuyvesant eleven, 3--0, in the first match on the program.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 781,000 bales, against 769,000 a week ago, 771,000 two weeks ago, 773,000 three weeks ago and 801,000 a year ago; of which American 335,000 bales, against 336,000 a week ago, 323,000 two weeks ago, 322,000 three weeks ago and 294,000 a year ago.

Dr. John J. Connellan, a retired biologist formerly connected with the Rockefeller Institute, died on Wednesday in St. Peter's Hospital. His home was at 95 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, and for twenty years he maintained a laboratory at 40 East Forty-first Street, Manhattan.

The "streamlined" division, after rolling more than 500 miles in four days, detrucked and-deployed in darkness early this morning, attacked a simulated Red "enemy" at dawn through a tangled wilderness of mesquit,' cactus and cedar, and won the campaign for the domination of North Texas.

Salary increases for professors, instructors and lecturers in higher institutions of learning were ordered today in a decree issued by the Council of People's Commissars. The decree also effects a considerable change in the system of payment, which heretofore has been on a virtual piecework schedule, instructors lecturing here and there in various institutions at so much hourly.

Mrs. Florence Roberts Benson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Roberts of Minneapolis, became the bride of Samuel Hawley of Bridgeport, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Hawley, at the Southport Congregational Church this afternoon.
New York University's football team will meet a fighting and always dangerous opponent this afternoon when it opposes Georgetown at the Polo Grounds. The game is scheduled to start at 2 P. M.

Many churches will be hosts to Masonic lodges for annual religious services tomorrow afternoon or evening. Other churches will hold a special service for patriotic organizations in further celebration of Armistice and Red Cross Week.

The biggest news in Loyalist Spain today is not military but political. The executive committee of the Spanish Communist party is holding a plenary meeting at Valencia. As frequently stated in these dispatches, the political trend in Spain since the war started has been away from extreme radicalism toward moderate republicanism.
Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland tonight came from behind to beat Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia, 125 to 121, in 49 innings in the world pocket billiard championship.

Mucho Gusto, beaten by a nose in today's Blackiston Handicap, opening-day feature of Bowie's Fall meeting, is one of ten named for the $2,500 Prince George Autumn Handicap, main event on the first Saturday of the meeting which will conclude the Eastern racing season.

A party was given at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday by the Depew Olive and Cherry Fishing Club in honor of King Cheese and his consort as a feature of National Cheese Week, which has been running since Nov. 7 and will end tomorrow.

Miss Catherine Wilds, 22-year-old stepdaughter of Paul Campbell, an attorney in the office of the United States Solicitor General in Washington, was discovered dead of gas poisoning yesterday morning in her room on the third floor of 68 Irving Place. Detectives listed the death

New York City's first City Council will have a minimum of twentyfive members and a maximum of twenty-seven, it was forecast yesterday as the first count of the proportional representation ballots for Councilmen neared completion in each of the five boroughs.

Angered by reports that Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert and two other officers of the Chicken Drivers Union, Local 167, were still on the organization's payroll despite their imprisonment for embezzling union funds, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora announced yesterday

Japanese troops along the PeipingHankow Railway, a few miles north of the Honon-Hopeh border are reported to have routed Chinese who threatened with a severe flank attack from the east. The Chinese were remnants of the Twenty-ninth Army.

A slight rise in world supplies of wool next year was predicted today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, but the supplies will be smaller than average for the last five years. Mill consumption in the

President Charles Seymour of Yale University warned American universities today not to make liberal colleges merely schools of contemporary social science. Speaking on the topic, "The University. Curriculum in Its Relation to Public Service," before the Association of American Universities at Brown

Movements of livestock -in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 12,000, including 2,500 directs. Choice hogs 180 pounds, down about steady with Thursday's average; others mostly 10c lower; spots off more late.

Charles W. Bagby said today that he had resigned as attorney for Basil (Pat) Ryan, copper fortune heir, who married a Miss Martha Barkley of Morganton a week ago last night after a brief acquaintance and a few hours later entered a hospital here.
Billy Rose announced today that he and Mrs. Eleanor Holm Jarrett, swimming champion and film actress, had decided to declare publicly they Would be married as soon as they obtain divorces.

A new type of microscope which makes it possible for the first time to observe directly vital organs in the living body in the act of functioning, showing in detail the different types of cells and tissues and the fluids that circulate through them, "catching life in the act," as it were, was demonstrated before the graduate fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine, which closed its sessions last night.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 10:s today, dated Nov. 10:
John K. Ottley, president of the First National Bank of Atlanta, has been elected a director of the Southern Railway to- succeed Devereux Milburn, resigned.
The football extravaganza of the New York season moves into the Yankee Stadium today before the customary packed house that gathers for the annual meeting of Army and Notre Dame.

Two upsets featured the completion of the third round in the Princeton invitation squash tennis tournament when the remaining five matches in that bracket were run off at the Princeton Club last night.

New non-residential building undertaken by private agencies during October showed a gain of 2 per cent over a year ago, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation, which reports that compared with the preceding month the September-October decline for this class of construction, amounting to 7 per cent, was no greater than the normal seasonal decrease which usually occurs at this time of the year.

Cardinal Hayes will be 10 years old next Saturday. He has refused every request by officials of the archdiocese of New York and his personal friends to permit a public celebration. They have yielded to his wishes, with one exception.

The so-called "Seven TVA" bill which will come before the special session of Congress was sharply assailed yesterday at the twentyeighth annual convention of the New York State Waterways Associtation.

Mr. and Mrs. Ely Culbertson, the bridge experts, and Crockford's, Inc., their club, filed yesterday in Supreme Court a claim for $250,000 damages from Giovannina Farrelly, Walter Malowan and Madge Keep, who are alleged to be the guiding spirits of the Regency Club at 15 East Sixty-seventh Street.
Easy money and the return of capital to France led the Bank of France today to reduce its discount rate from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent.

Officers and members of the Presbyterian Church, Scarborough, N. Y., tomorrow will honor the thirtieth anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Anthony H. Petersen as pastor. For twenty-two years he has also served as Protestant chaplain of Sing Sing prison. Next June Dr. Petersen will complete forty years in the ministry.
John Taylor Arms, president of the Society of American Etchers, announces that the exhibition hours have been extended for the twentysecond annual showing by the society, current through November.

MORNING All Hallows vs. Iona Prep at George Washington High School Stadium, 193d Street and Audubon Avenue, Manhattan, 10:00. Fordham Prep vs. Alumni at Fordham Field, Third Avenue and Fordham Road, Bronx, 10:00.
In the United States Supreme Court John T. Cahill and Thomas O'Rourke Gallagher of New York were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

The closing on Wednesday of the Berlin bureau of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, an American-owned news service, was revealed yesterday in an announcement by the agency, in which it was stated that the German secret police had for mally explained to the United States Consulate General "why it

The appointment of Otto Jabelmann as assistant to the president of the Union Pacific Railroad in charge of research was announced yesterday. When the company's research work was consolidated on July 1, 1936, Mr. Jabelmann was placed in charge of the department with the title of assistant superintendent of motive power and machinery.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Wilder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Enos Wilder of this place, to Gustav A. Rundin of Darien, son of Mrs. Gustav A. Rundin of Los Angeles, took place here this afternoon in the chapel of St. John's Episcopal. Church. The Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham performed the ceremony.

Trading by members for their own account in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange dropped to 18.32 per cent of the total volume in the week ended on Oct. 16, compared with 22.06 per cent in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today. Total volume was 10,817,690

Printing plant employes and firemen yesterday afternoon joined in subduing a blaze in the pressroom of the Neo Gravure Printing Company on the eighth floor of a nineteen-story loft and warehouse building at 601 West Twenty-sixth Street.

The general protective committee for security holders of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation has lent a letter to shareholders stating that it is "unalterably opposed" to the plan of reorganization recently proposed for the utility by the vias Corporation.

Two noted clergymen were operated upon yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. They were Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York area of the Methodist Episcopal Church and the Rev. Dr. John McDowell, associate director of the Department of Social Education and Action of the Board of Christian Education of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

IT may be that one reason why so many authors have turned again to the historical novel is that they have felt the swift and brilliant competition of the foreign correspondents. In any age people like to read about the valors and the villainies of kings.

Miss Loriel Martens Johnson, an daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Halsey Johnson of this place, and 1,148 Fifth Avenue, New York, -was martried here this afternoon at the home of her parents to William Livingston Desloge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Firmin Desloge of St. Louis and Nantucket.

The Princeton and Yale junior varsity elevens battled to a 13-13 tie in their annual game today. Chuck Wooster, the most consistent ground gainer for Yale, scored a touchdown and Bob Hopgood converted in the first period on short running plays.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Rheta Friend, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Friend of 505 West End Avenue, to Edward E. Reichman, son of Mrs. Max Reichman of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Reichman.

The Senate count in the recent election is now complete. The Ministry won only three seats in South Australia. Labor captured all the other seats, defeating Sir George Pearce, Minister of External Affairs, who continuously has represented West wealth Parliament of 1901.

The immediate objectives in the move to stimulate residential building by private enterprise, as a means of halting the current business recession and furnishing needed homes, were explained today by President Roosevelt. At the same time the
A discussion of utility valuation may take place next week when public utility executives confer with President Roosevelt.

German unemployment increased by 33,000 during October, but it is still 575,000 under last year's figures for the same month. It now stands at 502,000.
