The Government Employment Statistics Bureau says that 160,000 of these unemployed are incapable of full-time work on normal jobs and 255,000 are wholly incapable t of working.

Intimations that the Federal Trade Commission has been requested by the Rayon and Synthetic Yarn Producers Committee to investigate the International Silk Guild as a "Japanese propaganda agency" and charges that the Japanese Government has backed the move for fiber identification "which is not a consummer movement at all" were voiced yesterday by Erwin Feldman, counsel for the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers.

A strong wind and white water were not too encouraging for those who had planned to enter the surf fishing contest of the East End Fishing Club yesterday, but 2 P. M. found the wind down considerably, so the entries came along in large numbers. The entries came in-but not the fish.

The establishment of a textile research institute at a small, centrally located university was advocated last night by Dr. Elvin H. Killheffer of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. at the annual meeting of the United States Institute for Textile Research, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

Jeanne Behrehd, Philadelphia pianist, gave her second New York recital in Carnegie Hall last night. Miss Behrend was the first pianist to be graduated from the Curtis Institute and had studied there, with world-renowned masters, composiment.

Up to its old tricks, the theatre, in the person this morning of "Places, Please" is still pointing a haughty finger at Boston. One of these days Boston will be turning around and kicking the theatre right in the slats, which will serve it right and probably make a better play to boot.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that he did not believe the business recession was "as serious as some people seem to think" and added that he was confident there would be an improvement "in the early future; certainly in the Spring."

Harvard's varsity football team hopes to tune its attack for next week's Yale game in tomorrow's intersectional engagement with Davidson College of Davidson, N. C. Coach Dick Harlow is starting a makeshift backfield, the chief surprise being the selection of Bennie
Professors are not likely to write imaginative novels, but shoulV attempt more popular history and biography, in the judgment of Dumas Malone, co-editor of the Dictionary of American Biography.

Despite the fairly good showing on Armistice Day, retail trade figures here this week barely held their own with those for the same period a year ago, store executives said yesterday. The chief improvement noted during the week was the larger trade in men's cold weather apparel, stimulated by the drop in temperature.

Henry Franklin-Bouillon, independent militant Deputy, died today in a Paris clinic after a ten-day illness, at the age of 67. For many -years he was president of the Chamber's Foreign Affairs Commission, which post he relinquished when he left the Radical Socialists to form his own party, "the Republican Front," in 1926.

Oppenheim, Collins Co., Inc., reported yesterday net sales of $2,347,424 for the three months ended on Oct. 31. This was an increase of 5.7 per cent over sales of $2,219,987 for the corresponding period last year.
Angelo Trulio has been placed at the top of the list among four-wall handball players, according to the rankings announced yesterday by the metropolitan handball committee of the

The marriage of Miss Ella Marie Poor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wharton Poor of Flushing, Queens, and Narragansett, R. I., to Richard Henry Eggleston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Eggleston of 1,112 Park Avenue and Alexandria Bay, Thousand Islands, N. Y., took place here yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

The Federal Reserve System has embarked upon a new campaign to keep credit easy in the Autumn by open-market purchases of United States Government securities, it was revealed yesterday with the publication of the system's weekly report showing a rise of $10,400,000 in its holdings of government issues for the period ended on Wednesday.

Atlee Pomerene, former chairman of the -RFC, special prosecutor in the Teapot Dome oil cases, and for twelve years a Democratic Senator from Ohio, died in his home here tonight at the age of 73. He had been ill of broncho-pneumonia for several weeks. His wife was at his bedside.

Frank Figliolia, alias John Russo, wanted by United States authorities for the murder of Dorothy Tauman, who was strangled in New York City on July 11, was arrested today by Montreal detectives in a St. Catherine Street West restaurant, where he had been employed for three months.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, appealed yesterday over station WEAF for greater support for the Red Cross in its membership roll-call. Re described how the New York chapter raised $2,112,000 for flood relief without alighting any of its regular local relief and instructional work.

Holding it would be better to await the report of a government committee investigating the problem of granting holidays with pay in all industries, the House of Commons today by a single vote defeated the Laborite bill making

For the second consecutive week new bond financing this week was limited to tax-exempt issues and offerings of those were restricted to two loans aggregating only $1,250,000. This is the smallest weekly
The Brooklyn Friends School football team brought its season to a close yesterday with a 19-to-13 victory over Fieldston at Friends Field in Brooklyn. It was a Metropolitan A. A. P. S. contest.

Princeton defeated Yale at soccer by 4-1 today. Dick Sylvester tallied three times, Richardson accounting for the victors' other goal. Wilson recorded the Eli point on a penalty kick early in the first period.
A new type of annual convention is being planned by the National Retail Dry Goods Association for the event to be held from Jan. 31 to Feb. 4, it was announced yesterday by the organization.

Dr. Miguel Paz Batona, former President of the Republic of Honduras, died last night at his home in San Pedro Saula. Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES. WASHINGTON, Nov. 12.-Dr. Miguel Paz Barona was his country's Minister to the United States from 1933 to 1935, according to the Honduran Legation.

Le Bourget Airport, which was only a collection of wooden hangars with a few concrete buildings when Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's arrival there made it world famous, has been entirely rebuilt and today Air Minister Pierre Cot, at the official inauguration of the field by President Albert Lebrun, claimed that it was the largest international air station in Europe.

Homer Martin, international president of the United Automobile Workers of America, called upon the U. A. W. A. locals throughout the country tonight to take "direct action" to lower the cost of living, "principally" that of meat.

Commenting on the possibility of Dartmouth's football team accepting a bid for the Rose Bowl game. William H. McCarter, director of athletics, said today it was a traditional policy at Dartmouth not to play post-season contests.

With general farm legislation holding the key to progress by the special session of Congress which convenes Monday, a wide-open split developed today between the House Agriculture Committee and farm administration officials over the question of compulsory control of major crops and methods of financing whatever program Congress may adopt.

With "Stella Dallas" one of the more successful financial ventures of the season, RKO today determined to team the two stars of that epic, Barbara Stanwyck and Anne Shirley, in a similar heavy dramatic offering. "Condemned Women" by

Whatever, as Aunt Tillie used to say with her fine disregard of prepositional niceties, is the world coming to? Hollywood used not to take marriage seriously; now the wicked place is refusing to take even divorce seriously.

Construction of 100,000 miles of "accident proof" highways is America's fundamental need in the achievement of traffic safety, Paul Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation and the Automotive Safety Foundation, declared yesterday at the closing session of the five-day safety seminar conducted by the Commercial Investment Trust Safety Foundation in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A total of $833,033.07 has been raised to date in the $3,171,134 United Hospital Campaign, representing an increase of $355,781 over last week's total, John W. Davis, general chairman of the drive, announced yesterday at the commerce and industry report luncheon at Hotel Biltmore.

Curse the tongue in my head, That a guest has gone away And I have left unsaid Much that heart meant to say: God bless your evening road And bless tomorrow then; Lighten whatever load And bring you here again.

Taking advantage of the so-called "daylight margin" rules, the Securities and Exchange Commission has demanded of the members of the New York Stock Exchange data which will give it a complete crosssection of member trading in two recent periods of market activity.

J. G. L. Molloy announced his resignation as Assistant Corporation Counsel yesterday and said he would return to private law practice in the firm of Felix H. Levy at 11 Broadway. Mr. Molloy was law secretary to Mayor La Guardia before he resigned to run for the City Council in Manhattan.

Lieut. Col. George Alexander MacLean Buckley,, New Zealand soldier and- expIrer, died here today at the age of 71. His life was crowded with adventure from the days he served in the army in India. He also was noted as a swimmer, horseman and yachtsman.

The government rested today its gasoline price-fixing conspiracy case against nineteen oil companies and forty-five individuals after six weeks of testimony. Charges against seven corporations and one Individual were dismissed.

King George and Queen Elizabeth decided today to revisit the scene of their courtship. Breaking a routine of week-ends at Windsor Castle, they motored from Buckingham Palace to the Hertfordshire countryside at St. Paul's, Waldenbury, where Elizabeth spent much of her girlhood and George wooed her.
The Continental Can Company, Inc., has declared the initial quarterly dividend of $1.12 1/2 a share on the $4.50 cumulative preferred stock.
Estate, more than $10,000. To William L. Taylor, uncle, and Clara Taylor, aunt, executrix, both of 230 Central Park West, equally.

A "medical survey" is being made of men in the Police Department who have reached the age of 60, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday. While the Commissioner would not say that this was being done with the intention of retiring those found physically unfit for duty, this was believed to be the purpose of the survey.

The second first-degree murder conviction against Felix John Cummings, 29 years old, of 390 Willoughby Avenue, and George Lewis, 24, of 110 Nostrand Avenue, both Brooklyn, for the hold-up killing of Ralph Nischo, a waiter, was returned last night by a blue ribbon jury before Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato.

Extremely quiet conditions prevailed in the stock markets here today, the last day of the account, and prices in most sections weakened. Gilt-edge issues were firm, but foreign loans were unsteady. Dealings in Brazilian bonds again were postponed owing to the political situation. International shares were dull; United States Steel and International Nickel were marked down.

Miss Margaret Elson Burroughs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Burroughs -f this city, was married to Ward S. Sands, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Sands, also of East Orange, today in the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew, South Orange. The rector, the Rev. F. Randall Williams, performed the ceremony.

Trading was mostly slow. Lamb sold about 50 cents below Thursday's quotations. Other classes showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be steady to higher; other classes mostly unchanged as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 12, unless specified:
Some of the Japanese "good-will mission," which is on a world tour to explain to various countries Japanese viewpoint in the SinoJapanese hostilities, have remained in New York.

The Anaconda Copper Mining Company and subsidiaries issued yesterday a preliminary report of its consolidated net income for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, placing the income at $26,965,164, or $3.11 each on 8,674,338 shares of capital stock outstanding.

Senator Lester H. Clee, defeated Republican candidate for Governor, will apply tomorrow morning for-a recount of the ballots in Hudson County as the first step in what is expected to be a State-wide contest of the recent Gubernatorial election in which United States Senator A. Harry Moore, the Democratic candidate, won by a plurality of 44,000 votes.

Favored teams throughout the country will be shining targets of an assemblage of underdogs this afternoon as games adorned with tradition hold the center of the football stage, with Dame Upset in the wings waiting for an entrance cue. The nation's features will present an all-star gathering of favorites.

The United Automobile Workers of America announced tonight that it and General Motors Corporation had reached "a tentative agreement" on amendments to their contract, signed after last Winter's prolonged strike.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Without important exception, companies with securities listed on the New York Stock Exchange added to their holdings of reacquired shares in the month which ended Yesterday.

Columbia's football team, making its first home appearance in three weeks, will attempt to regain its winning form when it meets Syracuse today at Baker Field. The game, which is the seventeenth of a series begun in 1901, will start at 2 P. M.

A tract of 126 acres near Rahway, N. J., has been sold by the Fagan estate to Inman Estates, Inc., headed by Leon Kaiser and Irving J. Kadish, for cutting up into small farms. It took almost a year to get the signatures of the thirty heirs of the late John Fagan in order to complete the deal. One of the heirs, the late James Fagan,

The volume of bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding increased $1,827,544 in October to $346,246,657, according to the monthly survey made in the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday. This increase was much

The sudden and virtually complete change of management of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., the largest art auction house in this country, was disclosed here yesterday, at the same time that announcement was made of the organization of a rival auction house, to be operated by former executives of the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc.

The election of ten new members to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, the largest group to enter since 1908, when the membership was increased from thirty to fifty, was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the academy, 633 West 155th Street.

Frank J. Prial, former deputy controller, is one of the possible choices as City Treasurer whose qualifications will be studied by Mayor La Guardia before the appointment is made, it was reported yesterday at City Hall.

The modern worker in public welfare must be not only well trained technically, but able and willing as well to meet the practical democratic test of public opinion, Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, said here today in dedicating the new $281,000 building constructed by the WPA to house Ohio State University's School of Social Science.

Major Dermot McCalmont's King's Gap, a 4-year-old gelding by Buen Ojo-Queen Of The Nore, today won the Liverpool Autumn Cup, defeating Sir Alfred Butt's Noble King by a short head. In third place in the field of twenty-five was W. H. Thorpe's Inchkeith.

The prosecution in the Rand-Bergoff trial in the Federal District Court here for alleged violation of the Byrnes Act, forbidding the transportation of strike-breakers across State lines for the purpose of interfering with peaceful picketing, rested its case today with the presentation of the testimony of the last of twenty-eight witnesses.

Miss Alice McComb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wadsworth McComb of this city, was married tonight to Stanley Anderson Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Curry Harris of New York. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Edward A. Mohns, pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church here.

Mrs. Margaret Moffett Carlisle, daughter of James A. Moffett, president of the Standard Oil Company of California, obtained a divorce on charges of cruelty here today from Jay Freeborn Carlisle Jr. An agreement was filed covering custody of their one child, Jay F. Carlisle 3d.

Let this morning's report note that "Siege" is now, and officially, in rehearsal, having reached there yesterday under the baton of Chester Erskin. There is a cast of twenty-two, Barbara O'Neil and Zamah Cunningham being the two and only women involved: some of the

The Franklin D. Roosevelt Stadium, financed by the city and the WPA, was dedicated this afternoon at ceremonies attended by more than 10,000 persons, including 4,000 school children. The sports plant, extending from Twenty-fourth to Twenty-sixth Street on Hudson Boulevard, has a seating capacity of 20.000.

Dartmouth's annual Autumn house parties opened today with 708 feminine guests listed from a score of women's colleges, the largest number to be entertained at this event since pre-depression days. Many social attractions are planned for today and tomorrow, with the annual Cornell-Dartmouth football game furnishing the athletic highlight of the week-end.

Two democratic party leadersHungary's former League representative, Tibor von Eckhardt, who heads the small Farmers' party, and former Secretary of State Karl Rassay, chief of the Liberals-today gave their views on the Nazi movement in Hungary and the reasons they regarded it as a growing menace to the Constitution.

High-grade gasoline--more than 9,000,000,000 gallons of it a year-can be produced by a comparatively new process from the waste gases that now hover over refinery centers, the 2,381 delegates to the American Petroleum Institute heard today.

Today's major events: Sidney Sukoenig, pianist, at Carnegie Hall in the afternoon and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the same auditorium in the evening; Stanley Hummel, pianist, at the Town Hall in the afternoon and Orrea Pernel, violinist, in the evening; "Cosi fan tutte" as a matinee and "Coronation of Poppea" in the evening at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

During the week ended Nov. 10 member bank reserve balances decreased $10,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from an increase of $28,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, offset in part by increases of $17.-

Increases ranging from about 900,000 to more than 8,000,000 cases were shown in canners' stocks of peas, corn and green and wax beans on Oct. 1 compared with the stocks of a year ago, in a report issued by the foodstuffs division of the Deapartment of Commerce today.

Governor Barrows of Maine and Governor Clark of Idaho today agreed to compete against each other- in a'potato-picking battle next Fall. They deferred agreement as to the scene of the proposed contest--whether Maine or Idaho.

Bakers have not yet fully met changed conditions resulting from WA the "revolution" that took place in the banking business between 1921 and 1931, Frank P. Bennett Jr. of Boston, editor of The United States Investor, said here today in an address to the 400 delegates attending the annual mid-year conference of the New Jersey Bankers Association.

Yale men's leading Autumn weekend started this evening with a series of dances. The combined concert of the Yale and Princeton Glee Clubs was held tonight and teas and dances and the Dramatic Association's performance of "The Front Page" will follow the Yale-Princeton football game tomorrow.

BOSTON COLLEGE VS. KENTUCKY--One trouble with football is that the bystanders become more excited than the players. It's all in fun. Take it easy. Be composed. For that purpose, it might be a good idea to study the great composers. Johann Sebastian Bach, for instance. On a Bach-field shift,' one quiet vote for Boston College.

The fear that clutches at the hearts of nearly 3,000,000 Chinese remaining in Shanghai has also in a lesser degree gripped British and American officials who are responsible for the administration of the International Settlement.

European arms and armor from the collection of the late Theodore Offer??an of this city brought $30,842 yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., making a total of $40,322.50 for the two sessions to date.

Floyd W. Larson, executive secretary of the Minneapolis chapter of the American Institute of Banking, has been appointed assistant secretary of the institute and Professor William A. Irwin, head of the economics department of Washburn College at Topeka, Kan., has

Mrs. E. Palmer Gavit, one of Montecito's wealthiest and most philanthropic women, died in her sleep early. this morning in "Cueta Linda," her -country home. Mrs.- Gavit owned one of the few private railway cars in the United States. She was born in Washington, D. C.; the daughter of Major and Mrs. Emory Stratton Turner.

Asserting that the administration has lost strength because of its policies and the fear of increased taxation, Senator McNary, minority leader, said upon his return to the capital today that Republicans in Congress should now present a "progressive front" and take advantage of administration failures.

Irving Richard Lewis, treasurer and director of Walter Kidde Co., Inc., and of Walter Kidde Constructors, Inc., died last night of a heart attack in his home at 98 Liberty Street, here. He was 54 years old. Since 1906 he had been with the Kidde concerns, first as purchasing agent and later as treasurer and director.

Jesse Stuart writes to his publishers, E. P. Dutton Co., from Denmark, where, he says, he is taking a brief vacation from Scotland. Mr. Stuart has finished his revision of the story of his Kentucky boyhood and background, "Beyond Dark Hills," and the rewritten manuscript is now in the hands of his publishers.
The Republic Steel Corporation announced tonight that several subsidiaries are being taken into the parent company in order to simplify its capital structure.

Manhattan Alterations Henry St, 90; to 6-story tenement and stores; Leopold Saberski, 69 Orchard St, Tarrytown, N. Y., owner; Frank Strauh, architect; cost. $12,000. Broome St, 206; to 5-story tenement and stores; same owner; same architect; cost, $12,000. Norfolk St. 175; to 5-story tenement and stores; same owner; same architect; cost, $20,000.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $11,278,205, to be represented by one State and fifty-six municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $6,073,865, for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,649,539.
It's the "little man," says William A. Kelley, who knows the needs of the people, not the bank president and big business executives.

The Bank of Canada reported today a decline of more than $2,000,000 in deposits of chartered banks in the week ended on Wednesday, a drop of more than $1,000,000 in its holdings of sterling and United States dollars and a gain of almost the same amount in Dominion and Provincial short-term securities.

Deadlocked at 6-all at the conclusion of the first half, the Staten Island Academy football team speeded its attack and vanquished Woodmere Academy, 19 to 6, at Todt Hill Field, Staten Island, yesterday. Ed Thompson scored three touchdowns.

A funeral service was held 'yesterday in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventythird Street, for Mrs. Mary Ellen Clarke Keys,-who died on Tuesday at her home, 47 East Eighty-eighth Street. The Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, pastor of the church, officiated. Burial was in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.
A new shakeup in the administration of White Russia was reported today with the removal of the republic's second President in five months.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals has handed down a per curiam decision dismissing the appeal of a group of preferred stockholders who objected to Federal Judge Oliver B. Dickinson's final order of confirmation of the reorganization plan of the Baldwin Locomotive Works. The Circuit Court affirmed Judge Dickinson's order, which was entered on Sept. 1.

The five-story walk-up apartment house at 2,028 Grand Concourse, on the northeast corner of Bush Street, the Bronx, has been sold by the 2,028 Grand Concourse Corporation to Shafecraus Realty Corporation through Armstrong, Roeser-Feltner, Inc., brokers. The building is on a plot which fronts 102 feet on the Grand Concourse and 100 feet on Bush Street.

Miami Hurricanes swept to a quick touchdown in the second period and scored twice more on lightning thrusts in the final quarter to defeat Catholic University of Washington, 21 to 0, before 10,000 tonight.

Mrs. Janea Bunting Peterson, daughter of Mrs. Chardes Jackson McIlvain Jr. of Haverford, was married this afternoon to Benjamin Shibe MacFarland, son of Mrs. Franklin Hutchinson MacFarland of Alden Park Manor, Germantown, and of the late Dr. MacFarland.

A survey of the mother country of fascism at the moment when its lengthening shadow falls not only on Asia but on the American continent brings to light one element in the Italian situation that is interesting in the present as it may be important to the future.

Henry J. Thompson, trainer of Colonel E. R. Bradley's Idle Hour Kentucky stables and one of the most widely known of American race-horse trainers, died here today of a heart attack at his apartment in the Hotel Stafford. His age was 62. His home was in Louisville, Ky.

Miss Louise Edwards, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Hughes Edwards of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Dr. Edwards, was married yesterday afternoon in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral to John Hanna Morris, Sixth Deputy Police Commissioner of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Morris of Boston.

A total of 86,772 Americans sought the aid of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, 425 Lafayette Street, in the emigration of their relatives from many parts of the world, as well as in naturalization and citizenship problems, from Jan. 1 to Sept. 30, according to a report by Isaac L. Asofsky, general manager.

Acting upon its own motion, the Federal Power Commission has ordered an immediate investigation of the rates charged by the Safe Harbor Water Power Corporation to its two controlling companies, the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company. All three companies have their main offices in Baltimore.

" Laurel Hill," the ten-room residence near here of Major Edward Bowes, theatre and radio impresario, burned to the ground this afternoon and all of the furniture and art objects went with it. Firemen of the Millwood department succeeded in saving a guest cottage in the rear of the residence by pumping water from a lake on an adjoining estate. The estate is on Alapartus Road, three miles north-west of here.

Cheshire Academy defeated the hitherto unbeaten Springfield freshmen today, 13 to 0. In the second period, after a pass to Littlefield by Davis, Holden plunged for a touchdown. Late in the third quarter Davis went through the line from the 15-yard mark and converted. The line-up:

The trustees of the Massachusetts Investors Trust announced yesterday that the filing of a registration statement for 2,000,000 shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission did not represent any change of policy as to limitation of the size of the trust, and that the number of shares authorized to be outstanding at any one time had been fixed at 6,000,000 shares.
The findings by the commission which inquired into the sinking of fishing boats by a Japanese submarine will not be disclosed here. The documents are being sent to London by air mail.

Authors who draw and write about animals for children will talk in the Fair auditorium this morning at 10:30. In the afternoon at 2:30 and in the evening at 8 o'clock travelers, raconteurs, journalists and novelists will talk about what they write for adults.

Mr. and Mrs. Giraud Van Nest Foster left the Pierre yesterday for Swingalong, their plantation at Wilson, La., where they will pass the Winter. Mrs. Horace Bullock has come from Ardmore, Pa., to the Madison. Mrs. William A. Prime will be at the Plaza for the Winter.

The chief reason for the existence of the American Red Cross is that there should be in every locality an organization ready to make immediate and prompt response to any community need that cannot be prevented or anticipated. It is one of the true romances-of a democracy that a whole people can unite in such a common expression of human brotherhood.
Morristown School, leading conender for the New Jersey Group 3 prep school championship,

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 6 amounted to 732,145 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 39,510 cars, or 5.1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week and 27,470 cars, or 3.6 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, but 77,198 cars, or 11.8 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

After being held scoreless during the first half, the Horace Mann School football team rallied and conquered the Irving School eleven of Tarrytown, N. Y., 20 to 7, on the Horace Mann gridiron yesterday. A touchdown in the third quarter gave the home team the lead. two more being added in the final session.

The Netherlands legation here now has adopted the position that W. H. Cammans, 43-year-old Netherlander sentenced to death on a charge of treason, has double citizenship. The Netherlands representative explained that Dutch law permits such double citizenship.

A proposal that Congress stimulate business by granting tax relief immediately, instead of waiting until the regular session in January, came today from Chairman O'Connor of the House Rules Committee.

Mark Twain once remarked that his idea of a good library was one which did not include any of the works of Jane Austen. Consequently, the "model home library," brought up to date this year by the American Booksellers Association, wouldn't wholly please our beloved humorist.

Jones Whitlock, Inc., said to be one of the oldest insurance agencies in the United States, having been continuously in business for ninetyseven years, have leased a large unit of space on the ground floor and space on the fifth floor of 111 William Street, on the northwest corner of John Street. through Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc. The main floor unit will have a private entrance on William Street.
Two undefeated football teams will be fighting for Rose Bowl recognition tomorrow when Nebraska meets Pitt before 72,000 fans in Pitt Stadium.

Substitution of gay, cheerful colors in the classroom in place of the customary dull, drab yellowand-white combination was recommended in a report on lighting made public yesterday by the Board of Education.

John Montague and George Herman (Babe) Ruth, baseball's former home-run king, took part in a nine-hole practice match at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing yesterday in preparation for tomorrow's big charity match.

The Emigrant Bank sold ?? folk St Corp, I. Teitelbaum, president, the two six-story tenements at 149-151 Norfolk St, and took back two demand mortgages: one for $50,554. purchase money, the other for $38,500, or so much thereof as may be advanced under a building loan agreement.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., Owen D. Young and the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin appealed to the unemployed and the partly employed throughout the nation last night to register in the forthcoming voluntary census of the unemployed.

For the first time this season, Captain Bob McNamara of Brooklyn, veteran right guard, will call the signals when Pennsylvania meets Michigan in the sixteenth game of the series on Franklin Field tomorrow.

Upon resumption of play tonight in the sixteenth game of the match for the chess championship of the world, which was adjourned last night in an even position, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, the title-holder,

Recessions in industrial activity were smaller last week and this, together with favorable weather and special Armistice Day promotion prices, lifted the volume of retail sales over the previous week, so that the gain over a year ago, estimated at 5 to 18 per cent, was larger than the gain over 1936, which was registered in the previous week, according to the weekly trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Bonnells Island, formerly known as Whortlebury Island and Farwells Island, located offshore to the south of Byram Park, Greenwich, has been sold by Thomas H. Raynor, as broker, for the Greenwich Trust Company to William S. Meany Jr. It was held at $50,000.
Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd called on the people of this country last night to support Secretary of State Hull and his department in the effort for international peace and cooperation.

The Appellate Division was asked yesterday to reverse a ruling made by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman that former Mayor James J. Walker's first appointment as special assistant counsel tothe Transit Commission at $12,000 a year was illegal.

The fighting front west of Shanghai has become so wide since the disorganized Chinese Army's retreat that the Japanese Army is using six highly mobile columns, striking quickly at half a dozen points.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that he "could find no reason for disciplinary action" against Detective John Broderick in the case of Louis Bickhofer, 38 years old, who was released from Sing Sing prison last month by Su-, preme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme in Westchester County.

The marriage of Mrs. Solveig Thompson Shevelson' of this city, daughter of Mrs. Sievert Thompson of Chicago and the late Mr. Thompson, and widow of Samuel Harris Shevelson of Oak Park, Ill., to Garrett Newkirk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Newkirk of Kingston, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev.

The value of public utility properties for rate-making purposes, the President has declared, should be determined by the "prudent investment" actually made in them, and not by the calculated cost of reproducing those properties. The Federal Power Commission is now arguing for the President's position before the Supreme Court.

A public hearing will be held in Chicago on Dec. 1 by order of the Secretary of Agriculture to consider the establishment of limits on the speculative transactions in grain futures of any individual, as provided in the Commodity Exchange Act.

Dr. Jacob Simonson, one of the oldest dental surgeons in the State, died at his home here last night at the age of 93. Dr. Simonson, who retired ten years ago, had practiced sixty years in Newark. He was born on Staten Island and educated at Temple University, where he first studied medicine and then dentistry.
Plans of the that Duke and Duchess of Windsor to stroy buy a home in France were disclosed today. Friends said that this indicated there was little prospect of an early journey to the United States.

A siren screamed menacingly over the roar of traffic at the New York end of the Holland Tunnel exactly at 3 P. M. yesterday. With a squad of patrolmen behind him Lieutenant William O'Neil of the Port of New York Authority Police sprang into action as if closing in on Public Enemy No. 1.

Eight editorial employes of The Bayonne Times, this city's only daily newspaper, went on strike this morning and soon afterward two out of some sixty pickets, who had assembled in front of the plant, were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct.

Bones a farmer uncovered while digging a ditch near here were described by a University of Utah geologist today as those of "an extinct form of elephant covered with hair about fifteen inches long, with an under coat of wool."
The thirtieth annual edition of "Credit Manual of Commercial Laws" has just been issued by the National Association of Credit Men. 1 Park Avenue.

The city is entitled to a larger share of State aid than it is getting for use in providing hospital facilities, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in a statement made public at City Hall. This is particularly true, the Mayor said, in connection with the care of tuberculosis cases.

New York City's traffic signal system and traffic signs were condemned yesterday by Magistrate Frank Oliver, sitting in Bronx Traffic Court. 'In a formal statement, Magistrate Oliver declared that "we have reached the peak of safety that can be accomplished by the punishment of the motorist."
The pace established yesterday by the wheat market appeared today to have been too rapid and prices reacted, not having the urgent demand from shorts to help.

Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Finney of this city have sent out invitations to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Rosemary Finney, to William Edgar Edmonston 2d, son of Mrs. E. D. Edmonston of Baltimore and the late Mr. Edmonston.

West Virginia's Mountaineers, showing a return of their scoring power, hammered a 34-to-0 victory today over the Toledo University team coached by West Virginia's old mentor, Clarence W. (Tubby) Spears.

THE instrument panel of the Percival "Gull" low-wing monoplane in which Miss Jean Batten, 27-year-old New Zealander, made her recent recordbreaking flight of 9,900 miles from Australia to England in 5 days 18 hours 15 minutes shows she avoided an extravagance of equipment which might have made that perilous job safer and easier.

THREE years ago Evangeline Booth Commander of the Salvation Army in the United States, was elected General of that world-wide organization. There were those who wondered whether she would be able to stand the strain of continuous campaigning and arduous administration to which she was to be subjected.

Frank F. Fenwick, president of the Fenick-Reddaway Manufacturing Company of Newark, makers of textile belting, died yesterday at his home here after a six weeks' illness. His age was 60. Mr. Fenwick became president of the concern ten years ago upon the death of his father, Arnold G. Fenwick, who founded the business.

IN keeping with the policy of increasing the efficiency of the police department of the nation's capital, Major Ernest W. Brown, Superintendent of Police of the District of Columbia, has announced that the entire fleet of fifty motorcycles of the metropolitan police force will be equipped

Harvard students, through their social service center, Phillips Brooks House, have begun a new educational service in Cambridge and Boston, by which needy high school graduates, unable to afford college education, can become acquainted with the college courses that interest them most.

Members of the International Institute of the Young Women's Christian Association will hold their annual bazaar next Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the headquarters of the organization 341 East Seventeenth Street.

With the addition of three more serums to fight pneumonia, there is now available to physicians in the State the means to battle with five of the thirty types of the disease, Dr. Augustus B. Wadsworth, director of the division of laboratories of the State Department of Health, announced today.

A ceremonial tribute to the memory of the late Miss Lila Agnew Stewart, for many years a leading organizer and director of charity balls and pageants, will be the feature of a dinner dance now being arranged by her friends and associates for the night of Dec. 17 in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.
An alert Muhlenberg football team, ball hawks in snatching fumbles and intercepting passes, turned in an 18to-7 victory over Lehigh before a crowd of 9,000 in Taylor Stadium today.

(The following is an imaginary highly improbable conversation with Harold Young, the director of "52d Street," now playing at the Rivoli Theatre. It is printed merely fo" the record.) Question--Mr. Young, you are a motion-picture director who deplores the use of camera cliches, are you not?

Michigan State took to the air to down a fighting Carnegie Tech eleven, 13 to 6, today before a homecoming crowd of 20,000. All of the touchdowns were scored in the first nine minutes of the second period.

The United Mine Workers of America have filed a petition with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking the right to intervene in support of operating companies which are seeking a reduction in anthracite freight rates to tidewater.

When he isn't practicing opthalmology, Dr. Carleton Simon of New York is devising new ways of tracking criminals by the clues that they leave behind them. Most of these clues are such tangibles as fingerprints, blood stains, bits of cloth, hairs, handwriting, paper. To examine them microscopically is not difficult.

DANZIG, "in its physiognomy, its architecture, its culture and its speech," is "essentially as German as Nuremberg," Albert Foerster, Nazi leader for Danzig, said at Duesseldorf last week during a speaking campaign in Western Germany.

Mrs. Betty Hamilton Keusch of! New York and Mrs. Nina Melville Minor of Princeton head the cast for the Princeton Theatre Intime's second production of the current season, Ben Jonson's "Volpone," which will open in Murray Theatre on the university campus Monday evening for a week's run.

The marriage of Miss Marion Adele Snyder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Lloyd Snyder of this place, to Dr. Lewis Canfield Fritts, also of Somerville, son of James C. Fritts and the late Mrs. Fritts of Scranton, Pa., will take place Thursday in Trinity Chapel, Princeton.

Holy Cross remained among the nation's undefeated football teams by downing Brown, 7--0, today in a driving rainstorm. The wet field forced both teams to resort to straight football, and Holy Cross, which had the wind in its favor, received the first break.

Anticipating the early need for low-priced homes, the Colonial Colonies Corporation, developers of the Cotswold community at Tenafly, N. J., announces that it is about to start construction of a group of Cape Cod-type bungalows at Dumont, in Bergen County.

The United Hospital campaign to obtain $3,171,134 to meet the needs of the ninety-two institutions participating in the Unite'd Hospital Fund will intensify its drive this week with report luncheons, radio appeals, and radio dramatizations.
The annual Autumn luncheon and bridge party under the auspices of the Companions of the Jewish Braille Review will be held on Wednesday at the Franklin Towers, 333 West Eighty-sixth Street.

In its program to stimulate additional activity during the coming year in home construction for families of modest and low incomes the National Association of Real Estate Boards takes the stand that public enterprise in housing projects for families of small incomes should be limited to such developments for the housing of families whose nominal incomes

Chicago authorities may seek exhumation here of the body of Mrs. Nellis Cook Pearl, circus performer of the Nineties, to determine the cause of her death. Jack Rubens, investigator of the Public Administrator's Office in Chicago, said there had been persistent rumors that Mrs. Pearl, who died Sept. 30 at the age of 71, was poisoned.
Proving their scoreless tie against the California Bears last week was no fluke, the Washington Huskies routed the University of California of Los Angeles by 26 to 0 today.
Four persons, one a 2-year-old girl, received second-degree burns on hands and face about 3:30 P. M. yesterday in a fire in a tenement house at 403 East Forty-eight
The Union Society of Upper Darby, originally organized as The Horse Company for Protection Against Horse Thieves, celebrated its 114th anniversary tonight at its annual meeting and dinner.

TWO events of particular interest divide today's recital schedule between them. One of them is the first appearance here of the Creative Dance Group of Hampton Institute, Hampton, Va., one of the most solidly founded of the contemporary Negro dance organizations, at the Y. M. H. A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, this afternoon.
The Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association has announced through its president, Mrs. Alfred W. Paine, a strenuous campaign for the 1937-38 season.

Fordham College, Manhattan division, and the Fordham School of Business Administration, both in the Woolworth Building, held student elections last week and elected twenty class presidents and the president of the student council.

John L. Letzing of Roxbury, who is said to have been the first American soldier to capture a German prisoner and also the first to be decorated by the United States and the French Governments in recognition of his valor, died today at the hospital connected with the Soldiers Home in Chelsea, where he had been a patient since Oct. 7.
C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, and Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, made appeals over the radio tonight for nation-wide cooperation in the census of the unemployed.

Professor C. P. Yaglou of Harvard's School of Public Health rose in Washington last week before the local members of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers to utter a word of sympathy for the unfortunates who are comfortable only in hermetically sealed rooms and railway cars and who shout "where's that draft coming from?" when a door is opened by so much as a crack.

Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German (Nazi) party, according to the figures of the last elections in May, 1935, controls a round 1,210,000 votes. The total electoral vote of Czechoslovakia is about 8,230,000.

Thomas Jefferson, one of the most versatile persons produced by eighteenth-century America, was not only a statesman, philosopher, and bibliophile, but he was also a ranking architect, experimental botanist and gardener. His estate, Monticello, near Charlottesville, Va., is a worthy monument to Jefferson the landscape architect.

TIMID travelers who shrink at the thought of trying to land in an open skiff when the waves are lifting high no longer need to omit Capri from their, itineraries. Capri's new pier and breakwater, which extends out into the sea in a long L-shaped bend, make it possible for steamers from the mainland to effect an easy landing in all sorts of weather.

The markets had to contend yesterday with a moderate amount of profit-taking after several days of advancing prices. In the stock market this realizing was absorbed without difficulty and prices held within a narrow trading range throughout the half-day session.

Bruce Barton took up his official residence here today as New York City's most recently elected member of Congress. He declined to state what he intended to advocate. "What I am down here for has nothing to do with making speeches or getting my name in the papers," he said.

Working throughout a high wind and a pelting rain that made hunting conditions miserable, Pheasant Run Jil, 2-year-old springer spaniel owned by Robert McLean of Philadelphia, captured the open allage stage today in the thirteenth annual field trials of the American Spaniel Club, held at Camp Upton, L. I.

Terms for a new agreement between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America, rejecting practically every major demand of the union, were laid today before a special meeting of delegates from all General Motors locals.
ONE of the interesting figures among the Parisian bookbinders was Pierre Vente, 1722 ?-1793, who was a protge of both Voltaire and the Duc de Richelieu.
Franklin Hardinge Jr. of Chicago, secretary of the Society of Residential Appraisers, will speak at a dinner meeting of the New York Chapter of the organization on Tuesday in the Hotel Lexington.
The Music Library Association, a national organization formed to consider the problems of the music librarian, will meet at Smith College next Friday and Saturday.

Stanley Hummel, young American pianist, gave his fourth recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program began with the Mendelssohn Prelude and Fugue in E minor, after which came the Mozart sonata in D major (Koechel 576) and about half of the variations that make up the two books of the Paganini-Brahms set.
Emperor Haile Selassie of 'Ethiopia told reporters at Bath tonight that he had "absolutely no income" and was trying to sell his last car and house.

Legislation to be considered in the special session of Congress and plans for the biennial convention in St. Louis, April 25 to 29, 1938, will be discussed by the fifteen-member board of the National League of Women Voters, assembling here for a week's sessions.
Longer terms of office for town superintendents of highways were urged today at closing sessions of their State convention.

On motion of George S. Kaufman, co-author of "You Can't Take It With You," Federal Judge John C. Knox dismissed yesterday a suit by Virginia Gordon that charged that the 1937 Pulitzer Prize play was an infringement of "Rash Moments," an unproduced play of which she was co-author.

Viscount Halifax's "political exploration" of Germany, which arose out of an invitation to a hunting exhibition in Berlin that is due to start in a few days, is the first British diplomatic undertaking of recent times to arouse a uniformly favorable reaction in all political parties here.

Miss Eleanor Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Moore Smith of this city, will be married on Thanksgiving Day to John Canfield Howe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Canfield Howe of Passaic. The ceremony will be performed in Central Brick Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Harold E. Nicely, the pastor.
Mrs. Leroy Frantz of Davenport Neck, this city, will open her home on Tuesday for a tea for members of the Westchester committee of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Mrs. Herbert Witherspoon will speak.

When, a fresh batch of city employes is dismissed or "laid off" every day or two, Mayor S. Davis Wilson is faced with the problem of convincing skeptics that "economy," not "politics," is the guiding factor.

BESIDES having become in less than two decades the most important shipping center on the Baltic, this swiftly growing town is the gateway to a compact area where the tourist can in a few days observe sharply contrasing phases of life in North Central Europe.
Mr. and Mrs. Albert T. Conord of Bloomfield have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Yvonne Aimee Conord, to Richard S. Merrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Merrick of Kennett Square, Pa.

Recent deals of fairly large proportions in various parts of Long Island by building developers, combined with reports of negotiations pending for other sales of acreage properties, indicate that 1938 home construction activity in the three Long Island counties will probably show a marked increase over the large volume of building during the present year.

" The New York Stock Exchange: Is It an Economic Necessity?" will be the topic at the opening session tomorrow evening of the fifth season of forum discussions under the auspices of the Beekman Hill Neighbors at the Beekman Tower Hotel, 3 Mitchell Place.

In addition to inspecting the outstanding current books of 110 publishers at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center yesterday, visitors heard three programs of talks by wellkngwn authors in the morning, afternoon and evening.
The six-story loft building at the northeast corner of Broadway and Seventeenth Street will be sold at auction on Tuesday in the Vesey Street rooms by Joseph P. Day.

Drexel, leader of the Eastern Conference, defeated Delaware today on a rain-soaked field. The score was 8 to 6. Walt Ehmling scored a touchdown for Drexel in the first period when a sustained drive put the ball on the 2-yard line.

Alfred Kaskel, builder, has announced plans for the third unit of the Berkeley Gardens Apartments in Jackson Heights, Queens. Two of the units have been completed, one being fully rented and the other 75 per cent rented.

Midway in the opening period of their rain-drenched football battle in the mud of the Yankee Stadium yesterday, Notre Dame swooped upon an Army fumble and went 15 yards in four plays to score a 7-0 victory that fell far short of reflecting the Midwesterners' margin of superiority.
Superintendent Tracy G. Levee of reservation police said that D. W. Cook of Niagara Falls reported seeing a man climb the rail at Prospect Point today and plunge over the American Falls.

Miss Anne B. Quinby is a member of the debutante committee, of which Miss Mary Weeks is chairman, for the annual ball of the Association of Former Russian Imperial Naval Officers to be held Thursday on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis The group includes

Speculation as to the identity of the woman who will be honored this year for eminence in her field by the combined women's clubs will end tomorrow evening when Pearl Buck, author, will announce her name at the eleventh annual Friendship Dinner at the American Woman's Association.

HOT SPRINGS, Va.--The week for which huntsmen have been waiting and preparing is now at hand and .tomorrow they will be on stand or driving the bush for their single buck permitted by law. Many stories have come in from the mountains
IT happens that the country has a bumper crop of nuts. Fortunately, for Increasingly we use the-raw, crisped, roasted, salted, in confectionery, at the pharmacy ice-cream counter and in cookery.

Adam Carruthers, professor emeritus at University College, University of Toronto, died yesterday at the age of 80. Born in Scotland, Professor, Carruthers came to Canada as a boy and was educated at Hamilton Collegiate and University of Toronto.
" Our Bargain With the Soil" was announced today by Dean Margaret T. Corwin of New Jersey Collegs for Women as the subject for study at a week-end seminar on Nov. 19, 20 and 21.

Ben Pearson, Clemson halfback, kicked the only field goal recorded in the eight-year history of Florida's athletic field today to beat the Alligators, 10 to 9. The deciding point was tallied in the last two minutes of play.

Miss Virginia Schley has enlisted the aid of a group of debutantes in the arrangements for the dinner dance and entertainment in behalf of the Alice Hall Ali Memorial Fund of the Prosperity Shop to be held Friday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

It is not until the trees are thinned of leaves and the dullness of late Autumn takes possession of the landscape that the gardener truly appreciates the beauty of heavily berried shrubs. Then the fruit is more important than the flower, and a well placed shrub or tree bearing bright berries, silhouetted against evergreens or house walls receives enhanced appreciation since it holds the field alone.

Francis Viele-Griffin, American-born poet of the French symbolist school, died at his home in Bergerac yesterday in his seventy-fourth year. Mr. Vieli-Griffin came to France at the age of 8. With Gustave Kahn, Paul Adam and Henri de Regnier, he founded the review, Entretiens Politiques et Litteraires, in which many of his poems were published.

AT last "I'd Rather Be Right" has arrived in town. The town is still intact. The country as a whole is intact. Dominated by the buoyant personality of George M. Cohan, the Kaufman - Hart- Rodgers - Hart musical fandango turns out to be less daring than the nomination of a Southern Senator to the Supreme Court bench.

Crime is an outgrowth of unemployment and poverty, Lester B. Granger, director of education of the New York Urban League, a Negro vocational organization, said at the session of the Harlem Church Youth conference yesterday.
Faculty scholarships totaling $26,400 were awarded today to sixtysix students in the Harvard Law School. Among the recipients were:

MANY people thought that the question of women's rights had been settled-with women having their own sweet way-until the matter turned up on the agenda of the League of Nations recently in a formal request from fifteen countries that equality for women should be written into the League covenant.

Relief families were larger than non-relief families, and more persons rented homes than owned them in nineteen representative small cities studied by the Bureau of Home Economics, Department of Agriculture, in an effort to determine how much money the average American family makes and how it is spent.
Right next to the column in the morning paper where Sinclair Lewis deplored the subjugation of America by the salesmen
Two tracts of vacant land, formerly part of the 300-acre George Hunt farm at Putnam Valley, Putnam County, N. Y., have been sold by the recent owner, Herman Seiffert of Brooklyn.

Philip M.' Plant was accused by his divorce-seeking wife today of being an "incurable pathological drunkard." In a statement filed in support of her suit in Superior Court here, Mrs. Edna C. Dunham Plant of New York also charged her husband, heir to a large railroad building fortune, with infidelity.

Told by his parents to clean up the yard, William Carroll, 14, picked up what appeared to be a bundle of waste paper. It contained $7,000 in bonds stolen from the home of Mrs. Catherine Robertson while friends and relatives viewed her body at an undertaking establishment.

Health Commissioner John L. Rice made public yesterday a report of the Health Department's Bureau of Social Hygiene for the first nine months of 1937 showing that. cases of syphilis and gonorrhea examined in the medical advisory service had increased by 18 per cent, compared with the similar period in 1936, and 87 per cent over 1935.

Father Divine is scheduled to appear in Supreme Court here on Nov. 23 to answer questions propounded by counsel for Verinda Brown, a former "angel" in one of the Harlem peace missions, who is suing to recover $4,600 she donated between 1929 and 1934.

After six years of work Dr. K. C. D. Hickman of the Eastman research laboratories in Rochester, N. Y., announces that he has succeeded in obtaining vitamins from fish-liver oils merely by distillation. Already a semi-commercial plant is in operation which, small though it is, can supply about one-tenth the country's demand for Vitamin A, which is the one found in vegetable and fish oils and fats and which promotes growth and protects against infection.

KINGSTON--Despite the balmy weather last Winter, which ruined the prospects locally for snow, sports associations in the Catskills are pushing plans for a banner season and work is being done daily to improve facilities.
H. Gerrish Smith, president of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, said yesterday that the cost of building ships in American yards was out of the control of the builders.

Despite apparently strong sentiment among arriving members of Congress for revision of business taxes leaders expressed doubt today that anything could be done at the special session beginning Monday to modify or repeal either the undistributed profits tax on corporations or the capital gains tax.

THIRD MILITARY AREA The following Engineer Reserve officers, having accepted vacation appointment, without restrictions in the Officers Reserve Corps, are relieved from Attachment for Training, 373d Engineers (GS), and are assigned thereto: 2d Lt. Donald L. Clark, 7 Clinton Ave., Arlington, N. J. 2d Lt. James A. Clark, 7 Clinton Av., Arlington. N. J.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity again were in relatively small volume. The announcements were principally for small amounts of municipal and foreign issues, called to satisfy sinking-fund requirements. Except for a few small lots of municipal bonds called for retirement in November, last week's calls were for payment in later months.

Bound for a second trip to the Arctic to search for six Russians lost on a transpolar flight, Sir Hubert Wilkins landed at Edmonton today in the huge monoplane purchased for the hunt by the Soviet Government.

A FEW days ago this writer watched four persons wearing thick ski boots step from a Massachusetts car at the barred entrance of the Mount Washington automobile road in Pinkham Notch and begin unpacking their skis.

AFTER Louis XVIII's ascension to the throne of France, he and his wily Minister of Police, Joseph Fouhe, proscried a number of the high ranking officers who had been with Napoleon at the debacle of Waterloo after the fatal "Hundred Days."

Wedding rings of the past were considerably larger than those of today. This is illustrated in the exhibition of wedding rings, all copies, opened yesterday afternoon at the Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

Many seats have been purchased for the preview performance of "Four Cents a Word" on Saturday night at the Windsor Theatre for the benefit of the Metropolitan Junior Achievement, Inc. A supper dance at Larue will follow the performance.

The West Side Chamber of Commerce, in an open letter to the President and Congress, urges a declaration of a breathing spell for business and a statement that there will be no further changes in the economic system or additional taxes.

A consumers' testing laboratory for household goods, run by children and teachers, has been instituted this Fall by Manumit School at Pawling, in the first consumers' research course ever introduced into an elementary school.
Dr. and Mrs. Leo W. Bohm of this city and Yonkers, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Bohm, to Robert M. Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nat Schwartz of New York.
Boston College's football stalwarts smashed to a 13-0 triumph over a rugged University of Kentucky team before 2,000 rain-drenched spectators at Fenway Park.

Sidney Sukoenig, the pianist gave a Bach program yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, the program including the Italian concerto, two preludes and fugues from the "Well-Tempered Clavichord," the "Chaconne" in Busoni's transcription, the French Suite in C minor, and the Busoni transcription of the organ Prelude and Fugue in D major.

The publication this week of the Maritime Commission's shipping report has set an old problem before the country in a new light. That we have a merchant marine of sorts everyone knows. That it has recently been suffering from labor troubles is common knowledge. That its very foundations are precarious and its future uncertain has come, however, as a surprise.

The Lord Mayor of London gave a brilliant dinner in the ancient Guildhall last week; his guests included Prime Minister Chamberlain, Ambassador Grandi of Italy and Ambassador von Ribbentrop of Germany. Mr. Chamberlain made a speech, addressing himself particularly to the foreign envoys.
The magic of Coach Ray Morrison's aerial barrage, as executed by Sophomore Bert Marshall, gave Vanderbilt a 13-to-7 victory over Tennessee today before a homecoming day crowd of 23,000.

James Madison High School of New York City won a thrilling 25-to-13 victory over Bethlehem High School today. Although a driving rain made passing virtually impossible and mud made the footing precarious, neither team held back its offensive power and touchdowns came with regularity.
Elmira College will observe the annual Senior Day next Saturday, when parents and friends and members of their "big sister" class of 1936 will be guests on the campus.

RECENTLY in London Previsited the Wallace collection, eager to be identified again with that prophetic and commanding personality, Watteau. The day was fair enough, the sort a Londoner calls "bright."

With a crew of twenty-nine, only six of whom were rescued, the small Greek freighter Tzenny Chandris, heavily loaded with scrap iron, went to the bottom in a southeast gale between thirty and forty miles northeast of treacherous Diamond Shoals off Cape Hatteras early yesterday morning.

MEXICO is making progress in its extensive program of road-building in anticipation of heavy tourist travel. Already popular with Eastern motorists is the thoroughfare from Laredo on the Texas border to Mexico City, now completed and, according to a road expert recently returned from Southern Mexico, in good condition.

Oregon State dazzled Southern California with an aerial attack today and held the Trojans to a 12-12 score. U. S. C. made its first score when Ambling Ambrose Schindler passed and ran on a 40-yard drive to the goal. Granville Lansdell,

Extra-currioular activities were correlated with the cultural interests of Skidmore College in three events within a week. The Skidmore music course, which brings famous artists to the college each year, presented the Hampden Quartet, Negro singers, in a program of spirituals.
Auburn's fumbles gave Louisiana State breaks enough for the Bayou Tigers to chalk up a 9-7 victory today in a Southeastern Conference football battle witnessed by 30,000 fans.

One of the annual opera benefits forecast for this Winter is that to be given under the auspices of the Florence Crittenton League, an organization which for many years has maintained a shelter for young women at 427 West Twenty-first Street.

Mrs. Charles E. Adams heads the group of women in charge of the arrangements for a fashion pageant and luncheon to be held Nov. 30 in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Giveand-Take Shop.

F. and M. conquered Geneva College today, 18 to 6, in the mud. Geneva scored its touchdown just before the final whistle when Bainbridge, a substitute end, intercepted Asplin's lateral and ran 45 yards for the score.
THROUGHOUT the nation "univesities of scouting" are now in full swing, providing instruction and training for adults in leadership, administration and activities of the Boy Scouts.

Through the facilities of free classes in interior decorating offered by the WPA-Adult Education Program of the New York City Board of Education scores of women are being taught how to improve their homes and bring beauty, comfort and happiness to the most dreary tenement at little or no cost, Gustav A. Stumpf, project administrator, said yesterday.

Justice Department officials estimated today that Indians, whose forefathers' names fill some of the bloodiest pages of American history, have claims of more than two billion dollars pending against the government.

The racing luck of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, which has been uniformly bad for months, turned today and his Chanceview dominated the field in the $3,375 Prince George Autumn Handicap, giving the young master of Sagamore the first stake victory of the Bowie meeting.

Playing on a muddy gridiron, Westminster triumphed over Pawling today, 6 to 0. Schultz's plunge from the 2-yard line after he made a 43-yard run scored the winning touchdown. Heim and Nixon starred for Pawling.
The Sunday program of talks by authors at the Book Fair will be devoted at 3 P. M. to the general topic of "Books and the Religious Life."
A recent survey of apartment house occupancy in the Oranges by the brokerage firm of Sudler Conover reveals a very low rate of vacancies, the average being slightly more than 4 per cent.

Although prevented from castling in the twelfth game of the match for the chess championship of the world at Amsterdam, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris nevertheless found a place of safety for his king on the file of the king's bishop, from which point of vantage he directed the further development and subsequent mid-game strategy.

General farm legislation gradually being whipped into shape by the House Agriculture Committee was attacked by the American Farm Bureau Federation today as "wholly inadequate, ineffective and entirely unsatisfactory."

Winter activities of the Manhattan Girl Scout leaders will be launched tomorrow evening at a meeting to be held in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The principal speaker will be Dr. Lillian M. Gilbreth, vice chairman of the national board of directors.

By the reerection of the famous "leaning tower" of. the New Old South Church (but leaning no longer), Boston's characteristic sky line regains' its familiar contour. The deep-toned bell in the tower is ringing out again over. Copley Square and the Back Bay after a silence of nearly six years.

Benjamin 'Day, oldest locomotive engineer of the Lackawanna railroad died at his home here this morning. He was 91 years old, born in New Providence, N. J., the son of Samuel Thomas and Elizabeth Crane Day.

Reconstructed Old Main, Bucknell University's most important building, was rededicated today in a ceremony during which its central section was named Daniel C. Roberts Hall in honor of the Wilkes-Barre philanthropist whose benefactions to the university during the past two years have totaled $200,000.

Service in the Medinah Athletic Club, a skyscraper club-hotel at 505 North Michigan Avenue, was crippled by a strike Galled today at 5 A. M. without warning. Engineers, cooks, waiters, electricians, mechanics, elevator operators, maids, carpenters and "set-up" boys walked out on order of the Trades and Crafts Council, an American Federation of Labor affiliate.

Seventy juniors and eight sophomores are directing their own program of physical education at Vassar College, having proved their proficiency in six bf the departmental activities which are a part of the department plan covering a period of three years and which are required of all students for graduation.

La Salle downed P. M. C. today, 9 to 0. A 64-yard return of a P. M. C. punt by Bill Jennings gave a touchdown for La Salle in the first period and Frank Hartzel was downed behind the goal posts for a safety in the last period.

The social development of the college student is becoming more and more the concern of the educational, the professional and the business world. At Hunter College, which is both metropolitan and large, having a standard register of about. 7,000 students, a program of social guidance has been found necessary to help our students develop social poise and a well-balanced 'personality.

In an effort to strengthen the cultural ties between the two nations, Germany and Japan have made provisions for. the interchange of cultural and educational films, according to a report from Tokyo made public today by the Department of Commerce.
A second step toward better health facilities, a hygiene course designed to give students the best information available, has been established at Hobart College this semester.

Paul A. Wright waived formal reading of the complaint today at his arraignment on charges of murdering his wife, Evelyn, and his friend, John Kimmel. The formality lasted ninety seconds and Police Judge Frank Lowe set the preliminary hearing for Thursday.
ONCE more giving recognition to Italians' contributions to the arts, Italy has released stamps honoring famous sons identified with painting, music and literature.

The storm from the democratic benches against the government's toleration of Nazi incitements to overthrow the Constitution with which Parliament opened last week bore its first fruits this week when a bill was introduced establishing pre-publication censorship of products of the non-periodical press.

Proceeds from the dinner dance to be held Wednesday in La Maisonette Russe at the St. Regis will be devoted to two charitable projects, the Russian Refugee Children's Welfare Society and a fund, in memory of Prince George Matchabelli, for destitude Georgians in this country.

Miss Dorothy Leticia Davenport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hassel L. Davenport of Verona, who will be married Nov. 19 to John Calvin Lang, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lang of East Orange, has chosen her bridal attendants.
THE most pathetic attempt at colonization ever made in this country, probably, was that of the Napoleonic officers who settled in the canebrake region of Alabama.

Many openings vie for attention next week in one of the largest lists ever offered to the London stage. Robertson Hare, who has become known through both the stage and screen as the personification of comic timidity, has turned his hand to playwrighting and will be represented at the Strand Theatre on Sunday by "Dear Relations."
The building industry, in the face of rising costs, notably has reduced the price of its finished product and has given to the American public a vastly improved standard of housing excellence,

Premier Mussolini's second son, Bruno, a lieutenant in the Royal Air Force, returned home today after six weeks' active service with the Spanish Insurgents. Most of his time, if not all of it, was passed at Majorca in the Balearics.

According to Charles Michelson, publicity director of the Democratic National Committee, the current prominence of Herbert Hoover in Republican affairs and laudatory references to him by Republican leaders in various parts of the country point to him as the most likely choice of. his party for the Presidency in 1940.

Captain Angus Walters, skipper of the schooner Bluenose, said today that the future of Nova Scotia fishing was threatened by profiteering of combines which control prices, unsatisfactory bounty regulations and a shortage of native fishermen.
F. A. Scola broke 88 out of 100 targets in the rain at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday to lead a small field for high scratch honors.
WHILE in Leipzig this past Summer I called on the widow of Professor Paul Klengel, the brother of the famous 'cellist, the late Julius Klengel, who was a personal friend of mine. During my visit M?e.

According to a ruling by the unlform practice committee of the New York Security Dealers Association, transactions on a "whenissued" basis up to yesterday in Manati Sugar Company first-mortgage twenty-year 4 per cent bonds due in 1957 are to be settled on Wednesday,' with interest figured to that day, or settlement may be made earlier on one day's written notice.

Miss Nettie Timmonds, a 63year-old farm woman, has survived a series of personal misfortunes which affected most of her senses, and through it all has carried on the work of managing a 250-acre farm. Miss Timmonds successively has been mute, deaf, blind, partially paralyzed and crippled by arthritis.

The Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Sufragan Bishop of New York, officiated today at funeral services for the Rev. Charles Calvin Proffitt, Protestant Episcopal minister, who died at his home on Northern Drive here Thursday.

The Brussels conference on the SmoJapanese situation, called under the Nine-power pact of 1922 which guaranteed "the territorial and administrative integrity" of China and the "open door" to her commerce, met on Nov. 3, in the fourth month of the undeclared Oriental war.

A temporary injunction containing terms that would require striking employes of The Bayonne Times to go back to work whether they wanted to or not was issued today by Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan against the Newspaper Guild of America, the Hudson County Newspaper Guild and eight strikers and one strike sympathizer.

The proposal for creation of a State Transit Authority to acquire and operate the New York, Westchester Boston Railway was approved yesterday by the State executive committee of-the Socialist party, according to a statement issued by Dr. Harry W. Laidler, chairman.

President Roosevelt devoted much time today to work on his message to the special session of Congress and was to continue work on it tomorrow To be read to the House and Senate soon after they convene at noon Monday, it will outline legislation for crop control, wages and hours regulation, regional planning and government reorganization.
Brazil's coup d'etat this week is typical of the new political trend which is rapidly gaining ground throughout the South American Continent.

LONDON.--In connection with the negotiations at Washington between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization, the question has arisen whether the older craft unions and the more recently formed industrial unions (designed to embrace all workers in given industries, whatever their jobs) can come to terms and work together.

The new 17,000-ton liner Oslofjord, which will operate as flagship of the Norwegian America Line, will be launched on Dec. 29 at Bremen, Germany, according to word received yesterday by the New York offices of the line.
The first session of the course in real estate appraising sponsored jointly by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers and the General

In armories in each of the five boroughs hordes of clerks and Election Board officials struggled last week with the seemingly endless task of counting and sorting the ballots on which 2,000,000 New York City voters had recorded their preferences for candidates for the new City Council.

In the late Eighteen Eighties Chinese Sacred Lilies were introduced into the American markets and found capable of being grown in a bowl of water and pebbles. Complaints began to come in that, under city living conditions, the buds would often blast.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's renewed overtures to both Italy and Germany in his Guildhall speech this week and his decision to send Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, to Berlin are regarded in Berlin and Rome as the direct results of the pact of Germany, Italy and Japan which is less than a week old.

Admitting that payments were being made to the families of Arthur (Tootsie) Herbert and two other former officers of the Chicken Drivers Union, Local 167, while the three served jail terms for embezzling union funds, Robert Goodman, acting president of the local, said yesterday that such payments had been approved by the full membership of the union at a meeting held before the three went to prison.
A brilliantly fighting University of North Carolina football team outplayed a favored Duke University eleven today to drop the Blue Devils from the undefeated ranks, 14 to 6.

Harry H. Woodring, Secretary of War, and Mrs. Woodring entertained with a dinner last night in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Duncan Bradley, Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Carpenter, Mr. and Mrs. William Stanley, Mrs. Shirley Casey and Captain William L. Ritchie, aide to the secretary.

The fifteen-story store and loft structure known as the President Monroe Building, comprising the entire blockfront on the north side of Prince Street between Lafayette and Crosby Streets, will be offered at auction Friday in the Vesey Street salesrooms by Henry Brady.

The Most Rev. Gabriel Breynat, Bishop of the Vicariate-Apostolic of Mackenzie, with headquarters at Fort Smith, in the District of Mackenzie, in the northern part of Canada, who- is known as "The Bishop of the Wind" in his vicariate, which takes in 600,000 square miles, including Arctic territories, made a flying visit to New York yesterday.

A benefit performance of "Amphitryon 38," the modern version of the ancient Greek comedy in which Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne are now appearing, will be given for the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys of Millington the evening of Dec. 7, at the Shubert Theatre in New York.
