Campaigns carried on by manufacturers of small appliances to persuade retailers to stock larger qauntities of socket appliances for the holiday trade have proved exceptionally successful this year, selling agents said yesterday.

Ohio University, making its third visit East in fifteen years, added the Rutgers football team to its list of Eastern victims along with Columbia and Navy by downing the Scarlet, 13 to 0, before 4,000 spectators on flooded Neilson Field today.
The Women's Auxiliary of the Sisters of St. Dominic of Maryknoll will give its annual card party Saturday afternoon in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Two over-zealous efforts by Stan Mikulka and Bernie Bloom, which might uncharitably be called bad judgment, gave Georgetown a fourth-period touchdown and a 6-to-0 triumph over New York University on the muddy morass of the Polo Grounds yesterday before a rain-soaked gathering of 8,000.
On a muddy field and in a drizzling rain, the Hamilton College eleven defeated Union College in their forty-fifth game, 7 to 0.

Following a year's experimentation with a plan to bring faculty and students in closer social relations Tufts College this year has adopted the "counselor-aid" system as part of its educational machinery.

A program to halt the downward trend of American business became Item No. 1 at the White House last week. The President, curtailing outside engagements, spent much of each working day in conferences with business and administration leaders.

If Washington is perturbed by the anti-democratic coup in Brazil, there is equal anxiety here over indications that Germany is about to start a longexpected diplomatic offensive for the domination of Central and Southeastern Europe.

ARONOWSKY--DENHERB--Mr. and Mrs; H. Denker, 310 West 86th St., announce the engagement of their daughter, Judith, to Mr. Sam Aronowsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Aronowsky, 809 East 12th St., Brooklyn. BAUER--WARNER--Mr. and Mrs. Edward Beadle of Cranford, N. J., announce the engagement of their daughter, Edna Beadle Warner, to Frank M. Bauer of Rockaway, L. I.
The new symphony orchestra which the National Broadcasting Company has developed made its debut last night under the leadership of Pierre Monteux in the Radio City studios.
Two of the leading figures in billiards will meet tomorrow night when Willie Hoppe opens the defense of his 18.1 balkline title against Jake Schaefer at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

A new series of entertainments will be inaugurated tonight when the first meeting of the Sunday Evening Informal Club, established by Miss Jessie Fanshawe, will take place in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

The annual bazaar under the auspices of the Helpers will take place Tuesday in the small ballroom of the Plaza to raise funds for carrying on their many philanthropic enterprises. Luncheon and tea will be served by a group of young women who have long taken an active interest in furthering the work of the Helpers.

Mrs. George L. Ohrstrom's Glory Road, a bay gelding, captured the Glenwood National Steeplechase, three-mile brush race that carried a $1,000 purse and was the feature of the hunts meet over the beautiful Glenwood course.

Although preliminary reports from eighty-seven Class I railroads, representing 78.9 per cent of total operating revenues, show estimated operating revenues in October to be $293,545,220, compared with $308,700,655 for the same month of 1936, a drop of 4.9 per cent,

A SUBSTANTIAL reduction in average traffic fatality rate has been recorded for the first nine months of 1937 in nine of the fourteen cities in which accident prevention bureaus have been installed by the Safety Division of the International Association of Chiefs of Police, Evanston, Ill., according to a report recently issued.

Louis Dembitz Brandeis was 81 years old today, but the hours of the birthday were passed quite as simply as on other recent anniversaries of the Associate Justice. Disliking any special observance of such an occasion outside of his close home circle, Mr. Brandeis spent the day with little variation from others of the week.

A drive by public housing organizations to have the State Constitutional Convention amend the Constitution to provide for wide State and community aid to housing projects and to integrate local and State activities with the Federal Housing Act was mapped yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Astor sponsored by the National Public Housing Conference.

Cole scored all the points for St. Joseph's College of Philadelphia as Washington College was defeated today, 7-6, on a muddy field. A few minutes after the start of the final period the visiting fullback crashed over from the 2-yard mark and then place-kicked the winning point.
Senator Ashurst, who has held his position for twenty-six years, listed today the intentions of Congress as one of four great mysteries for man.

The Rev. Dr. John McDowell, former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, died at 7:30 o'clock last night in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Centre following a major operation performed on Friday. He entered the hospital on Nov. 3. His aged was 67.
The greatest single step toward solving the present business slump was taken here this week in the official recognition, evidenced by President Roosevelt himself, that there was a recession.

The Federal Wage and Hour Bill as passed by the Senate carried a provision permitting an increase in tariff rates wherever it was found that the bill had raised American as compared with foreign cost of production.

Another in the series of November teas in behalf of the performance of "Otello," the afternoon of Jan. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the New York Vassar Club will be given tomorrow by Mrs. Earl Kress Williams at her home, 1,111 Park Avenue.

An intensive study of current events in the Far East will be to crowded into the next ten days by the American Woman's Association. Beginning this afternoon when Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Jr. will speak on "My Chinese Holiday Under Fire," there will be four separate meetings concerned with the international complications in the Orient.
Work on the new Schrafft's restaurant building under construction at 155-57 East Seventy-ninth Street, adjoining the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue, is proceeding rapidly.
Every nation holds the indisputable right to solve its own problems in accord with its own necessities and strength. The new regime implanted in Brazil on Nov. 9 must be considered in that light.
The German team of Gustav Kilian and Heinz Vopel won the thirty-eighth international six-day bicycle race in a thrilling finish before 16,000 spectators at the Chicago Stadium tonight.
Mrs. Herbert J. Tily, wife of the president and general manager of the Strawbridge Clothier department store here, died at her home in Cynwyd today, after an illness of two months. Her age was 69.

Sailing yesterday on the Panama Pacific liner California was Daniel E. Finn Jr., Tammany leader of the First Assembly District and Sheriff-elect of New York County, who said he was going on a vacation trip to Havana and Miami.

Lewis W. Douglas, president of Magill University and former Director of the Budget, and Wayne C. Taylor, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, will speak on "Balancing the Budget" at the 121st dinner of the Economic Club of New York in the Hotel Astor on Tuesday night, Dec. 7, according to an announcement yesterday by Paul D. Cravath, president of the club.

Following four days of steady recovery, prices on he Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday to end with losses of 10 to 13 points, or 50 to 65 cents a bale. An increase in the volume of hedges, coincident with less aggressive foreign and domestic absorption of contracts, closed the list around the bottom.

One hundred and ninety-two scholarships with a total value of $17,000 were awarded to students in New York University's Washington Square College and School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance at Washington Square East, it was announced yesterday.
Litthe Three varsity honors in crosscountry were captured by Williams in a close 38-39 finish between Williams and Wesleyan\ on the Taconic course today. Amherst was last with 49.

Thirty per cent of Princeton University's undergraduate body, or 700 students, benefited from the $360,205.26 in financial assistance provided by the university during the academic year 1936-37, according to the annual report of Richard W. Warfield, director of the bureau of appointments and student employment and chairman of the university scholarship committee.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 12: MAJOR GENERALS Bowley, A. J., 23 days' leave, Feb. 1. Relieved from duty at Baltimore, Md.,
" REMEMBER that rivers are always your friends," Swiftwater Bill said to the boy just out of Stanford University, who was challenging fortune on the Klondike.

Although lower again, the decline of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended Nov. 6 was less sharp. The index dropped to 93.7 from 95.4 in the previous week and compared with 101.6 for the corresponding week last year.

New York's 1937-38 season of ice shows is to be opened at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night by the presentation of "Gay Blades," figure-skating spectacle. Karl Schaefer, seven times world champion and winner of the Olympic crown in 1932 and 1936,
An eight-room house on a three and one-half acre estate, known as Elmwood, has been completed on Colonial Road, New Canaan, Conn., by the Simons-Stroh Company, builders.

The Swarthmore College football team defeated St. John's of Annapolis, 13-0, on a mud-covered field today for the first Garnet victory of the season. Larry Wolfe ran 44 yards for the first touchdown at the beginning of the second period, and Hartman plunged through center for the extra point.
Penn State's fighting Lions registered a last-minute victory over Maryland's brilliant passing eleven today, 21 to 14.

Driving 30 yards late in the third period with Tony Cavallo of East Weymouth, Mass., the spearhead of the attack, Lafayette's undefeated and untied football team today won its seventh straight victory by beating determined Washington and Jefferson from Western Pennsylvania, 6 to 0. The game was played in a driving rain that turned the field into a quagmire.

The New Deal is turning once more to private housing as a means of stimulating the lagging construction industry and through it industry in general, whose post-depression progress has slowed up to a marked degree in the past few months.
Miss Mary Lane has been elected president of the Alumnae Association of Marymount College here, it was announced today.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Standard Oil Company of Louisiana will make a reduction tomorrow of 3/4 cent a gallon in the consumer, tank-car and dealer prices of all grades of gasoline throughout their marketing areas except at points where

IN search of the special flavor of The Coast Country which lies between the tourist's Florida and the tourist's New Orleans, you find yourself in West Florida, driving beside the Gulf-the misty, pearl-colored Gulf where every sunset is a new marvel, where the dunes are like diamond snow.

After spending millions of dollars in advertising alone to build up intercoastal tourist travel through the Panama Canal on their six big luxury liners, the Grace Lines and the Panama Pacific Line are abandoning the service and withdrawing their ships.
The Bureau of Mines estimated today that in December a daily production of 3,491,000 barrels would be needed to meet market demands for crude oil.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra at the third concert of its New York season in Carnegie Hall, Tuesday night, Nov. 23, will be led by Leopold Stokowski in a program comprising several short numbers and Sibelius's Fourth symphony.

Concluding the retriever field trial season in the East, the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club will give its fifth annual meeting next Saturday and Sunday at Southampton, L. I. The courses will be laid out in the covers of "The Port of Missing Men," the estate of Mrs. Walter Having.

ALTHOUGH he did not die until 1923, Elihu Vedder belongs essentially to an earlier generation--and to the nineteenth century rather than to the twentieth. He was born in 1836, and the large memorial exhibition that opened late in the week at the American Academy of Arts and Letterss has been organized as a centenary tribute.

General J. Leslie Kincaid, president of the Lexington Avenue Civic Association, points out that recent transit improvements have contributed materially to directing wide attention to the availability and conveniences of Lexington Avenue and its immediate neighborhood for residential and business purposes.

A new and well-equipped astronomical observatory has been established on the roof of Gillet Hall in the Bronx buildings of Hunter College, where sixty students do practical laboratory work with their telescopes between 5:30 and 8 in the evening under the supervision of Dr. John E. Merrill, instructor in the Department of Physics.

BY the law of contraries, first proclaimed by Heraclitus, and ages later by Blake, it would seem inevitable that the novel based on a materialistic dialectic so much in vogue in this chaotic age should stimulate by reaction the production of the novel based, as this one is, on a spiritual dialectic.

Eight railroads filed today exceptions with the Interstate Commerce Commission to the report of its examiner, B. N. Trezise, made in September, condemning the relations between railroads and freight forwarders.
Dr. William Henry McMaster, president of Mount Union College, resigned today, effective immediately. The announcement came as a surprise.

The arguments against collective action, to restore peace in the Far East are getting stronger every day, according to Senator Key Pitman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, on his return to the capital yesterday, and yet the sentiment of the country is more strongly in favor of collective peacemaking than ever before.
The Public Utility Commission today set Nov. 23 for a hearing in Newark on the application of railroad companies for authority to increase intrastate freight rates on heavy industry commodities.
THE wooded eastern slopes of the Blue Ridge Mountains between Leesburg and Charrottesville are coppery and gold now and the corn shocks stand about the rolling fields.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Milton Alexander Kent of Bronxville, N. Y., formerly of Larchmont Manor, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Mae Kent, to George Thomas Duram, son of Mr., and Mrs. Arthur Emmett Duram of Springfield, Ill.

American mountains and desert, American hospitality and manners and American women leaders are the five outstanding wonders of this country in the opinion of Miss Robin Hale, American-born granddaughter of the late Sir Johnston Forbes - Robertson, Shakespearean actor.
MUCH the greater part of this book is the dramatization of some of the stories in "Winesburg. Ohio," done in nine short scenes and with the dialogue

WHEN the Hudson River Day Line ties up its excursion boats for the Winter, the cottagers of Mount Beacon, unique community perched high above the old river town of Beacon, N. Y., know that their season, too, is almost over.

Miss Claire Hasbrouck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. F. Hasbrouck of Jersey City, was married here this morning to Harrison Waterbury, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Waterbury of Orchard Place, Cos Cob, in St. Catherine's Church, Riverside, by the Rev. Joseph J. Ganley, the rector.
A letter pleading for American friendship while he was on his deathbed has been received here from Baron Sotokichi Uriu, Japanese naval hero. It came to O. E. Weller,

Salary increases for several members of the White House secretariat and a few high officials in various departments were shown today in the 1937 Official Register, published annually by the Civil Service Commission.

Maude Adams has presented to Stephens College, the Missouri Junior College for Girls where she is now teaching, the full set of costumes used a few years ago in her production of "The Merchant of Venice," as well as two tons of stage electrical equipment.

National Socialism at every step in the last quarter year has been sinking deeper into religious difficulties. The conflict between church and State, or rather between religion and ideology, is assuming the character of one of those Greek tragedies in which Fate drives its unfortunate pawns from catastrophe to catastrophe.
A series of card parties in behalf of the philanthropic activities of the Loyal Workers will be held tomorrow at the McAlpin Hotel. Mrs. William Grant will be hostess.

The Italian Chamber of Commerce in New York celebrated its fiftieth anniversary ata dinner at the Hotel Biltmore last night, attended by more than 500 persons. The speakers were the Italian Ambassador Fulvio de Suvich and Mayor F. H. La Guardia who spoke by telephone from Washinton.

The typical freshman at Barnard College this year is 17 years and 2 months old, 5 feet 4 inches tall and weighs 125.3 pounds according to the Fall report. released yesterday by Dr. Guliema Alsop college physician, and Miss Agnes R. Wayman, head of the physical education department.

Several innovations in the handling of budgets and finances of undergraduate campus organizations at Pembroke College in Brown University have been introduced this Fall by the college finance committee under the chairmanship of Miss Isabel Lion, '38, of Salem, N. H. This committee, which is serving as a kind of efficiency expert, is sponscored by the Student Government Association.

Washington and Lee University defeated the College of Wrilliam and Mary today 14 to 12, before a homecoming day crowd of 5,000. The visitors got the jump with a touchdown in the first period, but William and Mary came back with an aerial attack in the next that made the score 12 to 7 at half time.
Scoring in the opening and closing periods, Massachusetts State scored its first victory of the season as it downed the Rensselaer Polytechnic eleven on Alumni Field today in a driving rain, 13--0.

Margaret Shanahan of 66 Morton Street, New York City, has been awarded first prize in the Freeport (L. I.) Chamber of Commerce's essay contest on the subject, "Freeport as an Ideal Home Community," it was announced yesterday. Miss Shanahan is a secretary in a New York life insurance company.
WHEN America as a nation was still fairly young, historians, as was but logical. gave a good deal more of their attention to the colonial period and the Revolution than is their custom today.

Miss Rosemarie Bergmann, daughter of Dr. Sigmund Bergmann and Mrs. Bergmann of South Orange, formerly of Munich, Germany, will be married the afternoon of Dec. 28 to Herbert Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ludwig Schneider of Munich.
The six affiliated American colleges in the Near East will benefit from net proceeds of the matinee performance of "Die Walkuere" on Dec. 29 at the Metropolitan Opera.

Turpentine firm, 26 1/2-3/4c; sales 82 barrels; receipts 348 barrels; shipments 5 barrels; stock 39,584 barrels. Resin steady; sales 914; receipts 880; no shipments; stock 81,407. Quote: B, D, E, $5.90-$6; F, G, H, I, $5.90-$6.07 1/2; K, M, N, $5.90-$6.10; WG, $6.50; WW, X, $6.75.

The marriage of Miss Margariete Louise Taylor, daughter of Louis Taylor of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Margaret Snow Taylor, to Francis Vinton Smith, son of Mrs. Littleton Kirkpatrick Smith of New Brunswick, N. J., and the late Mr. Smith, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

While the number of business failures for this year will fall considerably below that for 1937, credit executives predicted yesterday that the rising trend, now in evidence, would be intensified in January, with the number of suspensions for that month possibly 10 to 15 per cent ahead of January, 1937.

Monday Allwood (N. J.) Woman's Club-Meeting, child study department, home of Mrs. T. C. Travis, 8:15 P. M. Speaker, Dr. John Spargo, on "How Much Homework?" Barnard College Club of the Oranges and Maplewood (N. J.)--Meeting, home of Helen May, South Orange, 8:15 P. M. Dr. Guilielma F. Alsop, speaker, on personality.

A verdict returned late Friday night and filed yesterday in Federal court awarded to Patrick A. Connell, 49 years old, of 11 Hickory Street, Carbondale, Pa., $33,500 for injuries received in a railroad accident on May 21, 1935. The case was against the Delaware Hudson Railroad Company.

Receding industrial activity became an important factor in both wholesale and retail trade last week as employment was lessened in industrial areas and the hours of work by those still on the job were reduced in many instances.

A dinner will be given by the New York Committee of the Austen Riggs Foundation on Wednesday in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club in honor of Dr. Austen Fox Riggs, and to celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of his work in Stockbridge, Mass. Many dinner parties are being arranged.

THE present popularity of miniature or "souvenir" sheets abroad is illustrated by the fact that eight new ones have arrived during the past week, including sheets from Germany, Spain, Belgian Congo and Rumania.
World Premiere-Franco Vittadini's "Caracciolo."
Streams and rivers swollen by a record rainfall overflowed their banks in parts of Washington and near-by Maryland communities today, causing flooded highways and property damage.
Members of the Young Folks Auxiliary of the Godmothers' League will meet this afternoon at the headquarters of the organization, 115 East 101st Street.

Vice President John Nance Garner returned to the capital today with a smile and a joke--but no comment on the issues before Congress. The Vice President, rosy-cheeked and healthy-looking, was the first passenger off the train from St. Louis, where he stopped yesterday en route from Uvalde, Texas.

A PROGRAM consisting principally of old Welsh folk-music and choral compositions by individual composers of that ancient land will be given next Friday night in Carnegie Hall by the Cambrian Male Choir of Cleveland and the Welsh Women's Chorus of this city.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Brown of New York have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Mary Helen Moreno, to Hugh Bauer Taylor of Bellefonte. Pa.

TO the old hand at the short wave dials, strong European signals on the 49-meter band herald the approach of Winter, and all-wave listeners will now find the first harbinger of snowy days "trumpeting" across the seas through the medium of Berlin's station DJC on 6.02 megacycles.

The sale yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries was conducted by the usual staff. H. E. Russell Jr. was the auctioneer, the same porters shifted the art objects, and familiar appraisers were in the audience bidding for their clients. But for Mr. Russell, and most of the staff conducting the sale, it was the last sale in the old building.

A new method of producing artificial fevers to cure certain diseases, in which the patient would be relatively comfortable although "broiling" at a temperature of 105 degrees Fahrenheit and above, has just been patented here by Dr. Charles F. Kettering, inventor and director of research for the General Motors Corporation.

Dr. William M. Carhart, an authority on eye and ear diseases, died here today at the Peekskill Hospital after suffering from a stroke for a week. He was 73 years old. Born in Brooklyn, he received his early education at the Peekskill Military Academy, being graduated from there in 1881.

THE Schola Cantorum, conducted by Hugh Ross, will give two subscription concerts this season at Carnegie Hall, Jan. 12 and March 23. At the first, Frederick Delius's "Mass of Life" and Vladimir Dukelsky's "The End of St. Petersburg" will be presented, and at the second, Bach's "St. John Passion." At both performances the chorus will be assisted by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Soloists will be announced later.
Ralph Greenleaf of New York defeated Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, 125 to 67 in thirty-five innings tonight to make a triple deadlock for first place in the world pocket billiard championship.
The hotel structure, formerly known as the Hotel Klein, at New Brunswick, N. J., has been completely renovated and refurnished, and will be reopened Thursday under the name of the Joyce Kilmer Hotel.

A tentative formula for the "bluebook" method of appraising the trade-in values of radios has been worked out by the fair trade committee of the Brooklyn Electrical Appliance Dealers Association, it was announced yesterday by William H. Ingersoll, advisor to the committee.

With its art collection enlarged to more than 7,000 pictures by recent gifts from the Carnegie Corporation and by trustees' appropriation for the purchase of colored reproductions and books, the University of Maine has just completed the construction of a new art gallery in Stevens Hall and has made arrangements for the circulation of pictures among the fraternities and throughout the State.

Mrs. W. Barton Chapin Jr. is chairman of the committee in charge of arrangements for the bridge party and tea to be given under the auspices of the Young Women's Organization of the Women's National Republican Club on Wednesday at the clubhouse, 3 West Fifty-first Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Sorensen of Verona, formerly of Montclair, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mildred Marie Sorensen, to Donald J. Knox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Knox of Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

The annual sale and luncheon in aid of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women will be held Wednesday and Thursday at the headquarters of the organization, 2,914 Broadway, under the auspices of the board of managers of the home.
The Rev. John J. McCabe, pastor of Holy Saviour Catholic Church and an authority on canon law, died at Mercy Hospital today from an infection in his nostril. His age was 70.
The College of William and Mary is holding its annual homecoming this week-end, with a large program of events to entertain the alumni who have returned in greater numbers than in previous years.

Inventors who received the 723 patents granted this week reached new heights of ingenuity. For example: James A. Caldwell of San Antonio won a patent for a bumper to be worn by cows and steers to protect their heads from head-on crashes. It is a plate suspended from the horns over the head and between the eyes.

REJOINDER: George Arliss, actor, was asked last week, when arriving from Europe, whether he would, as rumored, make a movie based on the life of the late John D. Rockefeller. "They have been saying that," Mr. Arliss remarked, "ever since Rockefeller started looking like me. I have no objection. It only shows that he was not a vain man."

Government officials attended the funeral here today of James Theodore Marriner, "career man" in the United States diplomatic service. The 45-year-old United States Consul General was killed by the bullet of a dissatisfied Armenian at Beirut, Syria, a month ago.
Mrs. Herbert T. Hosking of Philadelphia, education chairman, will report on the year's work at a board meeting of the National Society, Daughters of the Revolution, tomorrow in the Graybar Building.

Those young and old salts who are making of their new North River Power Squadron one of the most active and interesting of all the units in the United States organization, have elected William L. Sayers as their new commander.

The Swedish steel -works and arms factory of Bofors is said to be considerably ahead of any other similar firm in the manufacture of anti-aircraft weapons. Military experts are especially enthusiastic about one extremely efficient 40-millimeter anti-aircraft gun that fires tracer projectiles and has an automatic adjustment to a moving target.

After thirtyeight years of service in the State museum, Dr. Rudolf Reudemann, whose work has brought him international recognition, has retired as State Paleontologist, Dr. Frank P. Graves, State Commissioner of Education, announced today. He has beer State paleontologist since 1936, having been an assistant from March, 1899.

Ten alumni of City College who have, in the estimate of the Associate Alumni, performed distinguished service for the country and their alma mater were honored last night at the alumni dinner of the Associate Alumni at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Postmaster General Farley filed a brief today with the Interstate Commerce Commission opposing an increase in payments to the Chicago and Southern Airlines, Inc., which holds an air-mail contract between Chicano and New Orleans.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 12, unless specified: At San Pedro: Astoria, Louisville, Quincy, Tuscaloosa. At Balboa: Charleston, Woodcock. At San Francisco: Colorado, Memphis, Oklahoma.

Jean Hazard, chief engineer of the French liner Normandie, has retired from active service after thirty-three years' service with the company's transatlantic fleet, according to an announcement made yesterday by Henri Morin de Linclays, general manager of the line in the United States and Canada.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Hand Wadhams, daughter of Albion James Wadhams of Dongan Hills, S. I., and Elizabethtown, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Wadhams, to John B. Pearson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Pearson of St. George, S. I., has been announced by her father.
Two unofficial representatives of China and Japan set forth opposing views of the issue behind the Far Eastern warfare yesterday before a forum of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor.
Opposition to rent control laws is expressed by James Felt, broker. In lieu of such measures he favors the establishment of an arbitration board which would hold hearings on rent disputes.

Ed Simonich's three-yard drive through the line in the first period produced the touchdown that gave Notre Dame a victory over Army in a rain-drenched battle watched by 65,000 persons at the Yankee Stadium. At New Haven Yale routed Princeton in the sixtyfirst game of their series, Clint Frank crossing the goal line four times. In another of the day's big games, with 72,000 looking on, Pittsburgh took the measure of Nebraska.

The forty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers will be held Thursday and Friday at the Hotel Waldorf - Astoria. Fire control aboard ship, ship propulsion methods, alloys in ship construction and other matters on shipbuilding and operation will be discussed.

A moderate upturn in securities and commodities, led by the stock market, reflected improvement in trading sentiment last week as a result of indications that the government plans to give business much-needed encouragement.

MANHATTAN WEHRENBERG, ELIZABETH M. (Nov. 1). Estate, more than $11,000. To Herman Henry Bertram, son, executor, Montclair, N. J. Letters of Administration Granted by Surrogate James A. Foley on the following estates: AHERN, CORNELIUS F. (Sept. 15). Estate, $1,700. To Philip C. Ahern, brother, 231 E. 50th St. Other heir, sister. CUNNINGHAM, GEORGE (Oct. 17). Estate, $1.000. To Caroline Cunningham, widow, 642 Amsterdam Ave. Other heirs, two sons, daughter.

THE Boston Symphony Orchestra will open its New York season with three concerts here this week. The orchestra will be heard at Carnegie Hall Thursday night and Saturday afternoon, and will give a Friday night performance at the Brooklyn Academny of Music.

Maurice J. Tobin, Mayor-elect of Boston, whose election nipped in the bud the attempted political comeback of former Governor James M. Curley of Massachusetts, said yesterday, after inspecting the counting of the Manhattan ballots for the City Council in the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory.

The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, charged yesterday that the National Labor Relations Board was seeking to build an "official labor movement" in this country by favoring "dual unions as opposed to established labor organizations."

Senator Antonio R. Barcelo, veteran chief of the Puerto Rican independence movement, sailed for the United States on the steamship Coamo yesterday afternoon, bent on blocking the revival of Senator Millard Tydings's bill,

The Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the formal opening of the Park Lane Cafe on Wednesday afternoon. Proceeds will be devoted to the work of the organization in New York.

A NEW production season is just beginning in the automobile factories of Detroit, where capital perfected mass production and labor perfected the technique of the sit-down strike. Assembly lines move slowly at this time of year, giving men's minds and muscles an opportunity to accustom themselves to unfamiliar tasks and movements.

Snow or no snow, ski shops are opening in stores all over town tomorrow. Just as college shops have on their staffs young women fresh from campuses, so ski shops are increasingly advised by experts in the sport.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ida Coale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Basil Coale of Richmond, Va., to Elmer W. Wheaton, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Warren Wheaton of Maplewood.

The Committee for Industrial Organization asked the National Labor Relations Board today to pass judgment on Bethlehem Steel Corporation's labor policies before considering the question of who should represent its workers in collective bargaining.

Dr. James I. Seder, kidnapped veteran Anti-Saloon League leader, lay at the point of death tonight as the State invoked the Lindbergh Law against his accused abductors. Dr. A. K. Kessler said he had "no hope" for the recovery of the 79-year-old victim,

Refusal of the government to permit the use of the free port on Staten Island for the storage of silver is depriving bullion brokers of this city of a volume of business running into millions annually, Ernest D. Kracht, broker,

Expanding its activity in the field of government, Massachusetts State College has increased its undergraduate courses in government this year and has started a research service for governmental agencies outside the college.

The Merchants Association of New York, at the request of Senator George R. Fearon, counsel to the special joint legislative committee on mortgage moratorium and deficiency judgments, has presented some suggestions toward amending those acts.
Governor and Mrs. Francis Parnell Murphy have announced the engagement of their youngest daughter, Miss Eleanor Mae Murphy, to Donald Walter Erion, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Erion of Buffalo.
The undergraduate committee for the Fiftieth Anniversary Fund at Barnard College announced yesterday that it would sponsor a photography contest from Nov. 15 to Dec. 15 to raise money for the fund.

George Miller, Indiana's burly center, whose greatest football delight is to kick a field goal, thoroughly enjoyed himself today as he did his favorite act from the 12-yard line to give the Hoosiers a 3-to-0 victory over a fighting Iowa team.

BRYANT'S Showboat plies the waters and plays the towns of the Ohio River and its numerous tributaries, and Billy Bryant is its comedian and king. He is the author of "Children of Ol' Man River"; he holds a pilot's license on the Ohio.

IT did not need Mr. Howe's book to tell us that there is such a thing as British propaganda in this country, or that it has at times had considerable influence in shaping. public opinion, or that some more or less prominent Englishmen, especially in the governing or professional classes, would apparently be much pleased if the United States would now play the British game.

A card party and tea under the auspices of the Lafayette Guild of the Maternity Center Association will be held Dec. 8 at the WaldorfAstoria to aid the association. Mrs. Sidney A. Witherbee heads the group in charge of the arrangements and her aides are Mrs. David B. Fleming and Mrs. Edwin F. Dakin.

The Boerse was firm and calm today. Heavy industrials, chemicals, eletricals and other leaders showed strength in a limited turnover. Textiles were mixed but generally resistant, although Bremen Wool lost 2 points. Shipping shares were quiet.

A subscription party entitled the "Gay Thirties" will be given under the auspices of a patroness committee of prominent women on Dec. 10 in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria in behalf of the Boys Club of New York. As there will be no public sale of tickets, applications for cards of admission should be directed to members of the committee.

With the opening of Congress Monday morning and throughout many hectic weeks to come, the center of the legislative stage will be held much of the time by a woman, upon whom will devolve some of the greatest responsibilities to be assumed by a member of the House of Representatives.

As indicated by last Wednesday's report on the crop yield of 1937, three main inferences stand out. One is that Nature, which behaved very harshly to agricultural America in 1936, has showered her bounty on the farm-producers of 1937.

John Timmy, 20, of Detroit, arrested on a charge of attempting to extort $1,000 from Marion Davies,motion-picture actress, was ordered held for preliminary hearing Nov. 19 at his arraignment today. Bail was fixed at $3,000.
More than nine-tenths of the student body at Middlebury College would refuse to participate in a war in which the United States is involved outside of its territory,

Mrs. Henry J. Fishback of this city- has announced the marriage of her daughter, Mrs. Marion Louise Collins, to Peter Penrose Hawkes of Corning, N Y., son of Mrs. Penrose Hawkes of Bride Park House, Cork, Ireland, and the late Mr. Hawkes, which took place here on Oct. 21.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Astrea M. Kemmler, daughter of Mrs. Charles Weldon of this city and of Charles W. Kemmler of New York, to James Blake Rogers, youngest son of Mrs. Will Rogers of Beverly Hills and the late Mr. Rogers, famous humorist and cowboy philosopher.
A 64-yard touchdown dash by Johnny Chalmers late in the final period enabled Middlebury to defeat the University of Vermont in their State classic today.

The dollar turned soft again in foreign exchange yesterday but finished the week with a substantial gain over its position of a sleek ago. The pound sterling yesterday rose 9-16 cent to $4.98 3/4, at which price it was off 1 3/8 cents from a week ago.

Two stakes were completed today in the second session of the annual field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club. The Derby Stake went to the dog Chesabob, owned by the Dilwyne Kennels of R. R. M. Carpenter Jr. of Montchanin, Del., and handled by Harry T. Conklin of Amagansett, L. I.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's conciliatory tone this week toward "the powers of the Rome-Berlin axis" and the possibility of a visit to Berlin by Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, in the near future show that once more Great Britain is in a mood to negotiate With those who are disturbing her peace of mind.

Plan for home building during the Winter season have been made for Broadlawn Harbour, Kings Point, Great Neck, L. I., according to James M. Curry, president of the Brimar Corporation, builders and developers of the waterfront property.

Announcement has been made by Lieut. Col. Thomas J. Hayes, U.S.A., and Mrs. Hayes of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Hayes, to William P. Brett, son of James H. Brett of Statesboro Ga.

The main ballroom of the Plaza will be the scene on Thursday of a large dinner to be given for Sir Evelyn Wrench, founder of the English-Speaking Union of the British Empire; Lady Wrench and delegates to the annual meeting of the National Council of the EnglishSpeaking Union of the United States.

Chief Justice Duff told legal agents of the Dominion and Provinces today that Jan. 10 had been fixed for a hearing on the validity of the Dominion Government's power to disallow provincial statutes and of a Lieutenant Governor's power to reserve bills for the pleasure of the Governor General.

A seizure of 240,000 lottery tickets of the Monte Carlo Sweepstakes, based on the Grand Prix de Nice to be run March 6, 1938, and the first of its kind in this country, was revealed yesterday with the arraignment of Harry Golden, 42 years old, of 1,398 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, on a charge of aiding in smuggling them here.

After hearing individual opinions from the delegates of the leading powers this morning on the Japanese reply and debating most of this evening the text of the general conference's statement to the world, the nineteen nations assembled here to induce Japan to mediate her conflict with China postponed until Monday its actual adoption.

TO a great many people the twentieth anniversary of the Bolshevist revolution naturally suggests the question: How far has the mentality and outlook of the Russian people been transformed by twenty years of communism?

Launching a passing attack in the final period, Virginia Polytechnic Institute sent Henry across for a touchdown and defeated Virginia today, 14 to 7, in the final home game of the season for the Cavalers.

Councilman Frederick W. Kuechenmeister Jr. died yesterday at his home of a heart ailment. He celebrated his forty-seventh birthday Wednesday. Mr. Kuechenmeister was the first Republican Councilman elected in Carlstadt in seventeen years.

A dinner will be given for Albert B. Hines, director of the Madison Square Boys Club, on Wednesday in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria in recognition of his twenty-five years of service to the club.

Franklin Chase Hoyt, justice of the Children's Court for nearly twenty-years and former chairman of the Federal Alcohol Control Board, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, where he had been a patient for several weeks. He was 61 years old.
Yale's undefeated and untied freshman team ended a great season in a burst of glory today, defeating the Harvard Yearling by 27 to 0 on Soldiers Field.

Yale's blue football banner, soaking and draggled in black mud, was pointed north for Cambridge and Harvard tonight at the head of an undefeated team. Behind, on the floor of the rainsoaked Bowl, was a Princeton team that never had a chance and fought itself out in a hopeless cause and in rain mud and a biting wind.
Hugh Converse, brother of Mrs. Gayle Vincent Strickler, wife of the pastor of the Stanwich Congregational Church here, died last night at his home in Columbus, Ohio, at the age. of 18.
Found guilty of disorderly conduct, twelve persons arrested for participation in "lie-down" demonstrations outside the Horn Hardart Automats at 1,440 Broadway and 455 Seventh Avenue

Full effects of the governmental reforms under Westchester County's new charter will not be felt until 1940, according to Bert C. McCulloch, chairman of a supervisors'. committee which drafted the instrument.
A melting pot of gold and silver of out-dated designs, donated by patronesses of the beneficiary, will be transformed into funds to purchase supplies for the Bellevue Hospital workroom.

Arrests, deportations and executions in Leningrad of leading Finnish and Estonian Communists on charges of espionage and Trotskyism have been so thorough that their organizations have been annihilated, according to a report from Leningrad.
Susquehanna's Crusaders, staging a brilliant offense, led the Roanoke College eleven today until the final period, when Roanoke scored twice to take the game by 14--7.

A large committee of debutantes, some of whose parents have long been interested in the Children's Aid Society, is working toward the success of the benefit performance of "Aida" to be held the night of Dec. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Retailers in the agricultural areas are making more headway in reducing unwieldy inventories than those in industrial centers, and reports here yesterday indicated that many merchants are feeling the effects upon purchasing power of increasing unemployment in the textile, steel and other industrial sections.

A conference of members of the Board of Education, Board of Superintendents, Board of Examiners and other persons interested in conditions relating to the substitute teachers in the New York City public schools will be held tomorrow at 8 P. M., at 500 Park Avenue, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced.

THE Army and Notre Dame squads didn't appear on the field until game time. Probably they were afraid somebody might be drowned in preliminary exercises. A few minutes before the scheduled kick-off, Gar Davidson sent out a scout to survey the field. He was afraid to look himself. One more heavy downpour and he would have turned the assignment over to the Navy.

John Cushing, 11 years old, of 1,442 Webster Avenue, the Bronx, fell five floors to his death about 5:30 P. M. yesterday while trying to help his father, Robert Cushing, a wounded World War veteran. With the aid of his crutches Mr. Cushing had climbed to the roof to fix his radio aerial,

The Amateur Athletic Union tonight moved toward a compromise with the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on the disputed subject of representation on American Olympic Games committees.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that $2,730,275 had been allotted as of last Oct. 31 for aid during this year to Jews in Central and Eastern Europe and other lands.
The appearances of L. M. Ericson B shares carrying identical numbers on the Swedish stock market resulted in the police discovering a big share-hoax.

The Transit Workers Union of America, C. I. O. affiliate, whose demand for recognition as sole bargaining agency for employes on the city's Independent Subway has been rejected by the Board of Transportation, announced yesterday that it would use "all necessary and legal measures" to force such recognition.

After notification from the Colohial Office that the family of Ramsay MacDonald had accepted the suggestion that the former Premier's body lie in state in the cathedral here, the authorities have laid new plans under which the colony will pay homage to the body upon arrival on Monday and departure on Tuesday.

The Department of Agriculture will celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary next week-a life span that has seen it develop from a free-seed distributing agency to an organization directing activities that involve $500,000,000 annual expenditure.
Rowland Rushmore, an end, kicked a 26-yard placement to give Iowa State a 3-to-O victory over Marquette today before 8,000 fans. It was Marquette's fifth straight defeat.

Oklahoma's pass-minded Sooners knocked and knocked at Missouri's goal line for fifty-nine minutes today before the Tiger forward wall yielded a 7-0 victory. Then Quarterback Jack Baer went over from the 1-yard line on the fourth down in the last forty-five seconds.

WHEN spotlights commence to glow at Madison Square Gar den tomorrow night, it will mean that this famous arena will be eady once again, not for a political meeting, a horse show or a prizefight, but for another of New York's popular extravaganzas, a figure-skating carnival.
THIS book about Southern France has nothing to do with the Riviera. It never mentions Biarritz. It has little to say of Arles and Nimes and nothing of Carcassonne.
HOLLYWOOD. THE movie camera, which has always ruled the screen on its own terms, has been as much a tyrant as Procrustes, who shortened his victims to fit the bed.

The New Zealand cricket team surprised Victoria today by concluding its first innings for 218 runs, 'then dismissing the Aussies for 141 in their four-day match. Going in a second time the tourists had lost one wicket for 18 runs when play closed.

The cost ot war has gone up, along with a lot of other things, since nations did their figuring in 1918. If the World War cost an estimated 190,000,000,000--and with interruptions to trade, property destruction and the like, this figure has been added up to $340,000,000,000--it is now apparent,that any war of today on the same scale could boost these figures considerably.
A son was born here to Mr. and Mrs. William M. Agar of Lakewood, N. J., on Tuesday at the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

Maurice HelyHutchinson, retired merchant banker, today was nominated as Conservative candidate in the forthcoming Hastings by-election, caused by the retirement from the House of Commons of Lord Eustace Percy, Conservative.

Dean Ned H. Dearborn of New York University's Division of General Education, predicted in his annual report to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase that adult education would become within the next generation the most important single movement in America, reaching fully 50,000,000 persons, unless adult education leaders failed.
JOHANNESBURG. -- Loafers in the Union of South Africa who will not work to support themselves and their families will soon be committed to work colonies.

Strength in United States Governmen bonds following the announcement of substantial purchases of Treasury obligations by the Federal Reserve, and further weakness in Brazil's dollar loans were the features of an otherwise quiet trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--With the small-game season open, Atlantic City has become headquarters for hundreds of visiting hunters who are tramping the South Jersey woodlands.
Before 1816 members of Congress were paid by the day, at the rate of $6. Now Senators and Representatives are paid $10,000 a year regardless of how many days their sessions last.

A short-wave program to Latin America by students at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute who come from Central and South America will be broadcast from 6 to 7 o'clock Sunday evening, Dec. 12, over General Electric's short-wave stations, W2XAD and W2XAF, in Schenectady.

Larry Hull, Dartmouth football player from Brooklyn, has been elected chief of the Undergraduate Fire Department, one of the oldest organizations in the college. At the same time James Feeley of Cambridge, another football player, was elected foreman.

Under the new set-up made necessary by deferred rushing for fraternities at Colgate University, put in effect for the first time this Fall, officials are working out a new system which will help both freshmen and non-fraternity members to enjoy the benefits of a social program suited to their needs.
A net profit of $611,890 for the first nine months of 1937 was reported yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of Kansas and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Costal Plains Oil Corporation.

Representative Thomas B. Fletcher, Democrat, Ohio, a co-author of the Harrison-Black-Fletcher bill for Harrison-Black-Fletcher bill for Federal aid to education, told the eighty-third annual convention of the New Jersey State Teachers Association today that between 8,000,000 and 9,000,000 persons in this country were handicapped by not having elementary education.

Lee Thompson Smith, general chairman of the rental conditions committee of the Real Estate Board of New York, announced yesterday that an occupancy analysis covering 67,816 elevator apartments in Manhattan from 1924 to February, 1937, had been completed.
BOTH the larger companies have gone to Liszt to find materials for two-record albums.

A survey on working and living conditions among the city's thousands of nurses has been instituted to uncover the facts of the so-called shortage of nurses which has for some time been puzzling hospitals and executives.
Six bearded members of Great Britain's strange back-tonature colony at Laxton threw down their axes and saws and had a bare-knuckle fight with the police on the village green.

Mrs. Leslie Carter, one of the most successful and popular of American actresses, died at her home here today of a heart ailment after a long illness. She was 75 years old. Mrs. Carter's heart ailment was aggravated by pneumonia and her death was not unexpected. With her was her husband, W. L. Payne, her former leading man of the stage, and an adopted daughter, Mary Carter Payne.

WORKS by more than a score of contemporary artists are included in the Second Anniversary Exhibition at the Walker Galleries (till Nov. 27). Doris Lee has produced for the occasion one of her most delightful fantasies, a "Pastoral" full of life and movement.

All divisions of the wholesale market were unusually quiet last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. The little activity that was noted favored evening dresses, sweaters, blouses, millinery, handbags and negligees for holiday selling. The report continues:

Development of a distinctive national architecture and the inoreasing tendency of Europeans to study architecture here prove that America has reached artistic maturity Dean Leopold Arnaud of the Columbia University School of Architecture declared in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday.

The drive in Germany in favor of the return of the Reich's lost colonies has an importance reaching far beyond the colonies them selves. A precedent is created. Though there have been many abandonments and repudiations of provisions of the peace treatieseconomic and strategic-this is the first time that the Nazis have ad vanced a challenge to the geographical settlement.

A special sale of dresses will be held next Saturday at the Nearly New Shop, 917 Eighth Avenue, under the auspices of the Masters School Day Nursery Committee of the shop. Donations from individuals of dresses suitable for resale are being requested by members of the committee.

Governor Lehman will face within a few months the task of filling State positions carrying total annual salaries of about $50,000 because of term expirations, resignations or already existing vacancies.
Appeals will be made In 300 churches in Manha-tan and the Bronx today for membership in and contributions to the American Red Cross. Similar appeals were made in Jewish synagogues yesterday.

The world's admitted exports of arms and ammunition in 1936 totaled $49,282,000 (this figure is based on the value of the dollar before devaluation), according to the League of Nations yearbook on arms traffic, just published.

A marked increase in the number of American private preparatory schools exchanging students with the official National Socialist boarding schools, called National Political Education Institutes, is represented here as another victory for National Socialism over foreign prejudice.
AN odd little piece, "Yes and No," by Kenneth Horne, aims at the popular target that was hit by "French Without Tears" and "George and Margaret."
The University of California's undefeated football team trounced the University of Oregon, 26 to 0, today in their Pacific Coast Conference game played on a muddy, rainswept field.

A Northwestern forward pass that backfired for a 53-yard Minnesota gain set the stage for a 7-to-0 Golden Gopher victory today, putting the latter team within one game of undisputed possession of the 1937 Big Ten title. A crowd of 63.000 saw the battle.

" An annual aviation award of merit to the American newspaper man who develops the best-informed writing in the dissemination of air information" is to be made Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., John B. Walker, vice president of the company, announced yesterday.

With many communities mobilized as in war days, the United States is preparing to take a census of unemployed and partially unemployed throughout the country on Tuesday. The census is the idea of Congress.

RETAIL trade might have held barely even with a year ago last week, and perhaps the average for the country was a little under 1936. The South Atlantic States reported gains and a small increase was indicated for the Middle West. Industrial districts were hit, however, by reduced employment.

Two adventure vessels are lying alongside historic Wharf 5 here, making ready for trips into far waters. One is the thirty-seven-foot ketch Naomi, on the first lap of a trip round the world. Her skipper, Charles Cox, young English writer, reached Boston from Shelburne, N. S., after running through heavy seas.
EACH year authors. illustrators and publishers of books for young people are increasingly busy: the presses roll and behold! a fresh and still larger crop of books for the young.

Homer D. Williams, one of Andrew Carnegie's ablest lieutenants and former president of both the Carnegie Steel Corporation and the Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, died today in the University of Maryland Hospital at Baltimore.
The New York Americans will play their first home game of the young National Hockey League season tonight, when they skate against the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden.
Trinity skidded, slid and slipped on Trinity Field to a top-heavy victory over the Norwich eleven today in the final game of the season. The score was 51 to 0.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow:

Howard Smith, diminutive Ursinus halfback, ran wild today, scoring two touchdowns for the Grizzlies as his team triumphed, 15-6, over a disappointing Gettysburg team in an Eastern Pennsylvania Conference game on Memorial Field before a huge Father's Day crowd.
THOUGH Hollywood occupies a deserved eminence as the world's most pixilated community, it has been, practically from its foundation, without a certified public pixie.

Young Josh Hackenburg today attributed his father's death to a "huckleberry feud" which, he said, has kept the rugged Jackson Mountain folk at odds for twenty years. They have been quarrelling, he explained, ever since his mother refused to sell to a member of another family some huckleberries she had picked in the mountains.

IT was along in July that Bayard Veiller was saying he would leave California, and, as people do when they take that step, he sounded pretty determined about it. He was going back to his Connecticut farm to do two plays.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Padmore of this place for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Padmore, to William L. Saylor, son of Mrs. Phoebe T. Saylor, also of Westfield.

Boys at Jackson Training School near Concord will have opportunity to learn the textile industry and at the same time make goods for use by students, according to an announcement made at the annual convention of the North Carolina Cotton Manufacturers Association at Pinehurst.

Frederick William Carlin Jr., an employee in the Department of Education in Brooklyn and a brother of Colonel Walter Jeffreys Carlin, a member of the Board of Education, died on Friday in his home at 235 Ninety-second Street, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. He was 48 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Griswold Ely of this place and Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Collins Ely, to Philip Page Johnston, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. Selden Johnston of Lyme, Conn.

VISIONS are nothing new to the man whose task it is to translate the New Deal's most ambitious dream into reality. James Delmage Ross has made banana plants and palm trees flourish amid the eternal snows of the Cascade Mountains and for many years he has confidently prophesied the sending of electric power through the ether like radio waves. Practically all his life Mr.

The birthday of Miss Nancy Leiter, who became 21 years old today, was the occasion for a dinner and dance given in her honor by her mother, Mrs. Joseph Leiter, at her home. Eighty young persons were invited to dinner.

Ignoring the hard luck part of the story, Elmer Layden, the quiet-spoken coach of the victorious Notre Dame eleven-or should it be thirty-six--declared after the game yesterday that "we had a lot of good luck to win."

THE ultimate utility of flying boats and dirigibles in transoceanic passenger service was given new recognition last week when the Maritime Commission in its official report on the status of the shipping industry pointed out that aerial vessels will have to be taken into account in any future plans by the government.

By appointing Earle R. Lewis, for many years box-office treasurer at the Metropolitan Opera House, an assistant general manager, the board of directors conferred authority on him which his colleagues and superiors, Edward Johnson and Edward Ziegler, have been asking him to shoulder in the past two seasons.

On my return to London from British East Africa, I may now relate another chapter of horror that has just been written in the story of Ethiopia. Wild beasts have set upon and made prey of remnants of the Lion of Judah's loyal followers,

PFITZNER'S "Palestrina," that eternity of dullness and desolation, has just been restored to the Staatsoper under Bruno Walter. The production reflects credit on virtually every one concerned -- particularly on Mr. Walter and on Dr. Otto Erhardt, whose stage direction of this interminable and dreary business is truly a labor of love.

Open war on syphilis was declared in a resolution adopted today by the nearly 100 representatives of student newspapers of twenty-six colleges and universities of the Middle Atlantic States attending the convention of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association at Lehigh University.

A dance under the auspices of the Alumnae of St. Catharine's Academy will be held the night of Dec. 4 in the Plaza Grill of the Plaza for the benefit of the philanthropic work of the organization. The funds realized will be used to aid needy young women in continuing their education.

Discoveries this season in Maya ruins by archaeologists of the University of Pennsylvania Museum led today to the advancement of a theory that a violent social upheaval may have contributed heavily to the decline of the more ancient Maya culture.
FRATERNAL: "You've got to be in something or you can't get anywhere," Senator James J. Davis of Pennsylvania once told a Knights of

The American Guards, a student group formed, according to their petition, to combat subversive elements and limiting its membership to "Aryans" and members of the Christian faith, yesterday failed to get the right to operate at City College.

The anthracite industry appointed a joint committee yesterday representing the miners and the operators to confer with Federal and Pennsylvania State authorities on legislation for the stabilization of the industry.
President Ignaz Moscicki received today a delegation from the Socialist party and the Federation of Labor which submitted a memorandum on the political situation.
The Official Gazette said today that all noncommissioned officers and men of the 1908 and 1909 army classes were being called back for military training in eight districts.

COLLECTORS are always keen for new discoveries in their field of interest, especially if they lead to establishing the identity of makers, dating their pieces more accurately, or confirming historical traditions which create association value.

Tulana had an advantage in the statistics table but Georgia won the football game, 7-6, today before 12,000. Held to a net gain of four yards from scrimmage, the battered Bulldogs scrambled to an upset victory on a 37-yard punt return by a sophomore, Vassa Cate,
S. L. Smith, who was appointed by the late Julius Rosenwald to direct the program of the fund Mr. Rosenwald created for public schools for Negroes in the South, has announced his retirement.
AMERICAN artists came to the fore in large numbers last week and, massed for action, furnish the current bill at both the Whitney Museum and the Museum of Modern Art.

Led by Andy Farkas, hard-running halfback, who returned to the line-up after a week's idleness because of an injury, the University of Detroit routed North Dakota, 40 to 0, in an intersectional football game today. A crowd of 9,000 watched the battle through a steady drizzle.
THIS translation from the French, "The Captain Had a Wife." is a novel of tragic strength executed in a trenchant style that is seldom brilliant but is always completely adequate.

The downfall of the previously unbeaten swimming team of Theodore Roosevelt High School marked the weekly series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the Public School Athletic League, held yesterday in the 25-yard De Witt Clinton pool.
BROWN--GREENWALD--Minna G., daughter of Mrs. Greenwald and the late A. 4. Greenwald of New York, to Daniel P. Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Brown of New York, taking place Nov. 14, 1937.

The Springfield College football team lost its seventh straight game to New Hampshire, 14-6, on a rainswept gridiron today. After a scoreless first half, in which the visiting Wildcats lost four scoring opportunities, they opened up with a brilliant forward passing attack to push over two touchdowns. in the third period to clinch the game.

One hundred attended the hunt breakfast given today at the Radnor Hunt Club by Mr. and Mrs. R. Stockton White for Miss Barbara Lucas. Because of heavy rains the hunt was canceled and guests remained at the clubhouse for dancing and music.

ONE of the first letters reporting reception of the General Electric Company's ultra-short wave transmitter W2XOY, atop the State Office Building, Albany, N. Y. upset existing theories that the tiny waves are quasi optical and are limited to a radius of about twenty-five miles.

Government Secret Service agents said today that the Rev. Sophrony Balaban, suspended pastor of the Holy Trinity Serbian Eastern Orthodox Church, had signed a statement in which he admitted he once had harbored members of a counterfeiting ring.

The suggestion that something ought to be done about liberating the Soviet Ukraine reappeared here in no less a newspaper than The Voelkischer Beobachter, chief organ of the National Socialist party. The article, unsigned and not prominently displayed, occupied two-thirds of a

The engagement of Miss Helen F. Brady, sister of Gilbert J. Brady of Caldwell and daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John A. Brady, to Edgar B. Lacey, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. E. Lacey of Jersey City, has beeh announced.

There is to be a fashion show and bridge party at the Viking next Thursday afternoon for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society. It has been arranged by a group of the daughters of the army and navy officers attached to the Newport stations.

Carrying the endorsement of President Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia, the fourth annual "Night of Stars" production will be held on Wednesday evening at Madison Square Garden under the auspices of the United Palestin Annppeal.

Constant demand from childless families for children to adopt has necessitated an investigation of the various procedures governing child placement, according to the Child Welfare League of America, which embarked last week on a nationwide study of all the elements involved with the object of providing better safeguards for child, parents and foster parents.

The annual honors day convocation of the College of New Rochelle, citing twenty-five students for special scholastic attainment during the year 1936-37 will be held on the campus of the college on Thursday morning.

RECENT events have made Europeans increasingly aware that their destinies may be affected by war in the Far East, by the temperature of Wall Street or by the mood of the Mississippi Valley, as well as by the military-diplomatic game being played upon their own continent.

Mrs. H. Schuyler Cammann heads the group arranging for the annual card party and tea for the benefit of the Church women's League for Patriotic Service which will take place tomorrow in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
George Washington University lassoed the Bisons from North Dakota today to brand the invaders with a 33-to-0 defeat in a muddy football spectacle.
England won the rubber in the three-game Rugby series with Australia by turning in its second straight victory today before a crowd of 30,000.

Playing in a driving rain, Tufts and Bowdoin battled to a scoreless tie at Tufts Oval today. The game was chiefly a punting duel and so closely were the teams matched that neither made a first down until the second half.

THE music section of the local Teatro del Popolo opened its seventeenth concert season at the conservatory some days ago with a symphony program by the Scala Orchestra under Gino Marinuzzi, whose own creative contribution was his rhapsody, "Sicania."

The following WPA Federal Art Project exhibitions are on view this week: Public School 208, Avenue B and Fortyeighth Street Brooklyn-Posters, "History of Civic Service." Post Graduate Hospital, Pediatric Clinic (downstairs), Twentieth Street and Second Avenue--Children's paintings. A. W. P. R. A. Council, 235 Seventh Avenue--Children's paintings.
Whistling in from the Atlantic, a coastal storm battered the metropolitan area yesterday morning, with the wind reaching a velocity of fifty miles an hour a little before noon.

Opposition to the elections which the government plans to hold on Feb. 15 for the partial renovation of the House of Representatives, was voiced tonight by a joint manifesto signed by ex-President Mario G. Menocal's new Democratic.Republican party, a popular revolutionary block formed by various small groups, and the Republican party of ex-President Miguel Mariano Gomez.

The word most descriptive of the current changes in higher education is probably "differentiation," the attempt to provide education differing for each individual according to his capacity, Dean Bernice Brown Cronkhite of the Graduate School of Radcliffe College told the Radcliffe Club of New York at its meeting Friday evening.

Like the pelting rain that bathed all those present, Andover kept driving constantly in Plimpton Stadium today and finally succeeded in defeating its old rival, Exeter, 20 to 15. But its victory probably will long be a subject of debate.

Miss Betty Scott Clark, daughter of Mrs. Scott Clark of Spring House, Wynnewood, and of Walter Scott Clark Jr. of New York, has completed plans for her marriage on Nov. 26 to John Wesley Cullen, son of Mrs. Edward E. Cullen Jr. of Rosemont.

Encouragement of credit expansion again has become the primary objective of Federal Reserve policy, it appeared. last Week, when the weekly statement of the system disclosed that $10,400,000 of Treasury bills had been added to its holdings of government securities.

Expressing the view that the present business recession will be short,Dr. Benjamin Haggott -Beckhart, Associate Professor of Banking at the Columbia University School of Banking, predicted yesterday a building boom accompanied by rising rents inhe near future.

The Brussels conference is back where it started from. When it met it had ample indication from Tokyo that Japan would not attend the meeting, called under the Nine-power treaty. Now Japan has refused formally twice to take part in the negotiations and the prospect of the parley bringing about mediation between Tokyo and Nanking has reached the point of disappearance.

The first benefit matinee performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which will aid the Neighborhood Music School, has a large patronage among members of society and the musical world. It will be held on Dec. 10 and the presentation will be Wagner's opera, "Tristan und Isolde," with Kirsten Flagstad and Lauritz Melchior in the leading roles.

An immediate and well-earned success was scored by Orrea Pernel, English violinist, at her local debut recital given in Town Hall last night. Miss Pernel proved herself an excellently schooled artist.
by the Hippodrome Opera Company at the Hippodrome last night before an audience of 5,000 persons.

Stanford's Indians, reaching peak form after early season defeats, crushed Washington State's Cougars, 23 to 0, today. Some 15,000 fans saw the Stanford attack begin clicking midway in the second quarter, when Carl Littlefield, Washington State fullback, fumbled to give Stanford the ball 11 yards from the goal line.

Scoring four touchdowns, Sid White romped off with the major share of honors as the Brooklyn Fort Hamilton eleven, 44-0, on mudsoaked Erasmus Field yesterday. White made runs of 35, 40, 60 and 90 yards.
The Smith College Community Chest drive has officially closed, having raised about $4,500 to date. The drive has been under the direction of Dorothy Moore, '38, of New York since Nov. 3.

An extensive industrial improvement involving about five blocks of old one-story brick buildings in Brooklyn, formerly used for warehouse and storage purposes, has been started by the Bush Terminal Company.

AHEARN--Suddenly, on Nov. 11, Elizabeth Atwell. beloved wife of the late John F. Abearn and loving mother of Mrs. William 3. Murray, William J. Ahearn, Mrs. Elizabeth Hood. Mrs. Howard P. Keady. and the late Thomas J. and Edward J. Ahearn,. Funeral from her residence,

A campaign to improve the speech at New York City's army of teachers and public school children, through the aid of voice recording machines, will be undertaken hero within the next few weeks, Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners, disclosed yesterday.
Friends of Lawrence Hall, a voluntary group contributing money to preserve the Williams College Art Museum, has been started here during the past week by faculty and undergraduates of the college.

ONE day at the end of this week or the beginning of next a young man named Sidney Harmon will board a train at Grand Central Station, wave good-bye to Manhattan and thus "end" a career as a theatrical producer which began way, way back in 1929.

THIS week the Autumn rush of Dew plays has brought us a new Bernstein and a new Lenormand. "Pacifique," the Lenormand piece, is hardly what one would have expected from this author, and falls into line neither with his subtle studies of morbid psychology nor with his excursions into poetic legend.

The junior class at Mount Holyoke College won the annual Fall sports competition today, amassing the largest number of points in the field day and horse show events. Next was the sophomore class, with 8 points against the juniors' 13.

The "ever-normal granary" plan will be one of the important issues before the special session of Congress opening this week. In the following article the proposal is explained and the agricultural future of the country discussed.
In a game that saw both teams fumble away apparent touchdowns, Bucknell ended its football season today by holding a favored Temple University eleven to a scoreless tie before a crowd of 6,000.
Alan Johnsen's letter in the radio section of THE TIMES of Sunday, Oct. 24, concerning symphony programs, brings to mind the reactions of my wife and myself regarding this subject.

The extra session of Congress opening Monday will be the twenty-fourth in the nation's history. Predecessors of Franklin D. Roosevelt have called special sessions to meet three kinds of emergencies-war or the effects of war, depression or financial panic, and need of aid for agriculture or industry.

Dr. Milan Stoyadinovitch, Yugoslav Prime Minister, is fighting, apparently successfully, a series of rear-guard actions against the Orthodox Bishops, on the one hand, and the Croatian and Serbian advocates of federalism and democracy, on the other.

Roy R. Sherid, athlete and former member of the New York Yankees, has been named director of activities for the Timber Trails Association, according to the Robert E. Farley Organization, developers of Timber Trails at Sherman, Conn.

ON June 2, 1902, ship-owner Ralph C., Emery called at the offices of the Boston Insurance Company and made a puzzling request. Puzzling because there was no precedent. The request was not, as usual, for insurance on a ship or a cargo.

Miss Rosemary Fee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Fee of Brooklyn, heads the junior committee for the performance of the musical comedy "Seven Chances," to be presented under the auspices of the Auxiliary of St. Angela Hall Academy Thursday night at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn.
A resourceful Furman Purple hurricane scored twice today when opportunity knocked and defeated the South Carolina Gamecocks, 12 to 0, before an estimated crowd of 7,000.

Official records of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association for the season of 1937 have been compiled by F. Fitzmaurice K ly, veteran cricket authority and secretary of that organization.
Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer M. Singer 0gave a reception and tea yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's after the Army-Notre Dame football game at the Yankee Stadium.

A break gave Notre Dame its touchdown set-up at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and the South Benders then spent the rest of the afternoon proving that it was no accident. Six times more the victors stormed down into scoring territory and six times Army, fighting frantically against overwhelming odds, rose in its might to turn aside the threats.

Price-cutting in the liquor market in New Jersey and Connecticut has run its course and Scotch prices in both those markets will remain steady through the holiday season, importers and wholesalers asserted here yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Tepper of 669 West Front Street, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Marjorie Tepper, to Dr. Harry L. Glass of Plainfield, son of Mrs. Max Glass of Carteret. N. J.

Goals by Richardson and Gallagher gave Williams a 2-to-1 soccer victory over a previously undefeated Amherst team today. In gaining the Little Three soccer crown the Purple recorded the first triumph over the Sabrinas in seven years.

EVERYDAY THINGS IN AMERICAN LIFE, 1607-1776. By William Chauncy Langdon. Illustrated. 353 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $3. THE story of the everyday things in American life is the story of the men and women who built America: not the story of individuals, except in a few outstanding cases, but the story of the people in their everyday tasks, domesticities, ambitions and progress.

Available real estate appraisal data, their economic and social significance and the need for additional types of reliable data in the future will be discussed at a national appraisal forum to be held at the Mayflower Hotel, Washington, D. C. Friday-and Saturday.
JOHN MASEFIELD is making an increasing number of public addresses, and in some of them he is developing a vein of delightful humorous satire.

Miss Hilda Ruth Geiger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Geiger of East Orange and Philip James Bowers 2d, son of Frederick J. Bowers of East Orange, were married this morning in the chapel of St. Anne Villa Convent.

Students at Cornell University have encircled the globe in arriving at Ithaca this year, according to Registrar E. F. Bradford, who made public today the geographical distribution of the campus population.

Mayors and their aides, numbering 400 from 150 cities, representing nearly one-third of the country's population, will gather here Monday at the annual United States Conference of Mayors to discuss problems they share with the Federal government. Among the topics to be considered are:
