The second concert of this season's students' series of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was given at Carnegie Hall last night. John Barbirolli conducted. John Corigliano, the orchestra's accomplished assistant concertmaster, was the soloist.

In thirteen months no child has been killed on Kansas City's streets in traffic, chiefly because of an educational campaign that has encompassed children, parents, and drivers of all forms of transportation.
Many of the school football games scheduled yesterday in New York City and the surrounding areas of Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey were postponed because of the inclement weather.
Reviewing the results of the apartment renting season which has just closed, Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., reported that activity was higher than during the same period last year.

AMONG the least apparent, but perhaps the most important, changes in the 1938 automo biles is the trend toward almost complete elimination of driving fatigue. Design changes are easily noted. Increased length and greater roominess are obvious, but when it comes to measuring "improved riding" one must take the salesman's word for it or be convinced by a demonstration.

More than 100 persons attended the annual dinner for the New York Athletic Club baseball team last night at the Winged Foot's clubhouse at Travers Island. Frankie Frisch, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, presented the prizes to the players rewarded for their services during the season.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is among the sponsors of the concert to be given on Saturday at Carnegie Hall to assist Chrystie Street House at which Elisabeth Rethberg, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, will make her first local appearance of the season.
The State Department made public the following text of the statement by Norman H. Davis, to the Brussels conference:
Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha disclosed today that Egypt's rearmament program is being speeded up and her entire defense system reorganized and strengthened.

Mrs. Henry V. Raymond, who heads the committee for the annual card party and tea for the benefit of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, will give a tea on Thursday at her home, 461 East Sixteenth Street, for the group of women serving with her.

WHEN the Curtis Institute Orchestra appears, under Fritz Reiner, at Josef Hofmann's Golden Jubilee concert, Nov. 28, at the Metropolitan Opera House, it will be augmented for the occasion by the entire Curtis Institute Orchestra faculty and also by twenty-nine Curtis graduates who are members of leading symphony orchestras of this country.
Great Britain today prepared a state reception for King Leopold of Belgium, who arrives Tuesday on what was described as a "very important" mission.

Postal authorities reported yesterlay that all was in readiness for he distribution in this city on Tueslay of 3,500,000 unemployment cenbus report cards, as part of the national effort to establish the lumber of totally or partly unemployed persons who are able and willing to work.

THE serious, middle-aged men who sell the bottled sunshine of the French vineyards are all in Beaune today. From all over the world, dealers, experts and connoisseurs have flocked to Beaune for the annual auction of the new season's wines at the old hospital of St. Esprit.
The country's "cotton problem" will come into prominence again with the convening tomorrow of the special session of Congress that has been called principally to hasten farm legislation.

Physicians for Basil (Pat) Ryan, New York copper heir, continued today to deny visitors access to his room in a local hospital which he entered eight days ago, less than twelve hours after marrying a 21year-old Morgantown girl.

The issue of government-in-medicine, long a matter of controversy among doctors, was plunged last week into the arena of public debate when a group of 430 outstanding American physicians joined in demanding that the government help provide for medical research, medical education, hospitals and the treatment of the poor.

Mr. and Mrs. William Barnes of 218 Lakeside Avenue, this community, will celebrate their sixtyfourth wedding anniversary with a family gathering at their home here Thursday of next week. For thirteen years they have lived with their son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. James Barnes.

Donald Ogden Stewart, writer, 42 years old, was seriously injured today when he was hit by an automobile at a Hollywood Boulevard intersection. At the hospital to which he was taken he was found to have multiple lacerations of the head and a possible basal skull fracture.
France will repay the British loan of [pound]40,000,000 due in December, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet announced tonight. He stated that it would be repaid in full between Dec. 2 and Dec. 26.

One of the higher ambitions of the New Deal is dead, and there was none to mourn. The wailing that attended the passing of the poor little pigs, and the loud laments at the cotton and wheat plowed under, did not follow the bier of this finer New Deal vision, a dream of American culture.

Members of the Class of 1940 at Georgian Court College, in addition to participation and leadership in sports and extra-curricular projects, broke a long standing tradition this week with the announcement that they would sponsor "The Pine Tree Ball," class social, before the scheduled functions of their Junior and senior classmates.

The petition of Senator L??r H. Clee, defeated Republican candidate for Governor, for a recount of approximately 300,000 ballots in Hudson County was granted this morning by Chief Justice Thomas J. Brogan of the Supreme Court.

Vassar College will play host to the second meeting of the World Youth Congress, Aug. 18 to 26. The invitation to the congress, extended by President Henry N. MacCracken, has been accepted by the committee on arrangements.

THIS miniature "Jane's" makes no pretense to "Jane's" wealth of technical information or completeness of detail, but it summarizes in concise form the characteristics of the world's men-of-war and presents a great mass of other naval information.

Chester C. Davis, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, declared here today that the current business recession was only a temporary period of readjustment. The formerAAA head, addressing the Southwestern Bankers Convention, said:

A luxurious lightweight streamlined train, first of its general type to be built for a railroad in this area, soon will be streaking over the rails between New York and Philadelphia as the latest equipment of the Reading Company's system.

One of the weirdest "fashion shows" New Yorkers ever saw originated a succession of corrective impulses which today are flourishing on behalf of the municipality, parallel to the consumer awareness behind the campaign for fiber identification sponsored by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

The annual Autumn festival, under the auspices of the woman's board of the Church Charity Foundation of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, will take place on Wednesday and Thursday at the Home for the Aged, 452 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn.

Beginning this afternoon and continuing through the middle of next May, a series of special lectures will be given on alternate Sunday afternoons at 3 o'clock in the lecture room of the Frick Collection, 1 East Seventieth Street.

In celebration of the fortieth anniversary of Madison House, a settlement center, a series of benefit events will be held this Winter, the first of these to be a tea dance on Dec. 5 at Le Coq Rouge under the aegis of the junior board.

With the staging of an actual trial in the auditorium of the Washington Irving High School tomorrow evening, the League of Women Voters will complete its program designed to take the guesswork out of women's first jury experience. The meeting will be open to the public.

The Canadiens staged a third-period rally tonight to gain a 5-2 victory over the world champion Red Wings, their rivals last Spring in the play-offs for the National Hockey League championship. A crowd of about 5,500 saw the match.

The annual Autumn tea under the auspices of the affiliated alumnae of the Sisters of Charity of New York will take place next Saturday in the Cardinal Hayes Auditorium of the College of Mount St. Vincent-on-Hudson.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 11: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Hake, H. F., San Diego, Calif., to Asiatic Station. Rupert, J. F., the Omaha, to Navy Yard, Portsmouth, N. H.
Reveling in the rain and muddy going, a high-geared Manhattan football machine uncovered hitherto a hidden power at Ebbets Field yesterday to turn back a good North Carolina State eleven, 15 to 0.

THIS most useful and important and almost exemplary book on Marlowe declares everything that scholars know of him today and adds a few items that Mr. Bakeless has been able to discover from the Corpus Christi buttery records of Marlowe as a student.
For forty-five minutes today Dartmouth and Cornell wallowed in the mire of Memorial Field, like two unwieldly army tanks marooned in deep mud.

Samuel Davis of 1,237 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, father of Edward H. Davis, publisher of trade papers in the tobacco, radio and sweet foods fields, died on Friday in Israel Zion Hospital, Brooklyn, after an injury to his hip suffered two weeks ago. His age was 88.

The conviction that China would survive the present invasion of her territory as she had survived all previous conquerors was expressed last night by Dr. Chengting T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to Washington, and Dr. James T. Shotwell,

IT has been pointed out that although Constable "had hundreds of English imitators in the nineteenth century who produced countless pastiches of his elaborated second versions" the painter's real contribution, nevertheless, "was not understood in England until the French Romantics and Impressionists had familiarized English spectators with this type of art."*

John Montague and Babe Ruth, erstwhile home-run king of the Yankees, will pair with Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson, former Olympic star, now in golf promotion work, and Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, former women's New York State champion, in an eighteen-hole exhibition Scotch foursome match on the Fresh Meadow links, near Flushing, today.

Family marketers are watching the price fluctuations of Thanksgiving turkey the way a stock broker watches quotations on the ticker tape. But they can rest easy. Turkey is considered a very good buy at 38 cents a pound, and the price is not expected to go up before the big day.

For the first time in the history of New York City cats and mice meet formally in a peaceful program (separated by screens, of course) on Nov. 19 and 20 in the Port of New York Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.
A powerful and tricky Marshall College eleven kept its season slate clean today by vanquishing the University of Cincinnati Bearcats, 28 to 0, in a Buckeye Conference game today.

MAXENCE VAN DER MEERSCH, though only 30, is already the author of seven novels and the winner of the Goncourt Prize. "Hath Not the Potter," his third book to be translated into English, differs greatly from its predecessors.
Mr. and Mrs. Oscar F. Neu of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Elizabeth Neu, to Leon Ellis Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis E. Jones of Joliet, Ill.
THE foreign invasion which, in a minor phase, provoked Congressional discussion few seasons back, has been revived on a scale hitherto unknown in the industry.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified that Nov. 19 has been designated the record date for a regular semi-annual dividend of 75 cents and a special dividend of 50 cents a share, payable on Dec. 1 to registered stockholders of the International Petroleum Company, Ltd. It has ruled that the registered stock be not quoted ex-dividend until Nov. 30.

Mrs. Henry DeWitt Smith will give a tea at her home here on Thursday to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Smith. The debutante will be assisted by the Misses Jane Craig, Patricia Rowland, Garoline Stuart and Elsie Foster, her cousin, all of Plainfield, Cecile Fernandez of Havana, Lilian Hall of Grand Rapids, Mich., Clare Haddoch of New York and Emmy Haggin of Lexington, Ky.

From the fruit orchards and cedar brakes of North Texas to the mesquite grazing lands of San Antonio the "army on wheels," comprising 9,200 men,1,108 vehicles and more than 1,000 tons of equipment and supplies, rolled 326 miles to this city today in 12 hours and 55 minutes, making the greatest motorized march in American military history.

The government is requesting bids for a $10,000,000 highway system throughout the country. The program will include the PanAmerican Highway, roads between Managua and Matagalpa and a highway between the Atlantic coast and the interior.

While upland game shooting in New Jersey on opening day we were surprised as well as apprehensive at the number of new "No Trespassing" signs on woods and fields that previously provided good shoot ing for any hunter.

Enveloped in army blankets and vari-colored waterproof garments, high-ranking officers of the army, society notables, distinguished churchmen and college professors viewed the Army-Notre Dame football classic at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, regardless of the rain.

The largest collection in the country of first-hand data on life in the CCC camps is now in the files of the University of Illinois. At present about 1,400 CCC units are regularly sending copies of newspapers and magazines published in the camps to the university library.
The oldtime Southern Methodist aerial circus, revived for a few minutes by a sophomore, made the fall of mighty Baylor complete today in a 13-7 triumph.
Before crowd of 5,000 rain-soaked people the St. Lawrence University eleven beat their traditional rivals, Clarkson Tech, 6 to 0, today.

With a building volume so far this year of close to .$10,000,000, Miami Beach, Fla., is experiencing its greatest expansion for any one year since 1926, according to C. H. W. Read, a Miami Beach real: estate broker.

French seventeenth and eighteenth century and Brussels Renaissance tapestries, gold boxes mounted with miniatures, tapestry and needlepoint furniture are the main groups in the collection of Mme. Annette Lefortier of Paris to be sold at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Saturday afternoon.

Japan's conquest of Shanghai last week did more than strike a serious blow at China. It brought up international complications because of the existence of foreign rights and claims in the captured city.

The Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues, which numbers among its members such distinguished scientists as Drs. Goodwin Watson, G. W. Hartmann and Gardner Murphy (all of Columbia), Dr. I. Krechevsky (University of Chicago) and Dr. E. C. Tolman (University of California), celebrated Armistice Day by sending out a manifesto denying that war is a psychological necessity.

The second annual all-army service football game will take place this afternoon, when the Fort Jay eleven of Governors Island clashes at Ebbets Field with the combination representing Fort Hoyle. Opening ceremonies will begin at 1 o'clock and the game is scheduled to begin an hour later.

Miss Charlotte McLaughlin is chairman of the executive committee that has arranged a card party for the benefit of Anthonian Hall, a home for blind women in Brooklyn, which will take place next Saturday at the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.
ASHEVILLE, N. C.--It's sorghum-making time in the mountains of Western North Carolina. Sorghum-making in community mills is one of the few industries that modern inventions have not affected.

MR. KLEP'S beautiful book has the rare distinction of being something new. It is, to be sure, based on the well-known principle that interest in history is kindled by great personalities, and. as we know, ever since the days when Newberry was publishing his little volumes for children. in St. Paul's Churchyard. there have been many compilations in brief of the lives of great characters in history.

King Carol today asked Ion Mihalache, leader of the National Peasant party, to form a new Cabinet conditional on his agreeing to cooperation with former Premier Alexander Vaida-Voevod, leader of the Nationalist front and himself a one-time prominent member of the National Peasant party.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Bartfeld of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Bartfeld, to Samuel Lawrence Kleinman, also of this city.

Madison Square Garden was packed last night by 20,000 members and sympathizers of the Communist party of New York State who celebrated the twentieth anniversary of the Soviet Union. Several thousand others were turned away before the meeting began.

Rear Admiral William G. Du Bose revealed today that the navy is making plans for warship construction beyond the present program, the most extensive in American peace-time history. Plans are being prepared "in anticipation of possible new building programs,"

The Church E. Gates Co.'s lumber yard property, bounded by the East River, Tiffany Street, Oak Point Avenue, Leggett Avenue and the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad tracks in the Bronx, will be sold under foreclosure in an action brought by the Mortgage Commission of the State of New York and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company to satisfy a judgment of $1,302,222.

GERMANY has abandoned the inefficiency - for - employment's-sake technique with which it started out to build its now famous system of so-called "autoways." The network of doubletrack express highways has completely outgrown its employment project stage. Disappearing unemployment, the motorization campaign, threats of war and strained finances have combined to force the Third Reich to employ all available engineering talent to get the job done at a minimum of expense and at maximum speed.

Miss Helen Ewald Autenrieth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Autenrieth of this place, will be married to John G. D. Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Stewart of New York, on Nov. 27 at the Hotel Pierre in New York.

The Blair Academy eleven triumphed over its old rival, Peddie, in their annual classic today, 6-0. Despite rain and mud, the contest was brilliantly played, with the visitors making a courageous fight of it all the way.

Wisconsin's last chance of sharing in the Western Conference football championship was lost today in a 7-7 tie with Purdue. A crowd of 23,000, held below expectations by unfavorable weather, watched the Boilermakers and the Badgers concentrate their scoring thrusts in the second period and then seesaw back and forth in a wide-opan style of play.

The Bird Fanciers Association will hold its third annual bird exhibition next Saturday and Sunday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Admission will be free. Among the song canaries to be exhibited will be the chopper, the roller and the warbler. The warbler combines the common, loud song of the chopper with the softer and more refined song of the roller.

Senator Robert J. Bulkley, Democrat, of Ohio, announced today that he planned to introduce in the special session of Congress amendments to the undistributed profits tax "to ease the burden on smaller corporations and eliminate restrictions on business expansion."

TRIAL AND ERROR. By Anthony Berkeley. 351 pp. New York: Doubleday, Doran Co. $2.50. ROM the opening sentence, "The sanctity of human life has been much exaggerated," this novel goes on to tell a completely unconventional story of murder. The central character is Mr. Todhunter, who has been told by his own physician and by two eminent specialists that he has at most only a few months to live.

FROM the Dodge farmhouse in the Eighties you could look out. over acres and acres of "bonanza" country, all rolling, not with little hills or trees with their swaying branches, but with solid miles of wheat.

MODEL - BUILDING fans change their hobbies according to the seasons. At the first nip of Winter yachts and airplanes are packed away and hobbyists start building complex railway systems within the space of a suitcase.

Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Scharfman of Wadley, Ga., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Fanny Scharfman, to Leon P. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Cohen of New Rochelle.

Dr. Ramon Castroviejo of Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, who was one of the first to transplant corneas from dead embryos to living eyes that needed repairing, is gilding and platinizing corneas to improve vision. Ask him about his work and he will deprecate it chiefly because he was not the first to think of the principle.
Mrs. Katherine Mackay O'Brien, daughter of Clarence Mackay, received a divorce today at Carson City from Kenneth O'Brien, judge of the New York Supreme Court, on the ground of mental cruelty.

RADIO program planners have always been puzzled on when and where to insert commercial announcements. It is also a riddle how many minutes Should be devoted to the "talk"; the sponsors wonder how long they can discuss themselves and their

TOO MANY HEROES--Tomorrow evening at the Hudson Theatre. A play by Mr. Dore Schary which tells of mob violence in the Southwest. In it are James Bell, Shirley Booth, Elspeth Eric, Clyde Franklin, Miss Leslie Bingham, Richard Keene, Ftancis Pierlot and Joseph Sweeney.
Stocks closed irregular but steady; turnover, 509,550 shares. United States Government bonds higher, corporation bonds firm, Brazilian issues down; transactions, $4,014,375.
The New York Aggies' were defeated today by the Hartwick College eleven, 19-0. Holly, Monahan and DePalma each scored touchdowns and Savino accounted for one point after touchdown.

Many luncheons, dinners, dances and receptions were given today and this evening in connection with the biennial visit here of the Princeton eleven, Yale's oldest gridiron rival. Another event was the joint glee club concert of the two universities.

President Manuel Azafia, visiting radrid today for the first time since the siege started, broadcast to all Spain tonight a plea in defense of the republic and republican institutions. It was an answer and challenge not only to the fascism of the Rebels but to the radicalism of the Anarchists and Communists.

TWELVE new radio bands have been set aside by the Federal Communications Commission for airport control under the current allocation of radio frequencies, it was learned from Edward L. White, commission engineer in charge of aeronautical problems.

A meeting in connection with the membership enrollment campaign of the Seeing Eye will take place on Tuesday at the home of Mrs. William Hale Harkness, 71 East Seventy-first Street, co-chairman of enrollment with Mrs. J. Hampton Barnes Jr.
The annual military ball in aid of the Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the United States Military Academy, West Point, was held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor last night.

Mrs. Rose Tanzer Schneider, wife of Max J. Schneider, Democratic candidate for President of the City Council in the recent election, died yesterday of heart disease in the Park East Hospital, 112 East Eighty-third Street, in her fortyninth year. Her residence was at 149 West 179th Street, the Bronx.

A comnpleted initiative petition calling for repeal of Massachusetts laws legalizing betting at horseand dog races has been filed at the office of Frederic W. Cook, Secretary of t State, he said today.

The Brazilian Government is not Fascist, nor will it join hands with European nations in pacts, President Getulio Vargas told foreign correspondents this. afternoon in the first interview he has granted since the new Constitution was imposed.

The Museum of Modern Art is expanding the sphere of its activities. Although at present much cramped for space in the temporary New York headquarters, pending completion of the building to which it will move in about a year, the museum has meanwhile established a branch gallery in Washington.

A temporary injunction order in the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers case, signed by Circuit Judge Gardner and District Judges Munger and Donohoe and filed in Federal Court today, enjoins State officers and county attorneys from attempting to enforce a State law passed by the unicameral Legislature.
Baltimore will make its bow as a transatlantic commercial air terminal tomorrow when the Pan American Airways Bermuda Clipper arrives here from Hamilton, Bermuda.

International relations is the extra-curriculum topic most absorbing among Wheaton girls this year, membership in the International Relations Club indicates. The enrollment of more than 100 includes almost a fourth of the students and is the largest of the campus clubs. Margaret Knights of Summit, N. J., is president.

Transit Commissioner Leon G. Godley announced yesterday that he would give up his post on Jan. 1 to resume the private practice of law with offices in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street. Notice of his intended resignation will be filed in Albany by Dec. 1.
The increase in the cost of living affects a multitude of things, some of them so remote, one would have thought, as to have been immune from such matters as costs.

Vacant land is somewhat more plentiful in Manhattan today' than it was five or six years ago. Those whose acquaintance with the island is confined largely to the busy business centers of Times Square, Fifth Avenue or Wall Street, with their unbroken rows of buildings and many towering skyscrapers, may not have been cognizant of the change.

The French Canadian Province of Quebec, which last March passed a "padlock law" against Communist propaganda and the employment of any premises for Communist purposes, made use of this measure this week for the first time.
Musically, London becomes richer in delight every Winter. Three firstclass orchestras now play regularly throughout the season under famous resident and foreign conductors, with eminent soloists.

Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lee Atherton of Glenview, Ky., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Anderson Atherton, to Basil Duke Henning, son of Mrs. Samuel Cowan Henning, also of Glenview.
Davey O'Brien personally conducted Texas Christian University to a 14-to-0 gridiron victory over the University of Texas today, scoring every point the Horned Frogs counted.

The Rev. Joseph H. Schaeffer, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Barrington, died yesterday at his home here after an illness of several months. His age was 58. Born in Baltimore,. he was educated at Princeton University and Princeton Theological Seminary and was 'ordained to the ministry in 1905.
ADLER--Mr. and Mrs. Stanley, announce birth of a daughter, Nov. 9, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital. BROOKS--Mr. and Mrs. Frank S., announce birth of a daughter, Nov. 5, 1937, at Polyclinic Hospital.

The engagement of Miss Helen Frances Volk, daughter of Mrs. Jacob Volk of 845 West End Avenue and the late Mr. Volk, to Dr. Hilliard Dubrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dubrow, also of this city, has been announced by her mother.

One of the leading college dramatic organizations in the countrythe Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania-will present its golden jubilee production, "Fifty-Fifty," on the afternoon and evening of Dec. 4 at the Center Theatre, Rockefeller Center.
The New England horse racing season came to an end today at Rockingham Park as 8,000 rain-drenched fans saw F. W. Webb's White Hot gallop to an easy victory in the featured Blue Spruce Handicap.

In a season already well filled with benefit opera and theatre performances, as well as other entertainments arranged for charitable causes, one of the events of the near future of interest to members of society and the artistic world is the recital to be given by William Fleming, concert pianist, on the night of Dec. 3 at Carnegie Hall.

Land-grant colleges and universities, instituted by act of Congress in 1862 to "promote the liberal and practical education of the industrial classes," are celebrating their seventy-fifth anniversary this week. Simultaneously, perhaps, they face a new responsibility.
Chicago's Maroons, after five straight defeats, broke into the winning column today for the first time this season, trouncing Beloit College of Wisconsin. 26-9. at Stagg Field.
Army vs. St. John's at West Point. Baylor vs. Loyola (New Orleans) at Waco. Boston College vs. Boston University at Boston Brooklyn College vs. N. Y. Aggies at Brooklyn.

Establishment of stores capable of handling a volume totaling from $425,000 to $450,000 annually in the Greenbelt community in Maryland, taken over by the Consumer Distribution Corporation from the Resettlement Administration,
Former Mayor James J. Walker of New York was about twenty minutes late tonight in arriving at Holy Name of Mary Roman Catholic Church here to serve as best man at a wedding.
Michigan uncorked a pretty forwardpassing play in the rain on Franklin Field today and defeated Penn, 7--0, before 20,000 fans.

Toronto scored three first-period goals within two minutes tonight and went on to defeat Chicago, 7--3, in the first game of a week-end National Hockey League double-header between the teams. They play in Chicago tomorrow night.
Punching over a touchdown before the game was three minutes old, the Boys High football team downed its old Brooklyn rival, Erasmus Hall High, 7 to 0, at Boys High Field yesterday.
The Julius Rosenwald Fund spent $691,763 on rural education and Negro health during the last year, according to the annual report of Edwin R. Embree. president of the fund.

A decline in number and a slight drop in monthly dollar volume of Manhattan foreclosure auction sales was registered in October, according to the monthly analysis of foreclosures by the statistical department of the Real Estate Board of New York.
A course which musters the combined resources of the departments of physics, chemistry and art at Simmons College is preparing for an exhibition of all phases of still photography in February.

Creation of more opportunities for students to use their own initiative and ability was given today as one of the major reasons why the proportion of high-ranking students at Brown University has increased so largely in ten years.

The Children's Health Center of Greenwich House has again this year taken over the performance of the children's opera, "Hansel und Gretel," which will be given as a matinee on Dec. 24 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The question whether the Tennessee Valley Authority's electric power distribution policy is destined to continue as an integral part of the Federal Government's power program or be restricted to a floodcontrol and conservation program is definitely headed for a showdown.
NO longer does one have to wait until the Park Department hoists the white flag with its flaming red ball in order to go skating-artificial ice has done away with that.

Few amateurs realize that late Autumn is an excellent time of the year for remaking and improving the rock garden. The great majority of rock garden plants are, by their very nature, extremely tough and hardy. Many of them are such early bloomers that if one waits until Spring to set them out the first flowering is likely to be lost.

The drama department of the Women's Club of Glen Ridge will present "Grumpy," a four-act play, Wednesday evening at the clubhouse. Leading roles will be played by Mrs. James F. Kelly and John M. Brinkerhoff. Mrs. John W. Borman, Mrs. William Sinclair, Mrs.

Rain, mud and Davidson College were unable to stop Harvard in the Stadium today as the Crimson splashed its way to a 15-to-0 triumph over the North Carolina eleven before some 3,000 hardy souls, the smallest Harvard football crowd in modern history.

Burly Ernie Lain, the ball tossing sophomore of the Rice Owls, scored with three minutes left to play today to give the Southwest Conference leaders a 6-6 tie with Texas A. and M. The attendance was 20,000.

A CLUTCH is released, a omb hurtles downward, a hit is scored. Flying debris, wounded men, smoke, flames! The ugly sene is repeated scores of times daily in China and Spain. Thee are two views of aerial warfare: that of the soliders and civilians who are under bombardment, and that which the aviator sees after he releases his "eggs."

To the Drama Editor: Having read with great interest the two letters on alien actors, I can but wonder why don't we get down to a few facts? The only real argument the actor from England puts up is that "when a play is so typically English," etc., etc.
The capture of Kiating, Chinese stronghold west of Shanghai, is hailed here as the collapse of China's "Hindenburg line" and has started rumors that an armistice will be shortly proposed.

Columbia University's annual award of the Mariana Griswold Van Rensselaer Prize in Poetry has been made this year to Florence French Dunbar of Amherst, Mass., for her sonnet "Wasp Time," appearing in "Columbia Poetry 1937," a collection of student verse issued yesterday.

Upon two factors in the immediate future would seem to depend the degree of stimulation of business which will flow from the administration's plans to overcome the recent recession. In some respects these two elements will be even more important than the details of government aid. One is the tone and manner in which the President offers his program. The other is the mood of Congress toward independent thinking.

The annual Prince-Tiger dance, sponsored by the boards of The Daily Princetonian and The Princeton Tiger, university publications, will take place next Friday night in the Princeton University gymnasium. Charles R. Devine, '38, of Pelham, N. Y., is chairman of the dance committee.

Announcement has been made by James L. Meeks of 7,725 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Virginia Denyse Meeks, to Thomas Clyde Smith, son of Mrs. Charles P. Monahan of Brooklyn and Bayport, L. I., and William H. Smith of New York.

Karl Haffner, 37 years old, a tinsmith of 1,174 Jackson Avenue, the Bronx, was killed instantly last night and two other persons were injured when a truck struck Haffner as he was alighting from a Boston Road trolley car and then hit a parked automobile, sending it up onto the sidewalk.

Predicting a "substantial increase in the total of gifts for the year," J. Harold Johnson, executive secretary of the Rutgers University Fund Council, revealed today that almost 9o per cent more Rutgers alumni have pledged gifts to the university since July 1 than subscribed during the same period last year.

Students of Marymount College in Tarrytown-on-Hudson will mark Founder's Day on Dec. 8 at the college and will celebrate also the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the oldest campus organizatibn of the institution, the Association of the Children of Mary.

From Leyden comes the news that Dr. D. T. MacDougal, retired director of the Botanical Research Section of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, is to contribute a volume on "Tree Growth" to the Chronica-Botanica, an international series in English, French and German.

University of Virginia students have developed a laboratory of their own for practical political discussion and action with the formation of their Little Congress, which is now about to undertake its second legislative program.

A "canine cocktail party to be given by and for pet dogs" has been arranged for Wednesday afternoon as a benefit for the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals. The fete will! take place in the supper room of Jack Dempsey's Restaurant, Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, under the patronage of several women of society, most of whom have accepted invitations to escort their pets to the party.

Because the Republicans have a majority of the delegates the State Constitutional Convention next April will be under the chairmanship of a member of that party--probably the eminent and highly qualified Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, Frederick E. Crane.
Splashing through the mud, the C. C. N. Y. eleven scored a touchdown in the first period to defeat Moravian by 6-0 today as a crowd of 1,200 looked on.

Although a steady downpour prevailed all day, the games were played as scheduled in the sectional tournament of the Northeast Field Hockey Association on the Smith College fields today. Two upsets were recorded when New York defeated Long Island, 1 to 0, and Stuyvesant won from the strong Boston eleven, 2 to 1.

Student members of twenty-one clubs at City College have elected eighty-six fellow students as officers for the Autumn semester, according to an announcement by Dr. John R. Turner, dean of men, in charge of extra-curricular activities.

Miss Tony Sender, Social-Democrat member of the Reichstag before the establishment of the Hitler regime, In a review of European conditions yesterday at the Rand School forum, 7 East Fifteenth Street, warned democratic governments against the encroachment of Nazism and the alliance of dictators.
The Brazilian Government's announcement suspending interest and amortization payments on external debts has created considerable anxiety among Portuguese holders of Brazilian securities.

A new community of homes of unusual type has been started by Alden Estates, subsidiary of the Greyrockon-Sound Development Corporation. on a tract of sixty-eight acres on King Street, Port Chester, Westchester County.

On a rain-soaked gridiron Taft School of Watertown defeated Berkshire School of Sheffield, 26 to 0, today. Play for the first quarter seesawed between the 30-yard lines, neither team being able to make much headway although at times Hill and Moore, fleet Taft backs, tore through wide holes in the Berkshire line for substantial gains.
On his own application: To take effect 12 midnight, Nov. 15: PATROLMAN--John F. Rogers, 70th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Oct. 8, 1912.
THE barometer dropped sharply last week and almost before we knew it, certainly before we had time to batten down the critical hatches, Samuel Goldwyn's "Hurricane" was upon us.

Mr and Mrs. G. Harlan Miller have come from Whimsey Farm, their Summer place in Arlington, Vt., to the Pierre, to stay until Nov. 24, when they sail for France. Mr. and Mrs. John Barnes Townsend have arrived at the Madison from Radnor, Pa.

From that day in 1887 when "light calisthenics to piano accompaniment" first were offered without charge to young employed women who needed exercise "because of limited leisure, cramped and confining toil," the New York City branch of the Young Women's Christian Association will review a crowded health program at an anniversary celebration on Saturday.
Lalo Codona, last performing member of the famous family of artists of the flying trapeze, will not appear in public again.

A new election of directors of the Green Bus Lines, Inc., bus operators in Brooklyn, on the ground that insufficient notice was given to stockholders last June when the present directors were elected, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer.

Johns Hopkins University gained a 25-6 triumph today over American University, whose faculty turned thumbs down on Coach Gus Welch's threat that "he might" let a co-ed attempt to kick a point after touchdown.
The decoration of Officer of the Legion of Honor has been conferred upon Dr. Frank P. Graves, the State Commissioner of Education has been notified by the French Consul.

A WAITING the attention of Congress is the survey of the American merchant marine made by the Maritime Commission. The report and the commission's conclusions submitted last week have deep interest for the American traveler,

Students of dancing at Bryn Mawr College are watching themselves in the movies as a way of seeking improvement in rhythm, poise and balance. Under the direction of Miss Josephine Petts, director of physical education, a film record has been made of all freshmen students and all of the other classes are likewise to be photographed.

The report of the Museum of Modern Art, for the year ending on June 30, has been presented to the trustees at the museum's temporary quarters, 14 West Fortyninth Street, by Thomas Mabry, executive director.

With the first count of the proportional representation ballots for the new City Council virtually completed, it became apparent last night that the main object of the plan, that of providing more adequate representation for minorities, would be achieved.

ALTHOUGH it almost passes belief, 85,418,314 persons attended the events of the Federal MusicProject throughout this country since October, 1935. And what did they hear? No less than 39,219 programs by Project symphony and concert orchestras; 24,414 band concerts by WPA bands and 369 performances of operas and operettas, according to a report submitted to Ellen S. Woodward, Assistant Administrator of the Works Progress Administration, by Dr. Nikolai Sokoloff, the Project's national director.

Amos Kubick, 67-year-old town crier, he of the leather lungs who greets boat and train passengers with announcements of tides and weather conditions and proclaims news through the streets, owns up that he is "beat."

Long before game time at Baker Field yesterday it was apparent that Columbia and Syracuse, meeting for the seventeenth time since 1901, would be virtually at the mercy of the elements. And as the battle progressed it became more and more a certainty that if a decision were to be reached only a definite break would produce it.

Led by the redoubtable Dutch Clark, who is hailed as one of football's greatest backs of all time, the Detroit Lions will invade the Polo Grounds today to clash with the New York Giants before an expected crowd of more than 35,000.

The State Department announced today that a treaty of friendship, commerce and navigation between the United States and Siam was signed yesterday in Bangkok by officials of that government and Edwin L. Neville, American Minister to Slam, on behalf of this nation.

Nebraska sat on top of the football world for about ten minutes this afternoon. The Cornhuskers scored a brilliantly executed third-period touchdown against the mighty Pittsburgh eleven and, in the light of what had gone before, this sole tally appeared big enough to bring the gallant invaders. a victory.
The Kansas football bubble, which week by week had grown glossier with unexpected success, burst with a bang heard all over the Big Six today, punctured by a 7-to-0 defeat handed it by Kansas State.

A luncheon, followed by a meeting, will be held tomorrow at Hampshire House by members of the executive committee of the Women's Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, to discuss plans and projects for the coming year.

Four hundred elementary and primary school pupils relinquished their play hours this morning to attend a safety rally under the auspices of the New Rochelle Safety Council at Albert Leonard Junior High School in connection with American education week. Heavy rain prompted Arthur Falk, chairman of the council, to cancel a safety parade in which the children were to have participated.

The Smith College vocational office, which sponsors a yearly series of lectures designed to assist college girls in selecting their future occupations, will have as one topic this year "Careers for Women in the Field of Aviation." Other subjects to be discussed during the first semester are:

Albright, undefeated this season, added Lebanon Valley, an ancient rival, to its string of six conquests today, by handing the flying Dutchmen, a 16-0 setback, keeping their goal line uncrossed for the season.

The McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will be aided by a card party and tea to be held Nov. 23 at the home of Mrs. John D. Ryan, 3 East Seventyeighth Street. In connection with the party there will be a booth, presided over by Mrs. James F. McDonnell and Miss Yvonne N. Gourd, where Christmas wrappings, place cards, seals and ribbons will be offered for sale.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Steindler of New York have announced the engagements of their daughters, Miss Irene Steindler, to Melville Thalheim, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Thalheim, and Miss Shirley Caryl Steindler, to Stanley Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Stern.

While retail credit managers are watching the general business situation carefully, the recession thus ??ar has brought no cutting-off of credit or any stringent tightening up of credit, reports here yesterday indicated.

Bad manner, bad personality and character traits have lost more jobs for beginners and employee in commercial jobs than have lack of ability or mechanical skill, Gwynne A. Prosser of the American Institute of Banking told 350 commercial teachers yesterday at a luncheon held' in connection with the fourteenth semi-annual convention of the Commercial Education Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
An agreement has been concluded between Britain and The Netherlands for cooperation in defense of their Far Eastern possessions, according to the diplomatic correspondent of The Sunday Times.

Several dinners were given before the annual Autumn supper dance held last night under the auspices of the Georgia Society, in the ballroom of the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. John Pate Carson were dinner hosts at their home, 77 Park Avenue, taking their guests later to the dance.

METRO'S production staff went into high gear last week with plans for remaking "Madame Pompadour" and "Journey's End," preparing a third "Thin Man" chapter and gathering material for a screen history of the Canadian Royal Mounted Police.
The relationship of the United States to the Far East crisis was discussed by two rabbis in sermons yesterday and Friday evening. Others referred to conditions in Spain, Brazil and Germany.

TO one familiar with the dark political outlook on the European Continent it would seem a most daring enterprise to present on any stage a play in which Mussolini occupies the center in his role of war lord and conqueror.

British as well as German oil interests are attempting to make a deal for handling the vast quantities of petroleum the Mexican Government is expected to obtain for its participation in the development of the rest of the east coast Pozarica oil field, probably the second richest in the world, with the Royal Dutch Shell-controlled Eagle Oil Company.
A fortune of about [pound]200,000 was left by Sir Johnston Forbes-Robertson. It is one of the largest ever left by a famous actor.

Delegates to the annual convention of the National Grange, which for years has advocated better educational opportunities for rural youth, expressed interest today in why the government has delayed distribution of $14,000,000 appropriated by Congress for further development of vocational education.

SOME time this week the 30,000,000th customer of the Radio City Music Hall will buy his (or her) ticket at the window and enter that palatial theatre. Historically, the occasion may have no tremendous significance; the fate-of nations will not depend upon it. But to the folks around the Music Hall it will be a moment of considerable importance.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey said last night that talking of the horrors of war and signing pacts would not end war and that "the hope of peace lies in bringing about a change in the hearts and minds of men."

Canisius passe gained a 6-0 triumph over Western Maryland in Rosech Memorial Stadium today. Custodi, the Griffin center, intercepted a pass on the Western Maryland 40-yard line with five minutes to play in the second period, raced 13 yards and then tossed a lateral to Fullback Hogan, who went the remaining distance.

The Philadelphia Assembly is to be held on Dec. 10 at the Bellevue-Stratford. The patronesses include Mrs. William H. Hart, Mrs. Livingston L. Biddle, Mrs. James E. Gowen, Mrs. B. Franklin Pepper, Mrs. T.

After two bronchoscope operations in which more than ten yards of white cord were removed from his right lung, 6-year-old Robert Sippel of Laurelton, Queens, was resting comfortably yesterday in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, 210 East Sixty-fourth Street.
Floyd White, 21, of Lisbon, N. Y., a farmer, died in a hospital today of bullet wounds which Allan L. Gurley, assistant district attorney, said were from the gun of Conrad O'Malley, Rochester hunter.

New York City school children are woefully ignorant of even the most important points of interest found here and reveal an appalling amount of misinformation about their city, Winfield L. Rice, acting director of civic activities, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the Association of Civics Teachers in THE NEW YORK TIMES clubroom.

The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners ordered today that proposed increases in intrastate carload freight rates filed by twentysix railroads be suspended pending an investigation and hearing by the board to determine whether the increases are reasonable and lawful.

An informal dinner dance was held at the Innis Arden Golf Club, Old Greenwich. tonight after the YalePrinceton football game, which several of the club members attended in the afternoon. One hundred members and guests attended.
The versatile skill of Quarterback George Gembis combined with the alertness of his team-mates today to bring Wayne University of Detroit a 23-to-6 triumph over Buffalo University's football team.

William F. Osborne of Ossining, a civil engineer and bridge designer who was associated with. the New York Central Railroad system for twenty-six years, died Thursday of a heart attack in his office in Man hattan at the age of 66.
The growing use of visual education to supplement classroom instruction in institutions of higher learning is emphasized by innovations made this Fall in the program of Syracuse University.
On the first play of his varsity career, Billy Robinson, Hampton (Va.) sophomore, raced 68-yards today to feature the University of Richmond's 19-to-0 victory over Hampden-Sydney.
A runaway British balloon crashed today near Signeville, fifteen miles from Chaumont, after having drifted wildly across the English Channel and Northern France. No one was aboard.

New England industrialists oppose the prospective reciprocity agreement with Czechoslovakia because they fear its effect on one of their major industries. At Zlin is the greatest shoe factory in the world, with an output of 180,000 pairs every working day.

All traffic along Main Street was jammed the other afternoon as hundreds of residents, visitors and passing tourists crowded about a car on the mudguard of which was fastened one of the largest bobcats ever shot in this State.

With rentals reported about 40 per cent higher than a few years ago, stores on Fifth Avenue are establishing occupancy records, according to a study of renting there by Harold C. Samuels of the Harold C. Samuels Company, realty brokers.

Thanksgiving Day arrangements include the annual dinner ball of American society in London at the Dorchester Hotel, a dinner at Dartmouth House, headquarters of the English-Speaking Union. and a luncheon of the American Women's Club.

The American Trucking Association, Inc., national organization of the trucking industry representing more than fifty associations of motor carriers, filed today an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission for leave to intervene in the case in which the Class I railroads of the country are asking for rate increases estimated to yield about $508,000,000 in additional annual revenues.

A luncheon and fashion show will be given on Nov. 22 in the garden of the Ambassador under the auspices of the Yorkville unit of the Speedwell Society. Proceeds will go toward providing convalescent, post-hospital care for babies of needy families.

A former Harvard psychologist's forecast that women will rule the world in 1,000 years is like "suddenly discovering that two and two make four," Dr. Stevenson Smith of the University of Washington said today.

Accused of suspicion of larceny, Peter Zuchor, 28 years old, of 439 Fifty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, a former employee of James Seligman, stock broker, 30 Pine Street, was held by Magistrate Mogilesky in Felony Court yesterday in $10,000 bail for a hearing tomorrow.
The Baton Rouge, a 13,000-ton tanker built at the Bethlehem plant here for the Standard Oil Company, was launched today in the presence of company officials and others from New York.

FRIENDS and admirers of Albert Roussel were greatly saddened to learn of his death on Aug. 23 at Royan, where he had gone to spend the Summer. He will be keenly missed not only as one of the most distinguished figures of French contemporary musio but also on account of his rare personal qualities.

An under dog Coast Guard football team registered an upset today by holding the powerful Connecticut State eleven to a scoreless tie. The sailors made only four first downs to their rivals' twenty and never were in scoring position, but they played doggedly throughout.

Senator Wheeler, who was a leader in the fight against President Roosevelt's court reorganization program, praised the President today as "the one United States President who has done more for the workers and the common people than any other."

Waldemar Wengorra, 28 years old, accused of setting fire Thursday morning to the Cosmopolitan Hotel, Chambers Street and West Broadway, where he roomed, was held in $10,000 ball for action of the grand jury yesterday before Magistrate Mogilesky in Felony Court.

Something else besides the earth's magnetism directs the cosmic rays toward the poles, announces Nobel Prize Winner Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago in the form of a highly technical paper published in The Physical Review. What the something is he does not yet know. It may be "an atmospheric barrier."

LONDON--An ingenious scheme for preserving the great country houses, which have long been England's particular pride, has been approved by the Chancellor of the Exchequer, whose inheritance taxes had placed them in grave danger.

Harrison L. Lasuer has become the tenant of the highest "penthouse" in New England. A few days ago he moved into Bascom Summit Lodge, on the top of Mount Greylock, 3,505 feet above sea level, highest elevation in Massachusetts.

New York women who pioneered in establishing the "housekeeper service" to families whose routine is broken by a mother's illness, have been included in a national conference of informal nature, formed as a result of a meeting held in Washington last week under the auspices of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.
A religious sect calling itself Jehovah's Witnesses has appeared in news dispatches from various Eastern points recently because its members regard flag-saluting as idolatrous.

TELEVISION is the greatest of picture puzzles. Daily at Radio City, "impresarios," all admittedly amateurs in the field, are studying the new and fascinating electrical art that dovetails broadcasting with much that belongs to Hollywood.

AFTER nearly twenty years of inactivity and poverty Louisiana's "Sugar Bowl," which with Florida supplies all of the domestic cane sugar, is in its second year of a remarkable renaissance. Along the lower Mississippi and the near-by bayous there is being harvested today the biggest sugar crop this section has ever produced.
The report of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, and issued yesterday, shows a net income of $25,474,248, after all expenses and charges.
Miss Katharine H. Bennett, daughter of John C. Bennett of this place, has chosen Nov. 24 for her marriage to Henry C. Tappen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Tappen, also of Montclair.

Ohio State's belligerent Buckeyes converted a pass, a penalty and a plunge into three touchdowns today to defeat Illinois, 19 to 0, before a home-coming crowd of 41,921. The unexpectedly high score was the second largest an Ohio team ever had run up on the battling Illini.

Mrs. James Russell Lowell and Miss Helen Carroll Johnson, who have charge of the fashion parade to be held in conjunction with a tea Thursday for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys' Club, have completed their list of manikins for the event which will take place in the Iridium Room, Lounge Room and Oak Room of the St. Regis.

A mighty Scarborough machine captured the mythical Westchester County prep school championship for the second consecutive season today by beating Peekskill Military Academy's football forces, 19 to 6. It was the thirteenth straight victory for the Maroon eleven.

THE deftness of the early settlers in Bermuda in making house hold furniture from wood of the cedar trees they found growing on the islands is preserved today, three centuries later, in many of their descendants.
The Williams freshman football team defeated the Amherst freshmen, 9-0, today to gain the Little Three championship.

In the recent leasing by the Dartmouth Club of the house at 28-30 East Thirty-seventh Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, from the J. P. Morgan realty interests, an important addition has been made to the club center in that section of the city, points out Thomas W. Hughes, general manager of the Fifth Avenue Association.

Preparing to leave for Washington for the opening of the special session of Congress, Senator William H Smathers said today that there was no doubt in his mind that some measure would be passed during the session to amend the Federa surtax on undistributed profits.

More than 200 parishioners of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, in Stuyvesant Square are cooperating with the general committee in arranging the bazaar on Dec. 2 and 3 to raise funds for the redecoration of the Memorial House, 207 East Sixteenth Street, in which the event will be held.

Vinnie Albanese scored four touchdowns as Upsala defeated Panzer in the traditional meeting of the neighboring colleges at Ashland Stadium today, 27-0. Bill Wilson plunged to convert all but the third touchdown.
Eleven out of thirty-seven classifications scored linage increases in the advertising of department stores in local newspapers, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records.

Announcement has been made by Cadwallader Washburn Kelsey of Troy, N. Y., formerly of Short Hills, N. J., of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Barbara Sinclair Kelsey, to Bleddyn Lloyd Griffith of Abergele, North Wales.

Because the State Board of Regents reversed a previous ruling and licensed four German refugee physicians to practice here without taking an examination, Supreme Court Justice William T.- Collins declined yesterday to make a declaration of policy regarding such future cases in this State.
THE public is interested in personalities. This book caters to the public taste. It is the most generally readable book

GEORGES ROUAULT, who has been styled the leader of the fauve movement (if that group of ardent individualists may be said to have had a leader) is perhaps less known and more argued about than most of the other French painters since 1900.
A conference to consider labor legislation which will come before the special session of Congress will be held in the American Federation of Labor Building here next Wednesday.

SCHILLER, the German poet, found that the smell of rotten apples inspired him to poetic composition, and Vernon Duke, successor to the late George Gershwin on the musical score of the forthcoming Goldwyn "Follies," has an equally curious neurosis: he can write music only in a moving vehicle.

The North Jersey Alumnae of the University of Pennsylvania will meet today at a tea at the Hotel Suburban in East Orange. Miss Georgina P. Yeatman, chairman of the National Alumnae Bicentennial Committee, will speak on the plans for the celebration of the bicentennial of the university in 1940 and a film, "Pennsylvania Looks Ahead," will be shown.
The Times of London recognized with an editorial today the feat of K. H. H. Baily, a Bournemouth (Hampshire) accountant who ran from Bournemouth to the Paris Exhibition.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer of New York are planning to reside in Paris for the next two years while their children are to be in school here. They have taken a residence in the Square du Bois de Boulogne, just off the Avenue Marechal Foch.

THE tenth annual tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup will begin at the Ambassador Hotel Tuesday night at 8:30. The entire competition is limited to teams of four, though five players may enter as a team, any four of them playing in each session.

Efforts to detect relief chiselers through the payroll files of the Social Security Board and the State Labor Department's division of unemployment insurance and placement have been blocked by the insistence of Federal and State officials that social security records must be kept confidential, it became known yesterday.

IT is probably lucky that most journalists' wives either can't write or don't care to, but it is also lucky that Lilian Mowrer cared to and could. Mrs. Mowrer is the wife of Edgar Ansell Mowrer of The Chicago Daily News, who met her in an English railway train in 1911 and courted her with that direct approach which was subsequently to be useful to him in newspaper work.

BERLIN.--Swing is the thing in Germany. At least in Hamburg and Berlin, where there are modernistic night clubs and imported jazz bands, the fashionable young German women and men do their dancing to swing music.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Majority rule as written into the Constitution was the majority rule of a divided or two-chambered Legislature. Economic and political power were conveyed into the Senate and the House so as to secure two independent points of view. The two houses were motivated by different impulses.
Financial problems as a contributing cause to broken homes will be studied in a novel program planned by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs.

Dr. George B. Wallace, pharmacologist and senior member of the faculty of the New York University College of Medicine, will be honored by several hundred friends and associates tomorrow afternoon on the completion of his thirty-sixth year of active teaching service in the institution.
A GROUP of liberal educators, librarians and others interested in the cooperative movement is sponsoring the Cooperative Book Club, with offices at 5 East Fifty-seventh street. New York City.
Long scoring runs before and after Williams made its touchdown in the fourth period enabled Amherst to gain a 13-to-6 victory today and take the Little Three football championship.

DENYING the truth of reports widely published in the philatelic press to the effect that the Scott Stamp Coin Company, New York, would shortly be sold, Hugh M. Clark, the firm's general manager, has given THE NEW YORK TIMES the following statement:

To what extent, if any, the Federal taxation of business contributed to the recent business recession is not now accurately determinable. Only the cold facts, as disclosed by statistics of earnings and their disposition, could furnish a definite answer to such an inquiry.
THE literary truism that a tale twice told is not necessarily a tale grown old has been adopted lock, stock and barrel by the diligent denizens of the West coast.

IT is not telling tales out of night school to say that the hotels are running away with the lion's share of the nocturnal trade. And not the least significant aspect of the hotel association's joy is that much of the cash in its top drawer is being contributed by the younger generation, who some day will be room-renters and otherwise schooled in the hotel habit.

The library committee of the Garden Club of America announces "an exhibition of medallion portraits of botanists and their patrons, by Josiah Wedgwood, lent by R. T. H. Halsey, and of books and prints relating to Benjamin Franklin and botany," which will be open to the public weekday afternoons from Nov. 18 to Jan. 8 in the library of the Garden Club of America, 598 Madison Avenue.

With eyes on business charts and ears to the ground, Congress meets again. This time it is in extraordinary session called by President Roosevelt to resume consideration of business left unfinished when members of the Senate and House of Representatives went home to their constituents last Aug. 21.

Returns from the 3 per cent sales tax imposed on all retail purchases in Illinois are surprising and embarrassing to State authorities. For the first ten months of 1937 they. have totaled $68,509,546, as compared with $57,794,239 for the same period in 1936.

Immediate investigation of overhead costs in the coat and suit industry by a specially appointed committee has been recommended to the board of directors of the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association, following a group meeting called to consider the problem of "profitless selling,"

The State Department disclosed today it had received a request for aid in composing the difficulties which have arisen between the Dominican and Haitian Governments over the alleged massacre of Haitian citizens on Dominican soil.

The marriage of Miss Henrietta Rhees, daughter of Dr. Rush Rhees, president emeritus of the University of Rochester, and Mrs. Rhees, to Dr. John Dunham Stewart of Boston, son of Mrs. Henry Dixon Stewart of Monroe, N. C., and the late Dr. Stewart, took place late this afternoon in the Rhees home. Dr. Rhees performed the ceremony.
When the Army football team was beaten yesterday by Notre Dame, Gar Davidson, chief mentor at West Point, was left with the prospect of finishing his present coaching assignment without a victory in

The annual Allaverdy Ball, to be held this year on Dec. 3 at the Plaza will be patterned after an old-time Caucasian fete. Members of the Caucasian Society Allaverdy, under whose aegis it is being given. will appear at the ball in their native costumes and will participate in folk dances to the accompaniment of a Caucasian orchestra.
The Yellow Jackets of Randolph-Macon defeated the invading Haverford eleven today 29 to 0. It was the home team's game all the way and their eighth victory of the season.
Officers for the coming year have been elected by the management division of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx. They include G. Crawford Eadie, chairman; Thomas J. Tracey, vice chairman;

Talk of a merger of the Chicago North Western Railway and the Chicago Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad, which was started early this month through the disclosure that some stockholders had thought about it, received stimulus last week as a result of guarded statements made by the heads of both companies.

A backstage visit to the Governor Clinton Hotel concluded yesterday a two-day field trip for ten students of Connecticut College at New London, during which they inspected a number of the city's restaurant kitchens, institutions and food laboratories. Miss Mildred Burdett, instructor of institutional economics, was in charge of the group.

Except for moderate Costa Rica and Panama, official Central America received with glee the news that the Italian-Japanese-German pact against communism had been signed in Rome during the present week.
The cornerstone of the Harry M. Ullman Annex to the William H. Chandler Chemistry Laboratory at Lehigh University will be unveiled at the first annual alumni Fall home-coming, Nov. 20.

Every major obstacle to a resumption of building activity on a large scale will be attacked in a variety of definite moves by the Government and the construction and material fields, some of which started last week and others of which are due to be launched by the end of this year, a canvass by THE NEW YORK TIMES revealed last week.
A nation-wide survey revealed today that "drunken driving" tests range all the way from forcing the suspect to repeat catch phrases to picking up hairpins from the floor.

Two college presidents, three college deans and prominent members of the alumnae will join the Smith College Club at a dinner Tuesday evening at the Waldorf-Astoria honoring Dr. William Allan Neilson, who has been president of the college for twenty years.
The Crimson Tide of Alabama, outplayed most of the way by Georgia Tech, overhauled the Engineers, 7 to 0, today in a whirlwind finish before close to 26,000 spectators.

Members of the Alumnae Association of the College of Mount Saint Vincent will hold their annual supper dance Friday at the Pierre. Miss Dorothy Boylan heads the group that has arranged the dance and her aides include Mrs. E. Borgia Butler, Mrs. John Mallon, the Misses Julia Ross,

The Wesleyan College eleven triumphed over a hard-fighting university of Rochester team today, 6 to 0. The only tally of the game came in the first quarter as a result of a forward lateral play with Holzer, Cardinal fullback, 38 yards to the score.

Combining the elements of education, propaganda and the drama, the WPA Federal Theatre Project has undertaken the role of adviserextraordinary to the estimated 40,000 to 80,000 amateur dramatic groups in schools and outside.
With public health agencies in many communities, including New York City, expecting a measles outbreak of epidemic proportions, Professor Jean Broadhurst, Teachers College bacteriologist,

Numerous up-State milk producers reaffirmed today their faith in leadership of the Dairy Farmers Union's nineteen-county milk strike and heard an appeal to "unite and provide a common remedy to cure our common ills."

Virginia Military Institute's fighting squadron carried too many guns for the Citadel's light brigade on Alumni Field today, and when the firing was over before a slim crowd of 1,500 the Virginia Cadets were victors, 27 to 0.

Six persons were killed and fourteen wounded today in terroristic activities in Jerusalem threatening to turn what until recently was a terrorist campaign into a warfare between Jews and Arabs. Of those killed today, five were Arabs and the other was a Jew.
Anna Sokolow made a distinguished debut at the Guild Theatre last night, assisted by her. Dance Unit, and with Alex North in the dual capacity of pianist and composer-in-chief.
Charging "political chicanery" and "obstructive policies," Remo Bufano, for the last three years managing producer of the Federal Theatre Project's marionette unit, has resigned from that position.

A triangular monument, with thirteen steps on each side representing the twenty-six residents of this place who lost their lives in the World War, was dedicated this afternoon at exercises attended by 5,000 persons.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Young Ball of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Adelaide Ball, to Davis Greene Kirby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry N. Kirby of Newtown, Conn.
Those hunters who looked at the barometer early enough Saturday morning and gave up their upland game plans in favor of duck shooting had a good day, whether they went to Long Island or Barnegat Bay.
The passage of the Federal Wage and Hour Bill in its present form would be injurious to the country, and most injurious of all to many of the very persons it is designed to help.
More than 40,000 persons to date have visited THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center, which enters its final week today.

The outlines of the city's permanent relief burden emerged yesterday from the disclosure that 201,350, or 57 per cent, of the 349,350 adults receiving aid from the Emergency Relief Bureau and the Department of Public Welfare were classified as unable to meet the employment requirements of private business.

The Pennsylvania State Grange urged educators today not to draw the farm boy from the farm. In a report adopted last week and made public today by John H. Light, executive secretary of the grange education committee,

The democracies of the world "should make up their minds and stop being to wishy-washy" in dealing with the aggressive tactics of Fascist States, James G. McDonald said toight at the first forum of the fourth annual series of the Town Hall of Washington.
The wholesale price index at the end of October stood at 611, compared with 618 on Sept. 30 and 452 at the end of October, 1936.

Best in show at the fifth annual toy breed exhibition of the Progressive Dog Club in the roof garden at the Hotel Pennsylvania went to Mrs. Richard S. Quigley's Yu Go Han of Orchard Hill, a Pekingese, last night.
The plenary session of the Communist party at Valencia was agreeing today on policies more suited to its proletarian program.

Thirty-six contests have been arranged for Princeton University's 1937-38 varsity, junior varsity and freshman hockey teams, according to the schedules released today by Asa S. Bushnell, '21, graduate manager of Princeton athletics.

The Associated Flour Haulers and Warehousemen, against whom Local 138 of the Teamsters Union called a strike of 700 flour truck drivers and helpers last Tuesday, announced yesterday that the employers would man the trucks themselves today to make "emergency deliveries" to small bakers in all parts of the city.

A complete reorganization of the army on the basis of an infantry division of a wartime strength of about 10,000 men is an almost certain result of the two-month experimental field tests concluded here yesterday.

American participation in a 3,000,000,000-yen semi-State corporation to develop heavy industries and mining in Manchukuo is a salient feature of a plan outlined in the press today on the basis of interviews with Yoshiuke Ayukawa, recently nominated by Premier Fumimaro Konoe as president of the new corporation.
Green Bay smothered the Philadelphia Eagles under a barrage of passes to run up its seventh straight National League football victory today by a score of 37 to 7, before 15,000.

The story of how sixteen sailors struggled desperately for their lives for more than thirty hours while clinging precariously to wreckage in a heavy sea infested with sharks was told tonight as the Coast Guard cutter Mendota hastened here with fifteen survivors from the Greek freighter Tzenny Chandris, which sank in a gale off Hatteras early Saturday.

George C. Holton, a New York corporation lawyer, died last night at C his home here from a heart ailment from which he had suffered for several years. He was 60 years old. Mr. Holton, whose New York office was at 17 John Street, was counsel for the Corporation Trust Company and a director of the De Laval Separator Company.

THE stranger, a cantankerous-looking young man with shaggy hair, stalked into the office waving a newspaper. "This list of 500 Books for a Model Home Library," he exclaimed in an angry voice--"this list in last Friday's TIMES--what about it? What do you mean?" He shook the paper under the reviewer's nose until it (the paper) rattled. "What do you mean?"
I am appealing to the people of America tonight to help in carrying out a task that is important to them and to their government.

In their libretto for "The Jolly Village," which was presented last night as the second musical production of the season at the Second Avenue Theatre, Isidor Friedman and Israel Rosenberg have provided the right sort of situation for such a specialist as Menasha Skulnik.

With Robert Bryan showing the way, the formidable Mount St. Michael High School football team swept to an 18-0 triumph over Xavier High. yesterday on the winner's gridiron. Bryan scored two touchdowns, one on a double re verse that ended in a 30-yard run for a score in the first period.

A rededication to the Christian faith in the face of opposition from totalitarianism, scientists and mechanization was urged upon the congregation of the Washington Heights Methodist Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 153d Street, by the Rev. Dr. Claude C. Coile, superintendent of the New York District of the New York Methodist Conference,who preached the seventieth anniversary sermon there yesterday.
Robert A. Seager is with E. A. Frazee Co. Edmund A. Whiting is in the trading department of Amott, Baker Co., Inc. Walter E. Bachman is with E. H. Gibb Co.

Professor Edward Harlan Webster, for the last ten years head of the English Department of the State Teachers College here, died tonight at his home, 305 North Mountain Avenue, at the age of 61. Ill with arthritis since Oct. 18, he was apparently recovering when he suffered a pulmonary embolism.

Dr. Cornelius J. Kiel of 922 Bloomfield Street died last night at his home of a heart ailment at the age of 81. Dr. Kiel was one of the oldest practicing dentists in the State. Since 1911 he had been dentist for Hoboken's public schools and, at various times prior to 1911, occupied other public offices.

Declaring the general recession in business "has not yet had any great effect upon the demand for hosiery," the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers reports today that total shipments of all types of hosiery in September amounted to 11,418,423 dozen pairs.

Lord Beaverbrook, publisher of The London Daily Express, left his new eight-passenger Grumman amphibian airplane in the National Guard hangar at Newark Airport this afternoon, preparatory to taking off Tuesday morning on a trip to Miami, and later to the West Indies.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 87.1, which compares with 87.9 a week ago, 88.1 two weeks ago, 89.3 three weeks ago and 89.5 four weeks ago.

Sunrise Novelty Co. dress trimmings, in 200 W ?4th St; Irvin A. Cantor, electric pencils, in 102 E 25th St; Julius Frankel, yarns and threads, in 17 W 20th St; Max Madlin. mfr of dresses. in 151 W 25th St; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc, brokers.

The Transit Commission made public yesterday a letter mailed to Mayor La Guardia on Saturday charging him with "flagrant misrepresentations" in his reply to the commission's invitation of last week seeking city cooperation in new negotiations for rapid-transit unification.
The mining industry of Quebec will probably produce minerals to the value of $60,000,000 by the year-end, according to an estimate prepared by the Quebeo Bureau of Mines.

The current week in the art world opens with the number of new exhibitions again topping the thirty mark. Museum attractions and large group shows, conspicuous in last week's list, are just as conspicuously absent from the roster of new exhibitions.

The Portland Fancy of "the roaring nineties" and the Paul Jones of World War dancing days are to the fore again in the guise of the Big Apple, the dancing hit of the moment, according to reports made yesterday at the meeting of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at the Hotel Astor.
The statement of Hiram WalkerGooderham Worts, Ltd., for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 last, issued for publication today, shows a net profit of $6,463,633 after all charges and taxes.

The strong Santa Paula team won its opening match in the Argentine polo championships today, defeating Venado Tuerto, 10 to 7, to join the United States entry, Aurora, in the second round. Aurora took its first match yesterday.

Showing eight new faces in their line-up, the New York Rovers got off on the right foot yesterday by subduing the Baltimore Orioles, 4 to 3, in the inaugural battle in the 1937-38 season of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League at Madison Square Garden.
