Mrs. Betty Kirby-Green and Flying Officer A. E. Clouston hopped from Croydon Airport at 9:55 o'clock tonight in an attempt to break the round-trip flying record between London and Capetown, South Africa. They planned to fly via Egypt.
The Boston Bruins thrilled their opening home game crowd of 15,000 by recording a 3-2 victory over the New York Rangers' stubborn National Hockey League forces tonight at the Boston Garden.

Germany's output of pig iron in October amounted to 1,417,000 tons, against 1,349,500 in September. The syndicate reports that manufacturers are getting their official rations of iron and steel more regularly, but that the South German machine industry has been having increasing difficulty in obtaining copper.
Mrs. Paul Redfern, wife of the aviator who has been missing since 1927, revealed yesterday that she had given up hope of hearing from him again.

Running a front race from gun to tape, Joseph P. McCluskey, the hardy perennial from the New York Athletic Club, stepped smartly away in a strong field of seventytwo starters yesterday to capture the metropolitan A. A. U. senior cross-country championship over a rugged six-mile course in Forest Park, Woodhaven.

British Board of Trade figures issued today for October are as follows: Total imports, [pound]96,080,000; exports of British products, [pound]47,210,000; re-exports, [pound]5,700,000; total exports, [pound]52,910,000; excess of imports, [pound]43,170,000.

Liquidation early last week and aggressive buying on the Argentine frosted scare later increased the week's volume of trading in wheat on the Board of Trade. In other grains there was no great change, although there was a spurt in buying of rye.
Today's major events: Opening of the Beethoven Association season at the Town Hall tonight and the National Orchestral Association season at Carnegie Hall;

Sheets of rain and muddy, multipuddled gridirons furnished a miserable setting on Saturday as a number of major prep school elevens ended their campaigns to conclude several successive days of traditional football games.

Mrs. Henry Harper Benedict of 5 East Seventy-fifth Street and Southampton, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Josephine C. Benedict, to Dr. J. Douglass Sharpe of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass Sharpe.

The nations adhering to the NinePower Treaty will take up tomorrow the declaration framed yesterday asserting that Japan is "out of step" with the -rest of the world and deploring that she will not confer with them regarding the violations of that treaty and by implication accusing her of upsetting the world's peace.
King George and Queen Elizabeth today attended services in the little village church of St. Paul's, where the Queen was baptized and where she worshiped as a girl.
The text of the report of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, Regional Director National Labor Relations Board, Second Region, New York, follows:

The Financial News index of thirty industrial stocks, based on July 1, 1935, as 100, on Nov. 11 stood at 102.3, compared with 103.1 a week before, 99.4 a month ago, 123.5 a year ago, the high record of 124.9 on Nov. 18 last year and the low record of 41.6 in June, 1932.

Secretary Perkins announced today that living costs for families in the lowsalaried and wage-earning groups in thirty-two large cities showed an average rise of 0.6 per cent in the three months ended Sept. 15.
The Northeast Field Hockey Association closed its sectional tournament on the Smith College field today with a match between the Northeast first and reserve teams. The former won, 5 to 2.
The Circle Wire and Cable Corporation sold to the Byd Realty Company the two-story factory containing about 100,000 square feet at 24 Woodward Avenue, Maspeth, L. I.
The Bowery Savings Bank extended to June 1, 1942, at 3 per cent, a mortgage for $11,880 on 265 William St held from the executors of the will of Emma Maria Geiss.

Reductions in insurance rates for bodily injury and property damage suffered because of automobiles, which are estimated to save policy holders in this State $3,500,000 a year, go into effect this morning.

Miss Sara Webb Key, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ben Witt Key of 1,170 Fifth Avenue, will be married on Dec. 18 to James Owen Watts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Watts of Lynchburg, Va. The ceremony will take place in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.
It is certain that fears here of a further devaluation of the dollar, although in no way justified, have resulted in the withdrawal of some French capital from the United States.

Princess Alexandre de CaramanChimay of Paris has left the Pierre to join her son and daughter-inlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Rutherfurd Stuyvesant at Tranquillity Farms, Allamuchy, N. J. Colonel and Mrs. Francis L. V. Hoppin will close their home in Newport next week and will be at the Savoy-Plaza until February.

Mrs. Sarah Eckerson Nichols of this town, widow of Frederick P. Nichols, was killed in an automobile accident in Middletown, Conn., yesterday afternoon. Her daughters, Sarah, 20 years old, and Sylvia, 16, were seriously injured.
Norfolk St. 78, 25x100: Teekayess Realty Co, Inc, to Simon Gluckstern, 156 S 9th St. Brooklyn: mtg $17,800 ($1).

A Detroit offense, based on blinding speed and a three-point attacking front, administered to the New York Giants their first defeat in two months yesterday as the Lions turned back the Maramen, 17 to 0, in a teeth-rattling, bruising battle before a gathering of 35,790 at the Polo Grounds.

Fines of $25 each were levied today by Frank Calder, president of the National Hockey League, against Babe Siebert of the Canadiens and Baldy Northcott and Stew Evans of the Maroons for their part in a fight during last Thursday's game between the teams.

Breaking 99 out of 100 targets, A. L. Burns took the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. He also won a leg on the doubles scratch prize with a card of 28 and finished the day by annexing scratch honors at 155 targets with 149.
The Whitney Museum of American Art has bought a painting by the late Arnold Wiltz, it was announced yesterday. The painting, 24 by 30 inches, was done in 1931 and is entitled "Firemen's Hall."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your report of the proposed bridge at Canal Street to provide for the extension of the West Side Express Highway to Duane Street, you said: "Further extension must await a determination of the location of the Manhattan approaches to the proposed BatteryBrooklyn tunnel."
Edward McManus, the last of 40,000 of New Jersey Civil War veterans who resided at the home for disabled veterans here, died today at the age of 92.

In an address before 2,000 members of Theta Pi Alpha, the Catholic teachers' association of New York City, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, President of Fordham University, urged a united resistance to the philosophy of subjectivism, which he termed the "dominant philosophy of the American university." The occasion of his speech was a communion breakfast at the Hotel Commodore yesterday after mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The world's need for a free press and for free writers for that press was emphasized by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of New York University, and other speakers last night at a dinner of the Lotos Club in honor of Dorothy Thompson, writer. Miss Thompson is one of few women to be honored by the club, which ordinarily does not admit women to the clubhouse, at 110 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Federal Trade Commission has announced that Samuel McCrudden Co., Inc., 1 West Thirty-seventh Street, New York, have agreed, in a stipulation, to stop advertising handkerchiefs not composed of linen as "linen" or "Irish linen."
BAKER BRANDS. INC., 431 E. 91st St,-- Voluntary Proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law. listing liabilities of $23,425 and assets of $31,157.

With exceptionally large fields entered for both events, the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. will hold its twenty-ninth annual varsity and eighteenth annual freshman crosscountry championships in Van Cortiandt Park today.

Counsel for the American Newspaper Guild will appear before Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan tomorrow to ask modification of an injunction issued by the court on Saturday, in which eight striking employes of The Bayonne Times are prohibited from participating in the walkout.

Dr. Phoebus Aaron Theodore Levene of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research is the winner of the 1938 William H. Nichols Medal of the New York section of the American Chemical Society, it was announced yesterday by Professor Victor K. La Mer of Columbia University, chairman of the medal jury.

A basis for settlement has been reached regarding the dispute in which Beth Brown and the estate of the late Samuel Shipman charged that Jack Curtis, theatrical producer, disposed of the stock rights of "Behind Red Lights" without their consent. Miss Brown and Mr. Shipman wrote the play, which Mr. Curtis presented on Broadway.

The market for corn on the Board of Trade here ran last week counter to the upward trend in wheat. Export business was not a big factor, although there was some business almost every day, with 500,000 bushels worked on Friday.

As a result of King Carol's stipulation of Ion Mihalache that he must include the reactionary anti-Semitic pro-German leader, Alexander Vaida-Voevod, in his Cabinet, eliminating certain Peasant party politicians known to be friends of Dr. Julius Maniu, M. Mihalache this afternoon returned the mandate to form a Cabinet, telling King Carol that on such terms the task was impossible.

The New York Americans made an auspicious bow to the home folks last night. Meeting the Maroons in their first Madison Square Garden game of the National Hockey League season, Red Dutton's aggressive stick-wielders turned back the Montreal outfit by the score of 2 to 0.
The Italian Foreign Minister and the British Ambassador had a polite and even cordial conversation last Friday.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. John McDowell, former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, who died in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in at this city on Saturday evening, will leg be held tomorrow at 2:30 P. M.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City was hailed as "Public Enemy No. 1 of communism" by the Rev. Matthew Toohey, State chaplain of the Catholie War Veterans, at the annual vesper service of the Jersey City Post this afternoon in Sacred Heart Church, Jackson and Bidwell Avenues.

Despite the government's crop report issued on Monday, indicating a cotton crop of from 500,000 to 600,000 bales above general trade expectations, and the largest crop ever produced in this country, prices of active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange at the close of the week showed net advances for the week of 15 to 21 points.

New low records in the city for births, infant mortality, tuberculosis, appendicitis and deaths by suicide were recorded during October, according to a report by the Department of Health made public yesterday.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amounted to $4,347,780,500. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills. The list follows:

The current business decline is not a new depression getting under way, but is another serious decline in the recovery phase of the depression that has been with us sinoe 1929, Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, vice president of the Cleveland Trust Company, says in the current issue of the company's business bulletin.

The Rev. Dr. Anthony Nicholas Petersen, pastor of the Scarborough Presbyterian Church for the last thirty years, announced his resignation from the pulpit today. It will become effective next June 21, the fortieth anniversary of his ordination.
An eighteen-root coral rocK column was dedicated today to 500 persons killed on Labor Day, 1935, when a tropical hurricane raked the lower Florida keys.

Despite the fact that the prospects of reduced car sales for the coming year would appear to warrant more intensive sales and advertising effort by the auto industry, automobile show schedules in the leading cities are falling under a year ago.

Mrs. Bertha Hofer Hegner, a pioneer in kindergarten work in Chicago, died today at her home in West Chicago at the age of 74. Mrs. Hegner was the founder in 1896 of the Pestalozzi Froebel Teachers College and also founded the first kindergarten at the Chicago Commons Settlement that year.
The special session which is to open tomorrow, its aims and what it should accomplish were discussed over the radio tonight by four members of the Congress, two Republicans and two Democrats.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission will certify 363 men from the police eligible list to fill vacancies in the Fire Department because of expansion under the threeplatoon system, it was learned yesterday.

The award of scholarship stipends valued at $148,128 to 381 Princeton University undergraduates was announced tonight by Dr. Robert Root, dean of the faculty and chairman of the University Schcolarship Committee.
BLAME it on the weather. Low scores and ties were abundant in the sloppy going. How did Yale run up that score on Princeton? It must be that some of Ducky Pond's players have webbed feet.

It is "Too Many Heroes," arriving tonight at the Hudson, that launches this crowded Broadway week--and launches it pretty violently, too, by all accounts, for this is Mr. Dore Schary's play about a Southwest lynching. (Its earlier title, in fact, was "Violence.")
New York State neared the end of its thirtyday hunting season today with a toll of twenty deaths, the result of fourteen accidental shootings, tour drownings, one exposure and a heart attack.
Although the coup d'etat in Brazil and its subsequent fiscal developments had a somewhat sobering effect in the City, a brighter underlying sentiment was noted in the financial markets this week.
A rugged football team from Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg. Md., held St. Thomas of Scranton to a 6-6 tie on a muddy field before 6.000 spectators today.

Calvin Day McMurtry, who served twenty years as Surrogate of Somerset County, died today at his home here at the age of 77. Mr. McMurtry, a lifelong Democrat, was born in Basking Ridge, N. J., May 25, 1860. His father, William McMurtry, was a former Sheriff of Somerset County.
The five counties of Greater New York contributed 1,079 of the 1,231 new stock corporations formed in this State in October, the Division of Corporations of the Department of State reported today.
A tea will be given Saturday afternoon in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador for members of the Society of Mayflower Descendants and their guests.

The long-expected deal whereby Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda acquire the shares held in the United Artists Corporation by Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin and Douglas Fairbanks has been consummated, according to an announcement issued yesterday by Mr. Goldwyn and Mr. Korda.

The demand for cash lard was fairly well sustained here last week at the pace set in the previous week, with further replenishment of supplies and some buying ahead of the advance in freight rates which will go-into effect this week.
The Brooklyn Savings Bank sold the two two-story buildings containing stores and apartments at 8,403 and 8,423 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, to investors through Hy.

The Rev. Walter David Knight, for sixteen years pastor of the Mount Washington Presbyterian Church, 84 Vermilyea Avenue, conducted yesterday morning his final service as pastor of the church. Mr. Knight, whose resignation is effective today, will leave soon for Boston to take up the duties of his new office as field representative of the Board of National Missions and ar Christian Education for the Presbyterian Synod of New England.

A donation of $50,000 for the creation of a gallery at the Museum of the City of New York depicting the history of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday by the museum. The donor, who does not wish to have his name made public, was said to be the senior partner of one of the city's oldest banking firms.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 41 per cent of capacity, down 7 points in a week, and less than one-half the rate in the week before Labor Day.

The University of Santa Clara, one of the few undefeated, untied major football teams of the nation, maintained its unblemished record today with a 7-to-0 victory over the St. Mary's Gaels, traditional rivals of the Bronqos.

Reeating his notable triumph of a year ago when, as a novice puppy, he advanced to best in show at the same exhibition, the popular seal brindle Champion Hagerty's Fascinating Model again gained the premier honors in the third annual specialty show of the Newark Boston Terrier Club at the Hotel Douglas today.
The General Confederation of Labor proclaimed today a boycott of Japanese goods for its 5,000,000 members in a series of national demonstrations "for defense of peace."
Professor Harry Edward Miller, Eastman Professor of Political Economy at Boston University, died yesterday at the Beth Israel Hospital, Brookline, after a brief illness. His age was 40.

The Detroit Red Wings, showing flashes of the team-work that won the Stanley Cup last season, defeated the Canadiens, 2 to 1, tonight before 10,872 spectators. It was the first Detroit victory of the current National Hockey League season.

The United States today accepted the invitation of President Stenio Vincent of Haiti to join with Mexico and Cuba in mediating the dispute between Haiti and the Dominican Republic over the alleged massacre of Haitians on Dominican soil.

The New York Maritime Council asks Congress, in considering the report of the Maritime Commission on the national merchant marine, "not to hesitate to take a progressive stand for the only logical alternate proposal-government ownership and operation."
Egbert Moxham Jr., with Mrs. Moxham as crew, sailed Stingaree II to a decisive victory in the Class B series in the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association regatta today.
An exhibition of children's paintings, enlivened by comments from the young artists themselves, was opened yesterday at the Catholic Youth Organization, 35S West Seventeenth Street.

Charles C. Cluff, who retired in 1932 as New York sales manager for the Carnegie Steel Company, died Saturday night at his residence, 1 Fifth Avenue, after two years of illness, including two strokes of apoplexy. He was born in Savon Hill, near Boston, 74 years ago.

Miss Celia Napoli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Napoli of this city, was married this afternoon to Salvatore F. Scillia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Scillia of Montclair. The ceremony was performed in Holy Family Church here by the Rey Anthony Di Luca. the rector.

In a frequently quoted speech to Germans at Liberec (Reichenberg) a year ago, President Eduard Benes said: "Nationality conflicts are natural and inevitable on all ethnographic frontiers, but our two peoples are today mature enough not to allow themselves to be denationalized."

Loom activity in the rayon-woven broad goods industry in the week ended Nov. 6 had been drastically curtailed from the year's peak, a survey made public by the National Rayon Weavers Association, Inc., at the week-end revealed.

Miss Sylvia Langman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Langman of Camden, Me., and former Assemblyman Elmer E. Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Brown of Carteret, N. J., were married yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Louis

With 1,100 persons present the thirtieth annual dinner of the National Home for Jewish Children at a Denver was held last night at the C Waldorf-Astoria. Samuel Fried- p lander, chairman of the New York Committee, announced that $30,000 had been raised by the committee.

Violin playing of refinement and distinction by Louis Persinger, whose accomplishments as a mentor of young prodigies has perhaps outstripped his repute as a recitalist, was heard by a large audience in Town Hall last night.

Early arrivals among the municipal officials who will attend the opening tomorrow here of a three-day meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors were exchanging views on municipal problems in Washington hotel. lobbies tonight.

Helen Beck, in 278 W 4th St: Georgianna Green, in 41 W 8th St; William J. Lynch, in 34 W 9th St; Herbert Glass, In 61 W 9th St; Margaret K. Baron, in 28 E 10th St; R. M. Stevenson, in 55 E 10th St; Horace B. Albright, in 195 W 10th St;

Willie Hoppe, world professional 18.1 balkline billiard champion, will launch the defense of his title today when he engages Jake Schaefer of Chicago in the. first. block of their 3,000-point challenge meeting at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. Schaefer is .a. former title-holder.
Considering the amount of work which lies before Congress, it is fortunate that the President has called a special session. Not only is the Administration seeking action on a series of new measures.

After a series of remarkably level performances both on upland game and on ducks, the annual field trial meeting of the American Chesapeake Club was brought to a close late this afternoon with the award of prizes and trophies in the open all-age stake.

The complete itinerary for the Princeton Triangle Club's fortyninth annual production, which will be presented in leading Eastern and Midwestern cities over the Christmas holidays, was announced today by William J. Watson, '38, of Trenton, N. J., president of the undergraduate dramatic group.
Real estate transactions reported over the week-end in the Bronx indicated a demand for dwellings and multi-family buildings.

Announcement that government agencies would start immediately to buy cash rye to stabilize prices for this grain had an instantaneous bullish effect' last week on the futures market on the Board of Trade here, and prices advanced as much as 4 cents a bushel in a day.

Grover Jones confided in a recent series of magazine articles that all he had when he started writing the script of "52d Street" was the title, the promise of a Walter BullockHarold Spina score and the assured presence of Sid Silvers, Jack White, Ella Logan and other denizens of Rowdy Row.

The "largest community chest in the world" was projected last night with the opening of a $6,250,000 drive on behalf of 116 hospitals, homes for the aged, child welfare institutions and other charitable agencies affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities.
An unusual situation resulted in the running of the cocker spaniel allage stake, final event of the thirteenth annual field trials of the American Spaniel Club at Camp Upton today.

Extraordinary powers were granted to the President today by the Senate in approving two new articles submitted by the Minister of Finance and Minister of War in passing the budget for 1938 on the second reading, which is equivalent to final approval.

An epidemic of hold-ups in which the victims, chiefly women and elderly men, were seized on the street at night and beaten if they offered resistance, was disclosed yesterday in the Stuyvesant, Crown Heights and Bedford sections of Brooklyn.
Foreign Minister Miguel Angel Araujo and the British Charge d'Affaires have signed a commercial treaty between El Salvador and Canada that will become effective Wednesday.

Like the recent survey of our shipping problem by the Maritime Commission, Secretary Wallace's annual report on agriculture, though more than 60,000 words long, is a model of what such a Government document should be.

The spiritual and religious crisis that confronts the man who lives in Germany, Russia or Italy today faces him in America as well, for he must decide for himself whether he is going to live his life in the way of Jesus Christ or on some other basis, the Rev. S. E. Gerard Priestley declared yesterday morning at the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street.

Poland has sufficient foreign exchange to make full interest payments on its externally held debt and there is no justification for its failure to pay bondholders in the United States, according to a bulletin to be issued today by John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance, which is conducted by the Investment Bankers Association in cooperation with New York University.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $750,000 of city and county of Denver, Col., air school 2 1/4 per cent bonds by a banking group comprising Lazard Freres Co., Inc.; Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; the First of Michigan Corporation and the William R. Compton Company, Inc.

New York need bow no longer to any other metropolis as the shrine of good eating, for this city "definitely" has become the "world's culinary capital," according to J. George Frederick, president of Gourmet Society.
The Board of Trade's index of British wholesale prices in October, based on the average of 1930 as 100, stood at 110.6, compared with 111.2 in the preceding month and 97.6 in October, 1936.

More than 100 of the nation's newspaper publishers and editors have accepted membership in the newly created Publishers Council that will aid in this year's nationwide "Fight- Infantile- Paralysis" campaign, it was announced yesterday by Keith Morgan, chairman of the Committee for the Celebration 'of the President's Birthday.

The first break in the peace and harmony that has prevailed so far in the forty-ninth annual convention of the National Amateur Athletic Union came tonight as former President Avery Brundage of Chicago called a caucus to nominate a presidential candidate.

THIS IS MY STORY, by Eleanor Roosevelt. (Harper, $3.) An autobiography. ISLAND OF BALI, by Miguel Covarrubias. (Knopf, $5.) The art and character of the Balinese. WOOLLCOTT'S SECOND READER, edited by Alexander Woollcott. (Viking, $3.) A new anthology.

Aldous Huxley, whose new book "Ends and Means" will be published by Harper on Wednesday, is on a lecture trip that will bring him to Mount Vernon, Iowa, on the day his book appears. He will speak in Chicago on Nov. 19 and will be in New York on Dec. 10.

While Frank Capra's return to Columbia is still a moot question, his partner-in-arms, Robert Riskin, has settled his differences with Harry Cohn and has returned to the lot to prepare and produce "You Can't Take It With You," the Moss HartGeorge S. Kaufman piece for which Columbia paid $200,000.

True friendship is possible only between the faithful, the Rev. Otto Duessel declared yesterday before the congregation of the Trinity Lutheran Church, Avenue B at East Ninth Street. Mr. Duessel, who preached the entire service in German, suggested as a textual example the friendship of David and Jonathan. "A friendship between thugs and infidels is not a worthwhile one," he commented.

The report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued for publocation today, shows a consolidated net income of $13,669,649, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.

Franke Losee, a veteran of fifty years on the American stage, died here today at his home, 26 Post Street, at the age of 81. His wife, Marion Elmore Losee, with whom he played in many productions, survives. They celebrated their golden wedding on Jan. 15, 1984.

In the professional-amateur best-ball golf tournament held today as a forerunner of the seventeenth annual Mid-South professional tourney which starts Tuesday, Al McDonald, professional of Yardley, Pa., and Howard G. Phillips, Pinehurst amateur, took the low-net honors. They scored a gross 68 and net 64.

The Merchants Association of New York will celebrate its fortieth anniversary with a dinner on Tuesday, Dec. 21, at the WaldorfAstoria. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will be the principal speaker.

The authors who will speak in the fair auditorium this afternoon at 2:30 are: Fannie Hurst, president of the Authors Guild, lecturer, traveler, housing worker, recently author of "Great Laughter" and "We Are Ten";

The consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in October amounted to 38,707 long tons, compared with 43,893 in Septmeber and 49,637 in October, last year, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Association. Imports of crude rubber in October were 52,508 tons, against 56,049 in September, and 40,920 in October, last year.
The Church of England made a truce with the Duke and Duchess of Windsor today through an invitation from fashionable Christ Church to preside at a charity sale in the suburb of Neuilly, Nov. 20.
President Roosevelt was host tonight at a dinner at the White House in honor of Viscount Cecil of Chelwood and Lady Cecil, who are week-end guests.

New Yorkers are to view for the PR first time what the producers have described as a new type of elaborateness in ice spectacles when the figure-skating presentation "Gay Blades" is shown tonight at Madison Square Garden.

General buying of steel continues at a minimum, and occasional awards of important tonnages are not sufficient to maintain production schedules, the magazine Steel says this week, adding that "consumers seem intent on reducing steel inventories and keeping them at a low point."

Reports of serious damage to the wheat crop in Argentina, with a much stronger trend of prices in Liverpool and Winnipeg, resulted late last week in a substantial upturn in prices of the staple in all markets.

D. P. Earle took high-gun honors in the first 50-target event at the North Jersey Gun Club today. Handicap prizes were won by Mrs. M. Conde, J. L. Flagg, A. F. Streelman, A. B. Blood, I. W. Wortman, Dr. Pruden and E. Jacobus.
Under the influence of foreign Stock Exchanges, the Boerse here opened downward this week, trading interest being confined to fixed-interest obligations and securities of mortgage banks.

Japan and Canada were the only foreign buyers of United States seaplanes in September, according to a report by the Department of Commerce today, which set aeronautical exports in that month at $3,187,109, compared with $1,934,495 for September, 1936.

There will be few blaring bands, and the cymbals and the fifes will play little part in the army of tomorrow, if recommendations expected as a result of experimental army manoeuvres here should materialize.
F. D. Crosby of this city has acquired control of the Transcontinent Shares Corporation of Philadelphia, sponsor of Fiscal Fund, Inc., whose investments are exclusively in bank and insurance shares.
They introduced John Montague, golf's mystery man, to his future public yesterday under circumstances that neither he nor his public will soon forget.

Last week's recovery on the Stock Exchange, after intimations had begun to come from Washington that some kind of change in governmental attitude towards business might be impending, was considerable; but it effaced only part of the decline scored since October.
Beverly, historic manor house which tradition says once was the center of an international plot to rescue the exiled Napoleon Bonaparte, was destroyed by fire last night.

Addressing a meeting of several hundred members and guests of the Catholic Poetry Society of America in the Starlight Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday afternoon, Robert P. Tristram Coffin, Professor of English at Bowdoin College and winner of the 1936 Pulitzer Prize for poetry, discussed poetry as a part of life.
The German wholesale price index on Nov. 3 stood at 105.9, against 105.8 in the preceding week.

Count and Countess Cecil Charles Pecci-Blunt, Lady Williams Taylor, Sir Rerick Julius Wernher, Mr. and Mrs. George B. De Long, Major and Mrs. Douglas King, Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Benson and Mrs. Martin Johnson, African explorer, are passengers due today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary.
Margaret Bannerman, English actress, made her American debut last night at the Opera House in a musical play, "Three Waltzes," produced by the Messrs. Shubert.

An industrial equivalent of his ever-normal granary plan in agriculture was proposed today by Secretary Wallace as a means of bringing about greater stability of industrial production and employment and as a protection to consumers.
The Paterson Panthers defeated the Brooklyn Eagles, 7--0, today before 7,000 fans at Hinchliffe Stadium to maintain their undefeated record in the American Football Association.

Mrs. Jeannette Nash Starkweather, widow of Louis P. Starkweather, died here today at the home of her son, Louis P. Starkweather Jr., Plainfield, in her seventy-fourth year. Her husband, prior to his death in 1911, was a general agent for the old United States Express Company. A sister,, Mrs. Mary Eva Wass of Boston, and three brothers, Hanilan Nash of Oakland, Calif.'; Ralph H.' Nash of Boston and Walter Nash of Addison, also survive.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned from Brussels to day to find himself the prisoner of a Cabinet "cabal"-Sir Samuel Hoare, the Home Secretary; Sir John Simon, the Chancellor of the Exchequer; Viscount Hailsham, the Lord Chancellor, and one or two others which had persuaded Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain last week to send Viscount Halifax, the Lord President of the Council, to Berlin.

H. E. Long, formerly vice president of purchasing for Nash Motors, has been appointed director of purchases for all divisions of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation, according to announcement by George W. Mason, president.
The condition of the Winter cereals crop on Nov. 1 was officially described as favorable. Wheat's grade index is 2.5, which means halfway between good and mediocre.
Canvass of the proportional representation ballots cast for the new City Council will enter its second stage today with the completion of the first count in at least three boroughs.

Miss Caroline Cope Ingram of this city will be wed next Saturday to Lawrence Southwick of Amherst, Mass., in Christ Church Cathedral here. Her grandfather, the Rev. David L. Sanford of Elizabeth, N. J., will perform the ceremony, assisted by her uncle, the Rev. Edgar L. Sanford of Moprestown, N. J. A small reception will follow at the Heublein.

The body of J. Ramsay MacDonald will be taken to the cathedral tomorrow afternoon, where it will lie in state until the following morning Vhen it will be placed aboard the cruiser Apollo for passage to England.

The regime of Premier John Metaxas, dictator of Greece, was criticized as blighting to the ancient traditions of democracy of the Greek people and as dangerous to American citizens of Greek ancestry yesterday afternoon by eleven speakers at the first mass meeting of the two-month-old Greek Union for Democracy.

The United Automobile Workers of America rejected a proposed new agreement with General Motors Corporation today and moved instead to obtain plant elections through the National Labor Relations Board.

Norman Thomas, standard bearer of the Socialist party in the United States, today voiced sharp criticism of the policies of Soviet Russia, charging that these violated Socialist principles, that they tended toward the emergence of classes, and that they constituted a denial of civil liberties.
Jesse Livermore Jr., son of the Wall Street trader, was married at a Maryland "Gretna Green" today to Mrs. Evelyn Sullivan, daughter of a former prize-fight promoter.

The Monroe National Bank of Monroe, N. Y., is among the thirty-one institutions whose receiverships were completely liquidated in October, according to an announcement today by J. F. T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency.

The National Bank of Nicaragua sent today $50,000 of newly mined gold to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by airplane. The gold will be used as a currency reserve for payment of government accounts in New York.

A tablet to the memory of Corporal Robert A. Slattery, first member of the New York City Police Department to lose his life in the World War, was dedicated at the children's playground at 183d Street and Ryer Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon. The ceremonies were attended by more than 1,200 persons. The tablet is inscribed:
Attacks by Democratic leaders upon the administration of the new State Department of Public Assistance were denounced today by social workers here as an "eleventh-hour patronage raid."
Second annual convention, Association of American Producers of Domestic Inedible Fats, begins at Hotel New Yorker this morning at 10:30 and continues tomorrow. Dinner tonight.
The St. Mary's Celtics gained 2 points yesterday in the American Soccer League series by defeating the Passon eleven of Philadelphia, 2 to 1, before a crowd of 2,000 at Celtic Park in South Brooklyn.

Miss Louise Iselin, chairman of the women's committee of the United Hospital Campaign, announced yesterday that Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney had contributed $10,000 to the drive. John W. Davis, campaign chairman, also announced a contribution of $5,000 from J. P. Morgan, the fund total now standing at $833,003.

Marking a "new harmony era," the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America for the first time will invite the active participation of their customers among the. chains, retail and wholesale . distributors in the closed sessions of the organization's twenty-ninth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 29 and 30, according to announcement by Paul S. Willis, president.
Waterfowl hunters heard a fiveword statement today that they had been waiting years to hear--"The ducks are coming back."

A drenched and tired retriever, marooned on a stone ledge by flooding brook waters for two days, was rescued today by two determined youngsters who walked in where a score of adults had feared to tread.

The search for security now in progress everywhere in the world is "one of the most perilous things we face" both in government and religion because of the impetus it gives to the totalitarian idea, declared the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.
Chicago's Bears tightened their grip on the Western Division leadership of the National Football League today by romping, over the Brooklyn Dodgers, 29 to 7, before 7,065 spectators at Wrigley Field.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York defended the efficiency of the Army Engineer Corps in its handling of matters pertaining to the improvement of rivers and harbors, flood control and related subjects in resolutions adopted by its board of directors and announced yesterday.
The United States exports of gold to France and Great Britain- were interesting as being the first important release of gold for Europe in several years.
A christening ceremony for the daughters of Mr. and Mrs. John Trecartin Ogden took place yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church.

Duke, the surprise victim of the day and Nebraska, conqueror of Minnesota, dropped from the thinning ranks of football's unbeaten on Saturday as the leaders of the East stood their ground without a single casualty in spite of rain, wind and the leveling influence of mud.
Leonora Cortez, native of Philadelphia, who has appeared in piano recitals here recurrently during the last twelve years, returned in a program at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
The Rev. Herman L. Streich, executive secretary of the general council of the Evangelical Synod of North America, died here today after an illness of several weeks. He was 58 years old.

In the polity of the Presbyterian Church the highest office is that of Moderator-an appropriate name for a presiding officer. His function as defined in the early records of the church was that of "preventing confusion in reasoning."

The body of a middle-aged woman was found washed up on the beach two miles east of here early today and was believed by police to be that of Mrs. E. N. Shackelford, who had lately been staying at the Hotel Moritz, Philadelphia.
The right to picket is a valuable right which enables union labor to focus public attention on its problems and to enlist public sympathy when its cause is just.
Tension in France over the international situation has unquestionably been relaxed on signs of England's rapprochement with Italy and Germany.

A little girl who became a celebrity by waving at the Twentieth Century Limited twice a day for three years will be the guest of honor this afternoon between 2 and 3 o'clock at the Stokes booth. They have published a juvenile book about her, entitled "The Little Girl Who Waved," by Clara A. Ford. She lives beside the railroad tracks at Elkhart, Ind., and her name is Kathleen Violet Smith.
Whether the 3-year-old Federal Communications Act prevents the government from convicting offenders through testimony obtained by wire tapping will be argued in the Supreme Court tomorrow.

In seeking to eliminate the determination of reproduction cost as a requisite for utility valuations, the Administration is motivated by considerations of economy as well as more expeditious procedure, Oswald Ryan, general counsel of the Federal Power Commission, said today.

A recount of votes cast in the Nov. 2 election has changed the result to a tie between the Republican and Democratic candidates for Mayor here, and now no one seems to know how the deadlock is to be broken.
Ernest Hemingway's first play, "The Fifth Column," was finished here today. It was all written here in the Florida, the famous hotel which has been so severely punished by Rebel shells.
" Meat strikes" by members of the women's auxiliary of the United Automobile Workers .of America were sharply rebuked today by another C. I. 0. union.

American descendants of Huguenot refugees who settled in Pennsylvania, Virginia, New Jersey and New York commemorated the 150th anniversary of the Edict of Toleration which ended the civil disabilities of the Huguenots of France and closed the time of persecution, at a jubilee service at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the National Huguenot Memorial, Church of the Huguenots, Huguenot Park, S. I.

The second concert of chamber compositions by the New Friends of Music took place yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, a concert, like its predecessor, fully patronized, and harkened to by an absorbed audience.
To Fort Jay went the football championship of the First Division at Ebbets Field yesterday as the Governors Island infantrymen turned back the artillerymen of Fort Hoyle. Md., 8 to 0.

A thirdperiod goal by Johnny Gottselig enabled Chicago's Black Hawks to gain a 3-3 overtime tie with the hard-skating Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in a fast National Hockey League battle before 13,000.

Congress must explore the "no man's land" of authority over the country's foreign relations to avoid confusion such as has been produced by President Roosevelt's disinclination to proclaim the Neutrality Act in effect toward Japan and China, Representative James A. Shanley of Connecticut said in an interview today.

The apartment house containing thirty-seven suites and seven stores at 148 Orient Avenue, corner of Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the R. O. Realty Company to a Bayonne syndicate for investment. B. F. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

Financial circles are not of the opinion that the situation in the United States is of a nature to raise fears of any real economic crisis, and there is even a feeling in some quarters that Wall Street's pessimism is exaggerated.

Edward Hungerford was selected secretary of the Silurians at the semi-annual dinner of that society of veteran newspaper men held on Saturday evening at the Hotel Lafayette, University Place and East Ninth Street, it was announced yesterday.
Playing in true championship form, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam tonight gained a decided advantage over Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris in the seventeenth game of their series for world chess honors.
Police arrested Harry Bolden, a Negro, of 1,360 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday on the charge of shooting Frank Mahoney, 35 years old, of 4,112 Quentin Road, a taxi driver.
Production of steel in Great Britain in October amounted to 1,133,600 tons, compared with the high record of 1,163,000 in the preceding month and with 1,060,500 in October, 1936.

Organization of the many ice boat clubs in the East into a workable association was started today at a gathering in the Larchmont Yacht Club. Temporary officers were elected and a rules committee was appointed. It will be known as the Eastern Ice Yachting Association. Interclub and sectional racing is expected to result.
Oakland P1. 723 (11-3095): Fannie Gershowitz to Jessie Schwartz, 723 Oakland Pl. Van Nest Ave, 681 (15-4032); Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Assn to Francesco Gandini, 1,189 Van Nest Ave.

The financial week commenced here with a general decline on the Bourse. The principal causes were the uneasy feeling caused by news from the United States and the drop in prices of raw materials. The latter naturally influenced other markets unfavorably.

Both William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and John L. Lewis, chairman of the Committee for Industrial Organization, have endorsed the work of the American Red Cross, Mrs. David Challinor, director of the Roll-Call of the New York Chapter, announced yesterday.

Institutions organized to obtain peace are driving nations into war, Professor Ruth F. Benedict, head of the Department of Anthropology at Columbia University, declared last night at a public forum at Cooper Union, Fourth Avenue and Eighth Street.

Supply contracts valued at about $4,118,991 were awarded in the week ended on Nov. 11 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor has announced.
The Fort Du Pont eleven defeated Fort Totten by scoring a touchdown on the final play of the game--a 90-yard return of an attempted place-kick. The final score was 19 to 13.
In this community, where every one seems to know what he likes in art, next Wednesday should be an exciting day.

An early end to the nineteen-county up-State milk strike was seen tonight by Jerry Loomis of Pulaski, T member of the Dairy Farmers Union Organization Committee. In a radio address he called closed business meetings of the union in each county for 8 o'clock tomorrow night to discuss discohtinuance of the strike. Later he said that he "thought it probable that the union will vote to discontinue the strike and solidify our organization."

Goodrich Leon, a son of Maurice Leon of Dublin Road, Irvington, died last night at the age of 26 after a brief illness and several years of poor health. His father is Maurice Leon, a member of the New York law firm of Evarts, Choate, Sherman Leon, 44 Wall Street. In addition to his parents, he is survived by a brother, Maurice Jr., and two sisters, Elizabeth G. and Frances W. Leon.

The importance of clinging to Christianity in a. changing world was emphasized by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Parish, in his sermon yesterday morning before the congregation of St. Agnes Chapel, the parish church in Ninety-second Street, west of Columbus Avenue.

Branding of a Jewish student, assertedly with a swastika, emblem of Nazi Germany, during a hazing of three freshmen Friday night, had tonight aroused Jewish stu-ents at the University of Delaware, at Newark, near here. Dean George E. Dutton began an investigation

The city's new $177,000 radio station, recently opened in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, could be expanded to operate as an international broadcasting station at a cost of from $40,000 to $200,000, depending on its power, Frederick J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, informed Mayor La Guardia in a letter yesterday.

Stock Exchange Stocks closed higher, recovering more than half the previous week's losses; turnover, 6,741,156 shares. United States Government and corporation bonds were steady and generally higher; Latin American issues off; transactions, $40,042,775.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Drothy Benjamin McQuade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Henry Benjamin of 229 East Seventy-ninth Street, to George von Lar of London and New York.

President Roosevelt, speaking from the White House tonight, called for "national team-work" in behalf of the census of the unemployed which is to start Tuesday, under the direction of John D. Biggers, with the mailing of questionnaires to every home.

As the government announced today that its decision on the oil-wage controversy would be delivered "within a fews days," conjecture here centered on whether United States oil concerns would get as good treatment as the British, who received an important concession in the past week in the rich Pozarica oil field.
The Order of the Chevalier of the Legion of Honor was presented today to Henry R. Luce, publisher, by Jules Henry, Minister-Charge d'Affaires at the French Embassy.

After a rousing send-off from two dozen fellow-countrymen, two Chinese pilots and a Chinese airplane mechanic left here by train today for the West Coast en route to the Orient, where they will enlist in the Chinese air service.

The New York Americans maintrained their lead in the national division of the American Soccer League yesterday when they defeated the Paterson Caledonians, 2 to 0, at Starlight Park before 3,500 fans.

More than ambitious schemes for the solution of mankind's political and social ills, mankind needs the dedication of men and women to the service and ideals of Christ it is to emerge from its present social travail, declared the Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent in his sermon yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

BANKS-William T. L. Banks, husband of Kate L. and father of Harold. Edith, Clifford, Nelson and Gladys. Nov. 13. Funeral services private. Kindly omit flowers. BERGMANN--Samuel. Cassla Chapter No; 245, 0. E. S., announces with regret the loss of its member Brother Samuel Bergmann, husband of Right Worthy Sarah is Bergmann, Past Matron. Funeral 1,283 Coney Island Ave., Monday, Nov. 15, 11A.M. SIMILIS LIPSITZ, Worthy Matron. GERTRUDE BUCHBENHOLZ, Secy.

Banking reports on Great Britain's trade situation and outlook continue encouraging. The Autumn revival, to date, is conceded to be making normal progress. Current business is good, although there are signs of diminution in the volume of new orders here.

The National Lawyers Guild, of which Judge John P. Devaney is president, stated today that it would publish on Nov. 22 the first issue of a quarterly that would provide a medium for expression of the "liberal legal viewpoint" on national questions.

Gift merchandise continued to lead in orders placed in the local wholesale market last week. In addition, initial orders were placed on the new black-and-white, screen printed crepe and printed synthetic jersey dresses offered for mid-season selling.
Sheriff Tom Cannon, who guided James A. Farley from the Grand Coulee Dam to Wenatchee when the Postmaster General dedicated the postoffice here, had a letter today from Mr. Farley.

The Rev. William Otto Bruckner was installed yesterday as pastor of St. Paul's Lutheran Church, South Fifth Street and Rodney Street, Brooklyn. He formerly was pastor of the First Lutheran Church of Bridgeport, Conn.
Washington F. Norton, Babylon's oldest resident, will celebrate his ninetythird birthday tomorrow.

The Republic Steel Corporation announced today that it had assumed control of properties of the Witherbee Sherman Corporation pending approval of a twenty-five-year lease by Witherbee Sherman stockholders.

Columbia University ended its fiscal year on June 30, 1937, with total resources valued at $119,230,976, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, in making public the annual report of Frederick A. Goetze, treasurer.

Without venturing to minimize the importance of youth in the task of building a better world, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers declared in his sermon yesterday in Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, that the older generation, experienced and mature, must bear a large share of the responsibility and obligation.

John Hay of 510 Park Avenue, New York, a student at Lafayette College, was robbed of his automobile and $1.47 late today by a youth who had asked him for a ride on the Brunswick Pike in Raritan Township.

Basic proposals for reorganization of Sigma Delta Chi, journalistic fraternity, to include junior, alumni and associate members were approved today at the national convention. The program will be submitted to a referendum of college and alumni chapters within sixty days.
Congress will convene in extraordinary session at noon tomorrow beset by more misgivings as to its future course than at any time during the last four and two-third years.
After three months of almost uninterrupted decline, the stock market this week enjoyed a substantial recovery due to a more cheerful diagnosis of the international situation.

Patrolman Thomas Reaney, 40 years old, of 595 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, attached to Traffic L, was taken from his home to Methodist Episcopal Hospital shortly after 10 o'clock last night, suffering from a bullet wound in the left chest.
After a lull of several weeks the Japanese war machine operating in the Tientsin-Pukow Railway sector has once more swung into aggressive action, driving east, south and west along the railway.
The Washington Redskins were upset by a determined Pittsburgh Pirate eleven, 21-13, in a thrilling National Football League game today before a crowd of 12,000.

Further action looking to the establishment of minimum prices was taken yesterday by the National Bituminous Coal Commission when it determined the weighted average costs of producing bituminous coal in minimum price areas numbers 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9 and 10.
Our thoughtful government has been planning a number of civic paradises from Alaska to Alabama.

Assemblyman Frank C. Osmers Jr., who said on Nov. 4 that he would ask the Legislature at its special session tomorrow to order an investigation of alleged election irregularities in Hudson County, announced at his home here today that since the Supreme Court had authorized a recount in Hudson he would not move for such action, pending the outcome of the recount.

Restrictions on the sale of liquor have been imposed in Moscow and Leningrad and they probably will be followed by similar measures in other large centers in order to reduce the amount of drinking and "hooliganism" (a good Russian word meaning exactly what the same word means in English).

John Hay of 510 Park Avenue, New York, a student at Lafayette College, was robbed of his automobile and $1.47 late today by a youth who had asked him for a ride on the Brunswick Pike in Raritan Township.

Basic proposals for reorganization of Sigma Delta Chi, journalistic fraternity, to include junior, alumni and associate members were approved today at the national convention. The program will be submitted to a referendum of college and alumni chapters within sixty days.
Congress will convene in extraordinary session at noon tomorrow beset by more misgivings as to its future course than at any time during the last four and two-third years.
After three months of almost uninterrupted decline, the stock market this week enjoyed a substantial recovery due to a more cheerful diagnosis of the international situation.

Patrolman Thomas Reaney, 40 years old, of 595 Eleventh Street, Brooklyn, attached to Traffic L, was taken from his home to Methodist Episcopal Hospital shortly after 10 o'clock last night, suffering from a bullet wound in the left chest.
After a lull of several weeks the Japanese war machine operating in the Tientsin-Pukow Railway sector has once more swung into aggressive action, driving east, south and west along the railway.

The recent sudden death of Captain Gordon Horsbrugh, marine superintendent of the Cunard White Star Line at Liverpool, is causing considerable confusion in the plans for the changes in the personnel of the fleet that were to be announced at the end of the year.

Chaminade High School fell easy prey to a hard-charging La Salle Military Academy eleven today and lost by a 33-6 score. The cadets scored 20 points in the first period and coasted for the remainder of the game.

Scoring twice in rapid-fire fashion in the second period, the George Washington High School football team downed a fighting St. Francis Prep eleven, 12 to 6, in an interborough game at George Washington Stadium yesterday.

" The majority of farmers of the Middle Vest are opposed to compulsory rop control," Senator Capper -of Kansas asserted in discussing in an interview the subject that Presi Lent Roosevelt placed first in his message to Congress today.

Every member of the Harvard varsity football squad was on the field in uniform today. Captain Allen, however, did not join in team practice, even being kept out of the signal line-up, but George Klein was back at right guard.

Fifteen sailors who tossed helplessly on pieces of wreckage for more than thirty hours in a raging sea off Cape Hatteras rested comfortably at a hospital here tonight after being brought safely to shore on a Coast Guard cutter this morning.

Traffic accidents and the number of persons injured because of them increased last week compared with figures covering the corresponding week in 1936, it was announced yesterday by the traffic bureau of the Police Department.
Plans for a half-million dollar store to be opened in Beverly Hills, Calif., about April 1, were announced here yesterday by Adam L. Gimbel, president of Saks-Fifth Avenue. The move to establish a

Today's major events: Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, at Carnegie Hall in the evening; Glauco D'Attili, pianist, at the Town Hall this afternoon, and Walter Mills, baritone, in the evening. Leota Lane, soprano, and Virginia Hamister, pianist, will appear in recital tonight at the BarbizonPlaza in aid of Tau Alpha chapter of Mu Phi Epsilon, national honorary music society.

J. P. Morgan returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary from his annual vacation in Europe, on which he started in his steam yacht Corsair on July 19. He spent three weeks at his shooting box on the Stottish moors.

All living graduates of the United States Military Academy at West Point are entitled to tire degree of Bachelor of Science and may receive it by applying to the superintendent of the academy, it was announced yesterday at the Second Corps Area headquarters, Governors Island.

Within an hour after the Red Cross enrollment booth was opened yesterday morning in the lobby of the New York Stock Exchange Building, the contribution boxes were filled and the volunteers in charge were requesting more coin containers, Mrs. David Challinor, director of the Red Cross Roll Call of the New York Chapter, announced last night.

Today without formality a fivestory mansion at 814 Fifth Avenue moves into the front rank of the world's small but great art museums. It is the former home of Jules S. Bache, banker, who announced last April his gift to the State of New York of the building and the great collection it houses.

In two stadiums, on Saturday, one figuratively washed by the waters of the Pacific and the other by the Atlantic, the chances for earthshattering upsetting will be presented even in the day when the upset is being taken more or less

The epithet "liar" was exchanged between former Premier Andre Tardieu and Colonel Francois de la Rocque, French Rightist leader, at a hearing today in the latter's libel suit against seventeen persons and newspapers for accusing him of having accepted money from the government's secret funds.

President Getulio Vargas's first official appearance since the promulgation of his new Constitution last Wednesday evoked a great popular ovation this morning. Brazil observed today the fortyninth anniversary of the republic, unveiling a bronze equestrian monument on the Boulevard Beiramar to Marshal Manoel Deodoro da Fonseca, the republic's first President.
Every one, including the author, has conspired to make a tumultuous one-act play out of "Too Many Heroes," which was put on at the Hudson last evening.

Although 2 per cent less new life insurance was sold last month than in October a year ago, the total for the first ten months this year was 5.7 per cent more than in the same period of 1936, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.

Carlos (Indian) Quintana, 119 1/2, of Panama pounded out an eightround triumph over Johnny Compo of New Haven at the St. Nicholas Palace last night before 2,500 fans. Quintana's spurt in the last two rounds decided.
The Syracuse football squad, recovering from the Columbia game last week, had an easy workout today as it commenced the drive for the objective battle with Colgate Saturday.

Returning to Paris today from Spain, where he had been for one month, Sam Baron, American Socialist, expressed his conviction that, unless there was an immediate change in the Loyalist Government to include the Largo Caballero Socialist and U. G. T. trade union groups and the C. N. T. Anarchist-controlled trades unions, "the war against the Fascists" would be lost.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called hearings in proceedings to determine whether the $10par preferred capital stock and the $10-par common capital stock of the Autoline Oil Company, and the first and refunding-mortgage 6 per cent Series A bonds, due in 1945, of United Towns Electric Company, Ltd., should be withdrawn or suspended from listing and registration on the Baltimore Stock Exchange.

Dr. Albert C. Barnes, art connoisseur and collector who heads the Barnes Foundation in Merion, said today that Philadelphia had been "stung" by paying $110,000 for Cezanne's "Bathers," a painting which he termed "about fifth-rate quality for a Cezanne."

A directed verdict of acquittal for nineteen major oil companies and forty-five individuals charged with illegal fixing of mid-West gasoline prices in 1935-36 was asked today by William J. Donovan, chief defense counsel.

Boston, Mass., which awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co., an issue of $2,307,000 of relief and airport improvement bonds, will re-enter the market tomorrow with an issue of $6,000,000 of temporary-loan notes. The notes will be dated Nov. 19, 1937, and will be due on Nov. 1, 1938.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks indicated in Federal Court here today that he would sign an order tomorrow authorizing the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company to proceed with the sale of the New England Steamship Company's Fall River liners "Commonwealth," "Plymouth," "Providence" and "Priscilla" for $88,000 for scrap purposes.

" In relating the conditions today to the framing of the Constitution 150 years ago, there is the danger that some will visit upon ,the fathers the sins of their sons," Professor Thomas Reed Powell of Harvard, an authority on constitutional law, told an audience of students, faculty and alumnae at Wellesley College tonight. He spoke at.

Jervis J. Babb, for the last six years with the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, has become associated with Booz-Fry-Allen and Hamilton, business surveys, Chicago and New York, effective today. Mr. Babb's headquarters will be in Chicago.

The most drastic cut in oil production in Texas since the wells in the East Texas fields were closed down by Governor R. S. Sterling in 1928 was ordered today by the State Railroad Commission when it instructed operators that the approximately 24,000 wells in the East Texas field must suspend production on the next four Sundays.
Dr. James I. Seder, 79-yearold kidnap victim held ten days in an abandoned coal mine in what Federal agents declared was a futile $50,000 extortion plot, died early today of pneumonia.

Henry Robinson Luce, editor and publisher of Time, Fortune and Life magazines, has been chosen to receive the Montclair Yale bowl as a graduate "who has made his 'Y' in life," at the annual Yale barn party to be held here on Saturday evening, Dec. 4, it was announced today by Nicholas Roberts, chairman of the executive board of the Yale Club of Montclair.

Mayor La Guardia, president of the United States Conference of Mayors, asserted at the opening of the conference's annual session here today that there had been no definite improvement in the unemployment situation in the cities.

While Congress heard President Roosevelt's message today outlining the reasons for calling it in special session, he was in conference with Secretary Wallace. The President and Mr. Wallace Vac discussed the farm bill, one of the principal reasons-for the special seesion, but Mr. Wallace would not say that he had reported "progress on the farm hill situation."

Knopf will publish on Jan. 10 a new novel by Robert Nathan, author of "One More Spring," "The Enchanted Voyage," etc. It is called "Winter in April." Carl Crow, author of "400,000,000 Customers" (Harper), will be a guest of honor and speaker at the Dutch Treat Club luncheon today. Frank Crowninshield will preside.

John Kent Kane, lawyer, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his home, Shirley Farms, Frazer, after an illness of three weeks. He was 64 years old. Born in Wilmington, Del., Mr. Kane was the son of the late Dr. John Kent Kane and Mabel Bayard Kane. He was a nephew of Elisha

MRS. ROOSEVELT'S volume of memoirs* proves to be very much the sort of thing one would suspect from Mrs. Roosevelt--a candid, enlightened and womanly book, neither scintillating nor dull, neither indiscreet nor reticent. Because in. point of time it stops short of the present (about 1924) it is of secondary political interest; it is chiefly noteworthy, as a record of personal development.

Phil Weintraub, hard-hitting first baseman-outfielder, has been sent by the Giants to the Baltimore Orioles of the International League in part payment for Harold (Hy) Vandenberg, right-handed pitcher, the Giant office announced yesterday.

Abraham Lincoln High School's undefeated but twice-tied eleven overpowered New Utrecht High, 32 to 7, at Lincoln Field in Brooklyn yesterday. The victory was the third for Lincoln. A crowd of 3,000 saw the game.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 10: An increase of $19,000,000

Helen Hayes, appearing here in 'Victoria Regina," intends to devote herself to "raising flowers" with her husband and child at the farm they purchased outside New York as soon as the run of her current tour ends.

About 200 key men in the city's snow, fighting army will recieve intensive training in the handling of their new mechanical equipment at Lake Placid as soon as the snow flies there, Sanitation Commissioner Carey said yesterday.

Representative Snell, House Mi nority'Leader, took an oral jab at the "Roosevelt depression" tonight and predicted that "if conditions go along as they have been, you'll see an entirely different complexion on the seventy-sixth Congress." The recent elections in New York and Ohio indicated more Republican gains in the future, he said.

Morris Ave (11-2806); e s 100 n of 177th St, 40x110: Joseph Horowitz to Rose H. Mendelsohn, 296 17th Ave, Paterson, N. J.; mtg, $18,000. 184th St, 15 W (11-3199): Maybelle Primus to Ernest Morlock, 59 W 182d St.

BRETTEL, JULIE B. (Aug. 4, 1937). Gross assets, $27,924; net, $26,167. To William L. Brettel, brother, $1,000 and one-third residue; Clinton Brettel, nephew and Charles F. Brettel, brother, $500 and one-third residue each; one other bequest. Chief assets, mortgages, notes. cash and insurance, $19,316. Alfred Byrne, attorney, 154 Nassau St.

President Roosevelt sent his message to the special session of Congresi, discussed farm legislation with Secretary Wallace and the farm and wages and hours bills with Representative Alfred L. Bulwinkle of North Carolina.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 36.4 per cent of ingot capacity, a decline of 4.6 points, or 11.2 per cent, from last week and the lowest rate since the week of Dec. 24, 1934, with the exception of two weeks in early July, 1935. Last week the rate was 41.0 per cent of capacity and one month ago 55.8 per cent.
Byron (Whizzer) White, able Colorado quarterback, is the nation's new leader in football scoring, according to the Associated Press.

With displays by 350 exhibitors, an increase of 52 per cent over the 230 at last year's show, the twentysecond National Hotel Exposition opened at Grand Central Palace yesterday and first-day attendance was described as better than usual. Total value of exhibits was estimated at $400,000. Charles S.

While warnings of difficulties were being issued all about him, 61-year-old Judge Samuel Eugene Hoyt, State's Attorney from New Haven, Conn., today moved into the presidency of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States without opposition.

Two Montclair boys, Henry Dent, 12 years old, a negro, of 133 Forest Street, and Carlo Lombardi, 7, of Forest Street, proudly displayed "Kindness to Animal" medals today, bestowed upon them by the Animal Welfare League of Montclair for rescuing a drenched and tired retriever, owned by Thomas F. Russell Jr. of 30 Cloverhill

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Page Maxfield Summerlin of this city, daughter of Mrs. Louis Henry Maxfield of Paget, Gloucester, Va., and the late Commander Maxfield, U. S. N., to Otto Marx Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Marx of New York and Mamaroneck, formerly of Birmingham, Ala. The wedding took place on

Charles Evans Hughes, Chief Justice of the United States, has withdrawn from honorary membership in the American Press Society, it was announced yesterday by Oliver Holden, chairman of the organization's board of governors.

Gordon Drillon, the Toronto Maple Leafs' rookie sensation of last Winter, leads the parade of the National Hockey League pointgetters in the first official scoring statistics issued by the league tonight.

This outpost of the British Empire paid tribute this afternoon to the memory of Ramsay MacDonald, former Prime Minister of Great Britain,. with the pomp and circumstance of State rites. A crowd of 20,000 lined Hamilton's principal streets to witness the slow procession of the funeral cortege to the cathedral, where tonight the former Premier's body is lying in state.

The opinion that the world powers do not want another great war but do want a number of small wars was expressed here last night by H. C. Engelbrecht, co-author of "Merchants of Death" and recently author of "Revolt Against War." He was one of three authors who addressed the evening visitors at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, which is now in its last week at Rockefeller Center.

Trading opened slow on most classes of locally dressed meats yesterday. Price trends were downward on traefa meats. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be uneven, veal and calf about steady, lamb stronger, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The debutante committee for the Kosciuszko Foundation's fifth annual "Night in Poland Ball" will hold its first meeting at a tea tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Cass Gilbert, 1 East Ninetyfourth Street. The committee is under the chairmanship of Miss Julia Gilbert Post, debutante daughter of Charles Morgan Post and granddaughter of Mrs. Gilbert.

Willie Hoppe successfully launched the defense of his world's professional 18.1 balkline billiard chainpionship yesterday at the Capitol Academy. Stroking smoothly and with remarkable accuracy, Hoppe gained a commanding lead over Jake Schaefer of Chicago in their 3,000-point challenge match and at the completion of the opening two blocks showed the way by 500-154.

The "line of talk needed to get the money" was given to the women's committee of the United Hospital Campaign yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, appearing in the role of sales counselor at the third report meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

With rumors of the wildest kind on every tongue, increasing nervousness is apparent in Nanking as a result of the Chinese withdrawals from the Shanghai district and the steady approach of Japanese troops by land, river and lake routes.

Holders of Kreuger Toll secured 5 per cent gold debentures have received about $515 for each $1,000 bond, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing in the Supreme Court of a referee's report recommending approval of an intermediate accounting of the Marine Midland Trust Company as trustee for the issue.

Mayor Ralph F. de Clairmont handed his resignation to the City Council tonight because he had found it necessary to go to Europe for an indefinite length of time on business. This leaves the council split 2 to 2 on current municipal problems.

A brisk demand for locations in the manufacturing districts below Fourteenth Street featured the report of business rentals yesterday. The Boston Suitcase Corporation took a floor in 35 West Third Street, the Dorene Manufacturing

State powers were sustained by a 6-to-3 vote in the Supreme Court today when the majority ruled that a corporation previously dissolved by Illinois could not be revived for the purpose of seeking financial reorganization under the National Bankruptcy Act.

Fifteen nations at Brussels yesterday adopted a resolution holding Japan was "out of step with the rest of the world" and arguing she should discuss her course in China with other nations. Italy voted against the

A spinal meningitis epidemic is spreading on the island of Ushant, fourteen miles from the Finisterre coast. The inhabitants, most of whom are lighthouse keepers, government radio operators and fishermen, sent a wireless appeal for aid.

The problem of neutrality will be brought to the front early in this special session of Congress. It was a matter of discussion in Senate and House circles today, and an effort to enact legislation that will be mandatory in nature appears fairly certain. That the effort will be successful is doubtful.

More than thirty giant flying boats took over the mission of destroyers today as the reorganized United States Fleet began its manoeuvres. The giant patrol planes, each with a radius of about 5,000 miles, replaced the destroyers in the scouting force.

Real and important progress toward ratification of the peace treaties signed here last December on the occasion of President Roosevelt's visit has been made in the last few days as a result of an aerial tour by five well-known American women representing the People's Mandate to End War.

Mme. Vyacheslaff Molotoff, the Soviet Premier's wife, who was promoted yesterday from head of the Soviet Cosmetic Trust to Vice Commissar of the Food Industry, has surrendered her cosmetic post, it was announced today by the Food Commissariat.

Great Britain has evidently decided to explore once again the possibilities of an agreement with Germany that might be made the basis for general European appeasement. For this ambitious undertaking the Cabinet has significantly chosen Lord Halifax, who has a reputation for friendliness toward the Reich-not Mr. Eden, who is believed to have opposed such an approach to Hitler at this time.

Commenting yesterday on the recent assertion of Magistrate Frank Oliver in Traffic Court that the city traffic lights were rendered confusing by the myriad colored lights of advertising signs, Police Commissiner Valentine said that the entire problem had been referred to his traffic division for survey and report.

One member each of the Irish Free State and United States Army teams qualified tonight for the final in the class for open hunters at the Royal Winter Fair horse show. Only twelve of seventy-eight entrants passed the preliminary round.

The stock market here today was firm on the whole, with sentiment bolstered by the strength in Wall Street on Saturday. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while among the foreign bonds, German and Japanese loans attracted support.

Discussions between Great Britain and the United States over whether to attempt the negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement have entered an extremely active phase. The discussions, proceeding simultaneously here and in London, have not yet reached a definite point, but an announcement may be possible soon.

The Army football squad held a light workout on the plains gridiron today. The field was wet from an all-day rain and most of those players who went through the Notre Dame battle on Saturday were resting. The B squad, armed with Navy plays, were pitted against second and third string men in a defensive drill.

The first resale price contracts in the confectionery industry have been signed between Rockwood Co., Brooklyn, manufacturers of cocoa and chocolate, and eleven candy jobbers, it was announced yesterday by Herbert Tenzer, counsel for the Confectionery and Tobacco Jobbers Association, Inc.

American mothers are showing greater interest in the problems of very young children, Mrs. Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg, director of the Child Study Association of America, said last night at the association's annual meeting at its headquarters, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden remained in the seclusion of his home today while Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, was preparing to leave for Berlin tomorrow afternoon-a day earlier than originally had been planned.

A little more than half a century ago two young citizens of New York, Arthur Curtiss James and William M. Kingsley, started a boys' club, to which they gave the name of its birthplace, Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst's church, which looked out upon Madison Square. The church has gone and Madison Square has become the front yard of great insurance companies.

Don Bruce of Port Jefferson High led a field of thirty-five in the tenth annual La Salle Military Academy interscholastic cross-country run between the halves of the La SalleChaminade football game today.
In contrast to the action of the stock market, listed bonds displayed a fairly firm tone in dealings on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, although the volume of transactions fell off.

36th St, 402-04 W, 16x50 and 19x61.11; Gansevoort Realties, Inc, to Kaproco Realty Corp, 822 Greenwich St. 3d Ave, n e cor 95th St. 25.8 1/2x100; Raphael L. Elias to Rose Joelson, 1,515 MacCombs Rd, Bronx. consideration $500 over first mtg $30,000: foreclosure.

Lord Vivian, who arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday after a visit with Mr. and Mrs. David Wagstaff in Tuxedo Park, will sail tomorrow on the Queen Mary to return to his home in Cornwall. Mr. and Mrs. Grosvenor Farwell are at 157 East Seventy-second Street for the Winter.

Preparations for the creation of an imperial general headquarters to take supreme direction of the war in China are complete, and the headquarters can be established now on a few days' notice by simple petition to the Emperor by the chiefs of the Army and Navy general staffs.

Over the rain-soaked hills and flatlands at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday Michigan State fled to its fifth consecutive cross-country championship of the Intercollegiate A. A. A. A. and permanent possession of a trophy that has been in competition for twenty-three years.
