King Leopold of Belgium will come here tomorrow in the full panoply of a state visit, but reports that weighty political conferences will mark his stay are discounted in the best-informed quarters.

John A. Dilliard, former president of the now defunct State Title and Mortgage Company, who was sentenced in 1935 to six months in jail for making false financial statements, and in 1936 won an appeal from his conviction, went on trial yesterday in Federal Court for alleged mail fraud growing out of the same charges.
Announcement was made here last night of the death on Monday in the Presbyterian Hospital, Chicago, of the Rev. Dr. Frank W. Bible, executive secretary of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions.

The President came closer to a cooperative attitude toward business today than at any time since he pressed through the emergency bank legislation and the Economy Act of 1933. Thus he verified recent predictions and sustained recent hopes, and the buzz of corridor Congressional conversation this afternoon attested how accurately he reflected the political feeling.

The Beethoven Association began its nineteenth season at the Town Hall last night with a program of music by Beethoven and Bach. It was cheering to note that the auditorium was almost filled, for this is an enterprise that deserves public support. Musicians of reputation come together to give an annual series of concerts "in a spirit of artistic fraternity."

The removal of hardships and inequities resulting from the undistributed profits tax, and wide tax relief to the smaller corporations, was agreed upon unanimously as their objective by members of the subcommittee on taxation of the House Ways and Means Committee, its chairman, Representative Fred Vinson, said tonight.

A woman was killed yesterday morning in the kitchen of her eighth-floor home in the Mirabeau, 165 West Ninety-first Street, by a mysterious explosion that cracked the walls and windows of near-by apartments.

Governor Lehman has been asked to make a prompt investigation of "the fitness of Albert Marinelli to continue to hold office as County Clerk of New York County," in a petition made public yesterday. The petition asserts that charges made against the Democratic district leader by Thomas E. Dewey in his campaign three weeks ago "still stand undisputed and unrefuted."

Daniel J. Kennedy, a lawyer and banker, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Ardmore. He was 46 years old. Mr. Kennedy was a star athlete at Holy Cross college, from which he was graduated in 1912, and he was actively connected with athletics throughout his life.

Chief of Police Alex Rosenswaike and Lieutenant Harry Yale, both of the Island Park (L. I.) Police Deapartment, and five co-defendants went on trial yesterday in the day Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions on a charge of conspiracy to obtain money under false pretenses by operating a charity scheme in which several thousand persons allegedly were victimized.

Every able-bodied Nicaraguan male between the ages of 12 and 15 living in districts infested by locusts will be required to devote one eight-hour day to destroying the pest which is devouring most of the cotton, corn, bean and rice crops.

Common Pleas Judge Charles S. Bell weighed tonight the question of a new trial for Anna Marie Hahn, who on Nov. 6 heard a jury doom her to the electric chair as the poison-slayer of 78-year-old Jacob Wagner. After two hours

The three-story store and dwelling at 784 Broadway, Bayonne, N. J., was sold by the Provident Institution for Savings in Jersey City to Minnie Rapport, through Julius A. Rose, agent. Sale was for cash

State Insurance Department officials declared yesterday that although the reduction in automobile liability insurance premiums would save car owners in this State about $3,500,000 the coming year, only new policy holders would receive the major benefits under the revised rates.

The time for exchange of Public Service Company of Northern Illinois Company common and preferred stocks for capital stock of the Commonwealth Edison Company has been extended to Dec. 21. Holders of 80 per cent of the combined issues have accepted the exchange.

It seems inevitable that the first place where the Chinese troops can rally and attempt another stand will be on a line extending from the Kiangyin forts on the south bank of the Yangtze River, south through Wusih and thence to the north bank of Lake Tai, west of Shanghai.

ADAMS-In Westport, Conn., on Nov. 15, 1937, Minnie Wood, widow of Willard S. Adams. Funeral services at the Charles H. Lewis Funeral Home, 83 E. State St., Westport, Conn., on Thursday, Nov. 18, at 2 P. M. Interment Willow Brook Cemetery.

The Princeton Theatre Intime's second production of the current season, Ben Jonson's five-act Elizabethan comedy, "Volpone," was presented tonight in Murray Theatre before an opening-night audience of 150 persons.

A new issue of' $25,000,000 of three-year 2 per cent consolidated debentures, Series C, of the Federal Home Loan Banks will be offered to the public today, Preston Delano, Governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, announced yesterday. The debentures will be due

Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, president of Princeton University, in response to inquiries today as to whether he would accept the chairmanship of the committee on program of the Republican party, declared his "obligations to Princeton would preclude acceptance of such a post."
Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Sterling gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Alethia Sheldon and R. Alastair MacLeod, who will be married on Thursday.

MANHATTAN CLUTE, M. MATILDA (Mtrch 22). Estate, less than $1,000. To Eugene Clute, son, executor, 114 E. 32d St. ESLER, WILLIAM T. (Nov. 7). Estate, less than $1,000. To Mildred C. Esler, widow, executrix, 5 Prospect PI., residue; two specific bequests. FLEMING, JOHN (July 8). Estate, less than $5,000. To Mary Larkin, sister, 111 W. 60th St., residue. The Public Administrator, petitioner.

Sharp declines in national and financial advertising were responsible for a drop of 1.2 per cent in total newspaper advertising in fifty cities for October, according to Media Records figures yesterday. Linage for last month was 134,979,361, as against 136,635,194 in the corresponding month of 1936.

Purses for four important stake events for 3-year-olds and upward at Belmont Park, Elmont, L. I., have been increased for the 1938 Spring meeting, it was announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association.

New York's three new members of the House were sworn in today by Speaker Bankhead. They are Bruce Barton of New York City, Ralph A. Gamble of Larchmont and Lewis k. Rockefeller of Hypdson, Republicans. Also sworn in were Dave E. Satterfield Jr. of Virginia and Lawrence J. Connery of Massachusetts, Democrats. Mr. Connery succeeds

Four charities receive bequests totaling $50,000 in the will of Mrs. Carrie L. Lehman, wife of Philip Lehman, senior partner of Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, who died on Nov. 10. Mrs. Lehman left her residuary estate in equal shares to her son and daughter. Her will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 23 and 24-Chicago Title and Trust Co. as successor trustee under the trust deed recorded as Document No. 10325493, petr., v. Forty-one Thirty-six Wilcox Building Corp. Decrees reversed and cause remanded to the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois. Opinion by Justice Sutherland. Dissenting opinion by Justice Cardozo, in which Justices Stone and Black join.

The nation's first all air-conditioned Congress assembled in special session today amid a blaze of colorfrom Senatorial neckties. While hot air hissed from the new system in the ceiling, the solons hand-shook their way into the chamber and spread out in a cravated rainbow that made veteran observers gasp.

The deflationary cycle set in motion by the stock market crash last month reached the food industry last week, pulling down retailers' dollar sales volume an average of 3 to 5 per cent, according to the national weekly survey of activity compiled by the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.

Closing its eighty-third annual convention here today, the New Jersey State Teachers Association went on record in favor of a graduated State tax on personal and corporate incomes to replace the present State school tax on real estate.
Rochester Socialist leaders were undecided today on a plan to combat action by the party's State Committee in revoking the charter of the local organization.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 14 unless specified: Crlstobal to San Diego, Nov. 15: Balch, Winslow. At Guantanamo Bay: Gannet, Patriot. At Mare Island Yard: Lark, Whitney. At San Pedro: Patridge. Nov. 13; Nltro. Acushnet, Washington Yard to Dahlgren Nov. 15.

One of the most unusual doubles in Bowie racing history was brought off today by Houghton P. Metcalf of Rhode Island when his Little Sally captured the third race, to be followed by his High Velocity in the featured Eden Handicap. Doubles,

Mrs. Gussie Stein Miller, clubwoman and wife of Louis Miller, Port Chester merchant, died yesterday at the Aurora Health Farm in Morristown, N. J. Her age was 54. She was a member of the Jewish Community Center and Sisterhood, the Council of Jewish Women, the Port Chester Women's Club,

" Merely Murder" was presented at Ford's Theatre this evening with Claudia Morgan and Douglass Montgomery in the principal roles. The scenes of the play are laid in a London suburb and the characters are representative English people.
Colonel John Tevis Hearn, founder of The Knoxville (Tenn.) Sentinel and The Shelbyville (Ky.) Sentinel, died here at the home of a son, Paul H. Hearn, early today. He was 95 years old.

Production of knitted underwear, other than glove silk and rayon, for Sepmember, 1937, totaled 1,655,835 dozen garments, compared with 1,650,707 in August and 1,999,498 in September, 1936, according to figures just made public by the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce. September shipments totaled 2,299,795 dozens, against 1,980,246 in August and 2,482,660 in September a year ago.

Columbia's first eleven and several of the top-ranking reserves were excused from practice yesterday, but the rest of the squad was sent through a heavy drill on rainsoaked Baker Field, where the Lions will meet Dartmouth on Saturday.

Most futures declined in fairly active trading on the local exchanges yesterday. Coffee futures were higher on short covering. In the cash markets, oats, cocoa and silk advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, flour, lard, pork, cotton, wool tops and rubber declined.

Basil (Pat) Ryan, wealthy young New Yorker, said in an interview here this afternoon that he did not remember going through a marriage ceremony on Nov. 4 with Miss Martha Barkley, 21-year-old Morganton girl.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Hurlburt, daughter of Mrs. William B. Hurlburt of Brookside, this place, and the late Mr. Hurlburt, to Arthur Leonard of Danbury, Conn., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Leonard, has been announced by her mother.

With the Spring buying season for men's clothing and furnishings finally under way, orders for the majority of stores are two to three months later than they were a year ago, according to reports yesterday by manufacturers and sellers.

The nation Is not interested In the fact that Herbert Hoover does not like Alf M. Landon and that Mr. Landon does not like Mr. Hoover, William F. Bleakley, Republican candidate for Governor in 1936, told several hundred party members at the Seventh Assembly District Republican Club last night.

The British Government's program for the protection of the civil population against air raids was the subject of lively debate in the House of Commons today as Sir Samuel Hoare, Home Secretary, explained in detail this work in the face of criticism that Britain was lagging far behind Germany and France.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. declared yesterday a dividend of payable on Dec. 14 to stock of record of Nov. 22. A similar year-end dividend was paid on Dec. 15 last. The action taken yesterday brings distributions voted for 1937 to $6.25 a share, compared with $6.10 paid in 1936.

H. G. Wells will be a guest speaker in the Book Fair auditorium tonight at 8 o'clock. The chairman will be Colonel Theodore Roosevelt Jr. The other guest speakers are poets: Robert Frost, three times winner of the Pulitzer Prize; Robert Silliman Hillyer, Boylston Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory at Harvard, also a Pulitzer prize winner, and. Mark Van Doren, poet and editor of poetry anthologies.

Thirty-three seniors and one junior in the four-year course in hotel administration at Cornell University took over for three hours yesterday morning the entire management of the Hotel Astor. With the regular executive personnel keeping the students under rigid supervision, theory was made to agree with practice.

The National Labor Relations Board yesterday released the brief it has filed against Remington Rand, Inc., in the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second District. The case was presented by the NRLB to enforce the board's findings against the company issued March 13.

Consolidated earnings of the Houston Oil Company of Texas and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Houston Pipe Line Company, in the third quarter of this year amounted to $328,411 after expenses, interest, depreciation, depletion, amortization and Federal income taxes.

New York's rival hockey teams, the Rangers and the Americans, will swing into action against each other for the first time in the current National League race tonight at Madison Square Garden. With both sextets noted for their aggressive, wide-open play, indications

Grand National today purchased "Angels With Dirty Faces" by Rowland Brown for $30,000 as James Cagney's next vehicle, a transaction that should allay for a time the persistent reports that the player is returning to Warners in the near future.

Dance International, an exposition of the dance in all its aspects, will open at the International Building, Rockefeller Center, Nov. 29 and continue through Jan. 2 with more than forty nations participating, it was announced yesterday by Miss Louise Branch, chairman.
Burglars equipped with sledgehammers and a "can-opener" invaded thirteen offices in the sixstory building at 690 Eighth Avenue, between Forty-third and Fortyfourth Streets, over the week-end.

Arthur Sloane, 27 years old, of 1,475 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, was sent to jail yesterday for five days in lieu of $10 fine because he sat down on the sidewalk when the police attempted to arrest him in a disturbance outside the Horn Hardart Automat at 1,557 Broadway.

James T. Burns of Kankakee, Ill., soldier, judge and legislator, died at the Hines Memorial Hospital in Maywood today of a stomach ailment attributed to injuries he suffered in France during the World War. He was 59 years old.

George J. Gillespie, president of the Board of Water Supply of this city and an outstanding Catholic layman in the United States, will marry on Saturday morning, Nov. 27, Miss Leonore M. Tierney, assistant principal in charge of Public School 68, Bushwick Avenue and Kosciusko Street. Brooklyn.

IN the football gathering the verbal blocking, tackling, forward passing and deep reversing went approximately as follows: "The way I figure it, Harvard is just about right to take Yale. Harvard can't always" "Ever hear of a player named Clint Frank? If he doesn't break a couple of legs in practice this week he'll ruin Harvard."
That part of Mayor La Guardia's address before the United States Conference of Mayors today, dealing with unemployment, labor and taxes, follows:

The dress returns problem was attacked yesterday in two moves when Louis Rubin, executive director of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, announced he would file with the Federal Trade Commission today a complaint under the Robinson-Patman act, and Mortimer Lanzit, executive director of the National Dress Manufacturers' Association, issued a statement calling for establishment of a joint board of control for the dress industry.

They say dogs don't reason, but we heard the story of Dash, an Irish setter, who not only reasoned but tried to teach his master that some snakes were dangerous and others weren't. As to the motives behind Dash's action, you may make your own interpretation, but we vouch for the complete varacity of the story, for we know the man who told it.

Harvey Titus Brown, secretary, treasurer and a director of the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., died yesterday at his home, 111-04 Seventy-sixth Drive, Forest Hills, Queens, after a brief illness. He was in his early eighties.
One of the State's leading colleges for women went into the hands of a woman receiver today when the Title Guarantee and Trust Company brought proceedings against Adelphi College, Garden City, L. I.

An opinion that a bank should be considered a customer rather than a broker or dealer for purposes of the over-the-counter market regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission, given by David Saperstein, director of the Trading and Exchange Division of that agency, in reply to an inquiry by the Investment Bankers Conference, Inc., was made public today by the SEC.
Mrs. Florette Guggenheim, widow of Benjamin Guggenheim, who perished on the Titanic, died yesterday in her apartment in the Hotel Plaza, after a brief illness, at the age of 66.

A large and extraordinarily fine exhibition of paintings, drawings and posters by Toulouse-Lautrec opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, where it will be current until Dec. 4. It is a loan exhibition, many of the works (eleven paintings and fourteen drawings) having come from the Mus e d'Albi in France, for the benefit of which the show is held.

Harry Goodman, president of Harry Goodman Company, Inc., fur dressers, testified yesterday in Federal court that fixed prices and working quotas were established in the fur industry in 1931 and 1932 by the Fur Dressers Factor Corporation.

Dr. George B. Wallace, pharmacologist and senior member of the faculty of the New York University College of Medicine, was honored by the presentation of an oil portrait of himself yesterday at exercises commemorating his thirty-six years of teaching in the institution.

Mrs. Osa Johnson, hunter and explorer, returned-yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Quen Mary after spending four and a half months in East Africa, where she went to do location work for a film based on the lives of Dr. David Livingstone and Henry M. Stanley for Twentieth Century-Fox.

Arrangements made under the so-called Morrow-Calles petroleum agreement guaranteeing the rights of foreign oil companies operating in Mexico have been upset in the contract for the development of further oil fields that was signed Friday between the Mexican Government and the British-controlled Mexican Eagle Oil Company.
The trial of Seyyid Riza and fiftyseven other insurgents implicated in the Kurdish rising of last Spring ended at Mamuset-el-Aziz yesterday and sentences of death were passed on eleven of them.

Not very long ago President Roosevelt said that the recovery of business during his first Administration was not the result of pure chance or a mere turn of the wheel in a cycle: "We planned it that way and don't let anybody tell you differently."

A new police policy toward strike picketing became apparent yesterday when it was learned that confidential orders had been issued from Police Headquarters establishing new rules for picketing and setting up a special police detail to deal with the noisier and more disorderly phases of strike demonstrating-particularly in the Times Square district.

" We are expecting a very close game at Columbia this Saturday. They have been stronger than their record would imply and they're always a team that has to be watched," said Earl Blaik, Dartmouth coach, today as the big Green players reported for their first practice session following the 6-6 tie of Saturday against Cornell.

The New York State Joint Legislative Committee investigating the petroleum industry will hold public meetings at the New York County Lawyers Association Building, 14 Vesey Street, on Thursday and Friday, it was announced last night by Assemblyman Harold B. Ehrlich of Buffalo, chairman of the committee.

The had inform Treasury's short-term bills sold today at a more favorable price than has been obtained for several months. Secretary Morgenthau announced that the issue of 120-day bills offered on Friday was sold at an average interest rate of 0.143 or an average price of 99.952.

The American Federation of Labor and the C. I. 0. shared honors in elections completed by employes of two ship lines as part of the industry-wide election being held-under the direction of the National Labor Relations Board to determine the labor bargaining agencies of unlicensed personnel, it was announced yesterday.

George Tatarescu, whose resignation as Premier was accepted yesterday and who was immediately commissioned by King Carol to form a new government, continued trying today to win the support of Vintila Bratianu,. the dissident Liberal leader. It is believed that M.

A resumption of hedging opernations which followed the advance above 8 cents in the closing days of last week brought yesterday a further set-back in prices on the New York Cotton Exchange. Although the transfer of hedges from December to later positions by spot interests held fluctuations within a limited range, the negative action of the stock market the last' hour depressed the list and left losses of 7 to 8 points on the day.

James Dalhover, 31, only Brady gangster to survive the battle with Federal agents at Bangor, Me., on Oct. 12, pleaded guilty in Federal court here today to an indictment charging him with the murder of State Policeman Paul Minneman.
A MEMOIR OF AE, by John Eglinton (Macmillan, $2.50). The authorized life of George William Russell. YEAR'S END, by Josephine W. Johnson (Simon Schuster, $2). Poems by the author of "Now in November."

One of the most important and farreaching Constitutional cases in American history came into court here today, involving not only the future of the Tennessee Valley Authority as producer and seller of electric power in competition with private 'interests in seven Southeastern States, but also the extent to which the New Deal may carry forward the collectivist tendencies of its whole nation-wide power program as opposed to the individualism of existing private enterprise.

The number of commercial and industrial failures in the United States in the week ended Nov. 11 was 172, compared with 162 in the previous week and 166 in the correspending week of last year, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. This was an increase of 3.6 per cent over a year ago.
A sit-down strike, said to involve about 2,500 workers, began tonight in the Fisher body plant here with plant doors barricaded and one gate welded shut.

Governor Lewis 0. Barrows of Maine told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that Maine's interests feared that domination of the Boston Maine Railroad by the Pennsylvania would "militate against Maine's ambition for greater cooperation with Canada in transportation."

The Lincoln Service Corporation, Washington, D. C., engaged In the smallloans business, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 40,000 shares of $25 par value 6 per cent cumulative participating preferred stock to be offered at $25 a share.
As a result of yesterday's violence in Jerusalem the Palestine Government thus far has arrested forty-five Jews against whom warrants have been issued in accordance with the emergency regulations.
Viscount Shinichiro Kurino, member of the Privy Council and a Harvard graduate, died today. He was Minister to the United States in 1894. His age was 86.

Louis J. Taber of Columbus, Ohio, was re-elected Master of the National Grange today for his eighth term. Mr. Taber, finishing his fourteenth year as head of the organization in convention here, appealed to the delegates last week to choose some one else.

Chilean import duties on automotive passenger cars, trucks, chassis, pneumatic tires and tubes, and motor vehicle parts will be increased by one-third under a new decree by the Chilean Government, according to a cable report from Santiago made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The judge was half an hour late, the audience kept shouting "We can't hear back here" and the room reverberated with partisan applause last night as the New York City League of Women Voters took another step in its campaign to educate women for jury service.

Books are scarce in the United States. If this statement startles any one let it be supplemented by the explanation that they are scarce in proportion to the number of persons who can read. The book trade, as all publishers and booksellers know, is as full of bottlenecks as the Boston Post Road. It is, to change the figure, an infant industry.
The Lawrence Academy eleven triumphed over Cushing by 26-6 today, Rutter making two 95-yard runs for touchdowns. The victors' fullback intercepted passes each time for the scores.

Solomon Schlionsky, 60 years old, and his wife, Anna, 56, of 172 Riverdale Avenue, Brooklyn, were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate William O'Dwyer in Pennsylvania Avenue Court, Brooklyn, on charges of violating the Public Welfare Act.
A message to Congress is supposed to report upon "the state of the Union." That is the language of the Constitution. Mr. Roosevelt's message yesterday was, of course, something very different.

The C. I. O. union that filed the charges that led the National Labor Relations Board to order dissolution last Thursday of the Consolidated Edison Company's contracts with the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate, asked the NLRB yesterday to arrange a consent election to determine the exclusive collective bargaining agency for 40,000 Edison employes in the metropolitan district.

In an address at Barnard College yesterday afternoon the Countess de Chambrun, internationally known authority on Shakespeare, told of her discovery of a second edition of Holinshed's "Chronicles of Britain," printed in 1587, supposedly owned by William Shakespeare and used in writing some of his dramas.
The mutuel handle at Rockingham Park, Salem, for this year's 18-day Spring meeting and the 48-day Fall session that closed Saturday was $17,511,720. The State's share was $612,910.21.

Edward C. Carter, secretary general of the Institute of Pacific Renations, will be the speaker at a luncheon meeting of the Bond Club of New York in the Bankers Club on Wednesday, Nov. 24. Mr. Carter will speak on "War in the Far East; the Attitude of China, Japan and Soviet Russia." Nevil Ford,

Mrs. Peggy Mapes Goodwin of this city, daughter of Mrs. Clive Spencer Mapes of Bayside, Queens, and her fiance, Howard E. Silberstein of 7 Park Avenue, assistant industrial commissioner in the State Department of Labor, obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building and said they would be married Friday by Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, in the justice's chambers.

Recent business in the New York fur market has been very slow, with most holders of raw furs trying hard to dispose of their stocks of last season's merchandise before fresh-caught furs become available, the United Fur Brokers, Inc., stated in a bulletin issued yesterday.

Domestic stocks of refined copper at the end of October amounted to 181,842 tons, compared with 144,321 on Sept. 30, a gain of 37,521, the Copper Institute reported yesterday. Blister stocks decreased 6,013 tons in October, making the net increase in copper stocks last month 31,508 tons.

Five violations of Federal mall fraud statutes and five violations of the fraud provisions of the Securities Act of 1933 are charged against seven defendants indicted yesterday in the Federal District Court for Northern New York in Albany. The indictments were

The disappearance of a $3,000 oustom-built organ from a dwelling at 254 South Second Avenue here was reported today by Dr. Jacques W. Redway, who had left the bulky instrument behind when he moved to an apartment two months ago.

Shuting to Governor Hoffman responsibility for financing unemployment relief during the rest of the year, the Legislature met tonight after a recess of several months only to adjourn until Dec. 20 without acting on two other matters the Governor deemed of major importance.

Full recognition of the necessity for activating private capital in the interest of more stable recovery was acknowledged by President Roosevelt today in his message opening the special session of Congress.

The six employes of the Brooklyn Manhattan Transit Company who are suing the company and the Transport Workers Union to have the closed shop agreement recently reached declared unconstitutional yesterday filed with the Appellate Division in Brooklyn a notice of appeal from the decision of Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May upholding the agreement.

Six theatre ticket agencies paid fines ranging from $100 to $250 yesterday for selling tickets that had not been stamped in accordance with the revenue law, which requires the recording of selling prices and the names of agencies on all tickets sold.
Manhattan realty trading yesterday consisted principally of the transfer of residential properties on the upper West Side.
The vote of censure against Japan in the Nine-Power Conference is considered milder in tone than the censure

Governor Herbert H. Lehman appointed today Nathan R. Sobel of New York City as his counsel and Thomas J. T. Corcoran, also of New York City, assistant. Mr. Sobel was appointed acting counsel to the Governor June 15 to succeed Charles Poletti, who was appointed to the Supreme Court.

Although the financial community, as a whole, found most of the President's message to Congress to its liking, there were points in it which proved disappointing either because of lack of definiteness or because they seemed to close the door to a few things that Wall Street had hoped for.

Several hundred Ford Motor Company office and stock department employes returned to work today preparatory to resuming assembly plant operations, suspended two months ago after company officials accused the city of failing to provide adequate police protection for workers.

The Treasury Procurement Division today announced the following awards of contracts for WPA textiles on proposal 587-T: Broadcloth, H. T. Poindexter Sons Merchandise Company, 13,000 yards; bleached muslin, S. B. Marks Company, 10,000 yards;

Following the merging of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, achieved after years of effort, the campaign, launched yesterday, has set as the goal of their combined effort $6,250,000--the largest sum ever attempted in any American--city for normal local, private services--and far in excess of any sum raised by the two federations.

The Home Thrift Association, which conducts many philanthropic enterprises in the Yorkville district of the city, will be the beneficiary of the first performance this season of the Yale Puppeteers tonight at the Women's Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street. Mrs.

A reduction of 50 per cent in the 1936 and 1937 real estate taxes of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway was offered here this afternoon by officials of Westchester County towns, cities and villages served by the thirty-onemile transit system. They attached only the proviso that the line operate through next year.

The fifteen-story apartment house at 1,185 Park Avenue, occupying the east blockfront between Ninetythird and Ninety-fourth Streets, will be sold at foreclosure auction on Dec. 7 to satisfy a mortgage judgment of $5,740,600 in an action brought by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company against the Bricken Construction Corporation and others.

An officiall of the Maritime Commission said today that the commission had no power to prevent the transfer of Panama Pacific and Grace Line shipping services from the California-New York route to New York-South American runs.

Mrs. Seymour P. Gilbert, mother of S. Parker Gilbert of New York, international financier and former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, died this morning at her home on Beacon Street, Brookline, at the age of 65.

Three lions died and a cow, an interested bystander, perished in a three-hour hunt that started yesterday when an overturned circus trailer liberated the lions near Bay Minette. Circus employes and a group of citizens joined in the hunt.
The Princeton football squad opened practice for the Navy tilt with a strenuous offensive session on University Field this afternoon. Eight of the regulars who played against Yale were excused.

We have several times expressed in these columns serious doubts regarding the value of the voluntary unemployment census that the Federal Government is undertaking through the mails today. These doubts have nothing to do with the way in which the instructions of Congress have been carried out.

Dr. Archibald Joseph Cronin, the British writer whose latest novel, "The Citadel," is high on best-seller lists both in England and in this country, arrived yesterday morning aboard the steamship Queen Mary for a talk at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair on Thursday night. After his address at the Book Fair, Dr. Cronin hopes to spend four or five weeks traveling about enjoying a holiday.
A resolution authorizing issuance of $1,500,000 in tax-anticipation notes was unanimously adopted today at the regular meeting of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors.

Another "Rasputin" libel claim against Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer was settled today in favor of Prince and Princess Alexis Pavlovich Chegodieff. The terms were not disclosed. In 1934 Princess Irina Youssoupoff received $250,000 in settlement of her libel suits against the producers of the motion picture "Rasputin the Mad Monk."

A letter has been sent to Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club by the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League to Champion Human Rights, of which Samuel Untermyer is president, in which the league states it will be forced to advise its members to withhold

King George and Queen Eilzabeth attended tonight a command performance of variety at the Palladium Theatre. The Duke and Duchess of Kent sat with Their Majesties in the royal box, and the party gave evidence of enjoyment of the music-hall humor.

Pittsburgh's Panthers, who displaced California a week ago as the nation's No. 1 college football team, were given another rousing vote of confidence yesterday in the fifth weekly poll conducted by The Associated Press.

Temporary Assignments For 15 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 16: SERGEANTS--Walter C. Brummerhop, of the chief inspector. Nicholas J. Nagle, from 100th Precinet to 18th Division, for duty in Bureau of Criminal Identification.
Athletes of fourteen countries will take part in the fourth Central American and Caribbean Olympic games to be held in Panama next February, officials of the Pan-American Union said today.

Carel E. ter Meulen of the banking firm of Hope Co., Amsterdam, died last night at the age of 70, a few days after an automobile accident which caused partial paralysis. After joining Hope Co. in 1901 Mr. ter Meulen went to the United States for several years, then to Russia.

Death Announced Retired Fireman John R. McIntosh, formerely a member of Engine 228, residing at 205 Woodbine St., Brooklyn, died Nov. 13. Funeral will take place from Boyertown Funeral Parlors, 38 Lafayette Ave., Brooklyn, at 2 P. M., Wednesday, Nov. 17. Interment at Greenwood Cemetery.

The pressure is on at Rose Hill. The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's are coming to town and the swelling beat of the Rose Bowl tom-tom is becoming so loud that Jimmy Crowley is in a cold sweat let it reach the ears of his Fordham Rams.

Demo-crats in the Senate and the House reflected a division of opinion in their comment upon President Roosevelt's message to the special session of Congress, some viewing it as a constructive, statesmanlike utterance and others as lacking in definiteness.

Arnold Bernstein, head of the Arnold Bernstein and Red Star shipping lines, which although Jewish-owned have operated under the German flag, went on trial before the Hanseatic Special Tribunal here today, charged with treason and violation of the foreign exchange control laws.
The eight-room house at 295 Boulevard, Scarsdale, Westchester County, has been sold by Clara Schutzman to Thomas Jerome. Chauncey B. Griffen was the broker in the deal.

Members of the board of governors of the Boys Athletic League, which last year provided play space and healthful activities for 25,000 children in New York slums, met yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Commodore to lay plans for 1938 and to review last year's achievements.

An unofficial cricket test match between an Indian eleven and Lord Tennyson's touring team today resulted in a ninewicket victory for the Englishmen. Dismissed for 121 in their first innings, the home players compiled 191 in the second attempt, but their opponents hit 207 and 114 for one wicket.

Archibald M. Reid, better known in the golf world as Archie and a member of the St. Andrews Club, Hastings-on-Hudson, will be the next president of the United States Golf Association, succeeding John G. Jackson, New York attorney.

Fifteen strikers picketing the plant of the Presto Lock Corporation at 70 Washington Street, Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday on charges ranging from disorderly conduct to inciting to riot, after an outbreak of fighting in which a police sergeant and a plant foreman were injured, bricks and stones thrown freely and an automobile, said to contain six strikebreakers, partly wrecked.
Rushing over a touchdown in the third period, the New Rochelle High eleven topped Gorton High, 6 to 0, in a W. I. A. A. battle on Gorton Field today.

Something new in spectacles was seen at Madison Square Garden last night when a group of internationally renowned figure skaters presented the ice ballet, "Gay Blades," in a first serious attempt to wed their art to the dance.

Congress in beginning its second special session of the New Deal Administration was in a mood more cautious, more conservative and more independent than at any other time since President Roosevelt addressed his first Congress nearly five years ago.

Recognition of a danger of foreign aggression in the Philippines in view of the SinoJapanese conflict was coupled with a significant gesture to the United States by President Manuel Quezon today in the celebration of the second anniversary of the Philippine Commonwealth.

John F. Davidson, trial examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission, reported yesterday that the registration statement for 225,000 shares of common stock in the Austin Silver Mining Company contained untrue statements and omissions of material fact.
How is the dollar today?" a reporter asked Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau at his press conference this afternoon. "Very well, thank you," Mr. Morgenthau replied. "Temperature normal."

William L. Austin, director of the Federal Bureau of Census, issued yesterday a financial report on the operation of the Jersey City government- for the fiscal year ended on Dec. 31, 1936, which showed a per capital cost of $65.80, compared with

Election of nine students as class officers in the Columbia University Law School was announced yesterday by Dean Young B. Smith. Tobias Klinger of Los Angeles, a graduate of the University of California, was elected president of the third year class.

James Willoughby Anderson, a patent attorney, died at his home here today following an illness of several weeks. He was 69 years old. Mr. Anderson was formerly connected with the firm of Duell, Dunn Anderson of New York and Washington, and at one time was chief examiner of the United States Patent Office.

Application for leave to file a petition for termination of the Wabash Railroad's receivership, so that bankruptcy proceedings may be substituted, was presented today to Federal Judge Charles B. Davis.

Owners of more than 2,365,000 square feet of land in the easterly half of the lower East Side south of Fourteenth Street have signed petitions favoring the rezoning of the area under a plan designed to provide for a more orderly rehabilitation of the district.

Among student honors announced today at Cornell University was the election of Bernard Gartlir, '38, of Brooklyn as editor in chief of the Cornell Sun, and Daniel W. Kops, '39, of New York City as managing editor
Fill-in requests and holiday orders continued to dominate activity in the local merchandise market yesterday, with the purchases quite numerous, but generally confined to small lots. According to
Wheat prices declined sharply on the Board of Trade here today on the weakness in Liverpool and in securities and a continued lack of European demand for North American grain.

United States ASSOCIATE ENTOMOLOGIST (TAXONMY), $3,200 a year, Bureau of Entomolgy and Plant Quarantine, Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file lot later than Dec. 13, if received from States other than those named below: Dec. .6 if received from the following States: krizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon. Utah, Washington, Wyoming. Competitors will lot be required to report for examination

Miss Louise Lutkins, daughter of ??nton Stephen Lutkins of this city and Rye, has completed plans for her marriage to Robert Le Brecht, which will take place on Friday in St. James Church. Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

In contrast to the deluge of measures usually poured into the legislative hoppers on the opening day of a Congress session, few bills were filed today. Clerks in the Senate bill room said that not a new measure had reached their desks up to 4 P. M. and that they did not expect any great activity for several days.

Dean George E. Dutton of Delaware College, the men's division of Delaware University, began today an investigation of a hazing stunt which sent two university students to a hospital with burns on- their faces.
At the Broadhurst tonight the Theatre Guild starts telling the sad story of "Madame Bovary," in Benn W. Levy's adaptation from the French of Gaston Baty, who in turn dramatized the Flaubert novel.

Malvina Hoffman, who merged science and sculpture in one of the most painstaking commissions ever executed, received last night the gold 'medal award at the Friendship dinner held annually at the American Woman's Association.

Flour truck owners, some of whom had not made personal deliveries in more than fifteen years, manned twenty-eight trucks yesterday to carry "emergency" loads of flour to 700 small bakeries in the five boroughs. Police escorts rode with them to protect them from possible molestation by striking members of Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

In a move to avoid any misunderstanding in their petition for additional freight-rate increases, the Class I railroads of the country, through R. V. Fletcher, general counsel of the Association of American Railroads, have informed the Interstate Commerce Commission, by letter,

Engineering contracts totaling over $1,729,000 were awarded by the War Department today, as follows: McWilliams Dredging Company, Chicago, for dredging Brandon Road Pool, Illinois Waterway, Chicago district, $410,785; McWilliams Dredging Company, Chicago, for dredging Lagrange Pool, Illinois Waterway, Chicago district, $354,607.76.

Judges of the Election Court tonight suspended the official tabulation by the County Election Board of votes cast in the Nov. 2 election here pending a court-supervised count of all votes cast in eleven wards using paper.ballots.

Andrew Montanez, fire chief of the town of Humacao, is under arrest, charged with setting fire to houses so that he and his men might earn more. Humacao's firemen are paid only when they 'answer alarms.

Creation of a special committee of the New York State,Bar Association to examine and report on all proposed amendments reported to the Constitutional Convention was named today by George H. Bond, president of the association.

With Alderman Frederick Schick, Democrat, elected as Richmond's single Councilman, the count of first-place ballots completed in Brooklyn and nearing completion in Manhattan and Queens, it appeared virtually certain last night that the Council would consist of twenty-six members.

Stocks reacted and closed at lowest levels of the day, leading issues fell 1 to 5 points; turnover; 1,450,210 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds steady, Brazilian issues rallied; transactions, $7,253,575.

The long victory streak of the Princeton Club in the metropolitan Class B league squash tennis tournament was ended yesterday by the Harvard Club, which turned back the 1936-37 champions, 3 to 2, on the losers' courts.
Darragh de Lancey, former chief of the Industrial Relations Division of the United States Shipping Board, died tonight at his home here after an illness of two years. His age was 67.

A simple funeral service for former United States Senator Atlee Pomerene, who died Friday of pneumonia, were held today at the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant here by the Rev. Dr. Philip Smead Bird, the pastor.

Operating revenues of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad this year will be about $172,500,000, against $168,992,880 in 1936, according to an estimate announced by Daniel Willard, president, at the annual meeting in Baltimore yesterday. Of this increase of 2 per cent in gross, about 1.6 per cent resulted from freight and 6 per cent from passenger traffic.

The marriage of Miss Eileen Donnelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis Donnelly of this place, to Gregory Field Keenan, son of former Judge and Mrs. John J. Keenan of Washington, D. C., will take place on the afternoon of Nov. 27 in the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel here.

A six-story apartment costing about $600,000 is to be built on Henry Hudson Parkway, in Riverdale, the Bronx, according to plans filed yesterday. The house is to occupy a plot 178 by 205 feet on the east side of the parkway, 217.8 feet north of 232d Street,

Green Bay holds a commanding lead in all National Football League offensive departments, according to the official statistics released yesterday. The Packers have scored 214 points, gained 2,800 yards and averaged 44 per cent in passing efficiency.

A forty-game schedule for the eight members of the International Intercollegiate Ice Hockey League, now preparing to enter its second season, was announced tonight by Asa S. Bushnell, the circuit's American secretary.

A readjustment plan covering the total debt of the city of Cordoba, Argentina, soon will be proposed, Ames, Emerick Co., Inc., of Chicago, have been advised following the default on principal and interest on the 7 per cent sinking-fund gold bonds of the city due yesterday. The firm asked bondholders

The New Brunswick Government has completed arrangements with a syndicate of Canadian investment dealers and bankers for the sale of 6,500,000 Province of New Brunswick debentures, Premier Dysart announced today.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, today reduced the lead of his rival, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, when he won the seventeenth game of their match, which had been adjourned last night after forty moves.

Hiram Walker Sons (Scotland), Ltd., wholly owned subsidiary of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., have sold to Lazard Brothers Co., Ltd., of London, f1,000,000 sterling of their authorized issue of [Pound]2,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent fifteen-year sinking fund non-convertible debenture stock, the parent company has announced.

Arrested as she alighted from a motor bus, Katherine Berg, 28, of New York, was 'arraigned today on charges of smuggling four pounds of opium into Canada and possessing smuggled narcotics. Hearing was set for Nov. 23.

" Chinese Backgrounds," Eleanor Markell, Hotel Plaza, 11 A. M. Metropolitan Museum of Art. "Design in Rugs," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M.; Far Eastern art (general tour) noon; motion pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Color in English China," Grace Cornell, 3 P. M.; "Dawn of the Great Egyptian Empire," Edwin L. M. Taggart, 4 P. M.
The National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin's direction, offered its initial concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night, with Muriel Kerr, pianist, as assisting artist.

The aggregate value of building permits issued during October for all types of construction in the suburban area of Chicago, Ill., rose while that of similar permits for construction in the city itself dropped, a survey by the Greenbaum Sons Investment Company reveals.

Hearings on the proposed plan of reorganization of the Radio-KeithOrpheum Corporation before George W. Alger, special master, were concluded yesterday at a meeting of counsel with Mr. Alger in the Bar Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

The me Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the Southwestern Development Company, Denver, for approval of acquisition by it of an aggregate principal amount of $3,292,000 of South Plains Pipe Line Company first mortgage and collateral trust fifteen-year 6 per cent sinking fund gold bonds due on Jan. 1, 1945.

Two assistant district attorneys from Los Angeles are in town looking for some one to help them handle the racketeers who have settled in the California city since Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey started making this city so unhealthy for them.

John F. Collins was re-elected president of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York at that organization's annual meeting held last night in the Hotel Astor. Other officers include Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Glennon and Joseph F. Higgins, deputy collector of Internal Revenue, vice presidents; Nicholas J.

To the Congress: Important measures are already pending before this Congress, and other matters will require early consideration. Therefore, it has seemed advisable to call this extraordinary session to expedite the work of the regular session which will begin in January.
American coffee drinkers and eaters of Brazil nuts benefit by recent government measures. Under the ruling reducing the coffee export tax and freeing exchange each 130-pound bag

Miss Bettina Rose Ferrel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Ferrel of 2,310 Avenue L, Brooklyn, will be married to Gilbert Russell Ott, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Ott, also of Brooklyn, on Friday night in St. Marks Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

Kearny High School's eleven conquered a stubborn Lyndhurst team by 6-0 today. Blocking a kick and recovering the ball on Lyndhurst's 15, Kearny marched to a touchdown in the third period, Al Norris crashing through center from the 1-yard line.

Ralph Greenleaf, defending champion of New York, and Irving Crane, youthful Livonia, N. Y., star, tonight finished in a tie for the world pocket billiard championship and will meet in a play-off for the title tomorrow night.

Following a fire early yesterday in a three-story apartment building at 2,838 Stillwell Avenue, Brooklyn, Henry Murray, 49 years old, janitor of the building. was held in $50,000 bail for the grand jury on a charge of arson. He pleaded not guilty before Magistrate Troy in Brooklyn Felony Court.
Congress came back Unto session today with no more definite program for immediate procedure than it had when adjournment Aug. 21 ended impasses in both houses over two major pieces of legislation.
Mrs. S. Bryce Wing, long a leading figure in Eastern society's steeplechase and hunting circles, died today of a heart attack at her estate at Monkton, Baltimore County.

Frank Cundall, librarian at the Jamaica Institute and the leading historian of the British West Indies, died here today at the age of 79. Mr. Cundall was born in January, 1858, in England, and was educated in private schools and King's College, London.

A panel of seventy-six public spirited citizens who have agreed to serve as arbitrators and mediators in labor disputes when asked to do so by the State Mediation Board was announced yesterday by William H. Davis, chairman of the board.

Jack Durant, in 330 W. 72d St; Frederick K. James, in 171 W 71st St: Warren Klinger, in 741 West End Ave: Judson Ehrbar, in 309 W 109th St; Apartment Renting Co, Inc, broker. Miss R. Boxall, n 434 E 52d St, through the Gresham Realty Co; Helen Masters Bunting. broker.

A butler and chef who served for nearly thirteen years under the name of Alfred Grouard in the Oyster Bay home of Joseph H. Sears, former president of D. Appleton Co., died here last night in a rooming house and was discovered today by health authorities to have been a woman.

John David of New York, founder and proprietor of the large chain of men's clothing and haberdashery stores in New York and Brooklyn, died here today in the Hotel Claridge of a heart attack after an illness of several months.

The Bureatt of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 12: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Bailey, E. L., the Maryland, to duty as officer in charge, Destroyer Stores Office, San Diego, Calif

Louis Shenk, Philadelphia baritone and composer, gave his first New York recital in two seasons at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. His program consisted of German lieder by Schubert, Franz and Brahms and songs in English.

Renewed weakness developed in the dollar in the foreign exchange market yesterday with the result that all important European currencies advanced. The pound ster ling rose to $4.99 15-16 and closed there, up 18-16 cents from Saturday's final price.

With the Postoffice Department prepared to undertake today the distribution of one or more unemployment census report cards to each of the 2,600,000 residences in this city, Mayor La Guardia appealed last night for the cooperation of all unemployed and partlyemployed persons in making the count here "both inclusive and accurate."

For the third succeesive week automobile output has declined against a rising seasonal trend, and the index has sagged to 95.4 for the week ended Nov. 13. It was 102.4 for the previous week and 100.5 for the week ended Nov. 14, 1936.
Mr. and Mrs. Hans Froehlich of Vienna and Brooklyn gave a reception yesterday at their home, 365 Clinton Avenue, for the Archduke and Archduchess Franz Josef of Austria.

The title of "the world's safest truck driver," was awarded tonight to a 55-year-old Texan at the American Trucking Association's national convention here. The winner, Allen B. Hill, has driven trucks about 1,400,000 miles in the last thirty years without an accident or arrest.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 15: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Levy, R. M., Adjutant General's Dept., two days' leave, Nov. 19. Winslow, S. S.. Q.M.C., Langley Field, Va., to Hawaiian Dep't., to sail from New York about Feb. 10. Kilpatrick, J. D., Q.M.C., Hawaii, to Quartermaster Corps, Headquarters, Governors Island. N. Y.
A New Jersey constable seeking a new trial on a charge of extorting $10 from a motorist voluntarily subjected himself yesterday to a test by Fordham University's "lie detector."

Arthur Machen of Baltimore, holder of a $1,000 First Liberty bond, insisted in a brief filed with the Supreme Court today that so long as the government "persists in its refusal to pay in gold coin," it cannot redeem the bond before the maturity date.

The Long Island University varsity basketball team will play seven home games in December, Clair F. Bee, director of athletics, announced yesterday. The games will be played at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gymnasium.

William H. Fischer, who inherited $1,250,000 from his father, Benedict Fischer, wholesale coffee merchant, filed suit yesterday in Supreme Court to recover $150,000 damages from two sisters, two nephews and a brother-in-law for false arrests and imprisonment.

Bob Nelson had a field day as Englewood High School's football team downed Ridgewood, 32 to 2, at Winston White Stadium today. The fleet left halfback gained 217 yards from scrimmage and scored all five of the victors' touchdowns. The triumph kept Englewood in a tie with Rutherford for leadership of the Northern New Jersey Interscholastic A. A. League.
As simply as if he really were going solely to see the hunting exhibition in Berlin, Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, left London today on his diplomatic journey to Nazi Germany.

Approximately 4,500 banking institutions and organizations will distribute within the next two weeks $320,000,000 to about 6,600,000 members of Christmas savings clubs, it was estimated yesterday by Herbert F. Rawil, founder and president of the Christmas Club, Inc.

Nicaragua's commercial difficulties with Germany have been settled. A reduction of 25 per cent will be given to Nicaragua on all debts for merchandise owed to Germany and the export subsidies paid by the Nicaraguans for German merchandise will be abolished.
39th St, 413 W, 25x98.9; excx of estate of Regina Schmidt White to Eugenia Ford, 413 W 39th St. 93d St, 142 W, 20x100.8 1/2; Oscar Henthorn to 142 W 93d St, Inc, 148 W 93d St; mtg $14,200 ($2).

The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts announces that its 133d annual exhibition will open on Sunday, Jan. 30, in the academy galleries in Philadelphia. / It will be made up of original paintings and sculptural works by living American artists that have not before been shown publicly in that city.
Several houses in the Washington Heights and Harlem section changed hands in transactions reported yesterday. The six-story apartment building containing 171 rooms at 710-716 West 173d Street,

Three stories were placed on RKO's I immediate schedule today by Leo Spitz, president of the concern. The next Fred Astaire-Ginger Rogers endeavor will be "Change Partners," by Guy Endore and Marion Ainslee, and Irving Berlin has the music one-fourth completed.

With only forty-five shopping days until New Year's, the most frequent guess today is that Pittsburgh, the nation's top-ranking football team, will not be invited to defend its Rose Bowl title on Jan. 1.

Clarence Morgan of Shelburne, Vt., retired treasurer of the Rutland Railroad and ,former chairman of the Vermont The State Liquor Control Board, died today at the Hotel Beaconsfield in Brookline. He was 66 years old.

Faced with a substantial market depreciation of his investment in the syndicate that controls the Alleghany Corporation, top company in the Van Sweringen railroad holding structure, Frank F. Kolbe has liquidated his share in the syndicate and retired from it, it became known yesterday.

Dr. E. D. Kohlstedt, executive secretary, today told the annual meeting of the Methodist Episcopal Church Board of Home Missions and Church Extension that social pronouncements by the church on economic justice were meaningless until some action was taken to relieve underpaid ministers.

The remaining items in the two-day sale of mezzotints collected by the late Martin Erdmann of New York brought the fairly high price of [Pound]7,845 at Christie's today. The sale, which began yesterday, has aroused considerable interest here and the salesroom was crowded.
Bringing their plane to earth here amid cheering crowds, Flying Officer A. E. Clouston and Mrs. Betty Kirby-Green tonight set a new record for the flight from London of 45 hours and 5 minutes.

The International Salon of Photography was opened yesterday afternoon in the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, where it will be open to the public without charge to Nov. 30. The Oval Table Society is sponsor of the exhibit.

The New York City Board of Education, in spending about $200 a year for Bibles, parts of which are read in public schools, is not violating the Constitution, the Court of Appeals ruled in effect today when it dismissed an appeal of Joseph Lewis, who had sought to enjoin the board.

Guy Rowson, Labor Member of Parliament, who once worked at the coal face in Lancashire coal mines, died today. Mr. Rowson was parliamentary private secretary to Clement Attlee, leader of the Labor Opposition in the House of Commons. Some weeks ago he introduced, as a private member's bill, a measure requiring employers to give all workers paid holidays. The bill was defeated.

Lou Salica, former world bantamweight champion of Bensonhurst, gained an eight-round decision over Sammy Garcia of Boston in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. The winner's weight was 117 1/2 pounds to 119 1/3 for his rival.

In a brief attacking anew the government's power program, Newton D. Baker, former Secretary of War, and other counsel for the Alabama Power Company told the Supreme Court today that the government's policy of making Public Works Administration loans and grants to public enterprise would destroy the balance established by the Constitution between the government and the States.

Captain Jimmy Blumenstock led Rutherford High School's football team to a 26-to-6 triumph over Cliffside Park High School in a North New Jersey Interscholastic Dor A. A. game today. The victors' leader scored two touchdowns and threw a pass for another. As a resuit of the triumph, Rutherford kept pace with Englewood in the race for the league title.
The district committee of the National Maritime Union was authorized to take any step necessary to force the International Mercantile Marine Company to enter into a wage agreement,

Seven men and one woman were indicted yesterday in a Federal grand jury presentment to Judge Robert A. Inch in the United States District Court in Brooklyn. The bill charges conspiracy to conceal and transfer $100,000 of assets in a bankruptcy proceeding.

WHEN Bronko Nagursk was with the Chicago Bears for their Polo Grounds debate with the Giants he wasn't in very long and didn't do very much. He had a bad foot. But a couple of nights later he successfully defended whatever wrestling title he holds.

A pair of hard-hitting middleweights will be seen in action tonight when Solly Krieger of Bensonhurst opposes Frank Battaglia, Winnipeg veteran, in the feature bout of ten rounds at the New York Hippodrome.
Premier Hendryk Colijn informed the Second Chamber today that the country's financial situation still was serious, owing to an extremely heavy debt burden and expenditure on unemployment asdistance.

Movement of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 15, unless specified: San Francisco to sea: Arizona, California, Cincinnati, Colorado, Concord, Idaho, Memphis, Milwaukee, Mississippi, Nevada, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, West Virginia.
Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a dinner last night at their home, 60 Morningside Drive, for Viscount and Viscountess Cecil of Chelwood.

The Mandates Commission examined today the Japanese Pacific Islands mandate and found that the value of its produce had risen from 2,000,000 yen in 1922 to 26,000,000 yen in 1935. It questioned Tokyo's representative, Uzuhiko Usami, especially on what good this did the natives.
The 10,000-ton cruiser Wichita, last of eighteen vessels of its class to be built under terms of the London treaty, slid gracefully into the Delaware River at the navy yard today.

Nearly 900 alumnae and friends of Smith College attended a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night in honor of Dr. William Allan Neilson, who has 'completed two decades in the presidency of the college. The dinner was arranged by the Smith College Club of New York.
JEFFERSON DAVIS, by Robert McRoy. (Harper, 2 vols., $8.) A biography. RICOCHETS, by Andre Maurois. Harper, $2.) Vignettes by the author of "Ariel."
Admiral Sir Arthur Murray Farquhar died today at Acheron, Scotland, aged 82. His father and grandfather were admirals, his father at one time being in command of the Pacific station.

Lieut. Commander John R. Lynas of Long Beach, Calif., an outstanding urologist of the Navy Medical Corps, died yesterday of diphtheria in Shanghai, where he was on duty with the marines, according to word received by the Navy Department. His age was 38.

Walter Mills, baritone, who frequently has appeared on the local concert platform, was heard in a recital at Town Hall last night. Mr. Mills began his evening's endeavors with selections from Handel's works, consisting of "Dank sei dir, Herr"; the first elder's aria, "Ye Verdant Hills," from "Susanna," and "Arm, Arm, Ye Brave," from "Judas Maccabaeus."

New York City school children will play Santa Claus next month, donating dolls, trains, wagons, tin soldiers and other playthings to boys and girls in underprivileged neighborhoods who otherwise might have a toyless Christmas.

Before more than 400 Mayors attending the annual session of the United States Conference of Mayors, J. Warren Madden, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, charged today that in some cities the new labor law was being frustrated with the "connivance of the Mayor and other officials who are sworn to uphold the law."

Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation declared yesterday a special dividend of $1 and a dividend of 50 cents a share to its stockholders. Both are payable on Dec. 28 to stock of record of Nov. 26.

A. A. Magee, acting president of Barclays Bank (Canada) since the death of Sir Robert Borden, was elected president of the institution at the annual meeting of shareholders in Montreal yesterday, and H. A. Stevenson, general manager, was elected vice president.

A six-month campaign against the proposed wages and hours legislation, undistributed profit taxes and capital gains taxes and in behalf of other aims will be conducted by the Merchants Association, it was announced yesterday.

Following a decline on the London Metal Exchange, the price of copper in the export market dropped yesterday to 10.29 cents a pound, c. i. f. European base ports. Early in the day sales were made at 10.58 cents, or about the same level as on Monday.

A mortgage for $444,000 on 223 2d Ave and 254 E 14th St held by the Mortgage Commission, as trustee, from the Church Extension Committee of the Presbytery of New York (Van S. Merle Smith, Oyster Bay, L I, treasurer) was extended to Dec 31, 1940, at 4 to 5 per cent.

The American Management Association will sponsor a conference on sales management problems tomorrow and Friday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. The sessions will feature discussions of sales-training programs and methods of paying salesmen.

166th St (9-2433), s w cor of Findlay Ave, 99x51; Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum to Tremont Improvement Corp, 1,615 Grand Ave. Valentine Ave (11-3147). e s. 150 ft n of 187th St 50x100. Lorremore V. V. Sweezy to 36 Holding Corp, 349 E 149 St: mtg 19,000.

Czechoslovak statesmen, from President Eduard Benes downward. concede that the biggest problem facing them both in domestic and foreign policy is a solution of the German minority problem, which has also a large bearing on the peace of Europe.

Long-limbed Kenneth Duncan, former Oxford University broad jumper and soccer Blue, has been appointed captain of the English track and field team that will compete in the 1938 British Empire games at Sydney, Australia.

Although he divided the third and fourth blocks with his rival yesterday, Willie Hoppe, defending the world's 18.1 balkline billiard championship against the challenge of Jake Schaefer of Chicago, forged far into the lead as the first third of the match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy was completed.

Bondholders of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway "looked with interest" today on an offer of tax reductions in Westchester County, and they may consent next Tuesday to permit the line to operate another year, according to William H. Hall, counsel for receivers of the railroad.

Buck Langhorne administered a typical Southern Maryland form shock to the players today when he was a three-length winner over Merry Maker in the Monticello Handicap, renewed at the mile-and-a-sixteenth distance. At the finish Mrs. K. N.

One of the most strangely officiated games on record was an early Fordham-St. Mary's encounter. . . . Slip Madigan and Major Frank Cavanaugh, two strong-willed coaches, each insisted on a different referee. . . So a compromise was effected whereby Madigan's man functioned in the first half and Cavanaugh's in the second.

Using Jimmy Gribbon, a reserve back, to impersonate Sidat-Singh. star of the Syracuse team, Coach Andy Kerr sent Colgate's Red Raiders on defense today against plays the Orange is expected to use at Syracuse Saturday.

Winners of all-Holyoke awards for membership on varsity sports teams at Mount Holyoke College were announced tonight at the Athletic Association dinner by Miss Barbara Palser of Worcester, president of the association.

Joseph B. Eastman of the Interstate Commerce Commission declared today that regulation of the motor carrier industry must be "decentralized so far as possible." Speaking to delegates of the American trucking associations at their fourth annual convention, he said the motor carrier industry "is essentially an industry of small units scattered in great numbers all over the country."
Dr. William O. Forbes, for many years Western district secretary of the Presbyterian Board of National Missions, died of a heart attack today at his home here. He was 85 years of age.

When the market showed some losses at the beginning of today's session, though the opening followed the first Presidential utterance fora long time which dealt sympathetically with the troubles of business, one of the President's. firstline aides (highly regarded by conservatives) made a couple of trenchant remarks to his associates.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. John McDowell, who rose from a breaker boy in a Pennsylvania coal mine to Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, took place here this afternoon in the Park Presbyterian Church, where from 1905 to 1915 he was the pastor.
The American Olympic Association at its quadrennial meeting tomorrow probably will settle the fight between American colleges and the Amateur Athletic Union for control of four Olympic sports.

Behind closed gates, Lehigh bore down today in practice for the traditional Lafayette encounter here Saturday. The teams' records provide a striking contrast, but the undefeated standing of Lafayette apparently has not dampened the spirit at Lehigh.

The eighteen game of the match for the chess championship of the world between Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris was begun tonight, with the latter in charge of the white forces. After a full session of five hours, the play was adjourned, to be continued tomorrow.

The State Board of Social Welfare and the Emergency Relief Bureau are considering a plan to bar the Workers Alliance and other pressure groups from district relief offices here without depriving them of the right to present grievances in behalf of the unemployed, Commissioner David C. Adie of the State Department of Social Welfare disclosed yesterday.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has added three paintings to its collection of contemporary American art. These are "Woman at Window," by A. S. Baylinson, Waldo Peirce's "Haircut by the Sea," bought through the Midtown Galleries, and Clarence Carter's "The Creepers," bought through the Ferargil - Galleries.

Although Flaubert's reasons were wrong, his conclusions were right. He refused to have "Madame Bovary" dramatized because of the prurient scandal that hung about it. But to judge by Gaston Baty's dramatization, which was acted at the Broadhurst last evening in a further adaptation by Benn W. Levy,

Mrs. Charles B. Knox, president of the Charles B. Knox Gelatine Company and pioneer woman food manufacturer, will be honored by her employes at a party here Thursday night in celebration of her eightieth birthday and the thirtieth year since she took over the management of the business upon the death of her husband.
Eighteen games have been arranged for the St. John's University freshman basketball team this season, it was announced yesterday. The five is to open its drive against Curtis High School on Dec. 4.

Paul Simon, an authority on hotel management who had been a partner in the Chicago accounting firm of Horwath Horwath since 1918, died in the Highland Park Hospital today after a long illness. He was 54 years old and resided in suburban Highland Park.

The winners of the final auditions for the sixth annual young artists' contest conducted by the MacDowell Club are Marvel Biddle, soprano, of New.York; Milton Kaye, pianist, of New York; Ben Jones, pianist, of Jacksonville, Fla., and Jean Spitzer, violinist, of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wilkes Sherrill of 308 East Seventy-ninth Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Stewart Sherrill, to Roy C. Crone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer C. Crone of Detroit.

The City of New York completed its arguments yesterday in support of its application for permission to use wells in Queens near the Nassau County line as auxiliary water supply until the Rondout-Delaware $275,000,000 system is put into operation. The hearing was held in the Municipal Building,

General Hugh S. Johnson, who was barred last Wednesday from speaking on social diseases over the WJZ network, in a statement issued here yesterday by his representatives, declared his satisfaction that another speaker had been selected by the National Broadcasting Company to talk on this topic.

Seven games of an eight-game schedule for the Rutgers University football team in 1938 were made public today by George E. Little, director of athletics. The season will be opened Sept. 24 against an opponent yet to be named and closed Nov. 12 at New Brunswick against Lafayette, traditional Middle Three rival of the Scarlet.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Charged with misrepresentation and lack of character and integrity, Joseph H. Van Dorn will appear on Friday as-the defendant in the first disbarment proceedings ever to be held by the "administrative tribunal" of the Securities and Exchange Commission. John F. Davidson will sit for the commission as trial examiner. Robert H. Winn will present the SEC's case.

The name of Ullstein, which once stood for the most progressive and liberal publishing house in Germany and which was a Berlin landmark, was stricken from the records today when the concern renamed itself the Deutsche Verlag, or German Publishing Company.

The number of commercial failures in the United States in the week ended Nov. 11, showed increases in two groups, a decline in one group and no change in two other groups, as compared with a year ago, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
The city's birth rate, which has been declining uninterruptedly for eight weeks, now stands at 11.9 per 1,000 population, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Glauco d'Attill, 16-year-old pianist of Italian parentage, made his debut in a recital at Town Hall yesterday in a difficult program with complete command of all the resources of the instrument for its adequate exposition.

A carefully phrased declaration by Ivan M. Maisky, the Soviet Ambassador, today associated Russia with the other non-intervention powers in preliminary stages of the attempt to withdraw foreign "volunteers" from Spain.

Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, elder British statesman and proponent of the League of Nations, sat before a wood fire in the library of Thomas W. Lamont's home at 107 East Seventieth Street yesterday and gave warning that only the maintenance of world organization for peace stands between the nations and a repetition of the great war.

Abbott Laboratories, North Chicago, Ill., has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 20,000 shares of $100 par value 4 1/2 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and 40,000 shares of no par value common to be reserved for conversion of the preferred.

The Board of Elections, like the mills of God, grinds slowly, and therefore another week or so must pass before we know the members of the new City Council. We do know, however, that they will not all be Democrats--or,
Senate and House Agriculture Committees made efforts today to compose the differences within their ranks in the hope of having a measure ready by Monday.
With the annual-service classic with Navy on Nov. 27 as its next and final objective, Army resumed football practice today, paying little heed t' Saturday's game with St. John's of Maryland.
Scoring in the final period the Stuyvesant High eleven defeated Seward Park, 13-6, yesterday at Commercial Field. It was the final game of the campaign for the winners.

Edward A. Frye, veteran newspaper man, died here tonight at his home in his eighty-fourth year. He had been employed by The Morning Herald for more than forty-nine years and previously had served on papers in Buffalo, Geneva and Rochester. His widow, Geneva Frye, survives.

All the colorful ceremonies incident to a state visit by a sovereign were revived today after a lapse of many years in honor of King Leopold of Belgium. Several Kings, including Leopold himself, have been visitors here since the new reign began but today's pomp Illustrated the difference between businesslike, private visits by Kings and state calls.

Thanks mainly to increased purchases by the United States, Great Britain and the Balkan nations, Germany was able to boost her exports during October over the preceding month, establishing a high record for the period since Adolf Hitler came to power.

The question or whether a French counterpart to the Ku Klux Klan really exists was again raised today through the arrest of a wealthy Lille contractor, Rene Anceaux, M. Vosselm, one of his employes, and Gerard de ia Motte-Saint Pierre on charges which remain unspecified, but are in the case of M. Anceaux plotting against the security of the State and for the others possessing weapons of war and "association with wrongdoers."

Insurance laws which would permit less stringent loan features in life policies and compel companies to keep the insured advised of their rights as policy holders were recommended yesterday at a hearing before the legislative committee on revision of the insurance laws in the State Building. Assemblyman H. Foster Piper, chairman of the committee, presided.

Continuing the display of superb form that marked his advance through preliminary rounds of the annual Princeton Club squash tennis tournament,, Thomas D. Flynn, former Princeton, tennis captain and hockey player, gained the semifinal yesterday.

The estate of Albert E. Putnam sold to the Racso Realty Corporation, Oscar Rosenbaum, president, the six-story apartment house on a plot 39.4 by 100 feet at 605 East 138th Street, the Bronx. It took back a first mortgage of $28,000 for five years at 4 and 4 1/2 per cent.

A supplemental report on transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities of corporations in September showed among others the sale of 1,500 common shares of General Motors Corporation by Donaldson Brown, New York, a director.
