Representatives of the Department of Water and Power of the city of Los Angeles, Calif.,have set Nov. 30 as the date for the sale of $10,200,000 of electric plant revenue bonds.

In response to requests from patrons who have been unable to gain admission to the symphony concerts presented at the WPA Theatre of Music on Sunday evenings because of capacity audiences, officials of the Federal Music Project announced yesterday another symphonic series for alternate Friday evenings.

The new plant of the Sheffield Farms Company on Ninety-fourth Avenue, Jamaica, L. I., said to represent an investment of about $2,500,000, was opened yesterday with ceremonies in which representatives of many women's organiations in Queens participated.

Ralph Greenleaf of New York, defending champion, defeated Irving Crane, young Livonia, N. Y., star, 125 to minus 1, in a play-off tonight for the world's pocket billiard title. The match went eleven innings. It was Greenleaf's sixteenth world championship.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange proceeded quietly yesterday with the main body of domestic corporation issues yielding ground against small resistance. The market, generally, lacked the aggressive support that characterized Monday's trading and, although the selling pressure was not severe in any group,

Norris J. (Tip) O'Neill, active in baseball as player and official for nearly a half century, died here today of a heart attack in Alexian Brothers Hospital after a long illness, at the age of 70. Until his health failed several years ago, Mr. O'Neill, a close friend of the late Charles A. Comiskey, occupied office space at the White Sox Park.
Princess Rajkumari Leilavathi, 28 years old, niece of the Maharajah of Mysore, arrived yesterday from California on the steamship Santa Rosa of the Grace Line on her return to India via Europe.

Charges were filed today with the directors of the Board of Trade by one of the special committees appointed shortly after the termination of trading in September corn against John H. MacMillan Jr., president, and Edward J. Grimes and Philip C.

The prank of a 14-year-old boy who was tired of going to high school opened a wide search for kidnappers last night, with two detectives guarding a parcel box in a subway station while Department of Justice agents and other detectives scoured the city for clues.

President Roosevelt's four-point program for economic and social betterment, and Congress's indefinite plans for aid to business, were enveloped in a cloud of confusion and delay today, twenty-four hours after the special session convened.
Lafayette's yearlings ended an undefeated football season with its 21-0 victory over the Rutgers freshman eleven today.

Declaring that the Roman Catholic Church had always been the "greatest friend of labor," Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. told an audience of 1,000 Catholic laymen last night that the church had been fighting for centuries for fair wages and the right of labor to organize. He quoted from Papal Encyclicals to show the attitude of the church since the early days of Catholicism.

The administering of medical care to persons on relief rolls should be recognized as a form of State medicine and the organized medical profession should have control of the administration, It was stated in a report adopted here tonight by the Westchester County Medical Society at its 140th annual meeting.

Stephen G. Thomas of 300 West 106th Street, lawyer and secretary of the New York Bible Society, was died yesterday in the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital a few hours after suffering a heart attack. He was born in Indiana, Pa., seventy-six years ago.

Miss Eleanor Wadsworth Cauchois, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Wadsworth Cauchois of Yonkers, N. Y., has completed plans for her marriage to Charles George Aubry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules F. A. Aubry, also of Yonkers, which will take place Dec. 18 in St. Paul's Church, Yonkers. The Rev.

Manhattan Alterations Broadway, 2,501; to 5-story tenement and stores; Muelight Realty Corp. 328 E 53d St. owner; S. Walter Katz, architect; cost $40,000. 10th Ave, 601-03; to 5-story tenement: Jacob Weisenfelder and Louis Hirsch, 201 W 92d St, owners: Otto A. Staudt, architect; cost $3,500.
After four months' vacation the French Parliament resumed its sittings today faced with the task of voting next year's budget estimates before the end of the year.

Richard de Blois Boardman, 59, Boston realtor and former commodore of the Corinthian Yacht Club, died tonight at Mary Alley Hospital four hours after he was found unconscious with a bullet wound in his head in his car at his Summer home in Marblehead Neck.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Sherman Olmsted, daughter of Mrs. Charles H. Wacker of Chicago and Biarritz, France, to George Graham de la Poer Horsley Beresford of this city, son of the Hon. Mrs. Florence Beresford of 116 East Sixty-third Street and the Hon. William Beresford of London. England.

Coach Dick Harlow's Harvard football squad tonight finished its hard work in preparation for Saturday's game with Yale. Tomorrow and Thursday there will be just the polishing off, and Friday a short signal drill.
Authoritative sources said tonight that France had clamped a ban on the passage of men and munitions into China through adjacent French Indo-China.

Continued technical and scientific developments in such fields as cellulose, plastics, synthetic rubber and conversion of coal into fuel oil and gasoline, together with possible replacement of certain industrial and agricultural activities through these developments, were predicted last night by Dr. Warren K. Lewis,

James M. Curley, three times Mayor of Boston and once Governor of Massachusetts, denied as a defendant on the witness stand in Superior Civil Court today that he and Dr. Joseph Santosuosso split- between them $50,000 out of an $85,000 settlement in Mr. Curley's last city administration.
An alleged plot to assassinate Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff, and other high army officials, has been uncovered, according to an announcement by the secret police tonight.

The Chinese Government has started the removal of Ministries to safer places inland-to Hankow, 300 miles west; to Chungking, the great Szechwan Province city at the head of the Yangtze River gorge, to Changsha and perhaps to Yunnan and Loyang.

Foreign Minister Kamil Krofta asserted before the Senate Foreign Political Committee today that "rumore that the Anglo-German discussions in Berlin will give Germany a free hand in Central Europe are stupid and nonsensical."
Dr. Lewis W. Douglas, principalelect of McGill University and former Director of the Budget, was elected a trustee of the Academy of Political Science at a meeting of the board of trustees yesterday.

Lou Ambers, world's lightweight boxing champion, won a ten-round decision from Charley Burns of Johnstown, Pa., in an exhibition match tonight. The champion carried the fight most of the way, but found Burns's long right bothersome.

Officials of the Ford Motor Company here, informed of a report that Japan and Manchukuo were planning a joint semi-government corporation capitalized at 3,000,000,000 yen to develop heavy industries and mining in Manchukuo and had invited the Ford company and the General Motors Corporation to participate, said today that they had not heard of such an offer.

Plans for tax revision to help a revival of industry were pushed further today by House and Senate leaders. Senator Harrison, chairman of the Finance Committee, said upon his arrival in Washington this morning that he favored changes in the tax system which would encourage industry, specifically mentioning modification of the undistributed profits and capital gains levies.

The Brick Presbyterian Church at 412 Fifth Avenue receives an interest valued at $233,859 in the estate of the late Alfred E. Marling, authority on real estate and taxation, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

Former athletic stars of De La Salle Institute discussed plans for the school's invitation interscholastic track meet, which will be held at the 102d Engineers Armory on Dec. 18, at an alumni sports dinner at Hans Jaeger's restaurant last night.

The two-story brick building at 4,930-2 Hudson Boulevard, West New York, N. J., has been sold to the Madonna Della Libera Roman Catholic Church, through J. B. Wolfe, Inc., brokers. Extensive alterations are planned which will convert the building into a convent,

Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda will pay $6,000,000 for the 60 per cent interest in United Artists Corporation held by Charles Chaplin, Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks, Mr. Goldwyn disclosed here today on his way to the Pacific Coast, where he will submit the sales contract to his attorneys.
The newly appointed Yugoslav Minister, Bosco Cristich, in presenting his credentials today addressed Victor Emmanuel as "King of Italy and Emperor of Ethiopia."
Al Youst's La Paloma Club, closed last night by raiders in Ku Klux Klan regalia, remained shut tonight despite his earlier plans for the usual show.

The tightening of police restrictions on strike pickets, reported to have been started last Thursday in a confidential oral order sent out to precinct commanders, is aimed at disorderly, roving bands of pickets, it was disclosed yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

It now looks as if Lou Little's football players will have to be "Sixty Minute Men" for better or for worse, whether they like it or not, during the final two games on Columbia's schedule-Dartmouth at Baker Field and Stanford on the same gridiron the following Saturday.
Smoke from a small fire killed Samuel Feinson, 73-year-old lawyer, last night in the basement of his home at 1,239 Carroll Street, in the Crown Heights district of Brooklyn.

ONE of the most curious stories in American history connects Theodore Roosevelt and Jefferson Davis. It seems that while Roosevelt was still a young man he published someting that the former President of the Confederacy, then in retirement and nearing the end of his life, regarded as a personal insult.

Almost the entire family of the late Grand Duke Ernst Ludwig of Hesse bei Rhein, grandson of Queen Victoria and last reigning Grand Duke of Hesse, was wiped out today when a Belgian airplane crashed near here, killing all aboard, eight passengers and three members of the crew.

Japanese aims and aspirations in China were expounded to German newspaper men today by Lieut. Gen. Sadao Takahashi of Japan, who recently arrived here ostensibly on a "study" mission. He summed up Japan's aims in China in four points:

Without a written opinion, the Court of Appeals today. affirmed the conviction of Salvatore Ossido for the murder of Einer Sporrer, an 11-year-old girl, at 293 Irvin Avenue, Brooklyn. The defense was that Ossido was insane when he committed the crime.

It was once the theory of the Democratic party (stated in its national platform of 1932) that by reorganizing the executive departments of the Government, by "abolishing useless commissions" and- by "consolidating bureaus," a saving of as much as 25 per cent could be made in the nation's tax bill.

Davey Kerr earned the hero's mantle last night when the New York Rangers defeated their city rivals, the Americans, in the first clash of the regular National Hockey League season between the teams. Neil Colville gave the Rangers a one-goal lead late in the first period and from then on it was up to Kerr to repel a steady succession of assaults directed at the cage that it is his assignment to watch.

The Coast Counties Gas and Electric Company, an operating subsidiary of the Pacific Public Service Company, will absorb the Natural Gas Company of California, another subsidiary of Pacific Public Service, under terms of a plan approved by the California Railroad Commission, it was announced yesterday.

Eliot Ness, safety director, turned over today to the chief assistant county prosecutor, Charles J. McNamee, details of a four-month investigation of some Cleveland labor leaders who, he charged, were involved in the extortion of large amounts of money from employers.

Gains in enrollments in several campaign groups led by prominent industrialists were reported yesterday by Mrs. David Challinor, director of the annual membership rollcall of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross. Mrs. C. P. Donahue, chairman of the mining and machinery division, announced that calls for more enrollment forms had come in from many groups in the heavy industries.
General Gaston Billotte, member of the French Supreme War Council and veteran colonial military leader, was named today to succeed General Henri Gouraud as Military Governor of Paris.

Three desperate members of "the nation's last organized kidnap gang," an under long Federal sentences for the abduction of John J. O'Connell Jr. of Albany, in July, 1933, escaped from the Onondaga County Penitentiary at Jamesville early this morning after binding and gagging five guards and forcing a sixth at the point of smuggled guns to drive them here in his own car.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,541,450 barrels, compared to 3,533,150 in the preceding week, an increase of 8,300 according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 32,450 barrels more than the calculation of 3,509,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for November.

Samuel Frank, president of Frank Brothers Footwear, Inc., and one of the first shoe merchants to open a store on Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in his apartment in the Hotel Warwick, Fifty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue, of a heart attack after an illness of four days. He was 75 years old.

Walter E. O'Hara, head of the Narragansett Racing Association, Inc., today pleaded innocent for himself and the corporation to Federal grand jury indictments charging violation of the Federal Corrupt Practices Act.

Warden Thomas Murphy of Clinton prison announced tonight that Clayton H. Birtram of Syracuse and James Sweet of Andover, N. Y., who escaped from the penitentary sanitarium here last night, surrendered quietly this evening to prison guards who surrounded them at Port Kent, about 35 miles from the prison.

Officials of the Church Pensions Conference, which is composed of twenty-four member denominations throughout the country, reported an increase in total annual benefits to 38,137 individuals at the opening of the twenty-third annual meeting of the group yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
KEOGH. ELLEN (April 7, 1937). Gross assets, $4,084; net, $2,955. To Anne Quirk, $2,955. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,084. Robert F. Mahoney. attorney, 50 Bioadway.

Manhattan's eleven started preparations for its contest with Niagara on Saturday at Ebbets Field by holding a two-hour drill at Innisfail Park yesterday. All members of the squad participated in the session. Four first-stringers, Vic Fusia, Joe Migdal, Pete Shulha and Joe Mitchell, who were kept out of the North Carolina State game because of slight injuries, took active parts in the practice.
Nine natives were killed and twenty-seven wounded during a riot last week-end in a camp at Isiolo, where 500 native deserters from the Italian forces in Ethiopia are interned.

The defense in the Rand-Bergoff case completed the presentation of its side today in Federal District Court here with the testimony of nine witnesses called to disprove the government's charge of violation of the Byrnes act by the defendants, James H. Rand, president of Remington Rand, and Pearl L. Bergoff, former head of an alleged New York strike-breaking agency, in the strike of the company's employes at Middletown last year.

George C. Edwards, 55 years old, retired partner of the MarshallHuschart Company of Chicago, machinery manufacturers, committed suicide here tonight in the bedroom of his apartment in Orient Point, according to Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester County Medical Examiner.
After an early loss that carried near months below 7 3/4 cents a pound, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and ended at the best figures of the session with gains of 1 to 4 points.

The New York State Athletic Commission voted yesterday to hold future meetings behind closed doors. The suggestion to adopt this policy was made by Commissioner Bill Brown and promptly followed by his colleagues, Chairman John J. Phelan and Commissioner D. Walker Wear.

Indictments were handed down in the United States District Court here yesterday against George J. Morrison and Emile Jaques, security dealers, for "wash sales" in the stock of the B/G Sandwich Shops. Richard Mason, an accountantinvestigator for the Securities and Exchange Commission, prepared the case and it was presented by Walter Thayer, assistant United States attorney.

The League of Nations' anti-terrorist conference ended today with the signing of two conventions, one providing for cooperation to repress terrorism, the other creating an international criminal court in which countries may optionally try terrorist cases.

Negroes in Westchester County have inadequate dwellings, encounter difficulty in obtaining municipal jobs and often are discriminated against in theatres and restaurants, investigators for the New York State Temporary Commission for the Study of the Colored Population reported here today at a meeting of the commission.

The Chinese armies on the Shanghai and North China fronts have suffered more than 800,000 casualties, according to Colonel C. E. De Watteville, representative of the International Red Cross, who has returned to Shanghai following an extensive tour of important Yangtze Valley cities.
The annual Christmas sale and tea for the benefit of Hope Farm, rural community and school for children near Millbrook, N. Y., will open this afternoon at the Pierre and continue through tomorrow.

The marriage of Miss Judy Bach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Bach of Purchase, N. Y., to Harry Angelo, son of Mrs. Leonard A. Cohn of this city, took place last night in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.

A verdict of murder in the first degree was returned last night by a Brooklyn jury against an 18-yearold youth who was indicted after ballistic experts had compared the markings on two bullets found in the body of a hold-up victim with the faintly etched lines in the barrel of a revolver the youth carried when seized in a robbery three months later.

Leading a field of ninety-six starters, which included many of the nation's top-notch professionals, Light Horse Harry Cooper and Lawson Little scored a best ball of 63 in the opening round of the thirty-six-hole pro-pro Midsouth golf tournament today, breaking the competitive best-ball record on the championship course by one stroke.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 13: LIEUTENANT Collett, J. A.. the Yorktown, to Aviation Unit, the Savannah, and for duty when commissioned.

Colonel Leonard Ayres is probably right in his contention that "the materials for construction of a real prosperity are here in abundance"; that "there is still great unfilled shortage of goods resulting from the depression years," but that "the outcome depends on actions and policies that will be decided on at Washington."

The National Retail Credit Association reported today 16,376 stores in forty-six cities experienced average increases of 1.3 per cent in collections, 3.6 per cent in credit sales and 3 per cerit in total sales during October as compared with the same month a year ago.

Major events today: The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by John Barbirolli, at Carnegie Hall tonight; Rosalyn Tureck in her second Bach piano program at the Town Hall in the afternoon, and Richard Tauber in his third Town Hall recital of the season in the evening.

Isadore Friedman, who had been a fugitive since indictments against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Jacob (Gurrah Jake) Shapiro and others were handed up last August, after 'Thomas E. Dewey's investigation of racketeering in the garment industry, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora.

Several decisions relative to the local football situation among secondary schools and rulings pertaining to swimming, basketball and soccer were made at the monthly meeting of the Public Schools Athletic League's high school games committee at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

Elimination next year of nearly threescore railroad grade crossings embodied in nineteen projects, involving an expenditure of $34,126,000, was approved today by the Public Service Commission. Sixteen of the projects, estimated to cost $24,577,500, were originally proposed for this year.
A United States proposal for the establishment of an international regional police radio communication system was approved by the technical committee of the radio conference here this morning.

A distinct trend toward elimination of special term rates which transient hotels had introduced during the depression, was reported by managers and other executives attending the National Hotel Exposition at the Grand Central Palace here yesterday.

Business men should take advantage of the Administration's recent "change of heart" toward business and take an active part in the adoption or rejection of measures that may be proposed at the special session of Congress, Joseph A. Huisking, chairman of the Drug, Chemical and Allied Trade Section of the New York Board of Trade, said last night at the group's forty-seventh annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Former Premier George Tatarescu's efforts to form a coalition government have failed, following the refusal of almost all party leaders to cooperate.
After a 17-year-old girl had testified in Yorkville Court yesterday that Charles Firestone, 60, a lawyer, who ten years ago was one of Mayor La Guardia's bitterest Tammany enemies in Harlem politics,

The State Department is studying closely reports received from the United States Embassy in Mexico City of expropriation by the government of lands owned by Americans and of developments in Mexico's oil policy, but it has reached no conclusion and is not prepared to make any statement of policy.

H. G. Wells, the English writer, declared yesterday that "at the present educational level world peace is an impossibility." His statement was in reply to a question about the potential influence of the New York World's Fair for peace. He had visited the fair grounds as a guest of Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair.
The stock market here was extremely quiet today, with most sections reflecting Wall Street's weakness of yesterday. Gilt-edge issues were dull and foreign bonds behaved uncertainly.

President Roosevelt cancelled all appointments and remained in the White House because of an infected tooth. In the Senate a filibuster was started against the anti-lynching bill and was still in progress, with Senator Connally holding the floor when that body recessed at 5:03 P. M. until noon tomorrow.

Bronze plaques were awarded last night to ten alumni of De Witt Clinton High School for achievement since leaving the school. The awards were announced at ceremonies in the school gymnasium at a celebration of the fortieth anniversary of the school.
Somewhere to the south ard of this port two down-East coasting schooners raced toward New York today, their skippers' honor and a case of bee and whisky at stake.

Owen D. Young, chairman of the board, and Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, each received compensation of $146,500 and Charles W. Appleton received $45,250 in 1936, according to information made available today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Persons whose deposits were frozen through the reorganization of the Guaranty Trust Company here in 1933 will benefit by the Bank Law enacted by the State Legislature last night, according to an announcement today by Mayor Charles D. White, president of the bank.

Sales of thirteen homes in Queens made recently by the Roosevelt Savings Bank, Brooklyn, were reported yesterday. At Richmond Hill the one-family home at 114-37 118th Street and the three-family dwelling at 86-38 111th Street were sold to. Stefeny Lewandowaki and Polin Lake respectively.

Kostas Palaskas, youthful third engineer on the Greek freighter Tzenny Chandris, which sank Saturday off Cape Hatteras, today retracted a statement, attributed to him by an interpreter, that he had to draw a knife to force the radio operator to broadcast an S O S.

Thomas L. Smith, formerly first vice president, was elected president yesterday of Standard Brands, Inc., to succeed Joseph Wilshire, who was elected to the new office of chairman of the board. Mr. Wilshire had been president since 1925.

The Federal Trade Commission today announced it had received a complaint from a committee of the rayon and synthetic yarn producers asking for an investigation of alleged propaganda activities of the International Silk Guild, and stated it could not undertake such an investigation in the absence of a "probable violation" of the law.
Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University and former Secretary of the Interior, and Mrs. Wilbur have arrived from Palo Alto, Calif., and are at the WaldorfAstoria.

Dr. Jeannette Scott, artist and former head of the painting department, College of Fine Arts, Syracuse t University, died at her home, 41 East Genesee Street, Skaneateles, today after an illness of several months. She was 73.

The leading foreign currencies continued to advance yesterday at the expense of the dollar although the volume of business here was small. European advices said the weakness of the dollar was due to the reception accorded the President's speech abroad and a fresh decline in stock prices here.
Another scheme for getting Japanese goods past import quotas in Latin America was discovered here today when agents of the Grace Line seized 700 silk shirts aboard the ship Santa Rita.

The sixth series of wool auctions opened today with the usual crowded attendance. Offerings totaled 7,121 bales, of which 4,508 were sold, and opening prices declined with the general expectations and showed drastic falls.

Benjamin Winter, the former house painter who built a real estate fortune estimated at its peak at $40,000,000, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court, listing liabilities at $8,542,736 and no assets.

The State Title and Mortgage Company and four of its former executive officers, who are on trial in Federal court for mail fraud growing out of the sale of $69,000,000 of guaranteed mortgages and certificates in 1932 and 1933, committed flagrant violations of the law and the trust of investors, Bernard Tompkins, Special Assistant Attorney General, told Judge Alfred C. Coxe and a jury yesterday in outlining the government's case.

Splendor is the fitting apparel of greatness. Lovers of beauty who recall the drabber days when an American statesman was usually encased in the statesman's frock coat of customary length and blackness are gladdened by the specially bright coloration with which so many of our Senators did honor to the special session and decorated the august chamber.

William F. Glendenning, 33 years old, a suspended. police patrolman, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of drunken driving early in the morning of Aug. 21, 1936, when his automobile crashed into a horse-drawn vehicle on the Williamsburg Bridge, tossing the driver 100 feet into Delancey Street and killing him instantly. A General Sessions jury failed to agree last August in a manslaughter trial.

Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Pierce H. Russell of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Russell, to William Wolfe Morrell of Pittsburgh, son of the Rev. Dr. Wheeler Morrell of Morristown. Tenn.

Congressional fears of war involvement were reflected today by the introduction in the Senate of two constitutional amendments to take from Congress the power to declare a foreign war until after an affirmative vote by popular referendum and a proposal for universal draft of men and resources in time of war.

In its annual statement to stockholders, to be released today, the Liquid Carbonic Corporation reports for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 a net income of $1,655,866 after all charges, including Federal income and undistributed-profits tax.

John L. Handy, in 32 E 64th St from Edward F. Brigham; F. Trubee Davison, In 36 E 72d St; Alden S. Thurston, in 212 E 48th St from the estate of Ogden Goelet; Walter D. Clark, in 167 E 82d St through Culver Hollyday Co; Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc, broker.

An agreement between committees of anthracite operators and the United Mine Workers of America to extend their wage contract for another year lacks only the approval of the main body of miners to make it effective.

X. G. Weld explained last night that he came to this country with "a definite conviction that America had completely forgotten about me." He reported on an investigation into the difficulties of selling books by H. G. Wells in America, in an informal talk at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair
Tommy Rawson, 136, of Boston won a close eight-round decision from Maxie Berger, 135 1/2, of Montreal at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before 10,000 fans.

The case of eighteen power companies against the Tennessee Valley Authority, now being tried in Chattanooga, is of great importance both on constitutional and on economic grounds. It is the first case to come before a three-judge tribunal as provided for under the recent Judicial Reform Bill; and if either side appeals the decision of this tribunal, as seems inevitable, the case will go directly to the Supreme Court.

Edouard Herriot, president of the French Chamber of Deputies, was named by the United States and Chile today as the. Joint Commissioner of the Permanent International Commission that is set up under the Bryan so-called coolingoff conciliation treaty of 1914.

In the first of several contemplated shifts, Coach Steve Owen moved Ray Hanken, stocky end from George Washington University, into the first -line-up of the New York Football Giants yesterday. Hanken, a defensive star and good pass-catcher, is slated to start in place of Jim Poole in the battle with the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

Efrem Zimbalist, who gave his only New York recital at Carnegie Hall last night as the second event in the special Hurok series, provided a large audience with one of his finest performances in recent years. His average consittutes an art that is dignified,

National Supply Company of Delaware common stock, $10 par value, and 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, have been stricken from New York Stock Exchange listing and registration. New securities have been listed for them.

Twenty nurses were graduated last night by the Lenox Hill Hospital School of Nursing. The commencement exercises, which also initiated a four-day celebration of the school's fiftieth anniversary, were held in the hospital's Einhorn Auditorium, 131 East Seventy-sixth Street.

Kenneth F. Simpson, New York County Republican leader, is at present the leading candidate to succeed Charles D. Hilles as Republican National Committeeman from New York and will probably be elected to that post by the Republican State Committee in the near future, barring unforeseen contingencies.

A loan of $2,500,000 has been arranged for ten years with the Mutual Life Insurance Company on the thirty-story Majestic apartments at. Central Park West and Seventy-first and Seventy-second Streets, through Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc.

The dismissal of Mme. Barbara N. Yakovleva from the government service after a long career of revolutionary leadership was confirmed today by appointment of a new Commissar of Finance for the Russian Socialist Federated Soviet Republic (Russia proper).
" Silent Knight," by Humbert Wolfe, from the Hungarian of Eugene Heltai, was presented at St. James's Theatre tonight by Gilbert Miller. It was well received and seems destined to run for some time.

Yale University has an attendance of 5,230 for the present year, including students from every State and from thirty-five foreign countries. Yale College has 1,536 students, leading wall the university divisions, and is followed by 859 in the common freshman class, the enrollment of which is limited.

Reports that Brazilian bonds are rising abroad, coffee prices becoming firmer and milreis quotations stiffening are accepted here as a certain indication of favorable reaction abroad to President Getulio Vargas's statement Saturday to foreign press correspondents.

Some 10,000 gallons of whisky, wine and beer seized by police in raids since 1933 will be destroyed at 10:30 this morning at the property clerk's warehouse at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.
Five persons were injured in a collision at 10 o'clock last night at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Strut. The cars caromed to the opposite sides of the intersection, so great was the impact.

Striking automobile workers, abandoning a twelve-hour sit-down in the Fisher Body plant here, gave assurances today against further strikes during negotiation of their grievance, and the management agreed to reopen the factory.

A near-perfect performance gave the United States Army team a clear victory in the international military jumping at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight. Only one fault was charged to the three American riders who jumped abreast over an eight-hurdle course.

Mark Graves, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, recommended the reduction of Federal taxes on business and personal incomes yesterday and advised the enactment of a Federal manufacturers' sales tax to supply needed revenue on a more equitable basis.

Appeals of ten railroads from property assessments for 1937 in this State totaling $19,372,444, scheduled to start today before the State Board of Tax Appeals, were postponed until Jan. 25 because suits involving taxes for 1934, 1935 and 1936 still are being argued in Federal court here.
The Maritime Commission extended today for six months the temporary agreements with managing agents of government-owned steamship lines.

One of the threefold purposes, of the Kipling Fund now being raised in the British Empire is the building of a memorial library on the grounds of-the Imperial Service at Windsor-which is the newer name of the school for boys who are sons of the servants of the empire, where Kipling- was himself a pupil.
An intensified Japanese drive along the Tientsin-Pukow Railway in Shantung Province pushed the Chinese forces southward across the Yellow River today along a large front.

The results of the first stage of the Brussels Nine-Power Conference are pitifully small. After a fortnight of discussions, a resolution mildly criticizing Japan for illegal action in China has been passed-not unanimously.
Syracuse cloned its soccer season today by defeating Colgate, 4-0. The triumph gave the Orange a record of five victories and three defeats.
Ely Culbertson, bridge expert, testified in Superior Court today that his income was $24,480 a year and expenses, from the Culbertsons, Inc., a holding company controlled by himself and his wife.
The theft from the Colonial Museum in the Bois de Vincennes of gowns, jewels and ornaments of the kings of Cambodia and treasure belonging to the African ruler Amadou was discovered today.

Philip de Laszlo, the painter, who for many years has charged a minimum fee of 1,000 guineas [[Pound]1,050] for portraits, is seriously ill at his Hampstead home following a heart attack at the age of 68.

The Bruins clicked off their third straight National Hockey League victory tonight by shutting out the Maroons, 1-0, as King Clancy, long a Boston favorite, made his managerial debut at the Boston Garden.

In a black-draped room aboard the British cruiser Apollo, former Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald's body is now on the way back to England following a repetition here today of the state rites conducted yesterday.

Business leases reported yesterday included a contract for the store at 430 Fourth Avenue with the Knickerbocker Ice Company, which will use the space for an office and salesroom for refrigerators and showcases.

Revision of the State banking statutes to permit a trust company again to divide a mortgage among two or more trusts under its control is being advocated in some circles as a means of promoting the financing of large realty operations.

As a jury was about to be chosen in General Sessions from a blueribbon panel for a third trial of Nicholas (Nick) Montana, 39 years old, on the second of two felony indictments charging compulsory prostitution, Judge Nott, on the recommendation of District Attorney William C. Dodge, accepted a plea of guilty to a misdemeanor vice charge.

The three-judge Federal court trying the injunction suit of eighteen private power companies against the Tennessee Valley Authority and its directors on constitutional grounds refused today to grant a subpoena duces tecum for the production in court of minutes of TVA directors' meetings relating to the government's power program in seven Southeastern States.

John F. Manning, deputy clerk of the City Court, Kings County branch, died yesterday of an abdominal ailment at his home, 304 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn, after a seven-week illness. Mr. Manning was Past Exalted Ruler of Brooklyn Lodge 22 of the Elks. His age was 57.

Snow-shoeing events, in which several of the leading performers of this country and Canada will compete, are on the program of the five-day Winter sports carnival and international ski meet which will be held in Madison Square Garden Touchd Dec. 7 to 11.
The winners of Princeton University's Fall class tennis championships were announced today by William F. Halsey 3d, '38, of Pensacola, Fla., president of the Intramural Athletic Association.

Times will become propitious in the near future for widespread inauguration of the "automatic saving plan" and its promotion as proposed by the Thrift and Security Foundation, it was asserted at a luncheon meeting of the organization in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Faced by a Japanese declaration that the Brussels conference had closed. "forever" the door to mediation of the Far Eastern conflict, Norman H. Davis, head of the United States delegation, conferred with Russian officials today on procedure at the next stage of the conference.

Efforts to evacuate all Americans from Nanking within the next few days were launched yesterday by the United States Embassy. Simultaneously the Yangtze gunboat Oahu was ordered here from Ichang to join the Panay for greater protection of the Americans and to provide additional evacuation facilities.

Two men were booked at the Poplar Street police station, Brooklyn, last night, as a result of an altercation outside The Brooklyn Daily Eagle Building, 24 Johnson Street, where members of the New York Newspaper Guild are on strike.

County Clerk Albert Marinelli, whose elective term expires on Dec. 31, is not likely to be appointed to that post by the Appellate Division, according to information in usually reliable political circles yesterday.

In its first declaration of policy in regard to the administration of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, the Securities and Exchange Commission stated today that the process of forming integrated public utility systems was of necessity in many cases "an evolutionary rather than a revolutionary" one and should be so conducted as to protect security holders from sacrifice attendant upon forced selling.

The nation's first comprehensive effort to count its unemployed got under way yesterday, with the distribution through the mails of 85,000,000 unemployment census report cards. All the 4,000,000 deliveries in this city were made by mid-afternoon and the jobless responded so swiftly that by nightfall great stacks of returned forms were beginning to rise in postal stations.

Albert Wilson, Yale right halfback, will be unable to play against Harvard at Cambridge Saturday because a cold which has failed to respond to treatment still holds him in the hospital. - Suffering from the attack a week ago, he was unable to face Princeton, although he saw the contest from the press box.

In one of the finest testimonials ever given to an amateur rider in this country, nearly 3,000 persons contributed to the fund for the trophy for the inaugural running of the Noel Laing Steeplechase at Montpelier, Va., Saturday on the estate of Mrs. Marion du Pont Scott.
Captious tongues will insist that woman's position in Soviet Russia has not been changed out of all recognition.

Stung by charges that nothing had been done in the past two years to protect the civilian population against a bombing attack, Geoffrey Lloyd, Under-Secretary in the Home Office, disclosed to the House of Commons tonight that the government had been dropping 500-pound bombs on a fullscale model of a London street to determine the "exact type of damage."

After going through the routine of receiving the city's 1938 budget and referring it to the finance committee without discussion yesterday, the Board of Aldermen considered a new five-day-week bill for city employes, drawn to meet the objections stated by Mayor La Guardia in his message vetoing the first five-day-week bill adopted by the Aldermen.

J. J. Broomall, horticulturist, died here Sunday of a heart attack while working in his garden. His age was 79. Born in Pennsylvania, Mr. Broomall came to the West Coast as a young man. Settling in Eagle Rock twenty-seven years ago, he established the two-acre dahlia farm next to his home that was to bring him fame in horticultural circles.

The international situation was described here tonight as "really very alarming" by Alexander A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet Ambassador. appealed for the maintenance of peace "by peaceful means," but asserted that "if it were necessary" his country "would not be afraid to give an instructive lesson to any foreign aggressor."

The League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers, has prepared a brief asking the Federal Government to repeal the tax on admission tickets to legitimate/theatres, it was learned yesterday.

The first newspaper campaign for Honor Brand Frosted Foods has been launched in one evening newspaper in Washington, D. C., and will run several months, Earl B. Thomas, who handles the account for N. W. Ayer Son, said yesterday.

Plans for a conference on the liability of banks for stamp taxes on transactions in securities are under way following the refusal of the Internal Revenue Bureau to rule on the question, according to a letter to the New York Stock Exchange from D. S. Bliss, deputy commissioner of Internal Revenue.

Steel ingot production continued its downward movement last week and more than seasonally. The adjusted index has eased to 63.2, its lowest point since the week ended July 20, 1935. The figure for the previous week was 71.0, while for the week ended Nov. 14, 1936, the index stood at 111.3.

A meeting of the New York State Safe Deposit Association will be held this evening in the Hotel Martinique. A dinner at 6:15 P. M. will be followed by an open forum. The corporate name of Swart, Brent Co., Inc., has been changed to R. E. Swart Co., Inc.
Running in rain, High Vote won the $2,000-added Inaugural Handicap today to open Tanforan's twenty-five-day Fall race meeting.

Resuming after a full stop-this brought about by "conditions" of a few weeks ago-"Father Malachy's Miracle" finally reaches the stage of the St. James this evening, under its original sponsor, Delos Chappell.

Delegates to the National Grange Convention adopted a resolution today expressing opposition to operations of the Chicago Board of Trade, asserting that "selling grain futures contracts has resulted in gambling in the prices of farm products and injured producers and consumers."

Professor T. Nelson Dale, retired, who for twenty-three years was with the United States Geological Survey, died here today at his Commonwealth Avenue home. He would have been 92 years old on Thanksgiving Day.

A "significant" decline in employment, amounting to 4.3 per cent in the last month and 6.4 per cent from August, was revealed yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board on the basis of results from a special telegraphic survey completed Saturday.

Ernest J. Poole of Reading, steel manufacturer and president of the State Chamber of Commerce, fell dead today while greeting associates at the chamber's headquarters in this city. He was 64 years old.

Testimony alleging a direct link. between politics and organized vice in Atlantic City was heard in Federal District Court here today during the trial of the first of a series of Federal "white slave" cases.

Camping at Heckscher State Park, in East Islip, will not be permitted next year because campers this season used the site set aside for them for purposes other than those for which it was intended, Chief Engineer Arthur E. Howland of the Long Island State Park Commission announced here today.

John F. Miller has been elected chairman of the Pittsburgh Screw and Bolt Corporation to succeed the late William G. Costin. John M. Yahres was elected executive vice president and John M. Auty, treasurer.
Coach Jim Crowley kept his Fordham football squad hard at work yesterday in preparation for the intersectional game with St. Mary's at the Polo Grounds Saturday.

Twenty-eight teams-of-four, including many of the best contract bridge players in the United States, sat down grimly last night at the tables in the Hotel Ambassador, Park Avenue at Fifty-first Street, to vie for the tenth annual contest for the custody of the Vanderbilt Cup. Harold S. Vanderbilt, donor of the cup, was a member of one of the teams.

John Starbuck, managing director of the Men's Apparel Quality Guild, the new organization of men's wear manufacturers that will sponsor an exhibit at the New York World's Fair, 1939, announced yesterday the establishment of an executive council, comprising C. R. Palmer, president of Cluett, Peabody Co.;

A petition for approval of changes in the city map to provide for a vehicular tunnel under Sutton Place between Fifty-fourth and Sixtieth Streets to accommodate the East River Drive at that point was filed with the Board of Estimate yesterday by the First Avenue Association.
A two-day chrysanthemum fashion show featured by luncheon on each day for the benefit of the Children's Village of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will be held today and tomorrow at the Versailles Restaurant.

A proposal of the Teachers Union that the Board of Highei Education reinstate Dr. Mirian Becker, discharged Hunter Col lege mathematics teacher, and leave the clarification of the Feld McGrath Tenure Law to legis lative enactment was rejected las night when the matter was taker up at a meeting of the-board held at the City College Building, Lex ington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.
Both President Roosevelt and Vice President Garner had toothaches today. Mr. Roosevelt was forced to stay in the White House and to cancel all his appointments.

Most commodity futures were lower in moderate activity on the local Exchanges yesterday. Coffee futures continued downward.- In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, raw sugar, eggs and cotton advanced, but cocoa, butter, lard tins, rubber and wool tops declined.

Hudson J. Bordwell, a trustee of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad, and former general manager of the Eastern district of the Erie Railroad, died last night of a heart attack in his home here. He was 53 years old.

Twenty thousand persons are expected to witness the fourth annual performance of the theatrical spectacle,- "Night of Stars," in Madison Square Garden tonight. Constituting the amusement indusiry's contribution to the United Palestine Appeal, the performance will mark the twentieth anniversary of the march into Jerusalem

Bernard Shaw's version of the last act of "Cymbeline," produced at the Embassy Theatre, makes strange Shakespeare, as if the bard had been "post-Ibsen and post-Shaw instead of post-Marlowe," as The Times says.

Awards will be presented to twenty-nine winners in the second modern plastics competition sponsored by Modern Plastics Magazine at a dinner tonight at the New Yorker Hotel. First prize winners in the five groups judged were as follows:

The 700 flour truck drivers who went on strike last Tuesday against the Associated Flour Haulers and Warehousemen at the call of Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters agreed yesterday to submit their dispute to the State Board of Mediation, 366 Broadway, this morning at 10 o'clock.

Registering two touchdowns in the final period, Ridgefield Park High School's football team routed the Bogota High School eleven, 19 to 0, today. Jim Reis, fullback of the victorious squad, tallied twice himself and, passed to Roscoe Warder for another score:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the admirable set-up of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair at Rockefeller Center, educational advantages of the highest order abound. The opportunity to hear and see famous. literary personages is one that is definitely intriguing, and, judging from the throngs attending the sessions, it is deeply appreciated.

Colonel Bryer H. Pendry, commander of the 245th Coast Artillery, New York National Guard, will retire next month on reaching the statutory retirement age of 64 years, according to an announcement yesterday.

Among the passengers booked to sail for Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary are Lord Vivian, Lady Kennard, Baroness Rothschild, Viscount Knollys, Baroness von Roon, Otto M. Schiff, H. G. Wells, the author; Lewis Einstein, Mr. and Mrs. B. L. Rist, Henry Schuengel, Victor Neuman, Mme. de Souza Dantas, Mr. and Mrs. Walter O'Keefe and Sir Kenneth Lee.

Breaking through a strong Alexander Hamilton High School defense with an aerial attack engineered by Frank Pezzella, the undefeated and untied Eastchester High eleven scored its seventh straight triumph of the season today, turning back the invaders from Elmsford, 12 to 0.
The Bay Shore High football team scored a surprise triumph over Huntington, 7-2, today. The losers, who hitherto had been undefeated, having won five games and tied two, concluded their campaign.

With Leon Daudet shouting "liar" until his nose bled, with former Premier Andre Tardieu suave and throwing poison darts in all directions and with the Basque Deputy Jean Ybarnegaray at times defending his leader,

Winners in the twelve secondround matches in the Eastern Squash Racquets Association tournament played on the New York Athletic Club courts last night included one Winged Foot entrant and two Yale Club players who are near the top of the seeded list.

A suggestion that Thomas E. Dewey, newly elected District Attorney, continue the investigation in Manhattan of fraud in proportional representation voting for City Council and assume responsibility- for prosecution was made yesterday to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. by Morris L. Ernst, who was deputized especially to study the new system of balloting.

The Sperry Hutchinson Company acquired yesterday on a bid of $425,000 the six-story loft building at 860 Broadway, northeast corner of Seventeenth Street, running through to 32-34 East Eighteenth Street.

Repreaentative Norton of New Jersey, chairman of the Labor Committee, filed with the clerk of the House today a petition to discharge the Rules Committee from further consideration of the Wages and Hours Bill, which it prevented from reaching the floor at the last session of Congress. By the time the House adjourned, forty-four members had signed it.

Counsel for one of the nineteen corporate defendants in the Federal Government's gasoline price fixing conspiracy case declared today that this was the first time he had heard of large companies being tried under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act for trying to preserve competition.

It isn't every hunter that has an opportunity to kill a deer with a pistol, and it isn't every deer that would continue to run straight at a hunter while he fired eight shots. Bruce W. Campbell of New York is not such a remarkable rifle shot, but he isn't so bad with the pistol, so he was able to take home a nice twelve-point buck.
Owing to increased taxes on utilities, the Public Service Commission today permitted the Rochester Telephone Corporation to charge "slightly higher rates" effective on Nov. 26.

The Brooklyn police are so mortified by a civic leader's recent charge of inadequate policing in the Bedford, Crown Heights and Stuyvesant sections of the borough that about fifty of them began last night a voluntary patrol of the streetson their own time-to curtail a growing "crime wave" that has kept elderly and more timid residents indoors after nightfall.

In spite of the indicated decline in industrial activity and the uncertainty regarding the future, borrowings are holding up well. Retail borrowing has not yet appeared in any sizable volume, but with the approach of the holiday season it should be stepped up considerably.
In the Supreme Court of the United States Otto B. Schmidt and Alfred H. Phillips of New York were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had:

Colonel Henry J. Seeley, former department commander of the Grand DR Army of the Republic in Connecticut and formerly, for eight years, commandant at Fitch's Home for Soldiers, in Noroton, died in his home here today at the age of 89. He also had served as national adjutant of the G. A. R. in 1913 and as assistant quartermaster general in Connecticut.
Mortgage loans aggregating $930,050 have been placed on New Jersey properties within- the last two months by the mortgage department of the J. I. Kislak, Inc.,

Purchase of mining rights to a 300-acre property near Moose River, N. S., by Baron Louis Empain, Belgian financier, was announced today by an official of the Compagnie Belgo-Canadienne de Credit Limitee.

Resriction of the markets for price-fixed national brands is the ultimate results of resale price-fixing under the Fair Trade Laws, Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., New York City, told the Illinois Manufacturers Costs Association at a dinner meeting tonight.
The National Coal Association asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to dismiss the petition of railroads, filed on Nov. 1, for authority to increase rates on bituminous coal and coke.

In contrast to recent news of murder and bloodshed in Palestine, a meeting of the councilors of the Jerusalem municipality, both Jews and Arabs, decided today to publish an appeal to the entire population of the city to return to normalcy and to restore order.

A 10-year-old Negro girl's written suggestion for the name of a park now under construction in Jamaica, Queens, drew ready acceptance from Park Commissioner Robert Moses, it was disclosed yesterday when the correspondence between the two was made public.

Joseph Pecori, 40 years old, of 538 Union Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot and killed at 10:30 last night by four gunmen who entered the rear room of the candy store operated by his brother, Robert, at 271 Leonard Street, between Devoe and Powers Streets, in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

The Princeton Tigers, in the midst of their efforts to salvage the remnants of a disappointing season, were dealt an unforeseen blow today with the announcement that 200-pound Conrad Balentine, regular guard, will be unable to see action against the Navy here Saturday.

Average wool prices now are well below those of last year. A fall of 10 per cent in merinos and up to 20 per cent in crossbreds has occurred in the last three weeks. Even at this level competition is most disappointing, hence a curtailment of offerings is urged by some growers and brokers, although others strongly oppose this procedure.

Stocks moved irregularly in cautious trading yesterday and closed generally lower, although there was a moderate rally late in the session, led by some of the steel issues. The trading volume again declined; the day's turnover on the Stock Exchange was 1,269,000 shares, against 1,450,000 the day before.

Wheat futures fluctuated in a nervous manner today within a range of around 13/4 cents a bushel and closed within a small fraction of a cent of the high points. The net gains were 3/8 to 7/8 cent, the former on the July, which was sold on reports of highly beneficial rains in parts of Kansas.

The art collection and residence of Jules S. Bache at 814 Fifth Avenue, which he gave to the State of New York for a museum, was opened to the public yesterday. Eight hundred letters and telegrams were received yesterday by Mrs. Mary Duggett Benson, custodian of the collection, asking for tickets of admission.
Federal assistance in controlling the waters of New Creek, Staten Island, to prevent the recurrence of flood conditions in the Dongan Hills territory, was requested by borough officials and property

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, a trustee of the Carnegie Corporation of New York since 1925, was elected chairman of the board for the year 1937-1938 at the annual meeting held yesterday. Elihu Root Jr. was elected a member to fill the vacancy caused by the death of his father. His term will run until 1939.

Walter C. Teagle, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and head of the industry section in the United Hospital Campaign, appealed for personal contributions from corporation executives yesterday in a speech at a luncheon meeting in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center.

Predictions of "a farm bill by Monday" were made today by Chairman Smith and other members of the Senate Agriculture Committee after the appearance at an executive session of the committee of Secretary Wallace, who supported "in principle" the Pope-McGill bill for cartrying out his "ever-normal granary" program.

Without a shot in defense, two of the three convicts who escaped yesterday from the Onondaga Penitentiary at Jamesville, where they were imprisoned pending their appeal from conviction in the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., were captured here at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon. The third is still at large.

Retail "package deliveries in the metropolitan area- showed a decrease of 6 per cent for the week ended Nov. 13, as compared with the same week a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Pardel Service.

Miss Viola Marie Finiels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. Finiels of Greenwich, was married to Carl G. Hakanson, son of C. A. Hakanson, also of Greenwich, and the late Mrs. Hakanson, in the First Presbyterian Church here this afternoon.

Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday eliminated Charles H. George, 64 years old, a lawyer, and John J. Langan, 41, from the grand larceny indictment returned in June, 1935, against them, William F. Peterson, -fugitive stock promoter, and his wife, Hilda M. Peterson, in an alleged stock fraud conspiracy involving $500,000. The Court acted on motions by counsel for George and Langan, who contended lack of prosecution.

Kent Cooper, general manager or The Associated Press, issued the following statement yesterday on the death of Mr. Roberts: "The life, character and work of Elmer Roberts exemplified the high standing which a loyally interested Associated Press man can reach. The Associated Press was his life.

Mr. and Mrs. Reginald William Pressprich entertained with a dinner last night in the Iridium Room' of the St. Regis for Miss Louise Lutkins and Robert Le Brecht, whose marriage will take place here tomorrow in St. James' Church.
Miss Elizabeth Rudderow was introduced this afternoon at a tea which her parents, the Rev. and Mrs. B. Janney Rudderow, gave at their home here.

After studying the conclusions of the Rev. Walter G. Summers, chairman of the Fordham University Department of Psychology, County Judge J. Edward Knight commented here today: "The report indicates that Fremgen was falsifying when he testified that he did not receive a $10 bribe from Swensen."

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor have decided to visit the United States soon after Christmas, according to a reliable source close to the couple. Pourparlers are stated to be in progress with the French Line and the United States Lines to induce them either to omit a scheduled call at a British port or to make that call before stopping at Havre or Cherbourg en route to the United States.

President Manuel Quezon opened the door to permanent American retention of the Philippines a bit wider today, intimating to the press that he would welcome proposals for a dominion status but declaring that the proposals "must come from some one else."

The Federal deficit climbed above the $700,000,000 mark in the first four and one-half months of the fiscal year which began on July 1, the Treasury statement showed today. On Nov. 15, expenditures had exceeded income by $702,238,089.

Dr. Harlow Shapley, the terrestrially known astronomer, director of the Harvard University Observatory, returned to his native Missouri a few days ago to give a St. Louis audience some account of the celestial territory which he has had an authoritative part

Dr. Charles B. Lindsley, Professor of Mathematics at the University School, died at Jewish Hospital here today. He was 56 years old. Dr. Lindsley ?? taught in the School of Education, University of Cincinnati.
Fifty-two of 534 students in the three upper classes at Radcliffe have been placed on the first two groups of the dean's list.

Charges that the action of the business conduct committee of the Board of Trade in ordering the Cargill Grain Comiany to sell more than' 1,000,000 bushels of September corn were grossly one-sided and unfair were made today by John H. Macmillan Jr., president of Cargill, Inc.,
The field of twenty-eight teams of four in the ninth annual contract bridge tournament for the Vanderbilt Cup was narrowed to sixteen teams last night at the Hotel Ambassador.

Exports of paper and paper products from the United States during September reached a value of $2,441,824, an increase of 6 per cent over August and a gain of 77 per cent over September of 1936, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce said in a report today.

The three-judge Federal court headed by Circuit Judge Florence E. Allen excluded from the trial record today exhibits offered to show savings of millions of dollars to consumers in recent years from rate reductions by the Appalachian Electric Power Company and associated companies.

Since mid-August, when the bear market commenced, there has been a tendency to blame market thinness for collapsing prices. There has been, as well, a tendency to blame Federal legislation, especially tax legislation, for market thinness.

Someone using the same method as the poisoner who killed seventy pigeons with strychnine-filled seeds near Seventy-third Street and Broadway on Aug. 10 brought death yesterday to about forty of the birds at the northwest corner of Seventy-ninth Street and Broadway, in front of the First Baptist Church.

Milton Hart of Ossining, an attorney, died last night in the White Plains Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was taken ill in the afternoon while arguing a case in the Westchester County Court House.

Tens of thousands of unemployed persons in the five boroughs of the city filed yesterday the yellow report cards that will enable the Federal Government to gauge the extent of its unemployment problem.
The A. C. H. M. Hall Realty Company announced yesterday that it had purchased another large parcel in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

An estate, a night club and many business properties and residences were sold by Suffolk County today for unpaid taxes for the year 1936. The sale was conducted by County Treasurer John G. Peck in the County Court House here and will continue tomorrow.

Children's books are now being examined for subversive doctrine, according to Munro Leaf, director of the publishing firm of Frederick A. Stokes Co. He told an audience yesterday afternoon at THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center about what happened to "Ferdinand," which he wrote for children and which has amused so many adults.

A jury before Supreme Court Justice Thomas C. Kadien Jr. in Brooklyn awarded yesterday a verdict of $10,800 to Simon Madison, 39 years old, of 259 Van Brunt Street, Brooklyn, father of eight children. He had sued the city for the death of his wife Frances, 37.

In an atmosphere of complete harmony and cordiality that was entirely at variance with preconceived notions of open warfare, the Amateur Athletic Union and the National Collegiate A. A. united behind Avery Brundage at the quadrennial meeting of the American Olympic Association today and smoothed their differences so neatly that not even a seam appeared.
Caledonia retained the MacTier Cup; emblematic of Eastern Canada's English rugby championship, when it defeated the Bank of Montreal team, Quebec champion, 35--0, today.

Rufus H. Fitzgerald, a graduate of Guilford College and the University of Tennessee, has been named provost of the University of Pittsburgh. The title provost, a new one at the university, replaces the title dean of administration, which position has been vacant for seven years.

Declaring that "the Federal Reserve System and the Treasury pursued for too long an excessively easy-money policy," Eugene Meyer, publisher of The Washington Post, former chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said today in an address at a luncheon of the Baltimore Advertising Club:

The three new directors elected to the board of the Pittsburgh Screw Bolt Corporation are George A. Blackmore, president of the Westinghouse Airbrake Company; John S. Craig and Leon E. Hickman. There were two vacancies, and the board was increased to ten from nine directors.

The Associated Gas and Electrio Company, top holding company of the Associated Gas and- Electrio System, has suspended interest payments on $49,567,000 of its convertible obligations bearing interest rates ranging from 5 to 7 per cent, it became known yesterday.
Philippine imports of nails, bolts and nuts are expected to drop when a new factory to manufacture such metal products is put into operation, the Commerce Department said today.

Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation and chairman of the commerce and industry committee of the United Hospital Campaign, declared in a broadcast yesterday. from radio station WABC that business had recognized its responsibility for the well-being of the entire community.

The meeting between Harvard and Yale on Soldiers Field Satumday offers the paradoxical situation of a team that has lost two games ruling no worse than an even bet, if not the slight favorite, to defeat a rival that stands among the unbeaten leaders of the East.

Divergent views are being presented on the manner in which the State mortgage moratorium statute might be amended or tapered, off, and it still is too early to try to forecast just what recommendations the legislative committee now investigating the situation will make, although it appears likely that some of the members of the committee see a need for action looking at least to eventual termination of the moratorium.

For the second time Felix John Cummings, 26 years old, of 390 Willoughby Avenue, and George Lewis, 26, of 119 Nostrand Avenue, both Brooklyn, stood before Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato yesterday and heard themselves sentenced to die in the electric chair for the hold-up murder of Ralph Nischo, a waiter, in a bar and grill at 1,942 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, on Jan. 7, 1936.
It is officially announced that Pope Pius will hold secret and public consistories on Dec. 13 and 16 respectively for the creation of five Cardinals.

John Franklin Jardine, president of the National Potato Growers Association and chairman, of the Northwest region of the Potato Control Board, died this morning after a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 63 years old.

President Roosevelt carried his fight for adoption of his Administration's farm program to the home of the "Father of His-Country" today. In a message to land grant college and university presidents at Mount Vernon he declared that George Washington almost certainly would have approved government action to help farmers bring their operations into balance.

Solly Krieger of Brooklyn, who has set back the aspirations of a number of good middleweights, gained a decision over Frank Battaglia, Winnipeg, in the ten-round feature bout at the Hippodrome last night.

The following tables show the latest Council returns in the Boroughs of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.- The Bronx returns, because of court actions, have been held up and the first count has not been completed. In Richmond the count was completed earlier in the week with Frederick Schick, Democrat, elected as the borough's sole Councilman.

Expropriation of all flour mills in Mexico and the setting up of a nation-wide producers' and consumers' cooperative organization was provided for in a bill studied today by the Mexican Chamber of Deputies.

The session of the American Federation of Labor-Committee for Industrial Organization peace conference committees, scheduled for tomorrow, has been postponed until Nov. 29. Request for postponement came from the A. F. of L.

A jury verdict today gave to the Federal Government a $20,000 farm near Woodstock, Ill., where a $15,000 distillery was found in operation last April. It was the first successful suit of its kind in this district since repeal.

Prince Ludwig of Hesse bei Rhein and his English bride, whom he married today, began a sad honeymoon with a trip to Ostend to identify members of the Prince's family who were killed yesterday in an air crash.

The Boston Bruins, unbeaten thus far in the National Hockey League campaign, will make their New York seasonal debut' tonight in Madison Square Garden when they line up against the Americans in what promises to beta highly exciting contest.

George Farkas, president of Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., announced yesterday that plans are being developed for the erection of a new three-story and basement building adjoining the Fordham Road store of the corporation.
Four Russian Arctic campers, riding an ice floe down from the North Pole, reported by radio today that they were about 125 miles off the northeastern coast of Greenland.

Farrar Rinehart report that a new printing of J. B. Rhine's "New Frontiers of the Mind" brings the total sale up to 110,000, including the Book of the Month Club sale. Sally Salminen's "Katrina" is now in a sixth edition.

Appeals filed against assessed valuation of real property with the Department of Taxes and Assessments were 469 fewer this year than last year, William Stanley Miller, president of the department, said yesterday.
Peace lovers will be glad to learn that military music is on its way out. From army manoeuvres in Texas it is reported that tentative
Philip J. Harkins of this city, a former railroad executive, died at his home here this morning. Born in Easton, Pa., he was for many years chief clerk for the Southern Railway Company.

Henry C. Turner, president of the Board of Education, asserted in an affidavit submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente that the board did not intend to demand that teachers and other employes comply with the so-called Lyons residence law, which becomes effective Jan. 1.

The Board of Tax Appeals decided today that the Commissioner of Internal Revenue erred in determining an income tax deficiency for 1934 of $2,040,411.91 against the estate of Cyrus H. K. Curtis. Executors named in the proceedings were John C. Martin and Mary Louise Curtis Bok.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray of New York and Ilex House, Southampton, L. I., gave a large reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 11 East Ninetieth Street, to introduce their daughters, the Misses Therese and Rosamond Murray, to older friends of the family.

The first performance in the Richard Strauss cycle and the debuts of four artists from abroad, Marita Farell, Carl Hartmann, Carlo Tagliabue and Adolf Vogel, will mark the opening week's bills at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday. The season will open on Monday evening, Nov. 29.

Bowery. 320-24: to three 4-story tenements and stores: Henry Lee Corp. 14 Washington Pl, owner; S. Schuman, architect; cost $7,500. Norfolk St, 28; to 5-story light merchandise and stores; Gerturde Stampler. 1,458 E 14th St, Brooklyn, owner; Philip Bardes, architect: cost $8,500.

Miss Clarita Heath, 21-year-old South Pasadena, Calif.; ace, who captivated the skiing world last Winter by her sparkling performances in Europe, started the exodus of American skiers for major foreign tournaments, including the world championships, by departing on the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line yesterday.

The fact that Lamar Hardy, United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, was incorporator, chief counsel and a director of the now defunct State Title and Mortgage Company in 1927 was emphasized yesterday by the defense in the trial of four former executive officers of the company on charges of mail fraud and conspiracy.

Protestant pastors and Catholic priests are no longer allowed to become members of the National Socialist party. Rudolf Hess, deputy leader of the party, has issued the following statement from Munich:

Independent sentiment in favor of helping business to take up the recovery burden rather than attempting other matters of legislation grew in Congress today while President Roosevelt's four-point program for the special session remained in the background and both houses spent the day in fruitless discussion.

During the period when Congress was away from Washington the President took a journey to feel the pulse of the people about things he wanted Congress to do when it returned to the capital. Of this trip the observation was made that Mr. Roosevelt picked territory where he and the government were unusually popular for several reasons-among them the concentration of Federal spending there.

Thirty-nine contests have been arranged for Princeton University's 1937-38 varsity, junior varsity and freshman basketball teams, according to the schedules released today by Asa S. Bushnell, '21, graduate manager of Nassau athletics. The schedules:

Despite a high wind and the fact that the back tees were' employed, par 72 for the championship Pinehurst layout came in for a beating in the final round of the mid-South pro-pro golf tournament today.
The threatened shake-up in the Lehigh team for the Lafayette game here Saturday materialized today when a drastically rearranged line represented the varsity in a scrimmage.

Tau Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity, has elected to membership nine undergraduates at the College of Engineering at New York University, it was announced yesterday Formal initiation will be held at the annual Epsilon dinner at the Hotel Great Northern on Saturday.

William C. Potter, chairman of the board of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, told a Senate committee today he did not believe that charges of fraud against some of the directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad were an obstruction to their continuing in office.

Vice President Garner hurried from the Senate Chamber today when a Senator said he "would make a great President." Senator Connally, continuing a filibuster against the anti-lynching bill, remarked that the South had little chance of electing a President, but that Mr. Garner would make a good one.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange continued in the doldrums yesterday as prices fluctuated irregularly within comparatively narrow limits. There was little incentive for traders to make commitments on either side of the market with the result that prices of the pivotal issues held within a narrow range.
John D. M. Hamilton, chairman of the Republican National Committee, told the Pennsylvania Council of Republican Women here today that the party's first job was "to get rid of Mr. Roosevelt."

Speaking after his twenty-eighth re-election as president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, Daniel Willard said yesterday that the company's property was in prime physical condition, but at the same time he went into some detail to explain the fiscal problems faced by his and other lines.

If the City of New York is to be permitted to use Its wells in eastern Queens the natural water supply of Nassau County will be depleted and contaminated, according to testimony yesterday at a hearing by the State Water Power and Control Commission in the Municipal Building.

The filibuster against consideration of the Anti-Lynching Bill continued to hold the Senate in its grip today, with Senator Connally, who took the floor at 2 o'clock yesterday, completing his "turn" at 3 o'clock this afternoon after characterizing Senator Wagner as "our chief labor agitator" and the bill itself as "a mucilaginous, outrageous, pusillanimous piece of legislation."

Miss Mary L. McGorkey outlined last night the State legislative program of the Association of Hospital and Medical Employes of Greater New York, of which she is president. She addressed 500 persons meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The stock market was strictly "trading affair" yesterday and prices drifted within a narrow range. The volume of 758,900 shares on the Stock Exchange was the smallest for a full day since Oct. 4.

The threat of' a bread shortage in this city was averted last night when Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing 700 striking flour truck drivers and helpers, signed a oneyear contract with the Associated Flour Haulers and Warehousemen. The truckmen will return to work at 8 o'clock this morning.
Some 150 or the city's dogs, augmented by a pet raccoon and a Brazilian marmoset, took their mistresses and a few masters to a cocktail party at Jack Dempsey's restaurant yesterday.

Sales running far in excess of those made at the last year's show were reported yesterday by Charles S. Hynes, manager of the National Hotel Exposition, which opened Monday and will continue through tomorrow.

Eight thousand signatures have been obtained to petitions asking the Legislature to create a State Transit Authority to operate the New York, Westchester Boston Railway, it was reported today by a citizens committee sponsoring the movement.

Reduced net returns for October were reported yesterday by the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and the Southern Pacific Railroads. This result was effective in the case of the Southern Pacific despite an increase in gross. The statements follow:

Rubber Man Johnny Risko bulled his way to a ten-round decision tonight over the former light-heavyweight champion, Bob Olin of New York, to bounce back into the heavyweight fight picture after an absence from the ring of two years.

The stock market here today was unsettled in general, and a number of sections showed declines. Gilt-edge issues were dull, but among the foreign bonds small gains were registered by German and Frenchloans. Transatlantic stocks, reflecting the late rally in Wall Street yesterday, attracted support and the list advanced.
