More than 500 persons attended yesterday morning a funeral service for John David, founder and proprietor of the John David clothing and haberdashery stores, who died Tuesday in Atlantic City. The service was conducted at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street.
Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Brazil, announced today he would marry Miss Gertrude McCarthy of Chicago on Saturday. Miss McCarthy will arrive here tomorrow from the United States.

For generations Britain's coal mines have presented an economic problem which has 'grown increasingly serious in recent years. The industry has long been a sick one. As the richer veins have become exhausted, it has become less and less profitable to exploit the poorer and deeper veins that are left, particularly with antiquated methods.

Only five New York names appear in the individual statistics of the National Football league, released yesterday, and none of the five is near the top. The upper brackets are monopolized by the Green Bay Packers, who hold first place in pass receiving, first and second in passing, third in ground gaining and second and fourth in scoring.
Paintings by the late Professor Boris Schatz and by Bezalel and Zahara Schatz will be shown at the Community House of Central Synagogue, 35 East Sixty-second Street, from tomorrow until Dec. 9.

A controversy over the artistic merits and historic accuracy of thirteen new murals in the postoffice on Westchester Avenue here apparently was closed this afternoon after. the artist, Domenico Mortellito of New York, spoke at a meeting of the Kiwanis Club and explained his work.
Jauy average sales of grocery chain stores for October of this year were about 1 per cent above the dollar volume for October, 1936, the Bureau of Foreign Commerce reported today.
The fourth annual presentation of "Night of Stars," benefit theatrical performance at Madison Square Garden last night, netted from $80,000 to $100,000 for its sponsor, the United Palestine Appeal.

Sir Gerald Campbell, British Consul General at New York, opened officially yesterday afternoon at the Biltmore Ye Olde English Faire, the annual three-day bazaar under the auspices of the Daughters of the British Empire in New York State. Picturesque features,

Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania, Mrs. Earle and members of his staff are sailing this afternoon on the steamship Drottningholm of the Swedish American Line for Gothenburg to attend the ceremonies commemorating the sailing of the first Swedish ships for America, the Kalmar Nyckel and the Fogel Grip, from that port in November, 1637, to found the first Swedish colony in America.

The first regular run of the Nippon Yusen Kaisa's new eastbound globe-circling express service will be started tomorrow when the Arima Maru, second of the five nineteen-knot Diesel-driven ships built by N. Y. K., arrives here on her maiden voyage from Yokohama.

Production of overalls, overall suits and children's overalls and play suits for September totaled 489,963 dozen garments, compared with 503,979 dozen in August, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

Announcing that an Army team of second and third-string players will start against St. John's College Saturday, Coach Gar Davidson continued scrimmage for the first, and second teams today in prepara tion for next week's annual service game.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the articles by W. L. Willkie and Secretary Ickes on the economics and ethics of the Tennessee power development. Mr. Willkie mentioned the fact, well known to all engineers, that flood control and hydroelectric power generation are essentially antagonistic.

An early slight improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange was halted yesterday by hedges from producing sections and liquidation of December contracts prior to notices on Nov. 24. Reports of curtailment of operations by mills and a reduction in domestic consumption operated against outside support.

The poetic muse, an infrequent visitor to Broadway, stops in at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre tonight under the name of "Robin Landing"-or Stanley Preston Young's play in free verse about an Ohio River trading post in the year 1770.

Three former employes of firms in the financial district, who opened their own brokerage business two years ago with $86,829 in securities stolen from a concern in which one of them worked, were sent to Sing Sing yesterday from General Sessions. All had pleaded guilty to the theft of the securities from Winthrop, Mitchell Co., stock brokers at 26 Broadway.
Twenty-one members of the senior class of Manhattan College were inducted into Epsilon Sigma Pi, scholastic honor fraternity, in Smith Auditorium yesterday afternoon
Wheat futures soared the permissible limit of 5 cents a bushel in most North American markets today as the result of severe frosts over a wide area in Argentina.
Columbia High School's eleven remained in the running for the Group 4 State High School championship by scoring a 25-to-0 victory over its neighborhood rival, East Orange High School, today.
The Brooklyn Daily Eagle strike committee of the New York Newspaper Guild announced yesterday that it had received a $25 contribution from Governor Elmer A. Benson of Minnesota for its strike fund.

The Democracia, pro-independence newspaper, acclaims the arrival tomorrow of Rockwell Kent to testify at Ponce at the trial of the eleven Nationalists accused of the murder of a policeman, but Rafael Martinez Nadal, Senate President and statehood leader, said this afternoon that the artist's visit was "just one more insult to the Puerto Rican people."

Jay F. Carlisle, senior member of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Carlisle, Mellick Co., 20 Broadway, who had been a member of the Exchange since March 23, 1893, died yesterday in the New York Hospital after an illness of ten days at the age of 69.
Moses sister Rothschild, one of the founders of the National Conference of Jews and Christians, and for years a leader in the life insurance field, died here lest night at the age of 74.

The engagement of Miss Ruth Agnes Pabst, daughter of Mrs. Louis C. Pabst of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Pabst, to William L. Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Roth of Scarsdale, has been announced by her mother.

Japan would regard as a hostile act by the countries concerned any decision by the Brussels NinePower conference to accede to China's appeal for material aid in the Far Eastern conflict, highly placed Japanese circles said today.
A contract was signed yesterday by Puerto Rico for exhibit space the New York World's Fair, 1939. Puerto Rico thus became the first island possession of the United States to participate in the fair.

HAHN, CHARLES (Nov. 10, 1936). Gross assets, $20,653; net, $9,900. To Elizabeth Dunn, $3,000; sister, Margaret Hahn. residuary estate. Chief assets, real estate, $13,969; stocks and bonds, $1,403?? mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $4,254; miscellaneous property. $1,025. Samuel I. Golieb, attorney, 130 W. 424 St.. IManhattan.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 16 unless specified: Altair, sea to San Pedro. Antares at Guantanamo. Case, at Boston yard. Downes, Balboa to San Diego Nov. 17. Paul Jones, Shanghai to Manila via Amoy and Swatow, Nov 17.

The Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., has received "considerable encouragement" from the Federal Trade Commission in its efforts to have the commission promulgate a fair-trade code with "teeth" for the dress industry, Louis Rubin, executive director of the group, reported last night at a dinner in his honor at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. The dinner was tendered by the organization's board of governors.
Members of the Sesame Club of Montclair, N. J., gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin. Among those present were the president, Mrs. James H. P. Reilly; Mrs. Chester T. Ayres,

The two-day executive meeting of the Joint Legislative Commission for the Investigation of Automobile Insurance ended yesterday afternoon with the announcement that a force of twenty investigators, under the direction of Katrine Collins, would take the field in Albany, Syracuse, Binghamton, Buffalo and Bronx County Nov. 22 to study automobile accidents.

Fifty-three gold medals and three watches won by Wesley M. Oler Jr., former national and intercollegiate high jumping champion and member of the United States Olympic team in 1912, were stolen yesterday from the trophy room of his home at 584 Boston Post Road here, it was reported today in an eight-State alarm sent out by police.

Princeton concluded its arduous preparation for the visit of Navy Saturday as the two varsity elevens, riddled by injuries, climaxed their last contact practice of the year-with seventy-five minutes of live and dummy scrimmage against combination elevens today.

Japan's first role in European politics since she left the League of Nations in 1932 will be recognition of the Franco regime in Spain in return for German and Italian recognition of Manchukuo, according to the newspaper Asahi. When Japan quit the League, nationalist politicians and officials welcomed her liberation from European entanglements.

Four corners were conveyed by the Optimist Realty Corp, Achilles H Kohn, vice press. dent, to Kate Wollman, Waldorf-Astoria Towers, the first mortgage she holds thereon not merging in the fee as follows: n s cor Canal and Ludlow Sts, 43.9x57; s w cor Madison Ave and 116th St, 25.11x 85; n w cor Park Ave and 118th St, 25.11 X90; s w Cor Columbus Ave and 107th St, 50.51/2X100.

Two companies filed registration statements today under the Securities Act of 1933 for securities aggregating $18,700,000, the first large registrations except by investment trusts in about six months.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon, of Convent, N. J., and Southampton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sallie Loraine Mellon, to Darragh A. Park Jr.
The five-story apartment house at 920 Hudson Street, Hoboken, N. J., has been purchased by Joseph Schwartz, operator. Samuel Reznick was the seller.
Waldron, W. H., Inf., 2 months' extension of leave. Baxter, J., Inf., Govenors Island, N. Y., to Ft. Adams, R. I.
The thirteen-story apartment house at the northeast corner of West End Avenue and 103d.Street, known as 884 West End Avenue, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
Stocks closed steady and iregularly lower in slowest trading since Oct. 4; turnover, 758,570 shares. United States Government bonds firm and higher, other issues irregular; transactions, $6,504,000.
Fire destroyed three two-story houses and threatened 300 other dwellings at Saltaire, Fire Island, before it

Laws making fingerprint records of mentally defective persons compulsory and requiring that such records be sent from State institutions for the insane to the police were recommended yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine to the legislative committee investigating sex crimes..

Many Japanese officials foresee that the removal from Nanking of various departments of the Chinese Government to various separate remote plaees may be followed by the breaking down of all centralized authority and administrative chaos. Although they do not disclose their plans these officials declare that Japan is confident that she can deal with any situation that may arise.

A storm of conflicting comments from psychologists, educators and mothers broke yesterday over the "debunking" of mother love by Dr. William Allan Neilson, president of Smith College, in an address Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The election of William C. Potter, chairman of the board of directors of the Guaranty Trust Company, and of Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machine Corporation, as class A and class B directors, respectively, of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York was announced yesterday by-Owen D. Young, deputy chairman of the bank.

Directors of the Bullard Company increased the dividend yesterday with the declaration of $1.25 a share on the common stock. Previously this year the company paid dividends of 25 cents each on March 31, June 30 and Sept. 30.

Walter S. Gifford was re-elected president of the Charity Organization Society yesterday at a council meeting that marked the society's fifty-sixth year of service in this city. Bayard F. Pope was reelected vice president and the following were elected members

The Lima Locomotive Works has begun delivery to the Southern Pacific Company of fourteen streamlined steam locomotives with a maximum speed of 106 miles an hour. This compares with a maximum of 90 miles an hour on the fastest trains now in service on the line between San Francisco and Los Angeles.
There was a strong indication after today's practice that Dean Hanley, 207-pound Penn State left tackle, would be unable to play against Plttsburgh Saturday.

Dr. Howard S. Busler, a nose and throat specialist, died last night at his home in Lansdowne in his forty-ninth year. Death was attributed to a heart- attack. Born in this city, Dr. Busler was graduated in 1911 from Hahnemann Medical College and began specialization in nose and throat work after serving an interneship in Buffalo General Hospital and studying in Vienna and Budapest.

The directors of the Twenty-third Street Association, at a meeting in the Cornish Arms Hotel, voted yesterday in favor of legislation making the deficiency laws permanent and extending the mortgage mora-torium laws to Jan. 1, 1940.

PERHAPS you didn't know that there has been talk of licensing newspaper men--much in the same way that lawyers and doctors are licensed. If a doctor makes the mistake of prescribing poison instead of physic, he is liable to prosecution. If a lawyer behaves unethically or otherwise in violation of the code, he is in danger of disbarment.

Electric power production continued to decline last week, running counter to both seasonal and longterm trends, and the adjusted index has dropped below 100 for the first time in more than eighteen months. The figure now stands at 99.0, compared with 100.8 for the previous week and 104.6 for the week ended Nov. 14, 1936.

For at least one member of Congress the explanation of the present recession of business is really very simple. '"This is a revolution of big money." Powerful financial and industrial interests are deliberately creating a psychology of fear in order to stampede Congress into scuttling the Administration's policies.

A guilty plea to the theft of $19,000 from three of the eightythree men and women investors in, his so-called "group trading account" in the financial district entered in General Sessions yesterday by Harold Russell Ryder, 42 years old, ex-convict and one-time "playboy of Broadway." Judge Nott remanded him to the tombs for sentence Nov. 29.
President Roosevelt still had a slight temperature from an infected tooth today and doctors ordered him to stay in bed. Engagements were canceled for the second successive day.

George Tatarescu, after long negotiations, today formed another government, which was sworn in at 10 o'clock tonight. There are few changes in it from his former Cabinet. Professor Nicolas Iorga's National Democratic party is participating in it, but Alexander Vaida-Voevod's semi-Fascist Rumanian Front has merely concluded an electoral cartel with the government.

Frank Bane, executive director of the Social Security Board, sailed yesterday on the steamship Washington of the United States Lines on his way to Geneva to attend a, conference to be held Dec. 7, 8 and 9 by the International Labor Office. Representatives of twenty nations will attend.

Miss Mary Bennett Opdyke, who successfully underwent an operation for appendicitis at 96 and would have been 100 years old on April 29, died yesterday in the Bucks County farmhouse at Ivyland, where she was born.

Removing hair by electrolysis is not practice of medicine, the Court of Appeals has decided in affirming the judgment of the Appelate Division, First Department, which reversed the Bronx Court of Special Session.

Private dwellings figured in many of the realty transactions reported by Manhattan brokers yesterday. Chandler Chapman rented his house at 159 East Eighty-second Street, furnished, to Mrs. Montgomery Hare. Beatrice L. Renwick, Inc., negotiated the deal.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: Winter wheat is in fair to good condition in the Ohio Valley and is reported well rooted and sturdy in central and southern parts; surface moisture is now generally adequate in Illinois, but the subsoil is dry in some central and northern sections.
Even the case-hardened sinners of Broadway ought to fall deeply in love with "Father Malachy's Miracle," which was put on at the St. James last evening.
The Army plebes concluded a suocessful football season today by defeating Dean Academy, 41 to 0. The cadets scored five touchdowns in the opening half.

The Russian Refugee Children's Welfare Society and a fund founded in memory of Prince George Matchabelli to aid destitute Georgians in the United States were the beneficiaries of a dinner dance and entertainment held last night in. La Maisonette Russe of the St. Regis.

The United States had an unfavorable trade balance with Mexico for the first nine months of this year, according to authoritative figures made available here today. Although sales by the United States to Mexico were the largest on record, purchases here by the United States Treasury of gold and silver, which constitute between 70 and 80 per cent of Mexican exports, made the balance unfavorable to the United States.
Simon Lake, inventor of submarines, received another respite today in his legal fight to save his Milford Colonial home from the auctioneer's hammer.
THE WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENTS, by Leo C. Rosten. (Harcourt, Brace, $3.) A study in modern journalism. JOHN PHOENIX ESQ., by George R. Stewart. (Holt, $2.50.) A biography of George H. Derby.
Belgian Army riders, took first and second places in the military "broad jump"
A strong recovery of the dollar took place yesterday in the foreign exchange market and the principal foreign currencies suffered, losses equal to or greater than their gains of the previous day.

Equipped with the familiar smile, stubby cigar and usual wealth of information about the Dionne quintuplets, Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, in town for a combined business, pleasure and shopping trip,> sat in his suite at the Hotel Chatham yesterday morning and offered a few new facts about the baby belles of Callander, Ont.

Trade relations between the United States and Russia have been improved and the volume of commerce moving in both directions has been increased in the last year, according to David A. Rosoff, chairman of the board of the Amtorg Trading Corporation.

Hughes Ave, 2,112 (11-3081) : Fifth Ave Bank, trustee, to Giuseppe Biagge, 2,121 Belmont Ave, $5,000. Tiebout Ave, 2,2000 (11-3143): Derlaw Estates, Inc, to Sara L. Barg. 485 Central Park W; mtg $200,000. De Kalb Ave, 3, 530 (12-3328B) ; Samray Bulding Co, to Daisy Seplow, 2,167 Cruger Ave. mtgs $147,500.

Captain John David Robnett, retired naval supply officer, died in the Naval Hospital here today at the age of 63. He was on duty at the New York Navy Yard from 1930 to 1935, when he was retired for physical disability resulting from his naval service.
Columbia's line, steadily weakened by injuries in the last four games; in now down to the last straw with not a single experienced reserve left for the tackle, guard and center positions.
In its last encounter of the season the Peddie School midget football team today bowed to Rutgers Prep, 7--0. Both teams lacked scoring

Resuming play in the eighteenth game of the match for the chess championship of the world in the Assembly Hall at the Zoological Gardens this evening, Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, fighting against great odds, finally succeeded in gaining a draw with Dr. Max Euwe, the titleholder.

Federal Judge Carroll C. Hincks signed an order today approving the sale of four side-wheel steamers. The boats, used on the Fall River Line of the New England Steamship Company, will be disposed of for $88,000 to the Union Shipbuilding Company of Baltimore.

SECOND GRADE DETECTIVES--From 18th Division, M. O. D. D. to precincts indicated, designation as second grade detectives revoked: J. G. Kennelly.... 20F. W. Ashley .... 79 PATROLMAN-Emil J. J. Simek. front 75th Precinct to Telegraph Bureau.

Applying the finishing touches to its offense for the last home game of the season against Niagara at Ebbets Field Saturday, the Manhattan football team went through a brisk scrimmage at Innisfail Park yesterday afternoon.

Accompanied only by his man servant, Viscount Halifax, former Viceroy of India, who now sits in the British Cabinet as Lord President of the Council, descended from the Nord express at Friedrichstrasse station this morning for a brief stay in Germany, the implications of which far transcend its ostensible purpose.

Now that Babe Ruth, Bob Edge' and Jack Matthews are back from their big, medium and small game hunt up in Nova Scotia. the guides of that Maritime Province can hitch their chairs nearer the stove and rest until the ice goes out and the salmon begin to run.
The first dance of the season will be held by the Southern reunion dances at the Hotel Gotham tomorrow evening. Others are scheduled for Feb. 4 and April 29.

Turpentins firm, 27 1/4c; sales, 59 barrels; receipts, 295 barrels; shipments, 269 barrels; stock, 37,783 barrels. Resin firm; sales 398; receipts, 1,398; shipments: 526; stock, 83,303. Quote: B, D, E, $5.60; F, to K, $5.821/2; M, $5.85; N, ;5.90; WG, $6.45; WW, X, $6.70.

Production of steel has dropped to the lowest level since 1934, excepting one week of July, 1935, The Iron Age reports in its weekly summary. The current rate is placed at 35 per cent of the country's capacity.

A verdict of $132,229 was returned in favor of former Ambassador Walter E. Edge today in the County Circuit Court in the second trial of his suit against the Boardwalk Securities Corporation, now in receivership.

A report recommending adoption of a revised plan for removal of grade crossings and the general improvement of adjacent areas along Atlantic Avenue, between the East New York and Jamaica stations of the Long Island Railroad, at an estimated cost of $23,967,000 will be submitted to the Board of Estimate tomorrow by the special committee headed by Controller Frank J. Taylor.

Baldwin Terry of the Yale Club, seeded third in the tournament, bowed yesterday in the third round of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association tourney at the New York A. C. Ralph Sleicher of Midston House eliminated him by 15-6, 15-8, 15-7.

The Federal Trade Commission today, to conform to provisions of the Miller-Tydings Price Maintenrance Act, modified a cease and desist order against P. H. Hanes Knitting Company of Winston-Salem, N. C., issued Dec. 21, 1925.

Pelham St. George Bissell, president justice of the Municipal Court, announced yesterday that the board of justices of the court in Manhattan had adopted a resolution recommending to the Appellate Division, Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate the construction of a court house in the civic center to house the Municipal Court.

While Viscount Halifax began his mission today The Yorkshire Post-generally regarded as the mouthpiece of Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretarywarned Britain editorially to beware of Germany's real ambitions in Central and Eastern Europe.

The Pontaic division of the General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that retail sales of its automobiles in the first ten days of November were larger than a year ago. The Buick division made a similar report.

Conservatism overcame modernism in art today and carried off the two major awards-one of them the Frank G. Logan prize-in the annual exhibition of American paintings and sculpture at the Chicago Art Insttute.

The engagement of Miss Christine Blair Long, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Breckenridge Long of Laurel, Md., to Arnold Auger Willcox, son of Mrs. Charles Willcox and the late Colonel Willcox of Washington, has been announced here.

Announcement by Great Britain and the United States that they contemplate negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement is expected momentarily as a result of a visit by Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, to the State Department late today. He went there for a conference with Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State in charge of the trade-agreements program.

DeWitt Pl, 2,940 (16-4565); Teresa Vilast to Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association, 441 Lexington Ave; installments, 5 per cent; $10,400. Fieldston Rd. 5,433 (13-3421C): Edwin A. Kane to Bowery Savings Bank, extends mtg to Sept. 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $10,500.

The four-story store and apartment building at the southwest corner of Main Street and Mamaroneok , White Plains, Westchester County, has been leased to the Malroy Realty Corporation, Julius A. Rosenthal, president.

The films to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, which have been approved as suitable for the young by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents and teachers in local private and public elementary and high schools, are as follows:
King George and Queen Elizabeth summoned a dance orchestra to the prim precincts of Buckingham Palace tonight for the first time in their reign to entertain King Leopold of Belgium at a state ball.

Enactment of legislation to make labor unions "amenable to the laws which govern business generally," and for municipal, State or Federal supervision of all union funds and disbursements, were recommended yesterday in a presentment handed up by the Kings County additional grand jury, known as the "rackets" grand jury.

Senator Borah of Idaho introduced today in the Senate a resolution to put Congress on record against any attempt to influence the Interstate Commerce Commission in its decision on the railroads' application' for increased freight rates.
The Composers' Forum-Laboratory gave the fourth program of its third series at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. The composers represented were Mary Howe and Christos Vrionides.

The Jewish War Veterans of the United States announced yesterday that they were sponsoring a movement to have American manufacturers conspicuously mark all products manufactured here "Made' in U. S. A." The organization intends to approach chambers of commerce and large industrialists to obtain their cooperation in the movement.

With the resourceful "Stalky" and the learned "McTurk" of Stalky Co. fame present in the flesh to do honor to their illustrious school-fellow, "Beetle," the campaign to raise funds for the memorial to Rudyard Kipling was launched tonight with initial contributions totaling [Pound]45,000.

More than 300 motor club executives from all parts of the country will gather at the Hotel Pennsylvania, Seventh Avenue and Thirtythird Street, tomorrow and Saturday for the thirty-fifth annual convention of the American Automobile Association.

Elmer Rand Jacobs, executive vice president, controller and a trustee of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, 74 Wall Street, died yesterday in the New York Hospital. Mr. Jacobs, who had been with the bank for many years, made a hobby of collecting children's savings banks, some of his finds dating from the early Sixties of the last century.

Loans for the building of aircraft for the foreign trade up to 75 per cent of the cost of these machines, and a system putting transoceanic flying under the supervision of the Maritime Commission, were among the recommendations in a report on aviation sent to Congress today by Chairman Joseph P. Kennedy of the commission.
Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie and the Misses Eileen and Phyllis Gillespie have come to the Pierre from Newport. Mrs. Margaret Emerson has left the Waldorf-Astoria for her villa in Palm Beach.
Canvass of the vote cast for members of the new City Council was accelerated yesterday in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, but in the Bronx it came to a complete halt.

The House Labor Committee decided by, a vote of 19 to 2 today to press its; fight to force the Wages and Hours Bill out of the Rules Committee's pigeonholes, where it has reposed since August, and obtained 105 of the needed 218 signatures on the discharge petition before the House adjourned.

the New York Rangers of the National League defeated the Cleveland Barons of the International-American League, 4 to 3, tonight in an exhibition game which opened a new million-dollar arena to hockey.
Seven investors on last April 1 controlled 86.315 per cent of the common stock of the A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, according to a report by the company to the Securities

The governing board of the Foreign Correspondents Association has submitted a resolution to the German Government protesting the expulsion of Paul Ravoux, chief correspondent here of the Havas News Agency, for "having the cheek" to connect the epizootic of hoof-and-mouth disease with the Four-Year Plan. The resolution says:

Helen Morgan, the actress, suffered a contusion of the left elbow yesterday shortly after 3 A. M. when an automobile in which she was a passenger was in collision with another automobile at Flatbush Avenue and Plaza Street, Brooklyn.

The United States Conference of Mayors notified the country by resolution today that Congress must provide more Federal relief funds to meet the rising tide of unemployment. The resolution also called for an additional WPA appropriation to keep people at work and thereby maintain buying power.

Current efforts under consideration to stimulate residential construction next year, if successful, will also generate a considerable volume of advertising, which this year has been disappointing, advertising' agency executives remarked yesterday.

Nansemond, the Howard Bruce brown filly that was third in both the Selima Stakes and the Maryland Futurity, captured the Crescentia Purse for juveniles foaled in Maryland, the main event today at Bowie.

Seizing the opportunity to shorten the gap between himself and, the titleholder, Jake Schaefer, Chicago challenger for the world 18.1 balkline championship came through with a grand exhibition of stroke; ing to defeat Willie Hoppe of New York in the sixth block of their 3,000-point match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy last night.

Whether munitions and arms seized by French police in and around Paris in connection with the clean-up of alleged Cagoulards [Hooded Men] were part and parcel of a vast gun-running scheme for Spain or really constitute evidence of a plot against the security of the State is a problem today facing investigators into the activities of this secret society.

Carl Chader, chief pilot of O. J. Whitney, Inc., of Floyd Bennett Field, reported last night that last Friday he flew to Philadelphia and back on one engine of a twin-engined Beechcraft plane to demonstrate the "extraordinary performance" of the new machine.
Hartley Joys, '39, of Milwaukee was --elected captain of the Amherst College football team for the 1938 season today at a meeting of the lettermen.

Germany has agreed to close five consulates in the Soviet Union by Jan. 15, 1938, as 'the result of diplomatic negotiations," it was officially announced today. German consulates at Leningrad, Tiflis, Kharkov, Vladivostok and Odessa will be closed.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, am reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 24,000, including 9,500 directs. The market was around 10c lower than Tuesday's average; top $8.60; bulk good and choice 150-250 pounds, $8.45-55; 260320 pounds in limited supply and mostly _8.30-45: most good packing sows, $7.75-$8;
Rosalyn Tureck gave the second of her formidable series of six piano recitals--one a week--devoted to the music of Johann Sebastian Bach at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
Army defeated the M. I. T. soccer eleven, 7 to 0, today. The Cadets rolled up 3 points in the first half and, after being held scoreless in the third period, shot four goals in the final quarter.
Harry Ducker, oldest trustee of the Greenpoint Savings Bank, Brooklyn, died in his home, 85-31 Ninetieth Street, Woodhaven, Tuesday evening after a short illness. He was 90 years old.

ADAMSKY--Henry, husband of Eva, father of Leonard, Anna and Corinne; brother of Max, Murray and Stella. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., today, at 2 P. M. ATTANASIO-Bessie (nee Schwartz), beloved wife of Antonio and sister of Kate Judge, Leah Pennamacoor, Rebecca Berger, and Joseph R. Schwartz,. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., Friday, Nov. 19, 1 P. M.

Courtmartial verdicts were handed down by the Navy Department today against Captain Howard B. Mecleary and Lieut. Commander Edward R. Winckler, commanding officer and navigator, respectively, of the cruiser Omaha, which went aground off Castle Island Light in the Bahamas on July 18.

Tampa Electric Company rights, which allow common stockholders to subscribe at $20 a share for additional shares in the ratio of one for each eighteen shares held, have been admitted to "when issued" dealings on the New York Curb Exchange. They expire on Dec. 20. The final date for Curb dealings will be Dec. 17.

Infant consumers of milk, their elder sisters and brothers, and their mothers, a thousnd strong, plan to march and ride to City Hall next Saturday morning to protest against the high cost of milk. The demonstration was decided upon and enthusiastically endorsed last night by nearly 1,200 members of the League of Mothers Clubs of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York, at their sixth annual dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

American Character Doll Company, 200 Fifth Avenue, New York City, was ordered today by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from certain misleading representations in the sale of its products.

George E. Acret resigned today as Acting Director of the Division of Trial Examiners of the National Bituminous Coal Commission, and in his letter charged that Senators Guffey and McAdoo were "chiefly responsible for the almost complete breakdown of the commission."
In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: Original-Ex parte Robert Gray Taylor. et al., petra. Motion for leave to file brief submitted.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, directed by Serge Koussevitzky, will make its first New York appearance of the season at Carnegie Hall tonight. Walter Gieseking, pianist, and Anna Turkel, soprano, will open the season of Artistic Production concerts this afternoon at the Hotel Ambassador.

The Rosenwald Fund of Chicago has voted to Fisk University, a liberal arts college for Negroes in Nashville, Tenn., securities with a current valuation of about $500,000, it was announced yesterday by Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of trustees of the university.
The booths of the 110 publishers exhibiting their latest wares at the Book Fair are changing rapidly, in time with the change of publishing season.
Forty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers will open at the Waldorf-Astoria this morning at 9:30 and continue tomorrow.

There was another deolded uplft In the Harvard football oamp today when Coach Dick Harlow used Bobby Green at left end throughout the dummy scrimmage defensive drill, and also held him in his aocustomed position during the entire signal session in the baseball cage.

Far from his native Kentuoky hills, the Rev. John William Dawson, tall, gaunt preacher of the Dry Fork Primitive Baptist Church of Morehead, Ky., stood in a Greenwich Village apartment last night and, to the tune of an ancient Gregorian chant, sang these words of a traditional mountain hymn:

Defending Coach Fritz Crisler against criticism because his Tiger football team has lost every major game this year, The Daily Princetonian, Princeton University undergraduate newspaper, published today an editorial assailing a "noisy minority" of graduates and sports writers.

A revelation that Japan had threatened France with reprisals, including the occupation of Hainan Island off French Indo-China, if the slightest aid were sent to China, was made in Paris yesterday by Henry Berenger, chairman of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee.

A card party and tea, for the benefit of the Peabody Home at 1,000 Pelham Parkway will take place this afternoon at the home of Mrs. George C. Arvedson, 116 East Sixtyeighth Street. Guests have been requested to bring gifts and packages of rummage suitable for a holiday sale to be held in the near future in behalf of the same organization.
A chill, gray and damp afternoon that brought vivid memories of last Saturday's mud battle in the Bowl saw the Yale varsity football squad go through itx last hard practice of the year today.
President Roosevelt again canceled all appointments and remained in seclusion because of an infected tooth. The Senate heard continued speaking against the Anti-Lynching Bill; heard Senator Bailey
A new personnel policy for the State Department of Labor, worked out after conferences with employee organizations, was promulgated yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews.

So much of Paragraph 2, Special Orders 250, Oct. 27, 937, ordering Major Louis Lippman. AG-Res.. to active duty in the office of the Corps Area Adjutant General, effective Nov. 7 and relieving him effective Nov. 20, is amended so as to order Major Lippman to active duty, effective Nov. 8 and relieving him effective Nov. 21.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo obtained yesterday the award of an issue of $6,000,000 of Boston temporary loan notes on a 1.64 per cent interest basis plus a premium of $33. The notes, dated Nov. 19,

Edwin Whittier Smith, nationally known attorney and business leader, died today in his suburban home at De Mount Washington. His age was 80. The senior partner in the Pittsburgh legal firm of Reed, Smith, Shaw McClay, Mr. Smith was graduated from Yale in 1878, being in President Taft's class.

Former President Herbert C. Hoover sat at a speakers' table last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and discussed the work of the Madison Square Boys Club with a Democrat who, too, would like to be President.

Contracts for business space reported yesterday showed a good demand for retail shopping locations in scattered sections of Manhattan. Wearing apparel, jewelry, antiques and hardware were among the lines represented in the renting activity.
Directors of the G. R. Kinney Company, Inc., have extended the time limit for the exchange of securities under its recapitalization plan to Dec. 15.

Federal investigators expressed belief today that the United Air Lines plane crash which killed nineteen persons in the Utah mountains on Oct. 17 could have been avoided had the pilot sought either a higher altitude or an alternate landing field.
The Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class A interclub tournament schedule continued yesterday, with the Junior League defeating the Cosmopolitan Club, 4-1.

The authors' program at the Book Fair in Rockefeller Center, Fiftieth Street and Fifth Avenue, will include the following speakers at 2;30 P. M.: Emily Post, novelist, whose publishers insisted on a book of etiquette with such response that she devoted herself thereafter to the subject;
Price movements of commodity futures were mixed in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Rubber and silk futures closed higher, but coffee, cocoa and hide contracts declined.

Trading improved on pork at lower Prices. Lamb sold steady to slightly below Tuesday's early quotation. Steer beef continued very weak, veal and calf were about steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated most classes to be about in line with Tuesday's close as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture

The engagement of Miss Jean Powrie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Powrie of Copenhagen, Denmark, formerly of Waukesha, Wis., to Dr. David Tolmie of Tuxedo Park has been announced here by her parents.

Oswald W. Knauth, general campaign chairman of the $350,000 City-WideChristmas Seal Appeal of 1937, announced yesterday the appointment of Bernard P. Day, vice president of Joseph P. Day, Inc., real estate company, as chairman of the special gifts committee.

The Chinese apparently are making at least a temporarily successful stand against Japan's westward advance. General Chang Fahkwei, commander of the Chinese forces west of Shanghai, launched a counter-offensive near Kashing to hold off two Japanese columns.

A partial eclipse of the moon began at 2:37 o'clock this morning and was visible bewteen intermittent rifts in a cloudy sky as a dent in the side of an almost full moon. The eclipse, caused when the moon touched the center, or umbra,
A mortgage for $225,000 on the 12-story loft building at 34-36 W 32d St, owned by the Rosedear Realty Corp, Joseph Durst. president, was extended by the Central Savings Bank to April 1, 1940.

James Joseph Monahan, former chief clerk of the Fourth District Municipal Court in Brooklyn and t long prominent in Democratic politics, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home, 449 Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn.

Establishment of all-day schools for adults, to be open from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M., and to serve as community centers for adult activities, was recommended yesterday by Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools,

Coach Andy Kerr today groomed two Colgate elevens for the game at Syracuse Saturday, believing' that manpower may decide the contest. He used one as much as the other in a scrimmage against the reserves.

William G. Gallagher, who was a familiar figure in the New York Curb Exchange for fifty years, died at his home here this morning, after a four-month illness of heart disease. His age was 64. Entering the financial district as a boy, Mr. Gallagher eventually became a specialist and an authority on mining stocks.

The slowing down of residential building was discussed from various angles at the conference on Local Residential Construction, which began a two-day session in the auditorium of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today.

Mayor La Guardia's board of survey on the transfer of relief administration from the Emergency Relief Bureau to the permanent Department of Public Welfare has been gathering the viewpoints of a wide variety of organizations interested in relief, it became known yesterday after two invited representatives of the Workers Alliance had urged the board to seek a'reduction of the authority of the State Board of Social Welfare over relief affairs in this city.

Harold B. Wess has been elected an executive vice president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., in charge of Division 5, a coordinative division, according to announcement made yesterday by the board of directors of the store.

A thousand members of the. Association of Manufacturers Representatives and guests from all sec-' tions of the grocery trade in the Eastern district, attending the thirtieth dinner of the association at the- Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night, heard Governor Harold G. Hoffman of .New Jersey urge greater faith in the country's future and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. of New York praise the metropolitan area as the world's greatest market.

Expansion of the work of Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney-elect, was indicated yesterday when the Sinking Fund Commission assigned the entire eighth floor of the old Health Department Building at 139 Centre Street for his use.

A revelation that the Federal Government considers only 800 of the 3,100 local jails it has inspected safe for confinement of its prisoners, was made by Attorney General Cummings today as he denounced as "deplorable" the escape of the O'Connell Kidnappers from the Onondaga County Penitentiary at Jamesville, N. Y.

Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum heard argument yesterday on a motion made by Alfred T. Davison, counsel for the Third Avenue Railway Company, for dismissal of a petition for reorganization filed last month by minority security holders.

Notice Deputy Chiefs and Battalion Chiefs. when selecting members as permanent Chiefs Aides, shall immediately make written application to have such members detailed to them. When such members are assigned to companies other than those designated to provide for Chiefs' Aides in Supplement to Special Order 29, Feb. 17, 1937, application shall be made to have such members transferred to the companies designated in the above-mentioned, supplement.

Dr. D. C. Mebane, physician and a former druggist and member of the Wilkes-Barre City Council, died last night at Evanston, Ill., where he had lived for the last fifteen years. He was 81. Dr. Mebane was educated at Davidson College, North Carolina, where he was a classmate of Woodrow Wilson, and at the Medical School of New York University.

Theodore Witte, who had practiced law for the last fifty-four years in Greater New York and on Long Island, was found dead in bed this morning at his home here. He was 79 years old. According to Coroner Grover A. Silliman, Mr. Witte died of a heart attack about 1 A. M. He had been staying alone overnight in the house and was found by a neighbor, who called to take him to the train.

SOMETIMES it's hard to make a Little talk. Columbia Lou was sitting in his office in John Jay Hall. It was an overcast day with probable showers and he was looking gloomily to the north. That's where Dartmouth will be-coming from.

Tom Hood and some other English poets had a conventional prejudice against November. Philosophers acknowledge that in the matter of weather all months are more or less like the little girl that had a little curl. This year our American November has had its usual bland relapses into Spring and almost Summer.
Organized labor was urged to support the New York Red Cross Chapter's roll-cll by George Meany, president of the State Federation of Labor, in a message broadcast yesterday from radio station WQXR.

A net profit of $2,064,035 .for the first nine months of this year was reported yesterday by RaybestosManhattan, Inc., after deductions for depreciation, Federal. income taxes and other charges, including $150,000 -reserve for contingencies for surtax on undistributed earnings. This is equivalent to $3.25 a share on the 635,200 shares of no-par capital stock.
The Fordham football squad worked on offense for almost three hours yesterday. Dusk had fallen on. Fordham Field when the unbeaten Rams finally raced to the showers.

Samuel I. Horowitz, manager and a member of the board of directors of Horowitz Brothers Margareten, 369 East Fourth Street, one of the largest matzoth bakeries in the city, died yesterday at his home, 373 East Fourth Street, of pneumonia, at the age of 66.

Two hundred arid fifty leaders of the Middle Atlantic States conference of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee will convene at Philadelphia next Sunday to discuss American aid to oppressed and impoverished Jewish population overseas.

Preliminary estimates furnished by the Bureau of Census put the population of the United States on July 1, 1937, at 129,257,000. The estimate represented an increase of 828,000, or six-tenths of 1 per cent, over the 1936 estimate.

The Thanksgiving turkey dinner it the home of Mrs. Mary Stewart will be served a week early. bird bought for the feast escaped. from the Stewart basement today and flew to a treetop roost from :which it was shot down by an )bliging policeman. "We'll eat it tomorrow, " Mrs. Stewart told officer.

The autograph manuscript of one of Henry James's novels, "Confidence," totaling about 70,000 words, was bought by Charles Scribner's Sons for $825 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galseries, Inc., at the auction of the library of the late Parke E. Simmons of Evanston, Ill.

The address prepared by President Roosevelt for delivery at the meeting of the presidents of the land grant colleges and universities and delivered by Secretary Wallace in the absence of the President was as follows:

As the increasing tempo of major events in the undeclared Sino-Japanese war now foreshadows an approaching crisis, any one of three momentous developments appears possible: a conqueror's peace, the culmination of the Japanese advance up the Yangtze toward Nanking and southward toward Tsinan, capital of the rich province of Shantung;

The 734 young women attending the College of New Rochelle will forego the use of silk stockings in future in protest of the Japanese invasion of China, it was announced today by spokesmen for the students.

After hearing a terrific onslaught on the Air Ministry and Imperial Airways, Ltd., in the House of Commons, the government tonight ordered a departmental inquiry into a series of charges concerning the operation of British civilian airlines with which W. R. D. Perkins, tall and aggressive Conservative backbencher, earlier in the afternoon had alternately angered and astonished the members.
The third sit-down strike in Michigan plants of the General Motors Corporation in three days began here tonight, a few hours after the second one, at Detroit, had ended.
Poland is prepared to act in Danzig only in defense of her interests and rights, according to the Foreign Office's official agency, Polish Political Information, in a statement today.

Christmas retail trade in New York City is expected to approximate last year's volume and will reach a figure a few points above or a few points below the volume of 1936, Secretary Roper said today after surveying reports from field agents throughout the country.
War Admiral, undefeated champion of the 3-year-olds, was entered today as a candidate for the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap March 5.
The total value of the estate of Irving G. Thalberg, youthful motion-picture producer and husband of Norma Shearer, was set at $4,469,013 in an inventory filed in Probate Court today.

Laws of other States are being studied with the idea of making recommendations to the Legislature in Albany to expand the list of legal investments for savings banks and trustees, William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks, said tonight at a meeting of the Erie-Niagara Counties Bankers Association here.

Changes in the capital gains tax designed to accelerate profit taking transactions and aimed especially at relieving the large investor from unduly heavy exactions were agreed upon today by the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Taxation.

The Broadway Association, ever anxious to keep Broadway a center of attraction, has cooperated in the last few weeks with city departments in a movement to rid the street of various kinds of nuisances. Through the cooperation of Commissioner of Sanitation Carey, more than 100 summonses were issued for violations of the sanitary code.

Comte Rene Buet-Willaumez, in 336 E 57th St; Walter Samuels, Inc, broker. Erastus M. Cravath, in 36 E 72d St; John E. G. Tull, through William A. White Sons, in 115 E 90th St; William W. Rocke, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, in 40 W 55th St; Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, broker.
The Montclair A. C. and the Columbia University Club remained in a tie for the lead in the metropolitan interclub Class A squash tennis race as a result of victories last night.
Three men were arrested early yesterday morning by detectives who had answered a radio alarm following the hold-up of a Whelan Drug Store, 660 Eighth Avenue, at Forty-second Street.

A demand that the Legislature impeach Supreme Court Justices John H. McCooey Jr. and Lewis L. Fawcett of Brooklyn was expressed yesterday at a meeting of a citizens' committee on labor injunctions in the Russell Sage Foundation. The two justices were accused of violations of anti-injunction laws.

Making their first appearance of the season, the Long Island University and Union Temple quintets played an exhibition rules demonstration game on the Temple court in Brooklyn last night, with L. I. U. emerging on top, 45-25.

Emile Allais of France, the world skiing champion, proposes radical changes in skiing technique and teaching in his book "Le Ski Franrgais," the first copies of which were printed today in Bellegarde, France, near the Geneva frontier.

The outlook for 1938 is considered favorable by a majority of individual industries, building and- construction and-trade and service aslociatlons who replied to a survey completed today by the New England Council.

Elmer Roberts, war correspondent and long chief of The Associated Press Berlin and Paris bureaus, died today at his home here after several years of ill health. He was 74 years old. Mr. Roberts was forty years In active newspaper work and thirtytwo in the service of The Associated Press. Nearly all of this time was spent abroad.
Gloria Swanson's return to the screen has become a definite part of Columbia's program. The studio today assigned "Vacation Bound" to Sidney Buchman for production preparation.

A river of "bathtub" gin, needled beer and wood alcohol found its way into the salty Lower Bay yesterday as the police department began a methodical task of shattering bottles containing $30,000 worth of illicit liquor against the brick walls of the property clerk's garage at the foot of Thirty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

John C. Allen, one of the last two Civil War veterans here, died in his sleep at the home of his daughter, Mrs. John H. Gregg, at noon today. He was 95. Mr. Allen was the last member of Joe Hooker Post, Grand Army of the Republic.

The necessity for some regulation of commissions of insurance brQkers and agents was stressed yesterday to an audience of approximately 100 insurance salesmen and representatives of companies ir the State Building by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, and Assemblyman H. Foster Piper, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee for Revision of the Insurance Laws.
Marshall College's undefeated football team has been asked if it would accept a bid to a new postseason bowl contest-a Tobacco Bowl game to be staged at Louisville, Dec. 4.

The guaranteed stake,' an heirloom from the old days in which the horsemen raced for their own money, was abolished in New York State as the result of a resolution adopted by the State Racing Commission at its meeting yesterday.

Picketing of Jewish-owned shops was reported today to have begun in many provincial towns immediately after non-Jewish merchants at a conference voted a resolution to "Polonize" trade and boycott Jewish traders. In Gdynia many Jewish shopkeepers were beaten and Jews were attacked in the streets, five being injured.
Hopeful of scoring a long-sought victory over the New York Aggies at' Erasmus Field Saturday the Brooklyn College football squad yesterday stressed passing, kicking and the timing of new formations.

Miss Catherine de Bernard de la Fosse, daughter of Mrs. Dorothy Ryle of this city and of Count de Bernard de la Fosse of Paris, was married here yesterday at noon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest to Rowland H. G. Leigh, son of the Hon. and Mrs. Rowland Leigh of London.

To press action against monopolistic practices, Attorney General Cummings has asked the Budget Bureau for $1,000,000, in addition to the $472,000 available, for anti-trust prosecutions, he disclosed today.

The right of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. 0. affiliate, to speak for employes on the city's Independent Subway was challenged yesterday by an American Federation of Labor affiliate, the American Federation of Municipal Transit Workers, Local 21193, in a letter to the Rev. John P. Boland, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board.

William Randolph Hearst's collection of old English silver, which once adorned his castle in Wales, was sold for a fraction of the original cost at an auction at Sotheby's today. The eighty-three items brought [Pound]22,000. Only thirty-two of them had cost the publisher [Pound]25,000.
Intensive work on new formations was the order of the day yesterday for the New York University football squad in preparing to meet Fordham on Nov. 27 at the Yankee Stadium.

The directors of the Alleghany Corporation, meeting in Cleveland today, are expected to consider a proposal to ask its bondholders for authority to use funds now impounded as collateral behind the bonds for the purchase of the bonds from the floating supply.

The Norwegian Socialist newspaper Arbeiderbladet says tonight that it has reason to believe the Nobel Peace Prize for 1937, which probably will be announced tomorrow, will be awarded to the Nansen refugee office in Geneva.
The first performance of Daniel Gregory Mason's "Lincoln Symphony" was given last night in Carnegie Hall by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, John Barbirolli conductor.

Blakely, C. A., commander of Carrier Dlvision 2, to duty as commander of Aircraft Scouting Force and to additional duty as commander of Patrol Wing 1. Train, C. R., Navy Dept. Washington, D. C., to commander of battleship Division 2, Battle Force, about Jan. 15,

Stocks day of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on Nov. 6 amounted to 307,224,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported today. Compared with a week before, this volume represents a net increase of 84,000 barrels, comprising a decrease of 280,000 barrels in stocks of domestic crude and an increase of 364,000 barrels in foreign crude.

Members of the National Liberal Club last night heard William Ewart Gladstone making a speech in 1889. It was reproduced from one of the earliest Edison-Bell phonograph records made in London and was lent by the British Broadcasting Corporation for the Gladstone memorial dinner.

England put a stop to Wales's run of international soccer successes today with a 2-1 victory before 35,000. Decisions had gone to the Welshmen in their last four games of the quadrangular competition, but they were definitely inferior to England, which now needs only a point to clinch the championship.
The expected debate on President Roosevelt's refusal to declare a state of war existing in China, thus bringing the automatic features of the Neutrality Act into force, broke out in the House today.

Speaking at a luncheon of the Municipal Bond Club of New York yesterday at the Bankers Club, M. S. Szymczak, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, hinted that no further monetary measures are contemplated to combat the current recession in business.
The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after interest, depreciation, amortization,

Food as a medium for painting and "sculpture" reached its, highest attainment of the year yesterday when chefs of the leading hotels and night clubs displayed their pieces de resistance at the sixtyninth annual Salon of Culinary Art,

Finely woven hats of corn-husk from Tennessee, delicately carved figures in anthracite from Pennsylvania and soil-tone braided rugs of burlap bag strippings are some of the pieces on display here until Nov. 30

It is not easy to define in legal terms the point at which picketing ceases to be legitimate, but it is pretty easy for the innocent bystander to tell when that point has been reached and passed. Under Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Valentine the pickets in New York City have been given the benefit of the doubt.
The Commerce Department ordered today the confiscation of a $1,500,000 cargo of whale oil if landed in this country by the Norwegian whaler, the Charles Racine.

There can be little hope for an early end to. the present downward swing of the business curve as long as "Washington holds to its present attitude toward business," members of the National Founders Association were told yesterday by Franklin R. Hoadley, president of the association.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bertles of Glen Cove, L. I., and Tuckerstown, Bermuda, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Elizabeth Bertles, to Harold Alexander Ley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Ley of Bronxville and Melvin Village, N. H.

The Western Pacific Railroad proposes to finance a repair program through the sale of certificates issued by the trustee in bankruptcy, according .to plans announced yesterday. Previously; the company had arranged with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to borrow up to $10,000,000 this purpose.
Captain Fritz Wiedemann, Chancellor Adolf Hitler's personal adjutant and recently his almost constant companion, left Berlin tonight with his wife to sail for the United States aboard the Europa.
Twenty-eight contests have been arranged for the Brown varsity and freshman basketball teams, according to the schedules announced by Dr. Frederick W. Marvel, director of athletics, today.

Cardinal Hayes will spend his seventieth birthday tomorrow very quietly at his Summer home, St. Joseph's, Sullivan County, N. Y. The Cardinal will motor there today, accompanied by his private secretary, Mgr. John J. Casey, and will remain several days.

Fifth Metropolitan Conference on Employment and Guidance under the auspices of the Section on Employment and Vocational Guidance, Welfare Council of New York City, begins at the Hotel Pennsylvania this morning at 10 o'clock and continues tomorrow.

Mrs. Henry De Witt Smith gave a tea at her home here this afternoon to introduce her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Smith. The debutante is a graduate of Hartridge School here and the Masters School, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., and is a provisional member of the Plainfield Junior League.

Formal announcement was made today that Great Britain and the United States had agreed to negotiate an unconditional most-favored nation reciprocal trade agreement covering the United Kingdom and this country.
Appropriately for a coronation year, King George today chose a Christmas card bearing a picture of the coronation review of the fleet at Spithead, painted by Frank Wood, for his personal use.

Viscount Halifax, British-Lord President of the Council, escorted by Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, took a train from Berlin for Munich tonight for the interview with Chancellor Hitler at Berchtesgaden tomorrow that is the real purpose of his visit.

The Touchdown Club's annual dinner will be held at the Hotel McAlpin on Dec. 9, it was announced at the organization's weekly luncheon yesterday at the Haryard Club. Dean Hill, president of the club, presided at the session, attended by seventy-five members, who were gridiron varsity lettermen during their college days.

Mrs. Betty Lyon, 29 years old, of Long Island City, Queens, was acquitted by a jury in Suffolk County Court here today of a charge of extortion. The trial was before County Judge Richard W. Hawking Arthur Tedman of Center Moriches, 71, a retired, tugboat engineer, was the complainant. He said between Spring, 1934, up to last March, he gave her in presents and cash about $15,000.

Peter Kemp, assistant controller of the Chase National Bank, died of a heart ailment at his home, 1,870 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, on Wednesday. He was 52 years old and had been ill for several months.

Mrs. Mary Kirk Raffray was married today to Captain Ernest A. Simpson, former husband of the Duchess of Windsor, in the ballroom of the Brooklawn Country Club in the presence of a small group of relatives and friends.

" Barchester Towers," by Thomas Job, based on the Anthony Trollope novel and starring Ina Claire, was presented here tonight for the first time by Guthrie McClintic. It is a satiric treatment of the Church of England and its representatives in a cathedral town in England in 1850.

In England the facetious judge is a familiar figure. He makes his jokes in court. Be they good or bad, the barristers present are expected to laugh dutifully. Some have attributed their jocose obiter dicta to the stimulating and irritating effect of the ceremonial wig on the intellectuals of its wearer. Lord Chief Justice Hewart

Yale's football players today said farewell to home gridirons for the season at practice in which offensive and defensive tactics were reviewed under the direction of Coaches Pond, Neale, Wells, Williamson. Ford and Renner.

MANHATTAN BATES, FRANK D. (Sept. 17). Estate, $2,700. To Viola C. Bates, widow, executrix, Hotel Dauphin, 126 W. 67th St. BETTELHEIM, SPENCER D. (Nov. 5), Estate, more than $10,000. To Edwin S. Bettelhelm, father, Lincoln Hotel, $5,000; Edwin S. Bettelhelm, brother, 170 I St. N. W., Washington, D. C., $2,000; Dorothy B. Healy, 6 Taylor Pl., Westport, Conn., and Gladys B. De Treil, 3,931 Prytania St., New Orleans, La.,

In the truck-farming counties of Gloucester, Salem and Camden, N. J., in the year 1935-36, half of the 861 families interviewed by the Bureau of Home Economics of the Agriculture Department had incomes of more than $1,370 in cash and "in kind," while the other half had less, according to a survey issued today.
The Good Shepherd Presbyterian Church, 152 West Sixty-sixth Street, opened its fiftieth anniversary celebration last night with a dinner in the church hall at which two former pastors spoke.
Unconditional independence of the Philippine Islands has been written off the records of the United States as "finished business," a survey of legislative and executive circles indicated today.

A contract was signed yesterday by RCA Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of Radio Corporation of America, and the Independent Employes Association RCAC, covering wages, hours and other conditions of employment for about 350 "nonlive-traffic" employes in Continental United States and Hawaii.

A plea for a "spiritual alliance" between the United States and the British Commonwealth of Nations, leading to a union of Christendom and finally to world unity, was made last night by Sir Evelyn Wrench, founder of the English Speaking Union of the British Empire, at a dinner in the Hotel Plaza ending the sixteenth annual meeting of the English Speaking Union.

Turpentine firm, 27c; sales, 26 barrels; receipts, 365 barrels; no shipments; stock, 38,148 barResin firm; sales, 421; receipts, 889; no shipments; stock, 84,192. Quote: B, D, E, $5.60; F. O, G 5.95; H, , $6;: , M, N, $6.05; WG, $6.0; WW, X, $6.80..

Five employes of the American Steel Foundry Company's plant at Avenue L and Edward Street were burned, two seriously, in an explosion in a kettle of molten steel late tonight. The kettle had a capacity of five tons and was about half full.
The rules committee of the recently formed Eastern Ice Yachting Association met tonight and drew ,up tentative rules which will be submitted to the association for approval at its next meeting.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 16: Glassford, Capt. W. A., Buenos Aires, Argentina, to command the Maryland. McIntosh, Lt. H. D., the Chaumont, to command the Hatfield.

August lIartkorn, in Canadian Pacific Building; Kane Import Corp., in 443 4th Ave; Philip Platin, in 231 W 39th St; the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corp, broker. Michael Stahl, electrical contractor, in 19 Vesey St, through Brett Wyckoff, Inc.

The wheat market was nearly as weak today as it was strong yesterday. The failure of further frost to materialize in Argentina, accompanied by higher temperatures; weakness in stocks and a flattening out in the export demand for North American grain led to general selling of futures and prices at the extreme showed a loss of nearly 4 cents a bushel.

The National Industrial Traffic League adopted today a resolution recognizing the need of the nation's railroads for increased revenue, but at the same time refusing to take a position "as to whether the carriers should be granted a general increase in freight rates or as to the manner in which such increases should be constructed."

Homer S. Cummings, United States Attorney General, will speak on "The Unsolved Problem of Monopoly" at a luncheon meeting opening the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel On Nov. 29,

Governor Hoffman declared in an address before the New Jersey League of Municipalities tonight that he would provide the $3,000,000 needed for State relief purposes the remainder of the year by taking the cash balances left in any of the State departments.
Reports of progress today by the two agriculture committees toward agreement on a farm bill caused a brighter outlook in the Congressional situation. Forecasts that

Herman L. Mehr, organizer of two dummy corporations, received $5 from the now defunct State Title Mortgage Company for every mortgage he signed after old mortgages sold by the company had been foreclosed he testified yesterday in Federal Court at the trial of four former officers of State Title for alleged mail fraud.

Before a dinner gathering that included many of the leading bankers and industrialists of the United States, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, charged last night that the recent business recession was due to governmental policies and called for repeal of "existing laws which hamper business recovery."

The second anniversary of the application of the League of Nations sanctions against Italy-the date abroad probably is growing dim, but it continues to mean much to Italians and to remind them how vulnerable they are in case of war as long as they are dependent on foreign countries for the greater part of their raw materials-was made the occasion today to take stock of the progress made on the road to economic selfsufficiency.

One of the game's young players, Thomas D. Flynn of the Princeton Club, who in his undergraduate days at Old Nassau captained the tennis team, gained the final round of the Princeton Club's invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday.

Today's events: Welsh concert at Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Arthur Loesser, pianist, at Town Hall, 8:30 P. M. Stephano Ballarini makes his first appearance tonight at the Hippodrome. as Amonasro in "Aida."

A report exonerating the trustees and executors of the estate of Charles H. Ebbets, owner of the Brooklyn National League Baseball Club, of charges of "waste and extravagance" in connection with the management of the baseball team was filed yesterday with Surrogate George Albert Wingate in Brooklyn by Henry C. Turner, referee.

The New YPork Curb Exchange has received notice that holders of common stock of Pressed Metals of America, Inc., of record tomorrow will receive rights to subscribe at $20 a share to one additional common share for each eight shares held. The rights will expire on Dec.
Movements of naval vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 17 unless specified: Shanghai to Mariveles, Nov. 18: Alden, Barker, Whipple. Hongkong to Manila: J. D. Ford, Peary, Pillsbury, Pope.

Trading was mostly slow in the local market yesterday. Steer beef and pork loins sold sharply lower. Wednesday's late lamb market was weak to lower. Veal and calf sold steady. Trading in kosher meats was confined mostly to lamb at strong prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A sharper decline than anticipated on the basis of seasonal trend took place in lumber output last week, and the adjusted index eased to 65.7 from 72.4. The figure for the week ended Nov. 14, 1936, was 73.6. Shipments and orders also showed substantial losses from the previous week's totals, according to the reports wired especially to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the regional associations.

New York State acted yesterday to seek a consolidation of proceedwings brought before the Interstate Commerce Commission by several Southern States to obtain lower north-bound freight rates on commodities produced in the South.

The Brooklyn College football team continued its heavy workouts yesterday as Coach Lou Oshins sent his charges through a three-hour session in an effort to polish the attack for the encounter with the New York Aggies at Erasmus Field tomorrow. Timing on a new set of formations was emphasized during a dummy scrimmage against the reserves.

Judge John E. Swift's acquittal of a motorist on a charge of manslaughter, because "he was so drunk he was not in a position to form a judgment or exercise his will," today brought repercussions from several quarters.

A typhoon of tremendous destructive force, the second to hit the Philippines within a week, left a large area isolated today, and first scattered reports showed ten deaths and indicated property damage in the millions of dollars.

The New Deal program repudiating payments in gold, upon whose main features the United States Supreme Court ruled two years, was under attack again before that tribunal to. day. Holders of Liberty bonds

The Theatre Authority, organized by theatrical unions and charities to check racketeering in the presentation of benefit performances, planned yesterday to extend its influence to all parts of the country after three of the most powerful artist unions, the Screen Actors Guild, the American Federation of Radio Artists and the American Guild of Musical Artists, became Authority members.

Injunctions restraining Fred J. Slater of Rochester, a former State Senator, and two other local business men, from the sale of stock of the Craig Gold Mines, Ltd., of Madoc, Ont., were signed today by Federal Judge John Knight of Buffalo and by Supreme Court Justice William F. Love of Rochester.
William G. Hogan, former inspector in charge of the First Division of the New York City Police Deapartment, died on Wednesday night in Doctors Hospital. He was 75 years old.

The greatest manhunt in local police history ended at 4:40 o'clock this afternoon when Percy (Angel Face) Geary, last of the trio of O'Connell kidnappers who escaped from the Onondaga County Penitentiary at Jamesville early Tuesday, was recaptured.

Frequently reported to be leaving the cast of "Hooray for What!" Hannah Williams is doing so early next week in Philadelphia. She is being replaced by June Clyde, the film actress, who arrived yesterday afternoon in that city by plane from the Pacific Coast and started rehearsing at once.

The New York Retail Tobacco Council, Inc., representing about 8,000 New York retail tobacconists, last night decided to bring court action under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act against three retailers as the first major step in a campaign for enforcement of the act. The council,

Rockwell Kent, the artist, who is reported to have said that the jury that sentenced eight Nationalists on a sedition charge was hand-picked stopped over here tonight en route to South America by plane, offering his services as a witness in the murder trial of eleven Nationalists at Ponce.

The signature of the commercial agreement yesterday between Czechoslovakia and Hungary was welcomed by the press generally as a successful effort to improve relations. It ends the customs war in existence since the expiration of the last agreement in 1931.

The abscessed tooth which has troubled President Roosevelt for two days was removed early this morning and Mr. Roosevelt was reported as resting more comfortably today. He again remained in bed and canceled all appointments.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is not empowered to interfere with the normal function of the law of supply and demand as it affects prices of securities, the Philadelphia Association of Security Salesmen was told today by David Saperstein of New York and Washington, director of the SEC's tradinig and exchange division.

Dr. Prank Wilcox Pinneo, who was secretary of the Essex County Medical Society for twenty years, died here today in Newark City Hospital following a heart attack last Thursday at his home, 430 Mt. Prospect Avenue. He was 71 years old.

Henry Armstrong, featherweight champion of the world, will make a bid for recognition as the outstanding contender for the world 135-pound crown tonight when he meets Billy Beauhuld, undefeated Jersey City battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

The undefeated and untied Bruins added another victory to their string last night when they humbled the Americans at Madison Square Garden. The Star-Spangled sextet jumped into the lead with a first-period goal, but yielded tallies to the visitors in each of the succeeding sessions to bow, 2 to 1.

The six-story elevator apartment house containing 205 rooms and seven stores at 1,275 Boscobel Avenue, corner of 168th Street, the Bronx, was bought by the Hewsmatt Corporation, represented by Stanley Ide LaCov, attorney.
J. Stuart Agnew, chairman of the Virginia State Milk Commission, died yesterday in a field about two miles from his home here while he was inspecting a herd of cattle. He was 48 years old.

Herman Goffberg, South Side High School's star runner, flashed over the tape a winner by 75 yards today in the twenty-fifth annual Newark High School's cross-country championship over the Branch Brook Park course.

Proposals have been made to transfer the following memberships in the New York Stock Exchange it was announced yesterday. Ridley Watts Jr., a partner in Wood, White Co. to Robert Lovell, who will become a general partner in the firm.

James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., and Pearl L. Bergoff of New York, former head of an industrial service agency in New York, were found not guilty in the Federal District Court here today of violation of the Byrnes law which forbids the transportation of strike-breakers across State lines with the intention of interfering with peaceful picketing.
Charles D. Strang, a pioneer in the moving and warehouse business in Brooklyn, died in his sleep on Tuesday night at his home, 1,920 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 67 years old.

Miss Dorothy Wilhemina Ott, 23-year-old student and daughter of John Ott of Winnetka, Ill., died in French Hospital here today of Landry's disease (a form of paralysis). She was traveling homeward after touring in Europe and Russia when she fell ill here.

A renewed setback hit the dollar in the foreign exchange market yesterday and the principal foreign currencies recovered practically all their losses of Wednesday. The pound sterling was up 3, cent to $5.007-16, while the franc gained % point to 3.39, cents.

Ray Pierre, Zedra Jurist, in 150 W 58th St; Howard Morton, in. 12 E 86th St; Roy S. Johnson, through Wm. A. White Sons, in 240 5th Ave; Mrs. H. J. Pheteplace, Thomas Rodd 3d, in 23 E 73d St; Brett Wyckoff, Inc, broker.

James H. R. Cromwell, husband of the former Doris Duke, tobacco heiress, is one of the leading prospects for appointment to the United States Senate to succeed Senator A. Harry Moore, who is Governorelect of New Jersey, it was learned today.

Secretary Hull's announcement that the United States and Great Britain have agreed to begin negotiations for a reciprocal tariff treaty is important news and good news. There is a large amount of trade at stake. But, more than this, it seems certain that

The Newport branch of the Navy Relief Society was the beneficiary of a bridge party and fashion show giver at Hotel Viking today under the auspices of the Tau Omicron Phi Sorority, which is made up of the daughters of the army and navy officers stationed at Newport and of which Miss Betty Greig is president.
