A group of twenty-eight men prominent in finance and society will act as honorary pallbearers at the funeral service to be held tomorrow at 2 P. M. for Jay F. Carlisle at his East Islip home. Mr. Carlisle, senior partner of Carlisle, Mellick Co., died Wednesday.

Price-fixing is a "force certain to cripple agency business," Paul Hollister, executive vice president and publicity director of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday told the Eastern seaboard meeting of the New York Council of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the Hotel Roosevelt.

American Public Service Company and Subsidiaries-Three months to Sept. 30: Net income after expenses and charges, $292,812, com paring with a net of $209,469 in the three months to Sept. 30, 1936. For the nine months to Sept. 30, net was $353,128, comparing with a net of $255,163 in the first nine r months of last year.

Arthur P. French, lawyer in Boston for nearly sixty years, with offices at 68 Devonshire Street, died today at the Charlesgate Hospital, Cambridge, at the age of 82. He had been in active practice until a few days ago. His home was at 191 Woburn

While advertising agencies are closely watching efforts to amend the tax on undistributed corporation profits, the effect on advertising of any loosening of restrictions will not be as important as it might have been a few months ago, agency executives said yesterday. The tax wad, responsible in the final quarter of 1936 for turning substantial sums of money into advertising.
Edward P. (Slip) Madigan's football extravaganza from St. Mary's College in the Moraga Valley of California arrived in town yesterday en route to Miami, Havana and New Orleans.

As if to remind Lord Halifax to inquire from his German hosts concerning their intentions in Eastern Europe, the Conservative Yorkshire Post(owned by the family of Mrs. Eden and regarded as the Foreign Secretary's mouthpiece) warns that "there is no evidence" that Nazi aggressive designs

Prime Minister Mackenzie King announced this evening that formal negotiations would be opened soon for a new reciprocal trade pact between Canada and the United States, although the present treaty has another year to run.

John T. Benson, animal farm manager, today warned that this would be a "short but cold Winter." In his annual prediction, based upon fur-bearing animals on his Hudson farm, Mr. Benson asserted that the tails of squirrels had not yet feathered and that beavers had not begun to store their Winter wood, nor muskrats their food.

Two contributions to the biographical cycle were projected today by two lots. At RKO it was disclosed that "The Woman Crusader," the story of the life of Clara Barton, would be made after the first of the year and Twentieth CenturyFox announced that "The Life of Alexander Graham Bell" would be made shortly.
So far as Germany is concerned the much disputed question as to whether the next war on the seas will be won by battleships or airplanes has been definitely decided in favor of the battleship.
The House of Lords today gave second reading to a bill transferring the British West Indian island of Dominica, for administrative purposes, from the Leeward to the Windward group. Viscount.

Mayor La Guardia's feud with Budget Director Leo J. McDermott over the official's recommendations for salary increases in the 1938 budget is expected to reach a quiet end today when the Board of Estimate acts upon Mr. McDermott's

Speechless for seventeen years, Arthur S. Low, 42, had recovered his voice today. It returned as mysteriously as it was stilled. In November, 1920, a few months after he had returned with the army of occupation, Mr. Low's voice left him. Since then, until a few nights ago, friends said, he used pencil and paper to communicate with acquaintances.

In revolt against the tax and tariff policies of the New Deal, the six Governors of the New England States called jointly today for the repeal of the capital gains tax, the tax on undistributed corporate profits and denounced the pending reciprocal trade agreement with Czechoslovakia as imperiling the jobs of thousands of citizens.

Coach Steve Owen of the Giants has gone to the movies every night this week and, as a result, the New Workers will stick to their fiveman defensive lines against the Green Bay Packers at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

It may have been Andrew Carnegie who first described the steel trade as always prince or pauper; but whether Carnegie did or did not originate the phrase, the steel trade of 1937 has certainly exemplified its truthfulness.
Two weeks hence and, except for the various recipients of bids for the various bowls-Rose, Sugar, Orange, Lemon, Lime, etc.-the football season will come to a close.

106th St, a a, 70 ft e of Lexington Ave. 26x16.2, for I-story comfort station: Department of Parks. City of New York, owner; Aymar Emibury 2d, architect; cost, i3,500. Alterations 9th St, 426 E, to 5-story tenement and stores; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, 51 Chambers St, owner; Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects; cost, $8.000.

Defense against Cornell's passing tack occupied more than an hour as Pennsylvania continued its drive today for the annual Thanksgiving Day game here with the Ithacans. The squad was on the field until long after dark.
Columbia concluded preparations for the Dartmouth game in a twoand-a-half-hour drill at Baker Field yesterday, with Lou Little maintaining his policy of barring contact work for the regulars.

Representatives of the women's apparel trade associations again expressed opposition to the proposals of retailers that the cutters-up take steps to provide means of identifying rayon to th consumer at the joint meeting of retailers and manufacturers held yesterday afternoon in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

The four-story dwelling at 626 Third Street, Brooklyn, Adjoining Prospect Part West, has been sold by Arthur J. Hoffman to Nicholas Espenscheid for investment. The house contains two duplex apartments of seven rooms and two baths each,

Constitutional democracy, if it is to withstand present-day attacks of "the opportunists of absolutism," must have the capacity to adjust its conceptions of powers to the changing social and economic needs of the nation, Stanley Reed, Solicitor General of the United States, declared last, night.

The Fred Smiths will be at it again about the middle of January, when the Benevolent and Protective and Completely Universal Order of Fred Smiths of America, grown from a handful of members to nearly 3,000, will give its second annual dinner at the Hotel Biltmore, Provost Fred Smith announced yesterday.
Mrs. Alice Hawks, retired public school teacher of Fishkill, died on Tuesday and her funeral services took place today at DuBois Chapel here. She was the widow of Spencer Hawks.

Attorney General Bennett began prosecution yesterday of ten men and two corporations in connection with the sale of $350,000 gold mining stocks alleged to be worthless. At the request of Mr. Bennett, Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer issued Wednesday an order temporarily restraining the defendants from selling any more securities in this State.

Mayor A La. Guardia of New York City tonight telegraphed Nathan Straus, administrator of the Federal Housing Authority, a demand that he "discontinue star-gazing conferences" and get down to work on a S practical housing program.

A charm bearing the name of Ethel Shutta, singer and wife of George Olsen, orchestra leader, on a bracelet resulted in the appearance of three youths in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday morning on charges of grand larceny arising from the alleged theft of the bracelet and a pocketbook containing $17 from Miss Shutta's mother, Mrs. Charles Shutta of 210-15 Thirty-third Road, Bayside, Queens.

Gene Tunney, retired heavyweight boxing champion of the world, has been elected a director of the Morris Plan Industrial Bank, it was announced yesterday at the home office of the institution, 56 East Forty-secpnd Street.
Professor Edward C. Hutman of the faculty of the Albany College of Pharmacy died today. He was born here sixtyseven years ago. He established several drug stores here.

Magda de Fontanges, French actress and journalist who arrived last Nov. 8 with plans to capitalize her self-reported romance with Premier Benito Mussolini, obtained a writ of habeas corpus yesterday calling for her release from Ellis Island, where she has been held for deportation on the ground that she committed a crime involving moral turpitude.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 17: MAJOR GENERAL Sunderland, A. H., Chief of Coast Artillery, four days' leave, Nov. 18. COLONEL Campanole, N. W., Infantry, Fort Francis E. Warren, Wyo., to retirement.

Primo Camera came back tonight-but only to the Salle Wagram, the arena where nine years ago he fought his first battle for a $20 purse. He lost on points tonight to a second-rater, Dimeglio, an Italo-Frenchman from Marseilles, in a ten-round match which was partly a wrestling exhibition.

Asserting that, the nation was "definitely in a period of recession," Dean John T. Madden of New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, said last night that if statesmanship replaced politics in government and if organized labor displayed intelligent leadership, "the recession need not be severe."

The following Reserve officers recently released to the First Military Area,N.N. Y., are assigned as follows: 31st Medical Regiment-1st Lt. William B. Stocking, Med-Res., 51 Lathrop Ave., Binghamton, N. Y. 19th General Hospital-Capt. Henry M. Spillan, Dent-Res., 613 N. Main St., Elmira, N. Y.; 1st Lt. Kenneth T. Rowe, Med-Res., 38 Elizabeth St., Dansville, N. Y.
Fifty-two lots in Woodside, Queens, have been sold-by a client of Lee Harris Co., brokers, to Chesterfield Homes, Inc., for improvement with fifty one and two story dwellings.
Herbert C. Clark, chief of the title and mortgage bureau of the State Insurance Department, died Wednesday at his home, 40 Egbert Avenue, West New Brighton, S. I. He was 55 years old.

The New York State Legislative Committee for Investigation of the Petroleum Industry, Assemblyman Harold B. Ehrlich of Buffalo, chairman, heard representatives of major oil companies argue yesterday against the proposal that the State adopt minimum standards for gasoline.

Largely as a result of declines In prices for livestock, The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices lost 1.1 points in the week ended on Tuesday. The index now stands at 87.8, the lowest since the closing week of November, 1936.

The Rev. Richard T. Ryan, for twenty-seven years rector of the Church of the Immaculate Conception here, died today in St. Peter's Hospital, New Brunswick, following an illness of three days. He was 60 years old.

The Royal Court of Appeals today heard the appeal of Major Ferenc Szalasi, Hungarian Nazi leader, who was recently sentenced to three months in prison for incitement to overthrow the social system and to one month for incitement against a religious confession--the Jews.

The controversy raging in the House over the deadlocked Wages and Hours Bill broke over party traces today, when leaders of the labor bloc called a meeting of adherents for Tuesday morning to propose what is regarded as perhaps the most drastic program seen in Congress for many years.

Contracts covering most of the Canadian export tonnage of newsprint have been signed for the first half of 1938 with publishers in the United States at the increased price of $50 a ton announced by Canadian companies some time ago, -it is said here on good authority.

The increase of $18,125,000 reported this week by the Federal Reserve System in its holdings of government securities represented a speeding up of the new open-market operation, by comparison with the purchases of $10,400,000 with which the campaign was begun a week before.

Announcement that negotiations for an Anglo-American trade treaty were on foot was officially made in the House of Commons today by Neville Chamberlain, the Prime Minister, in a form which indicated the British Government's expectation that this pact, so long desired by Secretary Hull, would be effectuated in time.

Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the National Municipal League tonight that if the highly industrialized system of the United States did not bring forth without delay some general satisfaction of "the range of human instincts," the people of the nation would be prey to "mass movements foreign n American traditions."

Cooperation of the banks serving the garment trades, and the resident buying offices, in plans of the garment and accessory industries for participation in the World's Fair of 1939, was promised yesterday at a meeting held in the Empire State Club. Joseph Love, chairman

Willie Hoppe yesterday set the world 18.1 balkline championship crown a little more firmly upon his graying head by defeating Jake Schaefer, challenger from Chicago, in both blocks of their 3,000-point match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy. The champion now holds the commanding lead of 2,000 to 1,324, with four blocks remaining..

Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Carter of Paris have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Mildred- Carter, to Philip Boyer Jr. of Philadelphia. Miss Carter, who spent her early childhood in Paris, later attended the Foxcroft School in Virginia and was introduced to society in Boston in the Autumn of 1933.
Stocks' closed with losses of 1 to 3 points; turnover, 902,820 shares. United States Government and foreign bonds higher, corporate issues lower; transactions, $8,338,450.

During the week ended Nov. 17 member bank reserve balances increased $43,000,000. Addition to member bank reserves arose from an increase of $14,000,000 in reserve bank credit and decreases of $30,000,000

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York and affiliated companies filed a petition in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday asking for a review of an order signed last Nov. 10 by the National Labor Relations Board requiring them to void their contracts with six locals of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

Gus Oliva, who had $4,600,000 eight years ago, came to town today with $1.20 in his pockets and a patch on his trousers. In one year the former newspaper carrier paid the government $250,000 in taxes on a fortune he reaped in the stock market.
Francis Leaman Bittles, sales executive and former broker, of Beverly Road, here, died this afternoon in Presbyterian Hospital, Newark, after a short illness. He was 39 years old.

American business will "be able to go places"' if the temper of Congress is continued so that some legislation will be modified,. Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation, said yesterday in a lecture on "Foods, Facts and Figures" 'before the New York Stock Exchange Institute.

At the lonely shrine of the dramatic poets Stanley Young is offering a tragedy in free verse, "Robin Landing," which was politely spoken at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre last evening. With a poet's fondness for the romantic past he is writing, perhaps symbolically, of civilized love and pagan love in a Kentucky trading post of the eighteenth century. Obviously,

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total United States Government securities to be at the highest point of the year to date. Gold holdings, as stated in the subjoined table, represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury."
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

Announcement that George Hooper, crack Syracuse guard, may be unable to play against Colgate here Saturday today dampened the victory hopes of Orange supporters. Hooper is confined to the infirmary with a leg infection and his fitness will not be definitely determined until Saturday. Al Handler, junior reserve, was used

Eighteen mural panels, which Boardman Robinson worked more than two and a half years to complete, have been installed in the ceremonial entrance leading from the Court- of Honor in the Department of Justice Building.

The Brown regulars got their first view of Rutgers' plays today when they held an extended scrimmage against the reserves who had been drilled in the attack of their Thanksgiving Day opponents. The reserves scored one touchdown on a pass, Verdery to Bernstein, but had little success with running plays.

Fireman lst grade John J. Austin of Engine 9, died Nov. 17. Funeral will take place from the Universal Funeral Parlor. 597 Lexington Ave., Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, Nov. 20. Interment at Calvary Cemetery. The Deputy Chief of the 1st Division shall detail a lieutenant and twelve firemen, who, together with six members from the off platoon of Engine 9

An underground chemical laboratory, which might have been used as a bomb factory, and a mattress containing seven sticks of dynamite wrapped in a newspaper dated 1913 have been discovered by men working at a house at 114-73 114th Street, South Ozone Park, Queens, that has been untenanted for a year, the Queens police revealed yesterday.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was on a somewhat more active scale, but with the exception of United States Government obligations and certain foreign dollar bonds, the increase in turnover was at the expense of prices. Domestic corporation bonds
A national political party that would make Brazil a one-party State under the leadership of President Getulio Vargas was reported today being formed to support the new regime he proclaimed Nov. 10.

The new contract under which striking flour truck drivers settled their strike here will go in effect next Monday. Cartage charges, it was said, had not been fixed, and will be determined later. Members of the Associated Flour Haulers

Robert S. Potter has been elected a vice president and John F. Russell Jr. has been made secretary and treasurer of the Ironrite Ironer Company. The Continental Bank and Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 350,000 shares of common stock of Alexander's Department Stores, Inc.

A check for $1,500, a donation from the postoffice employes of Manhattan and the Bronx, was contribute yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, which is conducting its twenty-first annual roll-call for funds.

There were many dinner parties given in connection with the first in a series of dinner dances for married couples, young women who made their debuts several seasons ago, and bachelors last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin.

An infection caused by a slight finger bruise suffered more than a month ago caused Colonel John W. Wright, commanding the Military District of Puerto Rico, to be taken by plane today to Washington to the Walter Reed Hospital.
For the first time since gold began moving some weeks ago from the United States to France, an increase was announced today in the gold reserves of the Bank of France.
Hurlin' Kenneth Heineman really puts on a football show. The Texas School of Mines quarterback has completed 68 of his 148 passes, for a net gain of 1,158 yards and a 17-yard average.

James Roosevelt told the rooters of the St. Mary's College football team today that he alone probably would "make as much noise as all of you put together" when he attends the Harvard-Yale game Saturday.

Two hours of scrimmage on offensive formations against the yearlings marked the New York University football squad's workout at Ohio Field yesterday as the Violet continued its preparation for the meeting with Fordham on Nov. 27 at the Yankee Stadium.

The Columbia University and Barnard College Glee Clubs will present a joint concert and dance tonight in the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Plaza. The concert will be conducted by Willard Rhodes, former assistant conductor of the Cincinnati Opera Company and conductor of concert tours with his

Gennaro Moccio, 18 years old, of 534 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn, did not appear in Kings County Court yesterday for trial on a robbery indictment and his attorney, former Magistrate Joseph Goldstein, explained that he was training for a boxing match next Saturday night at the Ridgewood Grove, Queens.

Chicago's Black Hawks, blasting in three quick goals during the second period, scored their first home victory of the National Hockey League season tonight by turning back the champion Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1.

Mr. and Mrs. W. Gould Brokaw will return from Europe next week and will be at the Plaza before going to their home in Locust Valley. William Gilman Low and his daughter, Miss Rhoda Low, of Tuxedo Park, who returned recently from Europe, have left the Ambassador for Newport.

Delaware, with only two-tenths of 1 per cent of the nation's population has contributed $130,000,000 toward the cost of relief in other States, said Pierre S. du Pont today in contrasting finances of this State and the Federal Government before the Rotary Club here.

George Dayton Morgan, retired vice president of the General Railway Signal Company of Rochester, N. Y., died at his Winter home today after an illness of several weeks. His age was 73. Burial will be in Brockport, N. Y.

In a rough game during which one player went to a hospital and another was carried from the ice unconscious, the Maple Leafs played a 6-all tie with the Canadiens tonight and bolstered their lead in the National Hockey League's international section.

It is now officially announced that the riot in which nine native deserters from Italian East Africa were killed and twentyseven were wounded, as reported Tuesday, started at a soccer match between interned prisoners and their British-commanded native guards.
Penn State's football team went through its last home workout of the year today, preparing for the Lions' thirty-seventh annual game on Saturday. Forty-one players will

The world will rejoice that Viscount Cecil of Chelwood has been awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for 1937. No one now living has labored longer or more creatively for the establishment of the reign of law among the nations.

A son, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Allen H. Waterous of 50 West Sixty-seventh Street yesterday at the Polyclinic Hospital. Mrs. Waterous is the former Miss Charlotta Smith, daughter of Mrs. Emery H. Smith of 953 Fifth Avenue and the late Mr. Smith, and a granddaughter of the late Alfred H. Smith, who was president of the New York Central Railroad.

Miss Johanne Kolstad, 24-year-old Norwegian ace, is the latest foreign entrant for the International Ski Meet and Winter Sports Show slated for Madison Square Garden from Dec. 7 to 11. Called the Queen of the Ski, Miss Kolstad has long ranked high in international skiing as the result of her sparkling

A formal demand that the Cargill Grain Company be represented by counsel at the scheduled hearing of charges filed against it for violation of an order of the business conduct committee of the Board of Trade in the squeeze in September corn, way sent today to Kenneth S. Templeton, president of the Board of Trade, by John H. MacMillan Jr., president of Cargill, Inc.
It is our contention, which we are prepared to defend against all comers, that the spread of red radicalism in this country is

Three children chaperoned by their mother picketed their uncle's furniture plant today demanding a job for their father. One carried a sign bearing the signature of their father, Louis Zolot, 53, who was at home ill. It read:

KINGS CASSIDY, MARY K. (Dec. 26. 1935), Gross assets, $21,211; net, $16,963. To husband, Joseph P. Cassidy. Chief assets, real estate, $20,500; miscellaneous property, $701. Waiter Jeffreys Carlin, attorney, 2 Rector St., Manhattan.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today a tobacco-diversion program designed to prevent accumulation of excess stocks of flue-cured and dark air-cured types of tobacco. The diverted tobacco will be manufactured into such products as nicotine, fertilizers, sprays and dusts for combating plant and animal parasites.

Louis Renaud, 51 years old, a patient at the Neurological Hospital on Welfare Island, plunged to his death yesterday morning from a room on the fifteenth floor of the Hotel George Washington, Twentythird Street and Lexington Avenue.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have been backing and filling ever since President Roosevelt spoke at Chicago, because we were imperfectly prepared for the propositions he advanced there. To the lack of realistic treatment of foreign affairs are due also the obvious contradictions of our policy or

Goerck St, 135, 25.10x100; Morris and Louis Lesser to Nathan Perimut, 682 Ocean Av, Brooklyn; consideration $200 over mtg for $9,500. Avenue C. 58, 24x64.3 Max Weisberg to Micbar Realty Corp, 56-26 Myrtle Ave, Ridgewood; mtg $11,000.
The Bureau of Mines estimated today a daily average supply of 3,491,300 barrels of domestic crude oil would be 'required to meet December market demands.
In the week ended on Nov. 13 the excess of buying over selling of odd lots on the New York Stock Exchange continued, according to figures made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Thirty students have been elected to membership in the Nu chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national honor fraternity, at Hunter College, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Marjorie Anderson, president of the chapter.

The 1937 Nobel Peace Prize was awarded today to Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, one of the founders of the League of Nations and a leading advocate of disarmament. The former British Cabinet member was selected because of his work in the League and his efforts to promote international good-will.

Samuel Edson Cassino, retired publisher of children's magazines, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 81. Until his retirement ten years ago, he was publisher of "Little Folks," "Our Little Ones," "Little Men and Women," "Boys and Girls." and "The Nursery."
The weekly statement of the Bank of England- shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
ENDS AND MEANS, by Aldous Huxley. (Harper, $3.50.) An analysis of the good society. SX CENTURIES OF FINE PRINTS, by Carl Zigrosser. (Covici, Friede, $5.) A history of prints and print making.

A practice session of less than two hours today wound up Princeton's hard preparation for Saturday's allimportant Navy encounter. Tonight the Tiger encampment settled down to await the contest that will mark the 1937 season as a dismal failure or bring the first major victory of the year to Old Nassau.

The second cavilux recital of this, the fifth season, by Thomas Wilfred, will be given this evening at 8:30 o'clock at the Art Institute of Light, 480 Lexington Avenue. The program includes "Elliptical Prelude," "Receding Forms," "Majestic Study," "Abstract and

Vic Ghezzi of Deal, N. J., Ben Loving of Rumson, N. J., and Bob Stupple of Chicago fired sub-par 70s through crisp, sunshiny weather today for a three-way tie for the top place as a field of ninety-odd i reached the half-way mark in the 36-hole midsouth open golf tournament.

Television was called upon to transmit a fashion show over the ether waves yesterday afternoon when the latest modes were paraded before the iconoscopee" in the National Broadcasting Company's television studio at Rockefeller Center.

His new book, "Ends and Means,"* is a bouillabaisse of related ideas on the larger abstractions, the principal distractions, and the resoundingly concrete problems of this strange day. It's all, you may say, a little like

A sixteen-foot head of Abraham Lincoln, upon which the sculptor George Grey Barnard has worked for more than ten years, will have its first public showing tomorrow. With the announcement of the showing it was disclosed that a committee of Negro ministers were making efforts to have the huge head erected in Harlem as a tribute of their race to the Civil War President.

3d Ave (10-2608), a e cor of 166th St, 75x70: Aleda Realty Corp to Daru Realty Corp, 1,555 Grand Concourse; mtg $34,300. Clay Ave (11-2799). w a, 275 ft n of 174th St, 75x95; Edna Picker to Samuel Alkoff, 1,825 _larrison_Ave.

Reunion of the three greater branches of American Methodism--the Methodist Episcopal, the Methodist Episcopal South and the Methodist Protestant Churches--was announced tonight by Bishop Waldorf of the Chicago Area as being assured.
The Fordham football squad took its turn at defensive work yesterday as Coach Jim Crowley sent the unbeaten Maroon through a threehour drill. After a short period
Nearrecovery of Edward Madigan, 5-year-old son of St. Mary's football coach, Edward P. (Sllp) Madigan, was reported in Oakland tonight by Dr. E. R. Guinan, the Madigan's family doctor.

Records of the Felony Court yesterday revealed that last Friday Magistrate Alexander Brough dismissed a charge of suspicion of extortion against Leo Safian, 52 years old, of the Layard Apartments in 123d Street, Rockaway Park, Queens. The charge had been made
Mr. and Mrs. Herman Livingston Rogers, American friends of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, arrived yesterday on the Italian motorship Conte di Savoia, from their villa at Cannes, France.

More than 500 mail carriers from twenty-two stations canvassed more than 100 square blocks in specially designated sections of the city last night in an effort to stimulate and speed up the Federal unemployment census.

Elmer M. Cunningham has resigned as assistant to the general attorney of the Mortgage Commission and director of the FHA activities of the Mortgage Commission Servicing Corporation to return to the practice of law,
Mrs. J. C. MacDougall, heroine of a mutiny at sea off the Philippines many years ago, died in a hospital here last night. She was 72 years old.

After bucking strong headwinds for several hours on a flight toward Baltimore. Captain Rod Sullivan decided to bring the Pan American Airways Bermuda Clipper back to Bermuda. The Clipper, making its second westward flight from here, carrying Baltimore newspaper men, will leave tomorrow.
Fred M. Beglinger, circuit judge in this district for fifteen years,, died of heart disease here today at the age of 74.
Governor Earle of Pennsylvania and a party of twenty-two salled yesterday afternoon on the SwedishAmerican liner Drottningholm to attend the Tercentenary celebration commemorating the sailing of the

The National Grange convention put its foot down today on enactment of the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill and asker fair consideration for agriculture in negotiation of reciprocal trade agreements.

Mrs. Blanche Kaplan, 30 years old, of 42-22 Ketcham Street, Elmhurst, Queens, plunged six stories to her death at 9:35 o'clock yesterday morning from the window of a wash room adjacent to her husband's office on the eighth floor of 101 Park Avenue.

Seminole Ave (15-4278), s w cor of Pawnee P1, 50x100; Nathan Welssblum to Ninth Federal Savings and Loan Association. 1,451 Broadway; due as per bond, $10,000. 165th St, 153 E (9-2472); Jacob Beilin to Frank L. Weil. trustee, 635 Park Ave:extends mtge to Aug 23, 1942, at 4% to 5 per cent; $77,000.

Three more Important victories were announced today by the Japanese Army spokesman, who said that despite deepening mud and a continuing cold Autumn rain the Japanese Army last night advanced seven miles toward Soochow after breaking the Chinese Fushan-Soochow defense line. The Japanese advance guard was reported to be only three miles outside the walls of Soochow.

The Second National Bank of Boston bought yesterday an issue of $500,000 of temporary loan notes of Quincy, Mass., on a 0.373 peri cent interest basis. The notes, dated Nov. 18, 1937, will become payable on May 26 and June 30, 1938.

Richard Scheuch, 33 years old, described by police as editor of the illegal, secretly circulated Nazi newspaper Austrian Observer, jumped to his death tonight from a fourth story window as political police raided his home.

Despite continued turmoil in certain sections, coincident with the final stages of the historic evacuation of the Chinese Government from Nanking, this capital began yesterday to assume an aspect of desertion.

Preaching conservative methods in finance and hard work as the only remedies' for national and world economy, Finance Minister Georges Bonnet today, in the first big debate of the new parliamentary session, won far more applause from the Right opposition than from the Left benches of the government majority, indicating how difficult his task is going to be in steering a balanced budget through successfully.

The fee of the land upon which part of the seventeen-story Hotel Martinique stands, at 1,266-68 Broadway, between Thirty-second and Thirty-third Streets, was sold at voluntary auction yesterday by Joseph P. Day, Inc., in the Vesey

Mrs. Edward Lyons, wife of the president of the Brevoort Savings Bank, died Wednesday night in their home at 224 New York Avenue, Brooklyn. The, former Miss Charlotte Tyler of Methuen, Mass., Mrs. Lyons had come to Brooklyn

Adoption of new rules liberalizing the examination procedure required of applicants for New York City teaching licenses was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph K. Van Denburg, chairman of the Board of Examiners.

The Metropolitan Savings Bank has sold to the 191 Park Row Corporation the six-story building at 18 Greene Street, assessed at $20,000. The building will be altered and occupied by the purchaser, according to Jerome Tanenbaum, broker in the transaction.

General. satisfaction over the Anglo-American trade treaty an nouncerent made by Secretary Hull in Washirngton yesterday was expressed by both exporters and importers here. Domestic producers were less enthusiastic aboul the proposed agreement, fearing that competitive items from .the United Kingdom will get the bulk of whatever tariff concessions. may be granted by- this country.

The count of the proportional representation vote for city Councilmen proceeded on schedule yesterday in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, twenty-six candidates being eliminated from the race in the three boroughs on the basis of the official figures.

Thomas J. Lyons, vice president of the State Federation of Labor and Secretary of Teamsters District Council 16, was elected president of the Central Trades and Labor Council last night to succeed Joseph P. Ryan, who declined to seek re-election after being criticized for his failure to support Mayor La Guardia.

More than $1,000,000, according to informal estimates, was bequeathed to the Johns Hopkins University in the will of Louis J. Boury, former Brooklyn grain merchant, it was revealed today when the executors filed a certified copy of the document in the Orphans, Court here.

The Federal Reserve System speeded up the pace of its new openmarket campaign to expand credit in the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed in the system's reports issued yesterday. The system added $18,125,000 to its holdings of government securities, the reports showed, on top of $10,400,000 which was added in the preceding week, when the new operation was begun.

The 236th anniversary of the founding of the Imperial Russian Naval Academy in St. Petersburg by Peter the Great was celebrated last night with the Naval Ball, given under the auspices of the Association of Former Imperial Russian Naval Officers, on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

A flying boat with accommodations for about 100 passengers will be the next step in transatlantic passenger service, it was asserted yesterday in a report made public in New-York by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

Falling prices of foods, hides, leather and textile products, caused a decline in the wholesale commodity price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for the week ended Nov. 13. The all-commodify index, based on the 1926 average as 100, stood at 83.2, as compared with 83.8 on Nov. 6, and 82 on Nov. 14, a year ago.

The University of California, favored to defeat Stanford Saturday for the Coast 'Conference football championship and win the Rose Bowl bid, hasn't given an official thought yet to an opponent for the New Year's Day game at Pasadena.

All testimony and exhibits relating to rate schedules, rate reductions and the like of either the private companies or the Tennessee Valley Authority were ruled out today by the three-judge Federal court hearing the suit of eighteen Southeastern power companies asking that TVA be declared unconstitutional.

The four-story brick apartment and store building at 199 Ninth Street, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Provident Institution for Savings to Frederick Pescio for modernization. There are six fourroom suites and two stores in the structure, which was sold through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. Insley, Decker Cross acted for the seller.

Ninety employes paid tribute here tonight to Mrs. Charles B. Knox, pioneer woman food manufacturer and philanthropist, as she celebrated her eightieth birthday anniversary after completing the day at her desk as usual.

A petition by thirteen water carriers operating between Atlantic and Gulf ports and Chesapeake Bay asking for a 15 per cent rate increase similar to that sought by Class I railroads on Nov. 5, and on similar grounds, was filed this afternoon with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

A proposal to establish a National Executive Housekeepers Institute to set up standards of quality and construction for furnishings and equipment . was discussed at a meeting of the National Executive Housekeepers Association In connection with the annual Hotel Exposition at the Grand Central Palace- yesterday.
Premier Mussolini was expected last night to name the Duke of Aosta as Viceroy of Ethiopia, succeeding Marshal Rodolfo Graiani.

The board of directors of the Chesapeake Corporation declared today an extra dividend of one-fifth of a share of Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company common stock on each share of its own stock, payable on Nov. 30 to holders of record of Nov. 26.

A nation-wide inquiry into the activities of "Les Cagoulards," "The Hooded Ones," today produced three additional arrests-all in Paris--subsequent to the discovery of two additional secret arsenals in the capital.

The second amateur hockey inaugural of the week will take place tonight when the Bronx Tigers launch their first season in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League in a game with the New York Rovers, who opened their drive last Sunday. The game will be played at the New York Coliseum.

Transfers and Assignments PATROLMEN-Frank J. Scheiner. 88th to Traffic C; Alfred Marks, Traffic C to 88th. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT-Christian L. Zimmer, from 5th Precinct to Telegraph Bureau, designated as acting captain, for 26 days, from 8 A. M., Nov. 24, during the absence of acting captain on vacation.

Contributions and pledges totaling $72,245 in the advance gifts phase of the national appeal for $500,000 of the American Social Hygiene Association were announced yesterday at the quarterly meeting of the board of directors at the Rainbow Room- Club, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. The public solicitation phase of the campaign will start on Feb. 2 next, National Social Hygiene Day.

Gloom settled yesterday over the pigeon lovers near the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventy-ninth Street, scene of Wednesday's massacre of forty birds, as thirty survivors of the poisoning found a new perch.
John M. Van Houten, secretary and general manager of the Dutchess Tool Company here, died last night of a heart attack at his home at the age of 52..

Tony Galento of Newark, N. J., knocked out Leroy Haynes of Philadelphia in 2 minutes 23 seconds of the third round of a ten-round boxing bout at Convention Hall tonight. Galento weighed 214 pounds, Haynes 197 3/4. Galento dropped Haynes three times for nine counts and when the tall Negro dropped to the floor
The Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., showed a net loss of $60,956 for the first nine months of this year, according to the financial statement released

A 41-year-old fugitive, who escaped from the Michigan State Prison on Jan. 11, 1919, and who is under four indictments for violation of the Prohibition Amendment, was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn by Detectives James Kissane and William Fyffe of the Safe and Loft Squad.
Pompoon, champion 2-year-old of 1936 and runner-up to War Admiral in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, reached Santa Anita today well on the road back to sound condition.

Paul Sifton, Deputy Industrial Commissioner, was assigned today to the general administration of the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance, succeeding Glenn A. Bowers, who wishes to retire on July 1. In the next few months

The Symington-Gould Corporation, maker of railway equipment, reported yesterday for the quarter ended -on Oct. 31 a consolidated net profit of $227,733 after depreciation, normal Federal income taxes, excess profit taxes and other charges, but before provision for undistribute profits taxes.

Several days ago Governor Lehman was asked to investigate the fitness of Albert Marinelli to hold office as County Clerk of New York County. This request came from representatives of the New York City League of Women Voters, the Honest Ballot

A total of $1,128,993.40 in cash contributions and pledges has been received by the United Hospital Fund in its campaign which started on Oct. 25 to raise $3,171,000 to aid ninety-two voluntary hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn next year.
Dartmouth's football team wound up practice for this year on Memorial Field today, looking over Columbia formations in a light workout.

A ship construction subsidy based on the differential between our own and foreign building costs is "more open to political influences, to favoritism or to serious errors than any other form of subsidy that could be devised," Joseph W. Powell, president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, said yesterday at the opening session of the society's two-day annual meeting.
The annual Prince-Tiger dance, the chief event of Princeton's Autumn social season, will be held tomorrow evening in the university gymnasium with more than 300 couples in attendance.

With every city reporting a loss, bank clearings,. throughout the country, after four successive weeks of gains, declined sharply in the past week from-the corresponding week a year ago, even after allowance was made for the Armistice Day holiday, which occurred week earlier in 1938. The loss for this city alone amounted to 35.0 per cent.
The Japanese Embassy tonight issued a statement that no ultimatum of any sort had been sent to France by the Tokyo government.

President Roosevelt and members of Congress have been asked by a conference of leading labor and civic organizations to remedy "defects" in the Black-Connery fair wage and hour bill. The group endorses the principle of the measure, but disapproves what it holds the tendency to freeze into law existing geographic, sectional, local and racial differences.
The Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported today that nature had taken a hand in balancing the cost of the Thanksgiving dinner this year.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, former New York Police Commissioner and war-time commander of the Twenty-seventh Division, suffered a heart attack last night on a north-bound New York Central train near Scarsdale, relatives said today.

Delegates representing 5,000 seamen on Scandinavian ships operating from American ports attended the opening session of the fourth annual convention yesterday of the Scandinavian Seamen's Club of America at the Vasa Club, 465 Dean Street, Brooklyn.

During Senator Bailey's effective assault on the corporate surplus tax Wednesday, a name was mentioned in a way that indicates its owner will be much and openly discussed when this particular levy is up for modification.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had granted applications for discontinuing trading in three security issues on national Exchanges.

Miss Anita G. Smith of 410 Park Avenue, New York, has purchased a cottage on Second Beach Road from the Cliff View Cottages, Inc., for her Summer home. Mrs. Howard L. Clarke, owner of Swallow's Cave on Indian Avenue,

Many parties were given last night at the opening for the season of the Starlight Roof dinner dances at the Waldorf-Astoria under the direction of Miss Fanshawe. One of the largest dinners was that given by Mr. and Mrs. W. Roosevelt Thompson and Mr. and Mrs. Archbold van Beuren.

Juniors will man the center of Lehigh University's line against Lafayette in the annual battle at Tay lor Stadium Saturday. Two of the starters named by Glen Harmeson are Thomas and Eugene Kirkpatrick.

From the number of men who turned out for the dinner of the New York Athletic Club Anglers on Wednesday, and from their enthusiasm for the sport, it was evident that this particular subdivision of the club has become a permanent fixture.

The auction sale of the library of the late Parke E. Simmons of Evanston, Ill., which was completed last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., brought a total of $20,017. The highest price of the evening was $510, paid by Thomas Eron

WITH his breakfast of orange juice in a glass on the table in front of him, Jack Doyle, the Sage of Broadway, said: "Yale vs. Harvard. Or as they always say in Cambridge, Harvard vs. Yale, Harvard being the older, you knbw. And did you know that I am a

Miss Betty M. Guggenheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Guggenheimer of 219 West Eighty-first Street, was married at the Warwick last evening to Malcolm I. Steiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Steiner of New York and, Hempstead. L. I.

Great Britain's Parliamentary battles will not be broadcast. Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, amid Conservative applause, told the House of Commons today that he did not think the proposal would commend itself to any considerable section of the public.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: 38-Fidelity and Deposit Co. of Maryland petr, v. Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance of the State of New York. Argued for both.

The principles and policies of the Sudeten German party, which is the biggest party and the biggest problem in Czechoslovakia, were expounded to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Henlein party leader at his headquarters in this town.

Business success in this age depends on immediate recognition of consumer desires and wants and the shaping of industrial operations and merchandising methods to meet the needs of the public, some 300 executives were told by speakers yesterday at a sales management conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

An audience that packed Carnegie Hall shouted and cheered after the concluding performance of the Sibelius Second symphony by Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, who last night made their first New York appearance of the season.
President Roosevelt underwent the removal of an abscessed tooth and was reported resting comfortably. He again canceled all engagements for the day.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave a dinner last night at their home, 307 West Seventy-first Street, for Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Greene, who were married recently in Indianapolis. Mrs. Greene is -the former Miss Eileen Booker of that city. The other guests included Mr.

Oxford University Socialists were defeated for a second time this term at the Oxford Union presidential debate tonight when a motion "that the Liberal party offers a better alternative to the National Government than does the Labor party" was carried by 185 to 97 votes.

The University Club's Class A squash racquets team strengthened its grip on.first place in the Metropolitan- League competition by defeating the Yale Club, 4 to 1, at the University Club courts last night. It was the fourth verdict in as many league matches for the victors.
The University of Pennsylvania basketball team will play eighteen games this season, two fewer than last year, H. Jamison Swarts, director of athletics, announced today.

Miss Josephine G. O'Brien of 110 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, principal of Public School 117, 143d Street near Eighty-fifth Drive, Jamaica, Queens, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Manhattan, after a brief illness. Miss O'Brien,

Supreme Court Justices John H. McCooey and Lewis L. Fawcett of Brooklyn declined yesterday to comment on a demand that the Legislature impeach them for alleged violations of anti-injunction laws which was expressed Wednesday at a meeting of a citizens' committee on labor unions in the Russell Sage Foundation.

Julio Alvarez del Vayo, former Foreign Minister, has resigned as commissar general of the Loyalist land forces and his resignation has been accepted by Indalecio Prieto, the Minister of National Defense, it was announced today.

The Dartmouth College' Athletic Council today announced the complete football schedules for 1938 and 1939. In 1939 the Navy returns to the program for the first time since 1929. Other newcomers listed are Hampden-Sydney and Lafayette. St. Lawrence and Dickinson are newcomers on the 1938 card.

A few hundred men whose sitdown strike in the Fisher Body plant here closed two automotive factories employing 14,721, held their ground last night and neither General Motors Corporation nor the United Automobile Workers of America professed to know of plans for peace negotiations.

In connection with its three-year road plan the government has called attention to the need for building modern hotels along all main highways, especially those that offer scenic and other attractions for tourists.

A check for $5,000, representing the greater part of the proceeds for the golf exhibition given last Sunday in which John Montague, Babe Ruth, Mrs. Sylva Annenberg and Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson participated, was received by Mayor La Guardia yesterday:

Contracts to rent plots upon which will be erected an all-glass display building and a structure for the dramatization of industrial chemistry at the New York World's Fair were signed yesterday afternoon with Grover A. Whalen, president of the exposition, in his office in the administration building at the fair site, Flushing Meadow Park.

The screams of a 19-year-old girl cashier at the Longchamps Restaurant at Madison Avenue and Fiftyninth Street last night halted the criminal career of a former WPA worker, who, according to the police, specialized in robbing Manhattan's better eating places.
A. C. Compton's Clingendaal was first in the featured Tench Handicap at Bowie today, turning in the fastest six furlongs of the meeting despite an impost of 125 pounds.
Young matrons and debutantes of this and recent seasons acted as manikins in the annual fashion show for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys' Club yesterday afternoon at the St. Regis.

The State Department of Social Welfare budget for the year beginning next July 1 will approximate $87,000,000, of which $54,000,000 will be needed for home relief, Commissioner David C. Adie announced yesterday.

The following Marine Corps changes, dated Nov. 15, were announced today: BRIGADIER GENERAL Matthews, H., headquarters, Washington, D. C., to retirement. MAJORS Mixson. J. A., to temporary duty with Second Marine Brigade, Shanghai, China, via the President Pierce, sailing from San Francisco Nov. 20.
Vic Fusia, Manhattan's veteran back, who was kept out of last week's contest because of injuries, will start at the left halfback post against Niagara tomorrow at Ebbets Field. Coach Chick Meehan

Trustees of the defaulted $5,500,000 Series B-1 guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, now in liquidation, applied yesterday in Supreme Court for permissionn to accept certificates- at their face value in the reduction of underlying mortgages and in the sale of real estate now in their hands. It is the first time that such a proposal has been advanced.

The football men of Harvard went behind the high walls of Soldiers Field today for the last secret practice of the year. Tomorrow afternoon they will share that old playing surface with Yale, their rival of Saturday, and will do little more than run through the motions of practice.

Turkey and all the traditional fixin's that go with Thanksgiving. including a day of rest to enjoy the treat, will be supplied to the 300,000 young men in the Civilian Conservation Corps a week from today. The War Department will provide about 500,000 pounds of turkey, purchased from farmers near the camps where practical.

The O. Henry Memorial Award Committee has announced the winners of its nineteenth annual award of three prizes for the best short stories by American writers published in American magazines during the year. The first prize of $300
Governor Herbert H. Lehman called upon County Clerk Albert T. Marinelli yesterday to make formal answer by noon next Wednesday to charges reflecting upon his fitness to hold public office.

Dana Wallace, former District Attorney of Queens County, who is being heard on charges of unprofessional conduct filed against him by the Queens County Bar Association,took the witness stand at vesterday's session and denied that he had ever solicited negligence cases or hired a "runner" to do so.

Modification of the P. H. Hanes Knitting Company order announced yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission does not mean that the cornmission on its own initiative will alter all outstanding orders to conform with the Miller-Tydings act, it was learned today.

The marriage of Miss Alethia Brandford Sheldon, daughter of Mrs. Oakley Sheldon of New York and of Dr. William Hills Sheldon of Rome, Italy, to R. Alastair Macleod, son of Mr. And Mrs. Norman Macleod of Sun Court, Hadleigh, Suffolk, England, took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, 170 East Seventy-eighth Street.

Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone halted argument today on a motion for a directed verdict of acquittal for the Gulf companies in the Federal Government's gasoline pricefixing case with the comment, "I've heard enough."
The stock markets here were generally quiet and- weak today, with most sections showing declines. Gilt-edge, issues lost ground, but foreign loans had a good tone.

Emily Post, who says she has written 5,000,000 words about etiquette in the last fifteen years, announced yesterday- that she was struggling with the problem of letting the modern woman pay part of the entertainment check. It is no longer formally outlawed.

A $600,000 mortgage loan for 10 years on the six-story apartment houses recently completed at 245-63 W 23d St and 238-256 W 24th St, has been arranged with the Prudential Insurance Company of America. The Chelsea Land Corp, J. M. Felson, president, is the owner of the building. Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc. were the brokers.

Manchukuo as well as Salamanca will adhere to the German-Italian-Japanese ahti-Comintern pact simultaneously and Manchukuo, still unrecognized herself except by the Dominican Republic, will recognize General Francisco Franco, the newspaper Nichi Nichi reports without quoting its authority.

An application by the Boston Maine Railroad to intervene in a proceeding instituted by the owners of the Ocean Steamship Company of Savannah for authority to operate a steamship line from Boston to New York was granted today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Army's varsity-was at full strength today for the first time this week, with Woodrow Wilson, Charlie Long and Riggs Sullivan in uniform again. A long scrimmage was held, with a punting drill starting the session.
Two freighters have been equipped at Flensburg with periphon devices for recording depths and obstructions by sound. Experiments began today with the Mathias Stinnes.

The appointment of Hugh F. McKenna as Federal Old-Age Insurance representative in New York State, was announced yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, New York Regional Director of the Social Security Board.

Robert W. Searie, general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, was instructed unanimously by more than one hundred members of the Federation, meeting yesterday afternoon at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and

An extra dividend of 10 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share were declared on the common stock of the Scott Paper Company. Dividends of 40 cents each were paid on Sept. and June 15.

As of Sept. 30, the Works Progress Administration registered a cumulative total of $503,681,761 for the purchase of materials, supplies and equipment for WPA projects, Harry L. Hopkins, administrator, reported today.

John Leslie Krauss of Milford, Conn., a sailor on the United States flagship Raleigh, will be married next Tuesday at Villefranche to Mile. Simone Tosello, a young French girl whose home is at Grasse.

Youth is turning with "sincere interest" to religion today and the problem of teaching youth "simple, positive essentials" of religion is a challenge to both the clergy and the laity, the Rev. Alden S. Mosshammer, pastor of the Congregational Church at Old Greenwich, Conn., told members

Lieutenant Marshall Cleland, 25-year-old jumping veteran of the Canadian Army team, won from twenty-eight other competitors tonight in the military touch-and-out stake at the Royal Winter Fair horse show. He rode the aged brown mare Roxanna.

John Holmes, vice president of Swift Co. since 1928, was elected president of the company today at a meeting of the directors. He. succeeds Gustavus F. Swift Jr., son of the company's founder, who was made vice chairman of the board.

Shy in the midst of a dazzling blaze of color for which they were mainly responsible and with their pleased WPA instructor looking on, three diminutive artists from the Bronx took all the prizes last evening at the second annual art show of the Catholic Youth Organization at 353 West Seventeenth Street.

A major change in the Multiple Dwelling Law will be required before the provisions of the new Building Code authorizing the construction of nine-story "non-fireproof" but fire-resistive apartment houses can become effective here, it was learned yesterday.

The Midston House racquet wielders gained undisputed possession of first place in Group 11 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association competition by downing the Crescent Athletic Club, 4-1, on the winners' court yesterday.

Americans who served under British, French or Italian command In the World War renewed old friendships last night at the first meeting of the present season of Les Amis, an organization of these veterans, at the Hotel White, Thirtyseventh Street and Lexington Avenue.

Miss Jean Harder was married to Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan and a secretary to Mayor La Guardia, yesterday afternoon at the home of her father and step-mother, Mr. and Mrs. George Achilles Harder of 510 Park Avenue.

The fingerprinting of all persons, starting with children when they enter school, was proposed yesterday by-Deputy Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell, director of the Police Academy and the crime laboratory of the Police Department.
Branch Rickey, vice president of the Cardinals, made it plain tonight Van Mungo, the Dodgers' hurling ace, will not be wearing a Cardinal uniform next-season.

Contending that the city's plan to acquire a new school site on Ninety-second and Ninety-third Streets between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues would deprive forty owners of private homes of their property, Dr. Robert H. F. Dinegar of 151 West Ninety-third Street wrote to Mayor La Guardia yesterday asking a reconsideration of the plan.
Sales of four homes In Pelham Manor, acreage in Bedford and a residential site in Harrison were reported by Westchester brokers yesterday.
New York University's football team will play eight games next fall; making two trips out of town, it was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager.

Two marked upsets occurred last night in the first knockout round among the sixteen surviving teams in the ninth annual play for the coveted Vanderbilt Cup at contract bridge now going on in the Hotel Ambassador.
After an early decline yesterday that carried December within 10 points of recent low records, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied and ended with losses of 3 to 5 points. All months closed below

Price movements of commodity futures were irregular in -moderate activity on the local Exchanges yesterday. Gains were registered by domestic sugar and rubber futures, but silk and hide futures were sharply lower. In the cash market rubber and butter advanced, while all the grains, flour, cocoa, raw sugar, lard, tins, cotton, silk and hides declined.

Baroness Ise von Dippe, Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. R. Biers, Dr. William Ranz, Colonel and Mrs. Dagoberto Juarez, Mr. and Mrs. Joachim Giesemann and Charles R. Phipps are arriving today from Europe on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland.

Herbert R. Chapman, branch manager of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company at 320 Broadway, New York, died at his home here today at the age of 59. Born in Brooklyn, he had passed most of his younger years in Newark.
Dominion Government deposits with the Bank of Canada dropped $6,101,364 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the bank's statement, but total deposits were up $5,301,744.
A special Senate committee plunged into a comprehensive study of unemployment relief today. The committee decided, said Chairman Byrnes, to determine these facts:

In the third day of the filibuster against the Wagner-Gavagan Anti-Lynching Bill, Senators Bailey of North Carolina, George of Georgia and Pepper of Florida brought out today the first attempt to break the impasse.
Following the recent appeal by Mohandas K. Gandhi to the Viceroy, the Bengal Government announced today that 1,100 detenus--political prisoners--would be released immediately.
Japan's national tennis singles went to a foreigner for the fist time today when Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany defeated Jiro Yamagishi, 7-9, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4.
British marine insurance underwriters made sharp reductions today in war risk rates on shipping both to the Orient and to the Western Mediterranean.

The Tome School football squad of Port Deposit, Md., will come here today to play the Horace Mann School for Boys at Horace Mann Field. The game, slated to start at 2:30 o'clock, will mark the first visit of a Tome team to the metropolitan district.

Mrs. Mary Harris Haff, clubwoman, died on Wednesday night at her home, 37-34 Eighty-fourth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, at the age of 69, after an illness of several months. She also maintained a home at Newton Highlands, Mass.
The Grace Line announced yesterday it's withdrawal from intercoastal shipping operations and the transfer of three ships which it has operated in that trade for several years to the Caribbean.

Coming through three rounds of keen competition, Miss Erna Treiling of the Greco F. A. triumphed in the annual Van Buskirk prep fencing competition staged at the Fencers Club last night by the women's division of the Amateur Fencers League of America.

State and city investigators, spurred by orders from Governor Elmer A. Benson and rewards totaling $11,000, turned to labor strife today in an effort to uncover a clue to the mysterious slaying of Patrick J. Corcoran, union chief.

Stanley A. Sweet, president of Sweet-Orr Co., Inc., received first choice of 119 examples of painting and sculpture last night at the annual drawing at the Grand Central Art Galleries, 15 Vanderbilt Avenue.

The Supreme Court took under consideration today a suit involving the Treasury's effort to escape paying-interest on gold bonds that were called for redemption before their maturity date. Solicitor General Stanley. Reed said that $70,000,000 of called gold bonds were still outstanding and would be affected by the litigation..

Labor's collective bargaining and the payroll tax on industry are tending to add to unemployment rather than reduce it, according to W. W. Bates, Delaware Hudson Railroad personnel official, who spoke last night at the fifth metropolitan conference on employment and guidance of the Welfare Council of New York City in the Htel Pennsylvania.

Charges of graft in the operation of the Los Angeles-Hollywood unit and hints of discord among administrators of the New Deal's theatrical relief network greeted the arrival here of Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, director of the Federal Theatre Project, and her assistant, J. Howard Miller, on the first leg of a country-wide insection tour.

Several thousand Legitimists attended a meeting here tonight celebrating the Archduke Otto's twenty-fifth birthday. The meeting passed without incident, although the police confiscated numerous stench bombs.

The report of the Joint Committee to take a survey of State fiscal policies will not be ready for submission tomorrow, Governor Lehman was informed today by Abbot Low Moffat, chairman. The resolution called for a report to the Governor on Nov. 20.

Aroused by the failure of the National Labor Relations Board to bring adjustment in Portland's lumber industry deadlock business leaders joined forces here today in a conference with Governor Martin to devise a formula by which the grip of industrial paralysis might be broken.

The International Seamen's Union, A. F. of L. affiliate for unlicensed shipping personnel has been designated as the spokesman of the seagoing employes of the Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., it was announced yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board.

The joint drive of the United Hospital Fund and the Visiting Nurse Association in Brooklyn toward a goal of $300,000 has almost reached the midway mark, it was announced yesterday by Carl Whitmore, executive chairman for the borough, at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Bossert.

Mrs. James J. Walker, wife of the former Mayor, is planning to open and operate a flower shop in this city, it was disclosed yesterday. Mrs. Walker confirmed the report at her home in East Seventy-second Street, but said her plans for the project were still in the "embryonic stage."

Constable Charles Fremgen of Beacon Hill, N. J., who was found guilty of extorting $10 from a speeding motorist, and who submitted to Fordham University's "lie detector" only to find that a report-of the examination indicated he had been falsifying when he

The rising tide of opinion against the capital gains tax is at length finding reflection in Congressional action. To determine whether the changes proposed have yet gone far enough, however, it is necessary to recall the objections to the tax as it stands.

A plan to bail out a billion dollars in frozen mortgages in New York State was presented to Federal officials today by State Senator Lazarus Joseph, chairman of the New York State Joint Legislative Mortgage Committee.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 13 amounted to 689,614 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 42,531 cars, or 5.8 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, and 95,366 cars, or 12.1 per cent,

Defining his foreign policy as a continuous effort to prevent such tension as would lead to another war, in which civilization would perish, Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos laid before the Chamber of Deputies this morning a plain statement of what he had tried to do, what he had accomplished and what he proposed to do to keep peace and develop it.

After Representative John J. O'Connor of Manhattan had asked for a delay on final approval for the mid-Manhattan traffic tunnel linking the East River and Hudson River tunnels yesterday, the Board of Estimate deferred action on the proposal until Dec. 10.

James Smith, the "hermit of Silver City," died yesterday, a month to the day after failing eyesight caused him to leave the "ghost town" near Banff that had been his home more than fifty years. He was 86 years old.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York, vacationing at the Hotel Traymore here, has announced three appointments to the New York State Appeal Board of Unemployment Insurance. They are David M. Bressler and Elmer A. Carter of New York City and John E. McGarry of Syracuse.

Coming from behind in the last two minutes of play, the Deerfield Academy football team tied Loomis, 7-7 today. Cold weather made ball handling hard, causing many fumbles, but numerous passes were completed by both sides.

Among the lessees of apartments included in the renting report submitted by brokers and agents yesterday were Alexander Smallens, orchestral conductor, who took a suite in Essex House, 160 Central Park South, and Andy Sannella, radio and dance orchestra leader, who rented quarters in 40 West Fifty-seventh Street, through Payson McL. Merrill Company. Inc.. broker.

Judge Oliver S. Dickinson, in the Federal Court, today granted an additional three months to the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company to submit a reorganization plan of its $95,000,000 business under the Federal Bankruptcy Law. The plan was due today.
A special Cabell County grand jury returned eight indictments today charging three men arrested in the abduction of the Rev. Dr. James I; Seder with kidnapping and murder.

Order of Retirement Under provisions of Subdivision 3 of Seation 354 of the Greater New York Charter as amended by Local Law 43 of 1936, and on police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMEN-Michael Cullinane, 100th Precinct, at $2,250 per annum; appointed July 3, 1928; John L. Toomey, Grand Central Parkway Precinct, at $2,250 per annum; appointed March 6. 1925.

Hester St, 86-88, 58x75.6 1/2x irreg.; Emigrant Bank to 68 E First St Corp, 2 Lafayette 13th St, 702 E, 24.1x109.3; Joseph C. Kenney to City of New York; consideration $1,000, foreclosing tax lien against Mildred Bierman and Enamel Products Co. Inc.

The typhoid epidemic at Croydon, a modern-developed southern suburb of London housing more than 250,000 persons, ??lared up afresh today over a wider area, striking down Lord Rochester and seventeen others just when it was thought the disease had disappeared as mysteriously as it arrived.

The marriage of Miss Louise Lutkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Stephen Lutkins of 1,120 Fifth Avenue, to Robert Le Brecht, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Marston Le Brecht, also of this city, took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Church.

The Count of Covadonga, heir to the former Spanish throne, who arrived in Havana by plane from Miami this morning, expects to fight the present divorce action brought by his Cuban commoner wife, Marta Rocafort, unless some agreement can be reached to obtain the divorce under different circumstances.

Miss Marie Louise Renton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Renton of this place, was married to Charles J. Hodge, son of Howard B. Hodge of East Orange, this evening at the Maplewood Club here. The Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, pastor of Morrow Memorial Church here, officiated.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, which has been working on the problem of rules for the peggoing or stabilization of securities during distribution, expects to formulate its general policy within two or three weeks.

F. E. Sellman, vice president of Servel, Inc., has been appointed treasurer of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers, to succeed the late Donald McDonald, secretary-treasurer of the American Meter Company, who died last month, it was announced yesterday.

To win public confidence business should first educate its own people, its workers, distributors and dealers, and after such a task is accomplished, perhaps educating the public will not be necessary, Edgar Kobak, vice president of Lord Thomas,

One of the most popular players ever to wear a St. Louis baseball uniform, Sunny Jim Bottomley, was out of baseball today. Bottomley, who succeeded another great baseball player, Rogers Hornsby, as manager of the revamped Browns in the middle of last season, was given his unconditional release.

Sergei Rachmaninoff, pianist and composer, played tonight before a capacity audience of 3,500 in the County Center. It was his second appearance here in four years and the concert was the second in the 1937-38 'series arranged by Mrs. Julian Olney for the County Center.

The existing trade agreement between India and Japan, signed in July, 1934, has been extended until March, 1940, it was announced here tonight. After the United States India is Japan's largest customer.

The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen, which renovated the six-story apartment house at 2,001 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, after taking it over in 1933, has sold the property to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators. Occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet, the building contains forty-seven apartments of three, four and five rooms. It is at the northwest corner of 179th Street and was sold through Nathan Strunsky, broker.

Wool prices have been falling continuously for more than six weeks. The average was higher than the 1936 level until the end of October, when it was 14.20d; compared with 14.44d correspondingly last year.

Federal Judge John C. Knox dismissed yesterday an action for triple damages of $3,000,000 brought under the Sherman Anti-Trust Law by the Union Terminal Cold Storage Company against the Erie Railroad Company, the Seaboard Terminal and Refrigeration Company, the City Ice and Fuel Company and Dennis P. Kennedy.
Enthusiasm was at its highest level in ten years today as Colgate and Syracuse supporters gathered for the thirty-ninth football meeting between the two rivals tomorrow in Archbold Stadium.

The body of Sun Yat-sen, "father" of the Chinese Republic and founder of the Kuomintang [Nationalist party], on Purple Mountain, outside Nanking, will be left behind if the capital in which he served briefly as the first President of China more than twenty-five years ago is captured by the Japanese.

Prince Ahmed Self el Din, who in 1898 at Cairo attempted to assassinate his brother-in-law, Prince (afterward King (Fuad because he believed Fuad was ill-treating his sister, died here today at the age of 60.

Dartmouth's unbeaten football team comes to Baker Field today bent on putting another jinx to rout and completing its most successful season since Swede Oberlander passed and ran the opposition dizzy in 1925.
Mrs. Margaret Sellers Brown, who took an active part in the fight for women's suffrage, died at her home in Swarthmore yesterday after a long illness. He age was 68.

Riding into town on the crest of a victory wave that has carried them through their last seven contests without a setback, the Green Bay Packers worked out at the old De Witt Clinton Field yesterday in preparation for their battle with the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds tomorrow.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing of 40,905 shares of $6.50 dividend convertible preferred stock, without par value, and 843,992 shares of no-par common stock of the Anchor Hocking Glass Corporation, which changed its name from Anchor Cap Corporation.

Rowcliffe Black Fury, owned by Walter Lampka and handled by Luke Medlin, won the open all-age stake for Cocker Spaniels today at the meeting of the Monmouth County Spaniel Field Trial Association, held on Frederick Burghard's Big Brook pheasant farm at Vanderburg.
THE BOUGH BREAKS, a play In three acts and five scenes by James Knox Millen; directed by Curtis Cooksey; settings by Raineri; produced by Paul L. Berney and Peggy Cleary. At the Little Theatre.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $5,712,315, to be represented by one State and thirty-three municipalities, compared with the revised total of $19,975,205 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,569,662.
A Spanish Government dispatch asserted government artillery today scored direct hits on an Insurgent staff headquarters at Fuentes de Ebro on the Aragon front.

A decision of the Domestic Relations Court requiring Mrs. Tillie Wagenheim, a widow, to contribute $100 a month toward the support of her daughter, Mrs. Ida W. Fishman, was reversed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division.

Professor Frederic Wood Jones, who will soon leave the Chair of Anatomy at Melbourne University for a similar post at Manchester University, yesterday in a farewell address before the Victorian Anthropological Socity, scathingly indicted Australia's neglect of the aborigines.

Sayville High made it a grand slam in cross-country in Suffolk County by capturing the third annual Edward J. Burlingham Memorial invitation cross-country meet held over the Argyle Lake Park course today.
The German Government distrusts and dislikes the idea of negotiations for a new Anglo-American commercial treaty. Its organs of opinion, however, are avoiding making too sharp an issue of the matter.

Harvard's varsity soccer team broke Yale's string of victories today, winning by 2-1. Harvard pressed the visitors from the opening kick and scored in three minutes when Mendie rammed a shot past Poole. Yale equalized on a solo effort by Erickson and Harden sent the Cambridge team ahead in the second quarter.

The demand was Improved for most classes of locally dressed meats yesterday. Steer hinds and ribs and fresh pork cuts were weak to another $1 lower. Other classes were steady and some strength was shown on lamb carcasses. Early trading in kosher meats Indicated beef to be steady to sharply lower; veal and calf strong,

Common Pleas Judge J. Wallace Leyden told a class of 124 new citizens in Bergen County Naturalization Court today he considered membership in the GermanAmerican Bund sufficient grounds for denying citizenship.

Benjamin Lissberger, chairman of the board of the Federated Metals Division of the American Smelting and Refining Company and leader in the smelting and refining field, died yesterday morning at his home, 270 Park Avenue, after an illness of two weeks. He was 61 years old.

Today's major events: The Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegle Hall in the afternoon; a benefit concert for the Chrystie Street House at Carnegie Hall in the evening, with Elisabeth Rethberg, Thalia Sabanieeva, Jehu E. Hanson, Mario Cozzi, Josephine Antoine, Pino Bontemipi, Serge Jean de La Scase, Fritz Kitzineger and Emilio A. Roxas as artists;

A warning against Jewish "lethargy" in financing the resettlement of Palestine, because of the present "political uncertainty" was sounded by Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, in a message yesterday to American Jewry through the United Palestine Appeal.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company pointed out yesterday that, because of a default in interest on $33,891,000 Wabash Railway first 5 per cent bonds due on May 1, 1939, the bonds might be declared due and payable if a majority of the holders should so elect.

Edward Kelly, a branch circulation manager for The Brooklyn Daily Eagle, was knocked down and stunned by an unidentified assailant yesterday morning as he entered an Eagle branch office at 149 Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn.

A new form of ship propulsion with mercury as the basis of a system which may, if perfected, revolutionize marine engineering, was described yesterday in a paper read before the annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.
