Captain James Vallely, one-time New York detective who captured and saved from a mob Leon Czolgosz, the assassin of President McKinley, died here today. He was 83 years old.

Two tall sycamores, doomed by the WPA, were temporarily saved from the axe today through the efforts of an 81-year-old resident, who had played beneath the trees when he was a boy. Joseph D. Holmes, a New York trade publication columnist, wrote to WPA officials, municipal bodies, police and newspapers urging that the trees be spared.

Changes in the listing of names of personalities in the New York Social Register, for 1938 disclosed yesterday the omission of the Colony Club from the club list following the name .of Mrs.- Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President.

The closest approach to a completely authoritarian State that the Western Hemisphere has yet seen has been established by the Constitution proclaimed in Brazil on Nov. 10 by President Getulio Vargas, an examination of the document discloses. Copies of it reached here today.

Professor James Harvey Robinson, American historian, who died Feb. 16, 1936, left a net estate of $112,480, according to a transfer tax filed yesterday. The principal assets were royalties from histories written by him or in collaboration with others, including potential royalties from unpublished works.

When Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, challenger for the chess championship of the world, won the fourteenth game at Zwolle in the Netherlands, he fulfilled one of the very important conditions which govern the contest for the title which Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam is defending.

Two young Southerners, freshmen among golf's professionals, turned in subpar performances today and tied for first honors in the MidSouth tournament, distancing a starting field of ninety-six pros. Henry Clay Poe of Durham, N. C., fired a 70, two under par, for a tie with E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, who registered a pair of 71's in the thirty-six-hole event.

Curtailment of production of underwear by the equivalent of three to five weeks' shutdown for the fourth quarter of the year is needed unless the industry is to accumulate a surplus stock, the Underwear Institute has advised its members, it was announced yesterday.

Frederick Whittlesey Oliver, Rochester and California lawyer, died yesterday at Sagamore Hotel. Born here, he attended Hobart College. Mr. Oliver's father, William S., was a well-known trial lawyer here. An uncle, Frederick A. Whittlesey, was Prominent in Rochester law.

Normally Australia would view with great concern the possibility of the United Kingdom granting to the United States concessions affecting the United Kingdom market for Australian primary products under the Ottawa agreement,
Assemblyman Irving M. Ives of Norwich, said today that education in American colleges was a failure as far as training for government office was concerned.
Engineering construction awards totaled $34,753,000 for the week ending on Wednesday, a drop of 21 per cent from the same week last year, when the total was $44,158,000,
The stock markets here were generally dull today, but selling eased. Announcement of a proposed Anglo-American trade treaty was reported to have helped check the downward trend.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 15,000, Including 7,000 direct. Market 15-25c lower than Thursday's average. Top $8.20; largely $8-S10 market on weights 150-300 pounds; few butchers 300350 pounds, $7.80-$8. Most packing sows $7.40-$7.65; light weights up to $7.85; shippers 1,500; estimated holdover 1,000.

The stock market experienced yesterday its sharpest decline in exactly one month. Following a fractionally lower opening, stocks moved steadily lower, and the activity increased as prices receded, with the tape sometimes running a few minutes behind the market in reporting transactions.
There will be three authors' programs at the Book Fair in its next-to-last session today: children's authors in the morning and authors for adults in the afternoon and evening.

A warrant for the arrest of D. Gordon Fichter, automobile dealer of Dover and Rockaway, N. -J., was issued here today accusing Fichter of swindling the Mutual Finance Company of Bloomfield by obtaining money on false bills of sale.

Max Weiss, who retired five years ago as president of M. Weiss Son, Inc., a hardware company at 100 Amsterdam Avenue, died Wednesday at his apartment in the Hotel Chalfonte, 200 West Seventieth Street, at the age of 68. Mr.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Peterson Sollers of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Sollers, to the Rev. Duncan Fraser, rector of Saint Columba's Berkeley Memorial Chapel of Middletown and son of the late Donald Fraser and Mrs. Fraser of Johnstown. N. Y.
Charles Louis Sicard, secretary, counsel and trustee of the Roosevelt Savings Bank, Brooklyn, died of a heart ailment yesterday at his country home on Manursing Island, Rye, N. Y.

Samuel Broeder, a prosperous fur dresser of Chicago, made the mistake in 1933 of getting orders from the New York market. The result, he testified yesterday in Federal Court, was that his factory in Chicago was bombed and he was later informed that his troubles would not stop unless he joined the Fur Dressers Factors Corporation.

A total of $6,750, more than double the amount collected in the same period last year, has been received by the church division of the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, which is conducting its twenty-first annual roll-call for membership, it was announced yesterday.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:
Increases of even to 15 per cent in passenger fares of fourteen major shipping lines will take effect Dec. 31, according to member lines of the North Pacific Coast-European Passenger Conference.

C. C. Slusser, vice president of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said tonight that the three plants closed by a sit-down strike would reopen Monday "for those who want to work, in spite of hell or high water."
Rallying in the second period, Penn's junior varsity football team closed its season by defeating the Princeton Jayvees on Franklin Field today, 13-6.

In the last twelve years State taxes on property throughout the country as a whole have shown a tendency to decline, Thomas J. Reynolds writes in a survey of State property tax rates that will be included in "Studies in Current Tax Problems,"

With the same unanimity that had characterized their views the day before in opposing a State measure for the grading of gasoline, representatives of the major oil companies yesterday went on record against State licensing of gasoline stations.

Contracts were signed today by the government with several American mining companies to mine gold at El Jicaral and Santa Rosa in the Department of Leon. American mining engineers have about 400 laborers clearing the jungle and building fifty miles of roads. It is believed the mines are among the richest in Central America.
Secretary Ickes announced today m the disbursement of $6,000,338 to is the States to finance vocational re education under the George-Deen Act, for the six months ending Dec. 31.

No one must starve. Those who cannot work must be provided for by the community if they have no other means of support. Those who can work ought to be given work, for their own sake and for the sake of the community.
SEVEN FOR A SECRET; THE HOUSE IN DORMER FOREST; THE SPRING OF JOY ARMOUR WHEREIN HE TRUSTED. (Dutton, 3 vols., $3 each.) Poems and prose of the Shropshire novelist, in a new illustrated edition.

Cotton-mill activity declined more than seasonally last week and the adjusted index has eased to 105.4 from 107.9, the revised figure for the previous week. The index for the week ended Nov. 14, 1936, was 131.5.

The National Bureau for Blind Artists announced yesterday formation of a committee to conduct a campaign for $50,000 to be used for the organization of a musical unit among 100 or more needy blind musicians.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: It strikes me as very peculiar that college football rule-makers seem to overlook what appears to be a constructive work on the part of professional football.
The will of Francis Patrick Garvan, former United States Alien Property Custodian, who died in New York on Nov. 7, was filed for probate with Surrogate Leone D. Howell here today.

Mr. and Mrs. Amos Tuck French are sailing for California today on the Santa Rosa. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wheelwright of Wilmington are at the SherryNetherland. Mrs. William Price Shreve of Boston is at the New Weston before going to Pasadena, Calif.

With Dick Weisenfluh making both of the New Yorkers' touchdowns, the Barnard School for Boys eleven downed Brunswick School, 12 to 6, today. It was the final game of the season for Barnard, which annexed the M. A. A. P. S. title.

Governor-elect A. Harry Moore certified to the Secretary of State today that he spent all but $229 of contributions totaling $13,690 in the Gubernatorial campaign. Mr. Moore's listed donations did not mention a $5,000 gift which James H. R. Cromwell, mentioned

The Montauk Manor, fashionable Summer hotel at Montauk Beach, was sold by Suffolk County yesterday for unpaid taxes for 1936. It was bid in by A. U. Rodney for the Bonded Municipal Corporation of Manhattan. The taxes, interest and other charges total $6,446.

The eighteen private companies attacking the power program of the Tennessee Valley Authority as unconstitutional scored an important victory today when the three-judge Federal court permitted them to introduce as evidence statements made by Dr. Arthur E. Morgan,

Staffs for the thirteen departmental and college-wide publications at Hunter College have been announced for this semester. Almost 150 students .are working on the college weekly, literary maga-, zine, year book and handbook, foreign language, mathematics and science papers. The staffs are:

Dr. Frederick A. Cook's $25,000 libel suit against the Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., was dismissed yesterday by the Appellate Division in a unanimous decision The court ruled that Dr. Cook was not libeled by the statement that his claim to discovery of the North Pole in 1908 was "universally rejected."

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday that 550 letter carriers, making a check between 5 and 7 P. M. on Thursday, had interviewed 31,000 persons to ascertain whether or not they had filed. unemployment census cards.

Yale's 150-pound eleven climaxed its second straight undefeated season by blanking the Lafayette lightweights, 25-0, on the Bowl gridiron today. The victory for the Elis, defending champions of the intercollegiate league, ties them with Princeton for the title, the Tigers having played them a 6-all deadlock earlier in the campaign.

The official announcement of the opening of negotiations between the United States and the United Kingdom for a trade treaty was warmly welcomed in League of Nations circles as one of the few hopeful signs on the economic and political horizons.

Overconcentration of power in the hands of the Federal Government at the expense of the States was attacked by former Governor Alfred E. Smith last night in an address at a meeting of the Centre Club, an organization of Catholic college graduates, at 120 Central Park South.

Two conflicting price movements stood out prominently in the course of bond trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Domestic corporation obligations, under the leadership of secondary railroad and convertible issues, sank to the lowest price-average levels in more than three years.
Edward F. Cassidy, former vice president of Typographical Union No. 6 and a former Socialist leader, died Thursday night at the New York Hospital. He was 69 years old.
The New York Americans and Ivan (Ching) Johnson finally came to terms yesterday, when the veteran defense star signed with Red Dutton to play with the star-spangled sextet this season.

It was confirmed today that a group of Netherlands banks is negotiating with the French Treasury for a short-term loan of 150,000,000 florins to facilitate repayment by France in December of the British loan of [Pound]40,000,000 to the French railroads.

Miss Helen Weeks Marsh of New York, daughter of Mrs. Norman J. Marsh of Tarrytown, N. Y., formerely of this city, and the late Magistrate Marsh, was married to Paul Davier, son of Mrs. John Davier of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mr. Davier, yesterday morning in the chambers of Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, who performed the ceremony.

Miss Rosemary Finney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick Finney of this city, was married to William Edgar Edmonston 2d, son of Mrs. E. D. Edmonston of Baltimore and the late Mr. Edmonston, this afternoon in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. John J.

A turbuient filibuster against the AntiLynching bill calmed down for twenty minutes today while the Senate listened attentively to a quiet, emotional talk by Mrs. Dixie Bibb Graves, the new Alabama Senator.

Miss Virginia Vogt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph W. Vogt of Montclair, N. J., gave a dinner yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza for her brother, John Vogt, who has returned from a trip around the world.

Six men and two corporations escaped yesterday with suspended sentences in Special Sessions on their guilty pleas in the so-called bogus watch racket, while another offender was fined $50 on the insistence of Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson because he previously had been convicted of a similar offense.

Noteworthy examples of folkmusic were estimably set. forth at the Welsh concert given in Carnegie Hall last night by the Cambrian Male Choir of Cleveland, conducted by William Albert Hughes, and the Welsh Women's Chorus of New York," under Llewellyn Roberts, with Mostyn Thomas, baritone, as soloist.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad petitioned today the Federal Mlstrict Court to approve the sale, free and clear, of pending bonds or liens, of assets of the Penn Anthracite Collieries Company of Scranton, Pa., a subsidiary of the New York, Ontario Western Railroad Company.

The two-family dwelling at 347-49 Columbus Avenue, Harrison, Westchester, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, has been sold by the Troy Trust Company to Angelo Russo for occupancy. Rostenberg Associates, Inc., was the broker.

Henry Armstrong scored another one of his crushing triumphs last night. The Los Angeles Negro, who holds the featherweight championship of the world, knocked out the hitherto undefeated Billy Beauhuld of Jersey City in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden, while a crowd of 15,000 fans looked on.

After twenty years of flying, In which he logged 2,400,000 miles over the airways of the United States, Captain Jack Knight yesterday announced his retirement from the cockpit of a mainliner to become director of "public education" for the United Air Lines.

White, Weld Co., as fiscal agents for City of Cordoba (Argentina) 7 per cent bonds of 1927, due on Aug. 1, 1957, have instituted suit in the Argentine Federal Court in Cordoba to compel the city to comply with the provisions of the fiscal agency agreement with respect to the Aug. 1, 1937, service of the loan.
Employment of Chinese troops in the event of a Russo-Japanee war was mentioned yesterday in an interview at Shanghai between the Italian Ambassador, Giuinno Cora, and General Iwane Mataui.

New Rochelle High won the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association cross-country championship over a wet and soggy Tibbetts Brook Park course today. Jimmy Beckmann, 18-year-old Gorton runner, covered the two and a half mile route in 12:20. clipping two seconds from the standard created last year by Peter Obuhanick, also of Gorton.
The Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania presented its golden jubilee production. "FiftyFifty," at the War Memorial Theatre here tonight.
Defense Minister Edouard Daladier accompanied by the Chief of Staff, General Marie Gustave Gamelin, will go next week to Alsace-Lorraine to inspect the French fortifications on the German border.

Having spent a lifetime hunting and tramping over a certain 5,000acre tract in the Catskills, J. H. Cruickshank has arrived at a conclusion which is shared by many other sportsmen-"it is cheaper to increase game by killing off predatorn than by any method of artificial propagation."
The first snow of the season that amounted to more than a few evanescent flakes fell in the city and in up-State New York and Northern New Jersey yesterday morning.

Two elevens that have been struggling to realize their potentialities over the course of the past month will clash in Princeton University's Palmer Stadium tomorrow before an expected 40,000 spectators as the sons of Old Nassau conclude their 1937 season against the -United States Naval Academy.

The Emigrant Bank sold to the 68 E 1st St Corp, Paul Demartini, president, at a price shown as $36,500, the premises at 86-88 Hester St, taking back a purchase money mortgage for $36,421 together with a building loan mortgage for $26,100, or so much as may be advanced at any time, both due on demand.

After he had warned that "unhappy surprises of terrible gravity" might be in store, following the discovery of a reported plot by a secret society known as "Les Cagoulards" [the Hooded Ones] against the State, Premier Camille Chautemps and his Cabinet obtained a 399-to-160 vote of confiaence in the Chamber of Deputies this evening.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr. was criticized yesterday in Supreme Court for continuing to collect his $15,000 a year salary as president the Brooklyn Bridge Freezing and Cold Storage Cbmpany during the last four years while he has been serving the city as Commissioner of Public Markets.

Kurt Robltschek, theatrical producer, In RKO Building, Rockefeller Center. New York Ecclesia Bible Students Associtation, Benday Foot Appliances and Anthony De Francisci, sculptor, in 1,941 Broadway; Charles F. Noyes Co., broker. Frederick P. Victoria, interior decorator, In 32 E 57th St; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens. Inc.. brokers.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it was learned today, is prepared to invest dollar for dollar with building material supply companies and other private business interests in the capital of giant home-building and financing associtations.

Third annual bird exhibition of the Bird Fanciers Association opens at the Waldorf-Astoria at 10 A. M. today and continues tomorrow. League for Political Education, the Town Hall, 11 A. M. "Current Books and Plays," William Lyon Phelps. Installation of a bronze plaque in memory of the late Robert E. Simon

Mrs. George Grant Snowden of Highland Hall, this place, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Snowden, to John Krumbhaar Peet, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Creighton Peet of Rye, N. Y.

A daughter who is backing strikers in her father's plant was revealed yesterday when the United Paper Workers, Local 202, C. I. O., announced that Anna Warshaw had contributed $20 to their strike fund and had promised to join the picket lines at the Warshaw Manufacturing Company, Inc., 1 Main Street, Brooklyn.
Stocks closed weak with losses of 1 to 7 points in broadest market since Oct. 29; turnover, 1,886,900 shares. Bonds more active and, except United States Government issues, lower;
Colonel Benjamin B. Hyer, U.S.A. (retired), died today in the Letterman General Hospital at the Presidio of San Francisco at the age of 66, according to the War Department.

Those sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian motor ship Conte di Savoia include Captain and Mrs. C. W. Lawson, Mrs. Robert Woods Bliss, Mrs. Dorothy Page, W. O. Bass, Mrs. Hannah Harris and Mrs. Elizabeth Mitchel.

Delegates to the thirty-fifth annual convention of the American Automobile Association launched yesterday a vigorous attack on the three major enemies of motorists and motoring in the United States--excessive taxation, diversion of taxes and the increasing accident toll.

A short railroad of the type which is tending to disappear from the field of transport has been transferred to James Stokes of Denver, it was announced yesterday by Clarence Blair Mitchell of Choate, La Rocque, Mitchell Ely.

An accord was signed today giving inland Bolivia an outlet through Argentina for her potentially rich oil deposits. The way for the agreement with Argentina was cleared when the Bolivian Government recently canceled oil concessions in isolated Eastern Bolivia held by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

BOSTON COLLEGE vs. Boston University-Coach Gil Dobie of the Boston College Eagles has had his troubles. Who hasn't? Consult the records as far back as Christopher Columbus. He was the victim of an illegal shift. He discovered the country and it was named after a fellow who came along eleven years later. On a delayed pass, one vote for Boston College.
President Juan Demostenes Arosemena received the credehtials today of the Spanish dramatist Jacinto Grau as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of Loyalist Spain.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Elizabeth Campbell, daughter of Mrs. Alexander Carlyle Campbell of 363 Parkside Avenue, Brooklyn, and the late Mr. Campbell, to Robert Lethbridge Foshay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Addison Youngs Foshay, also of Brooklyn, took place last night in the Reformed Dutch Church of Flatbush. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. J. Frederic Berg.

Leon Trotsky, who spent eighteen months in Norway as a refugee before going to Mexico, has agreed to pay 2,000 kroner in settlement of tax claims of Norderhov County, Norway, it was reported yesterday by the Oslo correspondent of the Norwegian News, 4,808 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

On the night of Aug. 7 a young man and his 2-year-old son, walking in a street of Lowell, Mass., were struck by an automobile and instantly killed. The wife and mother, seriously injured, is still under a physician's care.

Turpentine firm, 27 1/4c; sales, 36 barrels; receipts, 251 barrels; no shipments; stock, 38,399 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 404; receipts, 1,299; no shipments; stock, 85,491. Quote: B. D. E. $5.65; F, $6.05; G, H. I, K, $6.10; M, $6.15; N, $6.20; WG, $6.60; WW, X, $6.90.

A near-capacity audience oZ 2,000 persons attended the opening concert of the fifty-second season of. the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Brooklyn last night at the Academy of Music. Dr. Serge Koussevitzky marked the beginning of his twelfth season as conductor in Brooklyn by offering Haydn's Symphony in G major and the Second symphony of Sibelius. Jacques' Fevrier,

The marriage of Mrs. Peggy Mapes Goodwin of 310 East Seventy-fifth Street, daughter of Mrs. Clive Spencer Mapes of Short Hills, N. J., and this city and the late Mr. Mapes, to Howard E. Silberstein, Assistant Industrial Commissioner of New York State, took place yesterday afternoon in the chambers of Supreme Court Justice Charles Poletti, who performed the ceremony.

Although new bond financing this week for the second consecutive period was restricted to tax-exempt issues, the appearance of $25,000,000 of Federal Home Loan Bank threeyear 2 per cent consolidated debentures lifted the total volume of new loans on the market to $38,721,500.

Tomorrow will be the annual Sunday for the interchange of preachers between Canada and the United States along the border from the Atlantic to the Pacific. The interchange will be sponsored by the World Alliance for International Friendship through the churches.

In a last minute climax Harold S. Vanderbilt and his partner, by cautious bidding and deliberate play' of the cards, led their team into the semi-final round at contract-bridge of the ninth annual tournament for the Vanderbilt Cup in the Hotel Ambassador last night.

Twelve oil paintings by American artists acquired by gift and purchase during the current year by the Newark Museum have -been placed on exhibition there for the first time. The center of the exhibit is Joseph Stella's five-panel mural called "New York Interpreted.". Robert Brackman's "Mask," is a still life.

William Henry Leonard Edwards, former assistant district attorney ofNew York City, a descendant of Jonathan Edwards and a brotherin-law of Henry L. Stimson, former Secretary of State, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 67 years old.

Striking under the cover of night, a band of New York University students attempted to "kidnap" the Fordham mascot, Rameses VII, last night as a challenge to the Maroon football team, which the Violets will meet next Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.

The French stabilization fund has engaged $10,000,000 more gold here for shipment abroad today on the liner Champlain, it was learned yesterday. The export, which was arranged through the Federal stabilization fund in Washington under the terms of the tripartite agreement, follows a shipment of $10,250,000 to France, which was announced by the Treasury on Nov. 8, and one of $5,000,000 to England, which was announced a few days later.

Payments of dividends by receivers of thirteen insolvent National banks, among them the Salt Springs National Bank of Syracuse, N. Y., were authorized by the Controller of Currency in the week ended yesterday, according to an announcement today.

The New York City school system has made arrangements to conduct a "school of the air." Starting on Tuesday morning there will be weekly broadcasts on various cultural, social and academic subjects to 1,145,000 pupils attending the public schools, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

Robert Hill, retired manufacturer of housing materials, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 2,451 Devoe Terrace, the Bronx, at the age of 82. Mr. Hill was born in Scotland and came to this country when he was 27.

The. War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 18: COLONEL Woodruff, W. S., Inf., Shreveport, La., two months and one day leave, Dec. 27: to retirement on Feb. 28, upon his own aPplication.

World Art, Inc., the organization recently formed for patronage of art by Julius Fleischmann, Cincinnati sportsman and world traveler, has purchased for production here the Monte Carlo Ballet Company of Rene Blum, brother of Leon Blum, French Vice Premier, it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.

A demand that the State Department make an explanation of a published report that William C. Bullitt, Ambassador to France, has gone to Poland to advise that country against joining the anti-Comintern pact came today from Senators

The bodies of the Grand Duke Ernst Ludwig of Hesse bei Rhein and four members of his family killed in an Ostend plane accident were borne in state to the ducal mausoleum through crowded streets today.
A wave of criminal activity in Sicily, similar to that of the Mafia before its suppression, was disclosed today with the arrest of eighty persons.

Ferdinand, to explain him in his author's own words, is "the story of a Spanish bull that refused to go into the arena to fight--so they had to send him back home, where he settled down again to smelling the flowers."

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 802.000 bales, against 781,000 a week ago, 769,000 two weeks ago, 771,000 three weeks ago and 823,000 a year ago; of which .American 362,000 bales, against 335,000 a week ago, 336,000 two weeks ago, 323,000 three weeks ago and 306,000 a year ago.
Manhattan 7th Ave, 2,619, 170x75; for 1 and 2 story auditorium; Board of Transportation, City of New York, owner; W. S. Lewis, architect; cost $189,000.

The New York City Christian Endeavor Union will celebrate its Golden Jubilee today with a convention in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, beginning at 2:30 P. M. and including a supper and mass meeting at 7:30 P. M.

A 20-monthold dog tonight captured the richest money stake for dogs in the world. The $1,000 Big Four Novice Stake, sponsored by the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England was won by the black cocker spaniel Blackstone's Reflector, owned by Mrs. Leonard Buck of Far Hills, N. J., and handled in the ring by Bain Cobb.

The Municipl Committee for the Relief of Home Owners, formed here in 1934 to assist distressed owners in solving their mortgage difficulties, is preparing to close its five offices next week due to retrenchment in WPA activities, it was learned yesterday.

The Horace Mann School eleven was overpowered by the Tome School team of Port Deposit, Md., 25-0, at Horace Mann Field yesterday. The game, played through a steady rain, was the final one of the year for the New Yorkers.

Mrs. A. R. Demory of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Florence Virginia Demory, to Robert Moulton Coles Raetze of Santa Barbara. The bride-elect is the daughter of the late A. R. Demory and a granddaughter of Mrs. Stephen L. Selden of Greenwich, Conn.,

Shirley Yarfitz of 701 West 175th Street was named the prettiest girl at City College by Peter Arno, cartoonist, and Arthur Murray. Miss Mr Yarfitz has in this way earned the privilege of presiding as queen atthe annual House Plan Carnival at the college tonight.

Unbeaten Hun School of Princeton, N. J., defeated the La Salle Military Academy eleven today, 16-13, in a contest which saw the lead change hands three times. The winners took the advantage in the second period when Bob McDonnough blocked a kick on the 3-yard line and the ball rolled into the end zone for an automatic safety.
Charges of discrimination in WPA trucking contracts in New York City were put before Works Progress Administrator Harry L. Hopkins today by three New York City Congressmen.
James Cerribelli of the New York A. C. eliminated J. J. Reynolds of the Columbia University Club in an Eastern Squash Racquets Associtation third-round match at the New York A. C. yesterday.

Lehigh and Lafayette, with about 12,000 fans as witnesses, will forge tomorrow another link in the football chain that reaches back fiftythree years. Rivals since 1884, when Lafayette won, 34--4, the ancient foes face each other again at Lehigh's Taylor Stadium in what is one of America's oldest and longest gridiron rivalries.

The engagement of Miss Frances Stuart Turner to John Bauer Diefenbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Diefenbach of this place, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Turner of Laconia, N. H. The wedding will take place in December.

The government has accepted with minor reservations the United States' proposal for settling Norway's claim of $69,000,000 for damage sustained by Christopher Hannevig, a Norwegian citizen, through requisition of his American shipyards and shipbuilding contracts for war purposes in 1917.

NEW CHAPTERS IN NEW TESTAMENT STUDY, by Edgar J. Goodspeed (Macmillan, $2). This book comprises the 1937 Ayer Lectures, a series given annually at the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School. In his first chapter, Dr. Goodspeed examines New Testament literature in an attempt to answer the question "Were these writings intended for private use or to be published?"
Frank G. Raichle, counsel for the City Council Investigation Committee, stated today that Federal Attorney George L. Grobe would be summoned to testify in the committee's inquiry into city payrolls.

Frank C. Lowe, who has been resident manager of Hillside Homes, the 1,415-family housing development at Wilson Avenue and Eastchester and Boston Post Roads, in the Bronx, since its completion over two years ago,

Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for this year, and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and a former recipient of this honor, advocated yesterday forceful methods of peace enforcement in the face of current world events.

The Hudson Savings Bank sold to John Ostrowski the six-family flat at 150 St. Paul's Avenue, near Perry Street, Jersey City. It took back in. part payment a purchase-money mortgage for $7,500, due Jan. 1, 1943, at 5 per cent.

Eight parcels of Manhattan realty were sold in the Vesey Street salesrooms yesterday and the sale of a ninth parcel was adjourned until a later date. The plot on the east blockfront of Seventh Afenue from Nineteenth Street to Twentieth.
Vivian Frank Gable, a member of the Municipal Court bench for six years, died of a heart attack tonight while at the wheel of his automobile.

Women will direct but will not monopolize the hospitality center of the World's Fair of 1939, according to an announcement yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the exposition, which indicated that the building would. be one of the major structures.

Hurlbut W. Smith, president of the L. C. Smith and Corona Typewriters, Inc., Syracuse, N. Y., receeived compensation of $50,260 last year, the company reported today to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Prices of commodity futures for the most part were lower in fairly active trading on the local markets yesterday. Tin, domestic sugar and zinc futures were exceptions to the lower trend, recording slight gains. In the cash market raw sugar, butter, tins and cotton advanced, but all the grains, flour, cocoa, lard, silk, wool tops, rubber and hides declined.

New rules governing sails to fit the modern rigs of racing yachts were adopted last night at the meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union, held in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Fortyfourth Street.

Many parties were given at the annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Alice Hall Ali Memorial Fund of the Prosperity Shop last night in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis. Divertissements by professional entertainers were presented. The organization distributes milk daily to 500 children.

Thomas Craddock Hughes, counsel for the trustees in reorganization of the Prudence Company, Inc., and Thurman Hill, chairman of the reorganization division of the Treasury Department, yesterday informed Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the Federal court in Brooklyn that an agreement had been reached compromising at $475,000 tax claims of the government against the Prudence Company.

The Jefferson Personal Finance Corporation of New York has applied to the State Banking Department for authority to change the location of its place of business from 1,405 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, to 1,303 Flatbush Avenue. The change is to be effective, if granted, on Dec. 15.

Miss Charlotte Gerhard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Pepper Gerhard of Overbrook, was married this afternoon to Thomas Raeburn White Jr., son of Thomas Raeburn White of Penllyn and this city. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard T. Lyford, rector, in St. Asaph's Church, Bala-Cynwyd.
The Duke of Windsor's libel action against William Heinemann, the publisher, and Geoffrey Dennis, the author, of "Coronation Commentary," has been settled privately.
Hotel men, theatre managers and taxicab owners rubbed hands tonight in anticipation of one of their biggest week-ends since the depression, the attraction being tomorrow's Harvard-Yale football game.

The Wesley Methodist Episcopal Church, a fifty-year-old frame structure on Lewis Street near Hudson Street here was destroyed by fire this evening. Only the walls and steeple remained standing and the loss was placed at $50,000 by Fire Chief Ellsworth Kocher. The building was partly insured.

Stuart Chase, economist, who launched Consumers Research to protect the consumers of goods, said here last night he was making "the first public suggestion ofantheir research organization, this time to protect the consumers of words."

The General Electric Company yesterday declared a final dividend for this year of $1 a share on the outstanding common stock, payable on Dec. 20 to holders of record of Nov. 26. The company stated that an estimate has been made of its income for 1937, upon which basis the final dividend was declared.

Miss Alice Chilton Ives, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Holmes Ives of this city, was married this evening to Walter Sherman Whitesone of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George William Whitestone at the home of her parents here. The Rev.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Demand for wool on Summer Street continues meager. The necessity of waiting until surplus stocks of goods and clothing have been liquidated more fully, before business in wool can get back to normal,

Dr. Thomas H. Norton, 86-Year-old research chemist and writer, received the Lavoisier Medal of the Societe Chimique de France at a meeting last night of the American section of the Societe de Chimie Industrielle in Havemeyer Hall, Columbia University. Comte de Ferry de Fontnouvelle, French Consul General, made the presentation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES is to be congratulated on its editorial "How to Fix Utility Rates." There are two points in particular to which I wish to refer: the statement that in competitive enterprises the profit or loss is not determined either by actual investment or cost of reproduction, and the emphasis on the economic factor of ability to attract necessary capital.

In a statement issued yesterday Nicolas G. Tserepis, Consul General for Greece, described the recent press notices concerning the suits instituted by depositors against the National Bank of Greece and its subsidiary, the Hellenic Bank Trust Company, as misleading, and explained the procedure relative to the conversion into drachmas of deposits in those banks in foreign currency or foreign exchange.

The Senate heard today that the number of lynchings was related to the price of cotton. Senator Pepper of Florida, urging action on farm legislation while talking against the antilynching bill, declared that when the price of cotton had been low in recent years the number of lynchings increased.

The following tables show the latest Council returns in the boroughs of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. The Bronx returns, because of court actions, have been held up and the first count has not been completed. In Richmond the count was completed early in the week with Frederick Schick, Democrat, elected as the borough's sole Councilman.

In two bursts of speed, Captain George E. T. Eyston of England broke the world land speed mark for the measured mile today, driving his "Thunderbolt" over the distance at an average speed of 311.42 miles an hour.

Death sentences are asked by the prosecutor for three school teachers, one a woman, among eleven whose trial as "wreckers" has just been concluded in Leningrad. One of the three is the director of a nursery school near Leningrad and all the other defendants are members of his staff. Long prison terms are asked for the eight others.

The Jeptha Abbott Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution gave its annual Autumn ball for the benefit of local charities and the under-privileged mountain children at the Tamassee and Kate Duncan Smith Schools tonight in the Bellevue-Stratford ballroom.

Nathan Straus, Federal Housing Administrator, declared tonight it was his determination "to lease the socalled Federal projects, which the Authority inherited from the PWA housing division, to local housing Authorities as quickly as possible."

Weskness In Seeurities was largely responsible for a sharp break in the wheat market today. Fairly general liquidstion by holders of future contracts developed on, the way down, and at no time did the market show a pronounced disposition to rally.

If their debut performance can be accepted as typical of what is to come, the Bronx Tigers will make their presence felt quite keenly in the Eastern amateur hockey league. With 5,000 on hand for the inaugural ceremonies at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx sextet played through seventy minutes of hard hockey with the veteran New York Rovers last night.

Prospect Ave (10-2681), w s, 30 ft s of 168th St. 37x105: Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum to Fannie Fenster, 520 Rosedale Ave. 178th St, 933 E (11-3127); Edgar C. Spivey to Edmund A. Department store sales in the metropolitan area showed a dedine of 4.1 per cent for the first half of this month, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. New York and Brooklyn stores alone had a decrease of 3.4 per cent, while the sales of Northern New Jersey establishments were off 7.4 per cent.

Contributions totaling $639,000, an increase of $322,000 since the Nov. 5 meetings, were announced yesterday morning by the Women's Division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities at the progress report at the Plaza Theatre, Fifty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue.

In the ninth annual pistol competition between teams of the attendants and night guards of the Metropolitan Museum of Art held yesterday at the museum, the attendants won by 23 points. Each team was composed of five men.

Representative Martin Dies of Texas denounced the original Wages and Hours Bill In the House today, and was cheered by members when he called upon Congress to assert its independence of the White House.

HALF a dozen years ago enthusiastic Americans in coveys began rolling down to Mexico. They were in search of pastoral paradises wreathed in hibiscus, rampant with folkways and bathed in sunlight and tequila. They were emigres from panic. They wanted to see the great murals of Siqueiros, Orozco and Rivera,

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics, working under the direction of Major Garland Williams, arrested thirty-eight persons. last night in raids here and in other cities. The prisoners were believed to include the leaders of a nationwide narcotic ring.

While Albert T. Marinelll, County Clerk and a powerful Tammany district leader, maintained silence in the face of an order from Governor Herbert H. Lehman that he answer Thomas E. Dewey's charge that he

Willis Sharpe Kilmer's Nedayr, winner of the Walden Handicap and Pimlico Futurity and rival to Menow for the juvenile championship, will not be trained for the Kentucky Derby of 1938, it became known here today.

While Cardinal Hayes has within the realm of his archdiocesan authority requested that there should be no public celebration of his birthday, he cannot forbid the gratitude, devotion and good wishes that will rise to the hearts of millions not only within but beyond the boundaries of his eminent office.
Because of her outstanding work in "Wells Fargo," Paramount will cofeature Frances Dee with Randolph Scott in one of the studio's more imposing epics of the season, "Marching Herds," by Paul Sloan.

Renewing a football rivalry 46 years old, California's undefeated Bears and Stanford's Indians play their annual battle tomorrow in a smashing climax to the Pacific Coast Conference title race and the scramble for the Rose Bowl bid.

The Galloping Gaels of St. Mary's, a potential powerhouse that never has realized on that potentiality throughout a disappointing season, will serve as the penultimate barrier to Fordham's hopes to stay unbeaten and a Rose Bowl invitation this afternoon when the twice-beaten Californians clash with the undefeated Rams before some 40,000 fans at the Polo Grounds.

The National Industrial Traffic League, a shippers' organization, went on record today at its annual convention as favoring continued support of the Pettengill bill, which would repeal the long-and-short-haul provisions of the present Interstate Commerce Law.
Men who do not like their wives' hats gained a convert today in Vice President Garner. He took one look at the high crown of Mrs. Garner's new hat and said: "It makes you look like a flapper."

Two obstacles that have delayed the completion of the first count of the proportional representation ballots in the City Council election in the Bronx were overcome late last night when Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler signed an order "as justice may require,"

The Harvard junior varsity football team closed Its season today by beating the Yale Jayvees, 13 to 6. It was the first defeat of the season for any of Yale's four teams, varsity, jayvee, freshmen and 150pound.

Police Headquarters yesterday was advised of the death last night of former Police Lieutenant Raphael Schulum at his home at 2,470 University Avenue, the Bronx, after a stroke last Sunday. He was in his sixty-seventh year.

Members of the Association of American Railroads met here today and completed plans for the campaign that they will wage before the Interstate Commerce Commission for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates and an upward adjustment in passenger fares.

This country is wiping out the sources of taxation and preventing the building up of new sources by a policy of confiscation, John A. Riggins of Haddonfield, president of the New Jersey Utilities Association, said today in an address at the opening

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn by a 4-to-1 decision affirmed yesterday the conviction of Martin Schlossman and Harry Weiss for the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel in a plot to force him to confess the abduction of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr.

The first official action was taken today against a British ship for alleged violation of the act forbidding the carriage of arms to Spain. The act was passed by the British Government in support of its policy of non-intervention in Spain.
Hugh Lee Kirby, president of the Wyoming-Montana Company, a mining and lumber concern, died Thursday at his home, 45 Prospect Place in Tudor City, after a brief illness. His age was 58.

The annual Sophomore Hop at New Jersey College for Women was held tonight in the Bee Hive, Science Building, and was attended by 150 couples. Miss Carol Fiers of West Orange was chairman. The hop was the first formal dance of the college year.
Reports, still incomplete, of the damage wrought by the typhoon which swept the central Philippines

Edward Furman, 19 years old, who appeared as Spit in a road company of "Dead End," refused aid yesterday in obtaining work but promised Magistrate Anna M. Kross in Women's Court that he would no longer annoy Millicent Green, the actress with whom he had appeared in the play. Magistrate Kross adjourned the case for two months.

President Manuel L. Quezon a few days ago significantly hinted that, if "some one else" made such a proposal, he might consider on behalf of his country the substitution of dominion status for complete independence.

Rejecting the demands of officials of the United Automobile Workers of America that they evacuate the General Motors plant and return to work, 500 sit-down strikers remained in possession of the Fisher Body Division unit here tonight.

Retail trade here fell off quite sharply this week, the decrease for the week being the largest for many weeks past. Store executives put the decline at 9 to 10 per cent under the corresponding week last year.
Ambassador Robert W. Bingham sailed for home without advance notice aboard the Manhattan today as a result of a recurrence of the malaria from which he has suffered periodically.
It will be rather hard on Mme. Magda de Fontanges if she is excluded from the United States because she plans "to

A new verse play for radio, "Georgia Transport," by John Williams Andrews, author of "Prelude to Icaros" (Farrar Rinehart), will be given over WABC tomorrow night at 8 o'clock under the direction of Irving Reis. This is the first verse play for radio since Archibald MacLeish's "The Fall of the City" was produced under the same direction last April.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls opened their Eastern Amateur Ice Hockey League campaign tonight with a 5-to-1 victory over the Hershey Bears, 1936 champions, before a crowd of 10,000. Hal Dewey, right wing, led the Sea Gulls attack with two goals. Tony Grabowski chalked up the visitors' lone tally.
Dr. Allen Roy Dafoe, the Canadian physician who attended the Dionne quintuplets at their birth, received a warm welcome, yesterday from members of the Board of Estimate when he visited City Hall.

Dr. Walter V. Brem, former army medical chief, died last night at his home here at the age of 62. Born in Charlotte, N. C., Dr. Brem was educated at the University of North Carolina and Johns Hopkins.

Just what moral turpitude is becaine a subject of debate yesterday when James D. C. Murray, New York attorney, armed with a writ of habeas corpus, appeared before Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum with Magda de Fontanges, French actress, whom he had rescued temporarily from Ellis Island.

I dreamed there came a white deer driven Down a dark wood pursued by men; Hounds bayed among the trees and bracken And fiercely ran and leaped again. So near the menace dogged his heel, He gave a thin and derelict cry, Goaded by fear and pierced by steel, And well he knew that he must die.
Labor unions throughout the nation sent pledges of aid to union headquarters here today as investigators of the slaying of Patrick J. Corcoran questioned two unnamed Chicago men.

Evidence is accumulating that France is laying plans to pay in full or in large part the [Pound]40,000,000 ($200,000,000) credit that it obtained from banks in London some time ago and will mature next month. The credit comes due in five equal installments of [Pound]8,000,000 each between Dec. 2 and 26.

MANHATTAN ALLEN, ROSE (Nov. 1). Estate, less than $5,000. To Nellie Hickson, daughter, executrix, 46 Canal St. FRANKENHEIMER, FANNY E. (Nov. 14). Estate, more than $10,000. Representative Robert F. Rich, Republican, of Pennsylvania, suggested to the House today a list of government agencies for abolition as. part of the Administration's proposal for reorganization and consolidation.

The effect of commercial television on advertising will be as farreaching and revolutionary as its influence on entertainment and education, according to Fred H. Fidler of the J. Walter Thompson Company,

Stressing the need for a "pay-as-you-go" policy to finance relief, William godson, Public Welfare Commissioner of New York City, urged upon the National Municipal League today a broadening of the income tax base together with increased rates in the higher brackets as one means to achieve this end.
Italian observance of the second anniversary of the imposition of sanctions by the League of Nations has a decided bearing on the problem oppressing delegates to the Brussels conference.

The Crescent A. C. remained undefeated and retained league leadership in the metropolitan interclub squash tennis series by scoring another victory last night. The 3-to-2 triumph over the City A. C. was the fourth of the season for the Crescents.
President Roosevelt asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate high prices of commodities, but remained in seclusion in the White House recovering from his illness.

The Bank of the Republic continues to be the sole authorized buyer of gold and foreign exchange by decree issued by the President under temporary legislative powers granted by Congress to meet the crisis resulting largely from the removal of the limitation on coffee exports by Brazil.

Paul V. Gunning, who was in charge of the sale of certificates of the State Title and Mortgage Company in 1932 and 1933, testified yesterday as a government witness at the trial of four former officers of the company who are accused of mail fraud and conspiracy.

De Witt Clinton, banker and lawyer, great-grandson and namesake of the New York Governor who was largely responsible for construction of the Erie Canal, died in Buffalo General Hospital this afternoon.
Acquittal of James H. Rand Jr. and Pearl L. Bergoff at New Haven, Conn., on charges of violating the Byrnes Anti-Strike Breaking Act spurred Justice Department efforts today to amend the statute.

The report of operations of the Italian Superpower Corporation for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net loss of $503,960, compared to a net loss of $735,460 in the twelve months to Sept. 30, 1936. For the third quarter of this year the corporation had a net loss of $177,412, against a net loss of $195,772 in the September quarter of last year.

John Walter Galloway of Severna Park, Md., formerly of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad and for years prominent in the coal trade, died Wednesday while visiting friends in Jersey City. He was 64 years old.

A decline of $2 a-bale from last week's best levels attracted more support, and prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday to end unchanged to 2 points higher. Despite weakness in the stock market and active pre-notice

The Tennessee, Alabama Georgia Railway Company, a Delaware corporation, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to acquire and operate the Tennessee, Alabama Georgia Railway, a Georgia corporation, operating 94.62 miles of road between Chattanooga, Tenn., and Gadsden, Ala.

Senate investigators heard today that books and records which they had subpoenaed from the Constitutional Education League of New Haven, Conn., were in the back seat of an automobile touring the Midwest.

Net profit of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and subsidiaries for the quarter ended on Sept. 30 amounted to $420,486 after depreciation, interest and discount charges and estimated normal Federal income taxes, but before Federal surtax on undistributed profits and exclusive of profits earned in foreign countries having exchange restrictions, according to a report issued yesterday.

Police Chief Leo Lunney reported tonight. that he had made no progress in explaining the origin and purpose of the infernal device found yesterday morning in the rear compartment of an automobile owned by Herman Secor, 35-yearold truck driver, of 36 West Street, Spring Valley.

AMNHATTAN ALLEN, FREDERIC W. (Nov. 25, 1933). Gross assets, $448,752; net, $281,761. To Irene Catlin Allen widow, household, personal effects, real property appraised at $159,250 and one-half residue; Justine Allen Eaton; Irene Allen Grant and Martha E. Allen, children, succeeding estate in one-third of $115,901 each and life estate in one-sixth residue each; one other bequest.

Manhattan's football team will conclude its home schedule today when it engages a dangerous Niagara eleven at Ebbets Field. More than 12,000 fans are expected to witness the contest, which the Jaspers expect to win and thus establish themselves as the best team in the football annals of the school.

Retailers must pay their wholesale liquor bills by the tenth of the month following the month in which the liquor purchase or delivery is made, according to a new rule adopted yesterday by the New York State Liquor Authority at its fortnightly meeting in its offices 450 Lexington Avenue.

A new co-operative community to be made up of homesteads which will be at least partially self-sustaining, and which will be modeled after Ralph Borsodi's School of Living colony at Suffern, N. Y., will be started next week at West Nyack.

More than eight hundred students and guests attended the first joint concert and dance given off the campus by the Columbia University and Barnard College Glee Clubs last night In the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.

More than eight hundred students and guests attended the first joint concert and dance given off the campus by the Columbia University and Barnard College Glee Clubs last night In the Grand Ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.
The bluebloods of the world of cats paraded in scrubbed and shining splendor all day yesterday at a combined show of two cat societies and a mouse and rat club.
Further modifications of the corporate undistributed profits tax to aid private business were decided upon today by the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Taxation.

The Federal Government blocked temporarily today the effort of the Asbury Park Beachfront Commission to force the City Council to turn over approximately $198,000, covering the commission's current budget.

The marriage of Mrs. Susan Kronthal Koshland, daughter of Mrs. Leon H. Kronthal of this city and the late Mr. Kronthal, to Dr. Mortimer W. Rodgers, also of New York, took place last night at the home of the bridegroom's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Rodgers of 50 East Seventy-seventh Street.

Anxious that Bermuda should not be overlooked in a Britain-United States trade agreement, the Assembly sent a message to the Governor today stating that it was prepared to make financial provision for a representative of the colony to consult with the Colonial Secretary regarding negotiations.
The much discussed visit of Viscount Halifax to Chancellor Hitler is over. Although it was the basis of so many vivid imaginings in advance its known result tonight is a blank.

Presdent Roosevelt was reported today "coming along all right" after the extraction of an abscessed tooth yesterday. However, Dr. Ross T. McIntire, the President's doctor, who said he "did not want to take any chances," kept him in the White House all day.

Tonight's arrivals are threefold. At the Ambassador Theatre the Abbey Theatre Players are terminating the run of "The Far-Off Hills" after the matinee and some four hours later will present a double bill-J. M. Synge's "The Playboy of the Western World" and "In the Train," by Frank O'Connor and Hugh Hunt.

Industrial production slackened last week in many lines, and brought further declines in the rate of gain in both wholesale and retail sales over those of a year ago, according to the weekly trade review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet Inc.

Due to the strong domestic demand, exports of iron and steel products from Germany during September amounted to 269,699 metric tons, compared with 305,092 metric tons during August, while imports increased to 99,518 metric tons from 86,055 tons in August, according to a report from Cologne made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, will preach the sermon of the thank-offering service under the auspices of the Women's Missionary Society tomorrow evening in the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour's Atonement, Bennett Avenue and West 189th Street.

Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Brazil, will be married in the Cardinal's Palace tomorrow to Gertrude McCarthy of Chicago, who arrived yesterday from the United States. This will be the first time in twenty years, barring the short stay of Ambassador Gibson, that an American woman had presided over the American Embassy here.

A separate title setting up rigid control of cotton acreage and marketing by means of penalty taxes againstunauthorized production was written into the administration-sponsored farm bill today by a Senate Agriculture subcommittee, with indications that the proposal will be adopted by the full committee tomorrow.

After three rounds of hurdling left them tied for top honors, Lieutenant Scott M. Sanford of the United States Army team and Commandant H. de Menten de ?? of Belgium tossed a coin to decide first and second- places in the $500 military. jumping stake at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight.

Chief draftsman, $2,600 a year: principal draftsman, $2,300; senior draftsman, $2,, 000; draftsman, $1,800; assistant draftsman, $1,620. Optional branches: Topographic, statistical. Applications must on file not later than Dec. 13, if received from States other than those named below. Dec. 16, If received from the following States; Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.

Miss Bettina Rose Ferrel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Ferrel of 2,310 Avenue L, Brooklyn, was married last night to Gilbert Russell Ott, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Ott, also of Brooklyn, in St. Marks Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Dr. Ralph E. Davis.

The midnight clamor of revelers that has aroused Brooklyn Heights residents to demand and obtain a special police detail to guard their slumbers 'left Magistrate. Sylvester F. Sabbatino in a state of calm bordering on coldness yesterday 'as he refused to fine or jail nine persons who constituted the first mass haul of the new police slumber squad.

Arthur Loesser, who appeared in piano recital at the Town Hall last night, has an eye for programs that are off the beaten path. It may be that his activities as a music critic in Cleveland have hardened him to the conventional assortment of works.
Deals involving two properties on the Bowery were announced yesterday. The Bowery Savings Bank sold to Louis Fish the five-story brownstone business building at 163

J. Homer Reed, an assistant cashier of the Chase National Bank, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, 433 West 256th Street, Riverdale, at the age of 56. Mr. Reed was graduated from the University of Minnesota in 1902 and later took post-graduate courses at Columbia University.

Mr. and Mrs. William A. Gill of South Orange, N. J., are sending out invitations to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary A. Gill, to William Sterling Roby Jr., son of Mrs. William Sterling Roby and the late Mr. Roby of Rochester, N. Y. The wedding will take place Dec. 10 in Grace Episcopal Church, Orange. The Rev. Clifford L. Stanley of Grace Church and the Rev. Kenneth Dexter Miller of Denver will officiate.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 17: Davis, Capt. L. P., the Maryland, to duty as inspector of ordnance in charge, Naval Ammunition Depot, Hingham, Mass. Wood, Comdr. L., Bethlehem, Pa., to the Warrington and In command when commissioned.

Jake Schaefer's quest of the world's 18.1 balkline billiard championship in a challenge match with Willie Hoppe at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy became well nigh hopeless last night as he finished the day with two more defeats and faced the colossal task of scoring 1,386 points in the two remaining blocks today if he is to win.

Trading in round lots for their own account by members of the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Oct. 23, when total volume rose to 24,644,040 shares sold, aggregated 9,254,473 shares bought or sold, or 18.77 per cent of the volume, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

C. W. Applegate, export manager of the Esterbrook Steel Pen Manufacturing Company, was elected president of the Foreign Traders Association of Philadelphia at the group's annual meeting today. Other officers elected were A. Pablo Jury, Dr. D. Jayne Son, Inc.; Frank J.

The Philadelphia first field hockey team scored a 5-to-0 victory today over Virginia's first-stringers in the opening of the Women's Southeastern States tournament. The Virginia seconds won, 2-0, from an all-star aggregation which filled in for Lancaster, Pa.

President Roosevelt asked the Federal Trade Commission today to make an "immediate investigation" of reports that "monopolistic practices and other unwholesome methods of competition" have contributed to the sharp rise in the cost of living this year.

Two hundred and fifty big and little Indians held an anachronistic pow-wow last night on the slippery floor of the Hotel Park Central's Florentine Room. The Indians performed tribal dances and occasionally uttered cries that sounded like war-whoops.

The Brooklyn College football team went through its final workout of the season yesterday, Coach Lou Oshins concentrating on kicking and passing for the encounter with the New York Aggies at Erasmus Field today.

A hearing in the disbarment proceedings by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Joseph H. Van Dorn was opened yesterday before John F. Davidson, trial examiner, in the regional offices in 120 Broadway.

Miss Priscilla Sousa and Miss Constance Thurlow last night gav a scavenger hunt, followed by a supper party in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador, for Miss Martha King of Berkeley, Calif. The guests met at the home of Miss Sousa, 455 East Fifty-seventh Street, and later left for the hunt.

The Air Ministry tonight announced that a committee of three would conduct a departmental inquiry into charges of inefficiency in the civil aviation services, and that it would be headed by Lord Cadman, noted engineer.

A resolution appealing to the United States Government "to intercede in behalf of the down-trodden Polish Jews" and to demand of the Polish Government observance of the "Little Versailles" treaty was adopted tonight by 1,000 delegates to a national conference of the Jewish Peoples Committee.

In the United States Supreme Court Milton J. Leavitt and Anthony J. Travia of New York were admitted to practice today and the following proceedings were had: 15--Arthur G. Bogardus, Pet'r, v. Commissioner of Internal Revenue. Mandate ordered to issue forthwith on motion for the petitioner.

A hearing has been called by the Securities and Exchange Commission for Dec. 6 on a declaration by the Northern States Power Company covering the issuance of not in excess of $4,000,000 of 3 per cent unsecured notes,

Faith is the antidote for the fear that besets a world in which solemn obligations between nations seem to be regarded as not worth the paper they are written on, John D. Rockefeller Jr. said last night at a dinner at International House, 500 Riverside Drive, celebrating the first anniversary of the founding of the organization's Alumni Association.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 18 unless specified: Aa San Diego, Caltair, Langley, Pickerel. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfok, Nov. 19. Antares, Guantanamo to Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Nov. 19. Craven, Guantanamo Bay to Boston, Nov. 19 .

The Rev. Isaac C. Swift, who resigned in 1928 after serving as pastor of the East Syracuse Presbyterian Church for fifty years, died at his home here tonight after a lingering illness.. He was 91 years old.

Gray, forbidding skies, with a sun that shone sullenly and held a promise of snow, shut down tonight on the vanguard of what was expected to be the biggest Yale-Harvard football crowd of recent years as the two teams retired to suburban quarters-on the eve of their fifty-sixth meeting, Yale to the Belmont Country Club and Harvard to Middlesex School in Concord.

Biff Jones's Nebraska football team demonstrated today it did have an offensive. Twenty-five thousand shivering fans and an outclassed band of Iowa Hawkeyes were convinced of that by four touchdowns and four points after to make the score Board read Nebraska 28, Iowa 0.

Football victories may cheer the hearts of Brown University alumni and add color and enthusiasm to undergraduate life, but failure on the gridiron appears to have no ??ampening effect on the number or caliber of applicants for admission to Brown.

Unless the-State Legislature comes to the rescue by amending its Banking Laws, Rutgers University students are going to be without the services of the Campus Bank which for twelve years has helped out "short" students with loans of $5 to $25.

The present bonded indebtedness of the State of Arkansas, considering interest and maturities, is not too heavy a burden upon the State providing conditions go on as expected, in the opinion of the Scherck, Richter Company of St. Louis.

Direct conflict of testimony appeared yesterday at the opening of the. Securities and Exchange Commission's first disbarmenth proceedings, directed against Joseph H. van Dorn. The hearings are being held at the commission's New York headquarters, 120 Broadway, with John F. Davidson as trial examiner and Robert H. Winn as counsel for the SEC.

Manhattan completed a new chapter in Jasper football history yesterday by defeating Niagara, 13-7, before a chilled crowd of 3,000 at Ebbets Field. Not since the sport has been revived at the college has any of its gridiron teams won four games in succession, and when the green-jerseyed players, caked with the mud of a slippery field, went to the showers, they had made history by their triumph over the up-Staters.

OUTSIDE official Roman Catholic publishers the house whose imprint is on this book numbers among its authors more priests of that religion--from cardinals down--than any other in this country. While its acceptance of an ecclesiastic's book may be no more than a matter of routine,

All the animosity, bitterness, bantering and even hilarity that have marked the thirty-year campaign for a Federal anti-lynching law were evidenced again this week in the revival of the legislation in the Senate. Nevertheless,

THIS book makes a tough assignment for a reviewer. If he takes Mr. Lundberg's attack upon the rich at its face value, he will be quite certain that Mr. Th*m*s W. L*m*nt or somebody else from down near the south end of Manhattan Island will junp out at him with a shillelagh the next time he goes home past the cemetery after dark.
Illinois came through for its veteran coach today, trouncing Chicago, 21 to 0, with a last-half offensive to put a winning finish to Bob Zuppke's twenty-fifth season as Illini gridiron mentor.

Hershey defeated the New York Rovers tonight, 4 to 3, in an Eastern Amateur League hoc ey game. Both teams scored in the first period and each added another in the second. In the third session Hershey held the Rovers with two men in the penalty box.

WHILE strong, clear signals are heard on the dial's 14.38 megacycle mark from the Macgregor Expedition's station OX2QY in Greenland, another research party, the American Mu??eum of Natural History Expedition led by Dr. W. H. Holden, flashes a northbound wave up from the sa??annas of British Guiana.

A campaign for a permanent home of its own for every major Federal art center, to be supported actively by the community as are branch libraries, has been started by the WPA Federal Art Project in New York.

An analysis of the realty situation in the New York area, as represented in mortgage investments, foreclosures and sales of real estate, by the Mortgage Conference of New York reveals generally improved conditions over the preceding year.

SALES of new and used cars during the calendar year 1937 will amount to approximately 11,000,000 units, according to a recent estimate of Nelson A. Beardsley, general sales manager of WillysOverland Motors, Inc. Present indications, Mr. Beardsley explained, are that new-car sales will total upward of 4,500,000 units and used cars will account for 6,500,000 sales.

With the announcement today of freshmen pledged to Rutgers University fraternities during a two-week rushing period, a marked drop in the percentage of first-year men joining fraternities was noted. Sixty-four freshmen were pledged to eighteen of the twenty fraternities on the campus, Dr. Fraser Metzger. dean of men, announced.

For the eleventh consecutive time, the semi-annual national survey of office-building vacancies conducted by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers shows an improvement in occupancy over the preceding report.

Mr. and Mrs. William Frew of this city gave a tea this afternoon at the Pittsburgh Golf Club at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaretta P. Frew, to Theodore H. Conderman 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman K. Conderman of Bryn Mawr.
The following Foreign Service changes since Nov. 6 were announced today by the State Department: Ernest L. Ives of Norfolk, Va., Consul General at Stockholm, assigned to Belfast as Consul General.

Several members of the Bowery's Bird Gang deserted their haunts in the shadow of the East Side elevated yesterday to make a trip to Park Avenue, where they became week-end guests at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

If the end of the first week of the special session finds the work of Congress in a state of some confusion, it is, for one reason, because of the element of timing. The special session was called because the Administration desired the enactment of new measures in four fields of legislation.

EDGAR BERGEN and his irrepressible dummy, Charlie Mc Carthy, are reported by the broadcasters to be the most popular entertainers on the air, according to the latest program survey in more than thirty key cities.

The marriage of J. Henry Scattergood of Villanova, Pa., Assistant United States Commissioner of Indian Affairs in the Hoover Administration, and Miss Frances Tisdale Deane was announced today by the bride's parents. The wedding was held here yesterday and the couple left for a trip to Bermude.

Mrs. C. Elizabeth Wipper of 34 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Weeks of Newark, N. J., and widow of William Wipper, was married to Edwin Michael Long of Newark and Anaheim, Calif., yesterday afternoon in the chancel of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

The marriage of Miss Helen Bernice Elliott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Elliott of Barre Plains, Mass., to Vincent A. Carberry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter S. Carberry of Brooklyn, took place here this morning in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

A large proportion of home purchasers, obtaining mortgage loans through savings, building and loan associations, as well as many executives of such institutions, favor the short-term mortgage loan, according to the committee on trends of the United States Building and Loan League.

THE New York Department of Parks granted a boon to walkers in Queens as well as to motorists in the construction of the Grand Central Parkway Extension and the parkway proper, farther out in Long Island. There is a walk system paralleling the Grand Central Parkway Extension,

In a three-story red brick building in West Sixteenth Street the French Women's Christian Union is quietly celebrating its fiftieth anniversary as a residence club for young women, a milestone reached by few organizations in this city.

The Hudson Motor Car Company resumed the payment of dividends on its stock after a lapse of five years, with the declaration yesterday of a 25-cent dividend, payable Dec. 16 to stock of record Dec. 1. The last previous payment was made in January, 1932, when a similar amount was disbursed.

Out of the welter of confusion that marks the attitude of organized labor's spokesmen on the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill, which passed the Senate and is now languishing in the House Rules Committee, one fact stands out clearlynone of the labor spokesmen (A. F. of L. or C. I. O.) has come out strongly in favor of the Senate bill at this time.

A. B. Davis High School defeated New Rochelle High in a Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association encountered at Senior Field today, 19 to 12, and remained unbeaten and untied in league competition. Davis now is in first place, leading White Plains High, which has one tie to blemish its record in seven conference trips.
Marvin Marsh, 17-year-old firststring fullback for the Lufkin High School team, died tonight of internal injuries suffered yesterday in a football game.

Cecil Bolan, captain of the Navy cross-country team, led home a field of twenty-eight runners in a quadrangular meet with Army, Columbia and New York University yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park and helped the midshipmen capture team honors.

THE Franklin Institute of Philadelphia is holding a competition for an original patriotic song reflecting the humanitarian spirit of Benjamin Franklin to be sung May 19 at the formal dedication of the Franklin Memorial.
Mr. and Mrs. George W. Kuhn of this place announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Myrtle Kuhn, to Gordon Duryea Shellard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren P. Shellard, also of Ridgewood.

Any legalistic opinion that Governor Lehman's order directing Albert Marinelli, Clerk of New York County, to answer the Citizens Committee's charges was illegal because the Governor was out of the State when it was issued will have no effect whatever on the legality of the order, according to persons having knowledge of Governor Lehman's actions in the matter.

American-born foreign language teachers from New York and vicinity were warned yesterday not to let their emotions enter classroom lectures especially at a time when the country whose language they teach is at war, in an address by Dean Henry Grattan Doyle of George Washington University's Columbian College.
The J. W. Van Dyke, the world's largest welded ship and the first American-built turbo-electric tanker, was launched at the Sun Shipbuilding Company's plant here this afternoon.

James Johnson, 172 3/4 pounds, and Charlie Eagles, 176, fought an eight-round draw at Rockland Palace. Eagles's. aggressiveness in the early rounds was matched by the boxing superiority of Johnson, who used a straight left continually until Eagles found he could cross rights to the jaw.
Federal Judge Wayne G. Borah ruled today that the city of New Orleans was within its rights in refusing a permit for the play "Tobacco Road" to be shown here.

The national tournament of the United States Women's Field Hockey Association will be held this week-end at the New Trier High School, Winnetka, Ill. This event, which lasts four days, will bring together two teams each from four sections of the country, including the Northeast, Midwest, Great Lakes and Southeast.

Seventy-three students from New York City and vicinity are among the eighty-five recently initiated into the three sororities at Centenary Junior College here. Miss Bette Cooper of this community, who was chosen Miss America for 1937 at the Atlantic City beauty contest in September, is a new member of Delta Sigma Sigma.

Legal Light and Conquer were the respective winners of the Endurance and T. K. Lynch Memorial Handicaps before 12,000 persons today, both of them being saddled by J. P. Jones of Virginia, who was a doctor of medicine in Buffalo for years before he took up horse training.

Announcement of the initiation of trade negotiations between the United States and the United Kingdom is a gratifying indication that the conversations of more than a year have cleared the ground for a practical approach to a trade agreement between the two countries.

20. -Students at Mount Holyoke College with a major interest in American history have undertaken this year to correlate their academic work with the world around them in a series of informal-weekly gatherings at the home of their professor' Di. Viola F. Barnes.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Lounsbery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Lounsbery of Yonkers, N. Y., to Robert William Bode, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Bode, also of Yonkers, took place yesterday in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church in Bronxville. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harold F. Hohly.

Recommendations which would end the Georgia chain gang and place the penal system of that State among the most progressive in the country are contained in a report on the prison labor problem in Georgia made public today by Dr. Louis N. Robinson, chairman of the Prison Industries Reorganization Board.

Omnibus, the Skidmore College dramatic society, is combining with Williams College to give its annual Fall production. This year Omnibus has chosen as its year Omnibus has chosen as its vehicle "Mrs. Moonlight," the fanciful tale of a woman who desires physical beauty above all else. l else.
Bradford Junior College is holding its second annual series of personal conferences with students on moral, ethical and religious problems in an effort to give them practical preparation for living.
