A new residential community is being opened in Union. N. J., by the Schneider-Wagner Company on a large tract at Galloping Hill Road and Forest Drive where construction has been started on seventeen homes in the $6,000 to $8,000 price range.
Prince David Kalakaua Kawananakoa, last male descendant of Hawaii's kings, pleaded guilty to a charge of manslaughter today and was sentenced to ten years in Oahu penitentiary.
The Dowager Duchess of Roxburghe, only daughter of the American multi-millionaire Ogden Goelet of Newport, R. I., left a British estate of [Pound]296,093, it was disclosed today. She died March 26.

The liner Drotningholm arrived from New York today with two girl stowaways aboard. Helen Livingstine, 23, and her sister, Ruth, a year younger, who came out of hiding after the ship had been at sea twenty-four hours, said they stowed away to go to Sweden.

hELP WANTED: The successful anti-racket campaign of Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey, now District Attorney-elect, is bringing business to New York City. Two assistant district attorneys from Los Angeles, to which some of the thugs have fled, came to town last week seeking help. They were willing to pay a good detective $250 a month and expenses.
Wider interest in dramatics has developed this year at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where a drama shop has been established to give students an opportunity to produce plays.

A new type of cotton gin, which its inventor says will quadruple the production of ginned cotton, was viewed here today by S. H. McCrory, chief engineer of the United States Bureau of Agricultural Engineering.

With indications pointing to a late upsurge in Christmas shopping, retailers believe the peak of the buying will be reached on Saturday, Dec. 18, and the following Monday, Dec. 20, according to comment here yesterday.

A few days ago the Scandinavian countries refused to join in the resolution of the Brussels powers condemning Japan's aggressions against China. This abstention has been generally interpreted by the outside world as a sign that the Far Northern States are drifting away from the League of Nations and intend to follow an isolationist policy in the future.

Paced by Ray McLean, shifty and hard-running quarterback, the St. Anselm College eleven closed its 1937 season today on a snow-capped Pratt Field gridiron with a 20-to-0 triumph over Springfield College.

Hamilton College's Department of Public Speaking has offered to clubs, schools, and other similar organizations a new type of service whereby a group of student speakers and debaters will present facts in public meetings on questions which are likely to arise in the State Constitutional Convention next Spring.

FURTHER sagging in retail trade was reported last week from various parts of the country, with important sectors citing losses of around 5 per cent under a year ago. Some improvement was found in the Northwest, and the Southeast territory managed to stay fairly well ahead of volume last year.

Big slices were cut from every London-toCapetown flight record by Flying Officer Arthur Edmund Clouston and Mrs. Betty Kirby-Green, who arrived at Croydon flying field at 3:25 P. M. today, after battling a 60-mile-an-hour gale from Cairo.

Notwithstanding appeals for help to authorities in general, and to New York police in particular, there is not at the present moment a gangster behind every palm tree in Southern California-at least, not an "Eastern gangster."
Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight, will be seen in action in a Brooklyn ring on Tuesday night, when he faces Joe Pennino of South Brooklyn in the star bout of ten rounds at the Broadway Arena.

Discussions of the effect of communism, fascism and democracy on the Zionist movement will be featured at the fourteenth annual convention of the Junior Hadassah, opening Thursday in Detroit. Among the delegates to the fourday conference,

LOUISE WILBER'S book, "Vocations for the Visually Handicapped," has the distinction of being unique. Although many scattered articles deal with the education of the blind and with the problems of adjustment involved in the process of making them economically self-sufficient,

Miss Annette Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Stevenson Ross of this place, was married here to Alan Foster Whitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Whitman of New Brunswick, N. J., this evening in the Unitarian Church. The Rev. Charles Styron performed the ceremony.

HOLLYWOOD. A REBELLION is brewing in the ranks of players, directors and writers over the almost universal practice of studios in refusing salary increases at option time, even though advances are specified in contracts.

CHILDREN are naturally sensitive to music. Their response may be unintellectual; it is also unspoiled. They do not need to read program notes. The music makes direct contact with their emotions, and since they are not in the habit of simulating their feelings, their reactions are to be noted in the curve of the corners of the mouth, in the expression of the eye, the gesture of the head and the hand.

Holding that many teachers are "little czars in their own domains," a committee of the National Education Association has just published a guide-book bulletin on the practwice of democracy in the schoolroom.
A concert for the benefit of Chrystie Street House, a refuge for homeless young men now in its fortieth year of activity, was given last night at Carnegie Hall.
Geologists returning from exploration of the vast and desolate Kaiparowits Plateau in Southern Utah found it a scenic and archaeologio wonderland, where they discovered:

Sanctions in warfare as they exist today are valueless, Professor Frank B. Scott of McGill University, Toronto, Canada, told students attending the International Relations Clubs conference here today. "I see no value in attempting sanctions or military interventions except as part of a newly constituted League of Nations," Professor and Scott declared.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Owen D. Young's intelligent contribution in your issue of, Nov. 14, referring to my article of the previous week, was read by me with considerable interest.

The gas industry in the United States and Canada is starting a nation-wide program designed to stimulate the equipment of new houses and the modernization of existing dwellings with gas appliances, according to an announcement by the American Gas Association yesterday.

CRUISE mappers have supplied a substitute for the magic carpet. With that fabulous method of transport one had to know where he wanted to go and name it, while the routes charted for this Winter's nearly 200 cruises take in places not hitherto ports of call, and therefore little known to tourists.

Minnesota won full possession of the Western Conference football crown today by overpowering Wisconsin, 13 to 6, in a spectacular wind-up of the season. It was the fifth straight Big Ten victory for the Gophers.

THIS novelette by the author of "Green Light" belongs to a genre which is always threatening to vanish from current literature, but never does so. Now and then, along with the naturalistic or hard-boiled or sophisticated novels on the publishing lists, some item appears which is as simple, as full of tender and homely sentiment, as "A Christmas Carol" or "Goodbye, Mr. Chips"--or even "Home for Christmas."

Robert H. Armstrong gave out yesterday his annual list of the "ten best books of the year" on real estate and related topics. Several of the volumes in his 1937 citation are on the subject of housing. The books are as follows:
Eight groups representing Hobart College's seven fraternities and the neutral body, will gather in Coxe Hall Auditorium Monday evening to participate in the second annual inter-fraternity song fest.

Stimulated by the successful passage at the last Legislature of the bill requiring a seventy-two-hour waiting period for marriage-license applicants, the League of Women Voters is giving renewed emphasis to support of legislation requiring a physical examination of both parties before a license is issued.
A reading clinic, designed to discover and correct faults in children's reading which may be serious handicaps in later life, was established at the Pennsylvania State College this week.

Lower prices ruled in almost all sections of the listed bond market yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. United States Government obligations fell back moderately from the highs established during Friday's spirited advance,
Stony Brook School defeated an alumni team, 14--0, today in the annual homecoming day contest. Hank Neber scored both touchdowns for the school eleven.

With four former metropolitan college captains on its squad, the Original Celtics basketball team will meet the formidable Jersey Reds at the Hippodrome tonight in an American Professional League contest, starting at 9:15.

Wooster defeated Washington and Jefferson, 20 to 0, today for its first victory in four meetings with the Presidents. The running of Johnny Gatshall and Dave Henderson featured Wooster's attack, the former scoring the first two touchdowns and Henderson going over from the one-foot ilne in the last period.
Two new Queens County residential communities in which several model houses of the higher-priced variety have been completed will be formally opened today for public inspection.

Miss Marjorie Nye, daughter of Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, was injured at 4:30 P. M. yesterday in a collision at Ninth Avenue and 203d Street. Miss Nye was taken to Fordham Hospital after being treated at the Jewish Memorial Hospital for a fracture of the left ankle and lacerations of the left cheek and forehead.

The common criticism of dependence upon textbooks and the opinions of authorities leveled against college undergraduates can have no significance for the members of the Wellesley class in contemporary drama, which studies current publications and the productions of stage and screen.

Sixty-three girls have been pledged to sororities at New York University this semester, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Dorothy McSparren Arnoll, dean of women at Washington Square College and faculty adviser to the university's Pan-Hellenic Congress.
SOUTHERN PINES, N. C.--Accommodations have been made for 10,000 spectators to witness the air show here today marking the dedication of the Knowlwood Airport, one of the largest fields in the South.

Miss Alice H. Anthony, daughter of Mrs. Mark Anthony of this place and the late Mr. Anthony, was married here at noon today in the chapel of the Cathedral of the Incarnation to Charles H. Mayo Jr., sor of Mr. and Mrs. Mayo of Stewart Manor. The Rev. John Esquirol performed the ceremony.
Miss Jane Cannon Hill, daughter of Mrs. Hilary W. Lucke of the Ambassador and Winston Salem, N C., gave a tea dance yesterday in the Trianon Room of the hotel.

Before embarking on a heavy week of enter training, the King and Queen spent a quiet week-end with the latter's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. David Bowes-Lyon, in Hertfordshire House, where the Queen spent much of her childhood.

Retail trade figures slipped sharply below a year ago last week, with declines led by New York City, where sales were 10 per cent under those of last year. A few districts reported gains over last year but declines from the previous week. Industrial operations were off in most areas.
A luncheon and a fashion show to be known as the Christmas Cruise Style Revue will be held on Nov. 30 in the Caprice Room of the Weylin in behalf of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York.

Ohio State's Scarlet Tide rolled relentlessly over Michigan's hopes of a winning football season today, vanquishing the Wolverines for the fourth successive year, 21 to 0. The victory provided some balm for the Buckeyes' Western Conference title aspirations, blasted when Minnesota defeated Wisconsin today to win the championship, and gave them a record for the season of six games won and two lost.
Captain Frank F. Harding, a native of Hudson, Wis., a Spanish War veteran and a resident of Puerto Rico since then, died last night. He was 67 years old.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for Dec. 7 on an application by a committee for holders of West Ohio Gas Company 6 per cent first and refunding-mortgage bonds for approval of and report on an amended reorganization plan for the company.

Reports that control of the cotton acreage and the amount of cotton to be marketed without penalties probably would be recommended by the Senate Agricultural Committee exerted a strengthening influence on prices yesterday.

Several recent proposals calling for reorganization of certain activities of the FHA and the creation of a central Federal mortgage bank were criticized yesterday by George H. Patterson, secretary of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America of Chicago.

Ten members of North Carolina's powerful football team will be making their farewell collegiate appearance Thanksgiving Day when the Tarheels meet the Virginia eleven in a renewal of one of the South's oldest continuous gridiron rivalries.

Not exactly in keeping with Carnegie Hall traditions of virtuosity, but lively and refreshing Irevertheless, the Children's School Orchestra, composed of eighteen children from 2 to 8 years of age, was presented in concert at the Rudolph Wurlitzer Company, 120 West Forty-second Street, yesterday afternoon.

Thomas J. Whearty, trustee of the Queens County Savings Bank and President of the Shelter Rock Country -Club, has purchased from the developers, Callan Brothers, in the Wyngate community at Great Neck, L. I., a Colonial type residence on the corner of Garden Street and Shoreward Drive.

From Nanking a mass exodus took place last week. Rickshas and oxcarts piled high with bags, bedding, pots, pans and wailing babies; peasants and townsfolk on foot and burdened with belongings; autos and trucks laden with official documents and wounded soldiers-all turned their faces westward from China's capital and from the threat of Japan's military machine rumbling up from Shanghai to the east.

Elusive typhoid germs which caused seven deaths and over 120 cases of illness in Croydon today wrecked the London watercress market in Covent Garden and caused a near panic in aristocratic Kensington, where there was a new outbreak of the disease.

Lady Ribblesdale will arrive from Europe Tuesday on the Berengaria. Mrs. Walter Gibb and Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Du B. Hunter will give a reception on Dec. 10 at the home of Mrs. Gibb, 1,040 Fifth Avenue, for Mrs. Hunter's debutante daughters, the Misses Elaine G. Eldredge and Mary Althea Eldredge.
Plans were disclosed yesterday for building operations which will transform a vast section of the lower Riverdale community from a private residential neighborhood into a garden apartment center.

The estate of Mrs. Rhinelander Waldo at Garrison, N. Y., a 2,200acre tract containing relics that link it with the military history of the Revolution, has been sold to a syndicate composed of more than thirty residents of the town and vicinity.
The fourteenth annual Debutante Ball, to be held Thanksgiving Eve at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn Heights, will have the largest receiving line since its inception by Mrs. Ira Bertine Downs.
J. Edward Breuer has been appointed by the trustees of the Sheridan estate to sell at public auction the realty holdings owned by the estate at Sea Cliff, L. I.

The Interstate Commerce Commission broadexed today the scope of its investigation of railroad freight rates to include the water carriers operating from ports on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and Chesapeake Bay.
Announcement has been made by Mr and Mrs. Elmer E. Coyte of Deal of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lee M. Coyte, to Charles Cornell Dunlap Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cornell Dunlap.

Parliament was dissolved today and the Chamber elections were scheduled for Dec. 20 and the Senate Dec. 22. Ion Mihalache resigned his leadership of the National Peasant party and he was replaced by Dr. Julius Maniu. They will carry on the electoral campaign jointly.
Japanese labor has repainted its formerly democratically tinted platform in Nazi colors and the change has aroused so little concern that only one leading daily has commented on it.

Of the new synthetic products which German science has invented to replace the raw materials bought by the Reich from the outside world, the two most prized are the textiles made from wood fiber and Buna, the new artificial rubber.

Mrs. George Eustis Corcoran will give a small reception and tea on Tuesday afternoon at her home, 230 East Seventy-third Street, for members of the committee assisting her with plans for the Vacation Dinner Dance to be held on Dec. 18 at the Plaza.

Princeton University's varsity soccer team retained its championship in the six-team Middle Atlantic Association today by turning back Pennsylvania, 3-1, in the final game of the season. The Tigers wound up the campaign undefeated in association competition.

A technicality enabled the swimmers of George Washington High School to gain victory over Evander Childs, 36 to 35, at the weekly series of dual meets for the Manhattan-Bronx-Richmond senior high school championship of the Public School Athletic League, staged yesterday in the 25-yard pool of De Witt Clinton High School.
For the second time this season, the West Chester State Teachers defeated Pennsylvania Military College on the gridiron today, 6-3, scoring the winning touchdown in the last period.

THE TIMES LITERARY SUPPLEMENT devotes the front-page article of its current issue to an elaborate review of the opening volumes of the Yale University Press edition of Horace Walpole's correspondence, which it describes as the most ambitious project yet undertaken by the Yale school of English scholars, of which Professor Tinker is founder.

High public officials, members of the clergy and the legal profession in New Jersey, NewYork and Pennsylvania will gather at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in near-by Pleasantville next Friday to honor Alfred E. Smith, former Governor of New York.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth F. Paton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Paton of this city, to Walter F. Lindsley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Lindsley, also of this city, took place this afternoon in the Second Presbyterian Church here.

To Cadeau II, owned by F. Ambrose Clark of Westbury, L. I., and one of the best of the imported French jumpers, went the distinction today of winning the first running of the Noel Laing Steeplechase Handicap, inaugurated as a memorial to the noted amateur rider.

King Victor Emmanuel today appointed a prince of the House of Savoy, Amadeo Duke of Aosta, as Viceroy of Ethiopia, replacing Marshal Rodolfo Graziani, who is understood to have been relieved at his own request because of ill health.

Shooting for Thanksgiving turkeys featured the program at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Thirty-four gunners made up the field. The first choice went to twelve scratch gunners, A. L. Cornwell, A. L. Burns, F. A. Scola, E. P. Feeley, O. Agathon, Harry Thoens, G. E. Churchill, B. M. Higginson, E. Hughes, B. J. Field, E. J. Zeiner and S. B. Masten.

The spectacular Green Bay Packers, champions of the National Football League and the powerhouse that is rolling on to a new all-time offensive record, will storm Dut on the Polo Grounds turf before some 40,000 persons this afternoon in quest of their eighth straight victory, this time at the expense of the New York Giants.

In the face of a blinding snowstorm, which tossed pre-game calculations to the winds, Colgate's once mighty Red Raiders, without a major victory all season, today captured the one prize they most desired-a triumph over Syracuse.

COMMODORE THOMAS ap Catesby Jones was the hard - bitten, self - reliant commander of our Pacific Squadron in the days when California still belonged to Mexico and was looked upon with greedy eyes by England and the United States.

WASHINGTON. -- The average American city park contains about twenty-five acres, according to a nation-wide survey covering 10,000 individual areas recently completed by the National Park Service and the National Recreation Association.

The need of guiding mothers of pre-school children in the correct way of forming their children's habits and attitudes was emphasized yesterday by the Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart, director of the Division of Children of New York Catholic Charities, at the first session of a ten-week institute for staffs of twenty-five New York Catholic day nurseries.

Federal customs officials seized the cargo of whale oil, valued at $1,500,000, of theN orwegian tanker Charles Racine when she steamed into port today after hovering off the Virginia Capes for a week.

ANEW $50,000 short-wave broadcasting station will soon be under construction near Belmont, Calif., as the result of a permit granted to the General Electric Company by the Federal Communications Commission.

Tax receipts of the State of Louisiana for the first ten months of 1937 exceeded by almost $1,000,000 those for the entire year 1936, reflecting a "remarkable quickening of the business pace throughout the State," according to a statement issued yesterday by Governor Richard W. Leche.

Princeton University's 1937-38 enrollment of 2,665 undergraduates and graduate students comprise young men from twenty-one foreign nations, forty-five States, the District of Columbia and three United States Territories, according to the university registrar's office.
More than 2,100 policemen have been assigned to duty with the annual R. H. Macy Co. Thanksgiving Day parade, according to orders issued yesterday by the Police Department.

Through the generations, up to contemporary times, nothing more than a murmurous overture has been perceptible against this country's record and prodigal waste of human lives through lack of medical attention at birth.

Executives of multi-unit retail organizations gave close scrutiny last week to Representative Patman's announcement that he will propose an amendment to the Clayton act, the effect of which, if enacted, would be a reshaping of distribution as it has developed in this country since the advent of the chain-store idea.

Twenty-two States are scheduled to start unemployment benefit payments in January. Because of the increasing unemployment in recent months and the continued downward tendency in many lines of business, some of these States face the probability of a serious drain upon their unemployment insurance funds at that time.
Some time next May, if an amateur extension of figures just released by the Census Bureau can be relied upon. the one hundred and thirty millionth living American will make his or her bow.

Two passengers were killed, 53 persons were seriously hurt and 20 others were slightly injured toda: in the wreck of a Norfolk Western passenger train near here. Three were critically injured and their recovery was doubtful.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today she had resigned from the Colony Club in New York solely because she seldom had an opportunity to take advantage of her membership.

Suppose black skin was grafted on an unborn white baby. Will the baby be born black or white? Human embryos cannot be thus experimented with. But unborn chicks can. And with these Dra, B. H. Willier, Mary E. Rawles and E. Hadorn of the university did experiment. They report their work to the National Academy of Sciences.

No scientist has yet succeeded in producing a compound which is chemically and physically Indistinguishable from natural crude rubber. A half century ago he began to chase that will-o'-the wisp. Now he doesn't care-at least for commercial purposes-whether he catches it or not.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls scored once in each period to blank the Bronx Tigers, 3 to 0, tonight in an Eastern Amateur League hockey game. It was the Sea Gulls' second victory of their season, which they opened last night with a 5-to-1 triumph over Hershey, 1936 champion.

The National Interfraternity Conference, representing more than Misi sixty national Greek-letter fraternities, will hold its twenty-ninth annual convention at the Hotel Commodore for four days, beginning next Wednesday. About 325 delegates are expected to attend.

An exhibition of portraits of children, lent by -art collectors throughout the country, will open on Dec. 1 at the Arden Gallery. It has been gathered to raise funds for the Greenwich House Music School. It will include about fifty paintings and sculpture by old masters and artists of all periods including the present day.
The Swedish F. C. and the Prague F. C. will be rivals in a Premier Division, Metropolitan Soccer League, contest today at Dana Park in Brooklyn. The kick-off is set for 2:30 P. M.

IT was indeed lucky for the Irish dramatic movement that its birth took place in something rather like a stable-an empty, bedraggled and stageless place. And we may today thank our lucky birth star that the Abbey Theatre in Dublin is still housed in a place almost as unpretentious as a stable.

IN his essay "Democratic Vistas," written in 1871, Walt Whitman wrote: "Of what is called the drama, or dramatic presentation in the United States, as now put forth at the theatres, I should say it deserves to be treated with the same gravity, and on a par with the questions of ornamental confectionery at public dinners, or the arrangement of curtains and hangings in a ballroom. * * *

Justice F. Dickinson Letts of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia has dismissed without opinion an action brought by the Bagdad Copper Corporation against the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The National Maritime Union charged yesterday that the Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., had "untied one of their ships from a dock in Boston, dusted it off, loaded it up with an anti-N. M. U. crew and transported a handful of passengers" so that the International Seamen's Union,

Paul Gmelin, a member of the New York firm of architects, Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, 101 Park Avenue, died here today at his home at the age of 79. A native of Ulm, Germany, he was educated at Stuttgart, and came to the United States as a youth.

Fifteen Sears ago Charles Dworack plunged to earth from the United States dirigible Roma when hydrogen exploded. Now, at 51 years old, he is trying to obtain employment again in the Air Service. A mechanic, he says he is dissatisfied with his present job of running a rooming house.

Eighteen pickets found guilty last Tuesday of disorderly conduct in connection with lie-down strikes outside Horn Hardart automats were given suspended sentences yesterday by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in West Side Court.
A program of music without parallel in the annals of the city is being planned for the New York World's Fair in 1939 by the fair's advisory committee on music, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. William G. Lehing of Rutherford, chairman of the music department of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, has announced the following as recipients of the Meta Thorne Waters Scholarship at New Jersey College for Women:

S. Harold Greene, founder and first and only president of the Charles River Country Club and former president and treasurer of the Mutual Boiler Insurance Company of Boston, died late last night in his home in Newton Center. He was 57 years old.

Crimson flares threw their glow over a celebrating mob of Harvard men who danced on the floor of their old stadium aisles tonight. In their midst the Harvard band brayed: "With Crimson in Triumph Flashing."
Nott Terrace High, Schenectady, N. Y., today won the sixth annual interscholastic cross-country meet sponsored by the Johns Hopkins Chapter of the National Collegiate Society of Spiked Shoes.

Miss Elaine Christine Hansen, daughter of Mayor and Mrs. John G. Hansen of this place, was married here this afternoon at her parents' home to Edward G. Ringrose, son of former Mayor and Mrs. Edwin G. Ringrose of Westwood, by the Rev. Thomas Walker.
Virginia's two teams in the Southeastern States women's field hockey scored decisive victories today over their visiting foes in the final games of the annual tournament.

France has ordered that special measures be taken to strengthen colonial defenses, notably in Indo-China, it was announced today by Marius Moutet, Minister of Colonies. M. Moutet said the government realized that the colonies must have independent means of defense and that he had secured the allocation of large sums for this purpose from this year's budget.

Professors exiled from Spain during and after the war will have an unusually hard time findings posts in America, Dr. Stephen Duggan, of the Institute of International Education, asserts in his annual report.
THE team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup, which has been in progress since Tuesday night, was the only "national contractbridge championship" when it was first played in 1928.
As the tumult and the shouting dies official Washington finds itself distinctly less alarmed at the Brazilian coup d'etat of last week.
BATKIN-LOINGER--Mr. and Mrs. M. M. Longer and Mr. and Mrs. Herman Batkin announce the marriage of their children, Selma to Stanley, on Tuesday, Nov. 16, at the Hotel St. George.

Thirty-six luncheons, dinners and meetings are scheduled to be held this week in connection with the New York - Brooklyn federation campaign for a charity fund of $6,250,000. The drive, in which more than 5,500 volunteer workers are enlisted, begins its second week today.

Ninetyseven awards of contracts for supplies were made by thirteen Federal agencies in the week ended on Thursday under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announced today.

DWIGGINS once disclosed to me the formula by which he endows words on paper with more force and color than most people (including the people who wrote the words) ever saw in them. Of course. Dwiggins claimed no such objective; he simply described as to a humble pupil, a method He said:

Attendance at the twenty-ninth annual convention of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, opening a week from tomorrow at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, is expected to set a new record for such gatherings. A total of more than 600 manufacturers, in addition to wholesalers,

Sergeant John Morgan of Newark police and Lieutenant Thomas Dimond of the Essex County prosecutor's office today arrested three men and seized 15,000 lottery slips and a quantity of typewriters and adding machines in a raid

Natalie Bodanya, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera and an active member of the Alumni Association of the Union Settlement of this city, will give a recital for the benefit of the organization's camp fund next Sunday night in the auditorium of the settlement at 231 East 104th Street.

The James Monroe High School football team defeated Seward Park, 19 to 0, yesterday to end its most brilliant drive since 1930. For the first time since that year the Crimson finished its campaign unbeaten and untied in six games and with a defensive record of only 6 points scored against it.

Mr. and Mrs. A. Marvin Laidlaw of Greenwich entertained at a buffet dinner tonight in honor of Miss Jane Carrott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orville Browning Carrott of Belle Haven, and William Hall Boardman of Quarry Top, Riverdale, N. Y., whose marriage is to take place on Thanksgiving Day. Mr. and Mrs. Laidlaw are brotherin-law and sister of Miss Carrott.

George and Willis Duvalier, brothers, who were found guilty of murder Nov. 3 for the killing Aug. 20 of a native on Great Inagua Island in connection with rioting at the American-owned Erickson Salt Works, are to be hanged Monday morning.

Debutantes will act as hostesses at the series of tea dance recitals to be given by Dance International from Nov. 29 to Jan. 2 in the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center. They will be divided into five groups, one for each week of the series.
Luther D. Lovekin, marine engineer and inventor, died of heart disease last night at his home in Villanova after an illness of more than four years. He was 68 years old.

Harold W. Mason of this city, who was elected member of the Republican National Committee at the 1936 convention, was notified by Chairman John D. M. Hamilton today of his appointment as secretary :of the committee.

THE subscribers to the popular-priced season of the Teatro del Popolo cannot complain of lack of variety in symphonic fare just now. In the course of the last few days they have heard three of Italy's five finest orchestras, under leaders of repute: La Scala (Marinuzzi), Santa Cecilia (Molinari) and Turin Radio (Parodi).
So many postmasters have reported seeing snakes in the mails that Harllee Branch, Second Assistant Postmaster General, today issued this notification:

TWO years ago last June Sam H. Grisman, the overlord of "Tobacco Road," called me into his private cubicle, perched, as it then was, on the balcony landing of the Forrest Theatre, and said, "If you're not busy at the moment, will you come with me to the United Booking Office?
An all-day session to instruct volunteer leaders in naturalization and citizenship laws will be conducted tomorrow by the National Council of Jewish Women.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Price of Brookline, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their niece, Miss Barbara Phillips, to Arthur H. Willis, son of Mrs. H. Parker Willis of St. George, S. I., and the late Mr. Willis.

The estimated resources of Columbia University and affiliated institutions total $154,669,109, Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, provost of the university, announced yesterday. Capital endowment, excluding value of the plant, was reported as $86,688,931, while the value of lands, buildings and equipment was put at $58,878,187.

Abraham Lincoln High's hopes for an undefeated season were shattered by a powerful Boys High football team, as the Red and Black outfit triumphed by 14 to 0 at Boys High Field yesterday. A crowd of 7,000 watched the struggle, the final of the season for the Brooklyn rivals.

Miss Josephine Jellett, daughter of Mrs. F. Harold Tunnell of Germantown was introduced to society this afternoon at a tea given by her mother and Mr. Tunnell at the Warwick. The tea was followed by a dinner dance, also at the Warwick, attended by about 150 guests.

A spurt that netted some 3,800 points in sixteen hands brought the team headed by Harold S. Vanderbilt, donor of the trophy, into the center of interest last night as the semi-finals in the play for the Vanderbilt Cup for contract bridge progressed in the rooms of the Cavendish Club at the Hotel Ambassador.

Robert-Denoeu, 16-year-old French boy who ran away several weeks ago from the home of stepfather, an assistant professor of French at Dartmouth College, and was restored to his family Friday night through the Missing Persons Bureau, sailed yesterday for Paris on the French liner Champlain.

School administrators from Kindergarten to college in the East this Fall are face to face with a newly pressing problem. Declines in the birth and immigration rates, which are already putting school rosters in the red or forecasting losses in the near future, make a total readjustment in educational planning necessary.

The Japanese drove west to new conquests today following the fall of Soochow, keypoint of China's "Hindenburg line." The Chinese strove to form a new line to bar the invaders' progress to Nanking, from which the government yesterday formally announced the removal of the capital to Chungking in Szechwan Province.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, a pioneer advocate of woman suffrage, told members of the Woman's Club of Yonkers at a dinner here today that this is still a man's world and, "while we don't want it to be a woman's world, we feel woman should have a larger share of freedom."

PEOPLE who remember the performance of Mei Lan Fang will recall that he frequently set himself the following problem: he, a man, played a woman disguised as a man. That rated high as a bit of complicated impersonation until Romney Brent, a Mexican, appeared in "Dinner at the Ritz" as an Englishman's idea of what an American thinks an Englishman thinks Americans are like.

The most divergently distributed fund received at Dartmouth College, aiding more than 100 needy students, according to the personnel bureau, is the money received from the National Youth Administration.
The marriage of Miss Susan Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edwin Hall of Old Church Road, this place, to Eric L. F. Archdeacon of Berlin, will take place on Dec. 9 in London.

IF The Subway Sun does not mind being scooped on its big story of the year and night club announcements are of calendar worth, the time has come to remember to wrap all packages securely before mailing.
YOU pick up this book in the acute--and of course inevitable--consciousness that it is the autobiography of the wife of the President of the United States.

While the stronger demand created by the Japanese boycott has made spot supplies of lisle and certain types of rayon hosiery harder to obtain, this situation was held to reflect the more limited output of these types.

Forty-five members of Princeton University's senior class have provisionally qualified to study on the "no-course" plan which allows men of high academic standing to pursue their work independently and beyond classroom restrictions, Dr. Robert K. Root, dean of the faculty, announced today.
Plans are being made for two events on the early December calendar of Greenwich society. On Dec. 1 the annual Christmas sale of the Round Hill Community Guild will be held at the Community House.

Frank Gillmore, president of the Actors Equity Association, which has been torn by internal strife for several years, announced yesterday that the council of Equity was seeking a new salaried executive to relieve himself and Paul Dullzell, executive secretary, of some of their responsibilities.

The General Land Office of the Interior Department is one agency of the government which is operating at a profit to the Treasury. According to its annual report today, it had receipts in the fiscal year ending June 30
President Roosevelt, who has been suffering from an abscessed tooth, was reported as much better today, although he still remained in the White House and did not go to his office.

The Lighthouse Eye Clinic of the New York Association for the Blind was founded in 1905 as a ticket bureau, where persons who had extra seats for the opera or theatre donated them for the use of the blind.
The Old Greenwich Assembly Thanksgiving dance, to be held Saturday at the Stamford Yacht Club, is being arranged by a large committee under the leadership of Joseph A. Reynes Jr.
Miss Marie Houston, soprano, will give a recital at the College of New Rochelle on Monday night, it was announced today by Miss Marjorie Kelly of Binghamton, president of the Music Club.

Samuel Seabury demanded today that the coming State Constitutional Convention pave the way for creation of a unicameral Legislature elected by proportional representation and assailed Governor Lehman on the ground that, at the behest of Tammany Hall, he had delayed the La Guardia program.

When Professor Joliot and his wife, Irene Curie, discovered that nitrogen could be made artificially radioactive by bombarding it with neutrons, the physicists in the University of California, with Professor E. O. Lawrence and M. S. Livingston at their head, at once took up the clue and showed that common table salt could be made radioactive for a brief period.

Expecting a rise in unemployment, David C. Adie, State Welfare Commissioner, has notified Governor Lehman that at least $54,000,000 will be necessary to provide shoes, food, clothing and shelter for the State's unemployed in the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

IN celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the first appearance here of Josef Hofmann the Bohemians will give a dinner and a program of music with Kirsten Flagstad, Friedrich Schorr and Efrem Zimbalast as soloists, at the Waldorf-Astoria, Dec. 19.

A gala Football Dance has been arranged for Thanksgiving Eve at the Woman's Club here. The ballroom will be decorated with footballs, pennants and other insignia of leading colleges and universities, and several features of the party will point to the Army-Navy game next Saturday.
STROUDSBURG, Pa.--Only a few days remain before the opening of the deer-hunting season in the Poconos. Sportsmen have begun to prepare their camps.
THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's Pension Fund concert will take place tomorrow night, with Bidu Sayao, soprano, and Julius Katchen, 11-year-old pianist, as soloists.

Temple University is conducting an exhaustive research program, through its College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, into the cause of freshmen failures. This program is part of the functions of the Guidance Board of the College, which also has begun a personal survey for the general help of students in course.

BUENOS AIRES. GETULIO VARGAS'S dramatic establishment of a corporate State in Brazil a few days ago was the most spectacular act of his political career, but it was by no means his first dictatorial move. Vargas rode into power at the head of a revolution in 1930, nipped a dozen counter-revolutions and put down one civil war.

" Bye-Bye Centennial," written, produced and acted entirely by members of the junior class at Mount Holyoke College, was presented tonight in Chapin Auditorium to an audience of undergraduates, faculty and alumnae.

An enterprising woman thought up and promoted the idea of Christmas Seals in the United States back in 1907; now thirty years later, she will be joined by millions of women throughout the country in an effort that will bring forth additional means with which to carry on the war against tuberculosis.

THE resiliency of truth has become proverbial. On the other hand, falsehood crushed to earth is hardly ever able to rise again. In politics or metaphysics, maybe, but in the field of literary forgeries, never.

SOME of the mail received in New York from the Dominican Republic during the past week was franked with stamps which the Trujillo government released in commemoration of the 21,000-mile Pan - American good - will flight which four air pilots-three Cuban and one Dominican-began at Trujillo City on Nov. 11.

Rockwell Kent, American artist, took the witness stand in the trial of eleven Nationalists for the murder of Policeman Loyola last Palm Sunday, but on the prosecutor's objection, sustained by Judge Sepulveda, was not permitted to testify regarding matters on which the witness said he knew only through what he had read.

By JOHN H. CRIDER CHARACTERISTIC of attitudes during periods of economic decline, the world turned introspective after crash of 1929 and found, ong other things, that someng had to be done about unployment.
Problems of democracy, in particular, methods 'of preserving it in the face of attacks from extremes, were discussed yesterday by rabbis in regular Saturday morning sermons.

KATHERINE FULLERTON GEROULD had ringside seats at the great Dempsey-Tunney fight in Philadelphia, and she has written a brilliant impression of that combat as classic drama. But this book of her collected essays, as she has looked on at life and some of its battles from a ringside seat during the past decade, begins with a paper on Kipling.
WARRENTON, Va.--Hunting fixtures for the week here are: tomorrow, Canterbury Gate; Wednesday, Ryland's Corner; Thursday, Clovelly; Saturday, Ashland Farm, home of the M. F. H., and Mrs. Carhart.

Missouri hadn't made a field goal all year, but Stanley Mondala, portly fullback, slid back to his 20-yard line and booted the goal that gave the Tigers a 3-to-0 victory over Washington University today, althrough kicking against the wind.

The Boston University Pioneers defeated the Boston College Eagles today for the first time since 1894. Coach Hanley's eleven scored two touchdowns and kicked one extra point to gain a 13-point lead in the second quarter.

The annual Charity Ball at Smith College will be held on Dec. 4 in Scott Gymnasium. Unlike the Junior Promenade, at which attendance is restricted to members of the two upper classes, this ball, inaugurated in 1932 as a benefit for the Community Chest, may be attended by all students. The decorative motif will be in keeping with the football season.

Mrs. Henry V. Raymond heads the executive committee for the annual card party for the benefit of the blind of the Brooklyn Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor the afternoon of Dec. 4 at the headquarters of the organization, 401 State Street, Brooklyn.

John B. Beisheim, superintendent and renting agent of the Burton Building at 267 Fifth Avenue, New York, ??d secretary of the Prospect Home buildingg and Loan Association of Brooklyn, died of heart disease last night in a drug store in the Lackawanna Railroad station here.

WASHINGTON.-The horse and the mule are making a valiant stand against further inroads of the tractor, the truck and the automobile. The latest . Federal Government estimate shows the horse and mule population to be about 16,000,000.

There are indications that most of the members of the United States Conference of Mayors will go to Cuba in April to attend a meeting to which the executives of the principal cities of this country and Central and South America will be invited, Mayor Antonio Beruff of Havana reported yesterday.

Miss Grace Harrington, 55 years old, assistant secretary of the Continental Rubber Company of New York, at 745 Fifth Avenue, committed suicide by hanging early yesterday in her two-room apartment at 1 East Tenth Street, according to the police.

The Scarsdale Golf Club was the scene tonight of a dance featuring costumes of the "Gay Nineties." The dance was sponsored by the young married group of the Scarsdale Woman's Club. The proceeds will be used for the philanthropic fund of the Committee of 100 of the Woman's Club. Mrs. Samuel E. Darby headed the committee in charge.

When frosts first mow down the garden we are apt to resign ourselves to the inevitable and to regard grounds and plantings, temporarily, as things of the past. Yet one of the most colorful periods of the year is to come, and with proper planning may be enjoyed on one's own grounds well into the Winter.

FOR the reader of Mr. Lucas's previous collections of es says, this volume will have no surprises to offer. The enthusiast will expect-and will findthat the author writes with ease. whimsicality and charm on almost every subject which chances to fall beneath his roving eye:

Contracts were awarded for more than $367,000,00 worth of construction of all types in the New York: metropolitan area during the first, ten months of this year, reports the F. W. Dodge Corporation. According to the report, the value of construction for which the contracts were awarded aggregated $367,322,500 on Oct. 31 last.

The Japanese military authorities announced today that they "reserve the right to adopt any measures which may be regarded necessary" if the International Settlement authorities do not quickly curb "antiJapanese and Communist activities engaged in by Chinese within the settlement."

The directors of the State Izaak Walton League adopted a resolution at the Fort Schuyler Club here today calling upon the Legislature to turn over to a State conservation commission of three members the fixing of game seasons.

LAKEWOOD, N. J.--For the coming Winter season a full program of activities is being planned. Starting with the Thanksgiving holidays, one of the major sports will be golfing on the Lakewood Country Club course.

National Supply Company 6 per cent prior preferred stock, $100 par value, will be admitted to the New York Stock Exchange list tomorrow. The Anchor Hocking Glass Corporation (which recently changed its name from the Anchor Cap Corporation)

ALLUDED to last Sunday, but not then discussed, the "Paintings for Paris" exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art can hardly expect to receive a reception other than mixed. That it contains some excellent canvases must be conceded, and with enthusiasm, at once.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Kay Seagrove of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Seagrove, to Carl Nicholas Dunn, son of the late Mrs. Marion Slocumb Dunn of Fayetteville, N. C., and of. the late Carl Nicholas Dunn of Wilmington, N. C.

Ikuo Skeda, a big private in the Japanese Army, lost his shoes in the Shanghai fighting. They might have been easily replaced except for the fact that they were size 12. The quartermaster was unable to fit him.
Following is the text of the address given today by Samuel Seabury before delegates to the National Municipal League:

Santa Claus arrived in New York in several places at once yesterday. From the appearance of the new contents of his pack he has given up the idea of filling modern, playrooms with toys that look as if they were designed by industrial engineers.

The University of Arizona unleashed a third-period attack to score a 9-7 victory over Kansas today. Paced by Smilanich and Neilsen, the Arizonans pushed 70 yards to a touchdown in six spectacular plays in the third to overcome a Kansas advantage and take a lead they never relinquished.

Leo Y. Chertok, the American who in 1935 promoted a scheme, afterward abandoned, to-lease parts of Ethiopia, plans to issue a writ tomorrow against Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, from whom he claimed to have obtained a concession of mineral and other rights in 15,000 square miles of territory.
German circles, it was learned from competent circles today, were pleased on the whole with yesterday's informal conversations between Chancellor Hitler and his unofficial guest, Viscount Halifax.

Clothing thieves, who apparently secreted themselves in the loft building at 73 Fifth Avenue at closing time Friday night and remained to work leisurely until the early hours of yesterday, stole more than 1,000 suits and overcoats valued at more than $15,000 from the Wincraft Clothing Company.

IT might be better for Steve Owen and his football Giants to take to the hills today. The Green Bay Packers are in town. But stout Steve says he will chance a meeting at the Polo Grounds. Foolish fellow. Steve doesn't have to play himself. That may explain it.
George Washington University did today what no Southwest Conference eleven had done in three years-stopped the University of Arkansas scoring attack and held the passing Razorbacks to a 0-0 tie.

Press censorship, which had long been a source of annoyance to American and other foreign correspondents, has been discontinued in cable and radio offices in the International Settlement since the capture of Shanghai by the Japanese.

ARRAS, France. A NATION-WIDE movement to save the windmills of France from destruction, particularly those of Flanders, has been started by a group of writers and journalists. Jean Lecocq is the dominating spirit of this crusade, which has "Save Our Windmills" as its battle cry.

Howard L. Auerbach and Louise O. Meuer, who have heretofore conducted the real estate firm of Meuer Auerbach, Inc., at White Plains and Scarsdale, have dissolved that firm. Mr. Auerbach will continue in business at both White Plains and Scarsdale, maintaining the same White Plains office heretofore occupied by Meuer Auerbach at 99 Mamaroneck Avenue, with the same staff there.

MONTREAL.--Aid of the Federal Government in the creation and development of the provincial parks, one at Montagne Tremblante in the Laurentian Mountains and the other at Mount Orford in the Eastern townships, is being sought by the Quebec Government.

The American Ethical Union, the federation of Ethical Culture Societies in the United States, will hold its annuel assembly in New York City next Friday and Saturday, closing with the regular morning meeting next Sunday of both the Brooklyn and New York societies, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Henry Neumann, leader of the Brooklyn society, which will be the host.
Maxwell Anderson has bought a 1,000-acre game preserve in this little town. Ernest Farrar, the former owner, used part of the property as a fur farm, breeding mink and foxes.
WHILE studios pay little attention to public indignation, a small Oklahoma community has made its voice heard, and, indirectly, an unknown actor has received a contract.

HOW long is it since we have read stories such as these--charming, slight, brilliantly executed and without the least pretense of importance? They tell us nothing but that Andre Maurois is an amusing fellow who occupies himself with the little world at the top of the social pyramid and accepts it pretty much as it is.

Help in making the dining room table more attractive to guests for the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays is offered to women of this city through homemaking and cooking classes of the WPA adult education program of the Board of Education.
Gifts of $5,000 from Mr. and Mrs Harold S. Vanderbilt, and from Ar thur Curtiss James, were an nounced last night on behalf o?? John W. Davis, chairman of the United Hospital Campaign.

The Class 1 railroads installed 62,?? freight cars in the first ten months of the year, the largest number for that period in any year since 1930, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. The figure includes cars rehabilitated or built by the railroads ?in part from old equipment.

The present recession in the heavy industries results chiefly from the large amount of "collusive bidding" in those fields, Frank Coutant, vice president of Brown Tarcher and president of the American Marketing Society, said yesterday.

United States Ambassador at Large Norman H. Davis, British delegates and the Belgian Foreign Minister today debated the draft of a 'new statement on the Chinese-Japanese conflict to be submitted Monday to the apparently moribund Brussels conference.
Western Maryland's eleven, after playing an unsuccessful aerial game for two periods, turned to straight football today and defeated Mount St. Mary's, 20-0.

Cecil Isbell, 190-pound Texan, roamed all over the frozen gridiron this afternoon, running, kicking and passing the downtrodden Boilermakers of old Purdue to a 13-to-7 victory over their arch down-State foe, Indiana University, before 25,000 shivering spectators.

In the absence of Governor Lehman from the State, Acting Governor M. William Bray today issued the annual Thanksgiving proclamation, designating next, Thursday as the day "to be devoted by the people of the State to the service of a Provident Creator."
George Fischer, father of Edward E. Fischer, assistant manager of communications for THE NEW YORK TIMES, died today at his home, 177 Pine Street, after a brief illness. His age was 80.

Mrs. Bernice Mannix, 38 years old, wife of Edward J. Mannix, vice president and general manager of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studio, was crushed to death early today in an automobile accident near this resort.

An exhibition of paintings and sculpture by artists from the Southern States is in progress in the gallery of the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, and will remain open to the public through Dec. 4. The collection has been arranged by the Women's National Democratic Organization here.

TOY collection and repairingregular autumnal activities of the Boy Scouts--are now fully under way. Ever since the organization was founded almost twentyeight years ago, this pre-Christmas good turn has absorbed the movement's growing attention, and a large number of needy children have been gladdened at Yuletide by the distribution of the repaired toys.

Saragossa was subjected to a terrific bombing by thirty-five Loyalist planes this morning. The significance of the attack, as a communique of the Ministry of National Defense frankly admitted, was that it was in retaliation for the Rebel bombardment yesterday of Bujaraloz and Sarinena, behind the Aragon front.

SHORN of the sensationalism that attended the case, and of all the features of personal emotion, notoriety, false trails and suspicions. hysteria and self-seeking which at the time could not be separated from it, the story of the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the murder of Charles Augustus Lindbergh Jr. is a very interesting story indeed.

The history of the motion picture is' being presented at Middlebury College in a weekly extra-curricular series of screen demonstrations under the auspices of the Fine Arts Department. The development of silent films in the four decades from 1894 to the Nineteen Thirties has proven such a popular subject among students that standing room only is available to late comers at the college playhouse.

RUSSELL LLEWELLYN was standing one day-prophetically-on a street corner in Hollywood, waiting for a street car. A man came up behind him and, with a perfectly serious face, asked him if he would like to work in the movies.
Japan, her arms victorious and her banner of the rising sun floating over a score of newly conquered Chinese cities, is probably about to face the world with a fait accompli.

As one of the major features in a program for promoting international amity between the United States, Great Britain and her dominions, a pilgrimage is being planned to bring some 1,000 English men and women to this country from Barnstaple, England, next year to attend the tercentenary of Barnstable, Mass., founded by ancestors of the American Ambassador to the Court of St. James, Robert Worth Bingham.

THE two events of the past week are the return to London of Gladys Cooper with Philip Merivale in James Parish's "Good-bye to Yesterday" and the production by the new International Theatre Club of James Bridie's "Susannah and the Elders."

The wedding of Miss Rosalie Virginia Bertram, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Wendt Bertram of Cayuga Heights, Ithaca, N. Y., to William Mack Sheffeld of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur Sheffeld of Northampton, Mass., took place here this evening at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Lum.

Six Broadway theatres were picketed last night by members of the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union No. 18032, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, in its campaign to win recognition from the League of New York Theatres, the organization of the producers, as the collective bargaining agent for house managers, box office men, company managers and press agents.

Mrs. Julia Willmothe Henshaw, authority on native flora of British Columbia and author of several books on the subject, died Thursday night of a heart ailment at her home at the age of 68. She was a columnist and book reviewer for The Vancouver Sun.

Roast coon is a delicacy much sought these Autumn days by Berkshire epicures, especially at camps where veteran hunters gather and spin yarns about the thrilling midnight sport they enjoyed fifty or sixty years ago.
Members of the Graham Alumnae Association will hold a card party the afternoon of Dec. 2 at the home of Mrs. King Smith, 563 Park Avenue, in behalf of their charitable enterprises.
The Union League of Philadelphia, long a citadel of Republicanism, will observe the seventy-fifth anniversary of its founding on Monday, with a Democrat as guest speaker.

" DANCE International 19001937" will get under way in the International Building at Rockefeller Center next Sunday afternoon with a private preview of the various exhibitions of paintings, sculptures, and the like, which have taken their inspiration from the dance.

Miss Helen Creighton Palmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight R. G. Palmer of this place, was married this afternoon to Jonathan Edwards Currier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Currier of Montclair. The ceremony was performed in Hillside Presbyterian Church, Orange, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John A. MacSporran.

Musk oxen are getting to be quite a problem on Nunivak Island, near Point Barrow, Alaska. The Eskimos exterminated them in 1865, so the United States Biological Survey brought in some more to provide food and wool.

Thirty Stanford football players and four coaches entrained tonight for New York, where they will play Columbia next Saturday. The members of the traveling squad, most of whom saw action in today's 13-to-0 defeat at the hands of California. are:

Washington gained a first division berth in the Pacific Coast Conference with a 14-to-0 triumph over Oregon today. On the first scrimmage of the game, Merle Miller, Washington halfback, dashed 67 yards.
The Federal Trade Commission moved today to comply with President Roosevelt's request for an investigation of the factors responsible for the increased cost of living.
Stocks recovered and closed higher after receding to-low level of Oct. 19; turnover, 1,232,100 shares. United States Government and other bonds lower; transactions, $5,285,000.

Joseph P. Day announced yesterday that several sales of properties owned by the Atlantic Beach Sales Corporation at Atlantic Beach, L. I;, have been closed since his organization and William L. Austin Jr., Inc., were appointed sales agents by the corporation six weeks ago.

TO drive by automobile from Miami to Key West in four hours' time without ferrying across the two water gaps of Lower Matecumbe Key and No Name Key will soon be possible??robably within a few months' time.

Bohemia, the Eastern Shore (Md.) plantation of D. K. Este Fisher Jr. of Baltimore, has been purchased by J. D. Otley of Philadelphia through Previews, Inc., and the Maryland-Virginia Farm Agency of Baltimore.

Captain Odas Moon of the Army Air Corps died yesterday at the Hotel Chamberlin at Old Point Comfort, Va., where he was awaiting retirement from active service, effective Dec. 31, the War Department announced today. He was 45 years of age.

The 15 per cent increase in freight rates asked by the railroads from the Interstate Commerce Commission involves no real conflict between security owners, on the one hand, and producers, shippers and the public on the other,

The newspaper Hochi said today that Kensuke Horinouchi, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs, might succeed Hiroshi Saito as Japanese Ambassador to the United States. Mr. Saito, who was appointed Ambassador to Washington late in 1933, probably would be transferred to London, the newspaper said.

Mark Graves, president of the New York State Tax Commission, and A. A. Berle Jr., Chamberlain of the City of New York, will be among the speakers at a series of meetings to be held tomorrow and Tuesday in the Waldorf-Astoria by the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.

Upsala scored its first victory over Moravian and ended its season with four triumphs in eight starts by defeating the Pennsylvanians today, 7--0. Bill Wilson crossed the visitors' goal-line early in the second period on the third of three Vikings offensives that got inside the 5-yard line. Vinnie Albanese plunged for the final point. Moravian failed to make a first down.

" The court decisions in Iowa and Arizona which affirm the legality of urinalysis and blood tests as evidence in traffic accidents involving drinking drivers and pedestrians, are proving timely aids in the campaign to curtail the liquor-bred fatalities on the highways of the United States," said Charles R. Jones, executive vice president of the American Business Men's Research Foundation, in a statement issued today.
Less than six months after Neville Chamberlain became Prime Minister, there is already a revival of the familiar British pastime of guessing who his successor will be.

A slogan maue popular by a large American advertising agency reads: "Keeping everlastingly at it brings success." The rulers of the Third Reich have adopted that principle in their foreign relations and the result has been just what the slogan promised.

A reawakening of interest in religion is apparent this Fall among students at Sarah Lawrence College. They asked for a course on religion this year, and also organized independently a round-table to discuss religious problems. Almost 20 per cent of the student body attended the first Discussion.
Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended Nov. 17, which included only five business days in most of the reporting centers, aggregated $8,335,000,000,

Sid White broke away for three touchdowns to lead the Brooklyn College football team to victory over the New York Aggies, 27-0, on Erasmus Field yesterday. It was the sixth victory in a row for the Kingsmen.
Continually forcing the play, particularly in the first half, Lehigh University's stalwarts scored a convincing 4-0 victory over Lafayette's soccer squad on Lehigh Field this morning.

Undefeated Holy Cross was held to a scoreless tie by Carnegie Tech today in a dogged football battle, fought through a snowstorm before 15,000 half-frozen spectators. The visiting Skibos rose up with three great goal-line stands to turn back the Crusaders in the first half after Bill Osmanski's running and Ronny Cahill's passing had provided scoring chances.
MR. CHEVIGNY, in spite of his name an authentic American with the blood of Northwest fur traders in his veins, has done more than competent, craftsmanlike job in writing this book.

In the festivities that marked the twentieth anniversary of the revolution out of which the Soviet Union emerged, science received its due. Lenin, Stalin, all leaders, determined at the outset to put research at the service of the government.

An entertainment for the benefit of the Chinese Women's Relief Association of New York, of which Mme. Chiang Kai-shek is honorary president, will be given the evening of Dec. 5 in the Park Lane Cafe. Proceeds will be used to aid war sufferers in China.

In recent weeks the world has witnessed the collapse of one more attempt at governmental regulation of the law of supply and demand. This time the commodity is coffee, and the nation, Brazil. The world's largest producer of coffee has finally admitted, after more than thirty years of price control and valorization planning, the economic fallacy of such measures.

THE Postoffice Department, Uncle Sam's willing horse. performed another large extra task for the na tion last week without visible strain or audible murmur. Congress wants to know how many persons in the land are out of work. Several ways of finding out were suggested, but the postoffices, as usual, got the job.

For its fifth offering since it opened under the auspices of the WPA New York State theatre Project, the Theatre of the Four Seasons, presented tonight its company of players in one of Eugene O'Neill's earliest dramas,

Thwarted by a pass interception and a fumble on two first-half advances, Lafayette's Leopards came roaring back today to capitalize on a third-period break for a 6-to-O victory over Lehigh and the honor of being the Maroon's third undefeated and untied football team of all time.
Bath-tub manufacturers of the United States and Canada, meeting here today, declared that talk about high building costs does not apply to the plumbing industry.
Paul E. Stark, retiring president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards will speak on the housing situation in America at the Southeast Regional Convention

The first period of the HarvardYale debate today had the rooters for the two rivals in a daze. It looked bad for both teams. Away down in Harvard territory Macdonald got off a kick that would have been a swell lateral pass. But it wasn't worth anything as a punt. So Yale had the ball deep in Harvard territory and the game had just started.

last year in the number of students joining sororities at Hunter College has been announced by Miss Marjorie L. Langenbahn, faculty adviser of the Pan-Hellenio Association of the college. An increase of 11 per cent over' eight girls have been pledged by twenty-four sororities this semester and will be initiated at the end of the term.

A buck deer strolled through the yard of the old First Dutch Church here. It eluded efforts to corner it and crashed through the plate-glass window of the postoffice, backed out and butted into an auto truck, streaked south and paused in a Cedar Street back yard.
Arthur W. Slocum, assistant curator of the Walker Museum of Paleontology at the University of Chicago, died today at his home of a heart ailment.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. W. Everit Burnet of Orange of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elinore Everit Burnet, to Edward C. Platt, son of Mrs. A. Hunter Platt and the late Captain Platt of Versailles, Ky.
The country's Mayors have come and gone in Washington and left the capital more tangled than ever over the nation's more or less chronic budget-vs.-relief headache.
William L. Galvin, Baltimore attorney, has been elected a trustee of the Catholic University of America to succeed the late Francis W. Garvan of New York.
Councilman Frederick V. Ferber has become Acting Mayor of this city following the resignation this week of Mayor Ralph F. De Clairmont.

The formal deadline for the filing of unemployment census report cards passed at midnight last night, but postal authorities announced that they would continue to accept cards that came in the mail up to tomorrow morning . Great bundles of completed forms testified to the comprehensiveness of the response, but no estimate on the number returned was available.

Food budgets will not be put to any unexpected strain in footing the bill for the Thanksgiving feast this week, for in general most of the ingredients are moderate or low in price.. Many fruits and vegetables are cheap. While turkey is a little higher than it was a year ago, it is still considered an excellent buy at 33 cents a pound.

Princeton's football team salvaged some solace from a somewhat sad season today by scoring a surprise triumph over Navy. The Tigers, generally regarded as certain prey for the Midshipmen, struck quickly and often, and came through to a convincing victory, 26 to 6.

The Columbia College of Pharmacy basketball team opened its 1937-38 campaign by defeating an alumni quintet, 36 to 20, at the Columbia University gymnasium last night. Bob Lazarowitz, varsity center, captured high-scoring honors with 14 points.

A Christmas bazaar, sale and tea in behalf of the Art Workers Club for Women will take place on Dec. 2 at the Pierre. An organization of women artists and models, the club was founded in 1898 to give these two classes of art workers opportunities for association and mutual benefit.

Speaking before the New York Stock Exchange Institute on Thursday, by coincidence the day before President Roosevelt announced that he had asked the Federal Trade Commission to make an immediate investigation of factors which have contributed to the sharp rise in the cost of living this year, Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation, outlined the economic importance of the food industry in the United States.

IN earlier books Mr. Lewis told the story of a sheep dog, of a racing horse and of one of the dogs trained to guide the blind. Here the story is of a wild animal, a hill fox of the Scottish Highlands.
Harry A. Howard has been made general manager of the Boston division of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc. He was formerly manager of the company's Buffalo division.

Leslie MacMitchell, sensational schoolboy mile and cross-country star from George Washington High School, scored his eighth successive victory yesterday in the first annual interscholastic cross-country run sponsored by the New York University Spiked Shoe Club at Van Cortlandt Park.
ON MOTHER LOVE: Just about twenty years ago there came to Smith College at Northampton, Mass., a new President, Dr. William Allan Neilson,

The eighteen-story apartmenthotel structure known as the Buckingham at the northwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Sixth Avenue, together with all furniture, furnishings and equipment. will be sold. at auction tomorrow in the Vesey Street salesrooms by Edwin J. McDonald.

Hempstead High School pushed over a touchdown in the first period to defeat the Neptune (N. J.) High School eleven, 6-0, today. The victory was Hempstead's eighth straight of the year and enabled it to remain one of the two undefeated teams in Nassau County.

While the home building dollar today buys 15 per cent more plumbing than in 1929 and 21 per cent more than in 1926, the real basis for comparison is not in prices but in the greater beauty, durability. and improved performance of modern plumbing equipment, reports the Plumbing and Heating Industries Bureau.
Auburn's favored Tigers and Georgia's Bulldogs, a team given little, if any, chance, battled to a scoreless tie today in their forty-second skirmish of a feud dating back to the gay Nineties.

Sidney Hale Miner, a leading citizen of New London, died this afternoon of a heart attack at his home, at Post Hill Place, at the age of 69. A lifelong resident of this city, Mr. Miner was born Aug. 23, 1868, the son of Frederick and Jennie Hale Miner.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel W. Farnsworth of Montclair, N. J., of the engagement of their youngest daughter, Miss Frances Farnsworth, to Francis Murray Jaeckel, son of Mrs. Ethel Tracy Jaeckel of New York and Major H. F. Jaeckel Jr., of this city and Westchester.

Four more patrolmen were dismissed from the department yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine, bringing the total to 189 since he took office. Each of the latest dismissals was based on intoxication.

ANOTHER week with some twoscore of exhibitions to be chronicled forces the hand of the reluctant reviewer. With regret that the exigencies of space do not permit extended comment on many of the shows,

Creation of the new post of directress of dramatics at the University of Pennsylvania and the appointment of Miss Kathleen Quinn, formerly associated with the Theatre Guild, to fill it have resulted in an enlarged program in dramatics among women students, most of whom are enrolled in the College of Liberal Arts for Women and the School of Education.

By a fortuitous coincidence-its date had been fixed long in advance-the sixth annual meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors convened in Washington last week on the same day as the special session of Congress..

New York went to the polls to elect a Mayor, District Attorney and other officials, including a City Council. That night New York knew that Fiorello H. La Guardia had been re-elected Mayor, that Thomas E. Dewey had been elected District Attorney. But yesterday, almost three weeks later, the city still did not know the complete list of its Councilmen.

Miss Dorothy Louise Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grover D. Davis of Merion, will be married to Harry Nye Lucas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucas of Ardmore, next Friday evening in the Joseph Priestley Chapel of the First Unitarian Church of Philadelphia.

The police today continued raids in Paris and its suburbs and numerous provincial centers in their efforts to track down the conspirators and their arms caches in the mysterious plot against the State.
Eugene Treadwell, retired corporation lawyer, died yesterday morning at his home, 421 West 162d Street, after an illness of several years. He was 86 years old.
TWENTY - EIGHT contractors submitted bids recently to State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner of New Jersey for three projects which will be financed by the Federal Government.

A special conference on Better Care for Mothers and Babies has been called at the instance of medical and other interested groups to meet here on Jan. 17 and 18. In announcing the conference today, Miss Katherine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor,

The American Medical Association today opened fire on 430 insurgent physicians who advocate that the Federal government share with the medical profession the financial burden of caring for the sick. Private physicians have traditionally reserved this duty for themselves, fearing that "State medicine" would lower their standards of practice.

Despite the fact that the city of Los Angeles, Calif., has very few tenements, it has several slum sections which need eradication, points out George B. Buckley of the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce.

The Habsburg spirit, almost as Austria knew it for centuries under the monarchy, was abroad tonight on Archduke Otto's twenty-fifth birthday. Thousands sent telegrams and letters to Steenockerzeel Castle in Belgium, where the Austrian pretender spent a quiet day with family and friends after what Viennese legitimists termed a hunting trip "such as the Kaiser often makes."

The most unusual piano prodigy of recent years seems to be 11year-old Julius (Buddy) Katchen, who lives with his parents in the west end of Long Branch. Buddy plays the piano so well that the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra of New York is presenting him as soloist in the D minor Mozart concerto on Monday, on which day the orchestra plays its annual pension-fund benefit.

EUGENE BOUDIN. By Ruth L. Benjamin 8vo. New York: Raymond Raymond, 40 East Forty-ninth Street $4. A biographical and critical study of the artist. AMERICAN MEMORY. Compiled by Henry Beston. 12mo. New York: Farrar Rinehart. $3.50.

A veritable arsenal has been seized by the Bahia military area commander, consisting of millions of cartridges, hand grenades, machine guns and rifles. Minister of War Enrico Gasper Dutra today stated that they were found at the police state headquarters.

IF you have always thought of the amateur movie camera as a rather expensive toy, limited in scope to the recording of pleasant little domestic scenes, vacation travels, club plays and the like, the versatility and imaginative skill of many of today's amateur movie makers may come as something of a surprise.
Traffic congestion is a common complaint with European capitals, and no great city could be more busily engaged in combatting this difficulty than Paris is at this moment.

A mass meeting attended by some 60,000 persons was held this afternoon at the Tropical Stadium to promote a Three-Year Plan launched by Colonel Fulgencio Batista, Chief of Staff of the army, several months ago. It envisages an economic and social. reconstruction of the island.

The Canadian medical profession is watching the campaign being waged in the United States against infantile paralysis, Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe, physician to the Dionne quintuplets, declared in a statement issued yesterday by the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthdav.

Florida's defense wilted in the second half today before the onslaught of a powerful Georgia Tech football team and the Engineers rolled to a 12-to-0 victory. Stopping Fletcher Sims and Dutch Konemann, ace backs, proved too much of a job for the Gators, who kept the Yellow Jackets out of payoff territory during the opening periods but faded in the last two sessions.

J. Edward Tropp, 30 years old, manager of the Perfection Fur Dyeing and Dressing Company in Newark and former scholastic football star, hanged himself today in his home here. Dr. George P. 01cott Jr., assistant county medical examiner, pronounced the case suicide.

Wesleyan and Army battled in soccer to a scoreless tie today, despite two overtime periods. Led by Odom and Raleigh, West Point threatened three times in the first half. In the second half Esterbrook and Hammerstrom led a drive for Wesleyan which nearly scored.
