NATIONS Shall Speak Peace Unto Nations" is the legend carved above the portals of the British Broadcasting Corporation. It was hoped that this maxim might become the beacon of all international broadcasting. It has not.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis August Bodenheim of Kew Gardens, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene J. Bodenheim, to Willis J. Fosdick, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Sheldon Fosdick of Massapequa, L. I.
The unrelenting tenacity of the police, when one of their own is involved, ended yesterday the 6-year old mystery of the killing of a police sergeant in a hold-up and solved two Harlem gang slayings.

Two clean performances over a hard ten-hurdle course gave Lieutenant Douglas Cleland of the Canadian Army team the individual military jumping championship at the Royal Winter Fair horse show tonight.

With volume in their first year expected to reach $1,000,000, manufacturers of elastic supporters for men are planning to launch more extensive promotional campaigns for 1938, representatives of various companies said here yesterday.

The nineteenth game of the match for the chess championship of the world between Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris was begun here tonight, with Dr. Euwe conducting the white pieces.

To raise funds for a Gershwin memorial concert hall in Jerusalem, Mailamm, the American-Palestine Music Association, in cooperation with the George Gershwin memorial committee, will give a concert Tuesday night, Jan. 18, at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Leaders of an unauthorized strike in the Fisher Body Corporation plant here were summoned tonight by Homer Martin, international president of the United Automobile Workers of America, to meet in Detroit tomorrow with the U. A. W. A.'s executive board.

Mrs. Randal Morgan, founder and chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild for Philadelphia, has announced that several members of her committee will attend the "At Home" to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York next Friday.
On a snow-covered gridiron the Iowa State Cyclones pulled their annual Bix Six upset today by defeating a favored Kansas State football team, 13 to 7.
HOT SPRINGS, Va.--With Thanksgiving Day so near, it is natural that wild turkey should be the major objective of huntsmen in the Virginia mountains just now.

The former private residence of Colonel Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of State in President Hoover's Cabinet, at 120 East Thirty-sixth Street, which was sold last April to Mrs. Helen M. deKay, has just been completely remodeled by the new owner at a cost of approximately $25,000.
Major Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commanding the general headquarters of the air force, will make two awards for proficiency to army air corps units at Barksdale Field, La., tomorrow.

AMAZING, when you think of it, that the Pilgrims could be thankful even without a neighborhood movie house around the stockade corner. They never had a chance to watch Mickey Mouse or hear Donald Duck. Mr. Chaplin was no part of their lives, nor were Garbo, Joan Crawford, Kay Francis or Robert Taylor.
John D. Beals Jr. was re-elected governor of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York at the annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Ambassador.

This is the last day of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair in Rockefeller Center. It will close a seventeen-day run at 6 P. M. In three auditorium programs yesterday morning, afternoon and evening, thirteen authors addressed visitors who came,
The third anniversary carnival of the House Plan at City College was celebrated last night in the college gymnasium at 139th Street and Convent Avenue by about 1,000 students.

Publication of the first volume of historical records of New York counties outside of Greater New York City was announced today by Edward P. Alexander, State director of the Historical Records Survey, a nation-wide WPA project.

Tax reform legislation will be ready for submission to Congress by Jan. 15, and not before, according to members of the subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee who have been working on the problem for several weeks.

The author of the following letter, now Professor of Law at Louisiana University, was for twenty-five years the American representative on the Mixed Internatiknal Tribunal at Cairo, Egypt, of which he became chief judge.

A Little Rock radio station set up its broadcasting equipment for the George Washington-Arkansas game today-for the benefit of only one listener. By agreement, local stations do not broadcast local games.

President Getulio Vargas issued a statement after a Cabinet meeting tonight officially announcing that foreign debt payments had been suspended beginning today but that Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa had been authorized to begin negotiations with creditors for new agreements "within the realm of possibilities."

Most of those who are advocating a national ever-normal granary are "thinking almost entirely in terms of an approach toward price-control," according to a report issued yesterday by the farm committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, of which Warren W. Shoemaker, vice president of Armour Co., is chairman.

Operations in the grain market showed a disposition to expand today and prices moved upward on commissionhouse buying and short covering with sentiment generally more friendly to the bull side as a result of a rally in securities, reports indicating large export sales of corn and a lowering in estimates on the new Argentina wheat crop.

Hartford Rayon Corporation voting trust certificates for common stock, $1 par value, will be admitted to dealings on the New York Curb Exchange tomorrow. Following the lead of the New York Stock Exchange, the Curb will issue a Wednesday dividend supplement to its Saturday bulletin.
The Davega Stores Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on Sept. 25 a net income of $141,954 after depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Labor support of the present campaign of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross was acknowledged yesterday by Mrs. David Challinor, roll-call director. Contributions of the day, she adds, included a $500 check from the Italian Dressmakers Union, which was voted when the union's executive board met Friday night.

Four vacant tenement houses at 330 to 336 East Thirty-fifth Street, between First and Second Avenues, have been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to the 330 East Thirty-fifth Street Corporation, represented by Dwyer, Gold Kennedy, attorneys.

PHILADELPHIA must be simply rocking. Close on the heels of an announcement that the Pennsylvania Museum had acquired for $110,000 the famous huge "Bathers," from the Pellerin collection in Paris, came Dr. Albert C. Barnes's challenging retort that this canvas is no better than "fifth-rate for a Cezanne," and that Dr. Barnes himself had a chance to buy it for $80,000 and had even been assured he could get it for as little as $50,000.

The Estonian Consul General, Karl Kuusik, decorated two American Y. M. C. A. leaders yesterday with his country's Order Second Class of the Red Cross for the aid they have given in the rehabilitation of Estonia since 1920.

Gold Digger, owned by Charles Toy of New York and handled by Harry Cameron, came through to a handsome victory in the second annual meeting of the Monmouth County Field Trial Association today. The event, for non-winners and openall age cockers, was run over the Big Brook Pheasant Farm course.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago market today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 11,000 head, including 10,000 directs. Prices 10-15c lower than Friday's average. Early sales good and choice 200250 pounds average sold at $7.90 to $8 a hundredweight; top, $8, compared with week ago, around $1 lower.

Lebanon Valley downed Juniata College today, 16 to 0. It was the eleventh straight victory over Juniata since the series started in 1920. Tony Rozman booted his sixth field goal of the season in the first period to start the scoring.

Archbishop Samuel A. Stritch in a letter to Catholic pastors in the Milwaukee archdiocese today banned "chance games at church or institutional benefits or recreational activities at which the prizes given will be money or its equivalent."

Miss Karin Ness, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernhard Ness of East Orange, was marred to Pearce Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Morgan of Morristown, this evening in the Swedish Congregational Church here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Carl Peterson.
DEESPITE the fact that John Masefield is in this novel as expert as usual at tell ing a story, it is evident that a deeper purpose than mere story telling prompted the book.

Members of the Women's City Club will hold a dinner meeting at the American Museum of Natural History tomorrow evening to arouse interest in the city's museums. Following a program of speeches at which Mrs. Courtlandt D. Barnee will preside, the group will visit African Hall and see a demonstration of the preparation of specimens for the habitat groups.

Through funds made available by the National Youth Administration 122 members of the student body of Manhattan College are receiving financial assistance in defraying the expenses of their college education, it was said yesterday by J. Paul Gaffney, campus administrator of this governmental project.

James H. R. Cromwell, one of five prospects under consideration for appointment to the United States Senate to succeed Senator A. Harry Moore of New Jersey, criticized the proposed Wages and Hours Bill as one that would reduce labor standards and demoralize business in a radio address last night.

Another Dartmouth hoodoo was put to rout in the mud of Baker Field yesterday, and on one and the same afternoon Earl Blaik's Wah-Hoo Indians scored their first final-game victory in ten years, completed their first season unbeaten since 1925 and carried off the mythical Ivy League honors for the second successive year.

WITH the tremendous growth of the cruise business in recent years estimates make it a $60,000,000-a-year industry in West Indies travel alone-has come a corresponding increase in the efforts of operators to entertain the voyager.

ON several values of the Brazilian revolutionary stamps of 1931 appears a portrait of Getulio Dernelles Vargas, who has now by a coup d'etat again changed the form of government of Brazil. This change is likely to affect the future stamps of Brazil.

Catholic war veterans were urged last night by the Rev. Edward J. Higgins of the Astoria Church of the Immaculate Conception to become "the shock troops of the Catholic church in combating communism in all its branches."
President Anastasio Somoza said today that propositions submitted by the mediators in the HondurasNicaragua boundary dispute had been accepted with a few minor observations.

American participation in a 3,000,000,000-yen semi-official corporation for the development of Manchurian industry was predicted last week by Yoshisuke Aikawa, Japanese industrialist. The report was greeted in this country with denials and ridicule,
Several dinners will be given before the annual benefit theatre party of the Little Italy Neighborhood Association of Brooklyn tomorrow night at the Henry Miller Theatre.

THE announcement last week that Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., will make an annual award to the newspaper man whose work is judged best in the dissemination of aviation information, recalls the fact that several men have lost their lives reporting aircraft events.

The John Pullman Real Estate Company, Inc., one of Brooklyn's oldest realty firms, celebrated its fiftieth anniversary last week, having been established at its present location, 74 Union Street, in 1887.

A national appraisal forum was held in Washington, D. C., last week. Up rose Dr. J. B. Kincer of the Weather Bureau to warn his hearers that he dust bowl problems cannot be solved without regarding climate and weather.
" WHAT beauty is,' Durer wrote, 'I do not know; but it depends upon many things.' Therefore, he continues, the artist must inquire widely, so that he will have 'a mind well stored.'

A SPECIAL performance of "Cavalleria Rusticana" will be given by the Hippodrome at the twelfth anniversary celebration of the Italian daily, "Stampa Libera," to be held at the Hippodrome today at 2:30 P. M.

The Connecticut State eleven marched over Sabin Field today for a 76-0 rout of a demoralized Norwich team. All twenty-five members of the Connecticut squad took turns on the field with equal' success and Norwich never threatened.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their maturity dates were in somewhat larger volume than in the preceding period but the list again consisted principally of small amounts of foreign government and domestic municipal loans.

Miss Alice Jean Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ryan of this city, became the bride of Charles P. Lutkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Lutkin, in St. Mary's Catholic Church here this morning. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Thomas E. Larkin. A reception for the immediate families followed at the Carteret Hotel.
Developments on several fronts this week thrust the question of New Deal electric power policies into the foregrouna, with the issues more sharply drawn than ever before.

Swarthmore College closed its football season in a blaze of glory today, turning back a strong Drexel team by 20-12. The Dragons tallied first as they marched from their 34-yard line, Hughes going over from the Swarthmore 3.

The revived Baylor Bears smothered Loyola University of Los Angeles, 27-13, today as Bullet Bill Patterson tossed three touchdown passes. Patterson and Bubba Gernand put the Texans in the lead in the first quarter and they were never headed.
THE lives of these twelve saints and rebels are moving testimony of the age old struggle for freedom and social justice. In this day.

A SOCIALLY important branch of film business which seems to have escaped the notice of movie historians is the free film field. Without any of the ballyhoo familiar to Hollywood and without even the usual publicity releases, the use of free films has been increasing steadily over a period of twenty-six years.

EITHER just as it was, or installed in a thoroughly upto-date museum, the splendid Bache collection might be exhibited to advantage. One may doubt whether any in-between method would prove as effective.

On a Saturday night last August a weary Congress, irritated by the moist heat of the capital, exhausted by the intraparty debate over the Supreme Court and saddened by the death of Senator Robinson, adjourned with most of its business unfinished.

The Bear Mountain and Harriman Section of the Palisades Interstate Park launched its sixteenth Winter sports season today as the big indoor rink on the shore of Hessian Lake was opened to the public. Skating sessions will be held daily.
It is with a mildly skeptical eye that the French have been watching the new British effort to hold "exploratory conversations" with the governors of Germany.

The Great Neck section of Long Island has been the scene of much residential activity this year, states Harold R. Young, president of the Great Neck Real Estate Board, who points out that since Jan. 1 more than $2,000,000 worth of new homes have been built and sold in that vicinity.

GERMANY'S annual charity stamp issue has been received. As reported in these columns last week, the set is nautical in character. Values, colors and designs are 3 plus 2 pfennigs brown, a rescue vessel;

Real estate appraisers should not be saddled with the extra responsibility of negotiating mortgage loans, says S. Edwin Kazdin, chairman of the education committee of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers.

Amherst alumni, undergraduates and the administrative officers of the college are analyzing the facts and figures on which the committee on the cooperative business management of fraternities based the report read at the annual meeting of the alumni council on Nov. 5.

A 25-yard run around right end by Elmer Tarbox in the opening period netted a touchdown and carried Texas Tech to a 7-to-2 victory over Centenary today. The two points for the Gents were scored on a safety in the third period when Calhoun missed a low pass from center behind the goal line after his team had been penalized to the one.

Another tropical fantasy will be presented by members of the Seventh Regiment in their armory at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street on the night of Dec. 4, when they will give their annual Autumn military ball as a Mexican Fiesta.

Science has discovered a new chapter in the history of the Polynesians who settled Hawaii. Kenneth P. Emory, ethnologist of the Bishop Museum in Honolulu, found on the lava-caked flanks of towering Mauna Koa remains of what he believes were the world's largest workshops for the manufacture of stone implements.

A tremendous pick-up in building construction is inevitable. The longer it is delayed, the surer it is to come. Whether it will begin within a few months, in time to ameliorate. The present "intermediate" recession-as the government would like it to-is very questionable. But it will come.

There may have been better football games than the annual classic between Harvard and Yale on Soldiers Field today, but one would have to go a long way to match it in thrills, dramatic episodes, soulstirring plays and the sheer determination shown by the two old gridiron rivals.

In the busiest Saturday trading since Oct. 24, the stock market yesterday recovered part of Friday's severe losses, with leading issues up 1 to 4 points on the day. The recovery seemed easiest explained on "technical grounds," since there was little in the day's news to induce new buying.

The Baltimore F. C. will provide the opposition for the unbeaten Brookhattan S. C. this afternoon at Starlight Park in an American Soccer League contest. The meeting will be the second in eight days between the two squads, Brookhattan having triumphed by a onegoal margin in a thrilling battle at Baltimore last Sunday.
Flushing Garden Club will meet on Monday at 3 o'clock at the home of the president, Mrs.' Henry Austin Clark, to hear an illustrated lecture, "Gardens of Mexico," delivered by Mrs. Henry E. Coe.

Prince Fumitaka Konoye, 22-yearold spn of Japan's Premier, asserted last night that the further growth of world public opinion against his native land "may lead to a disastrous consequence for Japan."
THE American Academy in Rome announces its annual compe tition for the Prix de Rome in musical composition. The prize is a fellowship in musical composition with a yearly stipend of $1,250.

The marriage of Miss Caroline Baury Jansen, younger daughter of Lieut. Col. Thomas E. Jansen, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jansen of this place and Washington, D. C., to William Adams Pope, son of Mrs. Walter F. Pope of Sandwich, Mass., and the late Mr. Pope, took place today in the New Prospect Church near Pine Bush. The Rev. Harold L. Andress, rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Middletown, performed the ceremony.

Internal conflict between the C. I. 0. and the A. F. of L. was blamed yesterday for the closing of Brookwood Labor College, in a statement from the directors. The board also listed the depression and intensive activity in union organization as contributing factors in ending the career of the pioneer resident school for workers, opened at Ratonah, twenty-one years ago.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Elizabeth. MacArt, daughter .of Mr. and Mrs. James A. MacArt of this city, to Preston Henry Hadley Jr. of Newark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Preston H. Hadley of Bellows Falls, Vt., took place at a candlelight service this afternoon in Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church here.

Mrs. Louis Rembar Shapiro of this city and West End, N. J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Asenath Shapiro, to Howard Edward Kohn 2d, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James M. Kohn.

The New York Rangers outskated the Maroons tonight for a 3-0 National Hockey League victory, giving the Red Shirts their third shutout in as many games. The triumph, gained before 5,000 fans, moved the Rangers into a second-place tie with the Chicago Black Hawks in the league's American group.

Now that the partridge, quail and pheasant season is closed throughout this State, Long Island excepted, many hunters will give the birds no thought until next year. Fortunately for the birds, however, there are some sportsmen and a few sportsmen's clubs, concerned as to the wintering of this game.
OILS and water-colors by more than thirty artists, some of them relatively newcomers in the local exhibition field, are to be seen this week at the Montross Gallery.

THE mysterious death of Crown Prince Rudolph, son of the Emperor and King Francis Joseph, is once more attracting public attention. The stage. the screen, the printing presses have been mobilized to satisfy world-wide curiosity about one of the great royal dramas of modern history.

The Maritime Commission in a report today on storage of import property at North Atlantic ports criticized 106 American and foreign steamship companies for engaging in "unreasonable practices in connection with the free storage of import property" at New York in violation of the Shipping Act of 1916.

Thanksgiving week celebrations in Berkshire will start Tuesday night, with dances at Wendell Hotel, Pittsfield; Richmond Hotel, North Adams, and Berkshire Inn, Great Barrington, for the benefit of the Berkshire Hills Conference.
A special Senate committee discussed informally today possible changes in the Social Security Act to eliminate provisions for building up huge reserves.
Just where the pig figures in the wage scale had every one puzzled in County Court when Robert Spears was asking back wages from William Stevens.

THIS is the eighth collection of The New Yorker's pic tured comments upon the contemporary scene, and it is the largest of them all. Here are the shrewd observation, the gay cynicism, the amusing twist of thought, the occasional touch of humor that is close to pathos, which we look for in the work of these artists of The New Yorker;

TWO thousand years ago the twenty-third of last Sepmember was born a man who did about the best job in recorded history. He was born in a time of constant wars, both imperialistic and ideological; a time of "failure of nerve and revolt against mere intellect";

Blackstone's Reflector, black dog owned by Mrs. Leonard J. Buck of Far Hills, N. J., tonight was acclaimed best at the sixteenth annual specialty exhibition of the Cocker Spaniel Breeders Club of New England, which was concluded in Horticultural Hall in the presence of a big assemblage of spaniel enthusiasts from all parts of the country.

TOSCANINI has come and gone leaving behind a memory of unforgettable experiences and a trail of gossip, anecdote, hero-worship and herophobia. His admirers in London are legion but there is also here a small company determined to resist at all cost the fascination he exerts, ready to condemn for no better reason than because they are wearied by others' praise.

Kenelm Winslow, member of a socially prominent New York family, obtained a license here today to marry Madeline West of New York. Mr. Winslow, whose present address is Wellfleet, Mass., is 30 years old, and his bride-to-be is 27.

The pressure against the dollar in the foreign exchange market which was a characteristic of last week's dealings continued yesterday, although gains were confined to the Continental European exchanges.
The first impressions of Viscount- Halifax's talks in Germany have not yet discouraged those in high places here who were responsible for his journey.
A spokesman for Manuel Irujo said today that the republican Minister of Justice had pledged his aid toward opening the first Catholic church in Loyalist Spain since the civil war began.
The Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra-seventy-two men and nine women-gave its first concert yesterday, under the leadership of Russian-born Fabian Sevitzky of Philadelphia.

In an aside comment on President Roosevelt's opening message to the special session last Monday a Senator still high in the councils of the New Deal said with a sly smile: "It is to be hoped that the President will cooperate with Congress in a program of constructive action for the country's welfare."

IN its prospectus the Metroplitan Opera Assocation lists a group of ninety-eight singers as available for principal roles. The management, however, has ninety-nine. Who is the ninety-ninth? That is apparently the management's secret. Shall this unknown, unlisted, unannounced artist be called the mystery singer of the Metropolitan?

The football Panthers of the University of Pittsburgh, rolling along undefeated through the end of their home schedule, pummeled Penn State, 28 to 7, today before 23,000 spectators who braved snow and cold to see the old rivals in their thirty-seventh annual battle.
At a student assembly, held in Loyola College Library Hall today, the dean, the Rev. Lawrence C. Gorman, announced the following honor men on the dean's list:
Gerald Tracy, a young American pianist who has appeared here several times in recital, played a program yesterday afternoon at Town Hall in which marked improvement was shown.

Clarence Hodson Co., Inc., announced yesterday the public offering of 200,000 shares of Class A common stock of the American Business Credit Corporation. The shares offered by means of a prospectus, are priced at $6.25 each. The net proceeds will be used for working capital.

The Hip Sing Tong, with a network of branches and thousands of members throughout the nation, was branded by Federal authorities as a huge narcotic racket system yesterday, when it was disclosed that a former president of the secret Chinese society and two other officers were under arrest and sixteen other members had been secretly indicted.

A large group of deputantes of this and recent seasons are aiding Mrs. John Thomas Smith, chairman of the executive committee, in the sale of boxes and seats for the annual concert in behalf of the Maryknoll Missions, which will take place the night of Dec. 26 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The State of Ohio ordered 2,000 National Guardsmen to "stand by" today for possible duty at the Akron plants of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, and Governor Davey declared that sit-down strikes "will not be tolerated in Ohio."

Miss Anne Livingston Eustis was married to Grenville Temple Emmet Jr. here today at the home of the Bride's mother, Mrs. William C. Eustis. The Rev. John Igoe of Leesburg, Va., performed the ceremony. Both principals are New Yorkers.
THERE is an impression extant that Englishmen are a bit obtuse in the realm of humor. In other words, they're slightly sluggish on the uptake when some one springs a gag.

The demand for Swedish sponge iron, produced solely by the Hoganas-Billesholm Company at Hoganas, has expanded beyond the production capacity and its estimated record output for 1937 will probably be insufficient to meet all orders, according to a report from Goteborg to the Department of Commerce.

ALBANIA is celebrating this week the twenty-fifth anniversary of its proclamation of independence from Turkish rule, on Nov. 28, 1912, and in commemoration thereof the Balkan kingdom yesterday released nine special stamps which,

Two dances under the direction of the Misses Owen will be given for juniors in society during the midWinter holidays. These will be an afternoon dance on Dec. 27 at the Savoy-Plaza and a New Year's Eve party at the Colony Club. A third dance for the group will be given during the Spring recess.

Lou Feldman, 133 3/4, Brooklyn, received the decision over Joe Ghnouly, 135, St. Louis, last night in the feature bout of eight rounds at the Ridgewood Grove. All four six-round bouts ended fn knockouts. Jack Tolson, 151, Flatbush, stopped Larry Anzalone, 147, Williamsburg, in the fifth round;
Daniel F. Hennessy, for many years an executive in the B. F. Keith vaudeville organization, died yesterday morning in his apartment in the Hotel Taft after a long illness. He was 82 years old.
Operators of policy games in the city are using the proportional representation count for the City Council for their own ends, it developed yesterday.

Nathan Warshaw, president of the Warshaw Manufacturing Company, who built a $1,000,000-a-year business out of an initial investment of $100, announced yesterday that he would retire on Jan. 1 to devote all his energies to a crusade against communism.

Marching 69 yards to a touchdown in the third period, Flushing High School's football team defeated the Jamaica High School eleven, 7 to 0, at Memorial Field, Flushing, yesterday in the twentieth renewal of Queens' oldest school gridiron rivalry.

ASTOR-The.Hurricane: Jon Hall, Dorothy Lamour.* CAMEO--Conquerors of he Arctic, Soviet documentory. CAPITOL--Live, Love and Learn: Robert Montgomery, Rosalind Russell. CENTRAL--Behind Prison Bars and Old Wyoming Trail. CINEMA DE PARIS-Late Mathias Pascal, a French film.*

ARMY experts at Wright Field are convinced of the feasiility of pilotless flight, on the basis of the automatic landing technique they have developed, and await from Washington the authority to conduct automatic take-off tests at Muroc Dry Lake, Calif.

Most mulches for the garden serve best if not applied until after the ground freezes. It is none too early, nevertheless, to get mulching materials on hand and ready for immediate use when they are wanted.
Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, asserted yesterday that "spectacular progress" had been made in the elimination of many preventable diseases. But, he said, much is left to be done.

A beckoning gleam of California sunlight broke through a veil of snow at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Fordham crushed St. Mary's before a Rose Bowl-minded crowd of 35,000. The score was the most inconsequential and the oddest part of the rout.

John W. Lake has been elected president of the Realty Brokers of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He succeeds Herbert Bauersfeld. Other officers for the coming year are: Joseph W. Trimble, John A. Demane and Allan Cuttle, vice presidents;

An inspired undefeated Villanova football team, pointing for an invitation to either the Rose or Sugar Bowl post-season games, today routed its traditional rival, Temple, 33 to 0, before an amazed crowd of 35,000 at Temple Stadium.
Verdi's "Forza del Destino" was performed for the first time this season by the New York Hippodrome Company last night at the Hippodrome before an audience of 4,500 persons.
The destroyer McCall was launched this afternoon at the Potrero plant of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation. It was the first big launching in San Francisco since the World War.

A coordinating committee of social and religious agencies in each community to combat juvenile delinquency was proposed last week at the thirtieth annual meeting of the International Association of Daily Vacation Bible Schools at the Hotel Commodore.

Governor Lehman was urged yesterday by officers of the League of Mothers Clubs of the United Neighborhood Houses, representing 4,000 mothers of the lower East Side, to "take some official action which will ultimately bring an adequate supply of milk within our reach."

Little David O'Brien of Texas Christian hurled one deadly forward today and Rice Institute fell, 7-2. The 148-pound quarterback, whose hurling attempts were impotent in the first three periods, picked his spot soon after the fourth period opened and heaved a 41-yard pass.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Moriarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Moriarty of Maplewood, to John F. Quirk, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Quirk of South Orange, took place this morning in the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, South Orange.
In the unruffled dignity which befits a monarch, Laughton Lupin, a sleek-coated blue tom, surveyed an admiring audience yesterday afternoon as he was pronounced the "best cat" of all the cats.

IT is becoming a favorite practice among decorators to choose a theme for a room a new color vogue, perhaps, a fine rug or a treasured antique. Another method is to build the decor around the colors in a painting, and this is what four prominent interior designers have done in an exhibition at the Decorators Picture Gallery, 554 Madison Avenue. oven through Dec. 4.
There was further evidence today of a mild flight from the dollar in the foreign exchange market here, following the overnight Wall Street slump.

The unbeaten Red Devils of Dickinson College closed their season today by defeating Muhlenberg, 19 to 12, on a muddy field. The triumph gave Dickinson an undefeated season, marred only by a 7-7 deadlock with Washington-Jefferson.
The mounting total of tax liens against the Manhattan Railway Company's properties is called to the attention of holders of the company's consolidated 4 per cent bonds due in 1990,

IT will be fifty years on Nov. 29 since the 11-year-old Josef Hofmann played before an astonished audience in the Metropolitan Opera House. He was then making his American debut and beginning, on this side of the water, the career which has made him a leading figure in the modern world of art. He was a prodigy back in 1887.

Numerous fill-in orders were received last week in the wholesale market, but these were generally for limited quantities of goods, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Inquiries arrived for new Spring merchandise and orders will be placed shortly.

IN these days, when parlor practitioners of odd and assorted games would as soon ask you to submit to a psychological test as to have another highball, one of the favorite pastimes is that of "color reactions."

In seeking a basis for a minimum wage for workers in New York State, the State Labor Department is investigating the costs not only of food, clothing and lodging but also of home furnishings, personal care, insurance and recreation.

Your reviewer was disturbed to find certain Fascist implications in the Mercury Theatre production of "Julius Caesar," a production so admirable in many other respects. But he is in error when he attributes the totalitarian abomination to the Bard, because a plain reading of the play must show that Shakespeare held completely opposite views.
Marquette, beaten down in five straight games, uncovered a forward passing scoring punch to register one of the season's major upsets today by beating Duquesne, 13 to 6.

Southern Methodist University pitched its aerial circus in the Coliseum today and played a brilliant 26-to-13 performance for the benefit of the Bruins of University of California at Los Angeles and 35,000 spectators.

A message from President Roosevelt endorsing the program of the Church of the Epiphany to erect a new building next year at York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street has been made public by the Rev. Dr. John W. Suter Jr., rector, to whom it was addressed. The church is in temporary quarters at 229 East Fifty-ninth Street.
More than 100 alumnae of Barnard College have enrolled in cultural and recreational courses now open to them at Barnard on Tuesday nights.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--Anticipating a great influx of visitors to the resort over the Thanksgiving Day holiday, local hotel and amusement men are laying plans for their entertainment.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish.
MONT ST. MICHEL is a happy choice for the scene of a story by a writer who approaches the sacred promontory with the fervor of feeling which moved Henry Adams at the beginning of the century.
A card party, fashion show and tea under the auspices of the Brooklyn Circle of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae will be -held Dec. 4 at the Ambassador.

An application by the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to abandon a line in Litchfield County, Conn., four miles of which are used by Winter ski trains from New York, will be granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission, if it follows the recommendations of J. K. Lyle, an examiner made public today.
AFTER doing a long stretch in Hollywood, Clifford Odets has returned to the theatre with one of his best plays. In "Golden Boy" he has dissected the success story of a prize fighter.

Owing to the earlier postponement of the New York opening of Shubert's new musical comedy, "Between the Devil," the preview of the production, which will benefit the Maternity Center Association, will come in the middle of Christmas holiday activities and has already a tremendous advance sale of tickets.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 19 unless specified: At San Pedro: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Mississippi, Nevada, New Mexico, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Seratoga, Tennessee, West Virginia, Whitney, At San Diego: Cincinnati, Concord, Memphis Milwaukee.

THE Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under John Barbirolli, will give a concert to morrow at Carnegie Hall for the pension fund of the society. Bidu Sayao, Metropolitan soprano, and Julius Katchen, 11year-old New Jersey pianist, will be the soloists, the latter making his local debut on this occasion.

A military court here sentenced Antonio Fernandez Villa, a 45-year-old New York librarian, to twenty years' imprisonment on charges of sympathizing with the enemy. His wife, Mrs. Salvadore Villa, 35 years old, was sentenced to twelve years in prison.
Randolph Macon College of Ashland won the Chesapeake Conference title today by defeating the Hampden-Sydney Tigers, 3 to 0, before 3,000 spectators.

Miss Mary Poston, daughter of Mrs. E. McClellan Poston of this city and the late Mr. Poston, was married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church to Coleman Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Burke of Summit, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. Ronald Garney.

AHAITIAN villager hears from his neighbor that there is A-1 work to be done in the Do minican Republic on the same island. His needs are few, but jobs in Haiti are relatively scarce-jobs to be done for wages.

Orders issued by the municipal authorities of Morcow and Leningrad to reduce the number of beer saloons, many of which are libelously called "Amerikankas" under the misconception that they are American bars, will meet considerable popular approval.
From 1910 to 1935 fatal accidents caused by automobiles have jumped from 2 per cent 2 34 per cent of the national total of deaths from accidents, the Census Bureau has recently revealed.

MR. BAKER'S fifth volume ended with the Lusitania catastrophe. In the period which the present volume covers Wilson was to show whether, if at all, his emotional temperament, his political idealism and his ambitions for himself and the nation could be reconciled with the hard realities which the war in Europe was increasingly presenting.
EIGHT bars do not a prison make, in the usual sense of the word, but for three weeks they had Desmond Tester, the 17-year-old star of Gaumont British, pretty well caged up.

The Ralph H. Watson, first ore carrier launched at River Rouge since 1930 and the second on the Great Lakes in those seven years, went down the ways today. One of four new ships being put into service by the Pittsburgh Steamship Company,

Officials of the Church Pensions Conference, representing twentyfour denominational groups throughout the country, approved the protective aspect of the proposed revision of the New York State insurance law relating to annuity funds at the closing session of their annual meeting last week in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
AIKEN, S. C.--Early season activities here include a drag hunt on Thanksgiving Day. Mrs. J. Avent Clark, M. F. H., has announced the drag will meet at Fermata School at 11 A. M.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lucy Bowditch Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm B. Stone of this place, to George T. Keyes, son of Mrs. George T. Keyes of Pepperell and Boston and the late Mr. Keyes.
If a mural does not bite a man it is news, though not as sensational as it used to be.

Fort Jay's powerful football squad, which captured the First Division Military cha? pionship last week, will line up against a formidable local rival, Fort Hamilton, today at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn.

The stock market last week experienced its widest decline since the week ended on Sept. 11. The week's highest point was on Monday, or just before the President's message was delivered to Congress. In some respects the message was a disappointment to followers of the stock market,

Under the leadership of eleven counselors trained in personnel work, dormitory residents at Bucknell University are . engaging in activities ranging from the eating of a typical Hindu meal to participation in organized "bull sessions" at which faculty members are guests.

To the Screen Editor: In the numerous tributes that have appeared in memory of the late Winthrop Ames I have failed to find a hint of the slightest connection or association between Mr. Ames and motion pictures.
A unique "Phantom Ballet" has been arranged for next month as a means to bring financial aid to the Youth Consultation Service of the Church Mission of Help.

The Federal Trade Commission has announced three hearings in New York City this week. The case against Richard Hudnut and others, a Robinson-Patman proceeding involving charges of price discrimination in the sale of cosmetics, is set for tomorrow;

RENE HUYGHE of the Louvre makes no bones about it; Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec "was the acme of ugliness." His "poor laughable body" seemed that of a gnome; and once, mistaken for a circus freak, he was urged to perform.

The Yuletide Ball for the benefit of the Free Kindergarten Society will be held on Dec. 21 at the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn. Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard Jr. is chairman of the committee in charge of arrangements.

Miss Bonna Lee Schaefer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Schaefer of this place, and Harry E. Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Collins, also of this city, were married here this morning at the parsonage of the First Baptist Church.

THE reminder that feminine beauty, as exhibited upon the screen, is largely a manufactured attraction--the sum of make-up expertly applied--may stick like a bitter pill in the craws of persons romantically inclined.

Plans of a group of college students for a cooperative magazine to mirror the literary work, social activities and sports events of forty New England colleges and universities were brought to fruition this week with the publication of the first issue of quarterly "The Collegiate Review."

Captain William Thrall, commander of a Maryland Conservation Commission boat, arrested two Virginia oystermen today following a gun battle in the Potomac River. His boat, the Kent, surprised about fifteen small power boats handscraping for oysters before dawn.

Charley Weidinger's passing wizardry carried Maryland to a 12-to-2 triumph over Georgetown today as the Terrapins scored once through his tossing and moved to within touchdown range on another advance.

Lawrence High School's eleven today eliminated Baldwin, the defending Nassau County champion, from the ranks of the unbeaten at Horn Memorial Stadium before a crowd of 2,200 spectators. The score was 19--0.

There has just been celebrated in St. Paul's Cathedral a special service in honor of the tercentenary of the oldest fraternity of bell ringers, the Ancient Society of College Youths, founded by William Lord Brereton on Guy Fawkes Day, Nov. 5, 1637.

Miss Doris Adele Rever, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Rever of Guilford, Baltimore, was married today to Charles Classen Shafer, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. F. Shafer, in the First English Lutheran Church. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther Enders, the pastor.

MOSCOW.-At the recent meeting of the seventeenth International Geological Congress in Moscow the petroleum reserves of the U. S. S. R. were declared by Soviet geologists to be 3,877,000,000 tons, or nearly ?55 per cent of the world total of 7.077.000,000 tons.

Alumnae of the Academy of St. Joseph, Brentwood, L. I., are holding a dance Dec. 4 at the Ambassador. Miss Harriet Curtin of Richmond Hill and Miss Kathryn Nelson of Brooklyn head the group arranging the event.
The Supreme Court has declared constitutional the 1934 law granting vacations, sick leave and a dismissal allowance to private employes.

The Brussels, Lille, Aubusson and Beauvais tapestries of Mme. Annette LeFortier of Paris, together with her other art objects, realized $27,680 at auction yesterday afternoon at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.
The economic situation is operating to change the attitude of Democratic party leaders who some months ago planned to punish Senators who fought the administration's Supreme Court bill.

Thomas P. Henry of Detroit was unanimously re-elected president of the American Automobile Association yesterday morning as the motor group brought its thirty-fifth annual convention to a close. The two-day meeting, which began Friday morning, was held in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Believing that it is insufficient merely to train mechanics or printers, the New York City vocational schools are placing Increased emphasis upon the development of well-adjusted personalities among the 42,000 boys and girls taking trade courses, Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools, revealed yesterday.

California's undefeated football juggernaut rolled to a 13-to-0 victory today over Stanford's Indians, climaxing its finest season in nearly a decade by charging to the Pacific Coast Conference championship and the right to represent the West in the Rose Bowl game on New Year's Day.

Funeral services for Jay F. Carlisle, stockbroker and sportsman, who died Wednesday, were conducted at the Carlisle home here this afternoon at 2 o'clock by the Rev. William R. Watson, rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Bay Shore. Burial was in Locust Valley Cemetery, Locust Valley, L. I.

The demand of shipping nations for additional tonnage due to increased volumes of freight moving in the world markets has resulted in the recommissioning of many ships and increased value of available tonnage, according to the annual report of Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which was issued yesterday.

TO the great surprise of no one, Samuel Goldwyn and Alexander Korda finally announced last week the consummation of the deal whereby they acquired the interests of Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin and Douglas Fairbanks in the United Artists Corporation.

Current problems of labor relations under scientific management will be the theme of the annual conference of the Society for the Advancement of Management to be held at the Hotel New Yorker during the week of Dec. 6.
An early Winter slump has hit the intercoastal freight market and reports of canceled sailings are more frequent. The latest of these is from the American-Hawaiian Line.

The most definite and substantial bid for cooperation of private business in recovery to come from the Administration since collapse of the NRA is expected soon from President Roosevelt when he discloses details of new plans for organizing a nation-wide housing drive.

Fifty women representing colleges in the East will take the first step toward the establishment of a permanent information service covering the avocational and vocational needs of college women at a supper conference tomorrow.

Army concluded its home season today by overwhelming St. John's College of Annapolis, 47-6. A crowd of 5,000 shivered in the chill of Michie Stadium to watch the team play on a muddy field and in a snow storm.
A regular meeting of the Board of Education will be held Wednesday at 4 P. M. in the board headquarters, 500 Park Avenue. Election of an associate superintendent is scheduled at this meeting.

Two works were played for the first time in Carnegie Hall by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky conductor, yesterday afternoon. They were the orchestral suite, "Lieutenant Kije," op. 60, of Prokofieff, and Ravel's piano concerto for the left hand alone, in one movement.

A program of training for 6,300 WPA foremen and supervisor, intended to raise the efficiency of all relief projects in this city and to equip workers for private employment, was announced yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.

" Apparently different parts of the brain may go to sleep Separately and to different degrees," report Drs. H. Davis and P. A. Davis (Harvard) and Drs. A. L. Loomis, E. N. Harvey and G. Hobart (Loomis Laboratonry) in Science.

SIDNEY HOWARD'S new play, "The Ghost of Yankee Doodle," which opens tomorrow night at the Guild Theatre, was written for Ethel Barrymore and brings her back to the stage after an absence of several years.
The Patent Office granted 734 patents this week. Many ingenious inventions covering all fields of endeavor won patents for their inventors.

Accepting Congressional comment of the past week upon the subject of tax revision as expressive of legislative agenda, business will soon be relieved of at least some of the burdensome taxation under the pressure of which it is now struggling.

A petroleum industry has been one of the leaders in reducing the cost of its product while maintaining its record as a high-wage enterprise, J. A. Brown, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., declared in a recent letter to stockholders.

One of the most interesting events of the Autumn field-trial season and the final event for spaniels will be the competition for the Walton Ferguson Jr. Memorial Trophy for English springer spaniels. It will be given under the auspices of the English Springer Spaniel Amateur Field Trial Association and will be run at Saybrook, Conn., on Saturday, Dec. 4.

THIS writer desires to express his joy over one of the most significant offerings of the de Basil Ballet Russe, which has departed this city, taking with it Fokine's ballet, new to this country, "Coq d'Or."

A GAIN next Thursday the nation will return to the oldtime rites and customs that center around the Thanksgiving dinner, with its roast turkey, savory stuffing, giblet gravy, cranberry sauce and pumpkin pie.

The Corn Belt is wondering if Congress "at long last" is going to pull a real rabbit out of the hat. It is hopeful, but not over-confident. Reports of the committee work on the farm bill leave it wondering whether the result will be the safety of a multitude of counselors or the muddling of too many cooks.
Indiana University's crack crosscountry team, undefeated in twelve dual meets, will defend its Central Intercollegiate title at the annual meet in Lansing, Mich., tomorrow.

The annual hunt ball of the Goldens Bridge Hounds will take place next Saturday night in the clubhouse of the Lawrence Farms Golf Club here. The guests will include members of riding and hunt clubs from many sections of the East and their friends.

The authors who will address the Book Fair visitors in the final program today at 3 P. M. are: Manuel Komroff, adventurer, novelist, biographer of Marco Polo; James Weldon Johnson, Negro leader, essayist, novelist and Spence Professor of Creative Literature at Fisk University;

City and State officials and thousands of union workers quit their tasks today to join in funeral tribute to Patrick J. Corcoran, slain union chief. Governor Elmer Benson, who journeyed from Northern Minnesota, where he was attempting to settle a lumber workers' strike, and Mayor George E. Leach were among civic officials at the funeral.

A memorandum asking that bona fide real estate operating companies be excluded from classification as personal holding companies under the so-called "loop-hole plugging" provisions of the 1937 Federal Revenue Act has been submitted to the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives and to the Senate Finance Committee by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

H. L. Harris of the United Fruit Company announced today that the company's three fast mail ships which have been on duty between San Francisco, Los Angeles and various Pacific Latin-American ports would be transferred to the East Coast run next month.

THERE seems to have been a little misunderstanding regarding the subject of Mr. Behrman's next play, "Wine of Choice." From Baltimore, where he was convalescing last Spring from an illness, came word that he would be offering the case for liberalism vs. fascism and communism. And perhaps he will.

BERLIN.--German archaeologists employed with the, excavations at Aschaffenburg in South Germany have unearthed seven false teeth in a grave believed to be that of a German princess buried about the year 1200 B. C.

Sergei Rachmaninoff gave his only piano recital of the Philadelphia season before an audience that jammed the Academy of Music this afternoon. He was applauded not only by occupants of all of the extra seats placed in front of the parquet railing, but by an overflow crowd of 400 on the stage.

E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., scored a birdie three on the home hole today to defeat Henry Clay Poe of Durham, N. C., in a play-off for first place in the mid-South golf tournament. They ended the thirty-six-hole tournament yesterday tied with scores of 142.

Tomorrow will see the end of the long-drawn-out count of proportional- representation ballots for the election of members of the City Council for Manhattan and Queens, election officials announced last night.

Buying by industrial purchasing agents in the metropolitan area will be held to a hand-to-mouth basis for the balance of the year and few commitments of any size will be made before February, according to opinions expressed by executives for local corporations yesterday.

Cardinal Hayes, Archbishop of New York and one of the four princes of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, observed his seventieth birthday today at his Summer home on the grounds of St. Joseph's Mountain School, St; Joseph's, a few miles from here.

Jackie Coogan, who starred with Charlie Chaplin as the ragged urchin in the silent screen hit, "The Kid," eighteen years ago, and Betty Grable, blond screen actress, were married today in St. Brendan's Catholic Church. The Rev. William L. Mullane officiated.

The Ku Klux Klan is asserting itself with new strength .and boldness. The complexion of the organization has changed slightly. It is not so secretive with its program as it was fifteen years ago, and its attacks are in new directions.

Expressions of sympathy to their brother's of the church in Germany and Spain were dispatched by eightytwo members of the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church of the United States at the conclusion today of their three-day annual meeting in this city.

Unless there is an end of Britain's strained relations with Italy, who has been trying to cultivate Arab friendship since her conquest of Ethiopia, it is doubtful whether peace will be restored in Palestine.

Farm bill leaders, anxious to get a measure before Congress on Tuesday, set committee machinery into non-stop operation today. Joining in an almost unprecedented manoeuvre, the Senate and House Agriculture Committees undertook executive sessions which some members said would be virtually continuous until Monday.

Jake Schaefer rolled up a total of 953 points yesterday, but Willie Hoppe emerged at the finish of their 3,000-point match at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy with the world's 18.1 balkline billiard crown still resting firmly upon his graying head.

A fairly good idea of what the modern college student does with his spare time is formed by a study of the figures announced by Yale concerning activities at New Haven. Of the 3,035 students at Yale during the past year, 2,917 of them took exercise, which meant a percentaeg of 96.1 per cent.

Arkansas vs. Tulsa at Tulsa. Brown vs. Rutgers at Providence. Duquesne vs. Detroit at Pittsburgh. Kansas vs. Missouri at Lawrence. Kentucky vs. Tennessee at Lexington. Maryland vs. Washington and Lee at Baltimore. Mississippi vs. Mississippi State at Oxford.

THE airport problem in the United States has now grown so serious as to approach the nature of a crisis in the relation of municipalities to air transport. Last week Colonel J. Monroe Johnson, Assistant Secretary of Commerce in Charge of Aeronautics,
People like my mother and myself must rely almost entirely on radio for classical music, because we cannot afford to buy many concert and opera tickets.
Carl Littlefield's running and Eddie Bayne's passing gave Washington State a 7-to O victory over Oregon State today in a final Pacific Coast Conference football game.

French eighteenth century furniture and other appointments for interiors belonging to Mrs. Henry Fonda (formerly Mrs. George T. Brokaw), and Mrs. Mortimer W. Loewi and including part of the collection formed by the late Mrs. Francis Key Pendleton and property of other owners,

FRANENSMUTH, Mich. ALONG many American highways motorists may see signs reading: "Frankenmuth Chicken Dinners." Few know whence comes the term or what it means. The "Frankenmuth dinner" originated in this sleepy little town of 1,200 and today Frankenmuth Is a mecca for gourmets.

ADLER-Amy L., beloved wife of Norman, devoted mother of Norman, r.. and Marian, and the late Richard Lee: beloved daughter of Henry C. and Florence H. Leman. Services Sunday. 11:30 A. M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

When Governor Lehman, speaking at the convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs at Albany, deplored a lack of interest in the importance of the 1938 Constitutional Convention, he had not been informed of the concentrated study which women's organizations were making in anticipation of the April meeting.

The significant part music is coming to play in Princeton undergraduate life was hailed this morning as a step toward a betterrounded education at a universitysponsored symposium in McCormick Hall that culminated two years of experimentation in the broad field of music.
Harold H. Hackett, former national tennis doubles champion and member of the Davis Cup team and committee, died yesterday in his home at 580 Park Avenue after a short illness. He was 59 years old.

Waynesburg pushed over a touchdownn in the final quarter for 6-to-0 victory over Geneva College today before 1,500 fans. After valantly staving off Waynesburg for three downs on the 1, Captain Ariold Koepka crashed over for the score.

Academio honors for the 193637 college year were won by 108 students at New Jersey College for Women, Miss Esther W. Hawes, college registrar, has announced. Students having an average of 1.8 or better in any year receive honors for the year, and those who maintain an average of 1.8 or better for all-four years are recommended for honors upon graduation.
Girls of Keuka College, Penn Van, and men of Hobart College will participate, in an old-fashioned spelling bee over the modern facilities of radio, Sunday afternoon, Nov. 28.
I am opposed to the Wages and Hours Bill, not because I am opposed to the highest possible wages in the South or anywhere else, but because I am opposed to all of this sort of legislation.

The marriage of Miss M. Elizabeth Brehm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John. S. Brehm, to William Wessel, son of Mrs. Charles W. Wessel of Bronxville, and the late Mr. Wessel, took place here today at the home of the bride's parents, 3 Locust Lane.

Declaring the records show that stocks of silk and rayon dress goods in the hands of manufacturers amount to about a three months' supply, William Menke, chairman of the board of the Menke, Kaufmann Company and a member of the board of directors of the National Federation of Textiles, declared yesterday that it is vital for textile manufacturers to operate more closely to demand as shown in actual orders from customers.
AN important lesson was taught me by the captain of the Silveryew, the British cargo vessel on which I sailed away from New York six months ago. on the first leg of a voyage round the world.
A patent was recently granted in Germany for a device that will reproduce sound immediately after recording at a much lower cost than by methods now employed, the Commerce Department reports.

After slackening, the decline in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity again has become sharper. With all components showing losses, the index has dropped almost 3 points for the week ended Nov. 13 to 90.6, its lowest level since the week ended March 21, 1936. This compares with 93.5 (revised) for the previous week, and 104.4 for the corresponding week a year ago.

LAKELAND, Fla.--Cooler weather has set black bass in Florida's 30,000 fresh-water lakes to biting again, and it is already obvious that more anglers will try their luck this season than have ever before indulged in this popular outdoor diversion.

A warning against the danger of following "false prophets," who have set up ideals of hate, intol-erance, darkness and oppression, was voiced yesterday by Charles H. Tuttle, president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

The Mexican Government has announced that the provisions of the weights and measures regulations, originally promulgated Dec. 14, 1928, will be strictly enforced on and after Jan. 1, 1938, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the office of the American Commercial Attach, Mexico City.
Rival factions of St. Michael's Church, Mont Clare, clashed at the gates of the church cemetery today around the bier of Michael Galumbo, a 65-year-old laborer.
Senate and House Agriculture Committees have progressed so far toward agreement on a farm bill that by Monday a measure may be ready for one or both bodies.

The Brooklyn Tech rifle team gained its second leg on the New York Stock Exchange Trophy yesterday as it set a new record for the interscholastic event at the Crescent A. C. range with a total of 1.061 points.

EVEN now, three years before they have an opportunity to vote, politically minded citizens are beginning that fascinating game of guessing who the Presidential candidates will be in 1940. And at this writing, it is possible to name some two dozen, excluding Socialists and Communists, who might find themselves on the ballot, with, nevertheless, an excellent chance that none of the guesses would be correct.

Duke University defeated a fighting North Carolina State football team, 20 to 7, today before 10,000 fans in clear, cold weather. Fought to a standstill in the first quarter, Duke rallied in the second period when high-stepping Honey Hackney, quarterback, opened the scoring by taking a pass from Eric Tipton and racing for a 53-yard gain and touchdown. Hackney's placement for the extra point was wide.

FATHER NFPTUNE boards every craft that crosses the Equator, whether it is a luxurious liner or a tramp freighter. The night before the Equator is reached on the southward voyage of many passenger ships the lights are dimmed and out of the darkness come two blackclad figures with horns and long tails.
William H. Gocher, secretary of the National Trotting Association and an authority on trotting and pacing, died of a thrombosis today at his home in this city. His age was 78.

Police of New York and other near-by States were asked yesterday to search for Elmer B. Carner, 40 years old, an automobile sales manager of Amsterdam, N. Y., who is wanted on a charge of first-degree grand larceny.

Members of the Junior Committee of the Brooklyn Home for Children have completed plans for an entertainment and tea in behalf of the organization which will be held Nov. 30 at the Grace Church Parish House in Brooklyn.

To save leather for the high boots needed by German Army and National Socialist party organizations Germany is now employing fish skin as a substitute and the manufacture of fish skin goods has started on a large scale.

Leon Trotsky's difficulties with the Norwegian income tax authorities have been settled by a payment of 1,650 Norwegian kroner from Mexico it is learned here. This is in addition to his deposit in an Oslo bank, the amount undisclosed, which was seized by the authorities shortly after the trouble with Mr. Trotsky over the payment of his income taxes first arose.
STOWE, Vt.--The eastern slopes of Mount Mansfield are white with frost now and this little dairy-farm region awaits deep snow and cold weather. Nothing,
Duke University defeated a regaring North Carolina State football team, 20 to 7, today before 10,000 fans in clear, cold weather.
Scoring a touchdown in the opening period, Tufts held off a fighting Massachusetts State eleven today to triumph, 7-0. The punting of Niden of State featured throughout the game.

A determined woman, already loaded down with Book Fair folders, strode up to the information counter in the Modern Book Shop. "Catalog," she said crisply. The girl on the other side of the counter looked surprised. "Catalog," said the visitor sharply, "catalog, catalog!"

How strange the working of the Rome-Berlin axis may be on occasion was demonstrated in a curious fashion today when the Ministry of Popular Culture ordered the seizure of Tribuna, one of Rome's three afternoon newspapers, twenty-four hours after it had been distributed.

The University of Idaho's Vandals, given but an outside chance at the beet, finished their season in a blaze of glory today, tumbling the hitherto unbeaten and untied Grizzlies from Montana University, 6 to 0.

Princeton gained a tie with Yale for the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate 150-Pound Football League by downing Rutgers, 6-0, today. Buster Bedford, Tiger halfback, ran 75 yards through the entire Scarlet team to score in the closing minutes of the first half after taking Bud Shaw's punt.
Pompton Lakes and Bernardsville High Schools, Group Two cochampions for the last two years, battled to a scoreless tie in their initial gridiron meeting today.

William de Correvont, Austin High School halfback, today led his eleven to the public high school football championship of Chicago at Soldiers Field by defeating Senn High, 14 to 6, before a gathering of 15,000.

A $300,000 playhouse, reproducing an eighteenth-century theatre, will be opened here Friday evening with a Restoration drama entitled "The Recruiting Officer." Financed with Federal relief funds and two years under construction, the Dock Street Theatre is more than a theatre.

A forensic squad representing Oxford and Cambridge Universities will meet Hamilton College debaters on Monday evening in the college chapel in a discussion of "Resolved, That islationism is impracticable in the modern world."
A patent was recently granted in Germany for a device that will reproduce sound immediately after recording at a much lower cost than by methods now employed, the Commerce Department reports.

After slackening, the decline in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity again has become sharper. With all components showing losses, the index has dropped almost 3 points for the week ended Nov. 13 to 90.6, its lowest level since the week ended March 21, 1936. This compares with 93.5 (revised) for the previous week, and 104.4 for the corresponding week a year ago.

LAKELAND, Fla.--Cooler weather has set black bass in Florida's 30,000 fresh-water lakes to biting again, and it is already obvious that more anglers will try their luck this season than have ever before indulged in this popular outdoor diversion.

A warning against the danger of following "false prophets," who have set up ideals of hate, intol-erance, darkness and oppression, was voiced yesterday by Charles H. Tuttle, president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

The Mexican Government has announced that the provisions of the weights and measures regulations, originally promulgated Dec. 14, 1928, will be strictly enforced on and after Jan. 1, 1938, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from the office of the American Commercial Attach, Mexico City.

Miss Gertrude McCarthy of Chicago, daughter of Mrs. Daniel E. McCarthy and the late Colonel McCarthy, was married to Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Brazil, here this morning in the private chapel of the residence of Cardinal Leme da Silviera, who performed the ceremony.
The task of collecting unused and partly broken toys by members of the Police and Fire Departments of the city began last week at police and fire stations. The initial collectors were volunteers.

A merchandising problem created by the 20 per cent slash in bonded whisky prices confronts the liquor industry at present, with retailers speculating on the probable trends of Scotch whisky prices in the coming few months.

The Boston Bruins ran their winning streak to five straight tonight as they gave the Toronto Maple Leafs their first setback of the National Hockey League season, 3 to 2. The game drew a crowd of 15,089, a record for Maple Leaf Gardens.

GENIUSES lead obscure lives in Hollywood. Perhaps that is why we only recently dis covered that the head camera man for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is Karl Freund, who is already a classic, with examples of his most brilliant works, such as "The Last Laugh" and "Variety" enshrined In museums and film libraries.

Although most of the 300 species of the Passion flower or Passionvine are tropical, a dozen or so are native to the Southern United States, and in the last three Winters certain of them have proved hardy as far north as Long Island and Northeastern Pennsylvania.

" IF any one desires to know the leading and paramount object of my public life, the preservation of this Union will furnish him the key." So said Henry Clay, and for once his judgment was. sound. Clay's historical significance, indeed,

About 250 employes of the Civilian Conservation Corps, working at the Army Quartermaster Depot here, have been discharged this week since receiving explicit instructions not to register under the national unemployment census, it was revealed today.

The following tables show the latest Council returns in the Boroughs of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. The Bronx returns, due to court actions, have been held up and the first count there will be completed tomorrow. In Richmond the count was completed early last week with Frederick Schick, Democrat, elected as the borough's sole Councilman.
Dr. Francis Browne Grinnell, 53 years old, former instructor at Harvard Medical School, is dead in England, according to word received here today.
