Standing one step in front of her husband, the Duchess of Windsor this afternoon made her first public appearance in Paris and her first public speech when she opened a sale on behalf of the British Episcopal Church of Christ at Neuilly.

Uniform standards of apprenticeships in related industries throughout the nation to give economic opportunities to the nation's youth were urged yesterday by William F. Patterson, executive secretary of the Federal Committee on Apprentice Training.

Archbishop Cicognani, Apostolic Delegate to Washington from the Vatican, said today that he had been instructed by the Holy See to state that "corrections made by the Archbishop of Detroit to the remarks of Father Charles E. Coughlin published on Oct. 6 were just and timely."

Details of an essay contest being sponsored by the National Federation of Press Women were reported yesterday by its national president, Mrs. Douglas Malloch of Chicago, at a reception and tea given at the Hotel Iroquois. Mrs.
THERE are five ships in the world with registered gross tonnages above 50,000. Three of them will steam out through New York harbor Narrows this Winter for pleasure jaunts warm seas.
The American Federation of Labor said today that its legislative agents favored postponement of Congressional action on the Administration's executive reorganization bill until the January session.

The American business and financial community, on the good health of which the national welfare continues to depend regardless of periodic wishful thinking to the contrary in Washington, is going to find out this Winter three things it has wanted to know for some time. It has wanted to know them ever since the proRoosevelt enthusiasm of the Hundred Days of 1933 was dissipated by alarm over developing New Deal policy.

Mrs. Vincent Astor and her com mittee of social arrangements are making final plans for the reception of official guests at the golden jubilee concert of Josef Hofmann next Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Jacobs of 220 West Ninety-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Jacobs, to David R. Rugoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Rugoff of the Marseilles.
The Music School Settlement will be the beneficiary of the preview of Ed Wynn's new show, "Hooray for What!" the evening of Nov. 30 at the Winter Garden.
A dozen leading economists offered to Congress last night a formula for ending the slump in business activity. The gist of it was: "Do something to encourage business."

The Rensselaer Polytechnic eleven ended its season today with a sensational last-minute 13-12 victory over Buffalo University. Both teams scored in the first few minutes of play, but the Bulls built up a touchdown lead in the third period.

WHATEVER part of the world Mr. Clark happens to be writing about, he can be for travelers real or vicarious. a very amiable kind of host and in this "Golden Tapestry of California" he is that and more.

Sweeney-Charles Aloysius Sweeney-told it to Northwestern today. Notre Dame conquered its Big Ten arch-rival, Northwestern, 7 to 0, today in freezing, wind-swept Dyche Stadium, and it was Sweeney of Bloomington, Ill., hero of Notre Dame's triumphs over Navy and Minnesbta, who scored the single touchdown as the result of a seocndquarter break.

CONGRESS is meeting in special session to consider measures which involve the pressing issue of cenralization of government. Regional planning. crop control. wages and hours, even government reorganization-all these questions are tied to the problem of whether there shall be Imore or less centralization of power at Washington.

Counsel for the eighteen private companies attacking the validity of the TVA power program in Federal court here filed a brief and memoranda today in support of an application for a subpoena duces tecum for records and documents of the TVA, PWA and other government agencies and renewed their application, which the court denied earlier in the week, to bring into court the minutes of TVA directors' meetings pertaining to power.

With large national advertisers issuing orders last week to their agencies to curtail budgets, the trend of advertising in coming months will closely parallel the downward movement of business activity, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by executives.

Despite the disappointing retail trade in men's clothing and furnishings, current indications are that demand for evening clothes will hold up unusually well from now until Christmas. Retail store executives reported yesterday that both tuxedos and tails have started to move and that volume might well run ahead of last year.

Making his first appointment to a post created by the new charter, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that Magistrate Henry H. Curran, long prominent in the city's civic and political affairs, would be the Deputy Mayor.

The National Appraisal Forum closed today with a unanimous vote to continue its work of collecting and disseminating data on appraisal with the aim of stabilization of the real estate and mortgage market.
Norwich Free Academy ran and passed its way to a 19-to-0 victory over Bulkeley today in the seventythird game in the country's oldest scholastic rivalry.

As a certain sign of waning Autumn, the six-day bicycle race is preparing again to take over Madison Square Garden. The long grind is scheduled to begin next Sunday, and John M. Chapman, manager of the event, has announced that fifteen teams will compete for the prizes this year in what he terms a race of nations.

ZANZIBAR. EVERY traveler who has roamed the streets of this Sultanate must have stopped to admire the massive doorways in the old coral houses. These doors, with their rich carving and beauty, grip the imagination and fascinate the eye. Now, by order of the Sultan, no door may be torn from a building and sent out of the island.

In honor of the late Jeno Hubay, the celebrated Hungarian violinist and pedagogue, two of his operas, "The Venus de Milo" and "The Violin-Maker of Cremona," were scheduled for presentation recently at the Budapest Royal Opera House.

Religious leaders representing twentythree churches and other religious groups in this country and Canada will participate at Arch Street Presbyterian Church here on Monday and Tuesday in a national conference of the United Stewardship Council.

The Zo-Ak Company, 62 West Fortyfifth Street, and John L. and Nancy E. Hatch, trading as the Slimmets Company, 853 Seventh Avenue, New York, have stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission that they will discontinue certain misrepresentations in the sale of medicinal preparations, the commission has announced.
As director of a children's entertainment program that reaches into thirty States, Mrs. Dorothy L. McFadden is working toward the cultural education of thousands of America children.

A warning that "the forces of reaction" were beginning a united and determined effort to check the march of social and economic progress in the United States and a plea for a militant counter-offensive by progressive organizations were voiced yesterday by Vito Marcantonic, president of the International Labor Defense.

The trustees of Springfield College, Springfield, Mass., have decided on a seven-year drive to raise $3,205,000. Meeting at the office of the United States Trust Company, 45 Wall Street, last week, they set Sept. 1, next, as a tentative starting date for the campaign.

A good many pipe stems, buttons, mirror backs and phonograph records are made of synthetic resins. That these resins should also make it possible to produce pure water without distilling it is a discovery which has been made at the National Physical Laboratory, Teddington, England, and which is bound to have revolutionary industrial effects.
BLANK-NELSON-Mrs. J. Nelson of 1,815 Avenue I, Brooklyn, announces the engagement of her daughter. Rosalind, to Mr. Jess Blank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Blank of Brooklyn.

Bob Pastor will make his first local ring start in almost a year when he tackles Nathan Mann of New Haven in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden on Friday night. The battle, bringing together as it does two of the most promising fighters among the younger rop of heavyweights, has aroused considerable interest, and Promoter Mike Jacobs expects a crowd of 15,000.

The greatest University of Oklahoma football team in more than a decade closed its 1937 season today by shutting out the Oklahoma Aggles, 16 to 0, in the thirty-second annual renewal of their football rivalry.

The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Read, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Augustus Read, to Moseley Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Osgood Taylor of Boston, Mass., took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. William A. Read. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John R. Henry of Rye, N. Y.

A fea ture-length film devoted entirely to the back-stage operations of a the atre is being made at the Yale Department of Drama in an attempt to acquaint student and lay groups with the lesser-known phases of back-stage construction and technique.
Reports on community measures undertaken for the preservation of health in the Clinton district, will be made at a meeting of the American Woman's Association Council tomorrow at 8:30 P. M.

Current educational problems will be discussed at the annual convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools to be held here next Friday and Saturday, it was announced today.

Washington faces the danger that it will cost United States investors in Mexico between $500,000,000 and $1,000,000,000. to continue the good-neighbor policy with respect to Mexico during the remaining three years of the current Mexican Administration.

A tiny college here which has no buildings of its own, gives no lectures and awards no degrees sends its graduates to various parts of the country and to foreign lands to carry on an educational effort, stressing the development of creative ability.

Pittsburgh's champion vote-getter won a job which pays him only $1 annually, but he is looking forward eagerly to inauguration. John W. Adams, 60, elected County Surveyor by the greatest vote in local history, said today that he "regarded the position as one of prestige and honor" and could hardly wait for letterheads to be printed carrying his title.

A prize for the outstanding thesis on a subject connected with the Far East has been established at Prinoeton University in memory of Dr. Robert K. Reischauer, former leoturer in the School of Public and International Affairs, who was slain last August during an aerial bombardment of Shanghai.
Minimum prices for the entire Appalachian soft coal area, excluding Alabama, will be announced by the National Bituminous Coal Commission on or before Dec. 1, it was learned today.

South Side High School today won the championship of the Newark High School Football League by scoring a 25-6 victory over Central High School's eleven, the first city title triumph for the Sunnysiders since 1932.
Four Soviet scientists, cruising down from the top of the world on an ice floe at the whim of Arctio currents, today celebrated the passing of a half-year of their unique adventure.
Led by Everett Shaw, who scored three touchdowns, the Hofstra College eleven scored an easy 32-0 victory over Gallaudet College of Washington, D. C., at the Freeport stadium today.

Miss Marguerite Harrison Colwell, daughter of Chauncey Perry Colwell of this place, was married tonight at the home of her father to Dr. Charles S. Pennypacker, son of Mrs. Charles B. Pennypacker of Ardmore.
St. Benedict's Prep School, contender for the Group Four State prep championship, scored a 6-0 victory over the Manhattan College freshman eleven today.
The Brooklyn Eagles, defending title-holders, will return to Ebbets Field this afternoon to meet the formidable New Rochelle Bulldogs in an American Association football game.

Graduates of the University of Pennsylvania who have won prominence in business and the professions will return to the footlights next Saturday night to sing and dance in roles they created as undergraduate members of the Mask and Wig Club.

With the approach of December, traditionally a bad month in the theatrical world, the managements are scrambling to get their productions launched and there is again a spate of activity on the London stage this week.

WITH the recent opening of about two miles of realignment and reconstruction on Route U. S. 9W, on the west bank of the Hudson River north from the Bear Mountain traffic circle, an important step has been made to facilitate traffic through this region from the circle to Cornwallon-Hudson.

South Side High School today won the championship of the Newark High School Football League by scoring a 25-6 victory over Central High School's eleven, the first city title triumph for the Sunnysiders since 1932.

Sheriff James Foy of Clark realized today that he unwittingly let $5,000 slip through his fingers Nov. 11 when he released two men on $30 cash bonds. The men, giving their names as Harry Miller and Sam Bedrick, were arrested at Clark on suspicion of forgery.

While snow and below-freezing temperatures were general throughout the East, South and Middle West yesterday, according to The Associated Press, New York City experienced only a few slight flurries and some drizzling rain.

Supporting two resolutions now in the Senate that would deprive Congress of the right to "instigate foreign military campaigns" and transferring that right to the people "by means of a referendum," delegates to the New York City Christian Endeavor Union Convention, voted unanimously yesterday against war as being "un-Christian and of the greatest significance to American youth."

Tulane University today defeated a hard-fighting Sewanee football team, 33 to 7, before 10,000 spectators who braved a cold day.
New South Wales took a first-innings lead of 79 runs in its match against the touring New Zealand cricket team today. Dismissing the visitors for 195 runs, the home players made 274.
President Roosevelt's message did not create any unfavorable impression in financial circles here.
The Seattle Port Commission said tonight it had learned authoritatively that trans-Pacific American Mail passenger liners soon would operate only as freighters and that service would be curtailed.

With short-term ad contracts becoming the rule as business activity declines, the flexibility of newspapers under current conditions will be stressed strongly by space salesmen in coming months, according to reports.

Honorary membership in the International Photo-Engravers Union, A. F. of L. affiliate, was conferred last night upon A. J. Powers, president of the Powers Photo-Engraving Companies of New York, at a dinner of the union's international and local officers and other representatives of labor at Cavanaugl's restaurant, 258 West Twenty-third Street.
The value of French imports in October was 3,720,000,000 francs, an increase of 234,000,000 francs from the preaeding month and one of 1,477,000,000 francs from October, 1936.

A record total of $78,500 has been raised by the radio, refrigeration and music division of the joint campaign by the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities, it was announced last night.

A gross value of $33,932.28 is placed on the estate of Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink, according to an inventory filed in the Superior Court, where her will has been admitted to Drobate.
The Los Angeles Bulldogs rang up their tenth gridiron victory by trouncing the Boston Shamrocks in a free-scoring American League game today, 45 to 26.
Arturo Toscanini, famous Italian conductor, apparently has won another skirmish in his long campaign against Nazi ostracism of artists for racial and religious reasons.

Bill Reissig, former star at Fort Hays Teachers College in Kansas, scored thirteen points as the Brooklyn Eagles defeated the New Rochelle Bulldogs, 16 to 6, in an American Football Association game before 3,500 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday.

The Aurora team from the United States was eliminated from the Argentine open polo championship tournament today, losing an 8-to-3 decision to Santa Ines. Aurora, the only United States entry in the tournament, trailed, 2-3, at half-time.
As soon as the Cabinet is reconstructed next week, Prime Minister Joseph A. Lyons will ask it to consider making an overture to the United States for a trade agreement.

President Roosevelt's message has done little or nothing to lift the gloom that is filt here over conditions in the United States. The President's views are considered here as too indefinite for any hope that recovery can be built on governmental action.

The wheat market failed again last week to develop a definite trend and, while price fluctuations were extremely rapid, the maximum range was only about 6 cents a bushel, the greater part of which was achieved on Wednesday, when the December future advanced 5 cents a bushel as the result of reports indicating heavy- damage had been done by 'frost to the new Argentine crop.

Patrolman Otho Renz of the Herbert Street Precinct in Brooklyn, who lives at 198 Weirfield Street, Brooklyn, was kicked and severely beaten early yesterday morning when he tried to disperse a gang of noisy youths who had assembled at the corner of Nassau Avenue and Houseman Street, in Greenpoint.

The Lehigh Valley Coal Company will propose today to the holders of its five-year secured 6 per cent notes due on Jan. 1, 1938, a plan for extension of the maturity for five years to Jan. 1. 1943, at the same rate.

Announcing that Japan considered herself entitled to the rights always accorded to a conqueror, the spokesman of the Japanese Embassy said last night that Japan would claim in the Shanghai International Settlement and French Concession all the sovereign rights China enjoyed in the foreign areas.

For the first time in several :years the foreign demand for corn promises to become somewhat of - a factor in American markets. According to cash handlers here, there is a prospect of as high as 100,000,000 bushels being placed in Europe providing the price level continues favorable, compared with Argentina and with barley.

Alfred Y. Cornell, a teacher of singing in this city for the last thirty years, who had been the director of the Hunter College Choir since 1927, died yesterday of heart disease at his home, 420 West 130th Street, after a fortnight's illness.
The Ohio Oil Company has completed another oil well of enormous production in the Yates field of West Texas, according to word received here Today. ord received here Today.

Basil (Pat) Ryan, wealthy young New Yorker who married Miss Martha Barkley, 21, of Morgantown, N. C., the night of Nov. 4, was readmitted to a hospital tonight after having been out of it a week. Hospital authorities declined to discuss his condition.

Members of the Ku Klux Klan here have gone on record as being opposed to some phases of the night life this city offered for years. As a consequence visitors this Winter will find a subdued set of diversions.

Sale and display of all toys or games "suggestive of war" will be barred henceforth at Arnold Constable Co., Fifth Avenbe and Fortieth Street, Isaac Liberman, president of the store, announced yesterday.

The Preakness Stakes, which in 1938 will be the country's richest 3-yearold race, grossing approximately $80,000, has seventy-six eligibles remaining, according to an announcement by the Maryland Jockey Club today. Now under Futurity conditions, the original Preakness field of 173 nominees has been reduced gradually as the date of the race approaches and eventually only the starters will be left.

W. Rossiter Redmond, lawyer, of 70 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, was arrested early this morning at his home on a charge of grand larceny as the result of an indictment handed up on Friday by the Kings County grand jury.

Mrs. Lillian Fick of Glen Ridge sold to the Hudson County Park Commission for an indicated consideration of $18,150 twelve lots on the west side of Marcy Avenue, near Communipaw Avenue, Jersey City, for enlarging the Lincoln County Park.

A summary by the Securities and Exchange Commission issued today showed that registration statements which became effective in October under the Securities Act of 1933 covered securities amounting to only $127,621,000, reflecting the lag in financing in recent months.

A huge polychrome wooden crucifix of Christ the King was displayed yesterday morning at the opening of a week's celebration of the sixtieth anniversary of the founding of St. Augustine's Episcopal Chapel of Trinity Parish, 105 East Houston Street.

Anti-Nazi Week began yesterday with appeals to the Jewish youth of America to add their efforts to the "bloodless war" of boycotting Nazi Germany so that they can give example to the Jewish youth of other countries and do their share in the battle that will some day depend on them for leadership.

In a sermon commemorating the 260th anniversary of the founding of New Utrecht Reformed Church, Eighteenth Avenue and Eightythird- Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, the Rev. Martin Paul Luther, the pastor, emphasized a need to look ahead "supported by the experience of the past," so as "to see the direction we are to take and the quality of the service we are to accomplish."

Passengers due to arrive tonight from Europe on the French liner Normandie, include Paul Leroy Beaulieu, French Attache at Washington; Count and Countess de Montale, Duc de Nemours, Marquis and Marquise de Talleyrand, Princess de Poix, Countess de Maille, Colonel and Mrs. Bentley Mott, Major John B. Gribbel, Baron and Baroness R. de Kerchove, Judge and Mrs. Gustave Sanchez de Bustamente and Mr. and Mrs. Phillips R. Turnbull.

A proclamation will be issued by Mayor La Guardia at exercises at 12:30 P. M. tomorrow at City Hall in connection with the opening on Thursday, Thanksgiving Day, of the thirty-first annual Christmas Seal Sale, it was announced yesterday.

About 4,000 grocers, merchants and landlords, some of whom threatened legal action last week to collect on unpaid city relief vouchers issued in July, will receive checks totaling $350,000 from the city in the mail tomorrow.
Accused of stealing three overcoats, two women and a man, all with criminal records, were arrested yesterday afternoon near-the clothing store of Michaelson Brothers, 72 Canal Street.
Cuyahoga County relief administrators will open Friday a 500-acre farm where they hope to rehabilitate relief clients voluntarily seeking release from alcoholism.
Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 36 per cnt of capacity, down 5 points in week and 48 points from the first week in September, a period of even weeks.

The typhoon which swept the central Philippine Islands Wednesday whirled westward into the China Sea today leaving 180 dead, 170,000 persons in distress, and huge property damage. President Manuel Quezon proclaimed a state of emergency in the seven affected central islands to prevent the skyrocketing of food prices.

The current issue of 'the monthly bulletin of the International Juridical Association says many of the basic principles of the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill have been "whittled away" and that the measure in its present form falls far short of the goals set forth by President Ronnosevelt.

As a forerunner to the Old Glory Sale tomorrow, Wednesday and Thursday at the Squadron A Armory, the annual meetings and elections of officers of the governing bodies of the American trotting turf will be held this afternoon at the Prince George Hotel.
The attack on Governor Lehman made by Samuel Seabury in Rochester on Saturday was attributed yesterday to Mr. Seabury's own Gubernatorial ambitions, in a statement issued by Samuel Untermyer.

Six one-story stucco store buildings were badly damaged early this morning in a fire at Rockaway Park, Queens, within half a block of a similar fire two weeks ago. Damage was estimated at about $30,000.
John A. Perry, for twenty-six years Grand Secretary of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of Pennsylvania, died yesterday at his home, 1,992 Cheltenham Avenue, at the age of 71.
Two British privates and one Indian soldier were killed in fighting in Waziristan between Nov. 16 and 18 in addition to casualties previously announced, the Indian Government stated today.

Enactment of that part of President Roosevelt's reorganization plan which would change the name of the Department of Interior to the Department of Conservation was urged today by Secretary Ickes in his annual report to the President.

A fourth-period field goal gave Gonzaga University a 3-to-2 football victory over Portland University today. After losing the ball on downs inches from the Gonzaga goal line in the second period, Portland gained 2 points on a safety when Halfback Karamatic's attempted punt was blocked and rolled from the end zone.

Thomas Mitchell, the Dr. Kersaint of "The Hurricane," has signed a term contract with Samuel Goldwyn, the producer announced today. Regarding the player as a caliber similar to Charles Laughton, a story is being sought for him in which he will star.

The Noralien Corp., David Pasinsky, President, gave to the Maston Co, Inc, a mortgage for $11,800 on 541 and 543 W 113th St. A mortgage for $4,000 on 541 was assigned last June 9 by the Cathedral Court Co., Samuel Strasbourger, president, to the Henry Payson Management Corp.

Leaders of the Republican Union, one of France's strongest conservative parties, urged the People's Front Government today to repudiate its Communist allies and effect a reconciliation with Germany and Italy.

" Gay Blades," the figure-skating extravaganza which stars Miss Maribel Y. Vinson and Karl Schaefer, will return to Madison Square Garden from a three-day engagement In Boston Wednesday evening, it was announced yesterday.
The Throop Drug Store, for 136 years a landmark in Schoharie, thirty miles away, has a new home.
The long-planned Insurgent Aragon offensive was reported today to have been delayed in the hope that political strife within the Barcelona Government would provide a more opportune moment to strike.

Senator Borah grappled with a man whom he described as either "insanely drunk or crazy" in a Washington bus last night. The scuffle occurred while the seventy-two-year-old Idahoan was on his way from the Capitol to his apartment.

Attempts to control the prices of raw commodities have led usually to government control of producers; the beginnings of government intervention have customarily taken the form of emergency measures to meet specific temporary difficulties, and ultimately permanent programs for complete government control under international agreements have been developed.

Major events today: The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra directed by John Barbirolli in a pension fund concert at Carnegie Hall tonight, with Bidu Sayao, Metropolitan Opera soprano, and Julius Katchen, 12-year-old pianist, as soloists; Constance Hejda,

The need of erfding governmental interference and competition with business and of lowering tax rates was stressed by a group of corporation officers and heads of firms in their answers to a letter from the Merchants Association of New York, which asked the question, "What does business need in order to be placed on a better foundation?"

Two developments have indicated this week that the aniount of capital which is being repatriated, and concerning which no. precise figures are available, is much larger than was generally estimated in financial circles.

By the end of this year the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee will have raised $3,275,000 for overseas aid and reconstruction, compared with $2,665,000 last year, 250 leaders representing the Middle Atlantic States Conference of the committee were told today by Isidor Coons, national campaign director.

Mr. and Mrs. John A. Burke of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mise Eileen Elizabeth Burke, to Lee J. Marino, son of Mrs. Joseph Marino of Plainville, Conn., and the late Mr. Marino. The announcement was made this afternoon at a tea at the Burke home.

It was learned authoritatively today that more than fifty Sovietmade fighting planes had been flown into China from Russia in the past two weeks. They were reported to be based at Lanchow, capital of Kansu Province, about 1,000 miles in the interior.

Mrs. Stella M. Crater, whose husband, Supreme Court Justice Joseph Force Crater, disappeared seven years ago, announced over the radio yesterday afternoon that she would not go through with her action to have her husband officially declared dead and that for the present she would not take steps to collect his insurance.

Playing with a fury and inspiration found almost exclusively in the most moss-bound of traditional college games, the New York Giants upset the dreaded Green Bay Packers, 10 to 0, in a thrill-packed battle at the Polo Grounds yesterday, virtually clinched the Eastern championship of the National Football League and, to all intents and purposes, handed the Western crown to the idle Chicago Bears.

Riley Smith's third-quarter scoring burst of 10 points gave Washington's Redskins a 16-7 National Football League victory today over Cleveland's Rams. Don Irwin of Washington scored in the first period after alternating with Cliff Battles in line drives on the snow-crusted field.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, former president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, preaching yesterday morning at St. James's Lutheran Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street, said that a recent survey of 10,000 cases made by the Children's Aid Society showed that the radio and the movies played the largest part in the entertainment and development of the child.

The failure of apartment house construction to keep pace with new building in other residential classifications was attributed to the continuance of low rents and increased operating cost, in a statement issued yesterday by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Germany's new deal under the National Socialist regime, like President Roosevoelt's, is also approaching the point of economic and financial reorientation necessitated by the change of world economy from boom into slump.
For the third time in less than three weeks United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt tonight entertained the Duke and Duchess of Windsor at dinner.

Although only four took part in the robbery, five men will be charged with first-degree murder for the death of Police Sergeant Timothy. Murphy, who was shot while trying to halt three men fleeing from a hold-up in East Thirteenth Street on Sept. 14, 1931.

The week's industrial reports have been satisfactory, but business sentiment is not uniform. A favorable influence was the October foreign trade return, which combined an increase in imports which the country urgently needs with the highest exports since the depression and a substantial export surplus which made it possible for imports of gold for the first time since Spring to balance the exports of the metal.

High Nazi officials today gave a military welcome to the Hungarian Premier, Koloman Daranyi, who arrived for a visit that observers believed might draw Hungary into the German-Italian- Japanese anti-Communist pact.
In a tense, wide-open battle that was filled with action every minute the New York Rangers came from behind to gain an overtime tie with the Montreal Maroons at Madison Square Garden last night.

Some few of the many persons who never get a chance to celebrate New Year's Eve on New Year's Eve had their party last night at the American Woman's Association clubhouse, 361 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Representatives of some insurance companies were chiefly responsible for the corruption uncovered in the filing of fake accident claims, it was charged yesterday by Bernard Botein, Assistant District Attorney who headed the recent accident fraud investigation that resulted in charges being made against 131 lawyers, physicians, lawyers' runners and others.

The American Guild of Musical Artists, of which Lawrence Tibbett is president, has informed the Metropolitan Opera Association that the Guild is "the authorized collective bargaining agent" for a majority of the singers engaged by the Metropolitan for the 1937-38 season.

Night clubs and other entertainment places whose licenses are under police jurisdiction were warned yesterday by John J. Sullivan, second deputy police commissioner, that his department and the city administration would not tolerate the hiring of any performer seeking to capitalize on "a notorious past."

It was learned here today that Rumania is about to recognize Italy's conquest of Ethiopia. The retirement of the former Minister to Rome, Jon Lugoshanu, in order to enter political life will be taken advantage of for this purpose, The Rumanian Government promised

A survey of loom activity for the week ended Nov. 13, made by the National Rayon Weavers Association, is characterized by continued drastic limitation of production by manufacturers of rayon woven broad goods, that organization announces today.

Plans for alterations to cost $25,000 were announced when a leasehold covering the northwest corner of Flatbush and Caton Avenues, Brooklyn, was sold by the Magaroff Realty Company to the Arlesco Corporation. The property is known as 806-14 Flatbush Avenue and 2,119-27 Caton Avenue. It consists of three four-story buildings containing twenty-one apartments and eight stores and two private dwellings.
Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Rawls today announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine, Olympic swimming star, to William Starr, Daytona Beach advertising man.

Emergency government measures for the control of prices of commodities usually have led ultimately to permanent programs for complete government control, the National Industrial Conference Board concludes in a study, "International Raw Commodity Price Control." issued yesterday.

Lady Lister Kaye of London will arrive on the Europa Thursday and will be at the Ambassador for the Winter. Mr and Mrs. Robert T. Crane will give a tea dance on Dec. 18 at the Cosmopolitan Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Kate C. Crane.

Prices of cotton fluctuated narrowly last week. After following a downward trend most of the week, they recovered moderately. However, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net declines of 8 to 12 points in the week.

Coach Earl (Dutch) Clark and his Detroit Lions handed the Chicago Cardinals a 16-to-7 defeat in a National Football League contest at Wrigley Field today. The victory elevated Detroit to a second-place tie with Green Bay, which was beaten by New York's Giants, in the Western division and eliminated the Cardinals from title consideration.
Henri Cain, French author and painter, died today after a long illness. A versatile man of arts and letters, he was widely known for his numerous portraits, plays and novels. His age was 80.

Detective Charles Boyle of the Bath Beach station, impeded on his way home shortly after midnight Saturday by a driver ahead who zigzagged along Flatbush Avenue so that it was impossible for him to pass, encountered worse embarrassment when he finally managed to pull alongside and to bring the other car to a stop.

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, announced yesterday that the chapel now being built in Keating Hall would be completed before Christmas. The chapel, to be known as the Chapel of Our Lady of Sorrows, is being erected to the memory of Miss Dolores Marie Co kin by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry S. Colkin. Miss Colkin, whose two brothers attended the college, died last Summer.

The SinoJapanese war with its threat to British prestige in the Far East and its actual cost to business in British pounds illustrates the profound changes in foreign policy under which the government is striving to play a judicious role.

A souvenir bronze medal has been executed by Julio Kilenyi, sculptor, in connection with the opening of the Lincoln Tunnel between West Thirty-ninth Street and Weehawken, N. J., and-will be presented to guests at the dedication exercises Dec. 21, it was announced yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

NEARLY every one has heard that in 1896 Rudyard Kipling and his Vermont brotherin-law quarreled-reputedly over a piece of landand that in consequence Kipling and his wife suddenly deserted Naulakha, the home they had built with such care near Brattleboro, and went abroad.

Syracuse University will formally open its second new building this month when it dedicates the new $825,000 home of the College of Medicine tomorrow morning and hears an address by Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, president of Stanford University.

Elliott Margolies, 17-year-old high school student of 1,841 East Nineteenth Street. Brooklyn, was found dead early last night in the basement kitchen of his home, where all jets of a gas range had been turned on. Police listed the case as a suicide.

Mr. and Mrs. William Henson Wells gave a tea yesterday at their home in Forest Hills Gardens, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Adams Wells, to Dr. Henry Warren Frey Jr.; son of Mr. and Mrs. Frey, also of Forest Hills Gardens.

Daniel C. Roper, Secretary of Commerce, will be guest of honor at a dinner to be given by the business advisory council of the Department of Commerce in Chicago on Dec. 1, W. A. Harriman, chariman of the council, announced yesterday. Heretofore the council has met in Washington.
" I think the time has come for us to emphasize the alterability of human life," said the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Jersey City, 'where Mayor Frank Hague and his organization are regarded in labor circles as avowed foes of militant trade unionism, will be the scene of a mass Organization drive by leaders of the Greater Newark Council of the Committee for Industrial Organization, it was revealed today.
Dr. Nathaniel Stevens Hunting, dean of Quincy physicians and surgeons and a member of the staff of Quincy City Hospital since its founding in 1890, died today at his home in Quincy. His age was 74.

Establishment of a permanent council to prepare an annual program for the New York Legislature was advocated tonight by State Senator Thomas C. Desmond to end. what he termed "legislative dictatorship such as attempted by the present Governor."

Football's big push in the Far West, all over but the final exultant shouts, found the University of California on the Coast Conference throne today, pondering the selection of a suitable opponent for the Rose Bowl classic on New Year's Day.

Gabriele d'Annunzio assumed the presidency of the Italian Academy in absentia today, extolling the courage of modern Italy in a letter in the obscure and all but untranslatable prose for which the poet-warrior is famous.

Senator A. Harry Moore, who will relinquish his seat in Congress to assume the Governorship of New Jersey on Jan. 18, left for Washington tonight with the announcement that he was prepared to support measures providing for business tax revision.
Imports of gold by Great Britain in October amounted to f[Pound]12,729,690 and exports to [Pound]14,626,553.
Representative Jerry J. O'Connell of Montana attacked our neutrality policy yesterday as "aiding" the fascist governments of Italy and Germany in the Spanish war.
The interest rate for the Treasury's three-month bills has been lowered to 3 per cent, money has again become plentiful on the market and call money is quoted at only 1 1/2 to 2 per cent.

The Jersey Reds turned back the Original Celtics, 33 to 27, in an American Professional Basketball League contest before a crowd of 3,000 at the Hippodrome last night. Moe Frankel led the victors with 8 points, while Jack McGuirk topped the Celtics with six.

China's determination to resist Japanese invasion, not only now but to continue resistance "as long as the Japanese keep invading Chinese territory," was voiced today by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in a brief discussion of the general situation with THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent.

Scoring with consummate ease, the Fort Hamilton eleven furnished a surprise yesterday by handing the Fort Jay outfit, winner of the First Division military title last week, a stunning 25-0 reverse. A crowd of 3,000 at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn saw the game.

tlement of the three-day sit-down strike which closed all three plants of the Goodyear Tire and Rubbe?? Company and left 12,000 employee idle, was reached tonight when the Goodyear local of the United Rubber Workers of America accepted a proposal under which work was to be resumed at midnight.

Nations today were urged to study the principles enunciated by'Pope Leo XIII in his encyclicals concerning labor and the relationship between church and State, by the Rev. Paul B. Ward, who preached yesterday at high mass- at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul .the Apostle, Fifty-ninth Street and Columbus Avenue.

The Flying Caravan, a group of four American women touring South America by air in the interest of world peace under the sponsorship of the Peoples Mandate, arrived in Lima today from Santiago, Chile.
Reported by theAmerican News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's and Womrath's:

The Commissariat of Education, whose "old Bolshevik" chief, A. S. Bubnoff, was recently removed, was accused today of harboring traitorous wreckers who have been responsible for keeping several hundred thousand children out of schools, though the Soviet system provides for universal education.

Leaders of the Committee for Industrial Organization in Minneapolis asked Governor Elmer Benson and the Senate Civil Liberties Committee tonight to investigate what they termed "gangsterism in the Minneapolis labor movement."

Who would think that the Sanitation Department, once our municipal Little Orphan Annie, would turn out to be the aristocrat of the city services? But it has-in one of those charming Cinderella stories sd popular in fiction and so rare in real life. Of all Mayor La Guardia's

The election of at least three Democratic Councilmen from Manhattan seemed assured yesterday as the borough canvass of ballots was about to enter upon its final day. Some persons close to the canvass predicted that four of the six Manhattan members of the Council, which will have a total of twentysix members, would be Democratic, but the general belief was that the number would be three.
Albert de Jong is with Carl Marks Co., Inc., specialists in foreign securities. Richard A. Lewis is with Burton, Cluett Dana in Philadelphia.

Although calls for formal apparel and gift merchandise held up last week in the New York wholesale market, buying was generally slow. Scattering orders were placed on new mid-season collections of printed and pastel dresses in all price groups. Black-and-white dresses were reordered.
Alex G. Williams Sr., a 75-year-old Negro fisherman and trapper, was sitting at the bedside of his sick wife last night when he heard cries for help.

Dr. Harry N. Holmes, secretary of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches, speaking yesterday morning at the seventieth anniversary celebration of the Washington Heights Methodist Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and
TISH MARCHES ON, by Mary Roberts Rinehart. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.) New stories by the author of "The Book of Tish."

Edward Lee Marsh, former secretary and treasurer of the United States. Gypsum Company of Chicago and a director for the last nine years, died at his home here today at the age of 57. He was stricken yesterday with a cerebral hemorrhage.

Ringgold W. Carman, 94 years old, one of the three known surviving Civil War veterans in Queens, was made an honorary and life member of William M. McDonald Chapter of the Military Order of the Purple Heart at ceremonies yesterday at his home, 147-58 Fortyfirst Avenue, Flushing.
The Union League of Philadelphia, organized to support the administration of President Lincoln, will celebrate tomorrow night its seventy-fifth anniversary.

Preaching at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, Mgr. J. Francis A. McIntyre, chancellor of the Archdiocese of New York, exhorted each member of the congregation to examine and analyze his spiritual resources "as often and as carefully as your bank balance."

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Sanford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Edwin Sanford of this city, to Charles Chauncey Pool, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Scudder Pool of 160 Henry Street, Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Everett Watts of 1,010 Fifth Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Natalie 0. Watts, to Morgan Hatton Grace Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Grace of Lismore, Great Neck, L. I. The wedding will take place in January.

A four-and-a-half-line dispatch, wafted out of Washington the other day and promptly elbowed aside by the boisterous events of the preceding twenty-four hours, recites that after working at the job since the Seventies the United States Geological Survey has got the United States nearly half mapped. Did the reader,
Admiral David Foote Sellers, Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy, was the hero of a fire today that wrecked the fourth floor of historic Carvel Hall, a landmark hotel here.

" How do you like it?" Joseph Distexhe, 21 years old, asked proudly yesterday afternoon after he had put the finishing touches on a pistol he had converted from a .22-caliber rifle by sawing and filing it down.
Sales of the Allied Kid Company in October amounted to $608,025, compared with $841,330 a year before. For the first ten months of

More serious to Navy football prospects for the Army game than the unexpected defeat at Princeton yesterday was the probable loss of its powerful left tackle, Al Bergner of Kankakee, Ill., who was hurt in the first half of the contest.
For the third time in as many weeks, the Theatre Guild brings another show to Broadway tonight, this time leaving the same on its own Guild Theatre doorstep in West Fifty-second Street.

Twenty persons were injured today when stands near the cathedral collapsed as crowds here watched a five-hour parade in honor of the twenty-sixth anniversary of the overthrow of the thirty-year regime of Porfirio Diaz.

Mayor La Guardia's sweeping victory in the election shows that voters are disregarding old party lines and it will stimulate the Progressive movement throughout the country, Governor Philip F. La Follette of Wisconsin said yesterday on his return from Central America on the United Fruit liner Veragua.
The American Negro Ballet made its debut last night at the Lafayette Theatre in Harlem under the direction of Eugene von Grona and in a program of his compositions.
Liquidation was under way last week in the lard market on the Board of Trade here and all deliveries sold at new low prices for the season, with cash lard at the lowest figure since August. 1934.

Ace Parker led the usually faltering Brooklyn Dodgers to a 23-to-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates of the National Football League today in a stirring last-half display of gridiron fireworks. After pushing back and forth on the snow-covered gridiron for the entire first half without scoring, the Dodgers brought the 3,700 shivering spectators to their feet with three brilliantly executed touchdown plays and a field goal in the last two periods.

Sir Charles Bright, one of the world's leading experts on cable communications, died- yesterday at Bishop Stortford at the age of 73. He was credited with convincing the British Government in 1914 of the possibility of installing wireless in airplanes.

The possibility that some future Administration might attack Justice Hugo L. Black's right to sit on the Supreme Court bench can be staved off only if he is reappointed to the court after the expiration of his Senatorial term in 1939, according to an article appearing in the current issue of the Columbia Law Review, student publication of the Columbia University Law School.
Renewed discussion of the possibility of a dominion form of government for the Philippine Islands under the United States interested Manila editorial writers today.

The contract bridge team headed by Harold S. Vanderbilt, who races and plays bridge with the premier sportsmen of each field, was leading by a scant margin of 60 points last night as the first half of the final round of the Vanderbilt Cup competition ended in the Cavendish Club's rooms in the Hotel Ambassador.
Boston's fast-stepping Bruins tightened their grip on the American division leadership of the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 2 to 1, at the Stadium.

Princeton University's wrestling team will engage in eighteen dual meets during the 1938 season, according to the varsity, junior varsity and freshman schedules announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics. In launching its eight-meet campaign here on Jan. 8 against Rutgers. the varsity unit will be seeking its fifteenth consecutive victory.
The New York Civic Orchestra, directed by Eugene Plotnikoff, presented a varied program at the WPA Theatre of Music last night, with Sydney de Vries, baritone, as guest artist. Mr. de Vries was

William C. Price, one of the Jersey shore's best known hotel men and prominent in iceboating circles as rear commodore of the Long Branch Iceboat and Yacht Club, died of a heart attack this afternoon at Price's Hotel, Pleasure Bay. His age was 75.

Competition in the annual championship swimming tournament of the Brooklyn Catholic High Schools Athletic Association started yesterday with Bishop Loughlin Memorial High, defending title-holder, making an impressive showing as it conquered St. John's Prep, 56 to 19.
Hungary's recognition of the Spanish Insurgent regime became known tonight although the Hungarian Foreign Office declared existence of diplomatic relations was of general knowledge.

The Rev. L. Humphrey Walz, 27 years old, for the last three and a half years in charge of the Presbyterian Church at Oceanside, L. I., has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Second Presbyterian Church, Central Park West and Ninetysixth Street. He will be one of the youngest pastors in Manhattan.

The National Labor Relations Board has certified three A. F. of L. unions and one C. I. O. union at the General Steel Castings Commonwealth Division plant in Granite City, Ill. Elections were held on Oct. 29.

Construction has failed to revive in this country because private industry has not met the need for low-rent houses, according to Public Housing Progress, bulletin of the National Public Housing Conference.

After six weeks devoted exclusively to "Far-Off Hills," the Abbey Theatre Players have returned to one of their great works, J.- M. Synge's "The Playboy of the Western World," which they performed on Saturday evening at the Ambassador Theatre.
The Rev. Angus J. MacIntyre, Catholic priest called by former Premier R. B. Bennett "God's good old man" and known as "the children's friend," died in a hospital here today. His age was. 80.

More than 200 men and women gathered at the edge of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn yesterday for a meeting in memory of Amelia Earhart, who was lost in the Pacific last July while on a flight around the world.

Toronto's high-scoring Maple Leafs handed the faltering Detroit Red Wings their fourth defeat of the National Hockey League season tonight, blanking the 1936 champions, 5 to 0, before 13,293 spectators.
The effect of the decision'to increase the fiduciary note issue of the Bank of England by [Pound]20,000,000 can be readily and simply explained.

The Brookhattans maintained their lead in the American division of the American Soccer League by defeating the Baltimore S. C., 1 to 0, at Starlight Park yesterday before 4,000 fans. Joseph (Dixie) Skiba tallied on a 20-yard kick in the second half.

Dr. Henry W. Straus, a specialist in diseases of children, who was on the visiting staff of the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 214 Sterling Place, Brooklyn. Born in New York. forty-six

The Hispanos and Passon Phillies played to a 3-3 tie in their American Soccer League fixture at Commercial Field, Brooklyn, yesterday. Patenaude opened the scoring for the visitors. Quinones crossed to Burroughs to put the rivals on even terms at the end of the half.
The purpose of the Tennessee Valley Authority is to determine what an experiment of "good-will and honesty" in government can do for citizens, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today.

A check-up of the steamship Comet of the Colonial Line when it docked here yesterday morning from Providence, R. I., at Pier 11 disclosed that a passenger was missing. According to the harbor police, who investigated the case, the traveler had registered as G. Wilson when buying his ticket at Boston on Saturday afternoon.
The government has decided to divide the 1938 budget into two parts, military and ordinary. Combined it will total over 5,000,000,000 yen.

College-trained women of the last few decades are confused about the role of motherhood because of their attempts to intellectualize it and look at it objectively, Mrs. Sidonie M. Gruenberg, educational director of the Child Study Association of America, said yesterday in a statement prompted by the recent controversy over mother love.

The New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads announced yesterday that they had ordered more than a hundred sleeping, lounge and observation cars of advanced design from the Pullman-Standard Car Manufacturing Company.

The week's stock market here was uncertain, but the movements were predominantly reactionary, with moderate average losses. Speculative activity on the Boerse was concentrated mostly on the loan-stock papers, which were, at times, firm, although they weakened near the close.
The index for German wholesale prices on Nov. 10 stood at 105.5, against 105.9 on Nov. 3.

St. Joseph's closed its season by defeating La Salle at McCarthy Stadium today, 10-0, before 8,000 chilled spectators. The victory also gave the Hawks the city's college Catholic championship for the second straight year.

A survey of the occupations of Princeton University's class of '37, graduated last June, reveals that 86 per cent of the class is either employed or engaged in graduate study. The survey was made under the direction of Richard W. Warfield, director of the bureau of appointments and student employment.

General approval has been expressed here concerning the proposed Anglo-American trade agreement, which, if consummated, is bound to have a stimulating influence on trade in general. It is recognized, however,

Major Alexander de Seversky announced here today that his proposed take-off tomorrow from Floyd Bennett Air Field in Brooklyn in his new P-35 plane on a 2,300-mile non-stop flight to Mexico City and then by stages to Buenos Aires has been postponed until later this week.
A young woman becomes 25 at midnight tonight and gets a handsome birthday present, but is not excited and would rather not talk about it, which would not be unusual except for these two facts:

Fifteen-year-old Robert Miller, State Police Corporal Robert Benjamin said, shot and killed his father, Robert Miller, 41, late tonight in Raritan Township when the father came home drunk and beat his wife Marie. Another son, John, 14, witnessed the shooting, Beniamin said.
After two days of nearly continuous sessions, ending shortly before midnight tonight, the Senate Agriculture Committee agreed on a Farm Bill.
A new departure in celebrations was that of a young matron who drove through downtown Indianapolis with two woman friends.

On the eve of a hunt which was to open the season at the Cabin Bluff hunting preserve of the Sea Island Company tomorrow the body of Howard E. Coffin, industrialist and developer of Georgia coastal island resorts, was found crumpled on the floor, dead from a bullet, in an upstairs bedroom at the Sea Island home of his nephew, Alfred W. Jones, about 10:15 o'clock this morning.

The quality of the football played in the East in 1937 compares favorably with that in any other part of the country. The results of intersectional games have been very gratifying. The ten best teams in the East seem to be Pittsburgh and Fordham, with three all-stars each; Yale, Villanova, Dartmouth, Holy Cross, Navy, Harvard, Syracuse and Cornell.

Colonel Teofilo Iglesias, Minister of Finance, announced today that, due to a shortage of water, this year's rice crop was a failure and that the government had bought 60,500 tons of Siamese rice, costing 176,700.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Barbara Elizabeth Lockwood, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Charles Davenport Lockwood of this city, to Garrett Bunker of New York, son of Captain Charles Waite Orville Bunker, U. S. N., and Mrs. Bunker of Brooklyn.

The Count of Paris, pretender to the French throne, held a surprise secret meeting near here this afternoon, with 700 Action Francaise followers. He was "invited" at 6 o'clock by the Swiss Federal Government to leave Swiss territory immediately, together with all his followers.

The National Paper Box Manufacturers Association will hold its twentieth annual convention in Cleveland from May 22 to 25, according to an announcement by Allen K. Schleicher, St. Louis, president of the association.

Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union and complainant against Mayor James J. Walker at the hearings that led to the Mayor's resignation, yesterday made public a letter to Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division, First Department.

Theatrical celebrities will participate in a testimonial dinner to be given in honor of Mgr. Edward F. Leonard, pastor of St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, known as the Actors Church, next Sunday evening in the Hotel Astor.

Trading in grain futures on all contract markets in the United States increased 51 per cent in the fiscal year ended on June 30 over the previous corresponding period, according to the annual report of the Commodity Exchange Administration, made public today.

Mrs. Howard J. Rogers will give a luncheon today at the Weylin for a group of women serving with her on the executive committee for the matinee performance of "The Barber of Seville" on Feb. 11 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

International trade in 1936 lagged "about four years behind production," which surpassed the 1929 level but had not kept up with the increase in population, according to Part 2 of the Department of Commerce's World Economic Review, made public today.

A canvass by steel producers has revealed that in many instances consumers are operating at rates close to those of last Spring, using stocks accumulated through midyear, and refraining from further buying until the general situation has cleared, the magazine Steel says today.

Unidentified vandals left twelve huge splotches of red aniline dye on the newly finished stucco front of a physician's residence at 121 East Sixty-first Street, near Park Avenue, early yesterday morning. Detectives of the East Sixty-seventh Street station believed that labor racketeers threw the loaded electric light bulbs which caused the smears.

Despite a huge drop in Japanese sales to the United States between 1929 and 1930, Japan's exports to the United States have gained briskly during recent years, it was learned today from a study of Department of Commerce statistics.

A first-mortgage loan of $350,000 has been placed by Seely Cade, Inc., with the Union Central Life Insurance Company of Cincinnati, Ohio, on the four-story apartment house at 209 Prospect Street, East Orange, N. J. The property is owned by the Prospect Construction Company, builders in the Oranges.
An 80-mile-an-hour automobile chase over icy roads ended today in a crash, a shot and the death of Warren Sinclair Stanley, 16, a student at the Missouri Military Academy in Mexico, Mo.

Mrs. Annie Fitler Howell, widow of Charles H. Howell, died today after a long illness at her home in Torresdale. Mrs. Howell was a member of an old Philadelphia family and was the daughter of the late Edwin H. Fitler, one-time Mayor of the city.

Although a pawn behind when play was adjourned after forty moves last night, Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, world chess champion, was successful, when hostilities were resumed today, in drawing the nineteenth game of his match with Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris.
Actors were honored by the Drama League of New York at a tea yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pierre.

" The causes of America's distress today are much deeper than the defects of her leaders," the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, said yesterday morning in his sermon. "You and I, and people like
Although the visit here of Lord Halifax of Great Britain has monopolized public attention, it has had no influence whatever on the Boerse, which remained dull this week while moving somewhat lower.

A three-and-one-half-hour snowfall yesterday morning was just sufficient for the Department of Sanitation, already at high tension for a battle with a real snowstorm, to try out its motor sweepers. For two hours fifty-five "brooms" briskly swept the bridges that span the East River and those over the Harlem River, and also dusted off the East and West Side express highways.
Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 11 A. M. "The Citizen and the Government's Fiscal Policies," Professor William Starr Myers.

Donald MacVicar Jr., 15-year-old son of the assistant superintendent of the Pocantico Hills estate of John D. Rockefeller Jr., was found fatally wounded late this afternoon near a closet on the first floor of his home on the estate. He was rushed in an ambulance to Tarrytown Hospital and died there a few minutes later.
The total paid attendance at the second annual edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES National Book Fair, which closed a seventeen-day run yesterday, was 83,494.

A special ramp will be constructed from the Triborough Bridge over Wards Island so that pedestrians from Astoria may easily reach the 177-acre city park to be developed on the island, it was announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses.

Chancellor Hitler announced in an address here today that he did not expect a settlement of Germanys colonial claims for five to six years. He was enthusiastically applauded, however, when he made clear his conviction that Germany, like Britain, France and Russia, must become "a great empire."

Alternating at the helm and crewing in the Class X sailing dinghy Wow, Harry Hall and Dick Hill took five straight races today in the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club, finishing with a perfect score of 100 points. It has been a long time since any one accomplished that.

With the ghosts of Republican officeholders-who lost their political lives in the last depression gibbering and shrieking in Washington, it is unusually interesting to get some sort of line on what Herbert Hoover's successor feels about a third term.

All this week sentiment in Stock Exchange and market circles generally has continued thoroughly depressed. Rallying power among securities was conspicuous by its absence, the depression in the United States being a deterrent to optimism.

This is a moment of relaxation in Europe. The pause is not peace nor the prospect of peace. It is too vague and slight to be described as a change in the weather. Rather it is as if the international temperature had stopped rising and had perhaps begun to fall.

Replying to Rockwell Kent's assertion that the jury that convicted Pedro Albizu Campos was handpicked, United States District Attorney Cecil Snyder today said that in eleven judicial proceedings in District Courts of Appeal and the Supreme Court the defense counsel had charged that the jury was improperly selected and that all the courts had rejected the charges.

The Scots-Americans were in top form today, turning back the St. Mary's Celtics, 4 to 2, in an American Soccer League game. Rae of the Scots registered after ten minutes of play. Midway in the half a penalty was given against Wolstencroft, and Crilley made a successful kick to tie the score. In the second period Fisher, Moniz and Rae tallied for the Scots, McEwan for the Celtics.

The National Peace Conference, composed of representatives of fortyone organizations interested in better international relations, today praised Secretary Hull's reciprocal trade agreements program as an effective medium of "alleviating some of the conditions that make for war."

The Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, now picketing six Broadway theatres in an attempt to win recognition as the sole bargaining agent for its members, will continue to do so until "one side 'r the other wins," John H. McCarron, secretary-treasurer of the organization, said yesterday.

A plane participating with seven others in a game of aerial "treasure hunt" crashed on a municipal golf course on the Lake Michigan shore today, killing the pilot, Joseph Gabris, 22, of West Allis, Wis., and injuring his companion John Shields, 21, of Wauwatosa, also a flyer.
Public officials and civic leaders paid tribute yesterday afternoon to the memory of Darwin James, banker and philanthropist, in exercises at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

International House, in which during the last thirteen years 4,500 students from 101 different countries outside the United States as well as 7,500 from within have lived together as a big family for months at a time in peace and harmony, is a microcosm of the earth, which has hardly more nations in its larger house. Mr. John D.

An announcement that there was no danger caused 1,200 persons who were witnessing a Yiddish and American stage program to remain quietly in their seats last night at the Clinton Theatre, 80 Clinton Street, during a small fire in an adjoining storeroom.

The need for censorship of press and radio is suggested by Enrique Santos in connection with the extraordinary fiscal powers just voted to the President of Colombia, in an article appearing in Tiempo of Bogota just received here. The present regime in Germany is praised and those in Russia and Mexico condemned.
The level of British industrial activity in the September quarter was 3.1 per cent lower than the average for the preceding quarter but 7.1 per cent better than the September quarter last year.

Federal and State pressure was applied here today to compel the United Automobile Workers of America to control wildcat strikes before they get out of hand in General Motors plants and particularly to end the sit-down strike of 450 employes in the Fisher Body plant here, which has thrown nearly 15,000 workers out of jobs since Wednesday.

In churches throughout Westchester County services of thanksgiving were held today. One of the principal. events was the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the coming of Methodism to White Plains at the Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood at 78.4 on Nov. 17, compared with 79.7 a fortnight before, 80.7 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

National Commander Daniel J. Doherty called on two American Legion groups here today to support a drive for a law requiring universal service in war time. He spoke to State presidents and secretaries of the Women's Auxiliary and the Legion's Indiana executive committee.

Three Yale students who invaded a dormitory at Lasell Junior College, Auburndale, at 3 A. M. today "looking:for a date" were arrested by Newton police. after a mad chase through corridors in which women students pelted the intruders with shoes, books and desk sets.
Mother Frances Xavier Cabrini, founder of the Institute of Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart, moved a step nearer to canonization today.

The Peruvian Telephone Company, a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, opened its automatic exchange in Chorrillos, a suburb of the capital, last night. The automatic service will be extended to the entire city at a cost of more than 10,000,000 soles.

Rachel Crothers, who has been writing shows for Broadway since 1906, including several long-run hits, came to the Town Hall Club last evening for a one-performance engagement and met one of her best audiences. That organization,
About 600 delegates to a business meeting of the New York State Teachers Association prepared tonight to act on resolutions pertaining to the future of the State's public school system.

Age does not mean inactivity to Ieber J. Grant, president of the Latter Day Saints (Mormon) Church, who observed his eightyfirst birthday today. Mr. Grant, leader of about 750,000 Mormons, attributes his activity to the creed: "Clean life and hard work insure good health."

A Senegalese soldier was killed today and fifty demonstrators were wounded in a battle between French troops and rioting Lebanese Nationalists. Reinforcements restored order after arresting 150 leaders of the 800 Nationalists protesting dissolution of the political association that the government disbanded as semimilitary organizations.

Keith Morgan, chairman of the committee for the celebration of the President's birthday, announced yesterday that the President's plan for a national foundation for infantile paralysis had won nationwide approval.
Sinclair Lewis speaks tonight at the Brooklyn Academy of Music under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

Some thirty or more exhibitions crowd the calendar for the fifth successive week in the art galleries. If museum shows are absent and group exhibitions and displays of work by outstanding artists are fewer, the current attractions assuredly make up for such deficiencies in diversity and number.
Daniel C. Jackling, president of the Utah Copper Company, has been elected president of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, it was announced yesterday.

The present local and national scene was compared with that of a half century ago in a historical sermon by the Rev. William F. Wefer at a service yesterday in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Presbyterian Church of the Good Shepherd, 152 West Sixtysixth Street.

A passing' attack that netted five touchdowns and running plays that added two ethers gave the University of Detroit a 48-to-7 victory over Creighton University today. Detroit scored on two forwards in four and a half minutes of the first quarter. Palumbo passed from his 40 to Larson on the Creighton 15. Larson ran to the 8, whence

The great mission, of the- Chrlstian church is to make man conscious of the spiritual world, the Rev. Dr. Bruce Hunter, pastor of St. James United Church,:Montreal, Canada, said yesterday morning in his sermon at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Bob Fraser Jr., sailing Shiver, took three races and finished second in the fourth for 39 points and victory today in the Manhasset Bay frostbite dinghy regatta. Fraser scored in a fleet of ten Class D boats, in a northwest breeze that- blew so hard that the larger Class B craft could not race.

The dollarsterling exchange from day to day continues to follow an extraordinarily erratic course with the strong rising tendency of sterling counteracted only by support for the dollar through official equalization funds.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Annesley Murray of 5 Circle Hill Road, Pelham Manor, formerly of York, Pa., held a reception at their home this afternoon at which announcement was made of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Catherine Murray, to Herbert T. Creedon, also of Pelham Manor.

The Hearn Department Store will stage its annual outdoor circuses in Central and Prospect Parks on Thanksgiving Day. The store said preparations had been made to have this year's outshine any outdoor circus ever held.
An appeal for the redoubling of efforts in behalf of the $325,000 campaign of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, was issued yesterday by Leon Fraser, general chairman. He urged that the fund

The Metropolitan Opera's "Golden Horseshoe," as the parterre boxes are popularly known, will show striking changes when the new 1937-1938 season opens next Monday night. In the new list of boxholders, made public yesterday, many names long associated with the opera are missing, owing to death and other causes.

The four Soviet scientists adrift on the North Polar ice floe celebrated the completion of the first six months of their vigil tonight by exchanging radio broadcasts with Moscow. Just six months ago they were deposited on the ice at the North Pole.
In an atmosphere of pageantry the banners of twenty-nine patriotic societies were borne through the nave of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon at a Joint Thanksgiving service.

Aided by a four-minute handicap, Edward Blackwell of the Mercury A. C. of Philadelphia won first prize in the five-mile A. A. U. handicap road race staged by the Boys of Yesteryear in Harlem yesterday. The Philadelphian led the eighty-two finishers by covering the distance in the actual time of 28 minutes 14 seconds.
Paul Codos, noted French long-distance flier, landed his four-motored plane here tonight after a flight across the South Atlantic Ocean from Dakar, Africa.

After sitting at the soda fountain in the Pennsylvania Drug Store, 1,527 Broadway, at Forty-fifth Street, for more than two hours, a youth about 18 years old suddenly produced a pistol, held the cashier at bay, and took $125 from the cash register.

If you have planned to participate in the open season on "antlerless" deer in Pennsylvania, which was scheduled to run from the 25th to the 27th, inclusive, don't leave until you have queried the Game Commission.

The New York Rovers recorded their second triumph in as many starts on home ice yesterday when they shut out the Hershey Bears, 2 to 0, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden.

Ernest Perrin, French linguist, lecturer and poet, died yesterday at his home in Brookline at the age of 68. He was the founder of the "Matinees Litteraries," popular for years in New York and Newport society, and directed the plays of the Cercle Francais at Harvard University for twenty years.
The Davison Fund, established by John D. Rockefeller Jr., has contributed $30,000 to the United Hospital Campaign, it was announced last night by John W. Davis, campaign chairman.

The first Massachusetts C. I. O. convention today unanimously adopted a resolution calling for a "broad," democratically elected convention of all C. I. O., A. F. of L. and Brotherhood of Railroad unions" to unite the nation's organized workers.

Relatives here said they were advised tonight of the death of John Gould Jennings, chairman of the board of Lamson Sessions Company, of a heart attack while on board a train taking him to St. Petersburg, Fla., for the Winter. His age was 81.

The Kreiner Quartet officiated yesterday at the concert of the New Friends of Music, given in Town Hall, in the performance of Schubert's Quartet, Op. 125, No. 2; Friedrich Schorr sang the beautiful "Liederkreis" cycle of Schumann and an aggregation of string quartet and two horns, players from the Boston Symphony Orchestra, performed the Mozart Cassation in B flat, Koechel 287.

A shooting affray today at the home of Dr. H. E. Martin, 51-yearold physician, resulted in the death drew of Dr. Martin's mother-in-law and father-in-law and the arrest of the doctor and his wife on "technical charges of murder."

Eleven more cases of typhoid were reported in Croydon yesterday, making a total of 137, 'as two of Britain's most distinguished physicians expressed the opinion that the epidemic probably had resulted from the, contamination of "a portion of the water supply."
If, as appears probable, foreign opinion is slow to take seriously the new Brazilian Constrution, President Getulio Vargas will have no just grounds for complaint. The Constitution of

William Downey, 16 years old, who won much publicity a few years ago when his police dog, Pal, accompanied him daily to the Greeley School at Chappaqua and rested in a corner of the schoolroom, was killed by an automobile early this morning while walking in Washington Avenue, Pleasantville.
Mayor La Guardia, in appointing Magistrate Henry H. Curran as the first incumbent of the office of Deputy Mayor, named in the new charter, has set an excellent precedent. To be sure,

While overzealous critics and champions of parole continue to hurl thunderbolts at each other, the New York State Parole Board is quietly subjecting the results in this State to the first official scientific analysis.

Ten new single-deck buses, of streamlined design and equipped with automatic gear shifts, will be placed in operation today on the Fifty-seventh Street crosstown line of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

We are living today in an age that sees the triumph of secular civilization, the Rev. Dr. Irving Husted Berg, a former pastor, told the congregation of the Fort Washington Collegiate Reformed Church, Fort Washington Avenue and 181st Street, yesterday morning, and it behooves all good Christians to show the world the abiding qualities of the Christian church.

Mr. and Mrs. William Newell of 1,225 Park Avenue have announced the marriage of their only daughter, Mrs. Betty Newell McConnell, to William Guggenheim Jr., only child of Mr. and Mrs. Guggenheim, also of this city, and Sands Point, L. I., which took place on Thursday at Elkon,
A deed filed with the county clerk reveals that President Roosevelt has acquired 13.07 More acres of farm property in the town of Hyde Park.
Despite the reported heavy increase in merchandise returns this season by retailers to women's apparel manufacturers, particularly in the dress industry, the number of cases "mentioned"

Demanding a salary scale and leave privileges similar to those in effect among New York actors of the WPA Federal Theatre Project, a group representing the Los Angeles project is reported to have placed before Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national head of the project, a list of grievances following rumblings of discontent current in recent weeks.

What is perhaps the finest Greek bronze hydria, or water jar, known to have survived from the early fifth century, B. C., has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and will be placed on exhibition this morning in the room of recent accessions.

Oscar Fritzche, manager of the Longchamps restaurant at Fortyninth Street and Madison Avenue, New York, died here today at his home, 429 Nelson Avenue, after a three weeks' illness of diabetes. He was 48 years old. His widow, Elizabeth Fritzche, survives.

General Staff Colonel Loeb, director of the Reich office for raw and workshop materials, affirms that the shortage in nonferrous metals is abating because of an increase in home output and reforms in construction methods.
