A mission of peace has been passed on to living war veterans by the dead of past wars, the Rev. Edward M. Pennell Jr., rector of All Saints Protestant Episcopal Church, Seventh Street and

The final date for registration of motor vehicles: in New Jersey should be postponed from Jan. 1 to April 1 in accordance with the practice started recently in other States, E. J. Leary, secretary of the New Jersey Petroleum Industries Committee, declared in a statement today.

Louis J. Moss was unanimously reelected yesterday as president of the Brooklyn Region of the American Zionist Organization by 200 delegates to the unit's second annual conference at the Hotel Granada, Brooklyn. Assemblyman Albert D. Schanzer also was re-elected chairman of the regional board of directors.

In the penetrating cold of a Winter setting, the curtain was lowered Saturday upon the snow-mantled gridirons of most of the college football teams of the East and the Middle West. A week hence, the tumult and the shouting will have been stilled all along the front save in the warmer clime of the Far West and the South, where roses are red, sugar is sweet and a bowl is the common architectural denominator.

Miss-Kate E. Turner, who recently- retired after a career of fifty years, six months and nineteen days as an active member of the city school system, declared yesterday that she soon would climb into her brand new automobile and travel.

Sid White, the Brooklyn College halfback flash who didn't score his first point until Oct. 9 and has averaged three touchdowns a week since, has just about clinched the Eastern individual football scoring championship, according to The Associated Press.

The individual, the nation, the church, the corporation and the business founded in the teachings of the Lord and which are founded on the rock of Jesus will not fall when the time for testing comes, the Rev. Hillyer H. Straton declared yesterday before the congregation of the Central Baptist Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

The decision of the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society yesterday to sell for $50,000 twenty-five acres of land at the Mineola Fair Grounds as a site for the new county court house has revived interest in the proposal for a county community center on the tract and land adjoining it.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 86.1, which compares with 87.1 a week ago, 87.9 twro weeks ago, 88.1 three weeks ago and 89.3 four weeks ago. The present average is the lowest of the year to date; the highest was 94.7, in the first week of April.
The weekly index of France's wholesale prices stood on Nov. 13 at 605, compared with 604 on Nov. 6 and 611 on Oct. 20. Native products stood at 642, against 643 and 641 respectively;

A funeral service for Harold H. Hackett, former national tennis doubles champion and member of the Davis Cup team and committee, will be held at 2 P. M. today at the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. Mr. Hackett died Saturday
Twenty-eight dogs competed in the first day's trials of the limited open all-age stake at the fifth meeting of the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club on the estate of Mrs. Walter Hoving today.

Apparently unaware that more than $1,500 in football ticket sale proceeds was safely in the town bank, burglars broke into the office safe of the Bloomfield High School last night or early today and found only $10 or $15 in loose change.

Despite the fact that the cotton crop is now estimated at about 18.243,000 bales, 2,650,000 more than when plans for financing the cotton loans were announced early in September, Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today that the Commodity Credit Corporation would redeem the notes even though "substantially more" than the original estimate of $150,000,000 would be required.

Of the hundreds of metropolitan high school football results recorded this Fall, few carried more significance than the shut-out victory registered by undefeated Lawrence High over previously unbeaten Baldwin on Saturday.

Managua's mysterious ghost who had torn up the newly made grave of Fernando Villa and appeared nightly in one of the cemeteries during the past fortnight, causing inhabitants to spend sleepless nights, was exposed last night.

Surrogate Leone D. Howell of Nassau -County paid tribute tonight to forty-four members of the Nassau County Firemen's Association who died during the year at the annual memorial service held in the Roosevelt Methodist Episcopal Church.

The United States employment services placed 210,240 applicants in jobs with private employers during the month of October, Secretary Perkins announced today. During the month, including these private places, a total of 303,286 jobs were filled. While this marked an

Scott F. Marshall, president of point Council 40 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers, said today that the organization would soon start a seven-State bicketing campaign for 20,000 new members.

The Rev. Stanley Brown-Serman of the Virginia Theological Seminary, Alexandria, Va., and Mrs. Brown-Serman have announced to relatives and friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Montagu Brown-Serman, to Stephen Condict Walke, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Roger A. Walke of Pikesville, Md.
The Sacred Heart Church here was crowded this morning when Mgr. Richard B. Cushion, its pastor, was formally invested as a papal chamberlain to Pope Pius at a solemn mass.
Bishop William T. Manning dedicated yesterday two menorah lights in the chapel of St. Luke the Physician, Seaview Hospital, West New Brighton, S. I.

Even if business should "miraculously" return to the 1929 level, welfare expenditures would still be far in excess of what they were in that period, Dr. Mabel Newcomer of Vassar College declares in a survey included. in the volume, "Studies in Current Tax Problems," to be published today by the Twentieth Century Fund.

IT was good weather for ducks, just the kind of sloppy going that earned Ducky Pond his nickname when he ran against Harvard some years ago. But Ducky's reign over the Crimson cohorts ended in a snow flurry over the swampy terrain in the Harvard Stadium on Saturday.

Frankie Covelli of Brooklyn scored an upset tonight by knocking out Jimmy Perrin of New Orleans in the third round of their scheduled 10-round bout. Approximately 2,000 saw Perrin take his first ring beating in three years.
With a modesty that one might not ordinarily expect from a man who turned in one of the season's finest coaching jobs, Dick Harlow of Harvard gave the game back to the boys yesterday.

The volume of world trade was almost back to its 1929 level in June, for the first time, according to figures published by the League of Nation's monthly statistical bulletin today. With 100 representing the 1929 figure, the index in June reached 99.
NEWS OF METROPOLITAN REAL ESTATE
Indiana University successfully defended the Central Intercollegiate cross-country championship today and, for added effect, presented Don Lash in a brilliant side piece.

A wage dividend and "loyalty" bonus to employes of the Zenith Radio Corporation was announced yesterday by E. F. McDonald Jr., president. A 10 per cent wage dividend will be paid on all employes' wages and salaries for the last six months, which constitutes the first half of the company's fiscal year.
Stocks closed weak at lowest levels since April, 1935, with. losses of 1 to 7 points; turnover, 1,517,390 shares. All bonds lower in quiet trading; transactions, $7,888,600.

Due to a large increase in its business, the Underwriters Trust Company has leased additional space in the building at 37-39 Broadway, where the banking, trust and safe deposit departments now occupy the entire ground floor.

The annual dance under the auspices of the Junior League of Cliff Haven will be held tomorrow night at the Biltmore for the Catholic Summer School of America, an educational and recreational resort on the shore of Lake Champlain.

Representative Bruce Barton of New York City urged the Federal Trade Commission today to expedite its investigation of monopolies and high prices and bring relief to and high pries and bring relief to small business men.

Salvador E. Ros, retired sugar planter and importer, died on Sunday at his home, 10 East Eightyfifth Street, after a seven-month illness. His age was 73. Born In Santiago, Cuba, Mr. Ros was the son of the late Salvador Ros and the late Mrs. Sylvina Ros.

The number of business failures in the United States was 206 in the week ended Nov. 18, compared with 172 in the previous week and 143 in the corresponding week of last year, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The departure of General Jose Tomas Calderon, Minister of Government, from El Salvador on a three months' vacation has aroused speculation here as to its possible significance, regardless of the fact that the Salvadorean Congress elected him Second Vice President just before his departure.

Nelson T. Johnson, United States Ambassador to China, together with certain members of his staff, will leave Nanking tomorrow for Hankow, where it is expected that the Chinese Foreign Ministry will be established, the State Department announced tonight.

Provoked by the "utter disregard by many operators of motor vehicles of the provisions of the State vehicle and traffic laws, as well as of the local ordinances and police regulations," the October Westchester County grand jury petitioned. the Board of Supervisors today to make the prosecution of violators more certain by creating four new county offices and obtaining remedial State legislation.

The Budget and Appropriations Committee of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors conducted a public hearing here tonight--on the proposed county budget for 1938, totaling $2,875,778 more than the 1937 expenditures of $15,221,017.
Opponents of the establishment of a pro-Nazi camp here were preparing today for a town meeting tomorrow, when the issue of bringing the "goose step" to Southbury will be aired.

Samuel Seabury replied yesterday to Samuel Untermyer's criticism of his Rochester speech by declaring that nothing that Mr. Untermyer had said disproved his assertion that Governor Lehman "is and always has been friendly to Tammany Hall, aiding its efforts to defeat the public interest."

Arrested yesterday afternoon at the Garden Hotel, 800 Eighth Avenue, on a Federal warrant charging that she had willfully made false statements to obtain a passport, Hope Sinclair, 24-year-old night club entertainer, was faced with the possibility of a sentence of five years' imprisonment or a $2,000 fine, or both, and deportation.

The mortality rate of automobile accidents declined last week as compared to the corresponding week of 1936, it was announced yesterday by the safety bureau of the Police Department. According to the report First Deputy Commissioner Harold Fowler wrote:

In a letter to the editor, published in another column, Colonel Leonard Ayres takes issue with the contention of THE TIMES'S editorial of last Wednesday that there have not been six important trade recessions since 1932, but only three or four, and that there were probably as many similar reactions in the similar five-year period of older business recoveries.

An application on the part of the Motor Rail Company of Jersey City for a certificate of convenience and necessity before the Interstate Commerce Commission was opposed yesterday at a hearing at the Hotel New Yorker by representatives
Russian airplanes went into action for the first time yesterday as part of China's air force in a battle with Japanese airmen.

Postponement of tax revision for aiding business recovery until the regular meeting of Congress in January became practically a certainty today after President Roosevelt intervened, in a series of week-end moves, to limit the special session to his program, and especially to prevent runaway alteration or repeal of the levy on undistributed corporate profits.

The 1937 Big Ten all-star gridiron array, selected by the coaches for The Associated Press, lines up today with three stalwarts from Minnesota's champions, a trio from Ohio State, two from Purdue, and one each from Indiana, Northwestern and Iowa in the mythical battlefront.
Marsh Cunningham, formerly with the Shelton Holding Corporation, has joined the staff of Vivian Green and is now in charge of renting at the Green Park Building, 7 Park Avenue.

Adelphi College at Garden City, L. I., one of the State's leading.colleges for women, obtained yesterday from Federal Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn approval of a petition for reorganization under Section 77-B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
A baby was born between two rebel air raids on Alicante Saturday-night and in a second attack the baby and its mother were killed by a bomb.
President Roosevelt, suffering from a second infection in connection with a tooth drawn last Thursday, canceled his Thanksgiving trip to Warm Springs, but will leave next week.

A recurrence of a pus condition icident to an abscessed tooth forced President Roosevelt today to postpone his Thanksgiving trip to Warms Springs, Ga., and to remain in the Executive Mansion for treatment of a second infected pocket that developed after the tooth was extracted on Thursday. He did not drop work, however.

As the site for a nine-story building with stores, a plot 126 by 98 feet at the southeast corner of Broadway and Seventy-fifth Street, Jackson Heights, has been sold by William Roess to Morris Strominger. The Irving Berger Management Company was the broker.

Attorney General Cummings, who offered $2,000 reward each for information leading to the arrest of John Oley, Percy Geary and Harold Crowley, convicted members of the 1933 O'Connell kidnapping gang, said in a statement today that $4,000 would be paid to Ivan Whiteford, janitor of a Syracuse rooming house.

The four Aces, composed of Oswald Jacoby, David Burnstine, Howard Schenken and M. D. Maier, with Sherman Stearns as alternate, won the 1937 award of the coveted Vanderbilt Cup at contract bridge last night at the Cavendish Club in the Hotel Ambassador. The quartet of bridge experts put in a full week of play to win the cup.

The Far Eastern conference reassembled today to prepare for its abortive end. It is dying because it has neither teeth nor claws and its expression of high moral principles that ought to prevail in the world has proved useless without something more substantial or practical behind it.

The following tables show the latest Council returns in the Boroughs of Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens. In Richmond the count was completed some time ago, with Frederick Schick, Democrat, elected as the borough's sole Councilman.
William Caffrey, former amateur single sculls champion of America and a member of the police department here for forty years, died today at his home. His age was 70.
It is refreshing to have the psychologists, on the same page. in yesterday's paper, come out in support of two

Naming Charlie McCarthy at the top of a list of "national heroes," Sinclair Lewis, in a lecture last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, asserted that America's "glorification" of big business and salesmanship was as conducive to "the psychology of slavery" as certain precepts of Fascist and Communist nations.

The power of the Board of Estimate to control pay increases and promotions in county offices was attacked yesterday In a suit filed in Supreme Court by Assistant District Attorney Robert V. Santangelo, who said that the Controller had refused to pay him any salary since his promotion from a $7,500 to a $10,000-a-year post by District Attorney William C. Dodge.

In the Supreme Court of the United States the following proceedings were had today: The Chief.Justice announced the following orders of the court: 35-National City Bank of New York, petr., v. People of the Philippine Islands. On writ of cert.

Bishop Ernest M. Stires of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island urged a group of Long Island Baptist ministers yesterday to join in an interdenominational effort to have children whose parents desire it excused from school for one hour each week for religious instruction at nearby churches.

Need of laboratory and interne training and of greater emphasis on psychology and social sciences in medical education ware stressed in addresses of leaders in the medical world who participated in dedication today of the new $825,000 building of Syracuse University's College of Medicine.

Allegations that the Progressive Miners of America hired a man in 1934 to murder John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, were voiced in Federal District Court today by a government - witness in the conspiracy trial of forty-one men identified with the Progressive Miners.

William Vernon Platt of Rye, N. Y., who on Saturday finished his first season with the Yale football eleven as a regular at right tackle, today was elected captain of the team for next season, succeeding Clinton Edward Frank.

A portrait of the Countess Daru by the French artist Jacques-Louis David (1748-1825) has been bought by the Frick Collection from Wildenstein Co. Formerly in the colelection of M. David-Weill of Paris, it was lent to the notable exhibition of French art held by the Royal Academy in Lonaon in 1932. It has been mentioned in a number of publocations on David and reproduced in several.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Reactions in Recovery" says I am in error in claiming that this is the sixth important downturn of trade since the bottom of the depression in 1932.

Several leases to well-known authors and musicians were included in the long list of apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Arthur Kober, playwright, took a suite in Essex House, 160 Central Park South, and Miss Rachel Crothers, writer, rented from Mrs. Elsie Lawson, through Douglas Gibbons Co., an apartment in 1,001 Park Avenue. Other leases were:

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden indicated in the House of Commons today that Great Britain would not grant Japan's demand for virtual control of Shanghai's International Settlement without the consent of the Chinese Government.

Clyde Bedell, who has been in the executive office of Marshall Field Co. for two years, today was named advertising manager of that company to succeed G. Ray Schaeffer, who recently was transferred to the position of director of publicity and customer relations.

Helen Hayes thinks theatre audiences ought to learn how to behave. In fact, she suggested today, playgoers are becoming so errant that some one ought to establish a chair in a university to overcome the public's defect.

Westchester County supervisors were somewhat. perplexed today when a petition, eight feet long and bearing 210 signatures, was filed with them in protest against the proposed opening of a branch motor vehicle bureau in Ossining during the January sale of license plates. Communities often fight to obtain bureaus, but none ever had opposed the openin of one, supervisors said..
The annual meeting of stockholders of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was adjourned yesterday until Dec. 22 because of lack of a quorum.

The Roosevelt Administration was accused tonight by Bainbridge Colby, former Secretary of State, of engaging in the "dissemination of poisonous teaching" in connection with "bold and frontal" attacks upon the "essentials of constitutional government."

Between love and war Sidney Howard mentions a good many interesting topics in "The Ghost of Yankee Doodle," which the Theatre Guild put on in its own home last evening. Like a few people in the theatre and a multitude outside, he is discussing the incompetence of the liberal in a world that is dominated by mass hysteria.

With one exception, the affairs of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association will be carried on next year by the same officials. The only change in the slate that will be presented at the annual meeting to be held at 10 o'clock Thursday, Dec. 2, at the Hotel Biltmore is in the presidency, Mrs. F. S. Dickinson of Yountakah, Nutley, N. J., succeeding Mrs. Joseph Dey, the former Rosalie Knapp.

More than 200 sit-down strikers who had held the Fisher Body plant here for five days meekly followed Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, from the building here today after he had made a dramatic and unheralded appearance before them and had defeated the left-wing opposition, which had fought to have the general executive board sanction the strike.

Coach Lou Little excused sixteen regulars and top-ranking reserves from practice yesterday while the remainder of the Columbia football squad was coached in Stanford formations on the frozen turf of Baker Field.

The Brooklyn Y. M. C. A. has gone well past the half-way mark in its 1938 Budget Difference Campaign for $80,000, it was announced last night at final report dinner of the drive in the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn. Collections and pledges thus far amount to $58,511.
The classic features of Lord Byron, who wrote part of "Childe Harold" at the village of Cintra, will be carved on the highest rock of the mountain overlooking the famed Portuguese beauty spot.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has granted an application by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company for exemption from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

A decline in employment of about 145,000 workers in the manufacturing industries of the country during October, as compared with September, was partly offset by job gains in anthracite and bituminous coal mining and in retail trade, leaving a net decrease for October of 80,000, Secretary Perkins reported today in a monthly survey.

Joseph D. Frankel, 57-year-old former member of the New York Stock Exchange, who has a $5,000,000 suit pending against the Exchange as a result of his expulsion in 1933, was arrested yesterday by Police Lieutenant Grover Brown and Detective Henry D. Oswald of the main office squad on a warrant chargnings grand larceny.

Net railway operating income of the Reading Company for October amounted to $1,275,706, a decrease of $225,143 from the same month of last year, the company reported today, Total railway operating revenues for last month were $4,958,024, a decrease of $488,923 from a year before, while the total operating expense increased $63,998 to $3,501,893.

With only about forty days left of the term of New York County Clerk Albert Marinelli, who by noon tomorrow must answer charges filed against him with Governor Lehman, associates of Mr. Marinelli were reported yesterday to be preparing to request the Governor to appoint a Moreland Act commissioner to investigate the County Clerk's conduct.

Captain John F. Milliken, who was suspended Nov. 10 as president of the United Licensed Officers Association by the executive committee, accepted a summons late yesterday to appear this morning before Magistrate Morris Rothenberg to answer charges of alleged mismanagement of the union's affairs.

The Yorkville Unit of the Speedwell Society was the beneficiary of a luncheon and fashion show yesterday in the Garden of the Ambassador. The proceeds will be used in the maintenance of foster homes for the convalescent and post-hospital care of infants of needy families in the Yorkville section.

The six-day filibuster against the Wagner-Gavagan Anti-Lynching Bill ended temporarily today with the Senate's recess until tomorrow, but there came threats from the bill's foes that the filibuster would be resumed if the leadership insisted upon consideration after the farm measure is out of the way.

Candidates, campaign committees and political organizations rushed yesterday to file their reports on campaign receipts and expenditures for the recent election with the Board of Elections in the Municipal Building.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 26,000, including 9,000 direct. The market closed active and 10 to 15 cents lower than Friday's average. Top, $8;

Mr. and Mrs. William Orbison of Westport, Conn., gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Judith Ann Wilcox and Hugh Wheeler Sanford Jr., whose marriage will take place tomorrow in the Second Congregational Church of Greenwich.
In announcing yesterday the declaration of a dividend of 50 cents a share on its capital stock, the United Aircraft Corporation said there had been several changes in personnel.

More than twenty housing authorities from a dozen cities met today with Nathan Straus, administrator of the United States Housing Authority, in the first of a series of conferences designed to speed a start on new projects under the Wagner-Steagall Act.

The great interest in sports and travel received a primary place in Fashion Futures--American Edition, the first major fashion show to feature only the creations of American designers, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night by the Fashion Group, Inc., before 1,500 leaders in fashion and design from all parts of the country.

More than 200 sales representatives for Eastern distributors of the "Hotpoint" appliance line of the Edison General Electric Co., of Chicago, yesterday attended the opening of a two-day sales meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The company's complete 1938 line of major electrical appliances was placed on display.

W. Rossiter Redmond, Brooklyn lawyer and son-in-law of Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, was arraigned yesterday in Kings County Court on a charge of grand larceny while acting as a receiver appointed to handle a trust fund belonging to John Barry Ryan, son of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan.

The authorities here have received confirmation that Bishop Franciscus Schraven, Apostolic Vicar of Chengting, China, has been murdered by bandits. Nothing previously had been heard about his fate since he was reported kidnapped with a group of missionaries on Oct. 9, the day after the Japanese capture of Chengting.

The price weakness in various dry goods lines, which began in a small way in April and has continued in increasing intensity since, has caused many retailers who formerly bought direct from mill-selling agents to depend upon wholesales in their own districts for supplies as needed, it was learned yesterday, and for this reason some wholesalers in the first half of Nomember booked dollar sales above their volume of a year ago.

Pierre Etchebaster of France, world's open-court tennis champion, will defend his title for the first time since 1931 in a challenge match starting Dec. 4 at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club at Tuxedo Park.

Fifty representatives of New York's exclusive hotels, importers and dealers in liquor got a lesson in the manufacture, care and serving of fine wines last night, while they watched students of the International Geneva Association's beverage Merchandising course sip imported vintages.

The powers that be in the British polo world have decided to send a challenge to the United States Polo Association for a series of matches in September, 1939, for the Westchester Cup, it was learned tonight.

Another capacity crowd is anticipated for tonight's hockey game at Madison Square Garden, with the New York Americans playing as hosts to the world champion Detroit Red Wings, holders of the Stanley Cup.

Automobile production increased last week when the seasonal factor called for a nominal decline, and the adjusted index rose to 96.0 from 93.2, the revised figure for the previouss week. The figure for the week ended Nov. 21, 1936, was 104.3.

The case of Simon Elmore, who is charged with the murder of 4-yearold Joan Kuleba last August, is expected to be given to the jury shortly after noon today in the Richmond County Court in St. George, S. I.

Philip de Laszlo, who rose from a humble Budapest birth to the undisputed position of the most fashionable portrait painter of this century, died today after a week's illness at his Hampstead home. His age was 68.

A meeting of the Republican State Committee to recommend the election of a member of the National Committee in place of Charles D. Hilles and a secretary in place of the late Lafayette B. Gleason will probably be held about the middle of December, William S. Murray, State Chairman, said last night at his home in Utica.

A former treasurer of the Knickerbocker Club, 2 East Sixty-second Street, who has been sought by the police for fourteen years to answer a charge of embezzlement, is on his way to New York in the. company of two detectives because a member of the club,

George Catino, 38 years old, described as head of a British shipping company of Halifax, N. S., was arraigned before United States Commissioner Joseph F. Holland today after his arrest on a Federal charge of smuggling arms into the Republic of Honduras.

A general farm bill designed to carry out Secretary Wallace's ever-normal granary plan but bearing a striking resemblance to the invalidated Agricultural Adjustment Act was brought before the Senate today. Senator Barkley, majority leader, predicted that it would be passed within ten days.
Paul Codos, French transatlantic flier, piloted his big four-motored plane to a landing at the Air France airdrome today to establish a record for the flight from Paris to Buenos Aires.

Food brokers' and wholesalers' divisions of the food industry were hardest hit last week by the declining demand for grocery products, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc., reported yesterday in its regular survey of activity in food distribution.

For having written an article suggesting that France and Italy were not divided on fundamentals, F. Scardoni, Paris correspondent of the Rome Tribuna, has been recalled to Rome. He left Paris yesterday.

Mrs. Cecil Wilde, who for the last three years has been making her home at Holmrook Hall, Cumberland, England, has arrived here to visit relatives. She is the former Miss Emily Winslow, daughter of Mrs. Cameron McRae Winslow of Newport and the late Rear Admiral Winslow.
An announcement as formal as it was unsurprising today named California's undefeated Golden Bears as the West's representative on the Rose Bowl gridiron New Year's Day.

On a three-acre site purchased from the Mary B. Child estate just off Weed Street in New Canaan, Conn., where sixty-five acres of land are being developed into small estates, Alexander Houses, Inc., has just completed and opened for inspection a home of unusual design which is the first of a group of demonstration houses which this firm will erect in Connecticut to illustrate its new methods of construction.

The Columbia Club team dropped to a triple tie for first place in the Class B division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League yesterday, losing to the Crescent Athletic Club racquet-wielders, 4 to 1, on the New Mooners' courts in Brooklyn. The setback was the first in four starts for the Columbians, who previously had enjoyed sole ownership of 'the league-lead. The triumph was the third in four starts for the Crescents.

With publicity against the fair trade acts and the Miller-Tydings bill mounting rapidly, proponents bf resale price maintenance are beginning to feel that repeal of .the nabling act is a distinct possibility unless some counter-campaign is undertaken, they admitted here yesterday. Such a campaign has been in the discussion stage for several months now but nothing tangible has been evolved.

The proportional representation count for the election of members of the City Council moved slowly but fairly smoothly yesterday with the end in sight. The long-delayed task of counting the ballots in the Bronx got under way again and by 6 P. M. three counts had been completed there.

Individually and collectively, the Toronto Maple Leafs are monopolizing most of the National Hockey League honors. Tonight's official league statistics show the team leading its section and its players ahead in points, goals and assists.

A petition asking for an election to certify that they represent a majority was filed yesterday with the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board by a committee of twelve claiming to represent 363 employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle. Involved are employes other than those in mechanical departments.

AHEARN, ELIZABETH (Nov. 11). Estate, more than $10,000. To Margretta Ahearn Keedy, Elizabeth Ahearn Hood and Anna Ahearn Murray, daughters, 296 E Broadway, and William J. Ahearn, son, executor, 504 Grand St., residue BEVERLY. BELLE FREEBORN (Oct. 25). Estate, more than $10,000. To Belmont Freeborn Beverly, 11 Gedney Way, Newburgh, N. Y., and Brenton Freeborn Beverly, 601 W. 112th St., sons, executors, residue equally: one specific bequest.

Another dispute between labor and industry over powers of the National Labor Relations Board was put on the argument calendar of the Supreme Court today when the board won a review of a decision involving its orders against the Pacific Greyhound Lines.

Louis Arkin, 30 years old, of 201 Sterling Place, Brooklyn, was taken to Kings County Hospital for mental observation last night after he leaped from a fourth floor window into a waiting fire net while keeping the police at bay with his threats of suicide.
The City College junior varsity basketball team will open its season next Saturday night with the St. Francis Cubs in a preliminary, game to the C. C. N. Y.-St. Francis encounter.

As the Navy started its final preparations for the Army game this afternoon there was more regret over the loss of Al Bergner, powerful sophomore tackle, hurt in the Princeton game, than over the defeat by the Tigers.
Harvey Dow Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, and Joseph C. Rovensky, vice president of the Chase National Bank, will sail tomorrow

The Federal Trade Commission today made public proposed trade practice rules for the radio receiving set industry, which set forth precise definitions of such terms as "all-wave," and "standard broadcast" widely used in advertising the industry's products.

John H. Connor, senior vice president, director and manager of foreign affairs for the United Shoe Machinery Corporation, died today in the American Hospital at Paris. He resided at 85 Berkeley Street, West Newton, and had a Summer home at Rye, N. H. His age was 83. He had made more than 170 trans-Atlantic voyages.
Coach Jock Sutherland reported tonight his entire Pitt football squad was in good physical condition for the final scheduled game of the season next Saturday against Duke.

Forsaking the policy of Monday lay-offs, Coach Chick Meehan sent the Manhattan football team through a short practice yesterday afternoon in Innisfail Park as preparations began for the intersectional clash with the University of Tulsa, Dec. 4, at Tulsa.

Mrs. Brookfield Van Rensselaer has arrived from her home in Florence, Italy, and is at the Pierre. Robert D. Goodyear, United States Consul at Marseilles, France, and Mrs. Goodyear are at the WaldorfAstoria. Mr. and Mrs. John Magee are leaving the Savoy-Plaza today to pass Thanksgiving with relatives in Buffalo. Later they will go to Pebble Beach, Calif., for the Winter.
The Palestine Government took today one of the most drastic steps yet attempted in an effort to end terrorism in Palestine.

The prolongation of the struggle in China and the development of the warfare on a larger scale than was expected when Japan sent troops to North China in July have caused a revision of Japan's war aims, and, according to the newspaper Yomiuri, Premier Fumimaro Konoye is preparing a new statement of policy.

The list of the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, arriving today from Europe, includes Charles Dundas, newly appointed Governor of the Bahamas, with Mrs. Lundas; Lady Ribblesdale, mother of Vincent Astor; Philip Guedella, novelist and historian;

The announcement by Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau yesterday that he had invited the executive committee of the Federal Reserve's open-market committee to meet with him on Dec. 1 to discuss the Treasury's December financing provoked some discussion of what attitude the Federal Reserve authorities might take toward continuance of their current policy of buying government securities.

The report of the International Paper and Power Company and subsidiaries, excluding the International Hydro-Electric System, for the three months ended on Sept. 30, issued yesterday, shows a net profit after expenses and charges, including provision for accrued dividends on subsidiary preferred stocks not being currently paid, of $3,029,384.

Lynn Booth, a newspaper man who had worked on several New York newspapers and was at one time city editor of The New York Commercial, died yesterday of pneumonia in Columbus Hospital at the age of 48.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 20, unless specified: At Mare Island Yard, Nov. 21: Borie, Perry, Trever, Wasmuth, Zane. At Manila, Nov. 21: J. D. Ford, Pillsbury, Pope. At San Diego: Teal, Whitney.

Several groups of churchmen, including seven Bishops, have been arrested in various parts of the Soviet Union on charges of organizing espionage and sabotage in the interests of Germany and Japan and even in one case of plotting the assassination of Soviet leaders.

Although merchandise orders coming into the local markets were again confined to fill-ins yesterday, the volume was larger than that for last Monday, manufacturers and resident buyers reported here yesterday. Chief emphasis was placed on items which stores are sure will bring volume business.

Seventeen women and ten men, members of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, Local 16, C. I. O. affiliate, were arrested yesterday morning on a charge of disorderly conduct while picketing the Official Letter Company, at 141 East Twenty-fifth Street.
Objections to the will of Mrs. Josephine Del Drago, wife or Giovanni Del Drago, of 114 East Fiftysecond Street, who died in San d Remo, Italy, on Oct. 8, last, were filed with Surrogate James A.

The series of one-picture exhibitions at the Town Hall Club has been resumed, this season's theme being nineteenth century French art. It succeeds a survey of eighteenth century European and American art presented last year.

William W. Thomas, veteran of the Spanish-American and World Wars, who was credited with raising the first American flag over a trench on the Western Front in the latter conflict, died in the Veterans Hospital at Batavia, N. Y., yesterday, after a long illness. His age was 67. He retired six years ago as manager of the University Club here.

Preparatory to deliveries tomorrow, the first notice day for the December position, evening-up of outstanding interest in the near month increased the volume of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.
Led by Bobby Bryant, who crossed the line for touchdowns twice, the Mount St. Michael High School eleven swept to a 19-0 victory over Saunders Trade of Yonkers on the winner's gridiron yesterday.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 31 per cent of ingot capacity, a drop of 5.4 points, or 14.8 per cent, from 36.4, the rate last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Appealing to their "good common sense," the Duke of Guise, pretender to the throne of France, pleaded with the French to restore the monarchy in a manifesto that Paris newspapers will reproduce tomorrow.
Patrolman Vincent Priore of Traffic C, on duty yesterday morning at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, thrilled a large crowd of passersby when he made a leap and halted a runaway horse.

After deliberating for two hours a jury in Bronx County Court returned yesterday a verdict of guilty in the second degree against William Ray, a 26-year-old Negro, on trial for the murder of 10-year-old Mary Maglione. The defendant was sentenced by Judge Lester W. Patterson to serve twenty years to life.

Willis Duvalier was hanged at 8 o'clock this morning and his brother George at 8:33 A. M. Both died instantaneously. They were buried at 10:15 this morning. Although the execution was conducted inside the prison walls, 100 hysterical people gathered in the vicinity.

Willis Van Devanter, former United States Supreme Court Justice, was the principal speaker last night at ceremonies closing a twoday celebration of the 260th anniversary of the founding of the Reformed Dutch Church of New Utrecht at Eighteenth Avenue and Eighty-third Street, Brooklyn.

Despite the fact that N. Y. U.'s whole squad--players, coaches, managers, trainers and cheer-leaderswitnessed the Fordham-St. Mary's game last Saturday, they refuse to be dissuaded from completing their schedule.

The stock market here was extremely dull today and prices, fell heavily in almost every section. Gilt-edge issues were off, and among the foreign bonds Brazilian loans slid down following the debt-service news. Transatlantic stocks, after a firm start, lost ground and United States Steel and International Nickel had setbacks.
Thomas Curran won the first block of his 125-point match with Henry Savaria last night in the pocket billiard tournament for Class A amateurs at Jack Doyle's Academy.

Princeton University's varsity soccer team, two-year champion in the Middle Atlantic Association, turned back Wheaton College of Illinois, 2-0, today on Poe Field in the first intersectional soccer game staged here in years. It was a post-season contest for the victors.

Internal revenue collections in October were $85,002,317 greater than those in October, 1936, and for the first four months of the fiscal year collections exceeded those in the same period last year by $525,770,205, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced today.

Temporary Assignments PATROLMEN-From precincts indicated to 18th Division, duty in D. A. office, Kings County, for 1 day: V. F. Parry .... 79L. Colantuono .. 88 From 120th Precinct to 18th Division. duty in D. A. office, Richmond County, for 2 days;

Business interest centered on poultry for the Thanksgiving holiday and trading in meats was generally only fair to slow. Steer cuts were weak to lower; lamb cuts uneven, pork weak to lower; lamb strong, veal and calf unchanged.

Kings CALENZO, EMMA (May 8, 1937). Gross assets $6,000, net $1,294. To husband, Silvio Giannicchi, one-third of residuary estate; daughter, Jean Giannicchi. twothirds of residuary estate. Chief assets. real estate, $6,000. Peter J. Riccardo, attorney. 401 Broadway, Manhattan.

A. G. (Uncle Al) Pratt, pioneer of baseball, will be buried tomorrow as he wished-clothed in his Grand Army of the Republic uniform. The crack pitcher, who observed his eighty-ninth birthday last week, died yesterday at his home.

Alterations to existing buildings throughout the New York metropolitan area accounted for more than $50,000,000 in building contracts during the first ten months of this year, a report issued by the F. W. Dodge Corporation disclosed yesterday.

Several properties in White Plains, Westchester County, were reported yesterday as having changed hands. Included was a vacant plot 50 by 125 feet at 242 Main Street, which was purchased from Eldon Bisbee by clients of the Rostenberg Associates, Inc., brokers in the deal.

Christopher J. Halligan, former chairman of the National Veterans Rehabilitation Commission in New England and Past Commander of the All Dorchester Post, American Legion, died today at his home in Belmont. His age was 56.
The Treasury's 114-day bills were sold today at an average interest rate of 0.117 per cent, continuing the sharp downward trend of recent weeks.

General Douglas MacArthur, former Chief of Staff of the Army, who will retire Dec. 31 as military adviser to the Philippines, received the thanks of that government yesterday in a resolution adopted by the National Assembly, according to a cable received here by the War Department today, for "invaluable services in organizing the Philippine Army" and laying the foundation of the national defense.

Mrs. John Hubbard gave a tea yesterday at her home, 24 East Fifty-first Street, for several women actively interested in the Neighborhood Music School's benefit matinee performance of "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Dec. 10.

LETTERS FROM ICELAND, by W. H. Auden and Louis MacNeice. (Random House, $3,) A travel book in prose and verse. THE IMPORTANCE OF LIVING, by Lin Yutang. (John Day-Reynal Hitchcock, $3.) Essays on the good life.
Merry Maker, a colt that had been tried in the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and other 3-year-old stakes, found his notch at last today when he was first in the Johnnycake Handicap at Bowie.

Members of the Junior League of Brooklyn voted at a meeting yesterday in their clubrooms at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, to institute a central volunteer placement bureau, which will undertake to recruit, train and place volunteer workers with social welfare organizations.

The four-story apartment house at 639 Hudson Avenue, West New York, N. J., has been purchased by the Mill Realty Company from the Hudson Trust Company. The building contains twelve apartments and a superintendent's quarters and features a central heating system.

The Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East Thirty-sixth Street, will open to the public today an exhibition of literary treasures of the nineteenth century such as few other libraries in the world could arrange from their own shelves.

The libel suit by the Duke of Windsor against Geoffrey Dennis, author, and William Heinemann, Ltd., publishers of "Coronation Commentary," was settled today in an extraordinary court session at which Lord Chief Justice Hewart said the libels "appear almost to invite a thoroughly efficient horsewhipping."

The price of prime western zinc was reduced yesterday 1/4 cent a pound at East St. Louis. The new price is 5.50 cents and has been met by all leading sellers. Because of lack of interest, the volume of business at the lower level was small.

The whole Senate joined today in congratulating Vice-President Garner on the 69th anniversary of his birth and on his "youthful" appearance. To prove his fitness, the VicePresident announced that he had taken on a new job, that of making the grass grow in bald spots under the White House elms.
The Great Neck and Lynbrook High School football teams brought their seasons to a close today by struggling to a 6-6 tie.

Home St (10-2672), n s 191 ft w of Union Ave, 50x126; Hyman Landsman to I. H. L. Realty Corp, 398 E Tremont Ave; mtg $53,750. Burke Ave (16-4760), s e cor of Seymour Ave, 100x25; Benjamin Halpin to Hannah Corn, 300 West End Ave. 176th St (11-2802), n s, 98 ft s w of Anthony Ave, 50x92; Wilhelmina. J. Bossong to Josephine M. Ebling, 675 Bergen Ave; mtg $56,000.

Tony Chavez, Mexican featherweight contender, was matched today to meet Champion Henry Armstrong in an overweight ten-round bout here Dec. 6. Chavez defeated Armstrong on a foul last December in St. Louis.

Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, returned from Germany today guarding the secret of his talk with Chancellor Hitler as carefully as if something really momentous had been said at Berchtesgaden.
A slower trading pace in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange did not alter the downward trend in prices and major delines were recorded over a broad list of domestic corporation issues.

William Rand Chappell, a retired manufacturing chemist formerly associated with the Federal Laboratories of Pittsburgh, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage at the age of 42.

The Chamber of Commerce has approved unanimously a memorandum to the Ministry of Finance, to the Banco de la Republica and to the Exchange Control Board, criticizing last week's revision of the import ' and exchange-control regulations.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 20: Tyner, Brig. Gen. G. P., General Staff Corps, one month leave, Dec. 11, with permission to visit foreign countries. Brown. Lt. Col. S. E., Med. Corps, two months and fifteen days' leave, Dec. 18. Andrus, Lt. Col. C. (F. A.), General Staff Sa Corps, two days' leave. Nov. 25.

WHOA up! Easy with the whip, now. The horse has come to stay--for three days, anyway. There is no use in mentioning it to citizens who wouldn't know a nigh-horse from an off-ox, but the annual Old Glory sale is about to start and the harness horse addicts are feeling pretty spry at the moment.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Reorganization Petitions CHURCH E. GATES CO., lumber, Oak Point Ave. and East River, Bronx-Involuntary proceedings under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law instituted, by three mortgage participation certificate holders, Sophie von Diessen for $600; Rosalie Arthur, $2,800, and Julia A. Benedict, $600. The petition alleges that on Dec. 31, 1936, liabilities totaled $2,196,000 of which $2,094,000 was due on mortgages and certificates of indebtedness against assets of $767.000.

Colonel and Mrs. Vsevolod A. Yurevitch of this city have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Olga V. Yurevitch, to Lieut. Comdr. Albert G. Hillberg, Civil Engineer Corps Reserve, U.S.N.

Three women, one of whom received a brain concussion when she fell while attempting to open the door, were imprisoned in an automatic elevator yesterday afternoon between the fourth and fifth floors of the five-story apartment building at 1,670 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx. They were freed by a policeman.
Baby Salvy Saban, 151, Greenwich Village, and Frankie Cavanna, 146%, East Side, battled to a draw in the feature eight-round bout before 2,500 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.
HITLER AND EMPIRE

Princeton University's Winter sports season drew a step nearer today as the varsity swimming and wrestling teams became the fourth and fifth Winter units to start practice. Forty swimmers and twentyfive matmen reDorted.

An appeal was made tonight by Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer, Walker Professor of International Finance at Princeton University, for bankers to combat inflation. He warned that continued inflation appeared ahead for this nation, and that strong inflation usually ended in a collapse--declining values, bankruptcies, stagnation, and depression.

Plans for eighteen apartment buildings for the Riverdale section of the Bronx, announced Saturday and described in detail by the sponsors at that time, were formally placed on the records of the Bronx Department of Buildings yesterday.

Brazil's Ministry of Finance began today drafting formal notices to foreign holders of government bonds, announcing that the government had decided temporarily to suspend payments on national debts amounting to approximately $1,250,000,000.
The sharp last hour plunge of stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange today was echoed and then magnified in the market here.

Generalissimo and Mme. Chang Kai-shek. made a two-hour automobile tour of Nanking this afternoon in a demonstration designed to reassure the populace in the face of the increasing threat of a Japanese siege.
A coroner's jury found today that leader, was killed yesterday by a gunshot wound, "the cause of the discharge of the gun being unknown to the jury."

The Aluminum Goods Manufac-turing Company declared a 40-cent dividend, increasing the payment from 25 cents which was paid on April 1, July 1 and Oct. 1, last. Brown Rubber An extra dividend of 10 cents and the regular quarterly of 15 cents were voted on the common stock of the Brown Rubber Company, Inc. Similar dividends were disbursed on Sept. 15.

Liam O'Flaherty, author of "Famine" and "The Informer," arrived yesterday on the Normandie He plans to stay in New York for some days to discuss writing plans with his publishers, Random House, and then to leave for Cuba. Mr.

A hardy little band of thirteen football teams, surviving one of the most upsetting week-ends of the season, remained on the list of undefeated and untied elevens throughout the country today, according to The Associated Press.
If a nation-wide poll of sportswriters, conducted by the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle, is any criterion, Pittsburgh's football Panthers will defend their Rose Bowl crown at Pasadena. Calif.

The trial of two members of the International Longshoremen's Association on an assault charge made by Cleveland Bissell of 4 West Twenty-eighth Street, an editor and cartoonist of the C. I. O. laborers' publication, "Shape-up," ended in Special Sessions yesterday afternoon in the conviction of Frank Savio, 28 years old, of 1,086 Home Street, the Bronx, and the acquittal of James Kearns, 29, of 7 Seventh Street, Arlington, N. J.

Drunk enough with her own decibels, New York no longer keeps a town crier. It is good to know that she has borrowed one from Provincetown. Sometime after 12:30 P. M. today he will cry along Broadway and Wall Street Mayor La Guardia's Christmas Seal proclamation.

12:30-1:30 P. M.-Secretary of Agriculture Henry A. Wallace Discussing "The Wheat Situation," on Farm and Home Hour-WJZ. 3:00-4:00 P. M.-United States Marine Band Concert-WJZ. 5:45-6:00 P. M.--"Safety." C. S. Hart, Grand Ruler, B. P. O. E.; Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler-WOR.

Because of an error by Patrolman Irwin Samuels of the 114th Precinct in Queens, the Board of Elections discovered yesterday that it had no party enrollment figures for the Twenty-fifth Election District of the Third Assembly District in that borough.
There are few sounds more exciting--in their very nature--than that of a 'coon barking the "tree," although there are those who say a fox hound on a hot trail has no peer.

A contribution of '$1,000 to the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, from the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was announced yesterday by Mrs. David Challinor, director of the chapter's annual roll-call. She made public a message accompanying the gift from David Dubinsky, president of the union, which read:

Maybe it isn't true that one American can lick any day five Japanese, or four Italians, or three Germans or two Britishers. Maybe American statesmanship isn't divinely inspired out of the favoritism of Providence for this nation.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies receives a legacy of $20,000 and the New York Guild for Jewish Blind, $5,000 in the will of Benjamin Lissbergen; chairman of the board of the Federated Metals Division of the American Smelting and Refining Company, filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The Rev. John H. Stanton, pastor of the Presbyterian Church in suburban Westmont, said tonight he had tendered his resignation as chairman of the National Citizens Committee. Mr. Stanton denied that threats in the form of letters were a factor in his decision.
" An Intimate Talk on Writers I Have Interviewed," Eleanor Markell, Hotel Plaza, 11 A. M. Child Study Association, 221 West Fifty-seventh Street, 11 A. M. "Women and Jobs," Lillian M. Gilbreth.

Tonight's major events: The Philadelphia Orchestra, directed by Leopold Stokowski, at Carnegie Hall, and Selma Kramer, pianist, at the Town Hall. Mabel Hutchings Ward, soprano, will appear in recital tonight at the Barbizon.

Counsel for the C. I. O. United Rubber Workers, declaring Governor Martin L. Davey "in the same category as an industrial spy," dispatched complaints against his actions to the National Labor Relations Board and the Senate Civil Liberties Committee today.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarkson Runyon of 730 Park Avenue and Camp Medamin, Upper St. Regis Lake, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Allen Runyon, to Lieutenant Thomas West Hammond, U. S. A.

Clinton St, 99, 25.4x100; one-fourth interest; Sadie Fisher to Max Fisher, 2,037 76th St, Brooklyn. Riverside Drive, north cor 146th St, 99.11x79.8; Burns Holding Corp to Quaker Management Corp, 570 7th Ave, mtg $137,500 ($14.50).
President Manuel Quezon underwent an emergency appendectomy at 10:45 this morning at the Philippine General Hospital.

Deaths Announced Fireman 1st Grade Theodore J. Durholz of H. L. 149, died Nov. 20. Funeral will take place from Herbst Chapel, 7,501 5th Ave., Brooklyn, at 1:45 P. M., Tuesday, Nov. 23. Interment at Evergreen Cemetery.

Samuel H. Graham, storage warehouse proprietor, former Highway Commissioner of the town of Rye, town constable and chief of the Rye Fire Department for eleven years, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 82.
Sidney Harmon, one of Broadway's younger generation, has signed a producing contract with Paramount, the studio announced today. He is scheduled to report on the lot next week.
Major Wilfred Foulston Vernon, a responsible Air Ministry employee who recently was fined for failing to take proper care of secret documents, has been dismissed.

Ten modifications of Administration policies were suggested tonight by Senator Vandenberg in a radio speech. If adopted, he said, they would give business a chance to recuperate and end the "present recession."
Arrangements for the purchase of Dec. 1 coupons of the Young Loan, lin accordance with the procedure followed with recent coupons, were announced yesterday by the German Consulate General.
SIR WILLIAM JOWITT, Appearing for the Duke of Windsor--It is, I think, always a difficult problem for counsel to know how far he is wise in giving further publicity to defamatory matter.

Haunted by sleepless nights and a conscience bidding her to confess, Mary Keenan O'Connor, a 19-yearold college student, admitted almost eagerly to the police today that in an outburst of anger she had killed a neighbor child on Labor Day in the West Oak Lane district of Philadelphia.

Dmitry V. Bogomoloff was suddenly removed today as Soviet Ambassador to China after a mysterious flight from Nanking to Moscow. I. Luganets-Orelsky received the post. The change surprised diplomats, who believed Mr. Bogomoloff, when he returned to Moscow by plane late in September, had been called back for important conferences with the Foreign Office on the military and political status of the SinoJapanese War.

In the first transfer of the property in thirty-nine years, the fourstory and basement building at 192 Water Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Ariel Holding Company and the heirs of Cyrus Jones to the Treadward Realty Corporation, a holding company for C. R. Daniels Company, canvas manufacturers.

Establishment of Federal mortgage rediscount facilities to prevent the "freezing" of equity funds in private low-cost housing projects is cited as one of the major-needs of the residential building industry in a national poll of opinion in the construction field made public yesterday by Dwight L. Hoopingarner, executive head of the American Construction Council.
The Thanksgiving tea of the Orange Orphan Home will be held tomorrow afternoon at the home in Harrison Street, East Orange. Six hundred invitations have been sent out by the trustees.

Bruno Mussolini, second son of Premier Benito Mussolini, and the youth's flying instructor, Colonel Attilio Biseo, both of whom only recently returned from Majorca after about two months' service in the Spanish Rebel air corps, yesterday broke the world speed record for' land machines with loads of 500, 1,000 and 4,409.24 pounds over a 621.36-mile closed circuit.
Called back from his position at left tackle in the final quarter, Eddie Kaczorowski was successful in his try for a field goal from the 20-yard line as the Glen Cove High

Weakness in the security markets and the failure of the grain market in Liverpool to reflect the upturn of Saturday in North American markets were largely responsible for a decline of as much as 2 1/2 cents a bushel in wheat futures in the early trading today.

Seven-year-old Irene Mary Malo, who traveled from Shanghai to New York City alone by boat, was safe yesterday at the home of her uncle, Christopher Malo Sr., at 39-12 Forty-seventh Avenue, Long Island City. She had arrived at 9:15 A. M. aboard the liner Pennsylvania after a trip through the Panama Canal from San Francisco.

The report of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company and subsidiaries, controlled by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, shows for the quarter ended on NoN Sept. 80 a net profit of $1;698,587 after depreciation, depletion, normal Federal income taxes
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 17: Decreases of $42,000,000 in commercial,
K. R. Kingsbury, president of the Standard Oil Company of California, died tonight on the Grace liner Santa Paula, which was en route through the Panama Canal. He was 61 years old.

When employes on the personal staff of Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens reached Borough Hall in Long Island City yesterday morning they discovered that over the week-end Mr. Harvey's private office on the fourth floor had been ransacked.

The engagement of $6,196,000 gold abroad for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Of the total, $5,800,000 is being sent from Japan, $252,000 from Australia and $144,000 from Bolivia.

Many persons prominent in society attended yesterday Albert Morris Bagby's 397th Musical Morning, which was held at the Waldorf-Astoria. This was the first concert in the season's series. The artists were Eide Norena, soprano, and Rene Maison, tenor, both of the Metropolitan Opera Company, and Efrem Zimbalist, violinist.
The report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, including the Brooklyn and Queens Transit System, for the four months ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday,
After a private preview of "Tobacco Road" by clergymen and police in a hotel room today, city officials announced that the play might begin a two-week engagement without police interference.

ANDEREB--Anthony S., Nov. 21, beloved husband of Grace Anderer (nee Barry), devoted father of Gracemary, brother of Wendelin J. Funeral from residence, 2,975 Marion Ave., Bronx, Wednesday, 9:30 A. M. Requiem Mass Our Lady of Mercy Church, 10 A. M. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Kindly omit flowers.

William Murray, member of the Scottish National Antarctic Expedition as chef, winner of medals for distinguished service in three years of Boer war campaigning in South Africa and ammunition expert at the Winchester factory here during the World War, died yesterday at the home of his sister, Mrs. Bella Allender, Rocky Top, Mount Carmel. His age was 65.
Calling the demand a "dragnet" and "fishing expedition," the three-judge Federal Court hearing the suit of eighteen private utility companies against the validity of the TVA power program,
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 19:

Wade Killefer resigned today as manager of the Indianapolis American Association baseball team' to become manager and business director of the Hollywood Club of the Pacific Coast League. 1 orman A. Perry, owner of the Indianapolis club said Killefer's successor would be chosen within the next two weeks.

The French Casino failed to give its "Folies Bergere" last night and so became the first of the larger night clubs to admit the effects of the depression that has hit them all. At the end of the Sunday performances of the revue,

The mortgage for $57,250, which the Union Dime Savings Bank holds from the Jonas Realty Co., Inc., Jonas Spinner, Long Beach, L. I., president, on 52 W. 111th St. was extended to May 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent, the mortgagor paying off $250 quarterly.

The grim doings of John Steinbeck's dramatization of his own novel, "Of Mice and Men," are the business of this evening at the Music Box. If you had forgotten, or never knew, it is the story of a couple of wandering laborersplayed by Wallace Ford and Broderick Crawford-and the tragedy they encounter on a California ranch.
John Henry Ray 3d of Staten Island and George Gibsen Willis of Bound Brook, N. J., were elected co-captains of the 1938 Amherst soccer team at a meeting of the lettermen today.

IT is hard for a patriot to admit that a book at once as light and pointed as "Letters from Iceland"* couldn't have been written in America, but it couldn't have been; at least I can't think of any Americans who could write it.

Commandant Chevalier H. de Menten de Horne of the Belgian Army team rode an aged chestnut gelding, Whisky, to victory in the military jumping contest at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight. As on each of the preceding five nights, a jump-oft was necessary.

The House of Commons gave an unfriendly reception to the most important bill on the government program at this session-for government purchase of all British coal royalties-in the opening debate today.
Princess Baba, youngest daughter of the British Rajah of Sarawak, was married today to a wrestler, Bob Gregory, despite her father's threat to disinherit her.

The Pension Fund concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra are usually designed to evoke special interest and last night's at Carnegie Hall was no exception. The latest prodigy, 11-year-old Julius Katchen, pianist, was introduced to New York.

The will of Atlee Pomerene, filed for probate today, left $140,000 of his estimated $192,000 estate to his widow, and $30,000 to Wooster (Ohio) College. Mr. Pomerene, former RFC chairman and Senator from Ohio, died Nov. 12 of pneumonia.

Rebuked by Pope Pius XI, through the Apostolic Delegate in Washington, the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin today asked his "friends and followers" to stop their efforts to have his radio broadcasting resumed.

Bob Pastor and Nathan Mann, rivals in Friday night's important heavyweight meeting at Madison Square Garden, were reported yesterday to be rounding rapidly into fine shape. Both men worked out at gymnasiums here and now will begin tapering off.

The engagement is announced of Miss Elizabeth Knight Colburn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Selwyn Colburn of Baltimore, to Albert Hillsman Michaels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Urlwin Orgain Michaels of Baltimore, formerly of Philadelphia. The wedding will take place in January.

The close of the first day of the Gubernatorial recount in New Jersey showed a gain tonight for Governorelect A. Harry Moore, Democrat, over his Republican opponent, Senator Lester H. Clee, who had requested the recount.

After a long mock scrimmage between the Pennsylvania varsity and freshmen today, Head Coach Harvey Harman announced that three sophomores would start against Cornell in the annual classic on Thursday.

The death last night of Donald M. MacVicar Jr., 16 years old, in his home on the John D. Rockefeller Jr. estate here, was listed as accidental today by Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester Medical Examiner.

Blind of Arden, champion Labrador, owned by W. A. Harriman, took first prize today at the conclusion of the limited open allage stake at the Long Island Retriever Field Trial Club's fifth annual meeting. Blind of Arden, by Odds On and Peggy of Shipton, was handled by Tom Briggs in the competition on the estate of Mrs. Walter Hoving.

William Lee of 1,856 Park Avenue, 39-year-old paroled convict from Dannemora prison, was in the line-up at police headquarters yesterday morning charged with possession of burglar tools and with unlawful entry.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney-elect, arrived home last night from a vacation in Bermuda. He said he had not seen a New York newspaper in two weeks, implying that he had not heard about the proceedings looking to removal from office of County Clerk Albert Marinelli.

Holy Cross settled down to the final week of preparation today for its all-important game on Saturday against Boston College. The strenuout battle with Carnegie Tech took its toll of Crusader players.
Although called upon by the amended Tennessee Valley Authority Act to plan "the proper use, conservation, and development of the Tennessee River drainage basin,"

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator here, admitted yesterday that his plan for eliminating job-dodgers and unemployables from WPA was "nine-tenths dead" as a result of restrictions imposed by Federal relief authorities in Washington.

Cornelius Vanderbilt (Sonny) Whitney is shifting his interest from horses to fishes, at least temporarily. Mr. Vanderbilt, who sold his racing stable at Pimlico, Md., on Nov. 8 for $119,600, announced yesterday that he and associates would open next February at Marineland, Fla., "two of the largest individual aquaria ever built and the world's only specially designed underwater motion picture studio.

A resolution calling for the appointment of a special committee to investigate charges against the Bituminous Coal Commission was introduced in the House today by Representative Byron N. Scott of California.

Each of the various bondholders' protective committees of the Philadelphia Reading Coal and Iron Company has appointed a representative to serve on a committee of the whole, it was announced yesterday, following a meeting at the offices of the company in Philadelphia.

Dr. Joachim Prinz, noted German rabbi who came here last August as a permanent resident, was informed yesterday by the Juedische Rundschau, a Zionist German publication, that he could no longer act as its American correspondent because of attacks he has made on. Chancellor Hitler during addresses in the United States.

Behind the scenes peace talk is undoubtedly increasing in Chinese, foreign and Japanese circles, and the oft-repeated boast of China's spokesmen that China will continue fighting for one, two or three years if necessary, until Japan is bankrupt, is being assayed in cold reason.

It becomes increasingly difficult each year to select a team of standout performers. It becomes more apparent each year that football is primarily a team game and that the more successful teams are not so dependent upon the work of one or two stellar performers as they are on the coordinated efforts of the group.

A determined step toward raising milk prices for the farmers and lowering them for consumers was taken yesterday by representatives of organizations of producers and consumers. They established a joint committee with the purpose of forming a cooperative to eliminate the big distributors and act as the middleman in the distribution of milk.

A first mortgage loan of $230,000 at 5 and 41/2 per cent for ten years on the new building at 791-797 East 175th Street has been arranged by Nehring Brothers, Inc., for the owner, Bio Associates, Inc., A. Spirer, president. The mortgage replaces a temporary building loan previously arranged by the same brokers.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Suzanne Prentiss Becton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Wilbur Becton of this place, to William Lansing Chapman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Lansing Chapman of Rutherford, and Saybrook, Conn., on Dec. 18 in Grace Church here. The Rev. Charles Whitney Popham will perfrom the ceremony.

Nineteen contests, including games here with N. Y. U. and Fordham and a clash with Notre Dame in Albany, are on the basketball schedule of Colgate University, announced tonight by William A. Reid, director of athletics.
While clear, cold weather made New Yorkers conscious of Winter other parts of the country were recovering from the first heavy snowfall of the season.

United States ASSOCIATE BIOCHEMIST (SYPHILIS RESEARCH), $3,200 a Year. U. S. Public Health Service, Treasury Department. Applications must be on file not later than Dec. 28 if received from States other than those named below; Dec. 31 if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming.

Recommendations for budget cuts of $15,000,000 were presented to members of the finance committee of the Board of Aldermen at a sparsely attended public hearing in the 1938 budget in City Hall yesterday.

White substituted for White today as the nation's leading pointgetter in football. While Byron (Whizzer) White, Colorado University's ace, was idle over the week-end, Sid White of Brooklyn College scored twenty points to take first place, according to The Associated Press.
Chris Pappas, Temple fullback who captained the gridiron team in the Villanova game Saturday, today was awarded the Stephen Girard Lions Club Cup for outstanding Temple football player.

Fordham's unbeaten football squad began preparations yesterday for the traditional climax game with. New York University at the Yankee Stadium next Saturday. Calisthenics and a short signal drill, which served to eliminate muscle stiffness, kept the men on windswept Fordham Field for only a half hour.

The newspaper Midi-Journal said today a Belgian inquiry into last week's airplane disaster at Ostend indicated that the pilot attempted to land because the Archduchess of Hesse bei Rhein, one of the passengers, was giving birth to a baby.

Milk was sold for 8 cents a quart in New York yesterday morning when Madison House, in an attempt to alleviate the distress of poor families caused by the high price of. milk, went into business as a distributor itself.

The Nicaragua Government today made a mining contract with Henry Backus, Price Henry and Francisco Le Febre to develop the extensive mining properties of San Ramon in the Department of Matagalpa. The three men are Americans.

In such a situation as that which now prevails, it is not false optimism to recognize that along with many discouraging reports of the course of American business recently there has also come some reassuring news.

Football is moving ahead through the closing days of what is the shortest season for any major sport in the country. Starting with early October or late September excitement, football flares through No-vember like a skyrocket, then is blacked out,
Casey Stengel, the Bees' new manager, met the Hub's baseball writers today and confided he was "mighty pleased" with his job.
The American Federation of Labor, through its president, William Green, demanded today that the Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill be sent back to the House Labor Committee for reconsideration.

Legislation exempting American vessels from payment of Panama Canal tolls was proposed today as the first move in a West Coast effort to balk shipping company plans to transfer their craft from the intercoastal to the South American trade.
With six games yet to be played, more points have been scored in National Football League competition this season than in all of 1936, official statistics revealed yesterday.
Bill Silverman, co-captain and guard on the 1937 team, and Jerry Stein, star center, were honored at a dinner sponsored by the City College football squad at the Firenze Restaurant last night.
The Chicago City Opera Company's presenstation of "Norma" was delayed for thirty minutes tonight after the company had gone 751 miles--as the crow flies--for a tenor.

The War Department was notified today of the death yesterday at New Orleans, where he was on leave of absence from Fort Bragg, N. C., of Major Schaumburg McGehee, field artillery. His age was 54. He was born at New Orleans Feb. 23, 1883, and was first commissioned a second- lieutenant of the Louisiana National Guard on July 5, 1910.

Reductions amounting to as much as 75 per cent of present air-travel insurance rates will be made on or before Jan. 1, it was learned yesterday from Dan Scarritt, underwriting manager of Associated Aviation Underwriters of New York.

The resignation, after forty-seven years with the company, of William L. Nevin as managing trustee under the will of Rodman Wanamaker, pears son of John Wanamaker, founder turers of the Wanamaker stores here and in Philadelphia, was announced yesterday.

Fear that the amended credit rule of the State Liquor Authority, requiring retailers to settle liquor bills within ten days after the end of the month in which orders are placed, will cause the "bunching" of orders and deliveries in the early days of each month, was expressed by wholesalers meeting yesterday at the offices of the New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association.

The Textile Converters Association of America, Inc., and representatives of silk and rayon grelge goods mills, meeting last night at the Pennsylvania Hotel to discuss plans for correcting overproduction and overstocking through institution of two-shift mill operations, decided to appoint a committee of five converters and five producers to study the problem in detail.

A plan of reorganization for the Savannah Atlanta Railway, which has been in receivership since 1921, was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The road operates the shortest line between Savannah and Atlanta.

Battling a brisk wind from the Raritan, the Rutgers football squad went through a light 80-minute workout today in preparation for the final game of the season against Brown, stressing signal drill and running plays from spread formations.

Mrs. E. Halsey Malone gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 1 East End Avenue, for members of the benefit committee for the performance of "Aida" on Dec. 28 at the Metropolitan Opera which will be given in behalf of the Foster Home Department and Jones Children's Center maintained by the Children's Aid Society. Mrs. Malone and Mrs. Morgan Dix Wheelock head the committee.

The 3,300 employee of the Zenith Radio Corportion will receive Nov. 24 a 10 per cent bonus on their earnings in the first half of the company's fiscal year, E. F. McDonald Jr., president, announced today.

While Senate Republicans were in conference late this afternoon on their program for the 1938 session, Governor Hoffman surprised them with a call for a special session of the upper house on Wednesday afternoon to act on pending nominations.

Judge John P. Nields, presiding over the reorganization proceedings in the Standard Gas and Electric Company, handed down a ruling yesterday in the United States District Court of Delaware calling for the appointment of a special trustee to litigate a $100,000,000 law suit for stockholders of the utility against certain directors and officers of Standard Gas and Electric,

State Highway Comissioner E. Donald Sterner rejected today bids received for construction of a connecting ramp between Routes 1 and 25 in Jersey City. The low bid, $237,542, made by George M. Brewster- Son of Bogota, was more than $20,000 above the estimated cost.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and the Bancamerica-Blair Corporation purchased yesterday $1,350,000 of tax-anticipation certificates of indebtedness of the city of Syracuse, N. Y., on a 0.49 per cent interest basis, plus a premium of $21.

In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were had today: CUSTOMS 4071--Cohn Lewis v. United States. Per curiam (the opinion in this case was prepared by the late Presiding Judge Graham and adopted by the court after his death).
John Cormode, American Mail Line vice president, announced today that his company intended to resume operation of passenger service on all its ships from Seattle to the Orient as rapidly as possible.

Loretta Harynek, 15 years old, told, told, a coroner's jury today that she was the secret bride of Warren Sinclair Stanley, who killed himself yesterday. Previously she had told the police she had falsely informed the youth she was to become a mother.
