In a legal contest between manufacturers of electric shaving machines, Remington Rand, Inc. and its subsidiary, the General Shaver Corporation of Bridgeport, Conn., have started a suit for "loss and damage" of more than $1,000.000 against the Lektro-Shave Corporation here in the Federal Court of New Jersey, it was revealed today.
A movement seeking the simplification of the issuing of eligibility certificates for racing was begun yesterday at the annual meeting of the Trotting Horse Club of America in the Hotel Prince George.

Protesting against the Legislature's habit of being "free with other people's money" and saddling the city with mandatory expenditures, City Chamberlain A. A. Berle Jr. proposed yesterday that the coming State Constitutional Convention should do something about the practice.

Magistrate Henry H. Curran, designated last Saturday as the city's new Deputy Mayor by Mayor La Guardia, spent his entire day at City Hall yesterday familiarizing himself with the routine of the Mayor's office.
Coach Bernie Bierman of Minnesota has been named one of the East's coaches for the annual EastWest all-star charity football game here New Year's Day, Managing Director William M. Coffman said today.

Charles Harvey Hood, retired president of H. P. Hood Sons, Inc., died today at his Cherry Hill farm here. He was 77 years old. Born in Derry, N. H., Feb. 26, 1860, the son of Harvey P. and Caroline Corwin Hood, he was graduated

Miss Leonora Hobart of 156 Roberts Lane, retired educator and regent of Keskeskick Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, died early today of a cerebral hemorrhage in St. John's Riverside Hospital.

Deals in Manhattan realty reported by brokers yesterday involved properties in scattered sections from the downtown textile district to Harlem. An investing client of Arthur L. Dryfoos, broker, bought the double flat at 7 East 132d Street, in Harlem, from the Metropolitan Savings Bank.

Three high-ranked entrants in the annual Fall open tournament of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association captured their quarter-final round tests at the New York Athletic Club yesterday to join the unseeded Ralph Sleicher of Midston House in the semi-finals, which will be played tomorrow.

The city's voluntary hospitals and the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn were described as valuable "allies" of the Department of Health by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, in an address last night over Station WMCA in behalf of the United Hospital Campaign.

A piscatorial exhibit the like of which the world has never seen is being arranged for the New York World's Fair of 1939, Grover Whalen, president, announced yesterday in making public plans for the building in which will be shown "all things given up by the seven seas, the lakes and the streams of the world for the comfort and delight of humanity."

From the very beginning of the present Sino-Japanese conflict many foreign observers have predicted that, no matter what the military result, the special status of the Occident in the Orient would be lost and, in particular, that the extraterritorial and other exceptional privileges of the Western nations and other nationals in China would be irreparably undermined.

Mrs. Beatrice P. Trenkman will give a luncheon today at 1 Fifth Avenue for the committee arranging the entertainment to be given later in the afternoon under the auspices of the auxiliary of the Faith Home for Incurables at the home, 546 Park Place, Brooklyn.

The cast of "Gay Blades," the new international figure-skating extravaganza headed by Karl Schaefer, seven times world and twice Olympic champion, and Miss Maribel Y. Vinson, nine times United States and present North American titleholder, will arrive tomorrow morning from Springfield for another performance at Madison Square Garden tomorrow evening.
An automobile raced a train to the crossing south of Thornwood at 6:02 P. M. today and the automobile won by the margin of its spare tire, which was torn off and tossed high in the air.

The Buckingham, eighteen-story apartment-hotel structure at the northwest corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Sixth Avenue, was sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street Salesrooms. It was bought in by the Bowery Savings Bank, as plaintiff, for $250,000.

Mexican labor has decided to carry out a complete boycott on Japanese goods, the Mexican Labor News, organ of the dominant National Workers Confederation, announced today. The step was taken, it is explained, "as a protest against Japan's invasion of China in defiance of international law and treaty obligations."

The number of defendants in the Federal Government's gasoline price-fixing case dwindled still further today when Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone dropped the names of three companies and four individuals.

Charles Abrams, counsel to the New York City Housing Authority, resigned his post yesterday, in protest against Mayor La Guardia's ban on the Authority's participation in housing conferences with Nathan Straus, the Federal Housing Administrator.

After heavy selling in the morning which caused a majority of issues to touch new low levels, the stock market here rebounded this afternoon and staged a good recovery as bargain hunters provided support. Giltedged issues attracted little interest and the list was off fractionally.

Miss Phoebe Knapp, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Knapp, entertained this afternoon at her home here with a tea for Miss Jane Carrott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orville Browning Carrott of Belle Haven, Greenwich, who will be married Thursday to William Hall Boardman of New York.

Customs inspectors seized here yesterday about 300 ounces of heroin, having a legitimate value of $19,500, which they alleged was smuggled in aboard the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, arriving late in the afternoon.

City employes in the so-called ungraded service can obtain promotion to positions of greater responsibility and pay only through competitive examination, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins ruled yesterday.

Thanksgiving services will be held tomorrow morning in cathedrals, churches and synagogues. There will be union worship of different Protestant faiths and several services with Protestants and Jews uniting in worship.

Establishment in the United States of a plant for manufacture of Lanital, a -fiber made from casein; which is an element in milk, isplanned by Snia Viscosa, producers of synthetic fibers and fabrics also made from wood pulp,

The Court of Appeal today upheld the gold clause in a dispute over bonds issued before Great Britain went off the gold standard. It ruled for the British and French Trust Corporation of London against the New Brunswick Railway Company.

Liberalization of New York Stock Exchange listing requirements was announced yesterday by the cornmittee on stock list, which has amended a paragraph of the form of agreement that must be signed by companies applying to. list their securities. This paragraph now reads:

Great Britain's trade is booming. Gone are the "dog days," ushered in by the world-wide depression of 1929 and latest statistics show that the United Kingdom has turned well beyond that elusive "corner."

The Republican State Committee, in a financial statement filed here today with Secretary of State Thomas A. Mathis, reported it spent about $50,000 in behalf of the Gubernatrial candidacy of State Senator Lester H. Clee between Sept. 27 and Nov, 10.

Paul Dullzell, executive secretary and treasurer of the Actors Equity Association, informed Equity's council yesterday that he had reconsidered his resignation and would serve out his term of office, which expires in 1940. The message from Mr. Dullzell, who is ill at home, was brought to the council by E. J. Blunkall, an Equity councillor.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 23.--Federal and State taxes will take about $20,000,000 from the estate of $34,119,537 left by Senator James Couzens. This was asserted in a petition filed by attorneys for the widow, Mrs. Margaret A. Couzens, asking that the $25,000 monthly allowance granted to the widow a year ago by Probate Judge Thomas C. Murphy be continued for another year.

Stuart Chase, economist and writer on conservation, told a House Committee today that wasteful policies of the United States through the years had deprived some 10,000,000 Americans of their "resource base" in land, water or mineral deposits and given them nothing in exchange.
A voluominous report by the New York Power Authority, charging "widespread propaganda" by the utilities, was sent today to interested Congress committees and government agencies by the President.
BAGNALL--Matilda (nee Eustace), on Nov. 23, beloved mother of Victor. Funeral services at Kennedy's Chapel, 108th St. and amsterdam Ave., Thursday, 8:30 P. M. Interment Wallingford, conn., Friday.

Murmurs that the New York Stock Exchange had walked, head up, into a trap set by the Securities and Exchange Commission were heard yesterday in Wall Street. Hindsight prophets assured their hearers that members of the Exchange's law committee, which had undertaken the drafting of a goodwill letter to the commission, should have foreseen the situation that has arisen.

Freight and passenger revenues of the UnionPacific Railroad this month have been running under those of Nov. 1936, W. M. Jeffers, president, said yesterday. Agricultural products are moving in fair volume, although farmers in some cases are holding crops to await better, prices, he reported. Retail sales in the West have dropped and westbound traffic has declined considerably, he explained.

Officials of the New York City Housing Authority are studying recommendations just received by them for use of two extensive areas on the lower East Side of Manhattan as sites for public housing projects under the national slum-clearance program soon to be initiated under the terms of the Wagner-Steagall act, it was learned yesterday.

A whole family of five was killed today when gas from a broken main seeped through the home of Raymond C.-Yeoman, assistant secretary of the Bridgeport Young Men's Christian- Association. Besides Mr. Yeoman, the victims were his wife, Mrs. Elizabeth Winslow Yeoman, 37, and their three children, George, 16; Virginia, 14, and Jeannette, 7.

A jury in High Court here today awarded damages of f900 and costs to Henry Morris Sinclair, Dublin art dealer, against Dr. Oliver St. John Gogarty for libelous verses and prose passages in the English edition of Dr. Gogarty's book, "As I Was Going Down Sackville Street."
Mayor La Guardia defeated Jeremiah T. Mahoney for Mayor in Kings County by a plurality of 207,869 votes, according to the official canvass of that borough made yesterday by the Board of Elections.

The seventeen - family apartment house at 197-199 Baldwin Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., was sold by the Broad Avenue Realty Corporation for cash above a $43,000 mortgage. An investing syndicate of B. F. Kislak, Inc., broker, was the purchaser.

Edward Prioleau Warren, who played a prominent part in the revival of English domestic architecture on traditional lines, died today at the age of 82. The major part of his work was done for Oxford and Cambridge Universities-buildings for Balliol, Magdalen, Merton, and St. Johns at Oxford, and for Trinity and Caius Colleges at Cambridge.
Governor-elect A. Harry Moore gained two more votes today in the recount of Hudson County ballots obtained by his defeated Republican opponent, Senator Lester H. Clee, making a total net gain of

The success of the Jewish resettlement of Palestine Is the responsibility of the democratic nations of the world, Senator Robert F. Wagner said last night at a dinner given by the Jewish National Fund of America at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.
Tell Taylor, author of the ballad "Down by the Old Mill Stream," died suddenly today of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

It is learned that two of the Americans listed as captured by the Rebels near Morata in February are dead. They are Leo Targoff of Brooklyn and William Hathaway of Illinois, both killed in action on that front, Mr. Targoff about Feb. 15 and Mr. Hathaway Feb. 27 in the charge of Pingarron Hill.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney-elect, returned yesterday to a desk loaded with a mound of work that has accumulated during his Bermuda vacation, just ended. Full of bland good humor, he defied newspaper men to get any important news out of him.

Several properties in the Great Neck section of Long Island were reported yesterday as having been sold in deals negotiated by De Beaumont Mott, broker. Included war the Harry Jacobson estate known as Whitehall at Kings Point.
Henry Armstrong, world's featherweight champion, knocked out Joey Brown of Syracuse in 39 seconds of the second round of their ten-round non-title match tonight.

Pedro Montanez. Puerto Rican lightweight, knocked out Joe Pennino of South Brooklyn in 1 minute 30 seconds of the third round of a scheduled ten-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena before 4,000 last night. Montanez weighed 138 1/2 and his opponent was 2 1/2 pounds heavier.
Kindhearted Britons have been sending Haile Selassie food, wine, coal and even penny stamps since news of his straitened circumstances became known a few days ago.

Schofield Andrews has been elected a director of the Barber Company, Inc., to succeed Frank B. Foster, resigned. Phil Huber, vice president and assistant general manager of the ExCell-O Corporation,, has been elected president and general manager to succeed N. A. Woodworth, who resigned because of ill health. H.

The arrival of $5,395,500 of gold at San Francisco from Japan was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank here. This was the shipment reported on Monday as being on the way here. Originally it was reported as amounting to $5,800,000. Including this consignment, Japan has sent to this country $221,000,000 of gold since the middle of last March.

Carl Raymond Gray, vice chairman of the board of the Union Pacific Railroad and former president of that road, was elected today a director of the Maine Central Railroad at the board's monthly meeting here. His election must be approved, however, by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The most disheartening feature of the present panic--for panic it is, in the sense of universal fear for the future--is that nearly every tax under which we groan directly reduces future revenue and thus kills the goose which lays the golden eggs.

Dr. C. Louis Leopoldt, one of South Africa's most distinguished dieticians, announced today that he was planning a series of experiments on a pair of identical twins to determine whether milk or wine is more beneficial to health.

Boston's unrelenting Bruins were held in check for the first time in seven starts this season when the speedy Canadiens shared a 1-to-1 overtime deadlock with them before 15,000 tonight at the Boston Garden.

Mrs. Leda Utgoff of 334 East Fifty-third Street, widow of Commander Victor V. Utgoff of the former Russian Imperial Navy, was married to Baron Charles Philip von Wrangell of this city last night in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Savior, 51 East 121st Street.

A strike of 1,300 members of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainman employed by eight Greyhound bus lines was called early today effective at 12:01, A. M. tomorrow. S. R. Harvey, assistant president of the brotherhood, announced the strike call after conferences had failed to reach an agreement.

The Communist party is to benefit under the will of the Rev. William Montgomery Brown, deposed Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church. The will on file today provided that the residuary estate, after several specific bequests, should go to a corporation to be formed by the trustees under the will, who are instructed to devote all or any part of it to the cause of communism as "propagated by Karl Marx."

Princess A. de Caraman Chimay, Baron and Baroness Philippe de Rothschild, General and Mrs. E. A. Taufflieb, Lady Ward, Mr. and Mrs. Rae Smith, Mrs. Frederick Pope and Miss Ruth Draper are passengers booked to sail today for Havre via Southampton on the French liner Normandie.

Another move has been started to settle the nine-week strike of editorial and commercial department employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagles it was announced yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner. Mr. Andrews said the newspaper management and the New York Newspaper Guild had agreed to renew negotiations.
The Real Estate Board of New York will hold a luncheon meeting in honor of Borough President-elect Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan on Dec. 7 in the Hotel Commodore.

238th St (12-3270A), s w cor of Albany Rd, 90x105; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Lillian Cotkin, 1,895 Belmont Ave. Wickham Ave (16-4794), e s, 200 s of Arnow Ave. 50x95; Theresa Flamman to Denis Kelliher. 602 E 139th St.

Countess Pier Adolfo Cittadini of this city and Rome gave a dinner last night in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. d'Assern, who returned recently from their wedding trip.

Sir Jagadis Chunder Bose, India's foremost scientist, died in Giridih, Bengal, of a heart attack today at the age of 78. The reputation he won by persistent investigation and experiment as a physicist he extended to the Western world, which he frequently visited, as a lecturer and by the popular appeal of many of .his demonstrations.

C. S. Lincoln, treasurer of A. G. Spalding Bros., was elected yesterday secretary to succeed H. Boardman Spalding, who presented his resignation at a meeting of the directors. Herbert H. Pease, president of the New Britain Machine Company, New Britain, Conn., was elected a director to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of E. E. Combs, controller.

Dr. Chengting T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, last night accused the world's peaceloving powers of cost-counting and inertia in the face of lawlessness which, he said, "threatens to shatter the very foundation of international civilization."

Liquidation of bonds persisted yesterday in slightly more active trading on the New York Stock Dxchange. The selling pressure, coupled with the lack of near-by support, forced prices in the domestio corporation section to the lowest levels in nearly four years. Other major groups also were affected. United States Government

Miss Margaret Demarest Terhune, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Beekman R. Terhune of this place, was married this afternoon to Randolph Marshall Beebe, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Beebe, also of North Plainfield.
Twenty-ninth annual convention of the National Interfraternity Conference opens at the Hotel Commodore at 9 A. M. and continues tomorrow, Friday and Saturday.

New entrenchments, which are being rushed at many points near Nanking, provide further evidence that the Chinese intend to make a stand here against the Japanese despite the opinion of most military experts that such a course would lead to the trapping of the huge force, terrific, useless slaughter and enormous destruction of property.
Philip Guedalla, British author and biographer, arrived yesterday from England with Mrs. Guedalla on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to spend the Christmas holidays in New York and Washington.

Tammany, overwhelmingly beaten in its own borough in the recent Mayoralty election, obtained an even break on candidates for the new City Council elected by the proportional representation method, completion of the Manhattan count disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23--The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company advised the Interstate Commerce Commission today of a plan for extending $4,647,000 of 6 per cent notes of the Lehigh Valley Coal Company to avoid threatened defaults. Failure to avoid the defaults, it said, "would probably lead to receivership" for both the railroad company and the coal company.

There appears no longer to be any doubt that the full force of the executive and legislative branches of the government has been released to aid business. For the first time since the President became irritated over what the Supreme Court did to his NRA plan, the heavy accent here is on recovery rather than reform, if one excepts the bitter feeling against certain officials of the New York Stock Exchange.

Wall Street interpreted last night the statement by William 0. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, on reorganization of the New York Stock Exchange as an attempt by the SEC to put the trading body on the defensive, to make it shoulder the blame for the recent and continuinz decline in the market.

Continuing preparations for its intersectional clash with Tulsa University on Dec. 4 in the Oil Well City, the Manhattan football team went through a two-hour practice yesterday at Innisfail Park. In the absence of Coach Chick Meehan, who is confined to bed with a cold, the drill was directed by Jack Connor and Bing Miller, assistant coaches.
John Nance Garner was born on Nov. 22, as near Thanksgiving as so modest and wise a person would choose to be. His countrymen can't help numbering him among their blessings this week.
Registration statements for new securities filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission inM1,AA .

Michael Mooney, 19 years old, of 590 Columbus Avenue, and James Murphy, 17, of 525 West Fiftieth Street, both Manhattan, were convicted of murder, first degree, last night by a jury in Kings County Court.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Blinn of Radnor have announced the engagement of Mrs. Blinn's niece, Mrs. Elizabeth Carpenter Fell, to Lieutenant Richard Gerben Visser, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gerben Visser of Springfield, Mass.

Japan. will have between 10,000 and 60,000 square feet of exhibit space at the New York World's Fair of 1939 as the result of contracts signed yesterday. The primary object of the Japanese display, it was said, will be to present to the American people in a favorable light the nation's policies in the Far East and to interpret her progress and national spirit.
This city's opera season got under way tonight with a performance of Bizet's "Carmen" by the Civic Grand Opera Company of Philadelphia, which has ten productions scheduled for this, its second, year.

Retired Engineer of Steamer Thomas M. Loomis, formerly a member of Engine 58, residing at 1,607 Poinsettia Pl., Hollywood Calif., died Nov, 6. To Report to Medical Chief The following ununiformed firemen shall be directed to report to the chief medical officer, at these headquarters, at 12 Noon, on date specified above their names:

Taking advantage of a long session for practice today, the Navy eleven worked against its "Army" team composed of the pick of the strong B squad, testing both its offense and defense in preparation for Saturday's battle with the real Army eleven.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Hortense Month, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Siegfried Husserl of Newark, to Ira A. Hirschmann, vice president of Saks-Fifth Avenue, which took place here on Sunday night at the home of the bride, 3 East Eightyfifth Street.
The Weather Bureau performed a routine service today, but it may have repercussions. A business man called the airport station and asked: "Is there any snow in Southern Wyoming?"
Governor Hoffman is expected to announce tomorrow that on the expiration of his term in January he will accept appointment by the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission as its director.

Embattled farmers of this town, which was founded twelve years after the Revolutionary War, crowded the South Britain Congrenational Church this afternoon to denounce Nazi camps here and elsewhere and wound up their session with a prayer by the Rev. M. E. Lindsay, the pastor, and the singing of "The Star-Spangled Banner."

Bert Kirkman, president of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A. F. of L. affiliate, announced yesterday that 4,700 union electricians on construction jobs would receive a 25cent increase in their hourly wage under contracts just signed with associations of electrical contractors in all boroughs.

A net profit of $1,428,909 for the year ended on Aug. 28 was reported yesterday by Spencer Kellogg Sons, Inc., and domestic subsidiaries. The profit, computed after all charges, including depreciation, idle mill expenses, interest, Federal income taxes and $53,376 for surtax on undistributed earnings, was equal to $2.81 each on 509,213 nopar shares of capital stock outstanding.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Simon Nelson of this city to the marriage of their daughter, Miss Eleanore Thora Nelson, to Norman B. Land, son of Henry Clarke Land of Jenkintown, Pa., and the late Mrs. Land.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,573,850 barrels, compared to 3,541,450 in the previous week, a drop of 32,400, according to Ithe American Petroleum Institute. Production was 64,850 barrels more than the calculation of 3,509,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for November.

A banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., obtained yesterday the award of two new issues of bonds, aggregating $1,239,000 of the city of Memphis, Tenn. The syndicate paid a price of par for the $1,085,000 of sewer bonds, maturing $35,000 annually from 1938 to 1968, as 3s, and $154,000 of school bonds, maturing 1938 to 1948, as 2[Yen]hs, giving a net interest cost to the city of 2.97 per cent.
A $15,000 gift from the Davison Fund, established by John D. Rockefeller Jr., was received yesterday by the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York.

Having a story to tell in "Of Mice and Men," John Steinbeck has told it with reticence and integrity, and the theatre has had the genius to look at it from his point of view. Although the performance which opened at the Music Box last evening makes no artistic pretensions, it is art in the keenness of its expression.
Constance Worth, who successfully fought George Brent's suit to annul their marriage last Summer, admitted today that her reconciliation efforts had failed. She asked for a divorce.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income of $15,935,468 after all expenses and charges. This was equal,
The latest avilable statistics indicate that business in Canada is holding its own remarkably well despite a "deplorably small" purchasing power in the West, according to the Bank of Montreal.

The number of commercial failures in the United States in the week ended Nov. 18 showed increases in each of five trade divisions, as compared with a year ago, according to the weekly report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total was 206,

Harvard University's endowment funds increased about $7,000,000 during the year, according to the annual report of Henry L. Shattuck, treasurer of Harvard College, to the board of overseers. On June 30, the book value of the funds, exclusive of lands and buildings used for educational purposes, was $141,941,666, as compared to $134,601,999 last year.

COBB, ERNEST B. (Jan. 16, 1936). Gross assets, $189,988; net, $172,217. To Marion R. Cobb. daughter, $20,000, personal property and life estate in resiude. Chief assets. stocks and bonds, $141,941. Sullivan, Donovan Heenehan, attorneys, 14 Wall St.

A powerful senior class crew, including three varsity letter men, annexed the annual Princeton University Fall regatta over a mile downstream course today on Lake Carnegie as the official Fall season was brought to a close.
State and Federal agencies joined hands here today to provide 5,000 laborers for they cane fields, in the Louisiana sugar bowl to speed harvesting of the $6,000,000 standing crop.

While a policy of marking time appears to have been adopted by most advertisers, according to agency men yesterday some approvals went through this week for first quarter, 1938 budgets, with schedules, however, lacking complete details. The necessity of getting

Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Van Vechten will give a dinner dance tonight in the Green Room at Sherry's for their debutante daughter, Miss Nina Riker Van Vechten, before the supper dance to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Jameson at their home, 9 East Sixty-ninth Street, to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Jameson.

Although the after-effects of the abscessed tooth which was drawn last week again confined President Roosevelt to the White House today, he held a "streamlined" press conference at which he appeared well-and cheerful.

Mortgages aggregating $535,000 for ten years at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent have been placed on the two six-story apartment houses recently completed at 604-24 and 626-36 Fort Washington Ave. north of 187th St. They were arranged by Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc. in cooperation with Lawrence. Blake Jewell, Inc.

Two General Telephone Corporation subsidiaries, the Pennsylvania Telephone Corporation and the Indiana Associated Telephone Corporation, will acquire telephone properties of the Bell System in Johnstown, Pa., and in Northwestern Indiana, according to an announcment yesterday by John Winn, president of General Telephone.
Two foreigners, Paul Silberhorn and Erwin Klein, have been sentenced to twenty-five years' imprisonment by a military court in Leningrad on charges of spying on behalf of a foreign power.

A story Of a 76-year-old widow who committed suicide rather than continue as a burden to her unemplayed 42-year-old son and of the son who declined to ask for relief until the last minute, lest he hurt his mother's pride, was unfolded to detectives yesterday in Bellevue Hospital.
Staten Island defeated the New York Junior League, 3-2, in a Class B interclub team match of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday on the Staten Island courts.
A Circuit Court jury convicted the Rev. C. E. Newton early today of murdering Mrs. Dennis Kelly and fixed his punishment at life imprisonment.

More than 150 years ago the founder of a great Asiatic empire was uner severe criticism for the methods he employed in building up his power and for subsidiary derelictions. He was an Englishman, and his critics were his own countrymen.

Gains in deposits, total assets and other items were reported for the year ended Oct. 31 by the Imperial Bank of Canada in a statement issued yesterday by H. T. Jaffray, general manager. Total assets of the bank at the end of October were $159,667,419, an increase of $9,120,158 in the preceding twelve months, while deposits amounted to $132,198,089, against $124,616,919.
Sources close to the papal household said Pope Pius suffered a sinking spell last night, but appeared considerably better today, following his usual medical injections.

In a slashing bout that had 4,000 spectators on their toes from the first bell to the last, Joe Lubin of Brooklyn, unattached, gained a well-earned decision over William Schloeman of the First Avenue Boys Club in the open heavyweight class in the New York JournalAmerican amateur diamond belt boxing tournament at the Hippodrome last night.

The general executive board of the United Automobile Workers Union met here today to pave the way for renewed negotiations with the General Motors Corporation aimed at modification of the present agreement as it relates to responsiability for ending of wildcat strikes.

Colonel Timothy M. Coughlan, U. S. A., retired, died at Letterman General Hospital in San Francisco today at the age of 62, the War Department announced. Colonel Coughlan was born in Ireland on Oct. 17, 1875, and enlisted in 1898 as a sergeant in Company A of the 201st New York Infantry.
Standing a long drive gamely, as thoroughbreds do, Lavengro, from the Pacific Coast won the feature race today under the stern handling of his Western rider, Verne Thompson.
The statement of William O. Douglas, chairmann of the Securities and Ex??hange Commission, regarding the commission'ss negotiations with the Vew York ,Stock Exchange read as Follows:

Three representatives of manufacturers told members of the State Public Utilities Commission in session here today that they favored a rise in intrastate railroad freight rates for several commodities.

There is every reason to hope that the President's conference yesterday in Washington with Mr. Willkie of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation brought a substantial measure of agreement on both sides and that it will prove to be the first of a series of steps clearing the way for a better understanding between the Roosevelt Administration and the public utility industry.

The Parkville Social Justice Council, composed of supporters of the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin of Detroit, failed today to obtain permission to use the assembly hall of the Hartford Council of the Knights of Columbus.

At a meeting of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee investigating the guaranteed mortgage situation, Senator Lazarus Joseph, chairman, charged yesterday that the Prudence Company, Inc., had "left the public holding the bag" in the sale of mortgage certificates.

The question whether a closedshop agreement violates the constitutional rights of workers who do not wish to join a union was argued yesterday before five justices of the Appellate Division at a special hearing in Brooklyn.

A 22-year-old former chauffeur for the State asylum at Central Islip appeared before United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn Federal Building yesterday and pleaded guilty of attempted extortion. The prisoner was booked in $25,000 bail to await action of the Federal grand jury.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Schwartz of 317 West Eighty-seventh Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice M. Schwartz, to Martin S. Kimmel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry K. Kimmel, also of New York.
The Walgreen Company has notified the New York Stock Exchange of a proposal to decrease its authorized common stock from 2,000,000 to 1,955,828 shares.

Mrs. Marie Kibler Phillips, a former American Olympic and Temple University gymnastic star, was held in $500 bail late today as a material witness in the police investigation of the death of Nancy M. Glenn, 5 years old.

Speaking yesterday at a luncheon of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service in the Bankers Club at 120 Broadway, Mayor La Guardia appealed for public support for the organization's current drive to raise $250,000.

Arthur G. Gilkes, '39, of Kew Gardens, L. I., a member of the varsity track team, has been elected to the captaincy of Princeton University's 1938 cross-country team, it was announced tonight by Coach Matthew T. Geis. The captain-elect succeeds Frederic Rosengarten Jr., of Philadelphia.

Louis A. Schmitt, an executive since 1933 in the mortgage division of the New York State Department of Insurance, died here today at his home, 330 Eighth Avenue, after an illness of twenty months. His age was 46.

The Securities and Exchange Commission. announced today that two over-the-counter broker-dealers in securities had withdrawn their registrations and that three others had withdrawn their applications for registration.

With the score of the world chess championship match at 6 to 4 in favor of Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, and nine games drawn, the twentieth contest of his series with Dr. Max Euwe, titleholder, was begun here tonight.

Trading was slow on most classes of locally dressed meats. The lamb market was strong with Monday's advance of about 50c; other classes were mostly steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated lamb to be strong; other classes steady to weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Charles Maurice Stebbins, a retired high school teacher who had taught Latin and English in the Boys High School and the Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 1,427 Union Street, Brooklyn, of heart disease, at the age of 66.

Rumors of impending price cuts on Spring lines of rugs and carpets, current in the wholesale floor coverings market for more than a week, brought a statement yesterday from M. Karagheusian, president of A. M. Karagheusian,

Ferdinand Louis Kerran, British Labor candidate for Parliament, now in New York, has withdrawn the charge of censorship made against the Columbia Broadcasting System in connection with his talk on the air last Friday night over WABC, after deletions had been made in the text by C. B. S. officials.

Defeated Monday in their efforts to have the United States Court of Customs Patent Appeals upset a ruling by the lower Customs Court, Florida agriculturists were planning yesterday to carry their fight against the reciprocal trade agreements program to the United States Supreme Court.

Exemption from the undistributed profits tax of all corporations with a net income of $25,000 or less and a marked modification in the tax for corporations with larger net incomes were approved today by the House subcommittee studying tax revision.

Mrs. Walter George Shields and her daughter, Miss Virginia FosterShields, gave a tea dance yesterday at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League to introduce to society here Miss Mary Van Rensselaer Saxe, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Van Rensselaer Powell Saxe of Roland Park, Baltimore.

Five members of the grand ducal house of Hesse bei Rhein who were killed in a plane accident at Ostend were buried here today in a common grave beside the Grand Duke Ernst Ludwig, who died six weeks ago.

When our high-pressure Mayor lets off steam it evidently does him good, it often does other people good, and it seldom does harm to any good cause or well-intentioned person. But his exuberantly skeptical attitude toward the conference called in Washington this week by Federal Housing Administrator Straus, his description of that conference as "star-gazing," and his refusal to let the city government be represented there were not helpful.

A Mexican court today removed the last obstacle to the return to Mexico of Archbishop Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores, former Apostolic Delegate, and Monsignor Jose Manriquez y Zarate, exiles in the United States since 1934.

Tests of a new-type "wooden lung," for use by Fred Snite Jr., infantile paralysis victim, who ,has lived in an "iron lung" for the past nineteen months, were being conducted at the Snite residence here today. The "wooden lung" was devised by Mr. Snite's physicians, and preliminary tests indicated it' would rove satisfactory. they said.

The Yale senior prom committee was announced tonight. Six members are from Yale College. They are Hugh Auchincloss Jr. of New York, Joseph E. Clifford of Minneapolis, William H. Harding of Overbrook, Pa.; Albert
The Japanese Embassy will be the host tomorrow night at a diplomatic dinner commemorating the first anniversary of the German-Japanese anti-Comintern pact.

Only twentyfour hours after the return of Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, from his visit to Germany there is little doubt today that his journey has been a disappointment to those who planned it.

The good but evidently skeptical citizenry of New York town was somewhat amazed yesterday to see walking its streets an imported town crier, who, in the black. velvet" suit of a Pilgrim Father and arrying a five-pound bell, stoode along in determined fashion, reading the official announcement of the Christmas seal campaign. to laughing crowds.

More than 1,000 persons attended dances held tonight at the Hotel Wendell here, The Hotel Richmond in North Adams and The Berkshire Inn at Great Barrington for the benefit of the Berkshire Hills Conference, which is to have an exhibit at the Winter sports exposition in Madison Square Garden, New York. Dec. 4 to 11.

Prices of virtually every major meat cuts on the household shopping list have dropped since the peak levels were reached two or three months ago, latest figures from butcher shops indicated today. Furthermore, some

Four charitable and benevolent institutions share more than half of the estate of Charles F. Ash, who died last Christmas, in his eightyninth year, at 375 Riverside Drive. His will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Wholesale prices on high grade butter reached yesterday the highest level since February, 1936, which was in turn the highest point in several years. The grade known as fresh extra sold at 39 cents a pound, the highest since the level of 39 to 391/ cents was touched for three days in February, 1936. The Autumn rise has not been so marked in intermediate and cheaper grades.

The Netherlands army team scored its first victory in international jumping contests at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight but the manner in which the triumph was accomplished made --up for string of feats.

Captain John Milliken, president of the United Licensed Officers Associtation, steamship union affiliated with the A. F. of L., came out victorious in the Tombs Court yesterday when Magistrate Rothenberg dismissed a summons another officer of his union had obtained the day before, alleging he was illegally withholding the organization's property.

Heretofore scheduled for next Monday night at the Playhouse, "Merely Murder" has been shifting players and plans, and is now due somewhat later, probably Dec. 3 or 4. Douglass Montgomery withdrew from the cast after Monday night's performance in Princeton, being succeeded by Rex O'Malley.

Rescinding a seventeen-year-old ruling, the Teachers Retirement Board voted yesterday to deny pension credit for Summer or evening school work performed by regular members of the teaching staff. The action was taken on the advice of the Corporation Counsel, who declared the practice of granting more than one year of credit for retirement purposes in any calendar year was illegal.
Judge Horace Mann Towner, former Iowa Representative and former Governor to Puerto Rico, died at his home here tonight. He was 82 years old. Judge Towner suffered a concussion in a fall recently.

Jesse James, 190, Hollywood, Calif., threw Gino Martinelli, 198, Italy, with a back drop and body press after 52 minutes of grappling in the feature finish wrestling match before 1,500 persons at the St. Nicholas Palace last night.

Recognition of Japan's new position in Shanghai has been given by two new customs appointments, Sir Frederick Maze, the Inspector General of Chinese Customs, naming Yoshisuke Akatani of the Tientsin customs office as administrative commissioner for Shanghai and Kelichi Kato as revenue accountant of Shanghai.

The National Peasant party congress today re-elected its old chairman, Dr. Julius Maniu, to lead the electoral battle against the present system. Since Dr. Maniu resigned the Premiership and shortly thereafter his leadership of the party on the ground that King Carol had violated the guarantee under which he had induced Dr. Maniu to support his restoration-that he would dismiss Mme. Magda Lupescu and the

The producing copper companies yesterday lowered the price of the metal in the domestic market from 12 to 11 cents a pound. Immediately afterward the American Smelting and Refining Company reduced its price of copper to 10 3/4 cents a pound. For almost a month American Smelting and Refining has been selling copper at 11 cents, while the copper producers have been quoting 12 cents.

A copy of the first octavo edition, in the original parts and wrappers, of John James Audubon's "The Birds of America" brought $6,400 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., in the auction of the library of the late George C. Smith Jr. of this city.

The engagement of Virginia Queen Stocker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Stocker of 21 Ingraham Boulevard, Hempstead, L. I., to Lieutenant James Ferris Pearsall, United States Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Ferris Pearsall of Plainfield, N. J., was announced yesterday by Miss Stocker's parents.

The Group A team matches of the Women's Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association, played on the Junior League courts yesterday, resulted in a double victory for the New York players. After defeating the Westchester representatives in a hard-fought battle, 4 to 3, they turned back the New Jersey contingent, 5 to 2.

Mrs. Phebe Palmer of 216 Roseland Avenue, Essex Fells, will celebrate her 101st birthday next Monday. Almost directly across the street from her lives Mrs. Phebe Clark, at 223 Roseland Avenue, who will celebrate her 101st birthday Dec. 17.

In "Robert's Wife," staged at the Globe Theatre last night, St. John Ervine has woven a lively discussion on many of humanity's pressing problems around this story of a married couple whose sincere devotion to their respective careers threatens their happiness.
A group of ten boys and girls, students at Butler High School, assisted in the capture of a burglar here tonight as they were returning home from a high school play rehearsal.

Mayor La Guardia and the New York City Housing Authority divided sharply yesterday over the qualifications of Charles Abrams, Authority counsel who resigned last Monday, with the Mayor criticizing him as a pettifogging lawyer and the Authority supporting him as a great contributor to the cause of better housing.

7th St, n s, 150 w of 1st Ave, 25x90.8; Louis Akst and wife to Ralph Samstein, 137 1st Ave; mtg $18,500 ($6). St. Mark's Pl, 53, 25x93.11; Tena Penner and Bertha and Adolph Friedberg to George Davidovich, 63 St Mark's Pl; mtg $12,750.

JUST another crop of conglomerate remarks caught on the fly at a football gathering: "Why didn't Navy stick to the attack it was using last year? Now they've gone back to old stuff they couldn't win with before." "Why, they had to experiment. They weren't winning. Columbia was the only team they beat since Virginia. You can't stand pat on an offense when it isn't going anywhere."

In the first annual team competuition for the John Allaire Memorial Trophy held on the strips of the New York Athletio Club last night, the Fencers Club threeweapon trio of Hugo Alessandroni, Tracy Jaeckel and Norman Armitage won by a single point from Salle Santelli. The score was 135 to 134.

Movements or vessels follow, all dates are Nov. 22, unless specified: At Mariveles: Alden, Barker, J. D. Edwards. At Charleston Yard: Hatfield, Kane. Pompano, Mare Island Yard to sea. Richmond. at Mare Island Yard. Case, Boston Yard to sea, Nov. 23. Craven, at Boston Yard. Cuyama, Pearl Harbor to San Pedro. Dunlap, New York Yard to sea, Nov. 23. Gannet. Gulf of Guacanayabo to

Steel ingot output continued to drop last weekOalthough a nominal increase was seasonal, and the adjusted index declined to 55.4 from 63.2. The figure for the week ended Nov. 21, 1936, was 111.3. THE NEW YORK TIMES estimated operations at 36 per cent of capacity, compared with 41 per cent for the previous week and 75 per cent for the corresponding week last year.

More than 100 advertising men and publishers attended a dinner at the Metropolis Club, 105 West Fifty-seventh Street, arranged by the advertising and publishing division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies for its $6,250,000 New YorkBrooklyn campaign.

The Reich is about to assume permanent control of the property of the Jewish shipping operator, Arnold Bernstein, without awaiting his conviction on "economic treason" charges. His trial before the Hamburg Emergency Court has been going on for ten days.

Aaron E. Greenleaf of Wichita, Kan., asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to acquire controlling of Safeway Trails, .Inc.; Nevin Transit, Inc., and the Nevin Midland Lines, all bus companies oprating in Eastern States.

A long forward pass drill for the ends and backs, fundamentals for the tackles, guards and centers, then calisthenics and a signal drill for three elevens, followed by defensive dummy scrimmaging, kept the unbeaten Fordham football squad busy for almost three hours yesterday in preparation for the N. Y. U. game at the Yankee Stadium Saturday.
Mr. and Mrs. Wilton Lloyd Smith gave a dinner last night at the American Museum of Natural History in connection with the museum's ten year development program.
The Salamanca authorities have suggested that 3,000 foreigners be withdrawn from each army in Spain with simultaneous recognition of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's government as a belligerent.

Herman Secor, 35 years old, of 36 West Street, here, who notified police last week that he had "found" a package of dynamite, wired to the brake light, above the tire rack on his wife's car, admitted to police today he had placed the explosive there.

President Roosevelt refused today to concede that he used bad grammar. When shown an open letter by Professor Janet R. Aiken of Columbia University questioning his grammar in recent speeches, the President smilingly blamed newspaper men who reported his extemporaneous remarks.

The Anchor Post Fence Company reported yesterday that it had obtained from the' Metropolitan Water District of Southern California a contract for seventy-six miles of six-foot-high chain link fence to be erected around open sections of the Colorado River Aqueduct carrying water from Parker Dam to Los Angeles and vicinity.

Whether or not they go back to the Rose Bowl, the Pittsburgh Panthers are likely to wind up as 1937 national college champions in The Associated Press ranking poll. They are likely to do so, that is, provided -they disposed of Duke, their final opponent, at Durham, N. C., on Saturday. For Pittsburgh again ranks at the top in the weekly ratings made by sports experts all over the country.

150th St. 544-548 E (9-2276); Sandola Lombardi to N Y Protestant Episcopal Public School, 6 Church St, due as per bond; $13,000 Cruger Ave. 2,167-2.187 (15-4318); Cruger Estates, Inc, to 222-223 Riverside Drive Corp, 521 5th Ave; five years, 6 per cent; $50,000.
The Harvard Club's Class A squash racquets team remained undefeated in the metropolitan interclub series last night by vanquishing the Montclair A. C., 5 to 0, in a match previously postponed.

The board of trustees of the Seventh Regiment Armory Building in New York City won in the Court of Appeals today the reversal of a ruling of the Appellate Division, which had denied a mandamus directed against the Board of Estimate.

Alfred Solman, composer of popular song hits of the early Nineteen Hundreds, died on Nov. 15 in Mount Sinai Hospital, it was learned yesterday. His compositions, fitted to sentimental or humorous words, were sung, hummed and whistled by hundreds of thousands.

The German American Bund announced here yesterday that Fritz Kuhn, its national leader, had sent letters to the Departments of State, Labor and Justice in Washington protesting against a declaration by Common Pleas Judge J. Wallace

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today a reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 27,000, including 8,000 directs. The market closed strong to 10c higher than Monday's average; top, $8.05; bulk good and choice 150-300 lbs., $7.85-$8; few butchers 320-360 lbs., $7.60-$7.80; most good packing sows, $7.15-$7.50; lightweights to $7.60. Shippers 1,000; estimated holdover 1,000.

The Court of Appeals refused today to permit Nassau County to institute a new trial of Percy C. Reed and Richard F. Roberts, proprietors of a dog racing track at Mineola, on charges of bookmaking and gambling.

Merchandise delivered in New York City from an out-of-State firm is exempt from the city sales tax under two unanimous decisions returned today by New York's Court of Appeals, upholding claims of the National Cash Register Company of Dayton and the West Publishing Company of St. Paul.

Detailed plans for training the future rulers of the Third Reich, calculated to produce the first full effect in seventeen years, were announced today by Dr. Robert Ley, Reich Organization Director and head of the German Labor Front.

After fourteen false alarms had kept Queens fire crews on the jump over a five-mile stretch from 2 to 4 o'clock yesterday morning and caused twenty-two police radio cars to scour the region for the misciefmaker, a 17-yearold youth was arrested while riding his bicycle near a fire alarm box that was still ringing at.136th Avenue and 219th Street, Springfield, Queens.

Meredith Howland, a member of an old and distinguished New York family, died here today at the home of his sister, Mrs. Percy Rivington Pyne, at the age of 73. Last March he suffered a heart attack, and his death followed a recurrence of the same malady.

Announcement has been made by Christian Cornehlsen of 254 Cumberland Street, Brooklyn, of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Doris Cornehlsen, to Rodney Edwards, son of Mrs. Alfred B. Edwards of Plandome and East Marion, L. I., and the late Mr. Edwards.

Another attempt to "secure a different line of decisions" from the Supreme Court by abolishing or limiting its power of review of the constitutionality of Congressional acts will be made at the coming regular session of Congress or "very soon" afterward, Senator Edward R. Burke of Nebraska, one of the Democratic leaders of the opposition to the Supreme Court proposal, asserted yesterday.

Total contributions of $133,902 to the campaign of Thomas E. Dewey, who was elected District Attorney of New York County, and expenditures of $133,887 were reported to the Board of Elections yesterday, During the day the board received many reports by candidates and committees which had been mailed on Monday the last day for filing.
A number of residential properties in uptown Manhattan and the Bronx changed hands in transactions reported yesterday by brokers.

The St. Augustine's High School basketball team of Brooklyn opened its season yesterday by downing St. Agnes High School of College Point, 27-18, on St. Augustine's court. Cyril Stapleton, with nine points, led the attack for the winners, who led at the intermission, 14 to 7. The line-up:

Jerry Nolan's field goal in the last ten seconds of the game broke a tie and gave the Cathedral College basketball team a 26-24 victory over Manhattan College's Staten Island Branch as the victors launched their campaign last night at the Holy Spirit School gymnasium in the Bronx. At half-time the teams were deadlocked at 10all.
The Froedtert Grain and Malting Company, Inc., Greenfield, Wis., reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission today that its general

Wheat prices were on the down grade today. Liquidation by scattered longs developed and stop-loss orders caught on the way down dropped the May future as much as 3 1/4 cents a bushel from Monday's finish. While the selling movement quickly ran its course, the market showed little disposition to rally and closing trades on the Board of Trade here were at net losses of 1 7/8 cents to 2 cents.

The Voelkischer Beobachter prints this morning a violent attack against Otto D. Tolischus, correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as well as that newspaper, for an article last Sunday on Germanism abroad.

Irish Eddie McGeever, 142, of Scranton, knocked out Ralph Vona, 144, of Asbury Park, with a right to the jaw in 22 seconds of the sixth round of a scheduled eightround main bout in the Coliseum before 6,500 spectators last night.

Holcombe Ward of New York City, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, which under his leadership enjoyed one of its most successful seasons in years during 1937, will be returned to that office when the U. S. L. T. A. holds its annual meeting at Miami Beach, Fla., on Jan. 15.

We have an oversupply of good centers, fullbacks and quarterbacks on the Pacific Coast this year but are short on outstanding tackles and guards. There are plenty of halfbacks capable of qualifying for an all-star berth and we can raise an argument over the selection of the ends, not from lack of ability but from the closeness of the decision to select the leaders.
The Dartmouth football team today picked Robert E. MacLeod of Glen Ellyn, Ill., as captain for the 1938 season.
Administration forces went into action today on a front extending from the White House to Capitol Hill in their drive to stimulate private business to assume the main burden of recovery.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn will be permitted under an authorization voted yesterday by the Board of Aldermen to buy $105,512 worth of expensive furniture and equipment for its new court house at Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place without competitive bidding.

Matthew J. Murphy, 78 years old, who lived with his son, William J. Murphy, at 233 Sherman Avenue, Glen Ridge, was killed today at the Walnut Avenue grade crossing of the Erie Railroad here. He was struck by a train of the New York, Susquehanna Western Railroad running on the Erie tracks.

Preparing for tomorrow's encounter with the Brooklyn Dodgers at Ebbets Field, the New York Giants, leaders in the race for Eastern division honors in the National Football League, went through a stiff session yesterday.

The Shirt Institute, Inc., comprising ninety-six men's and boys' shirt manufacturers, voted last night to reject the terms of a proposed uniform sales agreement governing sales by converters to members of the institute as "unduly favoring the converter and as not offering

Confident that the American market is ready for more expensive perfumes and toiletries, despite the current recession in business,- Pnaud, Inc., will expand here by introducing early next year its more costly products which have hitherto been confined to France and the Continent, it was stated yesterday

John Keough, 31, who shot and killed James Heaney in a Brooklyn speakeasy in June, 1932, and was convicted of murder, first degree, is to have a new trial, the Court of Appeals ruled today. The opinion stated that whether the defendant was sane or insane at the time of the shooting "presents the close issue in the case."

By WILLIAM D. RICHARDSON General Lou (Custer) Little and his small but valiant band of Columbia Blue gridiron soldiers will make their last stand of the season against the Stanford Indians on Baker Field Saturday.

The city's maternal death rate for the forty-six elapsed weeks of 1937 indicates that a new low will be established for this year, it was announced yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. The rate to date is 4.1 to each 1,000 live births.

Mrs. Lillian Fitall, 35 years old, of 960 East Thirty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday plunged to her death from the eastbound platform of the Boerum Place station of the Fulton Street elevated line, Brooklyn. The body fell fifty feet and landed on the sidewalk,

Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that movement of private capital into banks was "long past due" and cited the increased use of such capital as one of eight steps needed for the "permanent strengthening of our banking system."

Donald Wayne, author of "Fine Flowers in the Valley" (Scribner) is now at work on a second novel, "The Show Must Go On." Mr. Wayne was stage manager for several Max Gordon productions before he devoted himself to fiction writing. His new novel will have a theatrical background.

Six months: of effort in drawing up a budget for the average working woman will have been wasted, according to -Miss Frieda Miller of the State Department of .Labor, if the wage boards delegated to determine the new pay rates in each industry insist on haggling over details of the living cost estimates now being, completed by the women's division, under the: new minimum wage law.

Western coaches for the all-star East-West football game at San Francisco New Year's Day will be Orin (Babe) Hollingbery of Washington State, L. M. (Biff) Jones of Nebraska. and Percy Locey, director of athletics at Oregon State, Locey, chairman of the Western Committee, announced today.

All motions for directed verdicts of acquittal for sixteen corporate defendants remaining in the government's gasoline price-fixing case were denied today by Federal Judge Patrick T. Stone, who then recessed court until next Monday and wished the defendants a "happy Thanksgiving."

Addressing a National Socialist audience at Fulda, the site of the annual Catholic Bishops' Conference, Hanns Kerrl, the Church Minister, tonight proclaimed the disestablishment of churches in Germany as an ultimate aim of the Nazi regime.

Samuel Seabury renewed yesterday his charge, originally made in an address delivered before the National Municipal League at Rochester last Saturday, that Governor Lehman had held up the La Guardia economy program for the city in 1934 by Renouncing an economy bill the Mayor had sent to Albany as unacceptable because it would give Mr. La Guardia "dictatorial" powers.

New Yorkers paused in their daily tasks yesterday afternoon to watch four blimps cruising over Manhattan and Brooklyn Heights. Knots of the curious gathered in the windows of office buildings and at street intersections as the colorful little dirigibles made several turns, over Times Square during training flights from the Naval Air Station at Lakehurst, N. J.
Jimmy Sheridan set the-pace with 14 points as Bishop Loughlin's basketball team defeated Power Memorial, 28-19, at the former's gymnasium yesterday. At half-time the winners led, 9-2.

City Councils and Boards of Trustees of every community in Westchester County levying taxes against the New York, Westchester Boston Railway have approved 50 per cent reductions in the railroad's 1936 and 1937 assessments, on condition that train service for 1938 be guaranteed, it was announced here this afternoon, after an executive meeting of Mayors and Corporation Counsels. They had suggested the plan Nov. 15.

Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott issued 'yesterday a warning to the public to refrain from buying tickets for fake "firemen's benefits" after he had received complaints that imposters were operating in the midtown district in the guise of uniformed firemen.

A report recommending acceptance of the plan of reorganization of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, with certain modifications, was filed yesterday by George W. Alger, special master, with Federal Judge William Bondy. Mr. Alger ruled that, subject to modification which he suggested, the plan, which had the backing of the Atlas Corporation and other security holders, was fair and equitable.

John G. Cavanagh of 904 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, arbiter and director of betting at New York race tracks for more than four decades, died yesterday in the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after an illness of twenty-two days. He was 76 years old.

George Palmer Putnam, writer and former publisher, said today he had agreed to head an expedition to the Galapagos Islands and Central America about Dec. 15 to obtain small animals and birds for Zoo Park here.

Haraden Pratt, vice president and chief engineer of the Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company, has been elected president of the Institute of Radio Engineers, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Pratt will take office at the January meeting of the institute, succeeding Harold H. Beverage, chief research engineer of R. C. A. Communications.

Denials by E. W. Bondeson, a security salesman, of stories told by officers of the William Stelmach Corporation brought to a close yesterday the Securities and Exchange Commission's disbarment proceedings against Joseph H. Van Dorn, an accountant licensed to practice before it.

Frederick B. Ryan Jr. of Short Hills, seeded first, won the fifteenth annual Princeton Club invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday by defeating a Princeton alumnus, Thomas D. Flynn, 15-10, 15-5, 15-8.

In an effort to end labor troubles on American ships, the American Steamship Owners Association yestoday called a conference of owners and unions of unlicensed personnel at which a plan will be discussed for an agreement covering all basic labor questions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--Federal compulsory control of the nation's principal crops of food, feed and fiber became a possibility today as the House Agriculture Committee chose between mandatory farm legislation and a voluntary program of agricultural adjustment involving annual expenditures of $250,000,000 in addition to the half-billion dollars a year now authorized for soil conservation.
Stocks recovered and closed irregular after falling to new low levels; turnover, 1,640,980 shares.' All groups of bonds lower in quiet trading; transactions, $8,886, 400.

The United States was Canada's best customer in the first seven months of the 1937-38 fiscal year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. The United Kingdom was second and Australia was third. The world markets bought $670,020,000 worth of goods from Canada, or 12.3 per cent more than in the corresponding period of the previous year.

The proposed 1938 capital improvement budget of the Westchester County Park Commission, aggregated $1,456,538, will be cut by more than $1,130,000 by the Board of Supervisors Budget and Appropriations Committee, members of the committee said today when they began preparation of a final county budget for next year.

Manhattan 7th Ave, 130-8, 101.8x60 irreg; for 1-story stores; The Texas Co, 135 E 42d St, owner; Scaccheti Siegel, architects; cost $15,000. Alterations Rutgers St, 26; to 6-story tenement and stores; Schrier Trading Corp, 535 5th Ave, owner; MacManus Gleich, architects; cost $15,000.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for Nov. 15 showed a slight decrease in the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation to 130.21 per cent on that date from 130.58 per cent on Oct. 31.

After a confused debate in which the Conservative back-benchers opposed the government's bill for the purchase of all British coal royalties because It opened the way for the nationalization of industry and in which the Labor party opposed it because it did not go as far as nationalization, the House of Commons tonight approved the bill on second reading without a division.

After the second performance of their golden jubilee production, "Fifty Fifty," which is continuing throughout Thanksgiving week at the Erlanger Theatre, members of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania gave a supper dance tonight at their clubhouse.

Daniel Frohman, dean of American theatrical producers and president of the Actors Fund, is confined to the home of his sister, Miss Etta Frohman, at the Hotel Dorset, 30 West Fifty-fourth Street, with injuries he suffered in a fall, it was disclosed yesterday.

After dwelling in the silences or rather in strata of invisibility, for three years, Peter Blume, once a first-prize winner down at Pittsburgh, re-emerged yesterday afternoon with a painted essay on Fascism.

Daniel Frohman, dean of American theatrical producers and president of the Actors Fund, is confined to the home of his sister, Miss Etta Frohman, at the Hotel Dorset, 30 West Fifty-fourth Street, with injuries he suffered in a fall, it was disclosed yesterday.

After dwelling in the silences or rather in strata of invisibility, for three years, Peter Blume, once a first-prize winner down at Pittsburgh, re-emerged yesterday afternoon with a painted essay on Fascism.
Charles Dundas, the newly appointed Governor of the Bahamas, arrived yesterday from England on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria accompanied by Mrs. Dundas and his aide de camp, Charles Austin.

By HENRY G. WALTEMADE Westchester Ave, n s, whole front between Clason and Taylor Aves, 63x180.7 irregular; Paul Valentine against Fillmore Building Corp; due, $4,370; taxes, etc, $345; to plaintiff for $1,000. By GEORGE J. KEARNS 162d St, 881 E, 2-story dwelling, 22x85; Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank against Albert Jarecky; due, $3,792; taxes, etc., $255; to plaintiff for $1,000.

Governor Lehman will reach a decision within ten days concern-. ing the charges against Albert Marinelli, New York County Clerk, it was learned last night from persons informed of the Governor's attitude toward the case.

Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, speaking yesterday morning at a report meeting of the women's committee of the United Hospital Fund campaign, urged 400 members of the committee, gathered at the Hotel Biltmore, to press on with their efforts to raise the $1,000;000 which is their quota for the current drive.

Governor Lawrence W. Cramer, who was responsible for calling the Legislative Assembly together in the first session provided by the Organic Act, indignantly left an Assembly meeting today because the members refused to consider bills introduced by him.
Simon Elmore, 57-year-old former WPA worker, was found guilty last night of the murder of 4-year-old Joan Kuleba by a jury in County Court, St. George, S. I.

For some time, almost since the' introduction of the chukar partridge to the list of American game birds, there have been discussionseven arguments-as to the possibilities of this bird for field trials.

The Chinese are making a final effort to extract from the Far-Eastern conference something a little stronger than what is now contained in the mild declaration of abstract principles with which it is planned to adjourn tomorrow.

Today's major events: Bedaar Djelal, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Rosalyn Tureck, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Yoichi Hiraoka, xylophonist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Madrigal Singers, WPA Theatre of Music, 8:45 P. M.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday voted to assess a 5 per cent tax on admissions to boxing gymnasiums. The ruling may result in a court battle, since the gymnasium operators are of the opinion that they are outside the commission's jurisdiction.

While New Yorkers and Americans throughout the land prepared to celebrate the traditional Thanksgiving holiday tomorrow, philanthropic and welfare agencies in the city made plans that none might fail to share the national feast day.

Sam H. Grisman, whose four Broadway theatres are being picketed by the Theatrical Managers, Agents and Treasurers Union, said yesterday he had informed his boxoffice employes that they were free to join the union without risk of losing their jobs.

The seat sale for the opening night performance of "Tristan und Isolde" at the Metropolitan Opera House next Monday opened yesterday morning at 9 and closed at 10. At that time the box office announced that every seat in the house was sold.

With assisting, Penn'wrote finis to football practice for the 1937 season today on Franklin Field. Lew Elverson of the 1936 team, Rea McGraw, captain of the undefeated 1924 eleven, and George Munger of the 1932 squad teamed with the freshmen, who are coached by Munger, to give the varsity a much needed practice to perfect its former Pennsylvania football stars pass defense for the Cornell battle on Thursday.
" Sink the Navy!" That is the Army plea and driving force this week as the cadets head toward the end of the football trail and the game with the midshipmen of Annapolis on Saturday.

General Gerardo Machado, former President of Cuba, who has been sought here since 1934 for extradition under charges of murder and embezzlement brought by the Cuban Consul General, will surrender to Garrett W. Cotter, United States Commissioner, next Monday, it was revealed yesterday.

The Brooklyn Heights Association, through its president, Harland B. Tibbetts, renewed yesterday its anti-noise campaign, somewhat jolted on Nov. 19 when Magistrate Sylvester Sabbatino suspended sentence on nine alleged revelers.

A search of a downtown bank today enabled Minister of the Interior Marx Dormoy tonight to give out the first definite information regarding the constitution and purposes of the secret society known as the Cagoulards [the Hooded Ones] to show that they are a Royalist group aiming to restore the monarchy.

Playing like the world champions whom they were opposing, the New York Americans conquered Detroit's Red Wings at Madison Square Garden last night. Red Dutton's skaters counted twice in the first period and once in the second to skate off with a well deserved 3-to-1 triumph.

That the trotting horse breeding industry and the sport of racing standard-bred trotters and pacers is more than holding its own was demonstrated yesterday at the first day of the forty-third annual Old Glory horse auction under the auspices of the Fasig-Tipton Company in the Squadron A Armory.

Miss Anne M. Calder of Bristol, Conn., is this year's holder of the Sarah Streeter Cup, given at Mount Holyoke College since 1914 by the Department of Physical Education. Announcement was made this morning in assembly by President Ham.

-The first award in King George VI's reign of the King's Gold Medal for poetry was made today to Wystan Hugh Auden, 30-year-old poet and dramatist, who was presented to the King by the Poet Laureate, John Masefield.

Funeral services for Howard Coffin, industrial leader whose death here Sunday from a rifle bullet remains a mystery, will be held at 11 A. M. tomorrow. Mr. Coffin's widow, the former Miss Gladys Baker, arrived last night from New York.

Three weeks after the event the Board of Elections was able to announce yesterday that on Nov. 2 the Borough of Manhattan elected six City Councilmen-three Democrats, one Republican, one Fusionist and one candidate of the American Labor party.

Four robbers who lay in wait for him in his own apartment ambushed William Bertelmann, 45 years old, a diamond dealer of 1,366 Clay Avenue, the Bronx, just before 7 o'clock last night and escaped with a wallet estimated to contain nearly $8,000 in gems and cash.

The benefits derived by actors, playwrights and audiences in their experiences with little theatre productions were described by Constance Morrow Morgan, sister of Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, yesterday afternoon in Brooklyn.

The orchestra of Philadelphia, under the direction of that necromancer of the baton, Dr. Leopold Stokowski, performed last night in Carnegie Hall. One might have wished that such powers as are his had been spent on more substantial material, where the first part of the program was concerned.

Tentative demands to be made in behalf of. hotel workers were approved last night at a mass meeting at Mecca Temple, 130 West Fiftysixth Street, attended by about 1,500 members of the Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Organizing Committee, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor.

The appointment of Daniel Willard Jr., now assistant to the genera' counsel of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, as assistant general counsel was announced yesterday by John J. Cornwell, general counsel. Mr. Willard was released by the B. O. in 1931 to serve as general counsel to the Railroad Credit Corporation, later becoming its vice president. The work of the corporatior is being terminated gradually.

A rebellion over money threatens the tranquil relations between RKO and Ginger Rogers. The star has learned that Katharine Hepburn, with whom she appeared in "Stage Door," and Fred Astaire, who is her starring partner in many of her films, have studio deals by which they participate in the profits from their pictures.

The two principal proposals now in the forefront of Washington discussion are a new farm bill and relief from unsound business taxes. Unfortunately, these two propasals are being discussed as if they were unrelated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23.--Stock Exchanges of the country were warned today to raise their administrative and functional techniques in the public interest or face sharper regulations from the Securities and Exchange Commission. The warning came in a statement issued by W. O. Douglas, chairman of the SEC.

A warwounded chemist, tormented by failing sight, and his sister "with beautiful eyes" were found dead today in the stately, -tree-shaded mansion of the Doctors Dancy. Investigators said the melancholy brother, a former military officer, apparently had shot his sister and then committed suicide.

The American Professional Football Association was faced today with a threat by Manager Charles DePhillips to withdraw the Paterson Panthers from the league because the board of directors, although admitting the referee erred in a crucial ruling, refused

Locations in midtown drew the majority of the lessees of business sites comprising yesterday's report by brokers and agents. Many of the firms listed are manufacturers of wearing apparel, while others are engaged in retail enterprises of a varied nature. Abraham Booke, manufacturer of men's hats, took quarters in 28-30 East Fourth Street, through M. L. Hess, Inc., broker.

Mrs. Robert E. Tod entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. George Ross, Mrs. Morin S. Hare, Mrs. Edwin Gould, Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell and Mrs. Arthur Ryle.

Announcement of the appointment by Pope Pius XI of the Rev. John D. Roach, founder and pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Spirit, the Bronx, as domestic prelate, with the title of Right Rev. Monsignor, was made yesterday by the chancery office of the Archdiocese or New York.

Directors of Stone Webster, Inc., at a special meeting yesterday, took steps to divorce the major controlled public utility properties in the Stone Webster system so that the $410,000,000 concern might continue unimpeded by the Publie Utility Holding Company Act its operations in the utility construction and engineering, investment ban%ing and property supervision fields.

New York University's football squad continued work on defensive tactics yesterday afternoon at Ohio Field for its final game of the season with Fordham. More than two hours were devoted to a drill which lasted until dusk. This was followed by an additional workout in the gymnasium.

In Monday's news was announced the acquisition by the Metropolitan Museum of Art of a Greek water jar wrought by unknown hands some two thousand three hundred years ago. It may have known other uses than that for which it was primarily designed, for such vessels served sometimes as cult objects, dedicatory offerings, cinerary urns, ballot boxes and especially' as prizes. This one, of great beauty,

Dr. Alfred Birch Herrick, noted American surgeon, died here yesterday of cancer, in the Panama Hospital, of which he was the head and founder. His age was 64 years. He had been a resident of Panama for thirty-three years.

Democratic leaders of the House announced today that they were unable to induce the Rules Committee to report out a resolution for consideration of the Wages and Hours Bill passed by the Senate last Spring.

The Intercoastal Steamship Freight Association, comprising the twelve principal shin lines operating between Atlantic and Pacific ports, announced yesterday that it would support the railroads in their application for an increase in freight rates of about 15 per cent.

A Labor Member of Parliament told Lady Astor to "keep still" in a debate on malnutrition in the House of Commons today. George Arthur Griffiths was relating how a woman told his family to cook cods' heads.
Speaking of Rose Bowl games, as every one seems to be these days, now that the season is on the wane, putting it poetically, how many followers of the game know when the series started?
After a Cabinet crisis lasting nearly a month, former Premier Paul van Zeeland today turned over his office to his successor, Paul Emile Janson, who announced his new Cabinet.

For the first time in his administration, President Roosevelt will eat his Thanksgiving dinner in the White House tomorrow. Hitherto, while President, Mr. Roosevelt has presided over the Thanksgiving dinner at the Warm Springs Foundation, except for last year, when he was on his way to Buenos Aires.
