The name of the Arnold Bernstein ship lines will be "Aryanized" soon by the government trustee in charge since Herr Bernstein was arrested on charges of violating foreign exchange regulations,

Charles Dundas, newly appointed Governor of the Bahamas, and Mrs. Dundas, who arrived on the Berengaria, are at the St. Regis. With the Governor is his aide-de-camp, Charles Austin. Mr. and Mrs. Francis Biddle are expected to arrive at the Carlyle today from Germantown, Pa.

Mohamed Sahinagic, known as the "Croesus of Bosnia," killed himself today. He was formerly Sarajevo's wealthiest citizen, but when he recently realized he had lost his fortune he sent his last gold coin to a goldsmith whom he ordered to make a bullet out of it.

The Montclair A. C. and Columbia University Club Clasp A squash tennis teams continued to set the pace in Metropolitan League play yesterday, each scoring its fifth straight victory in as many starts of the current campaign.

There was an air of sadness on the French Line pier at West Fiftieth Street 'yesterday morning when- the thirty-five show girls from the French Casino were going up the tourist gangway to the liner Normandie en route for France and England.
The Brooklyn College basketball team will open its 1937-38 campaign in its new gymnasium against Coach Nat Holman's City College quintet Saturday, Dec. 4 Saturday, Dec. 4.

Sales of the 1938 model have reached a new record, W. F. Hufstader, general sales manager of the Buick Division of General Motors announced here today. Output at the factories in Flint and in assembly plants in Linden, N. J., and Los Angeles is at a rate of more than 1,200 cars a day, representing an increase in original November production schedules and bringing employment and payrolls to a new high for this season.

The annual Alumnae Day Thanksgiving chapel of Hunter College was held yesterday morning in the Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street and Lexington Avenue. Alumnae and students participated in the program, part of which honored the memory of Professor George Meason Whicher, former head of the Department of Classics, who died three weeks ago. Dr.

A consent decree whereby the three largest automobile interests in the United States would divest themselves of their subsidiary finance corporations has been proposed by the General Motors, Chrysler and Ford corporations to the Department of Justice, Attorney General Cummings indicated today.
Miss Jane Kaufman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Graveraet Kaufman of this city and Palm Beach, was introduced to society last night at a supper dance given by her parents at Sherry's.
Except for a few schools which have post-season and postponed games to be played, the current schoolboy football campaign in the metropolitan area will officially come to a close today.

Miss Katharine H. Bennett, daughter of John C. Bennett of this place, was married tonight to Henry C. Tappen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry N. Tappen, also of Montclair, at her home. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Victor Mills, pastor of Montclair Methodist Episcopal Church, who was assisted by Dr. Frederick Mooney, pastor of the Methodist Church at Milford, Pa.

The New York Telephone Company instituted suit yesterday in Supreme Court to have the New York City tax on gross utility receipts declared invalid. In the event that the courts uphold a previous ruling that the tax is valid, the company wants a determination that it is only partly liable for taxes on telephone calls originating within the city but terminating outside.

Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to Great Britain; Dr. James Rowland Angell, former president of Yale University, and Mrs. Angell; P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the United States Lines; Mr. and Mrs. M. Jenkins Cromwell and Mrs. C. Benson Dushane Jr. are among the passengers due today from Europe on the steamship Manhattan of the United States Lines.
Trading in grain futures today was of a preholiday character and prices fluctuated erratically within moderate limits, with the action of securities having considerable influence on wheat at times.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Cornell Jameson gave a small dance last night at their home, 9 East Sixty-ninth Street, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Mary Jameson. Autumn decorations prevailed in the rooms given over to entertaining.

Leaving several notes attributing his act to loneliness and despondency over being unemployed, Arthur P. Steinbring, 36 years old, of Route Three, Wilmington, Del., committed suicide yesterday morning in his room at the Hotel Grand, Broadviayand Thirty-first Street, by shooting himself in the chest with an auto-matic pistol. Steinbring, a salesman, was the father of a baby 5 weeks old.

A copy of the rare first edition of Edgar Allan Poe's second work, "Al Aaraaf, Tamerlane, and Minor Poems," was bought by Gabriel Wells for $2,600 yesterday afternoon at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the library of the late George C. Smith Jr. of this city.
President Mikhail Kalinin in a speech in Leningrad yesterday-which was prominently Dublished here today--gave the Soviet explanation of a surprising fact, just now become conclusively evident.
A fiftyfour-hole medal tournament, limited to golf professionals of 50 years and over, will open the P. G. A.'s 1937-38 Winter program at the National Golf Club at Augusta, Ga., Monday.
New rules for the distribution of Christmas calendars by liquor dealers have been promulgated by the New York State Liquor Authority.

The House received assurance from its Labor Committee today that the Wages and Hours Bill, if permitted to come before the chamber for consideration, would be amended to substitute a single administrator in the Department of Labor for the independent five-man board now provided for the executive agency.

Virginia Lee Corbin Krol, 26 years old, juvenile screen star of fifteen years ago, was sued for divorce today by Theodore Krol, Chicago broker. His petition charged cruelty and asked custody of their children, Harold Phillip, 5, and Robert Lee,

" Creative thinking" by sales promotion executives will be a premium in retail stores in 1938, it is emphasized in the Retailers' Calendar and Promotional Guide for next year, issued yesterday by the sales-promotion division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. The calendar contains a day-by-day enumeration of special weeks and days in 1938 which offer promotional possibilities.

Frank L. Nowosatka, 34 years old, the first of the coal dealers in this city to be arrested fifteen months ago in the drive by Assistant District Attorney John C. McDermott against bootlegging of coal stolen from Pennsylvania mines, pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a misdemeanor conspiracy indictment. Judge Allen released him in $2,500 bail pending sentence Dec. 3.

The great outdoors called Metro today and announcement was made of the acquisition of Sir Gilbert Parker's "She of the Triple Chevron" which formed the basis some years ago of Edgar Selwyn's play "Pierre of the Plains." MGM along with other lots has noted a revived

Willis McFeeley, former Village President of Oak Park, a Chicago suburb, died today in the Edward Hines Jr. Memorial Hospital. Mr. McFeeley was 69 years old. Born in Buda, Ill., Jan. 1, 1868, he came here forty years ago.

Appointment of John Eardley, assistant appraiser in the customs service in New York in charge of the Textiles Division since 1923, as deputy appraiser of merchandise was announced today by Secretary Morgenthau. Mr. Eardley will have supervision over technical valuation decisions under the tariff laws and will be responsible for the training of personnel in appraisal methods.
Bennett Brothers Johnson have proposed to retire as New York Stock Exchange members on Dec. 2. James R. Sanderson retired from Grover O'Neill Co. on Nov. 15.

Capin Fritz Wiedemann, one of ree personal adjutants to Chan??or Adolf Hitler and his friend ?? many years, will arrive in New ork from Germany tomorrow ac??mpanied by his wife for what, ?? far as is known here, is solely private visit to see the United ates for the first time.

Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN-William T. Cox. 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Nov. 18, 1912. Temporary Assignments SERGEANTS-John Grunewald, from 75th Precinct to 18th Division, duty in Distric Attorney's office, Queens County, for 1 day.

By reducing the coffee export tax from 45 milreis to 12 milreis a bag and lifting exchange restrictions, Brazil has materially increased coffee exports. Incidentally, as a result of the exchange freedom and tax reduction, Brazil will be out about $40,000,000 despite the fact that greatly increased exports of all products should benefit her favorable trade balance.

The Ford Motor Company today won a victory when charges of felonious assault, brought against the company and eight individuals by organizers of the United Automobile Workers of America, were dismissed in the Circuit Court.

Intrastate freight rate increases ranging up to 10 per cent on six basic commodities were ordered here today by the State Public Utilities Commission. A hearing on the proposal of twenty-six railroads in New Jersey for the increases was held yesterday by the commission. The order is effective on Dec. 1.

Thomas E. Cross, former president of the New York State Horticultural Society, died in his home at Lagrangeville of a heart attack today. He was 76 years old. Mr. Cross was the founder of the New York and New England Apple Institute,

The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to await for a reasonable .time developments in connection with reorganization proposals by officials of the New York Stock Exchange before taking positive steps to put into effect by edict administrative and functional reforms which William O. Douglas, chairman of the commission, said yesterday were essential to the protection of investors.

The Excelsior Mutual Building and Loan Association sold three sixfamily flats on a plot 106 by 79 feet at 101-5 Ege Avenue and a six-family flat at 97 Old Bergen Road, Jersey City, to the P. , S. Holding Company.
A light Thanksgiving repast followed by a bountiful feast at the football board on Saturday constitute the menu for the last big week of the season.

Incorporation of the Stradivarius Memorial Association, which will have its headquarters at 130 West Fifty-seventh Street, was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel. One of the principal purposes of the society is to assist talented musical students by making available to them, by loan or gift, fine musical instruments of recognized masters.

Mrs. Samuel Simpson Logan of Chestnut Hill has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Josephine Simpson Logan, to John Lenord Merrill Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Lenord Merrill of Greenwich, Conn.

Tomorrow will be the last day of the Paris International Exposition, and it is still uncertain whether it will reopen next year. The day will be one of music, furnished by military bands from many nations, and the admission price will be reduced.

Asserting that the policies of the Roosevelt administration are responsible for the business recession, Senator Wheeler demanded today that Congress give to business an assurance of safety "lest the pendulum swing to the reactionaries."
Elections of student officers in nineteen lasses -in the Art and Engineering Schools of Cooper Union were announced yesterday by
Roger Kent, Inc., has introduced at its 40 Wall Street shop an "individual cutting" department. Paul Salmon, formerly manager of the 15 East Forty-fifth Street store, is in charge.

No bickering about football now. It might spoil the day and the digestion. -One big debate is off the Thanksgiving menu, anyhow. That's the Fordham-N. Y. U. football festival. It was decided to allow the Fordham players two more days in which to catch their breath after the St. Mary's encounter.
MANHATTAN CHRISTENSEN, FRANCES (Nov. 21). Estate, less than $1,000. To Ludwig Christensen, husband, executor, 333 E. 53d St. EDDY, JOSEPH D. (Nov. 5). Estate, more than $10,000.

Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., were the brokers in the recent sale of 157 and 159 Tenth Avenue to Benjamin Gottfried, who owns the adjoining parcels at 153 and 155. The property at 157 was bought from the Edwin Gould Foundation for Children and 159 from Hildagarde H. Hold, represented by the Cruikshank Company.

BAYLES-Funeral service for Charles M. Bayles will be held Friday, Nov. 26, at 2:30 o'clock at the Kimble Funeral Home, Princeton, N. J. BERRY-Isabelle D., widow of Jacob Berry, after a short illness, grandmother of Forrest B. Lindley, Lita Lawrence Alexander, and Gladys Vivian Butler. Services at Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave., Saturday, 11 A. M. Interment private.
The engagement of Miss Dorothy Heverin Wells, daughter of Mrs. John Barnes Wells of this place and the late Mr. Wells of New York, to Dr. Woodbridge Edwards Morris has been announced by her mother.

Edward H. Theis, deputy supreme dictator and New York State regional director of the Loyal Order of Moose, died in his home here today. He was 64 years old. The Moose, Masons and Elks will conduct funeral services fer him at the Theis home Friday evening.

Miss Juliet Vineberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Vineberg of 219 West Eighty-first Street, was married last night in the Terrace Club of the St. Moritz to Irving J. Newman, son of Mrs. Frederick Newman of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Newman, by the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson of Temple Emanu-El.

" Judged by common sense it is now time for China to make peace but it is up to China to decide. Japan is determined to fight till China hoists the white flag," General Kozushige Ugaki told foreign correspondents today.
A decline in the steel industry's operations over a ten-week period left more than 500,000 men today on curtailed work schedules.

Sheikh Farhan al Sadi, one of the most active leaders of Arab terrorist bands in Palestine, today was condemned to death by the newly instituted military court at Haifa. This was the first verdict announced since the establishment on Nov. 18 of special military courts in accordance with the provisions of emergency regulations.

Mr. and Mrs. Schuyler Van Vechten gave a dinner dance last night in the Green Room of Sherry's for thei debutante daughter, Miss Nina Riker Van Vechten. Miss Van Vechten will also be the guest of honor at a reception to be given by her maternal grandmother, Mrs. James Remsen Strong, on Dec. 22 at the Colony Club.
The Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce reported today that the preliminary adjusted index figure of the value of retail sales of new passenger automobiles increased

John E. Voegelin, a pioneer of the rayon silk industry in the United States and for many years foreign sales manager of the Viscose Company of New York, rayon silk manufacturers, died last night in his home here. He was 53 years old.
Dr. Louis Victor Saar, pianist and composer, died in a hospital here yesterday at the age of 69. He had been in the hospital only a day, suffering from an ear abscess.

A person who remains at work when his colleagues are striking is not a strike-breaker if he does not manifest "any affirmative action whatsoever toward breaking up the strike," Magistrate William Klapp ruled yesterday in a decision handed down in Washington Heights Court.

Tau Beta Pi, national engineering honor fraternity, announced yesterday the election of eleven new members. They included an alumnus, a professor and nine undergraduates of the Columbia University School of Engineering.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as especially suitable for young persons by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of. pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools. The list follows:

A further sharp decrease in industrial production, as a result of which the Seasonally adjusted index for October dropped to 103 per cent of the 1923-25 average, compared with 111 per cent in September and an average of 116 per cent in the first eight months of the year, was reported today by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.

John Steinbeck, author of "Of Mice and Men" (Covici, Friede), is now living in a cabin in the Sierra Mountains and working on a new novel which he hopes to complete in about six months. The setting for the novel is America's Dust Bowl.

Reports from Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, say that the Italian authorities have reached an agreement with the noted Indian concern of Mohammed Ali and have acquired its property at a fairly reasonable price. They have undertaken to transfer the concern's liquid assets to London in sterling at market rates.

The largest flying boat ever built in this country tested her tremendous wings for the first time today with two flights. The 63,000-pound craft, built by Glenn L. Martin for the Russian Government, taxied on the water for several miles.

The marriage of Miss Gertrude Liepe of 120 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Edward Liepe, to Henry A. Krooss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Krooss of Forest Hills, took place yesterday afternoon in the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. J. Lane Miller.

The governors of the New York Curb Exchange have approved the applications of Frank C. Masterson and Leonard M. Totten for reinstatement to regular membership. Both are members of the firm of Frank C. Masterson Co., which announced its failure to meet engagements on May 27.

The probability of organization Democrats controlling the City Council by a narrow margin increased slightly yesterday as the count of the vote neared its end in Queens and made substantial progress in the Bronx and Brooklyn.
The House approved today a bill to exempt Federal credit unions from all taxation except on real and tangible personal property.
Two nations honored Emily P. Bissell of Wilmington today at the unveiling of a bronze tablet commemorating her introduction of Christmas Seals to this country thirty years ago.

The marriage of Miss Esther Field Miller, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Miller of this city and the late Victor B. Miller, to Anthony Kivic, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kivic of Milford, Conn., took place this evening at the Ridgeview Congregational Church here. The Rev. Dr. William Dana Street, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

The Japanese Army announced today the capture of the important strategic walled town of Huchow, south of Tai Lake, thereby severing the Hangchow-Changying highway and making possible a flanking movement northward along the lake's western shore.
Senator Josh Lee, Oklahoma Democrat, said in the Senate today that the cotton-surplus problem would be solved "if we could get the 450,000,000 Chinese to lengthen their shirt tails half an inch.

The thrice-amended plan of reorganization for the $900,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company has been redrafted again and in its new form it was presented yesterday to the United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., for approval.
MANHATTAN BEROLZHEIMER, BELLE (March 16, 1937). Gross assets, $40,,752; net, $37,647. To Daniel D. Berolzheimer, son, and Violet Berolzheimer, daughter-in-law, one-half residue each;

The Federal Theatre Project announces the establishment of a central bureau which will furnish to amateur and little theatre groups plays on modern social problems. Under the auspices of the project's National Service Bureau,
The State Department told a delegation today that the United States still was trying to obtain the release of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Fernandez Villa from long terms in a Spanish Insurgent prison.

Charged with having failed to maintain an orderly market in Nash-Kelvinator capital stock Oct. 19, John J. Phelan, a specialist on the New York Stock Exchange, has been.prohibited from acting as a specialist for three months and publicly censured by Charles R. Gav. president of the Exchange.
The Tnion Temple quintet conquered the University of Newark, 36--31, at the Temple court in Brooklyn last night. Lester Trokle was high scorer for the winners with twelve points.

Business recovery depends on the cooperation of business men with a Congress that desires to close its term with the record of having restored peace and contentment in the business world; Representative Thomas H. Cullen declared yesterday at 'a luncheon in his honor in the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn. He was the guest of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Because of a wrangle over adjournment, the House will meet on Thanksgiving Day for the first time in many years. The session is scheduled to last for only a moment or so, however, with Speaker Bankhead and Representative Rayburn, the Democratic leader, pledged to adjourn the body over to Monday, when the Farm Bill will be brought up under unanimous consent for three days of debate.

Spirit is running high on Columbia's football squad as it approaches the last game of the season against Stanford, erstwhile Rose Bowl rival, with whom the Lions will clash on Saturday at Baker Field.

Preident Roosevelt discussed utility policies with Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the boards of the Consolidated Edison Company and the Niagara-Hudson Company, and worked on his housing message to Congress.

Trends in the world social and political scene are likely to receive thorough discussion when professors of history from leading Eastern colleges gather Friday at Russell Sage College for a two-day conference.
Distillers produced 7,877,273 gallons of whisky in October as compared with 20,298,951 gallons in October one year ago, the alcohol tax unit of the Treasury reported today.

William G. Kohler, former auditor of the New York Life Insurance Company and brother of Charles L. Kohler, former city Budget Director, died on Tuesday night in his home, at 2 Horatio Street, after an illness of two months. He was 61 years old.

Mrs. Wiley E. Woodbury gave a dinner for her debutante daughter, Miss Nancy Mae Woodbury, last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Afterward Miss Woodbury and her young friends went to the dance given for Miss Dorothy Aylesworth, who was one of the guests at the dinner.

In a beautiful passage in a very old best-seller one of the characters makes a promise to another: "While the earth remaineth seedtime and harvest, and cold and heat, and Summer and Winter, and day and night, shall not cease."

Prices paid to trappers on skunk, opossum and muskrat skins show a further cut of 10 to 20 per cent under the Nov. 1 prices, with raccoon, mink, red fox and gray fox showing no change, according to the price list dated Dec. 1, issued yesterday by Milton Schreiber, 135 West Twenty-seventh Street.

To the recurrent woes of Father Divine's "angels" was added yesterday another fire. Starting mysteriously on the second floor of an old-law red brick tenement at 232 West 124th Street, it virtually de-stroyed the interior of the threestory building-blackening without obliterating the legend "Peace" on the door.

Henry Ford said in an interview today that he was confident the present session of Congress would accomplish "something really constructive" to aid American business, and added he was sure "the United States will not be drawn into another World War, because there are 2,000,000 well-educated veterans here who know the futility of such conflict."

Two suspended policemen and two civilians entered not guilty pleas in General Sessions yesterday to an indictment charging firstdegree robbery, grand larceny, criminally receiving stolen property and second-degree assault in an alleged hold-up early last Sept. 26 in a Ninth Avenue restaurant.

Four convicts are to be deported at once under the provisions of a commutation of sentence granted by Governor Lehman today. In each case, the Governor stated, a substantial part of the sentence had been served.

" Gay Blades," the ice extravaganza that made its debut here on Nov. 15, returned for a one-night stand last night and drew an official attendance of 14,102-several hundred more than its previous record.

The high-scoring Toronto Maple Leafs will make their first appearance of the season in Madison Square Garden tonight when they take the ice against the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League struggle.

Miss Katherine Munro Goodwin was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. George Munro Goodwin of 57 East Eighty-eighth Street, in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.

A trimotored transport monoplane which had developed a jammed landing gear between Springfield, Mass., and Hartford, Conn., was able to make a normal landing at the Newark Airport here at 4:35 P. M. today.
The American Federation of Labor, hitherto a champion of the Administration's Wage-and-Hour Bill, has now come out against it, and the reason given for this change of front is interesting.

If you have been planning a trip to Pasadena for the Rose Bowl game, you may as well stay home. Ted Priestley, University of California graduate manager, said today 33,000 California alumni and stadium script holders, each entitled to six tickets, probably would fill the bowl's 80,000 seats New Year's Day.

In a brief filed with the Federal Trade Commission today the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which is charged by the commission with violating the Robinson-Patman Act, asserted that the case had its genesis in misinformation and a mistaken idea as to the buying methodsa of the A. P. company.

Lieutenant Greenock, 4-yearold gelding, won today's feature race at Tanforan over six furlongs. The time, on a heavy track, was 1:16. Below Zero ran second and City Slicker third. Cisneros, thoroughbred from the Argentine, was fourth. The favorite, Jargo, failed to threaten.
Today's major events: Phillharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P. M.; New. York Hippodrome Company, "Hansel and Gretel," 2:45 P. M., and "Traviata," 8:15 P. M.

The first large picket demonstration since the police were instructed to restrict mass picketing two weeks ago occurred last night in front of the Horn Hardart automat on Broadway between Fortysixth and Forty-seventh Streets at 10:45 o'clock as Times Square was well filled with theatre crowds.

Mr. and Mrs. Merlin Hall Aylesworth gave a dance last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria to introduce to socity their daughter, Miss Dorothy Aylesworth. The debutante, who received with her parents, wore a gown of white organza with silver sequin oval motifs, and carried a semi-old-fashioned bouquet of gardenias bound with blue satin ribbon. Mrs. Aylesworth wore a gown of gold lame.

The Board of Transportation has instructed the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company to discontinue operation of trains into the Thirty-third Street terminal beginning Dec. 5, so that reconstruction of the terminal in connection with the building of the Sixth Avenue subway line may start on that date.

Employment on WPA projects throughout the United States increased 36,613 between Sept. 25 and Nov. 6, it was learned today from Works Progress Administration officials. The WPA rolls reached the low point for 1937 on Sept. 25 with

A tea dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. Allen Skinner Hubbard of 800 Park Avenue yesterday in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis to introduce their daughter, Miss Harriet Elizabeth Hubbard. Miss Hubbard and her parents received before a bower of cybotium ferns and smilax.

It was learned today that Portland, at the eastern end of the island, had suffered most in last night's cloudburst. Fifty deaths were reported when a swift river torrent swept through the . mountain village.
Ray Schalk of Chicago, former catching star of the American League, and one-time manager of the White Sox, signed tonight as pilot of the Indianapolis club of the American Association for 1938.
Governor Hoffman appointed Joseph G. Buch of Trenton today to succeed former United States Senator W. Warren Barbour as a member of the New Jersey Unemployment Compensation Commission.

The first ten railroads to report for October showed declines in both gross revenues and net operating income. In recent months, gross revenues had shown a tendency to run ahead of last year's levels, although, because of increased expenses, net had decreased.

La La Success and Skerbeck Flame, a pair of high-stepping brown ponies from the stables of Miss Judy King of Atlanta, completed a grand slam at the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show tonight by winning the tandem harness event.

The better tendency which developed in late dealings in the stock market here yesterday was well maintained today and most sections went ahead. Gilt-edged issues advanced in general, but foreign bonds were idle for the most part.

The New York Savings Bank sold to Ostreicher Brothers the six-story apartment house on a plot 86 by 120 feet at 540 West 165th Street. L. W. Osterweis represented the buyer of the house, which was renovated recently.

Manhattan 59th St, 57-59 E, 36.8x100.5; for 2-story offices and stores; Nielmo Realty Corp, 502 Park Ave, owner; Charles Glaser, architect; cost, $35,000. Alterations Riverside Dr, 790; to 12-story and penthouse tenement; Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave, owner; D. E. Waid, architect; cost, $175,000.
The Treasury Procurement Division today invited bids on the following lots of textiles, the bids to be opened Dec. 6, and the goods to be shipped 50 per cent by Jan. 15 and 50 per cent by March 15:

Robert Boothby, Conservative Member of Parliament, who is generally regarded as a spokesman for the City financial interests, violently attacked President Roosevelt in the House of Commons today for "fantastic blunders" that he said imperiled the capitalist system throughout the world.

In observance of Thanksgiving. Day, banks, security and commodity exchanges as well as livestock and produce markets throughout the United States will be closed today. Foreign markets will be open as usual.

The news of yesterday's two-andone-half-hour conference that Julius Maniu, head of the National Peasant party, had with Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, leader of the.AntiSemitic Iron Guard, caused considerable sensation today.

Miss Eliner B. Price of this city was married this morning to Harold E. Keenan of Plainfield, city editor of The Plainfield CourierNews. The ceremony was performed in St. Patrick's Church here by the Rev. David J. Price, a cousin of the bride, who also was the celebrant of the nuptial mass that followed.

Leland Ave, 1,218, 50x100; William Haigh Van Dusen, trustee, against Cormar Holding Corp; due $13,637; taxes, etc., $507; to plaintiff for $10,500. By GEORGE J. KEARNS Hughes Ave, 2,155, 2-story frame dwelling, 16.8x95; Home Owners Loan Corp against Anna Ansanelli: due $6,982; taxes, etc., S61: to plaintiff for $1,100.

Irving Ben Cooper, special counsel to Paul Blanshard, Commissionor of Accounts, will be named a City Magistrate at the first of the year to succeed Henry H. Curran, who is resigning his post on the bench to become Deputy Mayor, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

The fifteen-story President Monroeloft and store building, covering the north blockfront on Prince Street, from Crosby to Lafayette Streets, was sold yesterday at auotion on a bid of $550,000 by the Irving Trust Company, as trustee, the plaintiff in an action to recover on a judgment of $1,309,093 against the 63 Prince Street Corporation, defendant.

In the report of the filing of a petition of bankruptcy by Benjamin Winter, real estate operator, in THE NEW YORK TIMES of NOV. 17, the Trade Bank of New York and the Manufacturers Trust Company were said to hold judgments for $50,708 against the petitioner.
The Navy Department announced today the award of fourteen contracts totaling $1,033,553 for 712,900 barrels of fuel oil to meet East Coast requirements for the first part of 1938.

Mr. and Mrs. Lester Stokes Abberley of 130 Lincoln Road, Brooklyn, and Fairfield, Conn., gave a supper party last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Abberley, to John Taylor Arms 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Taylor Arms of Fairfield.

President Roosevelt's endorsement of the national sale of Christmas seals was made public yesterday by the 1937 City-wide Christmas Seal Appeal Headquarters. The national sale will start today and continue until Christmas. The local goal is $350,000.

John Iraci, New York radio executive, died yesterday afternoon at his Brooklyn home, 440 Eighty-third Street, of a heart attack. Mr. Iraci had announced to his associates a week ago at WOV-WBIL that he needed a rest but did not complain of being ill.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Noble of Round Hill, Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margarita Noble, to Dr. Howard Paul Serrell, also of Greenwich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Paul Serrell of Montvale, N. J.

Retail package deliveries showed a decline of 10 per cent under a year ago for the week ended Nov. 20, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. This compared with a decrease of 6 per cent for the preceding week. For the four weeks ending on Nov. 20, the delivery organization reported a decline of 4 per cent. For the preceding four weeks' period no change from a year ago was reported.

Although a turkey dinner has been promised to them, and possibly a motion-picture show in the afternoon, the fourteen members of the Federal grand jury charged with determining whether major oil companies of the nation and their officials conspired to "rig" gasoline prices, resigned themselves tonight to a lonesome Thanksgiving.
No matter who controls the City Council, one thing is certain. New York henceforth has Councilmen.

There could be very little doubt in the mind of any visitor to Ford?? yesterday who reached the campus at noon or later as to just what was the most important item of business facing the student body.

It was reported by The Daily Mail tonight and confirmed by relatives and friends that the Duchess of Manchester, the former Cincinnati heiress, Helena Zimmerman, was married secretly to the Earl of Kintore in Edinburgh yesterday. The Earl a Scotsman is 58.

Criticism of the plan to replace 400 policemen on special details by civilians was expressed yesterday at a hearing before the finance committee of the Board of Aldermen by former Police Inspector Thomas P. Cummings, who spoke as secretary of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

Matt A. Daly, Cincinnati portrait and landscape painter, died in his studio here today of a heart attack. He was 78 years old. Mr. Daly attended the School of Design here, the Cincinnati Art Academy and studied for fifteen

Deaths Announced Retired Lieutenant Dennis V. Short, formerely a member of Eng. 257, residing at 1,652 Marine Parkway, Brooklyn, died Nov. 24. Funeral will take place from his late residence at 9:30 A. M. Friday, Nov. 26. The Deputy Chief of the 12th Division shall detail one captain, one lieutenant and twelve firemen as funeral escort.

The Archduke Franz Josef, member of a branch of the former ruling house of Austria, visited the site of the world's fair of 1939 on the Flushing meadows yesterday. The Archduke and his bride are visiting this country on their wedding trip.

Isidor A. Rabinow, 45 years old, a lawyer, of 317 West Fifty-fifth Street, was convicted by a Genera Sessions jury yesterday of the theft of $500 from a client. Judge Freschi remanded him to the Tombs for sentence Dec. 6.

The British Government, which hopes that the proposed Anglo-American trade agreement will strengthen its ties with the United States, may endeavor to consolidate American friendship by declaring its willingness to-resume "token" payments on the war debt at some future time.

While manufacturers' total sales of all types of confectionery and competitive chocolate products combined for October of this year were slightly above October, 1936, they declined 0.8 per cent from September, of this year, the Commerce Department reported today. Sales during October this year amounted to $28,015,062, as against $28,237,124 for September.

The War Department called today for redemption on Jan. 2, 1938, the due date, outstanding bonds, which total $410,000 of the $1,000,000 4 per cent issue of the series of 1908 of the city of Manila. The issue was for sewers and waterworks.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. Fullan of Forest Hills Gardens of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Buckley Fullan, to William J. Butler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Butler of this city, and Great Neck, L. I. Miss Fullan was graduated from the Sacred Heart Convent in this city, and is a sophomore at Trinity College in Washington.
After fiftysix years of continuous service George W. (Gravy) Barnes, Western Union telegraph operator assigned to handle messages for The Chicago Tribune, is to be retired on a pension Nov. 30.
Mayor La Guardia and Fire Commissioner McElligott witnessed a demonstration at City Hall yesterday by two new searchlight trucks recently bought by the Fire Department.

Emphasizing the need for cooperation and mutual understanding between capital and labor, Bishop William T. Manning, speaking at a Thanksgiving luncheon of the Kiwanis Club at the Hotel McAlpin, declared yesterday that the economic radicals of this country were the "real Tories and blind reactionaries."

A suggestion that dates for the payment of liquor purchased by retailers in any month be regulated according to the time of the month that orders were placed will be carried to the State Liquor Authority by a special committee of the New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, it was disclosed yesterday.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Nov. 23 unless specified: Antares, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Balch, at San Diego. Blue, at Guantanamo Bay. Brazos, San Pedro to Pearl Harbox.
For the twenty-fifth time since 1886, according to police records, Marcel de Passy faced curious officials yesterday and still introduced himself as "Count."

Reversing its present policy, the Board of Education will allocate money for school building repairs and alterations on a city-wide rather than a borough basis in its 1938 program, Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the building and site committee, announced yesterday.
Roger D. Lapham, president of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company since 1925, has been elected chairman of the board of directors. John E. Cushing has been made president, effective Jan. 1, 1938.

The New York Trust Company sold to Leo Silver the five-story apartment house for twenty families at 1,048 Boynton Avenue, the Bronx. Assessed at $45,000, the property is 50 by 100 feet and was sold for cash over a mortgage of $38,500 at 4 per cent for five years. Hoffman, Snyder Co. were the brokers. Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, represented the buyer and Middlebrook Sincerbeaux the seller.

The marriage of Miss Rae Epstein of Brooklyn, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Moses Baruch Epstein, to Henry L. Finkelstein, son of Mrs. David Finkelstein of Jackson Heights and the late Mr. Finkelstein, took place last night at the Park Lane.

The Bureau of navigation released the following orders ??day, dated Nov. 22: Marshall, Rear Admiral A. W., Naval Operation, Navy Dep't, to duty as President of the Naval Examining Board Navy Dep't, on Jan. 13: laxter, Comdr. T., San Francisco, Calif., to continue treatment at the Naval Hospital, Mare Island, Calif., on discharge from treatment, to home, relieved from all active duty.

The tiger skin given to Mayor La Guardia by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler as a trophy of his election was taken from City Hall yesterday to the La Guardia home at 1,274 Fifth Avenue, where it will decorate the room of the Mayor's 7-year-old son, Eric.

District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan of Brooklyn suddenly be-' came ill yesterday in his office on the fourth floor of the Brooklyn Municipal Building and was placed on a stretcher and taken in a private ambulance to his home at 1,842 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.

Lord Tweedsmuir, speaking here tonight on "Return to Masterpieces," undertook to put Shakespeare into the speech of a Hollywood sound picture. He defined poetry as "the best words in the best order" and the greatest poetry as "the only possible words in the only possible order."

Captain Walter N. Joyce, national patriotic instructor of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, died last night in the United States Veterans Hospital, No. 81, Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx. He was about 80 years old.

The engagement of Miss Clara Victoria Nance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Herndon Nance of this place, to George William Kay Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kay of Garden City, has been announced by her parents.

Thanksgiving guests began to arrive in Newport today and the celebration of the holiday began this evening when Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, who have Mr. and Mrs. Crawford Hill, Mr. and Mrs. C. Oliver O'Donnell, Mr. and Mrs. Howard G. Cushing and William Hunter as their house guests, gave a large dinner at Oakland Farm.

Bailey Ave (12-3259), n e cor of West Kingsbridge Rd, 130x75; KingCail Holding Corp to Max Olesker, 98 Riverside Dr, 6 per cent: $21,000. Boynton Ave, 1,048 (14-3715); Northpel Realty Corp to 1,048 Boynton Ave Corp. 100 Broadway; $38,500.

Miss Natalie Gauss, daughter of Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University and Mrs. Gauss, was married to George Storer Stephenson of New York at noon today. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert R. Wicks, dean of the university chapel, in Joseph Henry House, the Gauss residence. Only the immediate families were invited to the wedding.

Simon Elmore, 57-year-old WPA painter, convicted Tuesday night in the murder of Joan Kuleba, 4, was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair the week of Dec. 26 by Judge Thomas S. Cosgrove in County Court, St. George, S. I.
If George and Stephen du Pont do not get home to the United States for Thanksgiving dinner it will not be their fault. Today they flew as far as Port Au Prince.

W. Rossiter Redmond, Brooklyn lawyer and son-in-law of Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber, who is awaiting trial in Kings County Court on an indictment charging grand larceny, has presented a check for $1,719 in payment of funds due the estate of Miss Mary L. Brady in White Plains.

Fire Chief Archie M. Heath, 64 years old, a fireman forty years, died today in Mountainside Hospital of injuries suffered Saturday night in an automobile accident in Broughton Avenue, where he had gone to answer a false alarm.

Recently the Hebrew Free Loan Society has had a substantial sum of money lying idle in banks. This has been worrying S. Herbert Golden, chairman of its ways and means committee, so yesterday he started a campaign to inform poor people they can borrow without paying one cent for interest or other charges.

More than 1,500 delegates, representing scores of trade unions and labor groups throughout the United States and Canada, will assemble at the Pennsylvania Hotel tomorrow for the thirteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine, it was announced yesterday by Isaac Hamlin, national secretary.

Yoichi Hiraoka, who plays the xylophone, ostensibly an instrument of limited possibilities, gave a recital at the Town Hall last night and made music with the distinction of an artist. His touch was so delicate, his sense of style so penetreating and his command of color and nuance so subtle that he caused the xylophone to sing with the variety of one of the lordlier members of the instrumental family.

Minister of Justice Franz Guertner is reported to have made a personal appeal to Chancellor Hitler to obtain the release of the Rev. Martin Niemoeller, Confessional church leader. He was not successful.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice A. Littlehales, niece of Charles Henry Littlehales of Waterbury, Conn., to the Rev. Dr. Richard S. M. Emrich, son of Mrs. Jeannette Wallace Emrich of New York and the late Rev. Richard S. M. Emrich, took place here yesterday afternoon in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church in Stuyvesant Square.

The St. Francis College quintet opened its campaign last night by sweeping to a 50-13 verdict over the alumni on the victors' Brooklyn court. The varsity gained an early lead and increased it to 20-7 at the intermission.

Miss Mabel C. Beecher, a teacher in the New Rochelle public schools since 1904, suffered a heart attack while driving her automobile here last night and was pronounced dead when friends took her to the New Rochelle Hospital five minutes later.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Patterson of Haverford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catharine Hansell Patterson, to William Innes Forbes Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. William Innes Forbes of Scrooby, Villanova.

Brown rules a slight favorite over Rutgers in tomorrow's concluding game for both teams on Brown Field. The game is the revival of a series that shows only one previous game, the two teams having met in 1916, when Brown won, 21 to 3.

A lease for approximately 40,000 square feet of space taken by the Eastern Isles Importing Company, Inc., underwear and kindred lines firm, at 45 West Eighteenth Street, featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis Anthony Keating of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Keating, to Maurice Alexander Smith 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Alexander Smith of Himount. Greensburg, Pa.

Forty planes ordered by the Royal Australian Air Force from the Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation are now unlikely to be the NA-16's originally ordered but NA33's, an improved type with a maximum speed considerably higher than the NA-16's 220 miles an hour.

Another question concerning imposition of a Federal income tax upon the salary of a State employe was put before the Supreme Court by the government today. Review was asked of a Third Circuit Court decision granting immunity from this taxation to Clarence M. Freedman, a special deputy Attorney General of Pennsylvania.

During the past week a number of events, all similar in character, were held in order that certain shotgun shooters might have a turkey on the table today. In almost every instance these affairs were characterized "old-fashioned turkey shoots."

While the business recession will continue until late Spring or early Summer, a year from now industrial activity will most likely be on an upward trend, Dr. Joseph E. Goodbar, president of the Society for Stability in Money and Banking, declared yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Executives' Club at thd Hotel Astor.

Senator Lester H. Clee, defeated Republican candidate for Governor, made a net gain of four votes today in the recount in the Hudson County vote being conducted by the Board of Elections. The new totals reduced the gain of Governor-elect A. Harry Moore to five votes. The boxes counted were in the first, second and third districts in the Fourth Ward in Harrison.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 15,000, including 7,000 directs. The market was 10 to 15 cents higher than Tuesday's average but closed with part of the advance lost.

Bedaar Djelal, Turkish violinist, made her debut last night in a recital at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Society for the Advancement of Young Musicians. With Josef Adler at the piano, she was heard in a program the first of which was devoted to Corelli's "La Folia," the Bach "Chaconne" and the Saint-Saens concerto in B minor.

Members of the College Fraternities Secretaries Association, representing more than fifty national organizations in colleges throughout the country, made a preliminary survey of problems affecting these

With much of the statement of William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, there can be no valid disagreement. This is particularly true of his discussion regarding what the general aims of governmental control ought to be.

An award of $1,000 and a medal, voted by the American Committee. for Research in Syphilis to Professor Julius Wagner-Jauregg of Vienna for presentation a few months from now, was made yesterday morning at a hurriedly called meeting after it was learned that Dr. Wagner-Jauregg,

A. S. Burleson, former Postmaster General died of heart disease at his home here this morning. He was 74 years old. Members of his family found him suffering intense pain, and a physician was immediately summoned, but he died before the physician's

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Middleton Gibson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Huntley Gibson of this City, to Stewart Bryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Stewart Bryan, also of Richmond.

Mrs. Anson W. Hard of 440 Park Avenue, New York, and Haverford introduced her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Avery, tonight to Philadelphia society at a ball which she gave in the Bellevue-Stratford Rose Garden. Six hundred and fifty guests attended and the garden was transformed to represent a French village.

The first evidence of a possible reversal in the downward trend in steel production is given in the weekly summary by The Iron Age, issued yesterday. Output is estimated for the current week at 33 per cent of capacity, down 2 points from last Week, but 2 points higher than the estimate of 31 per cent made on Monday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Dartmouth Forensic Union announced today that five debaters would engage in a series of twenty debates with colleges throughout the Southeastern States. The trip will start this week-end and continue through Dec. 10.

Colonel Ernest L. Isbell, World War commander of the 102d Connecticut Infantry Regiment, died yesterday in the Veterans' Hospital at Bay Pines, Fla., it was learned here tonight. By profession a lawyer, Colonel Isbell served in the Spanish-American War and at the Mexican border in 1916. He took the 102d overseas and commanded it until January, 1918. Later he had charge of a rest camp in France.

Miss Marian Ruth Bingham, daughter of William W. Bingham Sr. of this city, was married tonight to Theodore P. Ralli, son of Mrs. T. P. Ralli, also of Nutley, in the Kilburn Memorial Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Samuel D. Chambers, the pastor, officiated.

Action designed to prevent M. Preston Goodfellow, publisher of The Brooklyn Eagle, from taking part in the mediation proceedings started by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, for settlement of the- strike of employes of the paper affiliated with the Aiherican Newspaper Guild was taken yesterday by a committee of twelve representing non-striking employes claiming to be a majority.

The Pennsylvania Military College polo team tonight defeated Cornell, 11 to 101/4/. It was the opening indoor match for both trios, and Corriell was the pre-game favorite. Bud Maloney for the Chester cadets and Art Christian for the Ithacans led in scoring with seven goals each.

In keeping with the spirit ol the day, the New York Giants and the Brooklyn Dodgers will be seeking something to be thankful for when they meet this afternoon at Ebbets Field in their annual holiday gridiron classic which starts at 2:15 o'clock.

Three men were dead and a fourth in serious condition here tonight, with poisoning from wood alcohol given as the cause of death. The men were members of the crew of the Norwegian freighter Blink, docked at Pugwash, fifteen miles away, after a trip from Philadelphia. Leis Skaar died after being rushed to a hospital here with Thomas Andersen. Erling Marchinsen and Evear Marchinsen died aboard the freighter.

The United States has many things to be thankful for on this Thanksgiving Day, Secretary Roper said in his own proclamation, issued at his weekly press conference today. These benefits include abundant harvests, social and economic progress, liberty and freedom and other blessings that people of other nations are denied, he said.

Bond prices followed an irregular course to lower levels yesterday in relatively quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Thee modest improvement displayed in some sections of the list was more than offset by further severe declines in others, with the result that the various price averages in the domestic corporate division again sank to new low levels.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Sherpick of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Eve Ella Green of 31 Park Avenue, New York, widow of Arthur M. Green, to Harry B. Helmsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Helmsley of New York.

A hard, fast scrimmage for more than an hour featured the New York University football workout yesterday at Ohio Field. The session was the most intensive for the Violet this season, with Coach Mal Stevens using every man so as to have the entire squad in tip-top shape to face Fordham Saturday at the Yankee Stadium.
Net gold receipts by the Treasury in the nine months ended on Sept. 30 aggregated $1,482,640,000, of which $1,340,390,000 represented imported gold, according to a report by the department.

Results in semi-final matches of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association tournament at the New York Athletic Club yesterday ran strictly according to form. Murray Vernon, Winged Foot entrant who is seeded No. 2,

Miss Annie Emery will celebrate her 101st birthday on Saturday at her home, 1,120 Sunset Avenue, Asbury Park, N. J. She formerly resided for many years at 339 West Twentieth Street, which is across the street from St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Miss Ruth Mary Gaven, daughter of Mrs. John W. Gaven of this city and the late Mr. Gaven, was married to Richard Wilton Hurley of Elizabeth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Hurley of Hurley's Pond, Belmar, here tonight at the home of her mother. The Rev. Thomas J. Callery of the Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel performed the ceremony.

Senator McAdoo of California introduced in the Senate today a bill to pay Federal subsidies to operators of vessels in trade between the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts: Subsidies ranging from $1.50 to $12 per nautical mile, depending on the tonnage and speed, were proposed.

Frederick H. Colburn, for twentyseven years manager of the San Francisco Clearing House and for eighteen years between 1911 and 1929, secretary of the California State Bankers Association, died here today of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

The Radcliffe News, undergraduate publication, called upon the students today to "be weighed and eat" for the college. Admittedly inspired by the Thanksgiving feast, Alice Burke, News feature editor, sought 100 girls willing to be weighed today

Miss Judith Allen, film actress, filed an amended complaint in her $2,000,000 suit today, citing recent and detailed developments to support her charge that the affections of her husband, Jack Doyle, were stolen by Mrs. Delphine Dodge
Commenting today on the recent acquittal of James H. Rand Jr. and Pearl L. Bergoff on charges of transporting strikebreakers across State lines, Attorney General Cummings said:

Chairman Marvin Jones of the House Agriculture Committee introduced today a measure based on the present conservation program but providing for commodity loans and marketing quotas that would be compulsory unless more than a third of the farmers voting expressed their opposition to such regulations.

Turpentine firm, 27c. Sale, 57 barrels; receipts, 454 barrels; shipments, 57 barrels; stock, 37,223 barrels. Resin firm. Sales, 616; receipts, 104; shipments, 140; stock, 81,429. Quote: B. D, E, $5.25; F to K, $5.75; M, $5.85; N, $5.90: WG, $6.45; WW, X $6.75.

THE Troy tale is with us again, this time in a ribald and gaga novel, so called, by Christopher Morley.* The Trojan warriors are in their locker room cleaning up after a hard day's fight with the Greeks. Young Marse Troilus is getting a rub-down at the hands of Fuscus, a black slave, while Aeneas, Antenor, Paris, Deiphobus, Hector, and so on, are drying themselves with towels and putting on their underwear.

United States Ambassador Joseph E. Davies left unexpectedly this evening to catch the next sailing of the Normandie for New York after receiving a cable from the physician attending Mrs. Davies, who is recovering from influenza in New York The message said Mrs. Davies should not return to Moscow for at least another month.

A detective's memory for an automobile license number resulted last night in a chase of several blocks through Yorkville, a pistol battle fought through the hallways and on the roofs' of two houses, and the fatal wounding of one of two sought as hold-up suspects.

Japan will "probably adopt a very stiff attitude" toward any attempts by American or other foreign interests to buy Chinese Government properties or the interests of joint companies operating in the Shanghai area, the Japanese Embassy spokesman said yesterday.

Tugboats towed the ferryboat Catskill to the Weehawken terminus of the Weehawken-Fortysecond Street, Manhattan, ferry line last night after the boat had drifted on the Hudson River for forty minutes while, carrying a capacity load of passengers and automobiles.

To the average New Yorker it was a delightful, pleasant afternoon. A bright Autumn sun, shining down on the polo field at the Westchester Country Club this afternoon, tempered the briskness in the air. All in all, one was impressed with the thought that here was an ideal day for a football workout.

The sharp crack of intermittent rifle fire echoed through Buffalo National Park today as the annual slaughter of buffalo got under way. Lack of sufficient grazing area forced reduction of the herd by 2,000 to 4,500.
Douglas Vickers, former chairman of the armament firm of Vickers, Ltd., died today at the age of 76. He sucneeded his uncle, Albert Vickers, in the chairmanship in 1918 and retired in 1926.

Henry H. Rein, 50 years old, of 55 Central Park West, who described himself as a stock trader, pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to an indictment charging him with forgery in the disposal of $13,000 in bonds which had been stolen from two brokerage concerns in the financial district last year.

In an effort to work out some plan of rehabilitation of outmoded districts on the lower East Side of Manhattan, representatives of a group of-savings banks with extensive holdings in that district have been holding conferences with Mayor La Guardia and other city officials within the past few days, it was learned yesterday.

Dow Chemical Company has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 30,308 shares of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, for an estimated offering price of $3,121,724.

Only one fact emerges from the official statements and the rumors about recent subversive movements in France: there has been a plot-perhaps two plots-against the republic. All else is speculation. Who are the plotters?
Delivery of only about 4,000 bales here and 8,000 in New Orleans out of 70,000 certificated proved less than operators had anticipated and prices on the Cotton Exchange improved further yesterday.
The Fall sports season at Smith College was brought to a close today with the award of five all-Smith blazers by Dean Marjorie Hope Nicolson.

A plan for the reorganization of the Hotel Drake, Fifty-sixth Street and Park Avenue, was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo. It involves the purchase of the hotel and its equipment and furnishings by holders of certificates in the underlying real estate mortgage.

Race track betting in Canada totaled $22,275,787 this year, an increase of $1,324,077 over 1936, the Dominion Department of Agriculture reported today. This year's record showed twentynine associations held thirty-seven meetings for a total of 302 days, compared to twenty-eight associations, thirty-six meetings and 300 days in 1936.

Grace Moore, screen and opera singer, narrowly escaped an accident early today when her automobile blew a tire on a 90-mile an hour dash to catch a train here. The chauffeur brought the car under control. Miss Moore was on her way to spend Thanksgiving at her home at Chattanooga.

At times the President is a very hard man to convince. On other occasions, as when General.Counsel Oliphant of the Treasury sold him the corporate profits levy and the silver purchase plan, and the Attorney General excavated the 1869
With shouts of "down with Congress" some 600 university and high school students, angered by delay of the Senate in taking up the Political Amnesty bill,

A coroner's report made here today disclosed that the late Rev. William C. Kidd, principal of Lakewood High School and a Presbyterian clergyman, died July 7 of natural causes rather than by poison selfadministered, as reported by the coroner at the time of the Rev. Mr. Kidd's death. Coroner Raymond A.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that the British Government held the Spanish Insurgents responsible for damage to the British destroyer Hunter. He said Sir Henry Chilton, the British Ambassador to Spain, had been instructed to tell the Insurgents the government estimated the damages at [POUNDPOUND]134,500.

For a chap who has just been deprived of Ginger Rogers as a co-star Fred Astaire is bearing up astonishingly well in Rivoli's new musical comedy, "A Damsel in Distress." He probably misses his dancing Partner a little--he'd have to say so

War Minister Plinis Mendoza Mira yesterday informed the House that the government is considering a proposal of a Netherlands firm to purchase for a minor European nation two British-built destroyers, constituting virtually the whole tolombian navy, according to Tiempo.
President Roosevelt announced today the names of the trustees of the new National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, formed for coordinating and directing the drive against this disease.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Paragraph 20, Special Orders 267, Nov. 17, 1937, relating to Second Lieutenant Robert B. Schofield, .QM-Res., is revoked. So much of paragraph 13, Special Orders 138, June 15, 1937, ordering Captain Charles Seltzer, Inf-Res.,

Following a four-day visit here, the American women's flying peace mission left today by commercial plane for Guayaquil, Ecuador. Speeches, teas and cocktail parties occupied their visit here, which seemed to arouse little public attention.

Forty-two students and graduates of City College as of June and-September, 1937, and five distinguished alumni were elected into the membership of the Gamma Chapter of the Phi Beta Kappa, national honorary scholastic fraternity, it was announced yesterday.

Mrs. Clement W. Miller of this city gave a tea dance this afternoon at the Wilmington Country Club to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Marion Dunham Miller. Later the receiving party and out-of-town girls were guests at a dinner dance given by Mrs. Miller at the club before going to the Bachelors Ball at the Hotel du Pont.

Miss Adele Vignot Van Beuren, daughter of Mrs. J. Walter Green of this city, was married this afternoon to Floyd Paul Butt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Butt of New York and Denver, at the home of her mother here. The Rev. John Coffey performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Orienta Beach Club, Mamaroneck.
Mayor Wilson announced late today that new warrants would be issued on Friday against the two young women under arrest in the police investigation of the Nancy Glenn death case.

Mayor La Guardia congratulated B. Charney Viadeck yesterday when the new Council member visited him at City Hall. Mr. Vladeck was an Alderman when Mayor La Guardia was President of the Board of Aldermen, and the two are old friends.

The division of unemployment insurance and placement of the State Labor Department will open thirty offices in this city next Thursday in preparation for the receipt on Jan. 3 of the first claims for weekly unemployment insurance benefits. There will be nineteen other offices in the metropolitan area and seventy-four up-State.

Dr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Huber of 113 East Broadway, this city, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Huber, to Dr. Robert J. Fletcher Jr., son of Dr. Robert J. Fletcher, also of New York, and the late Mrs. Fletcher.

Frank Van Camp, food packer once connected with the Van Camp Packing Company of Indianapolis, died here last night of a heart attack. He was 74 years old. For many years he was active in a sea food canning business here. Surviving is a son, Gilbert Van Camp of Los Angeles.
In an impressive ceremony the ashes of General Jay J. Morrow, third Governor of the Canal Zone, were consigned to the waters of the Chagres River at the spillway at Gatun Lake here today.

The secret society known as the Cagoulards [the Hooded Ones] called themselves the "Comite Secret d'Action Revolutionnaire" [Secret Committee for Revolutionary Action] and its emblem was a gilded fleur-de-lis on a blue background, the French Royalist symbol,

Bermuda will spend [Pound]25,000 for advertising and publicity in the United States, the Assembly this afternoon agreeing to this sum in the estimates of the Trade Development Board. This is a 3,000 increase over 1937.

Joh Weston, a 20-year-old art student, here from Monticello, Minn., since September and longing for a taste of the Thanksgiving delicacies that his family would have at home, got his wish last night when a hot roast chicken, three hot pumpkin pies and two jars of hot preserves, prepared by his mother. before 5 A. M. and shipped nearly 1,200 miles by airplane, arrived at Newark Airport at 4:45 P. M.

To increase its stake in the railway equipment field, directors of the Symington-Gould Corporation proposed today acquisition of the McConway Torley Corporation of Pittsburgh. Stockholders were called to vote on Dec. 15 on the plan.

The Rev. Harold Kelley of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York in a "Mayflower" broadcast last night paid special tribute to Captain Christopher Jones, whose good seamanship with that of the crew ("and God's guiding hand") brought the little vessel with its precious cargo through the hazard s of the sea.

The marriage of Miss Jane Schouler Dwire, daughter of Mrs. George Franklin Dwire of Essex Fells and the late Mr. Dwire of WinstonSalem, N. C., to Joseph Paull Marshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Marshall of Washington, D. C., took place here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Archibald G. Sinclair.

In the short holiday week which ended yesterday engineering construction awards totaled $72,481,000, the third highest weekly figure recorded this year, according to The Engineering News-Record. This was a gain of 45 per cent over the same week of last year, when the figure was $50,142,000.

Clerks In New York City's Municipal and Magistrates Courts were confirmed in tenure of their positions today when the Court of Appeals decided against the Municipal Civil Service Commission in its action to remove Daniel H. Sandford as assistant clerk of the Municipal Court.
Excepting Minas Geraes, all the Brazilian States now are governed by Federal commissioners, according to a decree signed today by President'Getulio Vargas.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Ordway gave a dinner dance last night in the Crystal Garden of the RitzCarlton at which they introduced to society their daughter, Miss Joan Ordway. Before the dance the debutante received with her mother in the Palm Court.

" People at Sea," J. B. Priestley's third concurrent London play, which opened at the Apollo Theatre tonight, is Priestley in his effective melodramatic-and sometimes sociological-mood overshadowing the parable on modern civilization that he has attempted to weave into the play's framework.

Governor Frank Murphy warned labor today against hasty and unjustified strikes over minor grievances, and at the same time called on industry to play fair with labor by recognizing its "responsibility" and "avoid summary action" that might aggravate" business conditions.

Net earnings of the General Finance Corporation for the eleven months ended on Oct. 31 amounted to $713,010 after normal Federal income taxes and other charges, but before surtax on undistributed profits, Owen L. Coon, president, reported yesterday.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today that Premier Camille Chautemps and Foreign Minister Yvon Delbos of France had accepted an official invitation to visit London next Monday and Tuesday "for an exchange of views on the international situation."

In a long letter to Governor Lehman which occasionally took on the chatty tone of a conversation, Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader of half of the Second Assembly District and New York County Clerk, yesterday defended himself against District Attorney-elect Thomas E. Dewey's charges that he was "the political ally of thieves, pickpockets, thugs, dope peddlers and bigshot racketeers."

Executives of private utility companies testified today at the trial of the eighteen companies' suit against the constitutionality of the TVA in an effort to show actual and threatened damage to their properties in Tennessee, Alabama and Mississippi through government competition in building transmission lines and making contracts with municipalities, rural cooperatives and private industries in their territories.

A last-half rally enabled Springfield College, New England Soccer League champion, to defeat Yale, 2 to 1, today. The Elis held the upper hand during the first half, Pond scoring in the opening minutes. Munro's tally in the third period tied the count and Eaton's goal in the closing minutes decided the hard-fought battle.

Ten million dollars in State-bonds for gradecrossing elimination are to be sold on Dec. 7 by Morris S. Tremaine, Controller, he announced today. The bonds will be dated Dec. 8 and will mature in equal annual installments of $200,000 each for fifty years.

The Air Line Pilots Association "probably will be called on within a few days" to inquire into the conditions under which seventeen pilots of United Air Lines were recently dismissed, David L. Behncke, president of the association, said last night.

Treasury experts expressed fears today that a revision of the undistributed corporate profits tax such as was tentatively decided on yesterday by ?? Ways and Means Subcommittee might produce a loss in revenue that would have to be made up somewhere else.

The United Hospital campaign has received $1,417,933 to date, Clarence Francis, president of the General Foods Corporation, reported yesterday at a luncheon of workers in the Hotel Biltmore. The figure represents a rise of $111,000 over the amount collected during -the same period last year.

Miss Judith Ann Wilcox, daughter of Mrs. Harold George Wilcox of this place and the late Dr. Wilcox, was married here this afternoon in the Second Congregational Church to Hugh Wheeler Sanford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh W. Sanford of Knoxville, Tenn., and Nantucket, Mass., by the Rev. Dr. Oliver Huckel.

Declaring that "almost unbelievable progress" had been made toward the clarification of problems incident to the starting of the new housing program under the WagnerSteagall act, Nathan Straus, Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, announced today that regulations governing procedure will be ready for issuance Dec. 20 and that qualified applications for new projects would be welcomed prior to that date.

A group of seven European skiers who are to appear in the Madison Square Garden's Winter Sports Show and International Ski Meet Dec. 7-11 will arrive this morning aboard the Manhattan of the United States Lines and the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line.

Electric power output showed a greater increase last week than a called for on the basis of seasonal and long-term trends, and the adjusted index advanced after having declined for four consecutive weeks. It now stands at 100.2, compared with 99.0 for the previous week and 104.5 for the week ended Nov. 21 1936.

The Wagner Labor Relations Act cannot be ignored because a California cannery derives the bulk of its fruit and vegetables from within the State and ships less than half its products in interstate commerce, the government insisted today.

Sir Ralph lore, vice president of the Yacht Racing Association, announced tonight that there is no prospect of Class J racing in British waters next season. This will mark the sec)nd year in succession with no fixtures listed for the spectacular America's Cup class craft. The chief racing class will be the twelve meters.

An offer of a draw in the twentieth game of the match for the world's chess championship, emanating from Dr. Alexander. Alekhine of Paris and accepted by Dr. Max Euwe of this city, the titleholder, brought the encounter, adjourned last night after forty moves, to an unexpected early conclusion.

Six of the eight striking editorial employes of The Bayonne Evening Times were ordered today to show cause Monday in Chancery Court here why they should not be adjudged In contempt of court for alleged violation of an injunction issued last Saturday by Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Co took from Beadleston Woerz, Frederick W. Woerz. president, a mortgage for $400,000, payable April 1, 1948, at 5 per cent until the new building is erected; 4 1/2 per cent, thereafter, with $3,500 paid off quarterly beginning April 1, 1939, on the north side of West 10th St, 52 feet west of Washington St.

Department stores here accomplished some reduction inventories last month, but stocks in many lines continued to run substantially above a year ago, according to the analysis of sales and stocks for-October, issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As I write this letter, Sir Hubert Wilkins is at Edmonton, Canada, en route to Aklavik, where he will make his first base for the purpose of searching for the lost Russian flier, Levanezsky, and his comrades.

The appointment of Arthur C. Jones as vice president and general manager of the Ridgway Tea Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Jones was once president of the Piggly-Wiggly Western States Stores and founder of the magazine Chain Store Management.

The National Maritime Union announced yesterday that it would accept the invitation of the American Steamship Owners Association to confer on a proposal for the establishment of a standard labor contract for the shipping industry as a step toward the elimination of strikes and other labor difficulties on ships.

The frequently shuffled first-night events of next week now seem to have settled down in the following order: MONDAY, Nov. 29-"The New Gossoon," at the Ambassador, and "Le Roi Cerf" (in French), at the Barbizon-Plaza.

There will be no turkey dinners for Bob Pastor and Nathan Mann today. While others are enjoying their Thanksgiving feast these two young men will be putting on the final touches in preparation for their ten-round bout in. Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

Loyal employes of the Ford Motor Company, in autos and afoot, crashed today through a picket line numbering nearly twice as many men as are employed in the building and continued to operate the assembly plant after the United Automobile Workers of America had called a strike there.

With the departure of the ClevelandCliffs freighters Hennepin from Allouez today and Pam Schneider from Marquette yesterday, final cargoes of iron ore from Lake Superior are on their way down the Great Lakes.

Eighty-one head were sold yesterday during the second day of the forty-third annual Old Glory horse auction in the Squadron A Armory under the direction of the FasigTipton Company. Receipts were $76,095, an average of $939. While more horses were sold for more money, the second day's average was below the $986 recorded the first day.

Governor Benson appealed for the aid of Federal agents today in the investigation of the slaying of Patrick Corcoran, prominent labor figure, as another labor leader reported that his life had been threatended.

By a vote of 18 to 1, Italy being the sole dissenter, the Far Eastern Conference adopted this evening a declaration of principles and suspended its sittings until such a time as there may be a better prospect for its intervention in the Sino-Japanese conflict. The hope of such a prospect is vocal rather than deep-seated.

In the latest of the Health Department's occasional drives against subway smokers and spitters, which took place on Monday and Tuesday, summonses were given to 447 smokers (including a few women) in the subways and to sixtytwo spitters in subways and other public places of the five boroughs.

Vincenzo Bafaro, 57 years old, of 2,318 Cambrelleng Avenue, the Bronx, who forged a power of attorney which he presented in the Surrogates' Court and on which he obtained $8,000 in money and securities from the estate of a brotherin-law, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by General Sessions Judge Freschi for from three to six years. He had been convicted on Oct. 21 of forgery in the second degree.

Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company chairman of the Ariierican Committee of Short Term Creditors of Germany, sailed yesterday on the French liner Normandie with Joseph C. Rovensky, vice president of the Chase National Bank, to attend a meeting of the creditors in London on Dec. 1.

The Democratic Congressional Register for 1937, published under the auspices of the Democratic National Congressional Committee, appeared today. The volume contains 128 pages of advertising, in which not many large corporations are represented.

Heavy movement of strategic materials, bound for Japanese ships was reported at Los Angeles Harbor today as an indication of the intensity with which they are carrying American goods to the Orient. Eight Japanese vessels were active as five freighters and passenger carriers departed or . arrived and three tankers loaded approximately 230,000 barrels of fuel oil for Japan.

Seven suits asking injunctions against the Mexican nationalization of 350,000 acres of oil lands held under lease were filed in the First Federal District Court here yesterday by the Richmond Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California.
Mrs. Ida Marks, 47 years old, wife of Lawrence Marks, 49, who is awaiting execution at Sing Sing for the murder of an 8-year-old girl, was found dead just before 10

Continuing its campaign of public education for eradication of venereal disease, the Health Department announced yesterday the opening of a social hygiene clinic in the Lower West Side Health Centre, 303 Ninth Avenue, at Twenty-seventh Street. Diagnosis and treatment are free for all men, women and children unable to pay private physicians.

Deputy Commissibner Harry M. Prince of the Tenement House Department sees no need for the ninestory limitation on the height of new multi-family buildings which may be erected under the new fireresistive classification in the Building Code which goes into effect here on Jan. 1.
