Capitalizing on their first opportunity and staging an effective defensive thereafter, Hun School's football forces today defeated Bordentown Military Institute, 6--0, thus ending their third straight unbeaten season while handing the cadets their initial setback in eighteen successive contests.

Emilio Colombo, one-time solo violinist to the Czar and one of the most popular dance band leaders in London, died of a heart attack today at the age of 63. He was playing at the Mayfair Hotel last evening with his waltz band,
The Louisiana Jockey Club will get its 105-day Winter racing meet under way tomorrow at the Fair Grounds with the Thanksgiving Handicap the main event on a seven race card.

Mrs. Agnes Stein, 43 years old, operator of a disorderly house in Atlantic City and once known as the "vice queen" of Philadelphia, was sentenced today in Federal Court here to serve seven years in a Federal penitentiary and pay a fine of $1,000.

The first anniversary of the signing of the German-Japanese pact is being celebrated today on a scale which shows how powerful are the influences behind the anti-Soviet front. Foreign Minister Koki Hirota, in his message to the nation, explicitly declares that the agreement is not a fascist bloc or a union of havenots against the haves. The agreement, he says, is spiritual.

A strike of union bus drivers went into effect on Greyhound Lines throughout Northeastern United States at one minute after midnight today. -Dispatchers at Greyhound headquarters here said drivers had been instructed to stop their buses at the nearest station where passengers could obtain other transportation.

Although some estimates place the Canton fatalities in today's bombing at more than 100, the latest reliable reports indicate that hardly more than 60 were killed and slightly more than that injured throughout suburbs.

Burning Star and Calumet Dick, two of the top-notchers in the handicap division, who have tried their speed in the country's leading specials, will meet once more tomorrow in the $5,000 added Thanksgiving Handicap,-feature at Bowie, which is expected to attract 20,000 persons. They are two of eleven entered for the mile-and-a-sixteenth test for horses of all ages.

The marriage of Miss Elsa Glaser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Glaser of Grymes Hill, S. L., to Arthur Lincoln Webber, son of Mrs. George Henry Webber of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Webber, took place here last evening in the chantry of Grace Church. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowle.
A sweeping investigation of short selling in the grain market is being pressed by the Chicago Board of Trade in connection with the inquiry into the "squeeze," in September corn it was learned today.

Americans, abroad as well as at home, will celebrate Thanksgiving Day today as a holiday peculiarly American because its origin is linked so closely with the origin of the nation. In the churches the original intent of the day, one of giving thanks to God, will be maintained.
The Navy ended its soccer season today by defeating Lehigh, 2 to 1, in an unusually well played game. The season's record for Navy is four victories and two losses.

William Henry Ketchum, retired New York banker, died here at his ??, 121 Haddon Place, after an illness ?? three ??. His age was 84. Mr. Ketchum retired in 1914 as assistant cashier of the Corn Exchange Bank and Trust Company of New York after serving that institution for forty years.

235th St, (13-3409a. 3409b), s w cor of Netherland Ave, 200x337; also 232d St, n e cor of Netherland Ave, 125x100; Mutual Life Insurance Co to Barca Realty Corp, 143 W 72d St. 183d' St (11-3143) s w cor of Webster Ave, O10x100; K. A. B. Realty Co, Inc, to Gordon Investors, Inc, 333 W 39th St; mortgage S133,033.

An indication of the large number of New York football fans who will journey to Philadelphia on Saturday to witness the annual service classic between Army and Navy was made known yesterday when it was announced by the Pennsylvania Railroad that thirty-nine trainloads of fans will be transported over its lines alone.

The Basler Nachrichten announced today that, despite the Swiss government's intervention, Germany had refused to renew the residence permit of the newspaper's Berlin correspondent, Herman Boeschenstein, who must leave- after tomorrow.

The board of directors of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the common and participating preferred stocks. Both are payable on Dec. 21 tn holders of record on Dec. 7.

This city late last night suffered one of the most terrible bombardments in its year-long ordeal. The pounding of shells still throbs in our ears, but only isolated bursts are coming now at 12:30 A. M., and soon even these will cease, too.

A plan of reorganization for the St. Louis-San Francisco (Frisco) Railroad which would scale down fixed-interest charges from nearly $13,000,000 a year to $3,956,000 was filed today by the board of directors in the court of United States District Judge George H. Moore.
German expansionism in Central Europe is expected to be the most important subject of discussion before the British and French Ministers in London next week.

With the twenty-first annual roll call for memberships in the American Red Cross scheduled to close today, Mrs. David Challinor, rollcall director for the New York Chapter, announced yesterday that twenty-four of the forty-one campaign divisions showed increases over the amounts collected during the same period last year.

St. John's University bowed to Wheaton College of Illinois in soccer yesterday at Victory Field. A goal by Roberts in the final four minutes .of play gave the invaders a 3-2 decision. The game was hard played all the way, with the issue standing at 1-all when the first half ended.

Lieut. Col. George A. Stowell of the Marine Corps, who had an outstanding record in the World War, died today of coronary thrombosis at Coco Solo, Canal Zone, where he was in command of the Marine Barracks at the submarine base. He was 48 years of age.

Miss Katherine Hellegers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hellegers of this city, was married tonight to Albert Stephens Pryor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert N. Pryor, also of Passaic. The ceremony was performed at the First Holland Reformed Church here by the Rev. Lawrence J. Borst, and a reception for eighty guests followed at the Marlboro Inn. Montclair.

The first definite result of President Roosevelt's efforts to induce private utilities to start a construction drive in the interest of business recovery came today in an announcement by Floyd L. Carlisle that the New York State power companies which he heads will begin immediately an expansion program calling for the expenditure of $100,000,000 to $112,000,000 in the next two years.

Arthur Koehler of Madison, Wis., a Federal wood expert, who was an important State witness at the Hauptmann trial, and Patrick T. Crowe, a reformed outlaw, filed with Governor Hoffman today claims to a share in the $25,000 reward offered by the Legislature for the arrest and conviction of the murderer of the kidnapped Lindbergh baby.
The Regis High quintet launched its season with a 49-20 victory over Immaculata High yesterday on the Regis court. McKay scored 20 points for the winners, who held a 21-7 advantage at the half.
The Harvard Crimson has elected Morris Earle of New York as president; Henry S. Goodhue of Boston, editorial chairman;

Magda de Fontanges, French actress and self-avowed friend of Premier Mussolini, committed a crime involving moral turpitude when she shot and wounded Count Charles de Chambrun last March in Paris, and she must be deported to France, Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum" ruled yesterday, dismissing a writ of habeas corpus calling for her release from Ellis Island.

The Chrysler Corporation notified its employes today of a curtailment in employment, effective at once. All plants will be affected. A downward revision of production schedules necessitated the reduction.
EDISON GROUPS PLAN OUTLAY OF $112,000,000 IN TWO YEARS AFTER TALK WITH ROOSEVELT

The Navy tightened its football battle line for the Army game today while the fleet threw its moral support behind the players and the regiment of midshipmen. Lieutenant Harry J. (Hank) Hardwick, head coach, perfected his war plans with marines guarding the practice field gates. The regiment of midshipmen rehearsed the manoeuvres they will stage in Philadelphia on Saturday.

A 400,000,000-peso budget for 1938, far the largest in Mexico's history, will be proposed to Congress by President Lazaro Cardenas, it was learned officially today, when the President approved the schedule of expenditures for eight of the ten government departments.

The six-story steel and concrete factory building at 79-81 Locimer Street, Brooklyn, which E. Greenfield Chocolate Company erected several years ago, and the five adjoining parcels, known as 395 to 405 Marcy Avenue, forming the corner, have been sold by the Lorimer Holding Company to the 79 and 81 Lorimer Street Corporation.
The low point of the year was reached on Nov. 20 in wholesale commodity prices, according to the index figures made public today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Deapartment of Labor.

The last of the Drexel holdings in Manhattan, comprising the two five-story buildings at 11-15 East Fifty-fourth Street, have been sold by Mrs. John R. Drexel to Sumner Gerard, who purchased them as an investment in the name of the Aeonitt Realty Corporation.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: With unfavorable weather for field operations, corn husking made little progress during the week, but this work is well along generally. The bulk of corn has been husked in Central and Western Ohio Valley and gathering is practically completed in the extreme western belt. In Iowa many ears of corn are on the ground and covered with snow in the unhusked fields.

Bowery, n w cor Bleecker St, 50x100: Wendel Foundation to Henry Lee Corp, 320 Bowery ($32). Avenue A, n w cor 17th St, 20x69: 275 Avenue A Corp to Antoinette Nunno, 35-38 72d St, Jackson Heights; consideration, $5,000. 85th St, s s, 175 ft e of Columbus Ave, 19x102.2; trustees will of Gustav A. Fried to Donald S. Fried, 1,230 Park Ave; consideration, $35,958.

Included among the apartment rentals reported yesterday by brokers and agents was a unit of eleven rooms and five baths taken by William R. Wood, an executive of the General Foods Corporation, in 1,172 Park Avenue, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker, who also leased quarters to Richard G. Croft in 1 East End Avenue, and to Mrs. Jean Gair, in 455 East Fifty-first Street.

The Pennsylvania football team, virtually at full strength for the first time since the start of the season, meets a favored Cornell eleven tomorrow on Franklin Field. The game will be the fortyfourth in one of the longest series in football.

Alabama's undefeated and untied Crimson Tide ruled a slight favorite over Vanderbilt tonight on the eve of the Thanksgiving Day battle that will go a long way toward settling Southeastern Conference title honors.

Mrs. Mariette Koevesi von Neumann, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gaza Koevesi of Budapest, was married here this afternoon to J. B. Horner Kuper, son of Mrs. George H. Kuper of New York and Redding, Conn., and the late Mr. Kuper, by Judge Robert E. Mattingly in his chambers in the Municipal Court.
The Bronx Tigers came to Baltimore tonight for the first time in three years and lost, 3 to 1, to a fastskating Oriole team in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game before 1,800 spectators.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved appointment today of a six-man committee to represent holders of - preferred stock of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad Company in pending reorganization proceedings of that road.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 23: COLONELS Mitchell, H. D., Adjutant General's Dept., one day leave, Nov. 26. Warden, J. A., Q. M. C., Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., to Atlanta, Ga., about Jan. 15. Starrett, R., Q. M. C., to duty- with the Organized Reserves, Sixth Corps Area, in addition to other duties at Chicago, III.
The nation's public relief bill for the first nine months of this year was $152,416,000 less than in 1936, according to a report by the Social Security Board today.

Premier Camille Chautemps succeeded today in ending another threat to his government by winning an agreement from most of the Leftist Deputies, except Communists, on a compromise plan for pay increases for State employes.

The Eastern Shore Public Service Companies of Maryland and Delaware applied today to the Public Service Commission for authority to issue $1,100,000 in refunding mortgage gold bonds and 3,500 shares of $100par common stock.

Miss Margaret Ayres, daughter of W. A. Ayres, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, was married to William F. Weigester today in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul. The bride was attended by her twin sister, Mrs. H. Janney Nichols Jr. of Westfield, N. J.

Nearly two-thirds of the motorists in the United States never have purchased- a new car, according to J. Mack Young, president of the Automobile Club of New York. He said yesterday that of the 26,000,000 owners in the United. States only 9,000,000 had ever bought new machines.

President Roosevelt and Congress were urged to revise certain government policies and legislation that were held responsible for the business slump in an interim report of the executive committee of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public last night by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the organization.

Absentee ballots cast Nov. 2 in the North Castle election by three employes of Mrs. Eugene Meyer, chairman of the Westchester County Recreation Commission and wife of the Washington publisher, were challenged in Supreme Court here today by Richard P. Limburg, who was defeated for re-election as Town Supervisor by one vote.

The Yonkers Tax Board of Review, completing today a long series of hearings on applications for reductions in realty assessments, disclosed that protests were received on 1,400 out of 45,000 parcels of property in the city.
The new edition of the Blue Book of Baltimore, her old home town, lists the Duchess of Windsor again after fourteen years. At the top of Page 410 is this entry:

A further shipment of $5,800,000 of gold from Japan was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as being on the way here. This follows the arrival on Tuesday of $5,395,500 in gold from that country and will bring to $226,800,000 the total of gold sent the United States from Japan since March 8 last.

An attempt to wipe out the Communists who control a large area in Northeast Shansi and Northwest Hopeh is seen here in the launching of a drive by Japanese forces north of the Shihkiachwang-Taiyuan Railroad.

Montclair State Teachers College closed its 1937 gridiron 'season with five victories, two defeats and a tie when it subdued Hofstra College, 14 to O, in the first meeting of the two colleges today. The contest marked the formal dedication of Sprague Field, with Dr. Harry A. Sprague, president of the college, raising a new school flag between the halves.
Reports that the Committee for Industrial Organization is facing a serious financial crisis by reason of non-payment of dues occasioned by the trade recession,

Willie Hoppe, who successfully defended the world 18.1 balkline championship against Jake Schaefer last week, will oppose Schaefer in a twelve-block encounter at 71.2 balkline starting Monday afternoon at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

In my opinion, four Southwestern stars belong on any all-Southern team. They are James Benton of Arkansas, Hale of Texas Christian, Joe Routt of Texas A. and M. and Dwight Sloan of Arkansas. Glowing reports come to me on Andy Bershak, leader of North Carolina, which must be ranked among the South's best teams. He has been a three-year sensation at end.

A request for immediate hearings on his bill to repeal 'the President's emeragency power to issue $3,000,000,000 in greenbacks was sent today by Senator Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, to Senator Wagner of New York, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee.

Mrs. Agnes Oley and Mrs. Josephine Geary, said by Federal officers to have "created quite a disturbance" yesterday, were confined tonight, like their kidnapper husbands, behind the bars of Albany County penitentiary.
West Virginia University's hard-running Mountaineers, beaten only by Pitt this season, smothered George Washington under a 26-to-0 score today to the evident satisfaction of 12,000 home-coming fans.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Roslyn Botwen of Astoria, Queens, daughter of Bernard Johnston Botwen of New York and Philadelphia and the late Mrs. Botwen, to Dr. Julius Baer, son of Mrs. Solomon Baer of Long Island City and the late Mr. Baer, has been announced by her father.
Several farm organizations, representing all parts of the country, have started an intensive campaign against the Black-Connery measure for regulation of wages and hours.

The country's 317th Thanksgiving was celebrated in traditional fashion by Americans at home and abroad yesterday with the customary feasting of family gatherings in homes and hotels and with bountiful care taken of the less fortunate.

Western Maryland closed its football season today with an easy 20-0 victory over Providence College. The Terrors' third-stringers were put in the game in the last quarter. The visitors' prize punter, Nugent, still suffering from a leg twisted in an earlier game, was unable to kick more than 35 yards.
Five firemen, including a battalion chief and a lieutenant, were overcome by smoke last night while fighting a fire in a junk shop at 150 Navy Street in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn.

Freedom of the press to publish names of grand jurors and witnesses summoned before grand juries had the support today of the State Supreme Court. The court yesterday refused to review the case in which Walter Morrow,

The Earl of Mansfield told dinner guests in London tonight that within about a year after storks were taken to his Dumfriesshire home, Comlongorm Castle, there was a perfectly amazing increase in the local population.

Ursinus defeated the Pennsylvania Military 'College eleven, 6-0, today. Ray Gurzynski ripped over on a reverse in the first period after his pass to Bodley made 36 yards and put the ball on the 4-yard line.
Washington University, defeated in six of nine previous games, deprived St. Louis University of a share of the Missouri Valley Conference football title today by winning from the Billikens. 6 to 0.

Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Sewall of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Olive Sewall, to Robert Horne Charles, son of Mrs. Benjamin H. Charles of St. Louis and the late Mr. Charles.
Controller Frank J. Taylor said yesterday he would recommend the Board of Estimate's approval of four assessment revisions to benefit property owners in Queens and Brooklyn.

The National Gallery tonight held a preview of its latest annual historical Canadian art exhibition, a one-man show for the late James Wilson Morrice, law student who turned artist and became known as this country's first great painter, although he did most of his work abroad.

A crowd of 61,000 at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, saw Cornell get two touchdowns in the last five minutes to take the measure of Penn in a game that provided thrill after thrill. At Providence Frank Foster ran back the opening kick-off 95 yards to score as his Brown team gained a one-point victory over Rutgers. These were the two big Thanksgiving Day contests in the East.

Declaration of two distributions aggregating more than $1,100,000 to holders of the defaulted $28,000,000 issue of mortgage investments known as Series F-I, which had been guaranteed by the NewYork Title and Mortgage Company, will be announced today 'by Aaron Rabinowitz, James L. Clare and Lawrence N. Martin. trustees.

Duquesne made two second-half touchdowns today to overtake the University of Detroit eleven for a 14to-7 victory before 10,880 spectators. The Night Riders' first daylight triumph of the season avenged a loss by the same score at Detroit last year, when the Dukes were penalized 140 yards. Today's game also gave Duquesne a 4-to-3 advantage in the seven-year series.

Omeco Overseas Mercantile Co, Inc, factory representative for Czechoslovakian manufacturers, store and basement in 13-15 W 28th St; Wright Hat Corp, store in 281 Mercer St; Stanley A. Lake, blue prints, in 202 E 44th St; The Cross Brown Co, broker.

On the day when untold thousands of New Yorkers were consuming vast quantities of Thanksgiving turkey, 200 members of the Vegetarian Society of New York gathered yesterday and showed their disdain for meat-eaters by eating succulent chestnuts, baked in an appetizing loaf with fresh vegetables, eggs and butter.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Baatz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Baatz of South Orange, to Paul W. Grover, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William C. Grover of Newark, took place this morning in Our Lady of Sorrows Church here. The Rev. Edward J. Kern of St. Walburga's Orphanage, at Roselle, officiated.
Fullback Rocco Pirro of Catholic University punctured the University of South Carolina's line almost at will today and the result was a 27to-14 victory for the Cardinal-clad Washingtonians.
Miss Dorothy Louise Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grover D. Davis of Merion, was married this evening to Harry Nye Lucas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Nye Lucas of Ardmore.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair Corporation, announced yesterday that Russia and Hungary had signed contracts for exhibition space at the exposition. Russia has taken 110,000 square feet of space and Hungary has contracted for 36,000 square feet.
Sturdy Dwight Sloan, a righthander with a baffling change of pace and marvelous control, pitched the Arkansas Razorbacks to a 28to-7 football victory over Tulsa University today.

The failure of Neville Chamberlain, British Prime Minister, to furnish any information on the subject of Viscount Halifax's negotiations in Germany, the Nazi-organized student strike in the University of Vienna which has lasted for three days and, above all, the mass arrests since Nov. 10 in the army for Nazi activities, has produced a general depression here that today went so far as to affect the stock exchange.

Miss Margaret Harman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Harman, and Frank D. O'Reilly Jr. were married here this morning by the Rev. William S. Davies, pastor of the Immaculate Conception Church. The bride is a graduate of the Lock Haven State Teachers College.

With a brave show of suspending its sittings only temporarily- "In order to allow time for the participating Governments to exchange views and further to explore all peaceful methods whereby a just settlement of the dispute may be attained consistently with the principles of the Nine-Power treaty and in conformity to that treaty's objectives"-the Brussels conference concluded its ineffectual labors.

More than a million and a half suits of woolen underwear, 300,000 woolen coats, and equal numbers of woolen trousers and wind-breakers, lumber jackets and mackinaws, are among the garments issued to members of the Civilian Conservation Corps to keep them warm during the Winter.
Seventy-two head were disposed of under the hammer yesterday in the third and final day of the forty-third annual Old Glory auction sale of light harness horses in the Squadron A Armory.

Wheat prices here continued lower today in sympathy with weakness in the overseas markets. Export business was entirely lacking and the closing showed losses of 3% to 2% cents with the cash article at $1,301/ a bushel and the November at $1.09 bid; December, $1.07%; May, $1.071% and July, $1.031 1/8.

An underrated team from Virginia Polytechnic Institute upset the favored Virginia Military Institute eleven today, winning the annual "military classic of the South," 12-6, and knocking the losers out of a clear title to the Old Dominion championship.

America's leading women field hockey players opened play at the national tournament today with three round-robin games and an exhibition match. The feature attraction was a 1-to-O victory scored by the Southeast stars over a picked team of Mid-west players, Miss Marian Edwards of Philadelphia, making the lone goal in the final minutes of play.

The undefeated but once tied Washington High School eleven of South Bend, Ind., came from behind today to defeat the previously unbeaten White Plains High School team, 13-7, before 11,000 fans at Parker Stadium.
The birth tonight of a daughter of the late fourth Earl of Londesborough ended an almost unprecedented situation in the history of the British peerage.
R. A. Coward's Waxwing captured the $2,000 added Thanksgiving' IHandicap today, run as the opening-day feature of the Fair Grounds Winter racing season.

A motion picture in which pupils play the part of heroes and villains, intended to help teachers detect and remedy "problem cases" as they arise in the classroom, has been produced under the direction of the Board of Education and the Guidance Laboratory of Teachers College, it was announced yesterday.

A delegation of 150 Camden County school children will go to Washington tomorrow to urge President Roosevelt to aid in obtaining government contracts for the New York Shipbuilding Company's plants in this city.

The Manhattan College freshmen defeated Wyoming Seminary, 12-0 at the Seminary stadium today in their annual encounter before a crowd of more than 3,000. The freshmen pushed over two touchdowns in the last period.

A single expiration date for all wage and working contracts with American ship lines held by the nine unions constituting the New York Maritime Council will be sought at a meeting of the council tonight at its offices at 10 Bridge Street.
Thanksgiving Day brought little change in the routine of the fourteen jurors, twelve regular and two spare, who are trying a group of the nation's oil producers on antitrust law violation charges.

ONE of Mike Jacobs's force was beating the drum for the Bob Pastor-Nathan Mann bout at Madison Square Garden this evening. To hear him tell it, Bounding Bob Pastor was going to make this one of the greatest Mann hunts in pugilistic history.

A defense of the purposes and activities of foundations dedicated to the advancement of education, encouragement of scientific research and broadening of the bases of philosophical thinking against the charge that they have been "fiddling while Rome was burning" is made by Dr. Frederick P. Keppel, the president, in his annual report on the work of the Carnegie Corporation, made public yesterday.

Miss Elizabeth R. Myers, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin J. Myers of this place, was married here this afternoon in Holy Trinity Episcopal Chapel to Laurence Laue Pitcaithly, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Laurence A. C. Pitcaithly of Westwood.
A powerful North Carolina team rode rough shod over Virginia today and won, 40 to O, in the fortysecond renewal of the South's oldest continuous football rivalry.
George E. Gaddis of Summit, an officer of the American Can Company since its organization in 1901, died here today in Overlook Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 70 years old.

One of the largest debutante parties of this season was the dance given last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton by former Governor and Mrs. Charles Seymour Whitman of this- city and Newport to introduce to society Mrs. Whitman's daughter, Miss Anne Somerville Grosvenor.

Colonel Sanderford Jarman's recent discussion before a meeting of the National Guard Association of the Government's plans for mobilizing man power in the event of war presents a mathematical forecast of what Ameri-. ca faces-if war comes.

Enactment of Federal legislation at the current special session of Congress to end child labor abuses in industrial establishments engaged in interstate commerce was urged by the National Child Labor Committee in its annual report made public yesterday by Courtenay Dinwiddie, general secretary of the organization.
Albania's celebration of the twentyfifth anniversary of her independence opened today with a 101shot salute to King Zog and a speech by him.

Of the total newspaper advertising linage used by chains and super markets in sixty cities throughout the United States this year, 38.7 per cent was inserted by the super markets, as against 61.3 per cent by all chains, according to a survey by Super Market Merchandising issued yesterday.

The Rev. Miles D. Kiley, pastor of St. Ann's Catholic Church and formerly pastor in Concord, died here today at the age of 73. Born in Margarie, N. S., he studied for the priesthood at St. John's Seminary in Brighton and was ordained by the late Archbishop Williams at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross in 1900.

The Rev. Dr. Luther Edward Todd, executive secretary of the general board of finance of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, died today of an infection of the arteries. He was 63 years old and had been ill since Nov. 7.

Dr. Storrs Barrows Barrett, Emeritus Professor of Astronomy and Astro-physics at the University of Chicago, died here tonight. He was 73 years old. He was a former secretary of Yerkes Observatory at Williams Bay, Wis., a member of the American Astronomical Society, the American Academy for the Advancement of Science and Psi Upsilon fraternity.
Frank B. Mulloy, 45-year-old member of the old "Pretty Boy" Floyd gang, was free today after spending fourteen months at Alcatraz.
Dick Todd sifted through a stout Texas line only once today, but that trip sparked the Texas Aggies to a 7 to 0 victory.

In connection with the current exhibition of rugs and carpets (through Dec. 5) at the Metropoliton Museum of Art, special talks will be given by Grace Cornell of the, museum staff in Gallery D6 on the second floor at 11 A. M. and at 3 P. M. on Nov. 27 and Dec. 1 and 2.

Deputy Police Inspector Henry Bauer of New York tonight fell about thirty feet from the deck of the steamship Yucatan to the dock as he stepped aboard. The ship was held nearly an hour, but had to sail without him.

The statement of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday, issued today, showed note circulation down almost $2,000,000 in the week. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities stood at 51.38 per cent, compared with 50.75 a week before.
Dr. John Carey Acheson, president of Macalester College since 1924, died in a hospital yesterday a few hours after he became sick at his home.

The University of Kentucky was thankful tonight its football team plays Tennessee's Volunteers only once each season. The Volunteers ruined an otherwise successful home-coming day by trouncing the Wildcats, 13 to 0, before 15,000 fans.

Announcement was made at the local Quartermaster Depot today that contracts have been awarded under Invitations 85, 99, 97, and 105, as follows: Invitation 85, for the manufacture from 20-ounce olive drab wool materials and findings, in part, furnished by the government of 218,700 pairs of service trousers for the Civilian Conservation Corps.

Premier Pattullo proposed last night the extension of British Columbia's boundaries to take in not only the Yukon Territory but also the territory east of the Yukon following the 120th meridian to the North Pole. The extension would add 400,

Dr. Oliver St. John Gogarty ought to walk down Sackville Street more warily in the future. Probably he won't. A man who escaped from kidnappers of the worst intentions during the troubles can't be expected to restrain his malicious genius because he has to pay [Pound]900 in damages and costs on top of that for libeling a fellow Dubliner.

A parade of 500 boys and girls in costume between Twenty-seventh and Thirty-fourth Streets from First to Third Avenue for prizes offered by the Madison Square Boys Club marked part of the public observance of Thanksgiving Day yesterday.

President Getulio Vargas today appointed Waldemar Falcao Minister of Labor. Mr. Falcao is the third Vargas Cabinet appointee in the new regime. Agamenon Magalhaes, whom Mr. Falcao replaces, is scheduled to be Interventor of the State of Pernambuco.

A plan for a "consumer cooperative" system of stores has been set up for the model home community at Greenbelt, Md., by which all of the residents eventually will share the benefits of mass purchasing.

The celebration of the first anniversary of the German - Japanese anti - Comintern pact, which was initiated with a ceremonial banquet at the Japanese Embassy last night which Chancellor Adolf Hitler attended, was featured today with a revealing exchange of radio speeches between Berlin and Tokyo.

Approximately 650,000 individuals in New York will receive their 1937 anti-tuberculosis Christmas seals today, marking the opening of active solicitation for the $350,000 city-wide Christmas Seal Appeal in behalf of the tuberculosis and health associations of the city.

The replacement of Marshal Rodolfo Graziani by the Duke of Aosta as Viceroy of Ethiopia, although it did not come altogether as a surprise, has had a discouraging effect upon influential Italians there.

Five tenements in Yorkville, comprising two. parcels, have passed into the hands of new owners who plan to modernize the buildings. The four five-story houses at 21113-15-17 East Ninety-sixth Street have been sold by Bernard L. Touroff, trustee, to an investing client of A. V. Amy Co., Inc., broker.

Edward T. Corcoran of 36 Nome Street, Forest Hills, Queens, lawyer, ex-soldier and a leader in religious, civic and fraternal societies, died yesterday in Rockefeller Institute at the age of 43. He had' been ill for two weeks.

The engagement of Miss Veronese Beatty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ross J. M. Beatty of Highland Park, Ill., to Dudley Nostrand of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Nostrand, was announced today.

A thinly veiled editorial attack on Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain for sending Viscount Halifax, Lord President of the Council, to Berlin, appeared today in the Conservative Yorkshire Post, which is not only owned by Mrs. Anthony Eden's family, but is also so close to the Foreign Secretary that it is often described in diplomatic circles here as "Eden's paper."

With control of the new City Council in the balance, the count of the ballots cast under proportional representation in the city election Nov. 2 will be resumed today in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, with the membership from all but the last borough likely to be determined before nightfall.
MAADME CURIS, by Eve Curie. (Doubleday, Doran, $3.50.) A biography. NOT SO LONG AGO, by Cecil K. Drinker. (Oxford, $3.50.) Medicine and doctors in colonial Philadelphia.
Whether or when the League of Nations' Far Eastern Advisory Committee will meet depends almost entirely on the Chinese Government, according to League circles.

The High School of Commeice downed De Witt Clinton High, 7-0, and Theodore Roosevelt High turned back Flushing High of Queens, 20 to 7, in a schoolboy double-header at the Randalls Island Stadium yesterday. The games attracted a crowd of 12,000.

James Remus Wright, a retired physicist who was employed for twelve years by the Standard Oil Development Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, died of a heart attack while walking in the woods here this afternoon a half hour after having eaten a Thanksgiving turkey dinner at the home of T. Edward King. Mr. Wright,

Horace M. Gray, chairman of the City Manager League of Yonkers, announced tonight he had requested Governor Lehman to authorize the appointment of an extraordinary grand jury and a special prosecutor to investigate alleged fraud in the vote on the local city manager plan at the recent general election and at the special election last Fall. Mr.
President Roosevelt on his recent Western trip said in the course of a talk at Cheyenne, "Engineers are human just like I am."

Passengers due to arrive today from Europe on the HamburgAmerican liner New York include Mr. and Mrs. James Robinson, Fred Kolb, Mr. and Mrs. O. W. Fox, Karl W. Neuhoff, Louis Bonnard, Mrs. Constance Prehn, Mr. and Mrs. William Miller-Collier, C. H. Dill, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Oberley, Mrs. A. W. Lishawa, F. L. Field and Mrs. Wilma Travis.

Dickinson High School's eleven routed St. Peter's Prep at Roosevelt Stadium today, 39-0, in the twenty-ninth renewal of a, series which had its inception in 1898. A crowd of 17,000 persons, including Governor-elect A.Harry Moore saw the Hilltoppers score their fourth straight victory over their old rivals.

By breaking 98 out of 100 targets, A. S. Cornhill won the high-overall. cup in the holiday shoot overthe traps of the New York A. C., yesterday. E. Hughes defeated P. Sleppy for the Class A Handicap trophy. Four tied for the Class B laurels, S. J. Mustain leading E. P. Feeley in the final shoot-off.
Colonel Paul Frederic Straub, retired army officer, died today at the age of 72. Colonel Straub received the Congressional medal of honor for his services in the Philippine insurrection.
With his faithful beagle dog lying across his chest, snapping at wouldbe rescuers, the body of Adam H. Dimick, 36, of Hornell was found today in a woods five miles from here.

Captain Harry W. Lyon, U. S. N., retired, navigator of the Southern Cross, first plane to fly the Pacific, and Miss Thelma Bradbury of Norway, Me., a nurse, were married here yesterday, it was. learned today. He is the son of the late Admiral Henry W. Lyon and Mrs. Liele Lyon.
Sidney Abramowitz, a novice from the liinety-second Street Y. M. H. A., won the annual City Hall to Coney Island walk yesterday, leading home a field of forty-three starters.

The sinking British freighter, Nollington Court was missing tonight with part of her crew aboard. The steamer Chagres, which took off eighteen men last night, lost sight of the stricken vessel off Haiti in a rain squall, and its fate was undetermined.

The President and Mrs. Roosevelt ate their Thanksgiving turkey in the White House for the first time today, and did it in company with one of the smallest family parties ever assembled there. The day was spent for the most part quietly indoors, according to home-keeping traditions.

Two young tenderfeet dressed as cowboys robbed a train with blazing guns on a New Mexico desert today, but enraged passengers overpowered and captured them after W. L. Smith, a switchman, of El Paso, had been fatally shot.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor today attended the Thanksgiving service at the American Quai D'Orsay Church. Their decision to attend was made at the last minute, and was not accompanied by any public demonstration or curiosity by the churchgoers.

A total of 1,624 Hunter College students earned $93,028 last Summer, according to an announcement by Mrs. Dean Smith Schloss, in charge of undergraduate placements in the Bureau of Occupations at the college.

The continued immunity of bonds of the Port of New York Authority from taxation by either the State of New York or the State of New Jersey has been upheld in an opinion written by Julius Henry Cohen, general counsel of the Port Authority, and concurred in by Thomson, Wood Hoffman, municipal bond counsel.

Six hundred employes of the Mueller Company, a plumbing fixture manufacturer, received about $70,000 in supplemental pay envelopes today under the company's profit-sharing plan. Regardless of length of service each employee received an outright gift of $15.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Jane Aylward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Aylward of the Chateau Lafayette, Greenwich, and Alfred Reed Pennell of New York, son of John Frederick Pennell, took place this evening in St. John's Episcopal Church, Stamford, Conn.

George H. Weed, Yale, '38, of Savannah, has been chosen as the first recipient of the Thomas F. Curtin Jr. Memorial scholarship. The scholarship was established in 1936 by gifts from the class, the Stone Trust-and the graduate "Y" men in honor of Tommy Curtin, who, as captain-elect of the baseball team, died without ever having led his team-mates onto Yale Field.

Asserting that wars, uprisings and usurpations "make the Briand-Kellogg treaty to outlaw war seem a mockery" and that "the temptation is strong to look for a magnifying glass to find some blessing that summons to Thanksgiving," United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels declared today that the world has nevertheless marched far in the past century.

The engagement of Miss Sylvia Beatrice Rosenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rosenfeld of 2,440 Cornelia Street, Brooklyn, to Jerome Carlin, also of Brooklyn, was announced by her parents yesterday at a reception given at their home .

In one of the wildest see-saw scoring jamborees this ancient Thanksgiving fixture has known, Cornell scored twice in the last five minutes of play today to defeat a game Pennsylvania team that turned an apparent rout into a thrilling spectacle with its long, spectacular passes and defensive stands.
United States plus Steel interests are represented at a meeting here of the European Steel Cartel, and have engaged in negotiations for American participation, according to the French press today.

Beer sales for October totaled 4,185,932 barrels, a decrease of 1.5 per cent from October, 1936, according to a report issued yesterday by the United States Brewers' Association, based on Treasury Department figures. Sales for the first ten months of this year totaled 2,501,510 barrels, an increase of 5.5 per cent over the same period last year. The association stated that,

The New York Rovers dropped from the leadership of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League for the first time in the young season yesterday and for that they can blame the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, who stopped them, 4 to 3, in the feature game of a holiday double-header at Madison Square Garden.

Trading in wool goods markets this week was extremely dull and unfilled orders for all types of wool goods amounted to about 40 per cent of the business on mill books at this time a year ago, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service stated in its weekly report yesterday.

A disturbing picture of the international wheat trade and the situation facing the Canadian farmer in the event of a big crop in 1938 was outlined today by J. H. Wesson, Regina, at the fifteenth annual convention of the Alberta Wheat Pool.

Toronto's flying Maple Leafs streaked into Madison Square Garden last night and registered a 3-to-i triumph over the New York Rangers. The aggressive stick wielders from the North and the equally aggressive Blue Shirts waged a thrilling battle.

Nowadays democracy is often said to be a slow and bungling way of managing human affairs. It does take time, to be sure. Contrast the approaching Russian election with the one we had in New York City on Nov. 2. We were electing a Mayor and some other officials and, as it now seems, a City Councill.
Less than thirty minutes after he collapsed at a football game this afternoon, Councilman Walter H. Craig, Director of Accounts and Finances of Chester, died at his home here. His age was 57.

Colonel Arthur Poillon, United States Cavalry, will succeed Colonel Robert S. Knox, United States Infantry, as commander of Camp Dix, it was announced here today by Colonel Knox, who will retire from the service next Tuesday.

The marriage of Miss Blanche Gaye Axelrod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Axelrod of 250 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, to David Jacque Kay of New York, son of the late Mrs. Edward Schwab of Bradford, Pa., and of the late Jack Kreinson of Bradford, took place yesterday at noon in Temple Beth Emeth, Brooklyn.

Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Griesemer of Chevy Chase gave a dinner today at their home at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Doty Griesemer, to Arthur D. Thomas Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas of Glen Ridge, N. J.

A squad of picked detectives who are familiar with local public enemies and their henchmen has been assigned by Police Commissioner Valentine to prepare copies of police records, fingerprints and photographs of known gangsters now at large for the benefit of Los Angeles and Hollywood police, it became known last night.

The number of direct relief cases handled by the Charity Organization Society of New York last month was the lowest since May, 1930, although applications for assistance showed an increase for the period, Stanley P. Davies, general director, reported yesterday.

Savings, building and loan associations in New York City increased their total volume of home mortgages insured under the Federal Housing Administration program by 29 per cent during the first nine months of 1937, according to a report received here yesterday from Stewart McDonald, FHA administrator.

Japanese artillery and munitions and commissary trains having finally overtaken the infantry, which had advanced far ahead of all contacts a few days ago, the army as a whole has again resumed smashing through the disorganized Chinese defenses far to the west of Shanghai.

International unionism in Canada, which is being attacked on four fronts, replied today to some of its assailants. Denying charges that it had inspired "anti-union strikes," "chiseling agreements," "nuisance picketing"
Lawrence High School's unbeaten eleven concludd its season today by turning back Freeport, 20-0, in the Freeport Municipal Stadium.

The "1938 Almanac for New Yorkers," compiled, like its predecessor, by workers of the WPA Federal Writers Project in this city, will appear on the newsstands on Dec. 6, it was announced yesterday, The almanac is sponsored by the Guilds Committee for Federal Writers Publications, Inc.
The University of Maryland ended one of the most successful seasons in Old Line history today with a wellearned 8-to-0 victory over Washington and Lee.

At 5 o'clock this morning Premier Camille Chautemps obtained from the Chamber of Deputies a 518-to-6 vote of confidence that seems to assure the Cabinet's life against nearly all emergencies until the budget is passed and the new year begins.
No one ever seems to think of New Jersey as a State particularly adapted to deer hunting, but reports from the Fish and Game Commission indicate that these animals are increasing there year by year.
Church services, special dinners in public institutions and the distribution of more than 1,400 baskets of food to the needy marked the observance of Thanksgiving in Westchester County today.

Miss Marie Tudor McCook, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George McCook of Pasadena, Calif., who is a granddaughter of Mrs. Anson G. McCook and a niece of Mrs. McCook Knox, both of Washington, and Miss Marian Kirk, daughter of Captain Alan Kirk, U. S. N., and Mrs. Kirk, were the Thanksgiving Day debutantes here.

For the second successive week, bank clearings throughout the country have failed to equal the corresponding 1936 total. For the week ended on Wednesday, clearings in the twenty-two leading cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, were $5,285,273,000, against $6,527,449,000 in the 1936 period. This was a loss of 19.1 per cent, against 29.4 per cent the preceding week.

J. Forbes Potter, retired corporation president and director, died yesterday after an illness of two weeks at the Murray Hill Hotel. The son of Job L. and Hannah Heath Potter, he was educated at the Brockport Normal School and in the New York public schools. He started in the warehouse and transportation business at the age of 20.

A contribution of $10,000 to the United Hospital Campaign from Mr. and Mrs. George Blumenthal was announced last night by John W. Davis, campaign chairman. He announced also that gifts of $5,000 each had been contributed by Mrs. H. McKay Twombly, John Mortimer Schiff and Mrs. John M. Schiff.

An article aginst France of a violence rare even in a country like Italy where violent articles are the rule rather than the exception appeared over Virginio Gayda's signaure this evening in the Giornale d'Itala.

A graphic story of a race against death from "elixir sulfanilamide," carried on by the Food and Drug Administration in fifteen States from Virginia to California, a race not won until ninety-three persons had died after taking the lethal dose, was told by Secretary Wallace today in a report responding to Senate and House resolutions.
An airplane with nine passengers and a crew of two was reported missing tonight on a 120mile flight from Pickle Lake to Sioux Lookout.
The St. John's Prep eleven administered a 21-to-0 setback to its old borough rival, Brooklyn Prep, in the twentieth game of their series at Boys High Field yesterday morning.

The principals in tomorrow's intersectional football contest at Baker Field tapered off their training yesterday with light, short dummy scrimmages and signal drills. Stanford was sent through its paces in the morning by Tiny Thornhill on the polo field at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, and Lou Little worked his Lions at Baker Field in the afternoon.

Dr. James Rowland -Angell, former president of Yale University, returned yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines with Mrs. Angell after making a survey of educational broadcasts in England, Scotland, Denmark, Sweden and Norway. He recently was appointed educational counsel for the National Broadcasting Company.

Isak Dahle, life underwriter and authority on Norse culture, died yesterday in the Passavant Hospital at the age of 54. After his graduation from the University of Wisconsin, Mr. Dahle served as secretary to his father, Herman B. Dahle, a member of Congress from Wisconsin, 1899-1900.

Hearings before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the application of the railroads for higher freights and passenger rates will start on Monday in 'Washington. The carriers are asking a general 15 per cent advance in freight rates, with the exception of five commodities, for which specific maximums are requested.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Mary Sherman Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ledyard Mitchell of this place, to Paul Harvey Deming Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Deming, also of Grosse Pointe Farms.

Miss Adelaide C. Spikins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Spikins of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Good Shepherd, Brooklyn, to Charles W. Schlemmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Schlemmer, also of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William F. Sunday.

A pair of 4-months-old twins and their 2-year-old sister left here today for New York, where they will embark, unaccompanied, for Hamburg, Germany. The twins are Helen and Hertha Coelln, and their sister is Anna Margareta.
A youth and a young woman were killed and another couple were bruised when an automobile ran off Long Beach Road at Mott Street here early today.
Tabulation of returns from the nationwide unemployment census began yesterday and a report to Congress will be ready about Jan. 4, John D. Biggers, administrator, stated today.

George R. Weintraub, who had been day city editor and recently Sunday editor of The Atlantic City Press and Union since coming from Philadelphia seventeen years ago, died of a heart attack today at his home here. Mr. Weintraub, who was 44 years old, was a veteran of naval service in the World War.

Despite early profit-taking, the stock markets here moved ahead again today as a new buying wave arrived in the afternoon. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while Japanese loans advanced among the foreign bonds.

-The Providence Journal said today that a plea for suspension of trading in the wool tops futures market, a division of. the New York Cotton Exchange, pending an invest tigation of trading regulations, would be placed before the Senate Wool Investigating Committee next Tuesday by a group of wool dealers in Boston.
The creeping cliff of Los Angeles, a mass of earth that became restless after ages of good behavior, got a publicity man today.

The country estate of Kate D. Laufer at Millbrook, Dutchess County, has been purchased by Charles Bambrick of New York. The property consists of a nineroom Colonial-type house with guest cottage and outbuildings on twenty-eight acres of land.

The Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America announced yesterday a united Christmas appeal for funds to aid war and other refugees. Entitled "A Christian Witness to a World at War," the message, asking for aid for sufferers in China, for children on both sides in Spain and for Christian German refugees, will be sent to 125,000 Protestant clergymen throughout the country.
New York State will receive about $10,935,027 in Federal funds for highway and grade crossing projects for the fiscal year starting next July 1, the Bureau of Public Roads estimates.
Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Godwin entertained with a dinner last night at Sherry's for their daughter, Miss Jacqueline Godwin, who celebrated her birthday.

Mrs. Ada G. Mohr, known as the "Mother of the G. A. R." because of her work in behalf of Civil War veterans, died Wednesday morning in Jamaica Hospital, where she was taken Nov. 7 after she had fallen and fractured her hip while on her way to a church service in Jamaica. Her age was 89.

Hempstead and Baldwin engaged in a hard-fought football battle today that ended with the score deadlocked at 7-7. Ten thousand fans attended. Baldwin; the underdog, gave a brilliant defensive exhibition. Three times Hempstead was in position to score additional points, but the Craigmen held.

Ralph Lewis, character actor, suffered serious injuries last night when his automobile and that of Abdul Maljan, a valet employed by Jack Warner, were wrecked. Mr. Lewis suffered a crushed chest and fractured legs.
The Federal Wage and Hour Bill can now be saved for this session, it is generally assumed, only if the needed 218 names can be obtained on the petition to force the measure to the floor of the House.

Representative works of eight seventeenth-century and eighteenthcentury English artists have been presented to Princeton University's Museum of Historic Art by Dickson Q. Brown, '95, of New York City, it was announced today by Dr. Frank J. Mather, director of the museum and Marquand Professor Emeritus of Art and Archaeology.
The University of Richmond defeated its ancient rival, William and Mary, 6 to 0, today. A crowd of 12,000, including Governor George C. Peery, witnessed the contest.

Robert (Scotty) Rankine of Preston, Ont., today set a new record of 47 minutes 16 4-5 seconds in winning the annual. Berwick marathon run for the fifth straight year before a crowd estimated at 15.000.
Eight outstanding ski runners of Austria, Finland, Germany and Switzerland arrived yesterday aboard the Manhattan of the United States Lines and the Europa of the North German Lloyd Line.
Before more than 14,000 spectators Rutherford High created an upset today by scoring a 12-to-0 victory over Passaic High in their thirty-fourth annual football meeting.
John Adams High School defeated Grover Cleveland, 26 to 0, ird their annual football battle at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday before an overflow crowd of 18,000 spectators.

Mr. and Mrs. George Newby Savage gave a dinner at their home here today at which they announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Elizabeth Jane Matthers of Stone Ridge, N. Y., to the Rev. Auguste Felicien Marlier, rector of St. Pater's Church, Stone Ridge.

Adrian Archbold, grandson of more of the founders of the Standard Oil Company, and Miss Jessie Gebauer, daughter of Mrs. George John Gebauer of Erie, Pa., were married today in the home of the bridgegroom's mother in suburban Bonita.

Miss Elizabeth Maulsby Bouldin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bouldin 3d of West Orange, was married this afternoon to Frederick Martin Blaicher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Blaicher of Orange. The ceremony was performed in St. Mark's Episcopal Church, here, by the rector, the Rev. Harold G. Willis.

Rear Admiral Raymond S. Patton, the government's chief map and chart maker, died here today after a prolonged illness. His age was 54. Admiral Patton attained his rank as director of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, an office he held for the last eight and a half years.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild's at home will take place tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House and will feature excerpts from and a discussion of the opera "Der Rosenkavalier," under the title "An Evening With Richard Strauss."

A letter from President Roosevelt endorsing the safety program which the Elks organization is conducting on a nation-wide basis was made public yesterday by Major Charles Spencer Hart, Grand Exalted Ruler. The letter, written in answer to one sent to the White House by Major Hart, follows:
Announcement has been made by Kenneth Ogden of 50 East Seventysecond Street of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Jane Campbell Ogden, to Richard Ide Cluett, also of this city.

Miss Lucille Natural, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vito Natural of this place, was married this afternoon to August C. Jannarone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Jannarone, also of Nutley, at the home of her parents.
A strike against the government was strictly observed throughout Beirut today, all business and all schools shutting in response to manifestoes distributed here yesterday.

Newspaper publishers must give new consideration to their public obligations and remedy internal abuses if the freedom of the press in the United States is to be preserved, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University School of Journalism declared yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

Lawrence Tibbett, American operatio singer, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after spending seven months abroad singing in all. European countries except Italy. He said he got his best reception in Sweden.
Robert Nathan's new novel, "Winter in April," will be published by Knopf Jan. 10. Mr. Nathan's previous book, issued in September, 1936, went into five editions totaling more than 19,000 copies.

Louis B. Gloeckner, president of the B. Gloeckner Furniture Company, died today after an illness of two years. Mr. Gloeckner was a member of Temple Commandry Knights Templar, the Elks and Fort Orange Club. He was born here seventy years ago, a son of the late Bernard Gloeckner and Eva Gloeckner.
Amor Brujo, South American turf star, made an impressive debut in this country today by winning the $2,000-added Thanksgiving Day Handicap at Tanforan track.

The Baltimore Orioles and the Bronx Tigers will clash tonight in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game at the New York Coliseum starting at 8:45 o'clock. The contest is expecting to attract a crowd of 7,500.
Ralph E. Ogden. Miss Gertrude Lawrence, Mrs. Ila P. Henderson, Mrs. Thomas Meighan. David Broderick, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, agent.

After the collision of a police radio car and another automobile in Maspeth, Queen, Patolman William Baker, 33 years old, attached to the Glendale station in Queens, was arrested yesterday charged with driving while intoxiday.
Captain Fred G. French, U. S. A., retired, nationally known contract bridge player, died yesterday in Walter Reed Hospital, Washington. He was 44.

Great surprise was caused among adherents of democracy by an announcement today by Dr. Julius Maniu, head of the National Peasant party, that he had concluded an electoral pact with Corneliu Zelea Codreanu, leader of the antiSemitic Iron Guard, and Vintila Bratianu, semi-Fascist leader of the Independent Liberals.

Two Nobel Prize winners of 1937, Viscount Cecil of Chelwood, winner of the peace prize, and Dr. Clinton J. Davisson, who shared the physics prize for demonstrating the dual nature of the electron in its material. and electrical wave manifestations, sailed for Europe yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

Annual assembly of American Ethical Union, the Federation of Ethical Culture Societies in the United States, begins at 9:30 A. M. at 2 West Sixty-fourth Street and continues tomorrow. Speakers tonight: Fannie Hurst, Dorothy Kenyon, Rosalie Loew Whitney.

Having called for Federal compulsory control of the principal crops in a general farm bill which continues to be the "first order of business" in Congress, the Senate Agriculture Committee today called for further adjustment and regulation of the dollar under a single government agency to insure, as it contended, the success of crop control programs.

A proposal that the United Automobile Workers of America should declare "guerrilla warfare" on General Motors Corporation to win concessions that cannot otherwise be obtrained has been made by those union leaders who are members of the Communist party or adhere to the (Communist) "party line," it was learned today.

Miss Gertrude Le Boutillier, daughter of Mrs. G. H. T. Le Boutillier of Jericho, L. I., and this city, and Philip Le Boutillier, was introduced to society yesterday afternoon at a reception with dancing given by her mother at the Cosmopolitan Club in East Sixty-sixth Street.
Descendants of delegaes to the convention which ratified the Constitution for Pennsylvania on Dec. 12, 1787, have been urged to help complete the collection of likenesses of the sixty-nine members.

With Leslie MacMitchell of George Washington High School of New York setting a new record as he led a field of 283 contestants over the Branch Brook Park course, Seton Hall Prep captured the national interscholastic cross-country championship today.
Yesterday afternoon's patrons of the New York Hippodrome Opera Company were treated to the spectacle of a young woman conducting the orchestra in a holiday production of "Hansel and Gretel."
Amendments to the Neutrality Act, which would leave in force few of its principal provisions, will be offered soon by Senator Lodge.

The Kansas Jayhawkers, who surprised the Big Six football conference with victories, and the Missouri Tigers, who surprised it with defeats, "fought to a scoreless tie today after the latter had missed a last-minute triumph by 12 inches.

The most unfamiliar composition on the variegated program of Thanksgiving night attractions provided by Mr. Barbirolli and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall was Francis Poulenc's concerto for two pianos, performed by Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson for the first time at these concerts.

Three men said by police to have taken goods valued at $70,000 in a systematic looting of the Universal Car Loading Company, a Boston Albany Railroad subsidiary, during the last seven months, were arrested tonight following a two weeks' investigation.

An increase slightly greater than anticipated seasonally was registered in cotton-mill activity last week, and the adjusted index has advanced to 106.4 from 105.4. The figure for the week ended Nov. 21, 1937, was 133.0.
Marshall College's undefeated. eleven, held to a' lone touchdown in the first half, added three in the final periods to defeat West Virginia Wesleyan, 27 to 0, before a crowd of 10,000 today;.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie J. Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Nelson of this city, to Warren L. Scott, son of Mrs. Louise Scott Brightman and the late George W. Scott, took place this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church here.

A determined Harrison football team, paced by Jerry Bisceglia,. today won the championship of the Little Three of Westchester by defeating Rye, 6 to 0, at the Rye High School stadium. Saturday the Huskies conquered Frederick E. Bellow High, which previously upset Rye in the triangular series.
An increase of $226,827 was shown today in Bank of Montreal's net profits of $3,408,328 for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, compared with $3,181,501 in the preceding year.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Beatrice Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolphus F. Wood of Tottenville, S. I., to Matthias Vincent Lenahan, son of Mrs. John Lenahan of New York and the late Mr. Lenahan, took place yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady Help of Christians, Tottenville.

The cry of privilege was heard again in the House of Commons today-over the recent visit to London of Leopold III, King of the Belgians. Among the members' most jealously guarded privileges is that of free access to the Commons.

President Leon Cortes Castro gave the local press a friendly warning at a luncheon yesterday in honor of the members of the mediation commission and the delegates of Nicaragua and Honduras here considering the boundary controversy between those countries.

Advocates of the Black-Connery bill to regulate wages and hours in industry will intensify their efforts during the recess of the House until Monday to persuade thirty-eight more members to sign the petition that would free the measure from the Rules Committee, which has held it up since Summer.

Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to England, was admitted to the Johns Hopkins Hospital late today, after arriving from New York. Doctors said his condition was not serious, but he was ordered to rest and visitors were restricted. He was accompanied by his daughter, Miss Henrietta Bingham.

Detrolt, trying to climb out of the American Division cellar in the National Hockey League, defeated Chicago, 4 to 1, in a holiday game before 9,500 spectators tonight. It was Detroit's second victory of the season ad its highest goal total for a single game.

Production of gold in Ontario in October amounted to $7,398,887, a daily average of 674, according to the monthly report of the Provincial Department of Mines, issued today. The report said this compared with a daily average in September of $239,416 and $238.717 in August.

Tranquillity on the war fronts continues, but this stillness does not indicate any slackening of the Insurgent war effort. Many contingents of what was formerly known as General Francisco Franco's Army of the North are resting, though always at points from which they can easily be hurried to the front.

In a pulse-quickening battle that left a gathering of 27,009 exhausted at the finish, the Giants and Dodgers fought to a rousing 13-13 tie at Ebbets Field yesterday, the result of a touchdown and two field goals apiece.

The annual meeting of the congregation of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, will be held there Monday, Dec. 13, at 8:30 P. M. The nominating committee has offered the following names for trustees to be voted on at the meeting:
The National Railway Workers Syndicate today was asked by President Lazaro Cardenas to take over and operate Mexico's national railway system.

Mrs. Marie Philips, star of America's 1936 Olympic gymnast team, denounced today as "a bunch of terrible lies" Mayor Wilson's suggestion that she and Mary K. O'Connor, confessed slayer of 5-year-old Nancy Glenn, had engaged in abnormal relations.

Two sisters, neither of whom was able to swim, ventured out on the thin ice of a pond near their home this afternoon and both drowned. The victims of the accident were Palma and Margaret Santini, 14 and 11 years old, respectively.

Furman University's line tightened in the pinches today and a highly favored Clemson football team was held to a scoreless tie before a crowd of 17,000. The tie gave Clemson the State championship, but deprived it of an unblemished Southern Conference record.
The country was somewhat taken back today to discover that one of the measures proposed by the Minister of Interior would restore a blue law of 1815.
Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew are giving a dinner dance tonight in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton to introduce Mrs. Loew's daughter, Miss Catherine Dodge Rogers.

New York is a pretty big place for a young couple to be lost in, especially when they are here on a honeymoon after being married on Thanksgiving Day. So big, in fact, that no one in the streets seemed ever to have heard of Patrolman Thomas J. Moffitt, a member of the city Police Department.
Manhattan and Bronx socer stars played a 1-1 game with a Brooklyn combination before a crowd of 3,000 at Starlight Park yesterday.

Miss Barbara Lee Stearns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archie James Stearns of this place, was married this afternoon to Rodmann Meyer Fellows, son of Mr. and Mrs. Folger P. Fellows of Ithaca, N. Y., in the Scarsdale Community Baptist Church here. The Rev. Edward C.

Prices advanced today in the Toronto share market -in the slowest trading since 1932. The holiday on the other side of the Line cut off the usual coterie of United States clients, and volume dropped to 245,000 shares,. or little more than half the average for the month.

A 60-yard run by Ev Rossett, after receiving a short pass from Erwin Erdosey with only six minutes of the final period remaining, enabled the Riverhead High eleven to tie Southamption 6-all today before 5,000 fans.

The American University eleven lost its final game of the season today to the 'deceptive Hampden-Sydney Tigers, who put on a thrilling drive in the last half for a 19-to-0 victory before a crowd of 2,000.

Charles R. Hook, president of the American Rolling Mill Company, Middletown, Ohio, has accepted the chairmanship of the resolutions committee of the annual Congress of American Industry, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Dec. 7 to 9, it was announced yesterday by William B. Warner, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, sponsors of the congress.
Thousands of New Yorkers left the city yesterday to spend the week-end in their. home towns throughout the country and enjoy
The United Kingdom Government has accepted appointment of the Duke of Alba as General Francisco Franco's chief agent in London.

A THOUSAND orators have fumbled for words to express the luster and the spirit and the genius of Marie Curie. They have had an incomparable inspiration, and they have usually done remarkably well. But it remained for a fellow-scientist, a fellow-genius who shares her qualities of greatness and simplicity, to express it best. It was Einstein who said: "Marie Curie is, of all celebrated beings, the only one whom fame has not corrupted."

Faced with an emergency in having the Russian Cathedral of: St. Nicholas: in suitable condition for the thirty-fifth anniversary of its establishment next Sunday, the Very Rev. Michael Masloy, dean of. the cathedral, undertook the repair of a leaking roof on that edifice at great. personal risk.

Witnesses who failed to tell all they know about vice and gambling here when summoned before the October grand jury will be recalled and compelled to testify at future sessions of the investigating body.
President Albert Lebrun today officiated at the Trocadero Hall ceremonies closing the 1937 Paris Exposition which will be reopened next Mayif the Chamber of Deputies provides the money.
Radical realignment of Paramount's production schedule has brought the long contemplated "The Light That Failed" to the fore with shooting probable before the first of the year.

Endorsement of the Federal Wage and Hour Bill with the revisions promised by Representative Mary T. Norton, chairman of the House Labor Committee, was given yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, chairman of a conference of labor, consumer, civic and religious groups which last week urged such revision while approving the principle of minimum wages and maximum hours.

Four Tennessee Electric Power Company district managers told a three-judge Federal court today that sales of Tennessee Valley Authority Power in the State would result in "usurpation" of private utility markets.

Henry Muller, 47 years old, a laborer of East Meadow, L. I., who was arrested last night on a disorderly conduct charge made by Mary Elizabeth Barnes, a Negro, of 26 Grove Street, Hempstead, hanged himself at 4:45 o'clock this morning in the detention room at Nassau County policee Headquarters here.
Apparently thankful that the holiday afforded extra practice time, Coach Jimmy Crowley put his unbeaten Fordham football squad through a double workout yesterday.

Victory-starved by Colgate for the last eight Thanksgiving Days, Brown's Bears changed their diet this year and today devoured Rutgers, 7--6, for the Bruins' first football triumph recorded in Turkey Day competition since 1928.

Miss Lilian Baylis, who as director of the Old Vic and Sadler's Wells Theatres did more to revive popular interest in Shakespeare than any other person in recent years, died of a heart attack today at the age of 63.

George Vaccaro, 20 .years old, of 227 South Street, this city, was shot and wounded in the neck by Anthony Musto, 51, of 632 Montgomery Street, at Third Avenue and South Street shortly before noon today. As Vaccaro collapsed on the sidewalk Musto turned the revolver on himself, firing a shot into the side of his head.

The marriage of Miss Natalie Clemens, daughter of Mrs. James C. Clemens of West Hartford, Conn., to George M. Burbach Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Burbach of St. Louis, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.
Gorton High School gained the Yonkers scholastic football title by playing a scoreless tie With Yonkers Central in a'W. I. A. A. test before a crowd of 5,000 on the Gorton field this morning.
David Lewis Davies, Labor member of Parliament for Pontypridd for six years, died today. Mr. Davies, a miners' agent, was returned unopposed in the 1935 general election.
The body of Ramsay MacDonald rested in Frognal House, his Hampstead home, tonight, just three weeks after he sailed for South America "in search of that most elusive of all forms of happiness-rest."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A few months ago a favorite target for some of the "bitter enders" among WPA critics, including many of the more or less humorous so-called humorists, to shoot at was the use of work relief funds for mosquito control.

Mississippi State scored a major upset today by beating its ancient rival, the University of Mississippi, 9 to 7. In the fourth quarter, Gray, State tackle, downed a State punt on the Ole Miss 22-yard line and then walked away. Ray Hapes,

The question, "How good is Bob Pastor?" will most likely be answered'to the satisfaction of all concerned tonight when the Washington Heights heavyweight, who once played football for New York University, opposes the sturdy Nathan Mann of New Haven in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Sauare Garden.

Alfonse Volandi, 2 years old, of 50 Broadway, this city, was exploring in the neighborhood of his home today. Beside a house at 4 Broadway Alfonse noticed a four-inch drain pipe sticking out of the ground a few inches. He stuck his right foot into it to see how far it went down.

Congress reached a new kind of peak today with a waiting list of 107 proposals to amend the Constitution. There are fifteen resolutions proposing to make declarations of war possible only after a popular vote.

The Mexican Government has requested Washington not to suspend ship service of the Panama Pacific Line via the Panama Canal to the Port of Acapulco on the West Coast of Mexico and California, it was learned authoritatively today.

The Central Park Zoo was virtually deserted yesterday morning although the animals had been brushed up and cleaned for the expected holiday crowds. Leo, the lion, was somewhat taken aback as he paced his barred cell and saw no admirers except three urchins.

Henry L. Doherty, president of the Cities Service Company, has received the Anthony F. Lucas Gold Medal for distinguished achievement in improving the practice of finding and producing petroleum, it was announced yesterday by the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Siegman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Siegman of 895 Park Avenue, to Nathaniel Stratford Goldsmith, son of Mrs. Nathan Goldsmith, also of this city and the late Mr. Goldsmith took place last night in the Mirror Room of the Plaza.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Martin of Elizabeth, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betty Ann Martin, to Leonard E. Korn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Korn, also of Elizabeth.

While the "don't buy silk" campaign in connection with the Japanese boycott has had very little direct effect thus far upon the hosiery industry, a sustained boycott of silk by the American woman generally "would translate itself into economic and social results which the propagandists do not fully realize," the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers warned in a bulletin yesterday.

Adjournment of the Brussels Far Eastern conference provokes only a passing sigh of commiseration in German official quarters, mingled with a note of gratification at Germany's decision to remain away from the Nine-Power Conference.

The police were working yesterday to solve the mysterious death of Claude H. Kendall, 46-year-old former publisher of at least one "mystery thriller," who was found dead yesterday morning with a bed sheet wrapped loosely around his neck in his $7-a-week room on the eighth floor of the Madison Hotel, 21 East Twenty-seventh Street, near Madison Avenue.

Before the dance given for Miss Anne Grosvenor yesterday, Mr. and Mrs. Aymar Johnson of East Islip, L. I., gave a dinner in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for their debutante niece, Miss Marie Hamilton Russell, daughter of Mrs. Marie J. Russell of Florence, Italy, and of William Hamilton Russell of this city.

Operating revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for the ten months ended on Oct. 31 were $393,246,228, rising $30,666,716 over the same period in 1936, according to a report made public by F. J. Fell Jr., vice president and controller. October revenue, however, was off $2,656,659 from the year before, at $39.902.999.

Wake Forest uncovered an assortment of deceptive plays today an defeated Davidson, 19 to 7, before a chilled throng of 10,000. Dave Fuller, Deacon fullback, bucked three yards for the first touchdown in the opening period.

The monthly index of industrial activity in Massachusetts for October was 76.6 per cent, compared with 83.8 per cent for the same month last year, it was announced today by Elizabeth M. Herlihy, chairman of the State Planning Board. The drop was attributed in part to a decline in new building and shoe and cotton production.

Ben Hecht has been squinting at "The Front Page" again and, with one eye crinkled shut and the other sardonically glinting, he has written an impiously impish comedy about that recurrent. journalistic marvel, the seven-day wonder.

Dr. Emanuel Gamoran of Cincinnati, education director of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, urged Jewish youth today to develop an appreciation of Jewish cultural and esthetic values in order to safeguard themselves against "feelings of inferiority and corrosion of character."

Preachers in New York City pulpits yesterday counted America's blessings, material and spiritual, warned of the dangers to American liberties at home and abroad and urged their congregations to emulate the spirit of the Pilgrim Fathers on the first Thanksgiving in the New World.

Fred Blacker, 42 years old, a motion-picture machine operator, was shot and killed early today in a typical gang assassination in Summit, a southwestern suburb. County highway police expressed the opinion that he was a victim of enemies in Indiana labor circles.
