Beore 22,000 persons, said by officials to be a record Bowie attendance, Calumet Dick today won the $7,100 Thanksgiving Handicap in what was. his first start since his injury in the Washington Handicap at TLaurel.

Finding that the transfer proposed would not tend toward localized manage ment or interconnection of facilities but would result in the direct ownership and operation of electric facilities in Vermont by a company whose executive offices are in Minnesota, the Federal Power Commission has denied the application for transfer of all the properties of the Newport Electric Corporation, Newport, Vt., to the Citizens Utilities Company of Minneapolis.
It is the Ritz Theatre which will get "To Be Continued" a week from this evening. The play, in which Luella Gear is the leading performer, is now trying out at the National Theatre in Washington.

They called on Haywood (Sandy) Sanford again today and the gangling sophomore kicked Alabama into the Southeastern Conference championship with a-22-yard field goal that beat Vanderbilt, 9 to 7, and brightened the Crimson Tide's hopes for an invitation to the Rose Bowl or Sugar Bowl.

Representative John Rankin of Mississippi, advocate of public power development, said today that "determined opposition to the compromises which the utility interests are proposing in their conferences with President Roosevelt was developing on Capitol Hill."
The case of Albert Marinelli was tossed back yesterday into the lap of District Attorney-elect Thomas E. Dewey, with whom it originated as a political speech, by Governor Herbert H. Lehman.
Playing before a crowd of 10,000 persons today, the Lions of Lincoln University defeated the Howard University Bisons, 9-0, at Shibe Park in the thirty-second renewal of their Turkey Day classic.
Nicaragua will send the first women basketball team to play in the international series at San Jose, Costa Rica, with other Central American Republics.

Captain Fritz Wiedemann, one of the three personal adjutants to Chancellor Adolf Hitler, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, accompanied by Mrs. Wiedemann, to spend three or four weeks visiting in New York and Washington.

Herbert Morrison, chairman of the Labor Party's national campaign committee, warned his followers tonight that Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain may rush a general election in the hope of snatching a new five year lease on the government before being overwhelmed by the economic depression that is expected to follow the rearmament boom.

Lieut. Gen. Sir Robert Finlayson, colonel-commandant of the Royal Artillery, has been appointed General Officer Commanding British troops in Egypt, the War Office announced today. He will succeed Lieut. Gen. Sir George Weir. The appointment is effective April 12.
Chairman Copeland of the Senate Commerce Committee said today that he would introduce in a few days legislation to set up a national mediation board for the maritime industry.
Five men, about to break into the strong box of a stolen safe containing $375 in cash and $25 in checks, were foiled here today by four local hunters, who saw the thieves at work in a deserted wood.

The wedding of Miss Eleanor Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Moore Smith of this city, to John Canfield Howe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Howe of Passaic, took place this evening in Central Brick Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Harold E. Nicely.

Although ample financing is available for the construction of lowpriced homes, little progress can be made in this direction until other obstacles are overcome by a cooperative effort on the part of the entire building industry, states C. Harry Minners, president of the Bankerss Federal Savings and Loan Association.
Thanksgiving Day suggests a truce with everything except memory, bidding comment and analysis of current events to efface themselves for the occasion.

The Amen Boys, senior organization of the Grand Street Boys Association, assembled here today from New York City to engage in four days of "monkey shines which dignity does not allow within New York City limits."

Hundreds of thousands of New York children and their all-toowilling parents watched the Man on the Flying Trapeze and Pinocchio, the forty-four-foot man with the nose that grew longer every time he told a lie, cavort down Manhattan streets yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Ann Wodtke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hans V. Wodtke, to William Echols Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Carpenter of Akron, Ohio, took place here this afternoon at Rosalind Gardens, the home of the bride's parents.
A union drivers' strike on eight Greyhound Bus Lines serving sixteen States caused partial interruption of schedules today as a Federal Labor conciliator resumed peace conferences.

Harry Newman, who was organizer and first president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, has purchased a majority interest in Judge Magazine, It was announced last night. Mr. Newman succeeds Monte Bourjaily, former head of the United Feature Syndicate, as publisher of the magazine.

Today's major events: Don Cossacks Russian Choir, Carnegie Hall, 8:30-P. M.; Henri Deering, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30 P. M.; "Faust," New York Hippodrome Opera Company, evening; WPA Federal Opera Chorus, Greenwich Orchestra and soloists, WPA Theatre of Music, evening.

Miss Jane Carrott, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orville Browning Carrott of Belle Haven, Greenwich, was married to William Hall Boardman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Boardman of "Quarry Top," Riverdaleon-the Hudson, this afternoon in St. Mary's Church, Greenwich.

Although outrushed seventeen first downs to seven, the Albright Lions triumphed over a fighting Muhlenberg team, 7-6 today in the season's closing game and kept their winning slate clear. More than 10,000 witnessed the seventeenth renewal of a series that dates back tb 1913.

Undefeated Colorado University and her Phi Beta Kappa quarterback, Byron (Whizzer) White, scaled new heights of football glory together today. Colorado won its first undisputed Rocky Mountain 'Conference championship in thirteen years by defeating Denver University, 34 to 7, before 29,000 fans.

Edwin V. Aellawell, receiver of the Newtown National Bank of New York in Elmhurst, Queens, announced yesterday that the remaining assets of the bank would be sold on Dec. 1 at 10:30 A. M. in his office, 103-02 Northern Boulevard, Corona.

Miss Winifred Staub, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. J. Staub of North Arlington, was married to Jack Eugene Le Comte, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lon Le Comte of Caldwell, today in St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Essex Fells. The Rev. Harold R.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 25.-Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, challenger for the world's chess championship, which he lost two years ago, increased his lead over the titleholder, Dr. Max Euwe of this city, by defeating him tonight in the twenty-first game of their return match for the championship.

An economic boycott by the United States against Japan, Italy and Germany and the lifting by the government here of trade restrictions from China and the constituent government of Spain was recommended in a report of a special committee on international law of the New York City Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild, made public yesterday.

The annual financial report of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries for the- year ended on Aug. 28, issued for publication today, shows an operating profit of $5,876,183 after providing for Federal income taxes, including $310,000 for surtax on Undistributed earnings and all other charges.

In an exciting game of football with a thrilling finish, the Navy B squad won form the Tample B team today 22 to 21, Herb Graves, Navy back, kicking a field goal by placement from the 25-yard line five minutes before the final whistle.

A gulf disturbance which left a freighter and dredge stranded near the mouth of the Mississippi River was reported headed toward the Northwest Florida coast late today. Storm warnings to vessels in the gulf and small craft near the shore were continued from the mouth of the Mississippi to Carrabelle, Fla.

In the threecornered conversations held and in prospect between Great Britain, France and Germany, the role played by the King of the Belgians is interesting because it bears on the influence of the United States in current developments in Europe.

Two field goals and a 45-yard touchdown dash with an intercepted pass gave the Chicago Bears, western division leaders of the National Football League, a 13-to-0 victory over the Detroit Lions before a capacity crowd of 25,000 today.

General Edouard-Arthur. Duseigneur, former Air Ministry attach, and Eugene Deloncle, a banker, two alleged leaders of the Cagoulards [Hooded Ones] are now in custody. General Duseigneur was arrested this morning and transferred to Sante Prison after prolonged questioning.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray of New York and Hex House, Southampton, gave a large supper dance last night at their home, 11 East Ninetieth Street, for their debutante daughters, the Misses Therese and Rosamond Murray, and a large group of younger members of society.

Dr. Roberto M. Ortiz's election as President of Argentina was promulgated tonight by the Legislative Assembly. His six-year term will begin Feb. 20. The Assembly had had charges of electoral fraud and intimidation following reports of widespread violence during the September voting.

The Los Angeles Bulldogs defeated the New York Yankees before 17,000 fans at Gilmore Stadium today, 27 to 0, scoring their eleventh straight victory this year. The Bulldogs were held to a 6-0 lead in the first half, but pushed over another touchdown in the third period and two in the last.

Gettysburg trounced Franklin and Marshall, 26 to 6, in their Eastern Conference game today, before a crowd of 10,000. F. M. scored in the first period when a sustained drive of 97 yards carried the ball to the 2-yard line. Roeder took the ball at this point for the touchdown.

Curtis High School's football team, pitted against a heavier and moral experienced group of boys from Massanutten Academy of Woodstock, Va., went down to a 20-0 defeat in an intersectional skirmish that attracted 10,000 persons to Thompson Stadium at Stapleton, S. I., yesterday.

A recommendation that the administration "return to the policy of neutrality prescribed by Congress and permit the fever of foreign aggression and dictatorship" to "burn itself out" is made by Professor Edwin Borrhard of Yale University, in the December issue of Events, a monthly review of world affairs, to be published today. The magazine,

Under the contract which Puerto Rico has made for space at the World's Fair, allocation has been most appropriately made of a site within the entrance to the Hall of the States-a space of 4,500 square feet.

Army's football scuad, in charge of Captain Gar Davidson, and accompanied by a corps of assistant coaches and handlers, left at 5:30 P. M. today for Philadelphia where the Cadets will meet the Midshipmen in their annual game on Saturday. Army held a signal drill today, its final home workout.
Two burlesque theatres, which since September have been operating under strict conditions imposed by the city administration, decided yesterday to close.

A $250,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Hotel President will be obtained within a week, according to Paul A. Burgess, title officer of the Chelsea Title and Guaranty Company.

St. Benedict's Prep School captured the North Jersey Group 4 High School Football championship and presented a strong claim for State honors today by defeating its arch rival, Seton Hall Prep, 6 to 0, before a crowd of 7,500.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 20 amounted to 647,251 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 42,363 cars, or 6.1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week;
Sir Karl Fredrik Knudsen of London died at Greens Farms last night. Sir Karl was a Norwegian who was knighted by the King of England. He had been in this country only a few days.

In ten months of 1937, 1,032 new mortgages totaling $37,903,764 were placed on Manhattan real estate, as compared with 933 new loans for $24,100,430 in the same period last year, according to an analysis of new financing made by the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc.

Arthur Plaut Jr. of Long Beach, L. I., who has been one of the best young riders during the past season, today captured the Good Hands Trophy at the opening session of the Peekskill Horse Show and became the first to qualify for the competition at the national exhibition next year.

The annual report of Dr. Frederick Keppel, president of the Carnegie Corporation, is especially interesting this year because it discusses foundations in general and their part in our social and economic order.

A delegation of civic leaders, business men and labor representatives from Camden, N. J., visited the White House today to urge President Roosevelt to use his discretion and authority and assign to the Camden yard of the New York Shipbuilding Company one or both of the two naval supply ships which are to be built.

Columbia and Stanford, which started their seasons some 3,000 miles apart, will hit the end of the football trail together today when the New Yorkers and Californians clash at Baker Field before an expected gathering of 25,000.

Governor Lehman turned down today the request of Horace M. ray, chairman of the City Manager League of Yonkers, for an extraordinary term of the Supreme Court a special grand jury and a special prosecutor to investigate alleged election frauds in the city of Yonkers in connection with a referendum on a city manager plan at the last election and at the election last year.

52d St, s s 216 ft w of 8th Ave, 49.8x100.5; William Friedrich to Elhar Property Corp. 318 W 52d St; mtg $32,000. 1st Ave, 2,199, 25x100; Irving I. Erdhelm to 2,199 1st Ave Realty Corp, 274 Madison Ave, c/o I. I. Erdheim. Ave B, s e cor 4th St, 20x90: Patrick Keating to Bowery Savings Bank, consideration $42,000, foreclosure.

Retail trade here improved substantially during the week, in comparison with last week, but on the average the showing of local department stores did not reveal any gain over the corresponding week of last year. Active purchasing today would change the picture somewhat for the better, but up to last night the comparative sales figures showed a variation ranging from an "even break" down to 4 to 5 per cent under last year.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Oswald D. Settler of Short Hills, N. J., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Virginia Settle, to Dallas Howell Dobelbower, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Colcord Dobelbower of Chatham, N. J.

The report of the Crown Cork and Seal Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 showed a net profit of $1,922,121 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal income taxes and $741,983 loss by the Crown Can Company, and after extraordinary expenses for that company, which commenced production on Jan. 1, 1937.

New bond financing this week was again restricted to tax-exempt flotations, marking the fourth consecutive period during which no new corporate loan has been marketed. Interrupted by the Thanksgiving holiday, this week's offerings dwindled to $3,315,000. consisting of six municipal loans.
To Sports Editor of The New York Times: As an alumnus of Notre Dame, permit me to answer W. J. McChesney's statements apropos of Notre Dame and Pitt severing football relations.
Mrs. Agnes Gray Pratt, wife of Dr. Henry Sherring Pratt, retired Professor of Biology at Haverford College. died yesterday at her residence in Haverford at the age of 66.
Amsterdam's Zoological Gardens, Europe's oldest, is in danger of closing Jan. 1, only a few months before it should celebrate its centenary.

If the British Government had taken drastic action earlier in Palestine, there would have been less disorder in that country, Morgan Jones, member of the Labor party in the British Parliament, said last night in an address at the thirteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Lily Pons, opera star, who owns an estate in Silvermine, Conn., has enlarged her holdings there by purchasing an adjoining tract of more than seventeen acres. The property has a high elevation and includes farm and woodland with large native hardwood trees.

Alex Rosenswaike, chief of police, and Harry Yale, police lieutenant, both of Island Park, L. I., and three civilian co-defendants were found guilty yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions on charges of conspiracy to defraud in the operation of a charity scheme in which several thousand persons were said to have been victimized.

Mr. and Mrs. John Bell Huhn gave a tea dance yesterday at their home, 1,111 Park Avenue, to introduce their daughter, Miss Phyllis Huhn. Yellow and white chrysanthemums and Autumn foliage were used in the decorations.

The Southeast first team, winner of women's national field hockey laurels in 1935, displayed scoring power in today's round of the 1937 tournament at the new Trier High School field in defeating the Great Lakes representatives. 8 to 0.

The Pullman Company asked a 10 per cent increase in all Pullman fares in a petition filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission. A company statement said that Pullman traffic volume showed a "declining trend of increase over the corresponding period in 1936"

Once again, as in former years, the New York Stock Exchange has acted to restrain the overflowing generosity of its members. To prevent them from making the coming Christmas too merry-and therefore out of keeping with the prevalent spirit-the committee on arrangements has published its rules for gifts of gold, frankincense, myrrh and cigars to the employes of other members.

Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc., has placed a first mortgage loan of $105,000 for ten years, at 5 and 4 1/2 per cent, on the recently completed six-story apartment house on the east side of Park View Terrace, 325 feet north of East 196th Street, for the Newbo Realty Corporation, Morris Bogdonoff, president.

Further intimation that he was in accord with the growing movement on Capitol Hill to revise the undistributed profits and capital gains taxes in the interest of activating private capital was given by President Roosevelt today as he announced still other plans designed to aid business in taking up the recovery load.

The following Marine Corps changes dated Nov. 22, were announced today: Hartsel, Maj. C. H., Washington, D. C., to duty as Inspector Instructor, 8th Battalion, Fleet Marine Corps; Reserve, Toledo, Ohio.

Make and Break, a long shot, rushed to the front in the stretch to win the feature race at Tanforan today. The time for the mile was 1:41 3-5. Mickey's Man was second by a nose over Wegoway, the favorite. The victor, owned by C. T. Leavitt, Canadian turfman, paid $18.80, $7.20 and $3.20; Mickey's Man, $6 and $3, and Wegoway, $2.40 for $2 mutuel tickets.
If he survives his first heat, Percy Belvin, Bermuda's only representative in the British Empire Games of 1938, will make a round trip covering 22,000 miles to swim 220 yards.

The great Boston wool district, where practically all the wool business of country is conducted, is divided the issue raised by various wool dealers and manufacturers on the value of the wool futures market.

Although aided by colder weather and Christmas displays, retail trade this week was held to from about even to 2 per cent higher than in the preceding week and from 2 to 10 per cent higher than in the same week last year, Dun Bradstreet reported yesterday in its weekly trade review.

From as far away as London, England, and from distant points in the United States calls have come to this city with offers of blood to help two victims of the rare and deadly streptococcus viridans. The offers had reached a total of hundreds tonight.
Miss Mary Leisenring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Leisenring of Ardmore, was introduced tonight by her parents at a dinner dance which they gave in the rose garden of the Bellevue-Stratford.

There has been a 25 per cent increase in the number of cases of social diseases reported to the Health Department this year, forty social hygiene executives were told yesterday by Marie de Mario, statistician for the Bureau of Social Hygiene of the Health Department. While about 75,000 cases were reported in 1936, the indicated total for 1937 is about 100,000 cases, she explained.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mueller of this place of the engagement of their daughter. Miss Myrtle Helen Mueller, to J. William Esberg Jr., son of Mrs. S. Pierce Esberg of Biltmore Forest, N. C. and Sacramento, Calif.
Kneeland S. Durham, former justice of the peace, Village Treasurer and clerk of the Board of Education here, died yesterday at his home at the age of 71. He was a retired New York hardware salesman.

A first glimpse of the exposition on its last day does not show much of the fair, only a jumbled picture of vast doll houses filled with shining gear and gadgets oddly repetitive; the bright spume of fountains, regiments of fountains; endless walls of glass and transparent towers;

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:...
The Insurgent base of action tonight was transferred from the cold north of Spain to warmer territory for a smash against Almeria, Government port on the southeastern coast.

Mrs. Carrie G. Bunzl, a member of the board of directors of the Chapin Home for the Aged in Jamaica, Queens, and a former president of the Graduate Club of Hunter College, died yesterday in Medical Center from injuries she received on Monday night when she was struck by an automobile near her home, 300 West 109th Street.
Romulo Gallegos, 53, Venezuelan novelist; his wife, 45, and brotherin-law, Raul Santana, 44, were injured today when their automobile turned over four times fourteen miles west of here.
Trading in fresh pork cuts was fair on the local market, other classes moved only fair to slow. The lamb market was sharply higher; fresh pork cuts steady to slightly higher; other classes unchanged.
SLOGUM HOUSE, by Mari Sandoz. (Little, Brown, $2.50.) A novel of the Nebraska cow country.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Finnigan of Forest Hills, Queens, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Adreon Finnigan, to Charles Arthur Partington, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Partington of East Oranze. N. J.
By pulling a lever which flooded the Claymont Trust Company's office with tear gas fumes, Miss Esther N. White, a mild-mannered bookkeeper, forced three armed bandits to flee empty handed today.
This week's Federal Reserve statistics, which appear one day later than usual because of the holiday on Thursday, carry some interesting implications.

The main match listed to a finish between Gino Garibaldi, 219, Italy, and Pat Meehan, 215, Ireland, was declared no contest in 16:45 when both grapplers fell from the ring and were counted out by Referee Hughie, Riley at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.
Mrs. Sarah Girdwood, widow of James Girdwood, a wholesale linen merchant of New York, died today at the home of her daughter, Dr. Ethel G. Peirce, a Bryn Mawr physician, in her eighty-third year.

A new ballet company to be known as the Ballet Russe, with Leonide Massine as ballet master and artistic director, is scheduled to make its American debut in a four weeks season at the Metropolitan Opera House next October.

Advent Sunday will be observed in all ritualistic churches tomorrow, it being the first Sunday in Advent and the first Sunday in the new year, according to the Church Calendar. There will be sermons and oratorios about the Advent season.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 23: CAPTAIN Grady, R. C., relieved from additional duty as commander of submarine division; to continue duty as Commander Submarine Squadron 6.

The executive committee of the Republican National Committee will meet at French Lick Springs, Ind., on Dec. 16 to select the policy committee of 100 which will be authorized to draft a declaration of party principles.
Summoned from retirement to end the pigeon nuisance in a fashionable neighborhood here, William Read, ex-policeman, "liquidated" 176 birds in a two-hour hunt today with a double-barreled shotgun.

A contribution of $25,000 from the New York Telephone Company headed a list of corporate gifts to the United Hospital Fund which was made public yesterday by John W. Davis, chairman of the campaign. Mr. Davis announced that the total raised to date in the drive for more than $3,000,000 was $1,417,933.94.

Chicago, due to its geographical advantage and the westward growth of population and purchasing power, is rapidly becoming the market heart of American commerce, Percy Wilson, treasurer of Marshall Field Co., said today at the dedication of the new Merchants and Manufacturers' Club in the Merchandise Mart.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $21,416,587, to be represented by sixty-two municipalities. This compares with the revised total of only $7,962,315 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $23,237,591.

Scott P. Squyres, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, announced tonight that the organization would undertake to obtain 25,000,000 signatures to petitions to Congress and the President, calling for the adoption of policies designed to keep the country out of war.

Mrs. Nancy Wilson of 135 West Fifty-sixth Street and John Lobb, an instructor, of South Hadley, Mass., obtained a marriage license at the Municipal Building yesterday and said they plan to be married in this city next month.
Formal control and supervision of Chinese postal, customs and communication organizations in Shanghai was being taken over this morning by the Japanese.

Striking United Automobile Workers of America, massing a heavy picket line with the aid of other C. I. O. unions, failed today in a second attempt to halt production at the Ford Motor Company assembly plant here.

A field goal in the final two minutes of play by Ed Looran St. Augustine left guard, broke a tie and gave his team a 35-33 triumph over the Alumni quintet in a game played on the winners' court in Brooklyn last night.

Baseball is ready to take a fresh toe hold and slam out one of its greatest seasons, William Harridge predicted today. The American League president, while declining to disclose exact statistics, said that the 1937 American League season showed a "handsome"

Allerton Ave, 914-20 (16-4445); Celia Cooperman to State Mortgage Commission; extends mtg to Aug. 20, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $25,000. Jerome Ave (12-3318), e s, 325 ft n of 196th St, 75x134; Newbo Realty Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave; extends mtg to Oct. 1. 1947, at 5 per cent until Nov. 24. 194 at 4 1/2 per cent thereafter; $105,000.

Frank Capra and Columbia reached an agreement today and signed papers under which the director will withdraw his suit against the studio and return to work tomorrow to launch plans for two films he will make next year.

Miss Mary Sutherland Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Sidney Harrison of this place, was married here tonight in St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church to Dudley Digges Pendleton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley D. Pendleton of Pittsburgh, by the rector, the Rev. Wilford E. Mann.

Miss Naomi Weinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Weinberg of Brooklyn, was married to Salomon Bochner of Princeton, N. J., son of Mrs. Joseph Bochner of London and the late Mr. Bochner, at noon yesterday in the Plaza by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise.
The 1937 International Exhibition of Paintings will close at Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, Sunday afternoon, Dec. 5.

Government officials and Federal employes, not to mention throngs of army and navy officers, began the trip to Philadelphia shortly after noon today to witness tomorrow the annual football game between the two service teams.

35th St, 317 W; to 5-story tenement and stores; Joseph Manheimer, 219 E 60th St, owner; John H. Knubel, architect; cost, $4,000. 35th St, 319 W; to 4-story tenement and stores; same, owner; same, architect; cost, $4,000.

Discovery that a $10 bill passed recently in Northern Illinois was part of the $50,000 ransom paid in vain for the return of Charles S. Ross gave new impetus today to the search for the kidnappers of the 72-year-old retired Chicago manufacturer.
District Attorney-elect Thomas E. Dewey is prepared to offer evidence to prove every statement he made about Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader and New York County Clerk, it was learned yesterday.

Mrs. Thomas Scudder Winslow of 901 Lexington Avenue gave a dinner with dancing last night for her daughter, Miss Mary Olive Winslow, in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Winslow had planned to present her daughter last season, but owing to the death of Dr. Winslow the formal debut was postponed.

The engagement of Miss Laura Noston Collord, daughter of Mrs. James V. Davison of 30 Sutton Place and George L. Collord of Pittsburgh, to Chamberlain Hoyt Woodruff, son of Mrs. Carroll McKim Stetson of Bronxville, N. Y., has been announced by her mother.

The marriage of Miss Edna Joan Giffels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Giffels of Laingsburg, Mich., to Thomas G. Lynch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Lynch of the Bronx, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Miss Betty Scott Clark, daughter of Mrs. Scott Clark of Spring House, Wynnewood, and of Walton Clark Jr. of New York, was married this afternoon to John Wesley Cullen, son of Mrs. Edward Everett Cullen Jr. of Rosemont.
Edward F. McGrady, director of labor relations for the Radio Corporation of America, was elected yesterday a director of the RCA Manufactoring Company.

The denial issued in Paris of the violently antiItalian speech that Marine Minister Cesar Campinchi is accused by the Italian press with having delivered at Toulon on Oct. 23 has done nothing but enrage Italian public opinion even further and to make-ItaloFrench relations ever more strained.

BOSTON COLLEGE VS. HOLY CROSS-Last down and about six yards to go. The Purple Crusaders have-wait a moment! Halt! About face! Mention of the Purple brings up the subject of the Bob Zuppke art exhibition at the Western Studios, eleventh floor, Woolworth Building. What purples! The perennial football coach of the Illini, using a single-wing set-up for his palette, has on exhibition about twentyfive spread plays he ran on canvas.

Mrs. Reginald Louise Hvass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Knott of Bristol, Conn., was married yesterday to Colvin W. Brown of Stamford and New York in the parsonage of the North Stamford Congregational Church. The Rev. George V. Hamilton performed the ceremony.

David V. Penn, supervising examiner for the Second District of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, with headquarters in New York, died here suddenly today of a heart attack in his home, 100 Palisades Avenue. He was 37 years old.
Mr. and Mrs. William T. McIntire gave a large reception this afternoon at their home here, 131 Brayton Street, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Catherine Miller McIntire.

With a decrease of about 19 per cent in "Christmas club" savings reported for the country generally, the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York announced new high totals yesterday in these savings and in their participants.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26.--The coming negotiations with Great Britain to formulate a reciprocal trade agreement with this country were, attacked in the Senate today by Senator Lewis as unjustified and dangerous.

Movements of vessels follow. all dates are Nov. 24, unless specified: At San Diego: Partridge, Nov. 25; Plunger, Downes. Arctic, at San Francisco, Nov. 25. Bridge, at Hong Kong, Nov. 26. Bulmer, at Shanghai, Nov. 26.

The basketball team of St. Nicholas of Tolentine yesterday defeated New York Cathedral Prep, 42 to 27, on the winner's court. It was Tolentine's third triumph in three starts, while Cathedral has won one and lost one.

On Dec. 10 the Limited Editions Club will award fellowships of $2,000 each to four American book illustrators selected by a jury composed of Thomas Craven, Robert B. Harshe, Henry R. Luce, Frank Jewett Mather and F. A. Whiting Jr. The winners will illustrate forthcoming publications of the Limited Editions Club.
Two teams that have won only three major games between them meet here tomorrow before the season's record crowd, and the whole town is caught up in a fever of football excitement.
Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein ruled today that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation had the right to participate in dividends from closed banks.

Howard Bergman and William Viertel scored in the amateur handicap 18.2 balkline tournament at the Lawler Manhattan Academy last night. Bergman, playing for 175, acquired his total in thirty-five innings, while his opponent, Edward Knapp Sr., needing 140,
Orrin Sydney Starr, a resident of Stamford fifty-four years, died at his home this morning in his ninetysecond year.

Miss Julia Bagley Epes, daughter of Mrs. Louis S. Epes and the late Justice Epes, was married to Allan Watts Staples of Roanoke, son of Attorney General and Mrs. Abram P. Staples, this afternoon at the home here of the bride's cousins, Dr. and Mrs. Edward Paisley.

New Yorkers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Italian motor ship Vulcania include Mr. and Mrs. Colvin W. Brown, Mr. and Mrs. Giacoma Dusmet, S. Morris Mead, Major and Mrs. Henry R. Allen and Mr. and Mrs. Richard Feier.

The State Commission of Correction blamed "laxity in regulation and control" at the Onondaga County penitentiary for the escape on Nov. 16 of three convicted members of the 1933 O'Connell kidnapping gang and called on the Legislature to transfer management and control of county prisons to the State, in a report released today.

A "declaration of convictions" for physicians, which declares for medical insurance and against the government aid proposed early this month by the' committee of physicians headed by Dr. Russell L. Cecil of New York, is being circulated by Dr. Eugene S. Kilgore of San Francisco among medical societies and individuals, it was learned yesterday.

Advertising and merchandising efforts for Baltimore Club blended whiskies, which for the last few months have been carried on in a number of markets in the East, will be concentrated for some time to come in the metropolitan New York area, Martin G. Taub, general sales manager of GordonO'Neill Company, Inc., and Baltimore Distilling Company, Inc., stated yesterday in announcing the appointment of a new advertising agency, Gussow Kahn Co., Inc., New York.

Kingsbridge Rd, (11-3215) s s 346 ft w of Grand Ave, 150x97; H-A-N-D Realty Corp to Suburban Brokerage Corp, 20 Broadway; mtg $130,200. Bristow St, 1,327 (11-2972); Charles Flaxman to Salvatore Grippo, 1,304 Chisholrd St. Edson Ave, 4,084 (17-4981): Mattie Juliber to Edward Small. 3.415 Edson Ave.

The provision for compulsory control of production of cotton in bills drawn by both Senate and House committees and monetary recommendations in the Senate stimulated buying operations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Now that Thanksgiving is over and the theatre is entering the dullish pre-Christmas period, the less hardy shows are beginning to droop along the way. Five of the town's list are closing after tonight's performances, and before the week-end is over there might be another one or two.
The navy, pushing to completion by 1942 its largest peacetime building program, disclosed today a shortage of draftsmen.

Miss Margherita Childs, daughter of Mrs. H. G. E. Kyburg of Cos Cob, Greenwich, and Eversley Childs of New York, was married to Maxime Charles Fidao of Cos Cob, formerly of Riverside, son of Maxime N. Fidao and the late Mrs. Fidao, in the chapel of St. John's Episcopal Church, Stamford, Conn., this afternoon. The Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham officiated.

General Electric workers who have been employed by the company for five years or more will receive a bonus of 7.2 per cent of their earnings in the last six months of this year, according to an announcement yesterday by Gerard Swope, president of the concern.

Miss Annis Burnham Stearns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stearns of South Orange, was married this afternoon to Frederick Spofford Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilbert of Englewood, in the Church of the Holy Innocents, Episcopal. of St. Cloud, West Orange.

Liberalization of the Federal Housing Administration's mortgage insurance policies appears to be the key to be used by President Roosevelt and Congress to unlock the door holding back private capital from the construction field.

Federal justice operatives and internal revenue agents were sent into Revere tonight, a few hours after Governor Hurley dispatched Captain James T. Sheehan and a squad of the Boston police into that city with orders to clean it up following the murder of Louis Gaeta, a gang leader.
Estonian official quarters are annoyed over the way local German elements are taking advantage of the official visit of the German cruiser Leipzig to stage pro-Nazi demonstrations.
Mrs. Ralph Peters Jr., entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Dorothy Riddell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Riddell Jr.
Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard construction of carded gray goods as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

KINGS BOESINGER, WILLIAM (March 4, 1937). Gross assets, $8,525; net, $7,921. To son. Seneca A. Boesinger. Chief assets, real estate, $5,400; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,100. Duer, Strong Whitehead, attorneys, 15 Broad St., Manhattan.
The census of school children taken by Swedish education authorities as a preliminary to the reorganization of teachers' training shows a remarkable decline in the number attending school.

The Corsican Duke, Joseph Pozzo di Borgo, a former lieutenant of Colonel Francois de la Rocque, head of the French Social party, was arrested today during a search which police made in his Paris home.

Although the Communist party has suffered some severe setbacks in its attempt to control the policy of the United Automobile Workers of America, it has not relinquished its pressure against the "Progressive" group led by President Homer Martin, and it is now laying the groundwork for a demand that will ultimately be made to call a special convention to oust Martin, it was learned today.
The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Nov. 24 were announced today: Jewell, Lt. Comdr. R. C., to command

A belligerent Boston terrier swaggered out into Western Avenue today and challenged all comers. The first to cross his path was a street car. The dog gamely held his ground. The trolley jerked to a halt.
Wheat made a weak start and a strong finish today, the December delivery rallying 3 5/8 cents a bushel from an early break to close at the high point. Net gains were 1 to 1 1/8 cents.

Metropolitan Museum of Art. "English Furniture: Queen 'Anne and Chippendale," Ethelwyn Bradish, 11 A. M.; "Rugs for the Modern Home," Grace Cornell, 11 A. M. and 3 P. M.; "Interior Decoration for the XVIII Century French Aristocracy," Roberta M. Fansler, 2 P. M.; Motion Pictures, 2:30 P. M.; "Holbein: Portraits and Compositions," Paul Ganz, 4 P. M.

The American Football League announced its own "All-America" team, today, giving honor positions to five Los Angeles team members, three from Cincinnati and one each from. New York, Boston and Rochester.

Miss Virginia Walbridge Hill, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. George W. C. Hill of West Hartford, was married here this afternoon to Richard Lyons Hughes, son of Mrs. Clarence Hall Wilson, also of West Hartford, in the South Congregational Church, of which her father is pastor emeritus.

A fiveday work week for employes of the Federal Government was proposed to the Senate today in a bill introduced by Senator Logan. A similar measure has been introduced in the House by Representative McCormack of Massachusetts.

Dick Harlow, Harvard football coach, told the Philadelphia Harvard Club today that he had his best material at Harvard in his first year, three seasons ago. "I had men on that squad who, if they had' been at Pittsburgh, would have received All-American mention," Harlow declared. "I refer especially to Don Jackson, who was an unusual player."
During one of the densest fogs ever experienced in Britain, a German night freight plane for Cologne tonight crashed into a hangar while leaving Croydon airfield, with the loss of three lives.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, world's chess champion, who is defending his title against Dr. Alexander Alekhine of Paris, experimented again with the double gambit idea in the seventeenth game of their match, which is still in progress. The full score of this contest reached here yesterday from The Hague. where it was contested.

Nearly 1,000,000 tons of British shipping were broken up or sold for that purpose in the fiscal year ended June 30. According to the latest edition of Lloyds Register, 460 vessels of 688,847 tons were actually broken up; 59 of 73,657 tons were in process of demolition, while 99 of 220,635 tons had been sold to wreckers.

Mayor La Guardia and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine have decided upon a substantial reorganization of both the uniformed force and the detective division of the Police Department about the first of the year, it was learned yesterday.

The Baltimore Orioles made a spirited last-period rally that netted a trio of goals, but the five tallied by the Bronx Tigers in the first two stanzas were sufficient to give the home forces a 5-to-3 triumph last night in the New York Coliseum before 3,900 fans.

Murray D. Safanie, economist and member of Shearson, Hammill Co., and J. Leo Grace, president of the Kokomo Lithographing Company, have been elected to the board of directors of the Brown Rubber Company, Inc., of Lafayette, Ind.

Business activity in the Pittsburgh district fell another 3 points last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh. The current downswing has now been under way with depressing regularity for nine consecutive weeks, during which the index has tumbled from 119.7 to 82.8, a decline of about 31 per cent.
A divorce on grounds of "cruelty" was granted here today to Mrs. Constance Edna Farber De Bower, former actress, from Herbert De Bower of New York.
Pensioned On his own application: PATROLMAN--Howard E. Young, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 27, 1912.
The following table shows the fifteen most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:
Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg's book, "Three Times Austria," was published today and is causing great interest in political circles.

Introduced as the "greatest apostle of tolerance in the nation today," former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York pleaded today for a more frequent expression of faith in the word of God by men in public life as a cure for world troubles.

In what she termed "the dreary role of best friend and severest critic," Fannie Hurst, the novelist, admonished the modern woman last night that her contribution to contemporary life "is not good enough."

Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist Organization of America, adopted a resolution at its convention today calling upon the World Zionist Organization in its negotiations with Great Britain "to bring about the complete implementation of the mandate over an undivided Palestine."

Nathan Mann, New Haven's candidate for honors in the heavyweight field, scored a convincing victory over Bob Pastor, champion of New York State, in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
A. H. Barker of the Yale Club, seeded No. 1, carried off the honors in the final of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association invitation tournament at the New York A. C. yesterday.

Notre Dame's squad, battle worn and weary, and the Trojans of Southern California, beset with injuries-but both still full of fightwill meet here tomorrow in the twelfth act of the country's longest consecutive intersectional gridiron rivalry.

The marriage of Miss Mary Frances Bruen, daughter of Mrs. Arthur H. Bliss of West Orange, to John Clifford Clay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford F. Clay of East Orange, took place today in Ridge View Community Presbyterian Church here, with the pastor, the Rev. Oscar Lowry, officiating.

Frederic A. Morny of 25 East Tenth Street, engineer and inventor, filed suit yesterday in Federal court for treble damages of $3,000,000 under the Sherman Anti-Trust Law against Western Union Telegraph Company, Trans-Lux Daylight Picture Screen Corporation, Trans-Lux Movie Ticker Corporation, News Projection Corporation and five individuals.

Miss Sybil K. K. Newhall, daughter of J. George Newhall of the Mill Run, Phoenixville, has completed plans for her marriage on Dec. 18 to Charles L. P. Townsend of Altamont, N. Y., son of Mrs. Franklin Townsend of Albany.

Holy Cross's unbeaten but twice-tied Crusaders were reported apprehensive about starting as favorites over Boston College in the thirty-fifth football game between the keen Jesuit school rivals tomorrow at Fenway Park.

More than 100 horses, many of them ribbon winners in metropolitan horse shows and the property of persons prominent in society in the Oranges and Montclair, were scattered over the wooded First Mountain here after fire of undetermined cause destroyed, this afternoon, the buildings and stables of the Montclair Riding Academy, one of the largest of its type in New Jersey.

Asserting that the present business decline appeared to be a temporary check in progress toward larger production volumes and higher standards of living, the American Federation of Labor in its monthly survey of business today urged the need for maintenance of wages and employment and measures to promote business confidence as steps to avert a more serious recession.

Representative Fred M. Vinson of Kentucky, chairman of the subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee which is considering revision of tax legislation, was appointed today as associate justice of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia by President Roosevelt, who also named as associate justice Henry W. Edgerton, professor in the Law School of Cornell University.

There can be no stronger bond of mutual regard and understanding than that of labors shared-of constructive work done together. In these words the Marquis of Linlithgow, Viceroy of India, a short time ago expressed his confidence in the newly established system of responsible government in the eleven provinces of British India.

13th St, 538-40 E, 1-story brick laundry, 64.8x103x irreg; Harold Schrler against United Power Laundries, Inc; due, $11,567, subject to mortgages of $30,000 and $13,200; to plaintiff for $43,700. By B. HOLLANDER SON Ave A, 194, 5-story tenement, 28.9x51.10; Peter Olenen and Mary Metz against Russian National Publishing Co; due, $10, 567. subject to mortgage of $17,000; to plaintiffs for $18,000.

Oxford is counting on three Princeton graduates, Jack Irwin of Keokuk, Iowa; Cresson Kearney of San Antonio, and Charlie Owen of New York and Miami, to lend valuable assistance tomorrow in the annual Oxford-Cambridge relays.
A reduction of about 200,000 tons in New York's barge canal shipments for 1937 was attributed today by Harvey O. Schermerhorn, State Commissioner of Canals, to lower exports of wheat.

Two new playgrounds in Manhattan and a third in Queens have just been opened to the public, it was announced yesterday by the city Parks Department. A playground along the Harlem River between 150th and 154th Streets, to serve the Harlem Housing Project, was developed on land set aside for the purpose by the Housing Authority.

The stock markets here were quiet today. Some sections were easier because of profit-taking, today being the last day of the account. Gilt-edge issues were firm, but most foreign bonds were dull; Chinese issues sold off.

The first photographs have arrived here of sketches by John Steuart Curry, one of the leading American artists, for his series of mural paintings for the Kansas State Capitol at Topeka. Last week Mr. Curry submitted his sketches and ideas to the Kansas Murals Commission, of which Governor Walter A. Huxman is chairman.

More than 600 reservations have been made for the dinner that will be given for the Very Rev. Edward F. Leonard in honor of his having recently been made a Papal Chamberlain by Pope Pius XI, in the Hotel Astor tomorrow.
First prize of $200 and a gold medal in the seventh annual contest of the Israel Sachs Foundation for Interior Decoration has been awarded to Miss Julia Strider of Pratt Institute, Brooklyn.

Today's major events: Sergei Rachmaninoff, Carnegie Hall, afternoon; Paolo Spagnolo, 6-year-old pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; Edward Steuermann, pianist, Town Hall, evening; New York Hippodrome Opera Company, "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," afternoon, "Aida," evening; Guiomar Novaes, pianist, Washington Irving High School, evening.

What has been one of the best teams of modern years to wear the Maroon of Fordham will trot out on the field of the Yankee Stadium early this afternoon to defend its record of no defeats against New York University.
A police-estimated crowd of 2,000 persons took City Manager C. O. Sherrill at his word today that the city had work for every man who was willing, and eligible for relief.

The Federal Maritime Commission will demand that United States ship lines receiving operating differentials from the government agree to abide by minimum manning and wage scales established by the commission and build ships sufficient to meet the competition of foreign lines in their respective trades, it was learned yesterday.

The one-story garage at 3,449 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, has been leased by John La Canin, Inc., through the Bulkley Horton Company, which also reports leasing the one-story brick business building at 956 Dean Street to the Mother Hubbard Cake Company and the premises at 1,005 Thirty-ninth Street to the Greenley Stores, Inc.,
Drake University of Des Moines, Iowa, staged a 45-yard-touchdown march early in the fourth period to defeat the University of Miami, 7 to 0, in an intersectional football game tonight.

Martin J. Feeney, retired chief of police of this city, died yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla., at the age of 77. Since his retirement in 1931, after forty-six years of service on the Police Department, he had been spending his Winters in Florida.

Funeral services for John G. Cavanagh, arbiter and director of betting at New York race tracks for more than four decades, were held yesterday in the form of a solemn requiem mass at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima, Parkville Avenue near Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

AXELROD-Yetta, widow of the late Selig, beloved mother of Nathan, Sally Diamond, Joseph Faye Mintz and Benjamin. Funeral Sunday. Nov. 28. 12 noon, from Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1,283 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, N. Y.

The nation paid its final tribute today to Ramsay MacDonald. A State funeral service in Westminster Abbey consigned to history the Scotsman who rose from humble birth in a tiny Scottish village to serve Britain on three occasions as Prime Minister.

Stefano Borgio, 54 years old, who is serving a murder sentence in Sing Sing prison, went into a frenzy today, stabbing himself in the leg with a potato knife, and later, in the prison hospital, slashing an inmate attendant with a dinner knife.

Newly equipped for Winter flying, the Pan American Clipper, used last Summer for transatlantic pathfinding flights, was put into the Bermuda passenger service yesterday and made its first flight from Baltimore, where operations at the United States end of the line are now based. The flying boat was rechristened the Bermuda Clipper.

Menacing Japanese soldiers with bayonets, bursting shells and roads strewn with bodies meant nothing to 15-year-old Valentine Holdosi, Russian-born schoolboy in China, last Oct. 30, when he realized that his pet dogs and birds had been left without food in the war area.

More than 600 trade union locals in the United Hebrew Trades, the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York and other organization are expected to be represented at a city-wide trade union conference at the Manhattan Opera House on the evening of Dec. 2 to protest against any police curtailment of the legal rights of picketing.

Leaders of business and labor groups, as well as those in educational circles, are seeking the counsel of representatives of religious denominations on major issues now facing the country, according to Mrs. Jesse M. Bader, chairman of the women's committee of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

The marriage of Miss Lillie Van Saun Berry of Short Hills, daughter of the late Captain and Mrs. Robert Laurence Berry, to Charles Jackson Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Smith, also of Short Hills, took place here this afternoon in St. Bernard's Protestant Episcopal Church.

The third annual "At Home" of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, was dedicated to the genius of Richard Strauss as manifested in "Der Rosenkavalier," which will be produced by the Metropolitan on Wednesday evening.

Jockeys George Rose and Bobby McCarty were thrown from their mounts in the fifth race at the Fair Grounds today in a pile-up at the first turn. McCarty, 17, suffered a possible leg fracture and was rushed to Charity Hospital for an examination. Rose escaped with a shaking up.

James G. Hendrickson of 49 East Thirty-fourth Street, the oldest war veteran here, died at his home tonight at the age of 85. He had served in the war with the Sioux Indians, shortly after the massacre of General Custer. He was a member of the Fifth United States Cavalry.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 866,000 bales, against 802,000 a week ago, 781,000 two weeks ago, 769,000 three weeks ago and 812,000 a year ago; of which American 434,000 bales, against 362,000 a week ago, 335,000 two weeks ago, 336,000 three weeks ago and 293,000 a year ago.
A dinner dance was given by Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew last night in the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton to introduce to society Mrs. Loew's daughter, Miss Catherine Dodge Rogers.

Stocks advanced gradually and closed higher, with leading issues up 1 to 4 points; turnover, 1,187,520 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds higher, foreign issues irregular; transactions, $6,829,700.

A divorce suit on the ground of mutual consent was filed in the town of Marianao just outside of Havana today by the Count of Covadonga, son of former King Alfonso of Spain, and his Cuban wife, Marta Rocafort.

British automobile manufacturers have been assured that no reduction of the 33 1-3 per cent McKenna duty on imported cars will be made in an Anglo-American trade agreement, according to Thomas H. Wisdon, motoring editor of The London Daily Herald.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income after all expenses and charges, of $8,863,931, comparing with a net of $6,950,115 in the twelve months to Oct. 31, 1936.
Five Folsom Prison convicts accused of slaying Warden Clarence Larkin in a riot Sept. 19 were convicted of first degree murder late today. The verdict imposed the death penalty on all.

The reductions on air mail to Central and South American countries, which become effective Dec. 1, will vary on letters to different countries but will average 32 per cent according to figures obtained by Pan American Airways from the Postoffice Department yesterday.

A 33-year-old woman who was identified in Los Angeles (Calif.) dispatches as the wife of former Deputy District Attorney David H. Clark of Los Angeles whose mysterious disappearance last January caused a stir, pawned a mink coat, valued by New York detectives at $3,000 or more, for $250 yesterday, paid a bill of $124.03 at the Belmont Plaza Hotel

" Yr. Obedient Husband," by Horace Jackson, opened here tonight at the Hartman Theatre, with Fredric March, the motion-picture actor, and his wife, Florence Eldridge, in the leading roles. The play is scheduled to open in New York in late December for what will be Mr. March's first Broadway appearance since 1926.

Our ancestors would probably have thrown up their hands in horror if they could have foreseen the state of affairs suggested by a survey of public employes released this week by the Civil Service Assembly. In 1936, the study shows, wages and salaries for all employes of Federal, State and local Governments, excluding those on work relief, added up to $5,145,873,000.

The average retirement allowance paid on 4,226 pensions of the New York City Employes Retirement system last year was $1,160 a year, according to the annual report of the system filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate by Miss Pearl Bernstein, secretary of the board.

Results of a study of comparative labor cost per man-hour in manufacturing industry in the various States indicate a wide variation in these costs in different sections of the country, the National Industrial Conference Board, which made the study, reported yesterday. The board stated that the findings were of special importance because of their bearing on the minimum wage legislation now pending in Congress.

M. E. Bristow, State Commissioner of Insurance and Banking, announced today that on Dec. 15 Virginia will become the first State in the Union to regulate minimum down payment and maximum number of payments for installment buying financed by State banks and industrial loan associations.

An increase was registered in lumber output last week, but it was smaller than anticipated on the basi of seasona trend, and the adjusted index eased to 65.2 from 65.7. The figure for the week ended Nov. 21, 1936, was 75.0. Shipments and orders were each slightly lower, according to the reports wired specially to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the various regional associations.

As a result of increasing emphasis placed on the civil service as a vocational aim by the Mathematics Department of Hunter College, about 70 per cent of the students now studying statistics plan to take civil service examinations within the next two weeks.
University of California anthropologists reported today they had uncovered the fossilized bones of human beings who may have been the original native sons of this State.
The microphone has penetrated into rockbound Albania, the proud and primitive little Balkan kingdom perched high

Actors in the costumes of the eighteenth century spoke the lines of a Restoration farce tonight at the opening of the Dock Street Theatre, reconstructed by the Federal Government at a cost of $350,000.

The eventual establishment of "reading clinics" in the American school system was prophesied here today by Dr. Stella S. Center, member of the Board of Examiners of the New York City Schools. Addressing 2,000 members of the National Council of Teachers of English at their annual meeting, Dr. Center asserted that today "many high school pupils go to college and fail because they cannot read."

Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Schieffelin Jr. gave a reception yesterday afternoon in their home at 1,220 Park Avenue to introduce their daughter, Miss Anne Louise Schieffelin, and their niece, Miss Mary Allen Sargent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Sargent of Cedarhurst. Mrs. Schieffelin assisted the debutantes in receiving.

The way was cleared yesterday for the public sale of a controlling stock interest in the $84,000,000 Jersey Central Power and Light Company when the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court approved unanimously a lower court's refusal to enjoin auction of the stock.

James Farwell of East Port Chester, Greenwich, died at his home today at the age of 69. Mr. Farwell was a well-known oyster man in this section and with his father and brothers purchased and developed Farwell's Island off Byram shore here.

Miss Nancy Carrington Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Peter Williams Jr., was married to George Tener Oliver 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Oliver, here today in the Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. E. J. Van Etten officiated.

Despite snowless streets and unseasonable weather, skiing made its debut for 1937-38 in the metropolitan area yesterday as the picturesque Winter Village in John Wanamaker's department store was officially opened for the season. A real Swiss Alpine setting was transplanted to the store's spacious auditorium with a ninety-foot-long ski slide, believed to be the longest for indoor practice in the world, dominating the colorful scene.

Scholastic football will fade almost completely from the 1937 sports parade today with the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association title clash between A. B. Davis High of Mount Vernon and White Plains High featuring a brief program of schoolboy gridiron activity in the metropolitan district. Because a championship is hanging in the balance, the Westchester contest at Howard Field in Mount Vernon tops, in some respects, the handful of school attractions carded in this vicinity.

Yielding to the pleas of business groups which feared serious damage to. their Christmas trade, the Board of Transportation decided yesterday to postpone from Dec. 5 to Dec. 26 the start of work on the remodeling of the Thirty-third Street terminal of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad, in connection with the building of the Sixth Avenue subway line.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel dismissed yesterday a suit brought by Mrs. Terese G. Spiegelberg to collect $24,000 from the city as part of the pension of her husband, the late Municipal Court Justice Frederick Spiegelberg.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit had affirmed a decision of the Federal Court for the Western District of Wisconsin, permanently restraining the Crude Oil Corporation of America, Tulsa, Okla., and B. A. Buckman Co., Madison, Wis., an investment house, from selling in interstate commerce delivery contracts without registration under the Securities Act of 1933.

A demand that "the majority employes of The Brooklyn Daily Eagle other than mechanical" employes have representation in any negotiations conducted by the State Board of Mediation for a settlement of the American Newspaper Guild's strike was sent yesterday to William H. Davis, chairman of the mediation board, by Fred A. Ironside Jr., who said he was counsel for the "majority" group. employes are not on strike.

Berlin, Nov. 26.--Walther Funk, Reich Press Chief and State Secretary in the Propaganda Ministry, today was appointed Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's successor as Minister of Economics, directing with or under Colonel General Hermann Goering Germany's economic policies.

Fred L. Wilson, who was treasurer of the American Steel and Wire Company here for twenty-eight years before he resigned in 1917, died this morning of a heart ailment in the home of his brother-in-law, Carlton Garret, 1,061 Rosemont Avenue.
The Private Bills Committee of the Legislative Council has decided that foreigners cannot be incorporated by mail in this colony.
Colors are soon to be christened with names which the American Pharmaceutical Association and the National Bureau of Standards hope will "stick." it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26.--The first experimental proof that particles of cosmic rays can penetrate the earth to a depth of at least 1,600 feet, a calculated equivalent of 275 feet of lead, was offered to the American Physical Society today by V. C. Wilson in a paper which also bore the name of Dr. Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago.
Charles E. Pickle, court reporter who recorded the testimony in the trial of Will Porter, who afterward became famous as O. Henry, died at his home here today at the age of 65.
The Interstate Commerce Commission broadened today the scope of its railway rate investigation to include rates on the Federal Barge Lines.
Mr. and Mrs. James Byrne of 25 Sutton Place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Byrne, to Gardner Cox, son of Allen H. Cox of Cambridge, Mass.

Miss Margaret Isabel Kelley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Mallette Kelley of West Orange, and Clifford Hanwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Hanwell of Montclair, were married tonight in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church here. The rector, the Rev. Douglas H. Loweth, and Canon George W. Dawson, rector of St. Mark's Church, Paterson, officiated.

Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former Chancellor of Germany, will come to Yale University as the guest of Pierson College next week and will give the annual Isaac Bromley lecture in the Yale Law School auditorium Dec. 2 on "Decisive Phases of Constitutional Development in Post-War Germany."
Many of Chicago's wealthiest citizens, John S. Clark, assessor, said today, will blink when they get their local tax bills for 1937.

David E. Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, denied tonight Federal court testimony that he had suggested to Chattanooga city officials seeking a TVA contract in 1934 that they meet private utility competition by "taxing hell out of them, or words to that effect."

CHARLES GOLDMAN, salesman, Newcastle, N. Y.-Liabilities, $504,800; no assets except insurance. The petitioner's obligations are mainly contingent and were incurred in connection with a business formerly operated by GoldmanRosenzweig Co., Inc. Principal creditors listed are American Woolen Co., $100,000; Sterling National Bank, $65,000: National Safety Bank, $40,000; Bank of U. S. in liquidation, $44,000 secured.
A $210,000 reduction in assessed valuation of Hotel Ambassador properties here may be protested by the city in an appeal to the State Tax Board, Mayor Charles D. White said today.

SLOGUM HOUSE" is a Gothic novel of the sod-house frontier. Mari Sandoz, who wrote it, is a Nebraskan who won the Atlantic $5,000 prize a couple of years ago for "Old Jules," a biography of her untamable father.

Mrs. Henrietta Coyle, 48 years old, a former actress, was found dead in the living room of her bungalow on Roosevelt Avenue here this afternoon. Lieutenant Daniel Allen of the Morris County Prosecutor's staff said the woman had been dead several days.

Peter G. Lehman, 20-year-old son of Governor Lehman of New York, forfeited $15 bail when he failed to appear today before Judge Emil A. Herrigal in police court to answer a summons charging him with speeding at 60 miles an hour on State highway, Route 29, here two weeks ago.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Captain Christopher G. MacDonald, Inf.Res., is relieved from further assignment and duty with CCC, Co. 2208, Camp SP-8 (N. Y.), Peekskill. N. Y., and will proceed to headquarters, Binghamton District, CCC, Binghamton, N. Y., for duty as subdistrict inspector, Subdistrict 6.

Mrs. Jessie A. Yereance, widow of James Yereance, who was Vice Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church, and herself long active in women's Christian organizations, died this afternoon in the Randall House, 520 William Street, where she had lived for the last eighteen years.
The Tokyo newspaper Hochi published today a dispatch from Tsuruga, Japan, asserting that 1,500 Soviet airplanes had been massed in the Maritime Provinces, that part of Siberia nearest Japan.
De Witt Clinton Campbell of 111 Elliott Place, Rutherford, vice president of Middleton Co., Ltd., New York importers and exporters, died today in the Passaic General Hospital. He was 66 years old.

Five hours of Senate debate on the General Farm Bill today brought out that its authors either did not know or were reluctant to say what it would cost the Treasury, that Secretary Wallace had yet to approve the bill as written and that Senators on both sides of the aisle had doubts as to the constitutionality of some provisions.

Paul Moss, License Commissioner, said yesterday that he was "still considering" the question of granting licenses to burlesque theatres now operating without permits. He indicated that a decision would not be reached until next week at the earliest.

Orders have been placed for 60,000 tons of rail, to cost more than $2,500,000, by the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad and its controlled Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis, Louisville Nashville and Clinchfield Railroads, Lyman Delano, chairman of the Atlantic Coast Line, announced yesterday.
John H. Kimball, for more than thirtyfive years a dealer in rare books, died at his home today at the age of 65.

The Chicago Black Hawks will tackle the New York Americans in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The facts that both teams are vastly improved over last year and that the six-day bicycle race will keep hockey out of the Garden for the next week augur well for an attendance of 12,000 or more fans to watch the rival sextets in action.

A section of Buena Vista Hill about a city block in length crashed across Riverside Drive tonight and surrounded several buildings with debris. No one was-believed to have been injured. Lights in the neighborhood were extinguished for several minutes before broken power lines were restored.

A fight by New England Governors against proposed changes in freight rates for Southeastern States went forward under new impetus today after the appointment of John J. Burns as their general counsel in cases before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Mayor Arthur Schuetze of this city died today at the age of 59. Mayor Schuetze, who was serving his second term, was largely responsible for obtaining Federal grants to finance a new City Hall and police station.
Calculated to prevent "price wars" and dumping of goods by merchants, an order-incouncil prohibiting the sale of merchandise under specified prices has been passed by the Alberta government.

Blinking away her tears, a 66year-old widow received from Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy yesterday a Distinguished Service Cross. It was a posthumous award made by the War Department to her son, Nathan, who on Oct. 5, 1918, was killed capturing a German machine-gun nest.

Mrs. Emily Rollinson Olssen Bleecker, widow of Sherbrooke Popham Bleecker, died yesterday at her home here at the age of 77. She was born March 10, 1860, at Scarsdale, N. Y., where her father, the Rev. William Whittingham Olssen, was called as the first rector of St. James-the-Less Church.
Thirteen teams remained in the nation's select set of undefeated and untied elevens after the Thanksgiving fireworks ended with all but two finished in their regular campaigning for the year.

There is every prospect that the present Congress will be called upon to consider a plan for reorganizing the Federal departments. Under that plan the Department of the Interior would become the Department of Conservation. Quick to seize the opportunity of widening the jurisdiction of his office, Secretary Ickes hopes to take over the F- -estry Service from the Department of Agriculture by executive order.
President Roosevelt has accepted the honorary chairmanship of the tenth anniversary celebration committee of the National Conference of Jews and Christians.

Proceeding under a statute rarely employed, this city caused today the commitment of Walter Chinelewski, 35 years old, to the Hudson County Tuberculosis Hospital on the ground he was "a menace to his family and the community."

" At the rate the cooperative movement is developing, it will take less than a hundred years more to supplant communism and Nazism in State, business and church with a cooperative brotherhood embracing all mankind," Dr. E. J. Helms predicted at the annual meeting of the Methodist Board of Home Missions and Church Extension, in session in Evanston, Ill., recently, reports the National Conference of Jews and Christians.
A lawsuit which the New York Real Estate Board has said may affect billions of dollars of real estate mortgages reached the Supreme Court for the second time today.

Although the New York Football Giants have an off-day tomorrow as far as National League competition is concerned, the Maramen will not be idle. Coach Steve Owen has booked an exhibition contest with the Paterson Panthers of the American Association. The game, which will be played in Paterson, N. J., will be used to give some of the Giants' untried backs a test under fire.

Mr. and Mrs. George Maurice Morris were hosts tonight at a "housewarming" of "The Lindens," the historic Colonial house built in 1754 at Danvers, Mass., and moved from that place to be their home at 2,401 Kalarama Road here.

The United States Government intends to continue its efforts for peace and for facilitating a cessation of the Sino-Japanese conflict if and when circumstances are propitious, but with the conclusion of the Brussels Nine-Power Conference no new move is in sight, according to President Roosevelt at his press conference today.

The production of "Faust," given last night by the New York Hippodrome Opera Company, was the occasion of the debut as operatic conductor of Arcady Dubensky, member of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and composer.

A hearing on separate maintenance pleas filed by the second and third wives of George C. Warren Jr., chairman of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission, was conducted here today before Robert Grosman, advisory master in chancery, who reserved decision.

A group of foreigners working as a subcommittee of the Nanking Christian War Relief Committee is being instrumental in ameliorating the appalling conditions among wounded soldiers in Nanking now arriving in numbers between 2,000 and 3,000 daily.

Dr. Henry C. Sherman, Mitchell Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University, has been designated for the 1937 award of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After reading several letters in THE TIMES about picketing, especially that of the Horn Hardhart places, I wish to say a good word for these restaurants, which have operated under the most trying conditions since Aug. 6.
Movements of livestock in tthe Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts 15,000, including 6,000 directs.

While four whales splashed and blew within casting distance of their craft, four miles off. Shark River, N. J., three sports fishermen hauled in enough mackerel to cancel the Summer gasoline bill for their boat.

Revision of the airways traffic control regulations in the vicinity of New York is under consideration by the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce and the air lines, as a consequence of the radio range beams being turned on recently at Floyd Bennett Field, it was learned from the Federal airways office at Newark Airport last night.

The system of dealing in odd lots on the Chicago Stock Exchange in issues which are listed also on the New York Stock Exchange is to be expanded on Monday to include twenty-seven such issues, according to an announcement here today.

Miss Aida Principe, formerly of the metropolitan district but now a member of the Washington F. C., won the annual Manrique novice competition at the Fencers Club last night under the auspices of the women's division of the A. F. L. A.

The marriage of Miss Sherley Elizabeth Gillen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Andrew M. Gillen of Brooklyn, to Francis Joseph McDermott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McDermott, also of Brooklyn, took place yesterday morning in the church of Our Lady of Refuge, Brooklyn.

Germany has made informal proposals to Mexico for a general trade agreement on a barter basis. It is proposed that Mexico send Germany raw materials and receive German manufactured goods and machinery.
The board of directors of the Long Island Lighting Company at a meeting yesterday voted to cut dividends on the company's 7 per cent and 6 per cent preferred stocks in half.

Mayor La Guardia was among those who attended a funeral service yesterday for William G. Kohler, former auditor of the New York Life Insurance Company, at the Kohler home, 2 Horatio Street. Mr. Kohler died on Tuesday.
Federal Judge W. H. Holly today extended to Dec. 24 the time for filing new plans for reorganization of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation under Section 77b of the amended Bankruptcy Laws.

In a unanimous ruling, the Appellate Division affirmed yesterday without comment the decision of Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman holding that former Mayor James J. Walker's original appointment as special counsel to the Transit Commission at $12,000 a year was invalid and illegal.

Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the board of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation, instituted suit yesterday in Supreme Court to recover $3,100,000 from the Chase National Bank and Albert H. Wiggin, formerly its chief executive officer.

Despite the delay in counting, the result of the proportional representation election for Councilmen has justified the claims of its sponsors, it was said last night by Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Citizens Union.
Miss Margaret Schneider, manager of Pine Cliff Lodge, a resort hotel in Montague Township, N. J., died today at her home here at the age of 76.
The one-family dwelling at 6 Highwood Road, West Orange, N. J., has been sold by the Oxford Building and Loan Association to Jerome Hilton through Krasner, Herman, Stavitsky Company, broker.
Miss Edith Pine Garver was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her father, Chauncey B. Garver, in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis.
A special meeting of the stockholders of the George A. Fuller Company, controlled by the United States Realty and Improvement Company, has been called for Dec. 21 to approve a plan for readjustment.
The Evander Childs High School soccer team scored a 4-to-1 victory over Stuyvesant High at Crotona Park yesterday and gained the final round play-off for the city P. S. A. L. championship.

Police were confident last night of an early arrest in connection with the death of Claude H. Kendall, 46-year-old former publisher, whose body, battered and bruised, was found Thursday morning with a bed sheet wrapped loosely about the neck in his $7-a-week loom in the Madison Hotel, 21 East Twentyseventh Street, near Madison Avenue.

An estate of about $4,000,000 was left by Louis Franklin Swift, pioneer meat packer, according to an inventory filed today with the Cook County probate clerk. This estimate raised by 400 per cent one made soon after Mr. Swift's death May 12, when a will was filed.
The strike of bus drivers called in sixteen States against the Greyhound Lines by the Brotherhood of Railway Trainmen tightened in this area and in the New England States yesterday.
