Probably the youngest travelers in modern times to cross the North Atlantic alone are the 4-months-old Coelin twins and their 2-year-old sister, who arrived in New York yesterday from Davenport, Iowa, en route to their grandfather in Wesselburne, Schleswig- Holstein, Germany.

The long-lost violin concerto written by Robert Schumann eighty-four years ago and vainly sought for a first performance in America by Yehudi Menuhin, was presented to the world in the German Opera House this morning by the Berlin Philharmonic under Professor Karl Boehm with Georg Kulenkampff as soloist.
Mayor Wilson sent to the City Council today a proposed ordinance that would impose a 1 per cent tax on incomes and profits in excess of $2,500 a year.

MANHATTAN BARLEY, ROSEMARY WILBUR (Nov. 15). Estate, less than $5,000. To Francis Porteous Wilbur, 145 Willow St., Brooklyn, and Arthur Ernst Wilbur, executor, Hotel Baltimore, Los Angeles, Calif., brothers, one-half residue each.

Abraham Ellis, concessionnaire, who operates the banquet halls in the old Manhattan Opera House at 311 West Thirty-fourth Street under a lease, announced yesterday that he had purchased the building from the trustees of the Consistory of New York City of Scottish Rite.

As she was working behind the counter some time between 3:30 and 4 P. M. yesterday, Mrs. Martha Hore, 65 years old, who ran a candy and sandwich shop at 564 Greenwich Street, between Charlton and King Streets in the oldest section of Greenwich Village, was murdered.

Plans for the mediation of the Far Eastern dispute by a small committee consisting of representatives of Great Britain and the United States only are believed to be under consideration in London. The Foreign Office has no official confirmation and,
Teams captained by Don Bradman and Victor Richardson today started a four-day cricket match on behalf of the testimonial fund being raised for Richardson, veteran South Australian,

Turpentine firm, 27c: sales, 49 barrels; receipts, 396 barrels; shipments, 226 barrels; stock, 37,393 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 878: receipts, 1,518; shipments, 558; stock, 82,389. Quote B, D, E, $5.15; F, G, $5.65; H, I, K, $5.70; M, $5.80; N, $5.85; WG, $6.40; WW, X, $6.75.

Harvard athletics showed a deficit of $785.61 for the academic year that ended last June 30, according to the annual report of the Harvard Athletic Association; made public today. This contrasts with a profit of $4,746 for the preceding year and a surplus of $2,306 for the year ending June 30, 1935.

In an outburst of protest against the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company's proposed Saugatuck Reservoir, 200 of the townsfolk of Weston, many of them members of the Saugatuck Valley Association, redeclared tonight their belief that any water storage or power project, private or municipal, is against the interest of the town.

Those who cut their wisdom teeth on the tales of Rudyard Kipling, plain and otherwise, will always have an interest in the British Army that has nothing to do with its efficiency as a fighting force-and nothing to do, either, with the way we feel about war.

A decree issued today by President Getulio Vargas creates a "Technical Council for Economics and Finance," which will be presided over by the Minister of Finance and will be composed of eight members to be appointed by Dr. Vargas.

The development of youth organizations in trade unions as a means of strengthening the American Labor party was advocated last night by John Little, executive secretary of the Young Communist League of New York State, who spoke at the opening meeting of the league's three-day convention at Livingston Hall, 301 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn.
Lord Glanely's Marcus Superbus tonight moved up into the favorite's position at 17 to 2 for the Manchester November Handicap, last of the year's big flat races to be run tomorrow.
Dexter W. Fellows, the man who spent most of his life telling the world of the multiple attractions under the big top, died here tonight at 9:30 o'clock.

President Roosevelt expects to leave here by special train late tomorrow night for four or five days of fishing in Florida waters. He will embark Monday morning at Miami on the yacht Potomac and cruise leisurely in Eastern coast waters.

Howard Chichester Co, Inc. combs, in 432 4th Ave; George Gordon, in 17-19 W 34th St: The Cross Brown Co, broker. Charming Dress Co, in 109 W 26th St; Harry Math novelties, in 36 E 22d St: Newcomb-Macklin Co, picture frames, in 45 W 27th St; renewals by Bastine Co, Inc, agent.

The Senate Committee on Commerce plans to introduce early next week amendments to the Merchant Marine Act covering most of the suggestions submitted to Congress on Nov. 10 by Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission.

Affidavits purporting to have been signed by twenty-nine employes of the Bank of Yorktown, 568 Eighth Avenue, who desire no collective bargaining agency were submitted yesterday to the State Labor Relations Board, 366 Broadway, by John J. Stewart, 374 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, who said he was credit manager of the bank.

A grand jury investigation of the death of Genevieve Augustin, 29year-old New York City school teacher, shifted today to "Witchwood Manor," Summer home of Gypsy Rose Lee, former strip-tease artist and now Louise Hovick of the screen.

Shoe manufacturers in St. Louis blamed business declines today for delayed production of late Winter and early Spring footwear and consequent employee layoffs. Company officials attributed a "marked slump" to "moderate overproduction" earlier in the year, one adding that August production, usually high, was "the worst in several years." He placed retail buying at 50 per cent of normal.

Anti-Semitic rioting has broken out again at Lwow University, where Nationalist students proclaimed "a week without Jews." Thirty Jewish students who attempted to enter the university grounds today were repelled by Nationalist pickets.

Stockholders of the W. T. Grant Company approved yesterday the formation of a new organization, to be incorporated in Delaware, to absorb the present company, the Grant Estates, Inc., and the Grant Finance Corporation.
California's board of athletic strategy fiddled today while the country yearned to find out who will be selected to play the Golden Bears in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

Deaths Announced LIEUTENANT-John Durkin of Engine 2, died Nov. 24, in the discharge of duty, from gas poisoning to which he was exposed while operating at fire in premises 688-704 11th Ave.. Manhattan, at 1:04 P. M., Nov. 23. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 419 W. 129th St., Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M., Saturday, Nov. 27. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

State Senator Lester H. Clee, defeated Republican candidate for Governor, had gained five votes over Governor-elect A. Harry Moore tonight at the end of the first week of the recount in Hudson County.
Mr. and Mrs. Irving Van Wart of Darien have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gloria Van Wart, to Clarence Preston Scoboria Jr., Brooklyn and Bedford, N. Y.

Attorney General Cummings today notified Governor Benson that the United States Department of Justice could not enter the Patrick J. Corcoran assassination case unless evidence were produced that a Federal crime had been committed.
The export of $5,000,000 gold to France and the receipt of $5,514,400 gold from Japan were announced yesterday. The shipment to France,

Henry Ward Turner, mining engineer and geological authority, died today in his home at Ross, near here, at the age of 80. Widely known as an author of geological textbooks and treatises. he published "The Origin of Yosemite Valley" in 1900.

Professor and Mrs. Jack Randall Crawford of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Crawford, to Richard Vincent Holahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Holahan of Darien, Conn.
The captain and sixteen seamen of the British freighter Nollington Court were taken off the 3,733-ton vessel and will be brought to Kingston, according to a wireless message received here tonight.

For the eighth consecutive year fraternity men led non-fraternity students in scholarship in colleges throughout the country, Dr. Alvan E. Duerr of New York reported yesterday at the opening of the twentyninth annual session of the National Interfraternity Conference at the Hotel Commodore.
David Warfield, veteran actor of the American stage, will observe his seventy-first birthday tomorrow at his home, 135 Central Park West, but without cake or candles.

For all the galaxy of famous names that went into the making of "Macbeth" at the Old Vic tonight-Laurence Olivier and Judith Anderson in the lead, Michel Saint Denis the producer and Darius Milhaud for incidental music-critics still found something lacking.

George W. Knappmann, president and director of the Kotten Machine Company, 164 Thirtyfourth Street, Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home, 150-15 Eightysixth Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, after a long illness. He was 58 years old.

Claude R. Orchard, director of the Federal Credit Union Section of the Farm Credit Administration told more than 500 members of the New York State Credit Union League that the credit union movement in the United States now has assets exceeding $100,000,000, and reserves and undivided profits of over $500,000.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 24: Birnie, Maj. Gen. U. Jr., Chief of Field Artillery, one day's leave, Nov. 27. Steger, Col. J. O., Adjutant General Dep't, fifteen days' leave. Dec. 20. Jarman, Col. S., C.A.C., General Staff Corps, one day's leave, Nov. 26. Sutherland, Col. S. J., Inf., Boston, Mass., to home and await retirement.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Wells of Mount Airy have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Way Wells, to Thomas Kenworthy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kenworthy of Windy Hill, Glenside.

The Queens count of the ballots for Council candidates was completed yesterday and, as expected, the result showed the election of Alderman James A. Burke, an independent Democrat who ran without party designation; Hugh Quinn and William N. Conrad, candidates on the regular Democratic ticket; Charles Belous, a Fusion candidate with American Labor party affiliations, and John M. Christiansen, a Republican.
The Don Cossack Male Chorus, conducted by its dynamic little leader, Serge Jaroff, made its sole New York appearance of the season at Carnegie Hall last night.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, at a hearing before the State Labor Relations Board at 366 Broadway yesterday, claimed as members 430 of the motormen employed on B. M. T. subway and elevated lines. The union has applied to the board for certification as sole bargaining agency for all motormen employed by the company.
Mrs. Sarah Cawthra Schoeffel, believed to have been Rochester's oldest woman, died today. She would have been 102 years old next May 1.

A mysterious substance, as yet unidentified, found to be the most powerful agent known so far. in producing malignant tumors in the stomachs of rats, which promises to yield an important new clue to the baffling origin of humanity's natural killer number 2, was reported here today before the annual Autumn meeting of the Americar Philosophical Society, founded in 1727 by Benjamin Franklin for "the promotion of useful knowledee."

The New York University frolic, the largest all-university social event of the academic year, was held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. More than twenty-five hundred persons attended.
Count Emanuele Castelbarco, sonin-law of Toscanini, is to have his first exhibition of American paintings at the Marie Sterner Galleries, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, for two weeks beginning Monday.
Governor-elect A. Harry Moore announced today the appointment of Hugh A. Kelly, architect, to be his secretary when he becomes Governor. The two have long been close friends.
The Navy spent $1 today and acquired title to a $100,000 site in Alameda on which will rise in the next four years a $14,500,000 naval air station.

The Federal Reserve System, continuing its open-market operations to expand credit. bought $9,300,000 of government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly reports of the system, issued yesterday.

Armed with a warrant in extradition proceedings which had been outstanding since 1934, the United States Marshal's office yesterday arrested General Gerardo Machado, deposed President of Cuba, wanted there on charges of murder and embezzlement.
Three striking employes of The Bayonne Times and a sympathizer were arrested late today on charges of disorderly conduct as they picketed the jewelry store of Sol A. Altschuler at 430 Broadway.

During the week ended Nov. 24 member bank reserve balances increased $27,000,000. Additions to member banks reserves arose from increases of $6,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $8,000,000 in Treasury currency, and decreases of $22,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks and $19,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $20,000,000 in money in circulation and $8,000,000 in Treasury cash other than inactive gold.

Dr. Frederick Winslow, practicing physician here for many years and a member of an old Boston family, died yesterday at his home at the age of 63. Born in Boston on July 27, 1873, he was a son of Walter T. Winslow, a leading Boston architect.

Sigurd Lindholm, an engineer, claims to have found a gas which in a few minutes makes the inebriated person who inhales it perfectly sober. This anti-alcohol gas, related to "laughing gas," is a composite gas containing a large quantity of acid.
Eduardo Giorgetti, for forty years a leading figure in the sugar industry and the first president of the Puerto Rico Sugar Producers Association, died here today at the age of 71.
Despite President Roosevelt's indication today that he was ready for tax revision, practical considerations are likely to prevent speedy action by Congress.

Miss Edna Theresa Robitzek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin R. Robitzek of Mount Vernon, was married this afternoon to Thomas P. Mandeville Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandeville of this place, in the Rectory of St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church here.

Markets for the non-ferrous metals were quiet yesterday, the only development of importance being a further cut of 1/4-cent a pound in the price of zinc. The new price is 5.25 cents a pound at East St. Louis.

Miss Dorothy Hartwig of Scarsdale, N. Y., gave a luncheon yesterday in the Louis Sherry Room at Sherry's for the Misses Laura Howell Smith and Frances Isobel Arnold, debutante daughters of Mrs. Albert L. Smith of 895 Park Avenue and Mrs. Dan Hinckley Arnold of Scarsdale, respectively.

The succession of losing favorites which has shocked players at Bowie continued today, one of the biggest blows coming in the featured Norfolk Purse when Matey, owned by Walter M. Jeffords, ran a miserable race to finish far out of the money.

A $1,000 crocheted bedspread (owner's estimate) decorated a utilitarian flat top desk, and filet luncheon sets dripped from the back of a swivel chair in an office suite at 522 Fifth Avenue yesterday, as five feminine judges rhapsodized, pondering the relative artistry of the more than 200 entries in the competition to determine the country's slickest wielder of the crochet hook.

The returns are in from the nation-wide unemployment census-bymail, and their tabulation has begun. The results are not expected to be announced until early in January. Meanwhile the country would do well to prepare itself to interpret those results properly when they appear.
About 12,000 of 18,000 employes of the American Smelting- and Refining Company, the largest mining organization in Mexico, have joined a movement of "nuisance" strikes.

Marcel de Passy, who has clung to his self-conferred title of "Count" through twenty-eight years and twenty-five encounters with the police, went back to the Tombs yesterday when he announced that he was unable to raise $1,000 bail.

To meet the educational needs of political exiles and other cultured foreigners in this city, the evening school system is preparing courses in English which will be geared to their intellectual level, Ignus O. Hornstein, assistant director of evening schools, disclosed yesterday.

A decidedly better undertone ruled yesterday in all classes of bonds, except the foreign dollar issues, in quiet trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The improvement was particularly pronounced throughout the list of secondary and convertible issues, both of which reflected to some degree the reversal of form in stocks.

Eight persons, including one woman, today were sentenced to prison for antiFascist activities. The convictions by the Special Tribunal brought to 109 the number sentenced for subversive activity in the past few weeks.

Samuel Schwartz, in 105 W 73d St through the Apartment Locating Bureau. Sarkis A. Sarafian, Peter McClees, Leslie H. Campbell, Auston S. Davenport, Joseph E. Hughes, Edgerton R. Jennings, E. Clyde McGrew, Charles Jundt Jr., Charles R. Stoddard, John J. Manning, Mrs. Margaret L. Donahue, Mrs. Nelle B. Cutler, Sackett Miles, Bessie S. Shannon, Patrick E. De Vine, Dr. Eldon W. Smith, Lieut. Comdr.

Angelina Campo and Joseph Fichera and his wife gave a mortgage to Sam S. Glauber, Inc, for $4,800 on 101 Madison St. A second mortgage for $8,665 due in five years at 6 per cent, with $150 paid off quarterly, was given by Jennie Farley to Charles J. Hassel on 304 E 52d St, subject to a first for $11,000 given to the American Bible Society.

Television history was made tonight when persons in London saw and heard in their homes an animated conversation between two men standing more than seven miles apart who could both see and hear each other.

Eugene du Pont announced today the engagement of his daughter, Miss Murton du Pont, to Walter Samuel Carpenter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Carpenter Jr. of Wilmington. Miss du Pont is a cousin of Mrs. Ethel du Pont Roosevelt.
A committee has started an international collection of "Nansen pennies" with a view to erecting a gigantic monument to the late Dr. Fridtjof Nansen, explorer, scientist and peace worker.
Funeral services will be held here tomorrow for Captain Walter I. Joyce, honorary national commander-in-chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, who died Wednesday in New York.

The weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department announced today that liquidation of the New York County Credit Union had been completed and the corporation dissolved. The announcement was dated Nov. 18.

A four-hour "stand-up" strike of 115 operators at the main office of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company ended today after a conference between officials of the company and the American Radio Telegraphists Association, a C. I. O. affiliate. The terms of the settlement were not announced.

Organizations in this country that are obtaining contributions for use for humanitarian purposes in Spain and that are required by law to be registered with the State Department had in the period from May, when the regulations became effective, to Oct. 31 received a total of $574,370.97 and expended $406,253.78 for relief in Spain and $141,287.05 for administration and publicity, according to the monthly report issued tonight.

J. A. Flores da Cunha, ex-Governor of the State of Rio Grande do Sul, was charged today by the War Department with ordering armament for his State Military Brigade in excess of normal needs and without authorization by the War Department.

Some thirty youthful editors and assistant editors from the five boroughs were assembled yesterday afternoon in the field house of the Heckscher Playground in Central Park to learn how their monthly playground newspapers had Weathered the fourth annual contest held by the Park Department.
Vice President Garner and Senator Pittman, who often fills in for him in the presiding officer's chair of the Senate, have a "working agreement," they disclosed today.

The National Maritime Union extended its string of victories in the industry-wide labor election to nine yesterday with the announcement that the unlicensed personnel on the thirteen ships of the Morgan Line and on the eleven ships of the New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company have selected it as their bargaining agency.
Pittsburgh's Golden Panthers, undefeated and tied only by Fordham, will face Duke University's football team in an intersectional battle tomorrow. The kick-off will be at 2 P. M.

IN his new study on "The Vinland Voyages," Professor A. W. Brogger points out that important finds in Greenland from the current Danish excavations are dispelling some of the absurdities in the either-or controversy centering around Leif Eriksson and Columbus and priority in the discovery of America.

Mrs. Fred Reynolds, who has owned raccoons for fifteen years, says the animals make ideal pets. She has only one now, however, Formerly, she raised them for the market, but because she disliked having them killed for "a fur coat" she discarded a profitable 'GOOD raising business.

E. D. Rogers, district manager of the Diarymen's League, said today that the league's plant here, one of the largest in New York, would be closed tonight because of a nineteen-county strike in progress since Oct. 28.

The engagement of Miss M. Virginia Geisler, daughter of Mrs. Theodore J. Geisler of 1,160 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Cincinnati, and the late Mr. Geisler, to Augustin D. Bourneuf, son of Mrs. V. M. Bourneuf of Chestnut Hills, Boston, and the late Mr. Bourneuf, has been announced by her mother.
For more than twenty years it has been the practice of most universities and colleges to examine students physically. A few institutions have been making such examinations for fifty years.

Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses and normal Federal income charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Rosika Schwimmer, originator of the Ford peace ship plan, will launch her new world peace program on Saturday at a meeting at the Waldorf -Astoria, when an international committee of men and women will present her with an unofficial peace prize. The award,

Alexis Leger, French Foreign Office Secretary, today received Renato Prunas, the Italian Charge d'Affaires, at the Quai d'Orsay, asking explanations of the press campaign in Italy which continues concerning a speech alleged to have been made a month ago by Cesar Campinchi, French Navy Minister, despite official denials.

Edward Aborn Greene, retired manufacturer and banker, died last night, in his eighty-second year. Mr. Greene was associated for many years with the Clyde Bleachery and Print Works at Riverpoint, which had been taken over from the founders of the mill by his grandfather.
Two of the world's masters of balkline billiards will introduce the new French game of 71.2 to this country in a match that opens tomorrow at the Capitol Bowling and Billiard Academy.

Centenary's powerful eleven defeated Oklahoma A. and M. today, 19 to 0, on a snow-covered field. Only once did the Aggies push into Centenary territory and thereafter the conquerors of Southern Methodist and Texas Christian kept the Aggies deep in their own zone.

League competition for the six Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball Conference teams will start with Carnegie Tech and West Virginia inaugurating the conference's sixth season in a game at Morgantown Jan. 8.

Dr. Charles Eastmond of 159 East Forty-ninth Street, X-ray specialist, died yesterday, after a long illness, in the Peck Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn, of which he has been attending roentgenologist for many years. He was born in Brooklyn, Dec. 27, 1879.

CITY'S FINEST: New York's police force, numbering 19,594 members, is soon to undergo a substantial reorganization. Men above 60 will be required to go through medical tests to determine their fitness for their posts; younger men will be promoted. Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine are behind the reorganization scheme; they want to revitalize the force.

Henry Wise Wood, chairman of the Alberta wheat pool since its inception in 1923 and now 80 years old, retired last night from the organization's board of directors at its fifteenth annual convention. He was made honorary

The engagement of Miss Regina Marie Walter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Walter of this place, to John Emmerson Woods, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Woods of Norfolk, Conn., has been announced by her parents.

THE Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts has given to the Viking Press its first annual award for "that publishing house which, in the past year, shall have done the most for furthering good design in trade books." The award, in the form

Johns Hopkins's "de-emphasized" football team mushed downfield on two sustained marches through the mud today to defeat St. John's College of Annapolis, 13 to 0, in the fiftyfifth renewal of their gridiron feud.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schey will give a tea this afternoon at their home, 895 Park Avenue, for their debutante daughter, Miss Theresa Todd Schey. Miss Janet Cruickshank has come from Washington, Conn., to visit her grandmother, Mrs. Ezra Fitch, at the Berkshire.
A standard cultural examination, given alike to freshmen, sophomores and seniors, will be a feature of a revised system of comprehensive examinations now being formulated at Allegheny College.

IN the past 17 years Adolphe Menjou has grown to be so unshakably implanted in the public mind as the embodiment of worldly grace, sophisticated charm and sartorial impeccability (whatever might occasionally be said of his moral status), that even tramps

DESPITE his seventy-odd years, Pietro Mascagni is still going strong, at least in ambition. Not satisfied to rest on his laurels, he has yielded again to the siren of the lyric stage and has laid the groundwork not only for one but for two new operas.

A Christian attitude on social problems was urged by the Bishops of the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference tonight in a statement deploring that "irresponsible doctrinaires have seized upon world-wide discontent and capitalized it."
El Comercio, the third oldest newspaper in South America, printed its fifty thousandth edition today. For nearly seventy years El Comercio has been issuing two editions daily.

Sociology courses at Barnard College are being reorganized under the direction of Dr. William Waller, newly appointed associate professor, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve announced yesterday. This is due to the recently adopted rigid requirements and strict

The marriage of Miss Doris Lillian Dilworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. C. Dilworth of 1,094 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, to Frederick Richmond Chevalier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Chevalier of Holliston, Mass., took place last night in the Church of St. Mark, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON -- Though New York and Pennsylvania, with 6,030 and 5,417, respectively, have provided the navy with more enlisted men than any other State, four other States, each with a contribution of over 4,000 bluejackets--Texas, Massachusetts, Iowa and Illinois--are close behind, according to figures recently made public by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, chief of the Bureau of Navigation.
The South End Gun Club of Reading, the oldest active trapshooting organization in America, was awarded three amateur wing-shooting championships for 1938 over the club's Lorane traps.

Extra-curricular organizations of the four divisions of Hunter College will cooperate to present Carnival, an event to be held in the Bronx buildings on Dec. 9 and 10. Student council, Bronx executive board and the Faculty-Student Social Relations Committee will divide
In mud, fog and rain, High Velocity annexed the Bay Shore Handicap at Bowie today, when misfortune struck down the favorite when in the lead. Hardly had 12,000 drenched

Interest in the activities of German House at Smith College has developed so rapidly since it was founded two years ago that twentythree students are living there this year and it has become necessary to establish a visitors' waiting list for those who wish to attend the open house gatherings held on alternate Fridays.

The singular problem as to what constitutes the end of a season intrigued Fordham football players, coaches and fans alike yesterday as the Rams completed their regular campaign undefeated and promptly bent an ear toward the Coast to hear the reaction to the smashing 20-7 victory over N. Y. U. in the camp of the University of California.
The official Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia today expressed belief that British diplomats would try to force France to accept demands made by Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany on Lord Halifax.

On Thursday and Friday evenings the William and Mary Players at the College of William and Mary will present their second production of the season under the direction of Miss Althea Hunt. It will be "First Lady," by Katherine Drayton and George Kaufman, and the leads will be taken by Miss May Fielder of Fort Leavenworth, Kan.;
With marriages noticeably decreased by the law requiring a seventy-two-hour waiting period between the license and the ceremony, new efforts at tightening the laws are already under way.

Citing the increasing burdens on business enterprises imposed since the 1929 depression, the National Association of Manufacturers in the report of a survey to be submitted to the Congress of American Industry, meeting here next week, emphasizes the "seriousness" of the present financial position of the Federal Government.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.--The business sessions of conventions and a sports program will take up the time of the visitors to this resort during the next few weeks.
Bergenfield (N. J.) Woman's Club-- American home and garden departments meeting, 2:30 P. M., Murray Hill Arms. Talk on "Romantic Cookery," by Florence Wren.
The nine-story apartment building at 27 East Sixty-second Street is now fully rented, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agents.

In a hard -fought contest, the Cooper Union basketball team opened its season by registering a 25-to-24 triumph over the Columbia College of Pharmacy in the Columbia University gymnasium last night. Skorsky of the winners and Lazarowitz of Columbia shared

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, a-member of the Board of Education and chairman of the New York Teachers Committee of the United Hospital campaign, has announced the formation of a committee of eighteen representatives of school teacher and personnel associations.
Four new ships have been ordered by the Polish-flag Gdynia America Line for its transatlantic services, it was announced yesterday by

LONDON.--Possibly as a result of the wide success of a recent bestseller which criticized the usages in the medical profession, the British Medical Association has become conscious of an undercurrent of skepticism toward professional medicine and has taken the revolutionary step of lifting the ban against self-advertisement.

It is quite the custom in British politics to make a controversial point with the aid of an apt extract from Gilbert and Sullivan. Last week the first part of the above-quoted stanza made its mark in American politics, serving as the punch-line in a statement from that experienced issuer of statements, Samuel Seabury.

A Canadian World War aviator, first of more than 2,000 volunteers whose blood met physicians' requirements, underwent a transfusion today in an attempt to save the life of 28year-old Weston Fletcher of Grand Blanc, Mich.,

The old Valentine farm in Queens Village, not far from Jamaica, which was recently purchased by George C. Dickel, head of the Dickel building firm, is being divided into home plots for the erection of a large group of homes in the $6,000 class for occupancy next Spring and Summer. Mr.

After circling through fog for more than an hour in a vain attempt to land either at Camden, N. J., or at Camp Dix, an army transport plane -carrying Major Gen. Frank Andrews, commander of the general headquarters air force, to the Army-Navy football game at Philadelphia was forced to turn back to Virginia yesterday afternoon,

Former Mayor Malachi E. Higgins and Mrs. Higgins of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Elizabeth Higgins, to Lieutenant Paul Francis Oswald, U. S. A., now stationed at Fort Hoyle, Md., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Oswald of San Antonio, Texas.

At what point does a pilot become too tired to fly safely? Joe Green, veteran flier on a commercial airplane, brings his planeinto its hangar at the Municipal Airport and reports into the office, wearily shaking the snow from his shoulders.

The Chinese authorities today advised foreign embassies that the Yangtze would be blocked Tuesday at the mud forts, sixteen miles below Nanking, where a new boom will be laid in a narrow stretch of the river.
IN Tokyo, nerve center of an empire at war, blunt, uniformed officers of the Imperial Japanese Army dominate anxious,

Whispered exclamations, "How cute," rose on all sides during tiny Paolo Spagnolo's recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. The 6year-old Italian pianist, who was making his American debut, certainly deserved the epithet, whether it referred to his person or to his playing.

A new method of testing radio listener response to educational and cultural programs, which will analyze effects of such programs on various population groups, like teachers and farmers, rather than on the population as a whole, will be discussed tomorrow in Chicago before the Second National Conference on Educational Broadcasting.

The marriage of Miss Wendy Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Fellowes Morgan Jr. of New York and Mount Kisco, N. Y., to Thomas Rodd 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Rodd of Pittsburgh, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The ceremony was performed

Fourteen and a half hours after he sailed from Boston, Theodore Petow, 33-year-old motion-picture operator, wanted on a charge of having murdered a 39-year-old hotel housekeeper, was arrested here yesterday morning as he stepped off the Eastern Steamship liner Acadia at the North River Warren Street pier.

Emerging from a free-for-all melee on the Madison Square Garden ice yesterday, the New York Rovers broke a deadlock with the Bronx Tigers on Ernie Westbury's goal midway in the third period, won the game, 3-2, and pulled back into a tie with the Atlantic

In compliment to the surge of consumer interest and intelligent curiosity about the items for which women buyers-for the most partspend their money, the governing board of the New York World's Fair of 1939 has authorized a special building to be devoted to the topic.
Women skiers of the United States have started their exodus to European ports to take part in the major tournaments on the Continent.
Members of the Women's Auxiliary of the Grand Street Settlement have arranged a two weeks' rummage sale in behalf of the organization which will open Thursday at 1,285 Second Avenue.

Miss Christella Bedell, daughter of Mrs. William V. Bedell of this city, was married to Thomas Weir Clohosey, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Addison Clohosey of East Orange, this morning in the Church of the Holy Name here Thep naston,
Theodore Augustus Walters, First Assistant Secretary of the Interior, died this morning in Naval Hospital of pneumonia. He had been operated upon on Wednesday.

Suspension of trading in wool ops on the New York Wool Top Exchange, which has been proposed by a group of wool dealers in Boston, would have a salutary effect on the market for wool goods, in the opinion of Herbert R. Leeds, president of Herbert R. Leeds Co., Inc., selling agents for wool

ics has become one of the major extracurricular activities at Bowdoin College, with 106 students enrolled under the Masque and Gown banner. Eighty-seven of them are listed as actors and forty-nine are interested in the technical or
THE town is viewing with some amusement the highly colorful yarns that have been dispatched across the land these past few days concerning racketeering in the "extra" ranks.

John Brophy, director of the Committee for Industrial Organization, told a National Unity Conference of Furniture Workers today that the C. I. O. would not accept a peace with the American Federation of Labor "that means death."
PINEHURST, N. C.--Starting on Tuesday and continuing for a period of two weeks or more, field trials will occupy the center of attention here. The

Members of the Mask and Wig Club of the University of Pennsylvania will Give a performance of their golden jubilee production, "Fifty-Fifty," by Louis C. Madeira 4th and George Elliott Hess with music by Clay A. Boland, next Saturday afternoon and night at the Center Theatre, Radio City.

Miss Agnes Warren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Northam Warren of Garden City, L. I., was married to Karl W. Illigen of Harrisburg, Pa., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Illigen of Alfred, Me., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church here.

Acting Lieutenant Hugh Sheridan in charge of detectives at the Charles Street police station announced yesterday that the police were searching for a 17-year-old youth in connection with the murder of Mrs. Martha Hore, 65 years old, who was killed in her candy and sandwich shop at 564 Greenwich Street Friday afternoon.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of paragraph 8, Special Orders 253, dated Oct. 30, 1937, relating to Capt. Nathan P. Ruditsky, M.l.-Res., as reads: "The verbal orders of the Commanding General," is amended so as to read: "The verbal orders of the Commanding General of Oct. 4, 1937." (Second Military Area.)
One of the most important parties for debutantes, to which they are looking forward with keen interest, is the season's first Junior Assembly Friday night at the RitzCarlton. The events, first as the

Of the many problems facing the owners of a new suburban or country home the one most often tackled back-end-to is that of landscaping the place. More often than not attention is directed first to flower beds, borders and lawns, and the question of big trees and shrubs is allowed to wait.

Class B gunners broke into the limelight when J. J. Van Gonsic and J. R. Sprague tied at 97 for the high-over-all cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. One hundred extra targets were required to determine the winner.

Members of the Engineering Women's Club will inaugurate on Wednesday their new clubhouse at 126 East Thirty-fifth Street-their third residence in the Murray Hill district since they were organized nine years ago.

The Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, basketball team last night scored its second victory in two starts this season by defeating the Evening Session quintet of City College, 55 to 24, on the clubmen's court. Adam Andrews paced the victors

Miss Ella McNicholl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McNicholl of East Orange, and William Glen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Glen of Bloomfield, were married this afternoon in Grace Presbyterian Church, Montclair.

Sample lines of Italian pure silk fabrics in high-style brackets have been placed in the hands of dress manufacturers and retailers in an attempt by producers in Italy to cut into the market here for French fabrics imported from Lyons.

While most stores have made considerable headway in the reduction of merchandise inventories this month and in October, the buying for January sales purposes probably will be the lightest in years, merchandise executives and resident buyers said yesterday.

One way of obtaining the effect of stereoscopic relief on a screen is to make stereoscopic pictures in red and green. Put on spectacles with one red and one green glass, look at the two pictures (properly spaced) and you see a single picture which seems to have a third dimension-depth.

ONE would think that the motorist driving along a highway at night with 50,000 candlepower of light guiding him through the darkness would be immediately conscious if 15,000 candles were suddenly snuffed out. Or 10,000 or even 5,000 of them. But, somehow, he does not seem to be; perhaps because the reduction of light is less sudden on the average than the snuffing-out would imply.
The Panama Pacific Line is prepared to retain its three 33,000-ton "luxury liners" in intercoastal trade at least until April 1, according to reports received here.
The So- collect viet Government announced tonight that it had rejected a Japanese protest against the transportation of Koreans from their homes in the Vladivostok region to Middle Asia.

Announcement is made by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers of Chicago of the organization of the Income Production Service Council; Leo J. Sheridan has been named chairman and Waldemar Karkow consulting engineer.

THE Youngstown Symphony Society of Youngstown, Ohio, has inaugurated a series of auditions for young artists, winners in which will appear as soloists at one of the organization's orchestral concerts next year. It is planned to make the
A committee of Middlesex County industrial leaders and local school authorities will be named to investigate how the Perth Amboy edunational system and industry's personnel needs can be correlated.
Rocks, earth and trees tumbled down the side of Elysian Park's "moving mountain" last night and geologists said that another, worse avalanche was imminent last night.

The Toronto Maple Leafs settled for last Tuesday's setback by walloping the Montreal Maroons, 4 to 0, tonight in a National Hockey League game before 12,000 fans. It was the first shutout of the season for Turk Broda, Toronto's young goalie,

WASHINGTON--With the setting up of Brazil as a "corporate" State, a question mark seems to have been placed over the future status of the American naval mission now in that country. Assigned to Brazil several

THIS is the third of the "crimefile" mystery stories, and it is also the best of the three. It begins with a double murder, which looks like a second Hall-Mills case, the victims being the headmaster of a boys' school in New Jersey and a young woman who has been his secretary.

Once a week, chapel periods at. Washington and Jefferson College will be devoted to discussions of moral, religious or social topics suggested by the students, the Rev. A. W. Wishart, director of religious activities, announces.

The annual Christmas seal sale of the National Tuberculosis Association has again been endorsed by national leaders in government, business, labor, church, civic and educational groups, it was announced by Dr. Kendall Emerson, managing director. This is the thirtieth year of the Christmas seal sale in the United States, which was started in Wilmington, Del., in 1907.

The women student of Colby College have pledged $1,576 to provide one room in the Women's Union on the future Mayflower Hill campus. This brings the total of subscriptions to $40,000 toward the necessary $100,000 for the central unit of the building.
The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today a program designed to encourage manufacture of part of this year's bumper crop of potatoes into starch and flour.

The football year of 1937 witnessed a leveling process that left no single section of the country with a fair claim to superiority, in the opinion of four nationally famous football coaches, who herewith present their all-America teams, selected for the North American Newspaper Alliance.

The Manhattan Mutual Automobile Casualty Company, Inc., announced yesterday a dividend of 7 1/2 per cent to all policyholders in New York State on the business for 1937.
Anti-aircraft guns purchased by the Nicaraguan Government from Ban Switzerland proved very successful today in tests at a range of seven kilometers [about 4.35 miles].

When we survey our governmental policies in recent years it is astonishing how many of them have this one quality in common: the sacrifice of the future to the present. The most obvious example of this is our unbalanced budget. Whatever defense may have been made of this lack of balance in its early stages cannot apply to its indefinite continuance.

Plans for an alumnae memorial window in the Mother Irene Gill Library now under construction on the campus of the College of New Rochelle at a cost of $400,000 have been completed by Voorhees, Gmelin Walker, architects of New York.

Announcement of impending negotiations looking toward an Anglo-American trade pact has aroused keener interest in Germany than any other similar event in recent years. First impressions forthcoming were that the pact must be viewed

The Cinderella Dance, which was founded twenty-eight years ago by Mrs. James Guthrie Shaw, is the oldest dance to be given consecutively in Brooklyn. This year's event will take place on Dec. 23 at the Heights Casino, Brooklyn Heights, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Adrian Van Sinderen. The guests are young women from 15 to 18 years of age who will make their debuts in forthcoming seasons, and young men in their group.

The Friday Assemblies, a comparatively new series of dances which for several years have received a large subscription from young matrons, former debutantes and single men, will be continued this year with two dances to be held respectively on Dec. 10 and Jan. 21 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

UNCLE SAM paid his air-mail carriers, both domestic and foreign, close to $18,500,000 in the fiscal year that ended June 30, according to figures compiled by the Postoffice Department and the Federal Bureau of Air Commerce.

A five-year cross-licensing contract of Remington-Rand, Inc., and the International Business Machine Corporation was voided yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman on the ground it constituted a monopoly in violation of the State and Federal anti-trust laws.

The WPA Teachers Union, through its attorney, Herman E. Cooper, filed an appeal yesterday with the board of examiners and the. State Commissioner of Education urging reconsideration of the denial by the examiners of a teaching license to Miss Laura Liebman, president of the union.

Behind two brilliant touchdown runs on the part of John Pingel, Michigan State College rolled to a 14-0 football triumph today over the University of San Francisco. The long-legged left halfback gave 20,000 fans their biggest thrills by running 75 yards in the third period
ALTHOUGH crime control is reserved by the Constitution to the States, Federal activity in this field is made possible by use of the taxing, postal, and interstate commerce clauses.

AS this department contemplates the very interesting early announcements of the Metropolitan Opera season, which opens tomorrow night, it is moved to reflect upon the way that time passes and public opinion changes with time, under the very noses of such students of the timeless as music commentators.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Lillian Montgomery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Franklin Montgomery of 160 Henry Street, Brooklyn, to Henry S. Jenkins, son of Mrs. G. Pike Jenkins of Derby Line, Vt., and Brooklyn.

The National Advisory Cancer Council today made its first three grantsin-aid of $54,800. One of these went to Professor E. O. Lawrence of the University of alifornia for establishment of a cyclotron laboratory at Berkeley.

Wheat prices fluctuated in an erratic manner today, and while there was a fair upturn at one time in sympathy with securities, the market ran into commission-house and local selling and reacted rather sharply from the high point, closing 1/8 to 5/8 cent lower, the latter on the July, which was affected by the receipt of beneficial moisture in the Southwest.

Two themes--Recovery and Reform--have dominated the New Deal. Successively, one or the other has been heard the louder. In the emergency of 1933 the emphasis was all on Recovery. Gradually, as the emergency passed, Reform rose to greater volume.

The United States Patent Office has just granted its 2,100,000th patent since the establishment on July 4, 1886, of the modern patent system by an act of Congress which was signed by Andrew Jackson, then President of the United States.

But no divorce was granted on grounds of domestic discord. And for no reason whatever might a woman be divorced by her husband unless her own parents

Massachusetts Institute of Technology this year has one of the most cosmopolitan student bodies in its entire history. No fewer than 216 students doing graduate and undergraduate work at M. I. T. come from countries and territorial possessions outside of the United States, with thirtyseven different nations represented.

ADVANC illustrations of Ecuador's stamps commemoratng the United States Constitution have been made available. As announced in these columns on Oct. 31, both postage and air sets are to be issued, each in values of 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50 centavos and 1 and 2 sucres. All carry the inscription "Commemorativo del Sesquicentenario de la Adoption y Promulgacion de la Constitucion de los Estados Unidos de America" and the dates 17871789 and 1937-1939.

The seven-man National Bituminous Coal Commission, set up for a fouryear period under the Bituminous Coal Act of last April, is getting down to its job of trying to make a sick industry--perhaps the country's sickest--well.

More than 22,000 miles of all classes of highway were completed in the fiscal year 1937, topping the former record of 21,700 miles in 1934, the Bureau of Public Roads of the Department of Agriculture reported today.

More self - government and greater interest in this government are the aim of the longer and more frequent student mass meetings which are being held at Skidmore College this year.

Long strides toward furnishing isolated farms in this vicinity with electric power through the Tri-County Rural Electric Company, a REA project, have been taken in recent weeks, according to Harry J. Postel of Oceanport, newly appointed superintendent of the former company.

Speedy Rod Lorrain pumped home a thirdperiod goal tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 2-1 victory over New York Rangers in the first meeting between these National Hockey League clubs this season.

The principal festivity occasioned today by the Army-Navy football game this afternoon In the Municipal Stadium was the Navy dinner dance given at the Bellevue-Stratford by the Naval Academy Association of Philadelphia for the graduates of the academy, both active and retired. Five hundred persons attended.

Public School Athletic League swimmers, idle yesterday because of the Thanksgiving vacation, will resume competition for the team championships of the various boroughs next Saturday and it will not be surprising to see record-breaking feats mark some
Arthur G. Williams, a theatrical representative for fifty years, died on Friday at the Polyclinic Hospital at the age of 75.

Mrs. Ruth Fahnestock Schermerhorn received a divorce here today from A. Coster Schermerhorn of Locust Valley, L. I., on ground of cruelty. It was not contested. An agreement covering property and the custody of a child was filed with the court.

" HOORAY FOR WHAT!" that merry melange of mirth, melody, misses, madness, mischief, magnificence, mode, movement, monkey-business and a little potato salad, please, will positively open at the Winter Garden Wednesday night, with Ed Wynn as its star.
To the Radio Editor: I see that there is much ado about types of programs, i. e., whether there ought to be a mixing of jazz with good music.

JAMES J. FERO, the Pride of Pimlico and an otherwise popular figure at the wagering windows, enters the theatrical race tracks this week on the opposite side of the betting table. He is placing what he calls "a little bundle" instead of taking it on a show known as "To Be Continued," commenting rather emphatically that he is betting the show to win and not to show.

While the curve of installment sales will follow any downward trend in cash buying at a faster pace, the figures on automotive and appliance paper so far this month are a "bit better" than for the same month last year, according to an executive of a leading finance company here.

Under the auspices of the JohnsManville organization a conference on home building will be held on Tuesday at the Hotel Roosevelt Owners and managers of the leading lumber yards in New York and adjacent States have been invited to attend. P. A. Andrews, vice
The Works Progress Administration spent $38,607,415 in developing airports during the year ended Sept. 30, Administrator Hopkins announced today.
Miss Mary Elizabeth Gourley, daughter of Mrs. Edwin Gourley of this city, and Irwin Ralph Hogenauer. formerly of New York. were married here last night.

For the seventeenth year in succession C. C. N. Y. and St. Francis met in the opening game of their basketball seasons at the Lavender gymnasium last night and for the seventeenth time the Beavers were victorious over their Brooklyn rivals. The score of the contest was

President Roosevelt completed today the messages on housing and highway aid which he will send to Congress next week and closed his desk for a vacation trip in the South, to be spent for the most part in fishing off the coast of Florida on the yacht Potomac.

Miss Rosabelle Bragg Brady, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Plunkett Brady and the late Mr. Brady, and Joseph Hamilton Thomas, son of Mrs. John R. Thomas of Vass, N. C., and the late Mr. Thomas, were married this afternoon in St. James's Episcopal Church here.

Miss Virginia Austin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Arnold Austin of 228 North Walnut Street, East Orange, and Oliver Wills Tuthill, son of Mrs. Oliver Bailey Tuthill of 554 Mountain Avenue, North Caldwell, were married here this afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.

Miss Anne Morgan is chairman of the patroness committee for the first National Crochet Exhibition, which opens tomorrow in the ballroom of the American Woman's Association Clubhouse, and continues there throughout the week.

An examination for a teaching license as first assistant. in mechanic arts in the city high schools has been scheduled, the Board of Examiners announced last week. Applications must be filed prior to Dec. 17.

HIGHWAY contractors are nearly finished with their work on State highways, and there will be little or no more pouring of concrete until Spring. Meanwhile, work on some of the contracts, where concrete is not required, will be continued during the Winter. Heavy grading in several sections will continue so that the 'roads may be completed during the coming Summer.
Werner Janssen of New York will take over the baton for the 1938 season of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, Frederick R. Huber, Municipal Director of Music, announced today.

County Executive-Elect J. Russel Sprague and the Republican organization of Nassau County will be honored at a "Victory Dinner" in the Garden City Hotel, Garden City, L. I., Saturday evening.

The Wages and Hours Bill now before Congress has loosed a flood of discussion. It is predicated on the idea that its minimum-wage provision would increase the national purchasing power by raising the pay of the lowest-paid groups and that its maximum-hour provision would divide jobs and create employment. Development of the shipping industry in Palestine offers employment opportunities for "tens of thousands of families," labor representatives told 1,500 delegates attending the thirteenth annual convention of the National Labor Committee for Palestine yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Lowell English, a guard, dropped back to the Kansas State 23-yard line in the final twenty seconds of the second quarter today and on a snow-glazed field place-kicked. Nebraska to its third straight Big Six football championship.

The first print sale of the season at the American Art AssociationAnderson Galleries, Inc., will be held on Friday evening. The auction will comprise the collections of Mrs. Leonard Elmhirst and the late Theodore A. Peyser, former Representative from New York City, and engravings and etchings from the collections of the late Seth Sprague Terry and Mrs. Gertrude S. Terry. D. Lyle Russell and Milton Towne.

With three of its components higher for the week ended Nov. 20, the decline of THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity slackened, and the figure now stands at 88.9. It was 90.5 (revised) for the previous week, and 104.7 for the corresponding week a year ago.
Jane and Hele Roman, 7 and 3 year old daughters of Mr. and Mrs. James Roman, were killed today in their farm home when they hauled a small electric heater into the tub in which they were bathing.
The Massachusetts Unemployment Compensation Commission will have available a fund of $40,000,000 on Jan. 1 to pay benefits to persons out of work and who have been under the provision of that law.

Marcel Dupre, organist of the Church of St. Sulpice in Paris and Professor of Organ at the Paris National Conservatory, will appear in a recital at the Chapel of Trinity College on Thursday with his daughter, Marguerite, a pianist.

THE second National Conference on Educational Broadcasting is scheduled to be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday at the Drake Hotel in Chicago. Dr. George F. Zook, president of the American Council on Education, will act as chairman.

On the basis of mortality statistics for the first ten month of this year, 1937 promises to be the best "health year" ever experienced in this country, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday.

The Pittsburgh Hornets tonight outplayed the Springfield Indians to win an International-American Hockey League game, 2 to 1, before 5,500 spectators. The Hornets' forward combination of Currie and Hudson accounted for Springfield's first loss in

The Committee for Industrial Organization has branched out into the field of education with the formation here of the Federal Workers School of the District of Columbia, offering, for a nominal tuition fee, courses to government employes and others on eighteen subjects ranging from economics to modern dancing. This is said to be the first instance of such activity in the history of government workers' unions.

One of the most intensive Fall trout stocking programs ever. attempted by the New York State Conservation Department will begin next week. The public fishing streams in the vicinity of Lake Placid and Malone will benefit from the plan, as approximately 100,000 brown trout ranging in size from six inches up will be planted there.

More than twenty-five Brooklyn churches will participate in the twenty-sixth Pilgrim Festival to be held by the board of managers of the New York Congregational Home on Wednesday and Thursday at the home, 123 Linden Boulevard.

BEBLIN-ISAACS--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Isaacs have the honor of announcing the marriage of their daughter. Lucille Lois, to Irving Berlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Berlln of New York City, Nov. 25, 1937. OLARK--FINE--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fine of 333 West 86th St., New York City, announce the marriage of their daughter. Ruth, to Mr. Joseph Clark of Detroit, Mitch.

Bryn Mawr College has broken ground for a new dormitory which will incorporate the ideas of undergraduates as to what a college dormitory should be like. Before having the plans drawn a committee not only asked the Bryn Mawr students about their needs, but it visited other women's colleges, investigated student housing conditions and talked with undergraduates in those institutions.

FOR the eleventh successive year Switzerland will release, in December, a series of semi-postal stamps which will include among its designs a portrait of a man prominent in Swiss history. These are Helvetia's Christmas-time "Pro Juventute" (For the Children) sets printed to raise funds to aid the nation's battle against the spread of tuberculosis among boys and girls.

The Soviet press, which virtually is the only channel through which the government discloses its views, has had surprisingly little to say about current Far Eastern events considering their powerful bearing on the Soviet's vital interests.

Representatives of the Greyhound Bus Company and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen met in conference last night at Cleveland for the first time since the lines of the bus system were affected by a strike called on Thanksgiving Day, The Associated Press reported.

The declining trend in industrial activity grew more pronounced last week, but the approach of the holiday season, coupled with colder weather, brought more optimistic reports of retail trade, and several districts reported larger business in the stores than for the previous week.

Fabrication and shipment of structural steel last month continued in large volume, according to final reports to the American Institute of Steel Construction, although bookings of new orders were the lowest of the year.

Miss Leslie Allen Petrie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Adamson Petrie of Montclair, was married this evening in the home of her parents, to Edward N. Lippincott, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Haines Lippincott of Atlantic City.
A white coffin containing the ashes of Ramsay MacDonald was placed today in his wife's grave in the tiny flower-embowered churchyard of Spynie, near Lossiemouth, Scotland.

The engagement of Miss Flora Blanc, daughter of Mrs. Edward H. Blanc of 121 Madison Avenue and the late Mr. Blanc, to Dickson Reeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dean Worthington Reeder of Fort Worth, Texas, has been announced by her mother.

Mrs. Clayton D. Lee, the first president and one of the founders of the Woman's Club of Maplewood, N. J., twenty-one years ago, will be the honor guest at the group's birthday celebration to be held on Friday at 2:30 P. M. in the clubhouse.

Federal Judge Richard J. Hopkins held today that former Representative Harold McGugin, Walter S. Keith, his law partner, and Anna Laura Barnett "participated fraudulently in the distribution" of funds belonging to the late Jackson Barnett, an Indian wealthy in oil properties.

Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Duryee Hull gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League to introduce their daughter, Miss Shirley Tucker Hull. The guests included older friends of the family as well as debutantes of this and recent seasons.

In a setting of cybotium ferns and Southern smilax, Miss Lisa Lawrence Renshaw was introduced to society at a dinner dance given for her by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Renshaw, last night in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. The guests were seated at small tables decorated with yellow spray chrysanthemums and yellow snapdragon and illuminated by tall yellow candles.
A large passenger plane of the Southwest Aviation Corporation was reported today to have crashed near the western border of Kwangsi Province near Lungchow while en route to Hanoi, French Indo-China.

Miss Rachel K. McDowell, religious news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will speak here Monday evening in the Town Hall on "My Recent Pilgrimage to the Holy Land." The address is under the auspices of the Congregational Church.

The problem of minorities and of Germans abroad was brought to the fore again with the Memel Diet's protesting of the Lithuanian Dispossession Law and Minister of the Interior Wilhelm Frick's address in Upper Silesia yesterday.
Lumber shipments on the Pacific Coast, according to figures up to Nov. 6, stood at 54 per cent of the average 1929 shipments, as production fell to 60 per cent of the 1929 average output.

Mortgages accepted by the Federal Housing Administration for insurance represented an aggregate value on Nov. 13, last, of $1,011,249,227, involving 249,507 individual mortgages. This total shows an average mortgage value of $4,053, being $44 more than the average one year ago.

Four years late, California grape growers are at last enjoying the benefits anticipated from prohibition repeal. The 1937 vintage season, now ending, gives to them the greatest net return from their vineyards since 1927.
Play Reading To the Drama Bditor: I had the good luck to get into the packed auditorium at the Book Fair when the literary aspects of the theatre were discussed.

The Goldens Bridge Hounds held a hunt ball here tonight at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club. Mrs. James C. Clark, M. F. H., was chairman of the event. She was assisted by Mrs. William C. Browning, Mrs. Arthur P. Choate, Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel, Mrs. W.

Despite fierce and continuous criticism from big business and financial interests, which has culminated in a lawsuit by eighteen private power companies, the Tennessee Valley Authority enjoys widespread popularity in the various Southeastern States in and adjacent to the Tennessee River Valley.

Special interest has been lent to the subject of astronomy at Vassar College this Fall by the presence of Dr. Robert J. Trumpler, astronomer of the Lick Observatory of the University of California and member of the National Academy of Sciences. As visiting lecturer dur-.
The New York chapter of the American Institute of Banking will hold its twenty-fourth annual bankers' forum and dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt on Thursday, it was announced yesterday.

Several interesting facts regarding the heating of office and apartment buildings are brought to light by James F. Durnell, vice president of Irving Ruland Co., Inc.

Moderate forward buying by magazine publishers has developed in white paper in the last few weeks, but book publishers have continued to purchase only against current needs, it was reported yesterday. Prices have held since the differential adjustment made in the Summer.

Because the fraternity system makes an important spiritual contribution, fraternities should improve themselves by self-criticism and reverse the attitude which has caused them to be "losing caste in recent years," Karl Litzenberg, assistant Professor of English and adviser on fraternities at the University of Michigan, declared yesterday.

Albert Sarraut, Director of French North African Affairs, obtained today unanimous approval of the Cabinet for his program of coordination in North Africa to combat unrest and improve conditions in Tunis, Algeria and Morocco.

Ernest C. Brimmer, who in motion pictures is Richard Dix, has won his appeal for a 50 per cent reduction in the assessed valuation placed upon his extensive undeveloped land holdings in this municipality.
Wylie G. Logue, commercial manager of the Radiomarine Corporation of America, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 235 Wellington Road, Mineola, L. I., at the age of 47.

Mr. and Mrs. Barnhard Apsidorf of this place have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Claire Apsidorf, to David Nicholas Laux, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Frank Laux of Bristow, Okla., which took place on Wednesday in Elkton, Md.

The question of Federal us. State power, brought before the country once more by measures in Congress and cases before the Supreme Court, was discussed last week in an article by James Truslow Adams, who attacked the recent concentration of power at Washington. In this article Professor Commager defends the present evolution.

For the new generation weaned on radio and movies, the WPA and the New York Board of Education have prepared an experimental set of "action-story" primers which treat of cowboys and Indians, policemen and robbers, pirates and rugged sea captains, the last serialized in three parts.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., pf. Holland Furnace Company, pf. Johns-Manville Corp., pf. and com. McKeesport Tin Plate Company. Myers (F. E.) Brothers Co. St. Joseph Lead Company.

Temple University has established educational centers in forty-six communities in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and Maryland. Nine courses have been established thus far, the report shows, with a total enrollment to date of 190 students.

WASHINGTON--Out of 400,000 arrests in the first nine months of this year throughout the country, the largest number of prisoners in any age group were aged 22. Prior to 1935 the arrested persons aged 19 outnumbered other age groups. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, revealing the results of an examination of records, adds that for age 20, this year, arrests were substantially lower than for ages 21 and 19.

DON'T let any one kid you into thinking that dancing is the easiest way in the world to earn a comfortable living-unless, that is, you choose to ignore some 140 pounds of contrary evidence in the person of Fred Astaire.

Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who has served the company almost fifty-five years, was due to leave his post on Dec. 31 under the retirement rules but has been re-elected to serve without salary after that date, it was announced yesterday by Leroy A. Lincoln, president.

The only debating society in the Philadelphia area to meet the British Oxford-Cambridge debating team, on tour in Eastern United States, will be that of Drexel Institute of Technology. Coming from Yale University, the visitors will be entertained at Drexel on Tuesday afternoon,
Celebrating her 101st birthday here today, Miss Annie M. Emery said she looked upon life as a "happy adventure" as she greeted friends who called to pay respects.

IT is reported that the attendance at the new Museum of Modern Art Gallery in Washington, during the first week of its opening, amounted to an average of 150 per day on paydays, 750 on Saturday, a free day, and 1,218 on Sunday, which is also free. The admittance fee is 25 cents. The gallery is closed on Mondays.

THERE are generally two occasions when an actor in the foreign-language films compels the question, "Who is he?" One is when that actor, after a series of sterling performances, is summoned to Hollywood--and accepts the summons. The alternative is when he refuses. In either case it is news.

Despite the fact that it has been almost a year since they played together, W. E. (Billy) Coyle, New York State amateur singles champion, and Walter Kinsella, one of the outstanding court-game professionals in the country, carried off a second-round match in the Heights Casino pro-amateur invitation squash racquets doubles tournament yesterday.

New York City public school children who come from homes shattered by divorce, separation or, death possess many inferior character and personality traits and do less competent school work than pupils from normal homes, according to a survey made public yesterday.
The recovery movement initiated in the stock market on Friday was vigorously pursued during yesterday's half-day trading period.
The world is familiar with the stratospheric cabin or cell, a metallic sphere entirely air-tight, supplied with manholes and some scuttles fitted with very powerful glass.

NORTH CONWAY, N. Blessed by nature with the longest Winter sports sea son in the East, the nine White Mountain communities which call themselves "the Eastern Slope" seem just about ready for the influx from New York and Boston of pilgrims bent on risking their necks to the glory of Telemark and Christie.
Miss Virginia Ivins Babcock, debutante daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James Woods Babcock 2d, entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Mirror Room of Le Coq Rouge.
Isaac N. Ragsdale, former Mayor of Atlanta, died today of pneumonia that developed following a dental extraction. His age was 78. He served two terms as Mayor, from Jan. 1, 1927, through 1930.

The Northeast first team will move into the final round of the women's national field hockey tournament tomorrow undefeated by virtue of its 3-0 triumph over the Midwest firsts in today's play at new Trier Field.
The American Association of Museums will sponsor a conference on the general subject of museums for children, Friday, Dec. 3, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The will of Samuel Frank, president of Frank Brothers Footwear, Inc., filed yesterday in Westchester County, revealed that Mr. Frank had made several bequests to charity.

While rain out the attendance at the Yale football games with Cornell and Princeton, a total of about 299,000 spectators witnessed contests this Fall, against 269,000 last year. The rain preceding the Cornell and Princeton battles reduced the crowds by some 20,000, it was estimated unofficially today.

ESTABLISHMENT of three experimental farms where efforts will be made to produce a more succulent oyster of uniformly high mineral content was recently announced by Commissioner Frank T. Bell of the United States Bureau of Fisheries. Locations are Milford, Conn., Beaufort, N. C., and Pensacola, Fla.

The appointment of Captain Johannes J. Bijl as master of the new Holland America Line flagship Nieuw Amsterdam. was announced yesterday by F. Ra. Wierdsma, general manager of the line's New York offices.

Human vanity is a major contributing factor to the foot disorders which afflict more than 75 per cent of Americans and which stand in the way of a happier and more sturdy race, in the opinion of Dr. Maurice J. Lewi, head of the First Institute of Podiatry, who will celebrate his eightieth birthday next Wednesday.

Two calm young girls of high school age, one with a pistol, rolled socks and a "page-boy" bob, held up a gasoline filling station here early this morning. Wrecking the telephone and forcing the station attendant, in the class room manner, to stand with his face to the wall, they escaped with $60 and four gallons of gas in a shiny new car.

The decision as to whether production should be reduced in an effort to maintain prices, or price reduced in an effort to maintain production in a period of business recession, should be made in the light of the particular conditions applying to the industry in question, in the opinion of R. P. Marple, director of research and technical service for the National Association of Cost Accountants.

Miss Dolly Madison, vice chairman of the national Young Republican organization and prominent in Republican politics in Middlesex County, was under technical arrest at her home here today on a charge of obtaining $3,200 under false pretenses.
Army authorities today disclosed the capture of a sailing vessel and her crew of eight, whom they accused of being seagoing cattle rustlers.

A luncheon and fashion show will be held Tuesday in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis in aid of the Give and Take Thrift Shop, a permanent organization at 1,272 Third Avenue, that is managed jointly by the alumnae of Barnard College and the Social Service Committee of the Neurological Institute in behalf of their charitable enterprises.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred V. Norton will preside at a moot trial on Friday at 8 P. M. to be conducted by the League of Women Voters, the Staten Island Business and Professional Women's Club and other cooperating groups.

Twenty flags, one for each State, were burned before thousands here today. President Getulio Dornelles Vargas, members of the Cabinet, army and navy officers, workers and school children watched the ceremony.

While high-powered rifles have been resounding through Vermont during the past week as the hunters go forth to kill as many deer as possible during the brief season, one Vermont nimrod has chosen to return to the pioneer days and hunt with bow and arrow.

BROADCASTING in New Zealand has gone commercial and is the outward expression of a new form of State-owned, Socialist enterprise.

Action in the New York wholesale market was spotty last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers. Although slight improvement was noted in some lines, most markets were still below normal. The report continues:

The annual Christmas bazaar under the auspices of the Garner School for Girls will be held Friday night at the school, 154 East Seventieth Street, for the benefit of the institution's various philanthropic activities. The proceeds will be donated to several local philanthropies as well as to the student library fund, the United Hospitals Campaign, the Red Cross, the Henry Street Settlement, the Chrystie Street Settlement and St. Bartholomew's Church.
An unusually large inquiry developed in the export copper market yesterday. Heavy transactions for Saturday were reported at 9.825 to 9.91 cents a pound c. i. f. the European base ports.

The Stage Society, pioneers in the once unknown fields of Ibsen, Strindberg and Shaw, returns to Strindberg on Sunday with the first English translation of "Queen Christina," which will be given a single performance at the Westminster Theatre with Wanda Rotha in the title role. Fritz Wendhausen,

Jacob Hurwitz, an insurance broker with an office at 1,170 Broadway, died yesterday at his residence, 415 Central Park West, after a long illness. Born in Russia in 1858, he came to this country in 1908. He had been ordained a rabbi

With the familiar cry of "Come on. Steve," ringing in his ears, Steve Donoghue, winner of 1,800 races, closed his long and brilliant career as a jockey today by bringing his mount into third place in the final plate on the Manchester race course.

MANHATTAN BAXTER, EDWARD L. (Nov. 5). Estate, less than $5,000. To Michael A. Baxter, brother, executor, Kate A. Baxter, sister, 600 W. 187th St. one-half residue each; six minor bequests. POLLOCK, REBECCA (July 11). Estate, approximately $700. To William Reinstein, brother, executor, 1,691 Clay Ave., Bronx, Benjamin Reinstein, brother, 682 Alabama Ave., Brooklyn, equal shares in residue; two minor bequests.

WITH both "The House master" and "Love of Women" practically ready to pounce from the road to Broadway, the Messrs. Shubert are looking further down their collective schedule and noting such items as these:

THIS book is a very abbreviated historical introduction to psychology. followed by a miniature survey of the princples of behaviomrsm and the Gestalt school. The opening chapter discusses Descartes as the father of modern psychology, and passes on to an examination of Locke, Berkeley. Hartley and James Stuart Mill. until it finally reaches the subject of Fechner's quantitative psychology.
