Allegations that Indo-China is a gateway for important arms shipments to China are contained in correspondence to Europe from a Swedish professor, Olov Janse, who is traveling in the Far East on behalf of French museums.

State 4-H Club leader for the extension service of the University of Vermont and State Agricultural College since 1914, when the work was started, has just been honored at the annual banquet of Epsilon Sigma Phi, national honorary fraternity of extension workers, with a certificate of recognition of his work.

COPPER wires have never refused to accept a challenge from radio. Ever since Marconi's first transatlantic signal dealt the cables a surprising blow, the wire lines have-never admitted defeat, but have boldly defled the "ether" to do anything in communication as efficiently as a copper artery.
Three Germans were reported found near the Bavarian border today without identification papers. They declared they were fliers belonging to the Richthofen Squadron who were ordered to Spain.

ONLY a few months after his admirable monograph on Mozart's "Magic Flute" Dr. Paul Stefan of Vienna has now published through the Herbert Reichner Verlag an uncommonly penetrating and scholarly study of "Don Giovanni."

Nearly a million school boys and girls and youthful workers in thirteen cities from Baltimore to Seattle today have a far better chance for landing in the right job than they had six months ago. And their future employers will not have nearly as much trouble with "misfits" as they might have had.

Miss Bessie May Griffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Griffin of this village, became the bride of Frank E. Hayt, son of Edgar F. Hayt and the late Mrs. Hayt of Patterson, N. Y., this afternoon.

The Winfield Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of a lecture entitled "A Safari Through Africa," illustrated by motion pictures, which will be given by Captain George Shearwood next Sunday night in the main ballroom of the Pierre.

The report of Stone Webster, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $2,273,027 after all expenses and charges.
The New Haven Eagles, playing a superlative defensive game, stood off all Cleveland rushes tonight and held the Barons to a scoreless overtime tie in an International-American League hockey game.

Miss Leonore M. Tierney of 1,356 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, was married to George J. Gillespie of 146 East Sixty-second Street, president of the Board of Water Supply, yesterday morning in the private chapel of the home of Patrick Cardinal Hayes, 452 Madison Avenue.

A novel system for government of men students is being tested at Syracuse University. Divided into three departments, administrative, legislative and judicial, it displaces the men's student senate, which was composed of twelve men elected from the various colleges.

Miss Dorothy Padmore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Padmore of this place, and William L. Saylor, son of Mrs. Phoebe T. Saylor, were married here today in the First Baptist Church by the pastor, the Rev. Eugene G. Mintz.

Lord Britain, 8-year-old chestnut gelding from the Map Top Stables, owned by Mrs. Edgar Mayer of Greenwich, Conn., gained the hunter championship as the annual Peekskill Horse Show ended tonight. That he was awarded the title came as no surprise to the crowd that watched him in several hunter classes throughout the two days of the exhibition.
Members of the Senior Class or Sarah Lawrence College will hold their annual promenade next Saturday night at the college. On Sunday there will be a tea dance followed by supper.

TISH never had more fatiguing or fantastic adventures than she has in this latest chronicle of her doings. She and Aggie, with the usual hay-fever symptoms, and the Lizzie who tells the stones sail to England in a dear little dirigible. get mixed up with the coronation and the crown jewels, go tarpon fishing in Florida and pick up a bear in the great open spaces of the Far West.

On a hot day in Baltimore last May, two foreign-born young women with an urge to see how Americans live and the money and time with which to do it smilingly watched Mayor Howard Jackson dash a bottle of champagne against a glistening new cream-colored trailer and name it "Esme"--Gaelic for "good luck."

JOHN BOYNTON PRIESTLEY has been seeing America again. A few years ago when this English man of letters arrived here on one of his frequent visits he was quoted as saying that the Americans had a general case of indigestion and that Boston was an overrated city of mock culture.

The second annual Winter Sports Show and international ski meet, scheduled for Madison Square Garden Dec. 7-11, is beginning to take form as a result of the arrival of many foreign skating and skiing aces in the past week. Representatives from Austria.
Several acreage tracts and plots for early residential improvement have recently been sold in the Bernardsville and Basking Ridge sections of Somerset County, N.J., reports Eiteworth Dobbs, broker.

HE Who seeks truth should be of no country," claimed Voltaire; we might add, Whoever wishes to record truth should not feel self-conscious as to the country about which that truth may be far from complimentary.

Placement of nearly all of the 1937 graduates of the University of Delaware in permanent positions in business and education is announced by Colonel Donald M. Ashbridge, director of the Business Guidance Bureau.

If the Administration hopes to reopen the market for new capital and enable private business to assume its share in checking the current decline in business activity through increased spending, it first must restore the confidence of private capital in its ability and right to earn a fair return, according to financial leaders. That a market,

-Oscar L. Wheeler, older brother of United States Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat, Montana, died today at Marlboro Hospital, where he underwent amputation of a gangrenous leg yesterday. His age was 74.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Krementz of Elizabeth, N. J., and Camden, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Krementz, to John M. S. Hutchinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. E. Hutchinson of Detroit and Jamestown, R. I.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James T. Seaver of Bronxville, of the engagement of their daughter. Miss Mary Elizabeth Seaver, to William Charles Eichmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Eichmann of Waterbury, Conn.
The wrecking tug Killering arrived here late today with Captain Ford and sixteen seamen rescued from the Nollington Court, doomed British freighter. Eighteen of the crew arrived here yesterday.

John Trumbull Robinson, one of the leaders of the Connecticut bar and a prominent Republican, died here tonight at his home, 1,283 Asylum Avenue; of a stroke suffered a month ago. He was.66 years old.

Indoor polo will open its new season on Saturday night with Squadron A holding the first games on its playing surface at Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. The contests will mark the earliest start here in some time and the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will receive a proportion of the receipts.

Boston University is a newcomer on the Massachusetts State varsity swimming slate of six dual meets arranged for the season. The schedule: Jan. 8. Boston University, at Boston; 15, Worcester Tech 22 Williams

A COMMITTEE of citizens, including Mayor La Guardia, is raising a fund of $50,000 to put into rehearsal a group of 100 or more blind musicians, recruited from those who must play on the streets for a livelihood, those forced into idleness and those who are professionals. The unit will include an orchestra, a choral group and a number of featured artists,
The Minister of Justice was asked today formally to charge persons arrested in the government's investigation of a widespread revolutionary movement with "plotting against the safety of the State."

Early reports indicate a swing to medium and popular price lines in initial Christmas shopping, but trade results this week are expected to give the first definite clues on holiday trade, both on the score of probable volume and type of Purchasing. and also on reorders.

Miss Helen Ewald Autenrieth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Autenrieth of South Orange, N. J., was married to John G. D. Stewart, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Stewart of New York, here yesterday morning at the Pierre by the Rev. A. H. Marion of Stamford. Conn.
Names of naval officers with distinguished records in the World War were assigned by the Navy Department today to five destroyers now under construction. The names assigned were:
With a total of 1,473 parallaxes determined up to the present, the University of Pittsburgh's Allegheny Observatory leads the world in this phase of astronomical study.

THEY who discover this book will agree that it is, taken for all in all, one of the fine autobiographies of the period. An unusual man reveals himself with a charming and modest candor. He has a great story to tell and he has told it in the right way.

Additional patronesses have been enlisted for the benefit entertainment and tea to be held Tuesday under the auspices of the Junior Committee of the Brooklyn Home for Children at the Grace Church Parish House in Brooklyn. Included on the program will bean entertainment by John Mulholland, magician.

For the first time in years the executive and legislative branches of the government are joined in extending a helping hand to American business, and most of the measures in prospect are highly practical: revised taxes, a private housing drive, a truce with the utilities, and more economy.

Both home and foreign comment, on the situation at Washington and on wall Street, has stressed the fact that the obvious remedy for existing financial troubles, removal of punitive taxation, is being resisted by certain factions in Congress, that the costly and highly controverted Administration plans are still pressed, and that the very recent indiscriminate denunciation of large business has been only partially abated.
Three priests were under arrest here today on charges of violating Veracruz State's anti-religious laws against which Catholics conducted a "peaceful rebellion" last February.
Colonel and Mrs. Walter Jeffreys Carlin of 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, will give a tea dance on Dec. 27 at the Ritz-Carlton for their debutante daughter, Miss Marjorie Jean Carlin.

Aided by two former Princeton athletes, Cresson Kearny of San Antonio, Texas, and Jack Irwin of Keokuk, Iowa, Oxford today defeated Cambridge for the second straight year in a relay meet. The score was four first places to three.

The 1937 edition of composite tables of percentage lease rates which various types of business interests can afford to pay, has just been issued by the brokers' division of the National Association of Real Estate Boards. The tables,in-
Georgia paid tribute today to Miss Moina Michael of Athens, Ga., originator of "poppy" sales to aid disabled war veterans, by unveiling a marble statue of her in the State capital.

Dmitri Shostakovich, young Soviet composer whose works are well known in America, is now apparently on the way to complete rehabilitation after his spectacular fall from favor in February, 1936. Until that fall he had been universally hailed in the Soviet as a genius and his works were widely performed.

With faculty guidance, debating has become the major extra-curricular activity at Good Counsel College here. The Preston Debating Society, an undergraduate organization, has a record membership with 20 per cent of the student body participating. Interest in oral

The Associated Press was accused of violating provisions of the National Labor Relations Act in a complaint issued today by the National Labor Relations Board, based on complaints from traffic department employes of the news-gathering organization.

Chemical creation in the laboratory of early embryonic forms of life from microscopic fragments of eggs which contained neither the male nor the female nucleus, thus bringing into existence for the first time living creatures that had neither father nor the principal element provided by the mother, was described today before the Autumn meeting of the American Philosophical Society.

With songs and costume dances reminiscent of the former Imperial Court at Vienna, a pageant entitled "The Renaissance of Elegance" will be presented as a feature of the Viennese Ball to be given on Jan. 15 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton in aid of the Judson Health Center.

Miss Harriette A. Bahney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luther W. Bahney of this city, became the bride of Lieutenant J. Caldwell Wylie Jr., U. S. N., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Caldwell Wylie of Glen Ridge, here this afternoon.

Miss Geraldine F. Tipper, daughter of Mrs. Christopher J. Tipper of this city and the late Mr. Tipper, became the bride of William J. Butler, son of Mrs. Mary A. Butler, also of this city, and the late Mr. Butler in the Church of the Blessed Sacrament here this afternoon.

Federal and State governments giving serious consideration to flood control, the School of Civil Engineering at Cornell University, designated by the army engineers as one of the principal research centers in the East, is full of activity this Fall.

Legal rights of unionists in the tickett line, which have been a matter of controversy raised by courts and police frequently of late, will be discussed at a conference of leaders of several hundred unions in the metropolitan area called for the Manhattan Opera House next Thursday evening.
As part of the observance of its fortieth anniversary, the Merchants' Association of New York announced yesterday that it would conduct a "Reveal-New York-toNew Yorkers" program.

Building activity throughout the nation during October, as measured by permit valuations, was lower than during either the previous month or the corresponding month of last year, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, announced yesterday.
SOME people claim that Thomas Hart Benton is not an artist For them his courage. vigor, originality and productivity count as nothing against his writhing style and discordant self-acclaim.

NOT too great a measure of hush and awe need necessarily attach to Peter Blume's having spent three years on "The Eternal City," which is presented, as constituting an exhibition in itself, at the Julien Levy.

The most striking demonstration to date of the inroads that Germany's religious warfare is making in national unity is the desperate petition sent to Chancellor Hitler by the chaplains of the armed forces. The text, which has finally become available, shows the chaplains' determination to convince the Fuehrer that the National Socialist attack on Christianity has become a major threat to the authority of the regime.

Under the influence of the most active trading in some time, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved into new high ground yesterday to close with gains of 8 to 14 points. For the first time since Oct. 30, all months ended above the 8-cent level and more than a half-cent above the low records of the month, which were made following the last government crop estimate.

Having maintained a more or less discreet silence ever since the last echoes of the world series, broken only from time to time by the impromptu eruptions of Dizzy Dean and Van Lingle Mungo, baseball will swing sharply back into the public prints this week with the opening of the annual December conclaves.

Students of the island today commemorated the sixty-sixth anniversary of the execution of eight Cuban students by Spanish colonial authorities. Public spectacles and amusement centers were suspended by government decree.

Warfare in China has blocked the world's principal commercial supply of mahuang, a Chinese grass also known as ephedra vulgaris, the raw material from which ephedrine is manufactured, according to C. C. Concannon, chief of the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce.

To obtain independence for the railroads in New England, the six Governors of the New England States have asked for a broadening of the Pennsylvania Railroad's offer of trusteeship for its holdings in the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad. They have addressed

Two staples on the housewife's market list, butter and eggs, have undergone price changes that will affect her food bill total not a little. Butter, partly because of the higher price of milk, has gone up appreciably, with tub butter holding steady now at 45 cents a pound and roll and print butter up to 47 and 48 cents respectively.

The annual supper dance to mark the conclusion of the drive in behalf of the scholarship fund at Barnard College will take place Friday in the Neptune Room of the Pierre under the auspices of the Barnard College Club of New York.

To observe the anniversary of the first airplane flight by Orville and Wilbur Wright, the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences will meet at 3 P. M. Dec. 17 at Columbia University to hear a lecture by B. Melvill Jones, the Francis Mond Professor of Aeronautical Engineering of Cambridge University, England.

Highly elated over their triumph against their traditional foe, Army's players and substitutes made the welkin ring with their shouts as they made their way into their dressing room when the game with Navy was over.

Details of the petition of the Pullman Company for a 10 per cent increase in its rates were made public today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Announcement was made yesterday in Chicago that the petition had been filed.

A motion to restrain the Ben Leider Memorial Fund, Inc., from using the name of Ben Leider, New York Post reporter who was killed while flying for the Spanish Loyalists, to solicit funds to be used in Spain to help Spanish Loyalists, is to be heard tomorrow morning in the Supreme Court here before Justice Peter Schmuck.

" The cooperation of the National Peasant party in the coming elections with other Opposition groups, including the Iron Guard, does not mean a political alliance but only the establishment of a common front against governmental terrorism," the party's leader, Dr. Julius Maniu, told the press today.
Formation of a committee was announced yesterday to make arrangements for the midwinter Collegiana of the Sub-Junior Division of the Joint Distribution Committee.

AUGUSTA, Ga.--With the opening of the quail-hunting season this week huntsmen are returning daily from the Forest Hills game preserve and adjacent territory with large numbers of the birds flushed out by Georgia's tamed native hunting dogs.

Producers of oxalic acid began last week to take contracts for 1938 at the prices which have prevailed for the last two years. The action ended a period of uncertainty in which there had been a good deal of conjecture among buyers as to whether a decline for 1938 would be announced.

THIS is mainly a play-by-play action account of the famed Hollywood run-around. The Hollywood run-around is that peculiar system of self-protection against the hungry that yea-men have developed. The idea of the game is always to say "yes" but never to perform any helpful action.

Max Silverman, his son, Harold Silverman, and his son-in-law, Edward Braff, are on the calendar of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn for trial tomorrow before Justice Erskine C. Rogers of Hudson Falls, and a blue panel jury, on a conspiracy indictment growing out of the Samuel Drukman murder case.

THREE concerts of Gabriel Faur's chamber music are being given by the Quatuor de Paris, assisted by Helene Leon, pianist. The first program of this series began with Faure's sonata Op. 13 for violin and piano (1876)-a well known and beautiful work. The piano quartet Op. 15 in C minor (1879) followed.

Mr. and Mrs. Julius A. Horowitz of 20 Dongan Place have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Vivian Horowitz, to Frank Chayes of Chicago, which took place here Thanksgiving Day in the Park Avenue Synagogue.

Large building operations in New York City are so severely penalized by the capital gains tax that the investing or so-called speculative builders are, to a large extent, unwilling to undertake projects inVolving a great outlay of money, declares John W. Ross, vice president of the realty firm of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc. That tax, he sass,
Nearly 8,500 people attended the New York Hippodrome Opera Company's performances yesterday, that of "Aida" in the evening and "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" in the afternoon.

The British financial community, which for months has been "deploring" recessions in the American stock market and blaming it principally for comparable declines here, finally has begun to tighten its own belt and look for recession causes nearer home.
The old lawn problem crops up again-this time on the grounds of the White House. Apparently it is proving as difficult to make good grass grow there as it is to balance the national budget.

A miniature parliamentary democracy, finding its inspiration in the two-party system of democratic government, has been established by the Whig and Cliosophio Debating Societies of Princeton University in an effort to build up an organization whose views will be representative of undergraduate political opinion.

Martin Miller Jr., 16, son of Martin Miller of 521 Fifth Avenue, New York, was killed today in an automobile accident. He was passing his Thanksgiving vacation from Palo Verde Ranch School at Mesa with friends here.

How common salt, coal, sulphur, tree sap, vegetables, milk and other every day substances become parts of automobiles by virtue of new skills in synthetic manufacture will be demonstrated at the sixteenth Exposition of Chemical Industries in Grand Central Palace, Dec. 6 to 11.
The Yale Squash Racquets team management has arranged a match with Purdue University at the Yale Club in New York City on Dec. 29. The place was chosen because of the Yale Christmas vacation.

With $2,500,000 worth of insured mortgages in its portfolio, the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association is the largest single holder of this type of paper among the 10,000 savings and loan groups in the country, according to Dr. Herman L. Reis, president.

NAVAL aviators and those of the sister service, including the marines as part of the naval establishment, who had looked forward to the annual report of the Chief of Naval Aeronautics for guidance and information about the air service, were disappointed when Rear Admiral Cook's report was recently made public.
NOT quite so prolific in exhibitions as the preceding periods, the last week made up in diversity of material for any numerical falling off in the number of attractions.

Twenty-five clubs were successful in today's first-round matches for the English cup, soccer's great competition that runs through the Winter sport season, But eighteen of the teams that battled will replay drawn games next week.

An inheritance tax appraisal filed today against the estate of Thomas S. Shibe indicated that his estate and that of his brother, John D. Shibe, heads of the Philadelphia American Baseball Club, would be nearer $500,000 than the $2,000,000 which they were thought to have possessed.
Byron (Whizzer) White, Colorado University's national football scoring leader, will exhibit his tricks outside the Rocky Mountain section after all.

Fifteen neighborhood and community centers affiliated with the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities reported yesterday an average monthly attendance this year of 492,953. This compares with a monthly average of 260.000 in 1929.
The Baldwin National Bank of Baldwin, L. I., has made mortgage credit advances amounting to $4,500,000 since it began to operate under the insured-mortgage plan of the Federal Housing Administration.

Dr. Thomas H. Curtin and Dr. Clarence H. Smith were guests of honor last night at a dinner given by the medical staff of the Morrisania Hospital, 168th Street and Gerard Avenue, at the Hotel Biltmore. More than 500 persons were present.
Rivermen reported today that they were again sighting fish flopping on the surface of the Niagara River, where a city chemist estimated that millions of fish were killed two weeks ago.

The anniversary of the signing of the Trianon Treaty was marked today by noisy demonstrations resulting in 200 arrests. Such demonstrations have been banned and large police and military forces were on hand to keep order.

A "time telescope" which makes possible remarkable motion picture photography of many motions formerly imperceptible has been invented at Rutgers University, it was announced today by Dr. Earle B. Perkins, chairman of the university committee on photographic research in biology.

A campaign to raise. $50,000 for construction of an extension on St. Francis de Sales Academy on Beach 129th Street near Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Belle Harbor, will start tomorrow night at a dinner meeting of the campaign workers at Grogan's Restaurant,

Four men accused of narcotic-law violations were held in $10,000 bail each yesterday by Federal Judge Murray Hulbert. Although the charges against the defendants involved the alleged sale of only two ounces of heroin, narcotic agents said they were wholesale and retail distributors of contraband drugs.

Mr. and Mrs. Clarence S. A. Williams of South Orange gave two parties today at their home to introduce their daughter, Miss Marjorie Lewis Williams. In the afternoon they entertained at a reception and tea. In the evening they gave a formal house dance.

Japan's soldiers today pushed their conquests deeper into China's eastern provinces, while Japan's representatives in the rear tightened their hold on the communications and customs services of conquered Sha ghai.

Plans were completed at a recent meeting held at the home of Mrs. Edward A. Clark at 140 East Eighty-first Street for a tea dance in aid of the child welfare work of La Margherita Society which will take place Dec. 11 at Le Mirage. The tea dance will be followed by a dinner and entertainment.

DURING the three years which have elapsed since the Czechoslovakian production, "Ecstasy," was first brought over here, it has become one of the most talked-about pictures ever made, despite the fact that none of its players are familiar to American moviegoers.

Smashing over for a touchdown in the last two minutes of the game to climax a spectacular 63-yard march, the Erasmus Hall High School eleven downed Peabody (Mass.) High, 6 to 0, in a postseason contest at Ebbets Field yesterday.

The eyes of the New York realty world have turned to the Riverdale and Spuyten Duyvil neighborhoods as a result of recent land purchases there which presage the development of a vast apartment colony covering a large part of eighteen blocks.

Prince Ernst Ruediger von Starhemberg's marriage to Countess Maria Elizabeth Salm-Reifferscheid-Raitz was annulled today by the Salzburg Archiepiscopal Court and the decision was confirmed by the Austrian Supreme Court.
The University of Oregon defeated the San Diego Marines, 24 to 7, today in a football game witnessed by 5,000 fans. Oregon opened the scoring with a touchdown in the first period.

Seeking wider foreign sales for her manufactures, Japan is planning to send delegations of marketing specialists to countries in Latin America and to South Africa, according to private advices received here last week by exporters.

Declaring that although George Kulenkampff's performance of the Schumann violin concerto in Germany last Friday, which was broadcast to this country, was "first rank," Yehudi Menuhin, youthful violinist, said yesterday afternoon that he "regretted the violinist did not play the original edition." The resignation of Dr. Hjalmar Schacht as Economics Minister of the German Reich must be regarded as a very significant landmark. He was the last obstacle to the Four-year plan as devised by Colonel Genaeral Hermann Goering, and his departure means that in Germany the system of 100 per cent autarchy will be fully enforced.
LONDON.--Members of Parliament, who have just begun to enjoy their 50 per cent increases in salary, are beginning to feel badly treated all over again.
Premier Benito Mussolini is such an essential part of the Italian machinery of government that it has been said often, more in seriousness than in jest, that he "runs a one-man show."
Grinding garbage and discharging it into sewers has been tried as a temporary measure by several American cities; St. Louis thinks so well of it that it has adopted it permanently.

ALTHOUGH a good many funeral sermons have been Preached over the limp corpse of the theatre in the past few years the enterprising young people are still coming forward. The entire future is in their hands, but it is encouraging to realise that part of the present is theirs already.

A labor row at Phoenixville, twenty miles northwest of this city, resulted in the death here today of Fred Brown, 23, an alleged "strong arm" man for a union. He was shot fatally last night when he and three companions clashed with a truck driver affiliated with a rival union.
The Junior Circle of the Social Service Big Sister League will give the first in a series of dances on Dec. 26 at the Pierre. Miss Phyllis Korn and John Menke are co-chairmen of the event.

Putting roses to sleep for the Winter need be no haphazard procedure for the amateur rose grower. He need not depend on his own limited experience as to how it should be done for there is available for the asking the experience of many experts.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, etc., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference. THE TIMES receives a great many more queries than it can publish. It endeavors, therefore.

THE man who says there is no such thing as philosophy is. by very reason of his statement himself a philosopher. That is to say, he has a definite point of view; and, however badly reasoned it may be, nevertheless to have a definite point of view is to have a philosophic position.

After an Asiatic study tour of sixteen months, during which he was said to have become the first white man to witness, photograph and participate in the religious rites of the lamaseries and monasteries of Tibet, Theos Bernard, 28-year-old American Buddhism scholar and Tibetan explorer, will return tomorrow on the Queen Mary.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George J. Posner of 300 Central Park West of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Ruth Posner, to Michael Leon Supnik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Supnik of Brooklyn.

William Creighton Feet, who retired in 1932 as a member of Feet Powers, Inc., 70 East Forty-fifth Street, New York, an electrical contract-. ing firm, of which he was a founder in 1908, died here today of a heart attack in his home on Grace Church Street. His age was 66.
The sale of eighteenth century French furniture and other art objects, which began on Friday and was completed yesterday at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, realized $34,278.50.
ONE of the games of scholarship is to pounce joyfully on some classic of neoclassicism and prove it three parts romantic, or find that some romantic was shameless enough to admire Boileau.

VISIT Germany this year! A modern people in a medieval setting!" So read the posters. The mind turns nouns and adjectives over and over like pieces in a picture puzzle, trying to fit them into their true pattern.

Professor J. B. Rhine of Duke University has been the target of brickbats hurled by psychologists who question his conclusion that some human minds are gifted with what he calls "extra-sensory perception." He asked students ho had demonstrated a certain "psychic" ability to call cards in a shuffled pack of twenty-five.

The first polo matches of the Indoor season here, which will be played next Saturday night at the Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, will be for the benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association. Squadron A teams will play those of Boulder Brook and the New York Athletic Club.

Don Salls and Bill Smetana, White Plains High's versatile backfield aces, gave a superb performance on the wet and slippery turf of Howard Field today as the Tigers topped A. B. Davis High of Mount Vernon, 16 to 6, to capture the Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association football championship.

Leading Article, B. P. Woodson's 6-yearold sprint star, splashed through the mud today to capture the featured Dixie Handicap at the Fair Grounds. Mower, the Millsdale Stable entry, finished second, and Sandstone was third. Leading Article rewarded his backers handsomely, paying $20.80 for $2 in the mutuels to win, $7.80 for place and $5 for show.

Despite emphatic denials by responsible spokesmen on both sides that indirect or secret negotiations for an armistice have been conducted recently, officials in Nationalist [Insurgent] Spain, who refuse to permit the use of their names, affirm that Britain's discreet conversations and overtures explain why no major military operations have occurred lately.
Georgia's Bulldogs and the Engineers of Georgia Tech, arch rivals of the gridiron since 1893, battled to a 6-to-6 stalemate today.
" The National Syndicate of Beggars," claiming a membership of 1,500,000, applied today to the Labor Department for registration.

Attention of European capitals this week centered on Lord Halifax's visit to Chancellor Hitler and everybody speculated about the results. The only immediate consequences were the surprisingly vague statement of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain in the House of Commons and

Hearings were started this week before the House Rivers and Harbors Committee on the administration's proposal to create seven planning regions in the United States, based on seven principal watersheds of the country.

Half of Louisiana's $6,000,000 of sugar cane which stood in the fields has been saved by one of the most astonishing mobilizations of labor in the history of a State which has seen a hair-trigger rush, time after time, to protect threatened areas against roaring river floods and to repair the losses of shrieking hurricanes.

IT is not altogether unusual, in these literate days, to come upon a first novel of artistic merit. But it is always bound to be something of an event when a first novel not only proves to be admirable on the score of craftmanship but also introduces to the ranks of contemporary novelists a new and original and arresting personality.
The Coast Guard reported early today, according to The Associated Press, that the cutter Champlain had taken in tow for New York the four-masted schooner Anna R. Heidritter.

Winter sports teams at Hun School will report for practice Monday. There are fifteen varsity basketball, eight jayvee basketball, nine varsity hockey, one jayvee hockey and ten swimming events scheduled.

Thanksgiving Day was celebrated by Americans in London at home parties and a special luncheon for members and guests of the American Women' Club and at the Dorchester Hotel, where American society gave a dinner and ball.
The State Conservation Department will hold its first hearing Dec. 14 to determine responsibility in hunting accidents which have resulted in one death and the wounding of five other hunters.

Vehicular traffic in Broadway near Thirty-eighth Street was at a standstill or seriously impeded for several minutes in the noon hour yesterday when 2,000 persons, attracted to the scene of a hold-up by the arrival of radio cars and an ambulance, blocked the street in front of the thirty-seven story office building at 1,400 Broadway.
Mrs. Anna Marie Hahn, 31-year-old mother, was sentenced today to die in the electric chair March 10 for the murder of Jacob Wagner, 78, a gardener acquaintance.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mrs. James H. R. Cromwell, the former Doris Duke, came to West Virginia today to make a tour of the Tygart Homestead.

Meeting the enemy under conditions supposedly prejudicial to its cause, Army struck through the air and defeated Navy, 6-0, in the rain and mud today as 102,500 bedraggled spectators peered through the enveloping fog and mist in the Municipal Stadium.

The marriage of Miss Mary Jane Fittin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Fittin of this city, to William J. Straub, son of Mrs. Anna K. Straub of Newark, took place this morning in St. John's Church, Orange.
Dr. and Mrs. Charles Albert Anderson.of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Gould Anderson, to George Theodore Mascott of Wilmette, Ill.

Colonel Robert S. Knox, infantry commander of the Camp Dix (N. J.) Post, will retire from the United States Army on Tuesday, after nearly forty years of service, according to an announcement made yesterday at Governors Island.

A strike of gravediggers at Greenwood Cemetery, one of the world's largest cemeteries, in Brooklyn yesterday disrupted the funeral of Mrs. Annie Brewer Wellington, mother of Witter Bynner, poet, and of Edwin Tyler Bynner of New York. Mrs. Wellington died at the Hotel Seymour on Thursday. She was 79 years old.

Dr. Oliver A. Ryder, specialist in children's diseases, died yesterday of a heart attack just after he had left a doctor's office. He was in a motor sales company office when he was stricken. His age was 50.

Just before the holiday last week THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks touched a new low for the year at 82.07. The depression low for the index was 33.98, touched on July 8, 1932, and the high was 144.44, on Nov. 10, 1936, or a net advance of 110.46 points.
At the United States Patent Office this week the following patents attracted attention for their unusual turn among the 639 just granted.

Meyer Klick, 34 years old, butcher of 316 Johnson Avenue, Brooklyn, took steps some time ago to protect himself against robbery. He bought a revolver, after obtaining a police permit. Last night, with the revolver in his right-hand coat pocket and $465, 1 the day's receipts, in an inside pocket, he closed his place of business and went to his home at 678 East Ninety-first Street, in Canarsie.
A small band of scientists and boatmen returned tonight from the deep gorges of the- Grand Canyon bearing archean rocks which, geologists believe, may hold secrets of the earth's beginning.
CONGRESS is back again. It means that 531 statesmen from the provinces and their families once more have added themselves to Washington's transient population.

Holding that parents may be at fault when children become unruly and misbehave, the WPA adult education program of the New York City Board of Education has developed a child guidance service, where the mothers, in addition to their offspring, receive a series of educational tests to find out why there is discord in the home.

The Chinese Women's Relief Association of New York, Inc., will hold a party for the relief of Chinese refugees at the Park Lane Hotel next Sunday from 4:30 P. M. to 7 P. M. Dr. C. T. Wang, Chinese Ambassador to this country, will be the host.
Miss Winifred H. Nash of Boston told the National Council of Teachers of English here today that "high intelligence and a lively sense of humor generally go together."

A few days ago a Corn Belt Congressman was seen hurrying from his own to the Senate side of the Capitol to hear the authors explain and, if need be, defend the far-reaching farm bill that had just been reported by the Senate Agriculture Committee. On the way he stopped

An arrangement between the United States and the Irish Free State, relative to air navigation in general, has been made through an exchange of notes between the American Legation in Dublin and the Irish Department of External Affairs.

The question whether the deflatiohary policy pursued by the Federal Reserve System from the middle of last year to the middle of this was a prime cause of the current business recession is being discussed among bankers and economists here and abroad.

Simultaneous representations have been made to the Japanese Foreign Office by the United States, Great Britain and France and possibly by other countries concerning the taking over by Japan of the Chinese customs organization in Shanghai, but whether with any effectiveness is not yet known here.

Creation of an internationally united front against anti-Semitism for the preservation of Jewish civil rights already lost in Germany and threatened elsewhere throughout the world was urged tonight at the opening of a two-day emergency session called by the American Jewish Conngress.

Student members of the City College House Plan, social activities center, elected 123 fellow-students as officers of thirty-five individual house sections, according to an announcement yesterday by James Peace, House Plan director.

The Baltimore Orioles pushed Hershey deeper itno last position in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League tonight by winning, 4 to 1. Caldwell put Baltimore in the lead in the first period with a long shot that filtered through the Hershey defense.

Oscar Matthews, 197, of Tallulah, La., scored his sixth knockout in as many starts at the Rockland Palace last night when he disposed of Jose Monez, 216 3/4, of Portugal, in 2:19 of the first round of a scheduled eight-round main event.
No matter what happens to our monetary situation, America is always on the gold standard when it comes time for the Army-Navy gridiron classic.

A memorial service for the Rev. Dr. William Howard Kephart, the pastor for forty-one years, will be held today at 4 P. M. in the North New York Congregational Church, 409 East 143d Street, the Bronx. Dr. Kephart died July 27. His successor has not yet been chosen.
The seventy-six acre estate with a large house, formerly owned by Mrs. G. E. Hamlin at Falls Village, Conn., has been purchased by Dr. N. P. Rathbun of Brooklyn.

Miss Margaret Shepherd Leggo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Leggo of this place, has chosen the afternoon of Dec. 4 for her marriage to Douglas Munroe, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Munroe, also of Rockville Center.

The Philadelphia Ramblers handed the Syracuse Stars their first defeat of the current season, winning from the International-American League ice hockey champions, 2-0, before 5,000 tonight. The victory sent the Ramblers into a tie for first place in the

Jesse O. Howard's cider mill on Wampenum Brook, South Mountain Road, a family possession for 109 years, was closed for the season today. The proprietor, 78, spry as the average man of 50, has been identified with the old mill sixtythree years, for he was only 15 when his father taught him to push the apples through the hole in the floor down into the cellar press room.

Whatever Germany's ultimate desires and demands may be, the most important immediate factor in the situation, it is believed here, is Chancellor Adolf Hitler's assurance to Viscount Halifax, British Cabinet negotiator, that he has no intention of seeking their realization by war.
Chanukkah, the Feast of Lights, will be observed in Jewish homes and synagogues at sundown today when the first light is ignited in the nine-branched candelabrum.

The collapse in Wall Street prices has now gone to unwarranted extremes, in the opinion of Sir Josiah Stamp, British financial authority and a director of the Bank of England. Psychological influences, he feels, are exaggerating the justifiable effect of the true causes of readjustment, such as previous inflation and tax disturbances. In an interview, Sir Josiah said:
THOMAS GREEN CLEMSON was a Philadelphian, but he married the daughter of John C. Calhoun, and thereafter his interests and ambitions were centered on the South and especially on his

Leading all the way, Polvo's Prince, a long shot, recorded a three-length victory over Basque today in the A. B. Spreckels Handicap at Tanforan. Stimuli was third. The time for the six furlongs was 1:14. The winner paid $22.40, $10.40 and $5.60, Basque $5.80 and $4.20 and Stimuli $4. Polvo's Prince is owned by Mrs. W. J. Potter of Memphis, Tenn.

THE first large tournament to be conducted by the new American Contract Bridge League will begin in Washington, D. C., Tuesday afternoon. Five events are scheduled, four of which are billed as national championships. For the first time in several years, these will be the only contests in their classifications for which a claim of the national chamnionship determination is made.

Fascism under the label of "Americanism" was denounced in a resolution adopted at yesterday's session of the annual assembly of the American Ethical Union. The organization is a federation of ethical culture societies.
fort to break down artificial departmental barriers at Elmira College by informal rather than formal methods is producing significant results. The policy at the

FOR two thousand years preceding the seventeenth century it was held that every scholar must familiarize himself with what was then known as "music" but what today would better be called the "science of music." Conventional learning consisted of the trivium and quadrivium: grammar, rhetoric, logic, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy and music. Accordingly,
A beagle, Meadow Lark Draftsman, owned by Louis Batjer of New Brunswick, N. J., was judged best at the silver anniversary show of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia tonight at Commercial Museum.

Vermonters have chosen Dec. 1 as a day to pay honor to George. Dewey. Dec. 27 is the 100th anniversary of his birth in Montpelier and the 1937 Legislature provided for a public observance of the anniversary, but since Dec. 27 was considered not a good time for, a celebration the date was set ahead.

To replace the old road hazard warranty of the Rubber Manufacturers Association, generally discarded last February, leading tire makers have adopted a new form of lifetime guarantee, it was learned here yesterday. The new guarantee is in the form of certificates.

Dallett H. Wilson, a corporation lawyer and at one time an advisory member of the Republican National Committee, died of a heart attack yesterday in his office in the Woolworth Building here. His age was 57.

SHERLOCK HOLMES sleuthed around the television cameras at Radio City during the past week and stalked out across the ultra-short wave lengths in the most ambitious experiment in teleshowmanship so far attempted in the air over New York.
Compton Mackenzie, one of the stormy petrels of British literature, is to write an authorized biography of the Duke of Windsor, according to The Sunday Dispatch.

AUSTRIA has commemorated the 200th anniversary of the completion of the KarisKirche in Vienna, the most important church in the city after the Stephans-Kirche, with a two-schilling silver coin. On the obverse of the coin is shown the Karls-Kirche with the inscription "Karls Kirche vollendet 1737" around the edge.
The piano recital given by Serge Rachmaninoff yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall became the occasion and the musical rite which it was logically expected to be.

Walter A. Ferris, District Attorney of Westchester, said today he would submit to the Westchester grand jury his findings in an investigation he is conducting into d alleged irregularities in the 1936 and 1937 referenda on a proposed city manager form of government in Yonkers.

Just as events in the Far East up to two weeks ago led to false conclusions in one direction, so events in the last two weeks are leading to false conclusions in the opposite direction. The Chinese were not winning the war up to two weeks ago. They have not lost it in the last two weeks.
The Air Commerce Bureau reported today that "personnel errors" caused 51.33 per cent of the accidents in miscellaneous flying during the first half of 1937.

The Reich's entire publicity apparatus was concentrated today on an effort to represent Dr. Hjalmar Schacht's final departure from the Economics Ministry as merely an organizational change and to discourage foreign and domestic speculation about its significance.
The Jewish Temporary Shelter for Children of Yonkers will be the beneficiary of a dance to be given under the sponsorship of the institution's Junior Group on Saturday at the Park Lane.

Sixty-five members of the Police Department who will be more than 64 years of age on Dec. 31 were ordered by Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday afternoon to appear before him in the trial room at Police Headquarters tomorrow at 11 A. M.

Sheppard S. Struchwick, actor, who played the role of Orlando in the recent production of "As You Like It," said yesterday before sailing for California on the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania that it was the New York dramatic critics who had forced the closing of the show through leaving before the play was over.

BECKER--Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Becker (nee Gertrude Taylor) announce the birth of a daughter, Judith S., Tuesday, Nov. 23. Jewish Hospital. Brooklyn. BERKOWITZ--Mr. and Mrs. Joe, 515 West End Ave., announce the arrival of Cecile's sister. Barbara, Nov. 21.
Anywhere from $10 to $30 is the annual loss sustained by each person in the United States because of the presence of smoke in the atmosphere, according to estimates made by the Public Health Servioe.
Sophomore Ollie Cordill, rawboned West Texan, nudged Rice Institute closer to the Southwest Conference flag today with a pair of touchdowns that dropped Baylor, 13 to 7.

FROM the title. "Belief and Action," a reader would naturally suppose this book to be an abstruse work in philosophy. But Viscount Samuel, the first in the realm to be elevated to that rank by King George VI, though a philosopher at heart and president of the British Institute of Philosophy, has all his life been a man of affairs. Selection of 200 contemporary from books soon to be presented to the ney D White House library was guided by well-established rules, but the term "model library" does not apply to the gift, according to Mrs. Emily Newell Blair, a member of the committee of fifteen who chose the titles.

The German press campaign against Czechoslovakia, which has tested the nerves of many people within that country as well as throughout Europe, leaves one man wholly unperturbed, and that is Dr. Milan Hodza, the swarthy Slovak Premier of Czechoslovakia.

Eastern and Western championships of the National Football League may be decided today when Green Bay invades Washington for a battle with the Redskins and Cleveland journeys to Chicago for a game with the Bears. Victories for the Packers and Bears would

Recommendations for an ideal program for women's fraternities will be considered at a meeting tomorrow of a special committee appointed by Miss Marguerite D. Winant, new chairman of the city division of the National Panhellenic Congress. The meeting will be held at the Beekman Tower headquarters of the organization, with Mrs. Ralph I. Culver, chairman.

The main boxing bout at the St. Nicholas Palace tomorrow night will bring together Italo Colonello, Italian heavyweight, and Jack Moran of Pittsburgh. Colonello has scored eight knockouts in his last eight bouts and is the general choice to defeat the Smoky City battler.

Seriously ill with stomach ulcers, General Liu Hsiang, Szechwan Province leader, left here tonight for Hankow accompanied by a foreign physician. An emergency operation is believed necessary. General Liu has been long a semi-invalid.
Dairymen may soon cultivate certain types of bacteria and add them to cream to be churned into butter to insure a more uniform product of better quality.
Plans for a two-story building of modern design were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing of the southeast corner of Broadway and Seventy - second Street to a syndicate. The structure

ST. SAVIOUR'S CATHEDRAL, in Southwark -- on the south bank of the Thames, near London Bridge -- where John Harvard, founder of Harvard University, was baptized 330 years ago--Nov. 29, 1637-- is facing another crisis in its 1,300-year history. It is

THE opening of the Metropolitan Opera season, Josef Hofmann's Golden Jubilee concert in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of his American debut, and the first performance of Charles Wakefield Cadman's "Dark Dancers of the Mardi-Gras" by the Philharmonic-Symphony are points of interest in the week's musical fare.
PERHAPS next best to owning an island (every man's dream at one time or another) is to go exploring one, an urge this Winter's world-cruise parties may indulge to their hearts' content.
Termination of the five-day, unauthorized sitdown strike in Pontiac brought to a focus the present relations between General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers of America.
The first for this season of the Yorkville dinner dances, which for many years have been popular entertainments of each Winter, will take place on Dec. 7 at the RitzCarlton. The dances are given for

Law students and young lawyers will read hopefully, oldsters at the bar and many laymen with less enthusiasm, the interview in today's NEW YORK TIMES Magazine with Dean Landis of the Harvard Law School. He is doubtless

The staff of the West Twentieth Street police station, which, incidentally, houses the homicide squad, has had its tense moments. The men have often proved themselves as steel-nerved as conditions required-but last night they were caught unaware, to say the least.

The Foresters, dramatic society of Drew University, have chosen for the year's major production Henrik Mbsen's "Ghosts," which wilt be presented next Friday and Saturday evenings in Madison High School auditorium.

A 77-year-old pioneer in social hygiene, Miss Eloise A. Hafford, who courageously brought the word "syphilis" into the open at a time when such forwardness resulted in ostracism, expressed last night her "thorough approval" of "the tremendous change in public attitude."

The season's football fighting beetween Army and Navy did not end yesterday at Philadelphia. It will be renewed this afternoon in the new Roosevelt Stadium at Union City, N. J.--minus the color and prestige of the game played by fulure officers from West Point and Annapolis, but still a struggle of service teams.

With the current recession tendinr to spotlight "more clearly than any time in the past the need for a united nation-wide housing campaign as the key to genuine economic progress," Saul Cohn, president of the City Stores Company and chairman of the housing committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared yesterday that in any new campaign the retailer should be considered a "primary element to its success."

A wholly new type of high school where boys and girls study the usual mathematics, languages and science only if they desire to and if such study seems "vital to their growth," is being tried out in a five-year experiment at Evanston Township High School in Illinois, with the cooperation of Northwestern University.

COLOMBIA, already with twenty or more short-wave stations on the air, has added another highpowered broadcaster to the list. When tuned during the past week, the new station, located at Bucaramanga just east of the Magdalena River, has been sending a signal which surpasses, in volume and clarity, the general run of South American waves.

IT took ten years to put it over, but at last the venerable John Chapman and his stout majordomo, Harry Mendel, have a citizen of the Argentine lined up for the start of the six-day bike race. It's the first time that any bike rider from the land of the galloping gauchos has been included in the mad whirl at Madison Square Garden and this one will be riding by advice of consul.

Auburn closed out a backbreaking football schedule today with a 14-to-0 victory over Florida. Diving deep into 'Gator territory on numerous advances, Auburn relied on Jimmy Fenton and Spec Kelly, a pair of top-notch backs, to puncture Florida's fine goal-line defense.

IN this family autobiography Mr. Carter, who is the author in collaboration and under pseudonyms of fourteen books. attempts to put under glass pre-war New England as he knew it. The well-bred, wellread, well-heeled class, he claims, ceased to exist after the World War, and their children became absorbed in the "lost generation."
MORLEY CALLAGHAN is one of those writers whose development is slow. His first novel was published in 1928, and he is still feeling his way.

Miss Evelyn McLean Whipple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Whipple of 3,421 Clarendon Road, Brooklyn, was married to Samuel Hunter Austin of New Brunswick, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Erle Harris Austin of Rocky Mount, N. C., last night in St. Paul's Church, Flatbush, by the rector, the Rev. Harold S. Olafson.

Three' hundred or more tightlipped, unhappy men and women who make up the political machinery of Albert Marinelli, Tammany leader in the Second Assembly District West, paraded yesterday before a special rackets grand jury where they were required to give their pedigrees.

In tribute to her thirty-four years of service in the executive work of the National Arts Club on Gramercy Park, the board of governors has just voted a life membership to Mrs. H. P. Crine on the eve of her departure for an extended leave of absence.

A committee of young women, headed by Miss Marion Sulzberger, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, is working toward the success of the benefit performance of "Barchester Towers," starring Ina Claire, to be held on Thursday evening at the Martin Beck Theatre. Assisting Miss Sulzberger are the Misses Helen Friendly, Louise Bloomingdale and Ruth Liberman.

THE most dramatic event of the auction season occurred, not at a sale but between rounds, in the form of an announcement two weeks ago of a drastic change in the management of the American Art Association Anderson Galleries.

The value of metals produced in Ontario in the first nine months of 1937 is 30 per cent greater than in the same period of 1936. Up to Sept. 30, Ontario's mines produced $152,001,543, compared with $116,927,945 the year before.
Mr. and Mrs. William Richardson Sinclair of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dora Sinclair, to Louis F. Loutrel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Loutrel of South Orange, N. J.
Revision of Canada's trade treaty with the United States to facilitate an AngloAmerican treaty has had a good press in Canada.

Although financial and automotive circles are exhibiting some nervousness over the trend in the motor car industry, the lull in production and sales is closely associated with the recession in general activity throughout the country, according to leaders in both circles.
More than 350 members of the younger set of Greenwich and nearby towns attended a Thanksgiving dance given tonight by the Old Greenwich Assembly at the Stamford Yacht Club.

A FEW weeks ago, in noticing the set of English madrigals made by Lehman Engel's Madrigal Singers, we lamented the fact that, with so much that might have been done, the album contained a high proportion of material previously recorded.

Mr. and Mrs. Ellery W. Mann of Garden City, L. I., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Marion Edna Mann, to James S. Murray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Murray of Baltimore, which took place on Tuesday.

Future of Landscape Architecture" will be considered at a conference of alumni in landscape architecture to be held at Massachusetts State College Dec. 10 and 11. Several leaders in landscape architecture will be on the speakers' program.

Province of Mendoza stamped external 7 1/2 per cent secured sinking fund gold bonds due in 1951 must be dealt in flat starting on Monday, and to be a delivery must carry June 1, 1938, and subsequent COupons, according to a ruling by the New York Curb Exchange eommittee on securities.

The Mediation Commission continued today its consideration of the replies of Nicaragua and Honduras to a plan for restoring the friendly relations between the two countries recently disrupted as the result of an old boundary controversy.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated Nov. 26: BRIGADIER GENERAL Hartshorn, E. S., three days leave, Dec. 8. COLONELS Koch, S., Cav., Ft. Meade, S. D., to duty in connection with recruiting, Houston, Texas. Mitchell, H. D., Adjutant General's Dept., leave of absence for one day, Nov. 27, is revoked.

REMINDERS of the time when smart coaches and carriages held the roads make an appeal to collectors through varied media. Prints, sketches, working drawings, miniature models-all things that have to do with vehicular travel before the advent of the locomotive and the automobile are treasured by eager hobbyists.

IT is twenty-three years since the tenth edition of Bartlett's "Familiar Quotations" was brought out, under the supervision of Nathan Haskell Dole. For the past three years Christopher Morley and Louella D. Everett have been at work on the completely revised eleventh edition.

IF they are still complaining around The Lambs club that actors no longer look like actors, they should be willing now to settle for Orson Welles. Mr. Welles looks very much like an actor, which, indeed, he is. No hat covers his longish hair, he gestures when he talks and he smokes a pipe.

On April 1, 1924, a 34-year-old political agitator, sentenced to honorable imprisonment for his attempt to overthrow the German Republic, entered the fortress at Landsberg on the Lech, in Bavaria, to serve his term.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, notified the unlicensed personnel of nineteen steamship lines yesterday that elections would be held among them to determine the collective bargaining agent for each line.

Many financial institutions which at the depths of the depression felt compelled to set up mortgage servicing departments to handle their growing lists of properties now are studying the advisability of turning this work back to the old real estate films, according to Elbert S. Barlow, vice president of Pease Elliman, Inc.

Mrs. Alice Marye Brown, daughter of Mrs William Canby Marye and the late Mr. Marye, was married here today to Edward Coxhall Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Jones, at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Mary E. Mathews in Roland Park.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Voorhees of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Annette Hyde Voorhees, to Willard David Roberson of New York, son of Elisha M. Roberson of Birmingham, Ala., and the late Mrs. Roberson. The wedding will take place Dec. 22.

Miss Charlotte Carr, director of Hull House, Chicago, and former director of home relief for New York City, will speak on Thursday evening at the second of a series of forums to be given this Winter by the Women's City Club.

Reports from various sources agree that Japanese bombers succeeded yesterday afternoon in damaging the Canton-Kowloon Railway extensively and that it will require a considerable period before it again can be used.

UNEASY visions plague my mind at off moments. This is not surprising since the drastic fate of the adapter when, on the far side of the Jordan, he meets the novelist he has mishandled is a scene which many a critic has imagined--with the ghoulish enthusiasm one expects of critics.

The development and strengthening this year of the Honors Program of study for high-ranking students at Brown University has brought about increased Honors registration and indicates a growing trend toward a more serious interest in college work, Professor Charles A. Baylis, adviser to Honors students, reported today.
Patrick F. Horan, an attorney and real estate dealer, died at his home in Frankford today after a short illness .

The Survey Associates will celebrate its silver anniversary at a dinner at the Hotel Biltmore Thursday. Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan, Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and Professor Felix Frankfurter of Harvard University will be among the speakers who will discuss "The Shape of Things to Come."

The Union Jack of Britain and the Tricolor of France between them fly over a large part of the earth's surface. More than 13,000,000 square miles of land, in Europe, Asia, Africa, the Americas, Australasia and Oceania, belong to the British Empire; more than 4,500,000 square miles are under the sovereignty of France.
Garden State fruit and vegetable growers will assemble in Atlantic City for the annual meeting of the New Jersey State Hortiultural Society, Wednesday through Friday.

President Roosevelt has decided to press his housing campaign on two principal fronts-slum clearance and low-rent housing, 90 per cent federally subsidized, and housing privately financed but federally stimulated and supervised, as provided in the Federal Housing Act.
Robert J. Roulston, retired wholesale grocer and former member of the Chicago Library Board and the Board of Education, died tonight of a heart attack at the age of 85.
A1 though home economics is not part of the Wheaton curriculum. students with domestic inclinations are having an opportunity to display their talents.

An emergency campaign to raise $1,000,000 to provide food, housing and medical relief to thousands of non-combatant Chinese refugees from the areas of the "undeclared war" in China during the Winter was announced yesterday by James M. Speers, chairman of the board of the China Famine Relief, U. S. A.
Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra, conducted by Erno Rapee, with Edwina Eustis, contralto, and Henrietta Schumann, pianist, as soloists: WJZ, 12:301.30 P. M.

Eduard Steuermann, a native of Poland, for many years a resident of Vienna, gave his first local recital last night at Town Hall. Mr. Steuermann was a pupil in piano of Busoni and studied composition with Schoenberg.

Announcement has been made by Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Charles B. McLaughlin of New York and Bellport, L. I., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Rose McLaughlin, to Francis J. O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. O'Brien of Brewster, N. Y.

More than 3,000 elementary school teachers, principals and superintendents in the metropolitan area will meet at Teachers College, Columbia University, on Friday and Saturday to discuss "Education and the Community" in the ninth annual Conference of Elementary School Workers.

Ivor B. Clark, New York realty man and mortgage specialist, went duck shooting the other day on Great South Bay. He got but one duck all day, but he considers the trip one to be remembered, because he had what he called "a duckshooter's dream."

Nearly 10 per cent of the uniformed police of the city is assigned daily to strike duty, it was revealed yesterday by the Police Bureau of Operations. Of the 18,322 members of the department now on active duty, approximately 8,000 are assigned to detective, traffic and radio patrol beats and are not called upon for such duty, it was said.

Italy at the Brussels Conference wasn't the least bit like the preacher in the Calvin Coolidge story. Mr. Coolidge care home from church and told Mrs. Coolidge that the minister had preached on sin; and when pressed for details Mr. Coolidge said the minister was opposed to sin.

The fifty-second annual dinner of the New York Southern Society will be held Friday night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the RFC, and Hatton W. Sumners, Representative from Texas and chairman of House Judiciary Committee, will be guests of honor.
Fordham's football team stood straddled in the murky twilight of a rainy, muddy day yesterday, safe at the end of the trail, undefeated and tied only by Pittsburgh.
The bodies of four horses, two of which were identified, were found today in the ruins of the Montclair Riding Academy here, which was destroyed yesterday by fire.

The latest member to be accepted in the "Fifty-Year Club," composed of those who heard Josef Hofmann play his earliest American concerts a half-century ago, is Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Mrs. Hofmann announced on the eve of the Hofmann Golden Jubilee Concert which will take place tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Miss Helen Ridgeley Ballantine was introduced to society at a large reception given yesterday afternoon by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Holme Ballantine, at the Colony Club. The debutante, who received with her parents, wore a gown of white lace embroidered in silver, and carried a bouquet of gardenias and lilies of the valley.

A definite reduction in the prices of electric razors is scheduled for next year, as more manufacturers enter the field, it was conceded: here yesterday by the executives of one of the leading companies.
MUSSOLINI thunders invectives from the Palazzo Venezia against communism and the menace of Red Russia -- and, at Livorno, Italian workmen build a light cruiser for the Soviet Government.

PHOTOGRAPHY was something altogether new at the beginning of Victoria's reign; and the remarkable thing about a book of Victorian photographs is not that it should be achieved imperfectly, but that it would be achieved at all.

THERE is no end to the surprises of the theatre. The play of which I wrote last week, "Good-bye to Yesterday" by James Parish, chosen by Gladys Cooper and Philip Merivale for their return to London, vanished after four performances.
President Roosevelt will probably veto any large appropriation made by Congress for which no compensating revenue legislation is enacted, Stephen Early, White House secretary, announced today.
ARCHER--Josephine Westerfield, Nov. 27, in her eighty-seventh year, beloved mother of Drucile Archer Rickby, and grandmother of Ruth Rickaby Darmstadt. Funeral private.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated Nov. 24: CAPTAINS Kirk, A. G., staff, Commander, Battle Force, to staff, Commander in Chief, United States Fleet, as Operations Officer. McCandlish, B. V., Guam, to the Boise and in command when commissioned.

Plans have been drawn for New York's first completely air-cooled high school, with facilities for more than 3,100 students to be trained for the city's largest industry. Ground is now being broken on West Twenty-fourth Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues,

Mayor La Guardia, Police Commissioner Valentine, judges of the Children's Courts and representatives of social agencies both public and private have been invited by the Joint Legislative Committee on Children's Court Jurisdiction and Juvenile Delinquency to attend the first of a series of hearings in the Aldermanic Chamber at City Hall next Wednesday.

Kenny Washington, halfback sensation of the University of California at Los Angeles, led the Bruins to a 13-to-O victory over Missouri today. The Bruins capped a game, dull for three quarters, with a final burst of energy.
Featuring three intersectional games, Syracuse University's 18-game basketball campaign will open here Dec. 8 against the University of Toronto.

Thomas E. Dewey, District Attorney-elect and a graduate of the Columbia University Law School, will make his first public address since the recent campaign at the annual Fall luncheon of the Alumni Association of Columbia College at 12:30 P. M. Wednesday in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

Nearly fifteen years ago, the late Ogden L. Mills, then a member of Congress and later Secretary of the Treasury, stated that he was sure that "a progressive income tax at high rates and tax-exempt securities cannot exist side by side."

Dana T. Ackerly gave a large reception yesterday afternoon at his home, 765 Park Avenue, for his debutante daughter, Miss Margaret Ackerly. Later in the evening Miss Ackerly was the guest of honor at a dinner given by her father in the Persian Room of the Plaza.
Fear of violence in the United Automobile Workers' strike against the Ford Motor Company was expressed today by an attorney for the company and by representatives of the C. I. O. union.

Threats by William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, that, unless the New York Stock Exchange "cleans house," the commission will take over enforcement of trading rules, have focused attention on the trading body's disciplinary machinery and practices.

A surplus in tax collections over budget estimates of 816,000,000 francs for the first ten months of the year was reported by the French Treasury today.

WASHINGTON.--President Roosevelt prefers to be inconspicuous when he goes motoring in Washington with. a police motor-cycle escort. When the officers leading the escort find it necessary to clear obstructions from the route they use police whistles, sounding blasts to warn unobserving pedestrians.

The Committee for the Defense of the Rights of Jews in Central and Eastern Europe, of which Senator Justin Godart is president, issued an appeal to Polish public opinion today over the signatures of twenty-four French political, intellectual and religious leaders calling upon the intellectuals and the clergy of Poland to bring to an end the persecutions and pogroms to which Polish Jews are being subjected.

The midnight performance of the variety show at the Apollo Theatre on West Forty-second Street was held up for more than a half hour last night as the result of a dispute over salary payment between the management and the actors.
A new electrical apparatus for removing scales from fish has made its appearance in Germany for use in hotel, restaurant and hospital kitchens and in fish markets.

Miss Eileen St. Lawrence Donnelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis Donnelly of this place, was married here this afternoon in the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel to Gregory Field Keenan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Keenan of Washington, D. C.

Under the auspices of the West Side Division of Ivriah, the Woman's Division of the Jewish Education Association, a Mardi Gras to celebrate the first night of the Festival of Chanukah will be held tonight at the True Sisters Building, 150 West Eighty-fifth Street.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.---A continued cold snap in the Poconos has produced a fine coating of ice on all the lakes and ponds and skating is now in full swing. The Poconos have been Covered with an inch or more of snow for several days.

The labor union jurisdictional warfare, which has paralyzed the lumber industry in Oregon, reached a crisis this week. Both State and local officials demanded that the National Labor Relations Board withdraw from the controversy, contending that the board failed in its mediation efforts between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization.

Two Swiss journalists, Hans O. Leuenberger and his wife, Miss Lydia Oswald, recently completed a year's motor tour from Switzerland to Peiping, China, and some thousands of miles in Japan, surveying the possibility of a transasiatic highway as a parallel to the Pan-American Highway now under construction. The entire Spanish Nationalist [Insurgent] fleet has been concentrating in Mediterranean waters since the fall of Gijon released it from duty in the Atlantic, and the blockade of the republican coast of Spain from Motril to the Franco-Catalan frontier is soon to begin in earnest. Majorca will be the main base of operations for the blockading forces.

Presidents and board members of the three Big Sisters' organizations will decide this week whether the cooperative drive for funds reestablished last Winter after a lapse of eight years will be launched again.

ACTING on the advice of her mother and business counselor, Ginger Rogers has requested RKO executives for a readjustment of her current contract to include a share of the profits from her pictures in addition to her weekly salary of $2,500.

Fordham College's 83-year-old Council of Debate, oldest student activity on the Rose Hill campus and one of the largest, will hold twenty intercollegiate debates in the coming school year and five debates within the next two weeks.
After a five-year silence volcanic Mount Shirane in Central Honshu broke into rumbling eruption today.

The six-day bicycle race returns to Madison Square Garden tonight, when fifteen teams of cyclists set out at 9 o'clock on a continuous run that will not come to a close until 11 o'clock Saturday night.

Burton.
AUTUMN vacationists, drifting southward as thermometers fall behind them, pause by the thousands at Mammoth Cave, in Kentucky, called one of the seven wonders of the New World.

The Saco Lowell Shops, Boston, manufacturer of cotton mill machinery, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement under a reorganization plan. The securities registered include 77,157 shares of $20-parvalue $1 cumulative class A convertible preferred 112,180 shares of $5-par common stock, both to be issued in exchange for $100-par 6 per cent cumulative preferred, $100par 7 per cent cumulative second preferred and no-par common stock of the predecessor company.

With Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman as honorary chairman, leading church women of fourteen denominations will join in directing a shop for the sale of articles made by the blind, opening tomorrow at Fifth Avenue and Forty-first Street. As in previous years, the sale will continue for five weeks, until Christmas Eve.

Miss Barbara Jane Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Blaine S. Smith of this place, was married to Anson Krickl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Krickl of Scarsdale, this afternoon in Christ Church here.
Chancellor Hitler announced his intention today of following in the footsteps of the Roman Caesars and the two Napoleons, who spent huge sums to make their capitals splendid symbols of greatness.

The latest addition to the London Zoo is a waltzing mouse. The strain is rare in Great Britain as they have to be selectively bred and are delicate. Waltzing mice have a habit of interrupting whatever they are doing several times daily to spin around for many seconds on end.

WHEN power from the great hydroelectric project which harnesses the energy of the roaring Columbia River first lights homes and turns wheels in the Northwest, it will bring new honor to the name of an explorer who up to a few years ago was all but forgotten.

Sheikh Farhan al Sadi, the most notorious terrorist leader in Palestine, was hanged at 8 o'clock this morning at the Acre prison, in accordance with the judgment of the military court at Haifa last Wednesday. The body was transported in an armored police car to Jenin, where it was handed over to his family.

Abandonment of British assistance to China and adoption of strict neutrality, withdrawal from the Nine Power Conference and severance of British relations with Russia were demanded in a resolution carried at a mass meeting in Tokyo yesterday organized by the newly formed society for expressing opinions on British policy.

Some 175 cats and a Dachshund puppy basked in the limelight as the fifth annual championship show of the Westchester Cat Club opened in the Little Theatre of the County Center today.

BY way of celebrating the 150th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution, the United States Constitution Sesquicentennial Commission has organized a large loan show of portraits, which, installed in four rooms at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington, opened with previews yesterday afternoon and evening.

Bosworth of Providence, F. I. The ceremony, which will be performed in the Central Presbyterin Church here, will be followed by a reception at the Glen Ridge Country Club.
