The National Federated Independent Union ended its first convention here today, electing Fred S. Galloway of Indianapolis president and choosing this city for national headquarters.

Merger of three branches of Methodism into the largest Protestant denomination in the United States moved nearer today with approval by the Louisiana Conference of the Methodist Church, South, of the reunion plan, by a vote of 215 to 10.

DOROTHY VARIAN is having a one-man show at the Down town Gallery. This artist paints-delightfully. Her brush has a very winning way. Its charm is real, not spurious, never cheaply sentimental, never slick and soft and cajoling.

About 400 members of society of the North Shore and Middle Island colonies attended the Smithtown Hunt Ball tonight at the Piping Rock Club. The dance followed many dinners at country homes and at the club and several large supper parties were given at midnight by guests.

MOTORDOM seems to be keeping a stiff upper lip despite the pessimistic reports emanating from other industries. Production during the past week ran to approximately 66,000 units with most plants operating on a three day week because of the Thanksgiving holiday. Others resumed operation Friday, including Ford, Oldsmobile and Graham.

THE item, or rather the collection of items, which takes first place in the attention of the dance world this week is the exposition known as Dance International 1900-87, which opens its five-week program this afternoon with a private preview of books, photographs and art objects inspired by the dance in the International Building of Rockefeller Center, 630 Fifth Avenue.
Stocks closed strong, with gains of 1 to 5 points in active trading; turnover, 1,141,230 shares. Corporation bonds strong; United States Government and other issues higher; transactions, $5,240,400.
Don Lash, former Indiana University star, will seek a record of four consecutive victories in the national senior A. A. U. cross-country title event over the 6 1/4-mile Branch Brook course tomorrow.

Legal opinion on the Equal Rights Amendment will be advanced at a meeting of the New Jersey League of Women Voters on Wednesday when William Clark, senior judge of the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey, will be the principal speaker at a luncheon conference in Newark. A large list of patrons and patronesses has been announced for the performance of "Barchester Towers" on Dec. 7 at the Martin Beck for the benefit of the Jacob A. Riis Settlement House.

Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam, chess champion of the world, and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, challenger, met tonight in the twenty-second game of their title series. The latter took a lead of three points by winning the twentyfirst game on Thursday.

Dogdom's most successful year in the United States is rapidly drawing to a close and only a handful of fixtures remain on the canine calendar. For December only five events are listed and three of these will take place on the Pacific Coast.

Something unique in the way of quizzes was given recently to economics students in Boston University's College of Business Administration. The students were passed a blank piece. of paper and he or she was asked to write their own questions, and then to answer them.

In contrast to many Institutions, church-going at Harvard University is showing a continuous gain, the Rev. Dr. Willard L. Sperry, chairman of the Harvard board of preachers, said today in his annual report to President Conant on the activities of the Harvard Memorial Church.

Seeking new methods of increased interest in their annual sales meetings, executives of a number of companies have adopted the Charlie McCarthy-Edgar Bergen technique and are delivering sales talks with the aid of a ventriloquist and his dummy. The method, they claim,

The first sixty-two railroads to report earnings for October show aggregate net operating income of $52,990,000, against $78,135,000 in October, 1936, a decrease of 32.2 per cent and against $65,316,000 in October, 1935, a decrease of 18.9 per cent. In September last, the net

Figures in naval engineering and Danish diplomatic and social circles yesterday honored Dr. William Hovgaard, Professor. Emeritus of Naval Design at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and naval construction consultant, yesterday on his eightieth birthday.
The Hawthorne Track, Chicago's oldest horse-racing plant, was left without a program today when the Illinois State Racing Commission refused to approve its application for 1938 dates.

The Brooklyn Eagles will try to gain their first victory in three starts against the Newark Tornadoes, leaders in the Southern Division of the American Football Association, when the two teams meet at Ebbets Field this afternoon in the only circuit encounter listed.

Mrs. Angelika W. Frink of 610 Park Avenue gave a supper dance last night at the Pierre at which she introduced to society her daughter, Miss Dorothy Frink. The debutante, gowned in Nile green slipper satin and carrying green orchids, received with her mother against a background of Australian ferns. The walls of the palm-decorated ballroom were festooned with Southern smilax and illumination was provided by lighted, iridescent balloons.

Another Larchmont Yacht Club captain is slated to become commander of the New York Squadron of the United States Power Squadrons, Inc. At Thursday night's annual election, which will be held preceding a dinner at the Hotel McAlpin, Ambrose Day is expected

ERSKINE CALDWELL--author of "Tobacco Road," "God's Little Acre" and a number of other novels and stories--went back to his home South and got the people talking hard times while Margaret Bourke-White -- star photographer for Life and Fortune Magazines--took their pictures.
With a constantly growing appreciation of native plants on the part of American gardeners, many longoverlooked beauties of the fields and woods are finding their way into cultivated plots.

THE making of silver is a craft in which prevails much of the same technique which Paul Revere and other colonial silversmiths used in creating their incomparable pieces. But a wider appreciation of fine handwork is now made possible by modern machine techniques which aid in producing less costly products.
The Golden Panthers of Pittsburgh cashed in on two opportunities afforded by Duke fumbles today to finish an undefeated season with a 10-to-O victory.

The Commodity Exchange Administration will endeavor to determine at hearings here on Tuesday and Wednesday whether limits should be placed on speculative transactions in grain futures contracts and whether trading. in an expiring grain future should end ten days before the final delivery date.

Davey O'Brien kept Texas Christian in the Southwest Conference football title race today by booting a field goal that defeated Southern Methodist University, 3 to 0, before 17,000 spectators in cold weather and on a wind-swept field.

Mary Keenan O'Connor, 19-year-old college student, and Mrs. Marie Kib ler Phillips, her friend to whom she first confessed responsibility for the death on Labor Day of Nancy Glenn, 5 years old, were named today in warrants issued by Magisi trate Jacob Dogole. Morals charges are involved in the writs, which, it was said, probably would be served on Monday.

Frank J. Marshall, who held the national title for twenty-six years until he retired in 1935, is defending his honors as champion of the Marshall Chess Club in the annual tournament now under way. In the first round he defeated Fred Reinfeld, former State leader, in the following well-played game:
Harry Dwyer, 22, and Henry Lorenz, 27, were charged today with murder and train robbery, both carrying a death penalty, for their Wild West attempt to hold up a passenger train on Thanksgiving Day.
Louisiana State's Tigers, stopped cold on the ground, tossed their way to a thrill-filled 20-to-7 victory today over Tulane's Green Wave before 40,000 fans.

Victor Richardson's eleven hit up 380 runs for nine wickets today in reply to a first-innings score of 184 by a team captained by Don Bradman. The cricket match is being played on behalf of the testimonial fund

Bergman S. Letzler, architect, of Louisville, Ky., declares that science and engineering are creating a new architectural style international in scope. He points out that basic new forms are coming into existence, not because of an effect to be different, but because of the necessity of taking advantage of the benefits to be derived from new and better .materials.
College will sponsor the first "Intercollegiate Crime Symposium" in this part of the country next month, and delegates from eight New Jersey and Pennsylvania colleges will take part.

The Holy Cross Crusaders, with Bullet Bill Osmanski leading almost every charge, completed their second undefeated season in the last three years by routing the Boston College Eagles, 20-0, today before 35,000 at Fenway Park.
Gino Garibaldi, 218, Bay Ridge, and Cliff Olsen, 215, Sweden, wrestled to a draw in the feature match listed for a finish at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.
